title: DEPARTING SENATE AIDE LEAVES TRAIL OF QUESTIONS
description: In the corridors of the Senate, where most aides hide behind a cloak of anonymity, John Edward Carbaugh Jr. was a self-professed ''humble servant'' whose influence came to rival that of many elected members of that institution. Strutting into a committee room and shaking hands with a Cabinet officer, whispering into the ear of his mentor, Senator Jesse Helms; pouring champagne for reporters at expensive French restaurants, using the telephone to the State Department to delay or push a job appointment, Mr. Carbaugh was a powerful and controversial figure on the ascendancy in Congress.

title: STATE MEDICAL EXAMINER TO CONTROL ESSEX OFFICER
description: The Essex County Medical Examiner's office was placed under the direct jurisdiction of the State Medical Examiner today as a result of charges by the County Prosecutor that the office's slipshod practices were jeopardizing his efforts.

title: Opposition Parties in Ireland Seek Confidence Vote Today
description: The opposition parties in the Irish Parliament announced today that they would force a formal vote of confidence in the Government on Thursday.

title: RIGHETTI IN MINOR LEAGUES: HOPE RIDES ON EACH PITCH
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I. T he Western Union telegram with the urgent instructions, ''Pls Dlr Immy,'' waited on a shelf in a cubicle in the Columbus Clippers' clubhouse. Two clean gray uniforms with No. 19 on the back hung on hangers. A hastily scripted piece of tape had been slapped across the top of the locker. It read, ''Righetti.''

title: Natal Court Overrules Seizure of Tribal Lands
description: The Supreme Court of Natal Province today nullified the white minority Government's seizure of black tribal land it intends to cede to neighboring Swaziland.

title: REAGAN OUGHT TO BEFRIEND LATIN AMERICANS' NATIONALISM
description: To oppose growing Soviet penetration in Latin America, the United States should befriend not the ''authoritarianism'' of the oligarchs and generals but rather the nationalism of the people.

title: EMOTION-FILLED CLOSE TO LENA HORNE'S RUN
description: Lena Horne ended her one-woman show on Broadway last night. Her closing wasn't exactly a reprise of her opening, but it wasn't that much different, either. Mostly, the difference was that Miss Horne, indisputably and unequivocally, was older. Yesterday was her 65th birthday, too.

title: Coffee Panel Nears Accord
description: The International Coffee Organization appeared set today to extend the third International Coffee Agreement to Sept. 30, 1985, following talks between producers and consumer nations.

title: Dreco Agreement
description: Dreco Energy Services Ltd., a Canadian concern, has reached an agreement with the First City National Bank of Houston, the Royal Bank of Canada and some unsecured creditors to remain operating for one month on a $2 million budget, Dreco officials told a bankruptcy court hearing here. Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, however, filed an objection to the agreeemnt, saying that its was owed ''an amount in excess of $10 million'' from Dreco Inc., Dreco Energy's principle United States subsidiary. In response to pressure from Continental Illinois, Dreco said, it was cutting its officers' salaries by 5 percent to 15 percent, effective Thursday.

title: One Good Turn Deserves Another
description: T ime was when the Navy didn't encourage anyone to pick up sailors.

title: COURTS BACK CALIFORNIA BUSING BAN: OVERTURNS RELATED LAW IN WASHINGTON
description: The Supreme Court decided two cases today involving the limits states may place on the use of busing for school desegregation.

title: Rosenfeld and Savitt Now Under One Roof
description: Savitt, Tobias, Balk will be acquired today by Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson, adding its more than $10 million in billings to the parent's $85 million and pushing it closer to its $100 million goal.

title: China Begins Census, The Biggest in History
description: China began the largest census in history today, using American computers and five million interviewers.

title: BOTANICAL GARDEN SETS CRAFTS FESTIVAL
description: THE New York Botanical Garden is opening its summer education program with a 13-day Festival of Crafts, beginning Tuesday and continuing through July 18. The festival is a potpourri of one-, twoand four-day courses and workshops that combine crafts techniques with horticultural themes.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Business and Mercantile Insurance Group Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial offering of one million class A common shares.

title: THEATER: GRAND KABUKI
description: THE Grand Kabuki, which opened Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for a two-week run, is likely to seem an alien world to Western eyes. It is, first of all, theater that combines music, dance and drama in remarkably even proportion. It is theater that is full of contradiction. Time and impersonations shift with dizzying rapidity. Symbols and symbolic action prevail, conventions refined in four centuries of evolution.

title: Eyes for Tennis
description: Eight years ago, a little girl was taken by an older big brother to watch his female friend play tennis. The little girl did not understand the game, but from the way she was watching, a tennis coach asked her to play.

title: ILLEGAL FIREWORKS: QUESTIONS OF SAFETY
description: the stuff the Fourth of July is made of, at least in the minds of many people. But fireworks, including sparklers and firecrackers, are illegal in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and many other states.

title: AUCTION RESULTS AID PRICES
description: Prices of fixed-income securities rose yesterday and yields fell as investors reacted to the unexpectedly strong demand shown at Tuesday's sale of Treasury notes.

title: U.S. GIVES DETAILS OF ARMS PLAN TO SOVIET
description: The United States gave the Soviet Union a detailed explanation today of its proposals for reducing nuclear armaments.

title: CUBANS IN ANGOLA: A STICKING POINT FOR NAMIBIANS?
description: The optimism that has seized the Western nations involved in seeking peace in South-West Africa does not seem to extend, in public at least, to the insurgents battling South Africa in the conflict.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP 1.5% IN MAY
description: Orders for new manufactured goods rose 1.5 percent in May while shipments for the month advanced 2.6 percent, the largest one-month gain since October 1980, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Export Credit Compromise
description: Finance ministers of the Common Market accepted with minor modifications today the compromise plan offered by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development to increase interest rates on subsidized export credits, Willy de Clercq, Belgium's Finance Minister, said.

title: Saxon Revises Financial Accounts
description: Saxon Industries, a New York-based paper and photocopier manufacturer that filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in April, said that possible overstatements in its financial accounts could ''substantially'' exceed a previous estimate. The company has previously said that the overstatements in inventories and accounting at its Miami Lakes, Fla., business products group could be ''at least $24 million.''

title: CITY GARDENING
description: Save Drowning Plants Gardeners with poorly drained soil discovered it the hard way this year as drenching rain rotted roots and stems and suffocated shrubs and flowers, which may now be turning yellow. Between storms, on a day when the soil is dry and feels crumbly, improve the drainage by working equal amounts of peat moss and cow manure into the soil. For terrace containers, also mix in an equal amount of perlite; yard gardeners can use either perlite or coarse builder's sand.

title: Thomson Unit Gets Manager
description: Robert L. Krout has been named by Thomson Newspapers Inc. as general manager of the Houghton Daily Mining Gazette, the publishing company announced today.

title: ABNER DEAN, SATIRIC CARTOONIST
description: Abner Dean, a satiric cartoonist and illustrator whose work appeared in magazines and periodicals, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Dean, who had lived in Manhattan, was 72 years old.

title: HOME BEAT
description: SHE can't quite remember how she got into making lamps except that it had something to do with a friend's gift of a couple of bases. ''I was doing scarves at the time,'' recalled Judyth van Amringe, a fashion designer, right.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 1, 1982
description: International The President discussed the crisis in Lebanon in greater depth than previously in a televised news conference. Mr. Reagan said his Administration had given ''no green light whatsoever'' to Israel to attack west Beirut, but he endorsed Israel's demand that all Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon be withdrawn. (Page A1, Column 6.) Talks in Beirut made some progress as negotiators for the Lebanese Government and the Palestine Liberation Organization sought an agreement on how and when the Palestinians should leave Lebanon. (A1:4-5.)

title: Marathon Holders
description: A hearing here was adjourned until July 28 on motions filed on behalf of 900 Marathon Oil Company shareholders who say that they did not get enough money for their stock when Marathon was taken over by the United States Steel Corporation. The stockholders, who received about $100 a share, are seeking $135 to $445 a share.

title: XEROX SLASHES COPIER PRICES
description: In an apparent acknowledgement of the inroads being made on its business by Japanese competitors, the Xerox Corporation slashed prices on some copiers yesterday by as much as 47 percent and said that for the next three months it would offer several discount financing programs to ''meet competition head-on.''

title: Bridge:; Janice Seamon Maintains Tradition for Legal Minds
description: If one listed all the great American players of the past halfcentury by profession - not counting the game itself as a profession - the law would prove to have the largest number of adherents. The legal mind seems particularly well adapted to the technical and psychological problems that present themselves at the bridge table.

title: TIME RUNS OUT FOR PROPOSED RIGHTS AMENDMENT
description: The drive to ratify the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, a goal of feminists since it was first introduced in Congress 59 years ago, failed tonight in the states, still three legislatures short of the 38 that would have made it the 27th Amendment to the Constitution.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL A BEN HUR MENTALITY
description: WHEN people complain about the Kool Jazz Festival, the comment one hears again and again is that there simply is too much of it. When critics complain about having to rush from event to event to event (where their free tickets are always for choice orchestra seats), one can take the carping with a grain of salt. But the more one talks to the fans who are buying tickets for these events, the more one senses a palpable frustration.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Eight Russian immigrants were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of selling drugs and firearms, the police said. Those arrested, in a series of raids by the department's narcotics division and the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, were said to be part of an operation that imported and sold cocaine, heroin and weapons. ... A dispute over the use of a bathroom in a Brooklyn apartment house led to the critical wounding at 7:30 P.M. of a 41-year-old man who allegedly tried to attack a police officer with a lead pipe, the police said.

title: Advertising; McCann Ushers In New Beer
description: Erickson yesterday to introduce Jacob Best.

title: CRAFTS ARE FEATURED IN OUTDOOR FESTIVALS
description: American Crafts Festival, the plaza at Lincoln Center for the Perform- ing Arts, 64th and Broadway, 677- 4627.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER NAMES TEAM OF 10
description: Argentina's President-designate, who takes office Thursday, has selected a Cabinet of nine civilians and one military officer.

title: CONNECTICUT LEGISLATORS VOTE $37 MILLION FOR FLOOD REPAIRS
description: The General Assembly approved a $37 million program of flood-relief measures today to aid individuals, businesses and towns that suffered damages in the floods June 5 and 6, which in many areas of the state were the worst in a century.

title: VICTORY IS BITTERSWEET FOR ARCHITECT OF AMENDMENT'S DOWNFALL
description: At 7:08 this morning, Phyllis Schlafly picked up a morning newspaper. ''Today is Wednesday, June 30,'' she read from the dateline. ''I can't believe it,'' said her daughter, Ann, shaking her head. ''I'm not going to know what to do tomorrow,'' said her assistant, Noreen Barr. The 10-year drive to ratify the proposed Federal equal rights amendment expired today, making Mrs. Schlafly, the Illinois housewife who became the principal architect of the defeat, Queen for a Day.

title: ALITALIA HIJACKER FREES 138 CAPTIVES
description: With his hands in the air, a Sri Lanka hijacker and more than 100 hostages walked off an Alitalia jumbo jet today, ending a 32-hour ordeal in which he had threatened to blow up the jetliner.

title: Mitchell Energy
description: The Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation is considering two unidentified acquisitions that would increase its oil and gas reserves, George P. Mitchell, chairman, told the annual meeting. Mr. Mitchell also said that prices of natural gas liquids improved last month to $16.20 to $16.50 a barrel for an average of 32,000 barrels a day. He predicted that gas output for the fiscal year 1983, ending Jan. 31, 1983, would easily exceed fiscal 1982's 155 million cubic feet a day.

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events: 5 P.M. Forum Room, New York Sheraton. Max Roach, drummer. Tickets, $7.50. 6 P.M. Carnegie Hall.

title: GUINEAN MEETS REAGAN AND BUSH
description: President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea, on a private visit here, met President Reagan and Vice President Bush today to discuss issues of mutual interest between Guinea and the United States.

title: McLouth Is to Halt Operations Aug. 14
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it would halt all its operations on Aug.14 and turn over its assets to its creditors by Sept.1 for liquidation.

title: PERILS FOUND IN ANTIBIOTIC USE
description: Bacteria that are made resistant to drugs by the heavy use of antibiotics appear to be often transmitted from animals to humans, according to a report in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Triumvirate Is Back In 'Great Songs' Series
description: AFTER almost a decade, the series of programs that began in the Newport Jazz Festival as ''The American Popular Song'' and became ''The Great Songs'' last year when the Newport Festival became the Kool Jazz Festival, seems to be running out of steam.

title: U.S. Says Chinese Dancer Met Immigration Aides
description: A 24-year-old Chinese dancer met with immigration officials after disappearing from an international ballet competition here, but the authorities do not know his whereabouts, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DJINN. By Alain Robbe-Grillet. Trans- lated from the French by Yvone Lenard and Walter Wells. 128 pages. Grove. Hardcover, $10.95. Paperback, $4.95.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Ralston, the former coach of the Denver Broncos, was named coach and general manager of the San Francisco Bay area franchise of the United States Football League. ... The Rangers have signed George McPhee, who was voted the outstanding college hockey player in the United States last year.

title: RELIGIOUS CLASHES BRING NEW FEARS
description: Lebanese Christian forces backed by Israeli troops have been engaging in artillery duels in mountains east of here with Syrian-supported Lebanese Moslem militiamen. Clashes have also been reported between Lebanese Christian and Druse gunmen in several villages in the area.

title: HINCKLEY VERDICT PROVES THAT THE SYSTEM WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Barton Acquisition
description: Barton Brands Ltd. said today it had entered a definitive pact to be acquired for $16 per partnership unit, or $38 million, plus undistributed earnings for its fiscal year ended today. Barton said it would identify the buyer within 30 days after certain conditions were fulfilled.

title: Keon, 42, Retires; 22 Years in N.H.L.
description: Dave Keon, known for his clean play and durability, today announced his retirement as a National Hockey League player, ending a professional career that covered three decades.

title: Wedding Day for 4,000
description: ''U nification Church Holy Wedding Box Office,'' read the sign yesterday at Madison Square Garden's Eighth Avenue entrance.

title: SOVIET OPTIONS ON G.E. ROTOR
description: THE case of the General Electric rotor appears to be an example of superior American technology being used as a diplomatic weapon. The Soviet Union was planning to use dozens of turbines designed by the General Electric Company on a pipeline to deliver natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe. President Reagan, in hopes of delaying or killing the project, which he thinks will enrich the Soviet Union and make Western Europe too dependent on the Russians for energy, has banned the use of American technology on the pipeline.

title: More Children To Get Free Meals
description: More school children will be eating free meals at more sites this summer, city officials said yesterday. Last year, 138,500 youngsters were served daily at 330 meal centers; this year, the Board of Education expects to serve 208,000 at 560 meal centers -at no anticipated added cost to the city.

title: After a Month, Athens Has Traffic Jams Again
description: A monthlong experimental ban on private driving in the city center aimed at alleviating air pollution ended today with dense traffic jams.

title: ISRAEL TRIES TO VILIFY PEACE FORCE, U.N. AIDE SAYS
description: A senior United Nations official said today that Israel was trying to demonstrate that the United Nations was biased in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization and hence unfit for peacekeeping in Lebanon.

title: CENTER RISES ON COAST FOR JAPANESE- AMERICANS
description: LOS ANGELES ONE of the largest ethnic cultural centers in the United States is rising in the middle of Los Angeles's Little Tokyo, 98 years after the first Japanese immigrants arrived in that eight-block downtown area.

title: CHAMBER: MUSIC OF SUMMER
description: THERE is no logical reason why the chamber-music series now under way at the 92d Street Y chooses to call itself ''Summermusic,'' rather than ''Summer Music.'' But the run-together title is somehow redolent of ice clinking in glasses, murmured conversations, the distant buzz of other people's lawn mowers, long naps in hammocks under the immemorial elms, and all that. In this air-conditioned age, however, there is no pressing reason for summertime concerts to be the watery tea they once were, so it is no surprise to find that the ''Summermusic'' programs, which will run through July 8, are models of musical substance.

title: Dissident Holders Sue Wieboldt
description: The Tri-State Holding Group, a group of dissident shareholders of Wieboldt Stores Inc. formed to make a tender offer for Wieboldt, has sued the financially troubled retailer in United States District Court demanding a copy of Wieboldt's shareholder list.

title: NEW YORK'S CABLE TV ACCESS LAW INVALIDATED BY THE SUPREME COURT
description: The Supreme Court today struck down a New York State law that required landlords to permit the installation of cable television equipment for a $1 fee.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: OPENING STATEMENT

title: FACTORY OUTLETS BOOMING IN MAINE
description: Years ago you could find them only off the beaten path, tucked away in sprawling factories that dominated the blue-collar towns that tourists seldom visited. But today they are a common sight in resort villages.

title: Searle Issues Angina Item
description: G.D. Searle & Company, the drug producer, today introduced a nitroglycerin patch for treating angina. The new adhesive pad is like one also introduced today by a joint venture of Becton, Dickinson & Company and the Ciba-Geigy Corporation.

title: BALLET: DANES GIVE GALA AT PILLOW SPECIAL GLOW
description: Until the late Ted Shawn, founder of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, invited a group of soloists from the Royal Danish Ballet to appear at the festival in 1955, the company from Copenhagen was as unknown here as the 19th-century ballets by August Bournonville that had molded the company's special style.

title: White House Posts Schedule For Reagans' 11-Day Vacation
description: President Reagan is to address a luncheon of Western editors and broadcasters in Los Angeles on Thursday before heading for his ranch about 30 miles northwest of Santa Barbara on the first day of an 11-day vacation in California, the deputy White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, says.

title: TRANSIT FARE RISES PUT OFF BY M.T.A. AT LEAST TO DEC. 10
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority decided yesterday to postpone at least until December proposed increases in subway, bus and commuter fares.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IN ''War and Peace'' Napoleon breakfasts with an envoy from Paris in his elaborate military encampment outside of Moscow. One imagines that before them were matching silver-gilt plates and flatware, with a carafe and goblets of cut glass - all from one of the traveling services regularly crafted for the Emperor from 1798 on by Martin-Guillaume Biennais. They were ''ingeniously designed to contain dozens of utensils for dining and personal use,'' according to a contemporary exhibition catalogue.

title: CARROLL G. HARPER
description: Carroll G. Harper, a partner in the New York law firm of Fitzpatrick, Cella, Harper & Scinto, died Monday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MILWAUKEE'S VALIENT MANAGER
description: W ith a grin that swerved from side to side with his bulging wad of chewing tobacco, Harvey Kuenn glanced at his artificial right leg. ''I'm a step slower now,'' Kuenn, the Milwaukee Brewers' manager, was saying in his office in the visiting team's clubhouse at Yankee Stadium. ''And the bullpen pitchers told me not to worry about them being ready to come in. They told me by the time I get to the mound, they'll have plenty of time to get ready.''

title: Even if Subway Fare Were Increased...
description: F ittingly, yesterday's M.T.A. meeting to determine the fate of the subway fare ran 64 minutes behind schedule. When it finally got under way, everyone agreed to push the matter off until the afternoon, and then it was mercifully decided to keep the price of a token at 75 cents, for a while at least.

title: Domestic Disarmament
description: Even supporters of San Francisco's new law banning handguns say it is only symbolic and that its effect on crime will be minimal. The truth of that remains to be seen, but in the meantime, the symbolic value of such a law should neither be disparaged nor lost on Washington.

title: BOEING GUILTY OF HIDING $7 MILLION COMMISSIONS
description: The Boeing Company pleaded guilty in a Federal court here today to failing to disclose payments of at least $7 million in commissions to overseas agents to help win orders for 35 aircraft valued at $344 million.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a number of thin hairline cracks in the cement stoop of my brownstone and I want to fill these to keep water from leaking through to the area below. I have only been able to patch these cracks with cement after using a chisel to open the cracks so they are at least one-fourth of an inch wide, otherwise the crack is not wide enough to hold the cement. The trouble is that when these open up again I have an even larger crack to fill. Is there a sealer on the market that is thin enough to flow into these hairline cracks yet will harden inside the cracks without flowing all the way through, or is there a better way to fill these cracks? - A.D., Manhattan.

title: KNICKS PLAN TRADE
description: Maurice Lucas, Marvin Webster and Campy Russell, the starting front line at the end of last season, have questionable futures with the Knicks, according to Hubie Brown, the new coach. So does Sly Williams, whose future the coach is hoping to determine at a meeting today.

title: DYSON QUITS RACE
description: John P. Dyson, chairman of the State Power Authority, abandoned his campaign for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor yesterday, saying a ''forced marriage'' with either of the candidates for governor could be ''disastrous.''

title: Judging Israel
description: Israel is, or should be, morally ''different'' from other nations. So say the critics of its pre-emptive war against the P.L.O. in Lebanon, in which uncounted civilians have died. Because Israel was born of the world's revulsion over Hitler's genocide, the critics note, they hold it to a higher code, even in war. Some of these critics are Israelis, struggling to show how morally different they are from their Arab enemies. Are the critics right?

title: ROCK-LIKE DIPLOMACY SOLVES NO PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESSIONAL PAGES TELL U.S. AGENCIES OF SEX ALLEGATIONS
description: The Federal authorities are investigating complaints about illicit sex between members of Congress and their under-age pages, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department confirmed tonight.

title: JAZZTET'S REUNION MIXES THE OLD AND THE NEW
description: THE Jazztet, a sextet that was one of the more interesting jazz groups of the early 1960's, is holding a partial reunion at Fat Tuesday's through tomorrow, as part of the current jazz festival. The primary distinctions of the Jazztet were that Benny Golson, its resident composer, was then at a peak in his composing career and that it had four outstanding soloists in Art Farmer, then playing trumpet; Curtis Fuller, trombone; Mr. Golson, tenor saxophone, and McCoy Tyner, piano.

title: Nissan's Net Declines 4.7%
description: The Nissan Motor Company, maker of Datsun cars, announced yesterday that its net income in the fiscal year ended March 31 fell 4.7 percent, although sales rose 6.9 percent.

title: Market Place; Spotlight On Insiders
description: INSIDERS of two Big Board apparel companies - Adams-Millis and Aileen - have demonstrated in recent weeks how announcements regarding future trading intentions by insiders can affect a company's stock price.

title: U.S. and U.N. Said to Study Vietnam Resettlement Offer
description: A State Department official said today that the Reagan Administration was working with the United Nations High Commission for Refugees ''to determine whether the Vietnamese are in fact prepared to release persons from re-education camps for resettlement abroad.''

title: News Analysis
description: A dispute over the interest-rate aid that Canada would provide to help a Montreal company sell subway cars to New York poses acute problems for the Reagan Administration, the Canadian Government and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: DOW EASES IN HEAVY VOLUME
description: With institutional investors making huge portfolio switches in the final session of the second quarter, New York Stock Exchange volume soared yesterday to 65.3 million shares, the heaviest turnover in nearly eight weeks. Many stock prices rose slightly.

title: Ex-I.B.M. Aide Indicted
description: A former employee of the International Business Machines Corporation, Raymond J. Cadet, was indicted today on three counts of stealing trade secrets from the computer manufacturer during a six-month period beginning November, 1980.

title: CHAIM GRADE, YIDDISH NOVELIST AND POET ON THE HOLOCAUST, DIES
description: Chaim Grade, a Yiddish poet and novelist whose work gained wide attention because of its passion and intensity in dealing with Jewish life in Eastern Europe and with the trauma of the Holocaust, died of a heart attack Saturday in Montefiore Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: FIRST INDICTMENT IS ISSUED ON DRAFT
description: A 21-year-old Californian who said he had refused to register for a possible draft as a matter of conscience was indicted yesterday for failing to register with the Selective Service System. It was the first such indictment returned by a grand jury since draft registration was resumed in 1980.

title: PHILADELPHIANS SWING TO 50'S ROCK
description: For the briefest of respites the good old days had returned to Philadelphia. It was the 1950's again, Dick Clark was on the stage, and so were Fabian, Freddie Cannon, the Shirelles, the Drifters and the Dobelles.

title: BRIEFING
description: Rare Dissent for Court

title: 'SOCIAL' PROMOTION: A STUDENT 'NIGHTMARE'
description: To the Editor:

title: A JUDGE BLOCKS ALL U.S. MONEY FOR THE WESTWAY
description: A decision blocking all Federal funds for the Westway project was issued in Manhattan yesterday by a Federal judge who accused government agencies of deliberately misrepresenting the project's impact on fish in the Hudson River.

title: O'Connor Buys 8.1% Trane Stake
description: O'Connor Securities, a private options-trading and risk-arbitrage company in Chicago, disclosed in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired an 8.1 percent holding in the Trane Company, one of the nation's largest air-conditioning manufacturers, for $24.6 million, and may seek control.

title: Kiwanis to Exclude Women
description: Kiwanis International, one of the world's largest service organizations, will continue to exclude women from its membership and will not allow them to be honorary members. After a long floor battle Tuesday, delegates at the Kiwanis annual convention voted, 2,329 to 1,083, against allowing women into the club.

title: DRUSE WORRYING ABOUT THEIR DESTINY
description: In a gesture of mourning over the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, two flags - one Lebanese and the other the banner of the Popular Socialist Party - hang at half-staff outside the great stone mansion that is the seat of the Jumblat clan, lords of the Shuf Mountains for almost four centuries.

title: AFTER RAVAGED WEST BEIRUT, EAST IS HAVEN
description: There are two distinct cities of Beirut separated by a no man's land called the Green Line. In predominantly Moslem western Beirut, frightened residents were poised for an expected Israeli invasion to rout 5,000 to 6,000 Palestinian guerrillas who are tucked away in houses and side streets.

title: BUSINESS AND THE REAGAN PLAN
description: Executives at some of the nation's largest companies are finding President Reagan's economic program bitter medicine, but remain convinced that it is the country's best bet for a long-term cure of lingering economic ills.

title: RABBI AND 2 CHRISTIAN CLERICS DENOUNCE INVASION
description: A rabbi and two Christian clergymen from the New York area yesterday jointly denounced Israel's invasion of Lebanon and called for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Israeli military forces.

title: Murray and Threadgill Prove 'Freedom Swings'
description: THE Kool Jazz Festival's ''Freedom Swings'' presented bands led by two young saxophonists, David Murray and Henry Threadgill, Tuesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall. It was the most substantial and genuinely exciting of the jazz festival programs this listener has heard so far.

title: Inco Curbs Costs; Freezes Salaries
description: Inco Ltd. said it was freezing staff salaries and putting workers in the Ontario division who are not needed during the summer shutdown on leave of absence with 50 percent salary.

title: PASSING THE BUCK ON TERMINATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: WALTER BREMOND, A BLACK ACTIVIST
description: Walter Bremond, president of the National Black United Fund, died of a heart attack Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: E.E.C. Inflation Steady
description: The annual rate of inflation in the European Economic Community in May was unchanged from April, at 11.2 percent, and down from 12.5 percent last year, the community's Statistics Office said today. The Netherlands, West Germany, France, Belgium and Britain showed increases in consumer prices of less than 1 percent for the month, while Luxembourg had the highest increase, 1.4 percent.

title: U.S. AND ISRAEL ARE CRITICIZED IN EGYPT
description: Egypt's opposition parties, stepping up their outcry over Israel's offensive in Lebanon, have declared that they will mount a ''national campaign against the Zionist and United States presence in Egypt.''

title: COUNTRY GARDENING
description: Flowers Large-flowered dahlias used for show competition and colorful summer bouquets have brittle stems. As they grow tall, be sure the main stems are tied to stakes with old nylon stockings or soft cord. Peonies should be cut back to the nearest compound leaf so the plant can be strengthened for next season's bloom. As coral bells, platycodons, veronicas and violas fade, cut off blooms so seed pods do not form. Unless columbines are to be allowed to reseed themselves, be sure to remove ripe seed pods carefully. Check petunias, geraniums, snapdragons, marigolds and verbenas daily to remove old flowers and prevent seed pods; otherwise flowering stops. Begonias and impatiens do not need this maintenance.

title: U.S. Opposes A.T.& T. Ban
description: The Justice Department argued before a Federal judge here today that there was no need to ban the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from entering the electronic information field because an antitrust settlement precluded the possibility that A.T.& T. would dominate the field.

title: ECONOMISTS DEBATE IMPACT OF REDUCTION
description: The 10 percent cut in tax rates and the increases in Social Security payments that take effect today are expected to return $48 billion to an economy plagued by a recession and high interest rates. But economists are debating whether this will propel the economy out of recession or merely inflate the deficit and abort a recovery.

title: Change, Mr. Regan, Please
description: Old riddle: I have two coins in my hand. Together they total 55 cents. One is not a nickel. What are the coins?

title: SOME PROGRESS REPORTED IN BEIRUT IN INDUCING PALESTINIANS TO LEAVE
description: Palestinian leaders and Lebanese officials made some progress today in negotiations over how and when the fighters of the Palestine Liberation Organization should leave Lebanon. One remaining problem appears to be that no Arab country is ready to accept them all.

title: After Dark Returning With Mid-August Issue
description: After Dark, a monthly magazine characterized as ''the chronicle of entertainment,'' is missing its June and July issues but will be out in mid-August with a combined August-September issue, according to Seth Cooper, a certified public accountant who is the new copublisher, treasurer and vice president, finance.

title: DOCTOROW'S 'DANIEL' TO BE FILMED AT LAST
description: Sidney Lumet will direct a movie version of E.L. Doctorow's ''The Book of Daniel,'' a book that Mr. Lumet has been trying to sell to the movies for the last 12 years. Timothy Hutton, winner of an Academy Award as the suicidal teen-ager in ''Ordinary People,'' will star in the film.

title: N.F.L. Legal Defenses
description: The jury trial of a former pro football player accused of peddling cocaine to his teammates has been put off for two months, and another player has been bound over for further court action on charges of carrying a concealed weapon and felonious assault. Mike Strachan, a former running back for the Saints, was scheduled to go to trial in New Orleans today but his lawyer said that a superceding indictment issued June 25 had complicated the case.

title: CANADIAN PROVINCES ARE WARY OF TRUDEAU'S ECONOMIC PLAN
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau sought today to enlist the cooperation of Canada's 10 provinces in fighting inflation but he received only lukewarm support.

title: J.W.T. Departure
description: Wilson A. Seibert Jr., known around town as Bill, is narrowing his focus. Formerly senior vice president of J. Walter Thompson Company International responsible for the creative product worldwide, he starts today as executive vice president, creative services, for Arnold & Company in Boston, with $60 million in billings. The 51-year-old executive joins Gerard F. Golden, another Thompson alumnus, who is president of the Boston shop.

title: Salvador Pounds Rebels On Slopes of Volcano
description: The Salvadoran Army began a 1,000-man offensive today backed by warplanes and artillery against rebels entrenched on the slopes of Guazapa volcano 15 miles north of San Salvador.

title: Judge Denies a Motion To Stay Haitians' Parole
description: A Federal district judge today refused to stay the order he issued Tuesday to free 1,900 detained Haitian refugees.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FLAGS AND FLAGPOLES TO UNFURL ON THE FOURTH
description: THE approach of the Fourth of July signals the time to get your Stars and Stripes flying. The patriotic homeowner enjoys flying a flag and hearing it snap in the summer breeze.

title: Union Chief Acquitted; Two Aides Found Guilty
description: A Federal jury on Tuesday acquitted Angelo Fosco, president of the 600,000-member Laborers' International Union, on charges of labor racketeering.

title: BRITAIN FIGHTS EMBARGO
description: The British Government armed itself today with legal powers to prohibit British companies from complying with the United States embargo on American-designed equipment for the Soviet Union's natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: THURSDAY, JULY 1, 1982; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators rose 0.3 percent in May, its third consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department reported. The increase in the index, which is used to forecast recoveries and recessions, was seen as another sign that the recession has bottomed out. However, some officials and private economists were disappointed that the gain was so small. (Page D1.)

title: A Spot of Trouble
description: How the wind blows: The producers of ''Torch Song Trilogy,'' which recently moved uptown to Broadway, tried to place a 60-second radio commercial making much of the term ''gay.''

title: USING POVERTY AS AN EXCUSE TO CUT FEDERAL POVERTY PROGRAMS
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about a Staten Island lake that is losing water included a comment from a resident who incorrectly described a proposed city project. It would be an oilimport terminal.

title: Lilco Cost Up
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today the estimated cost of its Shoreham nuclear power station had increased by $140 million, or 5.6 percent. The new estimated cost is $2.63 billion, it said. The company attributed the rise to more extensive engineering, construction and licensing activities that are needed to support additional safety analysis and inspections being undertaken.

title: Required Reading; Economic Tradition
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, and chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, during testimony before the committee, June 9, 1982:

title: Robey Wants Trade
description: Rick Robey, a substitute center, says he's not angry with the Boston Celtics but would like to be traded to another National Basketball Association team where he would play more. Robey thinks his chances of getting traded are better now that Boston's firstround choice in the draft on Tuesday was Darren Tillis, a 6-11 center from Cleveland State.

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR WEEKEND TRAFFIC
description: A. HENRY HUDSON PARKWAY: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B. FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT DRIVE: Two lanes will be closed in either direction from the Brooklyn Bridge to the Battery. Also, the southbound ramp at Robert F. Wagner Sr. Place will be closed. Farther north, one northbound lane will be closed to traffic at 42d Street as a project to strengthen the roadbed continues.

title: Dr. Donald H. Wilson Is Dead; Did Surgical Work on Epilepsy
description: Dr. Donald H. Wilson, a neurosurgeon at the Dartmouth-Hitchock Medical Center who was internationally known for his surgical treatment of epilepsy, died of cancer today at his home. He was 55 years old.

title: Victoria Station Names A New Chief Executive
description: Victoria Station Inc., an operator of railroad-theme restaurants, announced yesterday that Richard A. Niglio had been appointed president and chief executive.

title: Keon Retires at 42
description: Dave Keon, known for his clean play and durability, announced his retirement as a National Hockey League player, ending a professional career that covered three decades.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Microsystems Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., has elected Bruce R. Bourbon vice president and manager of information resource management. * Bristol-Myers Co. has appointed Pamela D. Kasa secretary.

title: A NEEDED VERDICT: GUILTY BUT INSANE
description: To understand the true purpose of the insanity defense, one must first appreciate the broader aims of criminal law. The object of criminal trials is not simply to pass moral judgment on a defendant. Criminal process is an instrument of societal control. One of its most important objectives is to enhance the resolve of all good citizens to be law-abiding.

title: Non-British Reporters Kept From Falklands
description: No non-British journalists have been permitted to visit the Falkland Islands, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight.

title: Inching Ahead
description: ''Now, would we draft someone on the first round who was under 6 feet tall?'' asked Joe Steranka, the publicity director for the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Ring, Ring, Ring, Ring, Ring; It is a time-honored concept that citizens should be able to communicate with government officials, but sometimes it's hard to figure out how to do that in this city. Often, the telephone is the line of greatest resistance.
description: What follows is a one-day log of calls to the main numbers of key public agencies: Transit Authority, a notoriously slow picker upper: Phone rings 23 times without response. Hang up and dial again.

title: THOMAS HOMER DEFEATS YANKEES
description: As long as Dave LaRoche was throwing LaLobs to Gorman Thomas, the Yankees were safe. But Shane Rawley threw Thomas a fastball in the 12th inning, and Thomas slammed it into the left-field stands for his 19th homer, a two-run shot that carried the Milwaukee Brewers past the Yankees, 9-7.

title: Irwin-Olivetti Venture
description: Irwin International Inc., a privately held concern, said today that it and Ing C Olivetti & C S.p.A. of Italy had agreed to manufacture Olivetti printers and memory systems in the United States through a new joint venture, Irwin Olivetti. It said Olivetti would take a 35 percent stake in the venture through conversion of some Irwin International debentures into equity, but declined to specify the value of the debentures. Irwin said the new venture would be the chief marketer of Olivetti products in Canada and the United States.

title: Madonnas of the 50's
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I am one of your madonnas of the 50's (''For Mothers, the Rules Change, the Job Doesn't,'' June 17). I certainly did not want a stranger, possibly of lesser intelligence and background and certainly of less caring, to raise my children like the ''poor little rich children'' of the past whose rearing belonged to successive nannies.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX ROSE 0.3% IN MAY
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, intended to forecast recoveries and recessions, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the third consecutive monthly rise and another sign that the recession is over.

title: Harvester Ends Accords in Spain
description: The International Harvester Company obtained approval from the Spanish Government to end truck-making and enginemaking accords with state-owned Empresa Nacional de Autocamiones, freeing an estimated $200 million for use elsewhere by Harvester, a company spokesman said. Harvester agreed in 1980 to invest about $200 million in the truck and diesel engine ventures, but the project has been delayed repeatedly since then.

title: HINTS AT '84 RACE
description: President Reagan, declaring that there was ''no substantiation'' for any of the allegations against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, said tonight that he would be ''sticking with'' Mr. Donovan. ''That case is closed,'' he said.

title: SYNTHETIC VACCINE IS CALLED EFFECTIVE IN ANIMAL DISEASE
description: A radically new type of experimental vaccine, made entirely from synthetic chemicals, has protected laboratory animals against footand-mouth disease, one of the world's deadliest plagues of livestock, according to a report published yesterday.

title: People
description: * Jeffrey A. Devlin has been named senior vice president at SSC&B, New York.

title: Egypt and Israel May Play Ball
description: Basketball coaches from Israel and Egypt have been meeting this week at a clinic in Monticello, N.Y., and Fouad Abdul-Kheir, the technical director for basketball in Egypt, has invited the Israelis to open a sports competition between their countries.

title: Sampson vs. Ewing
description: Ralph Sampson, the Virginia center, who was the player of the year in college basketball last season, and Pat Ewing, the Georgetown center, who helped his team reach the National Collegiate Athletic Association finals, will play against each other for the first time in their careers Dec. 11 at Capital Centre in Landover, Md.

title: KEAN SIGNS BUDGET, BUT HE CRITICIZES IT AS NOT RESPONSIBLE
description: Governor Kean tonight signed a 1983 state budget of almost $6.2 billion that he called ''neither responsible nor prudent,'' and he expressed hope that the Legislature would agree to enact supplemental appropriations.

title: Quakes Stop Cosmos, 4-2
description: Godfrey Ingram and Vince Hillaire scored two goals apiece tonight to lead the San Jose Earthquakes to a 4-2 victory over the Cosmos.

title: THE LONG WAY UP FOR AN EARLY REAGAN FOLLOWER
description: Helene von Damm is half a city block removed from her old desk outside the Oval Office now, but her faith holds strong in Ronald Reagan, the American dream and the authenticity of the original Reaganites amid Administration late-comers.

title: News Analysis
description: The tax cuts pushed through Congress last year by the Reagan Administration have been popularly criticized as favoring the most prosperous parts of society - well-to-do individuals and corporations - while shifting much of the tax burden onto the backs of the less exalted.

title: United Technologies Reorganizes Pratt Unit
description: As part of what the United Technologies Corporation of East Hartford, Conn., yesterday termed a major strategic reorganization of its power sector, Richard J. Coar was named president of the Pratt & Whitney Group.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE CHINA CONNECTION

title: Reagan's Avoidance of Two Subjects Stems From Distrust of News Format
description: President Reagan's reluctance to discuss two pressing national issues in detail at his televised news conference tonight reflects the privately expressed feeling of his advisors that he should tackle sensitive subjects only under carefully controlled conditions, and not in a free-wheeling news conference. Faced with repeated questions about the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, Mr. Reagan repeatedly declined to provide any details about the top topics of the week.

title: The U.N. Today; July 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M.

title: Kennecott Lays Off 910 Utah Workers
description: The Kennecott Minerals Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Corporation, announced broad cutbacks today and layoffs for 910 employees at its Utah Copper division.

title: Soviet Says British Warship In Falklands Carried A-Arms
description: A leading Soviet journal said today that there were nuclear weapons on board the British destroyer Sheffield, sunk during the Falklands conflict, and called on Britain to retrieve them.

title: METS' BATTERS FAIL IN 4-1 LOSS
description: The Mets came up with only five hits in a 4-1 loss to the Montreal Expos tonight and all that their batting coach was able to dote upon offensively was a walk to Rusty Staub.

title: No Headline
description: A lthough negotiating turbulent rapids in canoe, raft or kayak gets most of the attention on television and in print, one should not forget the pleasures offered by quiet waters.

title: Emhart Plans Layoffs
description: The Emhart Corporation plans to lay off 32 hourly production workers Thursday because poor economic conditions have reduced business and forced the company to cut costs, a company official said today. The layoffs will bring the number of workers taken off the job at the Berlin plant during the past month to 109, said Raymond Nieman, Emhart personnel director. Emhart's Berlin plant makes hardware products, such as doorknobs, locks and latches.

title: TV: FIVE SOVIET DISSIDENTS IN EXILE
description: ''SOVIET DISSIDENTS IN EXILE,'' a half-hour film on WNET-TV at 10:40 tonight, focuses on the feelings of five human-rights activists as they were forced to leave their native Soviet Union and move to the United States. The men are Joseph Brodsky, Vladimir Bukovsky, Alexander Ginzburg, Pavel Litvinov and Boris Shragin.

title: Comex Loses Court Appeal
description: The Commodity Exchange has lost an appeal of a Federal judge's order barring it from advertising or starting trading in futures contracts based on Standard & Poor's 500 stock index.

title: HENRY KING, MOVIE DIRECTOR KNOWN FOR BOOK ADAPTATIONS
description: Henry King, who directed more than 100 films, including ''Tol'able David,'' ''The Song of Bernadette,'' ''Twelve O'Clock High'' and ''Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing,'' died Tuesday at his home in the San Fernando Valley. He was 91 years old.

title: Presbyterians Reaffirm Curbs on Homosexuals
description: The United Presbyterian Church early today reaffirmed a 1978 ruling that bars homosexuals from ordained ministry in the denomination.

title: St. Paul Cos. Stake
description: The St. Paul Companies of St. Paul has bought a 14.99 percent holding in Minet Holdings P.L.C., a British insurance brokerage, through purchases on the stock market, Minet said today. A Minet spokesman said St. Paul had told Minet that it intended to remain a minority shareholder, leaving Minet independent. St. Paul, which is also an insurance company, said that the purchase represented a $30 million investment and that it had made the move to gain market exposure outside the United States.

title: Animal Crackers
description: Port Conway Lane, the big white gelding with a fractured skull who has raced more often than any other active thoroughbred in the country, is closing in on his 50th career victory. The 13-year-old son of Bold Commander is stabled at Monmouth Park, where last month he scored his 47th and 48th victories.

title: HINCKLEY VERDICT PROVES THAT THE SYSTEM WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lake Erie Drilling Passes Army Test
description: The Army Corps of Engineers, capping a four-year study, said today that drilling for natural gas in Lake Erie could be undertaken in an ''environmentally acceptable manner.''

title: EGYPTIAN HAS TALKS IN PARIS ON ENDING BEIRUT IMPASSE
description: France and Egypt are having discussions to try to find a way for Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization to end their impasse in western Beirut.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We want the bloodshed to end -there's no question about that.'' -President Reagan, speaking of Lebanon. (A1:6.)

title: Guatemala's President Declares State of Siege
description: President Efrain Rios Montt announced today that a state of siege would take effect in Guatemala at midnight Thursday.

title: Cable Health Network Begins Early
description: The Cable Health Network, a 24-hour service focusing on health and science, was begun yesterday by satellite to more than 400 cable systems, with four milllion viewers. The service will be offered free to cable subscribers and will earn its revenues through advertising.

title: Foundation Names Ture
description: Norman B. Ture, architect of last year's tax cut and the Reagan Administration's chief supply-side economist, has been named Visiting Fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington-based research group.

title: U.S. Settles 2 Lawsuits On Crab Price; Crab-Price Suits Settled
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - The Justice Department reached agreements today with eight Japanese companies and four Seattle companies to bar price fixing in the crab industry.

title: 2D STAGE OF TAX CUT ARRIVING AS CONGRESS SEEKS NEW REVENUES
description: The second stage of President Reagan's three-year ''supply-side'' tax cuts takes effect Thursday with the economy teetering between recession and recovery and Congress already moving toward new revenue increases.

title: 2 STRONG LEADERS TAKE COMMAND IN BARGAINING FOR THE UNIFORMED COALITION
description: Philip Caruso, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and a leader of the 35,000-member Uniformed Forces Coalition, seems to bring to negotiations, people who have watched him closely agree, a sense of the policeman he once was.

title: 625 Laid Off By Cameron
description: Cameron Iron Works laid off 625 of its 4,200 hourly workers today.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS RISE BY 7.4%
description: About 36 million retired Social Security recipients will join the nation's working population this week in receiving fatter checks, when their inflation-indexed benefits rise 7.4 percent. The cost-of-living adjustments will cost the hardpressed Social Security Administration $11.3 billion in the coming fiscal year.

title: News Analysis
description: A reported prediction by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that Latin American nations would inevitably seek to restore good relations with the United States once the Falkland crisis ended has gained credence by his resignation.

title: Connecticut Starts Drinking Age of 19
description: Eighteen-year-olds lost the right to drink in Connecticut at midnight last night as a law establishing the drinking age at 19 went into effect.

title: RABBIS DEFINING JEWISHNESS
description: The country's Reform rabbis began debating a proposal Tuesday that would dramatically change the definition of Jewishness and affect the children of thousands of mixed marriages.

title: Phillies 6, Cards 3
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Larry Christenson, who had not posted a victory since May 15, stroked a two-run double to highlight a three-run second inning and Bob Dernier went 4 for 5 to lead Philadelphia.

title: FINISHES TO HELP FABRIC STAY CLEAN
description: THOUGH Stephen L. Nelson says his role is to help people deal with ''inconsiderate friends, sloppy spouses, boisterous children and incontinent pets,'' he is not a psychiatrist.

title: NJ Transit Corp.  Raises Its Fares
description: The NJ Transit Corporation today announced increases in its rail and bus fares of 10 to 30 percent.

title: Transcript of news session, page D20.
description: President Reagan said tonight that the United States had given ''no green light whatsoever'' to Israel to attack west Beirut, but he endorsed the Israeli demand that all the armed forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization in the city be withdrawn from Lebanon.

title: STATE CONTROL BOARD RATIFIES CITY'S SPENDING PLAN WARILY
description: The State Financial Control Board yesterday approved New York City's next budget as balanced. The vote by the board, the city's chief fiscal monitor, was unanimous.

title: THE AKITA'S THE DOG HAVING HIS DAY
description: IF fads are not always born in New York, it is indeed here that they fly and eventually fall, only to be replaced by new ones. Down coats and spinach salads, high-tech sofas and sauces nouvelles, Rubik's Cube and the Chipwich, cats and Donkey Kong, Izod shirts and sequined head antennae, sesame noodles and the resurgent miniskirt - all have burst upon us sporadically.

title: FARMERS' PRICES SLIPPED 0.7% IN JUNE
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 0.7 percent in June, the first monthly decline of the year, the Agriculture Department reported today. The last decline in the index was in December.

title: Curfew Ends in Warsaw; Discos to Reopen
description: Poland's martial law authorities ended a two-month curfew in Warsaw today and said they would also reopen discos and student clubs.

title: Belmont Winner To Run in Dwyer
description: Conquistador Cielo, who set a track record for the mile in the Metropolitan Handicap and won the Belmont Stakes by 14 lengths, will run in the Dwyer Stakes at Belmont Park on Monday, Woody Stephens, the colt's trainer, said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida confirmed reports that it plans to ground 7 of its 29 jets and lay off hundreds of workers by Labor Day, and said that it also will reduce flights in the United States and Central America.

title: Aluminum Venture
description: Toyo Aluminium said today that it and Aluminium Alcan de France would soon set up a joint venture in France to produce aluminum powder and paste for car and marine paints.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MRS. KING UPSETS TRACY AUSTIN, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2
description: Billie Jean King beat Tracy Austin, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, for the first time today, and earned a berth in the semifinals of the Wimbledon tennis tournament.

title: How Tax Cut May Be Used
description: A 10 percent cut in tax rates, the second phase of President Reagan's tax program, takes effect today. In a New York Times/CBS News Poll on economic attitudes conducted in May, 43 percent of the respondents said they would save the money derived from the tax cut, 50 percent said they would spend it and 2 percent said they would do both. The remaining 5 percent were uncertain about what they would do with the extra money.

title: GARDENHIRE'S WRONG GUESS WINS GAME
description: W hat prompts a batter to hit a home run after he has gone to bat 232 times in the big leagues without hitting even one? Ron Gardenhire of the Mets did it Tuesday night, and the odds against him were even greater than that: He was a rookie batting eighth in the lineup, he was hitting only .239, he was swinging right-handed against a right-handed power pitcher for one of the strongest teams in baseball and he had only 23 hits in his last 44 games, and none of those was a home run or even a triple.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MORE and more people are fixing up their houses or apartments because high costs have made moving or extensive remodeling impractical.

title: THEATER: DAVID ROUNDS PLAYS 10 ROLES IN 'HERRINGBONE'
description: ONE of the many outstanding assets of the 1980 Broadway revival of ''Morning's at Seven'' was David Rounds's slow-fuse characterization of the starchy, overgrown momma's boy, Homer. What we didn't know then -but know now - is that this actor could have played every part in that play, regardless of sex or age. In ''Herringbone,'' a bizarre musical that opened last night at the Playwrights Horizons, Mr. Rounds enacts all 10 roles, ranging from a raspy old Southern grandmother to a tap-dancing tot, and at times brings three or four of them on stage at once. Such is the intensity and skill that Mr. Rounds applies to this task that he seems less an actor than a man supernaturally possessed.

title: CLEVELAND QUARTET NEAR END OF BEETHOVEN CYCLE
description: UNLIKE the Beethoven symphonies, only a handful of complete recorded cycles of the quartets remain in the Schwann catalogue, so it is something of an occasion when another cycle of these monumental works nears its conclusion - especially when the performers are the members of the highly regarded Cleveland Quartet. That occasion is scheduled for next October, when RCA Records will release the group's traversal of all the late quartets.

title: An Aging Voice
description: W hat's this? Can it be that the iconoclasts who put out the city's largest alternative weekly newspaper - that former hotbed of distrust for anybody over 30 - are worrying about pensions? Indeed, it can. Talks on a new labor contract are stalled at The Village Voice, once a good place for a writer to starve.

title: INSANITY LAW SEEN AS HURTING SOCIETY
description: Several psychiatrists said today that existing laws made it too difficult to keep potentially dangerous people, such as John W. Hinckley Jr., locked up in mental hospitals after they had been found not guilty of a crime by reason of insanity.

title: U.S.-Soviet Trade Grows
description: Trade between the Soviet Union and the United States almost doubled in the first quarter of 1982 from the comparable period a year earlier because of resumed grain sales by the United States, according to statistics issued by the Soviet Union today.

title: Dunham Named to Post Of American Symphony
description: Benjamin S. Dunham has been named executive director of the American Symphony Orchestra.

title: TRADE DISAPPOINTS WILLIAMS
description: It took Ray Williams most of his 27 years to move away from home. For four of those years as a professional basketball player, he existed in the shadow of an extremely talented older brother, Gus, who was with Seattle, and he struggled to find his identity on the court. With the burden of having to support his family in Mount Vernon, N.Y., he also struggled to find his personal identity.

title: I.T.T. Studies Iran Charges
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation disclosed yesterday that it was investigating charges by a former employee that an I.T.T. division had exported goods to Iran in violation of the boycott imposed by President Carter in 1980.

title: Jazz Festival Reunites 4 Saxophonists of 40's
description: THE title of the jazz festival concert Tuesday night in Avery Fisher Hall was ''World Saxophone Quartet Meets the Four Brothers,'' but if there was a meeting, it took place backstage. Out front, one heard a heartening set by the quartet followed by a rather more prosaic reunion of four saxophonists associated with Woody Herman's band of the late 1940's.

title: BUDGET ACCORD SAVES BONN COALITION
description: The coalition Government of Social Democrats and Free Democrats agreed on the basic outlines for a 1983 budget tonight, eliminating, at least temporarily, a threat to the Government's future.

title: CITY'S OFFER IS REJECTED BY UNIONS
description: Both Philip Caruso of the police and Nicholas Mancuso of the firemen enjoy strong support within their unions.$

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Since taking over as manager from Bob Lemon early in the season, Gene Michael's record is 27-29 after last night's loss to Milwaukee. Since taking over for Bob Rodgers last month, Harvey Kuenn's record is 19-7. (Television - SportsChannel and WHT Cable, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. In an effort to get some more hiting, Manager George Bamberger may play Rusty Staub in left field and restore Dave Kingman to first base in the finale of the three-game series. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Tigers vs. Boston Red Sox, at Detroit. The Tigers, once the leaders in the American East, had lost 14 of 15 before beating the firstplace Red Sox last night. (Television - USA Cable, 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Richie Sandoval vs. Ian Clyde, 10-round bantamweight bout, at Showboat Hotel, Las Vegas, Nev. Sandoval is promising and undefeated (13-0, 11 with knockouts) Clyde is 19-2, had 11 fights in 1981 and won 5 by knockout. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Soccer World Cup: Austria vs. Northern Ireland; Belgium vs. Soviet Union. Second-round play resumes after a day off. (Television - Channel 41; 11 A.M. and 2:45 P.M. ESPN will broadcast Austria vs. Northern Ireland at 11 A.M. and a tape broadcast at 4:30 P.M. Channel 13, Northern Ireland vs. Austria, 11:40 P.M., tape).

title: 2 STRONG LEADERS TAKE COMMAND IN BARGAINING FOR THE UNIFORMED COLAITION
description: Nicholas Mancuso left the Vista International Hotel at 6:45 yesterday morning for a four-mile jog through lower Manhattan. It was not a merely recreational escape from the setting of this year's negotiations with the Uniformed Forces Coalition. Rather, Mr. Mancuso, the president of the 9,000-member Uniformed Firefighters Association, took the chance along the way to stop at Marine Company 2, south of 14th Street, and tell the firemen there what progress - or lack of it - could be discerned in the talks.

title: COLUMBIA CREW 'HOT-WIRES' STUDENT EXPERIMENTS
description: A clever bit of rewiring, recommended by payload engineers and executed with the skill of an automobile thief, enabled the Columbia's astronauts today to bypass a defective circuit and switch on electricity for a cluster of scientific instruments known as the ''getaway specials.''

title: G.O.P. SENATORS REACH TAX ACCORD
description: Senate Finance Committee Republicans, meeting all day behind closed doors, reached agreement tonight on a $21 billion revenue-raising bill that would impose a 10 percent withholding tax on most dividend and interest payments.

title: VIDEO GAMES TO TO HOLLYWOOD
description: Hollywood is cashing in on the video game boom. In 1981, game cartridges that can be plugged into home television sets and coin-operated arcade games were an $8 billion business, while audiences paid less than $3 billion at United States movie theater box offices. In the last few weeks, nearly every movie studio has announced a joint venture or new division meant to siphon off some of those impressive video game revenues.

title: VW to Close Plant In U.S. 6 Weeks
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. will close its only United States assembly plant for six weeks late this summer for model change-over and to adjust bulging inventories of unsold cars, a company spokesman said.

title: Westchester Study Finds Dump Safe
description: A yearlong environmental and health study of Westchester County's garbage dump at Croton Point has determined that toxic and hazardous wastes buried there over the years do not represent a health hazard for the landfill's employees or people using it for recreation.

title: Queens Bus Line Hit by Strike
description: A strike by 528 drivers and mechanics at midnight yesterday shut down the Green Bus Line, the city's largest private bus company, according to the union and company. The line carries as many as 100,000 riders each workday on routes through much of southern and eastern Queens.

title: JERSEY TOWN HIT BY TORNADO STARTS $1.5 MILLION CLEANUP
description: Still stunned and bewildered, the people of this New Jersey shore community began to regroup today in the wake of a tornado Tuesday night that left one man dead and that cut a sporadic two-mile trail of destruction.

title: Jartran Reorganization
description: Frank B. Hall & Company's Jartran Inc., which is operating in Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, said today that it had filed a revised plan of reorganization and a disclosure statement with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Chicago. If the plan is approved by the court and its creditors - mainly the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and Fruehauf - the company said it could emerge from Chapter 11 by the end of the summer.

title: ISRAELIS ARE GIVING TALKS MORE TIME
description: Israeli Government sources said today that the Cabinet had decided to give the American negotiator, Philip C. Habib, and the Lebanese authorities more time to arrange an evacuation of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut.

title: Couple Arrested at Vatican
description: A man and a woman apparently armed with a knife and a replica of a pistol were arrested in St. Peter's Square today, minutes before Pope John Paul II's weekly general audience.Police sources said the two were stopped as they passed through metal detection equipment set up at entrances to the square.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error in some editions yesterday, an article in Around the Nation incorrectly de- scribed the status of more than 700,000 General Motors cars with faulty cata- lytic converters. None have been re- called.

title: BIOMEDICAL PROGRESS UNDERCUT BY BUDGET KNIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE OUT: THE SCREEN PORCH REDISCOVERED
description: IN the 1890's, with the introduction of wire mesh screening, the screen porch became America's summertime living room. On steamy evenings it was the center of country life - the only place in the house to go to enjoy a passing breeze without being bothered by swarms of bugs.

title: HERS
THE CONSENSUS CRACKS
description: Francois Mitterrand is the best friend Israel has had in Elysee Palace for years: a French President who made a point of visiting Israel early in his term of office, one with close personal connections to the Jewish community of France. So his reaction to the war in Lebanon is a signal to which attention should be paid.

title: No. 2 Man in Veterans Agency Resigns Over Policy Disputes
description: Charles Hagel, deputy administrator of the Veterans Administration, submitted his resignation to President Reagan last week, the agency said Tuesday.

title: Delta Revises Reservations
description: Delta Air Lines said that it would offer a computerized reservation system to travel agents that would be unbiased and would be based on the schedules in the Official Airline guide, long considered the definitive compilation of flights and fares by the industry.

title: Cigna Job Cuts
description: The Cigna Corporation, recently formed through the merger of the INA Corporation and the Connecticut General Corporation, said today it was consolidating the headquarters functions of its property and casualty groups in Philadelphia and its investment group in Bloomfield, Conn., resulting in the loss of about 500 jobs.

title: SCM Will Close Plant in Groton
description: The SCM Corporation said it would close its Smith-Corona portable typewriter plant in Groton, N.Y., with a loss of about 400 jobs, and shift production to Singapore, where it already employs about 1,000 workers.

title: No Challengers, Yet
description: Don King, the promoter, was looking for an emergency replacement for Mario Miranda, the top-ranked challenger, to oppose the World Boxing Council featherweight champion, Salvador Sanchez of Mexico, in the July 21 title fight at Madison Square Garden. Miranda received an ear injury 11 days ago while stopping Marcos Villasana of Mexico in his native Colombia.

title: ROMAN ANTECEDENTS OF ENGLAND'S CHURCH
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY FAILS TO PASS A NEW PENSION PLAN FOR PUBLIC WORKERS
description: A pension plan covering 300,000 state and local government employees expired tonight when the State Legislature failed to agree on a measure to extend or modify it.

title: PAN AM PRESIDENT GOING TO PUROLATOR
description: William H. Waltrip, who has served as president and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways for less than a year, resigned suddenly yesterday to take the position of president and chief operating officer at Purolator Inc. He will succeed Frederick H. Cook, 66 years old, who will continue as chairman. Mr. Waltrip, who is 44, joined Pan Am in 1972 as vice president in charge of planning and scheduling, and served before that at Eastern Airlines.

title: Addenda
description: * FCB International, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, has acquired a minority interest in the Dutch agency van Lieshout en van Hemert of Rotterdam. The new agency will be called van Lieshout en van Hemert/FCB B.V.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: I feel compelled to comment on Mary Kay Blakely's article about motherhood. I am one of those sacrifices - a mother of the 50's. I was also a mother in the 60's and the 70's, and am still a mother in the 80's - our third child is now a young teen-ager.
description: Until today I was unaware of being either a sacrifice, a survivor or a victim of a confidence game. It was wonderful to be able to stay home with my children and feel that I was doing a most important job - raising them.

title: POLICY STILL UNSHAPED
description: George Shultz, the next Secretary of State, has one big advantage over his temperamental predecessor, Alexander Haig. That is his cool personality, which takes him unscathed through the bureaucratic wars.

title: NEW YORK AND 9 OTHER STATES BLOCK U.S. ON SCHOOL FUNDS
description: A Federal District Court today granted a preliminary injunction enjoining the Secretary of Education from distributing $2.8 billion in Federal grant money for the teaching of disadvantaged children, a figure reached on the basis of 1970 census figures.

title: 8 Soldiers Held in Zimbabwe
description: Eight soldiers and an undisclosed number of civilians have been detained in connection with an attack on the residence of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe last week, Home Affairs Minister Herbert Ushewokunze said today. He gave no details.

title: FED TO LET BANK TRADE IN FUTURES
description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved a proposal by J.P. Morgan & Company to trade in financial futures. The action allows the Morgan Futures Corporation, a subsidiary of the bank holding company, to act as a futures commission merchant - in effect, a broker - in futures contracts for bullion, foreign exchange and United States Government securities.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BENJAMIN CASTLEMAN
description: Dr. Benjamin Castleman, a pathologist at Massachusetts General Hospital and a specialist on the parathyroid gland, died Tuesday of cancer. He was 76 years old. Dr. Castleman was the hospital's chief of pathology for 24 years until his retirement in l974.

title: CANADA OFFER BY CHRYSLER
description: (AP) - Chrysler Canada Ltd. is offering to sell its unprofitable spring plant and equipment to Local 444 of the United Automobile Workers for $1.

title: Talks on the P.L.O. Bog Down in Beirut; News Analysis
description: The negotiations for a peaceful settlement of the Lebanon crisis are mired in the no man's land between failure and success. Many people here wonder whether an agreement can ever be worked out.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE REACHES ACCORD ON 1983 TAX RISES
description: The Senate Finance Committee early this morning approved a $21 billion revenue-raising bill, supported by the Reagan Administration, that would increase consumer taxes on cigarettes and telephone service and restrict deductions for medical expenses and casualty losses.

title: Dispute Grows Between Yanks and Winfield Fund
description: A news conference called yesterday by the David Winfield Foundation led to two other news conferences and an indirect verbal scuffle between George Steinbrenner and Winfield, the Yankee outfielder.

title: National Medical Buys Care Group
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc., the hospital management corporation, announced it had aquired First Washington Group Inc., and its subsidiary, Psychiatric Institutes of America, for approximately $100 million.

title: Going Nowhere
description: Chip Winans, a 26-year-old champion windsurfer from Harwichport, Mass., set out Sunday on an unprecedented voyage: an attempt to windsurf 700 miles, from Bermuda to New York. But his trip has ended about 200 miles northwest of Bermuda.

title: Carroll G. Harper, 53, Lawyer Ex-Head of Met Opera Club
description: Carroll G. Harper, a lawyer who was a former president of the Metropolitan Opera Club and a former national chairman of the Metropolitan Opera National Council's regional audition program, died Monday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: SATANISM TALES SPUR P.&G. SUIT
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is not doing business with the Devil, and wants to tell everybody so. The giant consumer products company filed libel suits yesterday in Atlanta and in Pensacola, Fla., against three individuals whom it accused of spreading ''false and malicious'' rumors that Procter & Gamble and its executives are involved in Satanism and Devil worship.

title: A Lifetime For the Top Two
description: The Democrats got solidly behind the nuclear freeze and women's movements last weekend, which is good; had a high old time roasting Ronald Reagan, which is understandable; and gave the big hello to those two fresh faces, Edward M. Kennedy and Walter P. (Fritz) Mondale. Judge that for yourself.

title: Righetti Excels, but Fidrych Wins
description: In a duel between two pitchers on the comeback trail, Dave Righetti struck out 12 batters in six innings tonight in his first game since the Yankees demoted him to the minor leagues.

title: Israeli Consul Predicts Trials For Many Seized in Lebanon
description: An Israeli official said in New York yesterday that many of the 5,800 Palestinians taken prisoner by the Israeli Army in Lebanon would be tried as criminals.

title: WESTWAY COURT ACTIONS SEEN AS COSTLY SETBACK
description: A set of court decisions halting work on the Westway project will delay the project for at least a year and add about $200 million to the cost, the state's Commissioner of Transportation said yesterday.

title: BROADCASTS TO CUBA DEFENDED AND DERIDED AT SENATE SESSION
description: Administration officials told Congress today that American radio broadcasts to Cuba would permit Cubans to learn how their country is run, while Senate critics said the proposed broadcasts would heighten tensions between the United States and Cuba.

title: CITY ENDING ENFORCEMENT PROGRAM
description: There were 101 fewer traffic deaths in New York City in the first six months of this year than in the same period in 1981, a 27.5 percent reduction. The police say the reduction was attributable, at least in part, to special safety enforcement since last Aug. 11.

title: COMMUTERS DELAYED BY CONRAIL DERAILMENT AND QUEENS BUS STRIKE
description: Thousands of commuters who use Conrail's Hudson and Harlem lines were delayed for up to an hour going to and from work yesterday after seven cars of a 56-car freight train derailed in the Bronx, blocking the northbound and southbound tracks.
