title: Sculptor Is Selected For Vietnam Statue
description: A District of Columbia sculptor was chosen today to create a statue for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial that is now being built on the Mall near the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Birmingham Rotary Club Opens Doors to Blacks
description: The Birmingham Rotary Club has decided to officially open its membership to blacks, but there is no guarantee that any blacks will be invited to join.

title: Soviet Wins by 1-0
description: The Soviet Union set up a conclusive game with Poland on July 4 by beating Belgium tonight, 1-0, in a second-round match of the World Cup.

title: FINAL CONTRACTS TO BE SIGNED TODAY FOR THE PORTMAN HOTEL
description: After a decade of on-again, off-again negotiations, the final contracts for the Portman hotel in Times Square are scheduled to be signed today. The only remaining building on the site, the Piccadilly Hotel, was closed yesterday after the last tenant left.

title: MIDEAST: WRONG VICTIM, WRONG ANTAGONIST
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. Drops Case on G.M.
description: The Federal Trade Commission today dismissed a 1976 case against the General Motors Corporation involving charges that the auto maker's policy of selling repair parts only to its own dealers was unfair.

title: MEDICARE: PENNY-WISE ON PREVENTIVE CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS RISE 1.3%
description: New construction spending in May rose a strong 1.3 percent, marking the third consecutive monthly gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Standard Metals
description: The Standard Metals Corporation announced that it would acquire UCO Inc., a Denver coal company that is operating under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Standard Metals will purchase all of UCO's shares later this year under an agreement signed yesterday by the two companies. UCO owns and has leases on coal properties in Carbon County, Utah, which Standard Metals said it plans to develop.

title: SOVIET CUTS BACK SOME FOREIGN PHONE LINKS
description: The Soviet Union has ordered a cutback in telephone links with the United States and with at least eight Western European countries.

title: GUINEAN, IN TOTAL REVERSAL, ASKS MORE U.S. INVESTMENT
description: President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea, saying that his nation had ''fabulous economic potential,'' today urged stepped-up American private investment in his impoverished West African country.

title: Soviet Feminist Sentenced
description: Natalya Lazareva, a Leningrad feminist, was sentenced today to four years in prison to be followed by two years in internal exile for slandering the Soviet state, the press agency Tass said. It said that Miss Lazareva, using ''slanderous articles besmirching the Soviet state,'' had compiled a women's rights journal known as Mariya. Tass said it ''contained appeals to Western countries to interfere in the internal affairs of the Soviet Union.''

title: RULES PANELS DOMINATE LEGISLATURE'S CLOSE IN ALBANY
description: By all accounts, ''Mr. Rules'' is the most prolific presence in the Legislature. Last year, the Committee on Rules, or ''Mr. Rules'' as it is popularly known here, was listed as the sponsor of 1,039 bills in the Assembly. The Senate Rules Committee sponsored hundreds of others.

title: The House Is / Is Not a Home
description: Both Houses of Congress have now agreed to eliminate the fat automatic tax break they voted themselves for Washington expenses last fall. But Senator Russell Long of Louisiana says that simply returning to the old rules is not enough. He has introduced a sensible bill that would treat senators and representatives just like everyone else when it comes to expense accounting.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture accompanying the theater review of the Grand Kabuki yesterday was incorrectly captioned. It showed Fukusuke.

title: Irish Government Wins A Vote of Confidence
description: The Irish Republic's four-month-old minority government won a crucial vote of confidence in Parliament today and defeated an attempt to force the second general election this year.

title: Bridge: Strange Canadian Ailment Causes Dummy Problems
description: A strange phenomenon that has long terrified serious players has been prevalent recently in Canada where it has been christened ''the Y dummy.''

title: FESTIVAL CELEBRATES WOMEN OF JAZZ
description: THE Kool Jazz Festival is turning its attention to women this weekend. Ella Fitzgerald, as befits her position as the grande dame of vocal jazz, leads the way tonight in two shows in Carnegie Hall at 7 and 10 P.M., when she will join in what has become over the years a classic pairing with the Count Basie orchestra. The cleanup female swinger will be Anita O'Day, who will be part of a tribute to Stan Kenton on Sunday, the last day of the festival, at Avery Fisher Hall at 8 P.M.

title: ANOTHER ECONOMIST QUITS REAGAN TEAM
description: Jerry L. Jordan, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and its chief forecaster, has resigned, the White House announced yesterday. He is the Administration's fourth key economic official to resign this year.

title: Begin Aides Worry Over Lengthy Role; News Analysis
description: Whatever the outcome of the siege of west Beirut, it is becoming apparent that Israeli troops are going to have to remain in Lebanon for some time to guarantee the political achievements of their invasion.

title: Alexander & Alexander
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to acquire Clifton & Company, one of the largest independent insurance brokers in the Western United States. The acquisition, valued at about $9 million, will involve the exchange of 355,000 shares of Alexander & Alexander common, the company, an insurance broker, said.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL. By William Kotzwinkle. Based on a screen- play by Melissa Mathison. 246 pages. Putnam's. $12.95.

title: ZECKENDORF PROJECT ON UPPER BROADWAY
description: The late William Zeckendorf flashed across the postwar real estate scene, a man of great plans and broad visions. His company, Webb & Knapp, ultimately collapsed, but more permanent monuments survive. In New York they include the United Nations headquarters, Park West Village, Lincoln Towers and Kips Bay Plaza.

title: DIANA ROSS SPREADING HER WINGS
description: Diana Ross's concert at the 72,000-seat Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands will be the first nighttime pop-music concert in the history of the stadium, and the stadium will be the largest United States arena Miss Ross has performed in since she left the Supremes 12 years ago to pursue a solo recording career.

title: CATALYST FOR RARE UNITY ON THE HILL
description: Members of Congress may work mightily to get here, but once elected, ensconced in their offices and engaged in the nation's business, nothing takes precedence over going home for vacation.

title: 'WILLI BUSCH,' A GERMAN COMEDY
description: ''DER WILLI BUSCH REPORT'' is set in Friedheim, a West German town on the border with East Germany. This formerly bustling place has become, with the partition of Germany, a sleepy and remote frontier outpost, because the border now separates Friedheim from the rest of the valley in which it lies.

title: ASSAULT BY ISRAELIS IS FEARED
description: Negotiations to end the Israeli siege are snagged in a welter of details and disagreements over the fate of the Palestine Liberation Organization in western Beirut.

title: REAGAN HAILS PROPOSAL FOR NEW INSANITY LAW
description: President Reagan spoke approvingly today of proposals to replace the insanity defense with a new law that would allow juries to return ''guilty but insane'' verdicts in criminal cases.

title: Mr. Reagan Grades Himself
description: Is there confusion in President Reagan's foreign policy? At his press conference Wednesday night he sought to dispel any doubts:

title: BONN'S COALITION REPORTED AT ODDS
description: The West German coalition narrowly averted collapse Wednesday, according to a participant at a Cabinet meeting that led to an eventual agreement on outlines for a 1983 budget.

title: U.S. LISTS 60,000 ACRES OF FEDERAL LAND TO BE SOLD
description: The chairman of President Reagan's new Property Review Board today identified 60,000 acres of Federal land, including a slice of Waikiki Beach, ''which will be sold to reduce the national debt.''

title: NEW BUDGET FOR CALIFORNIA REFLECTS CUTBACK IN SERVICES
description: Four years after Californians rebelled and voted a limit on soaring property taxes, the state has adopted a new budget that officials say may bring about the kind of deep cuts in public services that were envisaged when the law was passed.

title: ART: SHOW IN BROOKLYN MINES BLACK FOLK VEIN
description: FOLK artists are a self-sufficient breed requiring no scene to belong to and no museums or exhibitions by others for inspiration and moral support. Most have turned to art late in life, and there's no telling their past occupations from their output. Some use art as a religious expression, but all seem to be operating in the same spiritual realm - a kind of never-never land that they share with children.

title: MINORITY TEACHERS MAKING HEADWAY HERE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: For the 2,075 couples married by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon yesterday, the service at Madison Square Garden was a step toward perfecting the world by creating ''true parents'' whose total loyalty to God is the foundation of a new society.

title: SOLAR POWER RACE AT JERSEY CONCERN
description: The company's office doesn't look like much, just a onestory brick structure with a series of hastily built extensions tumbling out the back. Inside, Zoltan J. Kiss, a one-time professional soccer player whose preceding business venture ended in a bankruptcy filing, munches on a sandwich at his desk while explaining how his six-year-old company lost about $1 a share in the past year.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE 'SERENADE'
description: SOME ballets endure, renewing themselves for each generation of bodies and sensibilities. Such a ballet is George Balanchine's ''Serenade,'' performed by the New York City Ballet Wednesday in the New York State Theater. Named after its Tchaikovsky score and created for the company's first, fledgling dancers, ''Serenade'' has retained the sweetness and mystery of the score and the innocence of those early performers. It is likely they did not dance it, however, with such crispness and eloquent technical brilliance.

title: Tuition at Rutgers May Increase 23%
description: The president of Rutgers University said today that he would recommend to the school's board of governors that tuition be increased 23 percent next year because of cuts in the state budget for higher education.

title: Ruth Liebman, Police Aide; Wed to Arthur Bergmann
description: Ruth N. Liebman, daughter of Esther Sullivan of Manorville, L.I., and the late Max Liebman, was married in Hauppauge, L.I., yesterday to Arthur Bergmann of Center Moriches, L.I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Augustus H. Bergmann of Golden Beach, Fla.

title: Market Place; Technology And Success
description: CAN an unusually successful technology company gain ground in the stock market at a time when stocks generally are perceived to be risky? If the technology company is Onyx/IMI, the answer seems to be no. But if the company is Verbatim Inc., the answer is probably yes.

title: 2 HOLDERS WIDEN ROLE IN BECKER
description: Warburg Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker Inc., which recently disclosed that it has been losing money, announced yesterday that its two major European shareholders would exercise options to increase their joint holdings to more than 50 percent, thus taking control of the investment company.

title: British Tories in Clash Over Falkland Inquiry
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and former Prime Minister Edward Heath clashed today over the Government's planned inquiry into the conflict with Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: PLAYS
description: I n 1943, Truett (Rip) Sewell of the Pittsburgh Pirates developed a blooper pitch that became known as the ''dewdrop.'' He first tried it against Dom Dallessandro of the Chicago Cubs and threw it on a three-and-two count. The surprised Dallessandro just let it float by.

title: MRS. THATCHER FAULTS U.S. ON SIBERIA PIPELINE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher criticized the United States today for trying to limit the ability of foreign companies to fulfill contracts for a 3,700-mile natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: A POLITICAL CLOUD OVER HENLEY
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 1 - The 133d Henley Royal Regatta began today amid several political controversies that have jarred the otherwise idyllic tranquility of this oldest world rowing event.

title: A.T.&.T. MAPS AMERICAN BELL GROWTH
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a plan with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday outlining a dramatic increase in the assets and capital investment of its newly formed unregulated subsidiary, American Bell Inc.

title: P.L.O. Seeks Pullback By Israeli Troops First
description: An official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it was seeking an Israeli pullback from Beirut before discussing its own future in Lebanon.

title: Honduran Soldiers Accused Of Abusing American Woman
description: An undisclosed number of Honduran soldiers and intelligence agents are under investigation for the reported assault of a 31-year-old American woman last month, an armed forces statement said Wednesday.

title: 2 MORE HARVESTER UNITS ON THE BLOCK
description: The International Harvester Company announced that it was offering its nodular iron foundry, in Waukesha, Wis., and its fiberglass components operation, in Columbus, Ohio, for sale.

title: DEARTH OF DATA ON DUMPING OF SEWER SLUDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Nast Buys 50% Of Interiors
description: Conde Nast Publications Ltd. has bought a 50 percent share in Pharos Publications Ltd., the publisher of Interiors, a glossy magazine aimed at upper-income readers.

title: John S. Walker, Ex-Counsel To Atomic Panel in Congress
description: John Stanley Walker, a former counsel to the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, died here Monday at the age of 62.

title: THE REGION
description: The staff of the State Public Service Commission has come out in opposition to the Long Island Lighting Company's request for a $148.4 million annual increase in electric rates. The commission staff contends that present rates would bring in $7.25 million more - or about 21 cents a month for the average customer - than Lilco needs for a fair return.

title: Thrift Unit Merger
description: A merger between the Allied Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Carver Federal Savings and Loan Association, both of New York City, was arranged yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which provided $2 million in financial assistance to facilitate the merger. The merger of Allied, with assets of $18.4 million and two branch offices, and Carver, with assets of $91.3 million and five branch offices, will create one of the nation's largest black-run thrift units. It becomes effective on July 31, the F.H.L.B.B. said.

title: Amax Trims Quarterly
description: Amax Inc. said today that it had cut its quarterly dividend to 5 cents a share from 15 cents, payable Sept. 1 to stockholders of record Aug. 10. The company said the move was made to conserve cash further because of continuing depressed market conditions for minerals and metals.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Hat for Haig?

title: COURT RULES CONFIDENTIAL TAPE DOCTOR SENT WIFE
description: The state's highest court ruled yesterday that a tape recording made by a Bronx surgeon for his wife shortly before he attempted to commit suicide was a confidential communication between spouses.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, some Late Edition copies of Sports Pages yesterday carried an early version of page B12, lacking the article about the New Jersey Devils hockey team. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: MIDEAST: WRONG VICTIM, WRONG ANTAGONIST
description: To the Editor: In reading the tragic news from the Middle East, the thought occurred to me that the Israelis and the P.L.O. are fighting the wrong enemy.

title: ARGENTINE OFFICER SWORN IN AS CHIEF
description: A retired army general was inaugurated today as Argentina's President in a ceremony boycotted by the head of the air force and other military leaders.

title: Judge Upsets Conviction Of San Quentin Inmate
description: The murder convictions of Johnny Spain, a former Black Panther, were overturned Wednesday by a Federal judge who ordered that the charges either be dropped or that Mr. Spain be retried within 90 days.

title: Analysts Discount Con Ed Suit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and analysts yesterday discounted suggestions that the company might be faced with a barrage of costly negligence suits in connection with its nuclear reactor components.

title: Panhandle Seeking Algeria Compliance
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, a diversified energy company based in Houston, said that it had begun arbitration proceedings to force Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil company, to fullfill a contract signed in 1975 that called for deliveries of 3.3 trillion cubic feet of gas over a 20-year period. The deliveries were to have started last August.

title: SCOUTING
description: Wilt Chamberlain's main interest these days is track and field, and he is angry because he says some top-ranked American competitors are ignoring international meets in this country in favor of better publicity and financial benefits at European events.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our goal is to re-establish the ideal family. And in establishing an ideal family, we can establish an ideal world.''

title: Married Catholic Priest Says His First Mass
description: With his wife present, the Rev. James Parker celebrated mass and became the first noncelibate Roman Catholic priest in the United States to perform the Western Rite, a church official said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Ship of the Line Will Call New York Home

title: Police Report Summonses Off
description: The number of summonses issued by police officers fell by about a third yesterday, the day after contracts for city employees expired, the Police Department said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No Obstacle to Love

title: UNKINDLY CUT OF A TAX PIE: 4 LEAP INTO IT
description: It was billed in news releases as a ''Titanic Tart,'' a ''Special Tax Pie'' that would celebrate this date, the starting day of President Reagan's 10 percent tax cut.

title: SOCIALIST PLAN WOULD DIVIDE UP PARIS
description: France's Socialist Government has announced a proposal to divide Paris into 20 municipalities, one for each arrondissement, each with its own mayor and town council.

title: Akzo Bid Fought
description: Akzona Inc. said that a class action suit had been filed in Delaware seeking to stop the acquisition by Akzo N.V. of the 34 percent of outstanding Akzona stock that it did not own. Details of the suit were not given. Akzo, of the Netherlands, proposes paying $16.25 for each of the remaining shares, and Akzona shareholders are expected to vote on the transaction this summer.

title: R.J. Reynolds Compensation
description: SALEM, N.C., July 1 (Reuters) -R.J. Reynolds Industries said it had received a $179.7 million payment as compensation for its Aminoil USA unit's Kuwaiti oilfield properties nationalized in 1978.

title: EGYPTIAN SAYS LEBANON CRISIS 'OBLIGES US' TO BUILD UP FORCES
description: Egypt's Defense Minister has declared that what is happening in Lebanon ''obliges us'' to build up the nation's armed forces.

title: Erie Lackawanna Reorganization
description: A reorganization plan for the Erie Lackawanna Railway Company was approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court, trustees of the railroad said.

title: BAND MUSIC STILL ECHOES OUT OF THE NATION'S PAST
description: There aren't many professional concert bands left these days. The Guggenheim Concert Band is currently giving its summer series in Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park and other New York parks. The George Seuffert Band is active in Queens and will perform tomorrow night at 8 in Crocheron Park and Sunday at 3 P.M. at Forest Park. There will be a lot of jazz bands around this Fourth of July weekend, but they don't count; they are of a different species, and they don't play the ''Anvil Chorus'' or the ''Carnival of Venice'' with solo cornet piercing the stratosphere.

title: The author of 'Author!  Author!'
description: ''AUTHOR! AUTHOR!,'' starring Al Pacino, is a movie filled with the flavors and textures of New York. There are philosophical cops, Broadway producers who say ''I smell money'' and scenes indicating how foolish it is to take your kids to Elaine's and what it's like to live in a Greenwich Village brownstone and write plays and live through opening nights, waiting for reviews that can make you or break you.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS SAY RULING WON'T ALTER GOAL TO AID WOMEN
description: Officials of Mississippi University for Women said today they would maintain their emphasis on educating young women in the aftermath of a United States Supreme Court ruling that they must admit men to their nursing school.

title: Driver, 2 Others Indicted
description: Bernard (Ben) Webster, a leading harness driver, was indicted along with a New York lawyer and a Delaware gambler today on charges of fixing races at the Meadowlands last year.

title: Roman coin sets record.
description: ZURICH A ROMAN coin that was minted around the year 300 became the most expensive ancient coin ever auctioned yesterday, when it was sold in Zurich for $120,000 by Sotheby Parke Bernet to Michel Bendenoun of Trad'Art, a Brussels dealer. The day's sale of coins brought $1.7 million.

title: SOLO PIANO: HAL SCHAEFER
description: HAL SCHAEFER'S solo piano concert in the Forum Room of the New York Sheraton Hotel Wednesday afternoon as part of the Kool Jazz Festival revealed him as a romantic with a rhythmic soul.

title: NEW YORK'S LEGISLATURE MOVING TOWARD RECESS
description: The 205th session of the State Legislature began moving toward its summer recess early this morning with a series of closed conferences and negotiating sessions.

title: YANKEES STOP BREWERS
description: For one inning last night, Gene's Shirley Temples resembled Harvey's Wallbangers. The Yankees, whose offense had been as tame as the children's drink in recent games, scored five runs for Manager Gene Michael in the first inning, then held on for a 5-3 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Marilyn J. Turtz Bride Of Jonathan Friedman
description: Marilyn Joan Turtz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Turtz of Valley Stream, L.I., was married yesterday to Jonathan Block Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Friedman of Freeport, L.I. Rabbi Reuben Katz performed the ceremony at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

title: Extradition Order In Slaying Upheld
description: An appeals court in New York yesterday upheld the extradition to Utah of Frances Schreuder, who is charged with first-degree murder in the slaying of her father, a millionaire auto-parts dealer, four years ago.

title: Court Upholds Limits On Liquor Wholesaling
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a California liquor-distribution law did not violate Federal antitrust law despite restrictions that it placed on the ability of wholesalers to do business with out-of-state distillers.

title: MOSCOW DEFENDS QUALITY OF ARMS IT SELLS TO ARABS
description: The Soviet Union has taken the unusual step of publicly rebutting assertions that the weapons supplied by Moscow to the Arabs were inferior to Israeli and American arms.

title: ARABS BUY 25% OF FIRM ON WALL ST.
description: In the latest step in what is being called the internationalization of Wall Street, the corporate parent of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company has agreed to sell 25 percent of it to a group of Middle Eastern investors.

title: DISENCHANTED HERO OF SANDINISTS EMERGES AS LEADER OF THEIR FOES
description: Barely two months after denouncing the radicalism of his former colleagues, Eden Pastora Gomez, a popular hero of the Nicaraguan revolution, has emerged as the clear leader of an exile movement to topple the three-year-old Sandinist regime.

title: Rate Climbs on Treasury Issue
description: The Treasury yesterday auctioned $4 billion of seven-year notes at an average yield of 14.62 percent, up from 14.42 percent at the last sale on March 31 and the highest yield since Jan. 6, when it was 14.74 percent. The average price on the 14.5 percent notes was 99.465.

title: BOND EXECUTIVE FINDS A REBOUND IN NORTHEAST
description: In the world of municipal bonds, Roosevelt & Cross, an old-line firm founded by Teddy Roosevelt's son Archibald, has carved out the Northeast as its special territory.

title: Pace of Name Changes Up 49% Thus Far in '82
description: The first half of this year saw the most American corporate name changes since 1978. The number was up 49 percent from the first half of 1981.

title: ELWOOD WILLIAMS 3D
description: Washington, July 1 - Elwood Williams 3d, a former State Department officer, died Wednesday at Georgetown University Hospital of multiple sclerosis. He was 68 years old. Mr. Williams joined the Foreign Service in 1940 as a clerk and retired in 1974.

title: 300 FEDERAL WORKERS FACE FURLOUGHS NEXT WEEK
description: The House officially adjourned today for Independence Day without acting on an emergency spending bill, leaving 300 Federal workers facing half-time, half-pay work schedules.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: About the 'Market Basket'

title: SHAKESPEARE IN THE PARK, THIS TIME IN BROOKLYN
description: Shakespeare returns to Brooklyn tonight in the first season of free theater in Prospect Park in several years. Joseph Papp, who is a Brooklyn native as well as head of the New York Shakespeare Festival, is presenting a production of ''Twelfth Night'' by Shakespeare & Company, a troupe based in Lenox, Mass.

title: The Pipeline Is Lost; Poland Isn't
description: ''Play our way - or play without us.'' That, in effect, is what President Reagan says by barring the use of American equipment or licensed technology in the construction of the pipeline to bring natural gas from Siberia to Europe.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cloudy Crystal Ball For Gypsy Rights Group

title: 8 Arraigned Over Secrets
description: Five employees of a Japanese computer maker and three other persons from California's high technology industry were arraigned today on charges of stealing industrial secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation and transporting them to Japan or acting as go-betweens. All eight pleaded not guilty.

title: Toyota and Unit Merge
description: The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest auto maker, and its sales division, the Toyota Motor Sales Company, merged today to counter expected competition in the worldwide small-car market in the 1980's. The new company, named the Toyota Motor Corporation, is worth an estimated $467 million and employs 56,700 workers, a spokesman said.

title: Grace Lifts Dividend
description: W.R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it had raised its quarterly dividend to 70 cents a share from 65 cents, payable Sept. 10 to stockholders of record Aug. 5.

title: Indians 6, Orioles 2
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Von Hayes continued his assault on Baltimore pitching with a three-run homer in the first inning as Cleveland completed a three-game sweep of the Orioles. It was the fourth consecutive victory for the Indians and their first sweep here since 1968.

title: TIMES NAMES 6 EDITORS TO NEW ASSIGNMENTS
description: New assignments for six editors at The New York Times were announced yesterday by A.M. Rosenthal, the executive editor. William H. Honan was named cultural news editor and Marvin Siegel was appointed as his deputy. Robert J. Berkvist was appointed editor of the Arts and Leisure section and Eva Hoffman was named his deputy. Annette Grant was appointed editor of Weekend. Donna S.K. Laurie was named editor of the national edition.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Voluntary Hospitals Face a Strike Threat
description: A strike date of July 15 was set at 55 voluntary hospitals and homes in New York City yesterday by District 1199 of the National Union of Hospitals and Health Care Workers.

title: Gilder's 64 Leads Western
description: Score Sets Course Mark

title: CHINESE DANCER SEEKS U.S. STATUS
description: A Chinese ballet dancer who slipped away from an international competition in Mississippi has asked Federal officials here to let him stay in the United States permanently, Government officials said today.

title: FULLER UNIT OF GATX FILLS PRESIDENT'S POST
description: Elmer D. Gates, 52, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Fuller Company, a subsidiary of the Chicago-based GATX Corporation. He fills the year-old vacancy left by Kenneth A. Krick, who was elected Fuller chairman and chief executive officer in June 1981.

title: HOUSE TO CHECK SEX REPORTS ON MEMBERS AND PAGES
description: The leadership of the House of Representatives today ordered an investigation into charges that some members of Congress had offered preferential treatment to teen-aged legislative pages in return for sexual favors.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Inside Story

title: Dow Off 8.66 on Profit Fears; Technology Stocks Lose
description: Stock prices moved generally lower yesterday, with reduced earnings estimates affecting several technology issues that once ranked as star performers.

title: St. Regis Layoffs
description: About 600 workers will be laid off as the St. Regis Paper Company goes into the third three-week shutdown of its Jacksonville plant this year, plant officials said today.

title: Claridge Granted A Casino License
description: The Claridge Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City was granted a regular operating license today after the dismissal of investigators' objections to an executive connected to the gaming hall.

title: U.S. Inquiry Opens on Report Of Harassment of Marchers
description: The Justice Department's chief civil rights enforcer said today he had received reports of racial harassment against people who marched from Alabama to Washington last month in support of the Voting Rights Act.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's 219 money market funds fell $1.24 billion, to $201.66 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the first week in the past six months when all three categories of funds declined.

title: MOTIONS HEARD IN RACING CASE
description: Attorneys for Michael Venezia and Jacinto Vasquez, two of the jockeys facing disciplinary action by the state Racing and Wagering Board for their possible involvement in fixed races at New York thoroughbred tracks in 1974, argued yesterday that the charges should be dropped.

title: An Honorary Celtic
description: Red Auerbach, the general manager of the Boston Celtics, has received a telegram from one of the players drafted earlier this week by the team. ''Thanks a million, you really made my day,'' said Landon Turner, the paralyzed basketball star who was honored by the Celtics as the final choice in the draft.

title: MONDALE TELLS N.A.A.C.P. TO USE VOTE POWER
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, echoing the convention theme of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People here, urged the organization today to work to defeat elected officials who he suggested were helping to create two separate and unequal Americas.

title: Getting Acquainted
description: Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks' executive vice president in charge of operations, called yesterday's 45-minute meeting with Sly Williams, the free-agent forward, ''upbeat.'' Williams, who was suspended twice last season for missing games, practices, a plane and a doctor's appointment, met with Coach Hubie Brown and Eddie Donovan, the vice president and director of player personnel.

title: Georgia Pacific
description: The Georgia Pacific Corpoaiton said it had agreed with the Damson Oil Corporation and another party to sell its 24.75 percent royalty interest in acerage in the Port Hudson field, East Baton Rouge Parish, La. Damson is to pay $54.3 million and the other party $13.5 million. The deal is subject to clearance by Damson and the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Two Flawless Homers
description: Bob Horner of the Atlanta Braves, knew he had a flaw in his swing, and he was determined to find it. '' Horner's .321 batting average fell to .298 during the last two weeks, but he corrected the flaw in a comeback victory over Houston Wednesday night by hitting two home runs and raising his average to .302.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THERE are birthday parties and there are birthday parties. But few o f them are like Lena Horne's 65th birthday party at Roseland W ednesday night. For starters, the singer couldn't get out of her l imousine after it pulled up in front of the mammoth dance palace b ecause the car was surrounded by throngs of well-wishers who began s inging ''Happy Birthday.''

title: GERULAITIS IS UPSET BY EDMONDSON
description: Grass courts always seem greener for Mark Edmondson and Brian Teacher. They reaffirmed that with victories over Vitas Gerulaitis and Mats Wilander at Wimbledon today.

title: ALASKA RESISTING U.S. OFFER TO GIVE UP A RAILROAD
description: The Alaska Railroad is the subject of a dispute between the governments of Alaska and the United States, centering on the Reagan Administration's determination to have the Federal Government divest itself of ownership of the line.

title: BONN OFFERING $1.8 BILLION TO BOLSTER STEEL INDUSTRY
description: West Germany has agreed to help pay for the restructuring and modernization of its ailing steel industry. At a Cabinet meeting Wednesday, the Government decided to grant what is expected to be about $1.8 billion in aid to Fried. Krupp and Hoesch, two of Germany's largest steelmakers, to assist them in merging their steelmaking operations. The Government also agreed to the equivalent of $52.6 million in aid to Stahlwerke Rochling-Burbach, the German arm of the Luxembourg-based steelmaker Arbed.

title: Bryan's Song
description: Bryan Trottier is best known for his skill at plucking hockey pucks away from opposing players and setting up or scoring goals for the New York Islanders. But he also plucks a mean guitar, and sings along, country style.

title: Polio Kills 9 South Africans
description: A polio outbreak has taken nine lives and 133 other people have been hospitalized in this area of northeast Transvaal, the Health and Welfare Department said. The department was appealing to parents to have their children vaccinated.

title: SENATE PASSES BILL FOR NEW JOB TRAINING PLAN
description: The Senate approved a bipartisan bill today to set up a five-year, $24 billion job training plan that would replace the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, which expires Sept. 30.

title: Kentucky Is Promoting Trade in South Africa
description: Kentucky has started an active campaign to promote trade with South Africa, which many states discourage to protest that nation's practice of apartheid, the policy of strict racial segregation and discrimination.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES * Arizona Chemical Co., Fairlawn, N.J., a joint venture of the American Cyanamid Company and the International Paper Company, has elected Donald E. Stiling president and chief executive officer, succeeding J.A. Schmidlein, who was appointed vice chairman until his retirement.
description: * Bankers Trust Co. announced the appointment of James M. Barry, Diane Berman, Joseph DiGrazia Jr., Andrew Gogates Jr., John Herron, Jeremy Hyland, Nigel Key, Gifford R. Lehman, Joseph J. Perticone, Christine L. Porter, John A. Rotante and Henry S. Wolff to vice president.

title: G.M. Institute
description: The General Motors Institute here became a nonprofit corporation today after the No.1 United States auto maker severed most of its 56-year-old ties with the school in a cost-cutting move. The General Motors Corporation will provide more than $20 million in a ''substantial transitional grant'' to the school over the next three years, its vice chairman, Howard H. Kehrl, said at dedication ceremonies.

title: BRENNAN STAYS RESENTENCING IN RAPE
description: At the last minute, a Justice of the United States Supreme Court intervened today to stay the resentencing of five young men who were given suspended sentences after pleading guilty to rape last fall.

title: MISS VAUGHAN AND GILLESPIE
description: ATLANTA'S Clark College awarded Dizzy Gillespie an honorary doctorate at the jazz festival Wednesday evening. But the high seriousness of the occasion didn't prevent Mr. Gillespie from mugging, telling jokes, and playing the trumpet with his customary vigor and technical aplomb.

title: GETAWAY DAY FOR HAIG, WITH YET MORE AMBIGUITY
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. slipped out of Washington today for a long Fourth of July weekend, leaving even some of his closest aides at the State Department uncertain how much longer he would officially remain as Secretary of State.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Backward Glance

title: THE LONG TREK TO 'E.T.'
description: The weather was sunny, the humidity down, which made that tribal rite of New Yorkers, waiting on line, all the more bearable, if not outright pleasurable.

title: CSX Earnings Climb by 89.1%
description: The CSX Corporation, the diversified rail, leisure, publishing and minerals company, reported yesterday that net income rose sharply to $70 million, or $1.67 a share, for the second quarter of 1982, compared with $37 million, or 90 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: SALES GAIN
description: Volkswagenwerk, Western Europe's largest German auto maker, reported today that net income for the first half of the year fell 4 percent, to 100 million marks, or about $40.5 million, from 104 million marks, or about $42.2 million, a year earlier. Sales for the period rose 16.5 percent, to 15.5 billion marks, which is approximately $6.28 billion, from 13.3 billion marks, or about $5.39 billion, in the 1981 first half. Percentage changes are calculated from United States dollars.

title: U.S. SEIZES TV MONITORING GEAR BOUND FOR CUBAN MISSION ON U.N.
description: The Customs Service seized television monitoring equipment in an Orlando, Fla., warehouse yesterday that it said had been ordered by a diplomat at the Cuban Mission to the United Nations.

title: A NASA SPACE CAMP FOR ASTRONAUT HOPEFULS
description: A longtime dream of the rocket pioneer Wernher von Braun has become a reality with the nation's first Space Camp, intended to interest boys and girls in aerospace careers. The eight weeklong camp sessions are continuing throughout the summer.

title: SOME TEAMSTERS STRIKE, AFFECTING JOB SITES IN CITY
description: Truck drivers who deliver building materials to construction sites in New York City went on strike yesterday, threatening a tie-up that could affect major development projects in the city if it continues for any length of time.

title: U.S. ASSURES ISRAEL ON TALKS IN BEIRUT
description: An American official reportedly told Israeli leaders today that a diplomatic solution to the Lebanese situation was possible.

title: SPAIN UNIFIED: AGAINST SPAIN
description: It sounds strange for a foreigner to get into a taxi and hear the driver say: ''Espana, mala.'' The visitor protests, no, Spain is a lovely country and Catalonia is a special region, but the driver shakes his head and says: ''No, Espana, mala.''

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Adds Compton to its Name
description: The word from London yesterday was that the deal by which Saatchi & Saatchi, Britain's largest agency, would acquire Compton Communications, was signed, sealed and delivered.

title: METS EXPLOIT ERROR TO BEAT EXPOS, 2-1
description: The Mets eked out a 2-1 victory over the Expos tonight, taking the three-game series, denying Montreal an opportunity to move into first place in the National League East and making Mike Scott a winner in his first successful start in more than a month.

title: John Egli, 61, Coached Penn State Basketball
description: John Egli, head basketball coach at Penn State from 1955 to 1968, died today at Centre Community Hospital after a long illness with cancer. He was 61 years old.

title:
HOW TO EASE THE PAIN;
CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA. - The medical profession is in trouble. At cocktail parties I reluctantly admit to being a doctor because such a concession invites attacks that range from the scurrilous to the nearly defamatory. The litany of complaints includes the unavailability of doctors when you need one, medical care costs and the recurring theme that doctors have lost the art of caring.
description: The modern physician is regarded as a competent technician who is cold, aloof and mercenary. By contrast, the old-time physician is idealized as compassionate, communicative and altruistic.

title: STAGE: 'DON JUAN,' OFFBEAT MOLIERE IN CENTRAL PARK
description: looking young girl, bewigged and in period costume, dashes across the stage. Soon she is followed by a chorus of 17th-century gentlefolk - some chalkfaced, some masked, all hideous - who go into a fevered dance around a Maypole. Then there is the music - a loud, pulsating roar of electronic organ chords - and, finally, the entrance of the hero, Don Juan. As embodied by John Seitz, the famous libertine looks like the pop singer Tiny Tim at the corpulent tail-end of his career. He proceeds to embrace a woman with one hand and caress a standing crucifix with the other. The chorus, horrified by his blasphemous behavior, shrieks. And the stage lights, many of them fluorescent, blare into the audience's eyes.

title: M.T.A. Lease Plan Gains in Senate
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved a provision of the 1982 tax bill tonight that would allow the Metropolitan Transport Authority to continue to use a leasing arrangement that generates $500 million of its $7.5 billion capital improvement plan.

title: Stallings to U.S.F.L.
description: Gene Stallings, an assistant coach with the Dallas Cowboys, says he has ''essentially reached terms'' to become the first head coach of the Birmingham Stallions of the United States Football League. The 47-year-old Stallings was head coach at Texas A&M from 1965 to 1971 and an assistant to Bear Bryant at Alabama for nine years.

title: BOB WILBER, A SIDNEY BECHET HEIR, IS LEADING A TRIBUTE TO HIS MENTOR
description: BOB WILBER, one of the leading exponents of Sidney Bechet's magical method with the soprano saxophone (the most temperamental of all the saxophones), will demonstrate tomorrow afternoon at the Kool Jazz Festival why he still reveres his old mentor more than the other jazz greats who helped shape his musicianship.

title: BIG RACQUETS ARE HOT ITEMS
description: Neil Amdur on Tennis

title: Renault Stake
description: The Signal Companies said that Renault Holding S.A. had converted a $65 million subordinated debenture into a 10 percent equity interest in Signal's Mack Trucks unit.

title: THE TAX BREAKS, A YEAR LATER
description: When President Reagan presented his tax program to Congress last year, he was seeking just two things: a three-stage reduction in personal tax rates and sharp cuts in business taxes through accelerated depreciation. Both of these measures were passed, and the President signed them into law on Aug. 13. But Congress also approved a host of other tax breaks, for everything from income earned abroad to retirement savings to research and development.

title: Fighting His Age
description: Saoul Mamby had been the oldest boxing champion in the world before losing his World Boxing Council junior welterweight title last weekend to Leroy Haley. Thus, he is asking the W.B.C. to waive its own rules against immediate rematches - ''to do me a favor'' - and let him fight Haley again.

title: Lena Horne Encore
description: An extra performance of Lena Horne's one-woman show, ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music,'' has been added by the Tanglewood music festival in Lenox, Mass., on Monday night at 8:30. There will be a 2:30 P.M. concert by student musicians, to which a ticket for the evening performance is also valid. Tickets are $13.50 to $45 for a shed seat, $6 for a lawn seat, and they can be charged through Ticketron, 977-9020.

title: Olivetti Merger
description: The Docutel Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to merge with Ing. C. Olivetti & Company of Italy and would buy the Olivetti Corporation, the Italian company's American subsidiary, for 2.2 million Docutel shares, plus warrants to buy 500,000 additional shares at $32 each between Jan. 1 and June 30, 1984. After completion of the deal, Olivetti will own about 47 percent of Docutel.

title: Thai Hijacking Over; Family Is Reunited
description: A Sri Lanka hijacker freed the last of 261 hostages aboard an Alitalia Boeing 747 today after being reunited with his estranged wife and son. On Wednesday, 138 hostages were freed.

title: Equitable Sees Bid
description: Equitable Life Mortgage and Realty Investors said that it expected a takeover offer from its investment adviser, the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, of at least $8.50 a share. A separate agreement was also announced between Equitable Investors and certain borrowers, under which the interest rate on a $30 million loan would be more than halved, to 8 percent, and deferred until about 1989. The Equitable trust said that because of these developments, it would omit its third-quarter dividend.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 2, 1982; The Economy
description: A bill to raise consumer taxes on cigarettes and telephone service and restrict deductions for medical expenses and casualty losses made headway in the Senate Finance Committee. The $21 billion revenueraising bill is supported by the Reagan Administration. The Administration has withdrawn its proposal for a stronger corporate minimum tax and supports a plan for a curtailment of some corporate deductions, a Treasury official acknowledged. (A1.)

title: McEnroe Dead End
description: The temper of John McEnroe has cost him the distinction of having a street in Little Rock, Ark., named after him.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 8 P.M. Craig Swan, who was hit hard by the Phillies last Sunday in the final game of the Mets' lost weekend in Philadelphia, is scheduled to get another chance at them. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland. Roger Erickson, 4-7 over all, is still looking for his first victory as a Yankee since being acquired from Minnesota. He is 0-4 in five starts. Rick Waits of the Indians is still looking for his first victory of the season. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770 and WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Soccer World Cup, Spain vs. West Germany and Brazil vs. Argentina. Argentina, the defending champion, will be eliminated if it ties or loses. Brazil is this year's co-favorite. (Television - ESPN, 11 A.M., live, and 8 P.M., tape; Channels 21 and 50, 6 P.M., tape; Channel 41, 11 A.M. and 2:45 P.M., live; 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., tape; Channel 47, 11:30 P.M., Brazil-Argentina, tape) Tennis All-England championships, at Wimbledon, England. Billie Jean King makes her 13th Wimbledon appearance in the women's semifinals against No.2-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd. (Television - Channel 4; 2 P.M., 11:30 P.M. and 12:45 A.M., all tape).

title: Mexico Limits Oil Sale Credits
description: Petroleos Mexicanos, the state oil company, confirmed today that it had tightened credit terms for buyers, effectively raising oil prices about 40 cents a barrel, starting today.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 2, 1982
description: International Britain criticized the United States for trying to block contracts signed by foreign companies to supply parts for a pipeline to carry natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe. The rebuke was expressed in the House of Commons by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the Reagan Administration's staunchest backer in Europe. (Page A1, Columns 3-5.) Negotiations in Beirut were snagged in a maze of details and disagreements over how and when the Palestinian guerrillas should leave Lebanon. The slow pace of the talks intensified fears that Israeli forces might resume bombardments or perhaps assault western Beirut. (A6:5-6.)

title: Return to Vengeance
description: New Jersey needs the death penalty, a state senator thunders, to ''bury the perpetrators and remember aloud the innocent victim and the family that victim left behind.''

title: Clippers to Stay In San Diego
description: The San Diego Clippers announced today that ''regardless of the outcome of litigation,'' the team plans to remain in San Diego.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * British Columbia Hydro floated a $150 million (United States) 15.25 percent, 10-year Eurobond at 99.5 to yield 15.35 percent, through an underwriting group led by Deutsche Bank.

title: Barbara Dohrenwend, Epidemiologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Barbara Snell Dohrenwend, a social psychologist and epidemiologist who pioneered in studying the relationship between stressful life events and the development of mental illness, died of cancer Monday at the Harkness Pavilion of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: P STREET INTERSECTS WITH MANY WORLDS
description: On a tour map of Washington, you don't see Nora Howard's house. Mrs. Howard, a welfare mother of three, lives on the eastern end of P Street, where rats prowl the alleys and junkies shoot up in abandoned buildings.

title: WASHINGTON - In his June 9 speech in Bonn, President Reagan outlined a new Western proposal for the NATO-Warsaw Pact talks in Vienna on Mutual and Balanced Force Reductions in Central Europe. Western negotiators will presumably soon present this proposal in Vienna. President Reagan's political push may move these M.B.F.R. talks, underway since 1973, toward a first agreement.
description: Such an agreement could be the only East-West arms control accord attainable in President Reagan's present term of office. From today's perspective, it seems improbable that either the talks on reducing intermediate-range nuclear arms or the talks that began this week on reducing strategic arms, both of them taking place in Geneva, will bring final results within the next two to three years. But if political momentum is maintained, the Vienna force-reduction talks can bring a concrete outcome within that period.

title: Farewell To Stalemate
description: One week ago, as the Israelis were trying all sorts of psychological warfare to scare the P.L.O. out of the capital of Lebanon, a White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, was announcing that ''assurances were given'' by Prime Minister Begin to President Reagan that the Israelis would not enter Beirut. Press reports escalated this to a solemn ''pledge'' and commentators have since been excoriating Israel for seeming to threaten to break its word.

title: Old-style, trendy or Scandinavian.
description: LADY ASTOR'S on Lafayette Street, just across from the Public Theater, comes as something of a surprise because its seamy, drab exterior hides an amusing and lavish reproduction of a gaslight-era sporting house. Heavy velvet hangings, crystal chandeliers and huge gilt mirrors make this a restful and engaging setting that somehow suggests a little girl dressed up in grandiose old clothes that she found in the family attic. Service is friendly, but at times the young and good-natured help is careless about bringing utensils. The kitchen can be slow, but an effort is made to speed things up when guests say they are going to the theater. Allow about an hour and half if you plan to have a full three-course meal.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph on Wednesday accom- panying a dispatch from Manila on shantytown squatters was actually taken in 1972 . There is no information to suggest that it portrays the current situation.

title: Speedier Test Is Found For Sickle-Cell Disease
description: Scientists have announced successful results of a new test to determine before birth if a baby will suffer from sickle-cell disease, an incurable and often disabling condition that affects one in every 500 blacks in America.

title: THREE STATE GUIDE TO A YANKEE DOODLE DANDY WEEKEND
description: IT took the 1976 Bicentennial to establish a new New York tradition, a celebration that every Fourth of July envelops Manhattan's southern tip and ripples to the far corners of the metropolitan area with parades on land and water, with entertainment, competitions and other events that visitors can discover almost serendipitously during the day, from the first 50-gun salute at

title:
THE EFFECT OF THE P.L.O. ON ITS LEBANESE HOSTS;
It will take a convoy of trucks several weeks to remove the weapons and ammunition Israel has captured from the Palestinian terrorists in Lebanon. But even now we know enough to confirm what many have long suspected: that within the past decade, the military arm of the Palestine Liberation Organization has been transformed into a quasi-army, organized in battalion and brigade formations, supported by Soviet-supplied guns, rocket launchers, mortars and tanks, and providing, in the meantime, an umbrella for like-minded terrorist organizations from Europe, Asia and the Arab world.
description: Much of what has been said about the invasion has dealt with Israel's motives, the death of Lebanese civilians and prospects for a more lasting peace. But it is worth reflecting on the nature of the enemy Israel confronts.

title: The U.N. Today; July 2, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Subcomminttee on Petitions - 10:30 A.M.

title: YOUNGER PLAYERS STEP OUT
description: BRUCE LUNDVALL, the president of Elektra's new Musician label, and Nesuhi Ertegun, who has been producing jazz albums for several decades, chose 14 young musicians to represent the ''next generation'' of jazz talent for a jazz festival program called ''The Young Lions'' that took place in Carnegie Hall Wednesday. At least two of their ''young lions'' have been playing jazz professionally for 20 years or more, but the music they made on Wednesday was strong enough to compensate for any minor misrepresentations regarding their age.

title: ASTRONAUTS ABLE TO OPEN CARGO DOOR
description: The space shuttle Columbia's cargo bay doors worked perfectly in a second test of closing and opening today, reassuring the two astronauts that the structural warping seen Wednesday was a passing phenomenon caused by thermal conditions.

title: Norcen Signs Consent Decree
description: Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. and its chairman, Conrad M. Black, today signed two consent decrees with the Securities and Exchange Commission barring them from fraudulent conduct and making false statements in the company's attempt to acquire the Hanna Mining Company.

title: Chem-Nuclear Sues To Stop Merger Bid
description: Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc. filed suit in a Washington State Federal Court yesterday to block a $63 million takeover attempt by Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest solid waste disposal company, charging that Waste Management had failed to tell shareholders that a merger might violate antitrust laws.

title: PUBLISHING: LONG SHOT WINNER
description: WHEN ''People of the Sacred Mountain'' won the recent American Book Award for history, few in the audience at the awards ceremony in Carnegie Hall seemed to have heard of it. Nevertheless, the listeners seemed much taken with the acceptance speech of its author, the Rev. Peter John Powell, an Episcopal priest who is director of St. Augustine's Indian Center in Chicago.

title: An 'Airborne' Car In Fatal Collision
description: A 34-year-old man was killed in a head-on collision yesterday with a car that became ''airborne'' on Harlem River Drive, the police said.

title: DRUG AGENCY SEES PERIL IN STARCH-BLOCKER DIET AIDS
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that starch blockers, purported diet aids that have swept the country in recent months, are unapproved and possibly dangerous drugs that must be removed from the market.

title: Dr. William Hapworth Weds Mada Steinberg
description: Mada Steinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Steinberg of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. William Emery Hapworth, son of Emery Herbert Hapworth of West Caldwell, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Catherine Hughes Hapworth. The ceremony was performed in St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. George W. Moore and Rabbi Joseph Gelberman.

title: COURT EASES RULES FOR EVIDENCE ON VOTE BIAS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that circumstantial evidence can be sufficient to prove that an electoral system was created or maintained for the purpose of discriminating against black voters.

title: Friday; FANTASY AT THE REGENCY
description: If you can't get away from the city over the holiday weekend, you can get away from reality at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street, where a ''Fantastic Film'' series is under way through July 27. The double bill through tomorrow is ''The Wizard of Oz'' (1939) with Judy Garland and ''The Yellow Submarine'' (1968) with the Beatles. On Sunday and Monday it's the original ''King Kong'' (1933) and ''The Thief of Baghdad'' (1940) with Sabu and Conrad Veidt. Admission is $4.50 ($2 for under-12's accompanied by an adult). Information: 724-3700.

title: West Europeans Charge Turks With Torture
description: Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France and the Netherlands lodged a complaint against Turkey with the European Commission for Human Rights today for what they called political repression and the torture of prisoners, Foreign Minister Kjeld Olesen of Denmark said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said its acquisition of Geosource Inc. had been approved by Geosource stockholders.

title: HEALTH PROFESSIONALS CANNOT BE IMMUNE FROM F.T.C. RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT SAYS SCHOOL CANNOT BAR MEN
description: The Supreme Court, in a ruling of limited practical impact but considerable constitutional importance, held today that a state-operated nursing school cannot constitutionally exclude men.

title: No New SS-20 Missiles West of Urals, Tass Says
description: The Soviet Union denied a charge today by a United States official that new SS-20 @intermediate-range missiles had been deployed west of the Ural Mountains since the freeze announced in March.

title: Judge Clears Gun Unit Of Liability in Slaying
description: A Federal judge threw out a $2 million jury verdict today against the National Rifle Association, which had been held liable for a murder committed with a gun stolen from its Washington office.

title: ART: GUGGENHEIM TRACKS DOWN NEW YORK SCHOOL
description: FOREIGN visitors to this city are often convinced even before they arrive of the power, the historical importance and the lasting beauty of the work produced by the New York School since 1945 or thereabouts. They've heard about it. They've read about it. They know how it looks in reproduction. It just has to be good, they think.

title: TENNIS, 3 WOMEN MINERS
description: THIS is the weekend of the Wimbledon finals, and tennis fans can feast on hours of live coverage on NBC. The women's finals will be broadcast tomorrow, beginning at 9 in the morning, and the men's finals can be seen Sunday, also starting at 9 A.M. Top names such as Bjorn Borg, Ivan Lendl and Guillermo Villas are not participating, but that just may make things look better for the American contingent headed by John McEnroe, the defending champion.

title: 4,000 FOLLOWERS OF MOON WED AT THE GARDEN
description: Four thousand followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, most of them selected for each other by him, were married amid flags and balloons yesterday in a mass ceremony at Madison Square Garden.

title: Student Enters Plea In Draft Registry Case
description: A college student who said he wanted to be neither an antidraft martyr nor a leader was arraigned before a Federal magistrate today for failure to register for the draft. He is the first American to be so charged since the Vietnam War.

title: Advertising; Red Man Tobacco Tries TV
description: "This is going to be a classic,'' said Charles N. Blakemore, executive vice president-creative services worldwide of Benton & Bowles, as the tube of the TV set in his office went dark.

title: 'Steaming,' a hit from London, due in December.
description: BROADWAY is going to look a lot like London's West End next season. Two current London hits have already been announced for fall openings in New York: ''Cats,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical based on T.S. Eliot's ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats'' and ''Good,'' the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of C.P. Taylor's dark moral parable about a liberal German intellectual who sells his soul to Hitler. Now comes word of a third British import, Nell Dunn's long-running ''Steaming.'' It is scheduled to begin a tryout at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., on Nov. 5 and to open on Broadway at a Nederlander theater on Dec. 9.

title: LESTER REMEMBERED
description: THE music and the person of Lester Young were recalled with great affection and admiration that verged on idolatry in a jazz festival concert called ''Salute to Pres'' in Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening.

title:
Economic Scene;
Reagan's Tax Program
description: GEORGE P. SHULTZ, the nominee for Secretary of State, will become a major force in the Administration, pushing for economic growth while resisting austerity measures. The State Department has often played a major role in economic affairs.

title: J-51 HELPS TENANTS AND NEIGHBORHOODS
description: To the Editor:

title: CORONA'S BROTHER IS TIED TO VIOLENCE
description: A defense witness said today that he saw Juan V. Corona's half-brother place a body in a panel truck after a scuffle involving a knife.

title: Company Earnings; HI-G LOSS $1.07 MILLION; LOAN EXTENSION GIVEN
description: Hi-G Inc., a diversified manufacturer of electronic components and systems, reported yesterday that it had a loss in its fourth fiscal quarter of 1982, ended April 3, of $1.07 million, contrasted to net earnings of $97,000, or 9 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: ARMS INSURANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CUTS IN EDUCATION FUNDS CRITICIZED BY TEACHERS' GROUP
description: Criticism of Reagan Administration policies, especially the Federal cutbacks in funds for education, were the focus of speeches yesterday during the opening session in New York of the annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers.

title: JOBS SCARCE IN MICHIGAN DESPITE SEASONAL GAINS
description: In a normal year, by now John Klink would have his full complement of seven or eight men in his excavating and paving business. The construction season of 1982 is normal only in that business is about the same as last year and the year before: bad.

title: Reduce Patients, Care Facility Told
description: The State Health Services Commissioner ordered today that the Bristol Convalescent Home reduce its number of patients because of findings by state inspectors that patient care is inadequate.

title: INDIAN POINT COULD BE EVACUATED IN A NUCLEAR MISHAP
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH REPORTERS TELL NEW SIDE OF FALKLAND STORY
description: British journalists returning from the Falkland Islands, no longer constrained by censorship, have been writing critical accounts of apparently inadequate British intelligence and military bungling there.

title: Consumer Saturday; IN KNITTING, HELP FROM COMPUTER
description: EVEN fairly good knitters who have followed instructions faithfully a re sometimes dismayed with the finished sweater. The waist is too l ow, the sleeves too short. The pattern for the sweater looked like t he right size, but it did not take into account the variations of b ody shapes, and the knitter didn't make the right adjustments.

title: Universal Sues Sony
description: Universal City Studios Inc., a subsidiary of MCA Inc., has filed a second suit against the Sony Corporation of America, its advertising agents and four retailers, charging contributory copyright infringement in the manufacture and sale of television video recorders. The suit is virtually identical to one filed by Universal in 1976, which the United States Supreme Court has agreed to decide, a spokesman said, adding that the second suit was filed to cover contributory copyright infringement by the defendants since 1976.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TEXTS OF OPINIONS BY JUSTICES
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's unanimous decision upholding a New York law that bars the sale and production of sexually explicit films, photographs or performances using children. The opinion by Associate Justice Byron R. White was joined by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Associate Justices Lewis F. Powell, William H. Rehnquist and Sandra Day O'Connor. Justices O'Connor, William J. Brennan and John Paul Stevens filed separate concurring opinions, with Justice Thurgood Marshall joining the Brennan opinion. By Justice White

title: WNET'S BUSINESSLIKE APPROACH TO OPERATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo Stocks In Sharp Drop
description: The Tokyo stock market plunged today, influenced by growing fears that Japan's computer industry could be damaged by the industrial spying scandal in the United States involving two major Japanese companies.

title: Your Money; Short-Term Health Policies
description: One person just graduated from college and has not yet found employment. Another recently left his job and is searching for a new one. A third is walking the picket lines because of a strike called by her union against her employer. And a fourth is still in the probationary period established by his company for new employees.

title: SEARCHERS AGAIN COMB THE ROCKIES, THIS TIME FOR MISSING 12-YEAR-OLD BOY
description: The hiking trail climbs steeply from Bear Lake, beneath the jagged peaks of the Continental Divide. Much of it is still covered with three-@ and four-foot drifts of heavy wet snow, and above the tree line, at 11,500 feet, the trail cuts across a rocky plateau, paralleling sheer cliffs and dizzying gorges on its way to the summit of Flattop Mountain.

title: Dow Off 6.28, to 796.99; Technology Issues Drop
description: Technology issues ran into renewed selling pressure yesterday as the general market continued to weaken. However, several energy stocks moved higher on takeover rumors.

title: DRUNK AS A DOG
description: Hardly an animal exists that is averse to booze. It was recently disclosed that during the darkest days of World War II, one of Winston Churchill's closest companions was Toby, a cobaltblue budgerigar that was fond of perching on his head and would take occasional sips from a glass of port on the dressing table. The man who supplied Churchill with his bird, a Mr. M. Fogg Elliot, who lives in Fordham, an Essex village, does not disclose whether Toby ever became paralytically soused. No matter. The fact remains that the bird can now be added to the roster of boozy denizens of the animal world whose exploits tend unhappily to be overshadowed by those of W. C. Fields and their other humanoid opposite numbers.

title: Scouting; Arguello Awaited
description: Aaron Pryor has been trying not to think of Alexis Arguello and a $1.6 million purse for defending his World Boxing Association junior welterweight title against the World Boxing Council lightweight champion some time in the fall. Pryor has been trying to concentrate on Akio Kameda of Japan, his almost unknown challenger tomorrow in Cincinnati.

title: UNIONS TURNING TO JOB ACTIONS TO PRESSURE CITY
description: Angered by the latest contract offer from New York City, the uniformed forces responded yesterday with what one high city official called a variety of ''harassment techniques.'' They ranged from a ''sick-out'' and a work-to-rule action in the Fire Department to a continuing job slowdown in the Police Department.

title: SENATE IN ALBANY PASSES BILL ON CO-OP CONVERSIONS
description: The State Senate passed a bill tonight to strengthen the protection of tenants facing co-op and condominium conversions in New York City.

title: REHEARSAL IN SPACESUIT GOES WELL FOR ASTRONAUT
description: The commander of the space shuttle Columbia entered an airlock, donned his full pressure suit and rehearsed other procedures today for going outside the spaceship, an activity that is to be practiced in reality on the next shuttle flight.

title: 3 JEWS AND A PALESTINIAN URGE MUTUAL ISRAELI-P.L.O. RECOGNITION
description: Two separate but related appeals for mutual recognition by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization were made today by three prominent Jews and the most conspicuous moderate in the P.L.O. leadership.

title: Jane Fonda Criticizes P.L.O.
description: Jane Fonda and her husband, Tom Hayden, arrived today for a weeklong visit here and said that the Palestine Liberation Organization's terrorist acts and refusal to recognize Israel had made the invasion of Lebanon inevitable. The visit was arranged by the Israeli Association for the Welfare of Soldiers, which has invited several American entertainers to Israel to improve morale.

title: De Gustibus; AT FANCY FOOD SHOW, NOVELTIES DISPLACE TASTE
description: They called it the New York Fancy Food Show, but a good 75 percent of what was passed off as fancy last week at the Coliseum could just as easily be labeled junk. Novelty candies, tricolor clown-faced lollipops, gummy bears and cutesy, beribboned gift sets in which the package is the product took up a large portion of the exhibition's space, as might be expected considering the volume of such merchandise that is sold in the Christ DE GUSTIBUS mas season. Far more discouraging was the perversion of decent food products into tricked-up novelties, pates and cheese being foremost in this compromised category.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Gives U.S. 90 Days To Alter Haitian Policy
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Government could detain newly arriving illegal aliens in the next 90 days because there was a ''meaningful concern'' that thousands of Haitians might flood into Florida if there was no deterrent.

title: KEY SENATE COMMITTEE APROVES M.T.A. SUBWAY CAR LEASING PLAN
description: The Federal tax-leasing arrangement for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's program to buy new subway cars was extended by the Senate Finance Committee yesterday as a provision in the proposed 1982 tax bill.

title: I.T.T. UNIT INVOLVED IN IRAN EMBARGO INQUIRY
description: The Treasury Department said yesterday that it had begun an investigation into charges that the Blackburn division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation circumvented the 1980 embargo against trade with Iran by shipping electrical equipment to that country during the hostage crisis.

title: ISRAEL SAYS FORCES MAY REOPEN FIGHT
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, speaking at a news conference in east Beirut, said today that Israel would rather see the Palestinian guerrilla organizations leave Beirut as part of a negotiated solution. But he made clear the fact that a military option was still very much alive in Israel's planning.

title: Shift at Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company announced that Marvin A. Pomerantz, 51, had resigned as corporate executive vice president and president of Harvester's construction and agricultural equipment group.

title: DEMOCRATS URGE INQUIRY ON SEX RUMORS LINKING MEMBERS AND PAGES
description: House Democratic leaders today pressed for a swift and comprehensive investigation of accusations of sexual misconduct involving congressional pages and members of Congress.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.2 BILLION
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply dropped $2.2 billion in the week ended June 23, placing it within the Federal Reserve System's annual target range for the first time this year, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve.

title: STRONG DOLLAR, WEAK INDUSTRY
description: American industry, it would appear, is paying the price of the strong dollar. For American tourists, the dollar's sharp rise against other currencies has been an boon. They can now buy at least 50 percent more French francs and Italian lire and 35 percent more West German marks than they could only two years ago.

title: News Analysis
description: After the Supreme Court's ruling yesterday upholding New York's child pornography statute, the defense attorney, Herald Price Fahringer, predicted grim times ahead for the First Amendment.

title: A FIRE DISPLAY IS ALL PLANNING, NO REHEARSAL
description: It was show biz yesterday on the Brooklyn docks. Crumbling pilings, damp T-shirts, cardboard boxes, dirty water, tote that barge, lift that bale - those were just the underpinnings of a musical extravaganza. Jean McFaddin and Bruce Bassman, who once worked together in an avant-garde theater company called the James Joyce Memorial Liquid Theater - no script, no direction - could see the whole thing taking shape before them, in the beige cardboard canisters aligned in odd geometric configurations on the flat metal decks of the big green boats.

title: GULF AND CITIES SERVICE GET F.T.C. BID FOR DATA
description: The Federal Trade Commission asked the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Cities Service Company today for more information on their proposed $5 billion merger so it could better evaluate whether the deal might violate antitrust laws.

title: HONDURAN SOLDIERS ARRESTED IN THE BEATING OF A U.S. NURSE
description: The Honduran Army has arrested a group of soldiers in connection with the reported detention and abuse of an American nurse and the disappearance of a Guatemalan doctor.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Hoax

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Feelings and Ideas By JOHN LEONARD CONJUNCTIONS AND DISJUNCTIONS. By Octavio Paz. Translated from the Spanish by Helen R. Lane. 148 pages. Seaver Books/Grove. Paperback, $7.95.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. The President's normally slicked-back hair style has given way occasionally to a wavy forehead droop. 2. William Arthur Philip Louis, the son of the Prince and Princess of Wales, and heir to the throne after his father, will be known as Prince William of Wales.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse of children constitutes a government objective of surpassing importance." - Justice Byron R. White, on pornography ruling. (1:6.)

title: HUDSON ON THE POTOMAC: NEIGHBORHOODS OR A NEW YORKER
description: When New Yorkers come to Washington, whether for sojourn or residence, they often look for signs of reassurance. They search out such places as the Chesapeake Bagel Bakery on Capitol Hill or Sutton Place Gourmet near Georgetown, the District's answer to Zabar's on Broadway. They are disappointed when they learn they have to drive to Silver Spring, Md., to find respectable corned beef.

title: Satellite Launching Delayed
description: The scheduled July 9 launching of the Landsat D earth resources satellite was postponed for at least a week today by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Walt Dundon, a spokesman, said that the launching would be delayed until no earlier than July 16 because two special Air Force tracking planes needed to back up the ground tracking stations would not be available.

title: Scouting; World Cup Guest
description: Like any other European-born sports fan, Henry Kissinger wanted to see some of the World Cup soccer games in Spain. So he accepted the invitation of his friend Ahmet Ertegun, the president of the Cosmos and board chairman of Atlantic Records, to join him there to watch the second-round games.

title: Argentina, Spain Ousted in Cup Play
description: A swarm of yellow shirts from Brazil, as persistent as hornets, eliminated Argentina, the defending champion, from the World Cup soccer tournament this evening.

title: PRESIDENT QUITS NEW YORK AIR
description: Neal F. Meehan, who has been president and chief operating officer of New York Air since its earliest days, has resigned, the regional airline announced yesterday. He will be succeeded by Michael E. Levine, who has been chairman since February.

title: Fairchild Wins Jet Contract
description: The Air Force today picked the Fairchild-Republic Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., as the winner in a hotly contested competition to build up to 650 jet aircraft for training new pilots.

title: Strike at Bus Line In Queens Ends
description: Drivers, mechanics and inspectors who went on strike against Green Bus Lines Inc. Thursday voted 407 to 22 yesterday to accept a new contract and return to work.

title: The Walls Still Stand
description: The murder 11 days ago of William Turks - whose only offense was that he was black - by a lynch mob of white men wielding bludgeons in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn reveals many things we find uneasy to contemplate.

title: Sports People; A Perfect Bowler
description: Glenn Allison of La Habra, Calif., knocked down every pin 36 consecutive times to roll a 900 - three perfect games - in league competition Thursday night.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS WINS DEBT DEFERRAL
description: World Airways Inc., which had been a pioneer in offering discount fares, said yesterday that its creditors had agreed to defer about $14 million of debt and lease payments coming due between now and next June, thus staving off a shutdown.

title: TO MARIN COUNTY, NO HOUSEBOATER IS AN ISLAND
description: ''Forbes's Island'' won't show up on maps of the bays around San Francisco, but its recent fame would make that redundant.

title: Around the World; 4,000 Black Miners Striking in South Africa
description: Rioting black miners burned down an administration building tonight, and 4,000 remained on strike in the worst unrest at South Africa's gold mines in nearly a year, mine officials said.

title: BALLET WINNERS: U.S., CHINA
description: Chinese and American dancers were the chief winners in the second International Ballet Competition at Jackson, Miss., which will draw to a close tonight. Janie Parker, an American member of the Houston Ballet, won the gold, or top, medal for women in the senior category, in which dancers from 20 to 28 years of age compete. The winner of the gold medal for the women's junior category, for dancers from 14 to 19, was Gina Gail Hyatt of the Federal Republic of Germany. No gold medals were awarded to male competitors this year.

title: Muncie Interview Details Drug Abuse
