description: Chuck Muncie, the San Diego running back, says he has cut down on his use of cocaine since his trade to the Chargers but that he still has a problem with alcohol and marijuana and would enter a rehabilitation center within a week for treatment.

title: Senate Approves Olympic Coin Plan
description: The Senate has approved and sent to the White House legislation establishing a commemorative coin program to help support the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: DEVICES TO DETER GROWING PERIL OF CAR THEFT
description: In April 1979 members of the Auto Crime Division of the New York City Police Department raided a warehouse in Brooklyn where they found, stacked in neat piles, the skeletal remains of 39 stolen cars, each stripped of doors, hoods, fenders, tires, radios and almost everything else of value. Fourteen of the cars, the police found, had been equipped with expensive antitheft devices.

title: SATURDAY, JULY 3, 1982; The Economy
description: Unemployment remained at 9.5 percent in June, the highest level in 40 years. But the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported another decline in factory jobs last month and a continuing increase in unemployment among adult men, to 8.7 percent. (Page 1.)

title: RATE FOR ADULT MEN INCREASES
description: The nation's unemployment rate remained unchanged in June, holding at 9.5 percent of the labor force, the highest level in 40 years.

title: Index; International
description: British journalists are critical of operations in Falklands 2 Argentina releases new casualty figures for Falkland fighting 2 300 Poles in Spain for World Cup soccer are said to defect 3 British Social Democrats elect Roy Jenkins first party chief 3 Honduran army arrests soldiers in beating of U.S. nurse 3 France and Egypt circulate a plan to save P.L.O. at U.N. 4 Around the World 5 Three Jews and a Palestinian seek Israeli-P.L.O. recognition 5 Washington Talk Briefing 5 Skills, not bias, seen as key for jobs 5 General Around the Nation 6 Talks on selling Boston Herald American are confirmed 9 Coverage of wars takes toll of broadcast news operations 44 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Independence Day will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Sunday rules; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules; subways and buses on Sunday schedules. Libraries - Closed.

title: Around the World; Spiritual Leader Slain In Central Iranian City
description: The spiritual leader of the central Iranian city of Yezd was killed in a grenade attack at a prayer meeting there today, the Teheran radio said.

title: U.S. SEEKS A BREAKTHROUGH WITH PEKING OVER TAIWAN
description: After months of secret talks with China on future American policy toward Taiwan, the State Department has submitted an option paper to President Reagan in the hope of achieving an early breakthrough on a new joint statement about United States-Chinese relations, a White House official said today.

title: TAX BILL ADOPTED BY SENATE PANEL REFLECTS A DESIRE FOR BASIC CHANGE
description: The $21 billion tax bill approved by the Senate Finance Committee today reflects a growing desire expressed by members of Congress to crack down on tax evasion and move toward a simpler income tax with markedly lower tax rates from top to bottom.

title: Around the Nation; 16 Runaway Buffaloes In Virginia Are Shot
description: Thirty-one buffaloes that escaped from a farm thwarted attempts by the police to round them up, but about half the animals were shot to death by their owner, the police said today.

title: THE SWISS DEBATE EFFICIENCY OF JOINING THE U.N.
description: The Swiss Government no long ago a go announced its decision to propose formally that Switzerland join t he United Nations. This important and, in my opinion, welcome step i s not the last on Switzerland's road to Manhattan because there willh ave to be, by virtue of the Constitution, a referendum on the m atter after both Houses of the Federal Assembly have endorsed the G overnment's proposal. The referendum could take place in 1984. A m ajority of the popular votes both at the overall, national level andi n a majority of the 26 cantons will be required for approval.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of jazz festival events in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect time for a concert tomorrow at the South Street Seaport with Daniel Ponce and New York Now-Afro-Cuban Percussion Ensemble, Shannon Jackson and the Decoding Society and the Archie Shepp Quintet. It is 5:30 P.M. to 9:30. There is no 9:30 show.

title: MORE CLASSICS BY STAVROPOULOS
description: The chiffon floated as usual, but it wasn't the whole show at the George Stavropoulos presentation of his fall and winter fashions. There were, for example, satin and taffeta and a plentiful supply of lace. But the specialty of the house, chiffon, was available in abundance, in short dresses and in the traditional long ones, embellished with metallic threads or bead embroidery, or simple and pristine in white.

title: FRENCH AND SOVIET ASTRONAUTS END 9-DAY MISSION
description: A French Air Force colonel and two Soviet astronauts returned safely to earth today after a nine-day orbital mission that made the French officer, Jean-Loup Chretien, the first Western European to fly in space.

title:
Sports of the Times;
THE LEAN YEARS
description: T here were better days, afternoons when Sam Cardile's thoroughbreds visited some classy winner's circles. The faded green walls of the office adjoining Cardile's corner of Barn 46 at Belmont Park are covered with the yellowing evidence: photographs of Cardile and Viscount after the 1958 Baruch Handicap at Saratoga, Cardile and Clem's Little Fairy after the 1969 Regret Handicap at Monmouth, Cardile and Secret Lanvin after the 1976 Ruthless Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: Xerox Reduces Rochester Staff
description: The Xerox Corporation said that it had cut its copier division's product development and engineering staff by 500 at its Rochester headquarters to ''counter declining profit margins by reorganizing management, cutting the payroll and streamlining manufacturing with automation.''

title: France Is Said to Hold A-Test in the Pacific
description: France detonated a 20-kiloton underground nuclear device at its South Pacific testing site at Muroroa Atoll, New Zealand's Department of Scientific and Industrial Research said today.

title: Around the Nation; 12 Illinois Women Jailed For Equal Rights Protest
description: Twelve women who chained themselves together in the Illinois Capitol in support of the proposal for a Federal equal rights amendment were sentenced to jail today for contempt.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Trials of a Juror
description: The defense attorney, a grandmotherly woman of earnest sincerity, began by extolling the glories of the jury system. The sentiments were unexceptional; what made the prospective jurors snicker during her talk was that the noble ideas were being expressed in a courtroom so small, dingy and ill-furnished.

title: MADISON SQUARE GARDEN GIVEN STATE TAX BREAKS
description: The State Legislature passed a wide range of measures Friday night, including tax breaks for Madison Square Garden, a bill designed to save New York City $500 million in potential property tax losses and a new reapportionment plan.

title:
PATENTS;
How to Paint a Ceiling Without Dropcloths
description: Frank C. Martucci of Fort Lee, N.J., has found a way a man can paint the ceiling without spilling paint on himself or the furniture. He was granted patent 4,337,002 this week for a dripless paint roller with a guard.

title: Aid Groups Appeal to Israel For Right to Enter Lebanon
description: American aid organizations, seeking to rush relief supplies to Lebanon, appealed to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel yesterday to allow medical and relief workers to enter Israel and cross the border into Lebanon.

title: Tuition Subsidies Are Not Benign
description: President Reagan is perplexed at the opposition to his proposed tax subsidy of up to $500 for private and parochial school tuition. ''People ... say in some way this would hurt the public school system - how? We're not taking anything away from the public school system. What would hurt the public school system is if all of the independent schools closed and those thousands and thousands of youngsters were dumped on the public school. ...''

title: THE ATHENS OFFICES OF 3 U.S. CONCERNS ARE TARGETS OF BLASTS
description: Bombs exploded early today outside the offices of three American companies and an Israeli concern, and unidentified callers told newspapers that the attacks were in protest against the Israeli invasion of Lebanon and what they described as American support for it.

title: WILLIAM M. ZIEGLER JR.
description: William M. Ziegler Jr., an advertising and public relations executive, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: CONTROLLERS' UNION, $40 MILLION IN DEBT, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, $40 million in debt after its illegal strike against the Government last year, today filed for bankruptcy to liquidate its assets.

title: Sports People; Hagler Bout Set
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the world middleweight champion, will next defend his title Oct. 2 against Fulgencio Obelmejias of Caracas, Venezuela, the World Boxing Association's leading contender.

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINION BY JUSTICE STEVENS IN THE N.A.A.C.P. BOYCOTT CASE
description: Following are excerpts from the decision of Associate Justice John Paul Stevens in the case of N.A.A.C.P. vs. Claiborne Hardware Company, in which the Supreme Court ruled, 8 to 0, that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People cannot be held liable for economic losses suffered by white merchants in a boycott in Claiborne County, Miss.

title: LEWIS EDGES SMITH IN SOVIET-MEET 100
description: Carl Lewis got revenge tonight against Calvin Smith and was happy about it. Smith was happy, too, even in defeat, and he got revenge of his own.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; DEATH PENALTY IS BARRED FOR SOME ACCOMPLICES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that the Constitution prohibits the imposition of the death penalty on a person who, despite being an accomplice to a crime resulting in murder, ''did not kill or intend to kill.''

title: News Analysis
description: The French Government's turnabout from economic expansion to at least temporary austerity has given the Communist Party, badly eroded by its uncomfortable junior partnership with the Socialists, some new political opportunities.

title: BOOK ON SCANDAL FLUSTERS HOLLYWOOD
description: ''Indecent Exposure,'' David McClintick's meticulously detailed account of the David Begelman embezzlement scandal, will not be published until September. However, dog-eared photocopied galleys have been circulating in Hollywood for the last three weeks, and the film community is awaiting the book's publication with a heavy feeling of dread.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph accompanying an article on Florida banking in Business Day last Saturday carried an erroneous caption. It showed Robert Marlin, a developer who is part of a group investing in the Southeast Banking Corporation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Footnote on Matrimony

title: ALUMINUM'S NOT TO BLAME FOR WARSHIP LOSS
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SaturdaySports
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Randy Jones beat the Phillies on opening days in Philadelphia and at Shea. He will get his seventh chance to win his 100th game. In his last six starts, he's 0-5. (Television - Channel 9; Radio -WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland. (Television -Channel 11; Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) White Sox vs. Seattle Mariners, at Chicago. (Television - Channel 4, 3:30 P.M.) Boxing Bobby Czyz vs. Manuel Melon, 10 rounds, middleweights. Pinklon Thomas, Philadelphia, vs. Jerry Williams, Fayetteville, N.C., heavyweights. Ice World Arena, Totowa, N.J. Czyz is 18-0 with 13 knockouts. Melon, of Brooklyn is 13-2-1. Thomas is 18-0 with 15 knockouts. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) North American Championships, at Las Vegas. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M., tape).

title: Around the World; U.S. Critics Meddle, Salvadoran Rightists Say
description: A rightist group today denounced Congressional critics of El Salvador as meddlers who were trying to change the country's way of life.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 10 More Green Machines For the Fire Department

title: PILES OF RUBBLE WERE THE HOMES OF PALESTINIANS
description: SHEMALI, Lebanon, July 1 - In the densely populated Palestinian refugee camps of southern Lebanon, the end of the fighting has not meant the end of the war.

title: TV COVERAGE OF 3 WARS STRAINS NEWS BUDGETS
description: Covering a war is a costly venture at any time, but this year, with three conflicts in rapid succession - in El Salvador, the Falkland Islands and the Middle East - the financial toll on news organizations has been extreme. Nowhere is this more true than at the major broadcast news operations, which in addition to deploying reporters, have borne heavy logistical costs to acquire, ship and transmit footage of the wars back to the United States.

title: Chrysler Workers To Get New Stock
description: The United Automobile Workers union said the Chrysler Corporation would distribute 6.24 million shares of Chrysler common stock to 91,000 company employees, of which 65,000 are members of the union. It said the new shares of Chrysler common stock are in addition to 5.99 million shares already distributed to Chrysler workers under an employee stock ownership plan mandated by Congress and the Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board.

title: Garden State Bowl Ends Because of Money Woes
description: The Garden State Bowl, the mid-December college football game played in Giants Stadium, is being discontinued after four years. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, the sponsor that incurred financial losses every year, announced yesterday that the event would not be renewed.

title: Jazz Festival; JAM SESSION 'PERPETUATES' MONK'S MUSIC
description: The Musician's Fund, organized at the Kool Jazz Festival last year to provide financial support to musicians who need immediate assistance, benefited on Thursday night from a jam session called ''Musicians for Monk'' that went on for more than four hours in Carnegie Hall.

title: TCHAIKOVSKY: U.S. FINALISTS WAIT TENSELY
description: The Seventh Tchaikovsky Competition went into its final round today, with 12 young Americans hoping to emulate the glory achieved here by Van Cliburn 24 years ago, at the first of the contests.

title: RYAN INSURANCE, COMBINED TO MERGE
description: The Combined International Corporation, W. Clement Stone's holding company with interests in insurance and finance, announced today that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Ryan Insurance Group to merge in a cash and stock deal valued at $125.8 million.

title: PUBLIC TELEVISION'S CONTRIBUTION TO DISARMAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Filtrona Corp. of Richmond said it had acquired more than 95 percent of the 236,016 outstanding shares of Dollinger Corp. for a cash purchase price of $36 a share.

title: Sports People; Kush Case Review
description: The Supreme Court agreed to review aspects of litigation involving Frank Kush, the former Arizona State football coach, and Kevin Rutledge, the punter during the 1978 season who charged that Kush punched him in the mouth during an incident on the sidelines. Rutledge sued, charging Kush with ''intentionally inflicting emotional distress'' upon him, and sought $2.2 million in damages from the coach, other Arizona State officials, the university and the Arizona Board of Regents.

title: TRUCK DRIVER TAKES TO SKIES IN A LAWN CHAIR
description: A truck driver with 45 weather balloons rigged to a lawn chair took a 45-minute ride aloft to 16,000 feet today before he got cold, shot some balloons out and crashed into a power line, the police said.

title: GILDER'S STREAK OF 60'S ENDS, BUT HE LEADS BY 1
description: Bob Gilder withstood a late charge by Tom Weiskopf today and maintained a one-shot lead midway through the Western Open by shooting a 1-under-par 71.

title: Scouting; Yankee Bat Boys Raise Averages
description: The Yankees' three bat boys had been working so many hours recently that their pay scale had slipped under the minimum wage level. But the Yankees say they have corrected that by reminding the bat boys that they should adhere strictly to a six-hour day.

title: U.S. Inquiry At Marietta
description: Federal authorities seized evidence from the offices of the Martin Marietta Aerospace Company at Vandenberg Air Force Base, saying they were investigating possible overcharges to the Government. The items at issue are desk models of the Titan 3 missile, the company said.

title: BOSTON HERALD AMERICAN FIGHTS RIVAL AND RUMOR
description: For almost a decade, as the readers, advertisers and presence of The Boston Herald American in this community steadily dwindled in a war for survival with The Boston Globe, the staff has been working amid rumors that the newspaper was about to be closed or sold by its owner, the Hearst Corporation.

title: 5 CHILDREN KILLED IN JERSEY FIRE AFTER ATTEMPTS AT RESCUE FAIL
description: Five children aged from 1 to 7 were killed early today in a fire that engulfed their apartment in a three-story frame building.

title: American Can Sells Paper Units
description: The American Can Company and the James River Corporation said American Can had sold some of its paper and forest-based businesses, with a book value of $365 million to a wholly owned subsidiary of James River.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 3, 1982
description: International Talks in Beirut have been fruitless, according to a senior official of the P.L.O. The negotiations, begun three weeks ago by the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Lebanese Government and the American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, were aimed at a settlement in the war between Israel and Palestinian guerrillas. Dr. George C. Habash, head of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and a founder of the P.L.O., said the guerrillas were ready for a battle in Beirut, partly because they felt that if they can hold the Israelis off long enough they will be in an even better negotiating position than they are now. (Page 1, Column 1.) Israeli military action in Beirut was very much alive among Israeli options, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said, although Israel would much prefer to negotiate the departure of the Palestinian guerrillas. (4:1-4.) The destruction of Palestinian homes by the Israeli Army has followed the cease-fire in Lebanon two weeks ago. Many fathers and older brothers are ''in Israel'' the people say, meaning that they have been arrested as guerrillas and taken to Israel for questioning. (1:2.)

title: Richmond's Home Robbed by Man, 28
description: A 28-year-old man was caught yesterday afternoon while robbing the Manhattan apartment of Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: HOLLY STOCK TUMBLES AS G.E. ENDS LOAN OFFER
description: Shares of the Holly Sugar Corporation tumbled by 15 1/4 points yesterday on news that the company's main financial backer, the General Electric Credit Corporation, had decided against lending it $100 million to take the company private at $65 a share. Holly closed at 33 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Around the World; Soviet Writer Repents, According to Tass
description: The Soviet press agency Tass reported today that Yevgeny A. Kozlovsky, a 35-year-old nonconformist writer arrested seven months ago, had repented and demanded that the West stop publishing his works.

title: 300 POLES SAID TO DEFECT IN SPAIN
description: More than 300 Poles who came to Spain to watch the Polish team play in the World Cup soccer tournament have defected and are seeking asylum in the West, members of the group said today.

title: U.S. PLANS BIGGEST LAND SHIFT SINCE FRONTIER TIMES
description: The Reagan Administration has begun what could be the most extensive transfer of public property and resources to private control in recent American history.

title: FOR WANT OF LEADING
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; United Parcel Pact Is Ratified, Union Says
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced today that a new 37-month contract with the United Parcel Service had been ratified.

title: Sports People; Ballot Stuffing
description: Using a photocopier and a computer, a minor league baseball executive produced thousands of ballots to try to influence the voting for the National League team that will play the American League in the All-Star Game July 13 in Montreal. Tom Hogan, a 30-year-old administrative assistant for the Richmond Braves of the International League, said he thought the Atlanta players on the ballot were worthy of more recognition and he sent ''between 10,000 and 20,000'' ballots to Paramus, N.J., where the votes are counted.

title: Inquiry Into Westway Is Initiated by Cuomo
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario Cuomo, saying he was acting as a candidate for Governor and not as a state official, announced yesterday that the former Abscam prosecutor would conduct an investigation for him into the Westway project.

title: Tons of Marijuana Seized in Jersey
description: A two-day surveillance operation led to the arrest of 10 suspects in a plot to distribute 15 tons of Colombian marijuana worth an estimated $12 million, authorities said today.Charges against three of the suspects were later dropped, however, for lack of evidence.

title: Bridge:; It's Nice When You Expect To Lose and Win After All
description: In all forms of duplicate play good players attempt to estimate whether they are doing well or badly, and to what extent. In a pair contest they can, and do, estimate their match points with varying degrees of accuracy.

title: JUSTICES DECIDE FOR N.A.A.C.P. IN BOYCOTT CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 0, that the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People cannot constitutionally be held liable for losses incurred by white merchants in a seven-year boycott by black residents of Claiborne County, Miss.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title:
PATENTS;
Protecting Cotton From Boll Weevils
description: A method of deterring boll weevils from feeding on cotton plants was patented this week for the Agriculture Department.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: At the New School, An Occasion to Look Back

title: Going Out Guide
description: ZOO VIEW

title: Pubco Chapter 11 Filing
description: The Pubco Corporation said it and two subsidiaries, Merkle Press Inc. and Publishers Agency Inc., had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code in the United States Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. Pubco said its other printing subsidiaries were not party to the proceeding and would continue to operate without interruption. Merkle ceased operations last year.

title: SENATE UNIT SETS CURBS ON SELLING TAX CREDITS
description: Exactly how the Senate Finance Committee intends to restrict the ''safe harbor'' leasing provisions of the Internal Revenue Code was not entirely clear today, but one thing was certain. As Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is the panel's chairman, remarked at 11:22 Thursday night, ''safe harbor lives.'' For 39 months, anyway.

title: Coast Guard Ship Rams a Pier
description: A 290-foot Coast Guard training vessel that had been scheduled to take part in weekend holiday festivities rammed into a Manhattan pier yesterday, damaging its figurehead and cracking its foreyard arm in two. No injuries to any of the 139 cadets, 40 enlisted men and 14 officers aboard were reported.

title: Model Ship Behind Schedule
description: The Hjemkomst, a model of a Viking ship, has fallen about two weeks behind schedule on its trans-Atlantic voyage to Norway because of a spell of calm weather, a spokesman said today. The longboat, which was to arrive Saturday in Bergen, Norway, on a trip from Duluth, Minn., is now expected to reach port July 13 to 18. The Hjemkomst was built in a warehouse in northwestern Minnesota by Robert Asp, who died of leukemia before the trip began.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Help Wanted

title: ARGENTINA PUTS ARMY TOLL AT 210
description: The Argentine Army announced today that 201 soldiers who fought on the Falkland Islands were dead or missing. The army tally brings the total announced Argentine dead and missing to 577.

title: L.I.R.R. Train Kills Bicyclist
description: A 25-year-old bicyclist from Queens was killed Thursday when he was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train at a rail crossing here, the police said. The victim was identified as Josiah Preston Halstead, of 41-39 Parsons Boulevard in Jamaica.

title: Scouting; Back in Step
description: The first thing a track athlete learns is not to leave his track shoes unattended. Mel Lattany, a sprinter on the 1980 United States Olympic team, forgot, and as a result he almost wiped out his season.

title: MCENROE AND MAYOTTE GAIN
description: For the sixth time in six years, an unseeded player has reached the semifinals of the men's singles at Wimbledon. Today, Tim Mayotte joined the list with a marathon fiveset victory over Brian Teacher.

title: Gato del Sol Tops Suburban Field
description: Gato del Sol, the Kentucky Derby winner, and Aloma's Ruler, the Preakness winner, will attempt to defeat older horses tomorrow when a field of eight goes to the post at Belmont Park for the $150,000-added Suburban Handicap.

title: British Airways
description: State-owned British Airways said a British independent carrier, Air Europe Ltd., a subsidiary of the Intasun Leisure Group P.L.C., had agreed to acquire from the Boeing Company for about $70 million two 757 aircraft previously ordered by British Airways.

title: Observer; THOSE MASKED MEN
description: I don't quarrel with a President's right to get rid of a Secretary of State and refuse to say why, but then I'm not a Secretary of State. If I were I'd prefer the President to tell everybody why he did it.

title: FACES MISS NAVRATILOVA IN FINAL
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Billie Jean King, so different as players but so similar as champions, played another memorable match today in the semifinals at Wimbledon.

title: No Headline
description: Roy Jenkins, the 61-year-old former President of the Common Market, was elected today as the first leader of Britain's new Social Democratic Party.

title: NLT-American General Talks Start
description: The NLT Corporation of Nashville announced yesterday that it was holding ''merger talks'' with the American General Corporation of Houston, raising the possibility that the insurance companies were close to ending the takeover battles started in April.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 19.

title: Army Sentences a G.I. to Die In Rape-Murder of a German
description: A United States Army court has sentenced an American soldier to death for the rape-murder of an 18-year-old German woman, an Army spokesman said today.

title: Test Plane's Designer Killed
description: An experimental plane that was to have made a flight around the world this fall crashed at the Mojave Airport today, killing the pilot, who was its designer. The authorities said Thomas Jewett, 30 years old, of Lancaster, Calif., was on a test flight when the plane, ''Free Enterprise,'' developed mechanical problems. He radioed to a ground crew that he was going to land, and the plane nose-dived.

title: FACING REALITY IN ARGENTINA
description: The democratic world should take careful note of current goings-on in Buenos Aires. Defeat in the Falklands apparently has not, as some feared, sent Argentina lurching to wilder extremes.

title: P.L.O. OFFICIAL SAYS TALKS IN LEBANON MAKE NO PROGRESS
description: A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that three weeks of negotiations between the P.L.O., the Lebanese Government and Philip C. Habib, the American envoy, had made ''no progress'' in finding a peaceful settlement for the Lebanese crisis.

title: N.A.A.C.P. DELEGATES CELEBRATE BOYCOTT DECISION
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today hailed the Supreme Court's decision in a Mississippi boycott case as a vindication and a key victory.

title: FRANCE AND EGYPT OFFER PLAN AT U.N. FOR DISARMED P.L.O.
description: France and Egypt have joined forces to seek a Security Council resolution designed to help preserve the Palestine Liberation Organization as a largely disarmed political force in the Middle East.

title: How Much for the Handicapped?
description: The Supreme Court's decision that the Peekskill school district need not supply a deaf fourth-grader with a sign-language interpreter may seem cold-hearted. But by setting a limit on public responsibility, it furthers fair education policy.

title: Players; A FIRST COUSIN PLAYS SECOND FIDDLE
description: T he Knicks picked two Tuckers in the recent National Basketball Association draft. They are senior guards and first cousins from Flint, Mich.

title: Sports People; Baseball Players Sue
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, the owners of the 26 major league teams and the Major League Baseball Promotion Corporation are the defendants in a lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan by three major league baseball players.

title: CAREY GETS COMPUTER STOCK BILL
description: A bill that would permit the transfer of shares of stock through the issuing of computerized statements - instead of stock certificates - was approved unanimously today by the State Senate. The bill now goes to Governor Carey, who is expected to sign it.

title: MIAMI BOY HITS JACKPOT IN A HOT CAR
description: A 17-year-old boy found he had hit the jackpot when he looked inside the trunk of a stolen car, the police say. More than $800,000 in cash was stuffed in two suitcases.

title: SKILLS, NOT BIAS, SEEN AS KEY FOR JOBS
description: Clarence Thomas says that, as a youngster growing up in the Deep South in the 1960's and 1970's, he benefited from scholarships and other special programs provided for minorities.

title: Ray Scarborough, 64, Major League Pitcher
description: Ray Scarborough, a major league pitcher from 1942 to 1953, died of a heart attack Thursday night at home. He was 64 years old.

title: NEW TACK ON E.R.A.
description: The disturbing truth lingers - the proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution is dead. A woman now wields power on the high court but the symbolism is hollow. The express mandate of the supreme law of the land has not changed since the first Federal equal rights proposal foundered before Congress nearly 60 years ago. A Justice who is a woman does not alone secure justice for all women. So where do we turn? Should we follow the Reagan Administration's proposal to place our trust in the states? Maybe yes - but the goal of the amendment will never be obtained by efforts such as the President's deplorable ''50 States Project,'' which slyly ''assists'' the states in ''reviewing'' their laws for sex discrimination but actually does nothing. Fortunately, there is an alternative.

title: SWAN EXCELS
description: It did not erase the memory of last weekend's embarrassing trip to Philadelphia, but it was a rebound in the right direction. Barely a week after the Mets suffered five consecutive defeats to the Phillies, they turned around and trounced them, 8-4, before 18,862 fans at Shea Stadium last night.

title: Briefing
description: E.P.A. Check on Critic F or years, Hugh B. Kaufman has been a thorn in the side of his superiors at the Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Kaufman, a prominent specialist in the area of hazardous waste, has warned in speeches, interviews and Congressional testimony that the Government is doing little or nothing to protect citizens from the dangers of toxic chemicals.

title: Jazz Festival; Peterson and Hancock Offer Harmonic Feast
description: The meeting of Oscar Peterson and Herbie Hancock, keyboard giants who represent different generations of jazz pianism, drew a sold-out house at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday in a concert that ended with the two playing together. Because both pianists share deeply lyrical sensibilities, the evening was a crowd-pleasing harmonic feast.

title: Officer Arrested In Queens Killing
description: A New York City police officer was arrested on a murder charge yesterday after he fatally shot a 20-year-old man during an earlymorning dispute on a Queens street while he was off duty.

title: AGENCIES IN CITY ORDERED TO TRIM THEIR EXPENSES
description: The Koch administration has ordered all New York City agencies to reduce expenses immediately by three-quarters of 1 percent, officials said yesterday. They said the savings could come to as much as $80 million and would be put in a general reserve fund for each agency.

title: SIEGFRIED WESTPHAL
description: Siegfried Westphal, Hitler's youngest general, died today at his home in Lower Saxony, his family announced.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Soviet Army and Air Force in Afghanistan are methodically turning that country into a forward operational base for possible military moves in southwest Asia, according to an Afghan rebel leader.

title: Seaver Fifth In Strikeouts
description: Tom Seaver of the Cincinnati Reds lost the game but moved into fifth place on the career strikeout list tonight when he fanned Rafael Ramirez of the Atlanta Braves in the fourth inning.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report Thursday about a preliminary injunction barring the Secretary of Education from distributing $2.8 billion in Federal money for poor children incorrectly reported how that figure was reached. The money was appropriated by Congress this year.

title: Connecticut Utility Seeking Rate Rise
description: Northeast Utilities announced today that it had requested an 8.7 percent increase in electricity rates and an 11.2 percent increase in natural gas prices.

title: CITY'S JUNE UNEMPLOYMENT RATE CLIMBED TO 9.9%
description: The unemployment rate rose sharply in New York City and New York State in June, reflecting the recession and a general weakening of the job market in the city and state, the United States Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Sun Gasoline Price Up
description: The Sun Company, the nation's 11th-largest gasoline marketer, raised its wholesale gasoline prices by a penny a gallon yesterday in New York City, Delaware, northern New Jersey and several counties surrounding the metropolitan area. ''By late summer, retail gasoline prices should be restablized at perhaps 3 cents to 5 cents a gallon above current levels,'' according to Data Resources Inc. in Lexington, Mass.

title:
Patents;
Improving Bacterial Vaccines
description: WASHINGTON RESEARCH at Georgetown University in Washington has developed a new method of preparing bacterial vaccines. They are expected to be important in treating both human and animal ailments.

title:
PATENTS;
A Simpler System For Relaying Data
description: A communications system and network with relay stations were patented this week by Elliot L. Gruenberg, president of Broadcom Inc., a research and development company in West New York, N.J.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Toward a Quiet Fourth

title: NEW MALL STRESSES OLD VIRTUES
description: An in-town Miami shopping mall built around chic boutiques and old-world shopping elegance may evolve into a nationwide chain of similar centers if the developers have their way.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
THE UNDERGROUND--NO RECESSION THERE
description: REGARDLESS of the recession, illegal economic activity has been f lourishing. Aided by increased commerce in the underground economy, t otal consumer spending in the nation has not been falling, but h olding steady, and has even begun to increase of late. Personal i ncomes seem to be larger than one would expect, and on a more m undane level, it seems to be as difficult as ever to obtain the s ervices of a good electrician, computer programmer or a bookmaker.

title: QUALITY WITH CONSISTENCY
description: IN an area where restaurants are known for their seasonal, if not weekly, ups and downs, finding one that is consistent on as high a level as the Inn at Quogue is a pleasure. The food is appealing and imaginative in a manner that respects both the seasons and the local resources. The preparation is generally very skillful.

title: GREECE MOVES TO END A UNION MONOPOLY TO TRIM PRESS COSTS
description: The Greek Socialist Government has obtained passage of legislation breaking the monopoly of the union of press technicians and making it possible for newspapers to slash production costs by introducing modern technology and reducing their staffs.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: AS events go, this one was pure Americana. There were families with picnic baskets, Dixieland jazz, popcorn and cotton candy. There was sunshine, and a big green field, and the Hudson River, its banks and bluffs cloaked in the haze of a hot summer day.

title: 1,000 YOUNGSTERS LEAVE CITY FOR 'FRIENDLY TOWN'
description: It was time to go, but Henry Rivera, 7 years old, would not stop crying. Tears streamed down his cheeks, which had taken on the same bright red hue as his baseball cap.

title: MUNICIPAL UNION NEGOTIATORS IN NO HURRY TO BE LOCKED IN
description: Negotiators for the city and the municipal unions may have failed to agree on a contract to replace the one that expired last week, but they were close to resoving one issue that had been hanging over their heads for years. It was listed on their worksheets as ''deferred wages,'' the nearly $300 million that workers gave up, some voluntarily and some not, to keep New York City from defaulting in 1975. Since then, the workers have been wondering when they would get their money back. The city has all but agreed the time has come.

title: Some Encouragement On Nonsmoking
description: Dear George O'Connell: We in the Lung Association enjoyed your interesting article ''Good Angels, Bad Angels and Prolonging Smoking'' (Opinion Page, June 13). We are pleased that you have found the American Lung Association publication, ''Freedom From Smoking in 20 Days,'' so helpful.

title: EUROBOND ISSUES SOAR
description: This year's Eurobond activity is sure to top last year's, when medium-and long-term corporate debt offerings totaled $21.8 billion. In a recent report to clients, Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm, reported that about $22 billion in Eurodollar bonds were issued in the first six months of the year.

title: Sports People; Youth Is Served
description: Nate Archibald, the playmaker for the Boston Celtics, is expanding the youth development league he started in the Bronx three years ago to Boston.

title: JULIUS RUDEL REFLECTS ON LIFE AFTER CITY OPERA
description: Acouple of seasons ago, Rolf Liebermann, then the director of the Paris Opera, wired an invitation to Julius Rudel to conduct Monteverdi's ''L'Incoronazione di Poppea.'' The former director of the New York City Opera, enjoying his new freedom to conduct where and when he chose, thought about it and declined.

title: WHEN THE BISHOPS THAT REMAIN ARE OF OPPOSITE COLORS
description: The factor of bishops-of-opposite-color has always been too heavily relied upon as a drawing device. In fact, there is little security in it. Of course, in pure bishop endings where the defender is a pawn down but has no pawn weaknesses, the draw is effortlessly accomplished: king and bishop blockade the opponent's passed pawn on a square of the same color as the bishop and there is nothing the superior side can do.

title: Postings; NO III?
description: The intersection of Routes 4 and l7 in Paramus is one of New Jersey's busiest, and soon it is going to get busier. Already clustered around it are the Garden State Plaza shopping mall and several office buildings, among them Paramus Plazas I and II, both built by Boroughs Development Corporation.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Royal Navy, which emerged battered but triumphant from the Falkland Islands war, is now the center of a struggle for money and power within the British military establishment. The outcome of that struggle, American naval sources believe, will affect not only Britain's role in NATO but also the extent of United States maritime responsibilities in the North Atlantic. The primary lesson of the Falkland war for Britain was that although the country's main military interests lie in the security of Western Europe, there must be enough flexibility to enable Britain to intervene outside the area.

title: Cynthia Ryan Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Ryan of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Jannine Ryan, to Joseph V. Castellana, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrosio Castellana of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: CABLE TV MOVES TO THE MUSIC
description: On screen, members of the Go-Go's glide along in a flashy red convertible while the rock band's lead singer, Belinda Carlisle, sings its hit, ''Our Lips Are Sealed.'' The image soon flashes to a strutting Mick Jagger performing during the 1981 Rolling Stones tour and then to a loft studio where a video jockey - or ''veejay,'' a cross between a disc jockey and a TV emcee -announces what has just been played on MTV.

title: Ruttman Gains Spot In the Firecracker 400
description: Joe Ruttman had the fastest lap today in the final qualifying session for the Firecracker 400 Grand National stock car race Sunday.

title: COURT RULING MAY GIVE MUSTO REDEFINED ROLE
description: UNION CITY Because of his recent conviction on Federal bribery and conspiracy charges, William V. Musto has been stripped of his public positions as Mayor of this Hudson County municipality and State Senator from the 33d Legislative District.

title: THE FELD PRESENTS NEW WORKS IN ITS NEW THEATER
description: So they did it. Not quite on schedule but nonetheless in 1982, as announced, the Joyce Theater opened as the new home of the Feld Ballet. It is exactly 15 years since Eliot Feld choreographed his first ballet, which was ''Harbinger'' for American Ballet Theater. In the interim, he has parked his own two companies - first, the American Ballet Company and now the Feld Ballet - in other people's theaters. Knowing Eliot Feld, it is not surprising that he would want his own.

title: WHERE THE ACTION WAS
description: EDIE An American Biography. By Jean Stein. Edited with George Plimpton. Illustrated. 455 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Brezhnev Off on Vacation
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev left Moscow today for his usual summer vacation, the official press agency Tass reported. It gave no details of where he was headed, but the 75-year-old Soviet leader normally spends July and August at a retreat in the Crimean peninsula.

title: Abby Ann Van Pelt Is Bride
description: In the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., yesterday Abby Ann Van Pelt, a former news reporter for WPVI-TV in Philadelphia, was married to Jay R. Feldman, vice president-general manager of WCAU-TV, the CBS-owned station in Philadelphia. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony.

title: Three Are Killed and 10 Injured In a Jersey Turnpike Accident
description: Three persons were killed and 10 others injured in a fiery three-car accident on the New Jersey Turnpike here early today, the state police said.

title: MEDIA REVENUE RATINGS
description: Media revenues from ''new'' electronic media companies far outpaced the gains of larger, more traditional leaders in the communications business last year, a recent report by Advertising Age shows.

title: THE MYSTERIOUS '4TH OF JULY CURSE'
description: FOR a mysteriously large number of the 56 men who signed the Declaration of Independence, to sign the historic document was to ratify their own ruin. Personal tragedies of all kinds for many of them, and their families, soon proved the bitter reward for their bravery.

title: Postings; AN ANACHRONISM THRIVES IN QUEENS
description: When people ask John Klein what he does at his home at 194-15 73d Avenue in Flushing, Queens, he tells them he farms. ''Then they laugh,'' he says, but it is true.

title: ITALIANS ARE IN THE GAME TO WIN
description: Ralph DiGennaro writes about men's clothing. Until five years ago, style on the tennis court meant having a fluid back-hand, crisp volley and classic serve. Today, it means wearing tennis clothes that are expensive, tight fitting, highly fashionable and, most importantly, Italian.

title: NEW REDISTRICTING BY NEW YORK STATE IS APPROVED BY U.S.
description: The Justice Department today approved the New York State Legislature's plans to reapportion Congressional, State Senate and Assembly districts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Swan Flashes Winning Form
description: George Bamberger, the Mets' 56-year-old first-year manager, was talking about a recent performance by Craig Swan. ''In baseball, you have your good days and your bad days,'' Bamberger said Friday night. ''He just had one of those bad days. He didn't have good stuff. And he had no command of any one pitch he could go with when he needed an out.''

title: A HISTORIAN'S PERSPECTIVE photo of Ephrata Cloister
description: MICHAEL KAMMEN, who won the Pulitzer Prize in History in 1973 for ''People of Paradox: An Inquiry Concerning the Origins of American Civilization,'' is professor of American history and culture at Cornell. By MICHAEL KAMMEN

title: FIREWORKS IN 60 TOWNS
description: Fourth of July fireworks in Connecticut will be only slightly less glorious this year. The State Fire Marshal's office reports that 60 towns applied for fireworks permits this year, despite the cost of the displays, which can run as high as $10,000, plus a $1 million bond that must be posted with the State Insurance Commissioner.

title: WORLD BANK PLANS VARIABLE INTEREST
description: The World Bank, which lends money to the world's poorest nations, has decided to make its borrowers pay variable interest rates for the first time.

title: Amy L. Schustack Plans To Be Wed to M.A. Tyler
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Schustack of East Northport, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Lynn Schustack, to Michael Aaron Tyler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Tyler, also of East Northport.

title: RECITAL: HARPSICHORDIST
description: Elaine Comparone's recital at Symphony Space Wednesday night was advertised as ''harpsichord witchery.'' While the result wasn't quite up to its billing (there were too many dropped notes and even Miss Comparone apologized for the lack of black cape and broom), the result was often quite bewitching.

title: Roberta Bennett Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bennett of Eastchester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Roberta Gail Bennett, to Peter Mark Gottlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton R. Gottlieb of Scarsdale, N.Y. Miss Bennett is a graduate of Lafayette College. Her fiance, a staff accountant with Deloitte Haskins & Sells, was graduated from Lehigh University.

title: The Nation in Summary; Freedom Delayed For Haitians
description: Had they come at another time or perhaps from another place, the thousands of Haitian immigrants now detained in the United States and Puerto Rico might have been welcomed at the country's ''golden door.'' Instead they are perceived as having climbed through a what one Government lawyer called ''a window of vulnerability'' that a Federal court in Miami may have opened a bit wider last week.

title: By John Wilson; Electric Guitars Ricochet In Fat Tuesday's Series
description: Fat Tuesday's, the jazz club at Third Avenue and 17th Street, which is offering a special series of programs called ''Kool Combinations'' as part of the current jazz festival, brought together four electric guitarists - John Abercrombie, Chuck Loeb, Vic Juris and Emily Remler - as its ''combination'' Monday night.

title: MILFORD BEACH TO STAY OPEN
description: WITH state park officials expecting huge numbers of people to visit state parks and beaches this season, the Department of Environmental Protection announced last week that the Silver Sands beach in Milford, one of Connecticut's few remaining sandy beaches, will remain open to the public again this year, despite a lack of financing for the continued development of a state park at the site.

title: ANTITRUST VERDICT WON'T HURT N.F.L.
description: THE decision of a six-person jury that Section 4.3 of the National Football League's constitution violates the Sherman Antitrust Act seems to have thrown the sports world - or at least sportswriters - into turmoil. In The New York Times of May 9, Dave Anderson wrote that eliminating the rule that requires three-quarters of the N.F.L. owners to approve franchise moves will make teams ''free agents,'' with each owner able to ''invite the civic leaders ... to an auction for his franchise.''

title: 'The Best Defense'
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Rockies Search Goes On For Boy Missing 4 Days
description: The group searching for a 12-yearold boy who has been lost for four days expanded today to more than 200 people.

title: 3 TIE FOR LEAD AT 212 IN L.P.G.A. EVENT
description: Beth Daniel, after moving ahead on the back nine, bogeyed the 18th hole today and fell into a three-way tie for the lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Peter Jackson Classic.

title: AFTER LEVITTOWN: LOOKING AHEAD
description: THE Levittown decision has been overturned. The Court of Appeals has decided that New York State's system of financing public elementary and secondary education violates neither the Federal nor the State Constitution. Any appeal to the United States Supreme Court seems unlikely to succeed. The issue is decided.

title: Tacuma and Rochester Perform at Soundscape
description: Jamaaladeen Tacuma, who appeared with the drummer Cornell Rochester under the heading ''Double Exchange'' Thursday night at Soundscape on the Purple Barge, is one of the two bass players in Ornette Coleman's Prime Time as well as a member of that downtown funk-jazz-rock all-star group, Golden Palominos.

title: Around the World; Zimbabwe's Opposition Is Accused of Gun Attack
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe today linked the opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, with a gun attack on his official residence last week.

title: Fire in U.S. Mission in Seoul
description: A minor fire broke out in the United States Embassy building here today, and the South Korean police said it was probably caused by an electric fault. The blaze damaged a room and destroyed furniture and documents.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Puerto Rican music will come to the aid of Puerto Rican education on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. The concert will be a benefit for Boricua College, said to be the only private Puerto Rican institution of higher learning in the country.

title: CO-OP EVICTION CHALLENGED
description: PORT WASHINGTON A group of tenants in a Port Washington apartment house have successfully challenged their landlord's contention that a sufficient number of residents had agreed to purchase apartments in the building, enabling him to convert it to a cooperative under a socalled ''eviction plan.''

title: ESTELLE PARSONS' ALASKA DIARY
description: As an actress who has spent most of my life in the theater, I suppose I have always dreamed of making a backpacking trek to Alaska - and briefly shaking off the tinsel of Broadway and Hollywood. Little did I realize, when my dream finally came true, that a highlight of the adventure would have a distinct theatrical flavor and that Alaska in itself would prove to be one of the most dramatic experiences of my life.

title: A Childhood Spent With Books
description: Annie Dillard's wonderful article conjured up many memories of a childhood and adolescence spent with books (''The Joys of Reading,'' May 16). I was amazed at how many books we had in common.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK FESTIVAL SET
description: NEW BRUNSWICK SOME of New Brunswick's rich 300-year-old heritage, from medieval Germany to Space Age New Jersey, will be revived by musicians, dancers, artists and artisans next Saturday.

title: HOW NOT TO GET A JOB
description: PERSONNEL departments. Most large companies have them. They are the places to visit if you are looking for work. Or so they say. Telephone any company, any department, and it is more than likely that if you say you are looking for a job, you will be referred to personnel - or employment, or manpower development, or human resources. Whatever the name, their function is the same: Personnel departments get rid of people.

title: LITCHFIELD IS HOST TO HOUSE TOUR
description: LITCHFIELD ITS handsome colonial homes, shady village green and imposing white clapboard Congregational Church, whose steeple can be seen for miles, have prompted some to describe this western Connecticut settlement as ''the most unspoiled 18th-century village in New England.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Maybe the Israelis will come and maybe they will win here, but I promise you it will be a big cemetery for them.'' - Rifaat Shihaab, a Palestinian commando, in a suburb of Beirut. (1:4)

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING AN EDIBLE LANDSCAPE
description: THERE is concern these days, and rightfully so, about the high cost of living. Somehow food always seems to bear the brunt of the dissatisfaction, although food costs have hovered between 16 and 20 percent of our disposable income for the last 30 years or so.

title: STATES FEEL THE CUT IN FUNDS FOR SUMMER LUNCHES
description: Florida officials are threatening to close, as early as Friday, a federally financed program that provides free lunches to 85,000 children, many of them from needy families.

title: WHEN AN INSTRUMENT HAS A SPECIAL 'PERSONALITY'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: U.S. ACTS ON MISSING WRITER
description: BOGOTA The House Foreign Affairs Committee has approved a measure that would include the name of John Sullivan Jr. of Bogota on a State Department list of Americans killed or missing in war-torn El Salvador.

title: Whitney Ray Sets September Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ray of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Whitney Ray, to Channing Lease Dawson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Dawson of San Marino, Calif.

title: HISTORIC MONUMENT IS TO BE REPAIRED
description: Commissioner Stanley J. Pac of the State Department of Environmental Protection announced last week that a crumbling fieldstone monument, erected 97 years ago atop Bear Mountain in Salisbury, will be repaired and used to mark the highest point in the state.

title: ALBANY LINES DIVIDE MORE THAN DISTRICTS
description: ALBANY WHEN the United States Justice Department rejects a reapportionment plan on the ground that it is racially discriminatory, black and Hispanic politicians usually cheer. But that was hardly the reaction last month when the department rejected the Assembly, Senate and Congressional district lines drawn by the New York State Legislature.

title: JENNY THEROUX WILL BE MARRIED
description: Delphine Tone Greenwald of Glastonbury, Conn., and Kenneth Walter Theroux of Avon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanette Marie Theroux, to Stephen Henry Zlotnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zlotnick of Falls Church, VA.

title: The World in Summary; Familiar Faces Across the Table
description: Edward I. Rowny and Viktor P. Karpov settled into comfortable chairs across a table in Geneva last week, ending a three-year hiatus in United States-Soviet negotiations to curb nuclear weapons capable of destroying both countries. President Reagan said they were ''trustees for humanity'' embarked on ''one of the most important tasks of our age.''

title: The Edible Landscape
description: I was pleased to see Ken Druse's article, ''Helping Nature Take Its Course'' (June 6). However, when Mr. Druse states that people are turning to ''disease-resistant fruit trees and shrubs instead of demanding vegetables,'' he must not be aware of the edible-landscape movement. Why plant fruit trees only for spring flowers and winter silhouettes? Varieties can be chosen and planted so that they also shade the house in summer and produce abundant fruit in the fall. Nut trees can be used in the same manner, also with an edible yield.Grapes can easily be trained to provide privacy as well as fruit for eating or for home wine making.

title: NEEDED: A LIFE OF DRYDEN; by D.J.R. Bruckner
description: Recently there has been a procession of literary biographies - of such different writers as John Ruskin, Franz Kafka, Lord Tennyson, Ralph Waldo Emerson, William Carlos Williams. Using new approaches to language, history and psychology, these books can give us valuable insights into ourselves and our culture.

title: Kathryn Gold Engaged to Henry Card
description: Mr. and Mrs. P. Daniel Gold 3d of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Edith Elizabeth Gold, to Henry Duncan Card, son of Dr. Alva Duncan Card of Oklahoma City, Okla., and the late William Lee Card.

title: Sandra Waife Fiancee of Dr. Steven Rothenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell M. Waife of White Plains, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Denise Waife, to Dr. Steven Jeffrey Rothenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Rothenberg of Westbury, L.I.

title: NJ Transit Is Chided On Way It Raised Fares
description: The news that NJ Transit's bus and train fares rose by 10 to 50 percent, starting yesterday, and will increase by 15 to 25 percent more, probably by September, was not earthshaking news by itself in these inflationary times.

title: C.P. Beale to Wed Pamela Hancock
description: Announcement has been made by Hampton S.T. Hancock 3d of Palos Verdes, Calif., of the engagement of his sister, Pamela Worden Hancock, to Christopher Prince Beale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bouvier Beale of Glen Cove and Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: THE TROUBLED FED SEEKS A NEW WAY
description: WASHINGTON PAUL A. VOLCKER and the six other governors of the Federal Reserve Board are a hardy and inventive breed. In the past few years they have begun a revolution in the way United States monetary policy is conducted and fought almost single-handedly to bring inflation below double-digit rates. All the while they warded off the barbs hurled at them by critics of every political stripe.

title: YALE, CALIFORNIA CREWS BEATEN
description: ON-THAMES, England, July 3 - American hopes of taking home the Henley Royal Regatta's premier trophy, the Grand Challenge Cup, ended today as the Yale and California heavyweight varsity crews lost in semifinal heats of the 143-year-old event.

title: GOOD WITCH, BAD WITCH
description: HERBALIST OF THE REMOTE TOWN By Amos Tutuola. 205 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $7.95.MASSENI. By Tidiane Dem. Translated by Frances Frenaye. 174 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $12.95.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Alarm Sounded On DNA Warfare
description: Evidence that the United States Army is interested in expanding its biological warfare research into gene-splicing techniques led a Federal panel last week to register opposition to work that could lead to weapons production. The National Institutes of Health's Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee voted to remind the Institutes' director, James Wyngaarden, that a 1972 treaty prohibits any use of molecular cloning for weapons development.

title: POLLUTION CONTROL INDUSTRY IN PERIL
description: WASHINGTON COMBUSTION Equipment Associates, a promising young Stamford, Conn., company in the promising pollution control business, was flying high in the mid-1970's, reaching peak sales of $150 million. By 1980, although its sales were still $140.5 million, its losses had swollen to $23.6 million and in October that year, it filed a bankruptcy petition.

title: Oswald Daughters Sue The National Enquirer
description: The two daughters of Lee Harvey Oswald have filed suit against The National Enquirer, charging that the weekly libeled them by falsely portraying them as ''social outcasts.''

title: U.S. Ties Series
description: A two-run triple by Keith Mucha highlighted a three-run first inning Friday that carried the United States to a 3-1 victory over Japan in the Japan-United States Collegiate Baseball Series. The American victory tied the series at two games each.

title: Susan Weiss Becomes Bride
description: Susan Alexandra Weiss and Joseph Esposito were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Wayne, N.J. The Rev. Robert Morris performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Weiss of Wayne and her husband's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John Esposito of Gillette, N.J. The bride is a landscape architect with Architect's Collaborative in Cambridge, Mass. Her husband is an environmental engineer for Lombardo Associates in Boston.

title: SPOKEN WORDS TRACE PATH OF HISTORY
description: IN a tape-recorded account of his 45-year career as a machinist, Michel Bilger of Watertown describes his lengthy apprenticeship in the 1930's at the Peugeot factory in France. It was a huge, 19thcentury workplace with machinery run by overhead belts and pulleys, a place where apprentices began by mastering a file, a hammer and a chisel.

title: ARMY PERSONNEL CHIEF DISPUTES REPORTS ON DRAFT AND BLACK SOLDIERS
description: The Army's chief of personnel, Lieut. Gen. Maxwell R. Thurman, says the service could expand from its current force of 790,000 soldiers to 850,000 without resorting to peacetime conscription.

title: Susanne Leary Is Wed in Washington To Paul Thomas Shoemaker, Lawyer
description: At Christ Episcopal Church, Georgetown, in Washington yesterday, Susanne Leary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neal Leary of Alexandria, Va., was married to Paul Thomas Shoemaker, son of Louise Proehl Shoemaker of Philadelphia and the Rev. Bryce W. Shoemaker of Baltimore. The Rev. William Clarkson 4th performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Mackenzie Wed to Professor
description: The marriage of Susan Adderton Mackenzie, a candidate for an M.S. degree at the Institute for Environmental Studies at the University of Wisconsin, to Carlisle Ford Runge, an associate professor of political science at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, took place yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Joseph Doty performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church, Georgetown.

title: The New Face Of Kabuki
description: The article on Kabuki theater offers an explanation for the replacement of female performers by men in female roles, which seems reasonable and scholarly (''The New Face of Kabuki,'' by Steve Lohr, May 30). However, when I was in Tokyo six years ago, and went to a Kabuki performance, I was handed a programlike brochure giving a quite different explanation. This was that the female performers so outshone the men that the men appealed to the Emperor to forbid the public appearance of women on the stage, and the Emperor agreed. ROSE LECHAY, Wellfleet, Mass

title: Around the World; Dutch Reportedly Expel 2 Soviet Diplomats
description: The Netherlands has expelled two Soviet diplomats accused of spying on Dutch and NATO military installations, the Amsterdam daily De Telegraaf reported today.

title: Art Pepper Film Clip Highlight of 'Summit'
description: Art Pepper was originally scheduled to participate Monday in the jazz festival's ''Alto Summit'' at Carnegie Hall. His presence would have made it a special evening; he always drove himself hard, and he expected his audiences to listen with the same sort of intensity.

title: THE BLUES ARE STILL A LIVING TRADITION
description: Glance at a row of subway billboards or watch an evening of television these days and chances are you will encounter a plug for a certain brand of Scotch whisky or fried chicken by the blues singer and guitarist B.B. King. Only a handful of black Americans have attained sufficient media visibility to be asked to lend their names and faces to such endorsements, and most of these black celebrities are athletes. Very, very few of them are musicians, and only one, B.B. King, is a bluesman.

title: New Jersey Monthly Defended on Articles
description: In the New Jersey Journal of June 20, Colleen Katz, the new editor of New Jersey Monthly magazine, is quoted as saying: ''We must recognize that, until we can afford a fine research and fact-checking staff, we have to stay away from controversial articles.''

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: agitation for third-world ''revolution'' and the ''liberation'' movements that flourished in America, particularly in California. A compound of commentary and travelogue by a Trinidad emigre, it is admirably written and often persuasive but would have benefited from a closer look at the cases of the poor, mostly elderly blacks who were the majority of the suicides.

title: JAPAN'S COMMUNIST PARTY FACES UNCERTAINTY
description: Japan's Communist Party, the nation's oldest political organization, is marking its 60th anniversary this month amid expressions of doubt about its future.

title: JUGGLING FISCAL AND POLITICAL BOOKS KEEPS GETTING HARDER
description: THE House away, the Senate last week started on the hard part - actually writing the spending and taxing bills that will fit Federal fiscal activity in 1983 within the ceilings and floors set by the earlier stages of the Congressional budget process. With the effectiveness of that process under increasing fire, The Week in Review asked three experts - Robert N. Giaimo, a former Representative who was chairman of the House Budget Committee, James T. Lynn, a Washington lawyer who was President Ford's budget director, and Alice M. Rivlin, head of the Congressional Budget Office - to talk about its failures and successes. Excerpts of their discussion with Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, and Martin Tolchin and Steven V. Roberts, who cover Congress for The New York Times, follow.

title: L.A. MADE HIM DO IT
description: 'LUDES A Ballad of the Drug and the Dream. By Benjamin Stein. 248 pp. New York: St. Martin's/Marek. $12.95.

title: EVERYDAY AND EXTRAORDINARY
description: BLUE BOY By Jean Giono. Translated by Katherine A. Clarke. 251 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $8.50.THE SONG OF THE WORLD By Jean Giono. Translated by Henri Fluchere and Geoffrey Myers. 312 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $9.50.JOY OF MAN'S DESIRING By Jean Giono. Translated by Katherine A. Clarke. 460 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $10.

title: A SOUTHERN TALE OF BRUNSWICK STEW
description: JOHN HERBERS is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By JOHN HERBERS

title: Prearraignment
description: In May, the police of the 23d Precinct on Manhattan's Upper East Side reported that an arrest often tied up an officer for his whole eight-hour tour of duty. Besides the paper work and travel time, hours were spent waiting in Criminal Court for an arraignment.

title: Dr. Janice Finkelstein to Married to Dr. Alan Levitt
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Finkelstein of Spring Valley, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Janice Eve Finkelstein, to Dr. Alan Farrell Levitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Levitt of Woodmere, L.I. The wedding is planned for next May.

title: Meredith Dixon Will Be Married To John A. Finan
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Garde Jr. of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Garde's daughter, Meredith Howland Dixon, to John Austin Finan, son of Austin L. Finan of Allegany, N.Y., and the late Elizabeth R. Finan.

title: ALONE AT LAST! ALONE AT LAST?
description: THE realization hit a few weeks ago. My husband and I were going to be alone for the first summer in nine years. Our son, Jonathan, an only child who is more like another adult in our household, freely joining in our grownup conversations on politics, friends and money, is one of those children who are usually seen and heard. This summer he is going to sleep-away camp because he decided several months ago that it was high time he had a vacation from us.

title: SIGNPOSTS IN THE SEARCH OF MAPS
description: Although rarely available free in gasoline stations anymore, road maps have improved greatly in variety and quality in recent years. They are available from many sources, sometimes still without charge.

title: 8 Orchestras Honored For Modern Programs
description: Eight American orchestras have been named winners of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers Award for Adventurous Programming of Contemporary Music.

title: Stephen Maurer to Wed Frances Stier
description: Barbara G. Stier of Roseland, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Frances Rhoda Stier, and Dr. Stephen Bennett Maurer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ely Maurer of Silver Spring, Md.

title: The World in Summary; Oaths and Vows In Argentina
description: The eighth anniversary of Juan Domingo Peron's death was hardly an auspicious day to inaugurate a new Argentine leader. But, undaunted by the memory of the populist dictator, retired Maj. Gen. Reynaldo Bignone was sworn in as President last week.

title: A BRONX-MANHATTAN BUS LINE IS URGED TO ADD HARLEM STOPS
description: A group of black business executives is seeking to have a private bus line that operates between the Bronx and Manhattan add some stops in Harlem.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MINT ACCEPTING ORDERS FOR THE WASHINGTON HALF
description: The United States Mint will start accepting orders for the new George Washington commemorative half dollar on Tuesday. Barring unforeseen delays the first examples should be in collectors' hands by mid-August. Production began on July 1, and order forms and descriptive brochures were being sent last week to customers on the Mint's mailing list.

title: Subway Proposal
description: To the Business Editor: The article ''Subway Defense'' (June 27) deserves clarification. The Canadians' base price for the 825 cars is $803,485 per car, or a total of $662.9 million.

title: Miss Monahan Wins Again at Horse Show
description: Katie Monahan, a member of the United States Equestrian Team, continued to dominate the open-jumper classes at the Lake Placid horse show today.

title: AMONG THE BATTLES THAT MUSSOLINI LOST
description: THE days of the great dictators - the flamboyant, larger-than-life tyrants with international clout - are over, if only perhaps temporarily. But in the 1930's, three of them were flexing their muscles at the same time: Hitler, Stalin and Mussolini.

title: LOCAL TALENT ABOUNDS-AND ANYTHING GOES
description: BROOKVILLE FEW areas in the country can mount sizable group exhibitions of quality composed of entirely local selections. Long Island is one place that can, for it is a singular area with a singularly dense concentration of quality artists.

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events: Noon to midnight. Saratoga Performing Arts Center, Saratoga Springs, N.Y. ''Jazz Kaleidoscope, Part II,'' with Ella Fitzgerald, All-Star Jam Session with George Benson, Herbie Hancock, Wynton Marsalis, Gerry Mulligan, Joe Henderson, Ron Carter, Tony Williams and Bobby McFerrin; Buddy Rich and His Orchestra, Gerry Mulligan and His Orchestra, Pieces of a Dream, Tania Maria Trio, Andrew Cyrille, Sonny Fortune Quartet, Jay McShann Quartet (Jackie Williams, Buddy Tate, Vic Dickenson and Bill Pemberton), Leroy Jenkins Trio, Main Gazane and Don Elliot and Friends.

title:
THEATER IN REVIEW;
THE BARD IS MAKING HIS MARK AT DREW'S FESTIVAL
description: MADISON Ever since Paul Barry's remarkable production of ''The Caretaker,'' which endowed a naturalistic splendor on Harold Pinter's three dowdy suburbanites, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University has experienced a dramatic shift in its artistic fortunes, highlighted by last year's tigerish version of ''Cymbeline.''

title: BALLET: SUZANNE FARRELL IN 'VARIATIONS' PREMIERE
description: Officially, the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Centennial Celebration ended last Sunday. In reality, it has never ended, for all of the company's recent repertory programs at the New York State Theater have featured works to music by Stravinsky, and Friday night's bill consisted entirely of Stravinsky ballets.

title: Sports People; Newman Carries On
description: ''I've got to stop these dangerous sports like jogging,'' Paul Newman, the actor and race-car driver, said after he broke a small bone on the outside of his right foot while jogging last week. Break and all, Newman went out and tackled his favorite sport this weekend, competing in the Kendall Cup Nationals at Lime Rock (Conn.)

title: CAREY CHIDES L.I. OPPONENTS OF PILGRIM PRISON
description: ALBANY When Governor Carey first proposed converting three vacant buildings at the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brentwood into a medium-security prison, a senior corrections aide to the Governor predicted: ''This is just the beginning of a long, tough fight. There is going to be a lot of opposition to this.''

title: FINALLY, AN AMERICAN COUNTACH, AT $95,000
description: After a seven-year absence from the American market, Italy's Lamborghini will return to the United States with its Countach cars later this month. The Countach, which is one of the world's fastest sports cars, has a top speed in excess of 175 miles per hour and, at $95,000, a price tag to match.

title: CONSUMER RATES
NEW JERSEY FIGHTING HAUPTMANN WIDOW ON PROPERTY REQUEST
description: New Jersey officials are opposing a request by the widow of the man executed for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh's son to return personal belongings seized 47 years ago.

title: Around the Nation; California Warns Of Suspect Tomato Cans
description: A can of tomatoes that may be toxic was traced to a shipment to New Jersey and other states across the nation, the California authorities said today.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The audience didn't seem to want to leave when the Gail Conrad/Tap Dance Theater played last at the Jazz Forum. Miss Conrad and her bright and skillful tappers and jazz musicians will be back at that little cabaret for another 14 performances beginning Friday.

title: SHIMATOREE WINS TRUE NORTH
description: Shimatoree, one of only two 3-year-olds in a field of eight, ran one of the fastest six furlongs in the history of Belmont Park yesterday to defeat older horses in the $82,650 True North Handicap.

title: Around the World; Soviet Protester Vows To Resume Fast for Visa
description: A hunger striker who began to eat again when promised an exit visa said today that he would resume his fast until the visa was in hand.

title: 'SAFARI' TO BOSTON'S TOWNIE SECTION
description: Lene Williams, a black woman from Toledo, Ohio, stood in a crisp blue summer suit and a nice perfume as she waited Thursday for her husband, Marshall. She looked out the polished glass front wall of the Sheraton Boston Hotel at the waiting bus, its front door open.

title: A CHILDHOOD SPENT WITH BOOKS
description: Ann Haven Morgan, whose ''Field Book of Ponds and Streams'' fascinated the 11-year-old Annie Dillard, was an acute observer. Her love for the beauty of living things and her detailed knowledge of how inhabitants of inland waters influence one another began in her Connecticut farm childhood.

title: J.R. Richard Impressive In 6-Inning, 4-Hit Stint
description: J.R. Richard, making the second start of his comeback since suffering a stroke two years ago, pitched four-hit ball through six innings of a Florida State League game tonight.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Waugh Revisited

title: QUASH INDICTMENTS, GIBSON, HARRIS ASK
description: NEWARK Attorneys for Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and City Council President Earl Harris are scheduled to appear in Superior Court in Hackensack on Tuesday to argue for the dismissal of the conspiracy and misconduct-in-office indictments against their clients.

title: Around the World; Hijacker of Italian Plane Is Arrested in Sri Lanka
description: The police arrested the Sri Lankan hijacker of an Italian airliner today, ending his two-day spree of high living. A Sri Lankan official said his country would honor its international obligations after an Italian request for the hijacker's extradition.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SURPRISE! SURPRISE! By Lothar Meggendorfer. Unpaged. New York: The Viking Press. $9.95. (All Ages) THE WIZARD OF OZ A Windmill Pop-Up Book. From the story by L. Frank Baum. Illustrated by Karen Avery. Unpaged. New York: Windmill/Simon & Schuster. $7.95. (Ages 3 to 5) THE CROCODILE AND THE DUMPER TRUCK By Ray Marshall, Korky Paul and Sara Sharpe.Unpaged. New York: Atheneum. $10.95. (All Ages) By BARBARA KARLIN

title: Nancy B. Herman Wed
description: Nancy Barbara Herman, an assistant vice president of Bankers Trust Company in New York, was married yesterday to William Sheldon Jarrett Jr., who expects to join Kidder, Peabody & Company, investment bankers in New York, as an associate next month. The Rev. Dr. Peter H. Samson of the Unitarian Community Church in White Plains performed the ceremony at Estherwood, the former estate of the late James Jennings McComb at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Walter L. Herman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Herman. Mr. Jarrett is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jarrett of Newton, Conn.

title: E.P.A. Head Says the Press Distorts Her Role in Agency
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, says she has been the victim of ''inaccuracies and distortions'' in the press that have hindered her in managing the agency.

title: BOARD SAILORS READY FOR REGATTA
description: RYE AT least a half-dozen board-sailing devotees were skimming over the windswept swells of Milton Harbor the other day, preparing for the Big Golden Apple international regatta that will take place off Playland Beach July 10 and 11.

title: For Certain Unalienable Rights
description: The impressive coalition that worked so hard for voting rights can take a rest this Independence Day, justly proud of the strengthened, renewed election bill that became law last week. The civil rights workers, religious groups, lawyers and legislators have given racial and ethnic minorities a new lease on political life, a fresh chance to vote and make their votes count.

title: NASA HOPES ILL WINDS WILL BLOW SOME GOOD
