description: What happens when the 100-ton space shuttle descends toward the earth on a controlled 21-degree descent, levels out, tilts up its nose, and then, just as its wheels are about to kiss the runway at 215 miles an hour, a sharp wind gusts across its path?

title: THE MAN BEHIND A NEW SPORTS SHOW
description: MERRILL GRANT does not watch much television with his wife and children. There are four sets in his house, but none in either the den or the living room, and they frequently go unused.

title: BIG BIRTHDAY CAKE
description: In Atlantic City today, about 200 chefs and chefs-to-be will celebrate the Fourth of July by putting together the world's biggest birthday cake. And for a $2 donation, you are welcome to cheer them on and then have a slice of the cake, which will enter the Guinness Book of World Records.

title: PIRATES WIN SIXTH IN ROW, 4-2
description: Jason Thompson hit a two-run homer and Manny Sarmiento held Montreal to one run in eight innings tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates extended their winning streak to six games with a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Expos. The loss was the fourth in a row for the Expos and their ninth in the last 11 games.

title: Postings; FOLLOW-UP
description: Four months ago, 100 angry homeowners in Bristol, Conn., banded together to protest their soaring mortgage rates. They complained that their bank had not explained to them that in taking out variable-rate mortgages, they were exposing themselves to monthly payment increases of as much as 30 percent a year if interest rates rose.

title: MY BOOKS AND BACKGROUND
description: Asked for some information about himself, John Sanford wrote the following to the Book Review from his home in Santa Barbara: My mother was born on the Lower East Side of New York, and my father came here from Russia as a boy of 5. Both were Jews, and I too am Jewish. He worked for his father, who was a butcher, put himself through law school and became an attorney. I was born in Harlem in 1904, attended the public schools and De Witt Clinton High and, after college, followed my father's lead by studying law at Fordham. I took a degree and was admitted to the New York Bar in 1928, but by then I'd found what I really wanted to do: write. A year or so earlier, I'd fallen in again with a boyhood friend named Nat Weinstein, and when he announced that he was writing a book - writing a book! - I knew that the law had lost me. Nat Weinstein, of course, was Nathanael (Pep) West. We picked up our old friendship, wrote together in hotels and in an Adirondack cabin, published together in the little magazines of the time and even came to Hollywood together in the mid-30's. He stayed with films to earn himself a stake for the writing of future books, but I could never make the grade at the studios and lasted only a little more than a year. By then, though, I'd met Marguerite Roberts, a first-rate screenwriter, and on our marriage in 1938 she sent me home to write my books while she worked for our keep.

title: LITTLE GROWTH IN BONN ARMS BUDGET SEEN
description: Preliminary reports on West Germany's 1983 military budget show that it will once again fall below goals set by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and possibly contain no growth at all.

title: Pitt Boy, $9, Captures $519,000 Pace in Jersey
description: Pitt Boy charged past No Nukes and McKinzie Almahurst in the stretch Friday night and scored an upset victory in the $519,000 New Jersey Classic at the Meadowlands. McKinzie Almahurst held on to finish second, and the odds-on favorite, No Nukes, faded to fourth behind the fast-closing Kildavin.

title: Ellen Walsh To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Walsh of Troy, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen DeLury Walsh, to Randolph Whitehouse Sides, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Sides of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: STALKING NEW TAXES
description: Provisions of a bill to reduce the budget deficit through new taxes were approved by the Senate Finance Committee.

title: ARMCHAIR AIRMAN SAYS FLIGHT FULFILLED HIS LIFELONG DREAM
description: All Larry Walters has as a memento of his three-mile-high flight in a balloon-propelled lawn chair is an empty plastic soda bottle.

title: SOVIET MEN, WOMEN ROUT U.S. IN TRACK
description: The United States-Soviet track and field meet ended today with Sydney Maree winning the 1,500-meter run in incredible time. Not incredibly fast. Incredibly slow.

title: Around the Nation; Federal Agency to Ban Mortgage Assumptions
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has decided to ban homebuyers from taking over the low-interest mortgages it holds.

title: TOWN MARCHES TO SAVE ITS STEEL PLANT
description: Marching bands, veterans, politicians, firemen with Dalmatians, girls with batons and Shriners with midget cars paraded down Main Street here today in happy celebration, not just for their nation's independence but also for this town's effort to buy its steel plant in hopes of preventing its closing.

title: Major News in Summary; Court Draws a Fine Line on Busing Cases
description: Those waiting for the Supreme Court to hand down a sweeping indictment or vindication of busing to achieve school desegregation are waiting still. In the two school busing cases argued this term and decided last week, the Court drew only a delicate line between a legitimate political action and an unconstitutional denial of equal rights by state voters.

title: Playing It Cool; by Betty Fusell Betty Fussell is the author of ''Mabel (Hollywood's First I-Don't-Care Girl).''; Lettuce cooleth the heat of the stomacke.  - JOHN GERARD in ''Herball,'' 1597.
description: Since we Americans have become ''the greatest salad eaters in the world,'' as James Beard has said, ''we ought to be getting more fun out of it.'' A lettuce called iceberg, developed by some smart lettuce breeder, has cooled the heat of our stomachs generation upon generation. A green garden salad of many lettuces is still a sight for hot eyes and parched tongues on a summer's day, but enough already. The Salad Revolution is upon us and, as thousands of saladbar troops have discovered, lettuce is only a dodge to maneuver a full meal onto your plate.

title: 50 YEARS' DEVOTED AID TO DISABLED
description: When Margaret Milbank Bogert was 5 years old, her father took her to visit what was believed to be the first rehabilitation center in the United States. Known then as the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, today it is the International Center for the Disabled, at 340 East 24th Street.

title: AT BAY
description: sided negotiations here last week over the future shape of Lebanon and the Palestinians' place in it, moderate Arab states - led by Saudi Arabia and Egypt - were trying to insure the survival of the P.L.O. leadership, in particular Yasir Arafat. Their hope was that a P.L.O. shorn of any military options against Israel would redirect its energies into a purely diplomatic struggle for an independent Palestinian state.

title: THE EDUCATION OF DAVID STOCKMAN, PART 2
description: Budget director David A. Stockman would probably like to forget about the celebrated Atlantic Monthly article that nearly derailed his career last November by revealing his innermost doubts about the Reagan economic program.

title: LOCAL SPENDING'S SLUMP
description: Corporations and savings and loan associations are not alone in being pummeled by high interest rates and recession. These factors, together with large cuts in Federal assistance during the past two years have also worsened the condition of state and local government balance sheets.

title: NEW YORK STATE THEATER CLOSES FOR RENOVATION
description: No matter how the New York City Ballet performs at its final appearance of the season tonight in the New York State Theater, it will bring down the house, or part of it. The end of the performance will signal the start of a $5.3 million acoustical renovation under the direction of Cyril Harris that is expected to keep the house dark until Aug. 29.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: 1954, edited by Elliott Mossman. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Letters exchanged between the Russian poet and his cousin.

title: IS OURS A SOCIETY THAT IS FOSTERING LONELINESS?
description: TWO recent incidents in my life, both minor and seemingly disparate, have come together in my mind to reinforce my growing impression that we live in a society that fosters human loneliness and alienation.

title: Headliners; Things Money Can't Buy
description: Money talks, but smart money knows when nobody's listening. John S. Dyson, the chairman of the New York State Power Authority, announced last week that he was dropping out of the Democratic race for lieutenant governor.

title: BREWERS WIN, 7-0, TIE FOR FIRST
description: The Milwaukee Brewers pitched and powered their way into a tie for first place with Boston in the American League East by beating the Red Sox, 7-0, tonight. Pete Vuckovich pitched a three-hitter, Cecil Cooper hit two home runs and Paul Molitor and Robin Yount each added a homer for the surging Brewers.

title: Frank H. Adams Is Dead at 64; Ex-Times Circulation Director
description: Frank H. Adams, circulation director for The New York Times from 1973 to 1975, died Friday of a heart attack at his home, Granlyn Farm, in Schaghticoke, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: Cushioning The Feet
description: It's refreshing to see that neglected feet are finally getting the attention they deserve (''The Shock Absorbers,'' by Deborah Blumenthal, May 23).

title: Foreign Affairs; AFTER THE RUBBLE
description: The guns and troops are still there. But four weeks after Israel's invasion, the worst has so far been averted in Beirut. There are signs that some movement has at last begun in men's heads instead of only with their armor.

title: Early Baroque Concerts
description: Two concerts of early Baroque works by Heinrich Schutz and Claudio Monteverdi will open a three-part Baroque festival by the Calliope Singers today.

title: LAKELAND ASSESSES SCHOOL-AID RULING
description: THIS past spring the Lakeland School District, which covers northern Westchester and parts of Putnam County, distinguished itself by getting special permission to put on a production of ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' while the musical was still running on Broadway. Five years ago, however, it made history with a 42-day teachers' strike, the longest ever in New York State.

title: BEGINNINGS AROUND BOSTON...
description: DUDLEY CLENDINEN is a Times national correspondent based in Boston. BY DUDLEY CLENDINEN

title: Diet Pill Maker to Sue Over F.D.A. Decision
description: A major manufacturer of ''starch blocker'' weight control pills says it is suing the Food and Drug Administration to prevent the agency from defining its product as a drug.

title: NEGATIVE SYMBIOSIS
FOR THE SHORE, THE SEASON IS HERE
description: CAPE MAY Strolling through this resort community of magnificent Victorianstyle homes, antiques shops and gaslight street lamps, it is easy for a first-time visitor to get the impression that he has lost his direction and, quite possibly, his sense of time.

title: FLOYD ESTATE OPENS
description: MASTIC BEACH The home of William Floyd, the first member of the New York delegation to sign the Declaration of Independence, was opened to the public for the first time yesterday. Guided tours of the historic residence will be available today, and every weekend until Labor Day, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: COUNTY'S TAX BRINGS WARNING FROM MAYORS
description: AS the county begins to collect part of the sales tax that previously went to Westchester's four largest cities, the mayors are warning that local taxpayers will have to either pay more to support present city services or give up some of those services.

title: Danelle D. Hahn To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Hahn Jr. of Garden City and Centerport, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Danelle Dorothy Hahn, to Bernd Rudiger Kensbock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno Kensbock of Nuremberg, West Germany.

title: Sports of the Times; PETE ROSE REMEMBERS TY COBB
description: SHORTLY after Pete Rose joined the Philadelphia Phillies in 1979, a stadium message board flashed during a game that a teammate had just moved past Johnny Callison in one of the club's career hitting categories. In the dugout, Pete Rose glanced at the message board and smiled.

title: ALASKA HUNTERS SEEK TO END LAW GIVING NATIVES PRIORITY
description: In a last-ditch struggle to hold on in the face of change, Alaska's sports hunters and fishermen have mounted a campaign to overturn a 1978 law that they argue favors the Alaska natives, the descendants of the state's Eskimos, Aleuts and Indians.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Western Roundup.

title: Philip M. Leahey to Marry Carole Frances Alderman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Marvin M. Alderman of Syracuse have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Frances Alderman, to Philip Michael Leahey, son of Hilda Leahey of Sheffield, England, and the late Ernest Joseph Leahey.

title: TO WIN, THE G.O.P. MUST BACK WEICKER
description: THE Republican Party has a marvelous opportunity to win the governorship for the first time since 1970 and only the second time since 1948; win a majority in at least one house of the state legislature, a feat it has not accomplished in 10 years; and perhaps, win as many as four or five seats in Congress, something the Grand Old Party has not dared even dream about since 1956, when President Eisenhower won re-election and carried with him to victory almost every Republican candidate running for office in the state.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HAPPY FOURTH
description: Never let it be said that the Island didn't go all out to celebrate Independence Day. And celebrate many folks will, by watching fireworks, putting a few hot dogs on a backyard grill or joining in mass public festivities.

title: Sports People; All-Star Coaches
description: Managers Jim Fanning of the Montreal Expos, Chuck Tanner of the Pittsburgh Pirates, Sparky Anderson of the Detroit Tigers and Dick Howser of the Kansas City Royals were named to the American and National League coaching staffs for the All-Star Game in Montreal July 13. Joining Fanning and Tanner on the National League team, which will be managed by Tom Lasorda of the Dodgers, will be John McNamara, the Cincinnati Reds' manager; the Reds' coach Joey Amalifitano, and Mark Cresse, the Dodgers' bullpen coach. In addition to Anderson and Howser, who will work with Billy Martin of the Oakland A's, the American League manager, Jackie Moore and Art Fowler of the A's will be the batting practice pitchers for the American League.

title: ARCHEOLOGISTS FIND A BOON IN PINELANDS
description: SMITHVILLE Archeologists laying open the powdery soil of the Pine Barrens are uncovering an ancient and mosaic past that dispels many widely held beliefs contributing to the area's mystique.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BASEL
description: PAUL HOFMANN, author of the recently published ''The Sweet Tempestuous Life'' (Congdon & Lattes), lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: UNTERMYER EVENTS
description: Westchester's only free professional performing arts festival opens Saturday at Untermyer Park in Yonkers. The series will present offerings at 8 P.M. every Saturday until Aug. 21 on the grounds of the restored 24-acre estate once known as ''Greystone.''

title: WORDS AT WAR
description: For the time being, it's settled: The name of the island group is the ''Falklands.'' Argentines (pronounced teens in the Americas, tynes in Britain and on two American networks) may still call it the ''Malvinas,'' but that must be used now in a sentimental or defiant sense.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
At Two Locations, Sewing and Fabric Buys
description: Thirty-two years ago, The English Shop opened in Pelham selling fabrics and sewing machines, including repairs. The site and the management are still the same, but the name was changed five years ago to Simpson's Fabrics.

title: Miss Mortenson Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Mortenson of Charlestown, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Lynn Mortenson, to Andrew H. Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram A. Friedman of Stamford, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: THE REAL PROBLEM: USING DRUGS TO WIN
description: IONLY wish that cocaine use by pro football and basketball players w as the lone drug problem among American athletes. Unfortunately, ther ecreational highs of a group of well-paid, celebrated professionals c onstitute a social problem that pales in comparison with the use of d rugs by amateur athletes whose motivation is not recreation, but r ather performance level.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: GETTING MEXICO MOVING AGAIN
description: The crowd of miners and peasants waited patiently all afternoon as the desert sun inched across an azure sky and disappeared behind the barren mountains that surround Concepcion del Oro. Then suddenly, wailing police cars broke the stillness of provincial Mexico, brass bands came alive, a cheerleader yelled through a microphone, a girls' choir launched into a bolero and onlookers excitedly threw confetti from balconies. El Candidato had arrived.

title: POLITICS ASIDE, WOMEN HAVE A WAY TO GO
description: TIME ran out on the equal rights amendment Wednesday night and it became, as expected, the first proposed constitutional change to be rejected by the states since the child labor amendment, submitted in 1924.

title: A GEM ON THE OCEAN
description: There are houses that are prototypes, and there are houses that are made for one time and one place only. Roger Ferri's recently completed house on the beach at Water Island, N.Y., is clearly of the second type. There are aspects of this small, taut house that offer lessons for houses everywhere, but the essential nature of this design speaks wholly to the calm, light landscape of Water Island, a particularly isolated and tranquil section of that celebrated barrier beach off Long Island known as Fire Island.

title: REBELLIOUS SPIRIT UNITES AMERICA'S EIGHT AND CANADA'S SEVEN
description: HUNTINGTON TO anyone familiar with the history of American art, the group of painters known as The Eight represents the triumph of the rebellious, independent creative spirit over the moribund academic tradition that governed taste in the early years of this century. Men like Robert Henri, John Sloan and George Luks loom large as standard-bearers in the struggle to establish an art that responded boldly and directly to everyday life and reflected the artists' individuality of style and personal vision.

title: Miss Willard, J. J. LaBerge To Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hanford P. Willard of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Christine Willard, to John J. LaBerge, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. LaBerge of Findlay, Ohio.

title: Arsenal to Destroy Bullets
description: The Army's Rocky Mountain Arsenal here plans to incinerate about 30 million rounds of ammunition next year because the bullets are considered contaminated with the pesticide DDT.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Music ManWhy did we invent music? What is it for? What does it do for us, to us and why? These questions, according to Curtis W. Davis, are what ''The Music of Man,'' a new eight-week public-television series, is all about. Yehudi Menuhin, the celebrated violinist, will narrate.

title: Sports of The Times; Endless Dancing In the Streets
description: IN Barcelona, they are dancing in the streets. Almost every day or night in some corner of this Catalan city, the people materialize to perform the Sardana, a stately circular folk dance. Catalonia needs no World Cup to surge with life.

title: DESIGNING A PROPER ENVIRONMENT FOR ART
description: It seemed, in the mid-1970's, as if the postwar surge of museumbuilding was coming to an end. Completion of the ambitious expansion plans of the Metropolitan and the National Gallery was within the foreseeable future. Many smaller institutions, like the Kimbell Museum in Fort Worth, the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, had just finished new buildings. Money was getting tight for everyone, and moreover, there didn't seem to be room for any more museums.

title: HOW TO AFFECT MOSCOW
description: When Leonid I. Brezhnev departs from the Soviet political scene, as he must one of these days, there will be major policy debates in the Kremlin. Their outcome will depend in large part on domestic circumstances, but American actions can tip the balance, significantly affecting critical postsuccession policy choices in the Kremlin. Unfortunately, the Reagan Administration is neither conceptually nor organizationally equipped to influence Moscow's decisions in the United States' interest.

title: Blues and Boogies Given by Jay McShann
description: Jay McShann gave a superb performance for basic but sophisticated jazz Friday afternoon in the Forum Room of the New York Sheraton as part of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: SUMMERMUSIC: 92D ST. Y PRESENTS CHAMBER TREAT
description: Summermusic at the 92d Street Y continued its current series Thursday night with an unusual and interesting evening of chamber music. Eight musicians in various configurations played pieces by Beethoven, Gershwin, Ravel and Schoenberg.

title: 13 Food Outlets in New York Fail City Sanitary Inspection
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 13 restaurants last week for violations of the city's health code. The department also named two restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for failure to do so.

title: Topics; WINGING IT; Stranger in Paradox
description: What joy lights the face of a person who, as she sits down to dinner, swallows starch blockers - those tablets that supposedly permit starch to pass through the body undigested. ''Hah, all the potatoes I can eat, and I'll still be 124 pounds.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING AN EDIBLE LANDSCAPE
description: THERE is concern these days, and rightfully so, about the high cost of living. Somehow food always seems to bear the brunt of the dissatisfaction, although food costs have hovered between 16 and 20 percent of our disposable income for the last 30 years or so.

title: Washington; THE FUNNY FOUNDING FATHERS
description: The Declaration of Independence was submitted to the Second Continental Congress 206 years ago by Richard Henry Lee of Virginia on June 7, 1776, and was passed unanimously, as amended, by ''the 13 United States of America'' 27 days later.

title: 'WORKERS '80,' POLAND'S LABOR TURMOIL
description: ''Workers '80'' is a rare film. It's a 90-minute documentary about the August 1980 negotiations in which Solidarity, the Polish tradeunion movement, won its extraordinary demands that, briefly, achieved independence for Poland's workers and promised to change the nature of the state itself. The film is not only a record of momentous events, but its production was a precondition demanded by Solidarity for its agreement to negotiate the end of its strike against the Polish government.

title: REVOLUTIONARY JUSTICE
description: EARL WARREN A Public Life. By G. Edward White. Illustrated. 429 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Jx FICTION 1 3 5 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 2 1 16 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 3 2 8 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 4 5 4 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 5 4 10 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 6 7 7 FOR SPECIAL SERVICES, by John Gardner. (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $9.95.) James Bond against his old enemy SPECTRE. 7 6 22 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.)

title: FOCUS IS ON OPPOSITION VOTE
description: Mexico will hold general elections Sunday in which the presidential candidate of the long-ruling Government party will for the first time face challenges from nominees of both leftist and rightist parties.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
CANALETTO VERSUS THE CAMERA
description: A good reminder of some of the virtues and vices of photography may be found in the handsome selection of 19th-century views of Italy now on exhibition at Photocollect, 740 West End Avenue at 96th Street. Many of the photographs in this exhibition come from the studios of the most famous photographers of the time and place, among them the Alinari Brothers, James Anderson, Robert MacPherson, Carlo Ponti and Giorgio Sommer. They come in every size and shape, from stereo cards to large panoramas, and they include such diverse types of 19th-century photography as portraiture, genre and local costumes.

title: COUNT BASIE'S ORCHESTRA AND ELLA FITZGERALD
description: The combination of Count Basie's Orchestra and Ella Fitzgerald in two Kool Jazz Festival concerts on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall was more provocative in prospect than in performance - at least, in the night's first performance.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Big BangsAmong the small screen's red-white-and-blue Independence Day programs is ''U.S.S. Intrepid - An American Celebration'' on Channel 5, Sunday evening at 7:30. Chuck Ashman, producer and writer, calls the halfhour show ''a tribute to the U.S. Navy on the occasion of the establishment of the Intrepid as a floating sea, air and space museum in New York.''

title: STABILIZATION PROCESSORS SAVE TIME
Czyz Stops Melon At 1:24 of Round 2
description: The undefeated Bobby Czyz continued his climb in the middleweight division tonight by stopping rugged Manuel Melon at 1 minute 24 seconds of the second round at Ice World Arena.

title: Fire Under IRT Car Disrupts Northbound Subway Service
description: A fire in the undercarriage of a car on an empty subway train yesterday halted service for 90 minutes on the northbound IRT No. 1, 2 and 3 lines from Chambers Street to West 96th Street, a spokesman for the Transit Authority said.

title: Palenque
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Listen In on Landing
description: Telephone calls allowing people across the nation to listen in on conversations between Mission Control and the space shuttle's astronauts are expected to rise Sunday. The calls costs 50 cents for the first minute and 35 cents for each succeeding minute from all states but Alaska, where it costs 50 cents a minute. The special phone number is 900-410-6272.

title: Rod Dixon Takes 10,000-Meter Race
description: Rod Dixon of New Zealand broke away in the final two miles to get ''a feather in my cap'' and win the Pepsi Challenge 10,000-meter national championship over the roads of upper Manhattan yesterday.

title: Spyro Gyra Appears With David Sanborn
description: The contemporary pop side of jazz was represented Friday at the jazz fesitval with two shows at Avery Fisher Hall featuring the upstate sextet Spyro Gyra and the alto saxopohonist David Sanborn. Neither act acquitted itself with much distinction.

title: ARTS COUNCIL EXPLAINS WHERE 'RICHES' LIE
description: We appreciate the generous coverage given to the Westport-Weston Arts Council in the Connecticut Weekly section on June 6. However there was one serious omission, in that the dedicated Theater Committee chairmen, Marcella Cisney and Ellen Rovins, who are responsible for this outstanding theater series, were not mentioned.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE sun is hanging high over the shoulder these days, and it's time to dust off the old camera once again for summer. After a rainy spring, the photography season is off to a late start, but, depending on how much you like to take pictures, better late than never. Long Island, in all its many beauties, sits there mugging through the trees, smiling through the surf, waiting for the lens to click.

title: THE DREAM OF 'ONE CANADA' IS MIRED IN ONE BIG MESS
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau embarked last week on a ''crusade'' to end Canada's 12 percent inflation and the worst economic crisis since the Depression of the 1930's. To succeed, he will need unaccustomed cooperation from skeptical Canadians. He seems confident of getting it: When a reporter asked if he had perhaps lost political effectiveness after more than 13 years as Prime Minister, Mr. Trudeau replied coldly, ''No, I haven't given that any thought.''

title: WAGING CORPORATE WAR BY PROXY
description: FOR the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, it was a stunning defeat. Less than two weeks before its annual meeting, the company found out that Alan E. Clore, a British investor, was waging a proxy fight for control of the ailing mining and chemicals concern. Almost before Gulf Resources's top executives could catch their breath, they were ousted in one of the fastest proxy contests on record.

title: Elizabeth L. Van de Mark Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Walton 3d of Toronto and Beaumaris, Ont., and Phoenix, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Walton's daughter, Elizabeth Louise Van de Mark, to Joseph Vincent Gallagher 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Gallagher of Mount Kisco N.Y., East Hampton, L.I., and Eleuthera, Bahamas.

title: KEAN'S ROCKY HONEYMOON
description: The first six months of the Kean administration have ended in a bitter dispute between New Jersey's Republican Governor and the Democratic leadership in the Legislature over the enactment of a $6.18 billion budget.

title: INVESTING
description: UNLIKE so many of the nation's money managers, Leo Dworsky has no n eed for the ritual known as window dressing at the end of each q uarter. In fact, last month, as the maneuvering to sweeten up r eports to clients was in full swing, Mr. Dworsky bought some 35,000 s hares of Schlumberger, an oil-services stock that was one of the b iggest losers of the season. He filled his order at about $36 a s hare, some 50 points below where it was trading only nine months a go.

title: VARICOSE VEINS
description: Varicose veins, a potentially troublesome medical problem, afflict millions of Americans. One of mankind's earliest recorded ailments - varicosis is mentioned in the world's first medical book, an Egyptian papyrus from 1500 B.C. - its causes remain enigmatic to modern medicine.

title: REMEMBRANCES FROM PHOTOGRAPHS PAST
description: IRECEIVED an invitation not long ago to the 50th-anniversary celebration of my mother's cousins, and I have saved it with my other mementos for one reason - the outside ''cover'' of the invitation is a reproduction of the cousins' original wedding picture. A bit fuzzyfocused and fragile-looking, the picture portrays a lovely young bride and groom whose features are unmistakably and immediately recognizable as those of the cousins, Sarah and Max. Whenever I'm in a nostalgic mood, I take out the invitation and look at that 50-yearold wedding picture. Other photographs, even more important to my own life, flash before me, and I realize how significant pictures have become to me.

title: PATIENCE WITH ISRAEL IS RUNNING OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: RISA CATHY SHEER TO BE WED
description: Sandra Sheer of Great Neck, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Risa Cathy Sheer, to Howard Scott Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Goldberg of Fair Lawn, N.J. An October wedding is planned. The future bride, daughter also of the late Jerry Sheer, is relocation consultant with Area Consultants Inc., in New York. Mr. Goldberg is a rating officer in the corporate finance department of the Standard & Poor's Corporation in New York.

title: WITH HAIG LEAVING, REAGAN CLOSES A COMPATIBLE INNER CIRCLE
description: By tradition, the departure of a Secretary of State is a time of frantic damage control exercises at the White House. But among President Reagan's key aides last week the dominant mood was relief. For with the resignation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Mr. Reagan was at last free to construct a corral of cordiality around the Oval Office. Its main stanchions are four easygoing Westerners -counselor Edwin Meese 3d, chief of staff James A. Baker 3d, deputy chief of staff Michael K. Deaver and national security adviser William P. Clark. The ascent of these three Californians and a lone Texan, Mr. Baker, shows that, for better or worse, Mr. Reagan intends to surround himself with advisers who make him feel comfortable.

title: CELEBRATING THE BARRYMORE LEGACY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Harvey is coordinator of special film projects at the Museum of Modern Art Department of Film. By STEPHEN HARVEY

title: LENNY, OF COURSE, AT CENTER STAGE
description: FAMILY MATTERS Sam, Jennie, and the Kids. By Burton Bernstein. Illustrated. 200 pp. New York: Summit Books. $13.95. By JUSTIN KAPLAN

title: Talking Buydowns; SWEETENING THE DEAL ON A HOUSE
description: MENTION the word ''buydown'' and most people would wonder just what y ou're talking about. Someone seeking to buy or sell a house or c ooperative has probably heard the term, but its precise meaning and a pplication for the individual might elude him.

title: Postings; ICEHOUSE COMETH
description: For those who find the rubble that once was the Helen Hayes and the Morosco Theaters a sad spectacle, there is a bit of cheering news up in Yorkville. A new theater, though far off Broadway, is being carved out of a former icehouse at 316 East 91st Street.

title: ASBURY PARK WEIGHS OCEANFRONT PROJECT
description: A proposal by private entrepreneurs to purchase and redevelop virtually the entire oceanfront of this aging seaside resort has city officials in a quandary.

title: AND NOW, A GLUT YOU CAN EAT
description: Among many farmers in the wheat and corn belt who were around in the 1960's - a time of abundant harvests and plunging incomes - there has in recent weeks been a clear feeling that history is repeating itself.

title: THE BEARER OF BAD NEWS HAS FEWER FRIENDS
description: WASHINGTON SPEAKER THOMAS P. O'NEILL Jr. approached Alice Rivlin at a cocktail party last winter and asked her to predict the inflation rate in the months ahead. Did the Speaker have any particular month in mind? she asked. ''How about November?'' the highly political Massachussetts Democrat said, referring to the Congressional elections.

title: EXPLOSIVES INJURE TEEN-AGER IN HOME ON UPPER WEST SIDE
description: A 16-year-old high school student with a strong interest in chemistry was critically injured yesterday when explosives he was experimenting with went off in his Upper West Side apartment, the police said.

title: The Region in Summary; It May Be a Hot Day in December Before Fares Rise
description: With a projected deficit of $210 million and a working but worn mass transit system, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority just may have been forgiven for raising subway, bus and commuter fares. But its officials, and state politicians, were taking no chances.

title: THE SECRET WORLD OF A GREEN BERET
description: The first call came on a muggy July evening in 1977. Luke Thompson, a master sergeant in the Army Special Forces, was at home in Fayetteville, N.C. The caller identified himself as Pat Loomis from Washington and asked if Thompson might be interested in recruiting a team of former Green Berets for an overseas mission that would pay well. Loomis provided no other information. Thompson conditionally accepted the proposal, not knowing that he was about to become involved in one of the strangest and most disturbing operations in the annals of international espionage.

title: F.C. Strasburger, Caroline Coleman Will Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Simmons Coleman of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Comstock Coleman, to the Rev. Frank Charles Strasburger, son of Charles Milton Strasburger of Baltimore, and the late Mrs. Strasburger.

title: Franz Schager Marries Sarah S. Meyer on L.I.
description: Sarah Symington Meyer, widow of Charles Garrison Meyer, was married yesterday to Franz Schager, a retired insurance broker and lawyer. The Rev. Bruce Rodgers performed the ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: ERADICATING THE 'P.L.O. DISEASE'
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Early Risers''Ron Steinman (an NBC 'Today' producer) had the idea for the ('Early Today') show during the inauguration in Washington in 1981. We were driving in at 5:30 in the morning to go to work because we're on the air at 7 o'clock and we see all these cars - a big traffic jam. He said, 'You know what we we need to do?' And I said, 'What?' And he said, 'We ('Today') need to start early.' That's why it all started and with an assist from our friends at ABC we did it.''

title: TRIPS UNDERWATER, GLOBAL AND ON FOOT; A Scuba Course On St. Martin
description: In the waters off the island of St. Martin in the West Indies lie the ruins of the British frigate H.M.S. Proselyte, which sank in 1801. Among the reef fish and the coral, visitors may still see the ship's cannon and anchors. The site where the ship lies is the sort of destination reserved for qualified scuba divers. And those who head for St. Martin this summer without qualification have the opportunity to return as certified divers.

title: PARENT-SUPPORT GROUPS GROW IN COUNTRY
description: ONE parent compared it to talking over the fence to a neighbor: complaining about his child being out until daybreak and exclaiming in exasperation, ''I don't know what I'm going to do with that kid,'' then getting understanding and some practial advice from the neighbor's experience with his own children.

title: Serpico's Child
description: Frank Serpico, the former New York City police officer whose fight against corruption in the Police Department in the 1960's led to hearings, reforms and a movie, was back in the news in a paternity case last year when a Family Court judge ordered him to pay $790 a month in support for a child he said he was tricked into fathering.

title: WASHINGTON AND MARY PHILIPSE: THE ROMANTIC LEGEND PERSISTS
description: HE was 24, a brash and promising young military officer, although his career had already been marked by setbacks and frustrations. When the opportunity arose, he enjoyed indulging himself in fine clothes, cards and the companionship of women. He longed to settle into the life of a gentleman.

title: POWER AUTHORITY PROPOSING RATE CUT FOR HYDROELECTRICITY CUSTOMERS
description: A 5 percent decrease in electricity rates was proposed this week by the chairman of the State Power Authority for about 2.6 million customers served by the authority's two large hydroelectric plants, the Niagara Project and the St. Lawrence-Franklin D. Roosevelt Project.

title: FUNNY THINGS TO THINK ABOUT AND EAT
description: UNCIVIL LIBERTIES By Calvin Trillin. 206 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $10.95. WAITING FOR DESSERT By Vladimir Estragon. 227 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Quintuplets Born in Mexico
description: A Mexican bottle washer's wife who already has six children gave birth to quintuplets, but one died and another has little chance of survival, hospital officials said today. Three of the infants, girls weighing about two pounds each, were in good condition following the Caesarean delivery on Thursday at the Social Security Institute hospital in San Luis Potosi, 260 miles north of here. The mother, Guadalupe Jimenez, 35, was reported in good condition.

title: TAXING COMMUTERS TO RAISE REVENUE
description: HARTFORD ''THEY'LL be laughing at us tonight in the cocktail parties in Albany,'' Thom Serrani told his Senate colleagues, as the debate opened last Monday on whether to overturn the Governor's veto of a commuter tax on New Yorkers. ''We're doing their work for them,'' the Stamford Democrat said, lamenting that William A. O'Neill's veto was nearly certain to be upheld.

title: SWAN SONG FOR INDEPENDENTS
description: The independent producer is getting unprecedented exposure on public television these days. WNET/Channel 13 is carrying, in addition to occasional one-shot specials, a slew of series featuring the works of independents: ''Non Fiction Television,'' ''Independent Focus,'' ''Matters of Life and Death,'' ''U.S. Chronicle'' and ''Video/ Film Review.'' Yet, an air of uneasiness permeates the overall picture. A recent public forum sponsored by the Association of Independent Video and Filmmakers, Inc., opened with the observation that what is happening now could be either the beginning of a new era of production expansion or the swan song for the close relationship between independents and public television. Two major problems were perceived by most of the speakers: budget cutbacks within public television itself, and a general political climate that occasionally seems less tolerant of views outside the official boundaries of the Reagan Administration.

title: The World in Summary; New 'Urgency' on Namibia Talks
description: Namibians can be forgiven if they are not holding their breath awaiting the outcome of new talks at the United Nations this week about their long-contested territory. Over the past five years, several breakthroughs have been announced; each time, ''obstacles'' developed and the country's one million people, most of them black, still remain under South Africa's white rule.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR FRIENDSHIP BETWEEN U.S. AND CANADA
description: The 50th anniversary of the International Peace Garden, which straddles the border of Canada and the United States and is located at the geographic center of the longest unfortified border in the world, is being commemorated by a just-issued 20-cent stamp from the United States.

title: Still More Gospel
description: To the Business Editor: Those who agree or disagree with Harvard Professors Hayes and Abernathy in ''Management Gospel Gone Wrong'' (May 30) will find themselves in accord if they will consider one all-encompassing thought:

title: PAN AM WINS AIRPORT CONTRACT
description: FOLLOWING a controversial challenge by Lockheed Air Terminal, Pan American World Services is expected to sign a contract this week renewing for five years its position as operator of the Westchester County Airport.

title: New York Times Magazine July 4, 1982
description: William Safire 6 On Language Words at War Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Where Are Your Children? Robert W. Stock 12 Bands on the March There's nothing like the oompah of a band to stir the spirit. The American band has made a comeback, and on this Fourth of July, more than ever, our streets and parks will be alive with ruffles and flourishes.

title: THE SCENE SHIFTS OUT-OF-DOORS
description: ALTHOUGH weather conditions may not have confirmed it with much sunny eloquence, summer has arrived once again. During the more-severe seasons, most of us encounter our art experiences on the inside, staring at wall after wall of paintings and/or photographs or floor after floor of sculptures.

title: Sports People; Furor Over Draftee
description: The Chicago Bulls, using the seventh selection in the National Basketball Association college draft last Tuesday, selected Quintin Dailey of San Francisco. But the Bulls did not anticipate the furor among the fans and the press that would be caused by the selection of the best guard in the draft.

title: News Summary; News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 4, 1982
description: International West Beirut was sealed off by Israeli armored troops that moved into Beirut to take up positions at the so-called Green Line, which separates the Christian-controlled east side from the Palestinian strongholds in the west. At the same time artillery fire erupted between Israeli forces and Palestinian guerrillas on the southern outskirts. The Israeli move appeared designed to force the Palestine Liberation Organization and its guerrillas to leave western Beirut. Meanwhile, negotiations made some progress with an agreement that a multinational force would ultimately be deployed in western Beirut alongside the Lebanese Army when it is allowed to enter. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: 2 SUMMER FESTIVALS
description: WITH Caramoor well on its way after a splendid concert last weekend, and Lyndhurst in full swing after yesterday's opening night, it is time to look at two other Westchester festivals: Summerfare, beginning its third year in residence at the State University of New York at Purchase on Wednesday, and the Untermyer Performing Arts Festival, celebrating its fifth anniversary on Saturday with the first of seven free programs in Yonkers.

title: IKE'S 18TH-CENTURY SCOTTISH CASTLE
description: ISRAEL SHENKER is most recently the author of ''In the Footsteps of Boswell and Johnson'' (Houghton Mifflin). By ISRAEL SHENKER

title: Major News in Summary; A Book Is Closed On Donovan
description: At times the smoke fairly billowed, but in the end no fire was found. After a six month investigation into charges that Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan had witnessed an illegal labor payoff and had ties to organized crime, special prosecutor Leon Silverman said last week that there was ''insufficient credible evidence'' to bring Mr. Donovan to trial.

title: SLOWDOWNS AND SICKOUTS OVER, KOCH REPORTS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that city services had returned to normal after a day of rule-book slowdowns and other job actions by police officers, firefighters and other uniformed workers protesting the city's last offer in stalemated labor negotiations.

title: WOODY BASKS IN THE HOMESTRETCH
description: IT has been going on for almost 20 years: Woodford Cefis Stephens, j ust plain Woody to his stable help and his millionaire clients, s tarts to think about retiring. He says he wants to travel a little, t ake it slow. He'd like a change from getting up at 5 o'clock every m orning with the thoroughbreds he trains and then spending all day att he races and most of the evening talking about the horses with theiro wners. Each autumn, as the leaves turn and the excitement of the r acing season begins to wane, retirement starts to sound very good toW oody Stephens.

title: Arts Council Explains Where 'Riches' Lie
description: Thanks and appreciation to John J. Geoghegan 3d and The New York Times for the informative article about the Westport-Weston Arts Council (''Arts Group of Westport-Weston Enjoys Its Success,'' June 6). As a member of the board of the council, I would like to make a few additions to the article so that a more balanced picture might emerge for Times readers who are not familiar with the organization and the reasons for its success.

title: PAIRED FOR LIFE
description: When the Rev. Sung Myung Moon married 4,000 of his young followers - most of whom he had selected for each other - in a mass ceremony at Madison Square Garden, he did little to dispel the anxiety he causes their parents. He did, however, provide social science with an opportunity.

title: PALESTINIANS, BRISTLING WITH ARMS, WAIT FOR ISRAELIS NEAR WEST BEIRUT
description: It takes only one trip to the Palestinian guerrillas' forward position on the southern outskirts of Beirut to understand why the Israeli Army is reluctant to invade the Lebanese capital.

title: FAIRCHILD IS GIVEN MILITARY CONTRACT
description: The Fairchild-Republic Corporation has been awarded a contract to build 650 trainer planes for the Air Force.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING AN EDIBLE LANDSCAPE
description: THERE is concern these days, and rightfully so, about the high cost of living. Somehow food always seems to bear the brunt of the dissatisfaction, although food costs have hovered between 16 and 20 percent of our disposable income for the last 30 years or so.

title: Ballesteros Leads
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain shot a two-under-par 69 today for the lead halfway through the raindelayed $140,000 Scandinavian Open golf championship. Ballesteros, the defending champion, has a total of 137, five under par, and a one-stroke lead over Bob Byman of the United States and Jaime Gonzales of Brazil, who shot 69's.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages)NEW YORK Week of June 28 Week of June 21 Week of April 5 Conventional 16.89 16.79 17.03 Rollovers 16.64 16.65 16.79 Adjustable Rate 16.36 16.34 16.51 Source: HSH AssociatesNEW JERSEY Conventional 16.80 16.59 16.99 Rollovers 16.46 16.43 16.70 Adjustable Rate 16.35 16.36 16.51 Source: HSH AssociatesCONNECTICUT Conventional 17.29 17.18 17.63 Rollovers 17.06 17.00 17.00 Adjustable Rate 16.51 16.51 16.00 Source: The Millard Group Inc.CO-OPS (N.Y.C) Conventional 18.08 18.08 18.25 Rollovers 16.75 16.75 17.29 Adjustable Rate 16.98 17.05 17.32 Source: HSH Associates

title: Johncock Holds Lead For Race Driver Award
description: Gordon Johncock, the Indianapolis 500 winner, was the unanimous first choice of panel members in secondquarter balloting for auto racing's driver of the year award, which is sponsored by Olsonite.

title: TWO ISLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSS'S SON ON TEAM
description: WEST HAVEN A FEW weeks ago while the Bristol Red Sox were mired in a mild slump, the shortstop, Jackie Gutierrez, called out to Marc Sullivan, the catcher, from the back of the team bus, ''Hey, Hayward, you better call up your dad and have him send us some new bats.''

title: 'Now's the Time' Sets A Jazz Festival Theme
description: ''Now's the Time,'' the title of one of Charlie Parker's earliest recordings, served as the somewhat ambiguous umbrella for three groups and a singer-pianist in a jazz festival concert in Carnegie Hall late Thursday afternoon. Participants were a well-established group, the eight-year-old Heath Brothers Quintet, the equally established but less firmly set James Moody Quartet, a new Chico Hamilton group and Amina Claudine Myers, moving out of the avant-garde settings in which she is customarily heard.

title: One-Hour Piano Recital Played by Mal Waldron
description: Mal Waldron's solo piano recital Tuesday for the Kool Jazz Festival in the Forum Room of the New York Sheraton was a strangely introverted affair. Mr. Waldron spent 50 minutes of his one-hour program mulling over a series of bits and pieces - rising passages, falling passages, fast passages, slow passages and interludes of heavy thumping - that were strung out in repetitious fashion without apparent development and only a superficial sense of movement.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: CABARET Three-and-a-half years ago, Jackie Cain and Roy Kral made an impressive departure from the style and repertory they had been cultivating very successfully for more than 30 years. After three decades of singing crisp, flippant, ironic, witty duets of Rodgers and Hart, the Gershwins, Fran Landesman and Tommy Wolf, and scat singing these and other standard jazz songs, they turned to the work of Stephen Sondheim.

title: ISRAEL MAY NOT DEMAND MULTINATIONAL FORCE
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel might not demand the deployment of a multinational force along the Lebanese border if some security arrangement can be achieved with the Government of Lebanon.

title: GENIUS AND SUPERGENIUS
description: FRIDAY By Robert A. Heinlein. 368 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95. By H.BRUCE FRANKLIN

title: HEPWORTHS IN A PARK
description: MOUNTAINVILLE SEEN in a gallery or against architecture, the bronzes and carvings of Barbara Hepworth look cool and eminently civilized. Each form connects faultlessly with its neighbor, surfaces are tightly controlled (the sculptor learned much of her trade in Rome from an Italian carver named Ardini) and the character of the work demonstrably owes a great deal to Brancusi, Arp and certain Constructivists.

title: 6 CROATION NATIONALISTS GIVEN LONG PRISON TERMS BY JUDGE
description: Prison terms of 20 to 40 years have been imposed on six Croatian nationalists convicted in Manhattan of Federal charges involving murder, arson and extortion.

title: Penny, Penny, Who's Got a Penny?
description: With the the continuing scarcity of copper coins still evident in many communities, Greenport is to be commended for deciding that ''Time's Up for the Penny Meter.'' It makes good sense not to hoard cents.

title: Sanction Is Withheld For 900 Bowling Series
description: The American Bowling Congress has ruled against sanctioning a perfect 900 series rolled in mixed-league play by a former professional bowler.

title: 18 HOUSING AUTHORITIES SUE U.S. OVER $500 MILLION IN UNPAID AID
description: Eighteen public housing authorities, including New York City's, are suing the Federal Government for $500 million, which they say represents unpaid subsidies appropriated by Congress for fiscal year 1982.

title: SUFFOLK STUDYING ROBINS I. SALE CONTRACT
description: Suffolk County is investigating a reported $6 million contract between two development concerns for the purchase of Robins Island, a 440-acre, undeveloped island in Peconic Bay.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Laying Down the Law on Guns
description: San Francisco last week became the first big American city to ban handguns, though the ordinance is expected to have more symbolic value than deterrent effect on crime.

title: FINANCIAL DISTRICT TAKES PRECAUTIONS IN FIGHT AGAINST CRIME
description: New York Telephone Company security guards go out on the street to watch employees leaving an early or a late shift make their way from the company's 140 West Street tower to the transit facilities in the World Trade Center.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Department to Enter Case of Stored Fetuses
description: The Department of Health and Human Services is investigating a discovery of 17,000 fetuses and embryos in a cargo container, Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ACOUNTY call for nuclear arms reduction, scheduled for a vote by the Board of Legislators last Monday, was returned to committee after an anti-weapons group was given a chance to argue for stiffening the measure.

title: PROSPECTS
description: After the Soviet Pipeline

title: Judith A. Packer Becomes a Bride
description: In Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, N.J., yesterday Judith Anne Packer and James Vijayaseelan Jesudason, 1978 graduates of Wesleyan University, were married by the Rev. William H. Strain.

title: MOSCOW SCOWLS AND BEARS IT
description: MOSCOW AT least in the short-term, Israel's invasion of Lebanon appears to have been a military and political debacle for the Soviet Union. The Israelis have routed the forces of Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, the main centers of Soviet influence in the Middle East. With 6,000 P.L.O. guerrillas facing extinction in west Beirut, Soviet diplomacy has been reduced to hunting for a fresh refuge for Yasir Arafat and his surviving fighters.

title: Clinton Kanaga Weds Miss Elmer
description: Victoria Elmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Basil Elmer of Somerset, Bermuda, and Orleans, Mass., was married yesterday to Clinton Richard Kanaga, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Smith Kanaga of Orleans. The Rev. H. Arthur Lane Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Chapel of the Holy Paraclete in Orleans.

title: South Korea Wins Title
description: South Korea won seven gold medals today to place first in the overall standings as the Asian Amateur Boxing Championships closed its eight-day run. The runner-up was Thailand, which won three gold medals, followed by India, which won two.

title: POP: A HERO AT BOTTOM LINE
description: With his critically praised debut album climbing the charts, Marshall Crenshaw has become this year's hometown rock-and-roll hero. And at the Bottom Line, where he played two sold-out shows Wednesday, Mr. Crenshaw pretty much lived up to all the adulation.

title: ...BUT VIRGINIA WAS FIRST
description: EDWARD B. FISKE is the education editor of The New York Times. BY EDWARD B.FISKE

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: ACQUAINTANCES SAW ANOTHER STRACHAN
description: People who know Mike Strachan say they cannot believe it, cannot believe that someone with such a likable style could somehow now stand accused of being a drug pusher. Nonetheless, that is the charge.

title: THE CONSTITUTION DOES NOT GRANT PRESIDENTIAL IMMUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE:4-PART 'WHORL' GIVEN BY LEE NAGRIN
description: Lee Nagrin dreamed with her eyes open in ''Whorl,'' her ambitious mixed-media event presented Wednesday night at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery by Interart Theater and the Silver Whale Art Foundation. The four-part piece with music by Richard Isen utilized both the inside and the outside of St. Mark's and the action was spread throughout the garden and on both sides of the sanctuary.

title: INSANE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN TWO VERDICTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN LAG IN SEEKING TECHNICAL JOBS
description: WOMEN and girls are shutting themselves out of one of the Island's largest and most lucrative job markets by continuing to steer away from technical and scientific occupations, education and business leaders have warned.

title: A TASTE OF JAPANESE DANCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ruby Shang, who was born in Japan, is a dancer and choreographer working in New York. By RUBY SHANG

title: THEATER: COMEDY IN SPANISH
description: An evening of fun awaits the visitor to the new production by the Spanish Repertory Theater of Emilio Carballido's ''Te Juro Juana, Que Tengo Ganas,'' (''I Swear to You, Juana, I Want to ...''). It helps enormously to know Spanish, but it is not mandatory to appreciate the show as theatrical comedy ingeniously staged and vivaciously performed.

title: COMEDY OF THE AGES IF NOT FOR THE AGES
description: EAST FARMINGDALE THE screenplays of Samson Raphaelson (most notably, ''Heaven Can't Wait,'' ''Suspicion'' and ''The Shop Around the Corner'') have outlasted his plays. ''Accent on Youth,'' a stage comedy that had a moderate success in 1934, is an idle curiosity, rarely revived and barely revivable. The Arena Players Repertory Theater production, which lasts through Sunday, shows us why.

title: CITING POOR HEALTH, REPUBLICAN ENDS BID IN CONNECTICUT RACE
description: Edward M. Donahue, considered the leading Republican candidate for Congress in western Connecticut's Fifth District, suddenly dropped out of the race today, citing health problems.

title: Nelson, Weiskopf Share Lead
description: Larry Nelson birdied the final hole today to tie Tom Weiskopf as the pair moved past the faltering Bob Gilder into the lead after three rounds of the $350,000 Western Open.

title: Melinda Blauvelt, E. E. Wells Jr. Wed
description: The marriage of Melinda Blauvelt, a photographer, to Edwin E. Wells Jr., an investment banker specializing in oil and gas mergers and acquisitions, took place in Keene, Va., yesterday. The Rev. Peter T. Way performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: ART ''Sadly, this man has not benefited from evolution,'' reads the caption on a postcard size image of a Cro-Magnon man. Another shows a tiny, neat house collaged on a background of ravenous prehistoric monsters; an accompanying legend warns the viewer, ''Stay at Home.''

title: KEEP THE PROS OUT OF COLLEGES
description: BROWN University's president, Howard R. Swearer, proposed some time ago that big college athletic programs be turned into professional or semiprofessional farm teams (''An Ivy League President Looks at College Sports,'' The New York Times, Feb. 21). The idea has been batted around over the years, but not until recently has it been taken seriously. When you stop to think about the actual mechanics of professional athletic teams' coexisting with a university and competing under the school's colors, the idea becomes unrealistic.

title: POP: JOAN BAEZ'S VOICE
description: The one thing that was indisputably right about Joan Baez's concert at the Dr Pepper Festival Wednesday was her voice. After two decades of public singing, Miss Baez's soprano is as strong and distinctive as it ever was.

title: HAS OUR MUSIC ATTAINED A NEW MATURITY?
description: The Fourth of July is the day we set aside for our annual celebration of all things American. That includes American music, and our summer national festivity has traditionally included patriotic musical effusions of one sort or another.

title: NETTLES STARS
description: Near the beginning and near the end, there was the big inning. The Yankees scored in bunches tonight to beat the Indians, 10-6, in a game that seemed lost more than once.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SINCE the mid-1950's, the Federal Government has financed a program to control infestations of golden nematodes in East End potato fields. Now the program is in trouble and some potato growers are worried, since $1.7 million in Federal funds runs out in October and the current Federal budget provides no funds for the program next year.

title: Drug Tests Planned For Saints Players
description: At least eight players for the New Orleans Saints, including the All-Pro running back George Rogers, will be asked to undergo tests to determine if they have drug or drinking problems, Fred Williams, the team president, said Friday.

title: SHALL WE OVERCOME?
description: LOVE, the song tells us, is better the second time around. Protest marches are not. I'm 48 years old and off on another round of citizen activism, fighting for causes still important to me, doing battle in wars already fought, once almost won.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: IN THE last 14 years, Leonard Soucy has nursed thousands of ailing and wounded birds back to health in the aviary hospital behind his home in Millington, in Morris County. However, none of his rehabilitation projects has been quite as satisfying as the bald eagle that he and his wife, Diane, recently brought back from near death.

title: Sports Festival Flame Lighted on Pikes Peak
description: The National Sports Festival flame, lighted at the top of 14,000-foot Pikes Peak near here today, began its way across the nation to Indianapolis for the opening ceremonies of the festival on July 23.

title: POINTERS ON PHOTOGRAPHING THE LUNAR ECLIPSE
description: On Tuesday night, at a few minutes past midnight (which will actually be in the wee hours of Wednesday morning), there will be a total eclipse of the moon and photographers will have a good opportunity to take pictures of one of nature's most interesting exhibitions. Before trying to give some pointers to those planning to photograph this event, it would be useful to understand exactly what happens when an eclipse occurs.

title: CANDIDATE PONDERS A LOST RACE AND PUBLIC SPIRIT
description: IRECENTLY ran in a local school board election and lost by more than two to one. I never had a chance and I knew it. The question is: Why did I enter the race in the first place?

title: WORRY GROWS OVER UPHEAVAL AS TECHNOLOGY RESHAPES JOBS
description: As new computer-based technologies are installed to improve productivity and reduce labor costs, there is growing concern about whether the nation will create the number of jobs it needs, in regions where they are most needed and at wage levels to which many people have been accustomed.

title: PERPETUAL MEXICAN FIESTA
description: ALAN RIDING is chief of the Mexico City bureau of The New York Times. BY ALAN RIDING

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: REAGAN AIDES MAKING THE MOST OF SHUTTLE LANDING
description: President Reagan's trip to Edwards Air Force Base to watch the landing of the space shuttle Columbia on Sunday promises to be a transcendent moment for the planners of White House photographic opportunities.

title: Q&A
description: Question:In keeping with current economic trends I am looking for ways to economize on my vacation plans, and one possibility seems obvious - a house exchange. Could you please supply the names of house exchange organizations? - E.D., Princeton, N.J. Answer:One of the largest organizations is the Vacation Exchange Club (350 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10013; 212-966-2576). In two directories published in February and April each year the club has about 6,000 listings. To be listed and to receive two directories costs $21.

title: PENSION BENEFITS ON THE CHOPPING BLOCK
description: The tax advantages of incorporating have for years proved irresistible to doctors and lawyers, who formed their own professional corporations just so they could set up more generous pensions than if they were self-employed. But the Government has lost millions of dollars in tax revenue as a result, and now a controversial bill has been introduced in the House of Representatives that would drastically curtail the tax benefits of incorporation.

title: MARTINA NAVRATILOVA TAKES WIMBLEDON TITLE
description: Martina Navratilova solidified her claim to the No. 1 spot in women's tennis by beating Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-1, 3-6, 6-2, today for her third Wimbledon singles title.

title: MOTIVATING THE HELP
description: CORPORATE CULTURES The Rites and Rituals of Corporate Life. By Terrence E. Deal and Allan A. Kennedy. 232 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Co. $14.95.

title: Two Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: SEASHORE SHOW HAS NAUTICAL MOTIF
description: STONE HARBOR THE pursuit of collectibles over the Fourth of July weekend need not end on the beach, especially if the jaunt is to this Cape May County resort.

title: SundaySports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland. On the final day of voting for the All-Star Game, the Yankees' Bucky Dent leads at shortstop and Willie Randolph trails Bobby Grich of the Angels at second base. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens. Steve Carlton (10-7) lost his first four decisions, including two to the Mets the first week of the season. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240, 1:30 P.M.) Boxing Aaron Pryor vs. Akio Kameda. At Riverfront Coliseum, Cincinnati. The W.B.A. junior welterweight title bout is scheduled for 15 rounds. Pryor is 30-0 with 28 knockouts, the last 21 in a row, and makes his fifth title defense against No.1-ranked Kameda, 17-0 with 13 knockouts. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) North American championships. Finals at Las Vegas, Nev. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) Soccer World Cup: France vs. Northern Ireland; Poland vs. Soviet Union. Poland needs at least a tie to advance. (Television - Channel 41, 11 A.M. and 2:45 P.M.) Strikers vs. Tulsa Roughnecks, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, Elmont, L.I., 1 P.M. Gato del Sol, the Kentucky Derby winner, and Aloma's Ruler, winner of the Preakness, are scheduled to run in the $125,000 added Suburban Handicap. The topweight is a 4-year-old, It's The One.

title: PLANNING PICNICS IS A NECESSITY
description: ASSUMING that the weather cooperates, it is time for picnics. Excursions to parks and beaches, to sporting events and outdoor concerts and even to a backyard gathering can be as simple or elaborate as time and budget allow. Whether it is a sandwich tucked into the tackle box or a buffet arrayed on an Oriental rug spread on the lawn, it qualifies as a picnic, requiring that certain rules be observed. Should we say ground rules?

title: Don't Call It Junk
description: To the Business Editor: Clearly, the article on ''Crafting Junk Mail'' (June 13) points up the legitimacy of advertising mail. The phrase ''...but now accounts for $9.9 billion annually in ad dollars...'' says it all.

title: DUTCH GRAND PRIX IS WON BY PIRONI
description: Didier Pironi of France took the lead on the third lap today and went on to win the Dutch Grand Prix in a Ferrari V6 by 21.6 seconds.

title: Headliners; Priests and Father
description: With his wife looking on and their two daughters lending moral support, the Rev. James Parker celebrated mass in Springfield, Mass., Wednesday becoming the first officially recognized noncelibate Roman Catholic priest in the United States to perform the Western rite, according to church officials.

title: TALE OF A TRUNK
description: THE trunk is back in its starting place. It stands more scratched and dented than it was four years ago in the middle of my living room. It was purchased to accompany my oldest daughter when she first left for college. Although it was larger than similar trunks and consequently more unwieldy, the salesman had convinced me it was a good buy.

title: ANGLERS FIGHTING POLLUTION
description: HIGHLANDS For the first time in the 12-year history of New Jersey's environmental movement, commercial fishermen last week shared the same deck space with environmental activists. They joined in a formal alliance - the Ocean Dumping Task Force - to protest against the dumping of sewage and hazardous chemical wastes in the Atlantic.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE pesticides used in the battle against gypsy moths and mosquitoes appear to be responsible for the deaths of bees kept for commercial use, state officials say. There are 2,500 registered beekeepers in Connecticut who control 8,000 colonies of bees.

title: AN ISRAELI AND A LEBANESE MEET AND ARE 'TOUCHED'
description: ''This is the first time I have spoken with an Israeli,'' said the young woman. She faced an army colonel on the steps of a Moslem school that had been founded by her grandfather. The school had been bombed and damaged, and then turned into a temporary headquarters by an Israeli army unit. Now the troops were pulling out, leaving the building empty again.

title: JAPANESE NEWCOMER IN WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT FOR lovers of dining diversity, there is cause for rejoicing when a new ethnic restaurant opens somewhere in Connecticut. Thus the arrival of Sakura, a Japanese newcomer to Westport, is welcome news. Distances between Japanese restaurants in the state are far indeed.

title: Student Guilty of Harassing Jewish Businessman by Mail
description: A 19-year-old college student has been convicted of misdemeanor charges stemming from a Nazi-tinged hate mail campaign against a Jewish businessman.

title: Sports People; Dietzel Files Suit
description: Paul Dietzel, the former Louisiana State University athletic director, has filed a $3.5 million lawsuit against James Wharton, the school's chancellor. Dietzel claims in the suit filed in the Orleans Parish Civil District Court in New Orleans, that Mr. Wharton defamed him in public statements about an internal audit of the athletic department. The suit charges that the chancellor made ''materially false and defamatory'' statements about Dietzel at a news conference last May 13 at which information about findings of the athletic department regarding fiscal mismanagement of the department was released.

title: No Headline
description: I don't know why Steve Lohr considers female impersonation exotic and peculiar.

title: Senate Confirms Journalist
description: The Senate has confirmed the nomination of John Hughes, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist, as associate director of the International Communications Agency. The agency is in charge of Voice of America. Mr. Hughes succeeds James B. Conkling, who resigned.

title: AN ELECTRIC FAN, WELL-PLACED, CAN DO WONDERS, AND CHEAPLY
description: THE high cost of electricity has caused many people to think twice before turning their air-conditioners on this summer - even when temperatures climb up in the high 80's with matching levels of humidity. Instead, more and more homeowners and apartment dwellers are turning back to what most of our parents or grandparents used in the days before air-conditioning was widely available: electric fans. Of course, these fans do use electricity, but only a small fraction of the amount that air-conditioners do.

title: Julia Anne Shull Wed To F. Bradley Scholtz
description: Julia Anne Shull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Austin Shull of Darien, Conn., and F. Bradley Scholtz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Henry Scholtz, also of Darien and New York, were married in Darien yesterday in the Noroton Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Edward R. Danks performed the ceremony..

title: If you're thinking of living in:; RIDGEWOOD
description: The Dutch farmers who settled Ridgewood in the 1660's paid both royal agents and the Leni-Lenape Indians for deeds to their properties, with the idea that this would buy them security from problems plaguing other settlers of the New World. It worked.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTER CLUBS FLOURISHING
description: In places of work, in homes, in hospitals and anywhere people use computers small enough to fit on top of a desk, residents of New York and its suburbs are forming clubs and organizing user groups to talk about the computer technology that is now available.

title: Trooper's Slaying
description: Last Dec. 21, a highly decorated New Jersey state trooper wearing a bulletproof vest was killed in a shootout on an isolated stretch of Interstate 80 near the Pennsylvania border. The trooper, Philip Lamonaco, a 32-year-old father of three children, was the state's first trooper killed in the line of duty since 1973.

title: LONG MAY IT WAVE-IF IT'S SAFE
description: ON the Fourth of July, as on many national and state holidays, the A merican flag blossoms forth on streets and buildings and flutters p roudly over lawns and yards. Showing the flag seems to be a simple m atter, but it is not in New York City.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Two Votes for a Military Draft
description: With the abolition of the draft, the armed services came to depend not on the force of law for manpower, but on the force of circumstance. As a result, two studies said last week, the armed forces have become racially imbalanced and, said one of them, may face a shortage of manpower.

title: MUSINGS ON AN ANTHEM, A LIBRETTO AND A FESTIVAL
description: Random thoughts while cleaning out the Miscellaneous file: I used to be a bore on the subject, but you will hear no more complaints from me about the depressingly indiscriminate playing of ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' which for too long was employed to tranquilize audiences before ball games, political rallies and other public assemblies in this country. For many years, I and other musically sensitive souls noted and denounced distortions of tempo, unsingable keys, fractured prosody and other crimes. The most idealistic among us cherished the illusion that the National Anthem could be codified and protected, perhaps by Congressional action, before it became extinct.

title: Index; International
description: Bonn's military spending shows little if any growth 3 ''Banning'' expires for an incorri- gible recidivist in South Africa 3 Around the World 5 Lebanon war is causing conster- nation in Egypt 8 Israeli aide says multinational force may not be needed 8 Japan's Communist Party, at 60, faces uncertain future 9 Mexico holds elections today, with focus on opposition vote 10 Honduras and El Salvador are re- portedly at odds over territory 10 Government/Politics Delegates at N.A.A.C.P. parley make a successful ''safari'' 14 White votes give Richmond a new black mayor 15 Army recruitment chief disputes reports on need for a draft 16 Reporter's Notebook: Publiciz- ing Reagan and the shuttle 16 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Independence Day will be observed tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Sunday rules; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules; subways and buses on Sunday schedules. Libraries - Closed.

title: TAX ABATEMENT PLAN FAILS AS LEGISLATURE ENDS SESSION
description: The 205th session of the New York State Legislature closed down for the summer tonight, sending a small mountain of bills to Governor Carey's desk.

title: The World in Summary; Land Reform's Big Spenders
description: The United States has put a lot of faith - and money - into El Salvador's ambitious land reforms. But the program's future remains clouded.

title: WORKERS UNTOUCHED BY JAPAN'S MAGIC WAND
description: Everyone knows about well-paid, competitive Japanese workers, relentless souls who make life so hard for American automobile and steel workers and who - just to rub salt in the wounds - have jobs for life. But there is another, much larger class of worker in Japan, poorly paid, unorganized, insecure and unprotected. They have been rarely heard of abroad; not many foreigners penetrate to the sweatshops and little factories.

title: ART TO READ AS WELL AS SEE
description: EAST HAMPTON AS intensely solitary as the creative process may seem, since Classical times painters and poets have been closely bound - feeding off each other for inspiration and subject matter. This special relationship gets a modern cast today when Guild Hall opens ''Poets and Artists: Poets and Artists Collaborating,'' an exhibition of works created when 84 individualists put aside their personal muses and joined forces to produce team efforts. Incorporating the words that prompted them, the paintings, sculptures and prints do not exist on their own; they must be read as well as seen.

title: Topics; Winging It
description: Pincers

title: REJECTION AND RESURRECTION
description: A MAN WITHOUT SHOES By John Sanford. 452 pp. Santa Barbara, Calif.: Black Sparrow Press. $25.

title: ENGLAND REBUFFED ON TIEBREAKER PLEA
description: The Federation Internationale de Football Association today turned down a protest by the English Football Association over tiebreaking procedures in the World Cup.

title: Headliners; Native Dancer
description: Lin Jianwei decided last week to vote with his feet - but creatively.

title: SILICON VALLEY GREEN MAKES THE CHIPS FLY
description: When the news broke last month that two of Japan's most prestigious manufacturers had been charged with attempting to buy American computer secrets, it didn't surprise a lot of the folks who congregate each afternoon at Rickey's Hyatt House and Dinah's Shack on El Camino Real.

title: SCULPTORS AS PRINTMAKERS
description: NEW HAVEN AN exhibition of prints that are never less than interesting and sometimes very beautiful will be on view at the Yale University Art Gallery through Aug. 31. Entitled ''Prints by Contemporary Sculptors,'' the show, with 86 works of art, is a large one, and it includes some of the leading artists of our day.

title: FROG'S LEAP: A PRINCE OF A WINE
