description: Quaint and catchy names from the countryside have become commonplace for California wines. Often they are meant to convey a sense of the outdoors, the rugged land where the vines grow and the grapes are harvested. Sometimes they reflect the names of people or places. Occasionally they are pure whimsy.

title: BLACK BACKED BY WHITES IS RICHMOND MAYOR
description: The City Council here, split for years along racial lines, has ousted one black member from the Mayor's post and installed another who is supported by the white Council members.

title: Black Crime, Black Victims
description: As a black, female, clinical psychologist, I was glad to read Lee Daniels's article, ''Black Crime, Black Victims'' (May 16). It is about time Afro-Americans started to take responsibility for crime on the streets where they - we - live.

title: The Region in Summary; The End (Again) For Westway?
description: What traffic was to the West Side Highway, lawsuits are to its proposed replacement, Westway. In the latest legal tangle, a Federal district judge in Manhattan last week barred the use of Federal funds for the huge highway and development project, leaving its fate murkier than ever.

title: Correction
description: A caption in ''The Lure of Bass Fishing'' (May 30) gave an incorrect location for the site where the author was fishing. The correct location is Cornwall, Conn.

title: WHERE ARE THE CHILDREN?
description: After my children reached adolescence there were many nights when I didn't know where they were at 10 o'clock. This didn't trouble me at first. It's the nature of adolescent children to spend 10 P.M. in places their parents don't know about. At that age I spent many 10 P.M.'s in such places myself. They seemed fairly interesting then, but by the time parenthood thickened my girth and widened my mind, such places seemed boring in the extreme.

title: CATHOLICS EXPECT NO CHANGE IN CELIBACY RULE
description: Roman Catholic officials say that the ordination of a married man as a Roman Catholic priest does not indicate any change in the official view on mandatory celibacy for priests.

title: Hofstra's Program In Engineering
description: The article ''Demand Rises Here for Engineers'' asserted that only three Long Island schools offer engineering degrees. That is a statement that the almost 1,000 Hofstra University alumni holding Bachelor of Science degrees in engineering would find inaccurate.

title: HIS COMMERCIALS USE L.I. AS U.S.
description: ''I KIND of use Long Island as my back lot,'' Sid Myers said. ''It has so many kinds of different backgrounds.'' Mr. Myers, who lives in Roslyn, is the president of Myers Films Inc., whose business is the production of television commercials for advertising agencies.

title: SPECIAL EFFECTS ARE REVOLUTIONIZING FILM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Culhane is the author of ''Special Effects in the Movies'' (Ballantine) and is writing a book about the making of Walt Disney's ''Fantasia.'' By JOHN CULHANE

title: It's Still Voodoo
description: Recall the catechism: If we cut taxes, limit spending and hold back monetary growth, the economy will be born again. Long-term interest rates will fall as lenders gain confidence that inflation is cooled. That will trigger a boom in productive investment. And it will be sustained by the personal savings of a revitalized workforce.

title: ONCE IN A LIFETIME
description: If someone offered an award to the country which had displayed the greatest energy and creativity in bridge organization in the past half century it would probably go to the Dutch. Consider some of their accomplishments.

title: Mary Groark Is a Bride
description: Mary Madeline Groark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen James Groark of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Willed Fairfield-Sonn, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Alexander Sonn of Milford, N.H. The Rev. William Conklin performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Assumption Roman Catholic Church. The bride, known as Lynn, is staff assistant for long-range plans at the Southern New England Telephone Company in New Haven. Her husband is studying for his doctorate in organizational behavior at Yale University.

title: The Nation in Summary; THe N.A.A.C.P. Wins a Big One
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People may have won more important court cases than the one it celebrated last week, but seldom has it had a more timely victory. The decision came on the closing day of the organization's annual convention, bringing cheers from the delegates and money to their strapped treasury.

title: LIFE IN BRITAIN GETS BACK TO NORMAL, UNFORTUNATELY
description: After three weeks of cease-fire, the Falkland Islands war has slid off most front pages and displays of patriotism in support of ''our boys'' have largely subsided. When Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher takes questions in the House of Commons these days fewer involve the South Atlantic and more concern the three million unemployed.

title: The Region in Summary; AS Tax Cut II Begins, Recovery Is Still Pending
description: The second stage of the tax cut that President Reagan declared 15 months ago would ''have an immediate impact on the economic vitality of the nation'' went into effect last week. Dawn, however, was only faintly gleaming. While unemployment held steady in June, it was holding at a postwar high of 9.5 percent, and the number of ''discouraged workers'' - those who have quit looking for work because they are convinced they can't find any - rose to a record 1.5 million.

title: TWO ISLANDS
description: To the Editor: We are a Martha's Vineyard married couple, one a Pennsylvania Dutchman, the other a native islander and we must thank Russell Baker for at least part of his description of our home in ''Two on the Isles.'' ut, we think he also has only reflected on a part of the wonderful diversity of geography that is the Vineyard. You will be hard put to find anything that resembles Gay Head or Katama or Oak Bluffs or Edgartown in Pennsylvania anywhere, much less in the Dutch country.

title: PALISADES: NEW YORK'S OTHER WEST SIDE
description: LIKE many a native New Yorker, Sheila Ross had a fierce and clannishs ense of place. Manhattan was her world and she rarely strayed far f rom its center. Sixteen years ago, when her husband bought a b usiness in New Jersey and moved the family from their home on 55th S treet to a spacious apartment in Fort Lee, she went into mourning. L eaving Gotham, she said, ''nearly broke my heart.''

title: COMMITTEE TO SELECT NEW APARTMENTS' TENANTS
description: BY letter and telephone and even the occasional visit to his office, Robert Francolini, a Hartford property developer, has been swamped in the last few weeks with nearly 1,500 people applying for 38 units of federally subsidized rental homes he is now completing in the southeast part of the city.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Travel on June 27, 'What's Doing in Ottawa,' gave the wrong address for the Snow Goose. The shop is at 40 Elgin Street.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING AN EDIBLE LANDSCAPE
description: THERE is concern these days, and rightfully so, about the high cost of living. Somehow food always seems to bear the brunt of the dissatisfaction, although food costs have hovered between 16 and 20 percent of our disposable income for the last 30 years or so.

title: Papal Nuncio Bugnini Dies; Figure in Iran Hostage Crisis
description: Archbishop Annibale Bugnini, the Papal Nuncio in Iran who tried to obtain the release of the American hostages in 1979, died today in a Rome hospital, the Vatican announced. He was 70 years old.

title: BANDS ON THE MARCH
description: Robert W. Stock is a senior editor on this magazine. By Robert W. Stock The Connecticut license plate on the battered blue Datsun reads: ''CHPS.'' Thomas Alberts, a chunky 58-year-old with a fringe of gray steel wool around an extensive forehead, emerges from the car. We've never met, but he greets me familiarly: ''How's your chops, Robert?''

title: PEETERS WINS LEG OF TOUR
description: Ludo Peeters of Belgium captured the first leg in the Tour de France bicycle race today, completing the 129-mile circuit around Mohlin 22 seconds faster than his nearest rival.

title: Isabelle Flaherty Wed To Thomas Dollinger
description: Isabelle Christine Flaherty, daughter of Mrs. Lawrence Joseph Flaherty of Jericho, L.I., and the late Mr. Flaherty, was married yesterday to Thomas William Dollinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dollinger of Spencerport, N.Y. The Rev. Gerard T. Walker performed the ceremony in St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: COPING IN OCCUPIED LEBANON
description: in the form of policemen and civil servants - after years of violent rule by Palestinian and leftist gunmen.

title: JULES FEIFFER'S 'A THINK PIECE' --'CALCULATED DREARINESS
description: Many's the time - year in, year out - when I've asked myself a question. We've come into the playhouse, small or large, and either there is no curtain or the curtain is up. In any case, we see the set. Fully. Fully lighted. Complete with props. We not only see it, we are apt to see it for a good 15 to 25 minutes before the dramatic activities that are going to take place in it actually do begin to take place in it. And then, before anyting can take place in it, we must go through a little ritual.

title: 2 CULTISTS HIJACK A BUS, THEN KILL THEMSELVES
description: Two followers of a cult religion hijacked a bus today, then begged the police to kill them and finally turned their guns on themselves today, apparently as part of a cult ceremony. Both died.

title: THOMAS M. DECKARD
description: Thomas M. Deckard, a former Olympic runner and track coach, died here Friday.

title: TRADE
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than mass-market paperbacks. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: MEASURE TO FINANCE HOSPITAL CARE OF WORKING POOR PASSES IN ALBANY
description: The Legislature, which ended its 205th session tonight, approved a broad hospital-financing program that would set up a fund to provide hundreds of millions of dollars to hospitals that treat poor, uninsured patients.

title: PARK PLAYS: STARS UNDER STARS
description: EDISON The curtain rose again last week on an annual Middlesex County summertime attraction, the Plays-in-the-Park Theater in Roosevelt Park. This is the 20th season for the series, whose opening production is Franz Lehar's ''The Merry Widow.''

title: ISRAELI ARMOR UNIT IN EASTERN BEIRUT CORDONS OFF WEST
description: Israeli armored troops today sealed off the Moslem western part of Beirut while Israeli and Palestinian gunners traded artillery and machine-gun fire on the southern outskirts.

title: CRAFTS
description: CALIFON ''PEOPLE can do more than they think, but you have to let them know that you expect them to progress,'' said Jacqueline Clipsham , a potter whose life flows between a studio in Hunterdon County and a Brooklyn apartment.

title: The Region in Summary; Commuter Tax Veto Is Upheld
description: Commuting to Connecticut is taxing enough, lawmakers in Hartford apparently have concluded. Last week, they upheld Gov. William A. O'Neill's veto of a tax on commuters from New York.

title:
DINING OUT;
FIRST COURSE: A KISS ON THE HAND
description: DRIVING up to Villa Richard, it's easy to imagine that one is about to visit a rather elaborate private home. In its heyday at the turn of the century, when it was the residence of Dr. B.F. Fackenthal Jr., visitors included the likes of Thomas A. Edison, Henry Ford, Henry Cabot Lodge Sr. and Theodore Roosevelt.

title: Word Processors
description: To the Business Editor: I am one of those ''older men'' from whom Barbara R. Bergman says resistance can be particularly expected when it comes to typing their own drafts on word-processors (May 30). I am perhaps something of a maverick: At age 14 I taught myself to touch-type and have always regarded this skill as invaluable to my productivity. However, when I arrived on sabbatical leave at the University of Edinburgh Faculty of Medicine in October 1974, the secretarial staff were nonplussed by my request for a typewriter. Upon observing my 80-word-per-minute speed, they commented with resignation: ''Only an American... .''RICHARD STEINMAN Professor of Social Welfare, University of Southern Maine Portland, Me., June 22, 1982

title: BANDS AND BANNERS
description: What can be more American than the Fourth of July and the images and sounds it evokes? There's Old Glory and there are the marching bands. There are banners unfurled and a maximum of glitter to brighten the day - the brassy bugles, copper trumpets, chromed Sousaphones played with such pride and more than a modicum of sweat by the uniformed marchers. And there are all those brass buttons on the soldierly costumes they wear as they energetically proceed, cheeks swelling, feet tapping to the roar of the crowds each time a familiar tune makes a crescendo.

title: APPROACHES TO HOLLAND TUNNEL BEING BEAUTIFIED
description: JERSEY CITY NEARLY $1 million has been set aside for a restoration and beautification project to brighten the worn approaches of the Holland Tunnel.

title: MICROPHONES TAILORED FOR THE AMATEUR
description: George Bernard Shaw, aside from other accomplishments, was a noted music critic. He also liked to write about hell (as in ''Man and Superman''), which is not surprising for an Irishman. Putting these two favorite topics together, Shaw declared: ''Hell is full of amateur musicians.''

title: BLACKS ON TV'S 'SOAPS'--A WHOLE NEW SCRIPT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Caryl Stern is an actress and freelance writer based in New York City. By CARYL STERN

title: WILL CREATIVE FINANCING SAVE THE STUDENT LOAN MARKET?
description: When the Reagan Administration tightened eligibility requirements for federally guaranteed student loans in October, some observers estimated that about 10 percent of college-bound students could find themselves out of money and, perhaps, out of school.

title: A MINORITY FROM DOWN UNDER SEEKS INTERNATIONAL ATTENTION
description: Few in number, patronized where they are not openly discriminated against, Australia's ''invisible people,'' the aborigines, have put this country's federal and state governments on notice that they will be invisible no more.

title: ...AND THE MAN WHO WAGES IT
description: HANGING in a closet in his opulent Wall Street office is a s kyblue, silk boxer's robe that proclaims on the back: ''Don Carter, P roxy Fighter.'' It is from Irwin L. Jacobs, the dissident s hareholder who began an unsuccessful proxy fight against the Pabst B rewing Company late last year.

title: Miss McKay Wed in Rye To Executive
description: Sandra McKay, a sales associate with the Hovey-Billings Real Estate Company in Denver, was married yesterday to Thomas A. Wilbanks, a vice president of Wilbanks & Associates, an oil and gas leasing and exploration company in Denver. Canon Wendell Phillips performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y. He was assisted by the Rev. Walter Hartlove.

title: About the Role Of a Role Model
description: James Michael Sullivan, in his article ''On Commitments and Father's Day'' (''Personally Speaking,'' June 20), comes across as a loving, liberated and well-educated parent.

title: PATRIOTISM TO MAKE THE HEART VIBRATE
description: Ivan Gamble, a Tlingit Indian, sat with me a while ago on the town wharf here, which is at the end of the United States, and told me the bitter story of how he lost half his hearing and most of his teeth. When he was a Marine recruit in San Diego, he said, drill instructors called him ''Nigger!'' and beat him and forced him to fire a bazooka without the protection of ear covers.

title: LEADING INDICATORS ROSE 0.3% IN MAY
description: The Index of Leading Indicators, the Government's gauge of future economic strength, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May for its third consecutive advance, the Commerce Department said. The gain was viewed as the beginning of a slow recovery.

title: THE GRIND OF SEARCHING FOR MAJOR LEAGUE TALENT
description: JUST to the right of home plate, in the first row behind the screen, sat Marv Olson of Gayville, S.D., a 75-year-old link from the days of Babe Ruth to players of the 21st century.

title: BEN FRANKLIN AND THE GREAT SEAL OF AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title:
Antiques;
BUSINESS 'SUPERB' FOR QUALITY DEALERS
description: ALTHOUGH numerous young dealers are expected to close up shop during the coming year - mainly because of lack of financial backing and recognition as experts - older, established dealers report that they expect to do as well in the 1982-83 fiscal year as ever before.

title: Reader Recalls Divers At the Great Falls
description: In the New Jersey Journal of June 13, there was an item about Robert Melly of Wayne getting himself in the record books by jumping from the rocks at the Great Falls in Paterson.

title: TEST CALLED SMOOTHEST EVER
description: The crew of the space shuttle Columbia was set tonight to steer the winged spaceship out of orbit and back to the earth Sunday, thus concluding the fourth and final test flight of the world's first re-usable space vehicle.

title: Max Roach Appears In Solo Drum Recital
description: Max Roach has been evident at this year's jazz festival in both expanded and contracted contexts - expanded with his ''Double Quartet'' concert on June 25 and contracted with a solo drum recital late Thursday afternoon in the Forum Room of the New York Sheraton.

title: A RESPECTABLE 'SALESMAN'
description: SHARON ''DEATH OF A SALESMAN'' is an acknowledged American classic. Everyone knows that, but how often does anyone see it? Besides a 1975 recreation at the Circle in the Square - a noncommercial, limited engagement - it hasn't been done on Broadway since the original staging by Elia Kazan in 1949.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Columbia Gets It Right - but At a High Cost
description: After more than a decade of research, development and testing that cost well over $10 billion, the space shuttle was headed for operational status today upon landing at Edwards Air Force Base. Its fourth evaluation flight, which mission controllers called the ''cleanest'' of the program, had demonstrated the military and commercial hybrid that now characterizes America's presence in space.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; F.D.A. Outlaws 'Starch Blockers'
description: America's big appetite for diet fads received a jolt last week when the Food and Drug Administration ordered so-called starch blockers off the market. The possibly dangerous pills, which are said to inhibit the digestion of starch, had been sold without Federal approval because manufacturers presumed they were a food, not a drug.

title: MOTHER OF DEAF PUPIL CRITICIZES DECISION
description: CORTLANDT ''DO the judges read or do their homework? -they're just ignorant,'' said Nancy Rowley last week, after learning the Supreme Court had ruled that the Hendrick Hudson Central School District did not have to provide a sign-language interpreter for her 10-year-old daughter, Amy, who is deaf.

title: SUFFOLK'S BATTLE TO RETAIN ITS FARMLAND
description: IT sounded like Levittown East: Last month the Southampton Town P lanning Board approved a 12.7-acre subdivision in Water Mill and a 1 4.3-acre subdivision in Bridgehampton, held public hearings on threeo ther subdivisions totaling 91 acres and scheduled hearings on p roposals for four others with a total of 33 acres.

title: STUDENTS' FORUMS A BLOOMFIELD BONUS
description: BLOOMFIELD ABOUT 10 years ago, this Essex County community began to hold New England-style Town Meetings for high school students. The motivating force was Dr. Martin Siegel, a local dentist, who attributes his interest to a talk he had with his son, Bart, now 21 years old.

title: Italy Seeking America's Cup
description: In the Commodore's Room of the New York Yacht Club, its walls lined with stern portraits of former commodores, a slender, impeccably garbed Italian yachtsman described the other day how Italy intended to take the America's Cup and give it a new home in Sardinia.

title: CAN THEATER SURVIVE ON THE BARD?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Don Shewey writes frequently about the theater. By DON SHEWEY

title: 'Post-Conservative America'
description: WHEN the first histories of the 1980's are written, the place of the radical transformation of conservative economics will be as important as that of any other transformation - geographical, cultural or institutional. As the 1970's opened, conservative economic theories were outsider credos b arely taken seriously by either the Republican Administration of R ichard Nixon or the business community; in 1981, monetarism, s upply-side economics and gold currency convertibility were r ecognized as the official economic theology of a new revolutionary c onservative government...

title: Spinning
description: To the Editor: In the article, ''Made by Hand in Vermont'' (Travel, June 13) a caption says, ''Deborah Felmuth demonstrates weaving.''

title: MUSIC: ASTON MAGNA OPENS 10TH YEAR
description: Every summer, Aston Magna reaches out to early music performers and scholars around the country and calls them to its charming retreat here. Each year there is a singular three-week blending of private study and public performance, and each year there is a theme. For its 10th season, Aston Magna has chosen France's world of the performing arts in the age of Louis XIV.

title: A HOUSE DIVIDED AGAINST ITSELF
description: The conservative movement in American has ''radicalized'' itself, and therein lie the seeds of its own demise, says Kevin T. Phillips in his new book, ''Post-Conservative America,'' published by Random House. The author, whose earlier writings foresaw the ascendency of the Republican party that culminated with President Reagan's 1980 election victory, says now that the contradictory and reactionary strains within Reaganism -supply-side economics and monetarism, among others - are a product of Republican politicians looking back in nostalgia for answers to present problems, rather than looking forward with a new vision.

title: 'GOING TO THE MOVIES,II''
description: If this piece had been conceived in Hollywood, it might be called ''Going to the Movies, II.'' It's a sequel to a February piece about the problems faced by people who pay money for the privilege of seeing films not on cable television, home box office or an airplane but in the theaters for which, one supposes, they are primarily designed. This is a true story. It contains lots of questions but no answers. Read it, Ridley Scott, and weep.

title: THE DOYENNE OF PRINTMAKING
description: In the print world, the name of Tatyana Grosman is virtually sacred. So revered are the contributions to printmaking made by this devoted Russian-born animateur, now 78 years old, that no less than two museums and a number of private galleries, both here and in Europe, are currently mounting exhibitions in tribute to the 25th birthday of Universal Limited Art Editions, the print workshop she founded in 1957.

title: Perspectives: Rent Controls; PRESSURES ARE RISING ON THE CITY'S RENTAL HOUSING
description: THE history of rent regulatory systems in the city is that they are s imple only in the beginning. Complexity creeps in inexorably. Then, w hen the system is virtually in collapse, the city overhauls it.

title: Wilhelm Busch
description: To the Editor:

title: Gail Kelly Plans September Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ward Kelly of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Kelly, to James F.X. Hiler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Hiler of Brooklyn.

title: The World in Summary; Europeans Tell Reagan What Friends Are For
description: Margaret Thatcher has been Ronald Reagan's closest European ally in the ideological wars against loose money and the Soviet Union. But last week, she criticized a Reagan policy with vehemence rarely used in public by a British Prime Minister speaking of the United States. Washington was wrong, she said, to pressure foreign subsidiaries of American companies to hold up construction of a $10 billion pipeline that would bring Soviet natural gas to Western Europe. Britain took legal steps to order its companies not to comply.

title: HISTORIC SITES AWAIT TAX BREAK
description: LONG ISLAND property owners seeking to benefit from the 1981 Economic Recovery Tax Act incentives to rehabilitate older structures may find themselves waiting in a line already two years old.

title: Kathryn A. Abele To Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Abele of Rockville Centre and Southold, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Ann Abele, to John P. Devine Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Devine of Bellmore, L.I.

title: CHARITY CARRIES OUT DONORS' REQUESTS
description: Golda and Molly Fine were Russian immigrants who came to this country, studied and worked diligently and knew exactly how they wanted their modest estate of $46,452.54 spent: to combat loud singing commercials and irritating noise, gadgets for gadgets' sake and the use of annoying abbreviations and acronyms.

title: FEISTY SOUTH AFRICAN NEARLY A LEGEND
description: In Alan Paton's new novel about protest politics in South Africa in the 1950's, ''Ah But Your Land Is Beautiful,'' there is a white woman of basically liberal bent who is so ardent in support of the black cause that she is ultimately hauled up on treason charges with a group of black nationalists and white Communists.

title: A THEORY UNTRIED
description: KEVIN P. PHILLIPS has some interesting things to say about Watergatea nd Vietnam in ''Post-Conservative America.'' The true story of W atergate, he suggests, is the destruction of President Nixon - an A merican Dreyfus - by a threatened Washington establishment that p ulled off a coup d'etat. As for Vietnam, the sellout of the troops b y the media, the universities and the liberal politicians has the m akings of ''a post World War I German-style recrimination.''

title: HONDURANS SAID TO HOLD SALVADORAN-CLAIMED LAND
description: The Honduran armed forces have begun a joint military campaign with the Salvadoran Army, with a primary objective of crushing Salvadoran rebels in their mountainous strongholds in the eastern Salvadoran province of Morazan, a senior Honduran military officer said.

title: Outdoors; A JULY DEER HUNT
description: ASUMMER deer hunt is most unusual, but Florida wildlife officials a re planning one in the east-central Everglades for the middle of t his month. An inordinately wet spring following more than half a d ecade of drought has made the hunt necessary.

title: DEEPLY IN DEBT, A YESHIVA STILL HAS FAITH IN FUTURE
description: The teachers have not been paid since February. There is a $10,000 heating oil bill, and the enrollment, once 600, is down to 150 students. The total debt has risen to more than $150,000, and there is a danger the school will be forced to close.

title: FOR SHARK HUNTERS, FISH AND FLOTSAM
description: ABOARD THE PENCIL POPPER A50-foot-wide oil slick several miles long, garbage floating on the surface, a black drum whose contents were not investigated and a 2 1/2-foot-long galvanized canister approximately 10 inches wide.

title: The Nation in Summary; Hinckley On Hinckley
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. did not testify during the eight-week trial that ended in a verdict of not guilty by reason of insanity in the shooting of President Reagan and three others. Last week, he broke silence in a series of telephone calls from the Washington mental hospital where he is confined.

title: Cancer Treatment At Long Island Jewish
description: The Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center wishes to point out a serious error in Dr. Miller's recent letter to the editor. In referring to the provision of therapeutic radiology services on Long Island, he disparagingly refers to the program at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center as a ''marginal facility.'' I do not know where Dr. Miller obtained his information, but his allegation could not be further from the truth.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: Paperback History. The story of Americans' taste in reading since World War II largely parallels that of the mass-market paperback, a fact that is currently tempting a number of students of popular culture to write histories of soft-cover publishing. The latest scholar to respond to this challenge is Thomas L. Bonn, a librarian at the State University of New York College at Cortland, whose ''Under Cover: An Illustrated History of American Mass-Market Paperbacks'' has just been published by Penguin Books at $12.95.

title: By Nellie Anderson
description: ONE SUPPLIER'S RISE AND FALL

title: FOR ARGENTINES IN CITY, SENSE OF BETRAYAL
description: The small blackboard hanging over the meat counter at Peter and Rita Amormimo's Argentine delicatessen in Jackson Heights, Queens, carried a message thanking those who had flocked to the store to read about battlefield developments provided by Telam, the official Argentine press agency, during the British siege in the Falklands.

title: Q and A; Renewing a Lease
description: Question: My lease expires July 30. My landlord offered a renewal of my lease in a letter dated April 1, although according to the postmark, the lease was not mailed until April 20. His letter says the lease would be automatically renewed if I returned it within 60 days. I sent it back after the 60-day limit from April 1 had expired, but within the 60-day limit from April 20. Can the management of the building reject my lease renewal? ... P.K., Manhattan Answer: The New York City Conciliation and Appeals Board says you have not jeopardized your right to renew your lease because the 60-day automatic-renewal period began when you received the letter, not on the date of the letterhead. If you had not exercised your right to renew within 60 days, then the owner could have legally sought another tenant.

title: Teaching the Autistic
description: A Further Opinion I feel compelled to reply to ''Teaching the Autistic: Another View'' (Letters to the Editor). In these days of fiscal crisis at all levels of government and the resulting cutbacks in spending directed toward special education, all sides of the issue should be examined. I do see both sides of special education; as a member of my school district's Committee on the Handicapped, I've observed that the majority of our district's certified handicapped students profit enormously from specialeducation classes and services in our district, and in special schools outside the district.

title: MR. SHULTZ, LORD MOUNTBATTEN AND GHANDI
description: To the Editor:

title: MCENROE, CONNORS PLAY IN FINAL TODAY
description: The gap that separates good from great in men's tennis was dramatized in straight-set victories by John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors in the Wimbledon tennis semifinals today.

title: CORPORATIONS INCREASE GIFTS TO LOCAL GROUPS
description: FOR hundreds of Connecticut's health, welfare and cultural organizations serving the community, the loss or reduction of Federal financial support is causing a crisis. But many of the state's major companies are rallying to help, in some cases with increased cash donations and also with offers of equipment, administrative assistance and experienced business know-how.

title: DANCE: YIDDISH THEMES BY PEARL LANG COMPANY
description: The world of Itzik Manger was recreated in colorful detail Thursday at the N.Y.U. University Auditorium, where the Pearl Lang Dance Company performed four recent dances by Miss Lang to themes and poems by the 20th-century Yiddish troubadour-poet.

title: RECRUITING CHARGES MADE AGAINST HADL
description: Two former high school football stars say they were offered money, as much as $30,000 in one instance, by John Hadl to play at the University of Kansas, The Kansas City Star reported today.

title: LEBANON CRISIS CAUSING CONSTERNATION IN EGYPT
description: The continuing wrath and frustration in Egypt about the Lebanon crisis is especially strong in some Moslem circles, and both Government officials and ordinary citizens are wondering uneasily what expression these emotions will eventually find.

title: Cary Bachelder Will Be the Bride Of D.A. Dufresne
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Bachelder 3d of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Cathryn Bachelder, to David A. Dufresne, son of Randall O. Dufresne of Shrewsbury, Mass., and the late Barbara Thayer Dufresne.

title: Computer Accusations Vex Japanese; They Feel Suspicious, Embarrassed
description: Charges that two of Japan's largest computer companies conspired to buy secrets stolen from the International Business Machines Corporation have produced deep embarrassment here, along with suspicion of United States motives and some soul-searching concerning the relative technological strengths of Japanese and American business.

title: No More Westway Fish Stories
description: A decade of disgraceful obstruction of Manhattan's Westway has been made more disgraceful still by the conduct of the highway's boosters. Federal Judge Thomas Griesa's latest opinion demonstrates anew how badly government agencies served the public by trying to skirt environmental safeguards. This opinion does not greatly add to the delay. There were in any case only a few months remaining in which supporters, no less than opponents, could get Federal and state agencies to face up squarely to the last environmental problem: fish.

title: CAIRO'S JEWS, A REMNANT OF PROUD PAST, REPORT NO HARASSMENT
description: From windows over Sebil el-Khazindar Street, radios blare the latest about the Lebanon crisis. On the sun-scorched sidewalks, news vendors hawk newspapers full of denunciations of Israel.

title: TV: MENUHIN BEGINS 'MUSIC OF MAN' TRIPS
description: ''The Music of Man,'' an eight-part series beginning on WNET, Channel 13, at 8 tonight, is a collaboration between Yehudi Menuhin, the violinist, and Curtis W. Davis, whose television career includes seven years as director of culture programs for National Educational Television. The series, completed in 1979, was originated by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation in cooperation with the Mississippi Educational Television Authority and the Ontario Educational Communications Authority.

title: SAVING DEPENDENT COLLEGE STUDENTS' SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A defensive player in a National Basketball Association game slaps the ball and breaks an offensive dribble. Can the offensive player immediately dribble again?

title: Sports World Specials; Class Coverage
description: The Charleston (W.Va.) Rockets of the American Football Association have won the league championship the last two years, but it might be hard to make an argument that the State of West Virginia has benefited from the team's success.

title: ONLY THE SHADOW KNOWS THE MOON'S COLOR TONIGHT
description: The heavenly orb that Shakespeare romanticized, the cow jumped over and astronauts left their footprints on is expected to provide the earthbound a flourish of splendor in the sky late tonight when a total lunar eclipse occurs a few hours after midnight.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Korean Shamans to Play At the Asia Society

title: No Headline
description: Because of an editing error in an article on Saturday, Nahum Goldmann was incorrectly described. He is a former president of the World Jewish Congress.

title: CAREY DENOUNCES STATE LEGISLATURE AS IGNORING NEEDS
description: Governor Carey sharply attacked the 205th session of the State Legislature, which closed yesterday, as focusing on election year politics instead of major state problems.

title: AUDIT BY GOLDIN SAYS CITY IS LAX OVER WATER USE
description: The New York City Comptroller's office accused the city yesterday of inefficiency in collecting unpaid bills for excessive water use by upstate communities.

title: Around the World; Death on Tennis Grounds Ends English Manhunt
description: A 17-day hunt by hundreds of armed British policemen ended today when Barry Prudom, suspected of three killings, was shot dead outside the Yorkshire town of Malton.

title: Alison Oresman Bride Of Warren Wilson 3d
description: Alison Jane Oresman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Oresman of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday at her parents' home to Warren E. Wilson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Jr. of Neenah, Wis.

title: MORE 'PLAIN TRUTHS' ABOUT THE MIDDLE EAST
description: To the Editor:

title: MODERN JAZZ QUARTET FINDS NEW WAYS TO DO WHAT IT DOES BEST
description: The Modern Jazz Quartet, the most careful and refined of all modern-jazz combos, found its niche and fitted itself comfortably into that niche long ago. A performance by the group always maintained exacting standards of individual musicianship and ensemble interaction, but the repertory consisted of a limited number of compositions, and one always knew what to expect.

title: New York Day by Day
description: At Lincoln Center For Performing Arts: Crafts

title: Isuzu-G.M. Pact
description: Isuzu Motors Ltd., 34.2 percent owned by the General Motors Corporation, has announced that it and G.M. will set up a joint venture here on July 30 to promote Isuzu vehicle sales in Southeast Asia, the Middle East, Latin America and Africa. The new concern will be named the Isuzu Motors Overseas Distribution Corporation.
To the Editor:

title: Garbage Spill Blocks Tunnel And Ties Up Traffic in Boston
description: Eighty feet of garbage spilled by an overturned truck clogged a major highway tunnel and created a 10-mile traffic jam that lasted nearly six hours Saturday, the authorities said.

title: ON LAKE CHAMPLAIN, INDIANS TURN EELS INTO PROFITS
description: In the lore of the Abenaki Indians of northern New York and New England, July was for centuries called the Month of the Eel, a time when the succulent fish was fattest and most easily caught to augment the tribal diet of deer, moose and beaver.

title: HURDLES
description: The perfect completion today of the nearly flawless fourth and final test flight of the winged spaceship Columbia appears to demonstrate that the shuttle has overcome its numerous technical problems and can, indeed, fly as its planners said it would.

title: WEISKOPF OVERTAKES NELSON FOR VICTORY
description: Tom Weiskopf sank a 7-foot birdie putt on the final hole today to win the $350,000 Western Open, overtaking Larry Nelson.

title: Washington Watch; Help Wanted: Supply-Siders
description: WASHINGTON THE supply-side-oriented Reagan Administration has a problem: finding some supply-side economists to fill two of the top economic posts in the Treasury Department. Part of the problem may be solved by dropping one of the jobs, however.

title: SAN ANTONIO PAPERS DEFY U.S. TREND
description: Everyone in the newspaper business knows there is no future for afternoon newspapers, and maybe not much of one for competing newspapers, morning or evening. So what is one to make of San Antonio, which supports not just one, but two, afternoon newspapers - The Light and The News - as well as a morning daily, The Express?

title: Inchcape Successor Led Unilever Arm
description: Sir David Alexander Orr, the Dubliner whose 34 years at Unilever P.L.C. brought him from management trainee to chairman, has embarked on a new career at age 60 and only six weeks after retiring in London from the company, which is an arm of the British-Dutch food and detergent giant.

title: JEWISH ORGANIZATIONS AID THE LEBANESE
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: Around the World 2 Moscow's July 4: a burst of polemics 2 U.N. Secretary General draws praise from many quarters 3 Cairo's Jews report no Moslem harassment 4 Government/Politics Reagan position on rights actions as Governor hard to document 20 N.A.A.C.P. struggles to develop strategies for the 1980's 20 Lehrman, dismissing G.O.P. pri- mary, focuses on Koch 22 Washington Talk Q. and A.: Bobby R. Inman 6 James C. Wright seeks crown of Barbecue King 6 Briefing 6 General Around the Nation 5 San Antonio newspapers defy trend of shutdowns 17 Indians and others reviving eel fishing in Lake Champlain 22 INDEPENDENCE DAY Today is Independence Day. Fol- lowing are holiday schedules: Parking - Sunday rules; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules; subways and buses on Sunday schedules. Libraries - Closed.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday by Reuters incorrectly described the way the holdings of Standard Oil of Ohio (Sohio) in the Prudhoe Bay oil and gas field were reduced. Under an agreement signed five years ago, parts of the field are owned by Exxon, Arco and Sohio, but the field is operated as a single unit. The three companies reviewed the ownership, and agreed that Sohio owned 50.4 percent of the field, rather than 53 percent.

title: FOR FOREIGNERS, A COURSE ON COPING
description: The Japanese are interested in housing and where to live, the Europeans in learning English and, frequently, in how they can change their visas into the green cards that allow permanent residence, but there are certain things everyone wants to know. How to make friends with Americans, for instance, and legal tax deductions, and what and when to tip. So says Dr. Roberta Seret, president of American Welcome Services, a company she organized less than a year ago to advise foreigners on how to get along and how to enjoy living in New York City and its environs.

title: ABSENT TRACK STARS ARE MISSED BY U.S. IN LOSS TO RUSSIANS
description: The United States-Soviet Union track and field meet here this weekend had just ended, and the American coaches were trying to explain why the Russian men and women had scored convincing victories.

title: NEW YORK MUST PROVIDE EQUAL EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN AFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR U.S. SPACE PROGRAM
description: President Reagan today affirmed his dedication for the United States space program in a speech here, but he withheld the promise of funds for which officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have been privately pressing the White House.

title: PIRATES, EXPOS SPLIT AS HITTERS DOMINATE
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday again showed that they are a changed team. Nine days ago, the Pirates were in fifth place in the National League East, seven and a half games behind the Expos, the division leaders. They then moved into Montreal and won the first three games of a four-game series, knocking the Expos out of first place.

title: Meira Rosenberg Wed To Robert Bookman
description: Meira Rosenberg, an associate counsel with the legal-services plan of the Committee of Interns and Residents in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Stuart Bookman, a staff lawyer with the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Around the World; 1,000 Blacks Leave South African Gold Mine
description: More than 1,000 black miners refused to work and left the giant West Driefontein gold mine for home today after 150 of their co-workers were dismissed in connection with three days of rioting, a mine spokesman said.

title: SAYING 'NO' TO MORE
description: In a statewide referendum last month, California voters sent an extraordinary message to the rest of the nation: growth and the resources to sustain it are no longer affordable. This pronoucement from the holiest temple of boosterism cannot be ignored. lThe California electorate, in rejecting a major water project for the first time in its histroy, yielded a new majority of skeptical resource consumers in the south and devoted resource conservationists in the north. That such an alliance overruled California's century-old doctrine of expansionism should cause political and business leaders throughout the nation to reassess visions of growth at any cost.

title: METS BEATEN TWICE BY PHILS, 9-7 AND 7-2
description: Sun-drenched Shea Stadium was a stage for two pitchers going in different directions yesterday afternoon: Philadelphia's Steve Carlton and Randy Jones of the Mets.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Never Too Old for Camp

title: Texaco Unit's Earnings Poor
description: The first-half oil-business losses of Deutsche Texaco A.G., a Texaco Inc. subsidiary, are too big to be offset by profits in other areas, according to its managing board's chairman, Armin Schram.

title: FOR NEW MUSEUM BOSS, ART RUNS IN THE FAMILY
description: The new director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art is 38-year-old Anne d'Harnoncourt, a curator at the museum for 13 years and a citizen of the museum world from the time she was 1. She succeeds Jean Sutherland Boggs, who resigned to oversee construction of two museums in Ottawa.

title: N.A.A.C.P. ATTEMPTS TO SHIFT STRATEGY
description: Members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which ended its 73d annual convention here Friday, say the organization is struggling to change an outdated outlook.

title: Hint on Peso By Argentina
description: The Argentine Economy Ministry said today it had decreed a holiday tomorrow for banks and foreign exchanges, a move that usually precedes a devaluation of the peso against the dollar.

title: A COLD CLIMATE
description: An old Soviet acquaintance, one given in the past to restraint and a certain irony in conversation, spoke grimly this time about Soviet-American relations.

title: HOW TO LOSE A HEAD AND YET GAIN CROWNS
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Teachers Say Many Are Quitting Over Pay
description: Public school teachers are quitting the classroom in droves because of low pay, teacher union activists said today.

title: BOMBS LEFT IN MIDTOWN AND QUEENS
description: A pipe bomb exploded and shattered the windows of a Yugoslav travel agency and a nearby house in Astoria, Queens, yesterday morning. A few hours later, a ticking gasoline bomb was removed from the doorway of Yugoslav Airlines on 51st Street off Fifth Avenue near St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: U.N. Bids Israel Allow Shipments of Supplies
description: The Security Council unanimously approved a resolution tonight urging Israel to permit the shipment of vital supplies, including water, food and medicine, into west Beirut.

title: Shell, Esso Plan Gas Line
description: Shell United Kingdom Ltd. and Esso Petroleum Ltd. are planning to build a 170-mile gas pipeline linking the Fulmar field and other North Sea discoveries with the Scottish mainland at an estimated cost of between $86 million and $143 million.

title: KEY PHARMACEUTICALS OWES ITS GROWTH TO TIMED DRUGS
description: For Miami's Key Pharmaceuticals, a strategy of turning well-established drugs into new products by giving them more efficient ''delivery systems'' has, to date, paid off handsomely.

title: Sports World Specials; Horse Feathers!
description: Veterinarians at Belmont Park are seeing red over a new ruling by the track that bars them from practicing if they have an ''ownership interest of any kind, either present or prospective,'' in a horse that races or might race in New York. Practicing vets have always been barred from owning active horses, but the new rule prohibits them from, for example, having any share in the breeding rights of an active horse, as is currently the case with Dr. William O. Reed and Timely Writer.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts 92d St. Y Announces 93-Concert Season

title: Cosmos Lose, 1-0
description: Carl Valentine's goal in the 65th minute gave the Vancouver Whitecaps a 1-0 victory over the Cosmos Saturday night in a North American Soccer League game played in a downpour.

title: Dailey Apologizes For His Remarks
description: Quintin Dailey, the Chicago Bulls' No.1 draft choice, apologized to the people of Chicago for remarks he made last week that caused a furor among fans and the press.

title: HENDERSON HEADS FOR RECORD BOOKS
description: OAKLAND, Calif. TO understand the kind of season Rickey Henderson is having, forget about Maury Wills, Lou Brock, Davey Lopes and the others who turned base running into a science.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * ARA Services Inc. filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering $100 million of unsecured debt securities, to be offered at prices and terms to be decided later.

title: HADL IS ACCUSED OF RECRUITING VIOLATIONS
description: Two former high school football stars say that John Hadl offered them money, $30,000 in one instance, to play for the University of Kansas, according to a report in The Kansas City Star today. Hadl denied the charges.

title: ANY ROLE FOR P.L.O. WITHIN LEBANON BARRED BY ISRAEL
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today to reject any peace proposal that would leave the Palestine Liberation Organization with a political or organizational presence in Lebanon.

title: The Early Screening Program Stands
description: To the Editor:

title: Qaddafi Urges Suicide For Arafat Guerrillas
description: Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has advised the 5,000 Palestinian guerrillas besieged in Beirut by Israeli forces to commit suicide.

title: Bonn Political Leaders On List in Bribery Case
description: A West German prosecutor investigating members of the Cabinet suspected of involvement in a political bribery case has confiscated a list of 40 names of major political leaders from all three principal parties, the news magazine Der Spiegel said today.

title: BEFORE SHE TOOK AN AX
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Jazz Recital Set in Park

title: Anthem at the Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet ended its season last night at the State Theater on a star-spangled note.

title: The City; Derelict in Park Stabbed to Death
description: A man described as a derelict was found stabbed to death yesterday evening in Central Park on a grassy area north of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the police said.

title: Around the Nation; League of Latin Citizens Rejects Political Plans
description: The League of United Latin American Citizens re-elected Tony Bonilla as its president today. But members rejected some of his plans to make the organization a national political force.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Camera column in the Arts and Leisure section yester- day incorrectly stated the time of this week's lunar eclipse. It will begin at 12:22 A.M. tomorrow. An article ap- pears on page 17.

title: 'This Time: The Ladies,' Women Composers
description: The point of ''This Time: The Ladies,'' a Kool Jazz Festival program at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening, was that women have written many of well-known popular songs, although most listeners are unaware that they are the work of women or that women have contributed as much as they have to the pop-song repertory.

title: OPEC IS SAID TO PLAN FRIDAY PARLEY ON OUTPUT
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency ministers' meeting in Vienna on Friday to review its oil output ceiling of 17.5 million barrels a day, a senior Oil Ministry official here said today.

title: Sports World Specials; Conquerors
description: The story has it that about 25 years ago a Californian named Wendell T. Robie set out to test the gumption of the men of his generation. So he issued a challenge: race on horseback along 100 particularly rugged miles of an old postal delivery route from Squaw Valley to Auburn, Calif., in less than 24 hours. The race became a tradition, though it proved to be only a mild prototype of what was to follow.

title: Bob Wilber Recalls Bechet, the Composer
description: Thirty-five years ago, Bob Wilber was a 19-year-old student and protege of Sidney Bechet on clarinet and soprano saxophone. He absorbed the Bechet style - and was absorbed by it -to such an extent that he spent most of the 1950's trying to extricate himself from its domination.

title: RED SOX QUIET BREWER BATS, TAKE FIRST
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, the leading power-hitting team in the major leagues, failed to hit a home run for the first time in 16 games yesterday and lost at home to the Boston Red Sox, 4-1. The defeat, after the Brewers had climbed into a tie for first place in the American League East by winning the first two games of the series, dropped Milwaukee one game behind the Red Sox.

title: Dr. Margaret Dunn Wed to Physician
description: Dr. Margaret Mary Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Dunn Jr. of Oakdale, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. William Anthony Spohn, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Spohn of Springfield, Pa. The Rev. Lee W. Freeman performed the ceremony in St. John Nepomucene Roman Catholic Church in Bohemia, L.I..

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Sent Jerry Dyb- zinski, shortstop, to Charleston of the In- ternational League to make room for Larry Milbourne, acquired Friday from the Minnesota Twins.
description: Optioned Aurelio Lopez, pitcher, to Evansville of the American As- sociation and recalled Dave Rucker, pitcher.

title: Terri M. Solomon Is Married to Howard M. Topaz
description: The marriage of Terri M. Solomon to Howard M. Topaz, lawyers in New York, took place yesterday at Singers Hotel in Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Eugene Markovitz performed the ceremony.

title: Relationships; SAVING THE 'LAST FAMILY'
description: THE message leaps out in flashing red, yellow and blue computer l ettering, a doomsday warning indeed. It reads: SAVE THE LAST HUMAN FAMILY

title: TAX SHELTERS LESS ALLURING
description: Tax shelters, those ubiquitous tax deferral devices used by many in the nation's middle- and upper-income groups, have lost some of their allure this year.

title: Colorado Flames To Play in Denver
description: A Denver group seeking to replace the departed Colorado Rockies with a Central Hockey League franchise reached an agreement Saturday with the city to lease McNichols Sports Arena.

title: 19 Is Safer Than 18
description: ''Why punish 18-year-olds?'' ask opponents of the measure to raise New York's drinking age to 19, which now awaits Governor Carey's signature. It's a fair question - with a persuasive answer.

title: Mass Transit
description: The Legislature resisted making major changes in a package of taxes passed last year to assist the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The chairman of the M.T.A., Richard Ravitch, argued that the taxes were falling short, but the legislative leaders said it was too early to make changes. They pledged to come back in December if the taxes continued to produce less than expected.

title: STATE DEPT. MOVES TO KEEP NAMIBIA ON COURSE
description: The State Department renewed efforts over the weekend to prevent a dispute concerning the presence of Cuban soldiers in Angola from endangering negotiations, scheduled to start in New York on Tuesday, that are intended to end the conflict in South-West Africa.

title: THOUSANDS IN NEW YORK HAIL THE 4TH
description: With fireworks exploding over the Statue of Liberty, a surfboat race in New York Harbor and a parade of mythical Indonesian villains, Chinese lion dancers and teen-age baton twirlers, the metropolitan area celebrated the nation's 206th Independence Day yesterday.

title: MondaySports
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Steve Sax, the rookie second baseman who replaced Davey Lopes, has been one of league's leading hitters. Promotional events rescheduled from the rained out game Saturday night include a showing of the original version of the film ''King Kong'' before the game and a fireworks display after it. (Radio - WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240, 7:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Mariners, at Seattle. (Radio - WABC, 770; 10:30 P.M.).

title: RAHAL IS FIRST IN 500
description: Bobby Rahal, competing in only his fourth race for Indianapolis-style cars, won the Cleveland 500 by more than 20 seconds from Mario Andretti today.

title: Quadriplegic Denied Wedding by Church
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Phoenix has refused to marry a couple because the man, a quadriplegic, is unable to consummate the union, the church says.

title: Going Out Guide
description: UP IN CENTRAL PARK

title: A.B. Dick's New Chief Describes His Strategy
description: Norman J. Nichol has not wasted any time in setting goals for the A.B. Dick Company, a supplier of information processing systems, office duplicators and printing systems.

title: STUDY CONFIRMS USEFULNESS OF MAMMOGRAM DIAGNOSIS
description: The results of a five-year breast cancer detection project indicate that mammography, or breast X-raying, is a highly sensitive technique capable of detecting very early and presumably highly curable cancers in young women as well as those who are older, according to a report made public yesterday in a journal of the American Cancer Society.

title: Gas Ban Shift Held 'Possible'
description: Commerce Under Secretary Lionel Olmer said here on Friday that it was ''possible'' that the Reagan Administration could review its controversial sanctions against a Soviet-Western European gas pipeline if Western countries agreed to restrict credits to the Soviet Union.

title: Oldest Man In the World
description: DINO ZOFF smiles politely when the stranger from the Stati Uniti asks if he has ever heard of Carl Yastrzemski or Pete Rose or Gaylord Perry. ''What sport do they play?'' Zoff asks softly in Italian.

title: Federal Agency Says Poll Finds Support For Evacuation Plan
description: A poll conducted for the Federal Emergency Management Agency reports that most Americans approve of plans to evacuate them from high-risk areas in the event of nuclear war, but that few make it their top civil defense concern and many are unaware the plans exist.

title: HAD MURDER ROLE
description: Joseph A. Peel Jr., a former municipal judge convicted of plotting the 1955 murder of a higher judge in a scheme to become governor of Florida, died of cancer Saturday, nine days after his parole from a Federal prison. He was 58 years old.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 5, 1982
description: International Israel rejected any peace proposal that would leave the Palestine Liberation Organization with a political or organizational presence in Lebanon. All members of the P.L.O. ''without exception'' must leave Lebanon, a statement by the Cabinet said after discussions of the political negotiations being held in Beirut. The statement was an apparent response to reports in Jerusalem that the P.L.O. had offered to withdraw some of its fighters if permitted to keep a political office and a unit in the Lebanese army. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Israeli siege of west Beirut was intensified. Water, food and fuel were prevented from entering the encircled stronghold of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Israeli ground troops blocked almost all traffic into west Beirut while tanks in a hillside village overlooking Beirut fired on Palestinian neighborhoods. (1:5.)

title: G.O.P. CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR STEP UP CAMPAIGNS
description: Merideth Adams and Susan Storey thumped out ''New York, New York'' on the living room piano, and then Lewis E. Lehrman, doffing his jacket so that his bright-red suspenders shone, explained how he planned to become Governor of New York.

title: Jody Griffin Wed To Gary Peterson
description: At Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, N.J., yesterday Jody Griffin, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Bryant W. Griffin, was married to Gary Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Peterson. Both families live in Summit.

title: HITACHI HAS IMAGE JARRED AS INNOVATOR
description: The computer espionage case has tarred Hitachi Ltd. with the image of a company that was eager to buy the technological skill of a rival, presumably because its researchers could not come up with that information by themselves. Yet, in Japan, Hitachi's reputation is just the opposite.

title: U.N. LEADER'S BOLDNESS AND STYLE ELICIT PRAISE
description: Six months into his new job of Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar says he intends to ''shake the house'' and make the United Nations a more efficient and costconscious place.

title: Around the Nation; Large Number of Sharks Sighted Off Coast Beach
description: Great white sharks sighted as close as 40 yards from the shore kept surfers and swimmers out of the water at Stinson Beach today.

title: Lena Horne Encore
description: An extra performance of Lena Horne's one-woman show, ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music,'' has been added by the Tanglewood music festival in Lenox, Mass., tonight at 8:30. There will be a 2:30 concert by student musicians.

title: ISRAELIS KEEP REMINDING BEIRUT THAT SIEGE IS ON
description: At leisurely intervals, the Israeli shells lofted down from the hills here above Beirut's airport and crashed into the battered apartment buildings below.

title: Willing to Stay, Kellogg Says
description: The Kellogg Company has promised to keep its headquarters here if the City of Battle Creek and neighboring Battle Creek Township merge.

title: TIME TO PULL TOGETHER
description: There is much perplexity here in the United States as to what should be our Middle East policy. The abrupt acceptance of the resignation of Secretary Alexander M. Haig Jr. has accentuated this perplexity.

title: SUN BELT HAVING DIFFICULTY LIVING UP TO ITS PROMISE
description: It has been a decade or so since the Sun Belt, that vast, warm-weather half of the country sweeping from Florida to southern California, began seriously to challenge the dominant economic and political power of the Northeast and Middle West.

title: Arafat Asks Socialist Aid
description: Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has ''implored'' a fact-finding mission of the Socialist International to go to Beirut and intervene in the crisis, according to Mario Soares, the former Portuguese Prime Minister. The Socialist delegation, headed by Mr. Soares, arrived here Saturday from Israel.

title: 'When Do I Report?'
description: WHEN the phone rang at his Indianapolis home, Landon Turner reached over from his wheelchair and answered it. ''Have you heard?'' said his caller, a local radio sports announcer. ''Heard what?'' asked Landon Turner, a 6-foot-10-inch forward on Indiana's 1981 national championship basketball team who has been paralyzed from the chest down since an automobile accident nearly a year ago. ''Have I heard what?''

title: Why Prolong the Haitian Torment?
description: What is it about those 1,910 pitiful Haitian migrants that makes otherwise reasonable Reagan Administration officials so relentless?

title: BRITISH FEAR U.S. HURTS RECOVERY
description: British economists fear that the strong American dollar and weak American economy will significantly impede Britain's progress toward recovery.

title: Pope Weighs Salvador Visit
description: Acting Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas said today that Pope John Paul II would like to visit El Salvador next year, but he did not say if the Pope had reached a decision on the trip. The Archbishop made the announcement during a homily here, his first since returning from a three-week trip to Western Europe that included a visit to the Vatican.

title: Dole Calls for 'Flat' Tax Rate
description: Enough tax money went uncollected last year to erase the Federal deficit, and five million people who should have filed a return did not do so, Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, said today.

title: Around the Nation; Auto Dealers Invite Women to Sales Parties
description: The Ford Motor Company is spending $500,000 on wine and gold bracelets to try to increase car sales to women. The project, tried out here and in San Diego, is an attempt to erase impressions among middle-class and professional women that car-buying is a traumatic experience.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Happy Fourth of July, and you know this has got to beat firecrackers.'' - President Reagan, after the shuttle landing at Edwards Air Force Base. (8:3.)

title: 500,000 HOLIDAY REVELERS SEE SHUTTLE LANDING
description: An estimated half-million holiday revelers shouted, clapped and waved American flags today as they peered skyward from the Mojave Desert and glimpsed the space shuttle Columbia's return to earth.

title: Sports World Specials; Bad Sports
description: Of the 24 elite national teams that began play in Spain last month for soccer's world crown, only four will be left in contention at the end of today's matches. Many of the others are learning again, as they return to their homes, that losing in the World Cup is quite often regarded as disgraceful.

title: MUSIC: SCHWARZ CONDUCTS WATERLOO FESTIVAL
description: The major impression from Saturday night's concert at the Waterloo Music Festival in New Jersey was not of the night sky clearing after a storm, nor of the outdoor tent erected in a restored Colonial village that is host to a summer of festivities. The major impression was that the conductor of the Waterloo Festival Orchestra, Gerard Schwarz, is developing into a mature musician with an expanding technique and an energetic and forthright intelligence.

title: MOSCOW'S JULY 4: A BURST OF POLEMICS
description: The American Ambassador to the Soviet Union used a July 4 address on Soviet television today to assure millions of Russians that the United States would never use conventional or nuclear weapons ''except in defense against attack.''

title: YANKEES WIN FOURTH IN A ROW, 3-2
description: The day that the Yankees batted out of order, it seemed that almost no one was in the right place. The Yankees, a team remade to emphasize speed during the offseason and again remade during this season to replace missing power, manufactured a 3-2 victory over the Indians this afternoon by scoring on a bases-loaded walk, on a line drive off the pitcher and on a sacrifice fly.

title: MILLER MOORE
description: Miller Moore, a retired vice president of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, died last Wednesday at his home in Highland Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: REAGAN RIGHTS RECORD AS GOVERNOR HELD HARD TO DOCUMENT
description: President Reagan's record on civil rights while he was Governor of California is generally recognized as better than those of his 32 predecessors but far short of the advances recorded under the current administration of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: MAN WHO WOULD BE BARBECUE KING
description: Many aspire to the Presidency, but not the House majority leader, James C. Wright. The Texas Democrat would settle for the Speakership of the House and a reputation as the best barbecue chef in the United States. He may not talk publicly about the Speakership, in deference to Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, but he makes no bones about his desire to be king of the barbecue.

title: SHUTTLE RETURNS FROM ITS LAST TEST
description: The space shuttle Columbia, completing its fourth and final test flight and now ready to haul the orbital freight of the future, soared out of a clear blue sky and landed smoothly here today to the cheers of a flag-waving Independence Day crowd led by President Reagan.

title: POLES DISCOURAGE PAPAL VISIT
description: The Polish military Government is urging Pope John Paul II to cancel or at least postpone his planned visit to Poland next month, according to Roman Catholic and other Western diplomatic sources.

title: U.S. Markets Closed
description: United States stock and commodity markets are closed today in observance of the Fourth of July. Foreign markets are open.

title: 400 Protest Marijuana Laws
description: Four hundred people gathered today in Lafayette Park across from the White House for a ''smoke-in'' to seek the legalization of marijuana use, the national park police said. The July 4th Cannabis Coalition, one group involved, had been staging protests in various areas, including in front of the Drug Enforcement Administration, since Thursday, a police spokesman said. Seventy-four demonstrators were arrested over the weekend on charges including drug violations and disorderly conduct.

title: 9TH OF JULY IS FOR N.Y.
description: New Yorkers should wait until the end of the week to celebrate their Independence Day.

title: MATT CENTROWITZ: ODYSSEY OF AN UNKNOWN CHAMPION
description: MATT CENTROWITZ of the Bronx is the fastest runner in the world this year at 5,000 meters, the sixth-fastest in history and the fastest American in history. He has been the national champion in the 5,000 the last four years. He was an Olympian in 1976 at 1,500 meters and in 1980 at 5,000.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH HEROIN MAINTENANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sinclair Is First In Peachtree Race
description: Jon Sinclair sprinted past Michael Musyoki today and won the Peachtree Road Race with a time of 28 minutes 6.3 seconds.

title: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A Series of Articles Appearing Periodically
description: Hanging over the sidewalk of East 100th Street, between First and Second Avenues, is a darkened neon sign whose foot-high letters spell out the word ''Drugs.''

title: Kim Keeps Title
description: Kim Chul Ho of South Korea fought to a 15-round draw with Raul Valdez of Mexico today to retain his World Boxing Council super-flyweight title.

title: KEEPER OF THE FLAME
description: I've known her since the age of nine when my fourth-grade teacher took our class of lower Eastside kids on a ferry ride to visit ''Miss Liberty.'' I was spellbound, overawed by the 302-foot (including her pedestal) structure towering above us, giddy over the adventure of climbing the narrow, winding 16-story staircase to the crown. We counted the 171 steps aloud as we made our ascent. A little fearful, our class gathered in front of the 23 windows in her diadem and stared down at the toy-like ships in New York Harbor.

title: Around the World; Nkomo, Claiming Illness, Skips Political Rally
description: Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, facing possible arrest after he was implicated by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe in a gun attack on Mr. Mugabe's home, cited illness today and failed to appear for a long-awaited political rally.

title: DAYTONA RACE TO ALLISON
description: Bobby Allison held off a challenge from Bill Elliott and won the Firecracker 400 Grand National stock car race today. An accident took out four of the top contenders 25 laps from the end.

title: Books of the Times; Famous Women of Myth and History
description: THE BOOK OF THE CITY OF LADIES by Christine de Pizan. Translated by Earl Jeffrey Richards. Foreword by Marina Warner. Persea. 281 pp. $16.95

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CITY IS A HIT WITH TEACHERS
description: In the Grand Ballroom of the Hilton Hotel, the presiding officers of the 66th annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers faced a familiar teachers' problem: how to get the class to settle down, be quiet and listen.

title: Pryor (31-0) Retains Title
description: The undefeated Aaron Pryor retained his World Boxing Association junior welterweight championship today by stopping Akio Kameda of Japan in the sixth round.

title: Anderson Leading In Tour de France
description: Phil Anderson of Australia won the second leg of the 69th Tour de France bicycle race today and also took the overall lead on bonus time.

title: CONNORS WINS WIMBLEDON FINAL
description: The journey took 4 hours 14 minutes, the longest men's singles final in Wimbledon history. At the finish, an aroused challenger, Jimmy Connors, had dethroned the champion, John McEnroe, in five sets that varied from boringly slow to fiercely brilliant.

title: MEXICO'S RULING PARTY SEEN AS CERTAIN ELECTION WINNER
description: Almost ritualistically, millions of Mexicans voted today fully aware that the country's next President will be the ruling party's nominee, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado.

title: LIGHTHOUSE HAS DAY IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: The Portland Headlight, a lighthouse almost 200 years old, has been rededicated, with Vice President Bush presiding, as Greater Portland celebrates the fact that it has been around 150 years longer than that.

title: New York Day by Day
description: A Comic-Book Fourth

title: Patricia Koch Married To Eugene Gelernter
description: Patricia Ann Koch, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Koch of Millburn, N.J., and Eugene M. Gelernter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Boaz Gelernter of Long Branch, N.J., were married yesterday by Rabbi Herbert Wiener at the Woodlake Country Club in Lakewood, N.J.

title: Janice Siegel, Trial Lawyer, Married to Dr. L.A. Marks
description: Janice Siegel, a trial lawyer for the Federal Department of Justice, land and natural resources division, and Lloyd Alan Marks, a physician and electrical engineer, who is a fellow in pediatric cardiology at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore, were married yesterday. Rabbi Noah Golinkin of Columbia, Md., performed the ceremony in Oldfield, L.I., in the garden of the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Petsco, friends of the couple.

title: SUICIDE IS REPORTED
description: President Antonio Guzman, who was scheduled to leave office next month, died today from a gunshot wound in the head.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: 'The Music Keeper' - Wagner and Nazism

title: COMPETITION SPURS LONDON'S BROKERS
description: On the London Stock Exchange, the only bright thing for brokers these days is high share prices. Growing competition may result in the elimination of fixed commission rates and the securities market could be restructured.

title: Around the Nation; Search for Missing Boy Focuses on 2-Mile Radius
description: Hundreds of volunteers seeking a 12-year-old boy who disappeared five days ago in the rugged Rocky Mountain National Park today narrowed much of their search to within a two-mile radius of where the Illinois boy was last seen.

title: ORTHODOX JEWISH DIVORCE: THE RELIGIOUS DILEMMA
description: In the Orthodox Jewish community she is called an ''agunah'' or ''anchored-down'' wife. She is not free to remarry even though she and her former husband may have obtained a civil divorce. She cannot obtain the religious divorce her faith requires because, under Jewish law, the man must give the bill of divorce or ''get'' to the woman, and the man refuses to do so.

title: Around the World; Indefinite Strike Halts Most British Trains
description: Britain's locomotive engineers began an indefinite strike today, ignoring Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's appeal for a ''Falkland spirit'' of patriotism.

title: ASSESSING GOVERNMENT'S APPROACH TO INTELLIGENCE
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman startled Washington in April when he announced his intention to resign as the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. He said he wanted to go into private business, but associates asserted that the real reasons for his departure were policy differences with the Reagan Administration and mounting frustration over dealing with the White House National Security Council staff. His retirement from the Government and the Navy complete, Mr. Inman sat down last week to discuss intelligence issues.

title: Ann Harriet Appelbaum Married to Neal Borovitz
description: Ann Harriet Appelbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Appelbaum of Decatur, Ill., was married in New York yesterday to Rabbi Neal Ivan Borovitz, son of Mildred Borovitz of Cleveland, and the late Jerry Borovitz. Rabbi Morton Leifman, vice president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, of which the bride is the general counsel, and Rabbi Lawrence Englander performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Grill.

title: BRIDGEPORT'S NEW FIREHOUSE SETS OFF LAND DISPUTE
description: The day after Bridgeport's new $2.3 million firehouse was dedicated recently, officials made a startling discovery: that the city did not own the land under it.

title: Syrian President Meets With the Saudis' King
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria arrived unexpectedly in Saudi Arabia tonight and was met at the Taif airport by King Fahd, the official Saudi Press Agency said.

title: Freddie Mac Mortgage Bar
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has decided to ban homeowners from taking over the lowinterest mortgages it holds, an action that could further reduce prices of residential real estate.

title: Concord All-Stars Pay Tribute to Tjader
description: With the recent death of the vibes player Cal Tjader, Saturday's ''Concord Jazz'' program, which he was to headline at Carnegie Hall, became a tribute to him, featuring the remaining three acts on the bill - the Concord Jazz All-Stars, the Tania Maria Quartet and the Charlie Byrd Trio. While none of the three was able to kick up any particularly bright sparks, they at least offered a varied program that balanced staid swing alongside Latin-American exotica and gentle bossa nova.

title: Body of 3d Victim Recovered In Crash of Plane in L.I. Sound
description: A third body has been recovered in the crash of a small plane June 27, authorities said today. Crew members from the yacht Tarquin notified the Coast Guard late Saturday that a body was in the water about a quarter mile south of Buoy 42 outside Mamaroneck Harbor.

title: McEnroe Fined
description: John McEnroe was fined $500 today for ''verbal abuse'' during his semifinal match against Tim Mayotte Saturday at the Wimbledon championships.

title: Harnischfeger President Is First Outside Family
description: William W. Goessel spent the first 20 years of his career working in the foundry - ''you know,'' he says, ''that hot, grimy place'' - before moving upstairs in 1960 to join the management at the Beloit Corporation in Beloit, Wis. Mr. Goessel is now leaving his position as an executive vice president at Beloit, a closely held maker of pulp and paper mill machines and foundry casings.

title: THE ROAD TO OPERA STARDOM CAN SOMETIMES BYPASS EUROPE
description: Stephanie Sundine, like many other emerging American opera singers, will have some decisions to make. American-born, American-trained, American-nurtured, this 34-yearold soprano has made her way from the University of Illinois through America's smaller opera houses and finally to an attention-commanding success at the Opera Theater of St. Louis last month in Prokofiev's ''Maddalena.'' Critics praised her ''splendid, intelligently used voice.''

title: This is the seventh article of a series appearing periodically on the effects of changing economic conditions on Americans in one small city.
description: Tickets to the Oak Ridge Boys concert went on sale at the Five Seasons Center here the other day, and the jeans and T-shirt crowd was lined up out into the street an hour before the window opened.

title: Briefing
description: Negative Campaigning

title: POLAND ADVANCES ALONG WITH FRANCE
