description: The Solidarity banners were torn down in the stands but Poland never lost its solidarity on the field tonight, playing to a 0-0 draw with the Soviet Union that allowed the Poles to advance into the semifinals of the World Cup.

title: TEST IN A CRISIS FOR NEW OFFICER
description: James Byrne, a probationary police officer who graduated from the Police Academy 10 days ago, had just entered the starting time of his third foot patrol in his logbook when a man with an accent called out to him on Fifth Avenue.

title: France Advances
description: France defeated Northern Ireland, 4-1, today to earn a semifinal berth in the World Cup for the first time in 24 years. Dominique Rocheteau scored two goals and Alain Giresse had one for the winners.

title: SANDRA HAYNIE WINS AGAIN
description: Sandra Haynie outplayed Beth Daniel and shot a four-under-par 68 today to win the $200,000 Peter Jackson Classic by one stroke.

title: BELMONT MARK SET BY 'BUCK'
description: Just when the consensus was taking hold that the older horses this year were a lackluster bunch, Silver Buck ran the fastest mile and a quarter ever at Belmont Park yesterday to win the 96th Suburban Handicap by three lengths.

title: ISRAELIS INTERCEPT WATER AND FOOD FOR WEST BEIRUT
description: Israeli troops tightened their siege of west Beirut today, preventing food, water and fuel from entering the encircled stronghold of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: STAGE: A KABUKI VIRTUOSO IN A DRAMA OF SUBTLETY
description: It is standard thinking by now to consider Japan's Kabuki theater an ''actor's theater,'' but it would be more complete to see it specifically as a star performer's art.

title: Charles River Crew Wins
description: The Charles River Rowing Association successfully defended the Thames Challenge Cup today to give the United States its only major trophy in the 133d Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Man Kills Family and Himself
description: A man shot to death five members of his family and then killed himself Friday, officials said today. The Sanders County Sheriff's Department said Loxley Sexton, 40 years old, shot his wife, Linda, 39, from whom he was separated; three children, Debbie, 18, Bobby, 16, and Michael, 8, and his mother-in-law, Frances Cunningham, 65.

title: ISRAELIS KILL 2 IN THE WEST BANK
description: Two Arabs were killed and 12 others were wounded today in the West Bank as Palestinians in the occupied territory staged their first protests against the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, an Israeli military official said.

title: The City; 2 Climb Tower At Coney Island
description: Two Brooklyn residents climbed the parachute tower in the Coney Island Amusement Park yesterday and flew the flag of Puerto Rico from its top. Both were brought down by police officers, but it took them almost two hours to do so, the police reported.

title: GUZMAN SINGULAR VOW: ONE TERM
description: Antonio Guzman, who was elected President of the Dominican Republic in 1978, was credited with moving the military out of politics, and last year he became the first elected President since the country was founded in 1844 to announce while still in power that he would not seek re-election.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Miss Liberty Crowns the Day

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Forty-five percent of the phone calls from customers go unanswered. A customer can be on the phone for 20 minutes without reaching a Transit Authority representative.

title: Cobb and Weaver Await the Word
description: George Benton, the challenger's trainer, was still not sure the other night. ''Is there a fight or isn't there?'' said Benton from the New Mexico training camp of Randall (Tex) Cobb, the heavyweight contender. In a situation reminiscent of the Mike Weaver-Gerry Cooney-James Tillis morass of a year ago, Cobb has been preparing to meet Weaver for the World Boxing Association heavyweight title. But the fight may not happen.

title: MUSIC: AMERICANA ON FOURTH
description: CARAMOOR'S summer season of concerts celebrated Independence Day in Katonah Sunday with an afternoon of American music. The pieces themselves were familiar, but the Caramoor Festival Orchestra, deftly conducted here by Michael Feldman, managed often to present them in unfamiliar forms.

title: OLD KENTON BANDSMEN REMEMBER THEIR LEADER
description: NINE one-time members of Stan Kenton's orchestra joined forces Sunday to create a program in tribute to the late band leader at Avery Fisher Hall on the final day of this year's Kool Jazz Festival. It was a presentation that succeeded to a remarkable degree in catching the excitment and color and theatricality of Mr. Kenton's music.

title: CONNORS WINS BIG FOLLOWING IN ENGLAND
description: The first time Jimmy Connors won at Wimbledon, it seemed like a fairy tale. He and Chris Evert were the tournament's ''love double'' in 1974, went to the victory ball as an engaged couple and danced to the strains of ''The Girl That I Marry.''

title: ISRAELI GUNS SHELL PALESTINIAN CAMPS AND CIVILIAN AREAS
description: Israeli gunboats and artillery bombarded Palestinian camps and residential neighborhoods of west Beirut today, and the blockade of the area created serious shortages of food, gasoline and some medical supplies.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Mike Scott (6-5) is out of the bullpen and back in the Mets' rotation. He beat the Expos, 2-1, in his last outing last Thursday. (Television - Channel 9; Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Seattle, 10:30 P.M. The last two times Gaylord Perry, the 43-year-old Mariner, pitched against the Yankees, he picked up career victories No. 299 and 300. (Television -SportChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 10:30 P.M.) Basketball New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman Gym, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. Maurice Lucas of the Knicks and Jan van Breda Kolff of the Nets play for Pony in the first game. Tony Grier, fourth-round draft pick of the San Antonio Spurs from South Florida, plays for Dyckman in the second game.

title: Kleer-Vu's Founder Prepares to Step Down
description: For an executive who founded a company and nurtured it for about 30 years, the idea of retiring and selling a controlling interest to another company can be a difficult prospect.

title: Business Digest; TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1982; The Economy
description: The Southeast's current unemployment problem may be a sign of underlying troubles that could hinder the ability of the region's industries to remain competitive. Although many Northerners perceive the Sun Belt as one continuous flow of prosperity, five of the nine Southeast states had unemployment rates higher than the national average in May. (Page A1.)

title: One State, Fiscal '82; Third article of a series appearing periodically on the Reagan economic program's impact on Pennsylvania
description: The surprise made the blow feel heavier. It came in a thick brown envelope, mailed March 19. Inside was a form letter to Michael Harlee from his employer with blank spaces inked in advising him that on April 7 he would be without a job.

title: 5 PEOPLE REPORTED SHOT IN CLASHES IN WEST BANK
description: Five people were wounded by gunfire today in clashes between Israeli soldiers and Arabs in the occupied West Bank, according to Palestinian sources.

title: A Blooper: Batting Out Of Turn
description: W ho tells a player when it is his turn to bat? The manager's lineup card tells him, the one that is posted on the back wall of the dugout. Every player checks it a couple of hours before the game to find out who is playing where and who bats when. It is posted early by a coach, so that the players will even take batting practice in the right order.

title: Judith Cohen Wed To Dr. B.L. Rosen
description: Judith Lisa Cohen, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Gerson D. Cohen of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Lewis Rosen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Rosen of Highland Park, Ill. The ceremony was performed at the Park Avenue Synagogue by the bride's father, who is chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

title: OLYMPIA BREWING UNIT IN PABST BID
description: A subsidiary of the Olympia Brewing Company, which agreed last month to be acquired by the Pabst Brewing Company, is offering to buy 4 million shares, or about 49 percent of Pabst, at $25 each, or a total of $100 million.

title: 7,000 Followers of Guru Gather in Oregon Hills
description: A remote section of central Oregon's sagebrush-covered hills is resplendent in red as several throusand disciples of a guru from India meditate at ''the feet of the awakened one.''

title: UNEXPLORED PROPOSALS
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: SAGA OF LOVE AND WAR IN JAPAN
description: KEI KUMAI'S ''Love and Faith of Ogin,'' which opens today at the Public Theater, is a decorous saga of 16th-century Japan. It tells of Ogin (Ryoko Nakano), a beautiful and devoted young woman in love with Takayama Ukon, a Christian warrior (Kichiemon Nakamura) who is in the service of the ferocious warlord Hideyoshi (Toshiro Mifune).

title: 'Jammin' With Hamp,' All-Star Presentation
description: ''JAMMIN' WITH HAMP,'' one of the jazz festival's two finales on Sunday, featuring Lionel Hampton and a roster of all-star guests including Teddy Wilson, his longtime colleague, began very shakily. But some three hours later, it soared to a thrilling climax with a fiery version of Mr. Hampton's theme song, ''Flyin' Home,'' in which the great master of the vibes played the drums, gleefully twirling the sticks, while his lusty 16-piece band, joined by no less than Dizzy Gillespie, Stan Getz and Arnett Cobb, raised the rafters.

title:
HOW TO SAVE THE WORLD;
Why, despite American-Soviet negotiations since the 1950's and current popular protests, are we closer than ever to the horror of nuclear war? Two fundamental causes of the nuclear arms race are rarely discussed.
description: First, American and Soviet leaders, who alone have the power, clearly lack the political will to negotiate an end to this 30-year madness. And they lack the will because, unlike ordinary citizens, they do not sufficiently feel the threat of nuclear holocaust as a personal danger. Both leaderships embrace a nuclear strategy of assured destruction of the other's citizenry that leaves both leaderships intact to wage ''controlled and protracted nuclear war.'' Their ''plan for continuity of government'' is reflected in separate and profoundly unequal provisions for civil defense in both countries. Civil defense for ordinary American and Soviet citizens is a government charade inspired by conventional bombardments of past wars. But for hundreds, or even thousands, of American and Soviet leaders (''national command authorities,'' as they call themselves), civil defense is a high-priority and potentially real sanctuary (''survival of strategic command, control, and communications system'') that involves hollowed mountains, special aircraft and superhardened bunkers. No wonder leaders can authorize plans for the instant incineration and radiation of millions of people; they expect to be elsewhere.

title: The U.N. Today; July, 6, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why, in impact disasters such as air crashes, do the victims' shoes so often come off?

title: NAMIBIA'S REBELS SUSPICIOUS OF U.S.
description: A senior representative of the insurgent group battling South Africa's control of South-West Africa said today that the United States had failed to dispel the organization's suspicions about Washington's motives in the conflict over the disputed territory.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Junior Year in Manhattan

title: A Secret Problem
description: Jerry Argovitz will be in tough negotiations with George Young, general manager of the Giants, this week in Houston as the National Football League team tries to sign its No.1 draft choice, Butch Woolfolk of Michigan. But Argovitz, Woolfolk's agent, has sympathy for Young: ''He's really caught in the middle.''

title: HOLIDAY CROWDS SAMPLE PRISTINE DAY'S PLEASURES
description: On a day as bright as a diamond, New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors flocked to beaches and parks, an armada paraded on the Hudson and shrieking squadrons of jet fighters put on a spectacular show yesterday, as the long Fourth of July weekend drew to a close.

title: Advertising; The Race In Quartz Watches
description: ONE certainly doesn't have to convince Japanese marketers of the power of television advertising. They've tried it. They like it. That certainly applies to K. Hattori & Company, marketer of the Seiko watch, which was introduced into the United States 12 years ago and now has over 47 percent of the quality watch market, nudging Swiss-made Omega out of the lead.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 6, 1982
description: International West Beirut was bombarded by Israeli gunboats and artillery, while ground troops continued the blockade of the Moslem half of the capital, where Palestinian guerrillas are encamped, causing serious shortages of food, gasoline and some medical supplies. An end to the Israeli siege, intended to force out the Palestine Liberation Organization and its members, was demanded by Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan, who called the siege ''criminal.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.) Restoring the cease-fire in Lebanon was essential, the United States said and called on Israel to observe a United Nations Security Council resolution demanding that the Israeli blockade of supplies to west Beirut be lifted. (A8:1-2.)

title: Equal Rights, the Retail Way
description: Try it my way, the President advises supporters of equal rights for women. They tried to achieve their goal wholesale, but now time has run out for the proposed equal rights amendment. What they should have been doing all along, Mr. Reagan says, is to try it retail.

title: Holiday Closings
description: All United States stock and commodities markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Foreign markets were open.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: GOOD news for fashionable knitters: Vogue Knitting is back after an a bsence of more than 10 years. The first issue of the how-to magazineo ffers 45 sweaters in the latest styles, including folkloric p atterns, rugged Celtic and countrified English looks and soft r omantic sweaterings trimmed with lace or pearls. Some, like the JoanV ass pullovers, look quite simple to make, while others are geared t o challenge the experienced knitter (see Kansai Yamamoto's intricatem ixtures of patterns and yarns). Twelve of the sweaters are availablea s kits, which come with yarn, instructions and trimmings at prices f rom $33 to $129.

title: Chess: Theory Is Often Obscured In a Wild Slugging Match
description: What begins as science often ends in a bare-knuckles brawl. The game between Yasser Seirawan of Seattle, a United States co-champion, and Larry Christiansen, a Modesto, Calif., grandmaster, in the fourth round of the Phillips & Drew International Tournament in London illustrated avant-garde theory in an important variation of the Queen's Indian Defense. But the opening was hardly over before theory was obscured in a wild slugging match.

title: English Eliminated
description: Spain 0 England 0

title:
DEVIL TO PAY IN SEOUL;
South Korea today is in the midst of a deeprunning, three-year-old crisis. In October 1979 this crisis brought the downfall of Park Chung Hee, and today it threatens his successor, Chun Doo Hwan. Also in jeopardy is the American relationship with Korea, now in its centennial year. Why? Because three American Presidents over the past decade have ignored, or supported, the repression of democratic dissidents.
description: Recent events, however bad, only symbolize this crisis. There will be worse to come. In March, student dissidents torched the American Cultural Center in Pusan and attacked the American role in backing President Chun and in aiding the suppression of the Kwangju rebellion of May 1980. Theology students did this, and their Roman Catholic priests sheltered them while arranging for their surrender. Now the fathers are on trial under the harsh National Security Law, and the students are termed Marxists. In May came the worst financial scandal in Korean history. Shady manipulations on the informal money market running into the hundreds of millions of dollars shook an economy that exists on state-controlled credit. Several companies went bankrupt, much of the Cabinet resigned and President Chun drew the wagons around the Blue House, stonewalling amid allegations that the loan sharks had close ties to him and his wife. In early June, women who are electronics workers held two Americans hostage for nine hours, until the American Embassy notified the Korean police and had the workers arrested.

title: U.S. Counts On Savings Bond Move; Rate Rise Seen As Aid on Debt
description: The Treasury, faced with the prospect of huge budget deficits, is counting on a reversal of the current big cash drain from United States savings bonds to help solve its financing problems.

title: JOHN WATTS, PIONEER IN COMPOSING MUSIC FOR THE SYNTHESIZER
description: John Watts, a composer whose works and performances helped popularize the electronic synthesizer as a musical instrument, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 years old.

title: 25 PERSONS HURT
description: Twenty-five sightseers were injured yesterday when a Circle Line boat struck a concrete bulkhead at the end of a West Side pier after completing a trip around Manhattan, authorities reported. None of the injuries were serious.

title: DEMOCRATIC GUBERNATORIAL CAMPAIGNS HIT FULL STRIDE
description: To the despair of his political handlers, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo lingers in the Concord Hotel to sign autographs as the clock ticks, ticks, ticks past the scheduled start of a speech miles away at Grossinger's.

title: Governor Brown Assails Reagan on Nuclear Arms
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. told the National Education Association convention today that President Reagan's program on nuclear weapons ''is a form of unilateral economic disarmament.''

title: Mary Bacon Released
description: Mary Bacon, the jockey, has been released from Herrick Hospital in Berkeley, Calif., after she sustained head injuries in a riding accident at Golden Gate Fields. Hospital officials said Mrs. Bacon had made a slow but steady recovery since the June 9 mishap in which she was unseated and struck by another horse in the race. Doctors expect her to make a full recovery.

title: Oklahoma Bank Fails
description: The Penn Square Bank, Oklahoma's fourth-largest bank, with heavy investments in the oil and gas industry, failed today, officials said. It was taken over by a team from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Alan Whitney, a spokesman for the Federal agency, said in a telephone interview from Washington that the bank would open Tuesday as the Deposit Insurance National Bank of Oklahoma City.

title: DANIEL SULLIVAN, EX-F.B.I. AGENT WHO HELPED CATCH DILLINGER, DIES
description: Daniel P. Sullivan, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who helped track down John Dillinger and later had a long career fighting organized crime in Miami, died Sunday of heart failure. He was 76 years old and lived in Miami.

title: 2 AIRLINES REALIGNING DEBT LOAD
description: Continental Airlines and Texas International Airlines disclosed yesterday that all but one of their major lenders had agreed in principle to restructure a total of $295 million of the sibling carriers' long-term debt.

title: A BUSINESS STUDY FINDS THE SUBWAYS TO BE BADLY RUN
description: A group of business executives who spent a year studying the New York City subway system from within report that they have found archaic procedures, inefficient use of manpower, confused lines of authority and woeful customer relations.

title: CATCH-51 IS ALIVE; It's finger-pointing time in J-51 land.  This tax abatement program for real-estate developers - the linchpin of what passes for a housing policy in the Koch administration - is now in limbo, and the administration and its critics are blaming each other for the outcome.
description: Much remains confused about the negotiations in Albany except that they collapsed on Saturday and the Legislature went home for the summer without reviving the J-51 program, whose state enabling legislation had expired on June 1.

title: Management Group Has New Chief
description: The American Management Associations, a not-for-profit institution that has ties to virtually all major American corporations, has a new chief executive.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ARDS. Rationalism and Reason in Poli- tics. By Jeane J. Kirkpatrick. 270 pages. American Enterprise/Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Imperial Oil Cuts
description: Imperial Oil, Canada's largest oil company, said today that it had cut 500 top management jobs and that its president, James Livingstone, 62 years old, is to retire early.

title: Fifth Man Guilty In Seychelles Plot
description: A South African who said he was an intelligence agent for the South African Government was found guilty of treason today in connection with last year's bungled coup in the Seychelles and will learn Tuesday if he will hang or go to jail.

title: EAST GERMANY SIZES UP ITS ANTIMILITARIST GROUPS
description: The East German Government is reportedly considering how to deal with small, scattered antimilitarist groups that are increasingly disputing official policies.

title: WAREHOUSES BULGE WITH SURPLUS CHEESE, BUTTER AND DRIED MILK
description: The other week, as in almost every other week of the year, more than 40 million pounds of surplus butter, cheese and dried milk, all of it bought by the nation's taxpayers, were hauled into spaces the Agriculture Department leases in 500 warehouses scattered across the country.

title: Wickes's Examiner Brings Experience
description: Robert M. Loeffler, the Los Angeles lawyer who has been named examiner in the Wickes Companies' bankruptcy proceedings, knows his way around troubled companies. He was the court-appointed trustee for the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of America after it collapsed in 1973.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Festivities' Counterpoint

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: *Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., has named Gene A Brothers president of it Midwec operating unit.

title: Coe-Ovett Race Is Off
description: A leg injury has forced Sebastian Coe to withdraw from his 3,000-meter race against Steve Ovett, scheduled for the Crystal Palace in London July 17.

title: TUITION TAX CREDITS CAN ONLY PROVE DIVISIVE AND EXPENSIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: The nuclear freeze issue, as an influence on this year's elections, is a political enigma. Most experts on both sides of the political aisle feel the issue will matter in this year's elections, and that it will help Democrats more than Republicans because more Democrats favor a freeze. But they are hard put to identify races where it seems to rate as a key question in voters' minds.

title: Hood, Hope of Tulsa Wins Shakey's Account
description: Hood, Hope & Associates, based in Tulsa, Okla., and the largest ad agency in the state, has been appointed the national agency for Shakey's, the Dallas-based fast-food chain, and will be taking over from Chiat/Day in Los Angeles.

title: SMOKING AFFECTS SEX
description: Smoking as few as two high-nicotine cigarettes can depress sexual arousal in men, according to researchers at Florida State University.

title: MARINERS RALLY TO SET BACK YANKEES BY 5-4
description: When the Yankees were good and the Seattle Mariners bad, the Yankees had trouble in the Kingdome. Now the Mariners are good and the Yankees are not faring too well, and the Yankees still have trouble in the Kingdome.

title: A SLIMMER OUTLET, UNDAUNTED BY REBUFF, STILL SEEKS MERGER
description: On July 6, 1981, some 87 years after two traveling salesmen set up shop in Providence, R.I., the Outlet Company heralded the announcement that it was being acquired by Columbia Pictures Industries.

title: ARGENTINA READIES CURBS ON ECONOMY
description: Argentina's new Economics Minister tonight announced an emergency economic program of strict controls that would include a devaluation of the peso to deal with an economy he said is ''in a state of destruction without precedence.''

title: CITY TO CONTINUE TAX BENEFITS ON HOUSING AFTER LAW ENDS
description: The Koch administration plans to continue tax breaks for the upgrading of residential housing, even though the state legislation that authorized such incentives has lapsed, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: DALLAS UTILITY OFFERING BONDS IN A LIGHT WEEK
description: As expected, the list of new offerings of fixed-income tax-exempt and taxable corporate securities this week has been shortened by the Fourth of July holiday and consists mostly of relatively small state and municipal tax-exempt issues. Only one important corporate issue is on the calendar this week: $50 million of Dallas Power and Light Company 30-year bonds, scheduled for sale Thursday.

title: TV: EARLY-MORNING NEWS PROGRAMS
description: ATLANTA'S Ted Turner started it all with his 24-hour Cable News Network operation that evidently proved news addicts were looking for a fix just about any hour of the day. Inevitably, there will be other 24-hour news operations on cable. Meanwhile, the networks are moving to expand their own news-scheduling territories. Yesterday, two early-morning shows made their debuts: ''ABC News This Morning,'' at 6 o'clock, and ''Early Today'' on NBC-TV, at 6:30. In essence, both are providing still another smattering of headline services.

title: Grain Elevator Collapse Spills Corn on Iowa Road
description: One of Iowa's largest grain elevators collapsed today, spilling corn up to seven feet deep across a major county road, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Inspector General Killed by Model Plane
description: Paul R. Boucher, the inspector general of the Small Business Administration, was fatally injured Sunday when he was struck by a remote control model airplane. He was 40 years old.

title: IT'S TIME TO END TOBACCO SERFDOM
description: To the Editor:

title: Cody Friend's Pension Brings No Illinois Action
description: The state Department of Insurance says that a friend of the late John Cardinal Cody is not eligible for a church pension she receives, but that no laws have been broken.

title: REALITY IS ALSO A STAR IN MOVIE 'THE RIGHT STUFF'
description: SAN FRANCISCO GLENN FARR sits at a shiny silver metal table amid boxes of redand-yellow plastic film cores. For 12 hours a day, his world is the acrid environment of an editing room, where rolls of film twisting back and forth always leave a slightly burnt smell in the air.

title: Rooting for the Caddie
description: J.C. Snead, who finished in a tie for 26th place and won $2,559, left the Western Open with bitter memories. His wife, Sue, says he won't compete again in Oak Brook, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.

title: Mahalia Jackson Given Show-Business Salute
description: THE gospel program at St. Peter's Church as part of the jazz festival Sunday was advertised as ''A Tribute to Mahalia Jackson,'' but according to the printed programs that were given out at the door, that was actually the subtitle. The entire title was ''Chapman Roberts and Friends in the Gospel According to Broadway: A Tribute to Mahalia Jackson.''

title: Ruling Out Perfection
description: The perfect 900 series Glenn Allison bowled last week will not be recognized as an official record by the American Bowling Congress because the lanes at the La Habra (Calif.) 300 Bowl were found to have been illegally oiled. An A.B.C. inspector examined the lanes where Allison had strung together the three perfect games in a mixed-doubles event.

title: 600 Falkland Prisoners Being Moved by British
description: About 600 Argentine prisoners, the last large group still held from the war over the Falkland Islands, were being taken today by ship from the islands to an undisclosed location, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: Steve Garvey's Future on Line
description: P art by part, as if rebuilding an automobile instead of a ball club, the Los Angeles Dodgers are assembling their ''next'' team, even while their current team reigns as World Series champions. The rookie second baseman Steve Sax is this year's ignition, just as Fernando Valenzuela was last year's brakes. Two young sluggers, Mike Marshall and Greg Brock, loom as next year's axles, especially if Steve Garvey is a discarded transmission by then, a transmission that the Mets, among other clubs, would surely covet.

title: REJECTION OF MAVERICK MISSILE IS SOUGHT
description: The $5 billion Maverick missile program should not move from the drawing board to production because tests fail to show it can destroy tanks as its backers contend, Government auditors said today.

title: Secret Site Selected For Sihanouk's Base
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of the new coalition of Cambodian resistance groups, and his two coalition partners have agreed upon a secret site in western Cambodia for the seat of the government, diplomatic sources said today.

title: ARABS QUESTION U.S. ROLE
description: The Arab world recognizes that American questioning of Israeli actions and claims in Lebanon does not mean acceptance of Arab perceptions or positions. But it has, we think, made Americans more sensitive to our legitimate aspirations. This new awareness opens up political opportunities that should be pursued, because forthcoming developments throughout the Arab world will require a large measure of American understanding and responsiveness. Yet it must also be underlined that without this understanding the Arab-American dialogue could be interrupted and relations could be damaged even further.

title: CONNECTICUT'S TOBACCO: GONE WITH THE WIND?
description: When times were best, the 60 acres of tobacco on the C.F. Woodford & Son farm here would have tickled a young man's waist by now.

title: Defending a Name
description: Brendan Byrne, the former Governor of New Jersey, has more than just a home-state rooting interest in the hockey team that now resides in the Garden State, the New Jersey Devils.

title: Slaying in Capital Subway
description: A man was stabbed to death early today in what was reported by the authorities as the first homicide recorded in the six years of operation of the Washington area subway.

title: DEEP BENEATH THE SEA LIES KEY TO ITS CHEMISTRY
description: EXPERIMENTS in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans, ranging from measurements in the deepest hole yet drilled into the sea floor to pounding the bottom with a remotely controlled hammer, have yielded a revolutionary view of the sea floor. The investigations have helped to explain the processes that have shaped the oceanic crust, generated ore deposits and controlled the composition of the sea itself.

title: RAIL STRIKE, SECOND IN A WEEK, STRANDS THOUSANDS IN BRITAIN
description: A nationwide rail strike stranded hundreds of thousands of passengers across Britain for a second day today, but management for British Rail said there were increasing signs that the walkout might be broken.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Tesla: Man Out of Time By Margaret Cheney. Prentice-Hall. 320 pages, illustrated. $16.95. It is difficult to think of a scientist-inventor of the past century more fascinating and enigmatic than Nikola Tesla. He was not universally admired. Waldemar Kaempffert, a former science editor of this newspaper, described him as ''an intellectual boa constrictor,'' a ''medieval practitioner of black arts ... as vague as an oriental mystic.''

title: Greek Economists Join New Cabinet
description: A new Greek Cabinet was sworn in today after the first shuffle of the Government since the Socialists came to power nine months ago.

title: Nigerian Oil Margin
description: Nigeria has doubled, to $1.60 a barrel, the profit margin that may be taken by companies producing its crude oil, sources said today. The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group of Companies are among concerns operating in Nigeria.

title: FAIR'S FAIR BUT WHAT'S FAIR?
description: Kenneth Sims, a defensive lineman who was the top choice in this year's National Football League draft, now has signed a contract that his agent says will yield him more than ''any major executive at any major company will be making.''

title: ARTILLERY FIRE THUNDERS IN HILLS SOUTH OF BEIRUT
description: On the outskirts of this hilly town south of Beirut, Israeli soldiers and Palestinian guerrillas have been exchanging artillery and small arms fire since Sunday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LITERARY STROLL

title: Market Place; Cautious View Of a Chartist
description: member of the American Stock Exchange, is one of those market watchers who predict stock movements based on statistics from the past performance of stocks. He argues that the action will be so fast that only the luckiest and nimblest of traders can get profits before the rally fizzles.

title: HIKE MASS TRANSIT AND MANY WILL HIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Russian Standoff

title: ANALYSTS EXPECT RATE RISE
description: The credit markets benefited last week from a technical rally, which ended a five-week decline and raised prices of long-term Treasury bonds as much as two full points, or $20 for each $1,000 of face value. The intermediate maturities gained about a point, while yields on Treasury bills fell about 40 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.

title: Curfew Is Imposed On Nkomo's District
description: The police imposed a 9 P.M.-to-4 A.M. curfew today on the predominantly black western suburbs of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second largest city and capital of the troubled southern province of Matabeleland.

title: AIDE SEES HIMSELF AS THE 'BAD GUY'
description: As the White House political director, Edward J. Rollins may have the most contradictory mandate of any Reagan aide.

title: PADRES ERASE 6-RUN DEFICIT TO TOP EXPOS
description: Ruppert Jones capped a six-run seventh inning with a single that brought home the go-ahead run as the San Diego Padres rallied to beat the Montreal Expos, 8-6, tonight.

title: Study Finds Boys Preferred as Firstborns
description: If mothers could choose the sex of their first child, such an option could lead to a ''predominance of males'' in the country, a Princeton University researcher said today.

title: 2 COLLEGE SECTORS CLASH OVER LIMITED RESOURCES
description: VIOLATIONS of the informal truce between public and private universities in New York State are occurring ever more frequently these days as the two sides feel growing pressure to cope with tighter resources and an impending scarcity of students.

title: CHINA COUNTS ITS QUARTER OF THE WORLD'S NOSES
description: China has begun the largest census in history in a meticulous effort to discover just how many people it has. The Peking Government claims about a billion citizens out of a total world population of 4.5 billion, though officials concede that no one knows the exact number of Chinese.

title: ITALY OUTS BRAZIL, 3-2, TO GAIN SEMIFINAL
description: Paolo Rossi, who returned this spring from a two-year suspension involving a betting scandal, helped bring Italy one of its greatest moments on a soccer field this afternoon when he scored the three goals that eliminated Brazil, 3-2, and gave Italy a spot in the World Cup semifinals.

title: CHILD-PORNOGRAPHY RULING IS SEEN ACTING AS DETERRENT
description: Prosecutors and the police in New York City said yesterday that last Friday's decision by the United States Supreme Court upholding a state law that bars child pornography should make that closed, clandestine world even smaller and more secretive.

title: A Concert of Fireworks And Folklore of Cuba
description: ARCHIE SHEPP, Daniel Ponce and Ronald Shannon Jackson and their bands took their turns on stage at the end of the South Street Seaport Museum's long pier on the night of July 4, at one of the last of this year's jazz festival concerts.

title: HOT NOW AND COOL LATER: STYLES TO GO BOTH WAYS
description: A long thin cotton cardigan to toss over the shoulders when the air-conditioning comes on too strong or a breeze whips up. A bare-arm dark silk pullover and easy skirt, both printed with primitive, stylized flowers, to wear now and into the fall. High-heeled classic pumps for dancing on summer evenings - and the rest of the year.

title: MUSIC: L' AREMA ENSEMBLE
description: THE explosive sounds produced by many celebrants in honor of the 206th birthday of the United States had a more genteel counterpart Sunday afternoon in the Sculpture Court of the Whitney Museum. Just adjacent to the museum's restaurant, and just below the museum's American collection, the L'Arema Ensemble presented its own light American musical fare for the pleasure of more than a hundred listeners and diners who sat at tables, spread out on the ground or stood by the side walls to sample the sounds.

title: NUCLEAR SUBMARINE NAUTILUS NAMED A NATIONAL LANDMARK
description: A nuclear submarine, an oceanic laboratory, the winter home of Frank Lloyd Wright and an Arkansas high school where a major desegregation clash took place have been designated as national historical landmarks by Interior Secretary James G. Watt.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: WYNC Chamber Music

title: Silver Price Moves Up From Lows
description: SILVER, among precious metals, has often taken a back seat to gold, and silver's price now has been so low, so long that many commodities analysts have begun asking when, if ever, the metal will go on another price spree.

title: TESTING OVER, THE SHUTTLE STILL MUST PROVE ITSELF
description: Officially, the testing period for the shuttle is over, but in a broad sense it really won't be over for some time to come.

title: Zurich Restaurant Bombed
description: Flames, apparently set off by a gasoline bomb, destroyed a downtown McDonald's restaurant today but injured no one. The police speculated the attack had been by members of the city's disenchanted youth movement. A police spokesman said windows of the fast-food outlet had been the target of rock-throwing youths several times last year.

title: MAN SHOOTS 2 AND KILLS HIMSELF
description: A Long Island man killed himself last night after critically wounding his estranged wife and their daughter in their Lake Grove, L.I., home earlier in the evening, the Suffolk County police said.

title: INSURANCE FRAUD: BILLIONS IN LOSSES
description: There was a screech of metal as the Mercedes bashed into the Lincoln. When the police arrived, all four of the Mercedes's occupants were complaining of head and back pain. Soon claims for bodily injury and lost wages were filed by the Mercedes's passengers against the car's owner, who was insured by Fireman's Fund.

title: U.S. STUDY REASSESSES RISK OF NUCLEAR PLANT ACCIDENTS
description: A study of thousands of mishaps at nuclear plants from 1969 through 1979 has concluded that an accident as bad as the one at Three Mile Island, or worse, could have been expected every 10 to 15 years, given the equipment in place at the plants in that period.

title: A Run Around
description: New York, a major stop on the indoor track-and-field circuit, does not get major outdoor meets, mainly because there is no suitable facility available. Even some local delegates to The Athletics Congress, which decides such things, voted against New York's getting the 1982 and 1983 national meets, and the 1984 Olympic trials.

title: HIKE MASS TRANSIT AND MANY WILL HIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Israel has been a study in extreme contradictions in the last month, displaying the most diverse capacities for both open debate and suppression of information.

title: THE PORTABLES COME MARCHING IN
description: THERE is a law of diminution in consumer electronics marketing which says that if you can make a product, you can also make it smaller - and even portable.

title: A New Beetle Barrier
description: A synthetic pheromone-like chemical developed by a University of Cincinnati chemist has been found to disrupt the communication system of pine beetles, holding the promise of controlling the pest that annually destroys almost $1 billion worth of timber, the National Science Foundation has announced.

title: Quake Hits Southern Japan
description: An earthquake jolted part of Japan's southern island of Kyushu today, but there were no reports of damage or casualties, the Meteorological Agency reported. The agency said the quake had a maximum intensity of three on the Japanese scale of seven.

title: Conquistador Cielo Sets Dwyer Mark
description: Eddie Maple and Conquistador Cielo were halfway down the stretch at Belmont Park yesterday when the jockey looked over his right shoulder, then under his left arm, and saw what he expected: a long swath of race track and, somewhere far behind, another horse.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Tuesday

title: BOMBS EXPLODE AT 2 FOREIGN MISSIONS
description: Two bomb explosions damaged diplomatic missions of France and Lebanon on the Upper East Side last night. No injuries were reported, however, and authorities said the damage was confined to shattered glass doors and windows and chipped facades.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: IN the last five years, pharmaceutical companies have marketed more than 450 new drugs in the United States, and many doctors have relied on ''detailmen'' to tell them how the drugs should be used.

title: Flat Feet Score Points
description: Flat feet are not a deterent for athletes, but instead could be an asset. Dr. Edward Fischman, vice president of the Podiatry Society of New York and the podiatry consultant to the Boston Celtics, said: ''Great athletes have flatter feet than normal. The flatter they are, the better they work to propel the body.''

title: How to Help the Weaker Banks
description: Congress will almost certainly act this year to help savings institutions survive the ravages of high interest rates. It wants no responsibility for such giant financial failures as the forecast loss of the Bowery and Emigrant Savings Banks in New York. But it is still far from clear what form the Federal aid will take.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Ionesco Play Aimed At a Sale to Cable TV

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Elusive 'Fifth'

title: Pym Pays Visit to Yugoslavs
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, arrived here today for a day of discussions with Yugoslav officials. The state-run press agency said the talks would center on European topics, world crises and other issues.

title: PLAYERS
description: S aturday night. Ice World arena, Totowa, N.J. In the small, yellow dressing room shortly before his fight, the boxer sits on a wooden bench, eyes businesslike. He is a tan-skinned, tall, leanmuscled heavyweight, nearly 6 feet 3 inches tall and weighing 212 pounds. He has a trim mustache and high cheekbones. On the back of his pink velour robe is the inscription, Pinklon ''Think Pink'' Thomas.

title: UTAH TRIAL STIRS NEW DEBATE ON PSYCHIATRISTS' TESTIMONY
description: Marc Francis Schreuder, who is 21 years old but looks five years younger, sat in a courtroom here last week with his chin cradled in his hands as his attorneys asked the State of Utah to believe that his love for his mother was so great that he had to kill his grandfather.

title: MEXICAN IS ELECTED BY 'A WIDE MARGAIN'
description: Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, the candidate of the party that has ruled Mexico for the last 53 years, was declared the winner of Sunday's presidential elections today and will succeed the outgoing President, Jose Lopez Portillo, on Dec. 1.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Riding the P?! Line

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ''I learned more about education issues in that one year than I had learned in the two decades before,'' says Jay Sommer, a 54-year-old language teacher at New Rochelle, N.Y., high school, who has just completed his 12th-month reign as America's Teacher of the Year. ''I recognize now that I made a fundamental mistake -virtually locking myself into Room 104 without paying attention to the big education issues.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM TASK FORCE REPORT ON TRANSIT AUTHORITY PROBLEMS
description: Following are excerpts from the report of the Economic Development Council's Transit Authority Task Force on a variety of problems and recommendations: Customer Service

title: Talking Business/with Tino Puri of McKinsey & Company How to Handle Trade Tension
description: A sluggish worldwide economy stirs fears of international trade restrictions as governments worry that domestic jobs may be lost because of foreign competition. Americans accuse Japan of exporting too much and importing too little.

title: POSTAGE SUBSIDY CUTS WILL HURT THE BLIND
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 KILLED AND 10 MISSING IN A FIRE IN WATERBURY SET BY AN ARSONIST
description: Six persons were killed when a fire that was deliberately set roared through two five-story tenements housing more than 200 people in downtown Waterbury, Conn., early yesterday, the Waterbury police said. Between 10 and 20 more people were reported missing.

title: Offer to Buy Giddings
description: The AMCA International Corporation of Montreal is offering to purchase Giddings & Lewis Inc., a machine tools maker, for a total of about $260 million.

title: DIANA ROSENBLATT
description: Diana Rosenblatt, a retired executive with the City University of New York grants program, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.

title: PRESTIGE IS ABC GOAL IN CUP TV
description: ''R ecognized around the world as the leader in sports television'' is the way ABC Sports bills itself. For such international events as the Olympics, major track meets, ski competitions and the like, this may be true. But for the sports event recognized round the world as No.1 - soccer's World Cup - ABC is not a leader but a late entry.

title: BRITONS JAILED IN ARGENTINA SAW WAR FROM A CELL'S WINDOW
description: Simon Winchester, one of the three British journalists imprisoned for 77 days by Argentina on spying charges, reported this weekend that while in prison he kept records of the movements of military planes and ships ''which we could glimpse through the cell's grimy little window.''

title: REMEMBERING THE HYATT DISASTER: EMOTIONAL SCARS PERSIST A YEAR LATER
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. IT is almost a year since two skywalks of the Hyatt Regency Hotel here collapsed, killing 113 people and injuring 200 others in the nation's worst building disaster. But many of the 1,400 survivors who had been attending a tea dance in the hotel lobby and the hundreds who came to their rescue are still haunted by nightmares, uneasy about balconies, bridges and walkways, and plagued with anger and guilt.

title: THE PRISON NEXT DOOR
description: A group of blue-jeaned suburban women sit around a backyard picnic table on a lazy summer afternoon, glasses of iced tea on the table, children splashing in the swimming pool, a tempering breeze ruffling leaves on the shade trees.

title: SIDE-ISSUES FIGURE IN TRICKY ALASKAN PRIMARY
description: Lieut. Gov. Terry Miller, a Republican, and William Sheffield, a Democratic businessman, are the leading candidates seeking the gubernatorial nomination in Alaska's primary election Aug. 24, according to politicians with access to private polls.

title: Ohio Racketeering Case Is Given to Federal Jury
description: A Federal court jury deliberated for more than two hours today on the fate of six men accused of conspiring to kill a rival to control organized crime in northern Ohio.

title: DODGERS AND WELCH SET BACK METS, 4-1
description: On a night when the Mets called up a minor league prospect to buttress their pitching staff, Pete Falcone showed why such help was needed. Falcone walked in one run and gave up two more on home runs on the way to a 4-1 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: BRIEFING
description: Real Estate Problem

title: Hunt for Boy Lost in Rockies Is Canceled After Sixth Day
description: Officials have ended their search for a 12-year-old-boy from Illinois who disappeared last week in rugged Rocky Mountain National Park.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Shifts at Y.& R.
description: James McCoubrey, a Canadian who has been senior vice president and area director for Canada and Latin America at Young & Rubicam, is stepping onto a bigger stage. He has been promoted to deputy area director and general manager for Europe, where the agency's work force of 1,600 in 12 countries processes $550 million in billings. Succeeding Mr. McCoubrey in this hemisphere is John Destler, returning to Y.& R. from two years as president of Grey International.

title: Clean Air Is a Regional Affair
description: Electricity in New York would be cheaper if Consolidated Edison burned coal instead of imported, low-sulfur oil. The air, however, would be dirtier. It isn't clear how much economy justifies how much loss in air quality. A sensible answer requires a hard look at all the smokestacks affecting the region, not simply Con Ed's.

title: Denise Beaudu Bride Of Dr. Gary Greenwald
description: Denise Genevieve Beaudu, daughter of Odette Kroft of New York and Marcel Beaudu of Phoenicia, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Gary Russell Greenwald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Greenwald of North Bellmore, L.I. Rabbi Robert Raab performed the ceremony at the Fox Hollow Inn in Woodbury, L.I.

title: AN ARTFUL EYE AT THE FEDERAL RESERVE
description: Unlike most of the money-wise officials around the Federal Reserve, Mary Anne Goley is no economist, but she sets a special policy of her own for the Fed.

title: Dollar Gains; Gold Also Up
description: The dollar generally rose against major currencies in quiet trading outside the United States today. Gold prices advanced.

title: Purchasers' Index Gains
description: The economy continued to decline in June, but at a slower pace than in May, according to the National Association of Purchasing Managers. The association's index, which is based on a survey of new orders, production, employment, vendor performance and inventories, rose to 39.6 percent last month, somewhat better than the 35 percent performance in May, and about the same percentage set in April.

title: SERVICE WORK GAINS AGAINST PRODUCTION JOBS
description: Employment in the consumer, financial and service industries has moved above the job total in the production industry for the first time in the history of the American economy, according to Labor Department data.

title: THE PRESSURE ON WORLD STOCKS
description: Stock markets throughout the world were broadly lower through the first half of this year, reflecting nervous investor reaction to economic and political turmoil in several countries.

title: U.S. URGES ISRAELIS TO ALLOW WEST BEIRUT TO GET SUPPLIES
description: The United States said today that it was essential that the cease-fire be restored and maintained in Lebanon and that Israel abide by a United Nations Security Council resolution to allow vital supplies to reach civilians in west Beirut.

title: TRADITION OF 4TH IS STILL KEPT UP BY SPIRITUALISTS
description: As they have for each of the last 103 Independence Days, hundreds of members of the Lily Dale Spiritual Assembly convened here this holiday weekend and proved they could outdo almost any other group of Americans in independence and spirit.

title: STEEL UNION TALKS OPENING THIS WEEK
description: Negotiators for the United Steelworkers of America and United States Steel Corporation are to meet this week to start talks on possible ways to moderate labor costs in the financially troubled steel industry. The union will hold discussions with other major steel producers later in July.

title: Enid Haupt Is a Victim In Manhattan Burglary
description: Enid A. Haupt, the 70-year-old philanthropist and former publisher of Seventeen magazine, had $100,000 worth of jewelry taken from her Manhattan apartment while she was away for the weekend, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Kozlovs Set U.S. Tour, Seek Ballet Theater Spot

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Lecture on Bands

title: No Need for Benefit
description: Larry Holmes and Gerry Cooney did not break the record of $17.1 million for most money made by two boxers for a single fight; the mark is still held by Sugar Ray Leonard (about $12 million) and Thomas Hearns (about $5 million). But according to various boxing sources, the two heavyweights missed by only about $200,000, which means that Holmes and Cooney each received about $8.5 million for their June 11 bout.

title: Bridge: Sometimes Offbeat Moves; May Work Out for the Best
description: Readers may be familiar with puzzles in which missionaries and cannibals are trying to cross a river in a small boat, with disaster impending if the missionaries are outnumbered. The required avoidance play might be called ''missionary impossible.''

title: AIRLINES TUSSLE WITH AGENTS
description: In the back offices of travel agencies, a struggle has broken out between the agencies and major carriers that could change their relationship and possibly affect the way the customer is served.

title: Mubarak, Reversing Policy, Says He Will Go to Baghdad
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, in a reversal, agreed today to attend a third-world conference in Baghdad in September.

title: DECLINING STOCKS OUTPACE WINNERS
description: The first six months of 1982 have been bad ones for the stock market -so bad, in fact, that the prices of 161 of the stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange have dropped by at least 35 percent since January. By comparison, only 50 issues gained 35 percent or more in the first half.

title: The Sun Belt Today Growth Pains Amid Prosperity; Second article of a series
description: The unemployment lines in the textile mill towns in North Carolina and South Carolina are the longest since World War II. In Alabama, the decline of steel and other industries dependent on automobile manufacturing has pushed unemployment there to the second highest level in the nation, trailing only Michigan. In Tennessee, Mississippi and Arkansas, local and state economies are reeling because of widespread layoffs of workers and shutdowns of plants in industries ranging from auto parts to pulp and paper to garment making.

title: NEW UNREST AMONG BLACK WORKERS SHUTS A GOLD MINE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: About 12,000 black miners broke out of their locked residences and burned down a shop today in the fifth day of rioting over different wage levels in South Africa's gold mines.

title: Reagan to Meet Dominican
description: President Reagan will meet July 15 with Jacobo Majluta Azar, the new President of the Dominican Republic, a White House spokesman said today. Mr. Majluta assumed the presidency after Antonio Guzman died Saturday of what was reported to be a selfinflicted bullet wound in the head.

title: THE STEALTH BOMBER WON'T FLY FOR A DECADE
description: To the Editor:

title: REVISED DISTRICT IN STATE UPHELD FOR FALL ELECTION
description: A special three-judge Federal court ruled yesterday that the New York State election could be held this year under district lines redrawn by the Legislature.

title: Article 259512 -- No Title
description: Governor Carey announced today a series of new state programs to channel about $8.5 million to nonprofit groups to renovate single-room-occupancy hotels and residences for the homeless.

title: Howard Rusk Jr. Named Head Of World Rehabilitation Fund
description: The World Rehabilitation Fund has announced the election of Howard A. Rusk Jr., a specialist in international medical programs, as its president and chief executive officer.

title: HOLLYWOOD DEBATES HBO ROLE IN FILM FINANCING
description: Early last year, when the producers of the movie ''On Golden Pond'' were experiencing financial difficulties, Home Box Office, the largest of the pay cable networks, agreed to invest money in several of the producers' movie projects. In return, HBO was given exclusive pay-television rights to the films that were eventually released, including ''On Golden Pond.''

title: WHOLE WORLD IS WATCHING
description: BARCELONA, Spain H ow seriously does the world take the World Cup? Seriously enough to touch off suicides, vandalism, illegal use of satellite facilities, car crashes, heart attacks and the collapse of a floor in Peking, according to various items clipped from European newspapers in the last two weeks.

title: A Publisher's Comment
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The article on vanity publishing (''More Authors Turn to Vanity Presses,'' May 26) was a fine one, but did not present an accurate picture of how bookstores handle subsidized titles, at least so far as our company is concerned.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: New York City is a place where everyone has an excuse. Many of these have to do with transportation and tardiness. The express trains were out between Brooklyn and Manhattan. There was gridlock in midtown. The Madison Avenue buses were full. There were no cabs. There was no place to park.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY SUIT DISMISSED
description: The Federal Government may use certain income tax forms to check on the eligiblity of four million elderly, disabled and blind people receive income supplements from the Social Security Administration, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The list of dividend meetings in Business Day on Monday was incor- rect. The correct list for this week ap- pears today on page D8.

title: STOCKS MOSTLY OFF, BUT DOW IS UP 1.91
description: Stock prices moved generally lower yesterday, although the Dow Jones industrial average posted a slight gain. It was a session marked by price swings in numerous issues, along with weakness in bank stocks related to problem loans.

title: Partisan Words
description: ABC Sports has asked Giorgio Chinaglia, the Cosmos' high-scoring striker, to provide halftime commentary in its New York studio when the network televises the World Cup final live from Madrid on Sunday. When Chinaglia played in the 1974 World Cup for Italy, the Italians were eliminated in the first round.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Totally False' Release

title: 3 YEARS AFTER SOMOZA'S DOWNFALL, DIFFICULTIES ENGULF THE SANDINISTS
description: Three years after toppling the Somoza regime, Nicaragua's Sandinist rulers are engulfed by problems, among them a stagnant economy, armed threats from abroad and a population openly disillusioned with the revolution.

title: Home Rates Dip Slightly
description: Home-loan interest rates declined slightly for the third consecutive month in June, reaching a 17.17 percent average that was the lowest in nearly a year for new, single-family homes, the Government reported today.

title: ALBANY'S PLAN FOR 3 PRISONS IN LEGAL SNARL
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered a halt yesterday to the conversion of buildings at three state psychiatric hospitals into medium-security prisons. But by the end of the day, the order had been stayed.

title: ISSUE AND DEBATE
description: SHOULD U.S. BUILD BIG AIRCRAFT CARRIERS OR SMALL ONES IN AN AGE OF MISSILES? By RICHARD HALLORAN

title: One Tomato, 2 Tomato ...
description: F or some who manage to have city gardens - expensive penthouses, equally expensive backyards or hard-won roof space - this is a time for worrying about potato beetles, or whether it is too early to transplant the iris, or what blight is being visited upon the tomato plants this year.

title: U.S. ENDS INQUIRY ON CARDINAL CODY
description: A Federal investigation into allegations that the late John Cardinal Cody improperly diverted hundreds of thousands of dollars in church funds for personal use while he was the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago was terminated today without indictments.

title: Export-Import Bank Revamps Rates
description: The Export-Import bank today announced new interest rates on export financing loans that are slightly higher than those agreed to last week by the European Economic Community, Canada and Japan.

title: WEST BANK MAYOR OUSTED BY ISRAELIS
description: Israel dismissed another Arab mayor today in the occupied West Bank, the state radio reported. Shawki Mahmoud, who was elected to head the town council of Jenin in 1976, became the fifth Arab mayor to be ousted. Palestinian sources said Mr. Mahmoud was replaced by Shihab Sanouri.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL WINS NLT
description: After the companies had tried for months to take each other over, the American General Corporation of Houston announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the NLT Corporation of Nashville for $46 a share in cash and stock, a transaction valued at $1.5 billion.

title: Burns Shares Lead
description: George Burns, one of the PGA Tour's leading money winners, shot a four-under-par 71 today to take a share of the lead after the first round of the $40,000 New York State Open at Grossinger's. Burns was tied with the defending champion, John Calabria, and Bobby Heins.

title: Bank Acquisitions in Ohio and Florida
description: Huntington Bancshares Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it held about 1.6 million common shares, or 38.8 percent, of the Cleveland-based Union Commerce Corporation.

title: ISRAELIS SAY THAT U.S. UNITS WOULD STAY UP TO A MONTH
description: Israeli officials said today that the United States had offered to send the Sixth Fleet and a detachment of marines to supervise the withdrawal of Palestinian forces from west Beirut.

title: 2 CHILDREN AND A SITTER KILLED BY CAR IN JERSEY
description: Two young children and their baby sitter were run down and killed in North Bergen, N.J., yesterday by a man in a stolen car being chased by two police cars, the North Bergen police said.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Star-Spangled Idea

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard NOTES OF A REVOLUTIONARY. By An- drei Amalrik. Translated from the Rus- sian by Guy Daniels. Introduction by Susan Jacoby. 343 pages. Knopf. $16.95.

title: KEY LAWMAKERS EXPRESS DOUBTS ABOUT PLAN
description: Key members of Congress voiced deep concern today over President Reagan's decision in principle to involve American forces in a peacekeeping role in Beirut.

title: 4 Finish Tied for First In Chess Tournament
description: Four persons finished tied for first place at the annual World Open chess tournament. About 1,000 players had competed in the event, which is billed as the world's largest noninvitational chess tournament.

title: Fight on von Bulow Bail Sent Back for Hearing
description: The State Supreme Court today ordered an open hearing to determine if Claus von Bulow had adequately posted $1 million bail pending appeals on two convictions for trying to murder his wife.

title: Hong Kong Subway
description: The Aoki Construction Company of Japan said today that the Hong Kong Mass Transit Railway Corporation had awarded it construction contracts valued at 28 billion yen for work on a new subway line.

title: Toyo Kogyo-Ford
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company, which is 24.4 percent owned by the Ford Motor Company, said Ford had asked it to supply diesel engines for Ford cars. Toyo Kogyo declined to disclose details, but industry sources said Ford wanted to buy more than 2,000 two-liter diesel engines a month. Ford has already concluded contracts to buy 2,000 2.2-liter diesel engines from Toyo Kogyo a month for trucks and as many as 75,000 2.3-liter turbo-charged diesel engines for each of three years, probably for cars and commercial vehicles.

title: MAREE TAKES 1,500
description: Henry Rono of Kenya ran the the fastest 5,000 meters in the world this year at an international track and field meet here tonight.

title: Figure Skating Breaks Pro Ice
description: A new professional figure-skating circuit, set up in a grand-prix format resembling that of professional tennis, will be launched in the United States next fall. Along with signing some of the top names in the sport, the circuit has also landed a network television contract, reportedly for five years.

title: 90 BELEIEVED DEAD IN SOVIET PLANE CRASH IN MOSCOW
description: A Soviet jetliner that was believed to be carrying about 90 people crashed and burned early today shortly after taking off from Moscow on a scheduled flight to West Africa. All aboard were reportedly killed.

title: Schwab Begins A New Service
description: Starting today, the discount brokerage firm of Charles Schwab & Company will allow its 300,000 customers to place buy and sell orders on a round-the-clock basis.

title: PABST ASKS SHAREHOLDERS TO ACCEPT OFFER BY OLYMPIA
description: The Pabst Brewing Company recommended yesterday that its shareholders accept a tender offer for 49 percent of its shares made by the Olympia Brewing Company with Pabst's blessings. Pabst said the bid was intended to defeat a competing offer for 39 percent of its shares by an investment group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, a dissident shareholder.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Brent Gaff, just called up from Tidewater to replace the injured Tom Hausman, starts for the Mets. He was 9-4 with the Tides. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Oakland, Calif. Rickey Henderson of the A's, who set the American League record of 100 stolen bases two years ago, is leading both leagues in steals and is ahead of Lou Brock's record pace for the major leagues. (Television -SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 10:30 P.M.) Basketball New York Pro Summer League at Nat Holman Gym, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 6:30, 8:30 P.M. Gus and Ray Williams will play for the Gems in the second game against Harlem USA.

title: Savings-Loan Unit In Sale on Coast
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association announced an agreement in principle to sell six of its twelve branch offices to World Savings and Loan Association for an undisclosed amount.

title: 'Magic Eye' Faulted
description: Jimmy Connors, the Wimbledon champion, has called for a ban on the electric ''magic eye'' machine used at Wimbledon on close line calls, and wants the All England Club to rely solely on the line judges.

title: Wathan Injures Ankle
description: John Wathan of the Kansas City Royals, who was nearing the major league record for most stolen bases in a season by a catcher, fractured his left ankle Monday night and will be sidelined for at least six weeks. Wathan suffered the injury in the first game of a doubleheader against the Boston Red Sox when he fouled a pitch off the ankle in the fifth inning.

title: G.A.O. EXPRESSES DOUBT ON MARITIME SUBSIDIES
description: The American ocean shipping industry is ''not in a state of general distress'' and would benefit from less protection, contrary to widespread public opinion and to legislation now pending in Congress, the General Accounting Office says in a study expected to be published later this week.

title: STATE DEPT. REVERSES POLICY ON ETHIOPIAN EXILES IN U.S.
description: The State Department, reacting to a plea by an unusual Congressional coalition of blacks, conservatives and liberals, has reversed its policy and proposed that more than 15,000 Ethiopian exiles remain in the United States and not face deportation hearings.

title: Purex Statement Is Delayed by Suit
description: Purex Industries, which will be aquired by a private company if shareholders approve an agreement reached in January, said it would delay mailing its proxy statement for the shareholders' meeting because of new information concerning a suit involving Purex.

title: 4 Seychelles Plotters Sentenced to Hang
description: Four foreign mercenaries were sentenced today to death by hanging and another was sentenced to 20 years in jail for their role in a bungled attempt to topple the Seychelles' socialist Government.

title: U.S. to Try Distributing Its Surplus Dried Milk
description: The Government plans to give away surplus nonfat dried milk to needy families as a pilot project in three states, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: PUFF PASTRY ROLLING PIN
description: MAKING puff pastry can turn from a chore into a pleasure if you have the right equipment. A heavy rolling pin, well designed and efficient, with two stationary handles that gently guide the roller as you work, is the best tool for this job. An especially clever pin of this sort has come on the market, capable of measuring the pastry as it is being rolled out, using centimeters and inches imprinted on the pin.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Putnam and Berkley Buy Grosset & Dunlap, PEI

title: FOR THE DRAFTERS OF BILLS, THERE IS NO RECESS
description: It matters not a bit to Ward M. Hussey that his 435 bosses have scattered to perform their traditional Fourth of July oratorical feats, leaving most House offices in pre-holiday torpor. It's business as usual for him, which is to say pretty exciting, given the limits of a job that consists mainly of turning other people's ideas into the dry legal language: the chaff, one might call it, of the lawmaking process.

title: 'E.T.' AT $87 MILLION, HIT OF SUMMER BOX OFFICE
description: The summer is not half-over, but it is already apparent which movie will be the summer's big box-office winner. To the accompaniment of Fourth of July firecrackers, Steven Spielberg's fantasy about a lonely visitor from outer space, ''E.T. - the Extra-Terrestrial,'' has overtaken the third installment of Sylvester Stallone's saga about a boxer, ''Rocky III.''

title: NEW WASHINGTON PAPER TRIES TO ANSWER SKEPTICS
description: The Washington Times has invited a group of 25 newspaper editors and publishers and their spouses on a 10-day all-expenses-paid tour of the Soviet Union this fall, with an option to spend a week in South Korea.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: IN 1975, Led Zeppelin was the most successful rock group in the world. Their albums were gobbled up voraciously; ''Physical Graffiti,'' for example, sold 500 copies an hour. The death of the group's drummer, John Bonham, in 1980 effectively brought Led Zeppelin's career to an end. But the group lives on: albums released some years ago continue to sell, and ''Stairway to Heaven'' is still the most requested song on American FM radio.

title: HARD TIMES AHEAD FOR SMALL WINERIES IN THE NAPA VALLEY
description: NAPA, Calif. THE vines are in full leaf now under the hot summer sun all across the Napa Valley and there is talk of a great vintage in 1982, but complacency is absent among the people who grow the grapes and make the wine.

title: Trial Scheduled in Draft Case
description: Benjamin H. Sasway, 21 years old, was ordered today to stand trial on Aug. 21 on charges of failing to register for a possible draft. Mr. Sasway, who is a student at Humboldt State College, surrendered to the Federal authorities last week after he became the first man since the Vietnam War to be indicted for not registering with the Selective Service System.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 7, 1982
description: International An American peacekeeping offer for Lebanon was confirmed by President Reagan. He said he had ''agreed in principle to contribute a small contingent'' of United States troops as part of a multinational force for ''temporary peacekeeping'' in Beirut if a settlement was reached there. Earlier, Israeli officials said that the American plan included French participation in a peace force of about 1,600 troops. (Page A1, Column 6.) The P.L.O. spurned a U.S. offer to evacuate Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut on ships of the Sixth Fleet. But Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said he did not oppose American participation in a proposed multinational peace force in Lebanon. (A1:4.)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Poverty is a career for a lot of well-paid people.'' - President Reagan, referring to bureaucrats in the poverty program. (A11:2.)

title: Plan for the P.L.O.  Is Discussed at U.N.
description: The Security Council's President, Noel G. Sinclair of Guyana, met separately with the other 14 members today to discuss a French-Egyptian plan to preserve the Palestine Liberation Organization as a political force in Lebanon, but there was no sign that either France or Egypt was pressing for an early vote.

title: Republic Steel Cuts Output and Staff
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had halted iron and steel production at its South Chicago plant and had laid off 2,000 workers temporarily.

title: AS FLORIDA GROWS, SO DOES CONCERN ABOUT SAVING SUN AND-SAND GOOD LIFE; Growth Pains Amid Prosperity Third article of a series
description: When a wind was called a zephyr, when salubrity was the goal, Florida, the national sandbox, slowly began to grow. This was long ago, when palm trees could strike Henry James as ''rows of puzzled philosophers'' and a less gifted writer, Lieut. George McCall, could say in all innocence, ''It is a paradise for those who love to live in the open air.''

title: EXTRA-CENTSORY PERCEPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESS COLLAPSES AT CORONA'S TRIAL
description: The key defense witness in the retrial of Juan V. Corona collapsed on the stand today in an apparent epileptic seizure.

title: RAIDERS IN ACCORD WITH L.A. ON LEASE
description: Representatives of the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission and Oakland Raiders reached agreement today on a lease for the pro football team to play at the Coliseum beginning next season.

title: REAGAN'S VACATION PROBLEMS
description: One way or another, the military forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization are probably going to be drummed out of their bunkers in West Beirut - blown out or starved out by the Israelis or invited out and dispersed around the Mediterranean in ships of the United States Sixth Fleet.

title: 9 in Trident Protest Deny Trespassing
description: Nine persons entered such pleas as ''not guilty by reason of governmental insanity'' today to charges resulting from an antinuclear demonstration at the plant that builds Trident missile-firing submarines.

title: MUNICH: A CITY OF CULINARY CONTRASTS
description: MUNICH, West Germany THIS is a city of sublime contrasts. It is famous for its art, its politics and its food, displaying the best and the worst of what Germany has to offer. It is the city in which Mann wrote and Hitler rose to power, where Kandinsky painted and Israeli Olympic athletes were killed by Palestinian terrorists. It is the city that offers some of the best cooking outside France and the most leaden dumplings ever set before a diner.

title: Error Invalidates Rape Conviction
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, invalidating a rape conviction, today ordered trial judges in the state not to direct a verdict in criminal cases.

title: ARAFAT SPURNS 'PROTECTION'
description: President Reagan said today that he had ''agreed in principle to contribute a small contingent'' of United States troops as part of a multinational force for ''temporary peacekeeping'' in Beirut if a settlement was reached there.

title: A TWO-TON APPLE PIE: WADE RIGHT IN
description: IT took seven bakers to bake it, 2,800 pounds of apples mixed with 800 pounds of a sugar-cinnamon mixture to fill it. It was baked in nine sections at 400 degrees for 90 minutes and then trucked by two tractor trailers 20 miles from Mrs. Smith's plant in Silver Spring, Md., to the Washington Monument last Thursday.

title: A.& P. POSTS PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company yesterday reported its first quarterly profit in more than two years, which it attributed to the benefits of its yearlong revitalization program in which it closed stores and plants, cut its staff by one-third and withdrew from loss markets.

title: Wendy's Old Fashioned Changes Ad Approach
description: Elsewhere in the world of fast foods, Wendy's Old Fashioned Hamburgers restaurants, after 13 months of alienating all the nation's grammarians with its ''Wendy's. Ain't no reason to go anyplace else,'' have changed their approach.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * ARA Services Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a $100 million debt issue, with or without warrants to purchase debt securities, to be offered through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: Real Estate; Olympia Group Sells 3 Buildings
description: OLYMPIA & YORK, in partnership with others, has recently sold three of its residential buildings in Manhattan for $44 million. The Canadian development company is widely recognized as one of the largest commercial landlords in the city, particularly since the company began the Battery Park City office complex. But Olympia & York also has a comparatively small residential component in this area through a partnership with American Landmark Developments. The president of American Landmark is Oskar Brecher, who was previously in charge of residential development in New York City for Cadillac-Fairview, another major Canadian developer.

title: Canadian Oil Deal
description: The Canadian Government-owned Petro-Canada is planning to buy as much as $300 million of oil from Petroleos Mexicanos through a syndicated financing facility, banking sources said. Arranged by the Royal Bank of Canada, the nine-month facility would allow Pemex to receive the full amount of the contract immediately, with banks later collecting the money from Petro-Canada.

title: EX-HEAD OF CHURCH COUNCIL
description: Bishop Reuben H. Mueller, former president of the National Council of Churches who was a leading United Methodist ecumenist, died of a heart attack yesterday in Franklin, Ind. He was 85 years old.

title: IN NOME OF THE 80's, GOLD IS STILL PART OF GLITTER; The Talk Of Nome
description: So much else has changed here since 1898, when three Swedish prospectors made their discovery on Anvil Creek, yet gold still pulls people from comfortable places thousands of miles away to live on this bleak shore of the Bering Sea.

title: Woman Shot Dead In Queens Dispute
description: A woman was fatally shot and another critically injured after a dispute with a next-door neighbor yesterday in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.

title: Sheik Is Under Arrest In Dispute Over a Bill
description: Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi of Saudi Arabia was arrested at his luxury hotel suite here today in a dispute over a $1.5 million food and room-service bill, his attorney said.

title: RockBill Magazine Makes Its Debut
description: A major event Monday night, at least so we are told, was the distribution of the first issue of RockBill magazine, a Playbill-size publication, that was given out free in 70 ''showcase'' nightclubs that have live rock music entertainment.

title: BRIEFING
description: Bastille Day Bargain

title: U.S. Court Grants Protection For Mobil Papers in Libel Suit
