description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Mobil Corporation would be able to protect confidential documents in its libel case against The Washington Post.

title: U.S.-E.E.C.  Steel Meeting
description: Senior American officials are expected to arrive here later this week for talks with the European Economic Community aimed at settling a dispute about steel, Common Market sources said today.

title: TEACHERS PROTEST REAGAN POLICIES
description: Thousands of teachers from around the nation marched through the city today to protest increased military spending and to demand greater support for public education.

title: Turkish Socialist Gets Two Months in Jail
description: A Turkish military court sentenced former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit to two months and 27 days in jail today for an article he had written for the West German weekly magazine Der Spiegel and an interview he had given to Dutch television.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S SICK ECONOMY
description: Less than two years after attaining one of the highest economic growth rates in the world, South Africa is bracing itself for its deepest recession since the 1930's.

title: PRESS LEVEL AT SHEA A MAZE OF DESPAIR
description: T heseus had his labyrinth. Borges had his library, Kafka had his castle and I, curse Ormazd, have a box seat on the Press Level at Shea Stadium. This is the second time in as many Dodger games that the Mets have stiffed me with a Press Level box seat. The first time, last year before the strike, was the night Valenzuela came to town, and so did everybody else from as far away as the Crab Nebula, and I forgave the Mets, even though from Press Level, Valenzuela looked like a black hole, or at least a blue dwarf. But Monday?

title: POPE IS SAID TO CONSIDER REPLACING BISHOP AT HEAD OF VATICAN'S BANK
description: Vatican sources were quoted today as saying that Pope John Paul II was considering replacing an American Archbishop as president of the Vatican bank because of a crisis involving its links to a private bank.

title: Chem-Nuclear
description: Waste Management Inc., which last week began a hostile takeover bid for Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc., said a Federal judge in South Carolina had issued a temporary order Friday to restrain Chem-Nuclear from issuing any stock that might block Waste Management's bid. Chem-Nuclear, which disposes of chemical and low-level nuclear waste, has one million preferred voting shares held in reserve; if issued, the shares would increase the number of voting shares outstanding by more than 13 percent. Waste Management is involved in the disposal of solid waste.

title: Exxon Sees Gain
description: The Exxon Corporation said it expected to realize an after-tax gain of about $130 million as a result of debt transactions it completed yesterday.

title: Begin's Government Regains A Slim Majority in Parliament
description: Mordechai Ben-Porat joined Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Cabinet today after Parliament ratified the Cabinet decision Monday to intall him as its 19th member.

title: ORGANIZING THOSE STRAY RECIPES FOR EASY REFERENCE
description: STUCK away somewhere in the kitchen of every good cook is a yellowed and tattered collection of recipes ripped out of newspapers and magazines or donated by friends. My pile of torn pages was nearly half a foot tall, and I also had two years of back issues of food magazines. Hidden away in this hodgepodge were the recipes for treats such as scallops in court-bouillon, oxtail soup, cumin rice and eggplant creole.

title: O.E.C.D. IS GLOOMIER ON GROWTH
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development sharply scaled back its forecast for the world economy today and said that unemployment was likely to continue to rise throughout 1983.

title: Surprise: Revenue Plus Reform
description: By the usual rules, it would have been a game of you scratch my lobbyist, I'll scratch yours. But the Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee, led by Chairman Robert Dole, were in no mood for games of any sort last week. Charged with the unpleasant task of raising some $21 billion in revenues to hold down the 1983 budget deficit, the committee did so at the expense of narrow interest preferences in the tax code.

title: DARTMOUTH SELLS STUDENT AID BONDS
description: Dartmouth College has announced the sale of $29 million in tax-exempt bonds to finance student loans and educational expenditures that would otherwise have to be curtailed as a result of reductions in Federal assistance.

title: JACKSON ALL-STAR STARTER
description: Reggie Jackson and three of his California teammates - but none of his former teammates on the Yankees - were named to the starting American League All-Star team.

title: Accounts
description: * Clinton Nursery Products and O'Neal's Restaurant chain to Staley, Falcone & Gaynor.

title: OPFFICIALS SAY EVIDENCE IN SEX CHARGES AGAINST CONGRESSMEN IS SCANT
description: Some of the Federal and Congressional authorities investigating accusations of sexual misconduct and drug use involving Capitol pages and Congressmen said today that the sex charges had not been substantiated but that the drug charges appeared more serious.

title: BRIEFING
description: Kennedy Picks Caddell

title: Prison Fund Cuts Assailed by Kean
description: Govenor Kean said today that state legislators had been ''insensitive'' in cutting more than $14 million in new programs to reduce overcrowding in state prisons.

title: Continental Air Payment Accord
description: A restructured payment plan on $295 million in long-term debt has been agreed to in principle by Continental Air Lines and Texas International Airlines and their lenders, a Continental spokesman said.

title: No Taste for Shrimp
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The article on irradiated foods by James Sterba (''Irradiated Food: Promise and Controversy,'' June 30) brought back memories of a food irradiation project with which I was affiliated while an A.E.C.- supported postdoctorate at Columbia University in 1956. At a scientific meeting one of the investigators told the following story.

title: Lunar Tunes
description: M ost New Yorkers slept while someone turned off the moon for a few hours yesterday. They probably figured there wasn't much they could do about it.

title: EXCERPTS FROM A DEBATE BETWEEN THE REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR
description: These are excerpts from a debate yesterday at the New York Times between Paul J. Curran and Lewis E. Lehrman, Republican candidates for Governor of New York. Crime

title: CANADA'S IMPERIAL APPOINTS PRESIDENT
description: Arden Haynes, 54 years old, executive vice president of Imperial Oil, Canada's largest integrated oil concern, will become president of the company on Oct. 1. He succeeds James Livingstone, 62, who is retiring after 40 years with the company.

title: SENATORS' GYM PLAN CRITICIZED
description: A decision to go ahead with a new gymnasium for senators in the $137.5 million Hart Senate Office Building was criticized today by Senator William Proxmire as ''especially ridiculous.''

title: FORT DIX KEEPS TRAINING ROLE
description: As many as 40,000 Army recruits are expected to complete basic training this year at Fort Dix, a spokesman said today. Rumors have circulated periodically that such training would be phased out.

title: Advertising; A Merger And Shifts In Accounts
description: WITH surprising vigor the advertising industry swung back into action after the long weekend and quickly produced a Boston-New York merger to delight the eye; a couple of account switches for your reading pleasure, and also a merger rumor to titillate and mystify.

title: RACING'S COLORFUL TRADITION
description: When 10 or 12 chestnuts and bays go racing down the backstretch together, spotting the numbers on their saddlecloths is almost impossible and the horses are likely to change places even as the race-caller announces their positions.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Grand Slam Lifts Kansas City
description: Royals 6 Red Sox 2

title: BRIEFING
description: About That Seating Chart

title: 2 Cuban Aides at U.N.  Being Expelled by U.S.
description: The State Department today announced the expulsion of two Cuban diplomats, including the chief Cuban intelligence operative in New York, for buying advanced electronic equipment.

title: Gold Chains Stolen
description: Two men pretending to be interested in buying gold held up a manufacturing company in midtown Manhattan yesterday, and made off with 300 pounds of gold-plated chains whose value was estimated by the owners at between $2.5 million and $3 million, the police reported.

title: DINING IN AND OUT WITH MAYOR KOCH
description: ''MENTALLY, I'm always noshing,'' said Mayor Koch, explaining the conflict he has between loving to eat and wanting to keep his weight down. ''What I mentally nosh on most used to be called 'a nickel a schtickel' - those small end pieces of salami that were sold on top of the counters in New York delis for 5 cents.

title: 50'S DINNER JACKETS: LAYERS OF NOSTALGIA
description: Men's dinner jackets, vintage 1950, are a summer success with women who enjoy topping contemporary fashions with a layer of nostalgia. The wearers apparently like the comfort of the loose-fitting, shawlcollared jackets; too-long sleeves are sometimes rolled up in their current incarnation. Prices may range from a thrift-shop $5 to around $35 at antique clothing boutiques.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION LIMITS DUE PROCESS IN DISABILITY CASES
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Group Shopping
description: The Wine Group in San Francisco, marketer of Mogen David and Franzia wines and Tribuno vermouths, will be looking for a West Coast agency to replace Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson. R.S.&L. was forced to resign the $1 million-plus account when it acquired Savitt, Tobias, Balk, which has the Manischewitz account.

title: METS COMMIT 5 ERRORS AND BOW TO DODGERS, 9-3
description: The Mets, weak in pitching, also fell apart defensively last night. They committed five errors, including three in the sixth inning when they were within striking distance of the Dodgers, and wound up with an 9-3 loss that was embarrassing to them.

title: HARD TIMES IN COPPER COUNTRY
description: Every day when he opens the newspaper, Art Windsor, who is a miner, turns to the financial pages, runs his fingers down the columns of black ink and stops at the price of copper. It is a community ritual also performed by the saleswomen at the Pines Ladies Store, the manager of the bowling lanes, the county administrator in nearby Clifton and the chairman of the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: SECOND SPACE SHUTTLE IS ROLLED TO TESTING HANGAR
description: The new space shuttle Challenger was rolled into a work hangar today to undergo a series of tests for its maiden voyage in January.

title: What Price the Marines?
description: The P.L.O., defeated, squats in its Beirut bunkers and shouts out ''conditions'' for its departure. It is down to its last weapon: a Samson-like suicide that would destroy half of Lebanon's capital.

title: AN INDEPENDENT DISARMAMENT GROUP IS HARASSED IN MOSCOW
description: Nearly a month after a small group in Moscow founded the Soviet Union's first independent disarmament movement, the authorities are continuing to harass its adherents.

title: Hostess and Coleco Set September Promotion
description: Come Sept. 7, when the smarts of sunburn are forgotten, it will be time to turn our attention to a joint promotion to be mounted by the Hostess division of Continental Baking/ITT and Coleco Industries, maker of video games.

title: CIVIL WAR HULL IS REPORTED FOUND
description: Researchers have found what they believe may be the resting place of a Civil War steamer that sank in the Mississippi River more than a century ago, reportedly with $18,000 in gold aboard and with a loss of more than 1,500 lives.

title: BRIEFING
description: Sign of the Times

title: SHORT-TERM RATES DECLINE
description: Interest rates fell at this week's auction of new three- and sixmonth Treasury bills, but the declines were not great enough to exert much influence on the longer-term market, where Treasury note and bond yields rose slightly.

title: ONE COMPANY'S LOSS NEEDN'T BE ANOTHER'S GAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: FALKLAND INQUIRY: MRS. THATCHER'S STAKE IS HIGH
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced today that an inquiry into the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands would begin shortly, with Lord Franks, a member of the Liberal Party, as chairman of a six-man investigating committee.

title: G.O.P. AD CREDITING REAGAN FOR PENSION RISE IS ATTACKED
description: Republicans today began a television advertising campaign aimed at persuading voters that President Reagan is responsible for a 7.4 percent increase in Social Security benefits.

title: Fire Hits in Hot Springs
description: A fire fanned by strong winds destroyed four businesses, including two nightclubs, in a historic section of this south Arkansas resort city. Assistant Fire Chief Moman Bates said an unidentified person telephoned about 4 P.M. Monday to report smoke on the second floor of a building housing a nightclub called The Body Shop, Jeannie's Antique Store and the Vis dress shop. The fire spread to the Black Orchid, a nearby nightclub.

title: Scenery Changes
description: From roller hockey on the streets of Hell's Kitchen in Manhattan to the National Hockey League - that's been Joey Mullen's dream-cometrue. And a proper flourish has been added to the dream, in the form of a three-year contract that the 25-year-old New Yorker has signed with the St. Louis Blues.

title: CAR INSURERS IN JERSEY GET 15% INCREASE
description: Insurance-rate increases averaging 15 percent and affecting more than one million New Jersey drivers were approved today by Insurance Commissioner Joseph F. Murphy. The new rates are effective Monday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: City Hall Meets Crime

title: DARWIN AND THE BIBLE CAN COEXIST PEACEFULLY
description: To the Editor:

title: SOLUTION TO SLAYING AT BOUTIQUE ELUDES THE POLICE
description: On the evening of June 5, a man walked into Design Observations, a boutique at the corner of Columbus Avenue and 73d Street, shortly before closing. He asked about men's clothing and was told by Gina Whitlock, a 22-year-old clerk, that the shop carried only women's wear.

title: Labor Secretary Gives Almost No Work to 19
description: The Reagan Administration has assigned little or no work for nine months to 19 career Labor Department policy experts. Their salaries for the period total more than $500,000.

title: COAST COURTS CHOKED AS VALUE OF VICTIM RIGHTS LAW IS DEBATED
description: John Cho, an 18-year-old Asian immigrant, was arrested about a week ago on charges of entering a food market in nearby Fountain Valley, flashing a .38-caliber revolver and robbing the shopkeeper of $135. The crime is punishable under California law by eight years in prison.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are good reasons why most sandwiches are looked upon with disdain by many connoisseurs. The bread may be spongy (most hamburger buns are), the filling of poor quality, the garnishes excessive or inappropriate and so on.

title: A VIOLENT PALESTINIAN MINORITY IS NOTHING NEW
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 259977 -- No Title
description: The M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company, formerly the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company, yesterday reported a $4.4 million loss in the third fiscal quarter, contrasted to a profit of $3.5 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: More Rioting Sweeps South African Mines
description: Violence broke out again in South African mines today as black miners protested against pay scales that give them one-fifth the wages of white miners.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some recipes call for baking soda plus baking powder and I am curious to know the difference between the two. Can you tell me?

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ACF Industries has elected James C. O'Hara group vice president.

title: BIGGER BANKS ARE HURT BY FAILURE IN OKLAHOMA
description: The failure over the weekend of the relatively small Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which had about $190 million in uninsured deposits, is causing large losses at banks across the country, possibly as large as $240 million for the Continental Illinois Corporation alone.

title: Motorola Awarded Damages in Suit
description: Motorola Inc. announced that three former executives whom it charged with copyright and trademark infringement and misappropriation of company information and technology had been ordered by a Federal court in Chicago to pay Motorola $200,000 as part of the settlement of a damage suit.

title: Excerpts from the debate, B5
description: In their first confrontation in the contest for the Republican nomination for governor, Paul J. Curran and Lewis E. Lehrman yesterday both criticized the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, as too liberal and too lenient on the subject of the rights of defendants.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER
description: The Hammermill Paper Company, an Erie, Pa., producer of fine and printing papers, reported that the impact of the recession caused net income in its second fiscal quarter, ended June 20, to drop 23.4 percent, to $10.5 million, or $1.13 a share, from $13.7 million or $1.61 a share, in the similar quarter a year earlier. Sales edged up five-tenths of 1 percent, to $332.6 million, from $330.8 million.

title: A DISORIENTING MOVE
description: At the United Nations, Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko announced that the Soviet Union was renouncing the first use of nuclear weapons in war. American commentators have treated his speech as a skillful thrust in the propaganda war for Europe, and unquestionably this was a major motivation for it. In military terms, however, the statement was mainly significant for the Chinese front, and it should be looked upon as an important event in Soviet-Chinese relations.

title: PERIPATETIC EXECUTIVE FINDS NEW APPAREL JOB
description: Warren Hirsh has a new job. Again. The apparel company executive, who in the past two years has seemed to change jobs as frequently as his industry changes fashions, has been named president of J. Breed Clothing Inc., a manufacturer of jeans under the Jesse Jeans label.

title: Letter: On Import Quotas; Give American Sugar a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR IN EL SALVADOR THREATENS TO SPREAD
description: A joint Honduran-Salvadoran operation against guerrillas in this country has raised fears that the civil war may spread throughout the region.

title: VIOLENT CRIMES IN NEW YORK FELL 8.2% IN FIRST FOUR MONTHS OF '82
description: The number of violent crimes reported in New York City declined 8.2 percent in the first four months of 1982 compared with the same period last year, Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday.

title: ON JUSTICE TO VICTIMS
description: Crimes that terrorize take many forms, from aggravated assault to petty thievery. But one crime goes largely unnoticed. It is a crime against which there is no protection. It is committed daily across our nation. It is the painful, wrongful insensitivity of the criminal justice system toward those who are the victims of crime.

title:
Economic Scene;
World Loan Responsibility
description: Karin Lissakers is a senior associate of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. This is the first of two columns by her. Leonard Silk is on vacation.

title: METROPOLITAIN DIARY
description: HOW does the average New Yorker trapped in the average subway car during the average interminable delay pass the time? Well, fuming and muttering are possibilities. Other options include staring blankly at the Driver Training Institute ad, counting the trains passing on the express track or realizing how truly thankful you are that you never volunteered for submarine service.

title: Children Killed in Fire Buried With Relative
description: Five young brothers and sisters and their grandfather, who was never aware that his grandchildren had died in a tenement fire, were buried together today.

title: ARMY CHALLENGED ON SOLDIER'S DISAPPERANCE
description: Her parents could not understand why the young Army medic, regarded by her superiors as the best soldier in her company, was listed first as absent without leave, then as a deserter when she disappeared two months ago.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Bronx Group Acts to Save Edgar Allan Poe Home

title: Giddings Will Study Bid
description: Giddings & Lewis Inc., a Wisconsin machine tool manufacturer, said that it would consider an unsolicited tender offer from the AMCA International Corporation at a board meeting on Friday.

title: TV: HAND-PUPPET THEATER ON CABLE
description: ONE of the most unusual and delightful evenings of theater can be found on Manhattan's Central Park West in a room seating only 24 persons. For more than 25 years, an acting company of five hand puppets has been holding forth there with everything from William Shakespeare to Noel Coward. ''The Little Players,'' as they are called, say they are New York's longest-running repertory theater and light opera company. They and their creators are the subject of a Robin Lehman documentary on the Hearst/ ABC Arts cable service (Channel 10 on Manhattan Cable) this evening at 9 o'clock.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Brooklyn Academy Aide Heads Historic Theaters

title: AVANT-GARDE: NEW MUSIC TAKES FESTIVAL TO CHICAGO
description: This city's decision to sponsor the fourth annual New Music America Festival, which began here Monday night, takes on a symbolic significance both for Chicago, as a sign of its burgeoning sophistication, and for the cause of experimental music, which is reaching inward from its coastal enclaves to reclaim its status as an inherently American form of art music.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 7, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan said a flat-rate income tax is ''very tempting'' and ''worth looking into.'' It was Mr. Reagan's strongest comment yet in favor of a simplified income tax. (Page A1.)

title: Britain Reports It Lost 255 in Falkland War
description: British casualties in the Falkland Islands conflict with Argentina totaled 255 dead and 777 wounded, a junior defense minister said today.

title: BRAZILIAN IS TCHAIKOVSKY CELLO WINNER
description: The first Gold Medal in this year's Tchaikovsky Competition, in cello, went today to a 24-year-old Brazilian; Americans came in fifth and seventh.

title: Stallings Declines Job in U.S.F.L.
description: Gene Stallings, saying that he had a commitment with the Dallas Cowboys, today turned down the head coaching job with the Birmingham Stallions of the new United States Football League.

title: Bridge: A Negative Double Means Trouble for Some Partners
description: Virtually all American experts nowadays employ the negative double, devised by Alvin Roth in the 1950's. Its use has obvious advantages, but it introduces some gray areas.

title: COMBINED-RYAN ACCORD YIELDS STONE'S SUCCESSOR
description: Ever since W. Clement Stone's son resigned last March as chief executive officer of the company his father founded, the Combined International Corporation, analysts have been wondering about how a successor might be found who shared the positive mental attitude Mr. Stone had promulgated. That question has apparently been resolved through the planned acquisition by Combined of the Ryan Insurance Group Inc., another direct sales insurance concern.

title: Errant Driver Forces 70 Cars Off Rte. I-70
description: A 72-year-old man drove his pickup truck down the wrong side of Interstate 70 Monday, forcing about 70 cars into ditches and onto medial strips, the police said.

title: ELMER G. KUMBLAD
description: Elmer G. Kumblad, an accountant in New York City for many years, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Clipper Legal Case Stays in San Diego
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the National Basketball Association and the San Diego Clippers would have to settle their legal differences in San Diego.

title: Supercomputer From Fujitsu
description: Fujitsu Ltd. displayed what it said were the world's fastest computers. It said its Facom VP-200 and VP-100 are designed to break into the supercomputer market, now dominated by Cray Research Inc. and the Control Data Corporation, both of the United States.

title: Righetti Has a Bad Night
description: Dave Righetti, trying to regain the form that made him the rookie of the year in the American League with the Yankees last season, has suffered another setback.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: ALL things being equal, it is nice to live in clean surroundings with everything polished, dusted, vacuumed, cleaned, sprayed, scrubbed and washed. But all things are rarely equal, and when push comes to shove, it's first things first.

title: U.S. BUSINESSES FACE YEARS OF HIGH RATES, FORECASTERS CAUTION
description: A growing number of economists are predicting that high interest rates are here to stay for at least another couple of years. That, they say, could have serious consequences for the already battered economy.

title: Renewed Subsidy Urged For Public Broadcasting
description: A panel created by Congress to study the financing of public broadcasting has reported that no alternative existed to take the place of Federal money and that any cuts would reduce services.

title: Gimbels Recalling Party Fondue Set
description: A Party Fondue Set sold by Gimbel Brothers Inc. has turned out to be a serious safety risk. The New York retailer is voluntarily recalling 3,046 of the fondue sets because their fuel cups may leak and cause flash fires, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES SHOWED 17.5 PERCENT DROP IN LATE JUNE
description: New car sales by the nation's three leading auto manufacturers, in an apparent reflection of consumer resistance to a lack of buyer incentive plans, fell 17.5 percent in the last 10 days of June, the companies reported today.

title: Douglaston Hero
description: John McEnroe, the conquered hero at Wimbledon, is still the hero in Douglaston, Queens, where he grew up.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MODERN DANCE

title: A VICE PRESIDENTIAL FLOOR: 'ISN'T THAT SOMETHING?'
description: They pulled the rug out from under Vice President Bush and there it was: one of the most magnificent parquet floors in all Washington.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Upscale 'Brown' Bag

title: Strike Ends at Mill in Florida
description: Members of three unions ratified a tentative three-year contract Monday, ending a 16-week-old strike at the Southwest Forest Industries paper mill here, a spokesman for the unions said. The workers belong to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, the International Association of Machinists and the United Paperworkers International. The company offer they accepted calls for pension improvements and pay increases totaling 20 percent over three years, the spokesman said.

title: PLAN FAVORING BLACK TEACHERS FAILS
description: The American Federation of Teachers, after almost an hour of emotional debate, turned down a resolution yesterday that would have endorsed the principle of dismissing experienced white teachers so that the jobs of newer black teachers could be protected.

title: YANKS LOSE 7-0 LEAD BUT WIN, 8-7, IN 12
description: Bobby Murcer and Rudy May, two little-used veterans, saved the Yankees tonight. After New York squandered a seven-run lead, Murcer hit a 12thinning home run, and May pitched three scoreless innings for an 8-7 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: DEATH TOLL INCREASES TO NINE IN ARSON FIRE IN WATERBURY
description: The death toll in the fire early Monday in twin five-story apartment buildings apparently rose to nine today as firefighters with shovels and pickaxes continued searching the wreckage.

title: Market Place; Energy Effort: Profits Sought
description: FOR more than two decades, Energy Conversion Devices has failed to produce much revenue from operations. Yet its stock has been one of the most spectacular - if erratic - in modern market history.

title: McWILLIAMS HOLDS HOUSTON TO 5 HITS
description: Larry McWilliams, making only his second start since being acquired from Atlanta on July 1, pitched a fivehitter, and Jim Morrison hit a second-inning home run tonight to enable the Pittsburgh Pirates to register a 1-0 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: GETTING THE MOST OUT OF MEAT BY COOKING IN SALT BED OR PASTRY
description: IN an era when people are being admonished to cut down on unnecessary salt in their diets, the notion of cooking a chicken in a dough that is almost 50 percent salt might seem downright nihilistic.

title: NECKTIES WITH AN ECONOMICS LESSON
description: Two Republican Senators, Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Jesse Helms of North Carolina, were hotly debating Government peanut acreage allotments. Senator Lugar was against them, Senator Helms was for them. Both were wearing their Adam Smith neckties.

title: Canada's Trade Surplus
description: Canada today announced a trade surplus of $1.05 billion (United States) for May, Canada's biggest trade surplus in 18 months. It was welcome economic news for the Liberal Government, which also denied rumors today that it would be asking the International Monetary Fund for money to cover its growing budget deficit and dwindling foreign currency reserves. One Government trade official cautioned that ''the reason that the trade balance is so positive is because our imports have dropped much more drastically than our exports.''

title: REPORT IS CRITICAL OF PHONE SERVICE
description: Telephone service in 17 of 95 central offices in Manhattan, including 13 in midtown or downtown, was ''less than satisfactory'' in the first quarter of this year, according to a report issued yesterday by the State Public Service Commission.

title: Train Wreck in East Germany Leaves 59 Hurt, 28 Seriously
description: Fifty-nine people were injured, 28 seriously, when a Rostock-to-East Berlin express train went off the rails today, the East German press agency reported.

title: Haig Calls It a Day, This Time for Good
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., who resigned as Secretary of State on June 25, has finally made it official and left office, the State Department announced today.

title: FRENCH INDICATE P.L.O. WILL DROP MILITARY ROLE
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today that he ''was in a position to confirm'' that the Palestine Liberation Organization had agreed ''to move from military action to political action.''

title: Banner to Honor P.O.W.'s
description: President Reagan has ordered that a special banner be flown over the White House and the Pentagon on Friday in recognition of all American prisoners of war and those still missing, aides said today. Mr. Reagan signed a proclamation designating Friday as ''National P.O.W.-M.I.A. Recognition Day, 1982.'' The banner has a white silhouette of a prisoner and a guard tower inside a circle on a black background.

title: NAMIBIA NEGOTIATIONS BEGIN AMID SKEPTICISM
description: Western and African nations began talks today aimed at ending the guerrilla war in South-West Africa and giving the South African-administered territory its independence as the nation of Namibia sometime next year.

title: Guatemala Censorship Order
description: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt's military Government today banned political activity and ordered censorship of all news about leftist guerrillas fighting for power here. A Government decree prohibited ''the publication of news and commentaries related to subversive activities occurring in the country, be it news that originates in the country or comes from abroad.'' The Government declared a state of siege last Thursday, giving it wide powers to search homes and make arrests without warrants.

title: A Willing Substitute
description: After a two-week search in which one contender turned down the offer, a replacement for Mario Miranda, the injured Colombian boxer, has been found for a bout against Salvador Sanchez of Mexico for the World Boxing Council featherweight title July 21 at Madison Square Garden. The substitute challenger is Azumah Nelson of Ghana, the undefeated British Commonwealth champion.

title: A MILLION LISTENED TO ASTRONAUTS
description: Hello, operator, connect me to space. Deposit 50 cents, please. More than a million Americans made such a call last week - but they dialed direct - during the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's dial-a-shuttle program.

title: SEALED EARS
description: Dr. Harold Liverworth, the syndicated sociologist, is under the impression that Americans want someone to listen to them. Hence the title of his latest book, ''How To Make People Shut Up and Listen To You,'' published by Quack & Blurb at $19.95.

title: 3 EVANS ALBUMS RETURN
description: GIL EVANS has been associated with Miles Davis off and on since the late 1940's, when he wrote arrangements for the Miles Davis Band that recorded the celebrated tracks later collected in album form as ''The Birth of the Cool.'' They worked together again in the 1960's on the award-winning ''Miles Ahead,'' ''Porgy and Bess'' and ''Sketches of Spain'' albums. Their creative give and take during the 1970's wasn't well documented on records, but it seems that while Mr. Davis was developing his own taut, aggressive jazz-rock fusion, Mr. Evans, with his big bands of the late 1960's and early to mid-70's, was coming up with something similar. He uses the rhythms and electronic instrumentation of rock and funk, but combines them with his singular scoring for horns, which breaks the standard jazz-band instrumentation down into odd but effective combinations and makes the group sigh and sing as well as shout.

title: A Woman's Ambition
description: Toni Onichuk, a secretary in the Fort Frances Recreation Department in Ontario, has an ambition to referee in the National Hockey League. ''Hopefully, they won't discriminate against me,'' said Miss Onichuk, who is 23 years old, 5 feet 2 inches tall and weighs 110 pounds.

title: Chrysler Reduces Price of 2 Models
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced a $448 cut in the price of its basic two-door hatchback Dodge Colt and Plymouth Champ subcompacts, which are imported from Japan.

title: Careers; Mandatory Retirement End Sought
description: ON Capitol Hill, Claude Pepper continues to press for a change in the retirement age. Successful some years ago in getting the age changed to 70 from 65 for most working people, the Florida Democrat now wants to eliminate an age cap completely.

title: Help for Stutterers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I read with interest the article by Jane E. Brody on stuttering (Personal Health, June 23). As a stutterer for about 40 years - I am now 50 - I tried just about every type of therapy with little or no success.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: T hey certainly know how to keep secrets from each other at the city's Department of Investigation.

title: GRANDSON IS CONVICTED IN UTAH BUSINESMAN'S DEATH
description: Marc Francis Schreuder was found guilty today of second-degree murder in the 1978 slaying of his grandfather, who became a millionaire in the automobile parts industry.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.B.A. Industries of Pinellas Park, Fla., said directors had rejected as inadequate a takeover offer from an undisclosed buyer of $12.50 a share for all A.B.A.'s common stock outstanding.

title: FOR GOOD NUTRITION: BALANCED DIET VS. VITAMIN PILLS
description: EVERYWHERE you turn these days, some advertisement is pushing vitamin supplements for someone: for the drinker, the smoker, the athlete, the dieter, the woman who's pregnant or taking birth control pills, the finicky youngster, the stress-ridden executive, the tired housewife, the budget-squeezed older person, not to mention ordinary people worried that their diet may not supply enough vital nutrients.

title: PRESERVING THE NUTRIENTS OF FOOD WITH PROPER CARE
description: The various vitamins and minerals are susceptible to destruction by air, light, water, acid, alkali, heat, time and the action of enzymes in the foods themselves. However, you can cut losses and significantly increase your nutrient intake by the care you take in choosing, storing and cooking foods. What to Choose

title: Heading Downtown
description: A fter 40 years in midtown, in quarters of growing shabbiness, the Voice of America officially moved its New York operation downtown yesterday, to 26 Federal Plaza. Now, the 25 reporters, editors and technicians here can actually see mainland America: Their new studios look over the lower Hudson, across to New Jersey and beyond.

title: FRANKLYN WALTMAN
description: Franklyn Waltman, director of publicity for the Republican National Committee from 1938 to 1941, died Sunday at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He was 79 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: UNICEF AIDE SCRAMBLING TO KEEP BEIRUT IN WATER
description: In this city of guns, bombings, strafings and killings, there are also people like Raymond Naimy, a Lebanese engineer who went from place to place in west Beirut today to assure that residents had water.

title: Bar on Dow Futures
description: A state appellate court today blocked the Chicago Board of Trade's plan to offer futures contracts based on Dow Jones & Company's industrial stock average, a Board of Trade lawyer said. The ruling overturned a lower court's ruling that the proposed futures contract would not violate any proprietary rights of Dow Jones.

title: Cleaning Up Kidporn
description: Child pornography, an especially offensive form of child abuse, got its comeuppance from a unanimous Supreme Court last week. Finding the sexual exploitation of minors in live and filmed performances ''a serious national problem,'' the Court reinstated New York's law against selling it.

title: 5 Children Die in 2 Years In Care of Sitter, 19
description: A 19-year-old baby sitter has had five small children die while in her care in two years, the latest on Saturday.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Rolling Stones in Spain For Controversial Concert

title: HARLEM PASTOR AND COOKE AIDE ARE NAMED AUXILIARY BISHOPS
description: Pope John Paul II has named a pastor from Harlem and the vicar general of the Archdiocese of New York as auxiliary bishops to Terence Cardinal Cooke.

title: BOOM IN NEW YORK ART SALES APPARENTLY OVER
description: The 20-year boom of the New York art world, when there seemed to be a buyer for the work of every artist and when dealers and auction houses broke their sales records virtually every month, is apparently over.

title: MEXICAN RIGHT TAKES 2D VOTING
description: The ruling party's presidential candidate, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, won over 74 percent of the votes cast in Sunday's election, while the conservative National Action Party emerged as the country's undisputed second political force, according to incomplete results made public today.

title: Subway-Token Blues
description: R eturning to work after a long weekend is an ordeal, but reality comes home extra hard for those New Yorkers who forget a Basic Principle of Urban Survival: Make sure you have a subway token for the morning rush hour. Yesterday's lines for tokens weren't too bad, maybe because many regular passengers had begun summer vacations. Still, the 72d Street IRT entrance on Broadway was its normally uncomfortable self as only one attendant flicked out tokens.

title: Sutter Out a Week
description: Bruce Sutter, the St. Louis Cardinals' star reliever, is expected to be out for at least a week because of a strained left groin muscle. Sutter suffered the injury while warming up Monday night in Cincinnati. He pitched the eighth inning, but was removed in the ninth. ... Sammy Stewart of the Baltimore Orioles, bothered for a month by sore knees, has been sent to Hagerstown, Md., of the Class A Carolina League on 20-day rehabilitation assignment.

title: A TOP COLT UNLEASHES TOP SPEED
description: E ddie Maple thinks that great race horses are like great running backs: In one explosive instant, they can accelerate before the chance is gone. The jockey's favorite football player was Jim Brown; his favorite race horse is Conquistador Cielo. And for one explosive instant at Belmont Park on Monday afternoon, Maple's favorite horse reminded him of his favorite running back.

title: Bob and Ray Tapes Are Played at Museum
description: Early and recent recordings and television tapes by the comedy team of Bob Elliott and Ray Goulding can be heard and viewed through Saturday at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.

title: PIGBAG WINS THE BRITISH PRESS
description: THE British music press has been all agog recently over the commercial success, in America as well as in Britain, of a new wave of British funk and jazz-funk bands and performers. Some of this music is distinctive and intelligently put together - ''Mama Used to Say,'' the big hit enjoyed earlier this year by Junior Giscombe, is an example.

title: AGENTINA SETS CREDIT CONTROLS
description: Argentina's central bank, carrying out a new economic policy aimed at pushing the country out of its deep recession and rebuilding domestic industry, announced new credit controls today and devalued the peso 22 percent for trade while floating it for all other transactions.

title: Two in OPEC See Violations
description: Two key OPEC oil ministers - Mani Said al-Otaiba of the United Arab Emirates and Subroto of Indonesia - acknowledged today that some members were violating the group's production-sharing agreement.

title: THE TAX CUT WON'T CUT HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonn Plans Aid for Telefunken
description: The West German Government announced today that it would decide soon on a series of measures to relieve a cash shortage at AEG-Telefunken that threatens the ailing electrical and electronics giant with insolvency.

title: Israel Gets Plea on Prisoners
description: The International Commission of Jurists has called on Israel to grant prisoner-of-war status to about 4,000 Palestinians thought to have been taken prisoner in the invasion of Lebanon. The commission, in a statement issued Tuesday, said the Israeli policy of holding the prisoners as ''administrative detainees'' was ''inappropriate in the present situation.''

title: Business Failures Soar
description: Business failures soared during the first six months of 1982, Dun & Bradstreet Inc. said yesterday. The 11,498 failures reported by the credit rating and business information service represented a 45 percent increase from the period a year earlier and more than the total for all of 1980.

title: Brennan Rejects Plea In Rape Resentencing
description: A Supreme Court Justice today cleared the way for the resentencing of three Massachusetts men whose original suspended sentences in a rape case led to a public outcry and a protest from the state's Governor.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts 'Richtofen' Lead Changes, Resetting Opening Night

title: NICARAGUANS SOUND GLOOMY ON U.S.
description: The Government has renewed its call for serious negotiations with the United States but seems close to concluding that the Reagan Administration has no interest in improving ties.

title: Japanese Steel Ruling
description: The International Trade Commission ruled unanimously today that imports of stainless clad steel plate from Japan are harming American producers of the product. The ruling, on a petition filed by the Lukens Steel Company, clears the way for the Commerce Department to impose duties on the products.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Circle Line Sued

title: BETTER GRAIN STORAGE SAFETY URGED
description: The nation's grain elevators, which have been rocked by more than 400 dust explosions in which 200 people have been killed over the past 22 years, should install dust collection devices and follow better housekeeping practices, a panel of the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: Dow Edges Up 0.76, to 799.66
description: Several prominent stocks posted sharp losses yesterday in response to adverse news, while bank issues continued to retreat because of problem loans originating with the now-defunct Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City.

title: LET RICH ARABS FUND PALESTINIAN WATER PROJECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TRIAL OPENS IN MOBIL LIBEL SUIT
description: The Washington Post was accused in a libel trial today of practicing ''reckless and irresponsible'' journalism when it published news articles saying that the president of the Mobil Corporation set up his son in business to keep the company's shipping operations profitable.

title: NEW YORK SINGER IS WINNER AT TCHAIKOVSKY COMPETITION
description: Five Soviet citizens and one American won the top six prizes today in the vocal category of the seventh Tchaikovsky Competition.

title: Start And Stop?
description: Even in a gloomy atmosphere the comment on the strategic arms talks was startlingly pessimistic. Valentin M. Falin of the Central Committee's International Information Department said, ''The Reagan proposal is not negotiable.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Human Jukebox

title: Pan Am Benefits
description: Pan American World Airways announced it had sold $14 million worth of tax benefits on three Boeing 727-221 aircraft on which it took delivery in April. Pan Am did not disclose the name of the buyer or provide other details of the transaction, which occurred June 30.

title: Victorious Wins Juvenile Stakes
description: Victorious stamped himself as the top 2-year-old in the East yesterday with a three-quarter-length victory over six other colts in the $54,900 Juvenile Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: NEW GALLERY OFFERS QUALITY CRAFTWORK
description: The space occupied by the newly opened Heller Gallery, at 71 Greene Street, is alive with theatrical excitement. The walls and 20-foothigh ceiling are resplendent in tones of somber charcoal. The dramatic lighting punctuates the art works in this monochromatic environment.

title: Return of Duran Inspires No Fear
description: Roberto Duran is in town, working out, planning another comeback. Duran says this one is different. The reason he gives is the same one Joe Louis gave, the same one Joe Frazier used.

title: JACKSON'S CRITIQUE OF YANKEES
description: As if he were a United Nations observer, Reggie Jackson has been watching the George Steinbrenner-Dave Winfield War with unusual insight. For five years Reggie Jackson was in the same foxhole as he traded bullets with the Yankees' principal owner.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS KEEP SHELLING AS TALKS SEEM DEADLOCKED
description: Israel kept up its bombardment and blockade of the Palestine Liberation Organization in west Beirut today amid indications that negotiations for a settlement were still deadlocked over the basic details of when, how and where the P.L.O.would leave Lebanon.

title: Brussels Site Of Steel Talks
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and Under Secretary Lionel Olmer were to leave Washington tonight for Brussels in an attempt to get an agreement to hold down exports of steel to the United States.

title: 3 G.O.P. Candidates Supporting Lehrman
description: Two Republicans seeking statewide office - James L. Emery, the candidate for lieutenant governor, and Frances Sclafani, who is running for attorney general - yesterday endorsed Lewis E. Lehrman for the Republican gubernatorial nomination.

title: LaPorte Gets Hearing
description: Juan LaPorte has been granted a hearing by the World Boxing Association regarding his controversial title fight last January in Atlantic City against Eusebio Pedroza of Panama, the W.B.A. featherweight champion. Howard Albert, LaPorte's manager, said he would appear before Luis Batista Salas, chairman of the W.B.A. championship committee, next Thursday in an attempt to prove that his fighter should have been awarded the verdict because of fouling by the champion.

title: MOBILE PHONE PACT IS STUDIED
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division today asked the nation's largest telephone companies to provide information on the agreement they reached to provide a new type of mobile phone service in 30 of the nation's largest cities.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Home for Tharp Troupe

title: 3-RUN 8th SPOILS GAFF'S DEBUT
description: Brent Gaff's loss did not dim the enthusiasm of Manager George Bamberger or the Shea Stadium fans last night because they got a peek at their future when the pitcher made his major league debut.

title: The U.N. Today; July 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Information - 3 P.M.

title: STUDY OF POSTAL SERVICE OFFERS PRAISE AND CRITICISM
description: The United States Postal Service has reduced costs and improved productivity in the last decade but in doing so has sacrificed employee courtesy and customer services, a new study concludes.

title: 50 Years Ago, Dow Reached Lowest Level
description: With the Dow Jones industrial average hovering near 800, many investors may be wondering just how low it can go. The Dow's all-time low was 41.22 - reached precisely 50 years ago, on July 8, 1932. That was down 89 percent from the Dow's record high at that time, of 381.17, reached on Sept. 3, 1929. Even on Oct. 29, 1929, the fateful day known as ''Black Tuesday'' the Dow closed much higher, at 230.07.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When my daughter painted her room she used masking tape on all the windows to protect the glass against paint smears. When she tried to remove the tape, which is now only partially removed because it is so hard to get off, a sticky, unsightly residue was left on the glass. What is the best way to get all of this tape off as well as the sticky residue that remains? - V.G., Brooklyn.

title: HERS
description: AS a member of the ticking-clock generation, I have long been concerned with the problem of Finding the Right Man (not to be confused with Mr. Right, from whom I have been divorced for some time). Imagine my interest, therefore, when I arrived home from a publishing lunch to find the following message on my answering machine: ''Hello.'' said the voice of a friend. ''Have I got a man for you! Call me!''

title: BRIEFS ON ARTS
description: $22 Million for Humanities

title: Bullies v. the Bench
description: When politicians attack the courts, they are almost always bullies. The victims, being judges, must suffer in silence, generally denied their day in the court of public comment. The best they can hope for is that when necessary, non-judges will speak up in their defense. It is already necessary in the case of the Republican candidates for Governor of New York.

title: 3 WIN HUMANITIES TV AWARDS
description: The writers of ''Divorce Wars,'' an ABC-TV movie, and episodes of ''Lou Grant'' and ''M*A*S*H'' have shared this year's $50,000 in Humanitas Awards, it was announced today.

title: WENDY'S PLANS STORES
description: Wendy's International Inc. said today it planned to open 220 stores this year, up from a previous estimate of 215.

title: Greek Bank Strike Ends With Pay Raises
description: A six-week bank strike ended today, after the Socialist Government's partial satisfaction of demands by 32,000 striking bank employees for substantial pay increases.

title: B.B.D.O. to Handle Pepsi's New Brand
description: As expected, Pepsico announced yesterday that it was entering the caffeine-free cola derby, with Pepsi Free going into eight test markets. Advertising will be handled by Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn beginning in the middle of August.

title: Vatican Bank's Head Is Reported Resigning
description: An Italian newspaper said today that Archbishop Paul Marcinkus, the president of the Vatican Bank criticized for reported involvement with an Italian bank under investigation, has offered his resignation to Pope John Paul II.

title: ISRAEL ADAMANT IN RULING OUT P.L.O. PRESENCE IN LEBANON
description: An aide to Prime Minister Menachem Begin reiterated today that all members of the Palestine Liberation Organization must leave west Beirut and that no political representation or token military force would be permitted to remain.

title: SOLOMON HOLLISTER, ENGINEER AND FORMER DEAN AT CORNELL
description: Solomon Cady Hollister, dean of the Cornell University College of Engineering from 1937 to 1959 and a professional engineer who led in the innovative use of structural concrete, died Tuesday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Stake in Charan
description: Charan Industries, which owns and operates real estate properties, including a chain of bowling centers, said that the Ryan family, its major shareholders, owned 75.3 percent of the 6.6 million new common shares outstanding that were issued in connection with its merger with BT Mortgage Investors on June 18. Before the merger, Charles P. Ryan Sr., Charles P. Ryan Jr., John J. Ryan and Kevin T. Ryan had owned 100 percent of Charan, which is based in Garden City, L.I.

title: LUCAS IS TRADED TO SUNS
description: Maurice Lucas flew to China yesterday morning for a tour with the National Basketball Players Association team, unaware that he was being traded by the Knicks to the Phoenix Suns for Len (Truck) Robinson.

title: 2 CHURCHES STILL SHELTERING HOMELESS
description: Last winter, during a particularly brutal stretch of frigid weather, Mayor Koch called on New York City's churches to open their doors to the homeless in their neighborhoods. A half-dozen responded by providing cots, blankets and warm rooms for men and women who otherwise might have slept in the streets or train stations.

title: Kroger Profit Climbs 25.5%
description: The Kroger Company announced yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter of 1982 ended June 19 rose 25.5 percent, while sales advanced 8.5 percent.

title: BROOKLYN MAN ADMITS KILLING LAWYER IN PARK
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man pleaded guilty yesterday to the fatal stabbing of Patrick E. Kehn, a lawyer who had been strolling in a Lower East Side park with a companion when the attack occurred last September.

title: NEEDHAM'S NEW HEAD IN U.S.
description: Here's Keith Reinhard, who left his hometown right after graduating from high school as president of his class, and now at age 47, without ever stopping for college, which he could not afford, becomes president and chief executive of the 18th-largest United States ad agency.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: At Breakfast Debate, A Helping of Quotations

title: Church of England Rejects Protestant Unity
description: The Church of England's governing body narrowly turned down proposals today that would establish closer bonds with other Protestant churches.

title: URBAN CONSERVATION: A ONE-WOMAN EFFORT
description: HATTIE CARTHAN adopts things. When she lived on Long Island as a young girl and drove to and from Brooklyn church services with her father, a minister, she used to ''adopt trees along the road because they came to be familiar to me,'' she says. ''They were my trees.''

title: Staten Island Ice
description: On Staten Island a generation ago, Nicholas Evamplios Fotiu was growing up as a New York Ranger fan, telling people that some day he would play for the Rangers. People laughed; there wasn't even a hockey rink on Staten Island.

title: NOT YOUR USUAL AMBASSADORIAL PAIR
description: Being the Canadian Ambassador isn't easy. ''For some reason, a glaze passes over peoples' faces when you say Canada,'' said Sondra Gotlieb, the Ambassador's wife. ''Maybe we should invade South Dakota or something.''

title: THE STAGE: AMERICAN 'MERCENARIES' IN CARIBBEAN
description: day Caribbean island. It bids us to enter that third-world heart of darkness where revolutionaries, smooth American envoys and hired soldiers-of-fortune are all up to no good.

title: TASTIER MILK WOULD SAVE THE U.S. MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: 400 Rebels Reported Killed in El Salvador
description: Defense Minister Jose Guillermo Garcia said today that Government soldiers had killed 400 rebels in Morazan Province, contradicting reports that the monthlong campaign near the Honduran border was bogged down.

title: Hungary Joins Agency
description: The World Bank said today that Hungary had become the 143d country to join the International Development Agency, a World Bank affiliate. The move had been expected following acceptance May 5 of Hungary as the second East bloc country to become a member of the International Monetary Fund, a prerequisite to World Bank membership. Rumania is the other East bloc member.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY, UNDER GREGORIAN, CELEBRATING A GOOD YEAR
description: At lunchtime these days, on the great stone steps of the New York Public Library at 41st Street, they are celebrating the joy of summer. Lunchers lunch, hawkers hawk, gawkers gawk, fiddlers fiddle, preachers preach and thousands of passers-by stop, stare, smile and then move on.

title: BOSTON METER COLLECTORS CHARGED WITH COIN THEFT
description: On Tuesday the seven city employees who collected coins from Boston's parking meters were arrested for stealing a lot of the coins. Today no one collected coins from the parking meters. Starting Thursday, and for the foreseeable future, Brink's Inc. guards in armored cars will do the collecting.

title: COMPUTERS ADD TO ARCHITECTS' REACH
description: Several months ago Dartmouth College called the architectural firm Moore Grover Harper in Essex, Conn., asking for design revisions in an art gallery still in the planning stage. Normally an architect and one or more draftsmen would spend about three days modifying the design, changing the specifications and redrawing the building. This time an architect made the changes on a video screen in a matter of hours and new drawings were in the mail the same day.

title: Australian to Head Jardine's U.S. Unit
description: Robert C. Sutton, a 43-year-old Australian, has been named president and chief executive officer of the newly created North American division of Jardine, Matheson & Company, the giant Hong Kong-based trading house founded in Canton 150 years ago.

title: FILM: SWISS TELL OF ROLE IN SPANISH CIVIL WAR
description: RICHARD DINDO'S documentary film-making style is so plain that his material is virtually left to speak for itself. In ''The Swiss in the Spanish Civil War,'' at the Film Forum, what Mr. Dindo chiefly does is to conduct interviews with veterans and their wives and present them without comment. After a brisk thumbnail history of the Spanish Civil War, the film devotes itself to viewing these survivors and listening to their accounts of the experience.

title: THREE STATES ENACT DIFFERING MEASURES TO CUT BACK CRIME
description: States in the New York metropolitan region have adopted a variety of measures in recent years in efforts to curb violent crime, but there seems to be no consensus on what works.

title: HOME BEAT
description: When Susan Tarlov worked as a textile designer she was sometimes frustrated because she found herself formulating a design rather than making a finished object. ''I felt I lost something along the way,'' she explained, ''so I decided to make a finished product.''

title: Investigations Chief Named
description: Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman today announced the appointment of Robert J. McCarthy, a former special agent in charge of the F.B.I.'s Newark office, as supervisor of investigations.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's offer of American troops to help guarantee the evacuation of Palestine Liberation Organization forces from west Beirut seems to mark a new turn in what has amounted to an awkward diplomatic minuet between the United States and the Palestinian organization for the last seven years.

title: PANEL QUESTIONS PUBLIC-TV FINANCING
description: A statement by a Reagan Administration policy panel has raised the question in Washington as to whether the Federal Government will continue to finance public television.

title: Auto Profits Expected
description: The Big Three auto makers are likely to post second-quarter profits as a result of cost cutting, contract concessions and relatively strong sales of big cars, industry analysts said today.

title: CLARK WORKS AT BEING AN 'HONEST BROKER OF IDEAS'
description: In recent administrations, the most powerful national security advisers have been strategic thinkers such as Henry A. Kissinger and Zbigniew Brzezinski, men who came to the White House with well developed views of the world and who sought to impose their notions of American strtategy on the foreign policy apparatus.

title: WAR PRODS BRITISH INTO MILITARY CHANGES
description: The Falkland war has prompted Britain to consider some military and naval changes, but without major alterations in its Atlantic fleet or its commitment to the North Atlantic alliance.

title: Optimism Seen On Polish Debt
description: Western and Polish bankers today expressed optimism after a one-day meeting here that they could reach an agreement on Poland's request to reschedule more than $4 billion in commercial debts due to the West this year.

title: BLACK MINERS SENT TO THE HOMELANDS
description: Gold mine companies began busing home at least 1,000 black workers today after riots that have taken 10 lives in seven days.

title: KARL W. DAHLEM
description: Karl W. Dahlem, a former vice president for public relations at American Airlines, died Tuesday at his home in La Jolla, Calif.

title: MOORCROFT BREAKS RECORD IN 5,000
description: Dave Moorcroft of Britain set a world record tonight in the men's 5,000-meter run of the Oslo Games with a time of 13 minutes 42-hundredths of a second, and Steve Scott of the United States ran the second-fastest mile ever.

title: TEAR GAS FIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: Israeli soldiers fired tear gas today at demonstrating Palestinian students at the University of Bir Zeit in the West Bank and reportedly arrested 100 of them.

title: LOS ANGELES COLISEUM APPROVES RAIDER MOVE
description: The Los Angeles Coliseum Commission approved today a 10-year agreement for the Oakland Raiders to play at the Coliseum starting this summer.

title: FEDERAL REPORT ASSERTS PRISON WORK PROGRAMS ARE LAGGING
description: The Bureau of Prisons is having trouble setting up efficient prison work programs to provide inmates with job skills and to prevent potentially explosive inmate idleness, according to a Government study circulated today.

title: I.T.T. UNITS TO BE SOLD TO FRANCE
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its largest French subsidiaries, Compagnie Generale de Constructions Telephoniques and Laboratoire Central de Telecommunications, to the French Government for $50 million.

title: Two Are Dismissed Over a Lunar Watch
description: A police officer and a dispatcher were dismissed after complaints that they were watching the lunar eclipse and did not answer emergency calls as a house burned down.

title: Early Hoopla
description: The college basketball season doesn't start until late November, but the folks at Ball State University have already launched a campaign for their star player for all-America honors. On June 24, they mailed a slick brochure in praise of Ray McCallum to prominent coaches, all members of the college basketball writers association, and other media members.

title: No Headline
description: Rudy May will learn Thursday whether he saved his job with his three-inning effort that brought him the victory Tuesday night in the Yankees' 12-inning, 8-7 conquest of the Seattle Mariners. ''I didn't go out there just with the game on the line,'' said May, who will be 38 years old July 16.

title: BRIEFING
description: Speculation at State

title: Farm Sales to Soviet
description: Sales of American agricultural products to the Soviet Union in 1982 will exceed last year's $1.7 billion and may surpass the $2.86 billion purchased in 1979, according to an Agriculture Department report released today.

title: Cosmos Lose, 2-1
description: Kai Haaskivi scored a goal in the second half and set up the winning goal by Jan Goossens four minutes later to lead the Edmonton Drillers to a 2-1 victory tonight over the Cosmos. It was the Cosmos' third straight loss.

title: Pabst Increases Severance Pay
description: Some 500 former Pabst Brewing Company employees have been awarded up to $22,650 each in additional severance pay as the result of an arbitrator's ruling.

title: Baines Hits 3 Homers as White Sox Win
description: Harold Baines hit three home runs, including a grand slam in the eighth inning, and Dennis Lamp pitched a five-hitter to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 7-0 rout of the Detroit Tigers.

title: Iranians Ousted by Iraq Can Visit for Ramadan
description: Iraq said today that it was willing to allow Iranians expelled from Iraq to return there to visit Moslem holy shrines.

title: CARTER IN NO. 1 ALL-STAR
description: In 1980, Gary Carter was named the reserve catcher on the National League All-Star team. In 1981, after he was voted the starting catcher by the fans, he hit two home runs and was named the game's most valuable player. Yesterday, Carter led all players in both leagues when results of balloting for the National League team were announced.

title: 'TRON' Hurts Disney Stock
description: Walt Disney Productions said that a ''quite negative'' reaction to its new movie ''TRON,'' previewed Tuesday by reviewers and securities analysts, had caused a sharp decline in its stock yesterday. The stock dropped 2 1/2 to close at 56 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CITY EFFORTS FAIL IN PLAN TO LEASE 3 GOLF COURSES
description: Negotiations between New York City and a private company interested in leasing three of the city's golf courses have broken off, with each side blaming the other for the failure to strike a deal.

title: USE OF A LIVE VACCINE IN BAIT STEMS RABIES IN A SWISS AREA
description: An effort to stem the sweep of rabies across Europe by sprinkling the landscape with chicken heads containing live rabies vaccine has proved so successful in a limited area of Switzerland that the same strategy will be used throughout the Alps between Zurich and Geneva this summer.

title: Korean Contract
description: American Standard Inc. said its Wabco Westinghouse International Company had won contracts totaling $40 million for work on the Seoul, South Korea, metropolitan subway. It is to design, manufacture and install interlocking signaling equipment by Dec. 31, 1985.

title: SOUTHWEST HIGH IN TECHNOLOGY BUT LOW ON WATER
description: Last year Randall Frank decided he had had it with Detroit's dark winters and unpredictable economy. So he signed on with an electronics company here and, in what has already become a familiar story for thousands of others before him, followed the sun to a desert subdivision outside Phoenix. ''For what we came here for, the job and the climate, it's been good,'' said Mr. Frank. But he and his wife have found that, in other ways, Phoenix falls short of expectations. ''I heard Phoenix had the worst roads in the country and now I believe it,'' said Rose Ann Frank. ''And with all the new people moving in, I worry it's only going to get worse.''

title: THURSDAY, JULY 8, 1982; The Economy
description: Antitrust officials asked the largest telephone companies for data on their plans to form joint ventures in a new type of mobile phone service called cellular radio, a computer-based technology that is expected to revolutionize the industry. Although the full import of the request was not immediately clear, one official confirmed that a preliminary inquiry was underway. (Page D1.)

title: PUNS GALORE FOR CANNIBAL
description: A limestone bust of Alferd Packer was unveiled Tuesday at the State Capitol, placing the 19th century cannibal, for the time being, among many of Colorado's most esteemed statesmen.

title: Cyanamid Cuts
description: The American Cyanamid Company said second-quarter operating earnings would be reduced by $5 million as a result of sales of certain pigment and rubber chemicals businesses. The action will result in gradual reduction in production and employment over the next year at its Bridgewater, N.J., plant to allow for an orderly transition for customers. It is expected that about 500 jobs will be lost, the company said.

title: THE JOHN BARRYMORE RECALLED IN TRIBUTE
description: ''He was brilliant, mercurial, outrageous,'' said Fay Kanin, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. He brought soup in a tin pail and ate it with a shoehorn as he made up in his dressing room one day, Ruth Gordon, the actress, recalled. He was ''the greatest American actor who ever lived,'' said Garson Kanin.

title: 15 Heart Transplants To Be Financed by U.S.
description: The Federal Government will pay for 15 heart transplant operations as part of a two-year study to see if Medicare should finance the surgery in some cases, experts in Arizona and Washington State say.

title: Connie Dinkler, 59, a Leader Of Society in Southern Florida
description: Connie Dinkler, founder of the exclusive Palm Bay Club and a leader of society in south Florida, died Tuesday of a heart attack. She was 59 years old.

title: Losing the Yanks
description: Throughout upper Manhattan at 1:30 yesterday morning, serious Yankee watchers endured a traumatic experience. Here was the scenario: Yankees in Seattle, game tied at 7-7, ninth inning, Jerry Mumphrey and Dave Winfield on base, Lou Piniella up to pinch-hit for John Mayberry.

title: PENNSYLVANIA SHAPES PRISON LAW TO CUT CRIME
description: The dead-eyed, somber faces appear on the television screens and a cold voice says, ''Commit a crime with a gun in Pennsylvania and this is what you're in for.''

title: SPONSORS CRITICIZE A MARIJUANA STUDY
description: A committee of experts appointed by the National Academy of Sciences has recommended eliminating criminal penalties for the use of marijuana, but its recommendations have been disputed by the Academy's president and rejected by the Federal agency that paid for the study.

title: DOW FINDS FAULT WITH SOUTH KOREA
description: While officials of South Korea and Japan were negotiating a major aid package for Seoul this week, the chairman of the Dow Chemical Company, the largest foreign corporate investor in South Korea, warned during a visit here that uncertain economic and political conditions in South Korea make new investments there seem unattractive for the near future.

title: Decline Is Suspected In Illegal Immigration
description: United States immigration officials, puzzled by an apparent drop in illegal immigration from Mexico, speculated today that devaluation of the peso might be partly responsible.

title: Opportunity Knocks in Namibia
description: The folder marked Namibia deserves George Shultz's early attention. The Secretary of State-designate, and his boss, need a foreign policy success, not next year but now. Sweeter still would be a success where Democratic liberals failed. All this seems possible in southern Africa, where the pins are set for a strike if the Administration bowls straight, fast and hard.

title: PAIN IN THE HEARTLAND
description: The recession is serious in Wisconsin. Life has become difficult, for some even unbearable. Last month, a 52-year-old stockbroker and assistant vice president at the Merrill Lynch office in Milwaukee plunged to his death from an 11th-story apartment window. He left a note on a business card saying he was despondent over his clients' investment losses. Milwaukee, already reeling from high unemployment and the loss of several old businesses to out-of-state takeovers, saw its pain in the broker's suicide.

title: Controlling the Course
description: Mark Balen, a 25-year-old from Lackawanna, had such a good round of golf today at the Michelob New York State Open that he did not have to use a putter for three consecutive holes.

title: Bridge: Colorful Characters Joined By the Monks of St. Titus
description: In the past half-century a handful of bridge writers have created a cast of characters as the setting for deals of interest. Which of these efforts was most successful could be argued at length, and the issue has now been complicated by a new contender: the bridge-playing monks of St. Titus.

title: Harness Trainers Are Suspended
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday suspended two harness trainers whose horses had tested positive for a respiratory stimulant after recent races at Roosevelt Raceway and Saratoga Harness.

title: Media Acquisition
description: The Media General Corporation said today it had completed the acquisition of the stock of the William B. Tanner Company for $36 million in cash. Media General is also to pay an additional unspecified amount over the next 10 years based on the performance of the acquired company.

title: Ex-Vietcong Reports Seeing P.O.W.'s Alive
description: A former Vietcong official now living in Switzerland was said to have seen 30 to 40 American pilots alive in North Vietnam in 1973, two months after the Hanoi Government declared that it had freed all American P.O.W.'s.

title: IN CATHEDRAL'S CRYPT, A WORKSHOP TURNS OUT CRAFTS
description: THE Cathedral of St. John the Divine has two bishops and a dean entombed in its crypt, traditionally the resting place of church dignitaries. These days the crypt is a lot livelier. There are dance classes, music rooms and artists' studios occupying the vast spaces under the north transept. The expected stillness is broken by the voices of young people and the sound of their footsteps on a metal staircase.

title: BOND AND NOTE PRICES GAIN
description: Prices of Treasury securities increased yesterday afternoon and yields declined after the Federal Reserve bought notes and bonds for its own account. Prices had declined earlier in the day, but by the close of trading, active issues had gained as much as half a point.

title: Charboneau Demoted
description: Joe Charboneau, the 1980 American League rookie of the year, has been sent to Chattanooga in the Class AA Southern League by Charleston, the Cleveland Indians' AAA farm team in the International League. Charboneau, who had been sent to the West Virginia team earlier in the season by the Indians, was batting .234 with one home run and five runs batted in for the Charlies. ... Joe Sambito, the Houston Astros' relief pitcher who had missed the last two months because of an elbow problem, underwent surgery at Centinela Medical Center in Los Angeles to remove a bone chip from his left elbow.

title: Amfac Exchanges Borrowing Rates
description: Amfac Inc., a Honolulu-based distribution and food processing company, said it had completed a novel $50 million interest ratecurrency swap with a British concern, Finance for Industry Ltd.

title: DOCTORS' APPEAL REJECTED IN RAPE
description: Three doctors convicted of raping a nurse lost a last-ditch bid for freedom today before the State Supreme Court and were ordered to begin serving their sentences immediately.

title: Sale by U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation said that as part of its program for redeployment of assets it had completed the sale of a 50 percent interest in its ocean shipping unit, the Navios Corporation, to Federal Pacific (Liberia) Ltd., a unit of Fednov Ltd. of Montreal. The sale price was not disclosed.

title: SHAMROCK AND SIGMOR IN $160 MILLION MERGER
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, a Dallas-based energy and chemicals company, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Sigmor Corporation, one of the largest independent gasoline retailers in the United States, in a stock and cash deal valued at $160 million.

title: Nippon Wins Facsimile Job
description: Nippon Electric Company Ltd. has been awared a major contract to supply the Federal Express Corporation with high-speed facsimile machines for use in an electronic mail network that Federal Express plans to start around 1984.

title: WORKERS INTERRUPT TOUR LEG
description: AU-PIRE, France, July 7 (UPI) - Protesting steelworkers forced the Tour de France bicycle race to be halted for the first time ever today.

title: Southwestern Bell Paid by Lloyd's
description: A three-year-old dispute arising from a fraud scheme involving computer equipment has been settled with a $1.8 million payment by Lloyd's of London to the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company

title: P.L.O. SAID TO BACK U.S. PLANS TO AID EXIT FROM BEIRUT
description: Despite public reservations by Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the United States moved ahead today with plans for the possible use of American troops to assist the evacuation of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut and for insuring the safety of the American units.

title: Ferragamo's Travels
description: The Los Angeles Rams, who received clearance to negotiate with Vince Ferragamo from Commissioner Pete Rozelle on Tuesday, are optimistic they will sign the 28-year-old quarterback.

title: Former Stockholders Of Denney File Suit
description: Frances Denney Inc., an old-line cosmetics and fragrance company founded in 1897, is embroiled in thoroughly modern litigation with its former stockholders, including the former chairman, Armand Deutsch, and the former chief executive, William Fine.

title: Australia Steel Study
description: The Italian steelmaking group Finsider/Italsider is studying the feasibility of building a $1 billion sponge iron plant in the Pilbarra iron ore region of western Australia, a Government spokesman said. The study is expected to be completed by the end of 1982 and will include talks with potential Australian partners.

title: FILL, SIZE, PRICE AND OTHER FACTORS IN BUYING PILLOWS
description: Looking for the pillow of one's dreams can easily turn into a shopping nightmare. Faced with the bewildering assortment of choices - there are more than two dozen styles on the market - and widely disparate prices, from $5 to about $1,600, many shoppers find it difficult to determine what is best when buying a pillow.

title: PRESIDENTIAL ARROGANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL-STAR VOTING
description: Final tabulations for the July 13 All-Star Game in Montreal. CATCHER 1, Gary Carter, Montreal, 2,785,407. 2 , Darrell Porter, St.Louis, 1,084,013. 3, B o Diaz, Philadelphia, 940,435. 4, Mike S cioscia, Los Angeles, 701,354. 5, Terry K ennedy, San Diego, 655,546. 6, Bruce B enedict, Atlanta, 568,763. 7, Tony P ena, Pittsburgh, 533 461. 8, John S tearns, Mets, 339,188. FIRST BASE 1, Pete Rose, Philadelphia, 1,845,679. 2 , Steve Garvey, Los Angeles, 1 ,349,123. 3, Al Oliver, Montreal, 1 ,172,466. 4, Keith Hernandez, S t.Louis, 949,449. 5, Chris Chambliss, A tlanta, 857,791. 6, Dan Driessen, Cin- c innati, 619,282. 7, Bill Buckner, Chi- c ago, 480,132. 8, Dave Kingman, Mets, 4 57,440.
