SECOND BASE 1, Manny Trillo, Philadelphia, 1 ,506,402. 2, Steve Sax, Los Angeles, 1 ,504,777. 3, Phil Garner, Houston, 1 ,120,517. 4, Joe Morgan, San Francis- c o, 920,960. 5, Ron Oester, Cincinnati, 9 14,762. 6, Glenn Hubbard, Atlanta, 7 48,182. 7, Tommy Herr, St.Louis, 6 65,495. 8, Juan Bonilla, San Diego, 4 15,221.

title: Hospital Fined For Denying Care
description: A hospital that refused emergency treatment to an 89-year-old heart-attack victim who died hours later pleaded guilty yesterday to a violation of the state's public health law.

title: Screening System Is Set For Casey Stock Deals
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has established a ''screening arrangement'' to keep track of the stock transactions of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, and to prevent him from taking official steps that would enhance his holdings.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Federal National Mortgage Association announced interest rates of 15 percent for $1.5 billion of debentures due Nov. 10, 1983, and 15.25 percent for $500 million of debentures due July 10, 1987. Both issues are offered at a price of 100.

title: JERSEY, WITH U.S. HELP, TO CLEAN 2 WASTE SITES
description: More than $3 million will be spent to clean up two of the state's worst toxic-waste dumps under an agreement signed today by Governor Kean and Anne M. Gorsuch, head of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Bayer Order Modified
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had modified a 1980 consent order so that Bayer A.G.'s Miles Laboratories would not have to divest itself of its American allergenic-extract business.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For some reason, a glaze passes over peoples' faces when you say Canada.

title: Federated to Buy Market Baskets
description: The Kroger Company, the second-largest food retailer after Safeway Stores, said in Cincinnati that it had agreed to divest itself of 65 California-based Market Basket stores in exchange for up to 2.65 million shares of Kroger common and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In the Spirit of Religion

title: SOVIET EMBASSY HEAVILY DAMAGED BY ISRAELI SHELLS
description: Several buildings in the Soviet Embassy compound were heavily damaged during the Israeli shelling of west Beirut on Tuesday night.

title: MUSIC: MOZART AND COPLAND
description: WITH virtually the same cast of characters as at its concert last Thursday and with music similar both in scope and quality, Summermusic at the 92d Street Y continued its current series Tuesday night with music by Mozart, Copland, Schoenberg and Brahms.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: When an overhead garage door is correctly installed and properly adjusted it will work smoothly and effortlessly and will never slam. It should be as easy to open as it is to close and should not bind or stick.

title: L.I. CAR INSURANCE BROKERAGE IS ACCUSED OF $4 MILLION FRAUD
description: New York State officials charged a major automobile insurance brokerage yesterday with having misappropriated premiums from thousands of motorists. They said this had caused losses estimated at $4 million to $6 million to the assigned-risk plan, which includes all the state's auto insurers. The result, they said, was increased costs to all motorists.

title: COURT DISMISSES 62 OF 132 CHARGES IN THE INDICTMENT AGAINST GIBSON
description: A Superior Court judge today dismissed 62 of 132 criminal charges against Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark because, he said, they were duplicated in more serious charges to be decided by a trial jury.

title: McLouth Wins Extension
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation today said that it received a 30-day extension on a financing agreement that has kept it in business since December and that it is negotiating with a Chicago company for the sale of its plants.

title: S.E.C. TO LET THRIFT UNITS SELL STOCK
description: A group of savings and loan associations won a major test today in their effort to sell stocks, bonds, mutual funds and offer investment advice.

title: FIRST KOCH-CUOMO DEBATE STRESSES RECORDS
description: Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo challenged each other's credentials yesterday in the first debate of their campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York.

title: Standards for Teachers Stiffened in New Jersey
description: Prospective teachers must take more liberal arts and behavioral science courses and fewer courses in the mechanics of teaching to be certified for classroom work under tough new standards adopted by the state today.

title: 800 PROTESTERS OCCUPY U.S. BASE AREA ON AN ATOLL
description: More than 800 protesting landowners in the Marshall Islands have set up tent camps on property that they had rented to the United States for a $1 billion military base on Kwajalein atoll, about 2,500 miles southwest of Hawaii, according to representatives of the demonstrators.

title: ONE MAN KILLED AS TRAIN DERAILS IN NORTH JERSEY
description: A Conrail commuter train derailed last night in Fair Lawn, N.J., and plowed into a macaroni factory, killing the engineer and injuring at least three, according to a Conrail spokesman.

title: CANCER DEATHS ARE LINKED TO WASTES IN JERSEY STUDY
description: A ''significant correlation'' exists between toxic-waste disposal sites and the cancer death rate in surrounding communities in New Jersey, according to a medical school study released yesterday.

title: New Canon Cameras Go to Grey and Dentsu
description: In what appears to be a grab for Kodak's market, Canon, the Japanese company that is the world leader in 35-millimeter camera sales, yesterday introduced two pocket cameras, the Snappy 50 and 20, priced at $115 and $145. Fujio Mitarai, president of Canon U.S.A., said the ad budget will be $1 million for the first year, with Grey Advertising handling the television and Dentsu the print. The advertising is expected in mid-August or early September.

title: Jersey Man Is Accused Of Killing 3 With Car
description: A 25-year-old North Bergen man was charged today with three counts of vehicular homicide in the deaths of a 19-year-old babysitter and two children, the assistant prosecutor for Hudson County said.

title: OPEC to Focus on Production
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries acknowledged today that the production of its members exceeds a self-imposed ceiling of 17.5 million barrels a day, but an attempt will be made on Friday to reimpose the ceiling.

title: GROSS PROVES MAN IN PINCH FOR PHILLIES
description: N obody is practicing the art of pinch-hitting more successfully this season than Greg Gross of the Philadelphia Phillies. When Gross went to bat for the pitcher in the eighth inning Tuesday night in Veterans Stadium, it was the 24th time in three months that Manager Pat Corrales had called on him in a critical situation. When Gross delivered a single on the second pitch, it was the ninth time he had pinch-hit safely. And when he later scored on a two-out single by Bo Diaz, the Phillies defeated the San Francisco Giants, 3-2.

title: WINFIELD HITS A 3-RUN HOMER
description: Dave Winfield continued to carry the Yankees tonight. He hit a three-run homer in the first inning that propelled New York to its sixth victory in the last seven games, a 5-3 decision over the struggling Oakland A's.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL PROVIDING TAX BENEFITS FOR MADISON SQUARE GARDEN
description: Governor Carey signed a bill today that will provide tax benefits and low-cost electricity to Madison Square Garden as part of an arrangement to keep the New York Knickerbockers and the New York Rangers from moving to New Jersey.

title: Absence Of Brazil Is Felt
description: The World Cup soccer tournament enters its semifinal round Thursday and nearly everybody seems to miss Brazil: bartenders along the Ramblas, neutral fans with tickets to the semifinal game here, and Johan Cruyff, the Dutch soccer star who called the Brazilians ''the moral champions'' in his column for the Barcelona newspaper El Correo Catalan.

title: 'Diminished Dedication'
description: ''We must be worth more than 4 percent.'' That's the slogan of the unionized police, firefighters and correction officers who marched on New York's City Hall yesterday. Their demonstration was supposed to dramatize the belief that they deserve a bigger raise because their jobs often require them to put their lives on the line. Not incidentally, it also served as a reminder of how painful they could make life for New Yorkers should they choose to do so.

title: VIETNAMESE FISHERMEN STIR BITTERNESS ON COAST
description: Henry McMasters climbed aboard his salmon boat, the Soko, and glared at the two Vietnamese fishermen sewing their nets in a boat in an adjoining berth at this fishing hamlet on Monterey Bay.

title: TIMES MIRROR CASE DROPPED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission today dismissed charges that the Times Mirror Company and its cornerstone newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, unfairly favored large advertisers by charging them substantially lower rates than lower-volume advertisers.

title:
HELPFUL HARWARE;
DOOR LOCKS THAT GIVE ADDED SECURITY
description: Two products for the security-minded that will help make door locks more effective have come onto the market. Fichet Inc. has introduced Secur-Bolt, a case-hardened steel dead bolt with a triple layer guard plate around the cylinder on both sides of the door.

title: U.S. APPEALS REFUGEE RULING
description: The Justice Department today asked a Federal appeals court to block the release of nearly 1,800 Haitian refugees held at detention centers in Florida and Puerto Rico.

title: AFTERMATH AT PENN SQUARE
description: ''I was in the oilfields 10 years ago when banks were failing,'' said Howard Bottger, an oilfield worker, standing in line with hundreds of other depositors of the failed Penn Square Bank here.

title: Fed Accounting Switch
description: The Federal Reserve Board indicated today that a new monetary policy operating technique, intended to make movements in the money supply less erratic, would not be put into effect before next May and probably even later.

title: NORCEN TO INCREASE ITS STAKE IN HANNA
description: The Hanna Mining Company of Cleveland, which had been fighting a takeover attempt by Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. of Canada, announced jointly with Norcen today that the two companies had settled their battle with an agreement in which the Canadian company will acquire an additional 11.2 percent stake in Hanna.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: New Olivier 'Lear'

title: CITY'S HOSPITALS AGENCY SUES ON 40 AMBULANCES
description: New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which said four months ago that defects in new city ambulances would be corrected by the manufacturer, announced yesterday that it did not want the ambulances and had filed a lawsuit for $2.5 million in damages.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Jesse Orosco (1-5) comes out of the troubled Mets' bullpen to make his second start of the season, his first at Shea. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. Doyle Alexander of the Yankees, a right-hander with a 0-2 record, is back off the disabled list after hurting his pitching hand by smashing it against a wall in the dugout in disgust. (Television - USA Cable and SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 10:30 P.M.) Braves vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Atlanta (Television - USA Cable, 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Tony Nelson vs. Jerry Holly, middleweights, 12 rounds, at Sands Hotel, Atlantic City. Nelson is undefeated in 11 bouts, with 10 knockouts. Holly is 15-7, with 12 knockouts. This is for the ESPN tournament championship. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Soccer World Cup semifinals in Spain: Poland vs. Italy, at Barcelona, and France vs. West Germany, at Seville. (Television - Channel 41 and ESPN, 11 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. Channel 41, midnight, tape. Channel 13, 11:30 P.M., tape.)

title: COUNSEL SAYS CITY CAN CONTINUE TAX BENEFITS TO IMPROVE HOUSING
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that in his opinion the Koch administration could legally continue to operate a program of tax benefits to encourage the renovation of rundown buildings. Critics of the program, known as J-51, contend that state legislation authorizing the program expired on June 1.

title: NATIONWIDE RAIL STRIKE IS THREATENED SUNDAY
description: The union representing 35,000 locomotive engineers and firemen threatened today to start a nationwide railroad strike Sunday night unless President Reagan issued a ''cooling-off'' order to prevent it.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Airbag's Still Alive
description: The automobile ''airbag'' - which has replaced fluoridation as the public safety measure conservatives love to hate - is not quite dead. A Federal appeals court has rejected the Reagan Administration's decision to ditch the ''passive restraint'' rule that had been kicking around Washington for a decade. By next month, the court ordered, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must come up with a plan to reconsider the issue.

title: REAGAN STEADY IN GALLUP POLL
description: Public approval of President Reagan's job performance, as measured by the Gallup Poll, is unchanged in the wake of his European trip and the Israeli invasion of Lebanon,

title: SCHOLASTIC POLICEMAN
description: It has been 37 years since Patrick Vincent Murphy went the way of his father and brothers and began his career as a patrolman on the tough Brooklyn waterfront. He cherishes memories from those days: never having to fire his revolver at anyone; inching out onto a building ledge to talk a ''jumper'' in from a suicide perch; happily greeting his people, his beat, with a ''buon giorno'' as he walked and watched.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: PARASOLS IN A LAND OF WAR
description: After a month of watching the violence and experiencing the danger and the fear, there may be no coherent way to describe this city, but certain images remain.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 8, 1982
description: International Plans to use American troops to aid the departure of Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut and to insure the safety of the Americans were pressed by the Reagan Administration. Officials said they had been advised through diplomatic channels not to take seriously the cold public reaction of Palestinian leaders to the evacuation plan. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel kept up its bombardment and blockade of west Beirut amid signs that the peace negotiations were still snagged over details of when and how the Palestinian guerrillas would leave Lebanon. (A8:1-2.)

title: A PIONEERING LOFT WITH OLD-FASHIONED IDEAS
description: David Utz's loft saga began in the early 1970's when he first came to New York, looking for what he called ''an exciting community in which to live and an interesting career.'' He soon decided to rent a loft space, the first of four he was to occupy during the next six years.

title: VIETNAM TO PULL MORE TROOPS FROM CAMBODIA
description: Vietnam's Foreign Minister said today that a ''significant'' number of Vietnamese soldiers would be withdrawn from Cambodia this month.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: HERBS AND A TOUR
description: Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Wash- ington Avenue, Brooklyn, 622-4433.

title: Police Chief Terms Belushi Inquiry Futile
description: Police Chief Daryl Gates predicted today that a renewed investigation into the death of John Belushi. the actor who died of a drug overdose, would prove futile.

title: DANCE: KABUKI ACTORS OFFER REVALATIONS
description: The superb Kabuki actors brought here by the Japan Society have offered many revelations in their regrettably short season at the Metropolitan Opera House, where they play through Saturday. There is the noble elegance of Fukusuke, for instance, and the virility of Ebizo. Utaemon stands out among the players of female roles, a larger-than-life Kabuki Bernhardt, and who will forget Tamasaburo, with hands like long translucent carvings? Best of all, there has been the great Kanzaburo, so poignantly believable whether playing the Lear-like General Kumagai, the companionable boatman of ''Sumidagawa'' or the henpecked philanderer in ''Migawari-Zazen.''

title: 'HEADS-UP' EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MURPHY ASSAILED BY POLICE CHIEF
description: The nation's largest police association has formally threatened a leading advocate of change in police practices with censure, expulsion or suspension for making ''derogatory statements'' about its members.

title: TOKYO AID FOR SEOUL NEARING
description: Almost a year ago, South Korea asked Japan for $10 billion of aid to bolster the South Korean economy, mired in its worst crisis in 20 years. This week, after arduous negotiations, the two nations have scaled the proposal down to $4 billion, still one of the largest aid and credit packages ever negotiated, and agreement on its final form seems near.

title: BANKERS SEE TIGHTER OIL-LOAN POLICY
description: The weekend failure of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City will make many banks much more cautious in lending to small, precariously-financed oil exploration companies, bankers predicted yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avis Inc., Garden City, L.I., has elected David Arbuthnot vice president in charge of Latin America and Caribbean operations.

title: Boeing Has Order
description: The Boeing Company said Royal Air Maroc, the national airline of Morocco, had ordered two 737-200 jetliners for $33 million. The planes are to be delivered in March and June 1983.

title: BETCHEL: A RECLUSIVE GIANT
description: It started out small and unobtrusively when a resourceful German rancher named Walter A. Bechtel in 1898 hired out himself and a pack of mules to help build a railroad. From such meager beginnings, the tiny California construction company blossomed into the giant of the engineering and construction industry, its builders dotting the landscape of the world with such engineering marvels as the Hoover Dam, the trans-Alaska pipeline and the Washington subway system.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American High Speed Rail Corp. said it had retained First Boston Corp. as its financial adviser in arranging a $2 billion financing for the construction of the first high-speed railroad in the United States.

title: UNIFORMED UNIONS RALLY TO PROTEST CITY'S WAGE OFFER
description: Thousands of off-duty police officers, firefighters and correction officers marched down Broadway and rallied outside City Hall yesterday to press the Koch administration to increase its wage offer in contract talks.

title: BOSTON'S FINANCES IMPROVED BY LEGISLATIVE ACTION
description: Boston has stepped into the 1983 fiscal year on a much more solid footing after the Massachusetts Legislature passed a bill that gives the financially beleaguered city new sources of revenue.

title: PLUS CA CHANGE...
description: After a sullen spring, Paris has finally burst out with its brightest sun, flowers and variously decorated tourists.Drivers complain because too many streets torn up at the same time have bunched traffic unseasonably, but the city has never looked better.

title: Dunlop Contract
description: Dunlop Holdings P.L.C.'s Aviation division has a contract to supply structural carbon brakes and main wheels for the new Boeing 757 jetliner, Dunlop said.

title: Daimler-Benz 1982 Outlook
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. expects satisfactory results in 1982 after a world group net profit of $330 million in 1981, Daimler's managing board chairman, Gerhard Prinz, told the annual meeting today.

title: Technology; Space Shuttle As a Factory
description: In more than two decades of government-sponsored space exploration, private enterprise has played a secondary role. American companies have built an array of hardware for use in space, but the cost has almost always been borne by the taxpayer.

title: MR. REAGAN'S 'RECKLESS' SOVIET PIPELINE DECISION
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN MINISTER FOR 17 YEARS
description: Raul Roa Garcia, Cuba's Foreign Minister for 17 years, died Tuesday in Havana after a long illness. He was 75 years old. Dr. Roa helped negotiate two important agreements between the United States and Cuba: the decision in 1965 to permit an airlift of Cuban emigrants to this country, and the 1973 accord calling for extradition or extreme punishment of aircraft hijackers.

title: Offer for KDI
description: The KDI Corporation, a maker of electrical parts, swimming pools and devices for the defense industry, reported that a group of investors had proposed a takeover offer valued at $57.4 million, or $7 a share.

title: Ex-Boarding Home Operator Gets Jail Term in Kidnapping
description: A former boarding home operator, Lucille Walker, was sentenced Tuesday to four to 20 years in prison for kidnapping three elderly women from a home she operated in Florida and bringing them to Michigan.

title: SMOKE AND JAZZ MAKE A BAD COMBO
description: To the Editor:

title: VOYAGE OF A MUTINEER'S DESCENDANT
description: Even the most fertile imagination would be hard pressed to dream up two islands more disparate than the pair that occupied Brian Young's world this week. One was Manhattan, that epitome of 20th-century urban life, with all its vexations and exhilarations. The other was his native Pitcairn Island, a storied, pristine land right out of schoolboy novels and swashbuckling movies, one of the most remote inhabited places on earth.

title: WHEN BLOOD TIES ARE BEDEVILED BY EXTREMISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Spaniards Fight Forest Fires
description: Spanish firefighters are battling a dozen forest fires that the police say appear to have been deliberately set. The fires, which started Tuesday night in the forests south of Barcelona, were reported to have destroyed almost 10,000 acres of pine woods.

title: Sunshine Biscuits Quits Marsteller
description: Marsteller Inc. said that it had received a letter of termination from Sunshine Biscuits, a subsidiary of American Brands and a client for the past three years.1979.

title: SMALL CLAIMS COURT: CITY OFFERS NEW AID
description: A consumer who has sued a business in Small Claims Court in Manhattan and has won, but finds that the defendant refuses to pay, can now get help from a new service of the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, Commissioner Simon P. Gourdine announced yesterday.

title: Market Place; Apple Fighting To Stay Ahead
description: Apple Computer, which is to personal computers what the Model T Ford was to automobiles, has not managed to cash in on its success. It's true that the company's shares, introduced at 22 in December 1980, rocketed to 34 1/2 within weeks. But they have been more or less in a decline ever since. In yesterday's over-the-counter trading, the shares ended at 11 1/2 bid, the lowest level so far.

title: BABY BOOM AFFECTS WALLPAPER MARKET
description: THERE are now about 16 million children under 5 years old in the United States, and by 1990 that figure is expected to reach 19 million, the Census Bureau reports.

title: Dome Exploration
description: Dome Canada Ltd. said it had received its first federal petroleum incentive program payment, of $110 million (Canadian), covering exploration expenditures for 1981. It said that it had used $100 million to retire bridging financing guaranteed by Petro-Canada, the state-owned oil company, on June 25 and that the balance, along with program payments still to be received, would be reinvested in exploration. Dome said it was currently participating in drilling 22 western Canadian and five Beaufort Sea wells.

title: BRAZIL MOURNS ITS FALLEN SOCCER TEAM
description: Flags have been flown at half-staff throughout Brazil for the last two days, and though the act honors President Antonio Guzman of the Dominican Republic, who died Sunday, it could easily be taken as an emblem of the national spirit here.

title: Pope Voices Concern Over People in Beirut
description: Pope John Paul II today prayed for peace in Lebanon and voiced concern about food and water shortages in Beirut.

title: IN EUROPE'S MUSEUMS, PEOPLE-WATCHING IS AN ART
description: One of the incidental pleasures of going through European museums is to monitor the different ways in which people behave from country to country. In the major Italian museums (and in the major churches, too) all may well be pandemonium. People talk at the tops of their voices. Whole troops of foreigners stampede through the rooms every time a colored banner signals for them to move on.

title: Delaney Coming Back
description: Joe Delaney's right eye has healed sufficiently to permit the Kansas City Chiefs' top rusher last season to attend training camp. Delaney underwent surgery to repair a torn retina on May 19.

title: DON'T SAY NO TO HAVANA
description: The troubled history of American relations with Castro's Cuba has been paved with mutual misperceptions and missed opportunities. The Reagan Administration seems intent upon perpetuating this pattern, responding to the most promising Cuban overture in recent years with an intensified economic embargo and diplomatic hostility that are both ill conceived and counterproductive.

title: MATURITY IMPROVES MISS HAYNIE'S GAME
description: S andra Haynie is taking a rest from the golf tour. It's for one week. Different from the last time she took an extended rest from the tour. That one was for four years.

title: SUMMER IS CRABBING SEASON
description: Y oung or old, serious blue-claw crabbers are passionately devoted to the sport. The marvelously tasty meat of the creatures is at least half the reason for this, but nearly as important is the democratic nature of the endeavor.

title: P.L.O. DISPUTES WHO'S TO LEAVE BEIRUT, IF ANYONE
description: A key issue in the continuing discussions on the evacuation of Palestinian forces from west Beirut is whether all must leave and if not, who should stay behind. So far, there is no sign that any of the 6,000 are preparing to depart.

title: YUGOSLAVIA STRUGGLING TO MEET DEBTS TO WEST
description: The new Prime Minister, Milka Planinc, says Yugoslavia's economy is in difficulty but her Government will fulfill its international financial obligations.

title: Barnett Buys Bank Offices
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., the state's second-largest banking organization, said yesterday that it had received Federal approval to purchase both offices of the Century Bank of Orange County, in Apopka, Fla., for a total of $7.5 million. Barnett has about $6 billion in assets and 160 branches throughout Florida.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt FLANAGAN'S RUN. By Tom McNab. 444 pages. Morrow. $14.50.

title: Ens. Nicholas Walsh Weds Ellen B. Sherk
description: Ellen Bostwick Sherk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Allen Sherk of Branford, Conn., was married yesterday in New Haven to Ens. Nicholas Holladay Walsh of the Coast Guard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Walsh of New York and Chappaquiddick, Mass.

title: Mego Holds Talks On Operating Plan
description: Mego International Inc., a toy maker and distributor that filed for protection from its creditors on June 14, said that it was holding talks with ''certain outside investors and its institutional creditors'' on a plan to continue operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company's domestic subsidiaries are participating in the talks, Mego said.

title: Nicaragua Has Aid Curb
description: Agricultural Development Minister Jaime Wheelock said Tuesday night that about $5 million that the United States planned to give the private sector would have to pass through state-controlled institutions such as the central bank and the International Reconstruction Fund.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Discoveries column of The Living Section yesterday gave an incorrect address for a store that makes and sells tote bags. The store, St. Remy, is at 156 East 64th Street.

title: A HOMETOWN SHRINE TO STALIN PULLS IN THE TOURISTS
description: Elsewhere in the Soviet Union, the name of Stalin evokes ambivalent and troubled responses, whether revulsion over a time of terror or nostalgia for a more heroic past. But there are no such complexes here.

title: EXPERIMENTING IN THE SHADE OF TERRACES
description: ''IT would be so much easier if shade were cut and dried and labeled in a definite way,'' said Harriet K. Morse, author of the recently reprinted 1939 classic ''Gardening in the Shade'' (Timber Press, $12.95). For when country gardeners speak of shade, it is often from trees whose fluttering leaves occasionally permit sunlight to touch the plants below - while city gardeners, in the shadow of tall buildings, rarely enjoy even a fleeting ray.

title: City Worker Rescues Two Children in Fire
description: Two young children trapped in a burning Harlem apartment were rescued yesterday by a Sanitation Department worker who raced up six flights of stairs, jumped onto a fire escape and broke through a boarded window, Sanitation and Fire Department officials said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OFF THE WALL

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC AMERICA IN CHICAGO
description: This year's New Music America festival was originally conceived as a series of concerts in a large, ''circusy'' auditorium at the end of the Navy Pier, which extends several blocks into Lake Michigan from the Chicago lakefront. Eventually, an opening concert Monday night in Orchestra Hall was added, installations and special events were organized all over the city, and funds were found to broadcast the concerts nationwide, in New York, live on WKCR-FM and tape-delayed on WNYC.

title: HEATING COST HURT ELDERLY
description: Elderly Americans on fixed incomes are often overwhelmed by winter heating costs, forcing them to cut back on food and medicine in order to keep warm, according to a study by the National Council of Senior Citizens.

title: AUTHORITIES MEET ON CAPITOL SEX AND DRUG INQUIRY
description: The Federal and local law-enforcement authorities investigating accusations of sexual misconduct and drug use involving Congressional pages and Congressmen met today to pool their information and to chart the course of the inquiry.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Three men posing as armored-car guards held up the Miller Bakery at 176 Woodward Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, yesterday afternoon and took $17,000 at gunpoint. One of the men, identified as Keith Terry, 21 years old, of 300 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, ran into a nearby building, where he grappled with a retired police officer, Paul Teknus, 51. Mr. Teknus was shot in the right leg during the struggle. Mr. Terry was captured by Robert Cooke, an off-duty police officer, after an auto chase. ... Three teen-agers, one of them armed, robbed a Coney Island post office at 817 Neptune Avenue about 12:50 P.M., then rode away on their bicycles. ... A gunman robbed a Citibank branch at 18th Street and Fifth Avenue of an undetermined amount of cash at about 1 P.M.

title: FRIENDS AND SCHOLARS PLANNING STRAVINSKY SALUTE
description: From Sept. 10 through Sept. 14, the University of California at San Diego will be the host to an International Stravinsky Symposium that will include the composer's friends, along with musicians and scholars. It is one of the most ambitious and varied celebrations of the composer being offered this year, the centennial of his birth.

title: Fire in Miami Tower
description: Fire broke out in a storage closet and spread through several rooms of a 20-floor luxury office and residential tower Tuesday at the Four Ambassadors complex, forcing the building's evacuation. Six residents of the downtown complex were treated for smoke inhalation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Jobs, Not Graduate School, Attract Barnard Class of '81

title: 4 Nations Warn Nicaragua
description: The Foreign Ministers of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras have said that their Governments will not tolerate any further military buildup by Nicaragua's leftist regime or what they called its meddling in the rest of Central America. They made the statement at the end of a three-day meeting of the Central American Democratic Community here Wednesday.

title: Ugandan Accuses Libya Of Arming Guerrillas
description: Uganda's Information Minister charged today that Libya was training and arming anti-Government guerrilla ''bandits'' in Uganda in an attempt to gain control of the headwaters of the Nile River,

title: ART: 'ISRAEL IN ANTIQUITY'AT THE JEWISH MUSEUM
description: ''ISRAEL IN ANTIQUITY'' is the title of the current exhibition at the Jewish Museum. A permanent installation, it consists of about 200 items - pots, jars and similar receptacles made of clay and glass, jewelry and other metalwork, including arrowheads. There is also an assortment of carved-stone pieces, such as altars, burial plaques and an ossuary, as well as miscellaneous objects, such as putative slingshots made of clay.

title: DISNEY 'TRON'
description: ''TRON'' means to be a gloriously puerile movie, the full-fledged screen embodiment of a video game. It even means to go to the heart of video gamesmanship, and its premise is very promising in its way. What if those tiny Space Invaders and Pac-Men were real creatures, miniature gladiators sent to do battle for the amusement of their heartless captors? What if a movie could capture the very spirit of a computer toy and make it last not just for a few quarters' worth of time, but indefinitely?

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens. This is a twilight-night doubleheader to include the makeup of a May 12 game that was rained out. The first game starts at 5:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, 5:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. California Angels at Anaheim, Calif. Although the Angels are slumping, they are far ahead of last season's home attendance and expect more than 150,000 patrons for weekend series against the Yankees. (Television - Sports@Channel 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Andres Tena vs. Robert Mullins, junior featherweights; Angel Cruz vs. Junior Velez, lightweights; Kenny Agosto vs. Julio DeJesus, featherweights; Pedro Vilella vs. Roberto Hernandez, welterweights, all 10 rounds, at Felt Forum, 7:30 P.M. The Tena-Mullins bout was picked out of a hat to be the main event. This is the first of three consecutive days of boxing at the Felt Forum and the Garden area. (Television -USA Cable, MSG Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Tennis Davis Cup, Sweden vs. United States, singles at Checkerdome, St. Louis. John McEnroe, United States, vs. Anders Jarryd, Sweden, and Eliot Teltscher, United States, vs. Mats Wilander, Sweden. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.) Other Events Basketball: New York Pro Summer League. The usual Friday nonprofessional tripleheader at Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and 138th Street. First game, 5:30 P.M. Golf: Michelob New York State Open at Grossinger, N.Y., 8 A.M. John G. Anderson Memorial best-ball championships at Winged Foot, Mamaroneck, N.Y., 8 A.M. Harness Racing: Meadowlands Race Track, East Rutherford, N.J. (Television - Cablevision and MSG Cable, midnight, tape.)

title: Auto Layoffs Are Down; Layoffs Fall at U.S.  Car Makers
description: The number of United States auto workers reported on indefinite layoff dropped to 222,257 this week, while temporary layoffs fell to 600, the five major domestic auto makers said today.

title: Topics; Invocations; The Godly Nuke
description: One has to admire the intrepid Phyllis Schlafly. Having won the fight against the Equal Rights Amendment, she now wants to take on the nuclear freeze movement. Her slogan enrolls the highest possible authority: ''The atomic bomb is a marvelous gift that was given to our country by a wise God.''

title: HILLS AROUND FALKLAND CAPITAL STREWN WITH ARGENTINE DEAD
description: More than three weeks after the conclusion of the Falkland conflict, the hilltop battlefields around this island capital are still littered with Argentine corpses.

title: Topics; INVOCATIONS; Free Choice
description: When it comes to schools, the President is strongly for voluntary choice. He wants Congress to give valuable tax credits to parents who choose to send their children to private and parochial schools.

title: Los Angeles Smog Getting Big Test
description: Tne day before a game, pro football teams like to work out on the field where they will play. Golfers try to get at least one practice round on the course of a tournament.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 9, 1982
description: International A key foreign policy review is under way in the Reagan Administration, according to authoritative Administration officials. They said President Reagan was seeking a possible way to ease the economic sanctions imposed against Poland and the Soviet Union over the military crackdown in Poland, including a scaling back of the ban on equipment for the new natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe. (Page A1, Column 6.) Moscow warned Washington that it would shape its policy ''with due consideration'' of any dispatch of American troops as part of a multinational force to evacuate Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut. The Soviet press agency Tass said the statement had been made by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in his latest letter to President Reagan. (A1:4.)

title: ART: TO ANCIENT CHINA IN A SMALL SHOW AT MET
description: ''SPIRIT AND RITUAL,'' which opened July 1 at the Metropolitan Museum, is an exhibition of ancient Chinese objects - ritual bronze vessels, tomb figurines and Buddhist sculptures. It is just the thing for a fine summer morning (starting at 10). It's not too large - 59 pieces in all - it takes us into areas of Chinese antiquity with which not every visitor will be familiar, and it has the handmade look of a collection that has been built up over a long period with care and affection. (Everything on view has been lent by Mr. and Mrs. Earl Morse, who built the Doughnut Corporation of America.)

title: PENSIONS ADD TO DEFICITS AND HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Dentist' in Nanuet Is Called an Impostor
description: A 36-year-old New Windsor, N.Y., man was indicted today on charges of practicing orthodontics for seven months without a license.

title: ACCOUNT OF BREZHNEV'S LETTER TO REAGAN ON CRISIS IN LEBANON
description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, about a letter concerning Lebanon that was sent to President Reagan by Leonid I. Brezhnev in his capacity of Soviet President:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard ITALIAN JOURNEY (1786-1788). By Jo- hann Wolfgang von Goethe. Translated from the German with an introduction by W.H. Auden and Elizabeth Mayer. 507 pages. North Point Press. Paper, $15.50.

title: IRAN OBJECTS TO OPEC OUTPUT QUOTA
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began arriving here today for what promises to be a stormy consultative session on the issue of adjusting their individual production ceilings.

title: Power Report on 93 Degree Day There's Plenty to Spare
description: W henever it gets as hot as it did yesterday - 93 degrees, the Weather Service said - thoughts turn to air-conditioning, and right behind that lurk memories of 1977 and the fear that Con Edison may not be up to the job again. Adding some urgency to this concern was a report the other day from the Public Service Commission, whose staff harrumphed about how the utility ''might have insufficient operating reserves if random outages similar to those in the past occur during the peak demand period.''

title: 'Georgia Brown,' One-woman show, to open in October.
description: ''GEORGIA BROWN & FRIENDS'' will open at the Nederlander Theater on Oct. 19. The title notwithstanding, this is a one-woman show, the ''friends'' being colleagues, acquaintances and family who are mentioned during the course of Miss Brown's reminiscences about her life and career, from her teen-age debut in a London nightclub, to her success on Broadway in ''Oliver'' and beyond. The producers are Hillard Elkins and Laizer Productions, who presented ''Georgia Brown & Friends'' at the Westwood Playhouse in Los Angeles last year for a limited run, and James M. Nederlander, who saw the show in Los Angeles and has been talking enthusiastically ever since about bringing it to New York.

title: DESPITE SUCCESS, SUN BELT OIL PATCH IS FINDING IT'S NOT IMMUNE TO RECESSION
description: The energy-rich Oil Patch, made up of Texas, Oklahoma and parts of Louisiana, is at once the most conspicuously successful and the most volatile region of the Sun Belt. Much of Texas, and the region as a whole, is about oil, industry and energy, but it is also about Arabs and agriculture, illegal aliens, air-conditioning and the attitudes of its people: relentlessly optimistic, aggressive, unquenchable.

title: Two Fined on Arms Charges
description: Two British gun dealers were sentenced today to five years' probation and were fined $100,000 each for attempting to export 1,146 M-16 rifles to South Africa last year. Peter Towers, 52 years old, and John Parks, 44, both of London, had pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to attempting to export military weapons illegally.

title: BITTER SOLDIERS TELL OF BUNGLED CAMPAIGN
description: The Argentine defense on the Falkland Islands was undermined by poor leadership and corruption that left many soldiers sick and hungry and with faulty weapons, according to many of the returning soldiers.

title: U.S. Judge Supports Reservoir Generator
description: A Federal administrative law judge has ruled that a license should be granted to the New York State Power Authority to build a millionkilowatt pumped-storage plant in Prattsville, N.Y., 40 miles southwest of Albany.

title: How to Melt the Butter Mountain
description: Butter, butter everywhere ... and cheese ... and dry milk: some 2.3 billion pounds of surplus dairy products now fill Government warehouses to the rafters. Isn't there something better to do with this mountain of dairy products than keep it in cold storage? Couldn't it, for instance, be fed to the world's poor?

title: HINCKLEY HAILS 'HISTORICAL' SHOOTING TO WIN LOVE
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. has declared in a letter that neither hospitalization nor imprisonment could diminish his ''historical'' shooting of President Reagan to win the actress Jodie Foster's love.

title: Nouvelle American and a marketplace.
description: FANS of Leslie Revsin who have missed her light, delicate nouvelle American style of cooking since her Restaurant Leslie closed last year, should be delighted to find her holding forth as executive chef at the graceful and romantic new restaurant called 24 Fifth Avenue.

title: PIRATES WIN, 9-8, ON FIVE IN 9TH
description: Jason Thompson lined a three-run double down the left-field line to cap a five-run rally in the bottom of the ninth inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Cincinnati Reds, 9-8, tonight.

title: SURVIVAL SUITS URGED FOR OIL RIGS IN ICY WATER
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, investigating the sinking of the offshore oil-drilling platform Ocean Ranger in the North Atlantic, urged the Coast Guard today to require all such drilling rigs to be equipped with exposure suits.

title: REAGAN ACTS TO AVERT NATIONWIDE RAIL STRIKE SET FOR SUNDAY
description: President Reagan, using his powers under the Railway Labor Act, today imposed a 60-day cooling-off period to avert a nationwide railroad strike planned for Sunday by a union representing locomotive engineers.

title: Amoco Suspends Shale Oil Project
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday that the Rio Blanco Oil Shale Company of Aurora, Colo., jointly owned by Indiana Standard and the Gulf Oil Corporation, would suspend operations indefinitely.

title: REPORT TO CONGRESS QUESTIONS URGENCY OF BREEDER REACTOR
description: The nation will probably not need a fast breeder nuclear reactor until the year 2025 at the earliest, according to a draft report prepared by the General Accounting Office.

title: Amex Plans Gold Options
description: The American Stock Exchange's board of governors has voted to open an options market in gold bullion and has requested approval for the new market from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Arthur Levitt, the exchange's chairman, announced yesterday. The commission recently proposed regulations that would permit options trading on many physical commodities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In connection with statements to the effect that the United States is prepared in principle to send a contingent of American troops to Lebanon, L.I. Brezhnev warned the United States President that, if this really took place, the Soviet Union would build its policy with due consideration of this fact.'' - Statement by Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency. (A6:4.)

title: Radio Ad Bureau Expands Leader's Role
description: In an unusual move for a media advertising-promotion association, Miles David, president of the Radio Advertising Bureau for 17 years, has been promoted to vice chairman while remaining chief executive officer. According to the R.A.B., formally called a ''media salesdevelopment bureau,'' there is a provision in Mr. David's contract for such a move and it is intended to allow the organization to broaden its top management.

title: BIG BET ON CONQUISTADOR CIELO
description: Conquistador Cielo is worth at least $33 million as a stallion. That is the value that has been placed on the colt in a syndication offer to his owner, Henryk de Kwiatkowski, by E.P. Taylor's Windfields Farm in Chesapeake, Md.

title: Checker Stops Making Taxis
description: The nation's last big, boxy Checker taxicab will roll off the assembly line Monday leaving some 200 bluecollar workers at the Checker Motors Corporation without jobs.

title: LEHRMAN LEADS 'UNIFIED' TICKET ON TOUR UPSTATE
description: Lewis E. Lehrman led what he called ''the unified Republican ticket'' across upstate New York today. Mr. Lehrman, the official designate of his party's leaders, is running for the gubernatorial nomination against Paul J. Curran in the Republican primary on Sept. 23. He campaigned today with two unopposed candidates - James L. Emery, running for lieutenant governor, and Frances Sclafani, running for attorney general.

title: NIGHT OF RKO MEMORIES
description: ''You look just the same,'' said George Cukor to Ruby Keeler, offering the most oft-used compliment of the afternoon. The occasion was a reunion at the Russian Tea Room of former RKO stars now living in New York, to mark RKO's donation of its film archives to the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: RESORT, CHARGING JURY TAMPERING, TO SEEK A NEW TRIAL OF PENTHOUSE
description: Lawyers for the resort LaCosta, which lost a $520 million libel suit against Penthouse magazine in May, plan to seek a new trial Friday, contending in part that the jury in the five-month trial had been tampered with.

title: BREZHNEV CAUTIONS REAGAN ON SENDING TROOPS TO BEIRUT
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev has sent a letter to President Reagan saying that, if the United States sent troops to Lebanon, the Soviet Union would ''build its policy with due consideration of that fact.'' Text of Tass announcement, page A6.

title: NEW YORK CITY OPERA TO OVERHAUL SCHEDULE
description: In an unexpected move, the New York City Opera announced yesterday a consolidation of its fall and spring seasons at the New York State Theater into one season extending from July until December. This will mean elimination of the traditional spring season as of 1983.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bus Strike Takes Toll On Multiply Handicapped

title: EX-AIDES CAUTIOUS ON U.S. DEPLOYMENT
description: Possible American troop deployment in Lebanon was viewed with caution by Americans with foreign affairs experience yesterday, although some recalled the successful use of 14,357 Army troops and Marines there by President Eisenhower in 1958.

title: PLAYS
description: O nly eight players in this century have hit four home runs in one baseball game. But hitting even three in a game is a pretty good trick, something like scoring three goals in a hockey game.

title: Ferragamo Returns
description: After spending last season with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, the quarterback Vince Ferragamo has returned to the Los Angeles Rams. Ferragamo, who is 28 years old, was signed to a three-year contract yesterday.

title: Ex-Coach Caddies
description: Sixteen months ago, with a year left on his contract, Dwane Morrison resigned as basketball coach at Georgia Tech. Last March, after receiving his final paycheck from the school, he became the full-time caddie for J.C. Snead on the Professional Golfers' Association tour.

title: Midwest Exchange
description: The Midwest Stock Exchange announced today that it would relocate its headquarters to a site about three blocks from where its main offices are now. The new location will triple the trading area, creating a trading floor of 19,000 square feet, and house the exchange and its subsidiaries as well as computer facilities. The exchange hopes to move by late 1984.

title: Pfister and Odizor Gain
description: Third-seeded Hank Pfister and unseeded Nduka Odizor advanced to the semifinals of the $100,000 Miller Hall of Fame tennis championships today.

title: 3 UNLIKELY CAMBODIAN ALLIES MAP WAR ON VIETNAM
description: The three exiled Cambodian leaders who last month formed a coalition opposed to the Vietnamese-backed Government in Phnom Penh are as different as they can possibly be, yet they are apparently still acting in unison.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT GREW BY $1.4 BILLION IN MAY
description: Americans took on $1.4 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in May, with most of the increase in auto loans, the Government reported today. It was the largest increase in eight months, but still a modest gain in comparison with pre-recession figures.

title: BURNS WINS STATE GOLF OPEN BY 2 SHOTS
description: George Burns took time off from the PGA Tour this week and it paid off. Burns posted his first victory in two years today as he won the Michelob New York State Open golf tournament at Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club.

title: FAIRCHILD BREATHING EASIER
description: Last fall, when many contractors began expanding production to meet the demands of the Reagan Administration's increased military budget, the Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, sharply reduced the Fairchild Republic Corporation's one prime contract - a 10-year-old agreement to make the Air Force's A-10 Thunderbolt attack planes.

title: OROSCO ROUTED AS METS DROP 6TH STRAIGHT
description: Five Mets pitchers were pounded for 15 hits in a 9-7 loss to the Giants last night, forcing Manager George Bamberger to observe that ''the All-Star break is coming at an excellent time for this ball club.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yester- day incorrectly described the assets of Mego International Inc. Mego, along with its domestic subsidiary, the Mego Corporation, has approximately $21 million in assets.

title: FED GUIDES FOR BANK MERGERS
description: The Federal Reserve Board gave the go-ahead yesterday for banking companies in one state to invest in the nonvoting stock of banks in other states. But the Fed issued strict regulations to assure that the purchasing bank would not gain control over the bank being acquired.

title: U.S. OFFER OF TROOPS STANDS DESPITE BREZHNEV WARNING
description: The United States, in effect, rejected the warning by Leonid I. Brezhnev today against sending American troops into Lebanon.

title: U.S.F.L. in Meadowlands?
description: The New York-area franchise of the United State Football League team has been offered the opportunity to play in Giants Stadium here, the head of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said today.

title: N.F.L. AND UNION IN NEW ROW
description: Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said today that veteran free agents not under a playing contract July 15 have the option of signing with another league. Garvey also said that unsigned rookies may not negotiate with clubs after that date.

title: The Out-of-Touch Police
description: The nation's largest police association, the International Association of Chiefs of Police, is dominated by small-town chiefs who cling to an authoritarian tradition and a simplistic view of police work. Their effort to silence Patrick Murphy, the former New York City Police Commissioner, exposes their irrelevance to serious debate about crime.

title: OUTDOORS IN SUMMER, BEETHOVEN IS EVERYWHERE
description: SUMER is icumen in, and that, as usual, means that music lovers are going out. It's hardly surprising. Even in this age of airconditioning and acoustic consultants, or perhaps because of it, there seems more eagerness than ever to put music and the great outdoors together.

title: Dutchman Wins 6th Stage of Tour
description: Hans Raas of the Netherlands won the sixth stage of the Tour de France today, covering the 144.5-mile leg in 5 hours 55 minutes 42 seconds. Phil Anderson of Australia retained the overall lead, which he has held since the second stage.

title: JERSEY DEVILS DETAIL SEASON-TICKET PLANS
description: The New Jersey Devils announced an unusual ticket plan yesterday, in which the only season tickets that will be renewable each year will be those accompanied by an initial $2,000 per-ticket bond. The remaining season tickets - the bulk of the seats in the Byrne Meadowlands Arena - will be drawn by lottery each season.

title: COMING FACE TO FACE WITH DEATH
description: IN ''A Time to Die,'' a ''CBS Reports'' documentary at 10 tomorrow night, CBS News looks at how some terminally ill people face death. It's not a new subject for television. Public television has dealt with it in a number of remarkable cinema-verite programs. But it is no less gripping this time.

title: Amway Disputes Canada's Charges
description: The Amway Corporation, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., and a subsidiary, Amway of Canada Ltd. of London, Ontario, are being sued by Canada for $147.8 million for making false statements to Canadian customs officials regarding the value of goods it imported into Canada and thereby avoiding paying proper duty.

title: NEW YORK CITY BEACHES: FREE AND EASY TO REACH
description: Accessible by subway or bus, 15 miles of city beaches line the shores of four of the boroughs - all except Manhattan. The beaches, maintained by the city, are free, clean and, now that the freeze on hiring municipal employees has been lifted, fully staffed with lifeguards.

title: Ex-Mine Union Chief Loses Bid for New Trial
description: W.A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers who was convicted of hiring assassins to kill a union rival, lost an appeal for a new trial today when the State Supreme Court ruled that the verdict was fair.

title: STOCK DECLINE AFTER SCREENING OF 'TRON' IRKS DISNEY STUDIO
description: Walt Disney Productions, annoyed at Disney stock declines after market analysts' negative reviews of its new movie ''Tron,'' said it might not invite analysts to any more screenings.

title: CHARTER TO SELL 3 PUBLISHING INTERESTS
description: The Charter Company, a conglomerate with interests in petroleum, communications and insurance, announced an agreement yesterday to sell The Ladies' Home Journal magazine and two other publishing properties to three different companies.

title: Salary Increase Averts Strike at Village Voice
description: A threatened strike at The Village Voice was averted yesterday when employees at the weekly newspaper accepted a new two-year contract.

title: Sex Bias Suit Is Filed Against Girard College
description: Two women's groups filed a sex discrimination lawsuit today in an attempt to overturn Girard College's policy of providing free education only to indigent boys.

title: Moscow's Silence On Air Crash Deplored
description: A Senegalese diplomat criticized Soviet authorities today for refusing to make public information about the presumed death of two citizens from his country in an Aeroflot crash believed to have killed all 90 people aboard.

title: A GUIDE TO MENUS AT THE MUSEUMS
description: EATING well at New York's museums is a matter of strategy. Although some of the food that is offered can represent the worst of institutional cooking, often there are dishes that are reasonable - even good. And since most of us get hungry after looking at paintings, it is worth knowing what to choose, particularly when the feet are sore and the nearest restaurant is blocks away.

title: GENERAL MILLS OFF
description: The General Electric Company, one of the first major companies to report results for the second quarter of 1982, said that net income in the period rose 6.7 percent despite a 4.7 percent decline in sales.

title:
Economic Scene;
Investment Role of OPEC
description: THE United States Treasury will be selling an unprecedented $90 billion to $110 billion of Government i.o.u.'s next fall to finance President Reagan's record budget deficits. But some of its best customers of recent years - the oil-exporting nations - may not be buying.

title: FRIDAY, JULY 9, 1982; Markets
description: Prices rose sharply and interest rates fell in the credit markets as speculation mounted that the Federal Reserve Board has eased monetary policy. In extremely active trading, Treasury bill rates declined by more than half a point, while Treasury note and bond prices were higher by up to 2 points. Most of the gains came after the Fed arranged temporary purchases of Treasury bills. (Page D1.)

title: SET UP NONPARTISAN REDISTRICTING COMMISSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: ISREAL PREPARES FOR POSSIBILITY OF LONG STAY
description: The army's Deputy Chief of Staff said today that Israeli forces in Lebanon were making logistical preparations to stay through the winter if necessary.

title: LAURINDO ALMEIDA, EVERYONE'S 'AMIGO,' IN TOWN
description: LAURINDO ALMEIDA, the guitarist who became a star with Stan Kenton's orchestra 35 years ago and whose playing is part classical, part jazz and all Brazilian, is being his full tripartite self this weekend, tonight through Sunday, at Village West, 575 Hudson Street.

title: Canada Study Notes Gloom
description: Canada's top business executives have become increasingly pessimistic about the country's economic prospects, according to a survey out today.

title: NOW U.S. MAY GET A TURN
description: BARCELONA, Spain I n Spain there are beginning to be whispers that Colombia's hold on staging the 1986 World Cup is not secure, and that the United States could be a leading contender for those games, instead of having to wait for 1990.

title: Becker Appoints New Leadership
description: Daniel J. Good and John G. Heimann were named yesterday as cochairmen of the management committee that will run Warburg Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker Inc., a New York-based investment company. They will replace Ira T. Wender, whose resignation was accepted as president and chief executive officer, the firm announced.

title: CHICAGO HOUSING CHIEF, UNDER FIRE, QUITS AS AGENCY IS REORGANIZED
description: Charles R. Swibel, the beleaguered chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority, announced Wednesday night that he would step down from the position he has held since 1963. The announcement came just hours after legislation reorganizing the management of the agency was signed by Gov. James R. Thompson.

title: 2 SCIENTISTS CITE NUCLEAR PLANT PERILS
description: A special panel of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission heard two scientists testify today that a major release of radio-activity from either of the two operating Indian Point nuclear power plants could render thousands of square miles uninhabitable for decades.

title: Boeing Jet Order
description: The Boeing Company said it had received an $88 milion order for four 727-200 planes from the Turkish airline Turk Hava Yollari. One of the aircraft was delivered last month, Boeing said, and the other three will be delivered by the end of September.

title: Situation Available In Computerland
description: D isplayed with a whirl of electronic merchandise promising miraculous help with human financial affairs and other wizardry, the sign in the window of Computerland on Sixth Avenue at 44th seemed downright quaint:

title: EX-CONVICT RECEIVES SENTENCE OF 30 YEARS FOR ASSAULT IN BRONX
description: A former convict was sentenced yesterday to a maximum term of 30 years in prison for sodomy and attempted rape in a knifepoint attack on a 19-year-old college student in the Bronx last year.

title: Grey Advertising Adds 2 Assignments
description: While Ogilvy & Mather was getting a Kayser-Roth panty hose brand from Grey Advertising, as reported Wednesday, Grey was getting two Kayser-Roth assignments from Ally & Gargano and AC& R Advertising.

title: KNICKS NAME 2 AIDES
description: Mike Fratello and Richie Adubato, both of whom worked for the Atlanta Hawks last season, were named yesterday as assistant coaches of the Knicks.

title: PUBLISHING: REAGAN VETO IS PRAISED BY AUTHORS
description: WRITERS and publishers have had little to celebrate in recent months, but President Reagan lifted their spirits with yesterday's veto of HR 6198, which would have extended for four years the socalled manufacturing clause of the Copyright Act. ''We're very pleased that the President has shown serious concern for the First Amendment and the rights of American authors,'' said Irwin Karp, general counsel of the Authors League.

title: SENATE PANEL ASKS CHANGES IN SYSTEM OF CAPITOL PAGES
description: A committee of Senate officials has recommended major changes in the way Capitol pages are recruited and supervised.

title: 4 SENTENCED IN SPRINGBOK PROTEST
description: Four persons were sentenced to up to a year in jail yesterday in connection with a demonstration against a South African rugby team at Kennedy International Airport last September. Each was also given an additional 30-day sentence for contempt of court for shouting slogans at the conclusion of the hearing in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: A village that saved its Jews.
description: CARL FOREMAN is excited again, as he says he hasn't been since he wrote the screenplay for ''High Noon.'' He's going to write and direct a movie based on ''Lest Innocent Blood Be Shed,'' a book by Philip Hallie, which is, Mr. Foreman says, ''about conquering fear and doing what you have to do.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FOR TRUE FANS, SOME NEW STATISTICS
description: If that government is best that governs least, the 97th Congress has been very good indeed, according to statistics complied by the American Enterprise Institute.

title: Commissioner Schultz
description: Dave Schultz, who was assessed 2,294 penalty minutes during his nine-year National Hockey League career, was named commissioner of the Atlantic Coast Hockey League. Schultz, who built his reputation as an enforcer while a member of the Philadelphia Flyers in the 1970s, still holds the career record of 412 penalty minutes in the Stanley Cup playoffs. ''I'm very excited about my first executive role,'' Schultz said.

title: Picturephone Service Begins
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company inaugurated its two-way Picturephone Meeting Service today by placing the first call between New York and Washington. The service lets businessmen in separate cities hold ''face-to-face'' discussions.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ALITTLE after midnight Ruth Fisher left her 23d-floor apartment on lower Fifth Avenue carrying b ottles of various liquors and Pac-Man cookies, ''because they look l ike the moon,'' and made her way to the roof setback on the 15th f loor where her Star Party was to be held.

title: BRIEFING
description: Haig's Departure

title: WEST DISCLOSES NEW PLAN FOR TROOP CUTS
description: The latest Western proposals for reductions in conventional forces in Europe were formally disclosed here today. The Warsaw Pact countries reacted coolly to the plan, which was first outlined by President Reagan a month ago in his speech to the West German Parliament.

title: ITALY AND WEST GERMANY MOVE TO CUP FINAL
description: West Germany came back from a two-goal deficit in overtime today and went on to defeat France on penalty kicks in Seville to advance to the World Cup championship game Sunday against Italy.

title: Market Place; How Tax Law Helps Rentals
description: JUDGING by the market action in Electro Rent Corporation stock, traders may have overlooked a change in the tax law of special importance to this company, which rents out Hewlett-Packard and Tektronix test and measurement equipment, mostly for research and development.

title: People
description: * Larry Olshan has been named general manager of the Entertainment Group of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. Inc.

title: POP JAZZ
description: FOR the last four years, Soundscape, a performance space on West 52d Street, has been providing a forum for audacious jazz musicians, Cuban refugees, moonlighting Latin musicians with something of their own to say and other performers who don't fit comfortably into more conventional concert or nightclub formats. But this summer, Soundscape has temporarily relocated on a barge anchored just south of Houston Street on the Hudson River, a purple barge owned by the Floating Foundation for Photography.

title: ATLANTIC CITY WHEN YOU'RE NOT GAMBLING
description: ATLANTIC CITY THIS recently reborn resort teems with people on a summer weekend, but so many of them are in the casinos that visitors not interested in gambling have plenty of room to maneuver on the oceanfront strip. And because noncasino enterprises have accompanied the casino boom, the opportunities to feel royally wined, dined and entertained are considerable -even if you ignore the casinos entirely.

title: Miss Zayak Hurt
description: An ankle injury has forced the world figure skating champion, Elaine Zayak, to withdraw from competition at this month's National Sports Festival. Miss Zayak, who is 16, has been advised by her physician not to skate for at least two weeks, the United States Olympic Committee announced. The Olympic Committee sponsors the Sports Festival.

title: ARTS FESTIVAL OPENS TODAY IN PURCHASE
description: HEAT bubbles up from the pavement. Ice cream vendors are on every corner. Rooftop ''tar beaches'' and tenement fire escapes are dotted with determined sunbathers. Those are the signs of summer in the city, but at the State University in Purchase, N.Y., you can tell it's summer by the Pepsico Summerfare. The 1982 edition of this outdoor arts extravaganza opens tonight on the rustic Westchester campus, where it will spread out over 500 acres of meadows, plazas and glistening new facilities through Aug. 8.

title: FEDERAL FOOD PROGRAMS: AN ADVOCATE SPEAKS OUT
description: Nancy Amidei has some policy suggestions for President Reagan. What we need, she tells audiences around the country, are deny-side economics, luxury stamps and cube grants.
To the Editor:

title: Cleveland Jury Convicts 6 Men of Racketeering
description: Six men, including the 77-year-old reputed leader of the Cleveland Mafia, were convicted today of carrying on a crime war for control of the rackets.

title: FIVE TEENAGERS SEIZED IN CRASH OF JERSEY TRAIN
description: Five teen-agers were arrested today and accused of having deliberately thrown a switch that derailed a sevencar train, sending it crashing into a factory wall and killing the engineer. A 14-year-old boy riding with the engineer was severely injured.

title: GAINS REPORTED IN NAMIBIA TALKS
description: Western and African diplomats said today that they had made progress in talks designed to free South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, from South African rule.

title: Marks, Regency In Merger Talks
description: Williamhouse-Regency Inc., a maker of specialty paper products, said that it was involved in ''preliminary merger discussions'' with Carl Marks & Company, a New York securities and investment banking firm.

title: Burden Gives Up, Begins Jail Term
description: Luther (Ticky) Burden, a former New York Knicks basketball player, who jumped $20,000 bail while he was appealing his conviction on a bank robbery charge, surrendered today.

title: Advertising; Diet Coke Prepares Its Debut
description: BETWEEN drags on a bottle of Coca-Cola, Bryan G. Dyson, president of Coca-Cola USA, yesterday announced the introduction of diet Coke, which he described as ''the most significant new product introduction'' in the history of the company.

title: U.N. ARMS TALKS WILL END TODAY WITHOUT ACCORD
description: A five-week conference on disarmament, which has reached no agreement on measures to curb the worldwide arms race, is due to end on Friday.

title: U.S. REPORTEDLY KNEW OF BANK'S TROUBLES
description: Federal bank regulators knew for more than two years that the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma was in serious trouble, but were unable to prevent its collapse last Monday, banking sources said yesterday.

title: INTEREST RATES DROP SHARPLY
description: Prices rose sharply in all sectors of the credit markets yesterday as speculation grew that the Federal Reserve has eased monetary policy slightly. In extremely active trading, Treasury bill interest rates declined by more than half a percentage point, while Treasury note and bond prices were higher by 3/4 to 2 points.

title: Former Inc. Publisher Is Weighing New Offer
description: Norman Raben, president of the Goldhirsh Group, publisher of Inc. magazine, confirmed yesterday that C.C. Randolph 3d, known to all as Jim, is out as publisher of Inc. and that he is now on Nantucket deciding whether to accept a Goldhirsh offer to run the group's teleconferencing operation. That decision should come today or Monday.

title: TCHAIKOVSKY PIANO JURY GIVES NO GOLD MEDAL
description: After deliberating until the break of dawn, the piano jury at the Tchaikovsky Competiton announced today that no gold medal would be awarded this year.

title: 3 CHELSEA CO-OP PROJECTS: RECALLING A GRACIOUS PAST
description: In recent years, the midtown neighborhood of Chelsea, once ignored by the development community, has experienced the same sort of luxury rental and cooperative development as other Manhattan enclaves. So far, however, most developers have sought to relate to the neighborhood's small-town ambiance and to its 19th-century origins as a genteel, middle-class community.

title: LTV Loan Plan
description: The LTV Corporation said it had reached an agreement with a group of 20 banks led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company for an eight-year, $120 million revolving credit. LTV also said that two existing bank credit accords totaling $225 million had been revised with extended revolving periods and reduced interest.

title: ROSA K. EICHELBERGER
description: Rosa Kohler Eichelberger, author of children's books, peace activist and lecturer, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital.
To the Editor:

title: BARYSHNIKOV, IN ITALY, DANCES AGAIN
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, returning to the stage after a five-month absence caused by a knee injury, performed a dazzling pas de deux tonight at the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds.

title: CALLS THE EFFECTS DEVASTATING
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden testified yesterday that he had suffered ''a devastating impact'' from charges accusing him of improper conduct when he was the Chief Medical Examiner of New York City.

title: THREAT OF NUCLEAR CONFLICT IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford to Omit Quarterly Payout
description: The Ford Motor Company's board of directors has decided not to pay a third-quarter dividend, according to Edward G. Snyder, a Ford spokesman.

title: 2 BIRDS RESIST THE STONE
description: Despite its policy of grooming its 10 black homelands for ''independence,'' and its assurances that blacks have genuine self-determination in these areas, South Africa recently announced that it would cede to neighboring Swaziland the entire Kangwene (Swazi) homeland, plus the Ingwuvuma district of KwaZulu. The decision, if carried out, would enable South Africa to rid itself juridically of 870,000 Swazis, half of whom live outside the homeland, and 80,000 Zulus. Meanwhile, it has not only caused a bitter confrontation with the country's leading black politician, Chief Minister Gatsha Buthelezi of KwaZulu, it has also united opposition South Africans of all races and political persuasions, as well as the people in the regions directly concerned, while generating unprecedented support for Chief Buthelezi throughout Africa.

title: ALEXANDER SHELLED BY A'S, 6-3, AND CRITICIZED BY YANKEES
description: Doyle Alexander of the Yankees and Mike Norris of the A's came off the disabled list and pitched against each other tonight. For their efforts, Norris got a victory and Alexander got a blistering verbal attack from the Yankee front office.

title: SWEDISH FEMINISTS SEE A NEW SENSE OF APATHY
description: Although the feminist movement in Sweden has scored some stunning successes in promoting equal rights for women and has gained an international reputation, its leaders here seem more concerned the campaign may be losing momentum.

title: BEIRUT HOSPITAL SEEKS FUNDS
description: The president of the American University of Beirut announced the start of a $5 million fund-raising campaign yesterday to save the university's hospital from ''financial disaster'' because of the war in Lebanon.

title: Addendum
description: * Science Digest magazine increasing its advertising rates by 5 percent and its circulation rate base to 525,000 from 500,000, effective with the October issue.

title: STEALING FROM THE MIND
description: In recent days many people have been shocked that Japanese businessmen might have stolen computer secrets from I.B.M. The allegations are the latest twist in the tense worldwide struggle for technological supremacy, but few businessmen, especially those involved in high-technology, research-based industries, can be very surprised.

title: SUMMARY OF MAJOR ACTIONS TAKEN BY NEW YORK LEGISLATURE IN 1982 SESSION
description: Following are some of the major actions of the State Legislature in its 1982 session, which recessed Saturday. Many of the bills approved in its closing days still await action by Governor Carey. Finance

title: Fiber Industries
description: Fiber Industries, a subsidiary of the Celanese Corporation, will lay off 363 salaried white-collar employees by Dec. 31. In a related move, the Celanese Fibers Marketing Company will lay off 70 employees, some in New York City and some in Charlotte.

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR WEEKEND TRAFFIC
description: A. HENRY HUDSON PARKWAY: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B. FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT DRIVE: Two lanes will be closed in either direction from the Brooklyn Bridge to the Battery. Also, the southbound ramp at Robert F. Wagner Sr. Place will be closed. Farther north, one northbound lane will be closed to traffic at 42d Street as a project to strengthen the roadbed continues.

title: HOLDOVER HIPPIES MEET FOR THEIR ANNUAL FLING
description: The aroma of the thick evening haze that settled over the forest clearing tonight was mostly wood smoke and marijuana. And through it appeared a scene from the past: thousands of people, some of them the aging remnants of the flower generation, others teen-agers too young to remember Woodstock, gathered in a midsummer celebration.

title: EXECUTIVES STUDYING SUBWAY PROBLEMS GOT FIRSTHAND VIEW
description: Like many subway riders, Richard L. LeKachman, a vice president at Citibank, would fume when standing in line at a token booth in which there were four agents but only one was selling tokens.

title: 3 YANKS AND 1 MET ON ALL-STAR TEAMS
description: The National and American leagues announced their complete All-Star rosters yesterday, bringing to 28 the number of players each squad will take to the All-Star Game Tuesday night in Montreal.

title: Mitterrand, in Hungary, Presses Better Relations
description: France and Hungary pledged today to strengthen political and economic cooperation to help improve relations between the West and the Soviet bloc.

title: Dean at Tuck School Stepping Down Early
description: The Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College will be getting a new dean one year earlier than expected. Richard R. West announced yesterday that he would step down from the position next summer, instead of at the end of his second four-year term in 1984.

title: Harry Meislahn, 77, Is Dead; Ex-Head of Albany Academy
description: Harry E.P. Meislahn, the headmaster of the Albany Academy for 28 years until his retirement in 1971, died Wednesday at his home in Albany at the age of 77.

title: The U.N. Today; July 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: References Required? Not in Boston

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. and others in a group said they held 9.8 percent of Western Air Lines Inc.'s $2 cumulative convertible preferred stock series A for arbitrage.

title: MAKING THINGS WORSE; by Tom Wicker
description: ''I don't care whose poll you look at,'' Representative William J. Hughes of New Jersey recently told Steve Roberts of The New York Times. ''Some of them show that crime is more important than national defense.''

title: Fashion Submits Plan to Reorganize
description: Fashion Two Twenty Inc., an Aurora, Ohio, maker and marketer of cosmetics that filed for protection from its creditors on Dec. 10, 1981, said that it had submitted a plan of reorganization to the United States Bankruptcy Court in Cleveland. Fashion Two Twenty had unsecured debt of $700,000, owed mostly to cosmetics suppliers, at the time.

title: U.S. STEEL AND UNION OPEN TALKS ON IDEAS FOR HELPING INDUSTRY
description: Officials of the United States Steel Corporation and the United Steelworkers of America today began two days of talks aimed at solving the economic problems of the company and its workers.

title: New Louisiana Oil Port Is Off to Sluggish Start
description: The mammoth Louisiana Offshore Oil Port, which opened just 14 months ago, is off to a rough start because of the nationwide recession and the nation's reduction in oil imports.

title: BAD CHOICE IN LEBANON
description: Bashir Gemayel, the 34-year-old commander of Lebanon's Maronite Christian militia, is trying to take advantage of the defeat of the Palestinian forces and their Lebanese leftist allies to become the next President of Lebanon. Mr. Gemayel may seem to Israel, the United States and some Arabs to be the best hope to control Lebanon and allow the Israeli forces to extricate themselves.
