But the prospect of a Gemayel government may so frighten other parties in the conflict that it will prolong the war.

title: Guru's Disciples Reach An Accord in Oregon
description: The disciples of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, who live on a ranch-commune near here, have reached an agreement that settles their year-long construction dispute with the ranchers and residents of the small town of Antelope.

title: Understanding Kabuki With Infrared Transmission
description: I ntroduced for the current Kabuki booking, the 700 no-wires, noplug-in earphone sets are the pride of the Metropolitan Opera. Spectators who pay an extra $5 can hear an interpretation of the Japanese text and action through infrared transmission.

title: STAGE: 'SEVEN BRIDES FOR SEVEN BROTHERS'
description: SO how does one begin to describe ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers,'' the threadbare touring package that mistakenly unpacked on Broadway last night? Perhaps it's fitting to start with the brothers themselves. There are indeed seven of them - all singing, all dancing - but what in heaven's name, one wonders, has happened to their hair? On close examination, it seems that someone decided to transform all the brothers into redheads - and then abandoned hope in mid-dye job. The result is an unmatched collection of strawberrystreaked chorus boys who, while purporting to be rugged farmers in 1850 Oregon, look for all the world like clowns.

title: Newsweek's Search
description: Newsweek magazine has narrowed its agency search down to Leber Katz Partners and Scali, McCabe, Sloves. The account, reportedly billing $3 million, is currently handled by Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: A Test for McEnroe
description: John McEnroe will oppose Anders Jarryd of Sweden in the opening match today as the United States opens its defense of the Davis Cup at the Checkerdome in St. Louis. Mats Wilander, the surprise winner of the French Open last month, will play Eliot Teltscher in the second match.

title: Mrs. Gorsuch and the Mirror
description: Anne Gorsuch, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has developed a severe problem of public image during her first year in office. Like others before her, she is blaming the reflecting medium. ''Inaccuracies and distortions'' in the press have hindered her in managing the agency, she complains.

title: Friend of Reagans Is Named In $5 Million Suit for Support
description: Alfred Bloomingdale, a member of President Reagan's ''kitchen cabinet,'' was named today in a $5 million suit filed by a woman who contends that Mr. Bloomingdale, the department store heir, had reneged on a promise to provide her ''lifetime support.''

title: DOW UP BY 5.32 AS RATES FALL
description: Spurred by falling short-term interest rates, prices of blue-chip stocks improved dramatically yesterday to produce a swing of more than 15 points in the Dow Jones industrial average. Trading was active.

title: AT $1,500 A SUIT, HIS CLOTHES MAKE THE MAN
description: Leon Block, a quiet, well-tailored and elegant man, very often doesn't wear custom-made suits. Most people don't wear custom-made suits, but then Mr. Block isn't most people. He is one-half of Dunhill Tailors, considered one of the most prestigious in the country, whose custom division now takes in almost $1 million a year.

title: News Analysis
description: In its term that ended last week, a deeply divided Supreme Court granted new constitutional rights to illegal aliens, retarded people in state institutions and public school students fighting the politically motivated removal of books from school libaries.

title: Possible Front-Runner For Bedford-Stuyvesant Job
description: A mid rising speculation, Ronald T. Gault, the city's Commissioner of Employment, is the reported front-runner - to become the third president of Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation.

title: CHEMICAL GAINS 10.2%
description: The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that its net operating earnings rose 10.2 percent in the second quarter, to $58.4 million, from $53 million in the similar period last year. Chemical, the nation's sixth-largest bank holding company, was the first of the majors to report second-quarter earnings.

title: FIVE STATES REPORT DISORDERS IN HAITIANS' IMMUNE SYSTEMS
description: Health officials in five states have reported a total of 34 cases, including 16 fatal ones, of a serious disorder of the immune system among Haitians who recently moved to this country. Ten of the patients were residents of Brooklyn, Federal health officials reported yesterday.

title: American Financial Move
description: The American Financial Corporation, a diversified financial holding company that Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, took private early in 1981, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Penn Central Corporation and the United Brands Company, and bought shares in the Progressive Corporation, for investment purposes.

title: THREAT OF NUCLEAR CONFLICT IN THE MIDDLE EAST
description: To the Editor:

title: SYRIA DENIES ROLE IN TALKS ON P.L.O.
description: The Syrian Information Minister said today that the Government had not been consulted about proposals for moving Palestinian guerrillas from Lebanon to Syria or for withdrawing Syrian troops from Lebanese territory.

title: Noranda Mines
description: The Scott Paper Company said it had contracted to allow Noranda Exploration Inc., a unit of Noranda Mines Ltd., to explore about 130,000 acres of land owned by Scott in Maine for deposits of copper, lead and zinc. Noranda has exploration rights for 10 years under the contract.

title: AUCTIONS
description: TWO prominent antiques collections will be auctioned next week by Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's in sales away from their New York galleries. On Tuesday at 10:30 A.M. and 2:30 P.M., Christie's will auction the contents of Duck Creek, the residence in Old Lyme, Conn., of J.A. Lloyd Hyde, the late antiques collector and author of two books on Chinese export porcelain. And next Friday at 1:30 P.M. and Saturday at 9:30 A.M. and 1:30 P.M., the collection of the late Pauline Heilman, whose husband had owned a taxi business in York, Pa., will take place at the York Interstate Fair Grounds.

title: Diamond Sales Drop in Period
description: Sales of rough gem and industrial diamonds by the Central Selling Organization for the six months to June 30, 1982, amounted to 636 million rand compared with 747.5 million rand in the same period of 1981, De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. said today.

title: Quite a Challenge
description: On June 23, Don King held a news conference in New York to announce his return to Madison Square Garden, where he would promote Salvador Sanchez's defense of the World Boxing Council featherweight title on July 21 against undefeated and top-ranked Mario Miranda of Colombia.

title: Required Reading; 'How Do I Live?'
description: Representative William M. Brodhead, Democrat of Michigan, in an interview in Common Cause, the monthly publication of the citizen's lobby of the same name, on the subject of his recently announced decision not to seek a fifth term, June, 1982:

title: Aborigines Complain Of Radiation Effects
description: Australian aborigine leaders said here today that some of their people were suffering genetic problems and bearing deformed children as a result of Australian and British atomic bomb tests in the 1950's.

title: TALKS IN BEIRUT SNAGGED ON FOREIGN TROOP ROLE
description: Negotiations between the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Lebanese Government remained snagged today over the role American and other foreign troops might play in any P.L.O. withdrawal and the precise manner in which it would be carried out, Government sources said.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 19-year-old supermarket employee was shot dead at about 6 P.M. yesterday when he tried to subdue a robber in the Morrisania section of the Bronx. The victim was identified as Santiago Cuello of Manhattan.

title: RAYMOND L. WILDER
description: Dr. Raymond L. Wilder, professor emeritus of mathematics at the University of Michigan, died Wednesday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: New Officer Seizes Suspect in Holdup
description: A 21-year-old police officer who graduated from the Police Academy two weeks ago captured a suspect in a bank holdup after a three-block chase in Times Square yesterday afternoon.

title: DRIVER'S STRIKE HALTS WORK ON MAJOR BUILDING PROJECTS
description: Major building projects in New York City have been halted, and 50,000 construction workers have been idled by a continuing strike by truck drivers, construction officials said yesterday.

title: Netherlands Dancers Open Next Tuesday
description: The Netherlands Dance Theater will open at the Metropolitan Opera House next Tuesday night with a program including two New York premieres by the company's director, Jiri Kylian. One of the premieres will be ''Songs of a Wayfarer,'' with music by Mahler; the other will be ''Svadebka/Les Noces,'' to music by Stravinsky.

title: NEXT TIME USE STATE CONVENTIONS FOR E.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Friday; CONNECTICUT'S SHAKESPEARE
description: The American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., opens its 27th season tonight at 8 with ''Henry IV, Part I,'' starring Christopher Walken, Chris Sarandon and Roy Dotrice. The site is 90 minutes from Manhattan, reached easily by car or Conrail; information: (203) 375-5000. Tickets are $12.50 to $19.50 (Chargit: 944-9300). Some of Stratford's attractions are minstrel singers, a museum and an Elizabethan herbal garden. Picnics are in order. Parking costs $2. AND WAVE HILL'S

title: U.S. PRESSING SALVADOR FOR CHANGES
description: State Department officials, voicing uneasiness over human rights and the pace of land redistribution in El Salvador, said today that the Reagan Administration had stepped up pressure on the Salvadoran Government for social and economic changes.

title: KOCH SAYS HE WOULD AGREE TO ARBITRATION ON CONTRACTS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was willing to submit New York City's stalled contract negotiations with the municipal unions to arbitration.

title: Rare Breeds
description: Have you ever heard of a Xoloitzcuintli? A Peruvian Inca Orchid? A Chinese Crested? These aren't flowers or birds, but dogs - three of about two dozen of the rarest breeds, which will be shown at the Hudson Valley Rare Breeds Dog Club Show on the grounds of the Regina Coeli Parish Center on Rte. 9 in Hyde Park, N.Y., tomorrow and Sunday.

title: SENATE REPUBLICANS TAP ELUSIVE TAX SOURCES
description: Driven by the specter of huge deficits in the Federal budget, the Republicans who control the Senate Finance Committee have wrapped into their 1982 revenue bill several moneyraising tax ''reforms'' that have eluded reformers for years.

title: News Analysis
description: For the 205th session of the State Legislature, the times made bold action unlikely. Election-year politics, a shaky economy that allowed little room for experimentation, reductions in Federal assistance and a deep political conflict of interest between Governor Carey and the Legislature conspired to make 1982 a year of caution. It was a time in which most politicians avoided any bold moves to the left or right.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Hermes L. Ames, Baldassaro A. Bascone, Carole Lynne Bell, Robert P. Bowles, William J. Burke Jr. and Carlos A. Burns vice presidents.

title: Loft Panel Vetoes N.Y.U. Residence
description: The Industrial Loft Advisory Council recommended yesterday that the city bar the conversion of three floors of a Manhattan industrial building into living space for New York University students and teachers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A CALIFORNIA SPERM BANK EXPOUNDS ON ITS EUGENIC MISSION
description: To the Editor:

title: Martin Stays Calm as His A's Struggle
description: The Oakland A's have encountered so many problems that the manager and the general manager are not talking to each other right now.

title: JEWISH GROUP FAULTS EX-AIDES' BID ON P.L.O. BUT TERMS IT REALISTIC
description: The executive committee of the World Jewish Congress informally disassociated itself today from a statement issued last week by two of its former presidents calling for mutual recognition and negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: FIGHTING HEAT AND WINNING
description: After the rains of June the heat should have come as a relief.

title: REAGAN IS SEEKING WAYS TO MODERATE POLAND SANCTIONS
description: President Reagan is searching for ways to ease economic sanctions against Poland and the Soviet Union, including a scaling back of the ban on equipment for the new gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe, according to authoritative Administration officials.

title: Ex-Manager Admits He Took Payments for Illegal Dumping
description: The former manager of the Lone Pine landfill admitted today that he took payoffs to permit the illegal disposal of hazardous chemical wastes at the dump in Freehold Township, N.J.

title: Funds' Assets Rise in Week; Funds' Assets Rise $944.3 Million in Week
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $944.3 million, to $202.6 billion, in the week ended July 7, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. In the previous week, the assets dropped by $1.24 billion, to $201.66 billion, in the first decline in six months.

title: Bridge: Segregation May Be Best In Disputes Over Smoking
description: A smoldering controversy has been receiving attention recently in parts of the tournament world. Should players be allowed to puff smoke in the faces of their opponents? Should the nonsmokers be allowed to bar tobacco at the table? Or should the two groups be segregated?

title: Farm Growth
description: As the Mets sink slowly in the East of the National League, there is some encouraging news from Jackson, Miss., where the team's Class AA farm team is growing outfielders by the bunch. ''In my 16 years in baseball,'' said the Jackson manager, Gene Dusan, ''I have never seen an outfield made up of three first-round draft choices.''

title: OIL REVENUE LIFTS IRANIAN ECONOMY
description: Early this year, the Islamic revolutionary regime was sunk so deep in a fiscal crisis that foreign analysts did not see how it could continue paying for vital food imports and meeting the huge Government payroll on which most Iranians depend for their livelihood.

title: ISRAEL SHUTS DOWN A UNIVERSITY IN WEST BANK
description: Israel ordered the largest Palestinian university in the West Bank closed for three months today, charging that its students had engaged in disruptive protests against the Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

title: LYNDHURST ESTATE ON THE HUDSON GIVEN $300,000 BY ROCKEFELLERS
description: Laurance S. Rockefeller and David Rockefeller have offered challenge grants totaling $300,000 to restore Lyndhurst, the landmark 19th-century mansion on the banks of the Hudson River here.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 10, 1982
description: International Removal of the Palestinian fighters from Beirut to Syria was not possible ''under the present circumstances,'' Syria said. The official statement was a reponse to reports that American and Lebanese negotiators in Beirut were discussing a plan to transfer the 6,000 guerrillas besieged there by Israelis to Syria. Syria had not been formally consulted. It was not clear whether Syria's objection was its final word on the matter. (Page 1, Col. 3.) The Palestinian Mayor of Gaza was dismissed by Israel's Defense Ministry, which has been removing Palestinians from prominent positions in the occupied territories. Mayor Rashid al-Shawa was the seventh Arab mayor to be ousted. (4:5-6.)

title: JUDGE ORDERS ANOTHER TRIAL IN PENTHOUSE LIBEL LAWSUIT
description: A judge today set aside a jury verdict exonerating Penthouse magazine of libeling two owners of the resort Rancho LaCosta. He ordered a new trial in the long-running legal dispute.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA SETS AN EXAMPLE OF HOW TO GROW OLD IN THE SUN BELT
description: A few miles outside town here, in the Moreno Valley, bulldozers are advancing across a desert like a force of invading armor, raising a rooster's tail of dust behind them as they turn a wasteland into plots for new homes. Even in the nation's worst housing recession since the Great Depression, there is development under way in the Valley, whose hard, dry land has been worked for generations to produce milk and eggs for the people of Los Angeles, more than 70 miles to the northwest.

title: KREMLIN RENEGES ON 2 EMIGRE VISAS
description: A senior Soviet emigration official declared today that two Russians on hunger strikes to force the authorities to let them join their wives in the United States would not be given permission to emigrate.

title: The City; Mother Convicted Of Killing Child, 3
description: A 26-year-old woman who once was released without bail by Judge Alan I. Friess and invited to spend the night in a spare room in his Brooklyn home, was found guilty of murder yesterday in the 1980 death of her 3-year-old daughter.

title: SUMMERTIME, BOREDOM, A FATAL DERAILMENT
description: On summer nights here, teen-agers can play basketball or tennis on lighted courts, meet friends in a recreation center, study art in a cultural center or explore New York City for a $2.50 round-trip bus fare.

title: Hoyt Hilsman, Writer, Weds Nancy Turner
description: Nancy Kay Turner, an artist and teacher, was married yesterday to Hoyt R. Hilsman, a writer.

title: Justice Dept. Is Cleared In Suit
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed a $29 million damage suit filed by L. Patrick Gray 3d, former Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, against top Justice Department officials who he charged maliciously prosecuted him on a conspiracy charge in 1978.

title: BOND RATING SERVICE GIVES M.T.A. ISSUE A FAVORABLE GRADE
description: The bonds that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to issue to help pay for the rebuilding of the subway system received an investment-grade rating yesterday from one of the two major bond rating agencies.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Language That's All Wet

title: Iranian Leader Repeats Threat to Invade Iraq
description: Iran today stepped up threats to invade Iraq with a warning from the third-ranking member of the clerical hierarchy, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, that the Iranians were prepared to turn their guns on the Iraqi capital of Baghdad, 75 miles from Iran's border.

title: Despert Memorial Service
description: A memorial service will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the First Presbyterian Church in Southampton, L.I., for Dr. J. Louise Despert, a child psychiatrist and author of ''Children of Divorce,'' considered by many an authoritative work on the subject. Dr. Despert died June 14 at the Todd Nursing Home in Southampton at the age of 90.

title: No Headline
description: A headline in the late editions of Friday's Sports Pages gave an incorrect score for the Italy-Poland game in the World Cup soccer tournament. Italy won, 2-0.

title: PARK RESTORATION GIVES BELVEDERE CASTLE NEW LIFE
description: Central Park's Belvedere Castle will soon be reopened, after a $1.5 million restoration, as a center for family and children's activities.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Prime Cut in St. Louis
description: The Southwest Bank of St. Louis cut its prime rate today to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent, effective immediately. Its chairman, Isaac Long, cited the recent downward trend in short-term interest rates, particularly the Federal funds rate. The nation's major banks are using a 16 1/2 percent prime rate.

title: JAMES OF ALABAMA WON'T RUN AGAIN
description: In a speech that indirectly criticized all his fellow Democrats who are seeking the job he now holds, Gov. Fob James told a statewide television audience Thursday night that he would not seek re-election.

title: Republic Steel
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said production would resume Sunday at its Chicago district rolling mills and finishing facilities after a one-week suspension. It said 1,200 employees would be called back to work, reducing the total layoff to 2,800. The company said, however, that production of iron and steel would continue to be curtailed in the coming week, and operations would continue to be scheduled on a week-to-week basis, depending on business conditions.

title: NEITHER SIDE IN SALVADOR APPEARS TO BE DOMINANT
description: Recent fighting in the two-year-old Salvadoran civil war does not appear to be going well for the Salvadoran Government. But the guerrillas, who seem stronger now than they were 18 months ago when they attempted a nationwide offensive, do not appear to be close to a military victory.

title: Consumer Saturday; LANDMARK DECISION ON SUN ACCESS
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court recently modified a long-held tenet of A merican common law that says ''a landowner owns up to the sky and d own to the center of the earth.''

title: MAXIMUM SENTENCE ISSUED IN GRANDFATHER SLAYING
description: A judge ordered today that Marc Francis Schreuder of New York serve the maximum sentence allowed under Utah law for the 1978 slaying of his millionaire grandfather.

title: India Presses for a Halt To Fighting in Lebanon
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that she had taken ''every possible initiative'' to help defuse the crisis in Lebanon and that she is in touch with President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, on ways to end the fighting.

title: Elizabeth Fordyce Mulford Bride of Ronald D. Wawra
description: Elizabeth Fordyce Mulford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Mulford of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church to Ronald Drew Wawra, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Wawra of Pompton Plains, N.J. The Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy performed the ceremony.

title: Mueller Acquisition
description: The Sybron Corporation said today that the Mueller company had completed its acquisition of Sybron's Leopold Company subsidiary for about $11 million in cash. Leopold makes waste-water treatment products and systems.

title: Bell Seeks Rate Increase
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, determined to raise the rates it charges competitors to connect long-distance service to local Bell System lines, proposed today a 95 percent increase in one of its key equipment charges.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JULY 10, 1982; Markets
description: Interest rates fell sharply in the credit markets after the Federal Reserve Board reported an unusually large $3.7 billion decline in the money supply. Treasury bill rates fell about a quarter of a point, with three- and six-month issues closing at 11.55 percent and 11.8 percent, respectively, down about three-eighths of a point. (Page 35.)

title: OPEC Parley Still Split On New Output Quotas
description: The oil ministers of the OPEC nations failed to reach agreement today on new production quotas intended to prevent oil prices from falling again.

title: A WOODY ALLEN RELEASE DEPARTS FROM TRADITION
description: It is usual for Woody Allen's movies to reach movie theaters during Hollywood's off-season. ''Manhattan,'' ''Interiors'' and even the Academy Award-winning ''Annie Hall,'' opened in the spring or fall at single theaters in the better districts of two or three key cities - on the East Side in New York and Westwood in Los Angeles.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF PREVIOUS AIR DISASTERS
description: Previous major international and domestic air disasters include these: July 6, 1982: An Ilyushin-62 Aeroflot plane crashed shortly after takeoff from Moscow on a flight to West Africa. All aboard, about 90, were killed.

title: ARGENTINE AIR FORCE CHIEF EXPECTS TO REPLACE ALL LOST PLANES SOON
description: The head of the Argentine Air Force said Thursday night that he expected to replace all the warplanes lost in the Falkland Islands conflict within three weeks.

title: Amstar Sugar To Shut a Refinery
description: The Amstar Corporation's sugar refinery here will close indefinitely this summer because of the depressed market for refined cane sugar, the company announced.

title: BLACKS ASSAIL APPOINTMENT AT ARCHIVES
description: The Harlem chapter of the Black United Front, a national group of political activists, held a rally yesterday outside the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem to protest the appointment of a white man to head the center's archives section.

title: NEW REAGAN PLAN INSISTS THAT CITIES SAVE THEMSELVES
description: The Reagan Administration today sent Congress an urban policy report that said the states and municipalities themselves were better able than the Federal Government to restore the vitality of cities.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Playwrights Meet In Waterford Tomorrow

title: WILL THE BEST MAN WIN?
description: One is not supposed to say, after a campaign debate, that the best man won. A podium, obviously, is not the ballot box, that ultimate decider. And defeat or victory at the lectern, after all, exists only in the eyes of the beholders.

title: News Analysis
description: The Koch administration believes that the tax-incentive program for real-estate developers that has been the focus of sharp dispute in recent weeks is crucial to stimulating housing rehabilitation and conversion in the city.

title: News Analysis
description: The public's generally low esteem of Congress has been buttressed by allegations of sexual misconduct and drug use involving Capitol pages and members of Congress.

title: U.S. WILL NOT SIGN SEA LAW TREATY
description: President Reagan formally announced today that the United States would not sign the Law of the Sea Treaty because of his objections to its limits on future seabed mining. The treaty was eight years in the negotiating.

title: AIRLINER'S IMPACT TURNS NEIGHBORHOOD TO RUBBLE
description: When the plane dropped out of the sky, Evelyn Pourchiau was outside her neatly kept brick ranch house with her grandchildren, 9-year-old Kerry and Paul, 5 1/2. They were washing the dog.

title: SOCCER OWNERS FIND LITTLE TO CHEER ABOUT IN U.S.
description: American and foreign businessmen and even multinational corporations have spent millions of dollars trying to increase American interest in the world's most widely played sport: soccer.

title: Nicaraguan to Hold Talks With French Leaders
description: Daniel Ortega, leader of Nicaragua's Marxist governing junta, will hold talks with President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy during a two-day visit in Paris beginning Monday, French officials said today.

title: New York Day by Day
description: 3-D or Not 3-D?

title: Sheik and Hotel Clash Over a $1.5 Million Bill
description: A lawyer for a Saudi Arabian sheik charged with ducking a $1.5 million hotel bill came to court today with two certified checks for the full amount, but Circuit Judge Joseph Price said the bill at the Diplomat Hotel should be settled in cash on Monday.

title: Scouting; Number, Please
description: The Kansas City Kings, like most National Basketball Association teams, last week sent out a preseason roster, updated to show draft choices and trades.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Medea' Is Canceled

title: 2 SIDES IN BEIRUT TRADE HEAVY FIRE
description: Israeli and Palestinian forces fought rocket and artillery duels across Beirut tonight after a day of intermittent shelling.

title: Loggers Find Volcano Victim
description: Weyerhaeuser Company timber crews have discovered the body of another victim of the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens.

title: U.S. Suspending a Part Of Its Ratings on Tires
description: The Government announced today that it planned to suspend part of its tire performance ratings because of concern over the accuracy of treadwear information.

title: YANKEES STOPPED ON 2 HITS
description: ANAHEIM. Calif., July 9 - Geoff Zahn, a deceptive left-hander, pitched a two-hitter and defeated the Yankees for the third time in three tries this season, this time with a 4-1 decision over Tommy John. The two hits were the fewest the Yankees have had in a game this season.

title: Ford's Escort Shift
description: The Ford Motor Company said it planned to discontinue production of the base model of its subcompact Escort by October, start of the 1983 model year, reducing the number of models available to four from five. As a result, dealers said, prices will rise 10 percent, or about $584, on the lowest-price 1983 model Ford Escorts. About 26 percent of the 240,725 Escorts sold during the 1982 model year were base models, a spokesman said.

title: G.E. CUTS BUSINESS IN AIR-CONDITIONERS
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it would sell its central air-conditioning business to the Trane Company of La Crosse, Wis., for 1.85 million shares of Trane's common stock and $100 million in cash. Trane's shares, which did not trade yesterday, closed Thursday at $33.125 on the New York Stock Exchange, bringing the current value of the deal to $161.3 million.

title: HE GOT THERE
description: Thanks to his private jet, he could get there in 35 minutes and often did. It was good getting there so quickly. Sometimes he got there just to enjoy the good feeling. Upon getting there, he would sit at the airport and marvel.

title: SHULTZ OUTLINES STEPS TO SEVER BECHTEL TIES
description: George P. Shultz says that if he is confirmed as Secretary of State he will disqualify himself from taking part in any decisions affecting the Bechtel Group Inc., whose presidency he is leaving.

title: Scouting; Publicity Survey
description: Does the balloting for the Heisman Trophy determine the best college football player in America? Or should the award be presented to the publicist who backs the leading vote getter?

title: McCrory, Stafford Go for 'Interim' Title
description: Milton McCrory, who began his boxing career as a babysitter and spent most of it fighting Thomas Hearns for no pay, faces Roger Stafford today in Phoenix. The scheduled 10-round bout could be considered a semifinal for the welterweight title if Sugar Ray Leonard decides to retire.

title: YANKEE INFIELDER IN THE 1920'S
description: Joseph A. (Jumping Joe) Dugan, who starred at third base for the famed New York Yankees teams of the 1920's, died on Wednesday in Norwood Hospital. He suffered from pneumonia and a stroke.

title: Giddings Board Silent
description: The board of directors at Giddings & Lewis Inc., a Wisconsin machine tool manufacturer, met yesterday to consider a $25 million unsolicited tender offer from the AMCA International Corporation. No announcement was made on the board's position concerning the merger.

title: Sports of the Times; THE LONELY RIDER
description: R uben Hernandez thought that Silver Buck was a cinch to win the Suburban Handicap last Sunday. He had ridden the colt in eight of his previous 10 starts and knew that he was just peaking. Hernandez was not suprised when Silver Buck drew off to an easy three-length victory and covered the 10 furlongs in 1 minute 59 3/5 seconds, breaking Seattle Slew's track record by two-fifths of a second.

title: Janet Coles Posts a 69
description: Janet Coles, seeking her first victory in four years on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour, shot a three-under-par 69 to take a one-shot lead today in the first round of the $125,000 West Virginia Classic.

title: MILITARY BUILDUP SOUGHT BY JAPAN
description: The Japanese Government decided today to propose a 7.34 percent increase in the military budget for the fiscal year beginning next April 1 while calling for 5 percent cuts for most other departments because of the economic recession.

title: FRENCHWOMAN'S HANGING SENTENCE STIRS MALAYSIA
description: On Jan. 27, 1980, a 20-year-old Frenchwoman named Beatrice Saubin checked out of the Eastern and Oriental Hotel here and headed for the airport, en route to Singapore and Zurich. A customs officer later testified that she had been under surveillance.

title: FOR RIGHTISTS IN LEBANON, THE P.L.O. IS A 'CANCER'
description: On the patio of his palace outside Aleih in the wealthy hill suburbs of Beirut, surrounded by retainers who are always at hand to light his cigarettes, Prince Feisal Majid Arslan, leader of the more conservative of Lebanon's two Druse factions, spoke approvingly of the Israeli invasion.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Keeping the Green Green

title: 2 SENATORS SPLIT ON USE OF TROOPS
description: Against a background of heavy artillery, mortar and rocket fire, two United States Senators called this evening for the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Lebanon, but they disagreed on the use of American soldiers to supervise it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Farming offers a retirement option no other job has. A farmer can work the fields until he drops dead -and a lot of them do.'' - Ray Samulis, Burlington County, N.J., agricultural agent. (26:4.)

title: THEY HELP PEOPLE LOOKING FOR SELF-HELP
description: There are self-help groups to assist people with overwhelming tragedies. There are self-help groups that address irritating little problems. There are self-help groups for atheists, artists and arthritics, for stutterers and schizophrenics, for parents of Vietnam veterans and parents of dwarfs, for American Indians and Soviet immigrants, for therapists and feminist vegetarians.

title: FALKLAND AFTERMATH: A NAVAL DEBATE
description: One of the legacies of the Falkland Islands war is the debate now under way in Britain over the use of aluminum superstructures in Royal Navy ships. It is an argument of interest to the United States Navy, which also uses aluminum in naval superstructures.

title: Sports People; Girl for Flanagans
description: Kathy Flanagan, wife of the Baltimore Oriole pitcher Mike Flanagan, gave birth in Baltimore yesterday to the nation's fourth test-tube baby.

title: S.& P. Drops Bank Ratings
description: The debt ratings of three major banks that disclosed loan losses from their involvment with now-failed Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma were lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: CANDIDATES FOR TITLE 'MR. CLEAN'
description: Once upon a time, environmentalists could rely on a certifiable, sparkling ''Mr. Clean'' to make work easy for them on Capitol Hill.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Turning Over a New Leaflet

title: Letter: On Port Authority Ventures; Sell the World Trade Center
description: To the Editor:

title: SAN FRANCISCO GUN LAW OFFERS GLIMMER OF HOPE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The caption under a United Press International photograph of President Reagan at Windsor Castle, published June 8, incorrectly identified the honor guard. The troops were Grenadier Guards.

title: BUILDING BOOM EXPECTED TO DOUBLE BOSTON HOTEL ROOMS BY '84
description: One looks like a handsome brick ocean liner come to rest on Boston's prosperous, renovated waterfront. Another was carved from the stately old neoclassical Federal Reserve Bank building in the financial district. A third, a soaring 1,000-room modern edifice, will perch on air rights at the downtown interchange of the Massachusetts Turnpike.

title: VEGAS NIGHT PATRONS AT A JEWISH CENTER ROBBED OF $200,000
description: Two hundred patrons at a ''Las Vegas Night'' at the Jewish Center of Bayside Hills in Queens were robbed of about $200,000 in cash and jewelry by six men late Thursday night, the police said yesterday.

title: IDEA FOR GREAT DEBATE IS JUST A CUOMO QUIP
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that Mayor Koch should quit to campaign full time for Governor of New York. Mr. Cuomo, who opposes Mr. Koch for the Democratic nomination, said he would quit, too.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 45.

title: 4 QUEENS DEMOCRATS DIVIDE NEW DISTRICTS FOR '82 HOUSE RACES
description: The four Democrats who represent sections of Queens in the House of Representatives have agreed to divide the borough's realigned districts so that no two have to face each other in this year's elections, politicians said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times To the Manners Born By MICHIKO KAKUTANI MISS MANNERS' GUIDE TO EXCRUCI- ATINGLY CORRECT BEHAVIOR. By Judith Martin. 745 pages. Atheneum. $19.95. Dear Miss Manners, Having been a diligent reader of your syndicated column for years, I realize that your mailbox probably overrunneth with correspondence. But this, rest assured, is not your usual request for advice; it is simply a thank-you note for writing such a marvelous book. And quel livre! You've managed to cover all the usual topics - Protocol, Weddings, Dinner Parties and so on - and your wit and common sense put dear old Amy and Emily to shame. I might also add that your acute observations of contemporary manners would have made even our beloved Anthony Trollope proud.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: TV Plans to Drop 'Sunrise Semester'

title: HARD HIT JERSEY FARMERS SEE HOPES FADING
description: Farmers tend to look at the world differently from the people they feed. Even in a field full of promise, some will talk of nothing but hard luck. A truckload of healthy sweet corn on its way to market - a sign of prosperity to some - usually reminds a vegetable grower of low prices, high interest rates and the changing fortunes of life between harvests.

title: Tentative Contract at Schlitz
description: Negotiators have reached a tentative agreement aimed at settling a 24-day strike at five breweries of the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company.

title: Sports People; Cobb Bout Approved
description: The World Boxing Association has given final approval to Mike Weaver's scheduled defense of his heavyweight title July 25 against Randall (Tex) Cobb. James Binns, the W.B.A.'s legal counsel in this country, said after a second daylong hearing in Philadelphia that the Weaver-Cobb winner must meet Michael Dokes, the mandatory challenger, within 60 days of the bout.

title: TRANSIT FARES AND TOLLS SHOULD MATCH ROUTE AND RIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; U.S.F.L. Drug Policy
description: United States Football League rules will include provisions for testing players for possible drug abuse, the Chicago franchise owner and coach, George Allen, said yesterday. ''I think one of the most significant things that our league recognizes is the importance of a drug-enforcement program,'' Allen said after the second day of meetings with league coaches and executives.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Reuters dispatch in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly reported an association between I.B.M. and Fu- jitsu Ltd. Fujitsu, a competitor of I.B.M., makes and markets comput- ers compatible with I.B.M.'s.

title: Dole to Offer Sweeping Income Tax Revision
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, announced today that he would prepare a proposal for a far-reaching revision of the Federal income tax that would lower individuals' tax rates across-the-board and simplify taxes by eliminating most deductions and tax credits.

title: The Region; 23% Tuition Rise Voted at Rutgers
description: The Rutgers University board of governors and New Jersey Institute of Technology trustees voted today to increase tuition 23 percent to 30 percent for about 55,000 students during the 1982-83 school year.

title: Panda Keeps Experts Guessing on Pregancy
description: Ling-Ling, the panda that zoo officials have wanted to bear a baby for several years, is showing some extra weight, but not even the animal experts can tell if she is pregnant.

title: PALESTINIAN MAYOR OF GAZA IS DISMISSED BY THE ISRAELIS
description: Israel's Defense Ministry dismissed the Palestinian Mayor of Gaza today as part of an effort to purge Palestinian nationalists from prominent positions in the occupied territories.

title: Errico, Ex-Jockey, Denied New Trial
description: A Federal judge denied a new trial yesterday to Con Errico, the former jockey who was convicted in 1980 of conspiracy and racketeering in connection with fixed thoroughbred races at New York tracks in the mid-1970's.

title: Fame Is Favored In Sheppard Pace
description: Fame, a 2-year-old Albatross colt trained by Jerry Silverman and driven by Bill O'Donnell, was made the 8-5 morning-line favorite in a field of nine freshmen for Saturday night's Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace.

title: Set the J-51 Record Straight
description: New York City's decision to press on with the J-51 program of tax concessions for housing rehabilitation has been raising eyebrows and protests. Didn't the city contend that the program would die unless extended? Didn't the Legislature turn the city down? Doesn't the city's position now demonstrate that it had been arguing in bad faith?

title: 4 KILLED ON GROUND AS PLANE SETS LOUISIANA HOUSES AFIRE
description: A Pan American World Airways jet crashed in a residential area just after taking off from New Orleans yesterday afternoon, killing all 145 on board. At least four people on the ground were killed.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 29. 1. A California wine. 2. Mexico; Mr. de la Madrid was elected as the candidate of the party that has ruled Mexico for the last 53 years. Dominican Republic; Mr. Majluta was sworn in after President Antonio Guzman died from a gunshot wound in the head.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL BALTIMORE (AFC) - Signed Leo Wis- niewski, nose guard who was second- round draft choice, to series of one-year contracts.  BUFFALO (AFC) - Signed Eugene Marve, linebacker who was third-round draft pick, to series of one-year contracts.  CLEVELAND (AFC) - Signed Chip Banks, linebacker who was first-round draft choice, to four one-year contracts.  SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Signed Charlie Joiner, wide receiver, and James Harris, quarterback, to new contracts.; COLLEGES
description: Named John McNama- r a head women's soccer coach. DE PAUL - Named Kenny Reynolds a ssistant basketball coach. Named J eanne Lenti assistant athletic director.

title: Panic Over Pilgrim State
description: The logic is hard to beat: New York State's prisons are crowded and tense; meanwhile, whole sections of state mental hospitals stand empty. Why not convert them into prisons?

title: U.S. ASSERTS LASERS SENT TO EUROPE WILL NOT HELP IN MAKING BOMBS
description: Administration officials said today that research lasers had been exported to West Germany and France but that the equipment would not help either country produce material for nuclear bombs.

title: TOMMY LOUGHRAN DIES AT 79
description: Tommy Loughran, a former world light-heavyweight champion and a member of the Boxing Hall of Fame, died Wednesday. He was 79 years old.

title: Players; CARLTON KEEPS STRIKEOUT FORM
description: PHILADELPHIA S teve Carlton, the left-hander famous for his pitching and selfimposed isolation, was in a little room off the Phillies' clubhouse. The sign on the door read, ''In use, please do not disturb.''

title: Index; International
description: Frenchwoman is sentenced to hang in Malaysia 2 Japanese Government proposes increase in military budget 3 El Salvador is set aside as the press turns to other crises 3 Salvadoran civil war is not going well for the government 3 Two U.S. senators in Mideast call for withdrawal of P.L.O. 4 Israeli-P.L.O clashes drive Bei- rut civilians into shelters 4 For Lebanese right, the P.L.O. is a ''cancer'' 4 Around the World 5 Soviet reneges on promise to let two hunger strikers emigrate 5 U.S. says exported lasers won't aid in making bomb material 5 Argentine expects planes lost in Falklands to be replaced soon 5 Britain debates merits of alumi- num versus steel in warships 5 Government/Politics Gov. Fob James of Alabama will not seek re-election 9 Democratic Congressmen from Queens agree on new districts 26 Washington Talk Candidate for the title, ''Mr. Clean'' 9 Briefing 9 General Around the Nation 6 Building boom will nearly double Boston hotel rooms by 1984 6 Southern California shows Sun Belt what it's like to grow old 7 Man convicted in grandfather's slaying given maximum term 24 Rockefellers give $300,000 to re- store Lyndhurst mansion 25 The Region 26 Patrons of ''Las Vegas Night'' in Queens Jewish center robbed 26 The City 27 Arts/Entertainment Sotheby's and Christie's report drops in some sales categories 11 A new Woody Allen release de- parts from tradition 11 Polygram buys ''Chorus Line'' film rights 11 ''Miss Manners' Guide,'' by Ju- dith Martin is reviewed 12 Three Japanese modern troupes at American Dance Festival 14 TV Notebook: NBC-TV said to offer best new shows 45 Style Consumer Saturday: a landmark decision on sun access 46 De Gustibus: tea and chutney - two different Greys 46 They help people looking for self- help 46 The latest crop of towels for the beach 46 Obituaries Tommy Loughran, light heavy- weight champion in the 20's 28 Industry/Labor Maritime unions reject Federal request to forgo pay rise 7 Sports Pages Mets split with Padres and end losing streak at 7 games 31 Angels beat Yankees, 4-1 31 Mary Decker Tabb sets world- mile record of 4:18.08 31 United States and Sweden tied at 1-1 in Davis Cup match 31 Players: Carlton stays in strike- out shape 31 Scouting: Paul Blair expected to be Fordham baseball coach 32 McCrory-Stafford bout has a link to Leonard's title 32 N.F.L. clubs advised to hasten of- fers to rookies 32 Steven Crist on a lonely rider 33 Viola, Twins rookie, stops Red Sox, 4-1, on six-hitter 33 U.S. ready if needed as 1986 World Cup site 33 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 10 About New York 26 New York Day by Day 27 Saturday News Quiz 29 Sports People 33 News Analysis Martin Tolchin on allegations of sexual misconduct in Congress 8 Michael Goodwin discusses the J-51 tax-incentive program 27 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: STOCKS RISE BY 9.14
description: A new mood of optimism spread through the nation's financial markets yesterday. Interest rates for Government securities fell sharply after the Federal Reserve Board announced an unexpectedly large decline of $3.7 billion in the nation's basic money supply.

title: TAX EQUALIZER
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; Opinions Differ On New C.D.
description: THE latest in the long and often confusing list of certificates of deposit that banks and thrift institutions can offer consumers, a 7-to 31-day account paying current market interest rates, was authorized last month by Washington. But there is sharp disagreement in the industry about how the public will receive the new accounts, which are scheduled to start on Sept. 1.

title: East Germany's Profitable Porcelain
description: Christa Hoffmann sits at a long wooden bench at the venerable Meissen porcelain works, her homemade wooden tools spread about her like a surgeon's instruments.

title: Court Backs F.A.A. Rule On Flights to Dulles
description: Dulles International Airport, 26 miles outside the nation's capital, is so empty that it might ''cease to exist'' without a rule alloting it some long-haul traffic to Washington, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: FED BACKS CITICORP ON DATA UNIT
description: The Federal Reserve Board cleared the way yesterday for Citicorp to enter the data processing and transmission business through a subsidiary to be known as Citishare.

title: BRIEFING
description: Shultz on the Move

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Peck, Gielgud, Plummer Cast for Vatican Drama

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Johnny Got His Gun' To Premiere as Play

title: The City; Uniformed Unions Lower Demands
description: Negotiators for the coalition representing the city's uniformed services lowered their wage demands yesterday afternoon, but the city's representative at the talks called the move ''insignificant.''

title:
Patents;
Microscopic Analysis Without Using Slides
description: Slideless microscopy, with which blood and urine can be analyzed as they flow, was patented this week for International Remote Imaging Systems Inc. of Chatsworth, Calif.

title: BLUE CHIPS LEAD RALLY
description: Responding to a long-awaited drop in interest rates, stock prices rose sharply in heavy trading yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 9.14 points, to 814.12, bringing its increase for the week to 17.13 points.

title: The Region; Youth Is Accused Of Church Murder
description: A 17-year-old Hartford resident has been indicted on a charge of felony murder in the robbery and beating death of a 90-year-old night watchman at the Cathedral of St. Joseph, court officials said.

title: Loss for Sotheby
description: Sotheby Park Bernet Group, the art auction concern, said yesterday that it lost the equivalent of about $1.5 million in the six months ended Feb. 28, compared with a $5.5 million profit in the 1981 period.

title: Data Terminal
description: Data Terminal Systems Inc., said it had laid off about 290 employees, or about 19 percent of its work force worldwide and was cutting expenses by about 25 percent. Data Terminal also said it expected a pretax loss in the second quarter ending Aug. 1, but that it should be below the loss a year earlier of $4.1 million.

title: Pioneer F.T.C. Appeal
description: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation asked the Federal Trade Commission to modify a 1975 consent decree under which the company agreed not to fix the resale prices of its products or to limit the customers with whom its dealers may do business, the F.T.C. said today. Under the agreement, Pioneer also agreed to reinstate dealers it had previously terminated.

title: DAMASCUS REJECTS PLAN TO TRANSFER THE P.L.O. TO SYRIA
description: Syria said today that ''under the present circumstances there is no possibility of moving the Palestinian fighters from Beirut to Syria.''

title: BAD LUCK IN A COMPLEX WORLD HAS CAUSED ONE-TERM PRESIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Al Seitz, Hotelier, Dead at 64; Owner of the Oloffson in Haiti
description: Al Seitz, the owner of the Grand Hotel Oloffson, a Haitian haven for celebrities in Port-au-Prince, died July 1 of cancer. He was 64 years old.

title: DANCE: FESTIVAL ENJOYS VISIT OF JAPAN'S MODERNS
description: This summer, for the first time, the American Dance Festival - which has played a crucial historical role in the development of American modern dance - has taken the unusual initiative of exploring modern dance's effect outside the United States.

title: LESSON OF A 'LYNCHING'
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; PEACE AND ANARCHY IN THE GARDEN OF EDEN
description: The Garden of Eden is on Eldridge Street between Rivington and Stanton Streets in a part of the Lower East Side thick with decay and drugs. A man calling himself Adam Purple, who once was known as Les Ego and who also goes by the name John Peter Zenger 2d, has created the garden on 15,000 square feet of land once occupied by tenement buildings. He has named it as he sees it.

title: A FORGETFUL MIDDLE EAST MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Day by Day
description: Knowing Where to Draw The Lines

title: 2 Lead Milwaukee Golf
description: Dick Zokol of Canada, a rookie on the PGA Tour, and the veteran Terry Diehl shot three-under-par 69's today to share the second-round lead in the $250,000 Greater Milwaukee Open. They were at 134 on the 7,010-yard Tuckaway Country Club course.

title: The U.N. Today; July 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Session on Disarmament - 10 A.M.

title: Martin, Ex-Sabre, Sues Over Injury
description: Rick Martin, a former wing for the Buffalo Sabres, has filed a $10 million suit against the team claiming medical negligence shortened his playing career.

title: SOTHEBY'S AND CHRISTIE'S DETAIL DECLINES IN SALES
description: The world's top two auction houses released some of their annual sales figures yesterday, showing that their drops in sales were led by sharp declines in jewelry, Impressionist paintings, Art Nouveau and Art Deco wares and stamps and coins.

title: U.S. READY AS CUP SITE
description: Gene Edwards, president of the United States Soccer Federation, confirmed today that his organization is preparing a contingency plan for holding the World Cup in the United States in case Colombia is not given final approval as a site.

title: U.S.-E.E.C.  Steel Impasse
description: The United States and the European Economic Community finished a round of high-level trade talks today with no sign that either side is willing to shift ground on the dispute over steel exports to the United States.

title: Hearts, Minds and Cambodia
description: Vietnam says it is withdrawing a ''significant'' number of its troops from Cambodia and offers to pull out more if Thailand will stop giving asylum to hostile Cambodian guerrillas. Those guerrillas, meanwhile, have come under the nominal control of a coalition led by Cambodia's former chief of state, Prince Sihanouk.

title: TV Notebook; NBC IS SAID TO OFFER BEST PRIME-TIME SHOWS FOR FALL
description: Which television network has the most promising new prime-time shows for the fall? If you believe a couple of advertising agencies that annually handicap the race, the answer is underdog NBC-TV.

title: Earnings; CATERPILLAR'S PROFIT FELL 93.9% IN SECOND PERIOD
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, hurt by the recession, high interest rates and a weakening in oil and commodity prices, announced yesterday that earnings in the second quarter plunged 93.9 percent, to $9.7 million, while sales fell 17 percent.

title: 3 TEEN-AGERS ON L.I. ARE ACCUSED OF $1.7 MILLION DAMAGE AT SCHOOL
description: In one of Long Island's worst cases of school arson and vandalism, three teen-agers have been arrested and charged with causing more than $1.7 million in damage in a break-in and rampage at West Babylon High School last month.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adage Inc. of Billerica, Mass. said it had agreed to exchange 205,000 of its common shares for all outstanding common stock of Fulcrum Computer Group Inc.

title: A STICKBALL DIPLOMAT
description: On a cold, damp afternoon in early April many years ago in the Bronx, the day after the Yankees opened their home season by walloping the Washington Senators, some neighborhood boys on West 180th Street chose up sides for what was to become, in my eyes and those of Melvin Schecter, the stickball game of all time.

title: Sarasota Journal Closes
description: The Sarasota Journal, a 30-year-old afternoon daily, was shutting down today. ''There simply is no reasonable alternative,'' David B. Lindsay Jr., president of Lindsay Newspapers Inc., said Thursday in announcing the decision. The Journal's circulation was 5,337, a third of what it was two decades ago.

title: Bankers Trust Sale Upstate
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating to sell its Bankers Trust Company of Western New York subsidiary to Key Banks Inc. of Albany.

title: The Region; Boy Killed in Fire At a Youth Home
description: One teen-ager was killed and another critically burned early today in a fire at a home for troubled adolescents.

title: Fed Reportedly Sticking To Tight Money Targets
description: Despite some short-term easing of pressure on interest rates by the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank apparently is sticking with its relatively tight monetary goals for the year.

title:
Patents;
High-Pressure Water Used to Destroy Wastes
description: Michael Modell, president of Modar Inc., Natick, Mass., was granted a patent this week on processes for destruction of hazardous organic wastes, such as PCB's, and the production of energy.

title: OWNER OF VESSEL SUNK BY A BARGE IS CITED FOR ERROR
description: The Coast Guard said yesterday that an error by the owner of a cabin cruiser was the ''probable cause'' of a collision with a barge in Long Island Sound last August that sank the cabin cruiser and killed five persons on board.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY DROP SENDS RATES DOWN
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced an unusually large $3.7 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply that surprised economists and traders in the credit markets and caused interest rates to drop sharply.

title: China Calls Hanoi Move On Cambodia a Trick
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry, responding to Vietnam's announcement that it would withdraw a ''significant'' number of troops from Cambodia, said tonight that if Vietnam was really sincere in wanting to resolve the Cambodian question it should withdraw all of its troops and comply with United Nations resolutions.

title: Chem-Nuclear Stake Obtained
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest solid-waste disposal company, announced that it had received 51 percent of the common shares of Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc. in its bid to take over the radioactive-waste disposal company.

title: New York Day by Day
description: No 9th of July Celebration

title: Suit Filed in Bid to Overturn Mayoral Vote in Atlantic City
description: James L. Usry, who lost the June 15 runoff election here for mayor by 354 votes, filed suit today in an attempt to overturn the vote.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GROUNDBREAKERS

title: Bridge: The Long and Short of It May or May Not Be a Joke
description: A very tall man employing a very short suit might seem comical, but it was a deadly serious matter for all the players on the diagramed deal, from the final of the 1982 Reisinger Knockout Team Championship.

title: LATEST CROP OF TOWELS FOR BEACH
description: Beach towels are something more than big sheets of terry cloth for drying or keeping a tanning body off the sand. Towels can be status symbols or a way of communicating. They may indicate that the owner is witty or rich or well-traveled or a patron of the arts. There are towels for ballet fans and baseball fans, for fans of ''M*A*S*H'' and of Miss Piggy.

title: POLYGRAM BUYS FILM RIGHTS TO 'CHORUS LINE'
description: Negotiations have dragged on for seven years, but at last it seems that a movie version of ''A Chorus Line,'' which won nine Tony awards and is the third-longest-running show in Broadway history, may go into production.

title: Twins Defeat Red Sox
description: Frank Viola, a rookie who did his college pitching at St. John's in Queens, stopped Boston on a six-hitter tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat the Red Sox, 4-1. The victory was the Twins' sixth in their last seven games.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS ECONOMIC SHIFTS AFTER ELECTIONS
description: The White House is conducting a wide-ranging review of economic policies, but President Reagan does not intend to announce any changes in the policies before the Congressional elections in November, according to Administration officials.

title: Chrysler Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation has joined the General Motors Corporation in telling dealers not to expect base price increases beyond 2 percent in early fleet orders of 1983 models, an official at a Chrysler dealership said. The move indicates that 1983 model base prices may rise only moderately in contrast to 5 percent or 6 percent increases in the past few years, analysts said.

title: METS DEFEAT PADRES, 6-3, AFTER 5-3 LOSS IN OPENER
description: When Dave Kingman launched an 0-1 pitch high into the darkening skies above Shea Stadium last night, George Bamberger did not even flinch.

title: EX-PAGE REPORTED TO FAIL LIE TEST ON SEXUAL MISCONDUCT IN CONGRESS
description: Federal officials said today that a former Congressional page who was a primary source of allegations about homosexual activity on Capitol Hill had failed a polygraph examination administered by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: President Picks Board In Railroad Dispute
description: President Reagan named an emergency board today to seek agreement on a contract dispute that threatened to touch off a nationwide railroad strike, but another union warned of a walkout at the end of the month.

title: BAN ON TV IN COURTS IS A LOSS
description: Nearly lost in the final hours of debate as the New York Legislature raced to adjourn last week was an important proposal for an experiment to allow cameras and microphones into New York trial courts.

title: HUDSON RIVER TRACKAGE WAITING TO BE USED
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. TABB SETS WORLD MILE MARK OF 4:18.08
description: Mary Decker Tabb of the United States ran the mile in 4 minutes 18.08 seconds today and broke the women's world record by almost three seconds at the Paris International track and field meet.

title: U.S. Defends Turkey On Human Rights
description: The Reagan Administration defended the Turkish military junta today against West European criticism of human rights abuses in Turkey.

title: New York Air Job Shifts
description: Continuing a major realignment of its executive ranks, New York Air said yesterday that it had named Richard H. Shuyler to the posts of vice president for finance and administration, and chief financial officer.

title: Scouting; League Reunion
description: These women played baseball - not softball, baseball - in the All-American Girls' Baseball League, which was founded by P.K. Wrigley, who then owned the Cubs. Concerned because many major league players were being drafted for World War II, Wrigley thought the girls' league might help keep the public interested in baseball.

title: Florida Sinkhole Plugged
description: A 50-foot-deep sinkhole that had threatened a $2 million apartment complex was plugged today with 10 tons of concrete and reinforcing rods. An automobile was believed to be acting as a stopper at the bottom. The hole developed Monday night in the parking lot of the complex, quickly swallowing the car.

title: THE CASH MARKET IN AIRPORT SLOTS
description: Donald C. Burr, the chairman of People Express Airlines, an expansion-minded carrier based at Newark International Airport, had been looking since fall for landing rights at better airports. In the aftermath of the air controllers' strike, and the resultant squeeze on landing rights at the nation's 22 biggest airports, his fleet of 17 jets had been forced to operate from secondary fields on the fringes of the most desirable transportation markets.

title: LIMITS TO GOVERNMENT
description: A major factor that accounts for the growth of government is inefficiency: spending more money than is necessary to do the work. Evidence is available all around us at all levels of government. The Veterans Administration operates nursing homes whose cost per patient-day is 83 percent higher than the cost incurred by the Veterans Administration when it provides comparable care to similar patients by placing them in privately operated community nursing homes.

title: Foreign Stake in U.S. Rises
description: Foreign investors spent $19.2 billion to acquire or establish businesses in the United States last year, up 57 percent from the previous year, and perhaps the highest total ever, the Commerce Department reported today.

title:
Patents;
Attaching Silica Tiles To Shuttle
description: WASHINGTON THE method of attaching silica tiles to protect the space shuttle, which has had four successful test flights, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Sports People; Browns Sign Banks
description: The Cleveland Browns signed Chip Banks, their top draft choice, to a series of four one-year contracts and an option year yesterday. The signing gave the Browns what is potentially one of the strongest groups of linebackers in the National Football League, with the 6-foot-4-inch, 233-pound Banks scheduled to play outside and newly acquired Tom Cousineau on the inside. The Browns also announced that Paul Warfield, the former all-pro wide receiver, has been named director of player relations.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Seven Brides' to End After 5 Performances

title: Pabst Receives Stake in Olympia
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said that its had received 2.33 million shares, or about 90 percent, of the Olympia Brewing Company under its $28-a-share tender offer for up to 1.27 million shares.

title: Relief Agencies to Get Interviews with Haitians
description: Immigration and Naturalization Service officials said today they had reached an agreement with relief agencies to permit them to enter refugee camps in six states and Puerto Rico to begin screening 1,850 Haitians for eventual release.

title: Art Inspired by Poetry Is in Exhibition on L.I.
description: ''Poets and Artists,'' an exhibition of art work inspired by mostly contemporary poetry, is on view through Aug. 1 at Guild Hall, 158 Main Street, East Hampton, L.I. More than 80 artists and poets are represented in the multimedia exhibition, including Larry Rivers, Lee Krasner, Willem de Kooning, Elaine de Kooning, David Ignatow, Kenneth Koch, Howard Moss, Harold Rosenberg and Diana Chang.

title:
Patents;
New I.B.M. Inventions
description: Six patents were issued to the International Business Machines Corporation this week. They were for semiconductors, integrated circuits, transistors, a cathode ray tube and a printing method.

title: De Gustibus; TEA AND CHUTNEY: 2 DIFFERENT GREYS
description: There are many dishes and food preparations named for the famous people who invented them or in whose honor they were created, and I have always been interested in knowing more about such people and how their namesake dishes came about. Many such generic, classic preparations are made by different manufacturers and sold under different labels.

title: Harvester Aide Resigns
description: The International Harvester Company announced today that W. Grant Chandler had resigned as senior vice president of corporate relations, effective next Friday. Mr. Chandler, who is 54 years old, will become executive vice president of the Crocker National Bank in San Francisco.

title: U.S. AND SWEDEN TIES IN CUP
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden evened the Davis Cup quarterfinal series between his country and the United States at 1-1 tonight by beating Eliot Teltscher 6-4, 7-5, 3-6, 3-6, 6-0.

title: SaturdaySports
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. Pete Falcone (4-6) goes against John Curtis (6-4). The Padres, having their best year ever, are in second place in the National League West. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WGBB, 1240, and WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Angels, at Anaheim, Calif. Ron Guidry, who was selected for the All-Star Game, will seek his ninth victory. (Television - Channel 11, Radio -WABC, 770; 10 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Minnesota Twins, at Boston (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.) Boxing Fifth annual Kid Gloves tournament, 15 bouts for boys 10 to 15 years of age. Outdoors at 32d Street and Seventh Avenue, noon. Admission is free.

title: Scouting; Blair Will Coach Fordham Team
description: Paul Blair, the former Baltimore Oriole all-star center fielder, who later joined the Yankees and retired in 1980, has been hired as head baseball coach at Fordham University.

title: EL SALVADOR OVERLOOKED AS MOST OF PRESS TURNS TO OTHER CRISIS
description: At the end of March, the war and the elections in El Salvador were front-page news and the lead items on the nightly television news programs.

title: Headliners; Sued and Sued Again
description: As former President Gerald Ford once malaproped, if Stephen Girard were alive today he'd turn over in his grave.

title: THE DANCE: REMEMBERING DUNCAN
description: Annabelle Gamson, the dancer who began reviving Isadora Duncan's works in the mid-1970's and has since become closely identified with them, came to Carnegie Hall Wednesday night with dances that Miss Duncan herself performed on the same stage with the New York Philharmonic in 1911. They made up a suite of four pieces choreographed to excerpts from Gluck's ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' and ''Don Juan.''

title: Q and A; A Real Deadline
description: Question: My building is being converted to cooperative ownership under an eviction plan that has been accepted for filing by the Attorney General's office. The tenants' deadline to purchase at the insider's price expired last February; I was undecided at the time and did not apply, but I have since changed my mind. Is there anything I can do now so that I can purchase the apartment at the insider's price? ... K.D., the Bronx Answer: No, there is not, according to the Attorney General's office. Tenants can buy apartments only at the price available to outsiders once the exclusive purchasing period for insiders has expired.

title: Marisela Hernandez Diaz to Be Bride Of Cary F. Staller, Lawyer, on Aug. 28
description: Marisela Hernandez Diaz, assistant to the president of the Fundacion Universidad Metropolitana in Caracas, plans to be married Aug. 28 to Cary Frederick Staller, an associate with the New York law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed.

title: The Factory And the Academy
description: In reference to the recent article ''Colleges Facing Unionism Issue,'' may I say that the steady encroachment of the courts into matters that until recently were properly and entirely handled within academic walls is perilous. It is a mark of the litigiousness of our society that the entire discussion of faculty unions in private universities has been approached as though it were a technical-legal question, with plenary citations of the Yeshiva case and subsequent applications thereof, however welcome they might be to some of us in the profession.

title: SKIPPER TO DEFEND HER TITLE
description: THIS week Kate Wilford of Greenwich is to begin the defense of her title as the best female sailor on Long Island Sound. Last year Miss Wilford, who sails from the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, was the winner of the Syce Cup, now renamed the Queens Cup, the emblem of women's sailing supremacy on the Sound. If she is successful this week, she will have taken a major step toward the ultimate prize in women's sailing, the Adams Cup, at the national championship in Texas in August.

title: Barbara Lawler Is Married
description: Barbara Foster Ely Lawler of New York, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Earl Foster of Bangor, Me., was married yesterday, to Dr. James C. Folsom of Brookwood, Ala., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Lawrence Folsom. The Rev. Carl Victor Bretz of the Unitarian Fellowship of Tuscaloosa performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's two marriages. Dr. Folsom is director of the International Center for the Disabled in New York.

title: Court Plaza; Renewal for Downtown Hackensack
description: Hackensack, N.J., hasn't had a good time of it since the mammoth Bergen County shopping malls drained the lifeblood out of downtown starting in the 1950's.

title: WOLLMAN RINK
description: Before the winter of 1980-81, the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park was closed for repairs, and ice skaters had to find other places for their blades. The plan was that the rink would be reopened in the winter of 1982-83.

title: BRITRAIL BREAKFAST
description: WILLIAM BORDERS, deputy foreign editor of The New York Times, recently completed an assignment in the London bureau.

title: MCCRORY OUTPOINTS STAFFORD
description: Milton McCrory, undefeated and the World Boxing Association's second-ranked welterweight contender, withstood an injury to his right hand to score a unanimous 10-round decision over top-rated Roger Stafford today.

title: Economic Recovery In the Middle West
description: The problems that plague the industrial Middle West today are the same problems that ravaged New England 40 years ago, and New York City 10 years ago (''Collapse of Our Industrial Heartland,'' by William Serrin, June 6). Today, much of New England has recovered, as old textile mills have closed and been replaced by businesses that employ white-collar workers. New York City today is on the way to recovery, as manufacturing jobs have disappeared in the outer boroughs and been replaced by white-collar jobs in Manhattan.

title: WATER GARDENS ADD A COOL DIMENSION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joanna May Thach is a writer who gardens on Long Island. BY JOANNA MAY THACH

title: PHILIPPINE DAM IS A BOON FOR MOSLEM REBELS
description: In this southern and predominantly Islamic city of 85,000 people, there is growing sympathy for the anti-Government struggle of the leftist Moro National Liberation Front.

title: EVEN A 'LEGACY MACHINE' NEEDS POLITICAL OIL
description: Establishing cordial ties with the Legislature was never one of Governor Carey's strong suits. This year, that failure may have cost the Governor his most cherished goal: to make his final year in office the highlight of eight years in the Executive Mansion.

title: AND DECAFFEINATED
description: Last year was a difficult one for the Seven-Up Company. Its market share of the $30 billion soft-drink business dropped below 5 percent for the first time in decades. Volume sales slipped almost 8 percent. And it looked as though the nation's fourth-largest soda manufacturer was about to be buried by Coke and Pepsi, which together control 60 percent of the business.

title: A NEW SEASON AND A NEW HAND AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: Gerard Schwarz never plays the trumpet anymore. He gave up a career as a virtuoso instrumentalist six years ago in order to conduct full time. Now he is music director of the Los Angeles Chamber Symphony and of New York's Y Chamber Symphony, which he founded in 1977, and of the Waterloo Festival Orchestra in New Jersey. He is also preparing for his opera conducting debut in Washington next season, and this summer he has taken on a new assignment - music adviser to New York's Mostly Mozart Festival, which starts tomorrow night at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: MUSIC: VUKSIC AND DEBUSSY IN SOHO LOFTZ
description: Debussy's Preludes, Books I and II, whose sultry, almost tactile imagery embraces everything from dancing fairies to sunken cathedrals, were featured in a recital Wednesday by Cesar Vuksic, an Argentine-born pianist. The performance, which took place in the SoHo loft of the Interlude Concert Series, followed by a month Mr. Vuksic's New York recital debut in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Fortune Teller Wins; Fame 3d
description: Fortune Teller, who was purchased for only $19,000 as a yearling, closed with a flourish in the stretch tonight to win the $543,500 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace for 2-year-olds at Yonkers Raceway.

title: THE DREAMLIKE PACE OF AN ITALIAN SUMMER
description: SONDRA GOTLIEB, the author of two novels, ''True Confections'' and ''First Lady, Last Lady,'' and several cookbooks, lives in Washington, D.C. Her husband, Allan E. Gotlieb, is the Canadian Ambassador to the United States.

title: BOTANIC STUDY UNIT TAKES A NEW NAME
description: THE place is old, but the name is new. The Kitchawan Research Laboratory in Yorktown Heights is now officially known as the Brooklyn Botanic Garden Research Center. Nothing has changed, according to Dr. S. Stanley Hagar, the director. ''The new name,'' he said, ''more closely identifies the station with the parent organization.''

title: Maria Pope Becomes Bride
description: Maria Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leavitt J. Pope of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church to Richard Slenker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Slenker of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Katola performed the ceremony. The bride's father is president of WPIX Inc. and Independent Network News. The bridegroom is an engineering supervisor with WPIX-TV.

title: SIKES SENIORS' LEADER BY SHOT
description: Dan Sikes rallied from five strokes behind today to take a one-shot lead after three rounds of the $150,000 Uniteds States Senior Open golf championship.

title: The Grand Train To Chicago
description: Though Paul Goldberger may not know it, there are several daily trains that depart from Grand Central Terminal for points considerably far removed from White Plains; for example, Amtrak's Lake Shore Limited to Chicago (''Man-Made Miracle on 42d Street,'' May 23). I've ridden in its commodious Pullmans, carpeted lounge car and streamlined diner regularly over the last six years. If Mr. Goldberger would care to drop by Track 18 about 6:30 P.M., he will see a train that is considerably more grand than the 4:05 to Stamford. GUY LUDWIG, Roosevelt Island, N.Y.

title: Red Sox Set Back Twins
description: A two-run single by Rick Miller, two sacrifice flies by Dave Stapleton and a home run by Dwight Evans lifted the Boston Red Sox to a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

title: CONVENTION COUNTDOWN
description: HARTFORD ALL the months of planning, speech-making and wooing of delegates will come down over the next two weekends to a few crucial roll-call votes that will shape the course of the statewide election campaigns for both parties for the rest of this year. It is state convention time again in Connecticut. Political conventions have become anachronisms in some states where the parties rely more on primary elections to choose their candidates. But here the convention system remains strong, and it is rare for a candidate for statewide office to be unseated in a primary election after winning the endorsement of a majority of the convention delegates.

title: Mailbox; A Flimsy Defense Of College Sports
description: To The Sports Editor: The article by President Atchley of Clemson (''Keep the Pros Out of Colleges,'' The New York Times, July 4), boils down to a transparent defense of big-time, big-income professional collegiate athletics. It seems it's O.K. if it's under the close supervision of the institution's administration. But aren't the people who are currently fostering professional collegiate athletics already under the close supervision of the same supervision of the same administrations President Atchley wants to put in charge?

title: GOOD REPORT FOR CLASS OF '82
description: IT is said that teen-agers today are growing up faster than desirable and that the results bode ill for the future of the United States.

title: Susan Gail Smith To Wed Tax Aide
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Smith of Louisville, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Gail Smith, to Steven Jay Linder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome G. Linder of New York.

title: A Sudden Need For a Successor
description: The echo of campaign slogans often mocks successful candidates, butPresident Antonio Guzman's ''change without violence'' proved especially poignant. The 71-year-old leader of the Dominican Republic, reportedly upset by family problems, last week shot himself in the head and died hours later in a Santo Domingo hospital.

title: ROOSEVELT ISLAND
description: FOR most of its history, Roosevelt Island would have been a good s etting for a Dickens novel. By the end of the 19th century the 1 47-acre island had a penitentiary, a workhouse, an almshouse for NewY ork City's poor and a hospital for incurables.
