Although its old b uildings had grown obsolete by the 1920's, when it was known as W elfare Island, it was still a principal lodging place for the i ndigent.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: HONDURAS REPORTED TO SEIZE REBEL ARMS
description: After two battles with Honduran rebels in the capital of Tegucigalpa, Honduran Government forces have uncovered a large cache of arms and other equipment, United States military analysts said today. The analysts said the equipment was apparently intended for shipment to leftist insurgents in El Salvador.

title: IT SEEMS LIKE A GROUP, BUT IT'S ONE ZESTFUL SINGER
description: MONTAUK PROMOTERS and club owners are notorious for exaggerating the talents of their artists. Thus a description by the co-owner of Waves, a Montauk club, of Julie Farbolin, singer and songwriter, as ''a combination of Janis Joplin and Stevie Nicks'' who ''packs the place every time she plays there'' was met with more than a little skepticism. But the reservations turned out to be largely unwarranted.

title: Gentrifying The South Bronx
description: The Bronx doesn't need unemployed post-abstractionist artists or other noblesse oblige types to upgrade the area (''Gentrifying the South Bronx,'' Guest Observer, by Richard F. Shepard, May 23). Sections of the borough are already handsomely developed, with many universities and bilingual colleges, medical centers, bustling shopping areas, numerous parks, beaches and recreation areas, a breathtaking zoo and botanical garden, inexpensive and spacious apartments and quaint brownstones, Art Deco lobbies, synagogues and churches.

title: POLITICAL VICTIM: THE DREAM THAT WAS THE A.I.A.W.
description: IT began as the dream of a few women physical education leaders. The goal was development of an athletic governance model designed for female student-athletes that reflected in every detail the notion that competitive sports experiences enhance the education of females. Thus, the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women was born in 1971.

title: The Very Rich Ivan Lendl
description: What's so wrong with pro tennis today was summed up by lawyer-agent Donald Dell when he asserted: ''The important thing about Ivan (Lendl) is that at the age of 22, he is already a tennis millionaire several times over'' (''Ivan Lendl Battles to be No. 1,'' by Judy Klemesrud, May 16). Donald Dell didn't say that the important thing is that Ivan Lendl is a man who keeps his word or who is a credit to the game.

title: Patricia Nelson Wed To Jeffrey R. Merrill
description: Patricia Mary Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Nelson of Middlebury, Vt., and Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey R. Merrill, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Merrill of Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. James H. Mattison performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Middlebury.

title: Q/A
description: Question:My husband and I would like to spend several months on Mallorca or on the Costa del Sol this winter. Where can we get information on renting accommodations in these areas? - H.D.S., Copake, N.Y. Answer:A spokesman for the Spanish National Tourist Office (665 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022; 212-759-8822) provided the names of three agencies that can arrange an apartment or house rental for you on Mallorca or the Costa del Sol:

title: Topics; ESTHETIC CHOICES; Air Waves
description: It probably is too much to expect New York City authorities to emulate the civilized ways of their British counterparts by banning radios from public parks and then enforcing the rule.

title: It's O.K. to Feel 8.2 Percent Safer
description: The cause may be debatable and the effect temporary, but it was good news regardless: Violent crime reported in New York City declined 8.2 percent in the first four months of this year from the comparable period of 1981.

title: NEIL DOUGLAS MCDONOUGH TO WED LISA MEREDITH HILL
description: Dr. and Mrs. Lyndon Marcus Hill of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Meredith Hill, to Neil Douglas McDonough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mules McDonough of Paxton, Mass.

title: TALKS IN LEBANON STALLED AS P.L.O. SEEKS CONCESSIONS
description: Negotiations for a settlement of the Lebanon crisis made little headway today, amid indications that the Palestine Liberation Organization has no intention of withdrawing from Beirut without major political concessions.

title:
INVESTING;
MEASURING THE MOOD OF THE MARKET
description: WHEN the Dow Jones industrial average slid below 790 in mid-June a nd investors wondered if the bottom was about to fall out of the m arket, Richard McCabe, chief technical analyst with Merrill Lynch, w as not overly concerned. One of his most trusted indicators - the a ctivity of retail cash investors - told him that the market's s elling spree had just about run its course.

title: WETLANDS INSTITUTE GROWING PAINS AT 10
description: STONE HARBOR THE Wetlands Institute, which is tucked away amid the tall plume grass along the boulevard between the Garden State Parkway and Stone Harbor, will begin celebrating this week the 10th anniversary of its efforts to preserve undeveloped areas of New Jersey's seashore.

title: A WORLD WITH FEWER NUMBERS
description: WASHINGTON GOVERNMENT statisticians, who now seem to be churning out an endless array of numbers on the sputtering American economy, may soon be charting their own waning fortunes if President Reagan's budget cutters have their way. It's just such a prospect that has aroused the ire of thousands of Federal number crunchers, as well as businessmen, academics, Congressmen and even farmers, who all fear that the timeliness, accuracy and very existence of many statistics gathered by the Government are now threatened.

title: HOW MITTERRAND'S PET IDEA BECAME A MONSTER
description: Henry IV thought Paris was worth a mass. Francois Mitterrand seems to have thought it worth a mess, though not as big, apparently, as the one he stirred up 12 days ago by proposing to divide the City of Light into 20 60-watt municipalities.

title: Miss Brewer Is Betrothed
description: Norma Flicker Brewer and Dr. Timothy F. Brewer 3d, both of Old Saybrook, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Marie Brewer, to John Morris MacKenna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil S. MacKenna of Beverly Farms, Mass.

title: Judy Lynn Stein Engaged To Andrew D. Lipschitz
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Stein of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judy Lynn Stein, to Andrew David Lipschitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Lipschitz, also of New Rochelle.

title: Cosmos' Rally Tops Sting, 2-1
description: Vladislav Bogicevic assisted Julio Romero and Steve Wegerle on the tying and winning goals in the final seven minutes tonight to give the Cosmos a 2-1 triumph over the Chicago Sting in a North American Soccer League game.

title: AN ALL-ARGENTINE FINAL IN SWISS TENNIS
description: Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc made it an all-Argentine final at the $100,000 Swiss Open tennis championships today.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: very large, 39 in full color, 106 in high-gloss black-and-white - are ''stunningly beautiful ... breathtaking.''

title: HOLLYWOOD LEAVES ITS IMPRINT ON ITS CHRONICLERS
description: Actors are potentially our best film historians: They're in an ideal position to describe both the thoughts and feelings that go into the filmmaking process. But more often than not, as anyone familiar with performers' own accounts of their experiences must know, the opportunity is wasted. Movie stars' memoirs are all too frequently given over to idle gossip, self-congratulation and rambling reminiscences.

title: ISRAELIS CHARGE PALESTINIAN USE OF MERCENARIES
description: Israel has given United States intelligence officials documents and other information obtained in Lebanon indicating that mercenaries from India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and various African nations were fighting with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: SLAIN BULLY'S TOWN LOOKS BACK WITHOUT PITY
description: It has been a year since Kenneth Rex McElroy, described as the town bully, was shot to death on the main street of this farming community. Despite two grand jury investigations, no one has been charged in the killing. Few residents seem to care.

title: BATTLE CONTINUES OVER DUMP SITE
description: WASHINGTON CONNECTICUT and New York officials are engaged in a legal and legislative battle over a decision to allow dredged sediment to be dumped near lobster breeding grounds in Long Island Sound.

title: U.S. ECONOMIC VIEW TILTED TO OPTIMISM
description: The Reagan Administration, in its midyear economic forecast, has a relatively optimistic outlook for growth through next year, Administration economists said today. But the forecast still predicts that unemployment will be over 9 percent at the end of this year and will average just below 8.5 percent in 1983.

title: SUMMER JOBS PLAN AIDING 80 STUDENTS
description: WHEN Alexander Adair, a 16 year old, graduates from Sleepy Hollow High School in North Tarrytown in another year, he will have earned almost enough money from his summer employment to meet his future college expenses.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IN his studies of insect life at the University of Connecticut, Raymond J. Pupedis, a graduate student, has had occasion to photograph many insects both in the field and in the laboratory. But it wasn't until earlier this year that his fast camera work paid off handsomely.

title: Ellie Weld To Be Bride Of A.C. Tilt
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. Weld Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Ludington Weld, to Alexander Chester Tilt, son of Albert Tilt 3d of Tetonia, Idaho, formerly of Greenwich, and the late Cornelia Murray of Jupiter, Fla.

title: The Downside Risk of Gold Includes Death
description: The sharp drop in gold prices has thrust South Africa into recession and diminished its power to buy racial and labor peace in the gold mines around Johannesburg. Strikes and riots erupted last week at a half dozen mines.

title: VOUCHERS AS AID TO EDUCATION
description: RECENT events continue to plague the Guaranteed Tax Base, Connecticut's plan for distributing state aid to local schools. The formula is very complex; new mistakes in the calculation of grants to towns surfaced last month. Leading politicians, including Governor O'Neill, call for simplification. Funding has increased dramatically. Yet the formula has not stopped cancellation of excellent educational programs, even in those cities and towns that supposedly have benefited most. The best-known example is Hartford, where financial exigencies have forced the Board of Education to eliminate Project Concern for all but a few students.

title: SHOCK OF WAR COULD IMPROVE OPPORTUNITIES FOR DIPLOMACY
description: WASHINGTON AMID the bloodshed and confusion of the Lebanon crisis, the Reagan Administration may have happened on a course that, while full of obvious risks, holds out the prospect of some windfalls for American objectives not anticipated when Israel invaded Lebanon more than a month ago.

title: GRAND ILLUSION: THE FIRST NOVEL
description: LIFE comes complete with all sorts of illusions, beginning with Santa Claus and continuing. ''When I get my driver's license,'' the child cries, ''I'll be free forever.'' ''When my divorce is final I'll be free.'' So we hear: when the boss retires, when Election Day comes, when we sell the house, when I get my degree.

title: FOR WOMEN, CROSS-CULTURAL TRIP TO LIMBO
description: Whenever Shehla Mushtaq, a 22-year-old graduate student in engineering at Texas Tech University, flies home to Pakistan, she knows she must do more than change from blue jeans to the baggy cotton pants and sheath traditional for Pakistani women.

title: Sports of the Times; PADRES' PRESENT INCLUDES A FUTURE
description: DOWN on the field at Shea Stadium, the present and the past of the San Diego Padres were only about 50 feet apart - the distance between Manager Dick Williams in the Padres' dugout and Frank Howard, the Padres' manager last year who now is the Mets' third-base coach. But for a change, the Padres' present also includes a future.

title: Cody Case Is Marked Closed
description: The question of whether John Cardinal Cody committed a crime in diverting church funds died when he did, in April. The question of whether others connected to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago acted improperly was laid to rest last week, when United States Attorney Dan K. Webb said he would close the case without seeking indictments.

title: ARGENTINA'S 'SEVERELY DILUTED NATIONAL CHARACTER'
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; A BALL INSTEAD OF A GUN
description: One thing that makes Americans different from practically everybody else in the world is lack of passion for soccer (which everybody else calls football, or even futbol). So it's not easy to understand the fever, the fury, the joy and the disgust that the World Cup in Madrid has provoked this past couple of weeks. It's already something of a disappointment for a lot of fans that the finalists are Germany and Italy -no Latin Americans, no Arabs, no Africans to make the championship match a real contest of continents.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $98,000 6 Clover Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old bilevel; *2*fenced yard, storage shed; taxes $2,418. Edison $105,000 19 Timber Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old split-level; *2*central airconditioning, patio; taxes $1,781. Metuchen $55,000 7 Tulsa Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, half-century-old two-story house; *2*enclosed proch, window air-conditioning unit; taxes $1,200. Milltown $94,000 11 Mary Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old two-story house; *2*central airconditioning, redwood deck; taxes $720. Piscataway $76,000 109 Wyckoff Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split-level; *2*one-car garage, near swim club; taxes $1,579. Woodbridge $70,500 77 Elmont Place *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; one-car garage, *2*window air-conditioning unit; taxes $1,331. OTHER AREAS Mamaroneck, N.Y. $70,000 Barry Avenue North *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 175-year-old colonial; *2*breakfast room-den, porch, new wiring; taxes $1,700. Brookfield, Conn. $97,250 5 Beech Tree Road North *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old Cape Cod; central air- *2*conditioning, two acres, 80 days on market; taxes $1,430. Patchogue, L.I. $51,900 7 Hill Street *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; eat-in *2*kitchen, formal dining room, full basement; taxes $2,000.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST FLOWERS FOR SUMMER CUTTING
description: ONE nice thing about summer is that flowers can be picked from one's own garden, and those who have planned and planted with this purpose in mind should have a house full by now.

title: Roop Rows to Victory
description: Scott Roop of Syracuse won the lightweight single final today in the United States Rowing Trials on the Cooper River. Roop covered the 2,000-meter course in 7 minutes 42.9 seconds and earned the right to compete in the world championships in August in Lucerne, Switzerland. Bill Beldon, a former world champion from Philadelphia, finished second in 7:47.1.

title: SALES DECLINE DIMS RECOVERY PROSPECT
description: The nation's largest retailers announced that sales were down in June, dashing hopes for a strong second-quarter recovery. Sears and K Mart reported sales declines of 1 and 1.2 percent, respectively, while other retailers, including J.C. Penney and Woolworth, reported slight gains. In another sign of sluggish consumer buying, sales of new cars by the Big Three domestic auto makers were down 17.5 percent in the final 10 days of June.

title: YANKEES RISK THE FUTURE
description: WILLIE McGEE, now the National League's leading hitter, said he had t wo chances of winning a job with the Yankees -''slim and none.'' S cott McGregor, now one of the best pitchers in the American League, r emembered that he was depressed when a Yankee trade for an e stablished left-handed pitcher ''killed my chances.''

title: YOUNG LIFE IN THE THEATER
description: IT is not a typical Saturday morning at Fox Lane Middle School in Bedford. Bright with lights, the Little Theatre is filled with young bodies sprawled contentedly on the floor, their noses buried in playbooks. The sounds of country fiddles and the unfamiliar twanging accent of early rural America filters through the dialogue as the first rehearsal of the New Youth Performing Theater's 1982 season begins.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 11, 1982
description: International OPEC members could not agree at a meeting in Vienna on how to hold down production in order to prevent oil prices from falling. The gathering marked the first time that a meeting of the 13-member cartel failed to result in any form of agreement. This means that production limits that were in effect would now be voided, at least temporarily. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Negotiations in Lebanon made no progress and there were indications that the Palestine Liberation Organization has no intention of withdrawing from Beirut without some major political concessions. Meanwhile, Israeli forces and P.L.O. fighters exchanged intermittent artillery fire after a night a fierce Israeli shelling that inflicted widespread damage. (1:1.)

title: JAZZ: THE GULLY LOW BAND
description: The Friday night assignment at the Red Blazer Too, the restaurant on Third Avenue near 88th Street that has a band more or less permanently assigned to each night in the week, has been taken over for the summer by the Gully Low Jazz Band, a six-piece group that is, basically, a Dixieland band in style but is much more vital and rhythmically rugged than that label usually suggests.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART It's not every gallery that makes a particular effort in high summer. All the more reason, therefore, to congratulate the Alexander Milliken Gallery, 98 Prince Street, on having asked Ed Baynard to curate the show that can be seen there through Friday next.

title: AT MOTOR VEHICLE OFFICE, THE WAIT GOES ON
description: WESTBURY FOURTEEN months after the installation of a new computer system that was intended to expedite the processing of license plates and automobile registrations, delays and frequent computer failures still plague the state motor vehicle office here, and lines of irritated motorists still stretch out onto the sidewalk in front of the building.

title: IN JUDGING ISRAEL'S ACTION, GET LEBANON'S REALITIES STRAIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Italian Premier Gains Reprieve for Coalition
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini gained another reprieve for his shaky five-party coalition today when the Senate approved tough new economic measures in a vote of confidence.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A JACKPOT OF SORTS IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE glitter of the gambling casinos, with their spinning roulette wheels, the shouts of craps players and the clatter of slot machines, seems an unlikely background for antiques. But a short ride up an escalator from several gaming rooms can lead you to some fine antiques.

title: ISRAEL STEPS UP DRIVE AGAINST P.L.O. ON WEST BANK
description: Occupied West Bank, July 10 - With its troops on the verge of victory in Lebanon, Israel has opened a political front against the Palestine Liberation Organization in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: MUSIC: BENEFIT FOR BORICUA
description: Puerto Rico's opera singers came to the rescue of a Puerto Rican educational institution Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. The benefit - featuring 14 singers, three conductors and an orchestra - was to raise money for New York's Boricua College, a bilingual institute that was damaged heavily by fire earlier this year. One can only hope some money was made. The hall was distressingly empty at 8 P.M. but filled somewhat as the evening wore on.

title: Umpires Are Named
description: Doug Harvey of the National League will umpire in in his fifth All-Star Game Tuesday night in Montreal when he works behind home plate. The umpiring crew, announced Saturday by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, will also have John McSherry (second base) and Ed Montague (left field) from the National League, and Marty Springstead (first base), Jim McKean (third base) and Mike Reilly (right field) of the American League.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN WHEREVER you live, there must be at least one somewhere in your town. Community life as we know it who have come to the Island from Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx (funny thing: I can't think of a soul out here who came from Staten Island) does not exist without that most important institution, the neighborhood candy store.

title: EDITOR'S COICE
description: 1954, edited by Elliott Mossman. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Letters exchanged between the Russian poet and his cousin.

title: IN COUNTRY'S SERVICE
description: Country music runs in the Sterling family. Slim Sterling, a squaredance caller known throughout the Northeast, will preside over the doh-see-doh's at 8:15 every Friday evening beginning this week through Aug. 13 at Kensico Dam Plaza.

title: Brooklyn Conversion; Arsenal Redux
description: After a five-year negotiating seige, the Brooklyn Arsenal Building has fallen to Herbert and Henry Mandel. The Mandels, pere and fils of a family that has been building in New York for four generations, purchased the former World War II armory in Sunset Park from New York State for $700,000 and plan to convert it into back-office and computer space renting for less than $10 a square foot.

title: Commuters Speeded
description: Most patrons at the commuter train station here ignore the novel regulatory signs, silhouettes of a man wearing a hat and of a woman in curlers.

title: Beth Titunik Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Beth Titunik to Phillip D. Emery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Emery of Garden City, Mich., has been announced by the bride-to-be's father, Alan Titunik of New York. Miss Titunik, daughter also of Elizabeth C. Titunik of Oakland, N.J., is a speech pathologist with the school system of Silver City, N.M., where her fiance is an assistant football coach at Western New Mexico University. Miss Titunik's father is director of fixed-income research with Jesup & Lamont Securities Company Inc.

title: DEMOCRATS COUNTER ENTRENCHED G.O.P.
description: THE Democrats, a party distinctly in the minority on Long Island, have had difficulty in recent years fielding credible challengers to well-entrenched Republican Representatives. As a result, some of the candidates for Congress in Long Island districts can sometimes be considered sacrificial lambs.

title: COSTS AND TENSIONS CUT IN MINE MEDIATIONS PLAN
description: New labor-management ideas are taking an unexpected hold on the slopes of the hostile Appalachian coal fields. Innovation appears to be slowly changing a mining industry whose labor relations have long been described as dismal.

title: JACKSON HAPPY, BUT STILL MISSES YANKEES
description: Reggie Jackson says it's great here, it's lovely, it's close to home and his friends, the owner's great. But ....

title: Tower Topped Off
description: Though the official ''topping-off'' ceremony will not be held until July 26, anyone gazing up at Trump Tower at 56th Street and Fifth Avenue can plainly see that the 68-story, 700-foot structure has reached its full height. By far the tallest concrete building in the world, according to its developer, Donald J. Trump, its superstructure took 90,000 tons of concrete and 4,000 tons of steel reinforcing rods to complete.

title: PROGRESS 'IN PRINCIPLE,' DYING IN THE MEANTIME
description: Siege or slaughter? Hoping to end the one and avoid the other, President Reagan last week agreed ''in principle'' to send American troops to help gain the withdrawal of Palestinian and Israeli forces from Beirut. France also offered ''in principle'' to contribute troops.

title: HAS ISRAEL ALTERED ITS VISIONS?
description: Amos Oz, the Jerusalem-born Israeli novelist, lives on a kibbutz, where he divides his time between writing, teaching and working on the land.

title: Regarding Rents And Co-op Prices
description: As a tenant who held jobs for 30 years in the economics field, I have comments on Charles F. Kaufman's letter (June 13) not covered by Kenneth J. Gould's article (Opinion Page, May 23) to which he refers.

title: POLAND TAKES 3D PLACE
description: Poland fought back with three goals in three minutes and went defeated France, 3-2, tonight for third place in the World Cup soccer tournament.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: THE most interesting artists develop their own unmistakable vernacular. It is an individual pictorial language composed of forms and colors that they have invented and assembled to suit their own spirits.

title: When Johnny Blood Rode
description: JOHN BLOOD MCNALLY, hearing the news about the current drug scandals in professional football, recalls his own use of stimulants. He does not claim to be the first football player ever to take drugs. But he says he never heard of anyone taking them before him.

title: U.N.'s Special Session On Disarmament Ends
description: The special session on disarmament ended today without producing a comprehensive program for arms reduction and control.

title: CONSUMER GUIDE TO LUGGAGE
description: KAY ELDREDGE writes on travel for national magazines.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Sports-Store Sale In Ardsley

title: Berra Leads Pirates Past the Braves, 6-1
description: Don Robinson of Pittsburgh, who failed to win a game last year when he was handicapped by injuries, joined the National League's 10-game winners tonight. He limited Atlanta to eight hits in eight and one-third innings and doubled home the first two runs as the Pirates defeated the Braves, 6-1.

title: SEXIST SYMBOLS: GOOD FOR GANDER, NOT THE GOOSE
description: IHAVE no objection to use of the words mankind, chairman, etc., to designate women as well as men. They may keep on calling the furies Maria, and I still address letters to ''Gentlemen'' and ''Dear Sir'' of companies whose management is unknown.

title: Letters; A 'Rape' of Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dartmouth Dodge
description: Like crafty tax lawyers who pry open new loopholes even as Congress closes others, private colleges are scrambling to stay ahead of Federal cuts in student aid. The newest example is Dartmouth, which recently persuaded a New Hampshire state agency to float a taxexempt bond on its behalf. The proceeds are for student loans.

title: Connecticut U. Votes 37% Tuition Increase
description: The University of Connecticut's board of trustees has approved the largest tuition increase in the school's history, raising undergraduate tuition for in-state students to $940, or 37 percent, for the 1983-84 academic year.

title: EXHIBITION FULFILLS ITS PROMISE
description: ROSLYN THE current exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art provides a memorable artistic experience. Celebrating the last century of art, the show, composed of exceptional works lent by Long Island collectors, is the most rousing and ambitiously beautiful, the most edifying and esthetically gratifying I have seen in some time on the Island.

title: HOW MUCH DOES DANCE OWE TO JOOSS?
description: The return of Expressionism in dance is a trend that bears watching at this time. After three decades of dance in which formal values have predominated or in which psychological concerns have been conveyed in symbolic or metaphoric frameworks, Expressionism - in its primary concern with emotional impact - is coming back to the fore. It is present in the work of Jiri Kylian, the artistic director of the Netherlands Dance Theater, which opens Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. And if one is to single out the most talked-about choreographer in Europe, then Pina Bausch, a neo-Expressionist, is that choreographer.

title: Reagan Nominates Abortion Foe For Commission
description: President Reagan continues to emphasize the need for new blood in the Civil Rights Commission, but critics contend that transfusions have already severely weakened it.

title: THEATER: 'TWELFTH NIGHT' STAGED IN PROSPECT PARK
description: Shakespeare & Company has turned a corner of Brooklyn's Prospect Park into a magic grove for a ''Twelfth Night'' with the kind of rowdy comedy and direct appeal that the Globe's productions were said to have had in Shakespeare's day.

title: INCUMBENCY IS LIMITED ASSET FOR O'NEILL
description: HARTFORD HAVING inherited the job two years ago, Connecticut Gov. William A. O'Neill would like nothing better than to win a term of his own. Five challengers (one a member of the Governor's own party) contend he doesn't deserve it. And although the polls give Mr. O'Neill a healthy lead, he concedes it is too early in the race to take much comfort in them.

title: AWAITING THE NEXT OIL CRISIS
description: Near the end of a recent visit to the United States, the president of a national oil company in a member nation of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries wrote out a list for his hosts: a shale-oil project in Colorado, a coal project in West Virginia, a tar-sands oil-extraction program in Canada, the Alaska natural-gas pipeline. ... The list went on. Beside each item he wrote one of three words - ''delayed,'' ''postponed'' or ''canceled.''

title: WHAT'S DOING ON DEER ISLE
description: BETSY WADE is an editor on the national desk of The New York Times. BY BETSY WADE

title: JEWISH 'CENSUS' ON THE ISLAND IS FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: THE recent finding by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies that there are 425,700 Jews in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, or one-third fewer than was generally assumed, has shaken local Jewish leaders.

title: Outdoors; THE STRIPED BASS AND WESTWAY
description: CONCERN for the striped bass continues to help protect the Hudson River from further degradation. The most recent instance of this was the decision of Judge Thomas P. Griesa in Federal District Court in Manhattan late last month that blocks, for the time being, all Federal funds for New York City's Westway project.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: JODY E. SMITH ENGAGED TO MICHAEL W. BROMLEY
description: Joan P. Smith of Westport, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jody Elizabeth Smith, to Michael Wesley Bromley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Bromley of Norwich, Conn.

title: Sports People; Pessimistic Agent
description: Jerry Argovitz, the agent for Walter Abercrombie and Jim McMahon, the No. 1 choices of the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Chicago Bears in the National Football League draft, says that he believes neither of his clients will come to terms before the expiration on Thursday of the collective bargaining agreement between the league and the National Football League Players Association. He said yesterday that he would seek a court ruling on Friday that would grant free-agent status to all his unsigned clients on the ground that the expiration of the bargaining agreement would void the draft, a provision of the agreement.

title: Economic Crises
description: To the Business Editor: It is hard to imagine a more striking picture of the crises and opportunities facing the American economy than that afforded in recent weeks.

title: POP GUITAR: PAT METHENY AT THE PIER
description: Pat Metheny's effervescent guitar melodicism has won him a sizable rock following in recent years. But as his quintet's stylistically eclectic performance at the Pier on Wednesday showed, Mr. Metheny's trademark -watery-timbred electric guitar scampering about conversationally -represents only one aspect of his group's current sound.

title: A WRITER'S PARADISE?
description: To the Editor:

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
TROUBLE AT THE FLAT EARTH SOCIETY
description: (The following is an abbreviated version of the address delivered to the Flat Earth Society by the chairman of the Navigational Reserve System.)FLAT EARTH delegates, welcome. We are witnessing troubled times in t he steerage of our nation. Profound intellectual confusion a ccompanies increasing disruption of the communications network. The b urden of tolls and traffic rules is growing; accidents are on the i ncrease; fundamental navigational principles are being challenged.

title: Leslie Burr Captures Jumpoff at Lake Placid
description: Leslie Burr of Westport, Conn., edged out Katie Monahan of Upperville, Va., by six-tenths of a second to capture the feature class today at the I Love New York Horse Show in Lake Placid.

title: UNFIT FOR POVERTY
description: A man whose job is to help the poor tells me the current recession has produced a new class of citizens. He calls them ''unskilled paupers.'' They are people who spent all their lives working at jobs and consequently never had time to master the arts of poverty.

title: ROGERS CONFIDENT FOR BRITISH OPEN
description: A year ago, by his own description, Bill Rogers was ''this little ol' kid from Texarkana, not having done much, just chipping away, not getting excited and making a nice living on the tour.''

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
REVALUATIONS STUN HACKENSACK CO-OPS
description: RESIDENTS of five cooperatives in Hackensack are still reeling from the city's tax revaluations f ollowing the recent conversions of their buildings. This year marks t he buildings' debut on the tax rolls as cooperatives, and the i ncreases in assessments range from $2.5 million to about $5.6 m illion.

title: METS TOP PADRES ON HOMERS, 9-7
description: Midway through a season laced with unfulfilled expectations, a sellout crowd of 55,515 at Shea Stadium was finally treated last night to the kind of power they had always hoped to see. And the Mets' hitters supplied the electricity.

title: Sports People; Campbell's New Agents
description: Earl Campbell, the star running back of the Houston Oilers, has announced that he has ended his association with Witt Stewart, a talent agent in Austin, Tex., and he has instead contracted with five firms in Houston to handle his business affairs.

title: ARAFAT LEADS THE P.L.O. INTO TOUGHEST SALVAGE OPERATION
description: BEIRUT LEBANON THE relationship between a leader and his people is often revealed by small gestures. Yasir Arafat's relationship to the Palestinians remaining in besieged west Beirut was illuminated by a scene following an Israeli aerial bombardment last week. The Israelis had blown up an apartment house in the Fakhani quarter. A corner building, it looked like a slice of cake someone had smashed with a fist. Trapped inside were many civilians, including an old woman's four children. She was wailing outside the twisted debris when Mr. Arafat came walking down the street accompanied by two guards and trailed by neighborhood folk. As soon as she spotted him, the old woman stopped crying, ran up and kissed his forehead. ''I lost four of my family inside,'' she said, ''but I have nine more and they are all for you.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Votes in Congress last Sunday incor- rectly characterized Senate votes on two amendments, one intended to pro- vide more money for the summer jobs program for youths, the other to set up a program to subsidize residential mortages. The votes were on motions to table the amendments, and the senators who voted against the mo- tions in fact supported the amend- ments.

title: SCHOLARS IN THE MIDDLE OF BATTLES OVER INFORMATION
description: IT may have failed to persuade Congress that the Freedom of Information Act is too free, but that hasn't stopped the Reagan Adminstration from attempting to correct what it regards as the excesses of open government spawned by the law. An Executive Order on Classification promulgated this spring, for example, gives officials broader authority to withhold information on the ground of national security. Budget cuts are restricting the compilation and dispersal of Government statistics and slowing declassification of documents at the National Archives. And last month, Mr. Reagan signed a measure making it a crime to disclose the identity of covert agents. These moves have troubled press and public affairs groups, but they are especially vexing to Federal historians, who must mediate between the often conflicting demands of the agencies they work for, outsiders who come to them for information and, of course, history itself. At a recent meeting of The Society for History in the Federal Government, Allen Weinstein, a historian and professor at Georgetown University and executive editor of The Washington Quarterly, Alfred Goldberg, chief historian in the office of the Secretary of Defense, and Quinlan J. Shea Jr., former director of the Office of Privacy and Information Appeal and currently director and counsel for the Justice Department's Executive Office for United States Trustees, discussed the dilemmas confronting Federal historians. Excerpts follow.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HOUSES WELL-WORTH A VISIT
description: CONNECTICUT has a treasure trove of old and distinguished houses - enough so that a post-office village cannot be found where there is no historic homestead to which residents can point with pride. One of the paradoxes of Connecticut community life, however, is that all too often many residents are content with pointing and seldom visit their own museum house, just down the road or across the green.

title: SPREADING HYDRO PLANS
description: Those who suggest that Big Government has sapped America's entrepreneurial spirit should note the activity in the hydroelectric industry, which generates about 13 percent of the nation's electricity. Over the past few years, new Federal laws have made entry into the hydro industry, long dominated by giant public and private utility companies, easier for the small businessman.

title: STORIES TO PIQUE A LISTENER'S IMAGINATION
description: IF things go well Friday and Saturday nights, a few minutes after the five featured performers in the Long Island Storytelling Festival take the stage, they will disappear.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Waiting to Hear From One's Child
description: I was absolutely appalled at the lack of feelings shown in the letters in answer to Elizabeth Timmes's article on Mother's Day (''The Call That Didn't Come,'' Opinion Page).

title: West Virginia's Taj Mahal
description: Adorned with gold and decorated within with precious wood, marble, onyx and stained glass, the palace - perched on a hillside and reached through towering gates embellished with gilded metal roses and lotus blossoms - sits amid landscaped hills where walkways wind through vast gardens. At night the waters of more than a hundred fountains play beneath soft lights.

title: JOHN BISHOP TO MARRY PAMELA NOEL GANNON
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Vincent N. Gannon of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Noel GAnnon, to John W. Bishop, son of Mr. an Mrs. Warren A. Bishop of Rodchester.

title: ANATOMY OF THE NUCLEAR PROTEST
description: Fox Butterfield is chief of The New York Times bureau in Boston. Randall Forsberg was born in Alabama with ''a few Georgia plantations ravaged by Sherman's troops floating around in my past.'' She graduated from Barnard College in the mid-1960's and became an English teacher at the proper Baldwin School in Bryn Mawr, Pa. There was little in her background to suggest that one day she would produce the idea that has turned the esoteric art of nuclear-arms control into an explosive popular issue.

title: MEDIATION, A NEW WAY TO DIVORCE
description: AFTER 15 years of marriage and two children, Grace and Stanley Miller are getting a divorce. Mr. Miller earns $50,000 a year and can well afford a lawyer, but the Millers are obtaining their divorce through a mediator for a fraction of the cost of two lawyers in an adversarial proceeding.

title: Wrong Message To the Soviets
description: I am writing to congratulate the people in Washington, Conn., for their wise and intelligent decision to reject the nuclear arms freeze resolution.

title: STUDY CALLS ON U.S. TO BRING GROUND TROOPS HOME
description: A new study published by the Institute of Foreign Policy Analysis here advocates withdrawing most United States ground forces from Europe and South Korea and relying more on sea power to defend American interests abroad.

title: PEEKSKILL PLANT, DESPITE RULING, MOVES ON
description: PEEKSKILL IF the county's garbage-recycling plan is having any difficulty, there is no sign of it here at the Hudson River construction site, where a plant to turn the county's garbage into steam and electricity is beginning to change the landscape.

title: Seniority Issue Divides Teachers
description: In school districts facing smaller budgets and dwindling enrollments, the practice of firing first the teachers who were hired last has become a double-edged sword. While cutting down teaching staffs it is also cutting into the numbers of newly hired black teachers, who usually have less seniority.

title: Nitz Captures Final In 1-Kilometer Cycling
description: Leonard Harvey Nitz of Flushing, Queens, captured the one-kilometer event in the 7-Eleven Bicycling Magazine grand prix finals at the Olympic Velodrome Friday night.

title: Empire State College Describes Program
description: In an otherwise excellent article on Long Island colleges' endeavors to hold the line on tuition, the accompanying map omitted Empire State College of the State University of New York.

title: In Connecticut; Landmark Fund
description: Connecticut landmarks have been known to walk. One historic building, an 18th-century colonial house in Newington, turned up as an antique shop in Colorado.

title: U.S. AND STATE NEARING SOLUTION ON NUCLEAR WASTE PILE
description: In a sealed carbon-steel tank here, encased in a concrete vault eight feet below the earth, is 560,000 gallons of poisonous waste, produced by the only commercial nuclear-fuel reprocessing plant ever to operate in the United States. The liquid will be dangerously radioactive for thousands of years; the tank has a life expectancy of 40.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The Tie-Ins of Summer

title: ALASKA COMBATING DRINKING PROBLEM
description: For years the problem of alcoholism, particularly among the state's natives, has been a scandal in Alaska. Now things may be changing in the 200 or so bush villages where most of the natives live.

title: AN ART CRITIC REVIEWS OSLO
description: JOHN CANADAY is the former art critic of The New York Times. His most recent book is ''What Is Art?'' (Knopf).

title: CUTBACKS PERIL DRUG-TREATMENT PROJECTS
description: CUTBACKS in Federal financing of programs that treat drug abusers - they have come at a time when addiction is increasing at an alarming rate and the demand is high for more prison space - have begun to seem like a paradox to some officials.

title: FRESH AIR SUMMER WORLD ONLY A BUS RIDE AWAY
description: They boarded the bus eagerly, with brown-bag lunches, detailed plans for their summer vacations and their mothers' admonition: behave.

title: Around the Nation; 10 From Ship Indicted In 'Voodoo' Killings
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted the cocaptains and eight crewmen of a Haiti-to-Miami ship that some passengers have said was the scene of voodoo sacrifices last October.

title: PARENTS' ROLE IN HIRING OF PRINCIPAL DISPUTED
description: A recent dispute over the appointment of a principal for a Brooklyn elementary school has focused attention on the process of selecting local school administrators under the city's decentralized school system.

title: 50 ARE SAID TO DIE IN BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: The Lebanese police reported today that 50 people were killed and as many as 200 wounded in the fierce rocket and artillery duels Friday night between Israeli and Palestinian forces.

title: GAG ORDER IMPOSED IN TRIAL OF EX-SAINT
description: A Federal judge has imposed a tough gag order for the scheduled Aug. 30 trial of Mike Strachan, the former New Orleans Saints running back who is charged with selling cocaine.

title: Karen Louise Gibson Is Bride of John J. Dickinson
description: Karen Louise Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Gibson of North Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to John Joseph Dickinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Dickinson of Hammonton, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Emanuel Lutheran Church in New Brunswick, N.J. by the Rev. Carol B. Goldstein, assisted by the Rev. James M. Clark, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Susan McCaslin Married in Ohio To Ph.D. Student
description: Susan Richardson McCaslin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. McCaslin Jr. of Glendale, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Victor William Henningsen 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henningsen of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Stewart Wood, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Hennigan, a Roman Catholic priest of Wappinger's Falls, N.Y.

title: LEMHI GOLD FIRST IN SWORD DANCER
description: Laz Barrera and Charlie Whittingham win so many stakes races in California that neither trainer ships his horses to New York unless he thinks he has the local talent over a barrel. Both trainers had the right idea in the $165,000 Sword Dancer Stakes on the grass yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: No Headline
description: The point raised in ''Foreign Aid Under Fire'' that family planning efforts in Bangladesh have been ''less than stunningly successful'' is certainly valid. But voluntary family planning programs must remain the first priority in development assistance for that country.

title: DEBATE ON SHOREHAM RATES INTENSIFIES
description: ALBANY THE Long Island Lighting Company's $2.63 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant has been the object of an extraordinary amount of debate. Last week, that debate even divided Governor Carey from one of his own appointees. And it led to some remarkable maneuvering in the closing hours of the 205th session of the State Legislature, which finally shut down for the summer last weekend.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST FLOWERS FOR SUMMER CUTTING
description: ONE nice thing about summer is that flowers can be picked from one's own garden, and those who have planned and planted with this purpose in mind should have a house full by now.

title: USE OF SHOT CLOCK IS GROWING
description: Mounting pressures to win have forced most college basketball coaches to play cautiously in recent seasons and to be overly protective of small leads. This tendency has produced fewer daring and aggressive offenses and more protective zone defenses against opponents equally leery of risking low-percentage long shots.

title: DAYTRIPS FOR FINE DINING OUTSIDE PARIS
description: PATRICIA WELLS, who lives in Paris, writes frequently on food for The Times. She is the restaurant critic of the International Herald Tribune.

title: PILOBOLUS: A DANCE GROUP CHANGING ITS OWN COURSE
description: WASHINGTON DEPOT HE is a dancer, this bearded, wild-haired young man who comes to the door of his 30-room Victorian home in the hills of northwestern Connecticut. His costume includes a formal bib shirt, bell-bottom trousers, white sneakers and a tattered, tweed sport coat.

title: MENTAL DEPRESSION AND ITS TREATMENT: MYSTERIES ABOUND
description: ''CANCER is the schizophrenia of the body just as schizophrenia is the cancer of the mind.'' This chilling statement has been indelibly etched in my memory ever since it was uttered by the novelist and social critic Norman Mailer in a discussion with the psychoanalyst Ronald Laing on television several years ago.

title: Honduran Commander Confirms Border Move
description: The commander of the Honduran armed forces confirmed today that he sent troops into disputed territory along the border with El Salvador last month. He said this was done to keep Salvadoran guerrillas out of Honduras.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN OF MANY ROLES IN COMPUTER FIELD
description: ''HOW big is the problem?'' asked Harold Joseph Highland of Elmont. ''Nobody wants to talk about it. The figures are wild - $100, $200, $300 million. Those of us who are in the field - only because people ask for a number do we pick a number out of a hat.''

title: IS THIS A DIFFERENT GEORGE C. SCOTT?
description: It is the first runthrough of ''Present Laughter,'' and George C. Scott, star and director of the Noel Coward comedy - which opens Thursday at the Circle in the Square - is talking to the rest of the cast and a small audience of friends. Wearing an old safari jacket and looking considerably more like General Patton than one of Coward's urbane sophisticates, he elicits a hushed, deferential response.

title: BURN-OUT SYNDROME
description: Some players are, beyond a doubt, much like horses. There are the mudders, for example, who like it best when everyone gets bogged down in draws and they can almost creep through to the wire. Their opposite numbers are the ones who want a fast track, where brilliance in winning many games far outweighs escaping a loss here or there.

title: Peter Smagorinsky Marries Anne Ellen O'Gorman
description: Anne Ellen O'Gorman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malachy T. O'Gorman of Kankakee, Ill., was married yesteday to Peter Smagorinsky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Smagorinsky of Princeton, N.J. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed in the Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago by the Rev. Derek Simons, assisted by Deacon Anthony Sabato, the bride's uncle.

title: Around the Nation; Chrysler Challenges U.S. On Change of Car Plans
description: The Chrysler Corporation is challenging a decision by the chief of the Government's General Services Administration to abolish plans to buy 1,174 Chrysler subcompact cars for $6.5 million.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: PUBLIC hearings will begin in several counties this week on two long-standing and controversial topics: The proposed criteria for siting hazardous-waste treatment facilities, and a legislative measure that would require return deposits on beverage cans and bottles.

title: RAISE DIVIDENDS, NOT RATES, CONSUMER UNIT TELLS CON ED
description: New York State's Consumer Protection Board contends that the Consolidated Edison Company could attract more investors and avoid any need for a new electric rate increase simply by paying higher dividends. The utility insists its policy is cautious and holds down borrowing.

title: THE O'CONNOR RECORD PROVES SURPRISING TO FANS AND FOES
description: Just before the Supreme Court began its end-of-term frenzy last month, Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor flew to California to give the commencement address at her alma mater, Stanford University.

title: BROADCASTER TELLS OF LIFE IN THE SOUND
description: PHIL CUTTING'S 22-foot open lobster boat, Shorewatch, was probably the only noncommercial boat on Long Island Sound at the height of Connecticut's devastating storm last month.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: O pportunities to buy air transportation at substantially less than established prices appear to be growing rapidly. For example, if you know where to look, you can:

title: BIOMEDICAL PROJECT HAS SPIRIT OF CAMP DAVID
description: Two scientists from Egypt and two from Israel are finishing their yearlong projects in a rare cooperative program between the two countries, in the area of biomedical research.

title: ESTHETIC CHOICES; Old Allies
description: At the Government level, British-U.S. relations may be strained, but in the July fields an old Anglo-American amity has been blossoming profusely. England's daisy and America's wild rose embroider the landscape with a dappled pattern of white and pink.

title: U.N. ENVOY SERVES NATION HE'S NEVER SEEN
description: He has never seen the palm-covered islands called Vanuatu in the South Pacific, but for more than nine months, Robert F. Van Lierop, a New York-born lawyer, has been representing that young Pacific country at the United Nations as well as tending to his Manhattan practice.

title: Anne Macleod Is Married
description: The marriage of Anne Macleod, daughter of the Rev. Donald Macleod of Princeton, and the late Norma Harper Macleod, to James Otis Weeks, took place yesterday in the chapel of Princeton University.

title: SALVADORAN REBELS: IDEOLOGY VS. UNITY
description: Although increasingly confident about its military capacity, El Salvador's guerrilla-led opposition coalition is still struggling to develop a coherent political and diplomatic response to the situation created by last March's elections.

title: DANCE: LAURA DEAN EXCERPTS
description: Artists who jump from medium to medium are a fixture of lower-Manhattan avant-gardism. In the case of composing choreographers, Meredith Monk led the way, but Laura Dean is not far behind.

title: Cureton of 76ers Suffers Fractured Bone in Foot
description: Earl Cureton, the Philadelphia 76ers' reserve center, fractured a bone in his left foot while jogging and will wear a cast for at least four weeks, a team spokesman said today.

title: Mailbox; Landon Turner And Celtic Pride
description: To the Sports Editor: In case anyone thinks that the Boston Celtics aren't really still the champions of the National Basketball Association, a franchise steeped in class and honor, all he or she has to do is take a look at the 10th-round draft choice of Red Auerbach and Company (''When Do I Report?'' The New York Times, July 5).

title: A YEAR LATER, WIFE OF A GUARD AT THE COUNTY JAIL RECALLS UPRISING
description: AS the first anniversary of the riot at the Westchester County Jail approaches, the memories again begin to haunt my mind. If only we were able to go back in time and erase those parts of our lives that hold the bad memories.

title: GREAT BARRINGTON, MASS.
description: From a distance, Aston Magna has the air of a summer camp - three tennis courts, a pond with ducks, energetic organizers with clipboards. At closer range, it resembles a rustic music conservatory - the buzz of instruments tuning up, esoteric conversations about bows and reeds and city-pale persons toting bass violins amid the trees in the Berkshire hills.

title: JUDY JAICKS BRIDAL IS SET FOR OCT. 10
description: Dr. and Mrs. John R. Jaicks of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judy L. Jaicks, to Tidal Windham McCoy, Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Manpower, Reserve Affairs and Installations. He is the son of Carolyn W. McCoy of Gainesville, Fla., and the late Van Quincy McCoy Jr.

title: UPWARD MOBILITY
description: In New York City's game of apartment renovation, walls virtually have become an endangered species, but ceilings have remained relatively sacrosanct. After all, one man's ceiling is another man's floor - unless, of course, the apartment in question is on the building's top floor. In that case, the ceiling may be fair game after all.

title: Karin Marilyn Adir Is Wed to M.J. Hume
description: Karin Marilyn Adir, daughter of Bernice Adir and Shillo Adir, both of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Hume, son of Paul Chandler Hume of Washington and the late Ruth Fox Hume.

title: CITY GAINS AID OF NEIGHBOR'S DEVELOPER
description: NEW LONDON FOR New London, the scenario was all too familiar. The city was about to lose Sears, Roebuck & Company, and possibly other stores, to the Crystal Mall, a $70 million regional shopping center planned just across the city line in Waterford.

title: Index; International
description: Honduras said to capture arms meant for Salvador rebels 3 Salvadoran guerrillas divided over issue of negotiations 3 Voice of America to broadcast more editorial opinion 4 Around the World 5 Study urges U.S. to pull ground forces out of Europe and Asia 7 A dam in the southern Philip- pines brings support for rebels 8 Study finds racial prejudices hin- der Soviet military 9 U.S. envoy meets with Syrian of- ficials to discuss Lebanon 10 Police report 50 dead in latest Is- raeli-P.L.O. fighting in Beirut 12 Israel waging political war against P.L.O. on West Bank 12 France agrees to send force to Lebanon 13 Government/Politics Dr. King visits Brooklyn to help register black voters 25 Jersey ruling clears way for trials of asbestosis lawsuits 28 Education/Welfare Parents' role in hiring of princi- pal in Brooklyn questioned 26 General Around the Nation 16 New mediation style cuts mine union costs and tensions 16 Atlanta gets crime foe to take down sign critical of city 16 Block to seek cut in wheat acre- age, aide says 16 Alaska acts to combat high rate of alcoholism 18 Investigators search for clue to cause of airliner crash 20 List of those aboard Pan Ameri- can jet that crashed Friday 20 A diplomat represents a country he has never seen 27 Religion Archbishop Bernardin chosen to succeed Cardinal Cody 17 Arts/Entertainment Organ series at Riverside 38 War is on the comeback trail at the Ritz 38 Bostonions open at Tanglewood 39 Excerpts of Laura Dean's work presented 39 ''Zulu Dawn'' at the Thalia 39 Wolf Trap Farm Park resumes, in a temporary structure 40 Annabelle Gamson recalls Dun- can days 40 Style For women, cross-cultural trip to limbo 41 Clue found to a pelvic ailment 41

title: FOSTER EAGLET
description: On April 12, a laboratory-born eaglet was introduced into the nest of New Jersey's only pair of nesting bald eagles, which for six years had been unable to produce a viable egg in their home in southern Cumberland County near the Delaware Bay.

title: Moore, Not Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Tours
description: To the Editor: The letter about the barred gates at the ancient monuments on Crete revived my feelings of intense frustration when in 1978, I viewed the Palace of Minos at Knossos through a wire fence.

title: City Council Meetings Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: MONDAY - Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, City Hall, 2 P.M. TUESDAY - Committee on Finance, City Hall, 10 A.M. Meeting of the full Council, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - Committee on Education, City Hall, 10 A.M. Committee on Youth Services, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. THURSDAY - Committees on Transportation and Public Safety, City Hall, 10 A.M. Committee on General Welfare, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY - Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, 250 Broadway, 23d-floor hearing room, 11:30 A.M.

title: TWO DEBUT ALBUMS IN SEARCH OF AN AUDIENCE
description: Since the music business, like the movie business, is ever more dependent on blockbuster successes to make a profit, many worthy original pop albums by obscure talents are having an increasingly hard time in the marketplace. This summer the record industry will be holding its breath to see if the latest albums by Fleetwood Mac, Donna Summer and REO Speedwagon turn into the commercial pop equivalents of movies like ''Rocky III,'' ''E.T.'' and ''Star Trek II,'' and help pull the business out of its slump. But what about the pop counterparts of movies like ''Diner'' and ''Diva''? What are the chances that they will find the smaller discriminating audiences they deserve?

title: THE ALL-STAR CITY HAS NO CHAMPION TO CALL ITS OWN
description: MONTREAL THIS diminishing city that I continue to cherish has hardly suffered from a surfeit of joy in recent years. For as long as I can remember we have been perversely proud to be the bank-robbery capital of North America, an average of two a day being burgled, an indicator that at least somebody out there is still interested in holding our ever-shrinking dollars. But now - with a tip of the toque to Premier Rene Levesque and his Separatist Parti Quebecois - we can also lay claim to paying the highest provincial income tax in Canada and forking out more for gas than anybody else on the continent.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Flying Solo

title: FROM CHORAL WORK TO BROADWAY HITS
description: JUST when the Pro Arte chamber singers thought it was safe to stop practicing for a while, the Flemish Choral Federation invited the Connecticut ensemble to sing this summer at the Cathedral in Brussels, to record for the national radio there, and to undertake concerts in several other Belgian cities.

title: Injured Bicycle Racer In Critical Condition
description: Barbara Buchan, who suffered head injuries in a bicycle race Friday, remained in critical condition today in Westlake Community Hospital's intensive care unit, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Sports People; Eye on Willhite
description: Ron Blanding, the owner of the Denver Gold of the newly formed United States Football League, said that his team ''will be talking to anybody not under contract'' and added that he might be interested in signing Gerald Willhite, a running back who was the No. 1 choice of the Denver Broncos in the N.F.L.'s college draft.

title: Cynthia Stock Is Married To David Campbell James
description: At Trinity United Methodist Church in Tallahassee, Fla., yesterday Cynthia E. Stock and David Campbell James, graduates of Florida State University, were married by the Rev. Walter Kalas.

title: Cornelia Beal, Trader, Wed to Peter P. Forrence
description: Cornelia L. Beal, a trader in the government securities department of Drexel Burnham Lambert, was married yesterday to Peter P. Forrence, a vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds.

title: Secrecy Shrouds a 'Star Wars' Sequel
description: CRESCENT CITY, Calif.  All the locals in this tiny (population 2,500) timber and fishing community know is that for some reason, a surprising number of strangers have moved into their midst, filling some of the motels and restaurants that would otherwise be empty in the worst recession since World War II. But until now, the inhabitants of this northernmost California town, where the official unemployment rate has topped 28 percent, have had no inkling of who the strangers are or why they are there. They have not known that practically in their own backyard, a $32.5 million film has been in production and that roughly $2 million of this amount is being spent right here on location, much of it on local salaries, food, lodging, transportation and materials.

title: Sarah R. Blodget Is Bride in Jersey Of Allen Sperry Jr.
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Sarah Richards Blodget, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden Sanford Blodget Jr. of Princeton and Annisquam, Mass., was married to Allen McBrier Sperry Jr., son of Mr. Sperry of Litchfield, Conn., and Robbie Oxnard of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Crocker, assisted by the Rev. Jack Miller, a Presbyterian minister.

title: WABC RADIO
description: In February, WABC, which had once been the most influential popular music radio station in the country, announced that it was switching to a format of talk programs and news.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
LONG 'WAR'
description: That Tolstoy's ''War and Peace'' is an epic, few will dispute. And the celebrated 1968 Soviet film version that cost $100 million to make over four years and walked off with all the major cinema awards is of epic proportions itself. Today, in one of its last showings on these shores before it heads back home, the six-hour film will be screened at the New Community Cinema in Huntington. However, mindful of the audience's needs, the cinema will show it in two sessions: Part I from 2 to 6 P.M. and then, after a dinner break, when viewers can picnic outdoors or dine at local restaurants, Part II will be shown from 7:30 to 9:45 P.M. The cinema is at 423 Park Avenue and admission is $3.50; $1.50 for children and the elderly; or $2 for members.SOLAR HOUSE

title: SIGN OF UNHAPPY DAYS FOR ATLANTA IS ERASED
description: The sign made city officials cringe. Vandals tried to sabotage it. The Chamber of Commerce wished it would go away. Finally it did.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
In Spain, A Soup Starring Garlic
description: ROBERT PACKARD teaches humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: OPEC SESSION FAILS TO REACH ACCORD ON CURBING OUTPUT
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended a two-day meeting late tonight in disarray over how to hold down production and prevent prices from falling.

title: Around the World; Iran Postpones the Trial Of Ex-Foreign Minister
description: The trial of former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, accused of organizing a plot to overthrow Iran's Government, has been indefinitely postponed, Iran's national press agency reported today.

title: Belgian Wins Tour Leg
description: Pol Verschuere of Belgium scored a photo-finish victory today in the seventh leg of the Tour de France bicycle race.

title: Fondue
description: To the Editor: Although the article by Kay Eldredge, ''Savoring Classic Fondue'' (Travel, June 20), brought back fond, appetizing memories, it omitted a few pointers essential to the fondue-eating American traveler: [ 1) One grave omission was the recognition of kirsch - the fiery cherry schnapps which is added to the fondue while it's cooking. As a waitress in a 'racletstuble' (specializing in raclettes and fondue), I observed Swiss from every part of the country commenting on the percentage of kirsch; usually asking for straight shots of it while they rested between bites.

title: Mark Murphy Marries Ann B. Tully in Albany
description: Ann Bruck Tully and Mark Murphy were married yesterday in St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church in Albany. Bishop Howard J. Hubbard of Albany performed the ceremony.

title: RACIAL CLASHES SAID TO HINDER SOVIET FORCES
description: A study of the Soviet armed forces has found that racial prejudices in the Soviet military have led to violent conflicts and to discrimination against minorities.

title: DUTCH WINDMILL IN HUNTERDON IS A MUSEUM
description: HOLLAND TOWNSHIP POUL JORGENSEN has been captivated by windmills ever since he helped the miller on his parents' farm outside Copenhagen some 60 years ago. Today, Mr. Jorgenson, a retired marine engineer, has a windmill of his own on his property in this Hunterdon County community.

title: Taiwan Edges U.S., 2-1, In Women's Softball
description: Taiwan scored a major upset today by beating the defending champion United States team, 2-1, in a preliminary playoff round as the World Women's Softball Championship reached its final stages.

title: A WARM, ITALIAN WELCOME
description: STAMFORD THERE aren't a lot of restaurants in the Fairfield County area where an entire softball team can come, all hot, muddy and T-shirted, right from the diamond, and be made to feel at home. But there they were, big and boisterous as life, during one of our visits to Pellicci's recently.

title: A PALACE OF PLEASURE FOR ART
description: In the once-beautiful city of Kassel in Germany there is from time to time an international exhibition of living art called ''Documenta.'' First mounted in 1955, it has come about every four or five years ever since. Against all the odds - financial, political, geographical - it has turned out over the last 25 years and more to be as often as not the best thing of its kind in the world. The latest exhibition in the series, ''Documenta 7,'' opened last month and can be seen through September.

title: MEN AND WOMEN IN TROUBLE
description: LOVE IS NOT ENOUGH By Bob Shanks. 318 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $12.95.DOCTOR LOVE By Gael Greene. 311 pp. New York: St. Martin's/Marek. $13.95.THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER By Jeffrey Archer. 464 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: A Correction
description: Robert J. Oberst Sr., president of Oceanview Associates, which is negotiating to purchase and redevelop the Asbury Park oceanfront, says that there are not 250 investors lined up in the proposal.

title: Adrienne E. Ferko Is Married to Thomas Darling
description: At the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Adrienne Elizabeth Ferko, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen G. Ferko of Awosting, N.J., was married to Thomas Christopher Darling, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wells A. Darling of Huntington Bay, L.I. The Rev. Francis McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Arthur Robinson Boone, an Episcopal priest and uncle of the bridegroom.

title: AFTER 11 YEARS, A START FOR THE HILLS
description: Gazing westward across the rolling hills of the town of Bedminster i n central New Jersey, it is hard to keep the mind focused on that p rovocative abstraction called ''exclusionary zoning.''

title: Shirley Anne Anderson Wed to John S. Gaither
description: Shirley Anne Anderson, daughter of Mrs. Harry Anderson of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Anderson, was married yesterday to John Stokes Gaither, son of Mrs. P. Stokes Gaither of Dedham, Mass., and the late Mr. Gaither. The Rev. John Olofson performed a Protestant ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: KEAN AT ODDS WITH DEMOCRATS OVER PRISONS
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY'S overcrowded prisons have become the latest political battleground for Governor Kean and the Democratic leadership in the State Legislature.

title: Israeli Says All Forces Have to Quit Lebanon
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel was quoted today as saying that all Palestinian and Syrian forces down to the last man would have to leave Lebanon for Israel to agree to withdraw.

title: PREFUNK: WAR'S COMEBACK
description: War, one of the most popular prefunk agglormerations of the 1970's, is on the comeback trail this year. At the Ritz on Wednesday, the octet, augmented by two, crisply reprised hits such as "Cisco Kid," "Low Rider" and "Flippin' Into Darkness," and offered extended versions of material from their new album, "Outlaws."

title: B.M. Fedor Weds Tara A. Flanagan
description: Tara Anne Flanagan and Lieut. Bruce Michael Fedor, U.S.N., were married yesterday at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien. Conn., by the Rev. Henry Albeke.

title: FAlkland Questions
description: The victors in the Falkland war were engaged in some finger-pointing of their own.

title: WALTRIP TAKES THE 420
description: Darrell Waltrip, who had finished only one of his previous six races, scored an easy victory tonight in the Busch 420 Grand National stock car race. The defending Winston Cup champion raised his season total to six victories.

title: THE END OF THE BEULAH QUINTET
description: THE KILLING GROUND By Mary Lee Settle. 385 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: AMERICAN DEMAGOGUES
description: VOICES OF PROTEST Huey Long, Father Coughlin, and the Great Depression. By Alan Brinkley. 348 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.50.

title: Karen Sulzberger To Be Wed in Fall
description: Karen Alden Sulzberger and Eric Martin Arthur Lax have announced their plans to be married next October.

title: VOICE OF AMERICA TO BROADCAST MORE OPINION
description: The director of the Voice of America said last week that he would increase the amount of editorial opinion the Voice broadcasts and that he was naming a former reporter for Fortune magazine to a newly created position as chief editorial writer.

title: MUSIC IS BECOMING A BIG ITEM ON THE SMALL SCREEN
description: Television and music have not been the most compatible of entities. One big reason is that television sets have traditionally been outfitted with relatively cheap speakers, making sound reproduction often unrewarding. Yet today, programs featuring musical performances and those about music or musicians are on remarkably ample display. Music, especially what is referred to as serious music, is being offered prominently both on public television and on the new ''culture'' cable channels. Public television alone has the regular showcases of ''Live From Lincoln Center'' and ''Live From the Met'' in addition to frequent music specials on ''Great Performances.'' Significantly, most of these programs are simulcast in stereo on radio, immeasurably improving the listening experience.

title: Strengthening Society And Its Sports
description: As a denizen of the Storrs area for nearly a decade, an employee of the University of Connecticut Athletic Department for three-quarters of that time and a current graduate student, I have a deep loyalty to both academics and athletics at the University of Connecticut. With numerous cogent arguments both for and against the construction of a new facility for athletics, I often find myself in somewhat of a quandary when asked to state my views.

title: 11 Are Identified as Victims In Fatal Waterbury Arson Fire
description: Authorities say that 11 persons, including seven children from one family, have been positively identified as having died in an arson fire in a Waterbury apartment building earlier this week.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF A STRONG DOLLAR
description: THANKS to the strong United States dollar, Americans are at a distinct advantage traveling abroad. The dollar h as been trading at record levels recently against the French franc a nd Italian lire, and is also very strong against the West German m ark, Swiss franc and Japanese yen.

title: NEW VIEW ON BURR TREASON CASE LETTER
description: The indictment of Aaron Burr for treason 175 years ago proved to be the final blow to the former Vice President's reputation and political career, even though he was found not guilty of the charge. Now, a scholar contends that a coded letter implicating Burr and long believed to have been written by him was in fact written by an associate.

title: LOOK OUT, N.Y.! BOTTLENECK IS COMING
description: The last notes of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra concert drifted beyond the trees of Meadowbrook in the gentle hills of Oakland County, north of the city.

title: CONVIVIAL ATMOSPHERE OF A CLUB
description: IF the Jockey Club were just that - a club -what a satisfactory place it would be. Its atmosphere is convivial, secure, comforting, the personal welcome hard to beat. Frequent diners are greeted clearly, by name, and newcomers are known before the meal ends. The dining room separates into levels corresponding to a theater's orchestra, balcony and boxes, a dramatic arrangement that allows almost everyone in the room to see and be seen; yet attractively-set tables (some with giant brandy snifters filled with flowers), roomy and well-spaced, lend intimacy, if that is desired.

title: THE YEARS OF MATURITY
description: THE DIARY OF VIRGINIA WOOLF Volume Four. 1931-1935. Edited by Anne Olivier Bell. Assisted by Andrew McNeillie. 402 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: JEAN ROSSNER ENGAGED TO GEOFFREY DEACON
description: Judith Rossner of New York and Robert Rossner of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Rossner, to Geoffrey Deacon, son of the Rev. Robert C. S. Deacon and Marta Hesthal Deacon of Bellows Falls, Vt.

title: REPLAY FOR LONG DISTANCE KIBITZERS
description: Two decades ago a television program entitled ''Championship Bridge'' ran here quite successfully for a couple of years. But with that possible exception nobody on this side of the Atlantic has ever found the perfect formula for presenting bridge to a home audience. It is obviously difficult to satisfy the needs of beginners and experienced players at the same time, and producers trying for a non-technical show with a big audience often end up satisfying nobody.

title: The Nissequogue
description: A Call for Protection Part of the recent article titled ''Changes at Kings Park Upset Neighbors'' is devoted to objections by two small yacht clubs to a state plan to replace them with a large public ramp facility. I am not a boat owner, but equally distressed, as are many of my neighbors, at the prospect of such an intrusion on the lovely, quiet and unique Nissequogue River.

title: TOP VALUES IN COMPONENTS
description: Last March I speculated in these pages upon the death of a hypothetical uncle who was to leave me a great deal of money. The point of those musings was the choice of stereo components under conditions of financial abundance. A number of readers were quick to point out that such conditions certainly didn't apply to them. Some said that my talking of expensive sound gear they couldn't afford made them feel bad. One of my correspondents thought it frivolous, fraudulent, or worse to wish the death and spend the inheritance of a rich uncle who never existed. But what really dashed me was a letter from a reader who asked, ''What if the uncle lives to be a hundred?'' I hadn't thought of that and realized with a shock of dismay that, for all I know, fictive uncles may live forever.

title: LIST OF THOSE ABOARD PLANE THAT CRASHED NEAR NEW ORLEANS
description: Following is a list, made public by Pan American World Airways, of crew members and passengers killed in Friday's jetliner crash near New Orleans. The list was provided by The Associated Press, which said that some name duplications might be explained because one person bought two or more tickets. Crew McCULLARS, Kenneth L., captain, Sebastian, Fla. PIERCE, Donald G., first officer, Miami Lakes, NOONE, Leo B., flight engineer, Miami. DONNELLY, Dennis M., purser, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. FIJUT, James P., flight attendant, Miramar, Fla. BROWN, Lucille, flight attendant, Hollywood, Fla. FORD, Vivian L., flight attendant, West Hollywood, Fla.

title: Navy's First Female Aviator To Die in Air Crash Reported
description: One of six persons killed in the collision of two training planes Thursday is believed to be the first female Navy aviator killed in a plane crash, a Naval Air Station spokesman said Friday.

title: WOLF TRAP RESUMES, IN A TEMPORARY STRUCTURE
description: Despite a fire April 4 that destroyed its main building, Wolf Trap lives, as the saying goes, with people heading into the Virginia countryside every evening for concerts of jazz, classical, country and rock music.

title: FOR SALE: RELOCATION SPECIALS
description: A huge inventory of houses acquired from transferred corporate e mployees is piling up in the hands of relocation companies. Efforts t o reduce losses on these properties have led to price cuts, offers o f lower-than-market-rate mortgages and attempts to lure buyers and b rokers with such incentives as free cars and trips.

title: THE DANCE: NATURE AND RITUAL
description: The forces of nature were at peace in ''Totem,'' the choreographic collaboration that Santa Aloi and Susan Osberg offered Tuesday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Although dances need not reflect their place of origin, this hourlong piece was so free of jitters and hassles that it is perhaps worth noting that both choreographers teach in Vancouver, British Columbia, a city in which one is never far from hills, woods and water.

title: GLOSSARY FOR VIDEO TECHNOLOGIES
description: As video technology has evolved, a special jargon has developed with it. Some terms widely used to describe segments of the industry are these:

title: Powerboats Will Race Off Jersey Coast
