description: Offshore powerboat racing returns to the New Jersey coast Wednesday with the running of the eighth annual Benihana Grand Prix. At least 50 boats, including 15 in the open class, are expected to compete for $45,000 in prizes.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The Netherlands Dance Theater, which has been warmly received by New York audiences in the past, returns to the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday with two weeks of new and familiar dances by Jiri Kylian, the company director, performed by a kind of mini-United Nations of dancers. Mr. Kylian's bow to the Stravinsky Centennial will be ''Svadebka'' (Les Noces). His other, peripatetic-sounding new works are ''Wayfarer'' and ''Nomad.''

title: Seattle Slew Filly Wins by 21
description: Landaluce, a daughter of Seattle Slew, scored a 21-length victory today in the $77,500 Hollywood Lassie Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Hollywood Park.

title: JUST IN CASE THERE'S ANOTHER DRAFT
description: NANETTE is the office manager at a weekly newspaper, Betty is a paralegal, Joe is a regional official for the Small Business Administration, Ray is a lawyer, Gene is a member of the New York Stock Exchange, Bob is a chemical salesman and Frank is an elementary school principal.

title: Barr Leads by a Stroke For Canada P.G.A. Title
description: Dave Barr, a Canadian pro who has played on the Professional Golfers' Association tour, shot a 2-under-par 69 today for a one-stroke lead in the Canadian P.G.A. $100,000 Championship.

title: PLANNERS LOOK TO THE 'OTHER' BOROUGHS
description: THE subject is the ''outer'' boroughs, or the ''other'' boroughs - o r, as Herbert J. Sturz has resolved to call them, the Bronx, B rooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: DIVERSIFIED
description: Although nearly $23 billion worth of Big Macs, Whoppers and other hamburger variants were sold in fast-food outlets last year, there are signs that Americans are suffering from burger fatigue.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST FLOWERS FOR SUMMER CUTTING
description: ONE nice thing about summer is that flowers can be picked from one's own garden, and those who have planned and planted with this purpose in mind should have a house full by now.

title: Sports People; Fan No. 1,000,000
description: For the first time since they settled in Atlanta in 1966, the Braves have attracted more than 1 million fans before the All-Star Game break. In honor of that accomplishment, on Friday night they selected Chris Chupp from a crowd of 28,601 as the one-millionth fan of the season and gave the 20-year-old hardware salesman a plaque, a radio, dinner for two, a night in an Atlanta hotel, a season parking pass and the use of a private box for 20 people at a future game.

title: 30-Foot Putt Puts Pair In Anderson Golf Final
description: Dave Boeff of Ontario Country Club of Rochester sank a 30-foot putt on the 18th hole to give him and his partner, Bob Horak, a 1-up victory over Dave Szewczul and William Hermanson of Tunxis Plantation Golf Club in the semifinals of the Anderson Memorial best-ball tournament today at Winged Foot Golf Club.

title: No Headline
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES Robert A. Heinlein, whose ''Friday'' is No. 12 on the hard-cover fiction list, becomes a two-time winner with the appearance of his 1980 hard-cover science-fiction best seller, ''The Number of the Beast,'' on the mass-market paperback list.

title: Headliners; A Hint of Scandal
description: Unfortunately, perhaps, for Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, the handwriting was on the paper - and it was his.

title: New Evidence on Breast X-Rays
description: Doctors generally agree that for women aged 50 and older, who account for most breast cancer cases in the United States, the advantages of X-raying outweigh the longterm risks. But for younger women, among whom the disease is less common and who might live long enough to suffer from cumulative radiation exposure, the advisability of such X-rays, called mammograms, has been contested.

title: HE'S THE MASTER OF THE MINI-SERIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the Hollywood scene. By STEPHEN FARBER LOS ANGELES Right above the entrance to his office at Warner Brothers Studios, the producer Stan Margulies has placed a nautical sign: ''To Lifeboats.'' The sign is there to remind him of a lesson he gleaned from his very first boss in the entertainment business, a senior publicist. ''My first day on the job,'' Mr. Margulies recalls, ''he told me, 'Never have more in your desk than you can take home with you on Friday afternoon.' That taught me very early that it is a chancy business and that the best approach is to travel light.''

title: 'THE JUNCTION': OLD STANDBY CARRIES ON
description: JERSEY CITY AT ONE time, trolley cars and buses carrying passengers from throughout New Jersey passed through the intersection of Grand Street and Communipaw Avenue in the Lafayette section of Jersey City. The last major transfer station for passengers before reaching the ferry terminal and passage to New York City, this five-cornered area is known as ''The Junction.''

title: Rosemary Ripley Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Dillon Ripley of Washington, New York and Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary Livingston Ripley, to P. Baxter Lanius 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Baxter Lanius Jr. of Denver.

title: No Headline
description: To add to the list in William Safire's ''My Fellow Americanians,'' where I lived out in the Wild West, we used to be called Santa Barbarians! SKONA S. LIBOWITZ, Princeton, N.J.

title: CAMACHO AND LOY HEAD GARDEN CARD
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho and Louie (Golden) Loy will match nicknames and unbeaten records in a rare Sunday afternoon fight at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum today.

title: SEAFOOD THAT'S FRESH AND SIMPLE
description: LAST year, Armando's Seafood Barge moved from its original red barge stationed on the beach overlooking Peconic Bay in Southold to a new structure, similar in design but approximately double the size. In all other respects the place is about the same. The stock in trade at this casual, unpretentious, nautically decorated family restaurant remains fresh fish and shellfish, simply prepared.

title: CONCERT: DUTCH VIOLINIST AND PIANIST
description: When the Dutch pianist Reinbert de Leeuw and the Dutch violinist Vera Beths played old American folk fiddling tunes at Marymount Manhattan Theater Wednesday night, it was more than just part of a four-concert tribute celebrating 200 years of diplomatic relations between the Netherlands and the United States.

title: STATE POPULAR FOR FILM SITES
description: CONNECTICUT has long been home to actors, screen writers and others involved in the film trade. But, increasingly, the state is stealing a bit of Hollywood's thunder as a location for making movies.

title: Esthetic Choices; Pointed Question
description: ''What would New York be without the Diors?'' asks an advertisement planned for the French clothing manufacturer. The answer - ''Newark.''

title:
CAMERA;
TIPS ON TAKING BETTER PICTURES OF THE BABY
No Headline
description: An Associated Press caption on a photograph published yesterday incorrectly identified the American Senator on a fact-finding tour of Lebanon. He was Carl Levin, Michigan Democrat.

title: CRIME FORCE CHIEF SEES IMPACT HERE
description: NEW HAVEN IT was the first time in a long time that Richard D. Gregorie could remember having a casual lunch in a downtown restaurant. ''I never do this,'' he said. ''This is different for me, there's never enough time. Usually I grab a sandwich across the street and finish half before I reach the office.''

title: Miss Sieck And Banker Are Married
description: Margaret Jean Sieck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Sieck of Newport, R.I., was married there yesterday to Robert H..B. Baldwin Jr., son of Mr. Baldwin of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., and Geraldine Williams Baldwin of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Gordon Jones, assisted by the Rev. Deane Lanphear, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: CAPE COD
description: To the Editor: I'm a little surprised that in the article ''What's Doing on Cape Cod'' (Travel, June 13), so much time was spent on an Indian powwow in Mashpee and the food served there, with no mention at all made of the many fine local museums which are of such great interest to history buffs and tourists looking for a touch of something old and typically Cape Cod.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON SYMPHONY OPENS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Tanglewood, the name by which that oldest and grandest of American summer music festivals is known, actually got under way July 1, with the first of several solo and chamber concerts, as well as two concerts by Lena Horne. But the true beginning of the Berkshire Music Festival, which is the actual name of the Boston Symphony's summer concert series, is really the orchestra's own first performance, and this year that took place Friday night.

title: DAVID GRAND TO WED LAURI ELLEN FIELD ON AUG. 28
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Fidell of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Ellen Fidell, to David Peter Granof, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clement Granoff of Elmira, N.Y.

title: Bermuda
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Kid Creole and the Coconuts, who are bringing their new show into the Ritz on Thursday, are an imaginative blend of Latin rhythms, funk, tuneful pop melodies and rock - a blend that could only have coalesced in Manhattan. Kid Creole is actually August Darnell, a founding member and lyricist for the most original new band that emerged during the disco craze, Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band.

title: Dr. Alisa Chaklai Marries a Doctor
description: Dr. Alisa Chaklai, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Chaklai of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Hedges McKinstry Thorne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Wooster Thorne Jr. of Oakland, Calif. The Rev. Dr. John Frank Scott, retired rector of All-Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Santa Barbara, Calif., and step-grandfather of the bridegroom, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the home of Mrs. Wells Barney, the bridegroom's great-aunt, in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Self-Help the Dartmouth Way
description: Dartmouth College announced last week that it would go into the bond-selling business to offset loss of support from a formerly generous Uncle Sam. Although some states have created authorities to float tax-exempt education bonds, Dartmouth's $29 million offer is the first by a private university.

title: Troubles Begin At Street Level
description: Some business executives who spent a year deep inside the New York subway system came out alive last week with a report on what's wrong in Transit Authority management.

title: STORIES THAT DEFINE ME
description: TELLING stories, I discovered at the age of 3 or 4, is a way of being told stories. One picture yields another; one set of words, another set of words. Like our dreams, the stories we tell are also the stories we are told. If I say that I write with the enormous hope of altering the world - and why write without that hope? - I should first say that I write to discover what it is I will have written. A love of reading stimulates the wish to write - so that one can read, as a reader, the words one has written. Storytellers may be finite in number but stories appear to be inexhaustible. For many days - in fact for weeks - I have been tormented by the proposition that if I could set down, in reasonably lucid prose, the story of ''the making of the writer Joyce Carol Oates,'' I might in some rudimentary way be defined, at least to myself. Stretched upon a grammatical framework, who among us does not appear to make sense? But the story will not cohere. The necessary words will not arrange themselves. Of the 40-odd pages I have written (each, I should confess, with the rapt, naive certainty, At last I have it) very little strikes me as useful. The miniature stories I have told myself, by way of analyzing ''myself,'' are not precisely lies; but, since each contains so small a fraction of the truth, it is untrue.

title: Deborah Anne Sullivan Wed to Richard Fuller
description: Deborah Anne Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Matthews Sullivan of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Avison Fuller, son of Mrs. William Mabon Davis of Suffield, Conn., and Little Compton, R. I., and the late Richard Eugene Fuller of Westfield, Mass. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Blair Deborah Johnson at the Trinity Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: A SPIRITED MUSICAL IS LESS SO ON L.I.
description: WESTBURY MORE than four years ago, ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,'' a modest and agreeable musical, opened Off Broadway, where it seemed to belong but was clearly not destined to remain for long. Within a couple of months, the understandably hit-hungry Broadway theater, especially famished when it comes to musicals, grabbed this one. It still has it.

title: Robert Wareham Weds Darice Grippo
description: Darice Paula Grippo, a vice president in the investment-research division of the Putnam Management Company in Boston, was married yesterday to Robert Leonard Wareham, a senior trust officer with the Old Colony Trust division of the First National Bank of Boston. The Rev. David Drew Rose, a United Church minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College.

title: PARIS AGREES IN PRINCIPLE TO SEND FORCE TO LEBANON
description: The French Government announced today that it had agreed in principle to send troops as part of an international force to be placed between Israeli and Palestinian forces in Lebanon.

title: PALISADES WATERFRONT: A FACELIFT?
description: red in the sunset.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Golden Notes James Galway, the flutist, is committed to the gold standard. His 18-karat gold instrument ''definitely'' sounds better, ''and it works better, too,'' he explained last week in an interview. Mr. Galway will conduct the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and perform in an Avery Fisher Hall concert that will be televised on Channel 13 on Wednesday evening at 8 as part of the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series.

title: SILVER RARITIES HOLD THEIR OWN; LONDON
description: ''The ups and downs in the price of silver bullion have as much to do with the value of antique silver as today's price of lumber does with the value of Chippendale furniture,'' said Jacques Koopman, the Dutch-born dealer.

title: Lured by Albany, Candidates Share The Rostrums
description: Some sparks flew last week when the Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor of New York paired off for the first debates of the campaign but, it turned out, they didn't illuminate many major political disagreements.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
FATHER KNOWS BEST WHAT'S BEST FOR FATHER
description: What happens to an elderly man when he can't stay in the apartment in which he has lived for 50 years? What happens, for example, to someone like my father-in-law -- 82 years old and arthritic -- when he is suddenly alone in stange surroundings?

title: TRAINING LEADERSHIP FOR CO-OPS
description: For most people thinking of buying into a cooperative or a c ondominium complex, the primary problem is how to pay for it. James D owden, on the other hand, is concerned about what happens to the c omplex once the resident owners take over its management.

title: THE DRAMATISTS DEFEND THEIR OWN
description: It may be a reflection of the uncertain status of today's playwright that the Dramatists Guild, an organization which usually functions behind the scenes, has recently found itself embroiled in public controversy. Shortly after this year's broadcast of the Tony Awards ceremony on CBS, the Guild issued a formal protest against ''the outrageous treatment of authors during the televised production of the 1982 Tony Awards'' and urged its playwrights, writers, composers and lyricists not to participate in future voting or ceremonies unless ''authors in all three categories - play, score and musical book - are allowed (and guaranteed) the same respect and treatment that the producers afford themselves.''

title: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.
description: THE second week of President Reagan's California vacation began with the unraveling of a well-kept secret - that the President had given his special Middle East Ambassador, Philip Habib, a potent ''bargaining chip,'' the promise of United States troops for a peacekeeping force in Lebanon.

title:
ART;
THE COOL AND THE EMOTIONAL
description: SOUTHAMPTON EXHIBITIONS at two of this village's galleries are highlighting very different, indeed apparently opposite, approaches to representation in contemporary art. Graphics by Andy Warhol, at the Tower Gallery, are cool commentaries on popular culture, while works by Don Gray and Jessie Benton Evans Gray at the Pond Lane Gallery are expressionistic, emotional and anything but detached. Both shows are on view through next Friday.

title: VISIT PARIS IN AUGUST? CERTAINEMENT!
description: SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON covers cultural news for The Times.

title: CLUE FOUND TO A PELVIC AILMENT
description: Women who use intrauterine birth-control devices are 70 percent more likely to develop severe pelvic inflammatory disease than those who use barrier contraceptives such as diaphragms, condoms and spermicidal chemicals, it was reported Thursday.

title: Argentina Takes Another Plunge
description: If Argentina's economy was desperate before the Falkland disaster, conditions are now ''in a state of destruction without precedence,'' the new Economics Minister, Jose Maria Dagnino Pastore, warned last week.

title: Headliners; Holes in the Bucket
description: When Boston's parking meter revenues declined sharply a few years ago, some wondered if thieves were getting to the meters before city collectors did.

title: THE CASE FOR LEAVING MUSICAL RUINS UNDISTURBED
description: Do you bridle, even a little, at the suggestion that someone might presume to finish the ''Unfinished'' Symphony? Or the Mahler Tenth, or ''The Art of Fugue,'' or Mozart's Requiem? I only ask because recently, during the American premiere of Prokofiev's incomplete opera ''Maddalena'' by Opera Theater of St. Louis, I caught myself feeling tiny twinges of annoyance at the presumption of people who tinker with history by piecing together works left unfinished by the masters. These twinges, I fully understand, were irrational and unjustified: Edward Downes, who orchestrated several scenes of this one-act opera, most of which the composer left in piano score, allowed us to hear - in admittedly questionable form - an early Prokofiev work that would otherwise have remained buried. We stand in Mr. Downes's debt, especially since the opera as performed proved to be a tolerably interesting period piece. Melodramatic and implausible, yes, but no worse in that regard than many another opera. Why, then, should anyone feel fleeting resentment?

title: MEXICO'S MIDDLE CLASSES VOTE THEIR DISCONTENTS
description: Although it was obscured by the landslide victory of the official party's candidate, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, the results of last Sunday's Mexican presidential elections included a warning to the country's entrenched political system: The middle class is increasingly unhappy with the Government.

title: BROOKHAVEN'S HIGH-ENERGY ISABELLE IS A 'GOOD BET'
description: To the Editor:

title: Track Robbery Heads Vanity Handicap Field
description: Track Robbery, the defending champion, heads a field of seven in Sunday's $200,000 Vanity Handicap for the filly championship of the summer meeting at Hollywood Park.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Mute Testimony? There will be sound but no dialogue in ''Deafman Glance,'' which will be this week's presentation on the ''Matters of Life and Death'' series Sunday at 11 P.M. on Channel 13. Described as ''a gothic video-drama,'' the half-hour work uses sound effects, as well as time and space, light and movement, in lieu of spoken words to recount a stylized tale of murder.

title: IRAN'S STAND ON OPEC POLICY
description: At the start of a stormy emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna, Seyyed Mohamed Gharazi (right), Iran's oil minister, warned that his country would not abide by the quota of 1.2 million barrels a day imposed on it under OPEC ceilings of last March.

title: MUSICAL ANNIVERSARY
description: Neil's New Yorker, a dinner-theater on Route 46 in Mountain Lakes, is celebrating its eighth anniversary today to ''The Sound of Music.''

title: EVERY DOG HAS HIS DAY: ICI ON PARLE FRANCAIS
description: IF you happen to meet Mirabelle one day, you will notice right away that she thinks we are her real parents. Now, this is really hard on us. I mean, we never actually told her anything about her true origins, but we never lied either - we thought that her four legs should be enough of a clue. Unfortunately, she seems never to have noticed that our other children have only two....

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FOR the Conrail commuter who squeezes aboard his train in the morning rush, it may come as a surprise to learn that, statistically speaking at least, he has fewer commuters sharing the journey with him.

title: WALL STREET GOES INTERNATIONAL
description: F oreign investors are pumping money into the heart of this nation's financial center in amounts never seen before:

title: FOR NOW, IT'S NASA'S DECK BUT PENTAGON HOLDS THE CARDS
description: Several times during the most recent mission of the space shuttle Columbia there were reminders of a fundamental change in the American manned space flight program. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's increasingly assertive partner, the Department of Defense, is stepping out of the background to assume a larger and more visible role.

title: TOUGH-NOSED AND ENIGMATIC
description: WASHINGTON ENVIRONMENTALISTS have dubbed him ''Tailpipe Johnny'' and ''Dirty Dingell.'' Ralph Nader has called him ''the No.1 enemy to consumers on Capitol Hill.'' And lobbyists have said the Democratic Congressman from Michigan is ''a big friendly kind of guy who is likely to put his arm around you and break a couple of ribs.''

title: Maria D. Fiddler Becomes a Bride
description: Maria Dolores Fiddler, daughter of Capt. Roy E. Fiddler of the Merchant Marine and Mrs. Fiddler of Westport, Conn., was married in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday to Walter Jay Leukart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jacob Leukart 3d of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. Anthony J. Eiardi performed the ceremony in St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church.

title: SHAKESPEARE, AS SEEN BY WALKEN
description: THE first impression Christopher Walken makes is with his size. The 39-year-old actor, who won an Oscar for his performance in the film, ''The Deer Hunter,'' is 6 feet 2 and weighs about 185 pounds.

title: EXPERTS CALL LIGHTNING UNLIKELY AS CAUSE OF JET CRASH
description: Federal investigators yesterday began gathering evidence, including precise data on the weather, in an effort to determine what caused the crash of a Pan American World Airways jet just after it took off from New Orleans in a rainstorm Friday afternoon.

title: Around the World; Sole British P.O.W.  Returned by Argentina
description: The only British serviceman held prisoner by Argentina in the Falkland conflict returned home today and said he spent 12 days in solitary confinement during his seven weeks of captivity.

title: POPULATION MAY HIT 8.3 MILLION
description: DESPITE anticipated declines in Hudson, Essex and Union Counties, the state's population will increase by almost a million by the year 2000, according to a new study by the Department of Labor and Industry.

title: A VINTAGE OF THE CENTURY REVISITED
description: Oenophiles on this side of the Atlantic have grown accustomed to the French phenomenon known as the Vintage of the Century, connoting the greatest possible wine year, a harvest when the grapes achieve perfect ripeness and wines of extraordinary balance and finesse are produced. The French, who are not only intrepid wine makers but good businessmen as well, have recognized the commercial value of declaring such a vintage from time to time.

title: CINCINNATI BISHOP WILL SUCCEED CODY
description: Pope John Paul II named Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin of Cincinnati yesterday to succeed the late John Cardinal Cody as head of the nation's largest see, the Archdiocese of Chicago. No date for the installation was announced.

title: Around the Nation; N.A.A.C.P. Suspends Its Ex-Miami Chief
description: William Perry, former president of the Greater Miami branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has been suspended by the civil rights organization's national office for his unauthorized call for a ''Black Monday'' boycott of white-owned businesses in Dade County.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: REDUCTIONS in the number of firefighters in many of the state's paid Fire Departments have resulted in a sharp increase in fatalities involving civilians trapped in fires and an increase in injuries to the firemen who attempt to rescue them, according to the New Jersey State Firemen's Mutual Benevolent Association.

title: Linda Bilkey Wed To Peter Krainik
description: Linda McFarland Bilkey and Peter Thomas Krainik were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Robert Brandt, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Daniel Hewlitt, a Methodist minister.

title: ORGAN: PAUKERT OPENS SERIES OF RIVERSIDE CHURCH RECITALS
description: For 25 years, Riverside Church has presented a series of summer organ recitals that feature a varied array of performers, cover a broad range of organ repertory and attract sizable audiences. The 1982 installment of six events began Tuesday with the appearance of Karel Paukert, a native of Czechoslovakia, who is now curator of musical arts at the Cleveland Museum.

title: AGRICULTURE SECRETARY SET TO ORDER CUT IN WHEAT ACREAGE, AIDE SAYS
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block will soon tell wheat farmers that they will not be eligible for Government loans and subsidies next year unless they reduce the number of acres they normally plant, a department official said.

title: AFRICA OF 1879 AND AN EPIC ZULU BATTLE
description: ''Zulu Dawn'' is a sequel to the British 1964 battle epic ''Zulu,'' except it isn't a sequel, it's a prequel. It tells of the events leading up to the bloody fight depicted in ''Zulu,'' a movie that presented white British troops slaughtering such staggering numbers of Africans that trouble sometimes broke out in the theaters in which ''Zulu'' was shown. ''Zulu Dawn,'' which was made in 1979, is another sweeping battle film, one that's less exciting but certainly more even-handed.

title: DR. KING VISITS BROOKLYN TO ASSIST AN EFFORT TO REGISTER BLACK VOTERS
description: Dr. Martin Luther King Sr. visited the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday to help begin a drive to register 300,000 black voters in the borough by the fall.

title: BROADER CABLE USE SOUGHT IN GREENBURGH
description: WHEN candidates for the Hastings-on-Hudson school board debated local issues this spring, they did so in the unaccustomed glare of television floodlights.

title: U.S. TEAM LOSES TO EAST GERMANY
description: MARX-STADT, East Germany, July 10 (AP) - East Germany defeated the United States, 207 1/2-172 1/2, today in the first track and field meet between the countries. The American men won by 120 1/2-102 1/2, but the American women were routed by 105-52 in the twoday event.

title: INDONESIAN BATIK: ARTISTRY BY DESIGN
description: PAMELA G. HOLLIE is a New York Times correspondent based in Manila.

title: INDIAN CRAFTS SHOW
description: Jim Roaix, a fifth-generation descendant of Irish and Abenaki (northern Maine) Indian forebears, will demonstrate his leatherworking skills from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. tomorrow at the American Indian Archeological Institute, Route 199, Washington, Conn.

title: Writing Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Law of Sea Is Not Law of Land
description: President Reagan finally scuttled official American participation in the Law of the Sea treaty last week, saying ''the deep seabed mining part of the convention does not meet United States objectives.'' The pact had already been adopted in April by 130 nations, however, and many analysts believe Washington will have to abide by most of its provisions anyway.

title: PLAGIARISM: A FOOTNOTE OR TWO FROM A HUMANIST
description: THE national image of New Jersey can scarcely withstand more criminal behavior, but we have recently become the plagiarism capital of the nation with two well-publicized cases in one termpaper-writing season.

title: THE FAIRNESS OF LIFE--AND DEATH
description: AS Freud said (borrowing heavily from Schopenhauer), the nice thing about pain is that it makes you pay attention. When you have it, you really know you have it, and when you lose it, you forget all about it.

title: PLEDGES ARE KEY TOOL IN CO-OP DEALS
description: THE first decision for most tenants living in buildings undergoing conversion to cooperative ownership is whether to sign a no-buy pledge. Such pledges are widely used by tenants as a way of strengthening their hand in negotiations with the landlord or sponsor.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: THE THEATER IN LONDON IS A DECIDEDLY MIXED BAG; LONDON
description: High drama is in abundant supply in London this summer, but one doesn't necessarily enter a theater to find it. Simply by walking outside, one could witness, in June alone, the jubilation surrounding both the Argentine collapse in the Falklands and the royal birth. There were diverting sideshows, too - from a crippling transit strike to Wimbledon to the much-chronicled David Frost-Lynne Frederick divorce. With so much public theater on view, perhaps the offerings in London's legitimate theaters are bound to disappoint by contrast.

title:
DINING OUT;
GETTING INTO THE SWING OF THINGS
description: TWO years ago, Ken Kelly took over as chef-owner of the restaurant at the Spring Meadow Golf Club, a public course near Allaire State Park in Monmouth County. This was a welcome move indeed in an area somewhat short of interesting dining spots.

title: ANGER AND ANGST TEST BONN'S CLUBBY POLITICS
description: New talk of political payoffs by West German industry - the fresh names this time include leaders of both the ruling Social Democrats and the opposition Christian Democrats - is reinforcing factions trying to turn around the economic and security policies that have been constants here since the end of World War II.

title: DANCE: NIGHT WITH BARBERS ETHNIC BALLET AND LIVE SNAKE
description: There would be little point in mentioning ''Berber Night in Morocco'' after the fact but for its $10 ticket, a fairly high charge for Off Broadway dance, and its one-time presentation by La Mama E.T.C., which has produced such serious and unusual ethnic work in the past. For the record, a group of luscious lovelies known as Inosiss, the Moroccan Berber Ballet Inc., descended on La Mama's Annex theater Wednesday for nightclub belly dance that had a faintly spurious air and certainly seemed unrehearsed.

title: MISS STACY GETS 66-137 AND LEADS BY A SHOT
description: Hollis Stacy, playing well on the Speidel golf course despite temperatures in the mid-90's, tied a tournament record with a six-under-par 66 today. She took a one-shot lead over Kathy Postlewait and Cathy Morse after the second round of the West Virginia Classic on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour.

title: THE SHINY MACKEREL: A VERSATILE FISH
description: THE pleasure of contemplating shiny mackerel, with their brilliant silver and blue-black skins and firm, svelte bodies, is even greater when you realize how little they cost. They are among the least expensive of fish and make excellent eating. Yet because they are cheap, they are often overlooked. But in Victorian times they were a great delicacy, grilled so their skins turn a crisp brown and served with a mustard or tart gooseberry sauce. The French like mackerel with gooseberries, too, so much so that ''groseilles a maquereau'' is the French word for these fruits; ''groseilles'' alone means red currants.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: MUSIC On Saturday at 8 P.M., a group called Nayjama will present a program of ''music of the Andes'' at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street, in lower Manhattan. Andean music is something of a mixed bag of actual and reconstructed Indian musics and more contemporary styles, and Nayjama itself, which is made up of two Chileans, two Bolivians and an American jazz guitarist, is an unknown quantity to this writer.

title: FOR CONGRESS, EVERYTHING IS STUCK BUT THE CLOCK
description: WASHINGTON CONGRESS returns tomorrow from its July 4th recess with little time left for action on dozens of bills that once were thought to have a high priority. Budgetary issues are expected to continue to dominate Capitol Hill's agenda, to the consternation of the vast majority of members of the House and Senate who do not serve on the fiscal committees. Many feel that they have spent the last 18 months treading water. Conservatives are among the most aggrieved, for they had looked to this Congress, elected two years ago in the Reagan sweep, for action on social issues.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THEY were learning to build houses, houses they would never live in. From cellar to roof, baseboard to ceiling, they were being taught to construct homes whose only function would be ornamental.

title: FOR WEICKER, THE HARD PART IS GETTING TO NOVEMBER
description: AS Connecticut Democrats and Republicans prepare to hold their conventions during the next two weeks, most of the early polls agree that, in the race for United States Senator, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. would be the most formidable candidate come November. The question is, will the two-term Republican incumbent still be a candidate by then?

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Short and Long of It Two programs, back to back on Channel 5 on Sunday evening, stand in contrast. The first, ''Rock 'n' Roll: The First 25 Years,'' at 8, is an hour-long compilation of concert footage, interviews and commentary; it features brief snippets of a flood of performers: Bobby Darin, Paul Anka, Connie Francis, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, Herman's Hermits, the Temptations, the Supremes, Stevie Wonder, the Beach Boys, the Mamas and Papas, the Lovin' Spoonful, Jefferson Airplane, Janis Joplin, Jimi Hendrix and others.

title:
STAMPS;
THE UNITED STATES PAYS TRIBUTE TO ITS LIBRARIES
description: A new commemorative in tribute to the nation's libraries, which have done more than any other instrument of American society to make the treasury of mankind's accumulated knowledge available to the people, is being issued this Tuesday in Philadelphia.

title: Foreign Aid Under Fire
description: Ann Crittenden's ''Foreign Aid Under Fire'' (June 6) is a welcome contribution to the coverage of complex third-world issues. What is missing from her article, except as a tantalizing aside, is a description of the role of United States private and voluntary organizations which she says are ''having a direct effect on poor farmers'' in the development of Bangladesh.

title: TOWN HAS 'EARTHBOUND' OFFICE
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP ALONG Route 571, which runs between the pleasantly shaded streets of Princeton and the heart and dusty center of downtown Hightstown, sits a 37-foot-high mound of earth whose sharp-edged, trapezoid shape recalls an overgrown Mayan ruin.

title:
MANAGEMENT;
WHO FOR THE PEDESTAL NOW?
description: "FIFTEEN years from now it is quite possible that the world's third greatest industrial power, just after the United States and Russia, will not be Europe but American industry in Europe.''

title: NO. 32 GOES TO BAT
description: THE scrub grass glistened in the sun; swirls of dust on the mound blew into the pitcher's eye and the manager came out of the dugout with a Kleenex. Time was called, and the catcher took advantage of it to take his allergy medicine. The left fielder left left field to deliver a handful of dandelions to his mother in the stands, and the chunky third baseman looked wistfully toward the hot dog truck in foul territory.

title: TUMBLING BOAT SALES
description: High interest rates, a continuing recession and extremely wet spring weather, which further dampened consumer enthusiasm, have becalmed the nation's pleasure boat industry.

title: IT'S NOT GOSPEL YET
description: THERE were many hopeful hearts among executives and takeover s pecialists before the Justice Department released its merger g uidelines last month. But many who thought they would be able to do m ore deals more easily have been unpleasantly surprised.

title: 17 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED FOR VIOLATIONS OF HEALTH CODE
description: The New York City Health Department has released the names of 17 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code. The department also released the names of two establishments that reopened after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for failure to do so.

title: THE LIFE OF A ZEK
description: NOTES OF A REVOLUTIONARY By Andrei Amalrik. Translated by Guy Daniels. Introduced by Susan Jacoby. 343 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. By ANTHONY AUSTIN

title: CARDIAC EXERCISE CENTERS GAIN
description: AFTER scoring 20 points in a basketball game, a 37-year-old resident of North Bellmore drove home, ate dinner and smoked a cigarette, all the while feeling as if he had the weight of a brick on his chest.

title: MAJOR DISKS EXPLORE MODERN EUROPEAN SYMPHONIES
description: Gustav Mahler is sometimes reckoned the last great Romantic symphonist, the man whose tortured sensibility, oscillations between bombast and intimacy, and rampant expansion and distortion of traditional symphonic form pointed the way toward Schoenberg and modernism.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Burr was probably guilty of something, but no one's absolutely sure of what.'' - Dr. Mary-Jo Kline, editor of the forthcoming ''Political Correspondence and Public Papers of Aaron Burr.'' (A1:1.)

title: William Gibson Weds Lorraine Besch
description: Lorraine Wrightson Besch, daughter of Mrs. Robert Woodruff Besch of Short Hills, N.J., and South Casco, Me., and the late Mr. Besch, was married in Red Bank, N.J., yesterday to William Lee Gibson, son of Mrs. William Barry Leavens Jr. of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J., and the late Joseph Wilton Gibson. The Rev. Allen A. Tinker, minister of Christ Church (interdenominational) in Summit, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of Olivia Wrightson Switz, aunt of the bride.

title: THE SUPREME AUTHORITY ON HIMSELF
description: A MOVING TARGET By William Golding. 202 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. By JAN MORRIS

title: NEW ACT FOR A 20'S SHOWPLACE
description: GREAT NECK GEORGE ABBOTT starred in the Great Neck Playhouse's first play - a two-night stand titled ''Straight Shooter'' -and Charlie Chaplin had a season ticket. That was in 1925.

title: Washington; SHULTZ TO THE RESCUE?
description: George Shultz will be the sixth U.S. Secretary of State in the last 10 years. (The Soviet Union has had only one in the last 25 years.) Mr. Shultz will be confirmed during another Middle East conflict, an East-West crisis over trade and nuclear arms control and at the beginning of a national Congressional election, but he will be welcomed by the Congress, the allies and the Soviets for a variety of reasons.

title: NEW LOOK AT INDIANS OF THE AREA
description: CROSS RIVER IN the fall of 1977, a delegation of American Indians - elders from the Delaware tribe in Oklahoma - led by Nora Thompson Dean, a medicine woman, visited the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation here. They conducted a consecration ceremony and gave their blessings to the efforts of the local museum staff to document and explain the traditional culture of the Delawares as it once existed in this area.

title: EXIT FOR HAIGSPEAK
description: Al Haig, the former Secretary of State whose vocabulary was so often skewered in this space, will no longer be using Foggy Bottom as his forum. Policy differences aside, his departure is saddening: Al was just getting the hang of the language.

title: ANGELS ROUT YANKS AS JACKSON EXCELS
description: When Reggie Jackson hit a home run against the Yankees April 27 at Yankee Stadium, it inspired a chant by the fans aimed at George Steinbrenner, the man who let Jackson get away. ''It's about the only fun time I had in the game,'' Ron Guidry, who gave up the home run, said of the fans' reaction.

title: Jane Ellen Auerbach Is Engaged to Neal Gelfand
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Auerbach of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ellen Auerbach, to Neal Gelfand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gelfand of Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: LIfe, Liberty And Exiles
description: Ethiopia's Marxist Government may or may not be less repressive now than when it took over in 1974, but 15,000 Ethiopian exiles in the United States won't have to go home to find out. Reversing a stand it took last year, the State Department said last week that the students and refugees who fled would not be deported.

title: E.R.A. BACKERS SEE CHALLENGE IN DEFEAT
description: ''MY phones have been ringing off the hook,'' said Lynn Taborsak, coordinator of the Connecticut Chapter of the National Organization for Women. ''Women want to know what the defeat of this amendment means. There's been no letup since June 30 in the calls.''

title: Family Needs $150 a Day On Auto Trips
description: When that typical American family of four - beloved of economists and statisticians -steps into its typical family car for a typical family vacation this summer, the person who keeps an eye on the family exchequer ought to figure it's going to cost $150 a day.

title: THE ART OF BEING TWO WRITERS IN ONE
description: ''MY first ambition in life was to see the whole world,'' said Phyllis Krasilovsky of Chappaqua, a travel writer who has visited 89 countries and is the author of 15 children's books.

title: Miss Carder Is Married
description: Elizabeth Byrd Carder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts George Carder of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Benjamin Franklin Price Ivins 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Donald Ivins of Milwaukee. The Rev. James Daughtry performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: TAKE THE SEA LAW ROUTE TO HELP WORLD STABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: RISING FEDERAL DEBT
description: It was nice while it lasted. For the first five months of the current fiscal year, it seemed that forecasts calling for Federal deficits of more than $100 billion would prove overly pessimistic. Until March, unexpectedly high revenues had some analysts wondering if the Government's 1982 budget deficit might actually end up lower than it had been a year earlier, rather than soaring to new highs, as many economists had predicted. Since then, however, Washington's tide of red ink has risen substantially.

title: CRAFTS
description: ALLAIRE A''felt-making dance'' accompanied by bluegrass music will be among several lively demonstrations at a crafts fair to be held Saturday in the Restored Village section of Allaire State Park.

title: HUNT GOES ON FOR BODIES AND CLUES IN PAN AM CRASH THAT KILLED 153
description: Sheriff's Deputy Gerald Hibbs of Jefferson Parish had been searching through the rubble of suburban houses tangled with the wreckage of an airplane for nearly 18 hours and he was tired and hollow-eyed and depressed. This morning, he did not want to talk about the bodies that he had helped put into body bags and load into a van. He would describe the only high point, 16 long hours before:

title: YONKERS ASKS DESIGNATION FOR ITS THREE OLD BATHHOUSES
description: YONKERS THERE was a time when not many workers trudging home from Yonkers factories, lunch pail in hand, could look forward to dissolving the day's grime in a nice, hot tub. Few of the bathrooms opening on the long halls of railroad flats built before the turn of the century had the luxury of hot water.

title: The Underground
description: To the Business Editor: The appointment of ''a national commission on the underground economy,'' as suggested by Paul W. MacAvoy in ''The Underground - No Recession There'' (July 4), would simply confirm that which is quite widely known - that millions of Americans systematically evade taxes and derive state and Federal benefits to which they are not entitled. It is equally well known that these motives thrive in a national moral climate in which ''getting away with something'' approaches a badge of personal achievement.

title: DEBORAH FRISHMAN AND RICHARD SIEGAL WILL MARRY
description: Rabbi Louis Frishman and Cantor Mimi Frishman have announced that engagment of their daughter, Deborah Harriet Frishman, to Richard Steven Siegel, son of Pearl M. Siegel of Lebanon, Pa., and the late Herman R. Siegel.

title: Cancer by the Gallon in N.J.
description: If the health of New Jersey's economy depends on the production of chemicals, the health of many of its residents depends on the proper disposal of them. The latest evidence came in a report released last week by the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, which found a ''significant correlation'' between toxic waste dumps and the cancer rates among those living near them.

title: TWO SCORERS KEY TO WORLD CUP FINAL
description: MADRID THERE is only one Pele, but every team must try to find its own Pele, the man who puts the ball in the nets. West Germany and Italy have forwards - Karl-Heinz Rummenigge and Paolo Rossi - who can save a soccer game with a key goal, which is why those nations are playing in the final of the World Cup today.

title: ADD WATER AND GROW
description: WATER AND POWER The Conflict Over Los Angeles' Water Supply in the Owens Valley. By William L. Kahrl. Illustrated. 583 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $24.95. By BENJAMIN STEIN

title: Around the World; Tass Denounces Pope On Plan to Visit Poland
description: The Soviet press agency Tass carried a bitter criticism of Pope John Paul II today that suggested that his planned visit to Poland this summer was a ploy to whip up opposition to martial law.

title: Music on Cable
description: To the Business Editor: In light of a June 16 article in Variety, which basically says that MTV, the focus of your ''Cable TV Moves to the Music'' (July 4), faces determined competition, primarily from Night Flight. I was most perplexed as to why Night Flight was not mentioned at all as a competitor to MTV.

title: A FAILED HIGH SCHOOL PREPARING FOR RENEWAL
description: The final bell has rung at Benjamin Franklin High School, and when summer ends, about 350 students will walk into the same building at 116th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in East Harlem to attend a new school, the Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics. All that will remain of the old school will be the building.

title: BEHIND THE FALKLANDS VICTORY
description: Thomas Pakenham, a British writer, is the author of ''The Boer War.'' By Thomas Pakenham This has been a strange nostalgic experience, this old-fashioned Falkland Islands war which seems to have ended, bringing to the surface, as it did, all sorts of old-fashioned emotions like patriotism and pride. There was in Britain a sense of pulling together, of rediscovering an old cause. Most people seemed to feel, and to feel deeply, that it was a just war -quixotic but necessary, as had been such earlier conflicts as the Boer War, with which there are many striking analogies. Yet one heard, even in pubs, remarkably little belligerence or jingoism.

title: MAKING AN EXIT
description: It may never be the subject of polite conversation, but it is a fact that the posterior is played up in much of the incoming fall fashion. In designers' collections, both here and abroad, the current move toward a narrower, more figure-defining silhouette has resulted in a spate of slim skirts that accentuate the natural curves beneath.

title: NEW CUTS IN U.S. SCHOOL AID WILL BE BOTH DEEP AND WIDE
description: A new round of major cuts in Federal aid to elementary and secondary schools has gone into effect, and large urban school systems and some relatively wealthy districts skilled in the art of obtaining Federal grants are likely to feel the biggest impact.

title: Dear Menachem:
description: As I consider our joint predicament, and opportunity, in the Middle East, it occurs to me that the warmth of our meetings always seems to prevent clear discussion of cold realities. So instead of inviting you back to the White House so soon, let me set down plainly the policies I will now pursue.

title: FRY BREAD AND BUCKING BRONCOS
description: ANNA DOOLING is a writer who lives in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: 'AIN'T MISBEHAVIN'' RADIATES CHEER
description: EAST HAMPTON THE ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' blitz has begun. With its economic practicality (five performers, five musicians and one set) and its proven popularity (a recently completed four-year run on Broadway), the bookless revue inspired by songs composed or recorded by Thomas (Fats) Waller looms as the high-frequency musical on the Island's summer stages.

title: GUILFORD EXPOSITION CELEBRATES 25 YEARS
description: WHEN the first Guilford Handcrafts Exposition was held 25 years ago, the committee members did everything themselves - from handfireproofing more than 100 yards of burlap to be used as booth coverings to making lobster salad sandwiches that sold for $1.50 each. And after it was all over, they reported to the Guilford Green early Sunday morning for cleanup duty.

title: BROOKHAVEN'S HIGH-ENERGY ISABELLE IS A 'GOOD BET'
description: To the Editor:

title: Therese Ann Boyle Is Bride
description: Therese Ann Boyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Boyle of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Kevin Timothy Coughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Coughlin of Franklin Lakes and Bayhead, N.J. The Rev. Emil Wcela performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a sales representatiove with the Eastman Kodak Company in New York and Mr. Coughlin an associate with the Newark law firm of Mattson, Madden & Polito.

title: EXPLORING THE IMPROBABLE
description: In Texas they do things in a big way, they say, which certainly applies to the summer sampling of ''fabricated'' photographs at the New York branch of Delahunty, a Dallas gallery which recently opened quarters here. Called ''Beyond Photography: The Fabricated Image,'' the exhibition includes work by 19 artists engaged in creating scenes for the camera. It is an impressive survey of this currently popular (even fashionable) genre, big in ambition and impact. The number of images on view - a total of 40 - may sound just shy of Texan, but the large size of the pictures more than compensates.

title: SEMINARY APPOINTS NEW HEAD
description: The Rev. Dr. Keith A. Russell, pastor of the Baptist Church of the Redeemer in Brooklyn, has been named president of New York Theological Seminary.

title: LEBANON HAS TOO MANY 'FRIENDS'
description: There is a 10-year-old Lebanese story about an old man in a poor southern Lebanese village close to the Israeli border. He walked into the countryside behind his village one day and suggested to the Palestinian fighters camped on the hill, ''Listen, tomorrow please fire three rockets into our village!'' When the Palestinian leader asked why, the old man answered, ''Well, every day you fire three rockets into Israel, they fire back 15 rockets on our village - so tomorrow please do us a favor!''

title: SMITHTOWN DECIDES IT NEEDS PLAN CHIEF
description: EIGHT months ago, the Republican majority of the Smithtown Town Board eliminated the positions of planning director and environmental planner, 17 jobs in the Planning Department and a few other parttime posts for ''economic reasons'' and ''because they weren't getting proper advice on the use of community development funds,'' councilmen said. The functions of the department were transferred to the politically appointed Planning Board.

title: Greek Tours
description: To the Editor:

title: L.C. LEIN TO WED JAYNE H. GURLAND
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jesse J. Gurland of Englewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jayne Hallie Gurland, to Lawrence Charles Lein, son of Mrs. Ruth Finley Lein of New York, and the late Irving Lein.

title: STAGE: A MUSICAL SPOOF AT BROADWAY SCANDALS
description: For ''Broadway Scandals of 1928,'' a featherweight revue spoofing the Ruby Keeler era of musical hijinks, the upstairs of O'Neals' has been turned into a high-tech speakeasy, where, to make the Prohibition ambience more ''authentic,'' drinks are served in coffee cups. An announcement from the stage informs us that the show will begin a few minutes late because Rusty, one of the girls, hasn't shown up. Just then, the tarty tapdancer bustles in, setting the make-believe anything-can-happen tone for a cheerful backstage-goesonstage musical that includes a couple of shootings and a wedding.

title: U.S. Team in Final
description: Six teams, including the favored United States, advanced today to the final round in the first Seoul International Invitational men's basketball tournament.

title: Sally Webber Is Married To William Morris Centner
description: Sally Webber and William Morris Centner were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester. The Rev. Dr. William H. English performed the ceremony.

title: About Cars; AN INNOVATION IN TURBO CONTROL
description: THE car was little and blue, a well-used '67 model with a V-4 engine and front-wheel drive. It was the first Saab I ever knew, and it was a case of love at first sight.

title: Lois B. Corrin Is Fiancee Of Gary Lafayette, Lawyer
description: The engagement of Lois Beatrice Corrin, daughter of Malcolm L. Corrin of East Orange, N.J., and the late Virginia Brown Corrin, to Gary T. Lafayette, son of Mrs. Opal Williams of Dallas, and Leamon Lafayette of Los Angeles, has been announced by the future bride's father. The ceremony will be performed next month in Christ Episcopal Church in East Orange.

title:
GARDENING;
THE BEST FLOWERS FOR SUMMER CUTTING
description: ONE nice thing about summer is that flowers can be picked from one's own garden, and those who have planned and planted with this purpose in mind should have a house full by now.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Soldiers of Misfortune On Thursday at 10 P.M., ABC will present ''Vietnam Requiem.'' A couple of weeks before broadcast time, the title of the documentary was more informative: ''VIPs - Vets in Prison.''

title: J.M. Oakes Weds Nicole I. Lewis
description: Nicole Irene Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roscoe V. Lewis of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jeffrey Morton Oakes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle D. Oakes of Philadelphia. The Rev. Ronald Parker performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: ADMINISTRATION TAX CUTS AS GOOD AS MONEY IN THE BANK?
description: To Reagan Administration economists, the savings rate holds the key to economic vitality. They attribute many of the economic troubles of the 1970's to underinvestment, which they say resulted from a personal savings rate that was simply too low. Many of the tax cuts approved by Congress last year were specifically aimed at reducing personal income taxes in the hope that savings would rise.

title: CRAFT BECOMES SMALL BUSINESS
description: HAMDEN ACCORDING to a young designer-inventor, the State of Connecticut was the catalyst in helping to turn her small crafts project into a small business.

title: Sports People; Texas Ranger Sale?
description: With his Texas Rangers headed toward a projected loss of between $6 million and $7 million this season, the club owner has said he may consider selling the team. Ed Chiles, an oilman from Fort Worth, was quoted in The Dallas Morning News as saying: ''This club has lost money every year: we lost $4 million last year.''

title:
ART;
STIMULATING SHOW INAUGURATES SITE FOR OUTDOOR SCULPTURE
description: A Very interesting and significant exhibition of outdoor sculpture opened recently on the grounds of the Bronx Psychiatric Center near the southern border of Westchester County. The show, which was organized by the Bronx Council on the Arts, will be on view until June of next year.

title: MARIA JERITZA, STAR OF OPERA'S 'GOLDEN AGE,' DIES AT 94
description: Maria Jeritza, the internationally renowned soprano who has been called the golden girl of opera's ''golden age,'' died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Orange, N.J., after a long illness. She was 94 years old and lived in Newark.

title: If You Missed Three Mile Island, Wait a Few Years
description: Statistically, at least, Three Mile Island may not have been so big a deal. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced last week that accidents as serious as the one in Pennsylvania could have been expected every 10 to 15 years, not the 200 to 300 years previously predicted.

title: JERSEY COURT CLEARS WAY FOR TRIALS OF ASBESTOS CASES
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court cleared the way this week for the trial of damage suits against asbestos manufacturers and distributors by stripping the companies of their chief legal defense: that no one knew or could have known asbestos was dangerous during the period covered by a number of complaints.

title: SECRECY SHROUDS A 'STAR WARS' SEQUEL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Audie Bock's most recent publication is a translation of the Japanese film director Akira Kurosawa's memoirs, ''Something Like an Autobiography'' (Alfred A. Knopf). By AUDIE BOCK CRESCENT CITY, Calif. All the locals in this tiny (population 2,500) timber and fishing community know is that for some reason, a surprising number of strangers have moved into their midst, filling some of the motels and restaurants that would otherwise be empty in the worst recession since World War II. But until now, the inhabitants of this northernmost California town, where the official unemployment rate has topped 28 percent, have had no inkling of who the strangers are or why they are there. They have not known that practically in their own backyard, a $32.5 million film has been in production and that roughly $2 million of this amount is being spent right here on location, much of it on local salaries, food, lodging, transportation and materials.

title: SundaySports
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens. Tim Lollar of the Padres (9-2) has the best winning percentage in the majors (.818). He beat the Mets, 6-0, on April 29. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570, 1:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Angels, at Anaheim, Calif. (Television -Channel 11, 4 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 4 P.M.) Braves vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Atlanta. (Television - Manhattan Cable, 3:05 P.M.) Soccer World Cup, Italy vs. West Germany, championship game, in Madrid. Italy's Paolo Rossi, with five goals, is the leading scorer in the tournament. West Germany has a streak of 33 games without a loss against European competition. (Television - Channels 7 and 41, 1:30 P.M.) Tennis Davis Cup, quarterfinals, United States vs. Sweden, at the Checkerdome, St. Louis. John McEnroe vs. Mats Willander and Anders Jarryd vs. Eliot Teltscher. (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M.) Swiss Open at Gstaad, Switzerland. $100,000 Miller Hall of Fame Championships at Newport (R.I.) Casino.

title: A DANCE SERIES FOSTERS DEBATE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Craig Bromberg organized the programs being presented by the Downtown Branch of the Whitney Museum. By CRAIG BROMBERG

title: CUTTING NUMBERS DOWN TO SIZE
description: WASHINGTON Almost every major Government agency will feel the impact of the Administration's efforts to reduce spending on the gathering of statistics, but some will be pinched more than others. Those expected to be most affected by the budget ax include:

title: TOUGHER TIMES FOR CABLE TV
description: LIFE once seemed much easier in the cable television business. With an evolving technology that promised to bring 100 channels of news and entertainment to television screens, viewers signed up by the millions to bring cable into their homes. Industry executives, meanwhile, talked of cable's limitless future -and profits. With strong financial backing from the nation's media giants, they enthusiastically looked ahead to the wiring of America.

title: PLANES IN HEAVY WEATHER
description: THE SPORTY GAME By John Newhouse. 242 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: LITTLE HEADWAY IS REPORTED
description: An American envoy met today with senior Syrian officials in what appeared to be a vain attempt to get them to reconsider their refusal to accept Palestinian fighters, currently besieged in Beirut by Israeli forces.

title: GETTING TO KNOW WHAT YOU'RE SEEING
description: SUMMIT ''KNOW WHAT YOU SEE'' is an exhibition that comes to the Summit Art Center with a caveat from its organizer, Louis Pomerantz, a fellow of the American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works.

title: AMONG PROS, MORE GO SUZUKI
description: American string players were unusually plentiful and prominent throughout the laborious elimination rounds of this year's Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. When the contest ended last week, the United States claimed five violinists and three cellists among the finalists, with violinist Tomoko Kato, a young Tokyo native studying at the Juilliard School of Music in New York City, taking home the second-place silver medal, and Stephanie Chase of Westport, Conn., and Andres Cardenes, a Cuban native teaching at the University of Indiana at Bloomington, tied for third.

title: TAX STUDY FINDS NEW YORKERS HID $25 BILLION OR MORE IN '80 INCOME
description: A special state investigation panel has estimated that New Yorkers failed to report at least $25 billion in 1980 personal income, about 15 percent of the total personal income in the state.

title: Bring Back Mencken
description: In his article, ''My Fellow Americanians'' (On Language, June 6), William Safire asks, ''Aren't there any rules for toponymic derivatives?'' The answer to his question is found in H.L. Mencken's ''The American Language'' (Fourth Edition) where he summarizes George R. Stewart Jr.'s principles that underlie the formation of the nouns designating a resident of a certain city. The sage, however, lists frequent exceptions to Mr. Stewart's rules, but not without a sense of humor, such as: ''Thus the people of Chicago have been called Chicagorillas, those of Baltimore Baltimorons, those of Omaha Omahogs, those of Louisville Louisvillains, those of Swampscott, Mass, Swampskeeters, and those of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, Bunnies (See der rabbits). JOSEPH R. DONOVAN, Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: The Bard's Walk
description: To the Editor:

title: DIVESTING
description: With a huge battle underway for public approval of its restructuring plan, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is preparing a nationwide marketing program that will include one of the most expensive corporate advertising efforts in recent years.

title: JAZZ GUITAR UNPLUGGED CLASSICIST
description: Although Laurindo Almeida, the guitarist, is known best in jazz circles at least for his three-year stay with Stan Kenton's Orchestra in the late 40's, his presence at the Village West, Hudson Street between Bank and West 11th Streets, a restaurant that supplements its food with jazz groups, is decidedly off the beaten track. He will be there through next Sunday.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: BEFORE they go the way of the bulldozer and suburban sprawl, the folk cultures of Suffolk County are being recorded for posterity. Last year, maritime folk life was documented; this year, thanks to a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts that came through last week, the folk arts and crafts associated with the farming industry will be studied.

title: Margaret Stone, Architect Wed
description: Margaret Dill Stone and William Neal Herman, 1981 graduates of Cornell University, were married in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday. Judge Kenneth MacKenzie of the Superior Court of New Jersey performed the ceremony at the Stronghold Mansion.

title: HOW TO KEEP WOOD DECKS AND PORCHES FROM LOSING LUSTER
description: ALTHOUGH a wood deck or porch made of pressure-treated lumber will probably last almost a lifetime without further treatment, few homeowners (or builders) actually use this type of lumber in residential construction. This is either because of the higher cost of this lumber or because it is not widely available. But those who do use it should be made aware that even where such lumber is used, if the wood is left as is, it gets dirty and dingy-looking in time, or it develops ugly discolored stains.

title: FICTION
description: 1 2 17 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 3 9 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 3 1 6 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 4 4 5 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 5 7 23 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 6 5 11 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 7 6 8 FOR SPECIAL SERVICES, by John Gardner. (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $9.95.)

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Gondolas
description: To the Editor:

title: YOGURT: EASY ON THE MAYO
description: Although yogurt for many years has been considered a basic ingredient in many dishes of India, it is not used all that often in this country as something to be cooked or otherwise blended in hot or cold sauces.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Respite for Rates?

title: Which Way Out Of the Embargo?
description: For President Reagan, a simple ''matter of principle'' has become a complex lesson in practical politics. Under threats from angry European allies, he is exploring ways to soften his recent economic sanctions against the Soviet Union and Poland.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GRADING: THIS SUMMER'S HOTTEST CONROVERSY
description: The summer of '82 figures to be a hot one for people who buy and sell coins - not because of temperatures in the 90's, but because of numbers in the 60's. The numbers in question are those assigned to mint-state coins when they are graded because grading has become the hobby's burning issue this summer.

title: SPIES AND LOVERS AND ACTION
description: THE BRINK By N.J. Crisp. 296 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95. FAMILY TRADE By James Carroll. 417 pp. Boston: Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: Norman Wins by a Shot
description: Greg Norman of Australia held off a late charge by Brian Marchbank of Scotland and won the $136,000 State Express Classic golf tournament by one stroke today with a 13-under-par 279.

title: PLAGIARISM CHARGES CONFRONT UNIVERSITY
description: FOR the second time this year, Fairleigh Dickinson University is investigating plagiarism charges. Although the university was aware of the allegations a year ago, no action was taken until last month.

title: Sports People; Marvelous Marv
description: ''Marvelous'' Marv Throneberry has been made out to be the symbol of the futility of the early New York Mets. He is still depicted that way in television commercials.

title:
A SCANDAL IN FINANCIAL MARKETS ROCKS SOUTH KOREA'S BUSINESS AND;
POLITICAL LEADERS
description: SEOUL, South Korea ON Wednesday, the trial of 29 bankers, business executives and moneylenders began here in what prosecutors have called ''the biggest financial scandal in Korean history.''

title: Langhorne Gibson, 82 Writer and Artist's Son
description: Langhorne Gibson, a writer and son of the artist Charles Dana Gibson, died Saturday at his farm in Greenwood, Va. He was 82 years old.

title: DOME PETROLEUM'S DEBT STRUGGLE
description: For years Dome Petroleum Ltd. was a company that glowed. In the increasingly lucrative oil and natural gas business, it was among the pioneers developing new drilling techniques in the forbidding Beaufort Sea. The stock market applauded, pushing the company's shares to new highs, while people happily referred to its chairman and founder as ''Smiling Jack.''

title: China Accuses U.S. Right Of Pro-Taiwan Drive
description: China accused right-wing Americans today of having begun a new anti-Communist, pro-Taiwan campaign in the hope of exploiting Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s replacement by George P. Shultz as Secretary of State.

title: Renaissance Mankowski
description: Phil Mankowski, the third baseman the Mets recently called up from Tidewater of the International League, grew up in Buffalo. He played all sports in season, and he eventually committed himself to baseball in 1971 after he had been selected in the free agent draft by the Detroit Tigers. In the late 1970's he spent four seasons with the Tigers before he was traded with Jerry Morales to the Mets for Richie Hebner in 1979.

title: FROM DISGRACE TO HERO
description: Paolo Rossi, whose six goals in the final three games provided almost all the offense that Italy needed to win its third World Cup championship in Madrid yesterday, was not eligible to play soccer in Italy only nine weeks ago. He had been implicated in a betting scandal in 1980 and suspended for three years by the Italian Football Federation, even though he was not found guilty by Italian courts.

title: Sihanouk Names Leadership Of Anti-Vietnamese Coalition
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk formally named the members of the coalition government of anti-Vietnamese forces today and appealed for international support.

title: Melody Cass, College Aide, Is Wed to Daniel L. Valdes
description: Melody Cass, admissions secretary for Eckard College in St. Petersburg, Fla., was married yesterday to Daniel L. Valdes, a cosmetologist with Glemby International in St. Petersburg.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a National Hockey League game, Team A, losing by 2-1 with less than a minute remaining, pulls its goalie. A player on Team B intercepts a pass and breaks for the empty net, but he is tripped from behind. If a penalty shot is involved, does the goalie return to the net? Also, how many penalty shots have been taken in playoff games, how many were successful and how many were in overtime?

title: CAN MINOR LEAGUE ANCHORMAN MAKE IT IN MAJORS?
description: HE was called ''the Walter Cronkite of Chicago,'' where after nine years at WBBM-TV he was that city's most popular evening-news anchor. He roamed the globe, reporting stories from Iran, South Africa, Poland and other countries where few local anchors have ventured, and he became one of Chicago's most admired citizens.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 12, 1982
description: International A fierce artillery fight in west Beirut seemed to indicate that the Palestinian guerrillas besieged by Israeli armored units still had a great deal of ammunition, weapons and resolve. For the first time, the Palestinians fired back on Israeli gun positions in Christian east Beirut. The battle broke up negotiations for a settlement as all diplomatic efforts focused on a cease-fire. (Page A1, Column 6.) Philip C. Habib needs more time to bring about an agreement in Beirut for the withdrawal of Palestinian forces, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said. ''A realistic assessment'' of the time needed by Mr. Habib, the special American envoy, is three more weeks, Mr. Weinberger said. Other Administration officials said, however, that they were far from certain that Israel would continue to hold off an invasion of west Beirut for that long. (A6:3-6.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: For Soccer Fans, Icing on the Cake

title: JERSEY TOWNSHIP PASSES CURB ON HEADPHONES
description: On the ears of strollers and joggers, bicyclists and motorists, headphones are appearing in force here, and the town fathers have decided that enough is enough.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Raquel Welch Lose Suit

title: CAMACHO DAZZLING AT GARDEN
description: With a dazzling display of speed and punching, Hector (Macho) Camacho established himself as one of the brightest young stars in boxing yesterday by stopping previously unbeaten Louie (Golden) Loy at 1 minute 24 seconds of the seventh round.

title: 'TAX HOME' IS THE OFFICE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Israel is in a quandary about how to get the Palestine Liberation Organization out of Beirut. The political negotiations seem less promising with each passing day. The military option, with its inevitable bloodshed, seems to grow more complex, more costly and less attractive as time drags on. But it also grows more likely, especially as rocket and mortar duels between Palestinian and Israeli forces increase daily.

title: Police Said to Arrest Activist In Argentine Rights Campaign
description: A leading Argentine human rights activist, Jose Westerkamp, has been arrested by the police in the southern province of Chubut, his wife, Angela, said today.

title: CLERC TROUNCES VILAS IN FINAL
description: Jose-Luis Clerc had little difficulty beating Guillermo Vilas in the all-Argentine final of the $100,000 Swiss Open tennis championships today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
SHAMROCK'S CHIEF HOPEFUL ON SIGMOR
description: William H. Bricker, the 50-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, is ebullient about his company's agreement to acquire the Sigmor Corporation, one of the largest independent gasoline retailers in the United States.

title: ARGENTINES ARE SEEKING WAYS TO OVERCOME SERIES OF LOSSES
description: One month after its forces surrendered in Stanley, Argentina is a changed nation searching for a new direction. The defeat in the Falklands combined with an economic recession, three-digit inflation, the imposition of Government control over a free-market economy, political confusion, international isolation and even the loss in the World Cup last week have left many Argentines demoralized about their past and questioning the future. A mood of uncertainty hangs over the country.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH A 'GUILTY BUT INSANE' VERDICT
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO OPINIONS ON AIRLINES;  IS the airline industry soaring to prosperity or is it descending into uncertainty? Two analysts react differently to this question.  Last Friday Salomon Brothers' transportation analyst, Julius Maldutis Jr., turned bearish. Noting disappointing June traffic figures in light of strength in airline shares, he canceled his recommendations on eight carriers.
description: By contrast, Anthony Low-Beer has been and remains bullish on the industry - particularly long-term. Mr. Low-Beer, transportation analyst for L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, cites supply and demand factors. He thinks airlines will be scaling back and deferring aircraft purchases to lay the foundation for high profits later.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Chaplin-O'Neill Theater Seeking $150,000

title: SOUTH AFRICA USING THE COURTS TO STRIKE AT CRITICS
description: There was some concern here a couple of months ago when newspapers carried reports that the head of the security police, Lieut. Gen. Johan Coetzee, appeared to be in favor of secret trials to overcome the tendency of the Government's opponents to turn courtrooms into political forums.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH A 'GUILTY BUT INSANE' VERDICT
description: To the Editor:

title: Music to His Ears
description: Dick Zokol, who has had little success in his first year on the professional golf tour, may have stumbled upon the secret ingredient needed to pull his game into winning form.

title: YANKS LOSE 4TH IN A ROW, TO ANGELS, 2-1
description: The Yankees limped into the All-Star Game break with another loss today that dropped them three games under .500.

title: DEVELOPING THE TOOLS TO COPE WITH THE REAL ENERGY PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A SMALL U.N.' CONVENES AT HYDE PARK
description: ''We really have a small United Nations here,'' Dr. Armand Hammer said today at the closing session of a conference on peace and human rights at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library and Museum here.

title: WELL-MEANING PENSION REFORM FAILS RANK & FILE
description: To the Editor:

title: JANET BAKER TAKING FAREWELL CURTAIN CALLS
description: century ago, Dame Janet Baker is bringing to a triumphant close a purposely limited but nonetheless splendid operatic career.

title: MANHATTAN IN CHANGE: A LOOK AHEAD TO A DENSER CENTRAL CITY
description: First of three articles. By PAUL GOLDBERGER

title: Meredith Tax and Marshall Berman, Writers, Wed
description: Meredith Tax and Marshall Berman, who are authors, were married yesterday at Temple Ansche Chesed. Rabbi Harlan Wexler of the Park Avenue Synagogue performed the ceremony.

title: Boeff-Horak Wins
description: Dave Boeff and Bob Horak of the Ontario Country Club of Rochester defeated George Marucci and Henri DeLozier of the Columbia Golf Club, 8 and 7, in the 36-hole final to capture the Anderson Memorial best-ball tournament today at Winged Foot Golf Club.

title: Richard Rychtarik, 87, Designer of Stage Sets
description: Richard W. Rychtarik, a former set designer for the Metropolitan Opera and the Columbia Broadcasting System, died Saturday at the age of 87 at the Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness.

title: MISS STACY TRIUMPHS IN PLAYOFF
description: Hollis Stacy sank a one-foot par putt on the first playoff hole and defeated Kathy Postlewait in a sudden-death playoff for the second year in a row in the West Virginia Classic today.

title: Chicago Prelate to Get Query on Cody Finances
description: Representatives of the clergy and the laity will ask the new head of the nation's largest Roman Catholic archdiocese to investigate and explain the financial dealings of his predecessor, a spokesman said Saturday.

title: KOCH AIDES SEE UNIONS GETTING DEFERRED RAISES
