description: Seven years after municipal workers gave up part or all of a pay increase to help save New York City from default at the onset of its fiscal crisis, the Koch administration has indicated that it is now willing to pay the money.

title: CARL E. PURINTON
description: Dr. Carl E. Purinton, former chairman of the departments of religion at Adelphi College and at Boston University, died Friday at Winchester (Va.)

title: ANALYSTS SAY G.O.P. NEEDS QUICK SIGNS OF ECONOMIC GAINS
description: President Reagan returned from an 11-day California vacation today, with political strategists saying he needs quick, clear signs of economic improvement to protect the Republican Party from election losses this fall.

title: Bring the Dust Children Home
description: The cause of the pitiful bui doi, the dust children of Southeast Asia, has just been advanced by a surprising benefactor, the Foreign Minister of Vietnam. It's an opening that Congress, as it returns to work today, has a duty to seize.

title: Legacy Of a Father
description: THEY sat side by side at breakfast, the son who now is a world lightweight champion and the father who never had the opportunity to win that title after he was wounded during World War II by shrapnel from a mortar shell.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Moving Offices to Brooklyn
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will temporarily move its national headquarters from Manhattan to the Brooklyn Heights area within the next six weeks, Benjamin L. Hooks, the organization's executive director, has announced.

title: A DOLL THAT BOWS TO SUPPLY AND DEMAND
description: Novelty manufacturers, like Democrats, lampoon Ronald Reagan at their own risk. Accordingly, the latest entry into the office-gift field in Washington, the Reaganomics Doll, is as carefully finessed and two-sided as a proxy vote.

title: THE PERILS OF VINCE FERRAGAMO, PART 3
description: In a move that had been expected for six months, but had in no way been assured, the Los Angeles Rams last week again signed their runaway quarterback, Vince Ferragamo. The signing by no means ended the affair; it was merely another disjointed scene in a drama fit for daytime television.

title: JUDGE OVERRULES A BID TO SHIELD 2 F.B.I. AGENTS
description: A judge has ruled that two undercover agents who infiltrated organized crime cannot conceal their true names when they testify in a Federal racketeering trial scheduled to begin this week in Manhattan.

title: UPSHAW THREAT SEEN
description: Gene Upshaw, the Oakland Raiders' offensive lineman who is president of the National Football League Players Association, has sent Craig Morton of the Denver Broncos a controversial letter over Morton's statements about the players' union.

title: Peete Wins by 2
description: Calvin Peete shot a three-under-par 69 today to win the Greater Milwaukee Open Golf title for a second time. The 38-year-old from Detroit won by two shots with a 72-hole total of 274, 14 under par for hilly Tuckaway Country Club. Peete, whose only other PGA Tour title came here in 1979, clinched his victory with a birdie on the 17th hole. Terry Diehl, a co-leader at the time, bogeyed the same 220-yard, par-3 hole to drop from the lead in a dramatic two-shot swing. Diehl, 31, trying to shake a season-long slump, settled for third place behind Victor Regalado of Mexico. Diehl, who had missed the cut in four of his last five tournaments, had a 71, the same as Regalado, another slumping veteran. Regalado had a total of 276, 12 under par on the cool, sunny day on this 7,010-yard layout just south of Milwaukee. Regalado earned $27,000. Diehl, whose total was 277, won $17,000. Dick Zokol, the Canadian rookie who shared the lead after each of the first three rounds, dropped out of contention with a bogey at 15, a double bogey at 16 and another bogey at 17.

title: Randi Shulman Married
description: Randi Beth Shulman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Shulman of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Brett Fallor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Fallor of Port Washington, L.I. Cantor Henry Herman performed the ceremony at the Kittle House Inn in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The bride is an associate director of the National Women's Health Organization Inc. in New York. Mr. Fallor is a production supervisor with CBS-TV.

title: A SELF-INFLICTED WOUND
description: The thin young man sat on the edge of his bed talking calmly about the prospect of his physical collapse. When I saw him, on July 7, Sergei Petrov had had nothing to eat or drink except water for 36 days. He was on a hunger strike for the right to leave the Soviet Union and join his American wife.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Cambridge Plan International Inc., Monterey, Calif., has appointed F. William Graham to the new post of senior executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Computer Pedalists
description: Last month, five prospects for the United States Olympic cycling team gathered at the Pennsylvania State University in University Park to submit to computer tests that may help at least one of them win a medal in the Games in Los Angeles in 1984.

title: HOW JOB ROTATION WORKS FOR JAPANESE
description: In his 26 years with the Toyo Kogyo Company, Mitsuji Muraoka has been an accountant, a plant designer, an efficiency watchdog, a materials-handling specialist and a computer systems manager.

title: NEW VACATION POLICY: KEEPING BUSY
description: It is an axiom among President Reagan's advisers that, given his choice, Mr. Reagan will head for California every time. And in his favorite state, Mr. Reagan's favorite spot is his ranch, tucked away in the tree-scented mountains that surround this coastal town.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Union Is Voted Down At Knott's Berry Farm
description: Union leaders said they would seek a new election after workers at Knott's Berry Farm amusement park voted nearly 6 to 1 against unionizing.

title: Child, 2, Dies in Crash
description: A car carrying family members to a reunion hit a ditch, flew into the air and hit an embankment, killing a 2-year-old girl and injuring five people, the state police at York, Pa., said. Shirkra Cohen of Newark was dead on arrival at York Hospital shortly after the accident at 7:30 A.M. Saturday.

title: PREMENSTRUAL SYNDROME: A COMPLEX ISSUE
description: Can a woman be so profoundly affected by the biological changes she undergoes every month that she could be driven to perform acts of violence that would be unthinkable at other times?

title: HOPES GROW FOR LOWER RATES
description: Was last week's sharp decline in interest rates just temporary or was it a turning point in the credit markets that will be followed by still lower rates in the second half of the year?

title: DIVERSE VIEWS OF ECONOMISTS
description: Although some recent economic numbers, such as the flash figure for the gross national product for the second quarter, appeared to signal that the recession was over, it's going to take more to convince Sam I. Nakagama, an economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: OPERA: CHINESE TROUPE PRESENTS FIRST OF 10 WORKS
description: THERE is the shock of ''deja vu'' about the the Guangdong Yue Opera Troupe of China, which gave its first performance in the Beacon Theater on Saturday night. The opera troupe, which is performing 10 operas in Chinese until July 18, is presenting a style of musical theater that developed only recently in Chinese history - a mere 200 years or so ago, which makes it a bit younger than European opera and a bit older than grand opera.

title: MEXICAN HELD AS LEADER OF ALIEN SMUGGLING RING IS ARRAIGNED
description: Wearing a white embroidered Mexican shirt, Salvador Pineda-Vergara listened to a reading in Spanish of a long indictment charging him with masterminding what the Immigration and Naturalization Service says is the largest illegal alien smuggling ring it has broken.

title: SMART HEIRESS RALLIES TO WIN
description: Woody Stephens was slightly baffled by the outcome of the Garden City Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The trainer had sent out the entry of Larida and Smart Heiress and had expected them to finish first and second in that order. He had put Eddie Maple, his regular stable rider, on Larida, and Mike Venezia on Smart Heiress. But at the finish of the mile and a quarter on the grass, Smart Heiress had caught her stablemate and won by three-quarters of a length.

title: BEGIN STUDIES MILITARY OPTIONS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin studied military alternatives today to force Palestinian guerrillas from Beirut after pessimistic reports on talks to solve the problem peacefully, a Cabinet source said.

title: 4 Injured in Fire At West Side Hotel
description: Four persons were injured when a fire broke out last night in a room of a West Side hotel, the police said. Many patrons fled as smoke filled some of the upper floors of the 28-story hotel, the Milford Plaza on Eighth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets.

title: CURB U.S. DEFICITS NOT THE MONEY SUPPLY
description: To the Editor:

title: JERVIS J. BABB, EX-CHAIRMAN OF LEVER BROTHERS, DIES AT 80
description: Jervis J. Babb, former president and chairman of Lever Brothers Company, died Friday at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 80 years old.

title: QUESTIONS RUMBLE BELOW ALL-STAR SURFACE
description: CARL HUBBELL remembers when they called it the ''midsummer classic,'' back in 1933 when the teams were picked by John McGraw and Connie Mack and when Babe Ruth hit the home run that won the first All-Star Game. But he thinks it has changed.

title: YOUNG & RUBICAM, USA ACQUIRES ELLIS, SINGER; Young & Rubicam USA Acquires Ellis, Singer
description: Ellis, Singer & Webb, an Orlando, Fla., agency with an estimated $7 million in billings, has been acquired by Young & Rubicam USA and will be merged into its Young & Rubicam/ Zemp, which the agency has owned in St. Petersburg, Fla., for eight years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Auf Wiedersehen On 14th Street

title: Kobe-Wheeling Tie
description: Kobe Steel Ltd, citing a worldwide decline in demand, has disclosed that it has postponed a decision on whether to accept a proposal by the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation for possible financial cooperation in a seamless steel pipe project. Wheeling-Pittsburgh plans to build a $140 million seamless steel pipe plant and has asked Kobe to put up half the cost, Kobe said. Kobe Steel sent two survey missions to the United States in May and June to look into the project.

title: TWO WIND ALERTS BROADCAST SHORTLY BEFORE JET CRASHED
description: Two alerts warning of hazardous wind shifts were broadcast by the New Orleans airport tower as a Pan American World Airways jet taxied Friday for the takeoff that ended in a crash in a residential suburb, Federal officials disclosed yesterday.

title: TAX FRAUD HYPERBOLE
description: At a recent Congressional hearing, the Internal Revenue Service estimated the revenue lost because of noncompliance at $87 billion in 1981 and projected a rise to $120 billion in 1985 if the funds for enforcement remained at the current level. These estimates properly alarmed the Congressional tax-writing committees and the public.

title: Intruder Talks to Queen In Her Bedroom at Palace
description: A man broke into Buckingham Palace, entered the bedroom of Queen Elizabeth II and sat on her bed, chatting for 10 minutes before she was able to summon a footman who took him away, The Daily Express reported today. It said the Queen was not harmed.

title: MCCRORY MOVING INTO TITLE PICTURE
description: With Sugar Ray Leonard's boxing career on hold while he recuperates from surgery to correct a detached retina in his left eye, the contenders are lining up in the welterweight division.

title: TRAINER OF HORSES
description: John M. Gaver, the head trainer for Greentree Stable for 38 years and a member of thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame, died early yesterday morning at his home in Aiken, S.C. Mr. Gaver, who had been in poor health since he was forced to retire after suffering a heart attack and stroke in 1977, was 81 years old.

title: 11 Hurt by Pamplona Bulls
description: Eleven men were injured today, two of them seriously, during the annual Pamplona running of the bulls festival, the police said. About 1,500 people raced in front of six bulls in the narrow streets of the capital. Fifty-two people have died since the event began in 1591.

title: Death Is Still Different
description: There may be more agreement than meets the eye in the Supreme Court's view of capital punishment. On close examination, a 5-to-4 decision sparing the life of a ''non-triggerman'' accomplice to murder turns out to show a unanimous commitment to the proposition that ''death is different'' - that the extreme penalty demands the utmost care in sentencing.

title: Helaine Gould Married To Lieut. R.P. Catalano
description: Helaine Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald W. Gould of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday at the Woodbury (L.I.) Country Club to Lieut.(j.g.) Robert P. Catalano, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Catalano also of Syosset. Justice of the Peace William Kelly of Oyster Bay, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: ISADORE D. PILLA
description: Isadore D. Pilla, a former president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx and the Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards, died Saturday at Rosary Hill Nursing Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 78 years old and a resident of Eastchester, N.Y.

title: Padres Defeat Mets As Lollar Excels
description: The baseball season has officially reached its halfway mark, and for the Mets the three-day hiatus could not have come at a better time.

title: 2 Lionel Chiefs Are Replaced
description: The Lionel Corporation, the electronics parts manufacturer and toy retailer that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, has replaced its two top officers under pressure from creditors.

title: IF ISRAEL WOULD REMAIN WORTHY OF OUR UNDERSTANDING
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: DIAGHILEV ON CABLE ARTS CHANNEL
description: THE so-called culture-cable outlets continue to find programs of note, the kind of presentations that public television once almost monopolized. CBS Cable has been presenting, for instance, Wednesdays at 8:30 P.M., a first-rate biographical series on the composer Igor Stravinsky. And now, this evening at 9, an equally fascinating companion piece, also produced for the BBC, can be found on the Hearst/ABC Arts channel.

title: The Man Who Marked Rummenigge
description: THEY call him ''Auntie'' because of his mature behavior at the age of 18 years old. Giuseppe Bergomi was the youngest player on the field yesterday in the most important soccer game in the world, the final of the World Cup.

title: Harrah's Hurrah
description: When a batter with a career average of .263 hits about 80 points higher than that for half of a major league baseball season, is there an easy answer? Not according to Toby Harrah, the third baseman of the Cleveland Indians who has been batting higher than .340 for three months.

title: Advertising; Magazine For Clubs Is Planned
description: THE collapse of Braniff Airways was a sorry blow to the Halsey Publishing Company in North Miami, Fla., which had gone into business in 1972 as publisher of the carrier's in-flight magazine, Flying Colors. While it was left with a number of other publications that it had gotten into later, including the Delta Sky magazine and Butler Skylite, it was, nevertheless, clearly facing a pinch.

title: RISE OF RADIO'S 'BLACK MUSIC' SOURCE
description: Just after sunset each night, not many years ago in the South, millions of people would crank their radios to the far right end of the dial, to WLAC, whose format in the sundown-tosunup hours was different from any other station broadcasting to a large area. It offered black music only.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REELING POLITICS

title: Rolling Stones, in Italy, Catch Soccer Fever
description: More than 60,000 fans screamed wildly as Mick Jagger pranced across stage Sunday, kicking off the first Rolling Stones Italian tour in 15 years.

title: BALLESTEROS IS STILL A PUZZLE TO GOLF PEERS
description: Severiano Ballesteros is to European golf what Arnold Palmer was to the game in the 1960's. He plays with the same audacity that Palmer had in his youth, and in Europe he comes close to matching Palmer's charisma.

title: The U.N. Today; July 12, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission Working Group on New International Eco- nomic Order - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Marcie Weiss Bride of Thomas Bassett
description: Marcie Joanne Weiss, daughter of Col. Donald G. Weiss, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Weiss, was married yesterday to Thomas Michael Bassett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Bassett. Both families are of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice George Beisheim Jr. performed the ceremony aboard the yacht Inspiration on the Hudson River en route to the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., where a reception was held at the Officers' Club.

title: Israelis Dismiss Arab Mayor
description: Israel has dismissed Rashid Hijazi, Mayor of Deir Dibwan, in the West Bank, the eighth such dismissal in the occupied territories since March, an Israeli spokesman said today. The Mayor was replaced by ''three Arab officials'' because he had ''staged a work slowdown in the municipality,'' the spokesman added.

title: Salvador Says Army Killed 130 Guerrillas
description: A Salvadoran military spokesman said today that army troops killed 130 guerrillas and destroyed a rebel training camp in a recent major offensive in Morazan Province, along the Honduran border.

title: AMID THE WAR, KITE-FLYING AND CHEERS FOR ISRAELIS
description: A white kite, its long tail fluttering gaily, flew high over Burj al-Brajna, a Palestinian refugee camp near the Beirut International Airport, this morning.

title: COLOMBIA UPHELD AS '86 HOST
description: Colombia is the only country being considered as the host for the next World Cup soccer tournament in 1986, Joao Havelange, president of the sport's world governing body, said today.

title: SMALL STOCKS POOR HALF
description: Issues on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market followed much the same dismal downward trend as those on the larger and less volatile New York Stock Exchange through the first half of this year.

title: Fat and Fear at Agriculture
description: Spare a thought for John Block and Richard Lyng, one racked by doubt, the other by an awesome fear. Mr. Block is the Secretary of Agriculture, but is unsure whether his job is to protect just agricultural interests, or also the public's. Mr. Lyng is his deputy and has never even tasted a doubt.

title: Dalai Lama to Visit Malaysia
description: The Dalai Lama, the spiritual and temporal head of the Tibetan people, will arrive here July 27 to begin a tour of Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia and Australia, Government officials said today. The Dalai Lama, who lives in exile in India, will be a guest of Malaysian Buddhist associations, an official said.

title: ROCK: X AT PALLADIUM
description: X MADE two of the most exciting rock albums of recent years and built up a substantial national following while recording for the independent Slash label. The group headlined at the Palladium for the first time Saturday night, just two weeks after the release of its first album for a major label, ''Under the Big Black Sun'' (Elektra), and the upswing in its fortunes has given it confidence to work harder and outdo itself.

title: VACATIONS: A COUPLE'S BATTLEFIELD
description: THEY fought in Barcelona, in Paris, in the Poconos. They fought on the ferry ride to Sausalito a nd in a Chinese restaurant in Dublin. Dublin was the worst, as she r emembers.

title: Vibrations Shut Down Upstate Atom Reactor
description: The James A. FitzPatrick nuclear power plant at Lycoming, N.Y., on the shore of Lake Ontario in Oswego County, shut down automatically yesterday because of what officials called excessive vibration in the main steam turbine.

title: FEW ISSUES ARE OFFERED THIS WEEK
description: Only about $225 million of corporate notes and bonds are scheduled for sale this week, though investment bankers said more issues might emerge if investor demand is strong and yields on competing Treasury issues continue to decline.

title: PEACE TALKS STALL
description: Israeli armored units fought a fierce artillery and rocket duel today with Palestinian guerrillas trapped inside west Beirut.

title: Katherine Wyse Wed To Henry F. Goldman
description: Katherine Lynn Wyse, daughter of Mrs. Lee Guber of New York and Marc Wyse of Pepper Pike, Ohio, was married yesterday to Henry Frank Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Goldman of Rockville Centre, L.I. Rabbi Max J. Routtenberg performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: ROBBERY REPORTS DECLINE BY 44% IN ONE PRECINCT
description: The number of reported robberies in a high-crime Brooklyn precinct has dropped 44 percent in the six months since the police began a program they say stresses old-fashioned police work.

title: Vanity Handicap to Sangue
description: Sangue passed Track Robbery midway through the stretch today to score a 1 1/2-length victory in the $200,000 Vanity Handicap, the race that traditionally determines the filly championship of the Hollywood Park meeting.

title: Commodities; Big Growth In Assets Of Funds
description: COMMODITY futures speculators need not be reminded that the first half of 1982 was an expensive time for most of them because they continued to favor the long - or buy -side of the markets during a period that witnessed large price declines in almost all commodities.

title: MONDAY, JULY 12, 1982; International
description: OPEC officials said unilateral price reductions or production increases by members were possible following a special session of the group that ended in disarray Saturday in Vienna. (Page D1.) Oil industry analysts say OPEC may have lost its bite as a result of the decline in oil consumption and the political squabbles among members. The collapse of the Vienna meeting, they say, is further proof that the cartel has been unable to adjust to the market's fall. (D3.)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MUSSOLINI. By Denis Mack Smith. 429 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $20.

title: Scypion Beats Frazie
description: The middleweight Wilford Scypion bounced back from a two-fight losing streak today to take a 10-round unanimous decision over the previously unbeaten Mark (Golden Boy) Frazie.

title: PROSPECTS FOR SOVIET GRAIN PACT
description: The question of renewing this country's grain trade agreement with the Soviet Union is a politically explosive issue that has divided the Administration and increased the worries of American farmers. It is a matter likely to be raised Monday when Agriculture Secretary John R. Block meets with President Reagan to discuss the depressed farm economy.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Philharmonia' No More

title: BRITAIN DROPPING DEMAND ON P.O.W.'S
description: Britain appeared today to be a step closer to returning the last 590 Argentine prisoners of the Falkland Islands war after apparently dropping a demand that their release be linked to a statement by Buenos Aires declaring the hostilities to be offically over.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Tradition Continues

title: IN MOODUS, 3 CENTURIES OF SHAKE, RATTLE AND ROLL
description: Martha Monte was drying her hair when the windows of her home began to rattle and a pop pierced the air. ''There it goes again,'' she said to herself. Thirty seconds later, serenity returned. It was just another earthquake. There are so many here, after all -hundreds in the last month and, at that rate, thousands since settlers came to this area in the 1630's. By one explanation, that is not coincidental.

title: RESTORING HARMONY IS THE OPEC GOAL
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries struggled today to avoid an outbreak of pricecutting and production increases, following the cartel's failure to reach any agreement at a weekend gathering.

title: LETTER FROM A POLISH PRISON SAYS DETAINEES ARE ABUSED
description: A letter reported by Roman Catholic Church sources to have been smuggled out of a prison in southern Poland complains that political prisoners have been beaten by guards, that many suffer illness because of their diet and that religious objects have been destroyed.

title: HABIB SAID TO NEED 3 WEEKS FOR A BEIRUT SOLUTION
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that ''a realistic assessment'' of the time needed by Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, to achieve a withdrawal of Palestinian forces from west Beirut would be three more weeks.

title: CRIME THREAT TO JERSEY CASINOS REPORTED
description: When the New Jersey Legislature debated and adopted the state's Casino Control Act five years ago, particular emphasis was placed on preventing organized crime from infiltrating the new casino industry in Atlantic City.

title: Wicket Diplomacy
description: Since baseball will be a demonstration sport in the 1984 Olympic Games at Los Angeles, members of the United States Baseball Federation have decided to give a couple of European countries a taste of the sport that they seldom see. With the backing of the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company, they have sent a team of 16 high school allstars from the Cleveland area to England and the Netherlands.

title: CLASH EMERGING ON U.S. RELIANCE ON OVERSEAS SOURCES FOR WEAPONS
description: The battle line between the House majority leader, Jim Wright of Texas, and the Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, has been drawn over United States imports of military weapons made in Europe, Israel and Egypt.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 'Silkwood' Is Cast

title: A GIDDINGS TAKEOVER LIKELY
description: Fjr several months now, reports have circulated that Giddings & Lewis, a lucrative but modest-sized machine tool company that sprouted here 23 years ago, soon would disappear into some big-city conglomerate.

title: News Analysis
description: In recent days, the credit markets have been reinvigorated by conjecture that the Federal Reserve Board has reduced pressures that have kept interest rates high. However, in the view of some bankers and economists, the Fed's injection of large amounts of reserves into the banking system last week was primarily an effort to calm jittery financial markets.

title: NEW MONEY ISSUES WAIT FOR CONGRESS
description: The 97th Congress will return Monday from its July 4 recess to grapple anew with the fiscal problems that have dominated its existence, including a quest for new taxes and spending cuts and consideration of a constitutional amendment for a balanced budget.

title: BRIEFING
description: Civil Rights 'Shadow'

title: ROUGH PLAN EMERGING FOR AFGHAN PEACE
description: For the first time since the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan two years ago, substantive diplomatic exchanges are under way to explore the possibility of a political settlement that would lead to a Soviet withdrawal.

title: TANG, MCLOUTH BIDDER, IS A LOW-PROFILE SUITOR
description: Why would anyone be interested in buying the McLouth Steel Corporation, an ailing company in a desperately troubled industry? ''After we purchase McLouth, we'll let people know why we're interested,'' said Cyrus Tang, a 52-year-old Chicago industrialist.

title: Ellen Davis Goldwater Is Dead; A Historian and Civic Worker
description: Ellen Davis Goldwater, a historian and civic worker, died yesterday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived in Rowayton, Conn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We reinvented the wheel.'' -Deputy Inspector John J. Hill, on a new program to cut crime in the 90th Precinct. (B1:6.)

title: ALBANIANS REKINDLE ANCIENT CLAIMS
description: Last weekend in Tirana, the Albanian capital, the Communist Government sponsored a conference on the ethnic roots of that small Balkan nation that carried implications for its territorial claims on neighboring Yugoslavia and Greece.

title: VIETNAM IS SAID TO LACK MONEY TO PAY ITS DEBTS
description: The International Monetary Fund has produced a report on Vietnam's economy that, while pointing to recent improvements in some sectors, nonetheless casts doubt on whether the country can possibly meet this year's scheduled payments on its external debt.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, Elmont, L.I., 1:05 P.M. The $50,000 added Astoria Stakes for 2-year-old fillies has drawn a field of only four with Gala Jubilee the probable favorite because of her victory on June 2 in the Rosedale Stakes. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7 P.M., tape).

title: G.I. Goes on a Rampage With a Tank in Germany
description: A United States Army soldier stole a 50-ton M-60 tank on Saturday and went on a rampage through Mannheim, crushing 14 cars and ramming a streetcar before crashing into a river, the police said. Salvage crews recovered the tank and the soldier's body today.

title: Eshete Takes Prefontaine Race
description: Getachew Eshete of the Millrose Athletic Association, a 30-year-old civil engineer, scored a 10-yard victory over Pat Chambers in the Steve Prefontaine Memorial five-kilometer run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Eshete, an Ethiopian and a graduate of City College, covered the 3.1-mile run in 15 minutes 32.4 seconds.

title: FIVE ARE ARRESTED IN BANK BURGLARY
description: Burglars with sledgehammers, acetylene torches and sophisticated electronic equipment bypassed an alarm system and broke into a Brooklyn bank early yesterday, but were thwarted by a vault-door alarm and two police officers who spotted two lookouts hiding in the bushes outside. Five suspects were arrested.

title: Phils Defeat Dodgers and Valenzuela, 4-3
description: Bob Dernier's single and mistakes cost Fernando Valenzuela a chance for his 13th victory as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3, today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ladybugs in Profusion

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL IS CALLED A FINE SUCCESS STORY
description: THE Kool Jazz Festival, the 29th renewal of the jazz festival that began in Newport, R.I., in 1954 as the Newport Jazz Festival, completed a 10-day run on Sunday, the Fourth of July, as an ''unqualified success,'' according to its producer, George Wein.

title: Police Kill Man Identified as Rapist
description: Two police officers yesterday fatally shot one of two men who had been pointed out to them by a rape victim as having kidnapped her at gunpoint and assaulted her, the police said.

title: Briefs on the Arts; '42d Street' Will Play At Caesar's Palace
description: The musical ''42d Street,'' in a kind of first for a Broadway show, will play Las Vegas, beginning a limited engagement at Caesar's Palace next May. The musical will be done in the hotel's 1,200-seat Circus Maximus room, which ordinarily houses Frank Sinatra, say, or Wayne Newton.

title: EXODUS OF SERBIANS STIRS PROVINCE IN YUGOSLAVIA
description: Danilo Krstic and his family are hardworking wheat and tobacco farmers, Serbs who get along with their Albanian neighbors.

title: STAGE: 'HENRY IV, PART I' OPENS RUN IN STRATFORD
description: Peter Coe, who took over as artistic director at the American Shakespeare Theater last year, has a simple plan for bringing glory to Stratford. It's his intention to do Shakespeare simply, in the presumed Globe Theater manner, with paramount concern for the letter of the text and no directorial funny business. While this back-to-basics approach has its limits in a modern world, it also seems a sensible way to revive a theater that has long struggled with esthetic and financial bankruptcy. If Mr. Coe can get Stratford to walk now, maybe he can get it to run later on.

title: ITALY BEATS WEST GERMANY IN WORLD CUP FINAL
description: Italy won its first World Cup in 44 years tonight, beating West Germany, 3-1. Paolo Rossi capped his remarkable return from suspension by scoring the first goal and setting up the second with a beautiful display of ball-control.

title: IN THE 'VILLAGE' A NEW BREED OF BARBER
description: ''So peaceful!'' Joy Coburn declared as she emerged from Gary Tomlins Hair, one of the attractive small haircutting shops that have sprouted up in Greenwich Village. ''I used to be exhausted by the time I got out of the big uptown salons,'' she said. ''The tension. The rock music. The waiting. The prices. What a difference this is.''

title: MCENROE GETS U.S. VICTORY
description: John McEnroe defeated 17-year-old Mats Wilander in a 79-game five-set match that lasted 6 hours 35 minutes today to give the United States a 3-2 victory over Sweden in the Davis Cup quarterfinals.

title: Brewers in First on Record Homer Pace
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, hitting home runs at a record-breaking pace for the first half of the season, yesterday used their favorite swing to down the Kansas City Royals, 8-5, and take over first place in the American League East. Completing a three-game sweep, the Brewers edged ahead of the Boston Red Sox in winning percentage, .578 to .576, as the major leagues began the three-day All-Star Game break.

title: ANALYSTS SEE OPEC'S INFLUENCE WANING
description: The collapse of the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna during the weekend seems further proof that the group bears little semblance to an effective cartel, analysts said yesterday.

title: LITTLE ITALY REJOICES OVER CUP VICTORY
description: Little Italy was a little bigger last night. Like a blanket, a still nervousness lay over Mulberry Street yesterday afternoon as the Italian national soccer team took the field against West Germany in the World Cup final at Madrid. But in the second half, green, white and red banners - the flag of Italy - appeared out of apartment windows. Suddenly, when Italy's 3-1 victory was complete, the flag was ubiquitous - on automobile antennas, in the hands of small children, stuck in an old man's hat. Women started banging pots through curtained windows.

title: Barber Takes Senior Open
description: For three rounds, the aging stars of professional golf had tried and failed to conquer the deceptive Portland Golf Club course. But Miller Barber ended the futility today, firing a six-under-par 65 to win the $150,000 United States Senior Open title by four strokes.

title: Sheik in Miami Pledges To Pay Hotel Bill in Cash
description: A Saudi Arabian sheik who owes $1.5 million to a hotel, $156,000 to a cab company and lesser amounts to several merchants, has promised to pay his debts Monday.

title: Body of Missing Illinois Boy Is Found in Rocky Mountains
description: The body of Robert Baldeshwiler, a 12-year-old boy who had been missing since June 29 in Rocky Mountain National Park, was found on a steep slope tonight by park rangers.

title: THE DANCE: JAPANESE DAI RAKUDA KAN AT FESTIVAL
description: Mothers fled out of the theater with their children. Wide-eyed adults sat - occasionally - on the edge of their seats. Imagine a Japanese version of the Living Theater with a touch of Hieronymus Bosch, and you can almost pin a label on the Dai Rakuda Kan company or envisage its exuberantly received American debut at the American Dance Festival here.

title: Mariah Will Publish New Muppet Magazine
description: Among the nation's magazine publishers, we might identify Donald E. Welsh, 39 years old, as having a proclivity for young adults. He moved from ad director of Rolling Stone to publisher of Outside.

title: OUTDOORS: FASCINATION OF THE MIGHTY MUSKELLUNGE
description: A FEW days after the June 19 opening of the muskellunge season on the St. Lawrence River in both Canadian and New York State waters, several fish in the 20-pound class were taken in the Cape Vincent-Clayton-Alexandria Bay area.

title: BATTLE FOR ILLINGWORTH BACK IN BRITISH COURTS
Bridge: Part-Score Bidding Holds Some Pitfalls for Unwary
description: One interesting aspect of the game remains a closed book to those who limit their activities to duplicate games and tournaments. They never have to consider the subtle adjustments that are called for in rubber bridge or Chicago when one partnership, or both, owns a partscore.

title: Albany's War on Health Costs
description: New York State faces two devilish health care problems. Hospitals that treat the uninsured poor are reeling under the weight of accumulated deficits. And inpatient hospital costs continue to rise at unacceptable rates.

title: Children's Aid
description: When he was growing up in Hawaii, Milt Wilcox had a young family friend who suffered from a bone deformity in her leg. ''The leg just wouldn't grow properly,'' he said last week.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The board of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority today unanimously approved a new fare package for its transit and commuter rail routes, including a fivecent increase in the basic transit fare.

title: Marathon Split By U.S. Steel
description: The Marathon Oil Company said that it had transferred all of its domestic exploration and production operations to another unit of the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Study of Employee Purchase of Conrail
description: A task force will study whether employees of Conrail, the federally subsidized railroad corporation, should be active in the sale of Conrail or even acquire it themselves, the Railway Labor Executives' Association said.

title: Advertising; A Leading Radio Duo Splits Up
description: winning togetherness, creating scripts and acting them out, Bert Berdis has departed to join another Hollywood radio advertising specialty firm, Barzman & Company. He becomes a partner and creative associate of Alan Barzman and Jim Kirby.

title: UNWED, UNHEARD, UNPAID; New Tricks
description: When those six guard dogs worked for a company hired by the M.T.A., they did ferocious guard duty, frightening away graffiti artists from subway yards. But now the company has gone under and the tax collectors have taken the dogs as surety against unpaid taxes.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Recovering More Plutonium

title: FOR WOODY HERMAN, A SHIFT FROM ONE-NIGHTERS
description: ANYTIME that Woody Herman has come to New York with his orchestra in the last 20 years, he has been on a trip from nowhere, on his way to nowhere - a series of one-night stands that have had no beginning and no end. In recent years, he has played one night at Carnegie Hall, one night at the Bottom Line, one night at Wednesday's and one night at Jack Kleinsinger's ''Highlights in Jazz.''

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Communist Party has ousted nearly 50,000 more members in the second phase of a purge.

title: RCA Videodisks
description: The RCA Corporation said today that it was accelerating an expansion program at its Indianapolis videodisk plant because of the strength of the market. RCA said videodisk owners who have had their sets for more than 12 months have accumulated an average of 32 disks each.

title: 57 West Bank Students Arrested in Jerusalem
description: The police today arrested 57 Bir Zeit University students who were among many who had gathered at East Jerusalem high school buildings to carry on with classes because their campus was closed last week.

title: HOUSE SET TO STUDY PAGES' ALLEGATIONS
description: Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today rejected a call to appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate charges of sexual misconduct and drug use involving Capitol pages and members of Congress.

title: Chrysler Retooling
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would spend $80 million retooling its Jefferson assembly plant for production of 1983 model ''E''-body, four-door family sedans. It said production would begin in the first week of August, and that 60 cars an hour -Dodges and Chryslers - would be produced on two shifts. Chrysler said the plant would employ 4,700 and have an estimated annual payroll of $180 million.

title: RICHMOND RESIGNS COMPANY POST
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, has resigned as a director of the Walco National Corporation, which had voted him a 10-year ''pension'' totaling $1 million. The payments were ruled an ''illegal gift'' by a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan earlier this year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Nurse, Pass The Spatula, Please

title: CONCERT: 2 MOZART WORKS FOR THE FULTE
description: THERE is something about the flute that pacifies. How else to explain the beatific smiles that it draws from its audiences, no matter what the music played on it. Perhaps because its sonorities seem so clear and its harmonics so uncomplex compared to, say, the violin or piano, the flute is typically a soothing rather than an exciting instrument. That could be why the Mostly Mozart Festival, which got under way last night, chose to begin with a program featuring the elfish flutist James Galway. It was a concert of summer music in the most relaxed manner, putting no strain on anyone's intellect or powers of concentration and dispensing charm in generous doses.

title: THE DECLINE OF SILVER PRICES IN IDAHO
description: At 7 A.M., when the miners gather here at the edge of the Bitterroot Mountains, the air is sweet with the smell of Douglas fir.

title: That (Not So) Awful Sea Treaty
description: You wouldn't know it from the headlines, but President Reagan finds real merit in the Law of the Sea Treaty he won't sign. Yes, the seabed mining provisions are distasteful, especially that business about resources being the common heritage of all mankind. But embedded in the President's rejection is the quiet and telling assertion that the sea treaty ''contains many positive and very significant accomplishments.''

title: Hearing Looms On Bell Canada
description: Canada's Bureau of Competition Policy is examining the reorganization proposal of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada and may recommend a public hearing, Ian Nielson-Jones, chief of the agency's regulated section division, said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: When Is Weather Deadly?
description: Each air crash prompts questions on how to improve air safety, and the last two in this country prompt the same question: when should pilots fly in bad weather?

title: A Female Steward
description: The California Horse Racing Board has selected its first female steward. She is Ingrid Ferman, who will be among three stewards presiding over the races at the 12-day meeting at the Solano County Fair. Mrs. Ferman, who was a steward's aide at Santa Rosa County Fair races in 1979 and a patrol judge at Del Mar, Hollywood Park and Santa Anita during the last year, is married to a race-track horseshoer.

title: ITALIAN COACH GIVES CREDIT TO SMART PLAY
description: Enzo Bearzot, coach of Italy's World Cup soccer champions, said today he knew his team would beat West Germany in the final after Paolo Rossi scored the first goal.

title: China Blames U.S. for Crisis
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua told an Arab League delegation today that the United States was responsible for the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, told the group that ''the lesson we draw from it is that the Arab world should strengthen its solidarity and never place its hope on the superpowers.'' The Arab League delegation is led by Foreign Minister Ali Lutfi al-Thaur of Yemen.

title: U.S. Cuts Estimate on Soviet Crop; Block Meets Reagan on Pact
description: Poor weather in portions of the Soviet Union east of the Ural Mountains led the Agriculture Department today to reduce dramatically its estimate of the 1982 Soviet grain crop to 170 million metric tons.

title: Personal Computers; FLOPPY DISKS: TECHNOLOGICAL BOON, BUT SO DELICATE
description: IN the movie ''The Graduate,'' Dustin Hoffman was told that the secret to future success lay in the one word ''plastic.'' We all laughed. Yet plastic is the future, for without plastic there would be no computers.

title: TRIDENT'S TECHNOLOGY MAY MAKE IT A POTENT RIVAL TO LAND BASED MISSILES
description: AS public attention focuses on such land-based missiles as the MX and the Pershing 2, the United States Navy is accelerating development of a submarine-launched ballistic missile expected to dramatically increase naval destructive power.

title: Pabst Sues to Halt Bid by Heileman
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said it had filed suit against the G. Heileman Brewing Company and the JMSL Acquiring Corporation, a company controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Pabst stockholder. The suit, filed in United States District Court in Delaware, charges that Heileman and Mr. Jacobs violated antitrust and securities laws in a bid Mr. Jacobs made to buy all of Pabst's shares.

title: F.T.C. Delays Tie
description: Conagra Inc. and the Peavey Company said they had agreed with the Federal Trade Commission to delay, until at least July 20, the completion of their $180 million merger.

title: SECURITIES GROUP SUING HOME LOAN BANK BOARD
description: The Securities Industries Association, the major trade association for the nation's securities firms, sued the Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday on charges of illegally permitting a group of savings and loan asssociations to operate stock brokerage and investment advisory services.

title: Business and the Law; Bankruptcies: Chaos Prevails
description: THE Supreme Court's June 28 decision that the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978 gave bankruptcy judges more power than was constitutionally permissible has left debtors and creditors, and their lawyers, confused about how to handle pending cases - and even more uncertain about the future of the bankruptcy system.

title: DEFINITELY NOT FOR SALE
description: Something is not for sale in Atlantic City. It says so in big red letters on a sign at Milt Wescoat's marina: ''Notice to realtors and speculators. This property is not for sale.''

title: 35 KILLED IN MEXICO AS A TRAIN PLUNGES INTO 800-FOOT GORGE
description: At least 35 passengers, including an American, were killed and up to 120 others were injured in a train that derailed and plunged down an 800-foot gorge near this city in western Mexico, railroad officials said today.

title: BEGELMAN REMOVED AS CHIEF OF UNITED ARTISTS
description: David Begelman was removed today as chairman and chief executive officer of United Artists, the second major movie studio he has been forced to leave.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Liv Ullmann Bringing 'Ghosts' to Broadway

title: Devellano Moves Up
description: The pizza restaurateur who recently bought the Red Wings, Mike Ilitch, bit off a slice of the Islanders' championship pie by hiring 39-year-old Jim Devellano, New York's assistant general manager, as general manager. Ilitch said he hoped Devellano would ''build like the Islanders.''

title: Accord Is Set To Split Estel
description: Hoesch A.G. said today that it had reached a basic accord with Koninklijke Nederlandsche Hoogovens en Staalfabrieken of the Netherlands on how to terminate Estel N.V., the holding company the two steelmakers established 10 years ago to coordinate their operations.

title: Market Place; Summer Rally: The Prospects
description: THE summer rally in stocks has carved out a reliable record. ''Between 1940 and 1980,'' according to Robert Colby of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, ''the Dow Jones industrials annually showed an average summer-rally gain of 9.5 percent.''

title: GIDDINGS TURNS DOWN AMCA'S OFFER
description: Giddings & Lewis Inc., one of the nation's largest machine tools manufacturers, rejected today as ''inadequate'' a $260 million takeover offer by the American subsidiary of AMCA International Ltd. of Montreal and urged its shareholders to vote against the bid.

title: DIVIDEND WITHHOLDING GAINS STRENGTH IN HOUSE
description: The provision in the Senate Finance Committee's tax bill authorizing the withholding of income taxes on stock dividends and interest payments, once given little chance of success, is gaining adherents, and passage by the House now seems likely, House Demoratic sources said over the weekend.

title: CHECKER TAXI, 60, DIES OF BULK IN KALAMAZOO
description: The Checker cab died here today of the automobile industry's lingering illness, and some of America's bigcity legroom began to die with it.

title: Q/A
description: Q. Why do ice cubes shrink after several weeks in a freezer?

title: China Finds Growth Slow
description: China's industrial growth is less hearty than implied by recent statistics showing a 10 percent annual growth rate for the first half of 1982, according to Zhang Jingfu, the new head of China's revamped State Economic Commission.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bobby Smith, the center for the Minnesota North Stars, signed a seven-year contract that reportedly will make him one of the highestpaid players in the N.H.L. He had asked $400,000 a year, but terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Film Society Names Gill

title: EGYPTIAN MOSLEMS MARK RAMADAN DESPITE CRISIS
description: A cannon's boom has resounded here on recent evenings, touching off much joy, for the sound is part of the rhythm of Ramadan, the Moslem holy month, now in its 16th day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We ourselves are satisfied on the basis of the evidence available to us that the Argentine Government accepts that active hostilities are at an end, thereby enabling us to act on the release of prisoners of war in accordance with Article 118 of the third Geneva Convention.'' - Statement of the British Foreign Office on the Falkland conflict. (A10:4.)

title: A 2D RALLY PLANNED
description: Negotiations between the Koch administration and unions representing police officers, firefighters and correction officers broke down again yesterday, and the union leaders warned that there would be a bad reaction from their members.

title: Trotter Syndicated For $5.25 Million
description: Mystic Park, a 3-year-old trotter, was syndicated for a record $5,250,000, Alan Leavitt, president of Lana Lobell Farms, announced yesterday.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Barrymores in Filmland

title: Bridge: After Many Years, Jacoby And Roth Merged Forces
description: Almost all the top players who have been around for a long time have on occasion been partners, or at least teammates. An exception to this disappeared at the Spring Nationals in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: Treasury Prices Down a Bit; 6-Month Bills At 11.967%
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell modestly yesterday and yields rose as a result of selling pressure from speculators and traders who wanted to lock in profits earned during last week's rally.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: MONTREAL D uring the introduction of the players at tonight's All-Star Game, the loudest cheers are expected to greet Gary Carter, the Expos' catcher. But he's more than just a local favorite. Gary Carter is now a symbol that baseball is a game again, instead of a labor dispute; a symbol that the fans have accepted it as a business of big money, as well as a business of big hits.

title: Boxing a Weapon In TV Rating Game
description: TV SPORTSNeil Amdur

title: BRITAIN, ASSERTING FALKLAND WAR IS OVER, WILL RETURN LAST CAPTIVES
description: Britain said today that the Falkland Islands war was officially at an end and that the remaining 593 Argentine prisoners would be sent home as soon as possible.

title: THE DANCE: KUI-IN CHUNG
description: IN CHUNG led her audience from the Korean countryside to the streets of New York at Saturday night's performance by Kui-In Chung and Dancers at the Merce Cunningham Studio. The rural scenes proved more pleasant than the urban.

title: Weaver-Cobb Indoors
description: The World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight between Mike Weaver, the champion, and Randall (Tex) Cobb, set for July 25 on national television (CBS), finally has a site.

title: I.B.M. Takes Options on Site For Westchester Laboratory
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced today that it had taken options on 188 acres of hilly, wooded land in the Westchester County town of New Castle for a research laboratory.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 2 Stars of 'Pirates' Cast in Marriage Role

title: DAVIS CUP TENNIS IS SPECIAL TO McENROE
description: When the match finally ended, an exhausted John McEnroe trudged to the net, shook hands with Mats Wilander, then embraced Arthur Ashe, the United States Davis Cup captain, burying his head on his shoulder.

title:
ARAFAT AND PEACE;
TEL AVIV - Never before had Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, received an Israeli. I had been asking to interview him since I first met Said Hamami, the P.L.O. representative in London, eight years ago. ''The time is not ripe,'' was the standard answer.
description: Now, in the private apartment of one of his assistants, I met him. He is very different from his television image: informal, friendly and soft-spoken. We talked for two and a half hours.

title: Northern Ireland Protestants Mark Battle of Boyne of 1690
description: Thousands of Orangemen paraded through the streets of Belfast today amid tight security to mark the anniversary of the victory of Protestant forces over Roman Catholics at the Batttle of the Boyne in 1690.

title: Making Things Better
description: Among its other postwar ''miracles,'' Japan manages to have a strikingly lower crime rate than the United States. In 1977, for example, 10 American men died by violence for every Japanese male who did.

title: Fight for Benitez
description: Wilfred Benitez, the World Boxing Council junior middleweight champion, will go to court tomorrow to have Jimmy Jacobs, his manager since 1978, served with a temporary restraining order that would remove him as manager. Howard Finger, Benitez's lawyer, said last week that the 23-year-old boxer was unhappy about a lack of endorsements and dissatisfied with the preliminary financial terms Jacobs was arranging for the title defense Benitez is scheduled to make this fall against Thomas Hearns.

title: AMERICAN SQUAD STRIVING TO END LOSING STREAK
description: Billy Martin conceded today that the American League had not taken the All-Star Game seriously in recent years. But as manager of this year's squad he promised a harder attitude that would end the league's 10-year losing streak Tuesday night.

title: AFTER THE SHELLING STOPS, ARABS TAKE TO THE STREET
description: In this battered town just south of west Beirut, people were out on the main street today after 16 hours of shelling between Israelis and Palestinians on Sunday,

title: REUBEN OPPENHEIMER
description: Reuben Oppenheimer, a legal scholar, author and leader of Jewish organizations, died Saturday at his home after a short illness.

title: RAMIREZ IS UPSET BY HOLROYD OF U.S.
description: Glenn Holroyd, a little-known player from Phoenix, put together a tough serve-and-volley game today and upset fifth-seeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico in the opening round of the $200,000 United States Professional tennis championships.

title: Addendum
description: * Family Weekly is increasing its advertising rates 2.5 percent, effective with the Sept. 12 issue.

title: EDUCATION
description: CHICAGO A PROGRAM offering loans to parents of college students, which the Reagan Administration had counted on to help compensate for the cuts in student aid, has been seriously hampered by bankers' reluctance to participate.

title: FOSTER CARE AGENCIES IN NEW YORK CITY TAKEN TO TASK ON PLACEMENT
description: Thousands of youngsters in foster care programs in New York City are still experiencing placement problems, sometimes waiting for years without being adopted, returned to their parents or placed with relatives, according to a study by a local children's advocacy group.

title: SAVE MEDICARE MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Bid for Ryan
description: The Combined International Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Ryan Insurance Groups Inc, subject to a vote by shareholders later this summer. Under terms of the offer each Ryan share will be converted, at the option of the holder, into either $34 in cash or 0.34 share of a new issue of Combined convertible preference stock.

title: 10,000 SAID TO FLEE LEBANON FOR SYRIA
description: More than 10,000 Lebanese and Palestinians have sought refuge in Syria since the Israeli invasion of Lebanon five weeks ago and more are continuing to pour in, the director of a Syrian relief committee said today.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Pepsico Will Spend $1.8 Million on Summerfare

title: STANDING UP FOR POLICE PROFESSIONALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Hana Mandlikova Wins
description: Hana Mandlikova, plagued by a back problem since her 1981 Wimbledon final loss to Chris Evert Lloyd, has given the first real indication that she can reestablish herself as a force on the tour. The 20-year-old from Czechoslovakia scored a 7-5, 6-3 victory Sunday over Pam Shriver in the Seiko Ladies Indoor Tennis Classic.

title: Husky Oil to Drill Off Nova Scotia
description: Husky Oil Ltd. said its wholly owned subsidiary, Husky Oil Operations Ltd., and Bow Valley Industries had agreed with Onaping Resources Ltd. and Scotia Energy Resources Ltd. to participate in three blocks on the Scotian Shelf.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Next Stop, Culture St.

title: Mrs. Moro Testifies At Red Brigades Trial
description: Aldo Moro's widow, testifying in the trial of the Red Brigades guerrillas who took responsibility for his murder, suggested today that his cooperation with Italy's Communists was the cause of his death.

title: FRENCH ARMS GO TO NICARAGUA
description: France said today that it had begun arms deliveries to Nicaragua's leftist junta despite opposition by the Reagan Administration.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 13, 1982
description: International Washington lifted the sanctions it imposed against Argentina at the outbreak of the Falkland war. But Administration officials said the ban on military sales remained in effect, pending a review of both the situation in the Falklands and any progress Argentina has made in human rights. (Page A1, Column 6.) Release of the last 593 Argentines held by Britain was scheduled after London received assurances from Buenos Aires that it planned no further military action over the Falklands. Declaring the war officially at an end, the Foreign Office said that the prisoners would be sent home as soon as possible. (A10:3-5.)

title: COMMUNIST CRITICS OF SOVIET SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH ATTACKS IN DEBATE WITH CUOMO
description: Mayor Koch, in his second gubernatorial campaign debate with Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, repeatedly criticized Mr. Cuomo today, saying he had failed to detect a payroll padding scheme on Mr. Cuomo's own staff.

title: ASIAN AMERICANS IGNORED IN REDISTRICTING
description: To the Editor:

title: A Thrift Unit Becomes Bank
description: The tiny Blue Ridge Savings and Loan Association in rural western Virginia was given conditional approval today to become a bank, permitting it to replace its stagnant mortgage loan business with more lucrative commercial and consumer loan services.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of 400,000 common shares, to be offered by Morgan Stanley & Co. as selling stockholder in exchange for up to $10 million of debentures.

title: Saxon Ends Plan To Sell 80% Stake
description: The Saxon Oil Company said yesterday that it would not complete a previously announced plan to sell 80 percent of the company to an investor group that would have guaranteed it $65 million additional bank financing.

title: Standard-Coosa Rejects Engle Bid
description: Directors of the Standard-Coosa Thatcher Company unanimously rejected a $60-a-share cash tender offer for 36.9 percent of the company, in favor of a $53-a-share cash bid for 100 percent of the company.

title: Brady Energy In Fraud Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged the Brady Energy Corporation, its former chairman, Ralph Brady, and five others with securities fraud in connection with the company's 1980 offering of one million shares of preferred stock through John Muir & Company.

title: Weyerhaeuser's Freeze Extended
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the world's largest timber products concern, extended a salary freeze affecting 8,900 of its managers for another six months.

title: Air Freight Executive Dies
description: Henry A. Pfaff, co-founder and vice president of the Emery Air Freight Corporation, died Friday at Mt.

title: ARGENTINE LAUDS PRISONER RELEASE
description: - Foreign Minister Juan Aguirre Lanari of Argentina said today that Britain's decision to return the 593 remaining war prisoners it had held on the Falkland Islands was a ''positive gesture.''

title: 'TOOTSIE': A WOMAN WHO IS DUSTIN HOFFMAN
description: HER name is Dorothy Michaels, and she has been turning up quite a lot lately. At the Russian Tea Room she introduced herself to Dustin Hoffman's co-star Jon Voight and cooed about how much she had liked him in ''Midnight Cowboy.'' On a cable-television show featuring the Circle Repertory Company she called in to ask a question, knowing Dustin Hoffman was interested in the answer. At a Manhattan schoolyard she had a long chat with Dustin Hoffman's daughter's teacher. No one thought any of this amiss. And Dorothy Michaels was, understandably, delighted.

title: U.S. SEEKS CHANGE IN CHECKS ON VISAS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service is proposing to do one of its jobs more effectively by giving the chore to private agencies, but the plan is running into stiff opposition from some of the service's line officers and from Congressmen and immigration lawyers who fear its implications.

title: INDIA LEGISLATORS CHOOSE PRESIDENT
description: Thousands of legislators voted today to choose India's seventh president. Zail Singh, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's nominee, is favored to win the contest.

title: Corporate Giving
description: Corporate philanthropy is growing and business leaders expect it to increase further, but none of them expects the increase to compensate fully for Federal spending cuts, according to a report released today. The report on the 15-month study by the Council on Foundations said that corporate philanthropy surpassed giving by private foundations in 1979, when it totaled more than $2.45 billion.

title: LIZZIE BORDEN: FOLKLORE STRONGER THAN FACT
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL TALKS ARE STALEMATED ON A NEW PACT
description: Negotiations between hospital workers, ranging from X-ray technicians to laundry handlers, and 55 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes in New York City and on Long Island are at a stalemate, and the workers' union has issued a strike notice for Thursday morning.

title: Couple Charged in Bid To Bilk the Reagans
description: A couple was charged today with trying to bilk President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, of about $1 million in a fraudulent deal to buy the Reagans' home in Pacific Palisades last summer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON THE WATERFRONT

title: Very Cold Volcanoes
description: Can volcanoes erupt when the ''lava'' within them is no warmer than 144 degrees below zero Fahrenheit? On some satellites of planets like Saturn, that might well be the case. Such eruptions, some of them explosive, are proposed by David J. Stevenson of the California Institute of Technology to explain the ''remarkable diversity'' of surface features on such Saturnian moons as Tethys, Dione, Rhea and Iapetus (all named for the Titans of Greek mythology).

title: Yesterday's Pay, Today's Reality
description: Two years ago, an arbitrator told Mayor Koch that he would eventually have to pay New York City employees the wage increases granted but withheld in the 1975 fiscal crisis. But he set no firm date for the payment.

title: HOT-AND-COLD METS LOOKING FOR ANSWERS TO ROTATION
description: George Bamberger flew home to Florida to do some fishing and thinking yesterday and put 1,100 miles between himself and his Mets. At the All-Star intermission of a strange season, the Mets stood fifth in the National League's East with 40 victories, 47 defeats and perhaps more question marks than they had brought north after spring training.

title: WRONG PENSION CURE
description: Congress is now considering legislation to correct abuses in our private pension system that give preferential treatment to high-income professionals and small-business owners. This would appear to be a laudable objective, but what nobody seems to have noticed is that the same legislation could inflict considerable damage on millions of middle- and low-income employees.

title: Baseball All-Star Game, at Montreal.
description: This is the first All-Star Game played outside of the United States. The National League manager, Tom Lasorda of the Dodgers, plans to start the Expos' Steve Rogers (10-4), and the American League manager, Billy Martin of the A's, is scheduled to go with Dennis Eckersley (9-7) of the Boston Red Sox. The National League has a 10-game winning streak and has won 18 of the last 19 All-Star Games. (Television - Channel 7, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WCBS 880, 8:30 P.M.) Basketball New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman gymnasium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. Boxing Jimmy Young vs. Vic Valentino, heavyweights, at the Tropicana Hotel, Atlantic City, 10 rounds. This is the fight postponed from June 29. Young (30-11-2, with 10 knockouts) had to put off the bout because of gastritis. Valentino (19-5, with 13 knockouts) won a split decision from Steve Zouski, who substituted for Young. In a pair of sixrounders on the undercard, the light-heavyweight Danny Cacaruso of Providence, R.I., (8-0) meets Tony Curovic of Cleveland (8-5), and the heavyweight Phil Capobianco of Huntington, L.I., (8-1) fights Luis DiLumbo of Pittsburgh (2-1). First bout is at 7:30 P.M. in the Royal Swan ballroom.

title: Buyer Sees Gains For Home Journal
description: Robert E. Riordan, president of Family Media Inc., thinks his career in magazines has now come full circle, from his first job 26 years ago at Gentlemen's Quarterly to his decision, announced last week, to buy The Ladies' Home Journal.

title: Walton's Test
description: After months of practice in pickup games, Bill Walton has picked the date for the first test of his health in a competitive basketball game since 1980.

title: Chess:; Kasparov of Soviet Wins The Bugojno Tournament
description: The brilliant 19-year-old Soviet co-champion, Gari Kasparov, achieved another great triumph in the formidable Bugojno (Yugoslavia) International Tournament. His imposing 9 1/2-3 1/2 score brings him up to second place on the International Chess Federation's computer rankings behind his countryman, Anatoly Karpov, the world champion.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE National Endowment for the Humanities is preparing new strategies for the support of excellence in schools and colleges, with emphasis on improving existing courses. This is a departure from their past policies, which concentrated on improving curriculums through the development of new courses and the encouragement of experimentation.

title: Topics; Unwed, Unheard, Unpaid; Generation Gap
description: A woman we know was telling about her 25th college reunion and one fact stood out: ''When I graduated,'' she said, ''most of us were married and the rest were not far from it.'' But now, she said, referring to the class of 1982, ''None of them is married, not one.''

title: Chairman Steps Down At Financial Network
description: The denouement came quickly for Glen H. Taylor, the founder of Financial News Network, which only last November began a business news network via satellite to 40 UHF and cable television stations across the country. On Sunday, he resigned as the network's chairman and president, only one day before F.N.N. made a public offering of $6 million in stock and warrants.

title: Japan's Trade Reported Off
description: Japanese imports and exports both declined in the first half of this year from the first six months of 1981, Japanese Government statistics showed today. The decline in exports was the first for Japan in seven years.

title: ARMS POLICIES QUESTIONED WITHIN SOVIET
description: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov said today that questions had been raised within the Soviet Union about its decision to renounce the first use of nuclear weapons.

title: SHOUTING IS NEVER OVER FOR REVOLUTIONARY IRAN
description: For many Iranians, life under the Islamic regime is one of slogans, increasingly more stringent rules for dress and conduct, and the fear of violence.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Something in the Air

title: AVANT-GARDE: SCOTT JOHNSON
description: SCOTT JOHNSON mixed the ''live'' with the ''canned'' in his brief evening of music Sunday at the Battery Park City Landfill. Mr. Johnson nestled close to the park's steep sand dune, surrounded himself with loudspeakers and tape equipment and played his electric guitar against a variety of recorded sounds - many of them quite cleverly handled.

title: Imports Hurt U.S. Car Sales
description: The American auto industry in June was hurt by record import levels, an industry trade journal reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Angry Performers Star in 'A Picket Line'

title: HEALTH BENEFITS OF THE PILL FOUND TO OUTWEIGH ITS DRAWBACKS
description: IN sharp contrast to early fears, the birth control pill does not appear to cause any cancer, according to recent research, and, in fact, evidently protects many women from getting cancers, particularly those of the ovaries and of the lining of the uterus. American and British researchers have found that the protection seems to last as a long as a decade after a woman stops taking the pill.

title: New Zealand Restoring Ties With Argentina Cut Off in War
description: New Zealand said today that it was restoring trade and diplomatic links with Argentina, cut off in April because of Argentina's occupation of the Falkland Islands,

title: BMW Ends Venture
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. said today that it had pulled out of a plan to develop a diesel car engine with Steyr-Daimler-Puch A.G. of Austria. A BMW spokesman in Munich said that BMW had decided to withdraw from the electronically fuelinjected M1 engine project but that Steyr would continue development. He gave no financial details.

title: BRITONS SHOCKED OVER THE REPORT ON PALACE ENTRY
description: Members of Parliament reacted with shock and indignation today to a report that an intruder sneaked into Queen Elizabeth's bedroom in Buckingham Palace early Friday morning.

title: British Airways Plans to Cut 7,000
description: British Airways, which last year lost $254 million, said that it would cut 7,000 jobs in the next nine months.

title: WESTERN NURSES A FRAIL RECOVERY
description: Shortly after retaining bankruptcy counsel last December, Western Airlines installed as its chairman and chief executive officer Neil G. Bergt, who promised to make the carrier profitable by the third quarter of this year.

title: A Fighter's One-Handed Triumph
description: For seven rounds Saturday, Milton McCrory, the World Boxing's Association's second-ranked welterweight, kept Roger Stafford away and piled up points with accurate left jabs and stinging rights. Then, in the middle of the eighth round of their 10-round fight in Phoenix, McCrory felt his right give out. It was a frightening moment; he immediately figured the worst had happened.

title: A U.S. Invitation To Italy's Heroes
description: Paolo Rossi put six straight goals into the net in the World Cup games while leading Italy to the world championship and became the new goal-scoring hero of Italian soccer. Italy's most famous goal scorer before Rossi? It was Giorgio Chinaglia, now with the Cosmos, and yesterday Chinaglia sent his successor a congratulatory telegram.

title: PERIL
description: The Congressional Black Caucus is struggling to survive severe financial problems stemming from recently enacted Congressional rules, according to sources close to the organization.

title: 56 Wounded Britons Are Sent Home From Falkland Islands
description: The British hospital ship Hydra arrived here today with 56 servicemen wounded in the Falkland war. The wounded, including 22 on stretchers, were to be transferred to a Royal Air Force plane for the flight to Britain with a stop on Ascension Island.

title: LAWYER MOVES TO BLOCK 4-DAY KILL OF EVERGLADES DEER
description: One day this week, unless Michael Hacker can stop it, an army of hunters will infiltrate a 900-square-mile section of the rain-swollen Everglades. They will be loaded for deer.

title: JAMES GALWAY LEADS MOSTLY MOZART PREVIEW
description: On an afternoon fit for staying indoors with the air-conditioning turned up full blast, James Galway led the hearty Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in an outdoor concert at Lincoln Center yesterday. The occasion was an open rehearsal, the traditional prelude to the annual Mostly Mozart Festival, which began its 16th season last night in Avery Fisher Hall with Mr. Galway, the popular flutist, appearing as soloist and conductor.

title: 2-Year-Old Sued for $200
description: A University of Washington business student who sued a 2-year-old boy on charges of driving a tricycle into the door of his 1976 Porsche has lost a bid for damages in Small Claims Court. The auto owner, Mark Hagen of Seattle, 23 years old, sued Nelson Moore in April, claiming $200 in damages.

title: Bozell & Jacobs Studies Rogers & Cowan Link
description: Bozell & Jacobs, the country's 18th-largest advertising agency, is having ''serious'' merger discussions with Rogers & Cowan, the Beverly Hills, Calif., public relations firm, Charles D. Peebler Jr., the B.& J. chief executive confirmed in a telephone interview the other day.

title: News Analysis
description: When the Social Security Administration announced plans to review tax records of welfare recipients to check their eligibility for benefits, lawyers for the elderly and disabled immediately complained that the Government was trampling their clients' privacy rights. Civil liberties advocates endorsed this view.

title: AMENDMENT DRIVE NOW IN HIGH GEAR
description: A drive to write a requirement for a balanced budget into the Constitution moved into high gear today, several months later than some of theleaders had hoped.

title: Unit of Jeanette Sought by Towle
description: The Towle Manufacturing Company, a Boston maker of silverware and giftware, said that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Old Harbor Inc., a candlemaking concern owned by the privately held Jeanette Corporation of Jeanette, Pa.

title: Required Reading; About Power
description: Elliot Richardson, who has held four Cabinet level positions; Robert S. Strauss, who served as the Carter Administration's Special Trade Representative; Stuart Eizenstat, a former White House aide, and Edmund S. Muskie, former Secretary of State, discussing power during a WETA public television program to be aired July 22 at 8:30 P.M.:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Susan Bolotin THE WOMEN OF BREWSTER PLACE. By Gloria Naylor. 192 pages. The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Dead Snails Reveal Climate
description: A researcher at the University of Florida, studying the evolutionary history of a Jamaican land snail, has found that their shells can reveal climatic conditions of eons long past. Glenn Goodfriend, a doctoral candidate in zoology, found that the size of the fossilized shells reflected the moisture conditions they lived in.

title: POSITIONS
description: The United States, growing increasingly concerned about the delays in reaching an accord to end the crisis in Beirut, reaffirmed today that the Palestine Liberation Organization had to leave the city. But Administration officials said no Arab country had yet agreed to take the P.L.O. forces.

title: Penn Square Bank Hearings
description: The House Banking Committee will open hearings on Aug. 11 concerning the failure of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, Representative Fernand J. St Germain, the committee's chairman, announced yesterday.

title: 2,000 Jersey Youths Will Get Jobs Under Special Program
description: More than 2,000 disadvantaged youths will receive summer jobs under a special seven-week employment program, the state announced today.

title: MUSICIAN GAVE FREE CONCERTS
description: Charlotte Bergen, an amateur musician and conductor who for more than 10 years sponsored free concerts in which she performed in Carnegie and Town Halls died Saturday at her home in Bernardsville, N.J. She was 84 years old.

title: BRIEFING
description: Home for the Shultzes

title: British Rail Strikers Ignore Work Appeal
description: Striking train engineers today ignored a final appeal by British Rail to return to work, forcing management to consider shutting the national network and dismissing the strikers.

title: MANHATTAN IN CHANGE: SHAPING VITAL SERVICES
description: Second of three articles on Manhattan and its future. BY DEIRDRE CARMODY

title: U.S. SAYS RISE IN TRADE BY SOVIET MAKES IT VULNERABLE TO SANCTIONS
description: The Soviet Union is far more dependent on foreign trade than Western analysts have long assumed and thus is more vulnerable to economic sanctions than previously thought, according to excerpts from a Commerce Department study published today. The new data, combined with a more accurate way of calculating Soviet prices, show an economy quite unlike the conventional Western portrayals of the Soviet Union as a country that is largely selfsufficient and insulated from world markets.

title: Hitachi Delays Computer Sales
description: Hitachi Ltd. said today that it was delaying marketing of its new supercomputer. One reason, a Hitachi spokesman acknowledged, is allegations that the company was involved in the theft of computer information from the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: REAGAN REMOVES U.S. ECONOMIC BAN ON BUENOS AIRES
description: President Reagan today lifted the economic sanctions that he imposed on Argentina at the outbreak of the war over the Falkland Islands.

title: Coho Salmon Season Is Closed in Oregon
description: The Oregon Fish and Wildlife Commission today ordered an emergency closing of the commercial coho salmon season from Cape Falcon to the California border, a move termed an ''economic disaster'' by coastal fishermen.

title: A QUADRUPLE FOR THE FLYING MIGUEL VAZQUEZ
description: Miguel Vazquez, a 17-year-old member of the Flying Vazquez circus team, has become the first aerialist to achieve the quadruple somersault, a goal that has eluded generations of performers throughout the 123-year history of trapeze flying.

title: AREA SALES UP WEEKLY IN JUNE
description: Sales at seven major New York City retail stores showed a small increase in June, rising an average 1.6 percent compared with June of last year, after registering a strong gain in May, a spot-check shows.
