title: New Hewlett Computer
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today it had introduced a personal computer, the HP-86, to sell for $1,795. The computer is to be sold only through dealers who provide local, direct support to customers. The company also introduced an increased memory version of the HP-87 personal computer, which will sell for $2,995.

title: YASIR ARAFAT IS NO MODERATE
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korean on Trial Calls Arson a Protest
description: A young South Korean on trial for his life said today that he had organized the burning of an American cultural center to protest disparaging remarks about his country by senior American officials.

title: Ethiopia Reportedly Attacks Somali Positions on 2 Fronts
description: Ethiopian troops and warplanes attacked Somali positions on two fronts today, prompting an urgent Somali appeal for aid in halting an 11-day-old Ethiopian advance, the Somali press agency reported.

title: Like Fine Wine
description: In 1960, when Dwight D. Eisenhower was President, Ed Burke of San Jose, Calif., started throwing the hammer. In 1966, Burke won the first of his three straight national titles.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEE PRESSURES TO CUT 1984 MILITARY BUDGET
description: Senior officials of the Reagan Administration said today that economic and political pressures would most likely force cuts in the projected 1984 military budget, requiring revisions in long-term military planning.

title: A President Is Named For Troubled Woolco
description: It apparently takes all sorts of experience to handle a tough job. That seems to be one reason why the F.W. Woolworth Company, the nation's fifth-largest retailer, has hired Harold Smith, 58, to fill the new post of president and chief operating officer of the ailing Woolco discount store division. Mr. Smith, who assumes his new post next Tuesday, most recently has been executive vice president of the Magic Mart discount store division of the Sterling Stores Company of Little Rock, Ark.

title: Security Pacific
description: The proposed merger of the Security Pacific Corporation and Hoare Govett, a brokerage, will not be referred to Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission, the Trade Department said in a statement today, indicating that the combination is free to proceed.

title: N.F.L. and Players To Resume Talks
description: The negotiations between the National Football League and its player union resume at noon today, 60 hours before their four-year labor contract expires. During the session at the New York Sheraton, the owners will present their first comprehensive contract offer, a package that will include an updated version of the existing free agency system.

title: BUTTON, BUTTON AS CUFF LINK
description: Tender Buttons, at 143 East 62d Street, has assumed an almost legendary place in the hearts of button fanciers.

title: 'KILLER BEES' APPROACHING U.S. REVIVE CROP FEARS
description: THE so-called killer bee is continuing to move north from South America and scientists are worrying about it again. They fear the bee's arrival in the United States, expected perhaps as early as 1988, may disrupt the nation's agriculture and beekeeping industries.

title: A H.U.D. OFFICIAL STICKS BY HIS PHILOSOPHY...
description: When he served as a high-level aide to Mayor John V. Lindsay back in the 1960's, E.S. (Steve) Savas was constantly promoting his pet notion that almost anything the Government could do, the private sector could do better.

title: Peres Against Beirut Attack
description: Shimon Peres, the Israeli opposition leader, said at a news conference here today that his Labor Party opposed any assault of west Beirut. He made the comment after talks with Foreign Minister Kjeld Olesen, who told Mr. Peres that the Israeli siege of west Beirut was ''unacceptable.'' Mr. Peres said some factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization refused to follow the orders of its chief, Yasir Arafat.

title: Uniforms Stolen
description: While the Niagara Falls White Sox of the New York-Penn League were on the road over the weekend, burglars broke into their clubhouse and stole the team's home uniforms and other equipment. ''I don't know what anybody would do with the uniforms,'' George Wenz, the team's president, said. ''If they wore them around here, I'd think someone would notice where they came from.''

title: UNEMPLOYMENT: THE OUTLOOK IS GRIM
description: ''I just came back from a tour of many of our country's depressed areas and I can tell you that watching mature men with good skills go on soup lines is not something I found very rewarding.'' This comment may sound like something right out of the 1930's, but in fact it was spoken in 1982 by Canada's Minister of Employment. The statement reflects a brooding suspicion in North America and Western Europe that a pervasive unemployment crisis may be at hand and that much of the industrial world will find it difficult to maintain a commitment to even approximately full employment.

title: Goldhirsh Group Planning Some Changes
description: Norman Rabin, president of the Goldhirsh Group, which publishes Inc., High Technology and Technology Illustrated magazines, reported yesterday that Charles C. (Jim) Randolph 3d, former publisher of Inc., declined to head the company's new Sat/Net, a teleconferencing unit. Mr. Randolph could not be reached for comment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Life Insurance Co., Wilmington, Del., a subsidiary of American International Group, has appointed Richard M. Frantz vice president for investments.

title: Hasbro Planning To Buy Wham-O
description: Hasbro Industries said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Wham-O International Company for $21.50 a share, or a total of $16.8 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The War of Dogs

title: Singapore's Leader on Trip
description: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew left today on a two-week trip to Britain and the United States. He will leave London on Saturday for Washington.

title: A CHANCE TO ELIMINATE TERRORISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Denver Bus Workers Strike
description: About 1,400 transit workers, including 900 bus drivers, went on strike in the Denver metropolitan area today, forcing some 162,000 bus riders to look for other ways to get around. The strike by the Amalgamated Transit Union was called after contract negotiations, which began about six months ago, broke down over the weekend.

title: ABBOTT RISES 17.3% IN PERIOD
description: Abbott Laboratories reported yesterday that rising sales of its hospital and laboratory products helped lift net income in the second quarter of 1982 by 17.3 percent.

title: World Copper Output Talks
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru has ruled out cuts in world copper production as a means of raising currently depressed prices but says exporting nations have to agree to a minimum export price for the metal.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices on all energy futures dropped their daily permissible limits yesterday, reflecing traders' fears that the global oil surplus may grow substantially as a result of the failure last weekend by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on output quotas.

title: REPORTERS OPPOSE SEAL ON LIBEL DATA
description: A reporters' group filed a petition today seeking to overturn an unusual court order that allows the Mobil Oil Corporation to keep the public and the press from seeing ''sensitive'' documents intended to be used as evidence in a libel suit.

title: Threatened Aquarium Finds a Way to Survive
description: The National Aquarium, whose survival was threatened last year by spending cutbacks, is reducing costs and expanding its exhibits after two months under private management.

title: EMBATTLED CHIEF AT EVERS COLLEGE REPORTED TO QUIT
description: Sources at the City University of New York said yesterday that the president of Medgar Evers College had asked for a sabbatical and reassignment to another institution within the system.

title: The Tasmanian Devil
description: Rupert Murdoch, though he continues to lose about $20 million a year publishing The New York Post, has managed to do in New York what he has done with his other papers in the United States and Britain and Australia: make politicians afraid of him and his power to sway minds.

title: Telefunken Plan Weighed
description: Representatives of the work force of AEG-Telefunken met today with Lord Weinstock, chairman of Britain's General Electric Company, to discuss plans, rejected by workers, for cooperation between the two companies.

title: PHONE INDUSTRY BILL FACES UPHILL FIGHT
description: A House bill that would reorganize the telephone and data communications industries, placing new restrictions on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, comes up Tuesday before the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The bill's chances of passage appear to be fading.

title: Criswell's Drug Trail
description: Kirby Criswell, the St. Louis Cardinal defensive end convicted last month on narcotics charges, said he was using drugs long before he came to the National Football League, starting with marijuana while in high school in Grinnell, Iowa. Criswell, sentenced to five years in prison, agreed with Don Reese, the former Miami Dolphin star who contended that cocaine was readily available to N.F.L. rookies.

title: Dunlop Holdings Unit
description: DM (Holdings) Sdn. Berhad, a subsidiary of Dunlop Holdings Ltd. of Britain, said today that it had sold its 51 percent holding in Dunlop Malaysian Industries Berhad to Pegi Malaysian Berhad for the equivalent of $126.4 million. Dunlop will continue to provide management and technical services.

title: Court Orders Recovery Of Teamsters Pensions
description: The Labor Department announced today that a court order had been filed calling for recovery of more than $3.5 million for a teamsters pension plan in New Jersey.

title: WEISKOPF IS IN THE MOOD FOR BRITISH OPEN
description: Tom Weiskopf gave a few insights today as to why he did the things he did, things that surprised even himself. Most of them added up to, ''That's me.''

title: IRANIAN ARMY POISED FOR INVASION OF IRAQ, U.S. OFFICIALS ASSERT
description: Administration officials said today that large numbers of Iranian troops had moved close to the Iraqi border and might invade in the next few days.

title: F.B.I. Investigation Reported In 3 Racketeering Acquittals
description: The Federal authorities are investigating charges of jury tampering in a labor racketeering trial that resulted in the acquittal of three key defendants, The Miami Herald reported today.

title: TV: CAVETT LOOKS AT 1917 FOR HBO
description: DICK CAVETT will soon be departing from public television with his talk show, which, whatever else, has featured a splendid list of guests during the last few years. The loss of the format probably accounts for Mr. Cavett's popping up in other areas these days - radio commercials for computers, magazine advertisements for hotels and, most disconcertingly, a series of ''documentaries'' produced for Home Box Office, the country's largest pay-cable outfit.

title: SHEIK PAYS $1.5 MILLION TAB, BUT THREATENS $1 BILLION HOTEL SUIT
description: A Saudi Arabian sheik paid a disputed $1.5 million hotel bill to a Hollywood, Fla., hotel today, said he would sue the hotel for $1 billion and threatened to move to St. Louis.

title: AMCA'S TAKEOVERS BRING FAST GROWTH
description: In the 11 years since the Dominion Bridge Company set out to diversify by seeking acquisitions in the United States, Canada's biggest steel fabricator has absorbed 10 American companies. In doing so, its annual sales have grown sevenfold, to $1.57 billion.

title: Ad Agency Salaries Top Publishing Sector
description: During the last two years, the basic salaries of advertising agency people who are members of the Business/ Professional Advertising Association moved ahead of the members in the publishing business. This is the first time that has happened since what was formerly called the Industrial Advertising Association began its surveys in 1968.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHILE other designers have done little this summer but pray for o rders, Calvin Klein is about to introduce five new product c ategories bearing his name: boys' wear, socks, luggage, small l eather goods and, in a belated stroke of marketing savvy, men's u nderwear.

title: ENDS AT 824.87
description: The stock market continued to rally in heavy trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 10.75 points, to close at 824.87. Energy issues, however, dropped sharply, reflecting investors' concern about lower oil prices.

title: ULTRAHIGH LEVEL OF POISON CITED AT LOVE CANAL
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams said today that the levels of dioxin in abandoned homes adjacent to the Love Canal, where a chemical company dumped toxic waste for 11 years, were ''among the highest ever found in the human environment.''

title: LOW CALCIUM TIED TO HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE
description: Too little calcium in the diet may be a hitherto unrecognized factor contributing to high blood pressure, according to a study done at the Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland.

title: FLORIDA WILL SPRAY MARIJUANA
description: State officials said here today that they had authorized the spraying of the herbicide paraquat on marijuana fields in Florida. It would be the first domestic use of the weed killer to kill marijuana plants, according to the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: Supreme Court Justices Appoint 34 Law Clerks
description: The nine Justices of the Supreme Court and one retired Justice have hired 34 young lawyers who will work as law clerks for the next year. They will work closely with the Justices, providing highly confidential research and, in some instances, drafts of legal opinions.

title: New President For Hoover
description: Merle R. Rawson, chairman of the Hoover Company, was yesterday named to the additional post of president of the large maker of vacuum cleaners, effective Sept. 1.

title: The U.N. Today; July 13, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission Working Group on New International Eco- nomic Order - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ...WHILE BOOK GIVES CLUES TO SHULTZ'S
description: George P. Shultz, who is to appear Tuesday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for a confirmation hearing on his nomination to be Secretary of State, recalled in a 1977 book that perhaps the two most important words he spoke in six years of Government service were: ''Do nothing.''

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP.'s NET ROSE 11.2% IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent company of the First Chicago National Bank, the nation's eighth-largest bank, said yesterday that its net operating income rose 11.2 percent, to $31.8 million, or 80 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1982, from $28.6 million, or 72 cents a share, in the same period of 1981.

title: Business Digest; TUESDAY, JULY 13, 1982; International
description: President Reagan lifted economic sanctions imposed on Argentina at the start of the war in the Falkland Islands. The ban on sales of military equipment remains in effect, however, pending a review of both developments in the Falklands and the human rights situation in Argentina, officials said. (Page A1.)

title: FAULTY TAPE RECORDING DELAYS INQUIRY IN JET CRASH
description: A defective tape recorder will delay an analysis of cockpit conversations that could determine whether the crew of a Pan American World Airways jet heard warnings of a wind shift minutes before the plane took off and crashed, killing 153 people.

title: FOR STEVE SAX, CHRISTMAS IN JULY
description: MONTREAL H e walked into the home team's clubhouse at Olympic Stadium yesterday, his eyes casting about for his locker. He is a clean-jawed young man of 22, compact in blue blazer and gray, rather rumpled pants, and he has the loose, confident walk of a professional athlete, of someone certain of the grace and magic his body is capable of. He noticed the names Rose and Schmidt and Carter and Dawson and Valenzuela, and then he saw his:

title: Rain in Japan Starts Slides
description: Fourteen inches of rain caused floods and landslides today in the southern part of Kyushu, Japan's southern island. The northern part of the island is suffering from drought.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Cyanamid Co. announced it was withdrawing from certain pigments and rubber chemicals businesses, an action that will affect approximately 500 employees at its Bridgewater, N.J., plant.

title: NO HALFWAY MEASURES FOR SKIRT LENGTHS THIS SUMMER
description: Lucky the woman who doesn't throw out her wardrobe every time a fashion designer predicts that long is out and short is in. Dictates of that sort just don't obtain anymore, especially in an unsure economy and particularly this summer, when New York women are wearing whatever they please just as long as it is made of lightweight to sheer fabrics, is pale as an iced drink and preferably washable.

title: YANKEES' FIRST HALF A TAILSPIN
description: It has been a team effort, Rich Gossage said. He was talking about the way the Yankees had staggered through the first half of the season. Usually, team efforts are credited with winning pennants. The Yankees' team effort, though, has resulted in their worst first half since 1974, a season that was played in the days before the team stocked itself with the highest-priced talent.

title: Wayne Carson, 55, Director And Actor in Broadway Plays
description: Wayne Carson, an actor, director and stage manager, died at his Manhattan home on the Fourth of July. He was 55 years old. Mr. Carson's most recent appearance on Broadway was in ''Medea,'' his 35th Broadway production.

title: RLC to Spin Off Its Rollins Unit
description: The RLC Corporation said it was spinning off its Rollins Environmental Services Inc. subsidiary to shareholders on the basis of one Rollins share for each two RLC shares owned, effective Aug.2 to shareholders of record on July 22.

title: TOWN RESENTS NOTORIETY FROM CHILD CUSTODY CASE
description: When the State Supreme Court ruled last month that Kathleen Blackburn should regain custody of her 3 1/2-year-old son, the tiny, rural southeast Georgia town of Millen reacted about the same way it did when the case first came up: with a wrinkled-nose air of embarrassment.

title: Child Abandonment Charged
description: The mother of a 3-year-old girl abandoned on the steps of a church was charged Sunday with wanton neglect of a minor.

title: LAST RITES FOR A MAN OF HEART
description: John F. Duffy, an engineer who would halt his train to let a stray dog cross the tracks, was buried today, the victim of a ''prank'' that derailed his train.

title: JAPAN LOOKS AT GRISLY SIDE OF ITS PAST
description: The best-selling book in Japan this year is an account of a Japanese germ warfare unit based in Manchuria that killed 3,000 Chinese, Koreans and Russians in biological experiments in World War II.

title: Embassy Seized in Mexico
description: About 50 Mexican leftists peacefully seized the Honduran Embassy in Mexico City today to protest incursions by Honduran troops into El Salvador to fight guerrillas, a spokesman said.

title: Peru, Citing Guerrilla Raids, Imposes Curbs in 3 Provinces
description: The Government declared a state of emergency and suspended civil rights in three Andean provinces today after guerrilla attacks killed five police officers in less than a week.

title: Soviet-German Pipeline Parley
description: West German and Soviet bankers met today in Leningrad to complete credit arrangements for the Siberian natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

title: UNWED, UNHEARD, UNPAID; Walkman vs. Talkman
description: Those ubiquitous miniature tape decks and headphones are more than another Japanese marketing triumph. They permit music addicts to envelop themselves in Mozart or The Cars without disturbing anyone else and thus reduce the irritation of urban life.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: festival concert.

title: ISRAELI CONFIDENT ON WAR ECONOMY
description: The Israeli Industry and Commerce Minister said today that, despite a cost he estimated at more than $1.5 billion, the war in Lebanon had caused no appreciable decline in Israeli production and exports.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ'S REMARKS TO SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statement made yesterday by Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as provided by the White House to The Associated Press, and excerpts from a transcript of the committee's questioning of Mr. Shultz, as recorded by The New York Times from the Cable News Network:

title: President of A.O. Smith
description: The A.O. Smith Corporation, producer of automotive equipment, said in Milwaukee yesterday that it had promoted Thomas I. Dolan, 55 years old, to president and chief operating officer. J.R. Parker, 64, who had been president, was elected vice chairman.

title: MODEST LUNCH FOR YOUNG FAST-TRACKERS
description: WHEN you're in your 20's and on the way up in your company, lunchtime in New York can be a problem. You really can't eat in places like Lutece or the Four Seasons. It would take too long and cost too much and, if the lunch was on the expense account, it might raise the eyebrows of supervisors.

title: TACUMA BAND AT DANCETERIA
description: JAMAALADEEN TACUMA is a busy man these days. As the remarkably fluent lead bassist in Ornette Coleman's trailblazing electric band Prime Time, Mr. Tacuma has been winning considerable critical acclaim.

title: ARMY-CONFISCATED ART HELD LONG ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: British Steel Narrows Loss
description: The British Steel Corporation announced today that it cut its loss to $608 million in 1981-82 from $1.3 billion the previous year.

title: Seafirst Raises Loss Figures
description: The Seafirst Corporation said today that it had decided to increase its provisions for loan losses in the second quarter of 1982 by $125 million.

title: TYRANNY OF FAR LEFT OR FAR RIGHT? NICARAGUAN SEES ANOTHER CHOICE
description: The writer, a hero of Nicaragua's revolution who uses the name Commander Zero, was Deputy Interior Minister until last summer, when he resigned and left the country. He publicly declared his opposition to the ruling Sandinist National Liberation Front on April 15 this year in Costa Rica. Like the ruling junta, his organization, the Sandino Revolutionary Front, takes its name from Gen. Augusto Cesar Sandino, who fought an American interventionist force in the late 1920's.

title: ROLLINS UNIT DESIGNATES CHIEF IN AUG. 2 SPINOFF
description: William B. Philipbar Jr. will become the chief executive officer of Rollins Environmental Services Inc. on Aug. 2 when the Wilmington, Del., hazardous waste disposal company spins off from its parent, the RLC Corporation.

title: AD STIRS PROTEST BY RELIEF GROUPS
description: Six relief agencies trying to obtain aid for victims of the fighting in Lebanon disavowed any connection yesterday with an advertisement that appeared in The New York Times and other newspapers on Sunday. The agencies objected that the advertisement associated their names with criticism of Israel.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I thought amaretti, the almond-flavored macaroons imported from Italy, had almonds ground up in them. When you read the label on a well-known imported variety, they consist of sugar and flour plus ground apricot kernels. Is this justifiable?

title: Riots and Reaganomics
description: Do the nation's cities face a new round of riots this summer? The idea, provoked by predictions from nervous politicians and urban leaders, seems superficially plausible: the recession strikes hardest in the inner city; so do the cutbacks in social programs. Blacks despair over the Reagan Administration's insensitivity to civil rights. The idleness and frustration of the unemployed are basic ingredients of unrest.

title: WURLITZER PRESIDENT ADDS TITLE OF CHIEF
description: George B. Howell, 63-year-old president of the Wurlitzer Company, assumed the additional post of chief executive officer yesterday, succeeding William A. Rolfing, 66, who will remain a director.

title: BRANIFF COMMITTEE OF BONDHOLDERS
description: Some bondholders of Braniff International will have a creditor committee to represent them in the grounded airline's bankruptcy proceedings under a decision made by Federal Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers.

title: LEHERMAN-CURRAN DEBATE DOMINATED BY TAX ISSUES
description: In their sharpest confrontation to date, Lewis E. Lehrman and Paul J. Curran differed today on taxes. The two gubernatorial candidates in the Sept. 23 Republican primary debated before the New York State Broadcasters Association meeting here at the Grossinger Hotel and Country Club.

title: Leftist Peruvian Guerrilla Unit In Attack on a Police Station
description: Leftist guerrillas armed with submachine guns and dynamite killed a policeman and wounded three others, stole their ammunition and blew up their station before fleeing, the police said on Monday.

title: Advertising; Of Rolling Stone and Record Ads
description: CONSIDERING what has happened to the record industry, it is a good thing that Jann Wenner has broadened his interests and the interests of his Rolling Stone.

title: Security Pacific Plans Takeover
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Green Tree Acceptance Inc., a subsidiary of Midwest Federal Savings and Loan Association of Minneapolis, for an undisclosed price.

title: TOLL OF LEBANON DEAD AND INJURED IS STILL UNCERTAIN IN CHAOS OF WAR
description: More than five weeks after the Israeli Army invaded Lebanon and fought its way northward to Beirut, the number of civilian casualties remains unknown.

title: Maritime Officers Agree To a Reduction in Wages
description: Ship officers and engineers voted today to approve a Reagan Administration request for a rollback of the 7.5 percent wage increase they received this year.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allied Stores Corp. filed a registration statement covering up to 600,000 shares of its common stock. It expects to exchange the shares for $18 million principal amount of its 10 3/8 percent notes due in 1990 currently owned by Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: 19 'GENIUSES' WIN 5-YEAR AWARDS TO STIMULATE CONTRIBUTIONS TO SOCIETY
description: A Chicago foundation that has been searching for ''exceptionally talented'' people named 18 men and one woman yesterday to receive tax-free awards ranging from $24,000 to $60,000 annually for the next five years.

title: KAISER REPORTS LOSS
description: The Westinghouse Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the second quarter fell 1.3 percent, while revenues edged up 3.8 percent.

title: HOUSING DEVELOPERS TO LOSE SOME TAX AID IN MANHATTAN
description: The Koch administration is planning to eliminate a tax incentive program for developers of new high-rise apartment buildings in parts of Manhattan.

title: A CHATTY COOKING SCHOOL IN HONG KONG
description: HONG KONG THE saying is so old that it almost sounds new: ''The way to a man's heart is through his stomach.'' Today women are likely to be criticized for promoting that philosophy, but not the Hong Kong cooking teacher Lucy Lo.

title: A Correction:
description: Douglas S. Crow, whose letter appeared July 12, was incorrectly identified. Mr. Crow was an associate in the Department of Religion at Columbia, Sept. 1981-May 1982. He will be an associate in the Department of Middle East Languages and Culture in the fall.

title: MISPLACED FEARS OF CARIBBEAN GROWTH
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Media Ministry Salutes Cliff Robertson

title: Witness in Corona Trial Tells of Seeing Stabbing
description: The man described as the ''linchpin'' in the defense for Juan V. Corona testified today that he saw Mr. Corona's half-brother stab a man identified as one of the victims of the 1971 murders.

title: North Koreans Seize 3 Boats in Sea of Japan
description: North Korean naval vessels today seized three fishing boats - two Japanese and one South Korean - in international waters in the Sea of Japan, officials in Japan and South Korea said.

title: 1. For a Woman's Tuxedo
description: What with the current fad of women wearing men's tuxedos, look for a rash of accessories to round out the outfit. One of the newest is a separate, stiff collar that can transform a plain shirt into a blacktie garment. Or it can be worn, like jewelry, just over skin. It's made of starched cotton, snaps together and has a silvery ornament at the front. You'll find it in the Fendi boutique at Bergdorf's, priced at $25.

title: The U.N. Today; July 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission Working Group on New International Eco- nomic Order - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mack Trucks Sets 4-Week Closing
description: Mack Trucks Inc. is closing all six of its plants for four weeks, beginning next week because of the recession, Bill Restmeyer, a spokesman said.

title: 3-DAY MARKET RALLY LOSES MOMENTUM
description: A three-day stock market rally came to a sputtering halt yesterday. Brokers said the market was under moderate selling pressure from the start, though there was a midday surge of buying.

title: KENNETH MORE, ENGLISH ACTOR ON STAGE AND SCREEN, IS DEAD
description: Kenneth Gilbert More, an English actor, died Monday night at his home here. He had suffered from Parkinson's disease and was 67 years old.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: KATHY CALIO is an intelligent, articulate and attractive college student with a demeanor that says, ''I know who I am and I like myself.'' Four years ago she was a frightened, emaciated teen-ager with just 73 pounds on her 5-foot-3-inch frame. She had few friends, kept to herself and spent nearly every waking moment thinking about food and her fear of gaining weight.

title: FILM: 'THE WITNESS,' FROM HUNGARY
description: ''The Witness'' was shown as part of the 1981 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times on Sept. 26, 1981. The film opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, at Third Avenue.

title: Mexican Bus Crash Kills 7
description: A bus crashed into a deserted house in T@eotihuacan, 22 miles north of here, killing 7 passengers and injuring 20, the police said today. All the victims were Mexican.

title: JERSEY ATORNEY GENERAL STRIVES TO BE 'INNOVATIVE'
description: When he assumed office as New Jersey's Attorney General in January, Irwin I. Kimmelman wanted to see all the incoming mail, not just the few letters screened for his attention by his staff.

title: Records Are Past
description: American swimmers will begin their annual assault on the records in trials next week for the world aquatic championships in Ecuador July 29-Aug.8. Mark Spitz's name, once synonomous with world marks, is gone from the record books, but Spitz has no regrets.

title: Mrs. Ashbrook Takes Office
description: Jean Ashbrook was sworn in as a member of the House Monday to fill the unexpired term of her late husband, Representative John Ashbrook, Republican of Ohio.

title: Beware the Cargo Ship Cartel
description: It is the bizarre proposition of ocean shipping companies that they can increase their efficiency by further reducing their competiton. With the support of President Reagan, they ask Congress to exempt them from the antitrust laws. Only by freeing ocean shippers to form cartels, they insist, can America build an effective merchant marine.

title: Arbitrators Intervene In British Rail Strike
description: Government arbitrators intervened in the 10-day-old nationwide rail strike today, and British Rail chiefs delayed announcement of whether the entire 11,000-mile network would be shut down and strikers dismissed.

title: MAYORS CALL REAGAN URBAN POLICY AN 'ABDICATION' OF RESPONSIBILITY
description: Several mayors today assailed the Reagan Administration's urban policy and ''new federalism'' proposals, saying the measures represented an abdication of Federal responsibility.

title: Belmoral Mines
description: Belmoral Mines Ltd. said the Continental Illinois Bank of Canada, based in Toronto, had called in loans totaling about $30 million (Canadian) and taken over operation of its mines. Belmoral owns gold-mining properties in Quebec and has a 50 percent interest in claims in the Whitehorse mining district of the Yukon.

title: FROM A PRO REJECT TO A TELEVISION STAR
description: Mike Warren admits that he was a bit naive to think that success would come easy. As a young and eager point guard on some of John Wooden's most successful U.C.L.A. basketball teams, Warren says he had ''big plans'' for his future. First, there would be a few highly successful - and visible -years with the Los Angeles Lakers. Visibility is important in Hollywood. Especially if one was interested, as Warren was, in pursuing an acting career after the pros.

title: Court Schedules Pabst Hearing
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said the Federal District Court in Delaware had scheduled a hearing for next Wednesday on Pabst's case, filed on Monday, against the G. Heileman Brewing Company and a corporation controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, a Pabst shareholder. The suit, which charges antitrust and securities law violations, seeks to block an offer from Mr. Jacobs to buy 39 percent of Pabst's common for $24 a share.

title: HEAD OF A.S.C. STORES WILL LEAD MORSE SHOE
description: Manuel Rosenberg, the 52-year-old president of A.S.C. Stores, a subsidiary of the Allied Stores Corporation, was elected chairman and chief executive officer of Morse Shoe Inc., one of the nation's largest retailers and producers of footwear. He succeeds Louis R. Shindler, 70, who is retiring after 32 years with Morse.

title: BALLET: TWO PREMIERES BY NETHERLANDS TROUPE
description: WHEN one of the most talented choreographers of our time deliberately embarks upon a wrongheaded approach, one can be sure he will, at the very least, be wrongheaded on the grandest scale.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: 'Naturally Sweet'

title: CLEAN TEAM ON THE JOB IN SUBWAYS
description: The 33d Street entrance to the Eighth Avenue IND subway looked depressingly familiar: the walls were streaked with grime and graffiti, the floors littered with gum wrappings and cigarette butts. But there was an unaccustomed sparkle to the subway turnstiles and exit doors, thanks to the efforts of a group of teen-agers who are spending the summer cleaning subway stations.

title: 3 JUDGES UPHOLD HAITIANS RELEASE
description: A Federal appeals court today refused to stay a lower court's order freeing 1,800 Haitian refugees from Federal facilities around the United States and in Puerto Rico. But the court said it would grant the Government an expedited hearing on any challenge to the order.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The legitimate needs and problems of the Palestinian people must be addressed and resolved - urgently and in all their dimensions.'' -George P. Shultz, Secretary of State-designate. (A12:4-5.)

title: HOUSE AUTHORIZES AN INQUIRY ON SEX
description: By a vote of 407 to 1, the House of Representatives today authorized an investigation into accusations that some Congressmen and their aides have used illicit drugs and engaged in ''improper or illegal sexual conduct'' with teen-age pages.

title: 2 Seized in Killing Of Youth for Radio
description: Two teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with fatally shooting a 17-year-old Queens honor student who had refused to give up his radio, the police said.

title: Sihanouk Plan Is Praised
description: Foreign Minister Willibald Pahr of Austria, chairman of the International Conference on Cambodia sponsored by the United Nations, said today that Prince Norodom Sihanouk, leader of a new Cambodian anti-Vietnamese resistance coalition, had a plan for a neutral Cambodia that was interesting and contained positive elements. Before being briefed by the Prince, however, he had said he was skeptical about the future of the coalition group.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK ACTS ON OIL LOSS
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, which suffered heavy losses in the failure on July 5 of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, has placed John R. Lytle, a vice president in the oil and gas group, on ''special assignment,'' a bank spokesman confirmed yesterday.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Management Fellowships

title: PROPOSED CHANGES IN GRADING OF BEEF
description: RECENT proposals to alter standards of beef grading have, like politics, made strange bedfellows. Hearings on such changes were held earlier this year and they underscored conflicting concerns of most cattlemen, who want to increase profits; health-minded consumers interested in leaner meat, and consumers who prefer traditional beefsteaks with the flavor and tenderness fat imparts. These critical interests are now being evaluated by the United States Department of Agriculture to determine if changes are in order.

title: BRIEFING
description: Interior: No 'Bad Story'

title: Angels and Charity
description: When Reggie Jackson and the California Angels come to New York on Friday, July 23, George Steinbrenner will be rooting for an especially large turnout because the net proceeds from the game will be donated to a charitable foundation formed by the Yankee owner. The Silver Shield Foundation, conceived by Steinbrenner last winter, will provide financial assistance for the college educations of children of slain New York City police and firemen. The game against California was chosen before the Angels had signed Jackson, the former Yankee slugger, because it was thought they would likely draw a large crowd.

title: BOUQUET GARNI: PUTTING HERB HARVEST TO GOOD USE
description: FOR those who have labored long and with fervor in the herb garden, now is the time to inherit the earth. The latecomers, such as basil and thyme, have finally arrived, rounding out the season's collection of fresh herbs. If there is a pre-eminent trio in this ethereal group as far as cooks are concerned, it is parsley, thyme and bay leaf, which make the bouquet garni.

title: Vilas Escapes Defeat
description: Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas, surprised in the opening set, scored a 3-6, 6-2, 6-4 victory over Brad Drewett of Australia in the first round of the $200,000 United States Pro tennis championships today.

title: L.I. Fireworks Show Scheduled Saturday
description: The skies over Three Mile Harbor in East Hampton, L.I. will be aglow Saturday night from 7:30 to 10:30 with the third annual George Plimpton Fireworks Show. The display, one of a number of activities planned for the evening, was designed by the author George Plimpton and the Grucci Family, noted fireworks handlers.

title: New Airline Approved
description: A Civil Aeronautics Board administrative law judge ruled today that Midwestern Airlines Inc., a proposed new airline, is fit to operate and should receive an air carrier certificate. The airline, based in Lansing, Mich., intends to fly between Lansing, Flint, Saginaw, Grand Rapids and other sites in Michigan and Chicago and Cleveland.

title: Corzine Is Signed To Offer By Nets
description: In an effort to solve a nagging problem at center, the New Jersey Nets went to the free-agent market yesterday and signed Dave Corzine of the San Antonio Spurs to an offer sheet.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE VOTES PLAN FOR U.S. BROADCASTS TO CUBA
description: The House Committee on Energy and Commerce approved a bill today to authorize the creation of Radio Marti, a Government station for broadcasting to Cuba.

title: Elevator Accident Kills Jersey Boy, 8
description: An 8-year-old boy was crushed to death Monday when he became wedged between the outer and inner doors of an elevator in the building where he lived, the police said.

title: Sliding Uphill
description: Our neighborhood is being gentrified. It may seem churlish of us to complain about it, since our arrival here 30 months ago was part of the process, but we complain about it anyhow. A New Yorker without a grievance to sulk about is as unnatural as a Floridian without a sunbaked hide and a Californian without a tennis racquet.

title: CITY WAGE OFFER IS RAISED A LITTLE AS TALKS GO ON
description: The Koch administration last night made a slight improvement in its wage offer to unions representing police officers, firefighters and correction officers, the first shift in the city's bargaining stance since labor contracts expired July 1.

title: Nebraskan Loses Effort To Block License Picture
description: A woman who said that the Second Commandment forbade her to allow her photograph to be taken has lost in an effort to be excused from having a picture on her driver's license.

title: OPEC Group Meets
description: A group of member nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been holding talks after last week's ministerial conference, aimed at finding a formula to defend current price levels, Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's energy and mines minister, said today. In statements from Vienna, he said that Kuwait, Algeria, Indonesia, Ecuador, Indonesia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela had met after the conference in the Austrian capital and that conversations were continuing daily.

title: Schering-Plough Bid
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said today that it had completed the acquisition of Dnax Ltd. for $19.05 million in cash and 340,000 Schering-Plough shares. Based on Schering-Plough's closing price of 30 1/4, up 3/8, on the New York Stock Exchange Monday, the total deal is worth $29.3 million. The 340,000 shares are to be distributed to Dnax's research staff and scientific advisory board over a five-year period.

title: 300 Leave Stockholm For March in Soviet
description: About 300 antiwar campaigners, most of them Scandinavian women, left Stockholm today for a 900-mile march in the Soviet Union.

title: Vistron Closings
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said its Vistron Corporation subsidiary would close its Lima, Ohio, ammonia, urea and carbon dioxide plants indefinitely. The company said that the plants were operating at a loss but that it would use the facilities as a terminal to provide customers with ammonia and urea from other producers. Workers at the plant will be reassigned to maintenance duties.

title: SOME POLISH DETAINEES BELEVIED FREED
description: Poland's military Government is believed to have quietly released an undisclosed number of Solidarity activists in the last few days.

title: DON'T LIMIT BIOLOGY TO TEACHING DARWINISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Anixter Unit Buys Canadian Concern
description: Anixter Brothers Inc., a distributor of cable television equipment, said that its Canadian subsidiary had acquired the assets of Micro-Sat Communications Ltd. of Toronto.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE ANATOLIAN. By Elia Kazan. 436 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: U.S. REPORTS PROGRESS IN NAMIBIA TALKS
description: The State Department today announced the ''successful conclusion'' of a key phase of negotiations to end the guerrilla war in South-West Africa. Officials said they were optimistic that the South African-controlled territory would become the independent nation of Namibia next year.

title: S.E.C. SETTLES CHARGES AGAINST 2 HUNT BROTHERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt with violations of Federal securities laws for failing to disclose in timely fashion the purchase in 1979 and 1980 of more than 5 percent of the stock of Bache Group Inc.

title: SPERM BANK'S FIRST MOTHER ONCE SERVED TIME FOR FRAUD
description: The mother of the first ''Nobel sperm bank'' baby is an former convict, records show, and she lost the custody of two children by a previous marriage after her current husband was accused of child abuse.

title: Reynolds Unit To Pay Fine
description: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company agreed today to pay $100,000 in civil penalties to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it did not clearly disclose the Surgeon General's health warning on smoking in all advertising, the commission said.

title: Fumes Kill Man and Woman In Car Parked in Queens Lot
description: A young Queens man and woman were found dead from carbon monoxide fumes inside a car in a parking lot yesterday, according to the police.

title: Timex Assignment
description: The Timex Corporation has assigned J. Walter Thompson the job of making the ads to sell the three electronic digital products it will introduce in the health-care field - a blood-pressure reader, a scale and a thermometer. In addition to the Timex Medical Products Corporation assignment, J.W.T. does advertising for the Timex computers, while Grey Advertising handles the watches.

title: Billy Martin Fumes
description: Billy Martin, the manager of the Oakland A's and of the American League team in last night's All-Star Game, is habitually wary of personal slights. Perceiving one, he recently sent a letter to the City Council in his hometown of Berkeley, Calif., requesting that his name be removed from a baseball diamond in James Kenney Park.

title: Real Estate; A Couple's Big Project In Midtown
description: THAT hole in the ground in the block between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue from 48th Street to 49th Street will become a 44-story office tower in early 1984, largely as a result of the work of an ambitious couple who head Solomon Equities, a 12-person company.

title: INTRUDER AND QUEEN REPORTEDLY CHATTED ABOUT ROYAL FAMILY
description: The lawyer of the man who sneaked into Queen Elizabeth's bedroom said today that his client spent ''just over 10 minutes'' talking with the Queen about the royal family before a chambermaid led him away.

title: WASHINGTON
description: When George Shultz appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to be confirmed as Secretary of State, one of the principal advisers at his side was Lloyd Cutler, counselor at the White House under President Carter.

title: Hospital Blood Levels Drop to 2-Day Supply
description: The supply of blood available to hospitals in the metropolitan area was down to a two-day inventory yesterday morning, according to the New York Blood Center.

title: STRUCTURAL PROBLEM IN U.S. FOREIGN POLICY MACHINERY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Two New Leaders For Business Committee

title: Reagan Chooses Upstate Lawyer
description: President Reagan has forwarded a recommendation to the Senate that Frederick J. Scullin Jr., a lawyer from Liverpool, N.Y., be appointed United States Attorney for the Northern District of New York, according to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.

title: CONTAINERS FOR SNAILS
description: SNAILS a la Bourguignonne, served bubbling in their shells with a garlicky butter mopped up with French bread, are one of my favorite dishes. In Burgundy when I was a boy I used to go snail hunting with my father every spring. We would pick out the plumpest snails and take them home, where they were enclosed in a pen and fed lettuce for several months. In the winter the snails hibernated.

title: Lehigh Valley Sale Of Some Assets
description: Shareholders of Lehigh Valley Industries approved the sale of Lehigh's Blue Ridge-Winkler textiles business and certain other assets for $10.5 million to a corporation controlled by its chairman, Lawrence Gordon.

title: Worker Dies in Jersey Crash
description: A construction worker was killed and another injured today after a car struck a vehicle they were using for work on the Garden State Parkway near Exit 148, the state police said. The police identified the dead worker as Jose Esquerrao, 50 years old, of Newark.

title: REAGAN IS UNDECIDED ON SENDING MARINES TO BEIRUT
description: President Reagan told Congressional leaders today that he had still not decided to send marines into Lebanon because his conditions for their safety had not been met. He declined to promise that he would formally seek Congressional approval for putting troops into Lebanon if their stay became extended.

title: BASF Acquisition
description: The Federal Trade Commission let stand today a ruling allowing the BASF Wyandotte Corporation to acquire the Chemetron Pigments division of the Allegheny Ludlum International Corporation.

title: CRENSHAW IS FASCINATED BY GOLFING LORE
description: Whenever Ben Crenshaw, the most famous member of the Golf Collectors' Society, comes to the United Kingdom, people give him so many gifts that he has to scurry about for cartons and crates to ship them to his home in Austin, Tex.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Paulo Rajao vice president and manager of compensation and employee relations for its Western Hemisphere operations.

title: Required Reading; On Air-Conditioning
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, in discussion on the Senate floor concerning pending action on a revised urgent supplemental appropriations bill, June 29, 1982:

title: J.A.L. Splits Account
description: Japan Air Lines, whose relationship with Ketchum Communications goes back almost 30 years, will be severing the tie Oct. 1 and splitting its overseas advertising among three agencies. Young & Rubicam is getting the United States, which bills about $2.5 million; SSC& B-Lintas, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is getting Europe, while another Interpublic company, Ling McCann-Erickson, Hong Kong, is being assigned Asia and the Australia-New Zealand region. In Japan, J.A.L. works with both Dentsu and Hakuhodo. Y.& R., interestingly enough, has a joint venture in Tokyo with the former and McCann with the latter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: City Loses Out on Contract And a Crack at 1,800 Jobs

title: Toyota-G.M. Link
description: The Toyota Motor Company of Japan has begun engineering and manufacturing studies on a possible venture with the General Motors Corporation to build small cars in the United States, Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s chairman, said.

title: FIRST OVERRIDE OF REAGAN VETO COMES ON EXTENSION OF PRINTING COPYRIGHTS
description: In the first major Congressional rebuff to President Reagan, the House and Senate voted overwhelmingly today to override a Presidential veto of copyright legislation that was intended to preserve jobs in the American printing and publishing industries.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Craig Enters Plea
description: Jim Craig, the goalie of the 1980 United States Olympic hockey team, pleaded not guilty yesterday to a charge of vehicular homicide in District Court in Wareham, Mass. The charge arose from a May 29 automobile crash in which a 28-year-old New Bedford woman was killed.

title: Hitachi's Computer
description: Hitachi Ltd. said today that its development of a supercomputer to handle scientific calculations was proceeding despite charges in the United States of a conspiracy to obtain secrets from the International Business Machines Corportion.

title: CheckList, in Memory of the Checker
description: Parents with triplets are not alone in mourning the five-passenger Checker cabs, the last of which rolled off a Kalamazoo assembly line this week.

title: GERMAN LOANS FOR SOVIET PIPELINE
description: A consortium of West German banks signed an agreement with the Soviet Union today to provide up to $1.6 billion to help finance the Siberian natural gas pipeline to Western Europe.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''THE ingenious people who run Conrail are determined not to run a boring commuter railroad,'' says Karl E. Meyer, in describing a recent trip to Grand Central. ''There is a Committee, I figure, and over the years its members have arranged any number of diversions for those of us who use the New Haven line: blackouts and brownouts, power failures and brake failures, the turning of expresses into locals or the unseasonable raising and dropping of temperatures, always done expertly, with an eye to maximum surprise and discomfort.''

title: THE QUALITY OF MERCY IS INDEED STRAINED BY 180,000 GUESTS
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has decided that in the event of an impending nuclear war, 180,000 people from New York City should relocate to Tompkins County in the heart of the Finger Lakes, asking the 87,000 people of this heavily rural region to be a ''host community.''

title: New York Post Reports Strike by Its Pressmen
description: A sudden strike by pressmen halted the printing of The New York Post early this morning, the paper said. ''There has been a labor stoppage and the best we anticipate is that the afternoon editions will be printed in the morning,'' a statement by the Post said.

title: Saxon in Sale Of Some Assets
description: Saxon Industries, a paper products and business machines company that has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell certain assets of its Business Products division to Alco Enterprises Inc., an investment group based in Tenafly, N.J. Saxon is based in New York.

title: Humanitarian Agencies Must Remain Impartial
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADA UPSTAGED
description: MONTREAL T he theme for last night's All-Star Game was ''A Salute to International Baseball'' but two Latin American players on the Cincinnati Reds upstaged this Canadian metropolis. Dave Concepcion of Venezuela hit a two-run homer and Mario Soto of the Dominican Republic struck out four in two innings as the National League won, 4-1, for the 11th straight time and the 19th in the last 20 games.

title: I.B.M. CASE: A DISMISSAL
description: The Justice Department withdrew charges today against a Mitsubishi Electric Corporation employee arrested in an F.B.I. operation involving the sale of I.B.M. computer secrets.

title: WARNER AND MCI POST GAINS WHILE CBS AND TIME INC. SLIP
description: Warner Communications and the MCI Communications Corporation, two of the nation's fastest-growing communications companies, yesterday reported hefty earnings increases in the second quarter, while Time Inc. and CBS, which are trying to expand into new electronic services, reported slight declines in net income. CBS

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Do-It-Yourself Approach Takes to the Road

title: Spark Plug Plant
description: Champion Spark Plug Inc. said it would close its Hellertown, Pa., assembly plant by mid-October, resulting in the loss of 190 hourly and 40 salaried jobs. Champion cited the sluggish economy and a weak after-market in the automotive industry.

title: Soviet Returning To Tennis in U.S.
description: Six years ago, the Soviet Union withdrew its team from the Federation Cup women's tennis competition in Philadelphia because of the presence of South Africa. Until this week, Soviet players had not competed in the United States, and the Soviet Union's international tennis program had been scaled down considerably.

title: WINE TALK
description: ST. HELENA, Calif. THE tall Victorian chateau with its towers and gables and veranda stands on Spring Mountain in the Mayacamas Range, looking eastward over the Napa Valley. It is the home of Spring Mountain Vineyards, where fine chardonnays and cabernet sauvignons are made, wines known to oenophiles seeking the best that California can produce.

title: Market Place; How Analysts Regard Exxon
description: SHARES of the Exxon Corporation traded yesterday at 26 1/8, their lowest price in more than two years, before finishing at 26 1/2, unchanged for the session, in heavy trading. Apparently several analysts' reduced estimates of Exxon earnings have affected the stock.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN ADDRESS TO COUNTY OFFICIALS MEETING
description: Following are excerpts from the text of President Reagan's speech as prepared for delivery today to the meeting of the National Association of Counties here:

title: MEXICAN TRAIN TOLL UP TO 120
description: The death toll in the wreck of a train carrying 1,560 passengers rose today to 120, including three Americans, rescue officials said.

title: SURGEON ACCUSES ISRAEL OF MISTREATING PRISONERS
description: A Canadian surgeon said today that he had seen two prisoners beaten to death by Israeli soldiers in a makeshift prison camp in Sidon and had witnessed the dropping of cluster and phosphorus bombs on a refugee camp near his hospital.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Athens School Head

title: Virginia Goillot Dead; Agent in World War II
description: Virginia Goillot, an American journalist who became a heroine while in the French Resistance during World War II, has died at the age of 77. She was a resident of Barnesville.

title: THE DAIRY LOBBY IS TOOL, NOT VOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: TIMEX SETS ENTRY INTO GROWING FIELD OF HEALTH PRODUCTS
description: The Timex Corporation, the world's largest watchmaker, yesterday announced its entry into the expanding home health-care field with a line of health monitoring instruments that it will sell through drugstores.

title: Abitibi Layoffs
description: Abitibi-Price Ltd. will lay off 800 workers at its newsprint mill in Grand Falls, Newfoundland, for two weeks starting July 25 to reduce inventories, a company spokesman said. The mill had been closed for two weeks in June.

title: Fannie Mae Loss Widens
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, a major purchaser of home loans in the secondary market, today reported a net loss of $43.1 million for the second quarter.

title: Bridge: Post-Mortem Can End Up Failing to Satisfy Anyone
description: Many spirited post-mortem discussions are purely hypothetical: ''What would have happened if the contract had been ... ?'' The answers to such questions are sometimes obvious. But they are sometimes so difficult that the players are virtually certain to get the wrong answer, or perhaps the right answer for the wrong reason. The diagramed deal is an example.

title: Orange-co Inc.'s Liability on Leases
description: Orange-co Inc., a marketer of citrus fruits and frozen orange juice based in Florida, said yesterday that Lumara Foods of America Inc., for which it had guaranteed leases, had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The total payment due on the leases, Orange-co said in a statement, is about $4.2 million for the current year and $64 million for the rest of the lease terms.

title: REAGAN BARS U.S. AID TO BUDD ON SUBWAY CARS
description: The Treasury Secretary said today that he would not authorize Government financing support of an American manufacturer that wants to sell subway cars to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in New York City.

title: E.P.A. SETS WASTE DUMPING RULES FOR SITES ON LAND TO PROTECT WATER
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced its long-deferred rules for dumping hazardous wastes in land sites, saying they would protect the nation's drinking water supply and the health of its citizens.

title: Knick Long Shot
description: The Boston Celtics were praised for using their selection on the 10th and last round of last month's college draft to choose Landon Turner, the former Indiana University basketball star who had been paralyzed in an automobile accident.

title: To His Alma Mater
description: B arry Rosen, Brooklyn College class of '65, is going back to his old school for a year, this time as a full-time special assistant to the president, Dr. Robert L. Hess.

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON ON REAL ESATE
description: When suffering under this city's summertime 90's (that's where the temperature and humidity generally can be found), visitors and residents alike may wonder: Why wasn't the capital put somewhere else, where there is less heat, less humidity, less rain and fewer bugs?

title: 3 NAMED BY VATICAN TO STUDY BANK TIES
description: The Vatican announced yesterday that it had appointed three outside banking experts to look into dealings between the Vatican bank and Italy's scandal-ridden Banco Ambrosiano.

title: SUSAN LITTLER, BRITISH ACTRESS, 33
description: Susan Littler, the British actress who charmed the New York theater critics with her sparkling comedic performance in Alan Ayckbourn's ''Bedroom Farce,'' died of cancer last Sunday in London. She was 33 years old.

title: Interest Rates Increase Again; Doubts Grow On Fed Policy
description: Interest rates increased for the second consecutive day yesterday as dealers blamed weak investor demand and a lack of fresh evidence that the Federal Reserve has eased monetary policy.

title: MANHATTAN IN CHANGE: THE FUTURE OF THE ECONOMY
description: Last of three articles on Manhattan as it looks to the future. By FRANK J. PRIAL

title: Avis to Compton
description: Picking its first plum since becoming part of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, Compton Communications has been named agency for Avis Car Rental in Britain, France, Italy and Germany. The account, with billings of $12 million, was previously with affiliates of BBDO International, which also has Avis in the United States. Avis is part of Norton Simon Inc., and Compton does advertising for Norton's Max Factor subsidiary in a number of countries.

title: Texas Air Merger Voted
description: Shareholders of the Texas Air Corporation and Continental Air Lines today approved the merger of the two companies, completing a transaction valued at $144.8 million.

title: Bell Measure Advances
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee, resuming work today on a complex telephone measure, beat back an attempt to relax the standards that will determine how long the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is singled out for special regulation.

title: SYRIANS DENOUNCE ISRAELIS AND U.S.
description: A rally presided over by Prime Minister Abdel-Raouf al-Kassem today condemned Israeli military action in Lebanon, but the brunt of the protest was directed at the United States for its support of Israel.

title: I.B.M. NET UP 24.4% IN QUARTER
description: Despite sluggish sales in the computer industry, the International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that net income for the second quarter rose by 24.4 percent, an increase that substantially exceeded Wall Street expectations.

title: Alabama Governor Signs Bill on School Prayer
description: A bill to allow prayer in Alabama public schools has been approved by Gov. Fob James, but the measure's opponents promised a court challenge.

title: Orders Canceled For 8 Boeing Jets
description: Orders for eight of the Boeing Company's jetliners have been canceled by two airlines, the company said.

title: UNR IS CONSIDERING A CHAPTER 11 FILING
description: UNR Industries Inc. of Chicago said yesterday that it was ''seriously contemplating'' filing for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. The holding company has wide interests involving industrial, commercial, transportation and consumer products.

title: HONOLULU PAPERS' 1962 JOINT OPERATING ACCORD CHALLENGED IN COURT
description: A 20-year-old joint operating agreement between The Honolulu Star-Bulletin and The Honolulu Advertiser has been attacked in an antitrust trial that opened here last week and will continue into August.

title: HOUSE FAILS TO OVERRIDE REAGAN'S VETO OF A SUPPLEMENTAL FUND BILL
description: The House of Representatives failed today to override President Reagan's veto of a $5.9 billion supplemental appropriation bill, then went to conference with the Senate on a stripped-down version of the bill.

title: Heron International
description: Heron International P.L.C.'s American subsidiary, the Pima Services Corporation, has bought 12,500 acres of development land in Arizona for $75 million from the estate of the late Howard R. Hughes, its chairman, Gerald Ronson, said today. The land is in 25 separate parcels in the Tuscon area. Heron has presold about 1,500 acres of the land for $40 million, he said.

title: FIERSTEIN AND 'TORCH SONG': A DARING CLIMB FROM OBSCURITY
description: CERTAINLY it is one of the most daring and anomalous plays to ever move to Broadway. A four-hour drama in three parts, Harvey Fierstein's ''Torch Song Trilogy'' recounts the story of Arnold Beckoff, a nice Jewish boy of ''great wit and want,'' who also happens to be an avowed homosexual and a transvestite who makes his living by appearing on stage.

title: China Simulates Atomic Blast In War Games Aimed at Soviet
description: China exploded a simulated tactical nuclear weapon last month during war games aimed at combating a Soviet invasion, Western military sources said today.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 14, 1982
description: International A new Iranian offensive in the Persian Gulf war began, and both Iran and Iraq reported that heavy fighting was under way. The battle reports were vague and sketchy. Baghdad reported that Teheran's forces were pressing to enter southern Iraq, but did not say whether they had already done so. (Page A1, Column 6.) Sympathy for the Palestinians was expressed by Secretary of Statedesignate George P. Shultz. In seven hours of testimony on the first day of his Senate confirmation hearing, Mr. Shultz said the Lebanon crisis had made it ''painfully and totally clear'' that the ''legitimate needs and problems'' of the Palestinian people must be resolved urgently if peace is to be achieved in the Middle East. (A1:3.)

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 14, 1982; The Economy
description: Retail sales plunged 1.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported. The decline erased more than half of May's sales gain and raised new questions about the recovery. The June sales decline, led by a 6.9 percent drop in autos, was the steepest since October. The reaction among analysts was somber. (Page D1.)

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE WINS 11TH STRAIGHT ALL-STAR GAME
description: Baseball moved its All-Star Game across an international frontier for the first time tonight, but the National League still defeated the American League, 4-1, and extended its remarkable winning streak in the series to 11 games.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle in some copies June 25 on restric- tion of domestic spying incorrectly at- tributed the remark that ''propagan- da, disinformation and 'legal assist- ance' '' groups ''may be even more dangerous than those who actually throw the bombs.'' It was said by Sen- ator Jeremiah Denton, not William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bu- reau of Investigation.

title: FOUR HERBS AND SPICES IN BOLD NEW BLENDINGS
description: OYSTERS with creme fraiche and ginger? Pears poached in wine with basil? Cumin with carrots? Coriander and orange relish with grilled steak? Are those dishes outrageous combinations of a chef gone wild, further examples of the excesses of nouvelle cuisine? Not to people who have tasted them. Their reaction is delight - and surprise.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTES EXTENDING LAW ON COPYRIGHTS
description: Following is the roll-call of votes by members of the House and Senate from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on a proposal to override President Reagan's veto of legislation to extend a printing copyright law. A ''yes'' represents a vote to override and a ''no'' represents a vote supporting the veto; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: Excerpts from testimony, page A12.
description: Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz said today that the Lebanese crisis had made it ''painfully and totally clear'' that the ''legitimate needs and problems'' of the Palestinian people must be resolved urgently if there ever is to be peace in the Middle East.

title: News Analysis
description: An Iranian invasion of Iraq would present the United States with a paradoxical international crisis in which critical American interests are at stake but American influence is negligible. That conclusion was discussed among officials here today before new fighting erupted between Iraq and Iran. The Iraqis said the Iranians had opened an attack aimed at striking into Iraqi territory, and the Iranians vowed to remove any Iraqi threat to their cities.

title:
Economic Scene;
A Weak Spot For Japanese
description: TOKYO THE Achilles' heel of the dynamic Japanese economy lies in the rapid aging of our population, at present the youngest among the advanced countries. The ratio of the labor force (ages 15 through 64) to retirees is 8.5 to 1, compared with 5.5 to 1 in other advanced countries.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKING COUNTIES SUPPORT
description: President Reagan appealed to county government officials here today for support of the revised ''new federalism'' proposal that he said he would send to Congress by the end of the month.

title: U.S. RETAIL SALES FELL 1.5% IN JUNE
description: Retail sales plunged 1.5 percent last month, the Government reported today. The decline, which erased more than half the May gain, raised new questions about the economic recovery.

title: Bill Would Create City Agency To Get Low-Cost Electricity
description: Legislation has been introduced in the City Council to create a city-run Municipal Utility Service, through which low-cost hydroelectric power could become available to city residents by the end of 1985, Karen N. Gerard, Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development, announced yesterday.

title: IGNORING SOCCER CAN BE EASY
description: F our years and three weeks ago, there were five of us in Athens on a Wednesday afternoon, when the smog came down like an alpenstock. Three were teen-agers in an advanced state of grump on account of strange language, strange food and museums full of Germans. The adult male read Bullfinch. The adult female, reconnoitering, was waylaid by a taverna-keeper who, behind the usual piratical mustache, promised the best American hamburgers in all of Attic Greece.

title: Heavy Fighting Reported North of Afghan Capital
description: Soviet and Afghan forces have mounted widespread attacks on Moslem rebels in Afghanistan and heavy fighting is reported from some areas, Western diplomatic sources said here today.

title: LIST OF PROGRAMS FOR STATES' CONTROL IS ISSUED
description: The White House, detailing President Reagan's revised ''new federalism'' proposal, today listed Federal programs that would become the responsibility of the states.

title: THE MAN WHO BEAT A.T.& T.
description: A 320-foot-high tower juts into the prairie sky next to the house in which Thomas F. Carter and his wife, Helen, live. A sign hitched to the fence tells the purpose of the tower. ''Carter Mobilefone Company,'' it says.

title: Armory in Buffalo Damaged by Fire
description: A team of military officials today inspected an 82-year-old, castle-like armory, after a fire Monday night that caused up to $5 million in damage.

title: CBS Slayings Data Sought by Defense
description: Defense attorneys for a New Jersey man accused of killing a Federal witness and three CBS employees in Manhattan last April 12 filed legal papers in State Supreme Court yesterday seeking access to prosecution information and evidence in the case.

title: OPERA: GUANGDONG YUE SINGS 'THE MAGIC LOTUS LATERN'
description: THE Guangdong Yue Opera Troupe ensconsed at the Beacon Theater through Sunday has received less publicity than the Peking Opera Company that played the Metropolitan Opera two years ago. But it is fully as fascinating - perhaps even more so, since the repertory includes four full-length works; the Peking company offered only excerpts, chosen to emphasize the spectacular and acrobatic.

title: Soviet Grain Pact Prospect
description: It is unlikely that a new, long-term grain agreement will be negotiated with the Soviet Union in the near future, according to Bill Brock, the Reagan Administration's special trade representative.

title: P.L.O. OFFICIAL REPORTS SHIFT ON ISRAEL
description: A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that he could state officially that the P.L.O. was prepared to recognize Israel ''on a reciprocal basis.''

title: MARINE, IRVING DIP
description: Two major bank holding companies, Marine Midland Banks Inc. and the Irving Bank Corporation, yesterday reported declines in secondquarter earnings, while a third, the Mellon National Corporation, said its net operating income surged 14.6 percent. Marine Midland

title: Science Digest Change
description: At Hearst Magazines, Thomas P. Losee Jr., 41, has been named publisher of Science Digest, having already been publisher of Harper's Bazaar and House Beautiful. For the last year he was vice president and assistant to K. Robert Brink, general manager. Charles Mandel, the current publisher of Science Digest, is joining John Mack Carter in the Hearst Magazine Development Group.

title: BEIRUT TRUCE IS HOLDING, WITH TALKS AT A STANDSTILL
description: A cease-fire between Israeli and Palestinian forces held for a second day as negotiators for a settlement of the siege of west Beirut continued their so far unproductive talks.

title: N.F.L. Players Irked by Offer
description: The National Football League's Management Council presented a fiveyear contract proposal yesterday to the N.F.L. Players Association that upgraded the present compensation system for teams that lose free agents. The players association angrily denounced the proposal, although negotiations will continue at 9:30 A.M. today.

title: Army Contract to G.M.
description: The Army said today that it had awarded the General Motors Corporation a $690 million contract for 53,248 trucks and other utility vehicles, to be delivered over four years. The Army also awarded a $25.6 million contract to the Boeing Computer Company, a Boeing Company unit, for the leasing of teleprocessing services.

title: TOUR BUSES HELP TO MAKE WORLD'S FAIR A SUCCESS
description: After little more than a third of its scheduled run, the World's Fair, which has been plagued by conflicts since its inception, can easily claim popular and financial success, with attendance climbing past five million over the weekend.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jose Sulaiman, president of the World Boxing Council, has dismissed a suggestion by a British physician, Dr. Robert Burton, that boxing be abolished in England. ''Abolish boxing, never,'' Sulaiman told the official Mexican news agency, Notimex.

title: Puppet Theater Days At Snug Harbor
description: Visitors to the first International Puppet Theater Festival at Staten Island's Snug Harbor Cultural Center can attend puppet, mime and clown shows and then learn the performance arts themselves in daylong workshops conducted by the Marquis Studios, a 25-member theatrical ensemble.

title: EX-DISNEY ANIMATORS TRY TO OUTDO THEIR MENTOR
description: HOLLYWOOD ATIMID mouse, an awkward crow and a fierce cat are dancing their ways down shopping malls across the country. The six-foot animals are part of a $4.4 million effort to advertise and merchandise ''The Secret of NIMH,'' which is opening in theaters in regional waves in July. The last wave will take ''The Secret of NIMH'' into New York late in July.

title: Careers; Importance Of Human Resources
description: LIKE the corporate strategic planner, the human resources development executive is a man for all seasons, and an especially favorable season appears to be approaching.

title: Phone Rings and Rings For Tchaikovsky Victor
description: Stephanie Chase, a violinist who is home from her triumph at the Seventh International Tchaikovsky Competition, today began to savor the effect of her new-found fame on what had been a struggling musical career. ''The phone has been ringing off the hook,'' said the 24-year-old musician, flushed and happy with her shared third prize in the Moscow competition.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS anyone with a basic knowledge of French menu terminology knows, certain ''code'' words are used in the French kitchen to specify one ingredient or a combination of ingredients to be found in any given dish.

title: ROCK: THE MOTELS HEARD AT THE RITZ
description: based rock quintet that packed the Ritz on Friday and Saturday, stylistically plays two ends against a very commercial middle. Led by the singer, writer and guitarist Martha Davis, the group plays in a mildly abrasive postpunk style that's closer in spirit to groups like X than to, say, the Eagles or Linda Ronstadt.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRENCH CONNECTION

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman gymnasium, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 6:30 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. Gus Williams of the Seattle SuperSonics was player of the week last week with 84 points in two games. He teamed with his brother, Ray, the former Knick and Net, in the backcourt for the New York Gems. They face Reggie Carter and John Williamson of Ka-Har-Lynn in the second game.

title: COSMOS BACK AFTER HARD TRIP
description: The Cosmos will be back at Giants Stadium Wednesday night after the longest trip in their history. The trip resulted in three losses in four games, which is rather unusual for them, and an altercation between two players in the final game, which is not so unusual.

title: A DRAFT EVADER WINS INDICTMENT AND CELEBRITY
description: Enten Eller stepped gamely in front of a brace of microphones at 2:03 P.M. today and faced the television cameras and the glare of the spotlights. Washington's newest instant celebrity was born.

title: U.S. BANKER NAMED A VATICAN EXAMINER
description: Joseph Brennan, the 71-year-old chairman of the executive committee of the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York, said yesterday that he was coming cold to the task of acting as a Vatican-appointed expert to look into the relations between the Vatican bank and Banco Ambrosiano.

title: PITTSBURGH SEEKS STADIUM'S CONTROL
description: After 14 months of negotiations, the city has decided to take over Three Rivers Stadium, the home of the Pittsburgh Pirates and Steelers. In return, the two teams would agree to keep their franchises in the city until the year 2011.

title: BAN TAPE FROM LOUISIANA CRASH LEADS TO CALL FOR NEWER RECORDERS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, disturbed by the poor condition of the sound recording recovered from the airliner that crashed taking off from New Orleans Friday, urged yesterday that airliners be equipped with much more modern devices.

title: CITY IS PREPARED TO EXCLUDE CABLE CONCERN FROM TALKS
description: New York City has made a major effort to speed its stalled cable television negotiations by notifying one of the six companies involved in contract talks that it was prepared to proceed without the company's participation.

title: A Hiatus on River Avenue
description: O n one of the bigger days of the season - they played the All-Star Game in Montreal last night - there was no major-league baseball in New York. Not often in the summer is that true.

title: AT LEAST $1 MILLION EXPECTED FOR J.M.W. TURNER PAINTING
description: One of the very few oil paintings by J.M.W. Turner still in private hands, ''Landscape With Walton Bridges,'' will be auctioned Oct. 28 by Sotheby Parke Bernet.
