The luminous study in yellows, rust, bronze and greens, depicting an arched double bridge in Walton-on-Thames, Surrey, was painted in the early 1840's. It is expected by the auction house to sell for more than $1 million.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Lawrence Wien Given A Straw-Hat Tribute

title: PRIVATE PENSIONS WILL PROVIDE MOST FUTURE RETIREMENT INCOME
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA'S IRRITATION WITH U.S. GROWING
description: China is displaying fresh irritation with the United States over what Peking feels is Washington's failure to bring about a quicker resolution of their longstanding differences on Taiwan.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tribute to a Doctor And Policy Maker

title: I.C.I. Deal in Spain
description: Imperial Chemical Industries is adding to its titanium dioxide interests in Spain in a $20 million deal, an I.C.I. spokesman said today. Explosivos Rio Tinto is selling its 55 percent stake in Titanio S.A. to Tioxide Group, the other shareholder. Tioxide Group itself is jointly held by I.C.I. and Lead Industries.

title: Military Analysis
description: Intelligence analysts in Washington, London and several capitals in the Middle East have differing views over the Iranians' prospects in any all-out attempt to invade Iraq.

title: Judge Refuses to Block Plan To Kill 2,200 Weakened Deer
description: A request to block the killing of 2,200 weakened, starving deer in the Everglades was denied today.

title: ASSOCIATE OF FORMER C.I.A AGENT ADMITS ACCEPTING A BRIBE
description: A former Federal official pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today to accepting a bribe from Edwin P. Wilson, the former intelligence agent now in custody on charges of illegally shipping explosives to Libya.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amtrak said it had given a $9 million contract to Breda, an Italian company, for work on subway cars that Amtrak will assemble for use in Washington, D.C.

title: Progress Report
description: Worldwide waves of adoration continue to wash over Italy's national soccer team, winner of the World Cup. Il Progresso, a daily Italian-language newspaper published in Emerson, N.J., yesterday invited the 22-man team to New York for a parade on Fifth Avenue, promising to raise the funds for the trip if the team would come.

title: COMMODITY WATCHDOG CRITICIZED
description: After an eight-month investigation, a Senate subcommittee today issued a report saying that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission is unable to protect the public from the ''recent tide'' of commodity fraud that has cost investors more than $1 billion in the last five years.

title: COURT CLEARS PRISONER'S MOVE TO L.I. PSYCHIATRIC BUILDINGS
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the state could transfer 1,000 prisoners to three vacant buildings on the grounds of the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in West Brentwood, L.I.

title: 55 HOSPITALS AND HOMES PREPARE FOR POSSIBLE STRIKE
description: Fifty-five nonprofit hospitals and nursing homes in New York and Long Island were preparing yesterday for the possibility of a strike tomorrow morning by a wide range of hospital workers, including laboratory technicians, garbage handlers, kitchen employees, social workers and engineers.

title: JERSEY RULING FAVORS GLENN MILLER'S 2 HEIRS
description: A son and daughter of Glenn Miller are entitled to nearly $800,000 in past royalties from records released after the bandleader's death more than 36 years ago and are also entitled to future royalties, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The studio in the building on Lexington Avenue is spare, white, with an enormous artist's table in the middle of one room. The drawers of the table are filled with artworks, and the top is covered with them, in neat piles; in the bedroom there are more, and in the closet. A very large one is tacked up with pushpins in the hall; a small one is on the wall in the dining nook. The place is a little stuffy.

title: 'IT'S OKAY, CHARLIE, THEY'VE GOT SEATS!'
description: First came Senator Alan Cranston, coat slung over his shoulder, hurrying through the crowd that lined the hallway in front of the the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing room.

title: Giants Acquire a Safety
description: The Giants yesterday acquired Pete Shaw, a strong safety, from the San Diego Chargers in exchange for an undisclosed future draft choice. Shaw, a 5-foot-11-inch, 180-pound native of Newark, had 12 interceptions in his five seasons with San Diego, most of them spent as a starter. He has also been used as a punt returner.

title: Bally Machine Curbed
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, a leading maker of coin-operated amusement and gaming machines, has been enjoined by a Federal court in Nevada from manufacturing, selling or leasing a video poker machine. District Judge William Foreman granted the temporary restraining order in favor of International Game Technology, which already makes such a game, in connection with litigation over competition between the two companies. Bally is planning to appeal the ruling.

title: Mr. Frank Inc.  Suing Waste
description: A suit seeking to enjoin Waste Management Inc., a solid-waste disposal company, from acquiring Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc., which is involved in nuclear waste disposal, was filed yesterday by Mr. Frank Inc., a family-owned waste transportation company and a competitor with Waste Management.

title: HIDING WHAT A SWIMSUIT REVEALS
description: IHAVE never been fond of my thighs, and about 10 years ago the vague dissatisfaction turned to positive hate. Every time I looked at them, which was as infrequently as possible, they would reproach me.

title: BRIEFS ON ARTS
description: 'Nutcracker' Is Safe

title: JAZZ: WOODY HERMAN
description: BIG bands such as Woody Herman's 16-man Young Thundering Herd rarely play small jazz rooms these days, for obvious economic reasons, although more than 40 years ago such bands as Mr. Herman's, Count Basie's and Charlie Barnet's were often squeezed into the little rabbit hutches that lined 52d Street when it was ''Swing Alley.''

title: 3 Leave Turkish Cabinet
description: Three Cabinet members resigned today. They were Deputy Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, Finance Minister Kaya Erdem and Minister of Public Works Serif Tuten.

title: LIVING FOR LESS: TWO PLANS
description: IN less difficult economic times Rick and Nurit Amdur would be settling into their new, larger apartment about now, someplace where their 13-month-old son, Ariel, could romp and where there would be a modicum of privacy for Mom and Dad. The Amdurs, who are in the importing business, rented their two-bedroom apartment in the East 80's five years ago, expecting to move when a child came along. Like many couples in their situation, they assumed that if they continued to progress in their careers and managed to put some money aside, a move would be the next logical step.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
COMPUTER ACCESSORIES
description: WITH the growing popularity of home computers, there is also a growing accessories industry. Items to organize components - keyboard, printer and disk drives - as well as disk storage and travel cases are available.

title: OUTDOORS
description: That time of year is here when few other fish, or none, tug as ferociously at some anglers as the black basses, the smallmouth and the largemouth.

title: Jordanian Asks Arab Meeting On Moves in Lebanon and Iraq
description: King Hussein called today for an urgent meeting of Arab leaders to discuss the Middle East's two invasions - Israel's six-week-old drive into Lebanon and the new Iranian attack on Iraq.

title: Female Musicians Set To Celebrate Brooklyn
description: The free Celebrate Brooklyn music series continues this weekend with concerts featuring female performers at the bandshell in Prospect Park, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. Tomorrow at 8 o'clock, it will be the jazz-fusion group Ibis and the rhythm-andblues ensemble Third Wind; the rain date is Saturday at 4 P.M.

title: SENATE PASSES TOBACCO AID CURBS
description: The Senate today approved, 77 to 17, a bill to substantially reduce Government subsidies for tobacco farmers.

title: WHY M-G-M DISCHARGED BEGELMAN
description: At approximately 11:30 Monday morning -only minutes before the information was sent over the Dow Jones business wire - David Begelman was informed that he was no longer the chairman of the United Artists division of M-G-M/U.A.

title: CRITIC's NOTEBOOK; DOES MUSIC HAVE AN AVANT-GARDE?
description: AT the ''Wall-to-Wall'' John Cage concert at Symphony Space last spring, Charlotte Moorman crawled into a blue parachute bag with her cello, wrestled with the instrument, and allowed parts of the cello's anatomy and her own to occasionally protrude. There was a bit of nostalgia to this theater piece by Nam June Paik - the cellist had collaborated with the composer on many a similar adventure nearly two decades ago. Even the sight of Miss Moorman's naked derriere emerging out of the blue was less an ''avant-garde'' shock to concert manners than a quaintly charming gesture from an earlier era.

title: WINDS OF TROON CHALLENGE BRITISH OPEN FIELD OF 150
description: The emblem of the Royal Troon Golf Club is five golf clubs banded by a snake. The significance goes beyond symbolism. This links course on the Ayrshire coast of the Irish Sea is a demanding golf course that penalizes every error and gives no second chances. On its layout alone - length, hazards, narrow fairways, blind shots, rough, gorse, whin and heather - this is a difficult course.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines said it is moving into the lucrative Washington-Newark-New York market with off-peak fares as low as $19.

title: HEALTH INSURANCE FOR THE FAMILY PET
description: HEALTH insurance for pets, which became available in New York State and California last April, has attracted the interest of thousands of animal owners, according to the two companies that introduced the plans.

title: Conoco Settles Oil Price Case
description: Conoco agreed today to pay $3 million to the Government and to provide it with $11 million worth of oil to settle an oil overcharging case.

title: Investigation Is Urged On Clinch River Aides
description: Two environmental groups urged the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today to investigate charges that officials at the Clinch River Breeder Reactor ''concealed technical information'' on the project's safety.

title: GARDENING
description: PETUNIAS and marigolds move over. Impatiens are challenging these top two annual flowers, which have been the leaders in annual flower sales for years.

title: PRESIDENT URGES SAUDIS TO FIND P.L.O. A HAVEN
description: President Reagan has written a letter to King Fahd of Saudi Arabia asking for help in finding an Arab haven for the 6,000 fighters of the Palestine Liberation Organization now in west Beirut, Administration officials said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Yellow Pages En Espanol

title: APPEALS JUDGES REFUSE TO BLOCK PRISONERS' SHIFT
description: The New York State Court of Appeals refused yesterday to block the transfer of 1,000 convicts to the newly converted prison facility at the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in West Brentwood, L.I. The first four busloads of prisoners from the Queensboro Correctional Facility in Long Island City arrived less than three hours after the court's ruling was issued at 3:30 P.M.

title: CAREY SIGNS BILL TO AID POLICE IN CURBING DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: Governor Carey has acted on a score of bills, his office announced today, including signing measures to help the police crack down on drunken drivers and to bar the manufacture and sale of ''imitation'' prescription drugs.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE RED SMITH READER. Edited by Dave Anderson. Foreword by Terence Smith. 308 pages. Random House. $15.95. TO ABSENT FRIENDS FROM RED SMITH. Introduction by Dave Ander- son. 478 pages. Atheneum. $17.95.

title: Army Refuses to Clear Name of Collaborator
description: The Army has refused to clear the name of Ronald E. Alley, saying its action against the only United States officer imprisoned in this century for collaborating with an enemy was ''manifestly appropriate.''

title: TV: VIETNAM VETERANS, U.S. CRIME AND PRISON
description: ''VIETNAM REQUIEM,'' being broadcast at 10 o'clock this evening, represents another unusual project for the ''ABC News Closeup'' documentary unit. With Pamela Hill as its executive producer, the division has used independent producers in the past on an ad hoc basis. Alan and Susan Raymond, for instance, were commissioned to produce a program on Northern Ireland. This time, Miss Hill has gone to Else, Couturie & Korty Inc., for a film that lists as executive producer John Korty, whose directorial credits include the television film ''The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman.''

title: May Inventories Cut By a Record 0.9%
description: Businesses cut their inventories by ninetenths of 1 percent in May, the biggest decline on record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HUDSON'S TO LEAVE DOWNTOWN DETROIT
description: A gloomy Detroit rumor became a sad fact today. Hudson's, the last major department store downtown, said it would discontinue retail operations there after the 1982 Christmas season.

title: CORDIAL AIR
description: Flame and ash: metaphors that don't work here. The Alps rise up, sharks' teeth in the distance. The lake glistens, a sapphire of a million carats. Looking out of the eighth-floor window of the offices where the Americans and Russians talk of banishing thousands of nuclear weapons, the world is so green, blue and white, so perfect, that words like fear and destruction shrivel into irrelevance in the brilliant light.

title: Congolese Ends Cuban Visit
description: Denis Sassou Nguesso of the Congo, who ended a five-day visit to Cuba on Tuesday, joined Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, in a communique today accusing the United States of aggravating international tensions and threatening peace and security.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Temporal Realm

title: Claims Board Resolves 11 Challenges in June
description: Eleven challenges to advertising claims were resolved in June by the National Advertising Review Board of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. Six cases were closed when the advertisers were able to substantiate the questioned claims.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The French Celebrate

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JULY 15, 1982; The Economy
description: New car sales by the Big Three auto makers fell 14.8 percent in the July 1-10 period, the companies reported. G.M.'s sales were down 18.9 percent, Chrysler's 15.9 percent, and Ford's 3.7 percent. It was the third consecutive period in which sales levels were below those of a year earlier. Analysts cited a lack of buyer incentives. (Page D1.)

title: F.D.I.C. Officials Busy In Penn Square Failure
description: The failure of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City left several bankers out of a job. But for G. Michael Newton and James Hudson, executives in the liquidation department of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the bank's closing meant new work, plenty of overtime and dealings with irate clients.

title: Topics; Political Protection; Sheltered
description: William French Smith still seems to think that politics is merely a dirty business. Six weeks ago he gave back a $50,000 director's fee paid just before he took office and also renounced sizable profits from two tax shelters. Yesterday Mr. Smith said he had turned back the money only because Senator Kennedy was making it a ''political issue.''

title: Bridge: Big Apple Championships Start in New York Tonight
description: Many top-ranked players will be tuning up at the New York Hilton Hotel this weekend for the Summer National Championships, which will start next week in Albuquerque, N.M. They will be competing in the Big Apple Regional Championships, which begin tonight with the first round of knockout team play.

title: ISRAEL'S LAWFUL RIGHT AND DUTY TO PROTECT ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Atari Contract
description: Warner Communications Inc. said its Atari unit had won a contract for 426 of its model 800 computers and peripherals from the Dade County, Fla., school system. It did not disclose the value, but said it believed it was the largest school system order ever.

title: Heavyweight Suit
description: Richie Giachetti, who was the manager and trainer of Larry Holmes from 1973 through April 1981, filed a $20 million breach of contract suit against the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion and Don King, the promoter, in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court in Cleveland. Giachetti charged that the champion had refused to honor a contract giving him 20 percent of Holmes's purses.

title: G.M. Cuts Frills
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would eliminate high-priced frills on 1983 base-model ''J'' cars in an attempt to raise the sales of the Chevrolet and Pontiac autos, which have been slow to sell. The features that are to be trimmed include coin holders, side window defoggers and digital clocks.

title: News Analysis
description: New York City's decision this week to halt negotiations with one of the companies seeking a cable television franchise underscores the fact that politics continue to pervade the franchising process.

title: Memorial to Roosevelt Is Approved by House
description: The House today approved construction of a garden memorial to Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: Rates Ease in a Quiet Day; Money Supply Data Awaited
description: In a day of quiet trading, interest rates declined modestly as traders and investors alike waited for evidence that a move to lower interest rates could be sustained in the face of heavy Treasury borrowing and a stronger economy.

title: SUPPORT OF BLACKS FOR CHICAGO'S MAYOR APPEARS TO BE ERODING
description: In this city of kaleidoscopic politics, where the Mayor may call an alderman the ''head of an evil cabal'' at one juncture and name him to run the Cook County Democratic Party at another, a recent shift in loyalties has attracted more than the usual attention.

title: Betsy Brown Wed To R.W. Apple Jr.
description: Betsy Pinckney Brown, executive director of the Foreign Student Service Council in Washington, was married yesterday in London to R.W. Apple Jr., chief London correspondent of The New York Times. The ceremony was performed at the Marylebone Registry Office.

title: DIET PILL IS TERMED EFFECTIVE AGAINST AUTISM
description: Doctors have found that a diet pill strikingly improved the intelligence and relieved the self-isolation of three young victims of autism, a mental illness that strikes children.

title: Last Super Jet Ends His Career
description: The message arrived yesterday, and its brevity was intriguing - an invitation to the press from the New York Jets for a news conference, Thursday, July 15, at noon. But there was none of the usual ''bait,'' which is usually a sentence about ''a major announcement'' regarding playing personnel, coaching personnel, television contracts or whatnot.

title: Too Late Now
description: Coach Ray Malavasi has said that the Los Angeles Rams would not have traded for Bert Jones had they known that Vince Ferragamo would be available as their quarterback. Still, the coach maintained at an orientation session with the press that Jones, the former Baltimore star, was still No.1 and that Ferragamo, wh rejoined the team two weeks ago, would have to battle his way back to the top spot. ... Another coach, Chuck Knox of the Bills, said that he has refused the request of Joe Cribbs, a running back, to be traded. Cribbs has been unhappy with contract negotiations.

title: LENDL HAS TO STRUGGLE TO WIN
description: Ivan Lendl, Guillermo Vilas and Elliot Teltscher won , but sixth-seeded Eddie Dibbs was upset in the second round of the $200,000 United States Pro tennis championships today.

title: ISRAEL'S LAWFUL RIGHT AND DUTY TO PROTECT ISRAEL
description: To the Editor: An exchange between R. Hurwitz and G. Fellman (Op-Ed article June 26) and J. A. Hooley (letter July 8) suggests confusion as to the proper attitude of Americans with respect to wars and the way they are waged.

title: SWAN, 4 ROOKIES DRILL
description: Five players attended a Mets voluntary workout at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: Standard-Coosa
description: The Standard-Coosa Thatcher Company said directors had urged shareholders to reject an offer for 180,000 to 195,000 shares at $60 each made by the Technical Equipment Leasing Corporation and the Hickory Furniture Corporation.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE LIBRARIAN LOOKS AHEAD TO FACTS AND FANTASIES
description: For more than 11,000 librarians, Philadelphia's Civic Center this week has been like a fantasyland, a threedimensional wish list.

title: G.T.E. AND WESTERN UNION POST QUARTERLY GAINS
description: The G.T.E. Corporation, the nation's second-largest telephone company, said yesterday that net income for the second quarter ended June 30 rose 12.7 percent, partly on the strength of telephone rate increases.

title: BAGHDAD'S STRONGMAN
description: Saddam Hussein, President and iron-fisted ruler of Iraq, is nothing if not tough. In his youth he was the only one in his revolutionary cell to escape after an attempt to assassinate a dictator. He cut a bullet out of his leg with a penknife and made his way on a donkey across the desert to Syria. On another occasion he held off an overwhelming force of policemen assaulting his hideout until he ran out of bullets for his pistol.

title: AREAS AFFECTED BY CHEMICAL WASTE DUMPING
description: The Hooker Chemicals and Plastic Corporation has acknowledged that from 1942 to 1953 it deposited about 21,800 tons of chemical wastes into a 15-acre area around the Love Canal in Niagara Falls. The canal itself is shown on the map in black.

title: U.S. TO ALLOW HAITIANS' PAROLE
description: The Justice Department said today that it would not ask the Supreme Court to bar the release of about 1,800 Haitian refugees being held in detention.

title: Scott Comes Close To 1,500 Record
description: Steve Scott ran the fastest 1,500 meters of the season tonight, missing Steve Ovett's two-yearold world record by less than a second.

title: Yeshiva U. Appoints Dean at Law School
description: Monroe E. Price, a faculty member of the Law School at the University of California at Los Angeles, has been named the new dean of Yeshiva University's Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School.

title: MARTIN IS UNSHAKEN DESPITE ADVERSITY
description: MONTREAL I t was late Tuesday afternoon but Billy Martin looked as if it had already been a long day. Or a long night before the long day. For sure, it has been a long season.

title: FIRE ISLANDERS STIRRED TO ANGER BY A SURGE IN ASSESSMENTS
description: On the beaches here and along the boardwalks that link nearly a dozen small villages on the west end of Fire Island, the main concern this summer is not the beach erosion, but something residents fear is more threatening to their way of life - rising taxes.

title: WATCHMAN IS SHOT TO DEATH IN CENTRAL PARK PATROL TRUCK
description: A Central Park night watchman was shot and killed in the park at the wheel of his patrol vehicle early yesterday near the Dairy south of the 65th Street Transverse.

title: ISRAEL'S LAWFUL RIGHT AND DUTY TO PROTECT ITSELF
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: ''CAN only write about this when it's over,'' reads the entry in my journal. The ''it'' I am referring to is not a crime or a love affair but the delicate matter of leaving a job. In the midst of this sensitive psychic negotiation, I am wary of the unbalancing weight of my own introspection. But now, equilibrium restored, the story can be told.

title: FLAT-RATE TAX PROPOSAL IS AN ODD COUPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Importer Introducing Welsh Whisky to U.S.
description: The Sazerac Company, a New Orleans importer, has arranged to import Swn Y Mor Welsh Chwesgi into the United States, a whisky that Peter W.H. Bordeau, executive vice president, translates as ''Sound of the Sea Welsh Whisky.''

title: Alcoa Australia
description: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser said today that Alcoa of Australia Ltd. was likely to freeze development of its $1 billion smelter project at Portland, Victoria, because of financing problems. In addition, the company today reported a 35 percent drop in net first-half profit to $36.90 million, from $57 million a year ago, and said earnings for the second half of the calendar year 1982 would be substantially worse. Alcoa said the project's future was under review and a decision was expected in the very near future.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $75 million of bonds to be underwritten by Salomon Brothers Inc. and First Boston Corp. at terms to be set at the time of sale.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Strength of Character, Weakness of Character

title: Air Collision in South Africa Kills 12, Including 2 Generals
description: Two light planes collided in flight tonight, killing 12 people, including two South African generals and the Government's Treasury Secretary, a military spokesman reported.

title: Volvo Bus Order
description: A.B. Volvo said today that it had received an order valued at the equivalent of $48 million to supply Lima, Peru, with 400 buses.

title: S.E.C. Charges Insider Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged in a civil complaint that J. Robert Fabregas, while he was a vice president of Credit Suisse at its Los Angeles office, profited illegally by using inside knowledge that the Whittaker Corporation wanted to acquire the Brunswick Corporation.

title: Rulings on Bid For Chem-Nuclear
description: A Federal judge in Seattle lifted a temporary order restraining Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc. from issuing any stock that might block Waste Management Inc.'s takeover bid. In exchange, Chem-Nuclear must notify the court and Waste Management 48 hours before issuing any of its authorized capital stock.

title: REAGAN RECEIVES HONDURAN LEADER
description: President Reagan conferred today with President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras and promised him antiterrorist assistance.

title: PANEL ASKS TO RAISE INCOME TAX ON UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION
description: A House subcommittee agreed today to increase taxes for some recipients of unemployment compensation but rejected welfare spending cuts supported by President Reagan and other Republicans.

title: Oil Market Calm
description: Reaction in oil markets to Iran's invasion of Iraq was muted yesterday.

title: Soviet's Plans On Pipeline
description: The Soviet daily Pravda said today that engineers in charge of the Siberia-Western Europe natural-gas pipeline had worked out plans to complete the entire project without foreign equipment.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 FALL 14.8%
description: New car sales by the nation's Big Three auto makers fell 14.8 percent in the July 1-10 period, the companies reported today.

title: Reagan Ally Appointed
description: The Senate confirmed the appointment today of James G. Stearns, an old ally of President Reagan, to the chairmanship of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

title: REAGAN SEEKS $65 MILLION IN AID FOR LEBANON
description: M. Peter McPherson, director of the Agency for International Development, announced today that President Reagan had decided to seek $65 million in emergency aid for Lebanon.

title: BRIEFING
description: Push Comes to Shove

title: Tours of Northport
description: The summer series of tours through Northport, L.I., continues Sunday, with groups leaving at 1 and 3 P.M. from the Northport Historical Society, 215 Main Street. The 45-minute tour visits turnof-the-century structures on Main Street and includes a stop at the society for a look at ''The Great Shipbuilding Era of Northport'' show.

title: Tennis Feuding
description: With the United States Open tennis championships less than two months away, internal dissension has crept into the preparations for the tournament.

title: The U.N. Today; July 15, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, working group on a new international eco- nomic order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Baghdad's Strongman
description: Saddam Hussein, President and iron-fisted ruler of Iraq, is nothing if not tough. In his youth he was the only one in his revolutionary cell to escape after an attempt to assassinate a dictator. He cut a bullet out of his leg with a penknife and made his way on a donkey across the desert to Syria. On another occasion he held off an overwhelming force of policemen assaulting his hideout until he ran out of bullets for his pistol.

title: Howatt Negotiates
description: Garry Howatt, a former Islander now with the Hartford Whalers, is a free agent who wouldn't mind playing the next National Hockey League season with the New Jersey Devils, according to Gary Wichard, his agent. Wichard says that Howatt, who led the Whalers in scoring last season with 18 goals and 32 assists, wants a contract of more than two years from Hartford.

title: DANCE: MUNICH's 'NO MORE GIANTS'
description: DANCE is so frequently called an art of movement through space and time that one can easily forget what that definition implies, and it may take a production with unusual movement problems to make one fully aware of just how space and time affect choreography.

title: Number of Prisoners At Record, U.S. Says
description: The number of state and Federal prisoners increased by 15,345 in the first three months of the year, reaching a record 384,316 inmates, the Justice Department said Tuesday.

title: JOINT VENTURE IN COAST-TO-COAST PAGING PLANNED
description: National Public Radio and the nation's fourth-largest paging service operator announced a joint venture today to offer the first nationwide ''beeper'' service.

title: CHIEFS OF POLICE CENSURE MURPHY FOR HIS 'INFLAMMATORY' REMARKS
description: The International Association of Chiefs of Police voted today to censure Patrick V. Murphy, a former New York City Police Commissioner, for statements critical of the organization and of police officials.

title: Market Gains in Late Rally
description: The stock market staged a late rally yesterday, fueled in large part by a recovery in major energy and other blue chip shares. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 4.19 points, to 828.39.

title: SENATORS SEEK TO KEEP LIFE POLICIES' HIGH YIELD
description: A high-yielding, fast-selling new form of life insurance, whose appeal was jeopardized by an Internal Revenue Service ruling last month, is expected to recover most of its allure as a result of provisions being written into new tax legislation.

title: Flow General Officers Sued
description: A Flow General Inc. stockholder has charged in a suit filed in the Delaware Court of Chancery that several company executives used inside information in trading company stock. Milton Small contended that Joseph E. Hall, president and chief executive officer of the biomedical company based in McLean, Va., sold 8,002 shares for $135,000 in early April because he knew that the stock price was about to fall.

title: HERALD SQ. KORVETTES STORE TO BE MALL
description: The old Korvettes building at Herald Square in Manhattan has been purchased by foreign investors who will turn it into a new shopping mall with 150 small stores facing Macy's on 34th Street and Gimbels on 33d Street.

title: John Alexander, 85; Film and Stage Actor
description: John Alexander, an actor of stage and screen whose career spanned more than 50 years, died Tuesday at a board meeting of the Actors' Fund of America. He was 85 years old.

title: A SCARSDALE SHOW ON FOLK-ART ELEMENTS IN CRAFTS
description: A show entitled ''Folk Art Influence in Contemporary American Craft'' opens tonight at the Craftman's Gallery in Scarsdale, N.Y. Although the selections reflect the contemporary American craft movement, devotees of folk art may find this an interesting show as well. The exhibition highlights nearly 70 modern crafts makers, whose works combine elements of today's technology and materials with techniques and themes generally associated with the naive and refreshing style of folk art. As might be expected, the show is a mixture of old and new, with much of the subject matter celebrating the artists' environments.

title: BRITISH RAIL PLANS SHUTDOWN NEXT WEEK
description: British Rail announced today that it would shut the strike-plagued system next Wednesday and dismiss any employees who had refused to return to work.

title: PLAYS
description: Mario Soto, the Cincinnati Reds' right-hander with a fastball that has been timed at 97 miles an hour, went to his ''second-best pitch'' Tuesday night in the seventh inning when the American League appeared to have its best chance of ending its 10-game All-Star Game losing streak.

title: IRANIAN INVADERS SAID TO PENETRATE 10 MILES INTO IRAQ
description: American officials reported today that Iranian troops had penetrated 6 to 10 miles into Iraq in what they described as the initial phase of an invasion.

title: Blocks of C.D.'s To Be Traded
description: Harvey Baskin & Company, a financial services concern based here, said today that it will begin operating an exchange for trading $100,000-denominated certificates of deposit in packages of $1 million or more late next month.

title: AMTRAK SUBSIDIES CRITICIZED BY CONGRESS BUDGET OFFICE
description: The Congressional Budget Office, in a sharply negative report, told Congress today that Federal subsidies to Amtrak could not be justified on any of the grounds usually given: energy efficiency, national security and transportation for the poor. The subsidies benefit mostly high-income travelers, the 85-page report said.

title: British Archeologist Released by Afghans
description: A British archeologist, Ralph Pinder-Wilson, was released from jail in Afghanistan today after nearly four months. He was flown immediately to India.

title: ALBERTA'S RESOURCES BATTLE
description: This resource-rich province on the high plains of western Canada harbors a long political tradition of fierce independence, marked by periodic eruptions of grass-roots radicalism.

title: BIKE RACERS AND BASTILLE DAY
description: VALENCE D'AGEN, France Yesterday was the 14th of July, Bastille Day, the national holiday of France. All over the country, people were enjoying a day of rest, good food, friends and family, and following the 11th stage of the Tour de France, the most important bicycle race in the world. Most people were following the Tour through two and one-half hours on television, but in this pleasant town southeast of Bordeaux, more than 80,000 people were estimated to be lining the roads for a glimpse of the most famous bicycle riders. This is what it was like.

title: Ex-Officer Kills 2 And Then Himself
description: A former transit police officer went on a shooting rampage yesterday, killing his mother and sister and committing suicide after telling the police of the killings, authorities said.

title: Another Davis Story
description: According to Robert C. Maynard, the publisher and editor of The Oakland Tribune-East Bay Today, Al Davis was still trying to arrange a deal that would permit him to keep his Raiders in Oakland on the same day that the managing general partner initialed a 10-year contract with the Los Angeles Coliseum. Maynard served as the conciliator between the city of Oakland and Davis from May 25 until July 5 in last-minute negotiations to keep the National Football League team in the Bay Area.

title: M-G-M REALIGNS DEBT
description: The M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company said today that it had completed an agreement to consolidate $525 million in long-term debt with seven major banks.

title: Technology; Lowly Beeper Coming of Age
description: PRETEND that Edward Thames, a college student, is traveling around California on vacation when an emergency arises at his home in New York. His mother dials a local phone number and transmits a message. Almost instantaneously, Edward pulls out his pocket pager and reads the message. ''E.T., phone home,'' it might say.

title: DISCORD AMONG U.S. JEWS OVER ISRAEL SEEMS TO GROW
description: Although the Israeli Government and the major Jewish organizations insist that virtually all American Jews support Israel's invasion of Lebanon, there is increasing evidence of disagreement as the attacks go on and the casualties mount.

title: BUILDERS GROUP ASSAILS PLAN TO LIMIT AID ON TAXES
description: The head of a major organization of real-estate developers and owners yesterday sharply criticized a plan by the Koch administration to ban a tax incentive program from parts of Manhattan.

title: HEARINGS ON BANK REGULATORS
description: Congressional committees that are about to investigate the collapse of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City will focus on whether Federal regulators failed to adequately supervise the bank's activities, House aides said today.

title: Options Diminish
description: After negotiations stalled between the Chicago Bears and their first-round draft pick, Jim McMahon, the quarterback from Brigham Young, a threat was made by McMahon's agent to take his client to the new United States Football League. But at least two teams in that new league - Los Angeles and San Francisco - say they are not interested in the man who set 56 national collegiate passing records.

title: UNIVAC INTRODUCES LARGE COMPUTERS
description: The Sperry Corporation's Univac division yesterday introduced its most powerful family of computers, machines designed to compete with the largest machines made by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Peking Curbs Contacts With Foreign Residents
description: China has imposed new curbs on study abroad and is clamping down on Chinese having unauthorized contacts with foreigners, Western diplomats said today.

title: Advertising; Canon Sets Campaign For Snappy
description: BECAUSE of what it calls a very positive reaction to its latest 35-millimeter cameras in the marketplace and on Wall Street, Canon U.S.A. is going to accelerate its marketing plans for the units, called the Snappy 20 and the Snappy 50.

title: U.S. SEIZES COMPUTERS IN GERMANY
description: In a continuing effort to block the illegal export of strategic high-technology equipment to Communist countries, the United States Commissioner of Customs said he has seized $400,000 worth of American-made computers in West Germany that were believed to be en route to the Soviet Union.

title: Moon's Conviction Is Upheld by Judge
description: A judge yesterday rejected defense motions to overturn the tax fraud conviction of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the Unification Church leader.

title: ORDEAL OVER, DONOVAN SAYS HE IS A REAGAN ASSET
description: With a broad smile, Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan relishes disclosing that the General Pulaski Memorial Committee of New York has asked him to be its man of the year and that Eddie Ostrowski, president of New York City's sanitation workers union, wants him at the head of the Pulaski Day parade on Oct. 3.

title: Dutch Papers Report Plot To Kidnap Queen
description: A group of Moluccans arrested this month on charges of firing on a police car planned to kidnap Queen Beatrix and Prime Minister Andries van Agt, two major Dutch newspapers said today.

title: People
description: * Edward A. Haymes named executive vice president, chief financial officer of Needham, Harper & Steers.

title: PEDESTALS STANDING ON THEIR OWN
description: AS a means of display the pedestal has ancient and honorable origins: Greeks built bronze or marble pedestals to support statues of their gods and the Romans to display busts of their emperors. Throughout the history of the decorative arts, pedestals in styles that match their periods have served to exhibit sculpture, urns and porcelains.

title: Needham Quits Arco
description: Atlantic Richfield, based in Los Angeles, has invited a small number of agencies to come in and pitch for its corporate advertising account.

title: U.S. FINDS LOVE CANAL NEIGHBORHOOD IS HABITABLE
description: The Federal Government declared today that the neighborhood surrounding the Love Canal was now safe enough to live in. At least 21,800 tons of chemical wastes were dumped into the canal in the 1940's and 1950's.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: OVERHEAD garage doors are of two types: the sectional or roll-up type, consisting of horizontal panels hinged together, and the onepiece, swing-up type, also known as a canopy door.

title: ROCK: BONNIE RAITT
description: BONNIE RAITT'S performance at the Dr Pepper Festival on Monday more than lived up to the high standards that she and her band set when they appeared here some months ago at the Palladium. Sticking to a meat-and-potatoes rock style strongly influenced by the Rolling Stones of the late 1960's and early 70's, Miss Raitt and her five-man group, the Bump Band, delivered a set that was particularly impressive for the way it mixed raw rhythm-and-blues with an interpretive clearsightedness that was almost delicate in its shading.

title: Texas International
description: Robert C. Gist yesterday was named chairman and chief executive officer of the Texas International Company, Oklahoma City, an oil and gas exploration concern which has leasehold acreage in 20 states and Canada. Mr. Gist, 41 years old, succeeds George Platt, 59, who will take early retirement on Aug.1. James A. Kishpaugh, 41, continues as president and chief operating officer.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Although he's 0-3 as an All-Star Game manager, Billy Martin won his 1,000th game as a manager last week when his A's beat the Yankees in Oakland. His team is making its final visit this year. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. The Mets, with a 6-17 record since June 20, start the second half of the season with an 11-game, 14-day trip; they return home July 29. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 10:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Kansas City Royals, at Boston. Both teams are trying to climb from second place back into first in the American League East and West, respectively. (Television - USA Cable, 7:30 P.M.) Padres vs. Montreal Expos, at San Diego. The Padres have been second to the Atlanta Braves in the National League West since early in the season. (Television - USA Cable, 10:30 P.M.) Drag Racing National Hot Rod Association $560,500 Summernationals, at Raceway Park, Englishtown, N.J., opening day. Shirley (Cha Cha) Muldowney, who has won 13 times on the pro tour and twice this year, is the points leader and the favorite.

title: LAST PRISONERS RETURNED TO ARGENTINA
description: The Argentine commander on the Falkland Islands and the remaining 592 Argentine war prisoners were returned by Britain today and released at a small port in southern Argentina under tight security.

title: COSMOS WIN ON BORJA'S GOAL
description: The Cosmos, back in familiar surroundings after a trip that saw them lose three of four games, edged the Montreal Manic, 3-2, tonight before a crowd of 25,634 at Giants Stadium.

title: AOKI FIRST IN POWERBOAT RACE
description: Benihana, the 38-foot catamaran driven by Rocky Aoki, roared out of the thick haze in the Atlantic Ocean to cross the finish line first today, capturing the eighth annual Benihana Grand Prix.

title: SORTING OUT THE SAXON TANGLE
description: Amid the welter of business bankruptcies this year, the sudden filing on April 15 by Saxon Industries stands out as a disturbing surprise with severely tangled financial aspects that are only gradually being sorted out.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Motors Corp., Kenosha, Wis., has elected to its board Pierre Tiberghien, executive vice president of Renault's automobile division.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The brass hardware on the outside of my house - door knockers, knobs and so on - has become dull and is coated with a hard-to-remove oxide that makes it difficult to polish the metal. If I take all the pieces off, do you know of a chemical solution they can be immersed in to help restore their brightness in preparation for polishing? - O.U., Port Washington, L.I.

title: POP VOCAL: 4 FRESHMAN IN 35th YEAR
description: THE Four Freshmen, who will be at Fat Tuesday's through Sunday, are celebrating their 35th anniversary in show business. And if their personnel has changed over the years - the slide trombonist, bassist and singer Bob Flanigan is the only charter member - the current edition offers a reasonable facsimile of the group's influential signature sound.

title: New Post Created At Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust Company, the nation's eighth-largest commercial bank, moved yesterday to complete a reorganization that began last month. It established a centralized ''administration function'' headed by Carlos M. Canal Jr., 51-year old executive vice president of the world corporate department and a member of the management committee. The bank also advanced three new executive vice presidents and named another to the management committee.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Children's TV Found Dominated by White Men

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: HOSPITALS PREPARE FOR STRIKE IN CITY
description: New York City plans to provide beds in municipal hospitals to help any private, nonprofit hospitals during a strike, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Members of U.N.'s Council Said to Discuss Truce Force
description: Members of the Security Council today discussed the possibility of sending United Nations observers to supervise a cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians in Lebanon, according to the representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're saying that the area is habitable.'' - Dr. Clark W. Heath of the Federal Department of Health and Human Services, reporting on the Love Canal. (A1:1.)

title: U.S. Reduces Wheat Quota
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, trying to trim a record United States wheat stockpile, announced today that farmers will have to limit wheat production to 80 percent of base acreage next year to qualify for Federal price supports and related benefits.

title: INDONESIAN SEES SHIFT IN HANOI'S CAMBODIA POLICY
description: Indonesia's Foreign Minister said today that Vietnam's offer last week to withdraw some troops from Cambodia was not simply propaganda but should be looked on as an indication of some change in Vietnamese attitude.

title: Dome Said to Owe $8 Billion Canadian
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s debt totals about $8 billion (Canadian), about $3.4 billion of it owed to five Canadian banks, according to Canadian Press, a national news agency that said it had acquired a financial statement prepared by the company and so far unreleased.

title: SOUTH KOREA ACCUSED OF TORTURE ON WIDE SCALE IN POLITICAL CASES
description: A 23-year-old South Korean theology student has charged at his arson trial in the southern city of Pusan that the authorities tortured him to fabricate an indictment falsely depicting him as a Communist sympathizer.

title: POLITICAL PROTECTION; Fool's Game
description: Ever wonder why a 300-page novel now costs $14 or $15? Thank inflation, which has driven up publishing costs. But save some gratitude for Congress, which prevents the publishing industry from holding down some of those costs.

title: To Restrain Iran
description: There have been no agreeable choices for American diplomacy in the 22-month war between Iraq and Iran. The discomfort grows now that a resurgent Iran threatens to repay Iraq's invasion in kind. But there is a clear Western interest in now containing this war. And the United States is not entirely helpless in the matter - not as long as Iran needs spare parts for American-made weapons and counts on oil sales to finance the battle.

title: ISRAEL WEIGHING IMPACT OF GULF WAR
description: Senior Israeli officials believe that Iran's invasion of Iraq, if it proves to be a full-fledged and sustained attack with the aim of overthrowing President Saddam Hussein, is likely to overshadow the war in Lebanon in its importance for East-West relations and the future of the Middle East.

title: A REPLY TO CRITICS: MORALITY AND THE WAR
description: "That war is just which is necessary,'' Livy said. Was the Israeli invasion of Lebanon necessary? Critics of the action have insistently raised this question, and, for the most part, have answered it negatively. Israel, they say, had no need to invade Lebanon to protect its northern settlements against the rockets and artillery of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The cease-fire was holding. It was broken by the Palestine Liberation Organization only in response to Israeli aerial bombardment of P.L.O. camps. There was no immediate danger to northern Israel that left only the alternative of overwhelming military action.

title: Market Place; Stock Picks Faring Poorly
description: LAST December, The New York Times polled four brokerage firms and two advisory services to determine their favorite stock selections for 1982. Indicating a broad diversity of opinion, only eight issues appeared on as many as two lists and, so far in this turbulent market year, only one is a winner. That stock, a perennial favorite in endof-the-year forecasts, is International Business Machines.

title: Holders Sue Pabst To Block Merger
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, a Pabst Brewing Company shareholder who is seeking to buy the company, announced that he and three other holders had filed suit against Pabst to block its proposed merger with the Olympia Brewing Company.

title: More Charges For Lewellyn
description: A Federal grand jury has expanded its indictment against Gary Lewellyn, accusing the son of a former bank president of fraud in addition to earlier charges of embezzling millions of dollars from his father's Humboldt bank.

title: RESTORING MIRRORS: TRICKS OF THE TRADE
description: Mirrors are almost as old as walls, reflecting the changes in style and decor around them. In the early days the skills required to overcome the difficulties in applying a reflective backing to glass, plus taxation of luxuries, made them too costly.

title: Losing to Golf
description: George Bamberger, the Mets' even-tempered manager, has had his patience and his surgically repaired heart tested repeatedly this season and has steadfastly resisted getting angry. ''Ask my wife, Wilma,'' Bamberger often says.

title: Jackie Jensen Dead
description: Jackie Jensen, a former outfielder with the Boston Red Sox and the American League's most valuable player in 1958, died yesterday of a heart attack at 55 years old. An obituary appears on Page B16.

title: Thin Oil Sheen Appears On San Francisco Bay
description: A thin sheen of oil with smaller patches of heavier oil was discovered early this morning on parts of San Francisco Bay.

title: COLLEGE TOURNEY GROWS
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will give 52 teams a chance to win its Division I basketball title next year, and all will be rewarded financially.

title: EXCERPTS FROM QUESTIONING OF SHULTZ BY SENATORS
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the second day of questioning of Secretary of State-designate George P. Shultz yesterday by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, as recorded by The New York Times from the Cable News Network: On Arms Sales to Taiwan

title: Court Approves Officer For Top Itel Positions
description: The Itel Corporation announced yesterday that Herbert Kunzel has assumed the titles of company chairman, chief executive officer and president, following approval by Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: JACKIE JENSEN, BASEBALL STAR WHO WON M.V.P., DIES AT 55
description: Jackie Jensen, the American League's most valuable player in 1958, died of an apparent heart attack early yesterday at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville. He was 55 years old.

title: Passing the Buck on Welfare
description: The second edition of President Reagan's ''New Federalism'' is just out, with some politically judicious editing but the same plot. The White House still wants to hand 30 domestic programs over to states. Chief among them is the core welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children.

title: Trial Set for Johnny Carson
description: Municipal Judge Andrew J. Weisz ordered Johnny Carson, the entertainer, to stand trial Sept. 20 in his court on two counts of misdemeanor drunken driving. Mr. Carson, who was in Europe, did not appear at the pretrial hearing. Mr. Carson's attorney, Robert L. Shapiro, said outside court that he would prove the entertainer was not inebriated when he was stopped Feb. 27. Mr. Carson was cited for not having a 1982 sticker on his car and was given a test for intoxication.

title: CALENDAR: ANTIQUES, FLOWERS AND GLASS
description: The Hamptons Antiques Show, Water- mill Community Club (also known as the Barn), Route 27, Watermill, L.I., 516-726-9659.

title: BONN AIDS TELEFUNKEN
description: The West German Government will give as much as $240 million in loan guarantees to AEG-Telefunken, but only on the condition that West German banks help, too, Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff said today.

title: PAINTINGS AS PERKS: WESTERNS PREVAIL
description: E. Pendleton James, the White House personnel chief who sifted through thousands of resumes for Ronald Reagan, remembers walking into his office in the early days of the Administration and seeing the White House curator's idea of a little joke.

title: Dow Names Chairman
description: Robert W. Lundeen, executive vice president of the Dow Chemical Company since 1978, was elected chairman of the company's board of directors today. Mr. Lundeen, 61 years old, succeeds Earle B. Barnes, who is retiring at age 65 after completing 42 years with the company.

title: THEATER: MOLIERE'S LEARNED LADIES'
description: MOLIERE has had no better American friend than the poet Richard Wilbur, whose translations of ''Tartuffe,'' ''The Misanthrope'' and ''The School for Wives'' are beautiful works of art in themselves. Mr. Wilbur's lighter-than-air verse upholds the idiom and letter of Moliere, yet it also satisfies the demands of the stage; the rhymed couplets are always crisp and playable. It's a remarkably selfless exercise, too. Though Mr. Wilbur's own poetic gifts are abundantly apparent in these translations, he scrupulously uses his talent to serve rather than to upstage or update the texts at hand.

title: HOUSE UNIT EXPECTED TO BACK CARIBBEAN AID FUNDS TODAY
description: President Reagan was informed today that a compromise version of his $350 million aid package for Central America would be approved Thursday by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: BRIEFS ON HOME BEAT
description: THEY were tested on their most discerning critics -infants and toddlers for whom the collection of toys was designed - and received a positive reaction.

title: MONTEVERDI'S 'POPPEA' TO GET ROCK TREATMENT
description: ONE of the more adventuresome operatic productions next season will not be performed in an opera house at all. The New York Lyric Opera Company will open its 10th season on Nov. 17 at the discotheque Xenon. In a space usually reserved for flashing lights and pounding beat, the company will present a version of Monteverdi's ''L'Incoronazione di Poppea.''

title: SUMMER MEALS PROGRAM IS STILL A HIT
description: It is just before noon on a weekday morning and Doris Crespo is sandwiched between two plastic-topped tables in Intermediate School 238, engulfed by children. There are children in summer-bright Tshirts and shorts, chattering and giggling and nibbling away at meatball heroes that look bigger than they are.

title: BARNETT BANKS SURGES
description: J.P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday that its second-quarter net operating earnings amounted to $96.8 million, barely higher than the $96.6 million it earned in the comparable period of 1981. Earnings equaled $2.35 a share during both periods.

title: California Solar Project
description: Plans to construct the world's largest solar electric generating facility were announced today by Luz International Ltd. and the Southern California Edison Company. The 15-megawatt, $100 million project is to be built in the Mojave Desert near Daggett, Calif.

title: P.L.O. WELCOMES SHULTZ'S COMMENTS ON MIDEAST
description: Statements by Secretary of Statedesignate George P. Shultz at his confirmation hearing Tuesday were favorably received by the Palestine Liberation Organization today and raised guarded hopes among Palestinians for a possible shift in American policy.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bedlwether issues

title: RATE OF SPENDING ON ARMS NEAR PEAK
description: The growth rate of military spending, which has risen sharply since President Reagan took office, is peaking this summer and will then begin to slow down, according to Defense Department budget estimates.

title: DEAK FINDS STRAINS IN RAPID EXPANSION OF CURRENCY OFFICES
description: Two years ago, the price of gold was peaking at more than $800 an ounce, the dollar was weak, and business was booming for Nicholas L. Deak and his worldwide chain of retail foreign exchange and gold dealerships.

title: Chewing Success
description: Jim Bouton watched the All-Star Game from Montreal on Tuesday night and saw a number of his former major-league colleagues blowing bubbles. But which bubble gum were they using - Topps, Fleer's or Big League Chew?

title: ORGAN: JOHN C. WALKER
description: THE Riverside Church's summer recital series on its large Aeolian Skinner organ offers a repertory of unfamiliar pieces mixed with a few better-known works. This is laudable, but John C. Walker's program Tuesday had its inconsequential patches.

title: Miss Enstine Duo Takes L.I. Golf
description: Grace McGrath of Piping Rock and Ann Enstine of the host club shot a 76 today to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association best-ball tournament for the second time. They had a two-day total of 148 at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

title: Article 016551 -- No Title
description: John and Barbara Jackson live in rural Kansas, where the winters are long and hard and there is not much to do except watch television.

title: Nursing Homes Need Watching
description: The Department of Health and Human Services says the new regulations it proposes for nursing home inspection are a technical adjustment to promote efficiency. They look more like an attempt to poke holes in a bureaucratic shield that protects 1.3 million nursing home residents.

title: FINANCING IMPROVEMENTS TO HOMES: IT'S STILL COSTLY
description: Despite the recession and high interest rates, the financing of home improvements is still possible, but it might not be easy to pay for. Home-improvement loans, which can be used for cooperatives and condominiums as well as single-family residences, are generally considered regular installment loans, with the rate at many banking institutions going as high as an annual rate of 21 percent.

title: MOON'S MIND CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: National Stars Still Dominate
description: Lee MacPhail, the president of the American League, considered the odds against losing 19 of 20 All-Star Games and said:

title: Vandeweghe Gets New Nugget Pact
description: Kiki Vandeweghe, who averaged 21.5 points last season, ranking 14th in the National Basketball Association, has signed a long-term contract with the Denver Nuggets, Carl Scheer, the team president, said today.

title: New Products: A Record Tally
description: June was the biggest month for new product introductions since Martin Friedman, editor of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, began monitoring introductions of food and drug products back in 1964. Does that reflect an optimism about the economy or is it merely a result of heavy spring rains? Mr. Friedman is not willing to go out on a limb.

title: N.F.L. Hits Snag On Rookie Issue
description: The four-year labor contract between the National Football League and its players union expires at midnight tonight amid disagreement whether unsigned rookies can then sign with the teams that drafted them.

title: VED MEHTA: HIS PROSE IS 'AIRY, ELEGANT, CLEAR'
description: MONEY may not be everything to the writer of serious works rarely destined for top-10's and movie deals, but it certainly helps, as Ved Mehta was saying this week about his five-year award totaling $236,000 from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

title: Outboard Corp.  Dumping Claim
description: The Outboard Marine Corporation, a leading maker of outboard motors including Evinrude and Johnson, announced that it had filed antidumping petitions with the European Economic Community and in Australia against the Japanese outboard motor manufacturers Yamaha, Suzuki, Tohatsu, Subaru and Honda.

title: FIRE DEPARTMENT SETTLING DOWN IN BROOKLYN
description: The New York City Fire Department - about to become the first mayoral agency with headquarters outside Manhattan since the consolidation of the city in 1898 - is in the middle of a move to Brooklyn.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. EQUAL RIGHTS MEASURE IS RE-INTRODUCED IN CONGRESS
description: With a flurry of press releases, more than 200 senators and representatives re-introduced the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution today and then posed for pictures behind a green-and-white banner on the Capitol steps.

title: U.S. REPORT ON SOVIET STIRS DISCORD
description: In asserting this week that the Soviet Union has become increasingly vulnerable to economic sanctions by the West, the Government has grossly overinterpreted its own data, various outside specialists charged today.

title: Judgment Is Invalidated In Seabrook Protest
description: The New Hampshire Supreme Court today invalidated a $180,000 judgment against the Clamshell Alliance for costs of policing a 1980 demonstration by the group at the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: FEDERAL CUTS HURT POISON DATA OFFICE
description: A Federal program that was instrumental in establishing hundreds of poison-control centers is losing most of its financing, in part because of its own success.

title: SOMALIA REPORTS AN INCURSION FROM ETHIOPIA
description: Somalia said today that Ethiopia had attacked two border settlements and that 60 Ethiopian soldiers had been killed in one of the communities.

title: Jet Falls Mile and Half Near Indonesian Volcano
description: A jumbo jet with 230 people aboard flew into a fountain of volcanic ash today and tumbled a mile and a half with its engines ablaze before leveling off in time for an emergency landing at Jakarta's Halim International Airport. It was the second such incident in three weeks.

title: Dr. L.T. HOPKINS, 93, EX-COLUMBIA PROFESSOR
description: L. Thomas Hopkins, professor emeritus of education at Teachers College of Columbia University, died Saturday at the Centerville (Mass.) Nursing Home. Dr. Hopkins, who was a resident of Truro, Mass., where he was born, was 93 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: $3.50 Now, $4 Soon

title: Warner Shares
description: Warner Communications Inc. said it might repurchase up to six million of its 64 million common shares outstanding. The purchases, from time to time in the open market or otherwise, will depend on market and business conditions.

title: ANYBODY LISTENING?
description: The interim between departure of Secretary of State Alexander Haig and arrival of George Shultz has brought a surprise to European governments. They've suddenly realized, as they hadn't so much before, that they have nobody to talk to in Washington.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS GAINS IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: The biggest political difference between the two Democratic candidates for the House in North Carolina's Second Congressional District, a seat the Republicans have high hopes of winning, is the one they do not talk about. Tim Valentine is white and Mickey Michaux is black.

title: Greek Justice Resigns In a Political Dispute
description: Greece's most senior Supreme Court justice resigned today in protest over what he described as the Socialist Government's attempt to control the judiciary.

title: GUATEMALAN OFFICER IS FIRMLY IN CONTROL 4 MONTHS AFTER COUP
description: Four months after being swept into power by a coup he did not plan, Gen. Efrain Rios Montt is firmly in control in Guatemala. He has dissolved a three-man junta, named himself President and, under a state of siege imposed earlier this month, suspended many civil liberties.

title: Cerone's Return Is Uncertain
description: Barry Foote and Butch Wynegar were awaiting their turns at the batting cage with Mickey Scott on the mound during yesterday's workout at Yankee Stadium when the two catchers noticed Rick Cerone heading toward the dugout.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: $10 and No Questions

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: ALONG with the city hall and the public library, banks once were among the most imposing edifices in town. They resembled Greek temples or, later, granite palaces.

title: Excerpts from testimony, page A18.
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today to approve George P. Shultz as the 60th Secretary of State. But plans for a quick confirmation vote on the Senate floor collapsed when Senator William Proxmire refused to consent to waiving the usual procedures.

title: Not Going to Jerusalem
description: The patriarch of Soviet refuseniks - Jews who have been refused permission to emigrate - is Aleksandr Y. Lerner. A distinguished scientist now 69 years old, Dr. Lerner has been trying to leave for Israel since 1971. Like others who apply for exit visas, he lost his job at once. He has been harassed by the police. His wife died a year ago, and the authorities would not let her body be taken to Israel.

title: Teledyne Drops; CPC Rises 11.3%
description: Teledyne Inc., hurt by a generally weak economy and lower results from its specialty metals operations, reported yesterday a 35.5 percent decline on a sales drop of 11 percent for the second quarter.

title: ETHICS CHIEF VOWS A DILIGENT INQUIRY
description: The chairman of the House ethics committee today promised a thorough investigation into charges of drug use on Capitol Hill and homosexual acts between lawmakers and teen-age pages, but the panel's staff director was overheard saying that the matter could be wrapped up in two weeks.

title: U.S. Steel Delays Project
description: A major modernization project at a plant of the United States Steel Corporation is being delayed, company officials said yesterday, and the Republic Steel Corporation is laying off another 3,400 workers as the companies continue to grapple with the weakening steel market. The industry is operating at less than 50 percent of capacity.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT OF COAL CONVERSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: South African officials are the soul of modesty when asked how the question of removing Cuban troops from Angola has come to be the final and crucial issue determining whether the drawn-out Western effort to achieve a settlement in South-West Africa will finally succeed. The credit should not go to them, they say, but to the Reagan Administration.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Financial Corp. said it had raised its interest in Mission Insurance Group Inc. to 19.8 percent and had reached an agreement under which the stake could rise to 25 percent without Mission's consent.

title: President Leaving Evers College Post
description: The board of trustees of the City University of New York accepted yesterday a request by the president of Medgar Evers College for a sabbatical and reassignment.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LAUGHERS

title: A DISPUTE ON MILITARY PENSIONS
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee approved a bill today that would restore the right of state courts to include military retirement pay as community property that may be divided in divorce settlements.

title: CONFEREES ACCEPT A $5.5 BILLION BILL FOR U.S. AGENCIES
description: House and Senate conferees agreed today on a $5.5 billion urgent supplemental spending bill. But they had no assurances from the White House that President Reagan would not veto it, as he did two previous versions.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT OF COAL CONVERSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 15, 1982
description: International Iranian forces have advanced six to 10 miles into Iraq in the initial phase of an invasion, according to Pentagon officials. They said that Iranian armored units appeared to be driving toward Basra, Iraq's second largest city, 14 miles from the frontier, and that fragmentary reports indicated they were meeting fierce but limited resistance. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington seeks Saudi aid in persuading Arab countries to accept the 6,000 Palestinian soldiers in beseiged west Beirut, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the President, in a letter to King Fahd, had urged that Syria be asked to take most of the Palestinians. (A1:5.)

title: HOSPITALS AND HOMES INVOLVED
description: Following is a list by area of hospitals with expired union contracts that have received strike notices for 6 A.M. today. All but Richmond Memorial Hospital on Staten Island and Hempstead General Hospital on Long Island are members of the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York: MANHATTAN - Beth Israel (and Morris J. Bernstein Institute), 1,022 beds; Cabrini, 478; Jewish Memorial, 189; Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat, 150; Mount Sinai, 1,272; New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown, 310; Presbyterian, 1,350; St. Luke's-Roosevelt, 1,377; St. Vincent's, 788. BROOKLYN - Brooklyn (Cumberland Hospital affiliate only), 346 beds; Community, 134; Jewish, 576; Long Island College, 612; Lutheran, 532; Maimonides, 653; Methodist, 573; St. John's Episcopal (including South Shore Division), 734; St. Mary's (division of Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens), 270. BRONX - Bronx-Lebanon (Fulton and Concourse divisions), 609 beds; Montefiore (including Albert Einstein College of Medicine Hospital and Rikers Island Health Facility), 1,861; St. Barnabas, 145. QUEENS - Booth Memorial, 417; St. John's Queens and Mary Immaculate (divisions of Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens), 651; Jamaica, 506; La Guardia, 302; Long Island Jewish-Hillside, 693. STATEN ISLAND - Richmond Memorial, 213 beds. NASSAU COUNTY - Manhasset (division of Long Island Jewish), 120 beds; Hempstead General-Hempstead Park Home, 461. SUFFOLK COUNTY - Eastern Long Island, Greenport, 66 beds; Southside, Bay Shore, 425.

title: SOUNDS OF A MOSCOW JAM SESSION ARE MUSIC TO RUSSIAN EARS
description: More than three years have passed since Muscovites last heard live American jazz -before cultural exchanges were severed in reaction to Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.

title: Nieman Captures U.S. Pentathlon
description: Bob Nieman, the only American to win a world pentathlon title, took his second national crown today, beating the defending champion Mike Burley by 114 points.

title: Silver linings at 2 galleries.
description: ALTHOUGH overall totals brought in by auctions of Impressionist and modern art dropped dramatically this season at Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's, several important records were set and many works still brought high prices. The figures for this season's sales, which were released earlier this week, showed that Post-World War II art works fared better at both houses, where there were increases in total sales and more than a score of artists' records were set.

title: FIRST SIKH AT THE TOP
description: Many saw it as a case of stretching loyalty a bit too far when Zail Singh, who was elected today as India's seventh President, said earlier this month that he would be willing to work even as a sweeper if Prime Minister Indira Gandhi asked him to do so.

title: EXPLORING SCIENCE AND RELIGIONS
description: AT 9 this evening on WNET-Channel 13, the Public Broadcasting Service is presenting a documentary called ''The Sun Dagger.'' It is narrated by Robert Redford, which immediately indicates two things. A superstar has been recruited to give wider circulation to what is really a rather scholarly work. And, given Mr. Redford's well-known crusades, there must be an environmental message somewhere in the hour.

title: REAGAN'S FIG LEAF
description: Who wants to run for office on a platform of 9.5 percent unemployment, a 16.5 percent prime rate, and a prospective budget deficit far in excess of $100 billion?

title: ASSAD SAID TO REJECT REQUEST BY REAGAN TO ADMIT P.L.O.
description: Syrian sources said today that President Hafez al-Assad had received and rejected a request from President Reagan that Syria reconsider its refusal to give sanctuary to Palestinian guerrillas trapped in west Beirut by Israeli forces.

title: Numbers Game
description: The National League's continued dominance of All-Star Games apparently has not dulled viewer interest. Last Tuesday night's game on ABC easily swamped a rerun of the movie ''The Greek Tycoon,'' (25 to 11.7 in the Nielsen ratings), with estimates that as many as 57 million viewers watched some or all of the game.

title: CITY PARKS STILL COAX OUT THE ELDERLY
description: As far back as anyone can remember, the elderly people have come out of their small apartments and their old houses to sit on park benches throughout the city in the heat of summer, and they still do. It may well be the ultimate urban scene.

title: DANCE: 3 NEW WORKS FROM THE FESTIVAL AT DUKE
description: week residency. The result was the concert of new works offered July 14 at Duke University's Reynolds Theater.

title: DEMOCRATS JOIN THE BATTLE OF TV ADS
description: Using an image of Republican scissors snipping away at a Social Security card, the Democrats fired back today in the war of television commercials. But their advertisement on the critical campaign issue was shown only to reporters; party officials said they hoped to raise money to put it on the air later.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Dome Fleet Sale Is in Jeopardy
description: The purchase of a 46.5 percent stake of Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s Beaufort Sea fleet by its subsidiary, Dome Canada Ltd., may fall through because of a failure to arrange long term financing, Dome said. It said that Dome Canada would cancel the deal if it is not concluded today, and that the initial $100 million payment Dome Canada made on April 6 would be repaid upon demand.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 20.50 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 13.04 12.88 18.80 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.52 11.96 14.52 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.96 12.22 14.37 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 14.06 14.18 14.27 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.53 13.64 13.38 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.83 15.89 15.44 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.30 13.30 11.72 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13.098 CERTIFICATES* * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SHULTZ IS UNANIMOUSLY CONFIRMED BY THE SENATE AS SECRETARY OF STATE
description: The Senate unanimously confirmed George P. Shultz today as the next Secretary of State, replacing Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: BUDGET RULE: NO
description: It is perfectly understandable that, faced with responsibility for a deficit of more than $100 billion, Congress now wants to go on record as forbidding itself to do again what it has just done. The President's impulse to support the effort stems, at least in part, from his share in the responsibility. But it is irresponsible for the President and Congress to permit this political posturing to interfere with the way the constitutional structure works.

title: MANHATTAN CAFE W RIV VU
description: Michael (Buzzy) O'Keeffe believes in covering the waterfront. He has done just that as owner of the River Cafe, the chic Brooklyn restaurant that sits snugly on a barge under the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MIDNIGHTS. A Year With the Wellfleet Police. By Alec Wilkinson. 200 pages. Random House. $11.95.

title: Fiddling Contest
description: Fiddlers of all ages and abilities will gather tomorrow at the Hudson Valley Old Time Fiddler's Contest in Memorial Park, Piermont Avenue and the Hudson River, Nyack, N.Y. About 50 musicians from the metropolitan area, New England and Canada have signed up for the competition, which will be judged by members of the North American Fiddling Judges Association.

title: HALF OF STAFF OUT, ST. VINCENT'S MAKES DO IN A PINCH
description: There was an unnatural quiet early yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Greenwich Village. Ceiling fans whirred softly in the humid air of corridors that on other days would be filled with the noisy traffic of technicians, housekeepers, clerks and nurses' aides. Sister Margaret Sweeney, president of the 813-bed private, nonprofit hospital, said that the hush had even ''rubbed off on the patients who sometimes have their television sets up very loud.''

title: Busy Body
description: If you think your summer Mondays are blue, consider the dilemma of Nels Van Patten. Next Monday morning, the 27-year-old son of Dick Van Patten, the actor, is scheduled to start filming a movie, ''Graduate of Malibu High,'' in California with Ernest Borgnine, Richard Roundtree and Jimmy Van Patten, his brother.

title: PALESTINIANS TRIED TO AVERT WAR AND ARE NOW BEING VICTIMIZED
description: To the Editor:

title: Garment Workers Rally in Chinatown
description: Thousands of garment-union members, most of them women, rallied and marched in Chinatown yesterday to persuade reluctant shop owners to sign the latest contract with their union.

title: INDIA: LET'S TALK TOGETHER
description: When Prime Minister Indira Gandhi visits President Reagan this month, they will be inclined to preach at each other on Afghanistan, nuclear policy, arms control and other cherished issues on which the two countries are at odds, and some preaching may be in order because each should understand what really troubles the other. Their advisers may suggest discussions on such technical aspects of Indian-American relations as Indian access to World Bank lending and American limitations on imports from India, and these are important matters. But preaching and preoccupation with details should not dominate discussions between Americans and Indians. There are more fundamental matters at stake.

title: Hitachi Supercomputer
