description: Hitachi Ltd. says it will put its new supercomputer on display by the end of September, denying earlier reports that marketing of the machine was being delayed because of Hitachi's reported involvement in a computer espionage case. Supercomputers, which generally cost $10 million or more, are designed for the highspeed processing of huge mathematical calculations, such as those used in scientific research. Takeo Mano, a Hitachi spokesman, said his remarks on the computer's introduction had been misinterpreted by reporters in translating his comments into English from Japanese and that Hitachi's supercomputer would be on the market by October.

title: Restaurant Sale
description: The Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation said it had agreed to sell a lease on its restaurant at Wall Street and Water Street two years before its expiration. The company said that it would report a gain of $1.15 million, or 15 cents a share, from the sale in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1983, which begins Aug.1.

title: HIGH STAKES RIDING AT YEARLING SALES
description: The annual summer rite of leading yearling thoroughbreds into the sales rings in Lexington, Ky., begins today. The five days of selling that begin with sessions this afternoon and evening are divided among three sales companies. Today and tomorrow, the Fasig-Tipton Company sells 490 yearlings. Last year, the average price for a Fasig-Tipton yearling in Kentucky was $70,200. This is a classy auction but something of a warm-up for things to come.

title: Judge Stays Deer Hunt In Florida's Everglades
description: A state-sanctioned hunt to kill 2,200 deer in the Everglades was blocked early this morning by a Federal District judge just hours before the shooting was to begin.

title: I.M.F. Team In Argentina
description: A team from the International Monetary Fund has arrived in Argentina for talks on the country's economic crisis.

title: Argentine Navy Orders Inquiry Into War Role
description: The Argentine Navy has ordered an inquiry into its performance in the war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, a spokesman said today.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES TOBACCO BILL
description: The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation curtailing taxpayer subsidies for tobacco growers.

title: Crime Victims Get New Law for Loss
description: Governor Carey's office announced approval today of legislation allowing a crime victim or his survivors to be compensated twice for injuries or death stemming from the crime.

title: From Jakarta to the Ginza.
description: SINCE the closing many years ago of the colorful little East of Suez, New Yorkers have lacked an atmospheric restaurant in which to have a decent, full-fledged rijstafel. A Dutch word meaning rice table, a rijstafel is based on Indonesian curries, stews and grills, served around rice with pungent condiments. Characteristic flavors include such seasonings as chilies, ginger, coriander and lemon grass, combined in mellow contrast to freshly made peanut butter, soy sauce, coconut cream and palm sugar.

title: Changing of the Guard
description: Eddie Gregson, the trainer of the Kentucky Derby winner, Gato del Sol, has temporarily handed over the colt's reins to Howie Tesher. Gregson has a large stable in California and has found it exhausting to commute frequently between the West Coast and Belmont Park, where Gato del Sol is stabled. Gregson will again train the colt when he returns to California to race as a 4-year-old early next year.

title: Frozen in the Cockpit?
description: Feudalism is an economic system long dead -except in the psyche of the airline unions. They want to attach airline workers to their planes and check-in counters, the way medieval serfs were tied to their land.

title: The Law of Averages
description: T he following conversation took place the other morning between two drivers waiting for a meeting of the Taxi and Limousine Commission to begin.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Roger Erickson, the starter, is 6-7 over all, but he is 2-4 as a Yankee since he came from the Minnesota Twins. (Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. Fernando Valenzuela (12-7) has two complete-game victories over the Mets this year. Pete Falcone (5-6) is 1-1 against the Dodgers. (Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240; 10:30 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Kansas City Royals, at Boston. Because of the All-Star Game Tuesday, there was no Monday night game of the week, so this takes its place. (Television - Channel 7, 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Gino Gelormino vs. Muhammad Mohajid, 8 rounds, featherweights. This is the main event of a seven-bout card beginning at 8 P.M. at the Holiday Inn, Rockaway Turnpike, Jamaica, Queens.

title: 'TO AN UNKNOWN GOD'
description: ''To an Unknown God'' was shown as part of the 1978 New Directors/ New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of April 7, 1978. The film opens today at the Thalia, Broadway and West 95th Street.

title: REGULATORS SAY BANK FAILURE WAS 'ABERRATION'
description: Federal regulators told the House banking committee today that 300 banks are under the same scrutiny that the collapsed Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City was. They emphasized, however, that the Oklahoma bank was so badly managed that its collapse last week was an ''aberration.''

title: SUMMER STAGE SEASON HITS ITS STRIDE
description: THE quintessential summer theater may be the Goodspeed Opera House. It is an 1876 building, lovingly restored; it is the home of musical revivals, lavishly produced. Its attraction now is ''High Button Shoes,'' the 1947 Jule Styne-Sammy Cahn-Stephen Longstreet musical, notable for its score, its dancing and its general jollity. In the second act, while the Keystone Kops chase a con man, a gorilla materializes, balletically, from a bathhouse. The Goodspeed audience stamps its tasseled loafers in approval. Outside, the sun is shining on the Connecticut River. It is what summer theater is all about.

title: Webster, Driver, Pleads Not Guilty
description: A leading harness-racing driver and two other men pleaded not guilty in Federal court today to charges that they tried to fix at least four races at the Meadowlands race track.

title: More Dogs Sought For Subway Patrol
description: The chief of New York City's transit police said yesterday that his department would like to expand the canine subway patrol force to at least 50 dogs.

title: ON-SHORE SKIPPERS TO RACE MINI-YACHTS IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A group of men and women will go sailing in Central Park tomorrow without even getting their feet wet. They'll be participating in the seventh annual Cutty Sark Mini-Yacht Race at the boat pond, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., and you are invited to watch.

title: CBS CRITICIZES DOCUMENTARY BUT STANDS BY IT
description: CBS News said yesterday that it had violated some of its own rules of journalistic practice in a documentary last winter about Vietnam. Van Gordon Sauter, president of CBS News, said the violations had not undermined the central thesis of the program and ''CBS News stands by this broadcast.'' But he said the organization was creating a new position, vice president for news practices, ''to insure that our organization is fully conversant with CBS News standards and their importance to the credibility of journalism.''

title: SAVINGS BANKS OFFER BEST MORTGAGE FINANCING
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bausch & Lomb Inc. of Rochester announced it had acquired Criterion Scientific Instruments of Hartford.

title: GUERRILLA DRIVE IN SOMALIA SEENS AS PART OF A PROXY WAR
description: Anti-Government guerrillas in Somalia said today that they had opened two new fronts in a two-week-old campaign that is apparently part of the long-running proxy war in the Horn of Africa between Somalia and Ethiopia.

title: NAMIBIAN ACCORD LINKED TO CUBAN EXIT FROM ANGOLA
description: To the Editor:

title: Chem-Nuclear
description: The United States District Court for South Carolina issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control from interfering with Waste Management Inc.'s tender offer for 4.2 million shares of Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc., Waste Management said.

title: FOUR FRESHMEN BRING THEIR BLEND TO A JAZZ CLUB
description: The Four Freshmen, the singing and instrumental quartet who have gone on calling themselves ''freshmen'' for 35 years, are appearing this weekend in a jazz club, something they have rarely done during the last quarter of a century.

title: CHINESE GETTING A BASKETBALL LESSON
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar looms large on any basketball court, but Han Pengshan, a center for China's national team, stood a couple of inches taller than the 7-foot-2-inch Abdul-Jabbar Wednesday night in Peking's Capital Stadium.

title: Thailand Orders Out Reporter For Asian Wall Street Journal
description: The Foreign Ministry today ordered the diplomatic correspondent of The Asian Wall Street Journal, Barry Wain, to leave Thailand within seven days because of an article published today about conditions at a Thai-run refugee camp.

title: WHERE TO ROUND UP BEST RIBS IN TOWN
description: New York, like the rest of the country, has been seized by rib fever, a lusty gastronomic epidemic that takes on special meaning in summer. There is something about gently crisp, tenderly meaty pork spareribs burnished with a spicy red sauce and washed down with icecold beer that seems to awaken even the most heat-jaded palate. Perhaps that is because ribs are basically Southern food, which we associate with hot climates and the lassitude they induce.

title: HAWAII GOVERNOR BALKING AT JUSTICE DEPARTMENT INQUIRY ON PRISONS
description: Gov. George Ariyoshi is balking at giving investigators from the Justice Department's civil rights division access to Hawaii prisons.

title: RANDY RASMUSSEN GIVEN A GOODBYE
description: Super Bowl III rings were visible everywhere at Randy Rasmussen's retirement party, thrown by the New York Jets yesterday in Manhattan. Weeb Ewbank, the coach of the Jets when they recorded their shocking upset of the Baltimore Colts on Jan. 12, 1969, reminisced about Rasmussen's early days. So did the current coach, Walt Michaels, who was the defensive coordinator then, and several of Rasmussen's teammates.

title: Railroads' Coal Plan Backed by 12 Banks
description: The Chicago & North Western Transportation Company and the Union Pacific Corporation jointly announced today that they had signed an agreement with a syndicate of 12 banks that will provide $345 million to finance the construction of the Wyoming Powder River Basin coal project.

title: NOMINATION TO U.S. LEGAL PANEL FOR POOR HELD UP
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today recommended confirmation of eight persons nominated for the board of the Legal Services Corporation, the federally financed agency that provides lawyers for the poor, but deferred action on George E. Paras.

title: Shell Oil Price Cut
description: The Shell Oil Company, retreating from a price increase announced June 28, said it had reduced the price it pays for domestic crude oil by $1, to $30 to $32 a barrel. Other major crude buyers had not followed Shell's earlier price increase.

title: EGYPT BIDS ARABS MEET ON THE P.L.O.
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt called today for a meeting of Arab leaders ''to agree on a unified policy for solving'' the Palestinian problem.

title: INDIA: CHANGES AT HOME
description: Although Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's approaching visit to the White House will undoubtedly include strong complaints about the impact of United States economic performance on India, there are some surprising parallels between parts of Reaganomics and policies being pursued in New Delhi. Most United States economic policies, however, are very unpopular in India, where the combination of high interest rates and recession that is plaguing the United States and Europe is causing serious domestic problems.

title: Aaron Wise Davis, 85, Dead; Ex-Head of Textile Company
description: Aaron Wise Davis, former president of the Manhattan textile manufacturing concern of Davis & Catterall Inc., died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Off 1.05
description: After a day of erratic price fluctuations, the stock market yesterday closed narrowly mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average finished off 1.05 points, at 827.34, after ranging between 832.19 and 825.06 during the session. The much broader-based New York Stock Exchange composite index closed up 0.02, at 63.38, while the Standard & Poor's 500 gained 0.03, at 110.47.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR IN MICHIGAN STRESS JOBS
description: Michigan's crowded campaign for the primary on Aug. 10 has entered its final month with the candidates for party nominations for Governor agreeing that jobs and the economy are the issues but differing on how the issues ''cut,'' as politicians put it, with the voters.

title: REAGAN PROPOSALS TO ALTER RULES FOR NURSING HOMES ARE ASSAILED
description: State officials and members of Congress said today that the Reagan Administration's effort to change inspection rules for nursing homes would seriously weaken the protection of elderly patients.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE PASS $5.5 BILLION SPENDING BILL
description: Ending a three-week stalemate with President Reagan, Congress adopted an urgent compromise supplemental spending bill today that Mr. Reagan is expected to sign.

title: A.M.C. Price Cut Extended
description: The American Motors Corporation said that it would extend price reductions on base prices of 1982 Renault Le Car models through Sept. 21, while Volkswagen of America Inc. said it had started a dealer incentive program.

title: NEW SCARE AT BUCKINGHAM PALACE
description: A soldier on duty at Buckingham Palace scared off a man trying to jump over a wall at the royal residence less than a week after a man stole into Queen Elizabeth's bedroom as she slept, the police said today.

title: CITIBANK OFFICER LEAVES FOR RECRUITING CONCERN
description: Donna R. Ecton offers two reasons for leaving Citibank, the nation's second-largest bank, to join a relatively small division of an executive recruiting company. Miss Ecton, who yesterday was named president of MBA Resources, a division of Nordeman Grimm Inc. of New York, said that, as a graduate student at Harvard Business School, ''one of the things we learned was to have a long-range goal of heading or owning a small company.'' She added, ''The other reason is that I greatly enjoy working with people and in executive recruiting that means both clients and job candidates.''

title: Stolen Art Seized; 4 Men Arrested
description: Four men were arrested today on charges of trying to sell $3.7 million in art stolen from a Sands Point home to undercover agents, the Nassau County police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was about to turn around and deck the guy but some people intervened.'' - Supreme Court Justice Byron R. White, after being assaulted. (A10:5.)

title: Buying a Piece of the Past
description: N ext to the Piccadilly Hotel, pink brick dust swirls up as bulldozers work the rubble of the Helen Hayes and Morosco Theaters, site of the future Portman Hotel near Times Square. One wall is already missing from a Piccadilly annex and yesterday it looked as if looters had taken over.

title: CHORAL MUSIC SING-ALONG IN SUMMER CAMP SETTING
description: For some of its participants the first session of the Berkshire Choral Institute here this week has been an escape from the city to the country. For others it has been a chance to visit a tradition-steeped part of the country. For just about all it has been a rare opportunity to share a love for the special world of choral music, in the relaxed atmosphere of a summer camp.

title: CONNECTICUT'S O'NEILL FACES KEY TEST AS DEMOCRATS GATHER FOR CONVENTION
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, taking full advantage of incumbency in his race for the Democratic nomination, went to the Connecticut National Guard's summer encampment earlier this month and had his picture taken as he watched the firing of an artillery piece. Mr. O'Neill held his fingers to his ears against the noise.

title: COAL DEAL MANAGEMENT BY INTERIOR AGENCY CHANGED
description: Congressional Democrats asserted today that the Interior Department had mismanaged the biggest sale of leases to mine Federal coal in history. They said that the department might have deliberately undervalued the coal to try to insure the success of the sale.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''A CCORDING to 'Linda Goodman's Sun Signs' we're affectionate, emotional, imaginative and often lonely people,'' Anita Helen Brooks told her living-roomful of Moonchildren and Leos the other evening as she toasted their birthdays with a glass of white wine. Most of Miss Brooks's guests were, like their hostess, born in July and, as she does every year, Miss Brooks gave a Bastille Day party to celebrate.

title: DULLES AIRPORT STILL WAITS FOR TRAFFIC
description: Dulles International Airport gave itself a 20th birthday party a couple of weeks back, complete with an air show and a country music concert on the tarmac.

title: The U.N. Today; July 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission Working Group on a New International Eco- nomic Order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Spanish Jet Deal Said to Be Close
description: The Spanish Air Force may have awarded a $3 billion contract to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to supply the Government with 84 of its F-18A fighter planes, according to reports printed in Spanish newspapers.

title: Market Place; McDonald's Prospects
description: SHARES of the McDonald's Corporation traded yesterday as high as 77 1/4, or just under their record price of 77 3/8 set a decade ago. The stock closed at 76 3/8, down 1/2 for the session.

title: PENSION SYSTEM FACING TEST
description: Facet Enterprises is just a modest-sized auto parts manufacturer based in Tulsa, Okla., but the lawsuit it has brought against the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation has dozens of larger companies running scared.

title: 'POETS AND ARTISTS' EXHIBITION IN EAST HAMPTON
description: The strange and difficult relationship between images and words is one of the subjects of ''Poets and Artists,'' this year's ''Artists of the Region'' invitational exhibition at the Guild Hall in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Service Before Football
description: There is a pro football career in the future for Eddie Meyers, the leading ground-gainer in the history of United States Naval Academy football, but it is a long way off. Yesterday, Meyers came to agreement with the Atlanta Falcons on a two-year free-agent contract. But Meyers will not be able to appear in a professional game for five years because he must first fulfill his military obligation, a fiveyear hitch in the Marine Corps.

title: Bolivian Junta Promises Elections Next April
description: Celso Torrelio, President of Bolivia's junta, said today that general elections would be held April 24. He said that he would turn power over to the winner on Aug. 6, 1983, and that the move would permit Bolivia to return to constitutional law.

title: Nissan-British Talks
description: Takashi Ishihara, president of the Nissan Motor Company, said today that his company had not yet reached a final decision on whether to set up an assembly plant in Britain, Kyodo News Service reported. Mr. Ishihara said Nissan would soon hold talks with British Government officials on the issue, Kyodo said.

title: S.E.C. Settles Insider Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has reached a settlement of a civil complaint filed in Federal District Court that charged that a former Banker's Trust Company official and two former Government lawyers used inside information to profit illegally from the attempted takeover of the Brunswick Corporation by the Whittaker Corporation.

title: Honda Net Off 33.2% in Period
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that its first-quarter profit fell 33.2 percent from a year earlier, citing a ''substantial'' increase in research and development spending, higher interest costs and the expenses of introducing new products.

title: Article 020196 -- No Title
description: Federal and state officials today announced a $7 million program for additional cleanup work at the Love Canal.

title: MENUFLECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: M.S. Wien Revocation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday revoked the Federal brokerage house license of M.S. Wien & Company of Jersey City, after finding that the firm had violated net capital and other rules. Wien is being liquidated by a trustee who was appointed under the Securities Investor Protection Act after the S.E.C. found it to be in ''critical financial condition.''

title: THE CITY;
description: A total of $15,000 in reward money was offered yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer of Michael Turner, a 30-year-old Parks Department watchman who was shot to death Wednesday morning in Central Park.

title: BANK IN TEXAS REPORTS OUTFLOW OF $50 MILLION
description: Depositors of the Abilene National Bank have withdrawn more than 10 percent of the bank's $428 million in total deposits since last Friday following a newspaper report that the bank had suffered heavy losses on loans to oil-and-gas ventures.

title: Interest Rates Post Decline; Fed Injects More Funds
description: Interest rates declined yesterday as the Federal Reserve continued to inject money into the banking system. Economists are not sure if the Fed's willingness to provide credit to the banking system during the past two weeks is a sign of an easier monetary policy. Traders, however, said the Fed's buying - including yesterday's temporary one-day purchases of Treasury bills - have definitely helped raise prices of short-term Treasury securities. The rate for three-month bills, for example, fell to 11.53 percent yesterday from 11.96 percent, while the six-month rate fell to 12.02 percent from 12.22 percent.

title: WEINBERGER TARGET: ARMED FORCES' SQUABBLING
description: WASHINGTON July 15 - Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger looked out over the graduating class at the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., last month, and said, ''I see sprinkled among you many wearing different shades of dark blue, white, olive green and light blue uniforms, as well as several in civilian attire.''

title: BRINK'S INQUIRY IS GETTING HELP FROM A RADICAL
description: A New York City man, described by the F.B.I. as the communications officer for militant radicals accused or suspected in the Brink's armored-car robbery last year in Rockland County, has been cooperating with law-enforcement authorities since April.

title: CONDOMINIUM RESTORING LIFE TO A QUEENS COMPLEX
description: People who come to look at the condominiums that went on sale two weeks ago off Cloverdale Boulevard in the Bayside section of Queens may not realize that they are standing in the midst of a housing resurrection. But they are.

title: Georgia Board Approves Plan On Carter Presidential Library
description: Plans for Jimmy Carter's Presidential library and an access road won unanimous approval today from the State Board of Transportation over protests from neighborhood groups.

title: Craig Named in Suit
description: Jim Craig, the goalie who was one of the heroes of the United States hockey team's victory in the 1980 Olympic Games, has been served with an $850,000 negligence suit in connection with an automobile accident on May 29 in which a woman was killed.

title: EXECUTIVE SHAKE-UP AT GIMBLES PITTSBURGH
description: ''It was not my choice to leave,'' Harvey Sanford said yesterday at a news conference. The 56-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of Gimbels Pittsburgh spoke as the company announced that he was being replaced by Daniel Levy, 39, a senior vice president in the corporate office in New York of the Batus retail division. That is the parent company of the Gimbel stores in Pittsburgh, New York, Philadelphia and Milwaukee.

title: Off-the-Ice Injury
description: Playing in a softball game that was in violation of his contract with the Boston Bruins, Ray Bourque suffered a fractured left forearm last week in Montreal.

title: On the Labor Front
description: F or a place once known as Strike City to some, New York has enjoyed a stretch of labor tranquillity. Lately, though, the peace has become a tad grumpy.

title: A LEANER BETHLEHEM STEEL
description: For steel executives there was no place to work like Bethlehem. Salaries provided for large homes on sprawling acres, raises came regularly and there were plenty of assistants to take care of things if a manager spent an afternoon of golf at the company-subsidized Saucon Valley Country Club.

title: A NEW WOODY ALLEN
description: ''SEIZE the moment,'' the characters keep telling one another in ''A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy,'' Woody Allen's latest and possibly least typical movie. This talk of impetuousness is new in Mr. Allen's work, as are the film's hopefulness, its light classical manner and its happyish ending. Whatever Mr. Allen is doing in constructing this pretty, slight, gently entertaining movie, he isn't doing the thing he does best. ''A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy'' gives the impression of someone speaking fluently but formally in a language not his own.

title: Arthur O'Connor Dies at 77; Coached Track at Fordham
description: Arthur O'Connor, who was the head coach of cross-country and track and field at Fordham University from 1946 through 1973, died of a blood infection yesterday at Parsons Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 77 years old.

title: THOUSANDS OF E.T.'S ARE HEADING FOR STORES
description: The first 5,000 E.T. dolls - 8-inch-long, slightly potbellied, brown vinyl models of the extra-terrestrial in this summer's most successful motion picture - will reach Macy's, Saks, F.A.O. Schwarz and other stores this week.

title: STAGE: SCOTT IN A NOEL COWARD PLAY
description: FOR about 10 minutes, it may bother you that George C. Scott is in some ways totally miscast as the hero of Noel Coward's ''Present Laughter,'' which was revived at the Circle in the Square last night. After that, you may well say: who cares? Mr. Scott is pickled with high spirits in this play. He's not just terrifically funny - he's actually having fun on stage, for the first time since ''Sly Fox,'' and his delight is contagious. He makes us feel glad to be in the theater with him - so glad that we're willing to meet him more than halfway in a purely silly summertime frolic.

title: Elusive Maserati
description: Sgt. William Parr of the West Los Angeles police auto division was routinely cruising city streets yesterday when he suddenly spotted a brown four-door Maserati.

title: F.C.C. PROPOSES TO END CABLE OWNERSHIP CURBS
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed today to drop its 12-year-old prohibition against television network ownership of cable television systems, saying cable has come of age and no longer needs such protection.

title: Church Gets Cody Estate
description: John Cardinal Cody left his entire estate, valued at $50,000, to the Chicago Roman Catholic Archdiocese that he headed for nearly 17 years, according to documents filed in Cook County Circuit Court. The Cardinal, who died April 25 of a heart attack at the age of 74, was the subject of a grand jury investigation into charges that he had diverted up to $1 million in church funds to his lifelong friend and stepcousin, Helen Dolan Wilson. He denied any wrongdoing, and the investigation ended earlier this month without indictments.

title: Martinez Takes House Seat
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - Matthew Martinez of California took the oath of office as a member of Congress today, bringing the House of Representatives to its full strength of 435 members. Mr. Martinez, a Democrat, won a narrow victory Tuesday over Ralph Ramirez, a Republican, in a special election to replace George Danielson, a Democrat, who resigned his Sixth Congressional District seat earlier this year to accept a state judgeship.

title: Trial Ordered for 5 Men Who Admitted Rape
description: A judge today ordered that five men who received suspended sentences and light fines after pleading guilty to raping a woman stand trial on the charges.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 11Asia* Asia 22Always on My Mind* Willie Nelson 33Dare* Human League 44Toto IV* Toto 55Still Life* Rolling Stones 67American Fool* John Cougar 710Eye of the Tiger* Survivor 89Get Lucky Loverboy 96Tug of War Paul McCartney 1011Special Forces .38 Special Singles ThisLast WeekWeek 11Don't You Want Me* Human League 22Rosanna* Toto 33Hurts So Good* John Cougar 45Eye of the Tiger* Survivor 56Let It Whip Dazz Band 612Hold Me* Fleetwood Mac 77Love's Been a Little Juice Newton 89Tainted Love Soft Cell 911Only the Lonely* The Motels 1010Caught Up in You .38 Special Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: Troop Cut Talks Adjourned
description: Representatives of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact, trying to negotiate troop cuts in Central Europe, adjourned today, ending the 27th round of their nine-year-old talks without agreement.

title: Ryder Free to Buy More Hall Stock
description: A Federal judge declined to block Ryder System Inc. from buying more stock in Frank B. Hall & Company, as long as Ryder informs the insurance brokerage concern of its intentions 30 days in advance.

title: SEAFIRST LOAN LOSS CAUSES LAYOFF OF 400
description: The Seafirst Corporation, holding company for the nation's 26th-largest bank, today announced the layoff of 400 employees and a freeze on merit pay increases to cope with a huge loss resulting from the failure of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City.

title: REAGAN PLANS TO TELL CONGRESS ISRAEL MAY HAVE VIOLATED ARMS RESTRICTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to inform Congress in the next day or so that it has determined that Israel might have violated its arms agreements with the United States by using American-made military equipment during its invasion of Lebanon, Administration officials and Congressional sources said today.

title: PRESIDENT CONSIDERS GRAIN PACT
description: President Reagan's advisers believe he is leaning toward a short-term extension of the agreement to sell grain to the Soviet Union, but Administration officials said he made no commitment on the issue in meetings today with his Cabinet and with Republican Congressional leaders.

title: REGAN CITES DELAY IN SUBWAY REPAIRS
description: Lax supervision and poor work habits in its two major repair shops contribute to the breakdown and delay of many subway trains and cost the Transit Authority millions of dollars a year, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Hanover Bank Posts 16% Gain
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that net operating income in its second quarter rose 16 percent, to $63.8 million, or $1.79 a share, from $55 million, or $1.63 a share, in the same period last year.

title: Help Wanted, Hockey Style
description: The advertisement appeared in the classified section of The Hockey News last week. ''PLAYERS WANTED: To play in the Atlantic Coast Hockey League.

title: BEIRUT TALKS OVER P.L.O. HAVEN
description: The question of where the armed fighters of the Palestine Liberation Organization would go if they withdraw is still holding up negotiations for an end to the Israeli siege of west Beirut.

title:
Economic Scene;
Behind Japan's Trade Disputes
description: TOKYO THERE are many apparent contradictions in the Japanese economy. In them lie reasons for both the nation's prowess and its problems as an international trade partner.

title: ETHNIC TENSIONS RISE IN NEW MEXICO AFTER ARSON
description: It was near midnight on Independence Day when arsonists set fires at four unoccupied dwellings in this sleepy village, deep in the rugged brown mountains of northern New Mexico.

title: A SINGING TOUR OF THE GAY 90'S TIN PAN ALLEY
description: Grab your coat! Get your hat! Leave your worries on the doorstep, as they say, and hurry over to the Flatiron Building, where Fifth Avenue and Broadway meet 23d Street, for the 92d Street Y's ''Gay Nineties Community Sing and Walking Tour of Old Tin Pan Alley'' at 10:30 on Sunday morning.

title: Colorado Flood Waters Engulf Resort Town
description: Waters let loose from Lawn Lake by a broken dam high in the Colorado Rockies roared down on the resort town of Estes Park today, moving buildings, cars, mobile homes and power poles, and carrying one camper away in his sleeping bag.

title: Hong Kong to Detain Refugees From Vietnam
description: Hong Kong officials said today that Vietnamese refugees who come to Hong Kong would be ''detained indefinitely.''

title: Subway Car Export Study
description: The Commerce Department started an investigation today to determine whether the Canadian Government was subsidizing the export of subway cars to the United States by a Montreal company.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: BILL FORSYTH has just turned 34, and ''Gregory's Girl,'' the movie written and directed by him, is about to ''open wide,'' as they say in the movie business. This means that, having shown ''legs'' in New York (i.e., it's been doing great business for the last five weeks), it's going to be sent around the country, to Washington, Boston, Chicago and other cities. So Mr. Forsyth is once again being interviewed about it, even though he finished it a year ago, and even though, as he puts it: ''It's really not anything to do with me anymore. It's like a friend, you know? I kind of wave to it when I see it. I'd maybe send it a drink. But I don't think I would cross a room to talk to it.''

title: INSTEAD OF WELFARE, WORK
description: Chronic welfare dependency is a domestic malady that confounds conservative and liberal Administrations alike. President Reagan's predecessors were unable to cure it by constantly enlarging the benefits. He is trying a more radical but hardly more promising approach: smaller welfare checks, ''workfare'' and, if his ''New Federalism'' ever flies, state control.

title: DAREDEVIL URBAN SKYDIVERS LOVE TO LEAP IN TEXAS
description: It seemed like a one-time stunt when four men sneaked to the top of the 75-story Texas Commerce Bank, leaped off and parachuted to the ground early one Sunday morning in June 1981.

title: In Memory of a Child
description: O nce a year, the secluded burial site of the Amiable Child gets the cleaning its sorely needs. Down from the nearby apartment buildings, a sprinkling of nearby residents come to pay tribute at Riverside Drive and 123d Street.

title: PUBLISHING: VISITING ROYAL BEDROOMS
description: BRITISH newspapers this week are filled with stories of the prowler who broke into Buckingham Palace, entered Queen Elizabeth's bedroom and spent 10 minutes sitting on her bed. The episode sounds bizarre enough to have come from a novel and, in fact, in October two publishers, Farrar, Straus & Giroux in the United States and Jonathan Cape in Britain, plan publication of Roald Dahl's ''The BFG,'' a children's book about a Big Friendly Giant who kidnaps Sophie from her orphanage bed and deposits her in the Queen's bedroom ''with the Queen herself asleep in there behind the curtain not more than five yards away.''

title: RUSSIANS SEEKING SUN, SEA AND CURES
description: The palms, glittering sea and scented air here speak of languid leisure. But vacationing Russians are just as likely to be talking of sulfur baths and physiotherapy.

title: News Analysis
description: A deep political malaise has transformed the cohesive and powerful Arab world of 1973. The heartland of the Arab world now finds itself between two wars and threatened by two of the region's non-Arab powers - Israel and Iran.

title: PUELO WINS HIS 7TH FOR METS
description: Maybe it was the wisdom of the manager, George Bamberger, who addressed the Mets this evening in a meeting that lasted fewer than 10 minutes. Or maybe it was the three-day break from nagging thoughts of the latest bad stretch. After 14 losses in 19 games, the Mets were searching for victories, not explanations.

title: PLAYER PIANO NIGHTS: MASTERS RETURN
description: They did indeed live up to their billing: Legendary Concert Artists. Their names were Josef Hofmann, Ignace Paderewski, Percy Grainger and Rudolph Ganz, to mention but four, and they ''appeared'' last night in the first of three recitals at the Cloister Theater of Riverside Church.

title: Pirates 5, Astros 1
description: HOUSTON (AP) - John Candelaria and Rod Scurry combined to pitch a five-hitter, and Dave Parker drove in four runs, three with a homer. Candelaria (5-4) struck out six and walked one, allowing five hits before giving way to Scurry in the seventh.

title: 60-SECOND DEBATE
description: John P. East Republican Senator from North Carolina

title: FRIDAY, JULY 16, 1982; The Economy
description: Factory output fell in June for the 10th time in 11 months, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The decline, by 0.7 percent, followed recent Administration assertions that the recession had bottomed out. The Fed increased earlier estimates of declines in May, to 0.6 percent from 0.2 percent, and in April, to 1.1 percent from 0.8 percent. (Page A1.)

title: New Team Picks Coury
description: Dick Coury, an assistant coach with the Philadelphia Eagles since 1976, was named head coach and general manager of the unnamed Boston entry in the new United States Football League.

title: Bowater Will Shut Mill for 16 Days
description: The Bowater Southern Paper Corporation said it would close its Calhoun plant, the largest newsprint producing mill in the United States, for 16 days beginning Aug. 22 to reduce inventories.

title: ASSAILANT HITS JUSTICE WHITE
description: Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court, preparing to deliver a speech to the Utah State Bar association this morning, was struck in the face and the head by a man who rushed at him shouting ''Pornography!'' and ''Busing!'' Justice White, 65 years old, was not hurt seriously.

title: Robinson Hospitalized
description: Sugar Ray Robinson, who fought for 25 years and held the middleweight title five different times, has been undergoing tests for an undisclosed illness at Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles.

title: IRANIAN INVASION OF SOUTHERN IRAQ APPEARS TO STALL
description: Iran's invasion of southern Iraq apparently stalled today as Iraqi forces halted, and at some points repelled, Iranian troops attacking along a 10-mile front, American officials reported.

title: STABLER ON NO-RECALL WAIVERS
description: Ed Biles, the coach of the Houston Oilers, placed the quarterback Ken Stabler on no-recall waivers today, eight days after telling him that he would not be invited to training camp.

title: BRITISH WOMEN ASSERTS SHE WAS BEATEN BY ISRAELIS
description: Occupied West Bank, July 15 - A British woman who works at Bir Zeit University said today that she was beaten with a wooden stick at the military headquarters here after being detained Sunday.

title: News Analysis
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, has long opposed a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget, but earlier this week he admitted that the proposal probably had enough political appeal to pass Congress this year.

title: HIGH-SPEED DATA LINK APPROVED
description: The Federal Communications Commission today authorized five companies to construct new digital electronic message services that would permit long-distance communications companies to bypass local phone companies in completing data transmissions.

title: BUDGET RULE: YES-POLITICIANS NEED IT
description: The Senate this week began considering a balanced-budget amendment to the contitution. With bipartisan support from more than 60 Senate co-sponsors and more than 220 House co-sponsors, there is a realistic possibility that Congress may offer this amendment to the states for ratification as the 27th Amendment to the Constitution.

title: Advertising; TV Prizes In Europe Debated
description: THERE is usually no talk on Madison Avenue about the annual festival of TV commercials in Cannes, France, but this year there were at least two stories in print and they must have generated some verbiage. They did, after all, border on being controversial.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: High-tide listings for Stamford and Port Jefferson in the Weather Forecasts and Records column from July 1 through yesterday were inadvertently computed from April tables. The tides have occurred between one and three hours later than the times listed.

title: ART: THE SPELL OF RUSCHA'S WORDS
description: ''I DONT WANT NO RETRO SPECTIVE'' is emblazoned in white letters against raspberry pink on the catalogue to Edward Ruscha's show, which is at the Whitney Museum, courtesy of Philip Morris Inc. and the National Endowment for the Arts. The words are the subject as well as the title of one of the artist's pastels and it may be a coincidence that, metrically, they echo the Rolling Stones's ''I Can't Get No Satisfaction.'' But then again, it may not; you can never be sure with an artist who once worked for Artforum doing layouts as Eddie Russia, that being the way most people pronounce his name (it should be ''Rooshay'').

title: A MAIN BREAKS, DISRUPTING FLOW OF WATER TO JERSEY CITY
description: The main aqueduct serving Jersey City ruptured yesterday afternoon, causing water pressure to drop rapidly throughout most of the city and leaving large areas without water.

title: BRIEFING
description: Personnel Reduction Plan

title: WHY THE ENGINEER DIED IN JERSEY TRAIN CRASH
description: To the Editor:

title: TAPES SHOW PILOT GOT WIND ALERT 6 MINUTES BEFORE LOUISIANA CRASH
description: The pilot of the airliner that crashed on takeoff in a New Orleans suburb a week ago was directly told by an air traffic controller of hazardous wind shifts in the area about six minutes before the crash, a source close to the investigation said last night.

title: POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR WEEKEND TRAFFIC
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B. Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive: Two lanes will be closed in either direction from the Brooklyn Bridge to the Battery. Also, the southbound ramp at Richard F. Wagner Sr. Place will be closed. Farther north, one northbound lane will be closed to traffic at 42d Street as a project to strengthen the roadbed continues.

title: Accounts
description: * John Blair & Company to Needham, Harper & Steers/New York for Radio Stations WHDH and WCOZ, Boston.

title: 5 UNIONS AT DAILY NEWS GIVEN TILL AUG. 6 FOR JOB CUT ACCORD
description: In an effort to break a bargaining impasse, the management of The Daily News said last night that it had set an Aug. 6 deadline for reaching agreements with five holdout unions on reductions in its work force to insure the newspaper's survival.

title: YANKEES BEAT A'S, RECALL RIGHETTI
description: The Yankees opened the second half of their season last night with two dramatic moves: Dave Righetti was recalled from the Class AAA Columbus Clippers and Graig Nettles connected on a two-run homer in the eighth inning that beat the Oakland A's, 2-1, at the Stadium.

title: Michael Blankfort, 74; Novelist, Screenwriter
description: Michael Blankfort, a New York-born novelist, playwright and screenwriter, died Tuesday at Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles of a head injury he suffered when he fell in the driveway of his Westwood home. He was 74 years old.

title: Olympia Extends Pabst Deadline
description: The Olympia Brewing Company said it had extended to July 19 the proration deadline on its offer to buy 4 million shares of the Pabst Brewing Company. The offer, being made through a subsidiary, OBC Acquisitions Inc., is part of a Pabst recapitalization program announced last month.

title: HONDURAS AND NICARAGUA ACCUSE EACH OTHER OF ARMED INCURSIONS
description: Honduras and Nicaragua accused each other today of instigating fighting along their border. President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras, here on a visit, said that Nicaraguan troops had crossed into his country and that Honduran forces might have driven into Nicaragua to repel the incursion.

title: HOW 1850'S JAPAN DEPICTED THE PALE-SKINNED INTRUDERS
description: STRANGER rhymes with danger, in case you haven't noticed, and all the more so for people who have had their country entirely to themselves for a very long time. Foreigners were banished from Japan in 1639, and for 200 years they kept away. But then in the 1850's foreign ships from all over sailed into Japanese ports. Boundless was the curiosity and vast the consternation with which the Japanese received them. If strangers were there, they said to themselves, could dangers be far behind?

title: Balanced Budget Candy
description: Go ahead and vote for the balanced budget amendment. Believe me, you've got nothing to lose.

title: Korean Dance Troupe
description: A 27-member Korean dance troupe led by Kim Mae-Ja will make its New York City debut tonight at 7:30 at Murray Bergtraum High School, 411 Pearl Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption accompanying the Outdoors column in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly identified the fish in the photograph. It was a pickerel.

title: A Bank-Like Hutton Trust
description: E.F. Hutton Group Inc., parent of the brokerage house, has been granted a license to start a nationwide trust management unit to be based in Delaware, Hutton said yesterday.

title: A Quick Spin Is Key to Timely Goal
description: T he soccer game between the Cosmos and the Montreal Manic Wednesday night at Giants Stadium was following the pattern of their previous five meetings. All had been decided by one goal, either in the final minute of regulation time, in overtime, or by a shootout.

title: APPLE IS UP 27.7%
description: The RCA Corporation yesterday reported a slight gain in secondquarter earnings, based partly on improved performance at its NBC and Hertz units. Analysts said the results were slightly better than expected and somewhat encouraging for the problem-plagued company.

title: Changes Asked On Farm Trade
description: The Common Market Commission today asked the member governments to relax trade rules on agriculture products, giving 123 underdeveloped countries better access to European markets.

title: Muchas Gracias
description: ABC got most of the World Cup attention last week because it was the first United States network to televise the World Cup final ''live,'' reaching 25 million American viewers, according to Nielsen ratings released yesterday. But the Spanish International Network televised all 52 matches in this year's edition of the quadrennial tournament, and every match could be seen either live or on tape later the same evening.

title: GIANTS SIGN WOOLFOLK IN TIME
description: Hours before the labor contract between the National Football League's 28 teams and its players union expired at midnight tonight, the Giants signed Harold (Butch) Woolfolk, the Michigan running back who was their No. 1 choice in last April's draft.

title: RIGHT TO LIFE GROUP OPENS CONVENTION
description: Organized opponents of abortion gathered today for the opening of their annual convention and were met by protesters from a hastily called rival convention as this suburban community became a setting for the national abortion controversy.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: IN May 1945, a shy young trumpet player a few days away from his 19th birthday made his first recordings, playing in a small ensemble led by a tenor saxophonist named Herbie Fields. The trumpeter was too nervous and unsure of himself to take a solo; he even played his ensemble parts through a mute. It wasn't a very auspicious beginning. But the young trumpeter was Miles Davis, and he went on to become one of the most influential and consistent trend setters in jazz history.

title: L.I. Survey Taken On Nuclear Plant
description: In the event of a minor accident at the Shoreham nuclear plant, which is under construction, one of four Long Island residents would try to leave the Island, even though they had not been told to do so, according to a poll Suffolk County officials announced today.

title: TO KEEP THE INSANITY ISSUE OUT OF COURT TRIALS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Soviet Officials Meet on Arms Cutbacks
description: American and Soviet negotiating teams met today in a new round of separate talks on reducing medium-range and strategic nuclear arsenals.

title: GRACE OFF 23.3%
description: The Allied Corporation, one of the nation's major chemical companies, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter declined 5.7 percent, while sales edged up six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Free the Brooklyn 53
description: The Brooklyn 53 are not radicals charged with committing crimes to protest war or social injustice. Nor are they criminals. But come Sunday, they will have been held behind Federal bars for a year.

title: COURT UPHOLDS CLOSING OF GREENPOINT HOSPITAL
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that New York City may continue with its plan to replace the 67-year-old Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn with the modern Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 16, 1982
description: International Iran's invasion of Iraq was apparently stalled as Iraqi forces halted, and at some points, repelled attacking Iranian troops, American officials said. In fighting described as intense, an Iraqi counteroffensive pushed some Iranian troops back to the border, the officials said on the basis of intelligence reports.(Page A1, Column 6.) George P. Shultz was confirmed by the Senate as Secretary of State. Mr. Shultz, in two days of Senate testimony, avoided making statements in direct contradiction of existing Administration policy but seemed to suggest that as Secretary of State he might try to modify some key aspects of American foreign policy. (A1:3-4.)

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * C3 Inc., Reston, Va., named Delany E. Blaine a vice president and also appointed him president of Micro Products Co., a division.

title: A Field of 12 in $1 Million Pace
description: No Nukes won the New Jersey Cup, Icarus Lobell won the Battle of Brandywine, Cam Fella won the Cane Pace, Elitist the Battle of Saratoga and Pitt Boy the New Jersey Classic.

title: Times Co. Dividend Up
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that the quarterly dividend on its class A and class B common stock would increase to 30 1/2 cents a share from 27 1/2 cents a share. The new rate is payable Sept. 28 to stockholders of record Sept. 4.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Children Who Hang Out: Who, Where and Why

title: R.J. REYNOLDS IN BIG JUMP
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the world's largest cigarette producer, yesterday reported second-quarter profits of $295 million, or $2.74 a share, the highest in its history and a 48.2 percent increase over the $199 million, or $1.82 a share, reported in the 1981 period. Sales in the quarter were $3.12 billion, 5.1 percent higher than the $2.97 billion reported a year earlier.

title: Ellen Burstyn is coming back in two new roles.
description: winning performance in ''Same Time Next Year'' almost seven years ago, will return this winter to star in ''84 Charing Cross Road,'' now running in London's West End. The play is a dramatization by James Roose-Evans and Helene Hanff of Miss Hanff's autobiographical novel of the same name title. Her story concerns the relationship, which develops through three decades of correspondence, between an American author and a British clerk who works in a cozy antique bookshop on Charing Cross Road.

title: U.S. FACTORY OUTPUT DOWN 0.7% IN JUNE, CHECKING OPTIMISM
description: The output of the nation's factories, a key measure of economic activity, declined in June for the 10th time in the last 11 months.

title: RAIDS ON ALIENS RULED ILLEGAL
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that raids by agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in attempts to apprehend illegal aliens at factories violated constitutional protections against unreasonable searches.

title: ENGLISH IN THE PYRENEES
description: runner.

title: Batus Accord With F.T.C.
description: Batus Inc. has agreed to sell at least one department store in Milwaukee, because its recent acquisition of Chicago's Marshall Field & Company may have reduced department store competition in the area, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

title: Bridge:; Italy's Blue Team Indicates It Hasn't Lost Its Old Skill
description: The Blue Team of Italy, which dominated the world championship scene for two decades, is virtually retired from serious play. The youngest member of the team, which used to win world titles in bunches, is Benito Garozzo at 55, and most of his erstwhile teammates are in their 60's. But they occasionally return to the battlefield and show their old fire.

title: MERGER SPECIALIST JOINS LEHMAN UNIT
description: J. Tomilson Hill, head of the merger and acquisition department of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, is joining Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. as one of the managing directors of its merger and acquisition operation.

title: Teltscher Is Upset In U.S. Pro
description: Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas defeated Tom Cain, 7-5, 6-0, but No.3 Eliot Teltscher was upset today in third-round play in the $200,000 United States Pro Tennis championships at Longwood Cricket Club.

title: Immunology Breakdown Found in Hemophiliacs
description: A mysterious, often fatal breakdown of the body's immunity to disease, which was first detected in homosexual males, Haitian refugees and drug users, has been found in hemophiliacs and is increasing in frequency, health researchers reported today.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose for the second consecutive week, the Investment Company Institute, the industry's trade organization, reported yesterday. The group said the new total for the week ended Wednesday was $204.4 billion, up $1.81 billion from the prior week.

title: THE FRENZIED WORLD OF SUMMER-STOCK PACKAGER
description: ''I need a pianist to leave town this Sunday for 'West Side Story,' '' Carleton Davis said into the telephone the other day, his voice charged with urgency. Then Mr. Davis, who was holding the phone while pacing around his modestly furnished apartment-office on the Upper West Side, took a step back and glared at the receiver. '' 'West Side Story'?'' he gasped. ''I mean 'South Pacific'!''

title: Clampett Posts 67 in Rain, Leads British Open by 2
description: A 22-year-old golfer in knee pants led the first round of his first British Open today, but most of the show was stolen by a man more than twice his age, a veteran who won this tournament here in 1962, when the upstart was 2 years old.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ON LOVE CANAL STUDY
description: Since 1978, the Love Canal neighborhood here has been a symbol of the problems associated with toxicwaste dumping.

title: Big Step for Richard
description: J.R. Richard, the 6-foot-8-inch Houston Astros pitcher who suffered a near-fatal stroke two years ago, took another comeback stride Wednesday night when he hurled his first complete game since his life was nearly ended by the attack.

title: SOME SENILITY CAN BE REVERSED, STUDY ASSERTS
description: A surprisingly large number of elderly patients in nursing homes suffer from mental dementia that is potentially reversible, according to a team of brain specialists.

title: Friday; BOB AND RAY ENCORES
description: So many people flocked to see the recent Bob and Ray retrospective at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street, that highlights of the show devoted to the comedy team - some five hours of television skits -will be offered daily, Tuesday through Saturday, from noon to 5 P.M. through Aug. 7. You can see, for instance, Ray Goulding interviewing Bob Elliott as president of the Fast Talkers of America and then as recording secretary of the Slow Talkers; a demonstration of a burglar kit; an interview with a collector of odd-shape vegetables; a joint recitation of the song ''Do You Think I'm Sexy?'' and the McBeeBee twins, who say the same things a fraction of a second apart. Suggested contribution: $2 ($1 for children and the elderly). Information: 742-4690. BRAHMS AT WATERLOO

title: HOUSING UNIT BACKS INCREASES IN TAXES AND SPENDING CUTS
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, beginning today to bring Federal spending plans into line with the first budget resolution for 1983, approved tax increases and spending cuts that would reduce the deficit by $21 billion over the next three years.

title: Missouri Thrift Units Merge
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today approved a merger of the Tri-Lakes Federal Savings and Loan Association of Branson, Mo., and the Great Southern Savings and Loan Association of Springfield, Mo.

title: June Oil Imports Up
description: United States imports of crude oil and refined products rose by 2.1 percent in June, the first increase since October 1979, the American Petroleum Institute, a trade group, said yesterday. Despite the increase, to an average of 5.1 million barrels a day, the average for the first half of the year was just 4.6 million barrels a day. This was 20.8 percent below the 5.9-million barrel-a-day average during the first half of 1981, the institute said.

title: Purex Buy-Out Meeting
description: Purex Industries, which has made arrangements with the Security Pacific National Bank for a $340 million credit facility, said its shareholders would meet Aug. 11 to vote on a proposed buy-out of the company.

title: Braniff, Pan Am Settle Lawsuit
description: The Braniff International Corporation said that it had settled a $107 million lawsuit filed by Pan American World Airways about a scuttled plan to have it operate Braniff's South American routes.

title: A TENTATIVE PACT AVERTS WALKOUT AT 40 HOSPITALS
description: Union workers and representatives of 40 nonprofit hospitals in New York City and on Long Island averted a strike yesterday. They reached a tentative settlement that would give the workers 7 1/2 percent raises in each year of a two-year contract, with an additional 1 percent in benefits over the life of the contract.

title:
PATENTS;
Electronic Card Game Developed by Rockwell
description: An electronic blackjack card game for hand-held operation was patented this week for the Rockwell International Corporation, El Segundo, Calif., a company better known for aerospace and automotive inventions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today, we're in an era of settle, settle, settle, and advocacy is going down the drain.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bedlwether issues

title: Angels Romp By 15-0
description: Bob Boone and Rod Carew each drove in three runs in a 10-run fifth inning tonight, and Ken Forsch pitched a four-hitter, sparking the California Angels to a 15-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: STUDY LAUDS MIDWIFE CENTER
description: Despite concerted and continuing opposition from prominent obstetricians, the nurse-midwifery Childbearing Center on East 92d Street in Manhattan has had a ''profound'' and ''positive'' impact on obstetric care nationally, according to a study released recently by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: VALENZUELA STRUGGLES BUT WINS
description: The Mets scored six runs against Fernando Valenzuela tonight. They forced him out of the game after six innings, and although this was not his worst game of the season, it was far from the best.

title: De Kalb-Pfizer Tie
description: A joint venture for the sale of agricultural seeds has been announced by De Kalb Agresearch Inc. and Pfizer Inc. Owned 70 percent by De Kalb and 30 percent by Pfizer, the new company, Dekalb-Pfizer Genetics, will be based in Dekalb, Ill. and market the product lines of both companies in more than 40 countries. The companies' investment in the venture was not disclosed, but Dekalb-Pfizer will combine the seed research and marketing facilities of each company, in addition to the product lines.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 44.

title: Military Analysis
description: After three days of resumed fighting, Iraqi and Iranian forces are facing each other in an arc-shaped front just inside southern Iraq, poised for a new phase of the Iranian invasion.

title: USE OF FACTORY CAPACITY OFF TO LOW 69.8% IN JUNE
description: Manufacturers used just 69.8 percent of their factory capacity in June, the lowest level in more than seven years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: To Market, to Market

title: JERSEY CITY'S WATER SYSTEM IS SHUT OFF AS LEAK PERSISTS
description: This city's water supply system, which provides water to more than 300,000 people, was shut down late today for overnight repairs after workers were unable to stop the flow of millions of gallons of water from a break in a 72-inch aqueduct.

title: Scouting; Staying Young
description: He was college football coach of the year in 1970 at Northwestern and, during his long career, Alex Agase was also head coach at Illinois and Purdue. But he recently resigned his position as athletic director at Eastern Michigan to sign on as an assistant to Bo Schembechler at Michigan.

title: Around the Nation; Tiny Shrimp Turn Up In Town's Water Supply
description: The city manager of Rawlins has warned residents that they may find freshwater shrimp up to onequarter-inch long in the city's water supply.

title: Sports People; Aaron Fund Mix-Up
description: A misunderstanding that arose over the amount of money the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People contributed toward a statue of the baseball star Hank Aaron from a spring fund-raiser is ''incredible,'' according to Julian Bond, president of the Atlanta Chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. Some members of the committee raising money for the statue have said they did not think enough of the dinner's proceeds were donated to the project, which is $19,000 short of its $72,000 goal. But Mr. Bond says the April 17 banquet was clearly billed as a fund-raiser for Aaron and other N.A.A.C.P. programs.

title: Scouting; Lunch Date
description: Weeb Ewbank, 75 years old now, was back in town the other day to help the Jets say goodbye to Randy Rasmussen, their last player from the 1969 Super Bowl championship team.

title: Cab Output's End Backed at Checker
description: The Checker Motors Corporation said its board of directors had formally approved a decision by company management earlier this week to cease taxicab production at its Kalamazoo plant, ''subject to future reconsideration.''

title: Savin Loss Widens
description: The Savin Corporation yesterday reported a loss in its fiscal fourth quarter ended April 30 of $21.6 million compared with a deficit of $3.5 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales dropped by 13.9 percent, to $107.7 million, from $125.1 million.

title: Briefs on the Arts; Miss Lansing's Contract Is Extended by Fox
description: Sherry Lansing's contract as president of 20th Century-Fox Film Productions has been extended ''for an indefinite period,'' the studio has announced. A spokesman for Fox said that the contract extension was being announced at this time to quash rumors that Miss Lansing might be leaving the studio.

title: G.I. Killed in Tank
description: An American soldier died today when the tank he was riding in caught fire after its radio antenna struck a trolley-car power line, a military spokesmansaid. Two other soldiers were injured. Their identities were withheld.

title:
PATENTS;
Filler for Nose of Bullet Makes It More Deadly
description: A filler for a nose of a bullet that increases the lethal effect of the projectile was patented this week for the Army.

title: LAWYERS FROM OLD SCHOOL LOSING GROUND TO NEW BREED
description: A few years ago, William Herrmann, then a professor at Brooklyn Law School, happened to refer in one of his classes to a faculty colleague, Joseph Crea, as a Court Street lawyer.

title: Around the World; Nicaragua Says C.I.A.  Backs Rightist Invasion
description: Nicaragua said today that rightists helped by the Central Intelligence Agency and evangelical sects working as a fifth column launched a ''silent invasion'' from Honduras 12 days ago.

title: Life Without a Shield
description: On a dog-day afternoon, Capt. Francis A. Bolz Jr. turned in his gun, computed his pension and had his Police Department I.D. card stamped ''retired.'' After nearly 28 years on the force, he walked away yesterday with an empty shield case.

title: Ecology Nominee Named
description: President Reagan Friday announced today that he was nominating Nancy Maloley to be a member of the Council on Environmental Quality. Miss Maloley, 36 years old, who serves as an adviser in the White House Office of Policy Development, will succeed Jane Hurt Yarn.

title: Around the Nation; 'Friday Firebugs' Strike In Boston for 4th Week
description: Five fires believed set by those who have become known as the ''Friday firebugs'' burst out today, straining the city's Fire Department to the limit.

title: Around the Nation; Camper's Body Found After Dam's Collapse
description: Searchers today recovered the body of one of four persons believed killed in a flood touched off by the collapse of an earthern dam, and nearly 200 stranded campers were removed from a Rocky Mountain National Park campground. The 79-yearold dam had been holding back the waters of Lawn Lake.

title: MOVE BOLSTERS JARUZELSKI'S POWER
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski tightened his control over Poland today with a sweeping shake-up in the Communist Party that included the demotion of the main challenger to his political power.

title: Sports People; A Name for Baby
description: When Michael Everest, a London taxi driver, went to see the British Open at Muirfield, Scotland, 10 years ago, his wife was six months pregnant. After the tournament, Mr. Everest told his wife, ''If we have a boy, we'll name him after Lee Trevino.''

title: DEBATE BEGINS ON TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: Senator Bob Packwood, a longtime supporter of tuition tax credits, said today that the Reagan Administration proposal on such credits did not contain enough safeguards to prevent assistance to students at private schools that practice racial discrimination.

title: Wounded Israeli Ambassador 'In Good Shape,' Doctor Says
description: Ambassador Shlomo Argov of Israel, who was shot through the brain June 3, is ''in good shape,'' his surgeon said today.

title: Kroger Plans Cuts
description: the Kroger Company said it would close or sell 140 food stores in 1982 to 1983, resulting in an earnings gain.

title: Fred J. Munder, Justice In State Supreme Court
description: Fred J. Munder, a retired State Supreme Court justice who served as Suffolk County District Attorney and then as administrative judge of the the county's courts, died July 14 in Washington.

title: Resources in Arrears
description: The American Resources Management Corporation said today that its liquidity problems were continuing and that it was in arrears on payment of interest on bank loans.

title: MRS. JOHN R. REITEMEYER
description: Gertrude Muriel Bullis Reitemeyer, the wife of the late John R. Reitemeyer, former president and publisher of The Hartford Courant, died Thursday in Hartford Hospital. She was 81 years old.

title: SHULTZ, AT SWEARING-IN, SPEAKS OF HIS OPTIMISM
description: George P. Shultz was sworn in today as the 60th Secretary of State and said that despite the problems facing the United States, he saw opportunities ''to do something wonderful'' in foreign affairs.

title: CBS PRODUCER DEFENDS PROGRAM ON VIETNAM
description: Mike Wallace of CBS News and George Crile, a producer, yesterday defended the accuracy and fairness of their controversial documentary charging that Gen. William C. Westmoreland and other officers had manipulated figures on enemy troop strength in the Vietnam War.

title: New York; 15 DAYS FOR KEEPING THE PEACE
description: First the social critics inveighed against the invasion, on streets and subways and beaches, of the thunderboxes - those pillow-sized stereo radios designed to induce early deafness. So the Japanese, ever accommodating, invented the antitoxin - earphones attached to little radios or tape players that created a race of metrognomes whose noise went in both ears and stayed there, bothering no one else.

title: WETLANDS TO LOSE SOME PROTECTION
description: The Army Corps of Engineers is planning to issue new regulations next week loosening some of its protection of the nation's wetlands despite reservations expressed by other Reagan Administration agencies.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $5.9 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply in the week ended July 7, a large gain for a single week but one that was widely expected. The rise followed three weeks of declines totaling $9.5 billion.

title: POP: THE TEMPTATIONS
description: The reunion of the Temptations, probably the best-loved of all the 1960's Motown groups, Thursday at Radio City Music Hall, was an elaborately choreographed and orchestrated affair drenched in nostalgia.

title: STAY LOW ON EAST SIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An Executive Change item in Business Day July 9 incorrectly identified a new director of Twin Disc Inc. Fred L. Brengel, chairman and chief executive officer of Johnson Controls Inc., was elected a director.

title: CBS DROPS A FORMULA INVOLVING RACE FOR EVALUATING TV FILM IDEAS
description: CBS has dropped a formula that had been used by its executives for five years to evaluate ideas for television films. The action came after details about the formula had come to the attention of some producers and agents in Hollywood.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Effluent Society

title: Indonesians Denounce U.S.
description: About 200 to 300 young Indonesians entered the compound of the American Embassy here Thursday in a peaceful but surprise protest against ''American collusion'' with Israel's invasion of Lebanon. American officials said today that it was the first such demonstration they could recall. The demonstrators identified themselves as members of the Aqsa Mosque Defense Committee.

title: Consumer Saturday; HEADSETS AND EAR DAMAGE
description: TOKYO FEW consumer offerings have been so popular so quickly as the portable stereo cassette player with featherweight headphones. The product was first introduced by the Sony corporation in 1979 and felicitously dubbed the Walkman. Today, with several other manufacturers churning out similar versions, more than 10 million people around the world own the little machines, wearing them while walking, cycling, jogging or whatever. Japan has the largest number of headphone stereo users, with more than four million.

title: Inside Trader Sentenced
description: A stock trader convicted of participating in an illegal scheme to profit through inside information on corporate takeover plans was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison. James Mitchell Newman, 38 years old, of Demarest, N.J., was sentenced by Judge Charles S. Haight of Federal District Court in New York. Mr. Newman was also fined $10,000 on his conviction for fraud last May 21. He was one of five men charged with profiting on stock trading by obtaining confidential information on acquisition plans between 1974 and 1977 from Morgan Stanley & Company and the former Kuhn Loeb & Company.

title: HOSPITAL EMPLOYEES ARE VOTING IN FAVOR OF TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: Hospital workers were voting 10 to 1 yesterday in favor of a tentative settlement reached Thursday with most of the nonprofit hospitals and nursing homes in the city.

title: MASSEY SUSPENDS INTEREST PAYMENTS
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the cash-short farmimplements maker, said today that it had indefinitely suspended interest payments to its North American creditors.

title: Fancy Housing or Fanciful Trailers?
description: New York's next major planning choice is between a live project to build 4,800 tax-paying apartments on the Hudson River, behind Lincoln Center, and a modernized rail yard that no one intends to build. It seems like no choice at all, yet officials have been delaying the apartments because they fear the cry of ''lost jobs.'' The Planning Commission should approve the housing before it is left with nothing.

title: POLICE QUESTION OFFICERS ON ROLE OF AN INFORMANT
description: New York City police officials said yesterday that they had questioned detectives about their handling of an informant who was said to have committed robberies while on the police payroll.

title: Sports People; Williamson Comeback
description: John Williamson, who was a high scoring guard with the New Jersey Nets from 1977 to 1979, is attempting to return to the National Basketball Association after an absence of almost two years. The 29-year-old guard is competing with free agents and rookies at a special training camp being run by the Atlanta Hawks.

title:
PATENTS;
SYSTEM TO IDENTIFY VEHICLES
description: WASHINGTON A vehicle identification system was patented this week for the RCA Corporation that may have applications in traffic control. The invention combines a radar speed sensor with a device that asks a vehicle to identify itself by a coded signal.

title: CANCER SPECIALIST
description: Dr. H. Marvin Pollard, a former president of the American Cancer Society and an authority on gastrointestinal diseases and cancer, died Thursday at the University of Michigan Main Hospital. Dr. Pollard, who was 75 years old and lived in Ann Arbor, Mich., suffered a stroke Wednesday.

title: CONNECTICUT DEMOCRATS CONVENE TO SELECT SLATE
description: Connecticut Democrats, hoping to project an appearance of party unity to contrast with the fights facing the Republicans next week, opened their state convention here tonight to designate candidates for the Nov. 2 statewide elections.

title: Jo-Ann Price, Religion Editor For New York Herald Tribune
description: Jo-Ann Price, a reporter and religion editor for The New York Herald Tribune, died Thursday of cancer at Brooklyn Hospital.

title: Testing Their Metal
description: These tend to be good hunting days for Woody Madeira and Jose Sanchez. People like stretching out on the grass in the parks, and that means loose change tumbles from their pockets. Mr. Madeira and Mr. Sanchez are ready.

title: Mortgage Rate Lowered
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association, the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan association, said it has lowered its variable rate on 30-year conventional mortgages a full percentage point, to 15 percent.

title: Bridge: The Use of a 4-Card Major May Be Worth the Candle
description: Whether the modern style of ''five-card majors'' is better or worse than the traditional ''four-card major'' approach is a question that is easy to ask but impossible to answer. The theoretical arguments can go on endlessly.

title: Bush Asks Patience on G.O.P.
description: Vice President Bush, sounding a probable Republican campaign theme for the November elections, asked Americans today to support President Reagan's attempts to ''turn around 30 years of reckless spending and a decade of weakening American defenses.''

title: SENATE VOTES TO EASE CURBS ON USE OF SUBSIDIZED WATER
description: The Senate, in a victory for large Western agricultural interests, voted today to liberalize 80-year-old rules that place severe restrictions on the use of federally subsidized water.

title: REAGAN DECIDES TO SELL TAIWAN ADDITIONAL JETS
description: The United States has sent a high-level message to China that it will proceed with co-production of F-5E fighter aircraft with Taiwan, well-placed Administration sources disclosed today. The sources said the Peking Government had protested the American decision.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ANGERS A ZULU MODERATE
description: The Government of Prime Minister P.W. Botha is engaged in a growing legal and political dispute with the leader of the Zulus, the largest black ethnic group in South Africa. The issue is its decision to excise a fragment of the Zulu ''homeland'' and cede it to the neighboring kingdom of Swaziland.

title: P.L.O. SUGGESTS MOVE TO NORTH LEBANON
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has suggested that it move temporarily to northern Lebanon while negotiations continue on its presence in the country, a senior P.L.O. official said today.

title: ISSUE AND DEBATE
description: Although the United States has been slipping as an economic power ever since World War II, its $3,000 billion economy still accounts for more than a quarter of the world's total output of goods and services. And with more than $500 billion of annual imports and exports, its trading influence is second to none.

title: Around the World; Somalia Says Its Troops Routed Ethiopian Force
description: Somalia said today that its troops routed an Ethiopian invasion, forcing the attackers to flee back across the disputed Ogaden region after 15 days of fighting.

title: BUYING SWIMWEAR IN MIDSUMMER
description: It's not too late to get in the swim. There are racks upon racks of bathing suits in many stores. Most of them are this spring's styles that have been marked down from 20 to 50 percent. But stores have also brought in supplies of fresh new suits. These are tagged Preview 83, supposedly the first arrivals of next winter's resort season, but actually just in time for summer. About the only fashions that now come into stores exactly when customers want them are bathing suits.

title: CUOMO'S WAR CHEST NO MATCH FOR KOCH'S
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has raised $934,459 for his gubernatorial campaign, but Mayor Koch, his opponent for the Democratic nomination, has raised nearly triple that amount.

title: Questor Merger
description: The Questor Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement for a proposed acquisition by Q Associates, an investor group headed by Dan W. Lufkin, subject to the group's getting definitive financing arrangements. Questor said it intends to hold a shareholder vote on the matter in late September. The price will be $14.25 a share.

title: MANY REPORTS BUT NO PROGRESS AT THE M.T.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: RACING BOARD BANS ARELLANO, A JOCKEY
