description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday revoked the license of Jaime Arellano, a jockey who the board says lied to its investigators about his possible involvement in a fixed race in New Jersey.

title: TAIWAN'S SILENT DREAM
description: Martial law on Taiwan has entered its 34th year, the longest period of martial law in modern history, and serves as a constant reminder that nobody - not the Kuomintang that governs Taiwan, not the People's Republic of China, not the United States - cares how the native Taiwanese people want to be governed.

title: Your Money; Benefit Plans: Personal Touch
description: MANY companies are now offering their employees one or more of what specialists in human resources call ''innovative'' fringe benefits. As a result, workers at other companies, both large and small, are getting additional ideas for benefits to request or bargain for.

title: TWO RESIGN AT SEAFIRST FOLLOWING LOAN LOSSES
description: The Seafirst Corporation, holding company for Washington's largest bank, said today that both its chief credit officer and the manager of its energy division had resigned.

title: REFINERS TRY COPING WITH ERRATIC PRICES
description: The latest roller-coaster turn taken by gasoline prices, an upward sweep that began in mid-April, was a major factor in pushing up the latest Producer Price Index. The 1 percent increase for June, reported yesterday, is the sharpest upturn in the index since March 1981, when gasoline prices began a 20-cent-a-gallon nose dive over the course of the next year.

title: De Gustibus; EDIBILITY BOWS TO OVEN ABILITY
description: Convenience foods seem to inspire convenience language, with words that are kwik and eezee to spell and remember. Lite, frostee and temptee, a spred may be lo in calories and hi in price. Like the empty calories in the foods they generally describe, such words seem to be linguistically empty, devoid of intellectual nutrients.

title: Two Bishops in U.S. Resign
description: Pope John Paul II's representative in Washington today announced the resignations of two Bishops. The Apostolic Delegate, Pio Laghi, said the Pope had accepted the resignations of the Most Rev. Alfred Watson, 75 years old, as Bishop of Erie, Pa., and the Most Rev. David Maloney, 70, as Bishop of Wichita, Kan.

title: 4 RUNNING FOR GOVERNOR MEET FOR FIRST SKIRMISH
description: For the first time in the New York State primary campaign, the four major-party candidates for Governor - two Democrats and two Republicans - shared a platform today.

title: Keep Credit Controls on the Shelf
description: The President's standby power to ration credit has expired without fanfare - and few regrets on his team of free-marketeers. They believe that steady monetary growth will assure that competitive interest rates decide who most needs a loan. Yet there is some reason to keep the President's power alive.

title: 'YOUNG DOCTORS IN LOVE'
description: Every imaginable kind of gag has been wedged into ''Young Doctors in Love,'' in hopes of getting another ''Airplane!'' off the ground. Not all of them are funny, and plenty of them fall flat. But there are enough bright moments to make this a passable hot-weather entertainment, if not one worth slogging through a blizzard for. ''Stupid, but funny,'' was one patron's verdict in the lobby of the National Twin, one of many movie houses at which the film opened yesterday. That's as good an assessment as any.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Making Fun of Symbols By JOHN LEONARD THE HEAD OF ALVISE. By Lina Wertmuller. 255 pages. Morrow. $12.50.

title: ISRAELIS SHRUG OFF ANY P.L.O. GAINS
description: Israeli officials say they are not concerned about the enhanced international political stature that the Palestine Liberation Organization may gain from the long siege of west Beirut.

title: Steel Union, McLouth in Talks
description: The United Steelworkers union and the unsecured creditors of the McLouth Steel Corporation have been meeting privately to discuss buying the financially troubled steelmaker, representatives of both groups said.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 17, 1982
description: International An arms shipment to Israel is being delayed by the Reagan Administration while the Begin Government is pressed for a report on its use of American-made cluster bombs in Lebanon, senior Administration officials said. The arms being delayed are cluster-bomb artillery shells. American intelligence reports contradict denials by some Israeli officials that cluster bombs have been used in Lebanon. (Page 1, Column 6.) Joint military exercises with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries were proposed by the United States. No such exercises are currently planned, Reagan Administration officials said, nor has there been a request for American troops from Persian Gulf countries. They said any such military exercises would be a symbolic show of strength and American support for friends. (1:5) The United States has told China that it will proceed with coproduction with Taiwan of the F-5E fighter aircraft, Administration sources said. The message to China merely reaffirmed the Government's position announced last January by President Reagan, officials said. Peking, which has strenuously opposed continuing American arms sales to Taiwan, has protested the decision, they said. (1:2.)

title: Clampett, at 133, Is Up by 5 Shots
description: Bobby Clampett changed his uniform of the day from knickers to long pants today, and the result was even better. The 22-year-old from California started the second round of the 111th British Open golf championship with a two-stroke lead and extended it to five strokes.

title: Bids Extended For Thrift Unit
description: The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, embroiled in controversy over its method of finding a merger partner for Fidelity Savings of San Francisco, said today that it had agreed to allow California thrift units a second chance to outbid New York's Citicorp for the distressed savings and loan association.

title: AFTER LEBANON, JORDAN?
description: I have recently returned from Egypt where Osman Ahmed Osman, a Cabinet member who was President Anwar el-Sadat's close friend, told me: ''Ironically, we Arab moderates now find ourselves in the same boat as liberal American Jews! We are just as embarrassed by the actions of the Begin administration as they are and we too are afraid to speak out lest our commitment to Israel's existence be called into question.''

title: Sports People; Hurt on Jetliner
description: Dom DiMaggio, the regular center fielder for the Boston Red Sox from 1940 to 1953, suffered a neck injury yesterday in a United Airlines jetliner that underwent a sudden loss of altitude over the Rocky Mountains on a flight to San Francisco, his hometown.. ''I had trainers crack my neck before but never like this,'' DiMaggio said.

title: Scouting; Scratch Boxing
description: Mike Cohen, a vice president of Momentum Enterprises, the boxing promoters, said he hoped to stage fights regularly at Yonkers Raceway on Saturday nights before the harness racing program. Cohen's selling point to the track was that boxing fans also liked to bet. ''But they told me they didn't think boxing would bring in any extra customers,'' said Cohen.

title: ERICKSON GETS 7TH VICTORY
description: The long ball lifted the Yankees to victory for the second game in a row last night when home runs by Roy Smalley and Ken Griffey sparked a 6-2 victory over Billy Martin's struggling Oakland A's.

title: National Arts Agency Names Dance Director
description: Nigel Redden, director of performing arts at the Walker Art Center, has resigned to become director of dance programs at the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington.

title: PATRICK DEWAERE, FRENCH ACTOR, 35
description: Patrick Dewaere, a French film star, was found dead of a gunshot wound today. The police said the 35-year-old victim's head wound was self-inflicted.

title: Players
description: 'Golden Boy' Erasing Doubts

title: This is the sixth in a series of occasional articles following one Middle Western family on its search for a new life in the Sun Belt.
description: It has been a year since Patricia Wahrenbrock packed up and followed her husband, Bob, from Michigan to a new life in Texas, and it has taken her about that long to get around to calling Dallas home.

title: Caracas to Lift Oil Output
description: Venezuela said today that it would break ranks with most of its 12 partners in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries by increasing oil production above its quota of 1.5 million barrels a day, agreed to last March.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of inaccurate data supplied by Standard & Poor's Computstat Services, a chart in Business Day yes- terday misstated the unfunded pen- sion liabilities of the Health-Chem Corporation. The liabilities at the end of 1980 were $433,100.

title: RUNNERS TAKE ON THE HEAT
description: Neither snow nor rain nor gloom of night can stay them from the swift completion of their appointed rounds. Those conditions, however, are a pleasure compared with the heat and humidity.

title: 5 Western Reporters Are in Iraq and Iran
description: Four Western reporters, all Americans, are in Iraq and only one, a French correspondent, is in Iran to cover the developing border war, according to a check yesterday with major Western news organizations.

title: HIGH COST OF A HIGH-SPEED WEST SIDE RAILROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Out Guide
description: DUPLEX

title: 8th TERM FOR BIAGGI NOW ALMOST CERTAIN
description: Representative Jonathan B. Bingham withdrew today from a primary for the Democratic nomination for the 19th Congressional District in the Bronx.

title: TITLE BOUT ROLES REVERSED
description: A year ago, they were sparring partners, the world champion from Uganda getting ready to face Sugar Ray Leonard, and the college student from the South Bronx with six pro fights.

title: Around the World; Bolivian President Offers Resignation to Military
description: Bolivia's military President, Gen. Celso Torrelio, has offered his resignation, two senior military commanders said today.

title: CREDIT UNIONS' GROWING PAINS
description: The nation's 20,000 credit unions have been doing a lot of growing up over the last few years. Like most financial institutions, their services have expanded broadly, moving beyond consumer lending to include real estate loans and individual retirement accounts.

title: MOON IS SENTENCED TO 18-MONTH TERM
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon was sentenced to an 18-month prison term yesterday for tax fraud and conspiracy to obstruct justice, but he remained free pending an appeal.

title: Briefing
description: What's on Carter's Mind

title: HILARION CAPTURES MILLION-DOLLAR PACE
description: Hilarion, considered the other horse in a three-horse entry with McKinzie Almahurst and Rompin Home, won the $1 million Meadowlands Pace in a photo finish tonight. The bay colt, whose previous winnings totaled only $38,359 in two years of racing, earned $500,000 for the 13 owners who make up the Nine Star Stable of Yardley, Pa., by winning the richest race for 3-year-old pacers.

title: NEW YORK UNDERGROUND STILL FREE OF ALLIGATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: TransCanada Bid Rumored
description: Reports spread through the oil industry yesterday that Petro-Canada, the Canadian Government oil company, might acquire TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., which is the exclusive shipper of Alberta gas to eastern Canada.

title: MRS. TABB SETS WORLD MARK
description: Mary Decker Tabb shattered the women's world record in the 10,000-meter run tonight, with a time of 31 minutes 35.30 seconds.

title: PABST HAS $371,000 LOSS; ELI LILLY INCREASES 22%
description: The Pabst Brewing Company, citing costs associated with the closing of its Peoria, Ill., plant, reported yesterday that it had a secondquarter net loss of $371,000.

title: Gutierrez Plays Tonight In the Mozart Festival
description: The pianist Horacio Gutierrez and the violinist Dylana Jenson will be the featured soloists tonight at 8 o'clock in the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway at 65th Street.

title: BALLET' NEW 'NOMADS' PRESENTED BY KYLIAN
description: The prize for this year's controversial ballet goes to Jiri Kylian's ''Nomads,'' which had its New York premiere Thursday night with the Netherlands Dance Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Prospect Park Concerts
description: The free Celebrate Brooklyn music series continues this weekend with concerts featuring female performers at the bandshell in Prospect Park, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. Tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: DISTRICT STATEHOOD PLAN: VOTING ON A REVOLUTION
description: One of the newest sets of words in this city of paper declarations begins soothingly, familiarly: ''We, the people ... '' But it quickly grows ambitious: '' ... of the free and sovereign State of New Columbia ... '' And by the last of its 18,000 words, the 50-page proposed District of Columbia constitution for statehood, which will be on the city ballot here this fall, sounds as radical as any design of the Founding Fathers.

title: Scouting; Wedding Party
description: Dr. Seymour Kilstein, a urologist who owns the Lancaster (Pa.) Lightning of the Continental Basketball Association, was at the recent wedding of one of his players, Steve Craig, and the number of guests was better than most Lightning crowds.

title: White Reported In Drug Clinic
description: Charles White of the Cleveland Browns, who won the 1980 Heisman Trophy while at the University of Southern California, has been undergoing treatment in a drug rehabilitation program, The Los Angeles Times reported in its Saturday editions. White, a running back, voluntarily entered the Care Unit Hospital in Orange County last month, according to The Times. He is scheduled to be released later this month and will report to the Browns' training camp, the newspaper said.

title: LABOR DEPT. SEEKS EASED REGULATION OF CHILD WORKERS
description: The Labor Department proposed today to expand the hours and the types of jobs that 14-@ and 15-year-olds are allowed to work. The revisions would be the first substantial changes in child labor regulations in more than four decades.

title: White's Assailant Freed
description: The man charged with hitting Associate Justice Byron R. White of the United States Supreme Court was freed on $10,000 bail today, saying he had no regrets and hoped his trial would focus attention on what he called ''outrageous'' Court rulings on busing and pornography. Newton C. Estes, a 57-yearold construction bidder, left jail less than 24 hours after he punched Justice White three times as he prepared to deliver a speech to the Utah Bar Association here.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: 'Whorehouse' Stays Open

title: DOOMED PLANE'S CAPTAIN WARNED IT WAS 'SINKING'
description: The captain of the airliner that crashed while taking off from New Orleans on July 9 warned his crew that the plane was ''sinking'' and they ''discussed'' actions that might be taken to avert disaster, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

title: HIGH PALESTINIAN OFFICER SURRENDERS TO THE ISRAELIS
description: A Palestinian guerrilla commander in southern Lebanon surrendered to Israeli forces this week because, he said, he believed the military phase of the Palestine Liberation Organization's struggle for a homeland was over.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The Matilda Ziegler magazine is, in a very small way, an institution, and like many institutions, it has also become a kind of friend. People write it letters, recall the first time they ever received it or learned to read it; last December it got nearly 50 Christmas cards.

title: FISCALLY ADRIFT AGAIN
description: Shrewd politics and sound fiscal practices are rarely compatible in New York City. During most of the 1960's and 1970's a series of three mayors, aided and abetted by their colleagues in the City Council, Board of Estimate and State Legislature, found it politically rewarding to spend in excess of the city's revenues to please a diverse set of constituents. Only when the financial community blew the whistle in 1975 and stopped underwriting municipal deficits was the pattern reversed. Even then, local elected officials resisted a prompt restoration of fiscal rectitude, making it necessary to create a set of independent fiscal monitors to insure that the city's elected leaders followed a path toward financial recovery.

title: Court Action Aids Move of Raiders
description: The California Supreme Court and the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals issued rulings today that practically guarantee that the Oakland Raiders would play in Los Angeles this season.

title: French-Soviet Pact Debated
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had known about a French-Soviet trade agreement that was said to have undercut United States efforts to limit Western government subsidies for a Soviet natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: COURTLANDT S. GROSS AND HIS WIFE DOMINANT IN MAIN LINE'S SOCIETY
description: Courtlandt S. Gross, who was found shot to death today with his wife and housekeeper in his mansion in Villanova, Pa., had been a leading officer of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for 35 years when he stepped down as chairman of the board in 1967.

title: BOSTON MAYOR, BEANED BY GLOBE, STILL HUGS OFFICE
description: Mayor Kevin H. White is a physical man, a clapper of shoulders, a poker of chests, a kisser of women. ''Ah,'' he said, reaching out as two women came up through the heat and wind to greet him in front of the New England Aquarium this afternoon, ''I want to say hello.''

title:
PATENTS;
Procedure Increases Ratio of Female Births
description: A method of increasing the proportion of female offspring born by humans and animals has been invented by Ronald J. Ericsson, who originated similar processes for increasing the male population.

title: THEATER: 'GREASE' AT BEACH
description: If you are passing through the neighborhood - and a pleasant neighborhood it is on a hot, summer day -you might be further refreshed, mildly, by the outdoor production of ''Grease,'' playing at the Jones Beach Theater through Aug. 1.

title: EL SALVADOR GETS $85 MILLION LOAN FROM I.M.F. AFTER A LONG DEBATE
description: The International Monetary Fund approved an $85 million loan to El Salvador today after many months of debate within the international financial agency.

title: No Suits in Their Closet
description: Went to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's regular monthly board meeting yesterday. Not much happened. One interesting thing, though, from John D. Simpson.

title: RIGHTS OF THE HANDICAPPED ARE INALIENABLE, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Penn Central Net Off
description: The Penn Central Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the second quarter of 1982, computed after a deduction in lieu of Federal income tax, dropped 26.7 percent, to $35.2 million, or 83 cents a share, from $48 million, or $1.23 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. Sales in the latest three moths fell 17.4 percent, to $772.6 million, from $935.2 million. Penn Central suplies services and products for the energy, electronics and telecommuications industries.

title: Sports People; Bartkowski Signs
description: ''I'm not the highest-paid player in the league, but I'm satisfied,'' said Steve Bartkowski after signing a two-year extension of his contract with the Atlanta Falcons before the deadline at midnight Thursday.

title: The War of Words at Love Canal
description: The latest report on Love Canal presents a credible and definitive conclusion: that the central dump site has been effectively contained, and that in terms of toxic chemicals, the zone around it is as habitable as the rest of the Niagara Falls area. The trouble is that after four years of incomplete, misleading or erroneous scientific information, the residents of Love Canal may be disinclined to believe it.

title: More Layoffs Are Reported
description: Layoffs were announced by major corporations in several industries; most cited the slow economy as the reason. The General Electric Company said it would lay off about 700 hourly workers at its Appliance Park facility in Louisville, effective Sept. 13 and that it would temporarily cease production of room air-conditioners for one week in both August and September.

title: GIUSEPPE PREZZOLINI, 100, AUTHOR AND FACULTY MEMBER AT COLUMBIA
description: Giuseppe Prezzolini, one of the world's oldest active writers, died in Lugano, Switzerland, at the age of 100 Wednesday night - one day after an article by him appeared in a Bologna newspaper. The Italianborn scholar, who taught for more than 20 years at Columbia University, wrote 57 books and almost 150 newspapers and magazine articles.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS CITE FRAUD AT PENN SQUARE BANK
description: Officials from the Comptroller of the Currency told a House subcommittee today that they had uncovered ''substantial evidence of fraud'' and criminal violations during an April audit of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City, which collapsed on July 5 with industrywide ramificiations.

title: Diamond Plans Sale
description: The Diamond International Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell the assets of its packaging division, container division, paperboard division and graphic arts division to a subsidiary of the Jefferson Smurfit Group of Ireland, which is to enter into a joint venture with Clarke Enterprises of Chicago to make the purchase. In 1981 the four divisions had income before taxes of $8.5 million on sales of $190 million.

title: FLAW FOUND IN RESEARCH MICE
description: Tests showing that inbred laboratory mice were not genetically identical have raised the possibility that hundreds of published experiments using the mice may have to be reevaluated.

title: HOWARD STRICKLING OF M-G-M
description: Howard Strickling, a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer publicity agent who promoted Clark Gable, Spencer Tracy, Greta Garbo and other stars, died in a Pomona hospital Wednesday after suffering a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

title: Dow Up 1.33 at End After Early Decline
description: The stock market bounced back from a morning slide to close slightly higher yesterday. Analysts said that investors were disappointed by a rise in producer prices, but encouraged by the prospect that the Federal Reserve Board would not have to tighten its control over the money supply and thus end the recent decline in interest rates.

title: U.S. IS HOLDING UP SHIPMENT OF ARMS ORDERED BY ISRAEL
description: The Reagan Administration is holding up a shipment of cluster-bomb artillery shells to Israel while pressing the Begin Government for a report on its use of American-made cluster bombs in Lebanon, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Grants to Aid Cities Set Up Arts Institutes

title: WAR GAMES IN GULF PROPOSED BY U.S.
description: With Iranian and Iraqi troops locked in heavy fighting just inside southern Iraq, the United States offered today to hold joint military exercises with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries that might feel threatened by the conflict.

title: COURAGEOUS EXAMPLE OF A GOOD NEIGHBOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Arraignment Delayed
description: Arraignment of Ann Yarbrough, 74 years old, and her husband, James, 60, accused of trying to cheat President Reagan in a fraudulent bid to buy his oceanview home, was delayed again today to give the Yarbroughs more time to hire a lawyer. They were ordered by Judge Sammuel Mayerson to return to Municipal Court July 30.

title: JERSEY BILL CUTS TIME FOR PAROLE AT COUNTY JAILS
description: The minimum jail time required before county inmates become eligible for parole was reduced from nine months to two months in legislation signed today by Governor Kean.

title: ISRAELI CHARGE ANGERS CANADA
description: Israel was accused today of besmirching the reputation of a Canadian doctor and two Norwegians who said they had seen Israeli soldiers beat two prisoners to death in southern Lebanon last month.

title: Saturday Sports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, Radio - WABC, 770; WGBB, 1240; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles (Television -SportsChannel, Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240; 10 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Kansas City Royals, at Fenway Park, Boston (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M.) Boxing Kevin Morgan, champion, vs. Marlon Starling, 12 rounds, United States Boxing Association welterweight championship bout, at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. Starling, from Hartford, is undefeated (23-0 with 15 knockouts). Morgan, from Los Angeles, is 20-9 with 15 knockouts. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Davey Moore, champion, vs. Ayub Kalule, 15 rounds, World Boxing Association junior middleweight championship bout, at Atlantic City. (Television - Channel 7, 5 P.M.) Kid Gloves tournament. Belmont Avenue between 186th and 187th Streets, the Bronx, noon. Admission is free. This is second week of fifth annual tournament sponsored by Madison Square Garden for kids 10-15 years old.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. Miguel Vasquez is the first aerialist to achieve the quadruple somersault, a goal that has eluded circus performers throughout the 123-year history of the flying trapeze.

title: Sports of the Times; The Perfect Series
description: Bowlers believe they are athletes. Converting a 7-10 split requires as much athletic skill and grace, they insist, as hitting a home run, clearing 18 feet in the pole vault or completing a triple axel on the ice.

title: Letter: On the Fish Debate; Westway Will Again Prevail
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY, JULY 17, 1982; The Economy
description: The Government sought to prevent broadcasters from agreeing to limit the number of commercials aired by television stations. Its proposed consent decree, filed with a Federal judge, could lead to more commercials if it is approved. The Justice Department said that letting broadcasters control the commercial time available to advertisers artificially increases the cost of air time. An industry trade group had promulgated a set of limitations. (Page 1.)

title: Observer; SO BUSY DOING SO NOTHING
description: Do you really care, friend, whether the Federal budget is balanced or not? If so, here is good news. Both the President and the Congress are behind a balanced budget bill. It will probably be law any day now. The bill says the Federal budget will always have to be balanced, from here to evermore, unless the President and the Congress don't want it to be balanced. It's like the famous law that put a ceiling on the national debt many years ago.

title: 3 KILLED IN MANSION ON PHILADELPHIA'S MAIN LINE
description: The retired chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, his wife and their elderly housekeeper were shot to death Thursday night in their secluded mansion here.

title: E.E.C. Holds Talks in U.S.
description: European Economic Community officials today held what were described as positive but uneventful talks with Reagan Administration officials on issues that have strained American-European relations.

title: Sports People; Issel's Ultimatum
description: Dan Issel, a free agent, said a three-year contract offer that would pay the 34-year-old center $500,000 a year was not enough to lure him back to the Denver Nuggets of the National Basketball Association. ''If that's all I'll make, retirement is not just an alternative, that's what will happen,'' said Issel after contract talks on Thursday.

title: 3 Top Draftees May Miss Camp
description: According to the National Football League Players Association, three first-round draft choices cannot go to training camp this summer unless an agreement is reached.

title: OIL RISE A FACTOR IN JUNE
description: Pushed up by rising gasoline and oil prices, the Producer Price Index for finished goods rose by 1 percent in June after having held nearly steady or declined for four months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Scouting; Hail Columbia, Track Fans
description: The lack of a major outdoor track and field facility in New York, outside of dilapidated Downing Stadium on Randalls Island, has been bemoaned often, as it was recently in this space by Fred Lebow, president of the New York Road Runners Club. But by the fall of 1984, there should be a new eight-lane, 400-meter track with a synthetic surface in a modern stadium seating 20,000 spectators.

title: ITALY BANK'S SUBSIDIARY DEFAULTS
description: A Luxembourg-based holding company controlled by Italy's troubled Banco Ambrosiano has been declared in default on about $400 million in debt by a number of major international banking groups, European bankers reported today.

title: MANY STATES ARE STILL FAR FROM READY TO GO IT ALONE
description: When President Reagan first announced his ''new federalism'' proposal nearly six months ago, many important details involving billions of dollars were unresolved. Mr. Reagan portrayed the vagueness and ambiguity as a virtue, leaving room for negotiations with state and local officials.

title: George Whitaker 3d Will Wed Marian S. Kramer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kramer of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marian S. Kramer, to George Warren Whitaker 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitaker Jr. of Westwood, N.J.

title: Penny Rogg is Married to John Kifner
description: Margaret Lowrie Rogg, daughter of Elisabeth Watkins Dulaney of Greenwood, Va., and the late Dr. Nathan H. Rogg of Washington, was married in New York yesterday to John William Kifner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kifner of Andover, Mass. Family Court Judge Peggy C. Davis performed the ceremony in Central Park.

title: A SCARY AND FUNNY 'BLUE LEAVES'
description: GARDEN CITY GIVEN the haste with which an Adelphi Festival Theater production is assembled, it is a wonder that a play as difficult to do as John Guare's dazzling ''The House of Blue Leaves'' was chosen in the first place, and it's no wonder that the result is diffuse.

title: AIR CRASH INQUIRY COULD BE DELAYED
description: The National Transportation Safety Board may be forced to delay its investigation of the July 9 Pan American World Airways crash for several weeks because of budget problems, a board spokesman said today.

title: More Bark Than Bite; Appetite for Monsters
description: Summer is back and a new monster has been discovered. It's a 30-foot sea serpent, it lives in the Chesapeake Bay and, like other strange beasts sighted there before, it will have to endure the indignity of being nicknamed Chessie - after Nessie, the doyen of monsters in Loch Ness.

title: Randolph Unruffled By Infield Changes
description: To fill the idle moments during a pitching change a few weeks ago, Willie Randolph surveyed the field from his vantage point on second base and was stunned by what he saw.

title: IN DEFENSE OF RODIN'S 'GATES OF HELL'
description: To the Editor:

title: MEHTA TO CONDUCT OUTDOOR CONCERT
description: COUNTY residents need only travel to the grounds of Westchester Community College next month to hear Zubin Mehta conduct the New York Philharmonic. The free outdoor concert in Valhalla will be one of only two summer parks performances Mr. Mehta will conduct in the New York City area.

title: A GIDDY 'EARNEST' VISITS SHARON
description: SHARON CRITICS aren't customarily allowed to attend a play before every last detail is in place. The notion of having someone see a rehearsal and then review it is the stuff that actors' and directors' nightmares are made of.

title: Nancy Yeager to Be Wed To Scott H. McLean in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William L. Yeager of Unadilla, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Kite Yeager, to Scott Hanson McLean, son of Dr. and Mrs. Roderick A. McLean of DeWitt, N.Y.

title: What About State Tax Breaks?
description: When you sell a home, you have to worry about state, as well as Federal, income taxes. New York State conforms to the Federal rules, which means that state residents can make use of such items as the $125,000 exclusion and the two-year tax-deferral provision for rollovers. The state's maximum tax rate for profits on the sale of a house is 14 percent. But long-term capital gains treatment can reduce this to an effective rate of only 5.6 percent (the 40 percent of the gain that is included in income multiplied by the top state tax rate of 14 percent).

title: NEEDED: A VISION OF OUR FUTURE
description: a social depression.

title: A SUMMER JOY THAT SHOULD BE EATEN WITH DISPATCH
description: FRESH corn is one of the joys of summer, a seasonal pleasure that is impossible to duplicate at other times. Some individuals claim that the summer corn they have frozen can evoke July in January, but accepting that view requires substantial compromise on the part of the connoisseur.

title: GUATEMALA ENLISTS RELIGION IN BATTLE
description: On a soccer field fenced by towering corn stalks, several hundred villagers mingled with soldiers in camouflage fatigues carrying Israeli-made automatic rifles. Barefoot Indian girls in bright hand-woven skirts bore on their backs smaller brothers and sisters wrapped snugly in blankets.

title: Now Available, 'Safe' Homes In Love Canal
description: Four years after frightened, furious residents began evacuating homes along the Love Canal, Federal officials said last week it was safe for many to return. But that finding may do as much to rekindle the uproar over the dumping of toxic wastes in the Niagara Falls, N.Y., community as it does to resolve it.

title: WHY THE PRESIDENT'S MEN STUMBLE
description: Almost unnoticed by official Washington, the Republican National Committee recently hired Richard V. Allen as its foreign-policy and national-security adviser. Allen, the former assistant to the President for national-security affairs, remains a consultant to the Presidential advisory board on foreign intelligence. He is also a ''distinguished fellow'' of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research institution with close ties to the Reagan Administration.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: MUSICAn unlikely couple, it seems at first, but not really. Percy Grainger, who gave us ''Country Gardens'' and a multitude of other fine folksong settings, and Robert Russell Bennett, who from the 1920's to the 60's was the leading orchestrator of Broadway musicals, both understood something fundamental about music - that a melody needs a sympathetic setting in order to make the best impression.

title: Ann Hulbert Bride of S.R. Sestanovich
description: Ann Halliday Hulbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Hulbert of Brooklyn, was married at the First Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Stephen Rockwell Sestanovich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen N. Sestanovich of Moraga, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Samuel L. Taylor performed the ceremony.

title: DODGERS SCORE 4 IN 9TH TO DEFEAT METS, 6-5
description: A four-run ninth-inning rally, which was started against Met rookie Terry Leach and ended with Ron Cey's tworun single against Neil Allen, sent the Dodgers leaping out of their dugout to celebrate a 6-5 victory tonight. The outcome prevented Brent Gaff from gaining his first major league victory and wasted Dave Kingman's two long home runs.

title: MAKING MUCH DO FROM 'NOTHING'
description: IN some sets, getting a nickname is a kind of elevation to sainthood, and in the junk and salvage business, Roger and Richard Benash have been canonized as the ''Grime Brothers.'' The identical twins own and operate RB Scrap Iron and Metal Company from a small salvage yard on a section of Saw Mill River Road in Yonkers, a street crowded with auto-body shops called ''collison centers,'' junkyards, factories, demolition firms and other businesses that are productive, noisy or dirty enough to earn the label ''heavy industry.''

title: CONNECTICUT DEMOCRATS PICK O'NEILL, FOILING CHALLENGER'S BID FOR PRIMARY
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill won nomination for a full term easily today at the Democratic State Convention, denying his challenger, Ernest N. Abate, the Speaker of the House, the opportunity to force a primary in September.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YONKERS IN a downstairs bar of the Polish Community Center, Frank Ryan recounted a myth whose origins he did not quite remember. ''At one time,'' he said, waving a large, powerful-looking hand, ''all the gods held a council meeting. The head of the council said, 'There are too many gods so we will take away the powers from a number of them. But while we are not using them, where will we hide these powers for safekeeping?'

title: PAN AM'S SUMMER OF STRUGGLE
description: AS if it didn't have enough worries of its own, Pan American World Airways is now fighting to dispel the ghost of Braniff International. Shades of the now-bankrupt airline seem to be almost everywhere. The three men charged with the task of rescuing beleaguered Pan Am - C. Edward Acker, John J. Casey and Russell Thayer - are all former presidents of Braniff. And Pan Am's advertising agency is none other than Wells, Rich, Greene, which was responsible for Braniff's jellybean-colored planes in the 1960's, and whose chairman, Mary Wells, just happens to be married to Harding Lawrence, who for 15 years was Braniff's chief executive.

title: JAZZ: HARRY (SWEETS) EDISON
description: Harry (Sweets) Edison is best known for his muted trumpet work, using tight, precise, clipped phrasing that parallels the piano style of Count Basie, whose band he joined in 1937 -although Mr. Edison says he was actually trying to sound like his Basie-mate, Lester Young. In the emphasis put on his muted work, however, the charm of his open horn playing is often overlooked.

title: Lawrence Richard Lerner to Marry Julia Ten Eyck
description: Mr. and Mrs. John B. Ten Eyck of Colorado Springs have announced the engagement their daughter, Julia Ten Eyck, to Lawrence Richard Lerner, son of Mrs. John Frank Goldsmith and Mortimer M. Lerner, both of New York.

title: WHAT DO FESTIVALS DO FOR COMPOSERS?
description: The summer solstice has passed and the sound of the music festival is now heard in the land. A distinct and unmistakable sound, like the muffled beating of drums, it emanates from the offices of impresarios and publicity directors. It is insistent and not to be ignored, obviously sending important messages of some sort. But what messages? What may we hope to learn from, say, this year's commemorative celebrations in behalf of Stravinsky and Haydn? Perhaps very little beyond the obvious fact that the promoters of summer concert series, now generically and indiscriminately called festivals, are in constant need of a theme around which to build their programs. From an educational standpoint, neither of those composers can be said to be in need of exposure. They both are, in fact, popular entertainers, using the words in their best and most respectable senses.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: PAOLO AND FRANCESCA UPDATED
description: WAIT FOR NOVEMBER By Hans Erich Nossack. Translated by Ruth Hein. 285 pp. New York: Fromm International Publishing Corporation. $14.95.

title: CLAMPETT FALTERS WITH 78 AS LEAD IS CUT TO A SHOT
description: Bobby Clampett nearly gave away the British Open today, but luckily for him no one took it. That could happen Sunday in the final round, because half a dozen players were within four strokes of him.

title: 'AVARICIOUS' SEA LAW SENSIBLY REJECTED
description: To the Editor:

title: Patients Out, Prisoners In
description: Residents of West Brentwood and Dix Hills, L.I., shared a peaceful, if somewhat uneasy, existence with the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center for close to five decades. But last week new neighbors moved in with the first bus load of medium security prisoners at a newly-converted prison facility.

title: WILDLIFE GROUP ADDS TO SUIT ON DUMPING
description: IN A suit to be filed in United States District Court in Washington before the end of summer, the National Wildlife Federation will allege that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has violated the Clean Water Act and thereby has encouraged continued dumping of waste in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: OUTSIDE RECRUITING OF NEW L.I. NURSES AFFECTING HOSPITALS
description: MINEOLA WHEN Alice Brown of Merrick graduated from Molloy College's nursing school recently, she received job offers from four hospitals on Long Island. The personnel directors at two of the hospitals called so often while she was considering their proposals, she said, that she was tempted to take her phone off the hook. In the end, she passed up all the local offers to take a job in a hospital in Houston.

title: Postings; A LUXURY ICING FOR THE BARBIZON
description: Some of the most expensive apartments in Manhattan are taking shape on the top floors of the Barbizon Hotel at 63d Street and Lexington Avenue and will go on the market Aug. 2.

title: No Headline
description: It is an understandable human trait to see the future in the reassuring terms of one's own experience or knowledge. It can also be most costly when armchair strategists design scenarios for wars to be fought on grounds of the familiar rather than the unexpected.

title: Shakers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BARD IN A PARK
description: If you like alfresco theater, try Shakespeare's ''As You Like It,'' directed by Wendell MacNeal in Danbury's Richter Park. Performances are scheduled at 8:45 this evening and Tuesday through next Sunday. Staged au naturel, the actors emerge from the woods, illuminated by lights set high in the trees. There are hand props but no scenery. Traditional 17th-century Elizabethan costumes are worn, custom designed and made by Beverly Langer.

title: A DREAM THAT FOUNDERED
description: THE waves were over 20 feet high and the winds stronger than 60 miles an hour on that eighth day at sea. ''The sun was setting in the west and we were sinking in the east,'' Jon Craig Cloutier said.

title: AFTER MANY YEARS, HE STILL LOVES GOLF
description: EASTON THE thickening crowd in front of the clubhouse at the Connecticut Golf Club was getting edgy. The weather was hot and sticky and the people, fanning themselves with program cards, were eager to catch a glimpse of their favorite celebrity.

title: Personal Finance; OF TAXES, I.R.A.'S AND THE MADISON FUND
description: The following are answers to some recent questions by readers of the Personal Finance column. Q.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 15 of The Times Magazine today fails to reflect the latest developments in the investi- gation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. A special prosecutor found on June 28 that there was ''in- sufficient credible evidence to war- rant prosecution on any charge.''

title: Prospects
description: A Third Dip in G.N.P.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Rules to Allow Deer Hunt in Florida
description: A Federal District judge today reversed his decision to stop a state-sanctioned killing of more than 2,000 starving deer in the Everglades, and agreed to allow the hunt to begin at 6 A.M. Sunday.

title: MORE WOMEN JOIN BUILDING TRADES
description: STAMFORD WHEN teachers in Danbury asked Lynn Taborsak's three children what their parents do for a living, they tell them their father is a teacher and their mother a plumber.

title: BIG TEL AVIV RALLY HAILS BEGIN POLICY
description: Thousands of people gathered here for a rally tonight to acclaim the Government's conduct of its military operations in Lebanon.

title: WINDOW ON THE WEST
description: SIDNEY SHELDON and Herman Wouk at the top of the best-seller lists, complaints that the market is being flooded by thrillers, new how-to books being developed by publishers worried that they will make no profits if they rely on more serious or more demanding books - it is the kind of talk one might expect to hear in recession-ridden New York, London or Paris, but hardly what I expected to find in Peking or Shanghai.

title: No Headline
description: Phillies Beat Giants in 11th, 5-3 SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (AP) -Mike Schmidt cracked a two-out, tworun double in the 11th inning today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to their fifth straight victory, a 5-3 decision over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Monadnock
description: To the Editor: In regard to ''New Hampshire: Simple Country Pleasures'' (Travel, June 13), it might surprise the New Englander and visitor that the term ''monadnock'' is well known among geologists.

title: Cairo
description: To the Editor: William E. Farrell's article '' 'Finds' in Cairo - With No Haggling'' (Travel, June 27) revived my nostalgia for a very happy time.

title: FRENCH ART SHOWCASES, HORSEBACK TREKS; New Museums In France
description: The figure stands at 72. That's the total number of museums in Paris, now that the Musee Zadkine, at 100 bis rue d'Assas, near the Boulevard St. Michel and the Luxembourg Gardens, has opened its doors. Back in the 1920's, the premises were the home of the sculptor Ossip Zadkine, a bit of countryside charm in the middle of Paris. Several of Zadkine's 300 sculptures stand beneath the trees and, inside, the artist's paintings and drawings are displayed. The hours are 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., Wednesday through Saturday.

title: WHAT THIS COUNTRY NEEDS IS AN INTERSTATE BANKING SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. OFFER RECEIVED COOLLY
description: An offer by the Palestine Liberation Organization to move its fighters to northern Lebanon while negotiations for a settlement of the Beirut crisis continue has been greeted coolly by both the Lebanese Government and Israel, Government sources said today.

title: CAREY SAYS DEFICIT FORCES DELAY OF '83 TAX REFUNDS
description: The Carey Administration, saying it now faces a budget deficit in this fiscal year of $362 million, has decided it will be necessary to withhold refunds on income tax returns for 1982 until after the next fiscal year begins, on April 1, 1983.

title: Milan
description: To the Editor:

title: REPRESENTING HOMO SAPIENS
description: RIDGEFIELD HOMO SAPIENS is the one remaining species of the genus, homo, and so, is the only homo we have. But it's no surprise to find that, according to the 46 contemporary painters and sculptors in the current Aldrich Museum show, also called ''Homo Sapiens,'' he is not in very good shape.

title: HOLLYWOOD SEQUELS ARE JUST THE TICKET
description: IN the high-risk world of the movies, where millions are gambled on t he fickleness of public taste, there is nothing so comforting as a h it. Only one film in 10 ever makes it to that exaulted rank, and e ven fewer become blockbuster hits -those that gross, say, $40 m illion or more. Given these razor-slim chances, Hollywood of late h as begun to churn out more new movies based on old hits than at any t ime in recent memory. Whether it is ''Jaws II,'' ''Rocky III,'' ' 'Psycho II'' or ''Airplane II,'' Hollywood hopes that when the dice r oll again, a sequel will better the odds.

title: THE DECLINE OF AMERICAN SWAY
description: THE IMPERIOUS ECONOMY By David P. Calleo. 265 pp. Cambridge, Mass. Harvard University Press. $17.50.

title: TIRED OF RETIREMENT, HE STARTED A BANK
description: ''IKNEW I made a mistake when I retired,'' said Laurence Marchini of Manhasset. In 1978, he had stepped down as president of the Century National Bank and Trust Company, the New York City bank he had helped found 14 years before.

title: The Importance of Middle Initials
description: In answer to William Safire's question, ''Who needs that middle initial, anyway?'' (''Middle Initials,'' On Language, June 13) may we reply that Roman Catholics in the sacrament of confirmation do. A recipient of this sacrament needs an extra name -a confirmation name that he chooses from among the saints' names to commemorate the saint he wishes to emulate. JULIE B. (BERNARDINE) MITCHELL, TIMOTHY P. (PATRICK) MITCHELL, New York City

title: CHILD WITH CHILD: LOVE ME, LOVE MY BABY
description: "Backward, turn backward, O, Time, in your flight, Make me a child again just for tonight" -ELIZABETH ALLEN By GILLIAN HADLEY

title: IS THE U.S. SUGAR SUBSIDY TOO SWEET?
description: Washington is in another tangle over imports. This time it's the sugar growers insisting on continued protection against lower-priced imports. Otherwise, they say, the domestic industry will not survive. The companies that use sugar the most disagree.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Investing in a Memory Bank

title: Jane Strauss, L. R. Palmer Plan Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George A. Strauss of Shaker Heights, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Alyson Strauss of New York, to Lansing Reed Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Palmer of New York and Mount Desert Island, Me.

title: IRREVERENCE AND OUTRAGE
description: THE VILLAGE VOICE ANTHOLOGY (1956-1980) Twenty-five Years of Writing From The Village Voice. Edited by Geoffrey Stokes. Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. Cloth, $15.50. Paper, $7.50.

title: If you're thinking of living in:; NEW CITY
description: NEW CITY emerged as a suburb in the late 1950's, when two major h ighways - the Palisades Interstate Parkway and the Gov. Thomas E. D ewey Thruway - were cut through Rockland County, putting it within a n hour's drive of New York City.

title: MOUNT KISCO JUDGE CITED IN SECOND CASE
description: A LOCAL committee has charged a Mount Kisco judge with favoritism, conflict of interest and misuse of office in his handling of a case involving a South Salem woman who was arrested for refusing to pay an automobile-repair bill.

title: Woman to Coach Men
description: Kathy Lawlor, who has coached the women's swimming team at the University of Pennsylvania to 39 victories in 55 meets in the last seven years, has been named coach of the men's team as well. Charles Harris, the Penn director of athletics, said the apointment made Miss Lawlor, 33, the first woman to coach both programs on a major college level.

title: CRAFTS
description: LAYTON THE Peters Valley Craft Fair, an annual show and sale carried off with old-style country spirit, will be held here next weekend, rain or shine.

title: Waiting for D.M. Thomas
description: D.M. Thomas's account of the flight of an author (''On Literary Celebrity,'' June 13) has prompted me to write. I was one of the ''nubile young women'' in D.M. Thomas's literature class and while my initial anger and disappointment over his desertion have waned, I take issue with his stated reasons for leaving.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 18 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 3 7 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 3 2 10 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 4 4 6 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 5 6 12 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 6 5 24 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 7 13 14 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.)

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times A Placid View

title: CHINA SWEET AND SOUR
description: W hile China remains for many Americans one of the most exotic destinations, the increasing numbers of travelers bound for Peking have severely taxed the resources of a country where tourism was all but unknown a few years ago.

title: Consultant, Miss Wendell Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harlan L.P. Wendell of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Thayer Wendell, to Byron K. Adams Jr., son of Mr. Adams of Somerville, N.J., and Arlene Pugh Adams of Short Hills, N.J.

title: BEACHES
description: To the Editor: As a land-locked Missourian, I read wth great interest and envy the roundup on beaches. Typically, the author overlooked what may be the beach-lovers' best-kept secret in the world: America's ''Third Coast'' along the eastern shore of Lake Michigan.

title: MRS. BLUM RECALLS TENURE AT AGENCY
description: When Barbara B. Blum became Commissioner of the state's Department of Social Services in December 1977, she did not expect to last very long. The department had had three different commissioners in the previous three years, and, she said, she believed that with such jobs ''you either get burned out or kicked out.''

title: Gunman Kills West Bank Aide
description: The director of public works on the Israeli-occupied West Bank was shot and killed today by an unidentified gunman in the Bethlehem marketplace, Israeli radio and television networks reported. Yaacov Kor, 35 years old, was shot as he was shopping with his two children and another relative, the reports said.

title: NEW YORK'S SOUR CHERRIES TRIPLE THE '81 CROP
description: ''Our trees are outdoing themselves,'' said Lee D. Brown as he stood in his orchard on the banks of the Hudson River here today, looking at an expanse of cherry trees laden with red, ripe sour cherries.

title: Audrey Charlson Wed to A. B. Duel 3d
description: Audrey Holden Charlson, daughter of Mrs. Philip D. Holden of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Holden, was married in Westbury, L.I., yesterday to Arthur Baldwin Duel 3d, senior partner in the Greenwich (Conn.) law firm of Duel & Holland. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan performed the ceremony in a gazebo on the grounds of Spring Hill, the estate owned by the bride's uncle, Ogden Phipps.

title: SCHMIDT IS ASSAILED BY HIS PARTY'S LEFT WING
description: Leading members of the left wing of the Social Democratic Party have unleashed a series of unusual public and personal attacks on Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE United States Geological Survey has made it official: For much of the state, June was the wettest month on record. Last month's rainfall ranged from 8.39 inches in Norfolk to 17.65 inches at the Cockaponset Ranger Station in Haddam. And for seven of 12 recording stations, the precipation, much of which fell during the June 4-7 storm, was the most recorded in the 50 years the records have been kept.

title: Tax Deductions Denied
description: An attempt by the parents of Tai Babilonia to deduct their expenses while accompanying their daughter to ice-skating appearances has been denied by the Ninth Circuit United States Court of Appeals in San Francisco. The ruling upheld a decision by the United States Tax Court, which said that Constancio and Cleo Babilonia could not claim travel costs as expenses incurred in connection with performing a service to a charitable organization. The court said it had determined the Babilonias' primary motive was to advance the career of their daughter, a former world pairs champion with Randy Gardner.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: Convinced that it would be futile with today's mortgage rates to try to sell a 20-room Victorian mansion in the realty market, Jane Pieriboni of Dover-Foxcroft, Me., put the house up for grabs in an essay contest.

title: BOOK CENSORSHIP: FEW CHALLENGES REPORTED IN STATE
description: ALTHOUGH the censorship of books in the United States has risen sharply since 1980, there have been few reported challenges to socalled controversial reading materials in New Jersey.

title: MATHEMATICS AND ALTITUDE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
Central America;
THE PROBLEM THAT WON'T GO AWAY
description: Robert E. White, a former Foreign Service officer, spent most of his 25-year diplomatic career in Latin America. His last post was that of Ambassador to El Salvador.

title: FEW SCARS VISIBLE ONE YEAR AFTER HYATT DISASTER
description: As convention delegates milled about him, Fred Watterson sat in a lobby of the Hyatt Regency Hotel today, waiting for his wife and thinking about the disaster that struck here exactly a year ago.

title: Watson Gets Big Raise
description: Steve Watson, a reserve receiver for two years with the Denver Broncos before he burst into prominence last season with 60 pass receptions, 13 touchdowns and 1,244 yards gained, has signed a series of contracts that will pay him a reported $150,000 a year. His salary last season, when he was a starter in the Pro Bowl, was estimated at between $50,000 and $60,000.

title: BALLOT POSITIONS: FIRST OR LAST
description: TRENTON THOSE who believe that position is everything in life would be heartened by an examination of the results of the Democratic primary for United States Senator last month.

title: Starting Over at State
description: The Reagan Administration now has a Secretary of State who knows his President and also the ways of Washington. On the path to unanimous Senate confirmation, George Shultz never once crowded his leader, ruffled Congress or misled other governments. In the place of the temperamental General Haig sits a confident, impressive diplomat.

title: THINKING ABOUT NUCLEAR MORALITY
description: Herman Kahn presents his proposals as part of a new nuclear ''morality,'' but his idea of what is moral differs from my own (''Thinking About Nuclear Morality,'' June 13).

title: Dr. Charles H. Stevens Dies; Led Piedmont Bible College
description: SALEM, N.C., July 17 (AP) - Dr. Charles Hadley Stevens, who founded the Piedmont Bible College and served as its president for 25 years, died Friday.

title: CONDO PROJECT STIRS MONTAUK DISPUTE
description: A PLAN to build luxury condominiums at Montauk Point has come under criticism from an association of neighboring property owners who assert that the developer has proceeded illegally and unethically.

title: ITEL RETURNS, SLIM AND PROFITABLE, SEEKING RECOVERY FROM CHAPTER 11
description: ON an otherwise bright October day in 1980, the headquarters suite o f the Itel Corporation, high above San Francisco's imposing skyline,h ad taken on the atmosphere of a wake. James H. Maloon, who had b ecome chairman of the troubled equipment-leasing corporation six m onths earlier, set the tone at a news conference about the company's 1 979 loss of $433.3 million.

title: A New 12-Meter Joins Cup Contenders
description: Defender, the newest United States 12-Meter yacht commissioned for the defense of the America's Cup here next summer, is expected to make its sailing debut on Narragansett Bay this weekend.

title: RIVERHEAD FEARS REMOVAL OF COURTS
description: IN 1727, when colonists in Southold and Southampton were in hot dispute over which of the Island's forks should be the seat of Suffolk County government, the Colonial Assembly struck a compromise. Legislation by the Assembly called for ''the erection of a courthouse and gaol to be located at or near River Head,'' where the two forks join in what is now the business district of the Town of Riverhead.

title: JAZZ: NEW YORK QUARTET AT SWEET BASIL
description: The New York Jazz Quartet is playing together for the first time in more than four years at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, through tonight. But because of a last-minute call for help from Lena Horne for Grady Tate, who had been her drummer all through her recent New York engagement, to join her on tour, the reunion is only threequarters complete, with Sir Roland Hanna, piano; Frank Wess, flute and tenor saxaphone, and George Mraz, bass.

title: JOSEPH C. GALDI
description: Joseph C. Galdi, a securities specialist, died Friday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island. Mr. Galdi, who was a resident of Hartsdale, N.Y., and also had a home in Southampton, was 69 years old.

title: BANISHING CLICHES IN ADVERTISING TO WOMEN
description: THE question of what women want stumped Sigmund Freud, even though h e spent ''30 years of research into the feminine soul.'' The same q uestion has preoccupied the nation's marketers. For them, however, t he answer used to seem fairly obvious: Women wanted to prevent ring a round the collar.

title: CHILDHOOD SUMMERS
description: I came by Donald Hall's ''String Too Short to Be Saved'' the best way you can come by a book if it turns out you like it, and the worst way if you don't: The author gave it to me.

title: CHECK BOUNCES
description: The ''Nobel sperm bank'' may check the backgrounds of its depositors meticulously, but it is apparently less concerned about those who make withdrawals. Reporters rooting through public records learned last week that Joyce Kowalski, who in April bore the first child conceived with sperm from the Repository for Germinal Choice, had lost custody of two children by a previous marriage in 1976, when her current husband was accused of child abuse. The couple had also done time in prison on fraud charges. The California sperm bank, which knew none of this, intended to screen recipients, a spokesman said, ''But, of course, we don't have the resources of the C.I.A.''

title: A SMALL PORTRAIT OF EARLIER ERA
description: THIS Tuesday, Jeremiah J. Jerome Jr. is scheduled to make a yearly payment to Consolidated Edison. Once again, he probably won't write out the check. Not that the company isn't entitled to the money: Mr. Jerome conceded that it was. Not that the amount is overly large: it's been the same $1 for the last 27 years.

title: Cobb-Weaver Is Off Again
description: Randy (Tex) Cobb suffered a cut lip in a sparring session today that required 24 stitches to close, apparently forcing the postponement of his title bout scheduled for next Sunday against Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association champion.

title: Waiting on Warsaw
description: Relief for Washington from the pain of the sanctions headache could come from Warsaw - if the Polish regime lifts martial law and frees more than 2,000 remaining political detainees.

title: John M. McIntyre Dies at 52; Headed a Hospital in Meriden
description: John M. McIntyre, president and chief executive officer of the Meriden-Wallingford Hospital in Meriden, Conn., died Friday at his home in Cheshire, Conn., after a long illness. He was 52 years old.

title: WEICKER IS ENDORSED BY G.O.P. CHAIRMAN IN SENATE CAMPAIGN
description: Connecticut's Republican state chairman, Ralph E. Capecelatro, abandoned his neutrality today and endorsed Lowell P. Weicker Jr., incumbent United States Senator, for renomination at the party's state convention here next week.

title: Pamela Goodfield Wed To John Allen Leonard
description: Pamela Eve Goodfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Elliot Goodfield of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to John Allen Leonard, son of Mrs. Charles Allen Leonard of Wyckoff, N.J., and the late Mr. Leonard. The Rev. Donner Atwood performed the ceremony in the Wyckoff Reformed Church.

title: Falkland Shoes Drop
description: It was time ''to put the past behind us,'' President Reagan said last week, lifting American sanctions against Buenos Aires that were imposed when the Falkland Islands war broke out.

title: HOMES THAT HERALDED THE GILDED AGE
description: SOUTHAMPTON AS the premier architects for America's Gilded Age, the firm of McKim, Mead & White played a major role in transforming sleepy pockets of rural Long Island into vacation playgrounds for the rich. Nowhere is this presence more apparent than in the Hamptons - statistically and historically, at least, if not stylistically.

title: CHANGING FASHIONS IN FANTASY
description: The ''Fantastic Films'' series now under way at the Regency is a composite of science fiction, horror, musical and miscellaneous films, and as such it chronicles the changing focus of Hollywood's imagination. From the days of ''Frankenstein'' and ''Dracula'' (both made in 1931) to the monsters and cold war fantasies of the 1950's, from the mysterious occult movies of a decade ago to the rational, scientific ones of today, the fantasy films of a particular period are often keen reflections of the era in which they were made.

title: Week In Business; A BIG RISE IN PRODUCER PRICES FOR JUNE
description: The producer price index rose 1 percent in June after four months of holding steady or declining, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said. The rise was largely attributed to higher prices for energy and new cars. It was the steepest jump in producer prices since March 1981, but analysts said that inflation might slow down, despite the rise, because of widespread weakness in the economy.

title: WARREN ZEVON'S CHECKERED CAREER TAKES A HAPPY TURN
description: LOS ANGELES The tail lights ahead kept blinking out, obscured by a steady rain and billowing fog as the rock singer-songwriter Warren Zevon's road manager led our two-car procession up the slick, precipitous roads that snake through Laurel Canyon. The brakes on my rented car kept grabbing on the curves, threatening to throw us into a sharp skid and off the road. It seemed a perfect preface to meeting Warren Zevon, one of pop music's most gifted and personal songwriters and man who has found himself on the edges of quite a few precipices, most of them precipices of his own devising.

title: DANCE BEGINS TO FLOURISH IN CHICAGO
description: Barry Laine writes frequently about dance and dancers.CHICAGO Chicago is home to the renowned Lyric Opera, Chicago Symphony and Art Institute, as well as a theater industry that not only borrows from, but contributes to, Broadway. The city also boasts the world's tallest building, distinguished architecture by Louis Sullivan, Frank Lloyd Wright and Mies van der Rohe, and two professional baseball teams. But until fairly recently, Chicago had an unreliable record in supporting local ballet and regularly lost most of its best modern dance talent to New York.

title: CITY SEEKS TO DISLODGE DRUG TRADE BY DEMOLISHING TENEMENT HAVENS
description: A multimillion-dollar heroin and cocaine industry on the Lower East Side, flourishing openly in vacant city-owned buildings that drug dealers have converted into private fortresses, has grown so intractable that New York City plans to begin tearing down the buildings.

title: Beaches
description: To the Editor: How could Anna Quindlen, author of ''On the Beach: A Roundup'' (Travel, June 27) have overlooked the delightful beaches in the Belgian seaside resorts of Ostend, Mariakerke, Middelkerke, Raversiide and Westende?

title: OTTINGER: A DAVID AFTER 25 YEARS
description: WHEN I first encountered Richard Ottinger, 25 years ago this summer, I was reporting Mount Pleasant Town Board meetings for a local newspaper, and he was running for town supervisor. It was his first political campaign and my first experience covering one. For this and other reasons, the experience was memorable.

title: TENNIS ACE A FISHERMAN
description: KEARNY RIGHT after winning the New Jersey men's clay-court tennis championship here last month, Herman Pappas said he was going fishing.

title: ANTIWAR DRIVE HAS ROOTS IN SPARTA
description: SPARTA ''WHAT we're doing raises ethical questions of war-making and, at times, we've met strong opposition,'' said Gordon R.Smith of this Sussex County community.

title: RIDDING HALLS OF ACOUSTIC ILLS
description: As if to mock our era's facile pride in its technology, most concert halls built since World War II turned out to be acoustical duds. In Europe, where new halls were built to replace those destroyed - as in London and Berlin -they simply failed in their purpose as adequate substitutes. And in the United States, where new halls were needed to accommodate a growing musical public - as in New York and San Francisco - the flawed halls deprived audiences of the chance to hear live music at its best.

title: Teacher to Wed Barbara Loether
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Loether of Somers, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jean Loether, to Edward M. Mathieu of Woodbury, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Mathieu of Red Hook, N.Y.

title: Miss Morgenson Will Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Rebecca Anderson Morgenson of Oxford, Ohio, of the engagement of her daughter, Gretchen Cooke Morgenson, to John Thomas Rackus Prout, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Prout of New York.

title: Diana Davis Is Married To Edward J. Michaels
description: Diana Valerie Davis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Cochran Davis of Geneva, N.Y., was married yesterday to Edward John Michaels, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Michaels, also of Geneva. The Rev. Richard Manzelmann of the New Hartford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony in the garden at the Altamont Inn in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: ARCHITECT VS. DEVELOPER: A CURIOUS DYNAMIC
description: It is an odd thing to hear a real estate developer describe buildings as ''obscenities,'' but that is what happened not long ago at a symposium sponsored by the Architectural League of New York. The event, co-sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art, was entitled ''New York's Hidden Designers: The Developers,'' and it was just what it sounds like - five prominent developers appeared before an audience of architects in a program designed to focus attention on the impact of certain powerful non-architects on the physical environment of the city.

title: Sarah Jane Smedley Becomes the Bride In Pennsylvania of Peter Anselm Spiers
description: The marriage of Sarah Jane Smedley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Smedley of Narberth, Pa., and Beach Haven, N.J., to Peter Anselm Spiers took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony.

title: DIVING FOR THE SECRETS OF THE DEEP
description: PORT JEFFERSON WHILE evening lights glow on Port Jefferson Harbor, Capt. Hank Olsen maneuvers his 45-foot charter boat with 15 divers on board out into Long Island Sound.

title: SOME RICH AND SILLY PEOPLE
description: "The Only Place To Be" is an unusual novel. Perhaps even unique. On the one hand we have in Joan Juliet Buck a more than competent author who uses language stylishly, runs through a couple of decades without a time hitch, conveys character with lightning accuracy and even - a rarer quality these days -leavens her load with with and irony. On the other hand we have a cast of characters, a background and a theme - though that is too inflatead a word for her subject - which would do nicely for a magazine article.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Point of View ''Crisis to Crisis,'' a series of documentaries examining major social issues, starts Friday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, and each segment has ''a point of view,'' according to Alvin Goldstein, the series' executive producer. But Mr. Goldstein says that doesn't mean solutions are offered on the programs, which take up such knotty topics as poverty, censorship, teen-age violence, nuclear arms, racism and politically conservative religious groups.

title: A NEW PIANIST DISPLAYS A NEW PIANO
description: Anew pianist, and a new piano, figure prominently in a pair of recent releases from companies on opposite sides of the Atlantic. The pianist is Cyprien Katsaris, the 31-year-old Frenchman of Greek-Cypriot descent who performed the ''Concerto in the Hungarian Style'' -now thought to have been composed by Liszt and orchestrated by Tchaikovsky - with the Philadelphia Orchestra and Eugene Ormandy last month at the Mann Music Center outside Philadelphia. The piano is the custom-made Mark Allen piano, a painstakingly handcrafted instrument that is said to possess a singing tone throughout its range, which Mr. Katsaris used in that concert. The first production model of the Mark Allen piano belongs to him; the second, and so far there are only two, belongs to Chick Corea.

title: RECITAL: DONALD JOYCE, ORGAN
description: The 1974 Hellmuth Wolff organ in the Church of Saint John the Evangelist is a relatively small instrument that hews closely to Baroque tonal characteristics, and it has a distinctive setting. The church, in a modern office building on East 55th Street, is mostly a matter of white walls and black ceiling and of no architectural distinction in itself.

title: Around the Nation; Colorado Dam Collapse May Be Tied to Badgers
description: State inspectors said today that water seepage and burrowing by badgers may have been contributing factors in the collapse of an earthen dam that caused flood damage initially estimated at $50 million.

title: From Beirut to Basra, Arabs Squeezed Hard
description: Arab governments, divided and nearly paralyzed over the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, were plunged into new trauma last week as 50,000 Iranian troops drove across the Iraqi frontier. High anxiety swept the Persian Gulf oilfields, from neighboring Kuwait to Saudi Arabia, where United States electronic surveillance planes pooled their observations with satellite pictures to penetrate the haze of rhetoric obscuring the conflict. Baghdad claimed it was ''cleansing the soil'' of the forces of ''the Khomeini clique.'' Teheran claimed Iraq's ''Baathist, Zionist aggressors were forced to retreat.'' Neither side let reporters near the front where the fighting, mostly near Iraq's oil refinery port of Basra, was said to be furious.

title: IT'S A BUYER'S MARKET NOW, BUT DON'T SELL OPEC SHORT
description: For the moment, the only direction oil prices seem likely to go is down. A week ago, a special meeting in Vienna of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries broke up in disarray as the 13 members failed to agree on continuing production limits to prop up prices. Now the oil world is watching anxiously to see whether a major break in prices materializes or the cartel again manages to pull itself back from the brink.

title: Sylvia McNeill Ripley Wed
description: The marriage of Sylvia McNeill Ripley and Christopher Calvert Addison, co-owners and partners of the Addison-Ripley Gallery Ltd. in Washington, took place yesterday at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield, Conn. The Very Rev. Francis B. Sayre, former dean of the Washington Cathedral, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. David Gurniak.

title: NEW YORK DISTRICTING BRINGS 3 MAJOR PRIMARIES FOR HOUSE
description: With the New York State political map changed to reflect population losses and to cut the Congressional delegation by five seats, three significant primary election fights have begun to take shape.

title: MOORCROFT OUTRUNS STARS IN SWIFT 3,000
description: David Moorcroft of Britain won a star-studded 3,000-meter race in the second-fastest time ever tonight at the Crystal Palace stadium.

title: No Headline
description: William Safire did justice to the M.I. (middle initial). More effort should be directed to the P.I. (post initial), which, in professional circles, is very confusing.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN WAS FIRST STATE PRESIDENT
description: Charles Robberts Swart, South Africa's first State President and participant in the drafting of some of the nation's apartheid laws, died Friday night at Universitas Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: STARVING FOR FREEDOM IS A PERILOUS TACTIC
description: Starvation as a means by average Russians to extract visas from the Soviet state may seem, at the least, ill-advised. Neither Yuri V. Balovlenkov nor Sergei L. Petrov, now waging hunger strikes to gain permission to join wives in America, have the international clout of an Andrei D. Sakharov. Besides, the Soviet Government seems in no mood to appease the United States and, probably more to the point, is not given to philanthropic impulses. (Mr. Balovlenkov's wife received a visa and was reported in Moscow where she met her husband yesterday.) And against the history of pressure tactics used to secure emigration, the recent rash of hunger strikes, of which Mr. Balovlenkov's and Mr. Petrov's are the latest, has a certain tragic logic.

title: Tuten Defeats Heninger For Public Links Title
description: Billy Tuten, the runner-up last year, defeated Brad Heninger, 6 and 5, today and won the national amateur public links title.

title: ALARM RISES OVER DECAY IN U.S. PUBLIC WORKS
description: In Pittsburgh, the United States Steel Corporation contends that it is paying at least $1 million a year to detour its trucks 26 miles around a major bridge that the state closed two years ago for lack of repair.

title: Getting in Step With Job Market
description: Robert S. Winkler's article (''How Not to Get a Job,'' Opinion, July 4) describes a 1960's approach to the 1982 job market.

title: TIME CAPSULE IN THE LIVING ROOM
description: WE have finally rid ourselves of our elderly, non-functioning television set. It has gone to that limbo where things like fountain pens and Hula Hoops wait patiently until they become genuine antiques. For now, it's no more than a bulky dinosaur -outmoded, unwanted and unloved.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Our attempts to get travel information from the Chamber of Commerce in San Diego, Calif. has resulted in a few motel brochures being sent to us by the respective motels. Could you inform us how else to get tourist information concerning attractions and events, as well as accommodations, for next winter? -A.A.L., Bolton, Conn. Answer:The San Diego Convention and Visitors Bureau (1200 Third Avenue, Suite 824, San Diego, Calif. 92101; 714-232-3101) will send you a visitor information packet. It contains ''What's Doing'' (a monthly publication listing special events as well as year-round attractions), a general brochure, a map and a hotel-motel guide. Other brochures you may request contain tourist information on Mexico, sports, camping and water activities; you can also ask for the annual calendar of events and a golf-tennis guide.

title: Q and A; More on Mobile Homes
description: Question:In the column of June 27, an inquiry was made regarding where to write for state laws governing mobile homes in Connecticut. Which agency in New York governs mobile homes? ... A.M., Bay Shore, L.I. Answer: In New York, municipalities, not the state, regulate mobilehome trailer parks but three state agencies regulate mobile homes in some fashion. The Department of Motor Vehicles issues licenses for mobile homes. New York City residents should contact the Manhattan office at 155 Worth Street, 10013, 587.4310. Those who live outside the city can contact the Public Information Office, New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, Empire State Plaza, Albany 12228.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SEX and politics combined to unseat her last month, said Susan Wilson of Princeton, former vice president of the State Board of Education. According to Mrs. Wilson, her championing of the teaching of sex education in the state's public schools made her ''too hot'' a figure on the school board, where she was chairman of the Family Life Education Committee.

title: U.S. POLICY SHIFTS TROUBLE AIRPORTS
