description: Airport operators have greeted with great relief a decision by the Federal Government to stop allowing airlines to sell landing rights.

title: YANKEES WIN, 4-1, ON RAWLEY'S 5-HITTER
description: Shane Rawley beat the Oakland A's, 4-1, last night and earned his first victory as a major league starter and a magnum of California champagne from the Yankees' principal owner who had recently called him the worst acquisition the team had made this year.

title: WHAT's DOING IN THE ALGARVE
description: ROB ROY BUCKINGHAM contributes to The Times from Lisbon.

title: Postings; RISING ABOVE THE RIVER
description: ''A jumble of not-so-charming antiquity that was about 10 miniutes away from total collapse.'' Those were the words Mary Pat Bevis, a Bronxville ballet teacher, used to describe the decaying Hudson River Inn in Cold Spring, N.Y., when she bought it back in February 1981.

title: TIME FOR PALESTINIANS TO BE REALISTIC
description: Occupied West Bank - When Beirut's siege is resolved, what will happen to the Palestinian people in the West Bank, Gaza and the Palestinian diaspora? Where will they go? To whose tune? What will be their relations with Arab governments? Will Israel then be able to carry out its plans for the occupied territories with no resistance or opposition?

title: Walker Remains a Sonic In Player-Rights Ruling
description: The Seattle SuperSonics can keep David Thompson, the former Denver Nugget, but they have been told by an arbitrator that they cannot trade away the rights to the free agent Wally Walker.

title: DISARMING PROPOSALS
description: COMMON SECURITY A Blueprint for Survival. By the Independent Commission on Disarmament and Security Issues. 202 pages. New York: Simon and Schuster. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $5.95. By MICHAEL MANDELBAUM

title: HISS'S LATEST APPEAL DENIED BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: Alger Hiss's long legal fight to overturn his 1950 conviction on espionage-related perjury charges has suffered another setback with a rejection, by a Federal judge in Manhattan, of Mr. Hiss's latest petition for a new trial.

title: POLICE SEARCH ESTATE FOR CLUE IN MAIN LINE KILLINGS
description: The police continued today to search a secluded estate here for clues in the slaying of Courtlandt S. Gross, retired chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, his wife and their housekeeper.

title: WOULD 'STREETCAR BE A HIT TODAY?; New York City To the Editor:$
description: There is more exhaustion in writing about the theater than there is in writing for the theater, as Margaret Croyden showed in her piece. Of all the weary tales retailed, the one which now must be retired is the goofiness about playwrights selling out to Hollywood.

title: REAGAN TEAM'S EARLY WORRY SHOWN IN MEMOS ON DONOVAN
description: White House officials were concerned about Raymond J. Donovan's possible ties to organized crime almost two weeks before President Reagan nominated him to be Secretary of Labor, according to documents forwarded by the Administration to Capitol Hill.

title: IN DEFENSE OF RODIN'S 'GATES OF HELL'
description: John Russell replies: I am well aware that ''The Gates of Hell'' draws a crowd. So would a public hanging, if it were allowed.

title: ORGANIST: DONALD JOYCE
description: The tropical evening air around Central Park's Bandshell made a perfect frame for Verdi's ''Aida'' Thursday, and the New York Grand Opera - heavily microphoned for the large and attentive audience sprawled around it - performed with a fervor and cheerful bombast that fit the setting well.

title: Nazi Newspapers
description: To the Editor:

title: A ROMANTIC FROM LEIPZIG
description: German composers dominated the 19th century, and up until World War I German musicians determined the course of American classical music, as well. They served as the models and pedagogues for our composers; they played in our orchestras and, not least, they were the best-known conductors, world-wide. The First World War began to disrupt all that, with an influx of French, Russian and Italian conductors onto our podiums, and in recent years we have seen the rise of what Klaus Tennstedt calls ''the exotics'' -Zubin Mehta, a Parsi; Seiji Ozawa, a Japanese; Eduardo Mata, a Mexican; Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, a Pole, and even the odd Englishman here and there.

title: WOULD 'STREETCAR' BE A HIT TODAY?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HOUSTONIANS QUICKLY DISCOVER TRUTH AND HUMBUG ABOUT ROACHES
description: Throughout the 1970's, new arrivals streamed into Houston, making it the fastest-growing city in America. One of the things most of the newcomers have some trouble getting used to is the Houston wildlife.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ASUIT aimed at enjoining New York State from proceeding with the construction of a 25-mile superhighway on the South Fork has been dismissed by State Supreme Court Justice Paul J. Baisley. The suit was brought against the state by the Halt the Highway Committee, a group of South Fork residents.

title: Design; RADICAL AFTER A FASHION
description: The question seems simple enough: ''Where do you most like to see the clothing you design?'' The answer, hardly more off-beat: ''On the street.'' And yet from just such an unpropitious exchange grew a radical concept for a new showroom for Williwear, the Seventh Avenue fashion firm headed by the designer Willi Smith and his partner Laurie Mallet.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY In l972, the idea of an ''alternative'' photography gallery did not exist, mainly because at that time there were few galleries devoted to photography, mainstream or otherwise. Inasmuch as photographers needed space in which to show their work, the Emanu-el Midtown YM-YWHA was persuaded to clear out a corridor and, with the help of the New York State Council on the Arts and the collector Robert B. Menschel, the Midtown Y Gallery at 344 E. l4th Street was born.

title: Yearling Brings $1 Million
description: A daughter of Northern Dancer was sold for $1 million today at Fasig-Tipton Kentucky Inc.'s thoroughbred yearling sale.

title: A MUSEUM PUTS ITS COLOR PRINTS ON ICE
description: In the first stage of photography's ''museumization,'' museums recognized photography's claims as an art form by collecting it, exhibiting it and creating departments to specialize in it. In the process the museum -and the gallery network with which it coexists - replaced publishing as the arbiter of what constitutes photography of value. Today, we are witnessing stage two of the museumization process, in which museums cope with the problems of how to store, preserve and display the collections they have assembled. The museum remains the repository of photographic connoisseurship, but the photography curator's essential task has largely changed from one of promotion to one of conservation.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing CART Michigan 500, at Michigan International Speedway, Brooklyn, Mich. Pancho Carter, winner of last year's inaugural, faces challenges from two of the year's hottest drivers, Gordon Johncock and Rick Mears, in the second of the three major 500-mile races of the Indy-car season. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M. to 5:30 P.M.) Baseball Yankees vs. Oakland A's, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. Rickey Henderson, chasing the major league stolenbase record, gets a chance to run for the last time in New York this season. (Television - Channel 11, Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles (Television - Channel 9, Radio - WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240; 4 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, Elmont, L.I., 1:05 P.M. The $200,000 Brooklyn Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at a mile and one-half. This is the third leg of the handicap triple crown, and neither Conquistador Cielo, the Metropolitan winner, nor Silver Buck, the Suburban winner, are entered. (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M., tape) Other Events Basketball: Rucker Pro Summer League, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, West 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, 2 and 4 P.M. The women pros play at 11:30 A.M. Admission is free.

title: JOBLESS RATES CLIMB IN 47 OF THE 50 STATES IN NEW U.S. LISTING
description: All but three states had higher unemployment rates in May than they did in the same month a year ago, the Labor Department has reported.

title: STUFFED CHOPS REVISITED
description: Perhaps it is advancing age, but we find more and more that when a dish is remembered with special pleasure, we tend to reconsider, revise or refine it. This happened again at dinner one evening recently. The woman sitting at our table spoke of a pork chop with rye bread and caraway filling, a recipe she recalled from more than 20 years ago. It then occurred to us to revise that recipe, altering one ingredient here, another ingredient there, and that is how one of the recipes here came about.

title: Letter: A Pointed View
description: To the Editor:

title: THOSE LITTLE SUBURBAN LIES
description: ''HAVE you called the plumber?'' ''Yes, I left a message with the answering service.'' ''Did you tell them it's an emergency?'' ''No, I just asked him to call me back. I'll explain the problem to him when he calls.'' ''He'll never call back. You have to tell them it's an emergency.'' ''But it's not an emergency.'' ''It doesn't matter. If you want to talk to the plumber, you have to tell the answering service that it's an emergency.'' ''But that's a lie.'' I tried to explain to my husband what every housewife who lives in suburbia knows and what every husband who leaves suburbia for the differently attuned existence of the city fails to understand, that is, the necessity of the art form known as the Suburban Lie. Husbands may understand the corporate lie or the legalistic manipulation, but they don't even begin to comprehend the complexity of the lie that makes their suburban lives possible, even pleasurable.

title: NEW PARK SHEDS LIGHT ON PATERSON'S INDUSTRIAL PAST
description: PATERSON WITH the recent opening of Raceway Park in the Great Falls Historic District, this city not only commemorated a major chapter in American industrial history, but also celebrated its continuing efforts to revitalize the derelict mill area that -for better or worse - made Paterson what it is today.

title:
In New Jersey;
BUILDERS OFFER NOVEL LURES
description: THE slump in sales of new homes and condominiums has prompted a few l arge builders to go beyond buying down mortgages for their c ustomers. Now, they are offering to buy down mortgages for their b uyers' buyers.

title: Some Children Are Forgotten
description: Statistics can speak as poignantly as case histories, and for 21,000 New York City children in foster care programs, some of the latest numbers are these: 73 percent of all youngsters up for adoption were still under foster care three years after entering the system; 41 percent of children who expected to be placed with relatives waited at least two years; more than half the children cared for by 69 foster care agencies under contract to the city experienced unspecified delays and frustrations.

title: NEW PROPOSAL DEFERS DECISION ON CLOSING OF BRITISH RAILROADS
description: Britain's state-owned railroad today put off a decision on whether to shut the system down completely when a mediation effort by the Trades Union Congress produced a proposal that satisfied the railroad management.

title: A BIT OF HISTORY
description: GLEN COVE A COUNTRY estate, it was designed in 1900 by Charles Lamb and John Rich, the architects who drew up Sagamore Hill. Its most flamboyant owner was probably John Storm Appleby, and for the last 22 years its graceful roof sheltered the charitable activities of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks.

title: 'LEAVE IT TO GEORGE'
description: Every new Secretary of State since John Foster Dulles has vowed to stay home and preside over the definition and direction of the nation's foreign policy, but the call of the wild blue yonder has been too much for them. George Shultz may be different.

title: Perspectives: Conversion Law; PROTECTIONS WIDENED IN NEW YORK CONVERSIONS
description: THE rights of tenants were expanded substantially in the bill on c ooperative and condominium conversions passed by the Legislature. B ut the lawmakers stopped short of accepting a key revision sought byo rganized tenants that would have made conversions by the nonevictionr oute tougher.

title: JUDGE IN SPOTLIGHT IN PENTHOUSE CASE
description: The judge in the libel suit involving the resort Rancho LaCosta and Penthouse magazine is in an unaccustomed spotlight after his decision last week to overturn the jury's verdict clearing Penthouse.

title: A SCARY DEBATE OVER 'LAUNCH UNDER ATTACK'
description: Launch Under Attack is a nuclear war strategy that is to many thinkers an anathema ranking not far behind preemptive war. But for a supposedly unthinkable idea, it has been much discussed of late. In recent months, a number of American defense policy reports have referred, though mostly negatively, to such a strategy. Briefly defined, it would mean firing some nuclear missiles after getting ''reliable'' electronic warning that enemy missiles are on their way. Last week, Moscow repeated hints that it might embrace the policy.

title: Festival Dates Set
description: The United States Olympic Committee has announced that June 24 to July 3 are the dates for the 1983 National Sports Festival, which will be held here after a twoyear absence.

title: OUTINGS TO NORFOLK, MUSIC MOUNTAIN
description: LAST weekend I took the easy drive to catch the Friday evening concert of the Norfolk Chamber Music Festivals. Then, after attending a student recital Saturday morning, I went over to Music Mountain to participate in a seminar with members of the Manhattan Quartet and some of the young ensembles they're coaching, then to enjoy the Saturday night recital.

title: JoAnne Burger Plans Wedding Next Winter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Burger of New York and Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, JoAnne Burger, to Michael Joseph Caplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Caplan of Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Tonopah
description: To the Editor: The story on ''Tonopah - Survivor of Mining Days'' (Travel, June 27) brought back many memories to this reader.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: 1954, edited by Elliott Mossman. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Letters exchanged between the Russian poet and his cousin. THE DIARY OF VIRGINIA WOOLF: Volume Four, 1931-1935, edited by Anne Olivier Bell.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: WHEN TIGERS FIGHT The Story of the Sino-Japanese War, 1937-45. By Dick Wilson. Illustrated. 269 pp. New York. The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: REMEMBER THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE?
description: ONE unspoken effect of college reunions is the haunting reminder of our human mortality. Life has retouched the images we remember: faces no longer yearbook-perfect, buildings strangely smaller, professors aged but enduring. Change, of course, is inevitable. Seeking fragile outlines of the past, we crave the illusion of stability in a world of flux.

title: IN DEFENSE OF RODIN'S 'GATES OF HELL'
description: To the Editor:

title: Nina Strnad Is Affianced
description: Nina Phelps Strnad and Tracy Nicholas Putnam, 1978 graduates of Harvard, plan to be married Oct. 9. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Strnad of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Lost Tree Village, Fla., who have announced her engagement to the son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Clark Putnam of Pittsford, N.Y.

title: Sarah L. Chapin Becomes a Bride
description: At the Pound Ridge, N.Y., Community Church yesterday Sarah Louise Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Hoyt Chapin of Bedford, N.Y., was married to Frank Carter Henry Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry of Center Sandwich, N.H. The Rev. Richard Monkman performed the ceremony.

title: A Breakthrough More Political Than Scholarly?
description: Two weeks after the Reagan Administration lowered the boom on allies' use of American equipment and technology to build the new Soviet natural gas pipeline to Western Europe, the Commerce Department published excerpts from a study reporting that the Soviet Union was more dependent on foreign trade than previously thought.

title: HE TOOK THE MONEY AND RAN (FOR OFFICE)
description: OTEMPORA! O Mores! The fickle finger of faith has dealt me quite a blow. Why have I been treated so? Stay pilgrim! Before you go, please listen to my tale of woe.

title: No Headline
description: In his article on anti-Semitic vandalism on Long Island, Ernest Volkman speaks of ''an imaginative police effort in one of Long Island's two counties.'' It would be more accurate to speak of such efforts in both of Long Island's counties. Having been involved in the beginnings of both counties' law enforcement efforts, and in virtual daily contact with them, I can say without hesitation that the Nassau and Suffolk County Police Departments have provided exemplary responses to the outbreak of anti-Semitic activity that has plagued Long Island since the late summer of 1979.

title: PRO CAMPS: MUSH FOR THOUGHT
description: TRAINING camp made mush of your mind. It was the routine. Day after day, week after week, you ran the same drills on the same field at the same time with the same players in the same stinking, filthy uniforms ... It was the routine, all right; the relentless repetition of the routine.

title: FOOD IS BECOMING THE CRITICAL PROBLEM IN LEBANON
description: If anyone is starving in west Beirut as a result of the nearly two-week-old Israeli blockade, it is not for want of food but of the money to buy it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the retail drug capital of the world.'' - Sgt. Robert Zink, commander of a special street narcotics squad on the Lower East Side. (1:2.)

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE LIFE OF EZRA POUND, by Noel Stock. (North Point Press, $13.50.) Although this detailed biography was first published in 1970, two years before Ezra Pound's death, it remains the standard work on one of the century's most enigmatic, controversial literary figures and one of our greatest poets. Noel Stock, who had access to Pound's papers, sorts out all the known facts of his career and presents them in unimpassioned, orderly fashion but says relatively little about his work. In a preface to this new edition, Mr. Stock takes note of information that has lately become available.

title: BOWING OUT
description: Dame Janet Baker could go on singing, but she won't - at least not on the operatic stage.

title: RED INK PLAGUES REVAMPED COAST PAPER
description: A two-and-a-half-year effort to revitalize The Oakland Tribune has brought the newspaper more staff, more news space, more commitment to covering the community, more time for investigative projects, more impact on local government, more effect on the lives of the readers. There is even a new morning edition, Eastbay Today, that reaches into San Francisco and other counties around the Bay.

title: SOME SIX LEGGED CREATURES ARE HANDY TO HAVE AROUND
description: Michael B. Trimble is a landscape gardener and freelance writer.

title: POLITICAL CONTRIBUTIONS BY OIL AND GAS GROUPS TOP $3 MILLION
description: The oil and natural gas industry has contributed more than $3 million to 1982 Congressional campaigns, more than any other industry group, a consumer coalition reported in a study made public today.

title:
THEATER IN REVIEW;
A SUMMER PUNCH WITH OUZO
description: MADISON THE rarely seen ''Timon of Athens,'' with its symbolic abstractions of good and evil, is not a completely effective play. To obscure its flaws, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival at Drew University is presenting the work in a nontraditional production that has a bright and hypnotic surface.

title: Gruyeres
description: To the Editor:

title: The Toothbrush
description: After much discussion and dissension, the regents of the University of Hartford rejected the Toothbrush in March 1981, though the planned 24-foot sculpture by Claes Oldenburg would not have cost the school a cent. The National Endowment for the Arts had offered a $25,000 grant, and private donors had agreed to put up another $25,000. Students, however, suggested it was unseemly to spend so much for sculpture when scholarship money was hard to get.

title: SEEING THE ART OF EL GRECO AS NEVER BEFORE; WASHINGTON
description: ''El Greco of Toledo'' at the National Gallery of Art offers us a first-ever opportunity of coming to grips - in one place and under optimum conditions - with virtually the entire career of one of the most distinctive painters who ever held a brush. Such, moreover, is the state of the paintings and the strength of their installation that there can be few visitors to whom the show will not represent a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

title: I.B.M. PROPOSES SEWER LINE AS PART OF NEW CASTLE PROJECT
description: HOMEOWNERS in New Castle appear likely to gain a sewer line if a research laboratory that the International Business Machines Corporation wants to build in the town's western section is approved.

title: 2 WOMEN SHARE LEAD IN GOLF
description: Sandra Haynie, seeking her third consecutive victory on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour, shot a four-under-par 68 today and moved into a tie with Sally Little after three rounds of the $200,000 Mayflower Classic.

title: FAIRS CELEBRATE FARMING LIFE
description: CONNECTICUT's agricultural heritage will be celebrated from one end of the state to the other this summer as country fairs provide residents and visitors with weekends of old-fashioned fun.

title: Isabel Pearce Has Nuptials
description: Isabel Sexton Pearce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Edward Pearce Jr. of Wilmington, Del., and Spring Lake, N.J., was married yesterday to Henry Alfred DePhillips 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. DePhillips Jr. of Wethersfield, Conn. The Very Rev. J. Thomas Cini performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's-on-the-Brandywine Roman Catholic Church in Greenville, Del.

title: WHERE HAVE HOLLYWOOD'S VOICES GONE?
description: John Malone is a New York based freelance writer with a special interest in the arts.

title: Old-Timers to Bat For Peers in Need
description: Many of baseball's legends will be in the lineup one more time Monday night in a five-inning benefit game. The Cracker Jack Old-Timers Baseball Classic will be played at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. Proceeds for the game, which sponsors say will have an advance sale of 25,000, will benefit the Association of Professional Baseball Players of America, many of whose members have fallen on hard times.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: JAZZ String Fever, an all-female 14-piece jazz group led by Marin Alsop, a violinist, is made up of six violins, three violas, three cellists, a string bassist and a drummer, who normally use their unusual instrumentation (unusual, that is, for jazz) to play such classics as Benny Goodman's version of ''Stompin' at the Savoy,'' Woody Herman's ''Four Brothers,'' Dave Brubeck's ''Blue Rondo a la Turk,'' pieces by Duke Ellington and Horace Silver and originals by the ensemble's chief arranger, Gary Anderson, a one-time saxophonist in Mr. Herman's band.

title: DRACULA FLYING AROUND STONY BROOK
description: STONY BROOK IN Act III, Scene Two of ''Dracula'' at the Fine Arts Center's Main Stage, the vampire's coffin ascends from the basement until it becomes level with the stage floor. The moment displays the technical facility of a super theater space, and it's the second-best thing that happens during the performance.

title:
Economic Affairs;
EUROPE SINGS THE BUDGET BLUES, TOO
description: IN my job, I spend a lot of time talking to foreign budget o fficials. They frequently visit me in the United States and I o ccasionally visit them abroad. The accents vary and sometimes there i s a slight difference of emphasis given particular problems. But, f or the most part, the conversations are interchangeable.

title: PATRONAGE BONANZA IN SUFFOLK
description: THE Suffolk Republican chairman, Anthony J. Prudenti, and his allies - the Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, and the Islip Republican leader, Anthony Pace - will have one of the biggest patronage bonanzas in years to dispense shortly: six Supreme, County and Family Court judgeships.

title: Chata Robinson, Hugh Smith Wed
description: Chata Ashley Robinson, daughter of Eileen G. Cumming of Penn Valley, Pa., and Robert J. Robinson of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Hugh Maguire Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard C. Smith of Washington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert S. Curry in Old St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Karen Ekberg Is Engaged
description: An announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Jerome Ekberg of Edina, Minn., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Stewart Ekberg, to Amory Sibley Carhart 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carhart Jr. of New York. A Sept. 25 wedding is planned. Miss Ekberg is a sales representative with Time Inc. The future bridegroom is an assistant vice president in government bond sales for Citibank.

title:
DINING OUT;
ALONG THE HUDSON, INSIDE AND OUT
description: THREE years ago, Thomas McQuade, who owns the Bully Boy Chop House in Congers, N.Y., decided to open a small restaurant with a European touch to it. The Angel Cafe, which sits on the banks of the Hudson River in nearby Nyack, N.Y., is the result.

title:
GARDENING;
WATERING: HOW MUCH AND WHEN
description: PLANNING for gardening problems can make such problems more manageable. The gardener who has anticipated summer's heat and dryness is in a much better position to sit in the shade and relax than someone who has ignored them.

title:
ANTIQUES;
'FESTIVAL' TO AID HALE HOME
description: COVENTRY THE two pine trees that stand like sentinels in front of the main door now soar high above the roofline of the old house. But if Deacon Richard Hale and his family were to ride by their home on South Street here two centuries after it was built, the now luxuriant trees would at first glance be the only real change they would notice on an ordinary day.

title: 3 Yachts Knocked Out In Lake Huron Race
description: The 58th annual yacht race from Port Huron to Mackinac Island got off to a fast start today, with a strong southwest wind accompanying the 279 boats in 15 classes sailing up Lake Huron.

title: Cynthia Horgan Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Marie Horgan, a researcher in the beauty department of Mademoiselle magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Gilbert Whelden Bushnell, an advertising representative with Energy User News, a Fairchild publication in New York. The Rev. Peter Maguire performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Newport, R.I..

title: MATCHBOOKS: A SPARK OF NOSTALGIA
description: When they were new, most matchbooks cost nothing. They came free with each purchase of a pack of cigarettes. As collectibles go today, this once-pervasive form of advertising remains among the least expensive. Rare examples, including matchbooks of the 1939 World's Fair, command as little as $5 each. However, this form of ephemera is now rapidily disappearing, and period examples are increasingly hard to find.

title: Sara L. Merwin Will Be the Bride of R.C. Lumpkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Merwin of San Francisco, formerly of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Lynn Merwin, to Ross Counsil Lumpkin, son of Capt. Pickett Lumpkin, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Lumpkin of San Antonio.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: Investing; WAITING FOR THE LITTLE INVESTOR
description: IF intentions are any guide to the future, individual investors w ill be returning to the stock market in droves by the end of the y ear. That is the word from Sindlinger & Comany, the polling firm in M edia, Pa., that samples investor and consumer attitudes every week.

title: HARTFORD: NEW RULES
description: CONNECTICUT'S legislature has provided new protection for tenants w hose apartments are converted to condominiums and has given more p ower to the state to regulate home-improvement contractors and a partment-listing services.

title: SHIELDING HOME SALE PROFITS FROM TAXES
description: SO you've finally triumphed over the softening real estate market, and have sold your house to someone who can manage the financing. Now comes the task of figuring out how much of your profit you get to keep, and how much you have to share with the tax collector. It can be a tedious and arduous chore, but the rewards are substantial.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HISTORIC REPLAY
description: Back in July of 1776, when news of the Declaration of Independence finally reached Huntington, the local militia had a blast. Its members blew up a statue of George III with gunpowder and then proceeded to make a Liberty Flag. Since Huntington still has a militia, and since it's still July, today at 2 P.M. on the Village Green, where it all happened originally, there will be a re-enactment of the historic event. To round out the encampment, women of the militia will demonstrate crafts of the period, and the unit will demonstrate its mustering and parading skills. This is all free to spectators. The Village Green is off Route 25A.GERSHWIN AND ELLINGTON

title: Elizabeth Bassett Is Married to Dr. John A. Pane
description: Elizabeth Bassett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Putnam Bassett of Fairfield, Conn., and North Pomfret, Vt., was married yesterday to Dr. John Andrew Pane, son of Dr. and Mrs. John T. Pane of Tenafly, N.J. Mary V. Mochary, Mayor of Montclair, N.J., performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: POPULATION PLANNING IS DEBATED IN PHILIPPINES
description: In the Philippines, where families of 10 or more are common, the church and the Government are battling again over the issues of contraception and abortion.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Mergers and Rumors of Mergers

title: HOBOKEN IS CAST AS STATE FILM HUB
description: NEWARK PLANS for Hoboken Stages, the large film studio above Hoboken's railroad terminal, are going according to schedule, thus pleasing the state's Motion Picture and Television Development Commission.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Readying to Get Set For Those Big Exams

title: Mazzei Comfortable As Interim Coach
description: When Julio Mazzei was given the coaching job of the Cosmos last Feb. 22, the stated conditions were familiar: he was named on an interim basis and could be replaced at any time. But Mazzei had been interim coach of the Cosmos once before, so it did not make him uncomfortable.

title: HE FINDS 'THE TIME'S ALWAYS RIGHT' FOR THE BLUES
description: FOR every musician whose name becomes a household word, there must be 50 who survive on the fringes of that fame and bear some responsibility for sustaining it. Many of these ''unknowns'' are unusually gifted and creative players.

title: DOLPHIN COVE SEEKS TO SECEDE
description: STAMFORD FOR several years, residents of the picturesque Dolphin Cove area on Long Island Sound here have believed that they were being shortchanged in city services. Whenever the subject came up at meetings of the Dolphin Cove Club Corporation, which represents the 104 property owners in the area, someone would suggest that Dolphin Cove secede from Stamford and become a part of Greenwich.

title: Man Charged With Arranging Marriages for 9 Illegal Aliens
description: A Jersey City man has been indicted on Federal charges that he arranged marriages for illegal aliens from the Middle East who were seeking permanent resident status in the United States.

title: Carol Kleinman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Kleinman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ann Kleinman, to Dr. Howard S. Kotz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kotz of Syracuse.

title: Nancy Knobloch Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward George Knobloch of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Marie Knobloch, to Sean Patrick Isacsson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Joseph Isacsson of Danbury, Conn.

title: Maile E. King Is Bride Of Alexander N. Feick
description: Maile Elizabeth King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lloyd King of Kailua, Hawaii, was married at her parents' home there yesterday to Alexander Nichols Feick, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Feick Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Stratton, Vt. The Rev. John Heidel, chaplain of the Punahou School in Honolulu, performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: GUILTY AS EVER
description: Alger Hiss was declared the loser and still guilty in Manhattan's Federal District Court last week. Mr. Hiss, a former State Department official who was convicted of perjury in a celebrated espionage case in 1950 and who lost subsequent appeals, had contended that information released under the Freedom of Information Act showed he didn't get a fair trial. District Judge Richard Owen said the new documents raised ''no real question whatsoever, let alone reasonable doubt'' as to his guilt.

title: BRITISH PALACE INTRUSION FASCINATES JAPANESE
description: All through the last week, as the British reacted with shock and amazement to the news that an intruder had entered Buckingham Palace and chatted with Queen Elizabeth II in her bedroom, Japan has been gripped by an empathetic fascination with the London incident.

title: HOW MUSICIANS AND MANAGERS COEXIST
description: Barbara Jepson is a freelance writer with a special interest in music.

title: Around the Nation; Exclusive Sperm Bank To Tighten Its Controls
description: Officials of the sperm bank formed to make available the sperm of geniuses said they would tighten their screening procedures after learning that a Los Angeles woman who is expecting the center's second child is unmarried.

title: Aloma's Ruler Wins by a Nose in Jersey
description: On the right race track, with the right pace, Aloma's Ruler can get to the front and never look back. He did it at Pimlico Race Course two months ago to win the Preakness Stakes, and tonight he did it at Atlantic City Race Course to win the $150,000 Jersey Derby by a nose from Star Choice.

title: It's the One Strong Choice
description: It's the One, second to Silver Buck in the Suburban Handicap, will carry top weight of 124 pounds as the strong favorite in the $200,000 added Brooklyn Handicap today at Belmont Park.

title: Budd Loses On Contract
description: Though normally identified with the auto industry, the emergency call to ''buy American'' has recently moved underground to the nation's subway systems. There it may turn to a whisper.

title: PLAYING THE LEBANESE NUMBERS GAME
description: A recent advertisement by a major oil company contends that ''35,000 people have been killed or wounded in Lebanon.'' By not mentioning the Palestine Liberation Organization, it suggests that the Israelis are waging war on ''the innocent people of Lebanon.'' Others have declared that hundreds of thousands of Lebanese have been made homeless by Israeli bombing. And it has even been said that the Israelis have killed ''thousands of children.'' Now that the first reliable reports are coming out of the war zone, it is, of course, being discovered that all these numbers are wild exaggerations inflated by 1,000 or 2,000 percent. That is scarcely surprising because the original numbers were merely the products of P.L.O. propaganda. Moreover, as the ''innocent people of Lebanon'' are beginning to speak to reporters, it is becoming evident that the vast majority of Lebanese of all faiths deem themselves very fortunate to have been rescued from the disorderly abuses of the P.L.O. - and that, too, is not surprising because long-term occupation by undisciplined gunmen inflicts far worse suffering than short and sharp military action, however powerful in effect.

title: Ticket Fixers
description: A widespread pattern of ticket-fixing by New York State judges was reported by the state's Commission on Judicial Conduct in June 1977. The commission said it had ''documentary evidence'' that more than 250 judges

title: REAGAN BACKS RETIREMENT BILL
description: The Reagan Administration has again endorsed legislation to eliminate mandatory retirement because of age, although it does not favor extending the protection to those over the age of 70 who are seeking jobs or promotions.

title: Letters; On Listings
description: To the Editor:

title: VISIONARY GROTESQUES OF JAPANESE MODERN DANCE
description: Asked what parts of the United States they would like to visit, members of the Japanese dance-theater troupe Dai Rakuda Kan replied: Harlem and the South Bronx. Having just seen this company's joint United States debut with three Japanese modern-dance troupes at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., I found Dai Rakuda Kan's response totally in character.

title: Rose Kennedy Endows Chair
description: Rose Kennedy, saying she wanted to ''do something different'' for her 92d birthday on Tuesday, gave $750,000 today to endow a professorship at the Harvard Medical School to research mental retardation and child neurology. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said his mother was interested in retardation because her oldest daughter, Rosemary, is affected.

title: IRAQIS SAID TO HOLD GROUND AS IRAN RENEWS ATTACK
description: Iran began a new offensive in southern Iraq Friday night, but the Iraqi forces appeared to be holding their ground today, United States officials here said.

title: WHAT'S BEHIND THE MASK
description: The European previews for fall are long since over, and the designers' lines are en route to American stores. But what has not been fully considered is the effect French and Italian designers will have on how women use makeup.

title: Military Analysis
description: An impression is growing among Western military intelligence officers that the Israeli Army is prepared - if diplomatic measures fail - to root out the military elements of the Palestine Liberation Organization in west Beirut.

title: Business Conditions; WHERE THE SAVINGS ARE
description: Congress's effort to encourage savings in last year's mammoth Economic Recovery Tax Act has begun to bear odd fruit. The funds moving into tax-free All-Savers accounts have generally been lower than anticipated, feeding speculation that the controversial program, which allows investors to buy one-year tax-free certificates, may not be renewed at year end, when it is scheduled to expire. But a recent survey shows that activity in Individual Retirement Accounts - I.R.A.'s - is running well ahead of expectations.

title: 24 ARRESTED AS AUTHORITIES SEIZE $28 MILLION IN MARIJUANA IN JERSEY
description: Authorities arrested 24 persons today and seized 70,000 pounds of Colombian marijuana valued at $28 million, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration said.

title: Examining Label Called Senility
description: Anyone over age 65 whose mental and physical abilities are slipping is commonly called senile. As a doctor's diagnosis, however, senility often masks diseases that are reversible but are not being treated, according to a team of brain specialists.

title: Queen Elizabeth, in Hospital, Has Wisdom Tooth Extracted
description: Queen Elizabeth II was admitted to King Edward VII Hospital for Officers on Friday and had a wisdom tooth extracted today, Buckingham Palace announced.

title: Cape Cod
description: To the Editor: The articles on Cape Cod brought memories into clear view on a rainy weekend as I recalled my recent three-year tour of duty as a Coast Guard helicopter pilot on the cape. Our territory covered all the coast (and occasionally inland) from Maine to Rhode Island, including all the islands mentioned in your articles, and a few more as we searched out disabled mariners on dark nights. My bride and I lived on the Upper Cape above a salt marsh where the geese flew low and honked on their graceful approaches to the water as if to draw us out to the natural splendor.

title: 15 Food Establishments Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department has released the names of 15 food establishments that are in violation of the city's health codes. The establishments are: VIOLATIONS Y.I.P. Restaurant, 18 Beaver St. Evita Coffee Shop, 2720 Broadway.

title: The Underground
description: To the Business Editor: One indication of underground economy growth in ''The Underground -No Recession There,'' (July 4) appears every week in the Federal Reserve reports: cash in circulation. For the reporting week published July 3, cash in circulation was $146.1 billion, up about $9 billion from a year ago, while required reserves, an index of demand deposits, was $39.8 billion, down about $1 billion from a year ago. A greater portion of the money supply consists of cash and a smaller portion of checking deposits than a year ago. JESSE BRYANT

title: A GROWING PROBLEM
description: THERE is a jungle walk at Wave Hill in Riverdale. The trail is perfectly safe to walk, however, as no tigers or lions will be encountered. But do look out for the tendrils and twigs of many plants that have gone wild. For Wave Hill has found that its once serene 10-acre woodland overlooking the Hudson River, has been taken over by alien plants that are growing out of control.

title: PEACE GROUPS LIST
description: Following are the names, addresses and telephone numbers of peace groups in New Jersey:

title: Around the World; Wife of Hunger Striker Flies to Soviet Capital
description: Elena Balovlenkov, the American wife of a Soviet hunger striker who is pressing for the right to leave the Soviet Union, flew into Moscow today and said she wanted to talk him out of his fast.

title: A Narrow Perception Of Personnel Function
description: At first reading of the article ''How Not to Get a Job,'' by Robert S. Winkler (July 4), I was astonished at the low esteem in which he places an honorable profession.

title: CHECKS AND IMBALANCES AT THE VATICAN BANK
description: The Vatican Secretary of State, Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, last week announced the appointment of three bankers - one Italian, one Swiss and one American - to investigate all financial dealings between the Vatican bank and the single largest investment bank in Italy, the Banco Ambrosiano of Milan, known as l'Ambro. Cardinal Casaroli emphasized that the Vatican had taken this step at the explicit request of the Vatican bank's president, 60-year-old Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus of Cicero, Ill., who has been in Rome since 1947 and the Vatican bank's president since 1967.

title: Not Exactly A Bedroom Farce
description: An Englishman's home is his castle, but somebody forgot to pull up the drawbridge last weekend at Buckingham Palace. In a breach of royal security that shocked members of Parliament, an astonished Queen Elizabeth II awoke to find an intruder by her bedside at 6:30 A.M.

title: A GAME UNFIT FOR MAN OR BEAST
description: MY brother-in-law is a very respectable fellow; he pays his taxes, has managed to stay out of jail and is still feted on Father's Day by his children. But a few weeks ago a latent sadistic streak emerged from his subconscious. He invited me to play golf.

title: Congress Acts On Sex Charges
description: ''I don't want the American people to think for one minute,'' Representative Thomas F. Harnett, a Republican from South Carolina, thundered during debate last week, ''that this body is full of rogues and dope addicts.'' Especially with elections drawing nigh, he might have added.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Portrait of Dayan A couple of months ago the life of Golda Meir unfolded on television in the person of Ingrid Bergman, who won critical praise for her portrayal. This Sunday afternoon at 3, ABC will present a two-and-ahalf-hour biography of another Israeli statesman: Moshe Dayan - but no one will play his role.

title: PRETORIA'S TACTIC ISOLATES 2 BLACKS
description: Malusi Mpumlwana, a close associate and political heir of the martyred black nationalist Steve Biko, filled out an application this week for a visa that would enable him to return to South Africa to resume his studies for the Anglican priesthood.

title: ALLOWAYS CREEK: A BIT OF UTOPIA ON THE DELAWARE
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK TWP. EVENING hours are especially popular at the ultramodern new swimming pool here, with everyone from children and parents to the elderly joining in the fun.

title: Dr. Joseph Bonn And Jill J. Alling Will Be Married
description: Mrs. Zebulon Bayard Lane Jr. of New York and New Smyrna Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jill Johnson Alling, to Dr. Joseph Bonn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Bonn of Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: 'THE OPUS EPNOYMY': THEORY AND PRACTICE
description: There is something funny going on in book titles. I first noticed it in a bookstore looking at Robert Ludlum's latest thriller, ''The Parsifal Mosaic.'' Beside it were a lot of his others: ''The Bourne Identity,' ''The Matarese Circle,'' ''The Chancellor Manuscript,'' ''The Scarlatti Inheritance.'' It doesn't take a genius to see that here's a man who's not only onto something, he's wrestled it right to the floor.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 18, 1982
description: International A U.S. effort to develop a new, longer-range Middle East policy was begun by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who called in the Israeli and Egyptian Ambassadors and also met all afternoon with Henry A. Kissinger and other Middle East experts. A State Department official said it was possible that Mr. Shultz might ask Mr. Kissinger or other prominent Americans to undertake a special mission to the Middle East. (Page 1, Column 6.) Lebanese and Israeli officials reacted coolly to an offer by the Palestine Liberation Organization to move its fighters to northern Lebanon while negotiations for a settlement of the siege of Beirut continue. (12:5-6.)

title: Food Aloft
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: YELLOWFIN TUNA is the most frequently caught species in New Jersey's recreational canyon fishery, which lies 70 to 90 miles or more offshore.

title: Martha Dixon Plans September Wedding
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Martha Dixon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold V. Dixon of Brooklyn, to John Lindsey Shepard, son of the Rev. and Mrs. John A. Shepard of Portville, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: 10,000 RECORD BY MRS. TABB
description: Mary Decker Tabb, entering an allcomers track meet on the spur of the moment, broke the women's world record by almost 42 seconds in the 10,000 meters Friday night with a time of 31 minutes 35.3 seconds.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bobby Cole has had something else on his mind this week as he competed in the Quad Cities Open golf tournament at Coal Valley, Ill. His wife, Laura Baugh, also a pro golfer, is expecting to give birth tomorrow in Clearwater, Fla., to the couple's first child.

title: YONKERS SUIT FILED ON AUXILIARY ROLE
description: TWO years have elapsed since the state law governing the status and power of auxiliary police units was amended -and, some observers claim, confused. The amendment limited the power of auxiliaries acting as ''peace officers'' to ''periods of attack by enemy forces'' and it mandated new training programs.

title: U.S. Motorcyclist Dies
description: Denny Pyeatt, a 24-year-old motorcyclist from Long Beach, Calif., died today after a crash at a race in Hackney Stadium Friday night. He had represented the United States national team.

title: Around the World; Argentina Restores Political Parties' Rights
description: Political parties in Argentina formally recovered their legal right tofunction today with the lifting of a ban imposed after President Isabel Martinez de Peron was toppled in 1976.

title: PAMELA MACLEAN PLANS FALL BRIDAL
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. MacLean of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Apleby MacLean, to John Wesley Chandler Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Chandler of williamstown, Mass.

title:
ART;
TRENTON MUSEUM IS PAYING TRIBUTE TO 16 LOCAL ARTISTS
description: TRENTON THE Trenton City Museum, in conjunction with the Trenton Artists Workshop Association, is engaged this summer in the highly commendable endeavor of showing the work of local artists. Each month through the end of September, four artists at a time are exhibiting under the collective title of ''Sixteen Artists '82.''

title: Needed: More 'Milestones'
description: The State Department reported progress in the snail-paced negotiations on Namibian independence last week, but others suggested the discussions remained stalled over something few officials would talk about: the ''linkage'' of the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola to that of South African troops from Namibia.

title: THE ALGARVE: POTRTUGAL'S PLACE APART
description: ENID NEMY is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times.

title: WEAVERS OF THE RIO GRANDE
description: CATHERINE C. ROBBINS is a writer who lives in Albuquerque, N.M. BY CATHERINE C.ROBBINS

title: Gloom Lifts At Hospitals
description: Strikes create hardships, but hospital strikes can create fatal ones. Fortunately for about 23,000 patients in New York City last week, a walkout by workers at 40 hospitals ended even before it could officially be declared.

title: Around the World; China Reacts Cautiously To Shultz on Taiwan
description: The Foreign Ministry reacted cautiously today to Secretary of State George P. Shultz's promise to support the sale of defensive weapons to Taiwan.

title: On Language By Frank Mankiewicz Hands On
description: Frank Mankiewicz is president of National Public Radio. William Safire is on vacation.

title: GILBERT AND SULLIVAN--CAN TV OFFER THE DEFINITIVE VERSION?
description: Benedict Nightingale frequently reports on cultural events in London. LONDON ''We are getting very near the limits of human endurance,'' remarks one of the production team, entirely without rancor, as the three exotically dressed gentlemen skip and gambol for a third time down the imitation path, past the imitation bushes and into an imitation bower. There, they brandish the lilies and sunflowers they are holding and strike attitudes apparently intended to combine the eccentricity of Oscar Wilde with the intricacy of a reef knot. ''You hold yourself like this,'' they trill, ''you hold yourself like that. By hook and crook you try to look both angular and flat.'' The camera-director nods. The choreographer looks happy. The stage producer makes it known, from his perch in a van outside, that he is satisfied, too. The conductor takes the earphones off his head. Yet another portion of ''Patience'' is in the bag.

title: Postings; REVIVAL'S REVIVAL
description: The Church of St. Ann and The Holy Trinity, an 1844 Gothic Revival structure in Brooklyn Heights, has the oldest and, some believe, the finest stained glass windows made in this country. When members of the Episcopal congregation began a project to halt the deterioration of their church at Clinton and Montague Streets, they soon learned that it would take more than a pass of the collection plate to meet the $8 million cost.

title: Talking 2d Thoughts; ABORTING A CONTRACT ON A HOME
description: IT is not at all uncommmon for the buyer of a house, condominium or c ooperative to wake up in the middle of night and realize that he hasm ade a mistake. If you are caught in such a situation, there may be n o need to panic. Even if you have signed a contract and put down a 1 0 percent deposit on the property, you may still be able to withdrawf rom the deal and get your money back. Not in all cases, but in many.

title: STRESS REJECTED AS FACTOR IN LICENSING ATOM PLANTS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission says it will not consider possible psychological harm in the licensing of an atomic power plant unless the plant has previously had a ''catastrophic'' accident.

title: CRACKS IN CONCRETE SHOULD BE PATCHED QUICKLY
description: CRACKS in a concrete patio or walk, or in walls made of concrete or stucco, not only are unsightly, but also can cause further damage if they are ignored long enough.

title: 4 Children Drown in Creek
description: Four young brothers and sisters who could not swim drowned Friday when they fell into a 15-foot hole while wading in a creek, Coroner Thomas Streams said. The victims, children of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Frain of West Wheatfield Township, were identified as Teresa, 13 years old; Janie, 10; Johnny, 9, and Diane Hancock, 14, a half-sister. They had gone to wade in Blacklick Creek in Indiana County with several relatives.

title: BEEF IS KING AT TRIO OF RESTAURANTS
description: IN today's cosmetic world of larger-than-life enticements, what you see is all too often not what you get: Kit-Cars belie a VW chassis, million-dollar ballplayers give five-and-ten-cent store performances, high-rise cardboard boxes house more air than cereal.

title: NO TRICKS FOR A KING
description: One might think that kings and queens would enjoy playing games featuring kings and queens. Some medieval monarchs did indeed play chess, but interest has waned in modern times.

title: QUEEN VS. TWO ROOKS
description: The exchange of two rooks for queen-plus-pawn benefits neither player, except when some special feature of the position intervenes to upset the balance.

title: THOROUGHLY MODERN MARGOT
description: DR. ROCKSINGER AND THE AGE OF LONGING By Jill Robinson. 337 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: AQUEDUCT REPAIRS DELAYED IN JERSEY
description: The National Guard distributed cartons of bottled water, restaurants and other businesses were ordered closed and the few Jersey City residents still with water were warned not to drink it as efforts continued today to repair a 72-inch aqueduct that ruptured Thursday.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Back Again To put it positively, this is the season to catch made-for-TV movies you may have missed when they were first shown. In other words, it's re-run time on the commercial networks.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
VISITORS TO THE HOME OF OUR CHILDREN
description: IAM hoping that I am the last generation of my family in exile. My father's fathers, their origins now known only by an act of faith, lived in one place for 800 or more years. My father's father moved his family from Aleppo to Beirut for economic opportunity.

title: Postings; A Legal Guide; Housing Primer
description: Is an oral lease legally binding? Are landlords always entitled to receive their rent? What is a warranty of habitability? When something breaks down, who has to fix it? And what happens if a tenant moves out without notice?

title: Herman Kahn's imagination works only in one direction
description: he is able to plot for us the most grim, farfetched scenarios of ''limited'' nuclear destruction, but he is unable to imagine a world where people live in peace without the constant threat of annihilation.

title: Sports of The Times; Commercializing the Tour
description: WHERE have you gone, Eugene Christophe? Nowadays, the Tour de France is so commercial, so organized, that the racers leave the course in army helicopters, as they did on Friday, taking seconds to go down the mountain after spending 30 grueling minutes going up.

title: A FISTFUL OF GARDEN REMINISCENCES
description: In the early 1950's, a fight manager named Vic Marsilio (he had been a co-manager of Jersey Joe Walcott) was host for a radio sports show from Jack Dempsey's restaurant in New York. One night he invited me to be a guest on his show, and when I asked what we might discuss, he said, "Let's just reminisce about tomorrow's fight at the Garden."

title: Business Conditions; POPCORN'S GROWING POPULARITY
description: A growing number of consumers seem to be discovering that they do not have to go to the movies or the ballpark to eat popcorn. In recent years, sales of one of mankind's oldest snacks have been rising steadily.

title: AFGHANS IN 'IMMIGRATION GULAG' DESERVE MERCY
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
SUMMER: IT'S A SEASON THAT RUNS BY ITS OWN SET OF RULES
description: THESE are the images, the ones that never change: A sprawling Victorian hotel, its turrets and cupolas gleaming white against a chalk-blue sky; a matching blue stripe (the sea) and, between the buildings and the beach, the shell shops, taffy stands and penny arcades that always line the boardwalk.

title: SHADOWS AND OBSESSIONS
description: THE SECRET HISTORY OF THE LORD OF MUSASHI AND ARROWROOT By Junichiro Tanizaki. Translated by Anthony H. Chambers. 199 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: THE SPIRIT OF CHRISTMAS FUTURE
description: THE TERRIBLE TWOS By Ishmael Reed. 178 pp. New York: St. Martin's/Marek. $11.95.

title: CABLE TAKES AIM AT WOMEN
description: There are dozens of visionary theories floating around corporate boardrooms that pertain to the future of cable television, and one of the most popular involves the concept of ''narrowcasting.'' Viewers will be spared the spectacle, we are told, of three giant networks competing for the same huge audience pie with basically similar programs. With greatly increased channel capacities, cable may be more like radio, beaming its fare to special-interest audiences. The future spells programming variety, we are assured. Of course, there are a few skeptics who keep pointing out that the massive web of radio stations blanketing the nation has resulted, for the most part, in little more than a vehicle for transmitting various kinds of popular music. But the undaunted theorists march on.

title: Around the Nation; Detectives Tell of Bribes In Food Stamp Inquiry
description: Undercover detectives were offered a house, four cars, seven television sets and the services of two prostitutes in exchange for food stamps, a Federal prosecutor said in Las Vegas today.

title: The Unsinkable Carrier Admirals
description: Preparing to fight the last war is an old military failing but an understandable one: the next war is not available for study. Less understandable is why the Reagan Administration is preparing to fight the war before last, ignoring the main, fiery lesson of the Falkland conflict.

title: SHE CHAMPIONS THE CAUSE OF INDEPENDENT FILM
description: ''To my mind,'' says Karen Cooper, ''there will always be that segment of the population that is not satisfied with being spoon-fed cinematic cliches and that requires - and lives on - more challenging forms.''

title: Morgan Mansion
description: To the Editor:

title: MAJOR ESPIONAGE SCANDAL REPORTED IN BRITAIN
description: British officials are investigating a major espionage case involving poor security at a top secret communications station, British news organizations said today.

title: Martha Smith Is Married
description: The marriage of Martha Elizabeth Smith and Robert Fletcher Adams, Washington lawyers, took place yesterday in the Great Choir of the Washington Cathedral (SS.

title: Ray Robinson at Home
description: Sugar Ray Robinson, the former welterweight and middleweight boxing champion, has returned to his home in Los Angeles after a week of tests for an undisclosed ailment at Cedars Sinai Hospital. Rumors of a serious ailment arose when both the hospital and members of Robinson's family refused to discuss the nature of the ailment.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITIC'S CHOICES
description: DANCE The swans, heartsick peasant girls and super-athletes of the past dance season have all fled for the summer. In their place are the latest in the anti-heroic, European-style. Take William Forsythe's new ''Say Bye Bye,'' for instance, a ballet billed as a parody of contemporary urban life. The Netherlands Dance Theater will perform it for the first time in New York on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Forsythe is a thoughtful type who is not averse to using brutal political imagery in his ballets. If ''Say Bye Bye'' is anything like his ''Orpheus,'' performed here by the Stuttgart Ballet in 1979, it could be a shocker.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: DARTMOUTH'S STUDENT LOAN PLAN IS A 'STEP FORWARD'
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOW IN SETAUKET FOCUSES ON THINGS PISCATORIAL
description: SETAUKET WITH so much fishing lore in our history and considering the important role that commercial and recreational fishing continue to play in our economy, we Long Islanders are justifiably noted as connoisseurs of all things piscatorial. How, then, could the dwellers of ''fish-shaped Paumanok,'' as Walt Whitman called our domain, not find the current exhibition at Gallery North very much to our liking?

title: Moore Stops Kalule in 10th to Keep Title
description: Davey Moore, who had won the World Boxing Association junior middleweight championship in only his eighth pro fight, today earned the respect that usually goes along with titles in his 11th bout.

title: THE RUBE GOLDBERG EFFECT
description: Do tax cuts pay for themselves? When economist Arthur Laffer captured America's imagination - and Presidential candidate Ronald Reagan's - with his contention that they do, many dismissed the claim of the professor from the University of Southern California as ludicrous.

title:
GARDENING;
WATERING: HOW MUCH AND WHEN
description: PLANNING for gardening problems can make such problems more manageable. The gardener who has anticipated summer's heat and dryness is in a much better position to sit in the shade and relax than someone who has ignored them.

title: SHUBERT'S REBIRTH AS ARTS CENTER AIM OF PROJECT
description: NEW HAVEN THE old Shubert Theater in New Haven, known in its heyday as the ''Birthplace of the Nation's Greatest Hits,'' may never ''recapture its former glory,'' admitted New Haven's Mayor, Biagio DiLieto. But, a proposal to reopen and renovate the Shubert as the centerpiece of a new entertainment, shopping, eating and residential addition, he insists, will result in a ''tremendous attraction'' in his city.

title: Chicago Gets Housing Funds
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne announced Friday that Federal officials had released a $10.6 million subsidy to the Chicago Housing Authority. The announcement came three days after the chairman of the agency resigned. The Federal Housing and Urban Development Department had demanded the ouster of Charles Swibel, a close associate of the Mayor, as a condition for releasing the money.

title: Kathryn Krause To Become Bride
description: The engagement of Kathryn Stearns Krause to James Crane Higgins 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Augustus Krause of Milwaukee, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Decatur Sawyer Higgins of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Higgins.

title: Herman Kahn tries to marry the no-first-use pledge with the ''rearming America'' program, but the partners are incompatible.
description: No first use, if taken seriously (if not, forget it) returns us from the current questionable pursuit of nuclear-war-fighting capability to the old, but not necessarily obsolete posture of mutual assured deterrence. This, in turn, brings back the notion of sufficiency.

title: N.Y.U. WAS THE PIONEER
description: FIVE years ago New York State's Office of Education decided that holders of doctoral degrees in the humanities and social sciences needed business school training to find jobs outside academia. It persuaded New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration to launch a short, intensive summer program in 1978, financed originally with seed money from the state and a two-year grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities. In 1980, N.Y.U. agreed to continue the course on its own.

title: NORTHERN SEA ROBIN; Prionotus carolinus
description: Size: Averages 12 inches, reaches 16 inches. Color: Reddish brown or grayish with dark markings above; yellowish white underneath.

title: A STRIKING NEW FACE WITH THE DUTCH DANCERS
description: There is a striking new face among the members of the Netherlands Dance Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House this season. It is that of Nora Kimball, a dancer who stands out for sheer, exotic beauty of expression and line.

title: Trudeau's Popularity Falls
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's popularity has sunk to an all-time low, and only 28 percent of Canadians now approve of his performance, according to a poll published today. The Gallup poll showed 61 percent disapproved of the way he was handling the job - 3 percentage points more than in the last poll in February. Mr. Trudeau, who has held the post for 13 years, has said he does not intend to run again. The next general election is in 1985.

title: INTERN-TRYOUT PLAN 'TRACKS' ITS STUDENTS
description: SINCE its inception 12 years ago, the student precareer volunteer program at the Westchester division of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center has enabled about 200 college students to test their interest in mental-health careers through an eight-week summer internship. This year, in order to learn more about the interns' subsequent career choices, Ann Eisner, the director of volunteers, drafted a questionnaire for former interns.

title: Military Defeat, Political Gain
description: Yasir Arafat's Palestinians, down but still far from out in west Beirut, managed last week to transform military disaster and a monthlong siege into a political offensive. While the Israelis waited to give American diplomacy a chance to negotiate a Palestinian exit from Lebanon, the Palestine Liberation Organization worked on improving its long-range bargaining position.

title: ANGOLA'S REVOLUTION IS PEDALING ALONG, BUT SLOWLY
description: When Angola achieved independence from Portugal, those bent on creating a new order wrote a slogan that compared their revolution to a bicycle: If you stop pedaling, you fall off.

title: TIM LEARY: A PAINFUL WAIT FOR AN UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: MALIBU, Calif. TIM LEARY remembered the day when he formally became a member of the Mets' pitching staff. A year ago in April, at the age of 22, Leary either lacked perspective or he possessed too much, because he had no idea how important he had become to the future of a baseball team. ''It was no big deal to me,'' Leary remembered.

title: READY OR NOT, THE STRUGGLE FOR CONGRESS HAS STARTED
description: CAMPAIGN 1982 is shaping up to be one of the hardest fought midterm elections in many a year. Democrats who lost control of the Senate in 1980, and often don't seem to be in charge of the House, are hoping for nothing less than a broad repudiation of Reaganomics and other Administration policies, laying the groundwork for an assault on the White House in 1984. Last week, the party unveiled a new television commercial designed to counter an earlier, controversial Republican spot that claims President Reagan is solely responsible for the latest Social Security increase. Republicans, for their part, recognize that G.O.P. losses would make it difficult for the President to have his way on the Hill. Accordingly, it was reported last week that the White House has begun blocking out a fall campaign strategy that, among other things, calls for Mr. Reagan to devote most of his stumping time on the West and Southwest.

title: POWER AUTHORITY IN RESPONSE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE COMPANY OF STRANGERS
description: CORNWALL EVEN before the restaurant that serves quiche, before the boutique that sells pottery and baskets, before the package store with its 22 kinds of imported beer and before the little ice cream shop in the railroad depot, there were ''weekenders'' in Cornwall.

title: USE TV IN COURT FOR THE RECORD, NOT NEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS IN FILM: HOW MOVIEMAKERS HANDLE HOT ISSUES
description: Robert Sklar teaches film at New York University and is the author of ''Movie-Made America.''

title: Ogaden, Again
description: The war by proxy flared again in the Horn of Africa.

title:
GARDENING;
WATERING: HOW MUCH AND WHEN
description: PLANNING for gardening problems can make such problems more manageable. The gardener who has anticipated summer's heat and dryness is in a much better position to sit in the shade and relax than someone who has ignored them.

title: Starling Stops Morgan at 2:06 of the First
description: Seven bus loads of Marlon Starling's fans made the nearly threehour journey from Hartford yesterday to see their hometown hero fight Kevin Morgan of Las Vegas, Nev., for the United States Boxing Association welterweight title at Madison Square Garden. It took them less than three minutes to see Starling win it.

title: CONCERT: MENDELSSOHN AND MOZART
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra's concert Friday at Avery Fisher Hall was just that - one symphony and two concertos by Mozart and a boyhood work from Mendelssohn.

title: Faulty Crash, Murky Clues
description: Defective and outdated flight recorder equipment hampered efforts last week to explain why a Pan American World Airways jetliner crashed minutes after takeoff into a New Orleans suburb nine days ago, killing 154 people. But investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board said they have pieced together some information.

title: TRENTON: FULL AGENDA AHEAD
description: WHEN the New Jersey Legislature returns from summer recess in the f all, it will have a heavy agenda of measures affecting housing to t ake up. At the top of the list is a proposal by Governor Kean c alling for a referendum on whether the state's claims to thousands o f properties once washed by the tides may be settled on terms f avorable to their owners.

title: Wendy Howes Is Wed To William R. Hansen
description: Wendy Griswold Howes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver P. Howes Jr. of Great Neck, L.I., and Roxbury, Conn., was married at the Roxbury Congregational Church yesterday to William Robert Hansen, son of Mrs. Harry John Hansen Jr. of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Mr. Hansen. The Rev. Donald Westerberg performed the ceremony.

title: LOVE CANAL PANEL DIVIDED ON SAFETY
description: A group of 11 scientists consulted by the Federal Government differed sharply in their assessment of whether the neighborhood around the Love Canal chemical dump site in Niagara Falls, N.Y., was safe enough to live in.

title: NEIGHBOR'S DIN ENDS BLASTING
description: WHEN pictures flew off walls and a chunk of ceiling fell down last month in Larchmont Manor, residents were alarmed - especially because the blasting for their new sewer line was scheduled to go on for a year and a half.

title: 2 AGENCIES COLLABORATE TO AID LEBANESE
description: Two organizations of the Red Cross, the Lebanese Red Cross Society and the smaller Palestinian Red Crescent Society, are involved in aiding the sick and wounded in the Beirut area.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW COMMEMORATIVE HONORS JACKIE ROBINSON
description: Jackie Robinson was a great athlete and a man of great courage - and the first black to play major-league baseball. When he signed on with the Brooklyn Dodgers 35 years ago, he paved the way for hundreds of blacks to follow, not only in baseball but in all sports.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A New Jane ''Jane Eyre,'' the Charlotte Bronte novel, arrives on Channel 13 in four parts starting Wednesday evening at 8, offering a new look at a much-filmed heroine. Jane, hired as a governess at that mysterious house, Thornfield Hall, headed by the romantic and tyrannical Mr. Rochester, has inspired at least three pre-talkie films and two with sound: in 1934 (with Virginia Bruce and Colin Clive), and in 1944 (Joan Fontaine and Orson Welles).

title: SNOWPLOWS NEVER OUT OF SEASON IN U.S. PARK
description: The snowplows have not been put away for the summer on Glacier National Park's precipitous Going-tothe-Sun Highway, and there is little chance that they will be.

title: TOP MARONITE MUSCLEMAN MAY COVET THE PRESIDENCY
description: Among the many ''states'' within this fractured country, probably none is more monolithic and powerful than the Maronite Christians headed by Bashir Gemayel, an aggressive 34-yearold lawyer. Mr. Gemayel and his associates control Lebanon's largest private army, estimated at 25,000 men before a reserve call swelled its ranks. His right-wing Christian militiamen disdain the Phalangist label, because of unpleasant associations with Franco's Spain. In Lebanon's crazy quilt of private armies and militias, they call themselves the ''Lebanese forces.''

title: Greek Isles
description: To the Editor:

title: MAINE ASKS 2 STUDIES OF CANADA'S FUNDY DAM
description: Contracts have been awarded for two studies of the potential impact on Maine of a giant tidal dam that Canada has proposed to build in the Bay of Fundy to generate electricity.

title: SCARECROWS POKE FUN AT GREENWICH
description: GREENWICH THE ladies of Greenwich's garden clubs stood in Veva Crozer's yard, scaring crows. They were admiring Madame's flowerbeds when the maid arrived to announce that lunch would be served. But Madame asked the maid to rake a bit first. Granny busily identified the hollyhocks, and Agnes primed for battle with any and all insects, her hand on the trigger of a spraygun of Flit. Poor Pinkie, newcomer that she was, sulked at the fringe of the group, afraid to speak for fear of offending.

title: DEFENSE CONTRACT LIKELY TO LEAD TO GRADUAL RISE IN WORK FORCE
description: THE Air Force's recent choice of the Fairchild Republic Corporation to build 650 jet trainer planes put Fairchild back in the military business after several months of uncertainty.

title: CAR INSURANCE: REFORMS ARE ON THE WAY
description: FINALLY, we are on our way toward significant reforms in automobile insurance, thanks to a package of legislation that has the support not only of both parties in the Legislature but of Governor Kean as well.

title: ENGLISHTOWN: A DAY AT THE RACES
description: ''This is Springsteen Country,'' proclaimed the bumper sticker on a spectator's car at Raceway Park, the New Jersey track where the final rounds in the National Hot Rod Association's Summernational drag races are being held Sunday afternoon. The track is located just a mile or so east of Route 9, the big four-lane highway referred to in ''Born To Run,'' a 1970's hit song by the rock star Bruce Springsteen.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Drop in Lead Poison Data
description: Programs to combat lead poisoning located more than 3,000 children with the ailment in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1982, but the number of children screened, 92,769, was down 35 percent from the previous quarter and was the lowest in five years, the national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. The agency blamed the drop on eight communities that did not report, including Chicago, Detroit and St. Louis.

title: MORE BARK THAN BITE; Old Scores
description: Monteverdi's ''The Coronation of Poppea,'' is one of the earliest grand operas, first produced 340 years ago. Now the Baroque work awaits a more startling reincarnation in a midtown disco, where it will be scored for electronic instruments and performed by rock singers.

title: SYRIA, OFFICIALLY SILENT, SEEMS TO BE BACKING IRAN
description: Syria, which so far has remained silent on the Iranian invasion of Iraq, allowed hundreds of Iranian Revolutionary Guards to hold an anti-Iraqi demonstration here Friday.

title: A CULINARY SURPRISE IN STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD SOME restaurant names telegraph instantly their culinary intentions: Cafe du Fran,caise, The Greenhouse, Viva Quaxaca!, La Scala. No question of the type of cuisine you are likely to experience inside.

title: THOUSANDS FROM HEAD START PICNIC IN PARK
description: On a path near the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, three youngsters struggled to coax their paper-bag kites higher than the park benches that they were running past.

title: OF SUNLIGHT, SHADOWS AND NEW MIDTOWN ZONING RULES
description: Peering up at the massive Equitable Building at 120 Broadway, New York City planners introduced the nation's first zoning ordinance in 1916. Despite that and subsequent laws, however, architects and builders have come to assume that the sky is the limit. As a result, the city's skies have been limited, too. So this year, to help preserve what sunlight it has left, New York became the first city in the nation to limit the amount of sky a building can block.

title: ROLL OF THE DRUM
description: a-d-i-e-s and gentlemen and children of all ages! Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus proudly presents a first in the 123-year history of aerial artistry - Miguel Vasquez, who last weekend performed the elusive quadruple somersault before an astonished audience. The daring 17-year-old flew through air before 7,000 spectators in Tucson and into the hands of his older brother, Juan.

title: ALBANY MEETS ISSUES OF CO-OPS AND LOFTS
description: FEW issues arouse as much passion in the New York Legislature as those relating to housing. Landlords and b uilders have long been generous political givers and effective l obbyists, while tenants are a huge part of the electorate, p articularly in New York City.

title: A LANGUAGE BANK
description: The Westchester Chapter of the American Red Cross has started a language bank to help out in emergency situations where an individual who does not speak English needs an interpreter. So far, 47 people in the county have volunteered their skills in 25 languages and dialects including Estonian, Czechoslovakian, several East Indian dialects, Korean, Mandarin, Cantonese, French, German, Russian, Dutch, Hebrew, Finnish, Danish, Swedish, Spanish, Italian, Arabic and Portuguese.

title: Central America Simmers, Burns
description: The politics of foreign aid to Central America got a lot stickier last week as France resumed arms shipments to Nicaragua, President Reagan vowed to help Honduras combat Nicaraguan ''terrorists,'' and a Congressional committee punished El Salvador.

title: N.F.L. Teams Split On Tests for Drugs
description: Most coaches and executives of National Football League teams say the league's highly publicized drug problems, though real, have been exaggerated. At the same time, despite the objections of the N.F.L. Players Association to drug testing, the Denver Broncos and the Miami Dolphins say they have tested for drugs, some other teams say they may have and others say they are considering such tests.

title: ANTINUCLEAR MOVEMENT: IT'S NO DUD
description: IN RECENT months, I have been watching, with absolute amazement, the enormous growth of the antinuclear movement. In less than a year, the idea of stopping the production of nuclear weapons has taken hold. And just last month, a half-million people converged on the United Nations with that one aim in mind.

title: HE IS BROADWAY'S KING OF THE ROAD
description: Come January, ''Amadeus'' will open in Louisville, Ky., ''Barnum'' will be playing in Toronto. And ''Dancin' '' will come to Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: PALMER IS MOVED BY TRIBUTE
