description: Arnold Palmer, whose victories in 1961 and 1962 helped rejuvenate the British Open's status, received an honorary life membership in the Royal Troon Golf Club this week in a ceremony that was first comical, then ighly emotional.

title: SHULTZ FOCUSING ON A NEW POLICY FOR MIDDLE EAST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz called in the Israeli and Egyptian Ambassadors today and later met all afternoon with Henry A. Kissinger and other experts in an effort to begin to develop a new, longer-range policy for the Middle East, State Department officials said.

title: The Corruption Of Bass Fishing
description: I have been fishing for trout, bass, pike and walleye in the Eastern United States for 15 years, and I was happy to see Robert Strozier's article on bass fishing (''The Lure of Bass Fishing,'' May 30).

title: Finally, E.P.A. Issues Rules On Toxic Waste
description: Critics of the Reagan Administration's drive to reduce government regulations watched at least one figurative fox get chased away from the henhouse last week when new safeguards on hazardous waste disposal were announced. The 500 pages of rules issued by the Environmental Protection Agency were ''tougher than anyone expected,'' said Charles A. Johnson, technical director of a landfill operators group.

title: TENANTS V. 'NONPROFIT' LANDLORDS
description: TWO decisions handed down by state appeals courts in recent months c ould have considerable significance for New York City tenants whose l andlords are nonprofit institutions that claim exemption from rent r egulation.

title: THE AFFORDABLE VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: M any vacationers assume that the only way to savor the rich beaches and warm waters of St. John in the United States Virgin Islands is to check in at Caneel Bay, the luxury Rockresort favored by former President Jimmy Carter and other celebrities. For families whose tastes run in less lavish directions - or who are barred from Caneel Bay either by its cost or the rule against children under 10 years old - there is a readily available alternative: camping.

title: EVICTION NOTICE
description: His creditors complained that Sheik Mohammad al-Fassi didn't merely bounce checks, he fairly dribbled them.

title: HARVARD OFFERS CRAMMING FOR A CORPORATE FUTURE
description: James Croyle got his Ph.D. at Harvard University in political science and since 1974 has been teaching at Washington University in St. Louis. At the age of 40, with two college age childen of his own, Mr. Croyle might have been expected to settle into the comfortable confines of academia.

title: CONCERT: JAMES GALWAY WITH STRINGS OBBLIGATO
description: It may be called the Mostly Mozart Festival, but the first four concerts on Lincoln Center's summer series at Avery Fisher Hall have been almost entirely devoted to James Galway. The admirable Irish flutist was conductor and soloist for the first concert Monday (repeated Wednesday), soloist with the Cleveland Quartet on Tuesday and the unchallenged featured performer for Thursday's sold-out affair, which was billed as another joint appearance with the Cleveland Quartet but which amounted to a Galway recital with strings obbligato.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Business Conditons; OVERSEAS BANKRUPTCIES
description: Although high interest rates and a slumping economy have pushed business failures so far this year to levels not seen since the 1930's, those factors and consequences are not unique to the United States. Economists at Manufacturers Hanover Trust have compiled a roundup of the situation in West Germany, Britain, France and Japan.

title: No Headline
description: Brewers Win by 5-2 For 7th in a Row

title: JoAnn A. Prelich Plans to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Prelich of Garfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, JoAnn Alecia Prelich, to Roger Halloran Goodspeed, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Goodspeed of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Around the Nation; Navy Sentences Officer In Death Aboard Ranger
description: A 15-month investigation into the death of a sailor on the U.S.S. Ranger has ended with the sentencing of a petty officer to three months' confinement at hard labor. The officer was the only one of 28 sailors originally charged in the death to be convicted.

title: Scientific Illiteracy
description: Blame Is Widespread Reading the recent Long Island Opinion article ''Is the United States Falling Into Scientific Illiteracy?'' by George M. Skurla, president of Grumman, really destroyed my Sunday morning. Why is the truth so difficult to accept? As much as it distresses me, I have to acknowledge the fact that Mr. Skurla is expressing those same thoughts concerning education that have been dormant in my mind and just needed a rude awakening.

title: ISRAEL REPLIES TO U.S. ON THE USE OF CLUSTER BOMBS
description: The State Department said today that the United States had received a formal reply from Israel over accusations that it had used American-made cluster bombs in Lebanon in violation of an agreement governing their use.

title: Coming to Terms
description: To the Business Editor: On a recent Sunday (June 20), headlines in The New York Times contained these phrases: ''Chaotic Credit Markets,'' ''Commodities Crumble,'' and ''The Year the Bottom Fell Out for Steel''

title: LAND OF PARADOX
description: ISRAEL NOW Portrait of a Troubled Land. By Lawrence Meyer. 300 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95 By SOL STERN

title: A MEDLEY OF EVENTS JUST OVER THE BORDER
description: THE county is aglow with summer festivals, but if you are willing to drive beyond its borders many other musical enticements also await.

title: New Rules on Child Labor
description: Doing and undoing through regulation what cannot be accomplished or rolled back through legislation is a classic Federal practice, of which the Reagan Administration last week provided a classic example. In proposing to expand the hours and types of jobs that 14- and 15-year-olds can work, the Labor Department offered the first substantial change in child labor provisions in 40 years.

title: 2 RIVAL GROUPS RALLY IN JERSEY OVER ABORTIONS
description: Thousands of opponents of abortion and members of a rival coalition held rallies today less than a mile apart in this suburban community.

title: PURCELL BEATS LENDL IN 3 SETS
description: Mel Purcell upset Ivan Lendl, 2-6, 6-3, 6-2, today and moved into the semifinals of the $200,000 United States Pro tennis championships.

title: Jane Peters to Be Wed To Robert Greenway
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Peters of Allendale and Bay Head, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Costley Peters, to Robert McKinley Greenway, son of Mrs. William Lanford of Winston-Salem, N.C., and the late Harry Greenway of Hollywood, Fla.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Jan MacLarty Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Jan Leslie MacLarty to Charles Phipps Benner, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Angus MacLarty of Pleasantville, N.Y. Mr. Benner is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Benner of Eureka Springs, Ark.

title: WHAT DO MEN WANT?
description: BEING A MAN The Paradox of Masculinity. By Donald H. Bell. 158 pp. Lexington, Mass. Brattleboro, Vermont. The Lewis Publishing Company. $12.95.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A New Means of Expression

title: REAGAN-SHULTZ AXIS READY TO ROLL
description: WASHINGTON FROM the outset, the foreign policy of the Reagan Administration was driven by powerful ideological views and pent-up political forces, by people who felt that the overriding need was to blunt the Soviet challenge. Everything else - arms control, relations with allies, improving ties with developing countries - had to be subordinated to this end. Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. acted as if the only way to halt or derail this locomotive was by throwing his body on the tracks in front of it, frequently in public view. More often than not, the tactic worked, until he overplayed his hand. In a way, his weaknesses, his insecurities and assertiveness, translated into bureaucratic strength.

title: MORE BARK THAN BITE; Reading Tree Leaves
description: Care to guess how many trees there are in Central Park? Guesswork will not be needed when a team of 20 interns - graduate forestry students all - completes its inventory of park trees whose caliper is more than six inches. ''Caliper'' refers to the diameter of a tree at a level four feet above ground.

title: WHERE THE SALMON LEAP
description: EDWARD WEEKS is editor emeritus of the Atlantic Monthly. His latest book is ''Writers and Friends'' (Atlantic-Little, Brown).S ince 1944, skipping very few summers, I have driven with my family from Boston to Fredericton, the capital of New Brunswick. In the old days, when one drove through Maine on the ancient Post Road, State Route 1, it was a two-day trip. If we got off to an early start with all our equipment aboard (not having to go back for my fish box as once occurred), we would reach our favorite lunching place on the north edge of Bangor where the fresh lobster rolls - then priced at 75 cents - were such a delicacy that one was not always enough.

title:
CAMERA;
HOW TO TELL GOOD COLOR PRINTS FROM BAD ONES
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. is a freelance photographer and the author of several books on photography.

title: NO KNOCKOUTS IN THE DEBATING RING
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini was sparring at Grossinger's last week, in preparation for his next fight, at the same time and at the same place that four gubernatorial contenders were doing some shadow boxing of their own.

title: Article 022705 -- No Title
description: The Labor Department reports that it has recovered almost $13 million since March in black lung benefits that had been paid improperly. The department said it had also referred more than 60 cases of suspected fraud to Federal investigators.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
SALE OF EARLY CENTS SCHEDULED FOR NEXT MONTH
description: Early American coppers -the half cents and large cents minted in this nation's early years - once commanded center stage in U.S. numismatics. In recent years they've been shunted aside, but an upcoming event may help put them back in the hobby limelight.

title: COVER-UP IS A PRACTICED ART IN BRAZIL
description: Shortly after a commercial jet crashed on landing in Brasilia recently, a team from Vasp, the airline involved, was dispatched to the runway; its emergency mission was to blot out all mention of the company name on the plane's tail and fuselage.

title: ACTIVISTS APPLAUD SOFT DRINK ACCORD
description: When the Coca-Cola Company and Operation PUSH announced a ''moral covenant'' nearly a year ago to expand black participation in the beverage industry, Coca-Cola officials were accused by many stockholders and other businesses of bowing to blackmail.

title: On Mrs. Gandhi's Team
description: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi got her own team player last week with the election of former Home Affairs Minister Zail Singh to the largely ceremonial job of President. The complaisant Mr. Singh, a Sikh, has said he would sweep the streets if Mrs. Gandhi asked him to. Mr. Singh, who was imprisoned for five years after forming a unit of Mohandas K. Gandhi's Congress Party during India's struggle for freedom, has held a number of ministerial posts since independence in 1947.

title: KENNEDY AND MONDALE BARELY LEAD REAGAN
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator Edward M. Kennedy each came out barely ahead of President Reagan in test votes in the latest Gallup Poll.

title: 209 FRESH AIR FUND CAMPERS STORE UP MEMORIES
description: It was the middle of July, but for 209 boys at Camp Hayden Marks in the Catskills, it was the end of summer. They had spent two weeks in the country as Fresh Air Fund campers, many of them seeing forests and lakes and frogs and lizards for the first time.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE eyes and ears of taxi drivers in Yonkers are about to be employed in the fight against crime. All 265 drivers who have appropriate radios in their cabs have been asked to volunteer to participate in a crime-prevention program. In the course of their duties, they will radio to their dispatchers reports of crimes, emergencies and unusual or suspicious events. The dispatchers, in turn, will call the police.

title: JERSEY CITY WATERFRONT: A RIPPLE EFFECT?
description: JERSEY CITY STRETCHING an imposing 75 stories toward the clouds, the Island Towers project on Jersey City's Hudson River shore would have seemed a reflection of the twin World Trade Center towers.

title: BUSH SHOULD BE G.O.P.'S CHOICE
description: FOR months now, incumbent United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and his proponents have sought to skirt widespread concern over his record by arguing that the Republican nomination for the United States Senate should be decided on the basis of which Republican candidate is more electable.

title: MODELING: NEW FACES FROM OLD FAMILIES
description: Modeling, never considered the most desirable profession by distinguished families for their offspring, seems to be rapidly gaining recruits from the ranks of the well-known and well-to-do.

title: Index; International
description: Guatemala fights rebels with food and religion before guns 3 In Brazil, the cover-up is a much practiced art 3 Espionage scandal of ''gravest'' nature reported in Britain 4 Decision on British rail shutdown is deferred 4 Intruder's entry into British pal- ace fascinates Japanese 5 Schmidt is under attack from the left wing of his party 6 Around the World 7 Population planning is hotly de- bated in the Philippines 8 Israel replies to the U.S. over the use of cluster bombs 10 Red Cross and Red Crescent work together in Lebanon 10 Syria, officially silent, seems to be backing Iran 12 Angola's revolutionary regime pedals along, slowly 16 Government/Politics Documents reveal early concern about Donovan associations 20 Two Democrats lead President Reagan in new Gallup Poll 23 New York State may have to delay tax refunds next year 36 Energy Maine sets up studies of impact of giant tidal dam 15 Energy groups reported to lead in political donations by industry 22 Panel won't consider psychologi- cal harm in licensing plants 28 General Airports buffeted by changes in Federal policies 17 Around the Nation 18 Judge in unaccustomed spotlight after ousting verdict 19 Scientists consulted by U.S. on Love Canal differ on its safety 27 Hiss's latest appeal is denied by Federal judge 35 Industry/Labor Revamped Oakland paper suf- fers sagging revenues 14 May jobless rate up in most states, new listing shows 23 Arts/Entertainment Galway plays in Mostly Mozart series 43 Striking new dancer with Dutch troupe 46 Harry Edeson appears at the Blue Note 46 Grand Opera presents ''Aida'' in Central Park 46 Style Modeling: New faces from old families 47 Obituaries Charles Robberts Swart, South Africa's first State President 32 News Analysis Drew Middleton examines Israeli combat potential inside Beirut 11

title: Kathleen Cohan Married
description: Kathleen Ann Cohan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Edward Cohan of Weston, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Edward Haire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Haire of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Daniel DeVare performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church.

title: Anti-Semitic Vandals
description: Another Explanation I was very impressed by Ernest Volkman's article about anti-Semitic vandalism on Long Island (''Anti-Semitic Vandalism on L.I.: What Are the Causes?,'' Opinion Page). This is a deadly serious issue, and Mr. Volkman has documented the frightening situation very well. I think, however, that his explanation of the phenomenon is somewhat simplistic.

title: Pedestal Watching
description: To the Business Editor: I was delighted to read John B. Schnapp's ''Who for the Pedestal Now?'' (July 11).

title: And a Nice Time Was Had by All
description: Crisis in the Middle East and George P. Shultz's considerable personal and political skills combined last week to make him a shoo-in as Secretary of State. President Reagan's designated successor to Alexander M. Haig Jr. waltzed through confirmation proceedings, receiving unanimous approval from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and full Senate in three days. The next day, he was in Rose Garden taking the oath of office from the Attorney General and hearing the President declare, ''George, welcome to the team.'' Mr. Shultz replied that he looked forward to the opportunity to ''do something wonderful.''

title: IN SEARCH OF THE PERFECT VERMONT INN
description: PAUL GRIMES writes the Practical Traveler column. He was assisted in preparing this article by his wife, Mimi.

title: Elizabeth Lois Adams Will Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Adams of Darien, Conn., and Megansett, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Lois Adams, to Christopher Crowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Crowley of Worcester, Mass., and Megansett.

title: JoAnn McGovern To Marry Oct. 9
description: Joseph A. McGovern of Stoneham, Mass., and Kennebunk Beach, Me., have announced the engagement of his daughter, JoAnn Catherine Mc-Govern, to Michael Dimitri Reed, son of Mrs. Keith Wellin of Greenwich, Conn., and Adrian Reed of Centreville, Md.

title: Soccer Tour in Doubt
description: The future of a $1.6 million soccer tour of South Africa, involving six games in 15 days, was in doubt after two Argentine stars left the touring team yesterday in Johannesburg and three black teams canceled games against the touring squad. Osvaldo Ardiles and Mario Kempes, who played for Argentina in the recent World Cup competition, withdrew because of threats by the Federation Internationale de Football Association (F.I.F.A.), the international governing body of soccer, that it would ban for life players who take part in the tour, which is designed to break South Africa's soccer isolation.

title: PLAYLAND'S SUCCESSES AND FAILURES REVIEWED
description: ''WE made a number of mistakes,'' County Executive Alfred B. Del-Bello said last week, looking back on certain policy decisions made by himself and the Board of Legislators in the operation of the Playland Amusement Park.

title: AND NOW THE VIEW ISN'T ALL
description: THE LONG WHARF in Sag Harbor boasts one of the more splendid waterfront settings on the Island, overlooking a small marina, with Gardiners Bay spread beyond to the horizon.

title: Mind, Body And Autism
description: Autism used to be considered a psychologic disorder, an expression of rage by a child against mother's unconscious rejection. But today it is generally thought to be a developmental disorder caused by damage to the central nervous system from genetic, metabolic, traumatic or infectious factors.

title: Martha A. Miles
description: KEITH SPIRA got carried away by enthusiasm for his vehicle some time ago, and as a result his vehicle won't carry him where it used to.

title: LONDON READIES SOME BUNDLES FOR BROADWAY; LONDON
description: In one way for sure, this fall's Broadway season will resemble most of its predecessors: Leading the parade of major openings will be productions imported intact or in part from London's West End. At the Winter Garden, one can already see a mammoth billboard for ''Cats,'' the hugely successful British musical which will open with an American cast in October. At least three other West End plays - Michael Frayn's ''Noises Off,'' C.P. Taylor's ''Good'' and Nell Dunn's ''Steaming'' - are expected to arrive soon after. If the past is any guide, some of these productions will repeat their London success in New York, while others will induce Anglophobia.

title: FIRST A WRITER, THEN A SPORTSMAN
description: THE RED SMITH READER Edited by Dave Anderson. Foreword by Terence Smith. 308 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.TO ABSENT FRIENDS FROM RED SMITH 478 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95.

title: THE CORPORATE RAIDERS
description: Hostile takeovers are similar to elections in which one side wins the moment it gets 51 percent of the vote. Shareholders of the target company ''vote'' by tendering (or offering) their shares to the bidder of their choice - for instance, Conoco shareholders had to choose among Du Pont, Mobil and Seagram. Each company has an agent - usually a bank - to whom shareholders send forms indicating their desire to tender their shares. Picking a winner means the shareholder is assured of reaping the windfall the bidder is offering. Conoco shareholders who tendered to Du Pont, for example, received $98 a share for stock they may have bought for only $80 a share at the height of the takeover battle. Shareholders who picked a loser, however, missed out on the winners' premium and, in some cases, even sustained a loss. An unlucky investor who bought Conoco for $80 a share and voted with either Mobil or Seagram would ultimately have received Du Pont stock valued at only about $73 a share.

title: UPSURGE IN FIGHTING IN PERSIAN GULF STIRS LITTLE ALARM AT U.N.
description: Although thousands of troops are fighting on the Iraq-Iran border, the latest phase of the conflict appears to have stirred little alarm at the United Nations.

title: Susan Gossling Is Married
description: Susan Elizabeth Gossling, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harry R. Gossling of Bloomfield, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church to Robert Waldo Gray, son of Lieut. Col. Waldo G. Gray, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Gray of Atlantic Beach, Cartaret, N.C. The Rev. Richard W. Gray performed the ceremony. The bride's father is professor of surgery and chairman of the department of orthopedic surgery at the University of Connecticut in Farmington.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
JAZZ IN ENGLEWOOD
description: A daylong jazz festival will be held in Englewood next Saturday. Called the American Festival for Jazz, the event is sponsored by the John Harms Englewood Plaza for the Performing Arts and will take place outside the organization's theater at 30 North Van Brunt Street.

title: Patricia M. Clark Will Be a Bride
description: Commander (U.S.N.-ret.) and Mrs. Gordon E. Clark of New York and Sachem's Head, Guilford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Melanie Clark, to Eric Hollerith Nietsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Erich Nietsch of Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: ENCOURAGING FANS TO VOTE FOR EXCELLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Somali-Ethiopian Battle Reported to Continue
description: Fighting appeared to be continuing along Somalia's border with Ethiopia today despite Somalia's assertion that it had beaten back an invasion force after two weeks of fighting.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MAPS YOUR GAS STATION NEVER HAD
description: ATLANTIC CITY PAUL AND DOROTHY GLASER sell rare books, maps and prints, plus some paintings and small collectibles. Their small shop - Antiquarium, in the Resorts International Hotel-Casino here - has a jumbled and scholarly air.

title: Sewing Up the Budget; Patches For Economy
description: Congress worked overtime last week, tailoring 1982 spending to the White House's measure and taking in the seams on 1983. At the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue, refitters were working nights too, trimming the Administration's expectations for recovery to the flabby facts of economic life. By week's end, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's admission that his prediction that the economy will come ''roaring back'' was ''a little bit of hyperbole'' looked like a little bit of understatement.

title: Official Slain in Peru
description: Fifteen armed men entered the mountain village of Callera, staged a mock trial of Zenon Palomino Flores, 55 years old, the district Governor, on charges of being a police informer, then shot him to death, officials reported. The gunmen then looted stores in the village.

title: Japan's Fast Food
description: To the Editor:

title: IN DEFENSE OF RODIN'S 'GATES OF HELL'
description: To the Editor:$

title: MAZDA GAINS A MARKET BY STAYING WITH THE ROTARY
description: HIROSHIMA, JAPAN IT was nearly 20 years ago, in March 1963, that Kenichi Yamamoto was called into the office of the late Tsunei Matsuda, then the president of the Toyo Kogyo Company, and told that he would lead a team to develop the rotary engine as a practical source of power for automobiles.

title: SEAPORT PLANNERS SET FINANCING GOAL
description: NORWALK THE Maritime Center at Norwalk, a planned seaport attraction unlike any in the nation, will start making headway next month on its course toward realization. It will do so under a set of $32.9 million financing arrangements as intricate and interdependent as the rigging on a square-rigged ship.

title: CORRESPONDENT's CHOICE; ELECTRONIC GADGETRY IN TOKYO
description: STEVE LOHR is a correspondent in the Tokyo bureau of The Times.

title: MORE SPIES IN THE SKY
description: There has been a strange cycle of public indifference and militant activity against the danger of nuclear arms since the first two were dropped. Distressed at failure to understand, Bertrand Russell and Albert Einstein issued a dramatic manifesto in 1955.

title: VIEWS ON BUDGET GIVEN BY CUOMO AND THE MAYOR
description: The two Democrats seeking their party's nomination for Governor offered contrasting views yesterday of the New York State's fiscal health. They were responding to Governor Carey's decision to defer payment of income tax refunds because of what he predicts will be a serious deficit this year.

title: WOMEN'S RIGHTS PARK OPENS UPSTATE
description: Many residents of this small upstate village just off the locks of the State Barge Canal felt uneasy when the feminists came to town two years ago.

title: Another Tack on Medical Costs
description: Greater competition in health care, the Reagan Administration's favorite answer to soaring medical costs, is about to get a thorough trial in California. A new law instructs administrators of health programs for the poor to seek out alternatives to fee-for-service arrangements and authorizes private insurers to do the same.

title: Metering Hard Times
description: Normally, summer is scrambling time for the city's taxi fleets, without enough drivers to keep all their cabs cruising the streets. Not this year.

title: WATSON HAS AIR OF CHAMPION
description: Six hours before Tom Watson became the undisputed golf-playing champion of the world, he sat with a pocket calculator in his third-floor room at the Marine Hotel, high above the 18th hole of Royal Troon. He was figuring the customs duty while his wife, Linda, stuffed souvenirs and cashmere sweaters into their suitcases.

title: EAST GERMANY TRIES TO COPE
description: The woman sharing the compartment on the jolting train to Dresden said she would vacation in Hungary this summer. An East German, she planned to pay her way on holiday by selling in Hungary a pair of salamander shoes and a Carl Zeiss camera lens, both made in West Germany

title: Garvey Hits at N.F.L. Tests
description: Ed Garvey said yesterday that the National Football League Players Association would file charges of unfair labor practices against the N.F.L. Management Council, the league and two teams, the Denver Broncos and the Miami Dolphins.

title: Harvester Rebates
description: The International Harvester Company said it had extended a program of cash rebates and low-interest financing on sales of new farm equipment to July 27. The rebates were slightly increased to a range of $500 to $3,500 on most farm tractors.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chemical Bank announced the retirement of W. Perry Neff as executive vice president for trust and investment. tirement of W. Perry Neff as executive vice president for trust and

title: LARGE AREA SHAKEN
description: A series of huge explosions shook northern Galilee today when an army ammunition dump accidentally blew up.

title: Zimbabwe Gunmen Kill One
description: Gunmen firing automatic weapons attacked a crowded beer hall here, killing one man and wounding nine other people Saturday night, the police said today. The gunmen escaped. The police said they knew of no motive for the attack.

title: Sally Little Shoots 68 to Win by Five
description: Sally Little shot a final-round fourunder-par 68 today to defeat Beth Daniel by five strokes in the $200,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Mayflower Classic.

title: News Analysis
description: A number of isolated incidents over the last few weeks have shaken faith in the world banking system, and many bankers fear that this erosion of confidence could be far more serious than the incidents themselves.

title: DECISION ON PRESS CALLED CONFUSING
description: In a ruling that confused journalists and lawyers, a California judge decided Friday that a reporter was protected from prosecution for refusing to divulge certain unpublished information or confidential sources in court but that the reporter must answer certain questions about that information at a trial.

title: Commodities
description: Contrary Energy Futures

title: DON'T FOCUS ON VINYL TUBING FOR SUBWAY FUMES
description: To the Editor:

title: Ann Sperling Wed To C.E. Archibald
description: The marriage of Ann Sperling, daughter of Donald A. Sperling of New York and the late Joan R. Sperling, to Craig Eugene Archibald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon E. Archibald of Colorado Springs, took place yesterday at the Vale, the former Lyman estate in Waltham, Mass. The Rev. Tom Goldsmith, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. MILITARY TOLD TO USE MORE OUTSIDE CONTRACTORS
description: The Defense Department has ordered the military services to move as many uniformed men and women as possible out of jobs that civilians can do and, in turn, to shift as many civilian jobs as possible to outside contractors.

title: 16 STATES FORCED TO GET U.S. LOANS TO PAY THE JOBLESS
description: Unemployment compensation funds in 16 states are experiencing painful cash squeezes and have to borrow regularly from the Federal Government to pay benefits to jobless workers.

title: DANCE: SECOND STRIDE, FROM BRITAIN, IN DEBUT
description: Second Stride, a modern-dance troupe from Britain featuring the work of three choreographers, made its American debut at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival this weekend.

title: LAUDA WINS EASILY
description: Niki Lauda of Austria took the lead in the 10th lap and held it to win the 76-lap British Grand Prix today.

title: Twins 6, Detroit 1
description: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - Tom Brunansky, Gary Gaetti and Gary Ward hit home runs, and Brad Havens allowed three hits as Minnesota broke Detroit's five-game winning streak.

title: Search for Aunt of Rep. Udall Is Temporarily Discontinued
description: Volunteers and sheriff's deputies called a temporary halt tonight to their search for 81-year-old Emily P. Udall, an aunt of Representative Morris K. Udall who disappeared Friday while driving to a recycling center.

title: SOME RATE EASING SEEN BY TRADERS
description: Predictions of an easier Federal Reserve monetary policy, lower short-term interest rates and a cut in the discount rate are being heard more frequently now after several weeks of slower-than-expected growth in the nation's basic money supply.

title: Trane Sues O'Connor
description: The Trane Company, one of the nation's largest air-conditioning manufacturers, said yesterday that it had filed suit against O'Connor Securities, a private options-trading and risk-arbitrage company in Chicago, charging O'Connor and its partners with fraudulent market manipulation of Trane stock.

title: Peanut Farmers Sue Peanut Butter Maker
description: South Texas peanut farmers have filed suit against the maker of Peter Pan Peanut Butter, saying the company reneged on agreements to buy 15 million pounds of their 1981 crop.

title: BRITISH CHIEF IN ULSTER BUSILY PRESSING FOR SOLUTION
description: James Prior, who became Secretary of State for Northern Ireland reluctantly last September, has gone on to influence the province's affairs more than anyone in recent memory.

title: THE SIX-WEEK WAR
description: It is six weeks today since Israel invaded Lebanon. To say that is to indicate how different this war is from all others in Israel's brief modern history: not a short sharp feat of arms with compelling objectives, not a six-day war, not 1948 or 1973, not Entebbe. And the costs to Israel are heavy in this stillunfinished war.

title: News Analysis
description: In the view of Lebanese and Palestinian officials, negotiations for a settlement of the crisis in Lebanon will remain deadlocked as long the Reagan Administration refuses to choose between two policy options.

title: JOHNCOCK TAKES MICHIGAN 500
description: Gordon Johncock, who had won this year's Indianapolis 500, added a victory today in the $500,000 Norton Michigan 500, a grueling race punctuated by caution flags and crashes that took out A.J. Foyt and Rick Mears.

title: WATSON CAPTURES HIS 4TH BRITISH OPEN CROWN
description: Tom Watson won his fourth British Open championship today and became the fifth golfer to win the British Open and United States Open in the same season.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Missing Bottle

title: CLUB WHERE PROFESSIONAL WOMEN CAN WIND DOWN
description: The Georgetown Women's Club, private and restricted to women, appears to be a success. It opened March 15 and has passed the halfway mark in its goal of 300 members.

title: COUNTERING A LITANY OF ANTI-ISRAEL DISTORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Royals 9, Red Sox 0
description: BOSTON (AP) - Derek Botelho and Mike Armstrong combined on a threehitter, and George Brett, U.L. Washington and Jerry Martin hit homers as Kansas City snapped a seven-game losing streak.

title: Tour Team Wins In South Africa
description: A composite soccer team touring South Africa beat the Amazulu squad of Durban, 1-0, today in the township of Soweto but controversy surrounded the visiting team.

title: MONDAY, JULY 19, 1982; International
description: Poland's military has been unable to turn the economy around after six months of martial law. Although returning visitors say food lines appear shorter, some Poles note that is because food prices have risen, while wages have been frozen. (Page A1.) In neighboring East Germany, curtailed deliveries of Polish coal to the chemical industry have pinched that nation's economy, while Soviet oil has been diverted to Poland, further aggravating the decline. Prices of imported raw materials have soared. (D1.)

title: SILVER SUPREME, $17.60, WINS
description: It doesn't take outstanding horses to put on an outstanding horse race. An unusually small and weak field of six turned out for the $219,500 Brooklyn Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park, but at the top of the stretch five horses were spread out across the track and it looked like anyone's race. A furlong later, Silver Supreme had drawn off to a two-length victory over Princelet, and the heavily-favored It's the One had faded to finish fifth.

title: BLUNTLY SPEAKING, STEARNS LEADS METS
description: THE only player on the Mets who made the National League's All-Star team and tackled a fan in Shea Stadium this year is John Stearns. He is blunt and sometimes impetuous. He rubs people because of his military manner. He plays, even tangles, as though he was still the safety for the University of Colorado football team. He is ''the Dude,'' the strutter.

title: STATE BOTTLE LAW UPSETS INDUSTRY
description: To hear the brewers, bottlers and grocers tell it, the recent passage of a New York State law requiring a 5-cent deposit on soda and beer containers is nothing short of calamity.

title: TAIWAN ARMS SALES CRITICIZED
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson, a Washington Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, said today that the Administration ''would be making a serious mistake'' in providing additional arms to Taiwan.

title: RECOVERY RECEDES IN FORECAST
description: Waiting for the recovery may take longer than some economists hadpreviously thought. That is the lesson emerging from recent economic reports, which add up to an economy that is still shrinking.

title: Coast Guard Replacing Kaufman With Uniworld
description: The Coast Guard has retained the Uniworld Group in New York to do its recruitment advertising, replacing Henry J. Kaufman & Associates, Washington, its agency for 18 years. It is interesting that Uniworld is an agency that specializes in reaching the black and Hispanic markets, as is the Vanguard Advertising Agency, which, with Goldberg/Marchesano & Associates, Washington, were the other two finalists.

title: Deborah Robins Married to Richard T. Markovitz
description: The marriage of Deborah Phyllis Robins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sy Raymond Robins of New York, to Richard Tyler Markovitz took place yesterday in Brentwood, Calif.

title: Siamese Twins Separated
description: Siamese twin boys, whose parents were accused of ordering food withheld from them after their birth a year ago, were in critical but stable condition today after undergoing surgery to separate them. The boys, Jeff and Scott Mueller, who were joined at the pelvis, underwent nine hours of surgery Thursday at Children's Memorial Hospital.

title: Netting Errant Fines
description: Professional tennis players seem to be quick to collect the rich purse money that is being offered these days, but many of them apparently are slow in paying fines that they are assessed. M. Marshall Happer 3d, the administrator for the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, announced recently that $431,700 was outstanding from players for fines incurred over the last few years.

title: PENN SQUARE'S OIL CONNECTION
description: The Penn Square Bank, closed by Federal regulators two weeks ago, was known for a certain flamboyance. To woo officers of the big Northern banks to whom it ultimately sold more than $2 billion in energy loans, executives were in the habit of taking them to local Western bars, where, on at least one occasion, a top official entertained his delighted visitors by drinking beer out of a cowboy boot.

title: First Title for Stewart
description: Payne Stewart shot a sevenunder-par 63, tying a tournament record, as he won the rain-delayed Quad Cities Open by two shots today. The victory was his first on the PGA Tour.

title: DANCE: NIKOLAIS PREMIERES AT DUKE
description: Because of Alwin Nikolais's ability to design animated props, stretchable costumes and chameleonlike lighting changes, everyone agrees that he is a clever showman. Yet audiences tend to divide into two groups in their estimation of his effects. If, for some dancegoers, they are essential components of his choreography, others regard them as tricks, or even as gimmicks that get in the way of the choreography. Therefore they urge Mr. Nikolais to use them sparingly.

title: TO THE BEACHES! OIL RIGS ARE COMING!
description: From Maine to Florida to California to Alaska, thousands of miles of America's coastline have long provided Americans with fishing, tourism, spiritual nourishment and a special way of life. Now all of this has been endangered by Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt's proposal for an unprecedented crash program to accelerate oil and gas drilling off the nation's coasts. California's spectacularly rugged Big Sur, New England's prime lobster and fishing areas and the magnificent icy bays along Alaska's coasts could be ravaged if Mr. Watt's irresponsible and reckless program is not stopped.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Crimes of Dispassion

title: TITLE BOUT PUT OFF
description: In what has become the custom this year in boxing, two more major title fights were postponed yesterday because of training injuries. Both the Mike Weaver-Randall (Tex) Cobb World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight and the Eusebio Pedroza-Bernard Taylor W.B.A. featherweight title match will not be held as scheduled.

title: Precinct 23; One Neighborhood Battles Crime; A series of articles appearing periodically.
description: Joseph McCallion paced the corner of Second Avenue and 86th Street the other day, searching frantically for a police car. A worried look on his boyish face, a sheaf of papers in his hand, he was soon grumbling like any other New Yorker who needs a police officer and can't find one.

title: Creeping Up on Hazardous Waste
description: The Environmental Protection Agency deserves modest credit for the new rules it has issued for governing hazardous waste dumps. But the rules are stronger in their philosophy than in the hard, regulatory detail that is necessary to tackle a long-neglected problem.

title: BREWERS ROUT WHITE SOX, 9-3
description: Don Money, Charlie Moore and Jim Gantner hit run-scoring singles in a six-run second inning, and the Milwaukee Brewers made 14 hits to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 9-3, today.

title: PEKING: BALANCING SOVIETS AND U.S.
description: The recent flurry of positive gestures between Moscow and Peking has coincided with a tense period in Chinese-American relations. This has prompted speculation that a few steps could become a headlong rush by China toward a rapprochement with the Soviet Union that would leave Washington peering through the dust at a new strategic landscape. But Peking, like Washington, has a complex strategy for coping with Soviet power that includes talking with Moscow as well as building alliances and strengthening military capabilities.

title: A Mountain's Best Friends
description: Although a climb up Mount Moosilauke in New Hampshire nine days ago was planned as a celebration of the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Intercollegiate Outing Club Association, there was some wistfulness beforehand and even some fear for the future connected with the ascent of the 4,802-foot peak.

title: WHAT PRICE KEEPING THE PUBLIC IN THE DARK?
description: To the Editor:

title: Radio Station Skips Summer Advertising
description: To fans of the advertising business, it comes as a bit of a surprise to see a TV commercial for radio station WAPP promising listeners a summer free of advertising. There is not, of course, any other income source for a radio station than dear old advertising.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE IRISH TOUCH

title: WILLIAM TAMPLIN, PUBLISHER, IS DEAD
description: William R. Tamplin, publisher and editor of The Marco Island (Fla.) Eagle, died Saturday of cancer at a Naples, Fla., hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Coast Highway Officer Slain
description: A 31-year-old man recently released from a mental institution shot and killed a California Highway Patrolman Saturday night.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. In their five previous seasons, the Mariners never reached the .500 mark, but they are a surprising contender this year under Rene Lachemann.

title: Hernandez Homer Lifts Cards
description: Keith Hernandez hit a three-run homer today to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to their third straight victory, a 6-5 triumph over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: SORTING OUT A CHILD'S NIGHTMARE
description: ACCORDING to experts there are two kinds of bad dreams that young c hildren experience: the nightmare, which is quite common, and night t error, which affects approximately 3 percent of all children.

title: Jets' Guard Of Honor
description: HE was built to last. And he did. Randy Rasmussen's thick legs resemble the bales of hay he hauled while growing up on a Nebraska farm. But he's 37 years old now and after 15 seasons as a guard with the New York Jets, he won't be reporting to training camp. It's the Jets' loss, not his. He was their touch of class, their last link to the Super Bowl III champions, their guard of honor.

title: Fiji's Ruling Party Wins Narrow Election Victory
description: The ruling party of Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara narrowly defeated the Indian-led opposition here today in general elections that were marred by racial tension and charges of foreign intervention.

title: RCA Canada Plant
description: The RCA Corporations's RCA Inc. color television picture tube plant will close at the end of the year, laying off about 600 workers.

title: TV: RAILWAY SERIES STARTS IN INDIA
description: MORE people love trains than ever knew it. Faced with the shrinkage or near extinction of the service in the United States, they fantasize. There is a public for the train book, the train magazine and the train record. At auction scale-model locomotives of the 1920's and 30's are beginning to rank with the Faberge egg and the firstedition Cartier watch. It's onward and upward with the dream of the train, even if we can't quite afford to take the remodeled Orient Express.

title: NEW FEDERAL APPEALS JUDGES LIKELY TO MAINTAIN COURT'S TENOR
description: President Reagan's appointment of four new judges for the Federal appeals court in Manhattan constitutes the most sweeping change of the court's membership in more than a decade.

title: YANKEES WIN, 7-3
description: Three players making comebacks of different sorts exceled yesterday in the Yankees' 7-3 victory that completed a four-game sweep of Billy Martin's sagging A's.

title: Smith Blames Politics In Return of $50,000
description: Attorney General William French Smith says he turned back a $50,000 severance payment and gave up large Federal tax deductions because Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was making them a political issue. Mr. Smith said that he still believed his actions regarding both were entirely proper.

title: ARMS FREEZE ISSUE DOMINATES A HOUSE CAMPAIGN
description: The Salem Common, where in 1969 a crowd of 6,000 rallied to denounce the Vietnam War and where the militia mustered in earlier centuries, was the oral battleground Saturday in a Congressional race focused on 1982's political concern over war and peace, the nuclear freeze issue.

title: ANTINUCLEAR GROUP, 25, GATHERS IN NOVA SCOTIA
description: The morning of Aug. 6, 1945, was clear and sunny, Prof. Iwao Ogawa remembers. At the time, he was helping his students at the Imperial Japanese Naval Academy, 10 miles south of Hiroshima, build a bomb shelter.

title: NEW YORK HEAT CLIMBS TO 98, AND MORE OF IT IS PREDICTED
description: The hottest day of the year baked the pavements and parks of metropolitan New York yesterday, sending residents fleeing to anything wet, cold or air-conditioned.

title: REVUE: 'ALL OF THE ABOVE'
description: ''ALL OF THE ABOVE'' is a musical revue in which the songs are listed alphabetically in the program rather than in the order in which they are sung at the Perry Street Theater. This suggests that those who are in charge of this hourlong production, primarily Michael Eisenberg, listed as author and composer, and Tony Berk, who directed it, were not sure where anything would go and were just winging it.

title: Heavy Toll To the Editor:$
description: Now that the toll on the Henry Hudson Bridge has been raised from 60 to 90 cents, one would expect the revenue to be used to improve the West Side Highway between the bridge and the Riverside Drive-G.W. Bridge exit. It has been in a deplorable state for years, with enough pot holes, bumps and protruding plates to damage the undercarriage of the sturdiest vehicle. Lack of proper drainage causes extensive flooding and slippery conditions after every heavy rainfall, not to mention snow and ice. EVA JACOBY Bronx, June 24, 1982

title: ISRAELIS CONCEDE AND DEFEND USE OF CLUSTER BOMB
description: Israel has officially acknowledged to the United States that it used cluster bomb weapons in its invasion of Lebanon, but has asserted that its actions were consistent with Israeli-American agreements on the use of those weapons, according to Israeli sources here familiar with the message.

title: The Future Of Oil Prices
description: THE Administration, after months of strenuous private debate, has decided that the question of how high oil prices might soar in a future emergency is too sensitive to even ask.

title: OUTDOORS: MORE THAN ONE WAY TO CATCH A BLUEFISH
description: WHEN bluefish are plentiful, taking them with a flyrod is a good way to enliven an endeavor that can quickly become rather humdrum. Bluefish are marvelously athletic and they never hit a lure in lackadaisical fashion. But after the initial excitement of getting into the first of the year of the species to appear -after one has hauled 40 or 50 of them through the surf to the beach in two or three trips - the average long-time angler becomes rather jaded.

title: Tribute by Stargell
description: Willie Stargell, the father figure in the Pittsburgh Pirates ''family,'' has announced that he will be retiring this fall after his 20th major league baseball season. But after the 42-year-old Stargell takes off his uniform for the last time, he will begin a project that he considers ''nonpolitical, non-sports-connected, warm, clear, honest and nice.''

title: INQUIRY ON CSONKA AND KIICK REPORTED
description: Larry Csonka and Jim Kiick, the former Miami Dolphins running backs, were investigated by Federal agents for their possible link to a multimillion-dollar marijuana organization, according to a newspaper article published today.

title: The Ordeals of the Chosen
description: DURING the ride from Rochester on Saturday, Sammy Ellis and Dave Righetti had six hours to kibitz in the car, and they did. Ellis talked about his days as a major league pitcher, Righetti went on happily about his dad and his dad's minor league days, and both teased each other about their botched shots during several rounds of golf last spring.

title: Talk of the Game
description: Terry Cashman, who grew up in Inwood, N.Y., has had a passion for baseball for all of his 40 years. He was good enough to be signed as a pitcher by the Detroit Tigers in 1959, but he was not good enough to last in the game longer than two years that were spent mostly in Alabama and Florida.

title: Guatemalan Army Says It Killed 22 Guerrillas
description: A female guerrilla commander and 21 other leftist rebels died in weekend clashes with Government troops that netted caches of rebel weapons, army spokesmen said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Le Anne Schreiber THE WOODS. By David Plante. New York: Atheneum. 123 pages. $8.95.

title: POLAROID'S JOB CUTS TOOK KEY WORKERS
description: When Theodore N. Voss arrived in Sunnyvale, Calif., two weeks ago, one of the first things he saw was a billboard with his name on it: ''So long, Ted,'' the sign read. ''Don't forget to write your friends at Polaroid.''

title: Blue Jays 5, Rangers 4
description: TORONTO (AP) - Alfredo Griffin hit a two-out, run-scoring single in the 10th inning as Toronto completed a four-game sweep. Griffin, who last week tied Toronto's team record with six consecutive hits, singled to right-center off Danny Darwin (6-4) to drive in Anthony Johnson from second base.

title: BASRA IS IRAQ'S KEY OIL CITY
description: Basra, which is apparently the target of Iran's push into Iraqi territory, is a city of half a million people and a key center of the country's oil industry.

title: Somalia Says Its Forces Repulsed Ethiopians
description: The Defense Ministry said today that Ethiopian mechanized units and ground forces advanced across two fronts in the disputed Ogaden region today, pouring across the border in renewed battles against Somali Government troops.

title: POLAND'S ECONOMIC PROBLEMS PERSIST DESPITE SURFACE GAINS
description: After six months of martial law, Poland's economic crisis seems no nearer a solution than last summer, when the now banned Solidarity trade union movement was at the height of its power.

title: BRONX IS GETTING 2 NEW PROGRAMS TO FIGHT ARSON
description: Two programs to fight arson,credited with success in other parts of New York City but with eld from the Bronx because of rivalry between the Fire and Police Departments, will both be operating in the borough starting today.

title: Shorter Captures Middletown Race
description: Frank Shorter, running over the roads he had trained on for years, outdistanced a field of about 2,000 in the 10-kilometer (6.2-mile) Orange Classic today. He led the entire way and finished in 29 minutes 18.4 seconds.

title: By Majorie Hunter; The Calendar
description: Monday

title: NOGUCHI GETS MACDOWELL MEDAL FOR A LIFE'S WORK
description: Isamu Noguchi, the 77-year-old Japanese-American sculptor whose mysterious, seemingly animate blocks of stone have helped sustain a faith in the sacred role of art through the post-World War II era, was awarded the Edward MacDowell Medal yesterday for outstanding lifelong contribution to the arts.

title: N.Y.A.C. Rowers Take U.S. Title
description: New York Athletic Club rowers overcame a strong challenge by the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia to take the Barnes Trophy and the team victory today in the 106th annual national men's rowing championship.

title: COUNTERING A LITANY OF ANTI-ISRAEL DISTORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTION BOX
description: S. Lee Kanner QUESTION: In the bottom of the ninth, with two outs and a runner on first, the batter hits a home run that barely drops into the rightfield stands. In his enthusiasm, he passes the runner, who has been hesitating to make sure the ball is not caught, between first and second, and scores ahead of him. What is the ruling? Also, in the same situation, but without a man on base, the home-run hitter fails to touch second. He realizes this after he passes third and attempts to return to touch second. Is this legal?

title: Barbara LeNoble Wed To Robert J. Warren
description: Barbara Frances LeNoble, a fund raiser with the national office of the United Cerebral Palsy Association Inc., was married yesterday to Robert James Warren, an associate with the New York law firm of White & Case. Rabbi Meyer Miller performed the ceremony at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Electro Rent Officer Sees Outlook Enhanced

title: Prudhomme Wins
description: Don Prudhomme captured his third straight Funny Car title today in the National Hot Rod Association Summernationals at Raceway Park. The 42-year-old Californian drove a Pontiac Trans-Am across the quarter-mile track in 6 seconds, averaging 241.28 miles an hour. Mark Oswald of Cincinnati won the Top Fuel title.

title: Pennsylvania Officials Study Boating Accident
description: Officials today began trying to determine what caused a motorboat to hit a lake ferry packed with college students on a sorority outing, killing two women and injuring more than 30 other people.

title: COUNTERING A LITANY OF ANTI-ISRAEL DISTORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: FOLK STYLE OF PETER GRIGGS
description: MUSIC by Peter Griggs was played last Monday night on a converted coffee barge at the Fulton Ferry Landing, just below the Brooklyn Bridge. The barge - air-conditioned, slightly bohemian, wood paneled, shifting occasionally from side to side - is the home of Bargemusic Ltd.

title: Bridge: Big Apple Championships Feature Interesting Names
description: Some interesting names surfaced at the Big Apple Regional Championships played during the weekend at the New York Hilton. In the knockout team event, one foursome in the semifinal stage yesterday afternoon was headed by the financier Mel Skolnik of Newport Beach, Calif.

title: Indians 5, Angels 4
description: CLEVELAND (UPI) - Bill Nahorodny pinch hit a double for two runs with two out in the ninth inning as Cleveland won despite two homers by Doug DeCinces.

title: Giddings And AMCA To Merge
description: AMCA International Ltd. of Montreal raised its offer to acquire Giddings & Lewis Inc. to $30 a share from $25 and Giddings accepted the offer, the companies are scheduled to announce today.

title: Talking Back to the Tube
description: How do you talk back if you feel aggrieved by what's on the tube? Retired General William Westmoreland was so stung by a CBS documentary last January that he called a press conference and raised a storm. There will now be a second documentary to consider the case made in ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception.''

title: Orioles 4, Mariners 3
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Ken Singleton hit a three-run homer to lead Baltimore. Singleton, who knocked in four runs in Saturday's 8-4 decision over Seattle, hit his seventh homer in the third inning following two walks by Mike Moore (4-7). Singleton has 20 homers and 60 runs batted in during 57 career games against the Mariners.

title: Officials Say Slain Sniper Was Mentally Troubled
description: A man who shot and killed two people from the porch of his second-floor apartment before the police killed him was known to be mentally troubled, officers said today.

title: It's Only a Game
description: ''I tell you, I'm not responsible for what I don't hold,'' protested the woman from Brooklyn's Mill Basin Bridge Club, near tears and leaning her head against a corridor wall at the New York Hilton yesterday.

title: Claiborne Will Race Again
description: Although Lexington is crowded with buyers from round the world bidding at the Keeneland yearling sales for horses from Kentucky's top farms, one renowned breeder is not represented.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 19, 1982
description: International Iraqis are fighting fiercely to repel an Iranian invasion of southern Iraq. The fighting has continued for five consecutive days near the port of Basra, the apparent target of the Iranian thrust, according to a report by the Iraqi high command. The statement did not make clear whether the fighting was taking place inside Iraq. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel has officially acknowledged to the United States that it used cluster bombs in its invasion of Lebanon, according to diplomats familiar with an Israeli message delivered Friday. But the Israelis said that the actions were consistent with Israeli-American agreements on the use of those weapons, the diplomats said. (A1:5.)

title: Smiles of a Summer Night
description: For the Guangdong Yue Opera of China at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, the Saturday night audience was predominantly Chinese: families, couples young or elderly and infants who did not cry, content in comforting arms under the spell of the music and the fluttering of butterfly fans.

title: WEST SIDE LUXURY HOUSING PLAN GAINING
description: A proposal to turn the largest remaining expanse of undeveloped land in Manhattan into the Lincoln West luxury-housing complex is headed for the city's Planning Commission today, and top Koch administration officials say they expect it to be approved.

title: SOME INDUSTRIES LAG IN JAPANESE ECONOMY
description: A report on labor productivity, released in Japan last week, underlined a fundamental gap in how well Japanese industries perform. It is a difference that Westerners focusing on the ''Japanese challenge'' tend not to notice.

title: IT'S A BIG SUMMER FOR ARTS IN THE CITY
description: Despite somber reports on the economy throughout the country, New York City is bustling with cultural activity this summer - in some areas perhaps more so than it was a year ago.

title: One-Legged Man Scales 14,408-Foot Mt. Rainier
description: A one-legged mountain climber fulfilled a 10-year dream today by ''hopping to the top'' of 14,408-foot Mount Rainier and planting flags in the name of the handicapped.

title: WHEN TEL AVIV WAS 'WEST BEIRUT'
description: I remember another ''west Beirut.'' Then it was Tel Aviv. The year was 1947. To recall it now may help the Israelis understand the besieged Palestinians and learn, as the British did then, the limits of overwhelming military power when confronted with a nationalism desperate enough to gamble on suicide. No one should be able to see the point more clearly than Menachem Begin: he was then the besieged.

title: METS WIN, 8-3, FROM DODGERS
description: Frustrated by their inability to hold leads that Dave Kingman's home runs had given them the previous two nights, the Mets tried something completely different today.

title: Robinson Is First
description: Rudy Robinson of the North Shore Track Club won the New York Road Runners Club's fourth annual four-mile Benefit Run in 19 minutes yesterday in Central Park. Jessie McCutcheon of Adelphi University was 400 yards off the pace in second place, in 19:59. Anna Thornhill of the Millrose Athletic Association captured the women's title in 25:01.4.

title: VILAS AND PURCELL REACH U.S. PRO FINAL
description: Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas defeated Yannick Noah, and Mel Purcell beat the heat and Fernando Luna today to reach the final of the $200,000 United States Pro tennis championships.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The man on foot has become like the bald eagle. He's almost extinct.''

title: D'Amato Visits Lebanon
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, toured suburban Beirut today and said that if Israel invaded the besieged western sector of the capital, the costs to the Israelis, trapped Palestinians and half a million civilians ''will be tragic.''

title: STUDY SEES SHIFT IN U.S. POPULATION
description: The proportion of Americans who are white and of European ancestry, the nation's basic ethnic stock since Colonial days, will decline at an accelerating rate in the next two decades, according to an analysis of population trends by a California research organization.

title: Rights Unit Bids Reagan Keep Ban on Arms for Argentina
description: Americas Watch, a New York-based nonprofit organization that reports on human rights conditions in Latin America, said over the weekend that President Reagan should not lift a ban on military sales to Argentina because of that country's poor human rights record.

title: THE BATTLE OF THE SOCIAL SECURITY ADS
description: It was the Republicans who drew first blood in the battle of the Social Security television commercials on Capitol Hill. They produced a commercial showing an elderly postman walking down the steps of a house that evokes turn-of-the-century America.

title: Market Place; New Demand For Municpals
description: ''WE'RE doing more municipal business at the retail level than ever before,'' Alan W. Leeds, a partner at L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, remarked Friday. ''The public demand is quite gratifying.''

title: SANCHEZ: THE 100 PERCENT BOXER
description: pound limit.

title: S.C.T. in Accord
description: The Standard-Coosa-Thatcher Company, a Chatanooga, Tenn., textile maker, said yesterday it had agreed with Technical Equipment Leasing and Hickory Furniture that the Technical group would drop its $60-ashare tender offer for 36.9 percent of S.C.T., which in turn would pay the group $300,000 in legal fees and end all litigation. S.C.T. said it would continue with a previous agreement to be acquired by a group of its executives in conjunction with Wolsey & Company, a New York investment firm, for about $28 million, or $53 a share.

title: COSMOS TROUNCE TIMBERS, 6-2
description: The Cosmos tore apart the best defense in the North American Soccer League tonight for their largest production of goals in 25 months at Giants Stadium.

title: PARK OPERA: 'LA TRAVIATA'
description: THE New York City Opera piled singers, sets, orchestra and equipment onto trucks and buses Saturday night and shipped itself out to Long Island's Eisenhower Park for a performance of Verdi's ''La Traviata.'' According to Nassau County organizers, the crowd numbered between 40,000 and 45,000, and indeed there were people as far as the eye could see.

title: 'X' Is for 'Xcellent'
description: Edward Dermon of Roslyn Heights, L.I., noticed recently that the first two batters in the lineup of the Los Angeles Dodgers were Steve Sax and Ken Landreaux. He mused that it was probably the first time in baseball history that the names of the first two hitters ended in ''X.''

title: RENOVATION OF BEAUMONT IS IN DOUBT
description: Because of sharply rising costs, the board of directors of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center has decided to re-evaluate the planned interior renovation that is keeping the theater closed indefinitely. The estimated cost of the renovation has risen in the last year from $6 million to more than $7 million.

title: A FASTING RUSSIAN SEES WIFE
description: A Soviet hunger striker, Sergei Petrov, was reunited with his American wife today on the 47th day of his protest fast to gain a Soviet exit visa.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Carey President Notes Rise in Lease Financing

title: At Least 14 Are Injured In Refinery Explosions
description: Explosions ripped through a chemical refinery east of Houston tonight, igniting a fire that injured at least 14 people and sent flames more than 300 feet high.

title: Search for Flood Victims Is Suspended in Colorado
description: The authorities today suspended the search for three campers missing and presumed dead after a wall of water poured from a ruptured earthen dam last week.

title: MILITARY IS QUIETLY REBUILDING ITS SPECIAL OPERATIONS FORCES
description: The United States armed forces have quietly begun to rebuild a capability for guerrilla operations, sabotage, clandestine assault and other forms of unconventional warfare, according to Reagan Administration officials and military officers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stalking the 'Food Culture'

title: MURDERS ON MAIN LINE STIR NEW FEELING OF FEAR
description: To a parish that no longer needed a warning, the Rev. William J. Krupa's words were a reminder that, even here on the Main Line, wealth and influence and homes of massive stone on spacious grounds provide no sure haven.

title: KATHARINE H. LEWIS, SINGER, THE DAUGHTER OF W.C. HANDY
description: Katharine Handy Lewis, an early blues singer who was the first to sing the songs set down by her father, W.C. Handy - ''the Father of the Blues'' - died last Thursday at her home in the Bronx after a long illness. She was 80 years old.

title: ROOM AT THE TOP FOR YOUTH IN HIGH TECH
description: It was lunchtime in the studio of MTV, a cable channel with music programs that appeal primarily to an 18-to 24-year-old audience, and the staff, which is roughly the same age, was variously engaged in eating fast foods, playing video games and hanging out on the set.

title: COUNTERING A LITANY OF ANTI-ISRAEL DISTORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Journey At Sea Wins the Swaps
description: Journey At Sea led from wire to wire today to capture the $158,800 Swaps Stakes for 3-year-olds at Hollywood Park.

title: VOLUNTEERS DIG INTO MANHATTAN'S PAST
description: Behind a bright blue plywood fence that has sprung up in the heart of Sheridan Square, a crew of volunteers has begun what it says is the first archeological dig in Greenwich Village - one that archeologists hope will unearth clues to life on pre-Colonial Manhattan.

title: FOR PALESTINIAN REFUGEES, ACUTE DIFFICULTIES AND FEW SOLUTIONS
description: The refugees from the devastated Palestinian camp of Ein Khilwe huddle over small wood fires on the sidewalks of a street in Sidon. They squat and sleep in a row of vacant stores, crowded with crying children. They carry water from a street-corner tap and use the basement of an unfinished building as a bathroom, turning it into a vast and fetid sewer.

title: Seychelles Backs Effort To Recover Diego Garcia
description: The Seychelles has thrown its support behind Mauritius' campaign for the return of Diego Garcia atoll, which Britain leases to the United States as a military base.

title: MEMORIES OF A MURDER LINGERING IN VERMONT
description: Two 12-year-old girls were raped, stabbed and tortured here last year. One died. The crime traumatized this pastoral state of birch and mountains and Morgan horses, brought hard-line changes to its laws and left its people confused and bitter.

title: 581 DEER ARE SLAIN IN THE EVERGLADES
description: Nearly 2,000 hunters swarmed into the Everglades today to began a two-day ''mercy kill'' sanctioned by state to thin a herd of starving deer.

title: THE CALL OF THE CAMP
description: Anyone looking for top Administration officials this week won't find all of them at their desks. Many will be frolicking among the giant redwoods of Northern California.

title: ANGOLA IS EMERGING AS SOUTH AFRICA'S MAJOR FOE
description: For those who view Africa as a chessboard of opposed forces, Angola is a critical piece. It is not, perhaps, the dominant piece in the region - in economic and military terms, that would be South Africa - but it is certainly a principal warrior in black Africa's campaign against white minority domination in South Africa.

title: NEW-ISSUE VOLUME UP
description: The recent decline in interest rates has attracted more corporations to the note and bond market, where this week's volume could be more than $1 billion, up from $975 million a week earlier. The combined volume of this week and last week is almost certain to exceed the $1.6 billion of new issues sold in all of June.

title: DANCE: 3 MODERN TROUPES FROM JAPAN AT PURCHASE
description: THE Japanese modern-dance companies appearing in the United States this summer under the auspices of the American Dance Festival opened in a previously unreviewed program Friday at Pepsico Summerfare '82 at the campus of the State University of New York's college at Purchase. It was an evening of mixed blessings.

title: Newspaper Ad Revenue; Up by 4.7% in Quarter
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau is in the midst of revamping its system of monitoring advertising linage in United States and Canadian daily newspapers, so it is unable to provide month-to-month ad revenue estimates. However, it does have a report for the first quarter, which says that revenues were up 4.7 percent from the corresponding period last year.

title: Lonnetta Gaines Back
description: Lonnetta Gaines will return to Greene Street, the SoHo cabarettheater at 101 Greene Street, at 10 tonight in an improvisational jazz-dance performance. Miss Gaines, now based in Louisville, Ky., danced with the companies of Eleo Pomare, Dianne McIntyre and George Faison and was featured in the ''Women in Jazz'' series at Greene Street last April. Information: 925-2415.

title: The Tough Price of Tax Reform
description: Senate moderates in both political parties face a difficult choice this week. By voting for the Finance Committee's budget reconciliation measure they would be approving a $17 billion cut in medical and welfare programs over the next three years, some of which would hurt the poor. But by voting against the bill they would be scuttling a fine tax reform package that would generate $98 billion in revenues during the same period.

title: MILITARY WEIGHING BOLIVIAN CHIEF'S OFFER TO RESIGN
description: A power struggle in the armed forces left Bolivia virtually leaderless today. Saturday night, the military high command rejected a bid by Col. Faustino Rico Toro to assume the presidency but confirmed reports that the President, Brig. Gen. Celso Torrelio, had offered to resign.

title: SYRIAN ON WAY TO U.S. TO SEEK LEBANON PEACE
description: Syria's Foreign Minister left here for Washington today on a mission to find a way to end the Israeli presence in Lebanon. He also indicated that he hoped to make progress toward a settlement of the larger Palestinian problem.

title: JERSEY CITY WATER STARTING TO FLOW
description: Water began flowing this morning to some of the 300,000 people here and in Hoboken who have been without service since Friday after a 72-inch aqueduct burst.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Leader at Equitable Preparing for Role

title: The U.N. Today; July 19, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, working group on a new international eco- nomic order -10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Jennifer Mackby Bride of Marc Nitsche
description: Jenifer Mackby, political-affairs officer for the United Nations Political and Security Council Affairs Department, was married yesterday to Marc Erik Nitsche, an associate with the New York law firm of Rosenman, Colin, Freund, Lewis & Cohen. Justice of the Peace Michael Venus performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: BRITISH RAILWAY STRIKE ENDED AS ENGINEERS ACQUIESCE
description: Britain's striking railway workers decided today to accede to management demands for increased productivity. Their action represented a major victory for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: Advertising
description: Ogilvy Unit Buys Shop In Germany

title: LET AARON BURR REST IN PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Use Traced
description: Bill (Caveman) Lee lasted only 67 seconds in his attempt to take the middleweight boxing championship from Marvelous Marvin Hagler on March 7 in Atlantic City.

title: 2 Banks Cut Prime Rate to 16%
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the First National Bank of Chicago lowered their prime lending rates yesterday to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent.

title: Ukrainian Arrested in Ohio
description: John Demjanjuk, a Ukrainian-born immigrant who was stripped of his United States citizenship after a Federal Court held that he falsified immigration papers, was arrested today after failing to appear at a deportation hearing a week ago. Mr. Demjanjuk, 62 years old, who denies charges that he hid a past as a guard in a Nazi concentration camp, was taken into custody in the Old Federal Courthouse.

title: U.S.F.L. Can Use Kennedy Stadium
description: The D.C. Armory Board agreed in principle today to allow the Washington franchise in the new United States Football League the use of 55,000-seat Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: BRITISH CALLED TIGHT-LIPPED ON DETAILS OF ESPIONAGE CASE
description: United States intelligence officials said today that the British Government had not provided American officials with any details about an espionage case involving top secret communications intelligence.

title: Horses, Birds and Heat
description: We are trying to remember what it was like to shiver at a bus stop. To spend our waking hours comparing the cost of replacement windows, storm windows and quilted curtains.

title: CURBS ARE EASED ON USE OF WATER IN JERSEY SYSTEM
description: Officials today lifted most of the wateruse restrictions imposed on the 300,000 customers of the Jersey City Water Department on Saturday, but left in place, at least temporarily, the requirement that all drinking water be boiled for five minutes.

title: BRITAIN WILL NOT PROSECUTE IN CASE OF PALACE INTRUDER
description: The intruder who surprised Queen Elizabeth in her bedroom at Buckingham Palace 10 days ago will not be prosecuted because he did not commit a criminal offense, the British authorities announced today.

title: VALID ALTERNATIVE TO FEDERAL STUDENT AID
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: A 'Getting Yours' Guide

title: How to Save Penicillin
description: Antibiotics, the sole known cure of many bacterial diseases, are slowly waning in strength. Penicillin, once lethal to the organism of gonorrhea, now fails to cure many cases. Leprosy is on the rise again in the United States in a form resistant to the standard drug. The reason is overuse.

title: FED MOVE SENDS RATES LOWER
description: Interest rates declined yesterday immediately after the Federal Reserve announced a half-point reduction in the discount rate it charges on loans to banks, to 11 1/2 percent, from 12 percent.

title: Dow Declines 2.57, to 826.10; Merger Issues In Spotlight
description: Corporate takeovers, both real and rumored, provided the main excitement for the stock market yesterday. Meanwhile, leading market indexes slipped slightly.

title: Fiber-Optic Links by Bell
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, whose last contract for fiber-optic communications systems caused an international controversy, said it is seeking competitive bids for construction of more than 1,000 miles of fiber-optic telephone cables in five separate systems through 1985.

title: County Charges Noguchi Solicited a Donation
description: Dr. Thomas Noguchi was accused by county officials today of withholding records from a company until it donated $2,000 to a nonprofit group that he heads.

title: Several Makers Of Real-Time Clocks
description: Following are several manufacturers of real-time clocks for personal computers: Hayes Microcomputers, Norcross, Ga. 30092.

title: CORDIAL TALK CITED IN THIOKOL MERGER
description: It was over a ''fine'' cup of coffee last month that Charles S. Locke, the 53-year-old chairman of Morton-Norwich Products, came to believe that his company's proposed merger with the Thiokol Corporation would actually come to pass.

title: 4 in San Antonio Street Killed by Berserk Driver
description: A man who may have been enraged by a tavern quarrel drove his pickup truck into a crowd of people, killing four and injuring two. The police said today that some witnesses might know the driver's identity but would not disclose it.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Actor to Have Exhibition Of Paintings in Theater

title: MICHIGAN PRIDE, ITS LAW SCHOOL, ELUDES DECLINE
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich. ''SMALLER is better'' is the motto these days at the University of Michigan. Faced with severe budgetary problems induced by the state's economic troubles, the school has already eliminated its geography department, and the departments of art, natural resources and education could be the next to go.

title: The Streets Of the Cities
description: The success of the Fifth Avenue Mile last year has spawned a series of mile road races down some of the world's most famous streets. Yet to be announced, the series will look something like this:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Saving Lots of Watts

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are there so many kinds of white animals in cold climates and black animals in hot climates, if black absorbs solar heat and white reflects it?

title: FOR PRICE, 2D PLACE IS A VICTORY
description: Until this British Open, Nick Price was a South African golfer familiar to only the most knowledgeable fans. He was 86th on the European tour money list, a struggler who had missed three cuts in seven previous tournaments.

title: COAST NOMINEES FOCUS ON GOVERNOR'S RECORD
description: Attorney General George Deukmejian, the Republican nominee for Governor, proposed today that the 28,000 inmates in California prisons be offered work opportunities and be billed for their upkeep.

title: Conagra Consent
description: The Federal Trade Commission accepted a consent agreement with Conagra Inc., settling charges that its acquisition of the Minneapolis-based Peavey Company would lessen competition in the wheat flour industry. As a result of the agreement allowing the acquisition, Conagra, based in Omaha, will divest itself of several facilities and will be prohibited for 10 years from acquiring stock, assets or interests in any flour milling plant in the Western region without F.T.C. approval.

title: New New Yorker
