description: Scott Hastings and his wife, Judi, were newlyweds when they made their first trip to New York City last month - for the National Basketball Association's collegiate draft. In fact, they used the occasion as part of their honeymoon.

title: FRIEND OF SHULTZ TO BE HIS DEPUTY
description: President Reagan today announced the nomination of Kenneth W. Dam, the provost of the University of Chicago and a longtime friend of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, as the Deputy Secretary of State.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ART, LIVE AND OTHER

title: OF TUITION SUBSIDIES AND 'SHODDY THINKING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Angola Seeks Guarantee Against South Africans
description: Angola has indicated that Cuban troops will remain in that country until it receives guarantees that there will be no South African attacks on its territory after South-West Africa becomes independent as Namibia.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about summer cultural events in New York City was accompanied by an outdated photo- graph. The actor Barry Bostwick has been replaced by John Vickery in ''The Death of von Richthofen as Wit- nessed From Earth.''

title: GALLIC SHRUG FOR JAPAN'S STYLE
description: At one time, French designers dictated and dominated what millions of women wore all over the world. Then came the Italians, who gave the French a run for their money. And now, the Japanese.

title: ROCK: GANG OF FOUR
description: DIALECTICAL materialism never struck this listener as a very promising subject for rock songs, so he didn't warm immediately to the Gang of Four, an analytical rock quartet from Leeds, England, with a decidedly Marxist bent.

title: Carr's 'Training' Plan
description: Roger Carr, the Baltimore wide receiver who is eager to be traded, has changed his mind about reporting to the Colts' training camp in Towson, Md., on Friday. ''I'm going to training camp, but I'm going to do just enough to get by,'' he said at his Cotton Valley, La., home yesterday.

title: Senate Takes Up Tax Bill
description: The Senate began considering today a Republican tax bill that most Democrats find more to their liking than they wish to admit in this election year.

title: TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1982; Markets
description: The Federal Reserve Board lowered its discount rate to 11 1/2 percent from 12 percent. Analysts said other interest rates may now drop slightly in the next few weeks. (Page A1.) Interest rates in the credit markets declined, with those for Treasury bills falling to their lowest levels since last December. (D16.) Manufacturers Hanover Trust and First National Bank of Chicago lowered their prime lending rates a half point, to 16 percent. (D16.)

title: WEAVER TO FIGHT DOKES
description: Mike Weaver has signed to defend his World Boxing Association heavyweight title in September against Michael Dokes, the No.1 contender, the promoter Don King said yesterday.

title: RULING ON HAITIANS FACES U.S. APPEAL
description: The Justice Department said today that it intended to appeal the decision of a Federal judge who ordered the release of more than 1,800 Haitians held in detention as illegal aliens.

title: CASH FOR THE TURNSTILES
description: To the Editor:

title: CAN LIE DETECTORS BE TRUSTED?
description: WHEN a former Congressional page made sensational allegations about sexual misconduct on Capitol Hill last month, Federal agents turned to a trusted investigative tool - the lie detector. They hooked up 18-year-old Leroy Williams of Little Rock, Ark., to a lie detector, asked him a series of questions and concluded that he had made deceptive replies.

title: REYNOLDS OFF
description: Armco Inc., the nation's sixth-largest steelmaker, said yesterday that it lost $57.4 million in the second quarter, compared with profits of $87.6 million, or $1.53 a share, in the comparable 1981 quarter.

title: COLT BRINGS $4.25 MILLION
description: An unnamed, unraced 15-month-old thoroughbred colt was sold for $4.25 million here this afternoon. It was the highest price ever paid for a race horse at auction and the first of several astounding records set on the first day of the Keeneland Select Yearling Sales.

title: THE HEAT FAILS TO WILT 'DRESS FOR SUCCESS' RULE
description: When his eyes are closed and sweat is bubbling off his brow, Djibril Sall can pretend he is in his native West African city, Dakar, Senegal. There, he can escape the sweltering heat under a baobab tree.

title: BRUNANSKY'S GRAND SLAM PACES TWINS
description: Tom Brunansky hit an inside-the-park grand slam, and John Castino and Lenny Faedo added homers tonight, leading the Minnesota Twins to a 6-4 victory over Milwaukee. The Twins ended the Brewers' eight-game winning streak.

title: CONCERT: THE NEW CALLIOPE PRESENTS BAROQUE MUSIC
description: PETER SCHUBERT'S admirable singing ensemble, the New Calliope Singers and Chamber Players, coped well with the heat and the noise of traffic Sunday night, but it had more trouble surviving the mushy acoustics of St. Joseph's in the Village, at the Avenue of the Americas and Washington Place.

title: Hernandez Shows How To Beat Odds
description: I n baseball, the ''book'' says that a left-handed pitcher has the advantage over a left-handed hitter, especially when the hitter is in a slump and most especially when he starts to guess what is coming. But Keith Hernandez of the St. Louis Cardinals beat all those odds Sunday: he was swinging against a left-hander, he was slumping, he was guessing. Yet, he hit a three-run homer that led the Cardinals to a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: BASEBALL REPAYS ITS PAST
description: Ernie Banks did not suggest ''Let's play two,'' as he did as a shortstop for the Chicago Cubs, but he showed his usual unbridled enthusiasm tonight as he awaited the start of the Cracker Jack Old-Timers Baseball Classic.

title: High and Dry Canals
description: Canal systems built along the Peruvian coast by the Chimu civilization between A.D. 500 and 1200 irrigated 35 to 40 percent more land than is now irrigated by existing canal systems there. Many of the ancient canals, it now appears, became useless because of a geological evolution: Underthrusting of the Pacific Ocean floor beneath the mainland inexorably raised the landscape and cut the canals off from their sources of irrigation water.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt CHEATING. Deception in War & Magic, Games & Sports, Sex & Religion, Busi- ness & Con Games, Politics & Espio- nage, Art & Science. By J. Barton Bow- yer. 439 pages. Illustrated. St. Martin's. $14.95.

title: FORMER PRESIDENT OF BRANIFF
description: Charles E. Beard, former president and chief executive officer of Braniff International Airways, died of a heart ailment Sunday at Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas. He was 81 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: Zaire Invites Begin to Visit
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin has received an invitation from President Mobutu Sese Seko to visit Zaire next month and will make the trip if developments in the Lebanese conflict permit, Mr. Begin's spokesman said today.

title: LEADING IOWA CANDIDATE SET BACK BECAUSE SHE PAID NO '81 STATE TAX
description: Roxanne Conlin's campaign to become Governor of Iowa has been jeopardized by her disclosure that she paid no state income taxes for 1981, in part because she and her husband took advantage of tax shelters that she had denounced.

title: HYDRANTS CLOSED AS HEAT PERSISTS
description: New York City declared a water-pressure alert yesterday and Consolidated Edison said it had delivered a record amount of electrical power as the metropolitan area endured its fourth straight day of searing heat and high humdity.

title: Bahamas Bars Ambrosiano
description: The authorities here have suspended the license of Banco Ambrosiano Overseas Ltd. for 30 days, following the inability of the Italian parent company, Banco Ambrosiano, to make a declaration in support of its overseas subsidiaries.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: New Director Named For Historical Society

title: STALEMATE IN BEIRUT
description: Now that a negotiating stalemate has developed in Beirut, should the Reagan Administration order its representative, Philip C. Habib, to enter into direct American talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization?

title: 'Skytrain' for Sale
description: The trade name ''Skytrain,'' the bestknown asset of bankrupt Laker Airways, is up for sale. One world airline already has offered $180,000 for the name Sir Freddie Laker gave to his cut-price London-to-New York air service, spokesmen said. The carrier collapsed last February.

title: JOHANNA M. RICCIARDI
description: Johanna Marie Ricciardi, assistant to Halston, the fashion designer, died Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 32 years old and lived in Manhattan and Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Justice Official Predicts Increase in Executions
description: Executions of death row inmates will be stepped up in the next two years, possibly approaching a rate of three a week, a Justice Department official predicted Sunday.

title: Westinghouse and Key Union Agree on Tentative Contract
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reached a tentative contract agreement early today with its 11,000-member white-collar employees' union, a week before a strike deadline.

title: Gallery to Show Prints Of Japan's Theater Arts
description: Japanese woodblock prints from the late 18th and early 19th centuries, called surimono, will be on view through Oct. 4 in the Amsterdam Gallery of the General Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, 111 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CHRYSLER POSTS PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: The Chrysler Corporation, profiting from its vast cost-cutting program and the sale of profitable luxury cars, yesterday reported a second-quarter net income of $106.9 million, or $1.34 a share.

title: TEHERAN TRYING TO SOOTHE FEARS OF GULF NATIONS
description: With Iranian and Iraqi forces apparently stalemated after six days of fighting in southern Iraq, Iran has begun a political offensive in the Middle East apparently intended to allay fears that it poses a threat to other Persian Gulf countries.

title: Gabriel's Video Games At Cunningham
description: Cunningham & Walsh, one of the Mickleberry companies, has become the agency for CBS Video Games, a new division of Gabriel Industries, whose video game cartridges should be coming to market in the fall.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: SOME of the recent conquests against infections have been so spectacular that they have nearly driven from public consciousness the vast array of organisms that can still make people ill.

title: FMC Bidding for Scherer
description: The FMC Corporation is offering to pay $90.2 million in cash, or $22 a share, for up to 4.1 million shares of the R.P. Scherer Corporation, a major manufacturer of soft elastic gelatin capsules for drug concerns.

title: WEBER'S NATURALISTIC EYE ON MEN'S FASHION
description: Scratchy jazz floated through the screen door, circled the hydrangea and settled. At that moment, Bruce Weber emerged through a gate by the swimming pool, his golden retriever leading the way. He was not what one might have expected of the person credited with revolutionizing men's fashion photography in the last four years. With a handkerchief tied around his head, he more resembled an unkempt surfer.

title: ISRAELIS TO RELEASE CAPTURED BOYS
description: An Israeli Army spokesman announced today that 220 boys, aged 12 to 15, captured during the fighting in Lebanon, would be turned over to the International Committee of the Red Cross to be reunited with their families in Lebanon and Syria.

title: IN NEW YORK, AN INVISIBLE G.O.P. RACE
description: It has been the invisible campaign so far - the contest for the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat.

title: LeFlore Apologizes
description: Ron LeFlore, the Chicago White Sox outfielder who was suspended for three games without pay, gave his manager, Tony LaRussa, a letter of apology yesterday. LeFlore had been late for a Sunday game in Milwaukee and watched the game from the stands as the White Sox lost their fifth straight.

title: The U.N. Today; July 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission Working Group on a New International Eco- nomic Order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: LAST week the summer unfolded as it always does in mid-July. E veryone who could packed toothbrush and bathing suit and fled on then ext available seaplane. Those left on the streets wore high-heeled s neakers. Few parties really fizzed. And markdowns seem to be a way o f life. Indeed, most stores had reduced their fashion merchandise asm uch as 60 percent, not that it appeared to do any good. But that didn ot stop Seventh Avenue designers from going ahead with their resort c ollections.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC FROM THE ANDES
description: THERE is a renaissance taking place in performances of folk music and ''folk''-inspired music. Fueled by the crisis in the European musical tradition and by the Romantic heritage of the 60's counterculture, the music of other lands proliferates in festivals, new-music concerts - and with regularity - at the fine presentations of the the Alternative Museum in TriBeCa.

title: Frontier's Net Declines 2.7%
description: Frontier Holdings Inc., the holding company for Frontier Airlines, reported today that its second-quarter net income declined 2.7 percent from a year earlier, to $5.76 million, or 60 cents a share, from $5.92 million, or 64 cents a share.

title: THE MARINERS' MANAGER
description: O nce a batboy, he's now a candidate for manager of the year. That's the scenario Rene Lachemann is creating as the Seattle Mariners continue to be a contender in the American League West.

title: 3 HOMERS HELP JOHN DEFEAT MARINERS, 5-3
description: It was Tommy John's turn last night to cloud the Yankees' pitching plans, and he did. John, who had gained only one victory in nine starts since May 25, became the fifth of six would-be starters to pitch impressively in five games since the All-Star Game break as the Yankees defeated the Seattle Mariners, 5-3. Dave Righetti, the sixth starter, gets his chance tonight.

title: D'Amato Meets Israelis For Talks on Lebanon
description: Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato, Republican from New York, met here today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Mr. D'Amato said that the Prime Minister had given him a letter to President Reagan that he would be delivering Tuesday in Washington. He declined to comment on the content of the message.

title: MORTON TO ACQUIRE THIOKOL
description: Morton-Norwich Products Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Thiokol Corporation, a manufacturer of rocket propulsion systems and chemicals, in a cash and stock transaction valued at $540 million.

title: Bridge: Californian's Squad Wins Big Apple Knockout Play
description: A young financier embarked on two quite different bridge battles last week. The financier, 39-year-old Mel Skolnik of Newport Beach, Calif., who has amassed a considerable real-estate fortune, has already won one battle, in the Big Apple Regional Knockout Team Championship, which ended at the New York Hilton Hotel here Sunday, but the other will take longer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the Americans will make up their minds to negotiate directly with the P.L.O., the question of where they go will not be a problem.

title: A New Military Junta Takes Over in Bolivia
description: The leaders of the army, navy and air force replaced the 10-month-old Government of President Celso Torrelio tonight.

title: U.S. MOVES TO CURB INSANITY DEFENSE
description: The Reagan Administration today endorsed a proposal to limit severely the use of the insanity defense in Federal criminal cases. The proposal would hold a defendant responsible if he ''knew he was shooting at a human being to kill him.''

title: GUATEMALA CAN'T TAKE 2 ROADS
description: There is a village in northern Guatemala that maintains a list of townspeople who have been executed by the army. In June, this year's roster passed the 400 mark; nearly half of them women and children. The latest entry, a man suspected of giving food to the guerrillas, had been chopped into tiny pieces.

title: Aeromexico Jets
description: Mexico's state-controlled air carrier Aeromexico said it had purchased four DC-9 Super 80 jets from the Mc-Donnell Douglas Corporation for $100 million. Delivery of the planes, expected in November, would increase the carrier's fleet to 43 aircraft.

title: IN SIERRA NEVADA, OMINOUS TREMORS COULD MEAN ANOTHER MOUNT ST. HELENS
description: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. DAN MILLER, a geologist, hacked at the slope with an army trenching tool and set off a small avalanche. The fine soil, shaken free, slid downhill in a rush, carrying with it pumice stones the size of popcorn, flakes of obsidian and chunks of basalt. Another hack, another avalanche. This is not solid ground.

title: MUSIC FESTIVAL FOUNDER CHERISHES CITY'S VITALITY
description: MARGARET CAMPBELL seems proudest of her Washington Square Music Festival when park bums gather in glassy-eyed respect at the fringes of the crowd and listen to Mozart. Mrs. Campbell, 82 years old, has been chairman of the festival since 1956, and tonight she will help celebrate the series' 25th anniversary.

title: Del Monte Plans A Line of Dolls Offer
description: Del Monte, one of the longtime, big-time San Francisco advertisers, is promising its biggest, or at least ''most extensive,'' consumer promotion when, in September, with its ad agency, McCann-Erickson, San Francisco, it begins promoting a brand new premium offer, a line of plush dolls called the Country Yumkins: Reddi Tomato, Lushie Peach, Sweetie Pea and Cobbie Corn.

title: N.F.L. Bid Denied
description: Judge Harry Pregerson of United States District Court today denied a second motion by the National Football League for a stay that would keep the Oakland Raiders from moving to Los Angeles. The motion came after the California Supreme Court ruled that a lower court erred in dismissing a suit brought by the city of Oakland, which sought to keep the Raiders there by eminent domain. The N.F.L. claimed the Raiders should not be allowed to move until the eminent domain case was decided.

title: VILAS CAPTURES U.S. PRO
description: Guillermo Vilas defeated Mel Purcell, 6-4, 6-0, in the final of the $200,000 United States Pro tennis championships tonight.

title: Cal Fed Cuts Home Interest
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association said today that it had lowered its variable rate on 30-year conventional home mortgages a full percentage point, to 15 percent.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Preserving the Past

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: MOST of the ablest college graduates whose first job is teaching leave the profession within five years. For them, teaching is merely a stepping stone to other fields.

title: PALESTINIANS SEEK NEW U.S. INITIATIVE
description: With the monthlong negotiations of the special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, having failed to produce any tangible results, Lebanese and Palestinian officials said today that they were looking for a new initiative from Washington to stave off an Israeli assault on west Beirut.

title: ARTHUR ANDERSON LIABILITY IS REDUCED
description: Judge Charles E. Stewart Jr. of the Federal District Court in New York has reduced an $80.7 million jury award that Arthur Andersen & Company was ordered to pay to the Fund of Funds for not fulfilling its duties as the mutual fund's auditor in the late 1960's.

title: Delay on 911 Call Brings Suspension
description: The Emergency Medical Services suspended an operator yesterday because of the death early Saturday of a Bronx man after an attack of asthma.

title: Bankers Trust Climbs 16.5%
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the nation's eighth-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that its income before securities transactions, excluding a special gain, rose 16.5 percent in the second quarter from the corresponding period of 1981. Earnings totaled $49.3 million, or $1.72 a share, compared with $42.3 million, or $1.56 a share, in the 1981 quarter.

title: I.B.M. Debentures
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $500 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2007. Proceeds will be used to meet capital requirements for construction of facilities and for rental equipment, I.B.M. said. The underwriting group will be comanaged by Salomon Brothers Inc. and Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: DEADLY WAR FOR LIFE OF ARIZONA CACTI
description: Vandals shoot them up for target practice. Thieves dig them out of the desert and peddle them on the black market. Developers sometimes bulldoze them to build new subdivisions.

title: How Old Is That Shrimp?
description: Zoologists have long sought a foolproof method of determining the age of insects and crustaceans. A possible solution has been discovered by an Australian scientist who has developed a promising new technique for determining the age of animals as diverse as fleas and shrimp.

title: YANKS NAME ELLIS TO COACH PITCHERS
description: Sammy Ellis became the Yankees' fifth pitching coach of the season yesterday. Ellis, who had been the pitching coach for the club's Class AAA farm team in Columbus, replaced Clyde King less than six weeks after King replaced Stan Williams. And Williams had taken over from the cocoaches Jeff Torborg and Jerry Walker only 14 games into the season.

title: A HIGH-SPEED DATA ANALYST
description: WASHINGTON W hen Lou Brock broke the major league base-stealing record for a single season with 118 steals in 1974 - the record Rickey Henderson of Oakland seems certain to break this season - he was 35 years old. At an age when most ballplayers are on their last legs, Brock was romping like a colt.

title: TV CITIZENS GROUP IN FISCAL TROUBLE
description: The National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting, a nonprofit public-interest group that has been in operation for 15 years, is running short of money and may go out of business in the next year.

title: Accounts
description: * Rubbermaid Inc. to Needham, Harper & Steers/Chicago for its housewares.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Named Ron Schueler assistant general manager.
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Activated Frank P astore, pitcher, who had been on the in- j ured reserve list since June 24 with a torn f inger tendon; optioned Ben Hayes, rookie p itcher, to the Indianapolis Indians of the A merican Association. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Called up Tony G wynn, outfielder, from the team's Ha- w aii club.

title: Dr. Jack L. Rubins Dies at 66; A Psychoanalyst and Teacher
description: Dr. Jack L. Rubins, former member of the faculty council and training and supervising analyst of the American Insitute for Psychoanalysis of the Karen Horney Psychoanalytic Institute and Center in Manhattan, died July 12 in the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 66 years old and lived in Queens Village, Queens.

title: MARIJUANA ACTIVISTS SUE IN FLORIDA TO BAR HERBICIDE SPRAYING OF CROP
description: A pro-marijuana group filed a lawsuit today in a state court to block Florida's planned use of the herbicide paraquat to destroy the state's flourishing crop of the illegal drug.

title: BRITAIN TO SELL 51% OF ITS TELECOM COMPANY
description: The British Government announced today that it would sell a majority share in the country's telephone company to private investors ''after the next election.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bedlwether issues

title: PANEL URGES REAGAN TO GUARD CREDIBILITY OF VOICE OF AMERICA
description: An official report to President Reagan strongly urged today that the Voice of America and its parent body, the International Communication Agency, remain free from ''stridency and propaganda.'' It recommended that they ''take particular care'' to broadcast news abroad with objectivity.

title: Mitsubishi Is Indicted in I.B.M. Case
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation of Japan and four of its employees were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in San Jose, Calif., on charges of conspiring to transport to Japan stolen property from the International Business Machine Corporation.

title: Dome Plans Offer
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it would make an offer in Canada to purchase up to 10 million $5.75 class A retractable preferred shares of Dome Resources Ltd. at $50 a share. The shares were issued in March in exchange for shares of Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company Ltd., and all shares bought back will be canceled, Dome said. It said it would not need to borrow funds for the acquisition, which is subject to regulatory approval.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES UP 18.6%
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that an extraordinary gain of $40 mildion caused earnings in the second quarter to rise 18.6 percent as sales slipped 1.4 percent.

title: Fencer Hurt in Match
description: Vladimir Smirnov, the fencer who is defending his title in the world foil championship in Rome, suffered a severe injury yesterday when the weapon of Matthias Ber of West Germany, broke through the Soviet Union star's mask, pierced his left eye and entered the frontal lobe of his brain.

title: Two Officials Quit at Chase
description: Two Chase Manhattan Bank executives whose department was reponsible for Chase's purchase of loans from Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma City have quit following Chase's acknowledgement that it might lose money because of Penn Square's collapse, banking sources said yesterday.

title: JERSEY CITY'S MR. FIX-IT
description: Fire hydrant caps popped like corks on champagne bottles all over town today as residents celebrated the return of water to Jersey City.

title: Education Loans
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES On Tuesday, July 13, you reported, in an article by Winston Williams (''Large Banks Remain Wary of Loan Program for Parents''), that bankers were reluctant to participate in the PLUS program.

title: Everglades Deer Hunt Halted After Two Days
description: A ''mercy kill'' to thin out a herd of sick Everglades deer was halted at dusk today, far short of its goal. Game officials said starvation and disease had already taken a ''catastrophic'' toll and hunters had had difficulty tracking down remaining deer.

title: Rollins Files Suit
description: Wayne (Tree) Rollins, the Atlanta Hawks center, has filed a suit in Superior Court in Atlanta that charges M.L. Carr of the Boston Celtics with ''verbally and physically'' abusing him during some 40 National Basketball Association games. The suit, which names the Celtics and Carr, is seeking a total of $4 million in damages.

title: Article 027272 -- No Title
description: The first survey of war damage in southern Lebanon shows that in the town of Tyre alone, which was a major Palestinian headquarters, the Israeli invasion resulted in losses of approximately $75 million in housing, industry, schools, hospitals, agriculture and public utilities.

title: DANCE: KYLIAN'S 'CHILDREN'S GAMES'
description: JIRI KYLIAN'S ''Children's Games'' began with recorded voices of laughing children. Although the children were surely having fun, their laughter was so shrill and taunting that it was not a pleasant sound.

title: News Analysis
description: Nearly three weeks after most city contracts expired, this year's contract talks between the Koch administration and municipal labor unions have bogged down in a tangle of problems that is even more complex than usual.

title: The Saddest War
description: Pity the people of Ethiopia and Somalia, trapped in a war as sterile and brutal as the Ogaden desert over which it is waged. It is Africa's oldest running war. It began in 1960, turned into a real bloodbath in 1977-78, flagged and then last week showed signs of boiling up again in earnest. Ethiopia, it appears, was the aggressor in a testing border assault, but that is disputed in the usual exchange of insults between Addis Ababa and Mogadishu, whose regimes are alike in their zealotry.

title: People
description: * Gene Grayson, creative director, has become executive vice president of Edwin Bird Wilson Inc.

title: Chess: Four Finish Tied for First In 365-Player World Open
description: Four international masters - Nick De Firmian of Oakland, Calif.; John Fedorowicz of New York; Dimitry Gurevich of the Bronx, and Eugene Meyer of Arlington, Va. - tied for first place in the World Open Tournament in Philadelphia. Each scored 7-1 to win $2,375 in the eight-round Swiss-system competition.

title: Zellerbach Spending Cut
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said today that it had reduced 1982 capital expenditure plans to a maximum of $300 million from $345 million last year.

title: HOUSING'S JUNE STARTS FELL 15.3%
description: New housing starts fell 15.3 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 911,000 units, wiping out most of May's big gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SYRIA SAYS IT WILL STAY IN LEBANON AS LONG AS ISRAELIS ARE IN BEIRUT
description: President Hafez al-Assad has refused to withdraw Syrian forces from Lebanon in response to what he terms an Israeli ''ultimatum'' as long as Israel's invasion forces remain in Beirut.

title: Burroughs Up 16.6%; NCR Net Down 3.3%
description: The Burroughs Corporation yesterday reported that net income for the second quarter ended June 30 rose 16.6 percent, to $36.5 million, or 86 cents a share, from $31.3 million, or 75 cents a share in the second quarter last year.

title: Jeweler Files Suit Over Singer's Ads
description: Harry Winston Inc., the Fifth Avenue jeweler, filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, seeking $100 million in damages from Phyllis McGuire, the singer, and Melvin Belli, her attorney, for what it termed a ''malicious advertising campaign conducted by the defendants.''

title: Airport Challenges Braniff Ruling
description: Braniff International's landlord, the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport Board, is taking the bankrupt carrier back to court, appealing a Federal judge's decision allowing the airline not to pay $500,000 monthly rent on its corporate headquarters.

title: PASSION PLAY TEXT STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: Four performances of a 13th-century Passion play at the Cloisters last March have created controversy, resulting in two articles in the June issue of the ADL Bulletin, published by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: A U.S. EDUCATOR IS SEIZED IN BEIRUT
description: Unidentified gunmen kidnapped the acting president of the American University of Beirut from the campus in west Beirut today, a university spokesman said.

title: A GUCCI SUES RELATIVES
description: Paolo Gucci, the designer, filed a $13.3 million lawsuit yesterday against five other members of the Gucci family and their American company, Gucci Shops Inc. He accused them of breach of contract, causing him emotional harm and physically attacking him during a meeting of the board of directors in Italy last week.

title: WARFARE AMONG ALLIES
description: Six weeks after the seven-nation economic meeting of heads of state at Versailles, it is safe to say that relations among Europeans, Americans and Japanese are at their lowest point in recent history, some say the lowest point in postwar history.

title: U.S. Steel Mill
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia said it had arranged a $690 million (United States) syndicated loan for the United States Steel Corporation's Fairfield Works, a seamless-pipe mill in Alabama that the company closed in June. The bank said the agreement had been signed with the General Electric Credit Corporation and involved financing from 16 other banks. The plant will be purchased and leased back to U.S. Steel, with lease financing arranged by General Electric Credit.

title: Chem-Nuclear Appeals Order
description: Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc. said it had appealed an order issued last Friday in Federal District Court here denying its motion for a preliminary injunction against Waste Management Inc.'s tender offer for 50 percent of Chem's stock.

title: KEY TO HEALTHY BANKING AND THRIFT INDUSTRIES
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa Tour To Be Continued
description: A team of foreign players touring South Africa plans to continue its schedule despite boycotts by local black teams. ''I met with everyone involved on the organizational side for an update on the tour,'' Dennis Roach, a British-based soccer agent, said today.''

title: Kicking In
description: Ruud Krol and Kevin Keegan both phoned to R.S.V.P. yesterday, saying ''yes.'' But organizers are still waiting anxiously for some of the really big names to call and say they'll definitely play in the F.I.F.A. World All-Stars Game Aug. 7 at Giants Stadium.

title: Britain's Rail Service Nearly Back to Normal
description: Rail service in Britain returned to nearly normal today after the collapse of a 15-day-old strike by locomotive engineers because other unions would not support it.

title: ARSON AND J-51
description: The present city administration has never publicly acknowledged that its programs of tax incentives for the creation and rehabilitation of housing have fostered arson by rapacious landlords in a hurry for their tax and other rewards.

title: Staying in Football
description: Although he has been put on waivers by the Houston Oilers, 37-yearold Ken Stabler has no intention of leaving the game. Henry Pitts, a Selma, Ala., attorney who is also the veteran quarterback's agent, said yesterday that Stabler believes he'll be playing somewhere this fall or next spring. He said that playing with a team in the new United States Football League, which will begin competition next spring, was a possibility.

title: DANCE: ART ON THE BEACH FESTIVAL
description: THE dance component of the Art on the Beach Festival opened Sunday afternoon with a piece that made extraordinary use of the Battery Park City Landfill, on which the summer arts festival takes place. An untitled new work by Susan Rethorst moved figures through that strange, sprawling landscape to often magical effect. Though it was a less cohesive dance than many past Art on the Beach efforts by young postmodern choreographers, the piece had a great deal more to do with where it was danced.

title: SEARCHING THE PAST COURT TERM FOR BURGER'S STAMP
description: A search through the recent Supreme Court term for Warren E. Burger's footprints reveals shadows rather than firm impressions.

title: Hough, Trainer, Suspended a Year
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday suspended the license of the harness trainer Charles Hough for one year.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS $5.4 BILLION APPROPRIATION BILL
description: President Reagan, ending a veto battle with Congress over spending levels, has signed a bill to provide $5.4 billion to avert the furloughing of thousands of Federal workers.

title: CHASE IS SUING F.D.I.C. ON PENN SQUARE MOVES
description: In a suit that disclosed an investment of $212.2 million in Penn Square Bank loans, the Chase Manhattan Bank asked a Federal court today to stop the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation from distributing Penn Square deposits without keeping Chase's interests in mind.

title: NEW STUDY OF DOWNDRAFTS EXPECTED TO REDUCE DANGER OF PLANE CRASHES
description: IN a $2.2 million project employing a dense network of ground stations and six specially equipped aircraft, scientists in Colorado believe they may have learned enough about the sudden downdrafts, or ''microbursts,'' that have been blamed for several plane crashes to reduce greatly the danger of such accidents.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Weather

title: SINGAPORE, CITING UNITY, AGAIN REINS IN THE PRESS
description: For the second time in 11 years, the Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew has sought to advance its campaign for a national consensus by cracking down on the press.

title: HISTORY GIVES HOPE IN U.S.F.L. VENTURE
description: I n 1960, the first year of the American Football League, the average Nielsen television rating for the eight-team league on ABC was 5.8, with an 18 percent share of the audience. Not terribly good but not deadly either, especially for a new venture.

title: Market Place; McLean's Loss And Its Merger
description: WHEN is bad news good news? When the bad news is not as bad as expected. Thus, a substantial loss for the McLean Trucking Company in its fourth fiscal quarter did not result in a stock market setback.

title: West Germans Rescue 4 Kidnapped Children
description: A West German commando squad freed four kidnapped children -two Americans and two Yugoslavs -and arrested their kidnapper in Montenegro Province in Yugoslavia, Stuttgart officials said tonight.

title: Mobil Canada
description: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. said today that it had found oil and natural gas in two of five tests of a wildcat well north of its huge Hibernia discovery off Newfoundland.

title: Fan at Reds Game Dies After Fall
description: A 21-year-old woman was pronounced dead on arrival at General Hospital tonight after she reportedly jumped from the top deck during the Reds' game against the Pittsburgh Pirates at Riverfront Stadium.

title: WALTER H. JONES, JERSEY POLITICIAN
description: Walter H. Jones, a former New Jersey State Senator and Assemblyman, died yesterday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived in Norwood, N.J.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Home Finance Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a shelf registration covering up to $100 million of G.N.M.A.-collateralized bonds, to be underwritten by Dain Bosworth Inc.

title: Sharp-Olivetti Deal
description: The Sharp Corporation said today that it had signed an agreement with Olivetti covering technical cooperation in the field of office automation machines. The two will manufacture high-speed copying machines at an initial rate of 2,000 a month in Japan or Italy, starting this fall, it said. Sharp said it would also provide Olivetti with medium- and high-speed facsimile machines, mainly for the European market, leading to the joint development of such machines in the future.

title: REAGAN ASKS CONGRESS TO APPROVE SPENDING FOR MX AND C-5 PROJECTS
description: President Reagan pleaded with Congress today to preserve funds in next year's budget to build MX intercontinental missiles and C-5 air cargo transports.

title: U.S. SAID TO DECIDE AGAINST NEW TALKS TO BAN ALL A-TESTS
description: President Reagan decided today not to resume negotiations on a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: Talking Business with Roger J Marzulla of Mountain States Legal Foundation Free Market Philosophy
description: The Mountain States Legal Foundation, a five-year-old nonprofit law firm in Denver, gets a substantial part of its support from business sources. Unlike older public interest law groups, with their liberal orientation, Mountain States is part of a counterwave of public interest firms that bring a free market philosophy to court. James G. Watt, the former president of Mountain States, was appointed Secretary of the Interior last year, and Roger J. Marzulla replaced him. The Reagan Administration shares Mountain States' views on many public land questions the foundation has addressed, so Mr. Marzulla thinks it has an opportunity to tackle broader issues such as business regulation and tax policy. Recently Mr. Marzulla, 34 years old, discussed the foundation's work.

title: U.S.-Europe Airline Pact
description: The United States announced yesterday that it had formally accepted a multilateral agreement with 11 European goverments that allows airlines to set trans-Atlantic fares within specified zones without government approval.

title: POLISH OFFICIAL AT VATICAN TO DISCUSS TRIP
description: Poland's Foreign Minister visited the Vatican today for what church sources described as ''final, definitive'' talks on Pope John Paul II's proposed visit to his homeland this year.

title: LUXURY HOUSING GIVEN APPROVAL BY CITY PLANNERS
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday approved plans for construction of the Lincoln West luxury housing complex on Manhattan's West Side. Community leaders unhappy with the plan protested the commission's procedures.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Four Concerts Planned By Brooklyn Philharmonic

title: MORE PRISON SPACE IS NO SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Roman Jakobson, 85, Slavicist and Linguist
description: Roman Jakobson, an internationally known authority on Slavic languages and literatures, died Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 85 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Florafax Has Plan To Acquire F.T.D.
description: Florafax International Inc. said its directors had approved a plan to purchase Florists' Transworld Delivery Association for $50 million, an offer that F.T.D. directors will consider.

title: President Will Visit St. Louis
description: President Reagan will visit the Mathews-Dickey Boys' Club in St. Louis and attend a fund-raising dinner for the United States Olympic Committee there on Thursday, his spokesman, Larry Speakes, said today. Mr. Reagan may also be present for the end of a speedboat race up the Mississippi River from New Orleans to St. Louis in which his elder son, Michael, is competing. The dinner honors August A. Busch, president of Anheuser-Busch Inc., the brewery, and of the Cardinals baseball team, as ''sportsman of the year.''

title: Briefs on the Arts Dance Theater Workshop Opens Season Sept. 29
description: The Dance Theater Workshop, following its 18-year policy of presenting contemporary works by young artists and companies, will open its fall season Sept. 29 with a new work by Molissa Fenley, a postmodern choreographer and performer. ''Eureka,'' the one-woman premiere, will have music by Peter Gordon commissioned by the workshop.

title: STEPHEN H. GAYLE
description: Stephen H. Gayle, managing editor of Black Enterprise magazine, died Sunday after suffering a heart attack on the beach at Sag Harbor, L.I., where he had a summer residence. He was 34 years old and lived in New York City.

title: U.S. SAYS WILSON THREATENED TO ASSASSINATE A PROSECUTOR
description: The Justice Department said tonight that Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent awaiting trial on charges of illegally aiding Libyan terrorists, had threatened to kill the chief Federal prosecutor in the case.

title: C.A.B. Drops Reprisal
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board will not impose sanctions against two Peruvian airlines now that Peru has ended restrictions against Eastern Airlines, a C.A.B. spokesman said today.

title: Joltin' Joe?
description: They haven't played a major league baseball game in Washington since 1971, and Joe DiMaggio hasn't appeared in a regular-season game there since 1951.

title: WHAT THE PATIENTS AT PILGRAM FEAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Statoil Contract
description: The Norwegian state oil company, Statoil, said today that it had awarded part of a $60.4 million gas-storage tank contract to A.G. Noell, a unit of Salzgitter of West Germany.

title: Lack of Quality Grain Distorts Wheat Prices
description: Prices of wheat futures yesterday continued to be distorted by a shortage of quality grain in the face of huge crops and burdensome surpluses. While futures prices were declining after their sharp advances last week, cash buyers were raising their premiums for the shrinking supply of quality wheat. In fact, concern about the quality of current winter and spring wheat crops has become the dominant factor in the grain market.

title: U.S. LINKS UNION CHIEF TO 2 UNSOLVED SLAYINGS
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that the head of two security guard unions, convicted last month of racketeering, had also conspired in the unsolved murders of two men in 1977.

title: POVERTY RATE, 14%, TERMED HIGHEST SINCE '67
description: The number of Americans officially classified as poor increased by about 2.2 million, or 7.4 percent, in 1981, the Census Bureau reported today. That gave the nation its highest rate of poverty since 1967.

title: 3 CHARGED IN SECURITIES FRAUD
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit yesterday against two former employees of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. and a former government securities trader charging that they fraudulently traded securities at artificial prices, and took $691,000 in profits.

title: TEMPERS FRAYED BY HEAT OF DAY ON CITY TRANSIT
description: Barry Schwartz kept cool at Pennsylvania Station by eating ice cream. At Times Square, Ronald Daniels carried a towel to mop the sweat from his brow. Others hunted for the elusive air-conditioned subway car, or simply loosened their ties and swung their jackets over their shoulders.

title: Solid Ground for a Prison Policy
description: Like abortion and the nuclear freeze, the issue of prison construction focuses whole ideologies. The law-and-order school argues that more prisons are the obvious answer to the crime problem. The crime-is-a-complex-social-problem school argues that prisons cost too much and that crowding problems should be eased by managing criminal justice better.

title: HUTTON'S PRESIDENT GOES TO PRUDENTIAL
description: George L. Ball, widely viewed as one of the most effective and innovative managers on Wall Street, resigned yesterday as president of the E.F. Hutton Group Inc. to head a new Prudential Insurance Company subsidiary that includes the Bache Group Inc. and the rest of Prudential's growing investment and brokerage operations. The Ball appointment, which took Wall Street by surprise, was hailed by some analysts as offering a badly needed solution to the troubles at Bache, which was acquired by Prudential in June 1981.

title: Mozambique Rebels Hit City
description: A spokesman for the Mozambican National Resistance rebel group said today that guerrillas sabotaged water and power supplies to Mozambique's Indian Ocean port of Beira last week.

title: DEMOCRATS SAY THE BILL IS A SHAM
description: With bands playing and signs waving, President Reagan stood on the steps of the Capitol today and urged Congress to give rapid approval to a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget.

title: KINGMAN A TERROR TO DODGERS
description: The fans were just a few feet from the Met dugout in Dodger Stadium, packed on the field as part of a Camera Day promotion that allowed them to get close to the players.

title: U.S. INSISTS ARABS MUST GIVE HAVENS TO P.L.O. FIGHTERS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met today with the Syrian and Saudi Arabian Foreign Ministers to underscore the American contention that Arab nations must provide havens for the 6,000 Palestine Liberation Organization fighters under siege in west Beirut.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT IS INDICTED IN LIBYAN EXPLOSIVE SCHEME
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a former Central Intelligence Agency agent, Edwin P. Wilson, and two other men on charges growing out of the shipment of 20 tons of restricted, strategically sensitive plastic explosives to Libya in October 1977.

title: THRUWAY'S TOLLS TO END IN '96 WITH FEDERAL AID
description: Starting in 1996, motorists in New York State will be able to use the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway without paying tolls, under the terms of an agreement signed here today by representatives of the Federal Highway Trust and state officials.

title: News Analysis
description: With what could be either resolve or bluff, the Soviet Union has vowed to circumvent an embargo by President Reagan by substituting Soviet-built compressor stations and completing the controversial gas pipeline to Western Europe in time to make initial gas deliveries on schedule in 1984.

title: PUBLIC BROADCASTING WINS STRUGGLE FOR '84 FUNDS
description: After a long struggle on Capitol Hill, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting has succeeded in getting Congress to restore $24.4 million to its budget for its 1984 fiscal year. The money, part of an urgent supplemental appropriation bill signed by President Reagan on Sunday, raises the corporation's appropriation to $130 milllion from the $105.6 million originally requested by the Administration.

title: FROM A FARM IN KANSAS, A MAN OF LAW AND ECONOMICS
description: When he first arrived in Washington 25 years ago, Kenneth Willard Dam was fresh out of the University of Chicago Law School and still just a few years away from the Kansas farm where he grew up.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS, PAINE WEBBER ADVANCE
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its second-quarter profit climbed 7.5 percent from the previous year's level. The company said that earnings totaled $144 million, or $1.48 a share, in the quarter, up from $134 million, or $1.42 a share, in the corresponding period of 1981.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Action Industries of Pittsburgh said it had mailed shareholders a tender offer to purchase 250,000 of its common shares at $4 each.

title: Fireman's Fund Plans Acquisition
description: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies, a unit of Shearson/ American Express Inc., has reached an agreement with Houston-based Kaneb Services Inc. to purchase ARC Automation Group Inc., a Kaneb unit, for $52.5 million in cash.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Drilling Corp., Palo Alto, Calif., named Robert J. Horstmeyer president.

title: TOP PARTNER IS APPOINTED AT SEIDMAN
description: John D. Abernathy, partner-in-charge of the New York office of Seidman & Seidman, has been elected the next managing partner of the national accounting firm, succeeding B.Z. Lee, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Abernathy, who is 45, will take office in October 1983; the long transition period is meant to insure a smooth changeover, the firm announced.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at San Francisco. This is the second stop on the Mets' Western swing, and Dave Kingman, the National League home-run leader with 25, has six in his last seven games and four against the Giants this season. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; 10:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Basketball New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. Gus Williams of the Seattle SuperSonics, will team with his brother, Ray, the former Knick who is now with the Kansas City Kings, when the New York Gems play the New York Pros. Gus Williams is leading the summer league with a 33.3-point scoring average. The Pros feature Mike O'Koren, Geoff Huston and Hollis Copeland. Admission is $2 for adults, children $1.

title: THE UNINVITED GUESTS OF QUEEN VICTORIA
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME, AS THE MACHINE KNOWS IT
description: GOING back in time to childhood summers at my uncle's farm on Sweden's east coast, I remember a large chiming living-room clock with a single hand. I'm not sure whether the clock was so old as to have only the hour hand or whether the minute hand had simply fallen off. In any event, the missing hand mattered little. One knew the hour and the half-hour; the times between could remain approximate. Cows are pretty forgiving about minutes. Computers, on the other hand, are not.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 20, 1982
description: International Nuclear test talks will not resume, according to Administration and Congressional officials. They said that the decision not to resume efforts to conclude a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing with the Soviet Union and Britain had been made by President Reagan at a National Security Council meeting. (Page A1, Column 6.) An apparent Iran-Iraq stalemate after six days of fighting in southern Iraq has apparently prompted a change in Teheran's policies. Calling Iran's invasion a ''defensive operation,'' Iranian leaders have said in statements and broadcasts that other Persian Gulf countries should not feel threatened by Teheran. (A1:5.)

title: Ring Comeback at 50
description: Kenny Lane left boxing 15 years ago to become a television repairman. But at the age of 50, he is making a comeback, and his first step was a successful one.

title: Lundquist Breaks World Swim Mark
description: Steve Lundquist, a 21-yearold senior at Southern Methodist University, broke the world record for the 100-meter breast-stroke tonight.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Other Carnegie Hall

title: Article 027350 -- No Title
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation posted a second-quarter net loss of $1 million compared with profits of $22.1 million, or $3.09 a share, in the corresponding period last year.

title: Fund of Funds Lawyer Enjoys Competitiveness
description: More than $80 million was involved in a decision that a Federal judge handed down Friday on a lawsuit brought by the Fund of Funds against Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm. But Charles D. Reycraft, the fund's soft-spoken chief lawyer in the suit, said yesterday that he had no trouble sleeping nights during the course of the 55-day trial in a Federal courtroom in New York last year.

title: MOFFETT SEEKS SOFTER CAMPAIGN IMAGE
description: Sipping a cup of coffee on his front porch the other morning, Representative Toby Moffett of Connecticut talked of how he would like to project a softer image as the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate.

title: JAMES T. TYNION
description: James T. Tynion, a lawyer in New York City for 50 years, died Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS LOAN RATE TO BANKS A HALF-POINT, TO 11 1/2%
description: The Federal Reserve Board today lowered the interest it charges on loans to banks to 11 1/2 percent from 12 percent. Some analysts said the move would allow many other interest rates to drop slightly in the next several weeks.

title: EXXON TO DISCOUNT CASH PURCHASES
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A., the nation's largest oil company, said yesterday that it would cut prices to dealers nationwide in August to allow discounts on cash purchases. In the program, similar to one announced by the Amoco Oil Company last month, Exxon hopes to compete with companies such as Hess and Arco, which had undercut Exxon's prices by not offering credit card service.

title: CONCERT PIANIST, 34, IS FOUND MURDERED ON APARTMENT FLOOR
description: A 34-year-old concert pianist was found murdered in his midtown Manhattan apartment yesterday afternoon, according to the police. The pianist, tentatively identified as Raymond Shigeoka of Hawaii, was found face up with a pillow over his face in the middle of the living room of his apartment at 310 West 56th Street at 5:45 P.M., according to Sgt. Edward Burns, a police spokesman.

title: Advertising; Holland America Campaign
description: THERE are a few former agency people running the marketing show at Holland America Cruises, and things seem to be hopping. For one thing, the 1982 media budget is $10 million, more than double last year's, and, apparently, the marketplace is reacting.

title: Mary St. George Bride of Richard Adler
description: Mary Louise Mullen St. George of Lucaya, the Bahamas, was married in Southampton, L.I., yesterday to Richard Adler, the composer. State Supreme Court Justice Katherine England performed the ceremony in the garden at Pinewillow, the bridegroom's home.

title: CALIFORNIANS GEAR UP FOR A DEBATE ON GUN CONTROLS
description: Californians are moving on a broad front to limit the spread of pistols, and leaders of the state's strong gun lobby say they are preparing for a difficult and expensive battle to halt the effort's momentum.

title: Silver Futures Advance In a Surge of Buying
description: Falling interest rates and a weakening dollar provoked new buying in the silver futures market yesterday. Silver's advance spilled over into the gold futures ring of New York's Commodity Exchange, where large gains were also posted.

title: HUMAN SERVICES DEPT. SEEKS RIGHT TO CUT PUBLIC ROLE IN RULE-MAKING
description: The Department of Health and Human Services is proposing to change its procedures so that new rules for Social Security, Medicaid, welfare and other programs could be issued without advance public notice.

title: Movie on Bear Bryant
description: Saying that ''somebody was going to do a movie whether I liked it or not,'' Paul (Bear) Bryant has reluctantly given permission for a film to be made on his life and times as football coach at Alabama. The movie will be called - what else? - ''The Bear.''

title: A New Publication Aimed at Physicians
description: Physicians are prime advertising targets on two grounds: they prescribe billions of dollars worth of pharmaceuticals and they have among the highest incomes of professions. So there are those publications that want to reach them with health care advertising and those with consumer product advertising.

title: Article 030428 -- No Title
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that it lost $16.1 million in the second quarter of 1982 as a result of its dealings with a small New York securities firm and an Oklahoma City bank that failed.

title: LEBANON AND P.L.O. JOIN IN SEARCH FOR AMERICAN
description: The Lebanese police and security forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization searched today for David S. Dodge, the acting president of the American University of Beirut, who was kidnapped by unknown gunmen Monday night. The search has yielded no results so far.

title: Lockheed Up Sharply
description: The Lockheed Corporation reported today that net income for the second quarter of 1982 increased two and a half times from a year earlier, to $51.8 million, or $2.68 a share, from $14.8 million, or 83 cents a share. The results for the 1981 quarter were reduced by a $19.5 million provision for discontinued operations, the company said.

title: Nuggets Get Hanzlik
description: The Seattle SuperSonics have sent Bill Hanzlik, one of their starting guards last season, to the Denver Nuggets to complete last month's David Thompson trade.

title: Honduran Guerrillas Repulsed Near U.S. Envoy's Residence
description: Leftist guerrillas tried to seize the central police barracks 300 yards from the residence of Ambassador John Negroponte of the United States tonight, but they were forced to scatter after a heavy firefight, a military spokesman said.

title: TWO LEGIONNAIRE'S DISEASE DEATHS CONFIRMED BY A ROCHESTER HOSPITAL
description: Two patients contracted Legionnaire's disease at Highland Hospital here and died last month while being treated for other medical problems, officials reported today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Derwinski for Energy?

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Enid Nemy WOMEN'S DIARIES OF THE WEST- WARD JOURNEY. By Lillian Schlis- sel. 262 pages. Schocken. $16.95.

title: INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $1.1 million for the qr and $1.5 million for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $700,000 for the qr and $2.1 million for the 6 mo

title: FED WILL STICK TO TIGHT 1982 TARGETS
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the nation's central bank would stick to its relatively tight monetary targets for this year despite the continuing slump of the economy and the strains on the nation's financial markets.

title: 1. Philharmonic T-Shirt
description: Another T-shirt? This one not only benefits a good cause, but alo is more attractive than most. At all the free parks concerts of the New York Philharmonic this summer - the first one is next Tuesday on the Great Lawn in Central Park - volunteers will sell the shirt as a souvenir. It is a deep blue, decorated with stars, a crescent moon and the parks concerts logo, and it costs $7. In addition, there are ''I'm a Friend of the Philharmonic'' buttons ($1) and blue-and-white shoelaces ($2). Profits help the parks concerts program.

title: RAYMOND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Stock Split Proposed
description: The General Electric Company P.L.C. proposes to split its existing 25-pence ordinary shares into five new shares of 5 pence nominal value, a company statement said today. A circular giving full details of the proposed split will be issued Aug. 5.

title: ARGENTINA'S JUBLIANT REBIRTH OF POLITICS
description: The small boxing arena shook with the fervent cheers and chants of more than 10,000 sweltering Argentines crammed into the bleachers, stuffed down the halls and spilling out onto the street.

title: Shuttle Astronauts Plan 3-Hour Walk in Space
description: Two astronauts will take a three-hour space walk on the fifth flight of the space shuttle Columbia to practice techniques that may be used in 1984 to retrieve and repair a broken satellite, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: 2 Bolivian Unions Plan Strike As President Is Inaugurated
description: Two unions vowed today to stage a one-hour strike Wednesday as Gen. Guido Vildoso is sworn in as President.

title: P.& G. Files 3 More Suits
description: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday brought three more lawsuits against individuals whom it accused of circulating ''false and malicious'' statements about the company. The suits, like two others filed July 1, are aimed at stopping the spread of rumors that the consumer goods company is involved in Satanism and Devil worship.

title: BRIEFS
description: * CBS Inc. and the Ideal Toy Corp. said their boards had approved a definitive agreement for the merger of Ideal with a wholly owned CBS subsidiary. The agreement provides that Ideal shareholders receive $14.85 in cash per share held.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. Seattle, which is doing better than it ever has at this stage of the season, makes its last visit here. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Giants, at San Francisco. This game is also a season-series finale. (Television - Channel 9, Radio - WMCA, 570; 3 P.M.) Cracker Jack Old-Timers Classic, at Washington. First telecast of the game played Monday night in Washington for benefit of former players, coaches and scouts. Johnny Mize, who starred with the St. Louis Cardinals and New York Giants, and Enos (Country) Slaughter, who starred with the Cardinals, both wound up with the Yankees, and so played for the American League. (ESPN, 8 P.M., tape.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VISITOR

title: DRINKING WATER IN JERSEY CITY MUST STILL BE BOILED
description: The requirement that the 300,000 customers of the Jersey City Water Department boil all of their drinking water for five minutes remained in effect today after state officials detected possible excessive bacteria in the water, city officials said.

title: Bridge:; Leventritt Team Leading In Von Zedtwitz Tourney; A team of great experience seems on the road to a successful defense defense in the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, which would add to a collection of titles won at every level of the game.
description: Peter Leventritt, Dick Kahn, Ronald Blau, Marty Ginsberg and Edgar and Betty Kaplan won the 1982 event, and the same group, with Boris Koytchou replacing Mrs. Kaplan, is the only undefeated team in the 1982 event.

title: LABOR LEADER SAYS CITY HAS MONEY FOR 7% RAISE
description: A leader of the coalition representing more than 180,000 municipal workers said yesterday that New York City had up to $511 million in its present budget to pay for the first year of a labor settlement.

title: Mitsubishi Deal
description: The Mitsubishi Oil Company said it had signed a contract with a British Petroleum Company subsidiary, B.P.Oil International, to buy 15,000 barrels of crude a day for three years, starting in October.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Interest rates fell yesterday, with the steepest declines occurring in the Treasury bill market, where they dropped about five-eighths of a percentage point from Monday's auction level for the three-month issue and by slightly more than a quarter of a percentage point for the six-month issue.

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 CONGRESSIONAL PRIMARIES FACING DEMOCRATS IN CONNECTICUT SEPT. 7
description: Connecticut Democrats were faced today with two Congressional primary elections on Sept. 7 as a result of district nominating conventions.

title: U.S. SAYS IRAQIS NOW HOLD EDGE IN GULF FIGHTING
description: After a week of heavy fighting, Iraq appears to have achieved a limited but important military victory in its war with Iran by blunting a major Iranian offensive and forcing a standoff in the battle, according to American officials.

title: AT 75, APPLING DISCOVERS A SWING THAT HITS HOMERS
description: H ow can a 75-year-old man hit a home run in a major league stadium? And hit it 320 feet, over a fence, with Warren Spahn pitching?

title: CARTS OF MANY FLAVORS
description: When the weather is good, and even when it is not so good, the ice cream carts come out in force. At high noon on the Avenue of the Americas in the 50's, as many as a dozen different companies set up shop in multiple locations. Some have a cart or two on every block; five or six competing carts on a given stretch of sidewalk are not unusual.

title: Koch, Class of '81, Asked About Job Prospects
description: L ast fall, 36 years late, Edward Koch finally got the bachelor's degree from City College that he missed receiving because of World War II. Apparently he is carried now as a member of the class of '81, for he received a three-page, 40-question survey sent by the City University to those who graduated a year ago.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MEMORABLE DISHES FROM A MASTER MEXICAN CHEF
description: AFEW months ago Pierre Franey and I were invited to plan a menu and supervise the preparation of quintessentially American food that was to be served to nearly 200 French chefs visiting this country. The vast majority of these chefs had never sampled the native fare of the United States. The dishes we proposed covered the country - the Creole cooking of Louisiana; crabs from California, Florida and the Chesapeake Bay; New York-style pastrami and corned beef with rye; a barbecue from Kansas City, and desserts, from Southern pecan pie to Yankee-style cheesecake.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Applied Magnetics Corporation's issue of one million common shares was priced at $17.875 a share by underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs.

title: MUNCIE REPORTED WARNED
description: The San Diego Chargers are reported to have told Chuck Muncie, their best running back, that he cannot attend training camp unless he seeks treatment for a drug problem. The team will not confirm or deny the report.

title: Superior Reports Results of Drilling
description: The Superior Oil Company said that its Annie M. Hill No.3 well, 30 miles north of Mobile, Ala., flowed at a rate of 1,992 barrels of oil and 1.5 million cubic feet of gas daily on a 22/64-inch choke from perforations between 16,948 and 16,952 feet. A second zone, perforated between 16,906 feet and 16,914 feet, flowed 2,496 barrels of oil and 1.7 million cubic feet of gas daily on a 23/64-inch choke.

title: IN CONGRESS, THE INVASION HAS ERODED ISRAEL'S ALMOST AUTOMATIC SUPPORT
description: After six weeks of war in Lebanon, Israel's support in Congress has been significantly eroded to what some members describe as its lowest point. But in their view it has not reached the stage where substantial numbers would oppose further American aid to Israel.

title: SYRIA BIDS U.S. END SUPPORT OF ISRAEL
description: Syria's Information Minister called on the United States today to end its military and political support of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon and initiate an even-handed policy in the Middle East.

title: Rising Temperatures Mean Sagging Bridges
description: S pirits were not the only things that sagged during the heat wave. When temperatures rise so high, suspension bridges around town sort of droop, lowering the clearance for passing ships, though never to the point of trouble.

title: USAIR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OFFICE BOOM LEADING DEVELOPMENT IN PRINCETON AREA
description: Ten years ago, first-class office space was practically nonexistent in this quiet university town surrounded by miles of beautiful farms. Outside of the downtown area where businesses favored restored houses for their offices, there was a complex of 17 office buildings that resembled garden apartments and rent was $3 a square foot.

title: MISGUIDED PROTECTION FOR U.S. SUGAR GROWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: LABOR NOW ALSO COUNSELS CANDIDATES
description: COPE, the political arm of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has started giving candidates advice along with contributions as part of a broad effort by organized labor to increase its political influence this year and in 1984.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POLE EXPECTED TO ANNOUNCE EASING OF MARTIAL LAW CURBS
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, met today with associates on the eve of a session of Parliament at which he is expected to announce an easing of martial law.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Sunday about the Nether- lands Dance Theater was accompa- nied by an incorrect photograph. The Netherlands dancer shown was Karen Tims.

title: UNION PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a net gain of $29,800,000 or 31 cents for the qr and the 6 mos fromthe sale of interest in IC Industries; the company disposed of 2,100,000 shrs of IC Industries common stock under a 1971 greement with the Interstate CommerceCommission to dispose of the shrs by Aug 1982

title: HOUSE UNIT TO START DRAFTING TAX BILL
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that the panel would start drafting a revenue-raising bill Wednesday or Thursday and would try to finish by the weekend.

title: WHEN FLAVORS COME IN TUBES, A LITTLE SQUEEZE MEANS A LOT
description: WHILE a squeeze of mayonnaise, a squish of garlic and a squiggle of cod roe are commonplace in Europe, where more than 400 million tubes of food are purchased annually, only anchovy paste, domestically produced, has been readily available in tubes in this country until recently.

title: 2 EJECTED AFTER BRAWL OVER DOUBLE PLAY
description: Kent Hrbek drove in two runs before he was ejected from a fight-marred game, leading the Minnesota Twins to a 5-3 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers tonight.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My family name is Mornay, which is, as you know, the name of one of the most famous sauces in the French kitchen. I have had many inquiries from friends to know if I am a descendant of the creator of that sauce. I can trace my family history back for a few generations but can find no reference to any association with the culinary arts. Do you know the origin of that name as it is used in the kitchen?

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Life on the Edge
description: style.

title: BATTLE OVER FLORIDA WETLANDS ENDS AFTER 10 YEARS
description: After a decade as a cause celebre, the legal battle between a giant development corporation and state and Federal officials over the fate of thousands of acres of fragile wetlands in Southwest Florida ended amicably today.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
P.L.O. OFFICIALS EXPRESS GUARDED OPTIMISM ABOUT DISCUSSIONS AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Palestine Liberation Organization officials expressed guarded optimism today over reports about the results of President Reagan's meeting with the Foreign Ministers of Syria and Saudi Arabia.

title: Sanchez Big Favorite Tonight
description: For two years, Azumah Nelson has been stalking Salvador Sanchez to win the title he says ''belongs to Ghana.'' But Nelson, who, despite only 13 pro fights, says he is a millionaire, is among only a few persons who believe he can take the World Boxing Council featherweight title tonight at Madison Square Garden. Sanchez, the champion, is considered among the most accomplished boxers at any weight.

title: SENATE UNIT STARTS STUDYING F.B.I. UNDERCOVER INQUIRIES
description: In the first day of Senate hearings on undercover investigations, a select committee swiftly focused on the use of such inquiries in corruption cases involving Government officials, especially the Abscam investigation.

title: HUNT, PHILIP A, CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $66,000 for the qr and $123,000 for the 6 mos;yr ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations

title: Another Tenant At Meadowlands
description: The United States Football League has called a news conference for tomorrow morning at Giants Stadium to announce a lease agreement at the stadium for the league's New York franchise.

title: Capital Demands
description: Abe Pollin has set four conditions he says must be met if the Washington Capitals are to continue playing hockey in their Landover, Md., arena. The owner of the Capitals said the financially troubled club would play elsewhere under new ownership or be disbanded unless certain attendance goals were met and tax concessions granted.

title: BRITISH WITHHOLD SPY CASE DETAILS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher refused today to furnish details of Britain's latest spy scandal to an apprehensive and unruly House of Commons.

title: California Youth Pleads Guilty To Death He Boasted About
description: A teen-ager who the authorities said bragged to friends about killing his girlfriend pleaded guilty today to first-degree murder, ending his murder trial.

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LARGEST MOVIE COMPLEX IN U.S. OPENS ON COAST
description: HOLLYWOOD THE largest movie theater complex in the United States opened last week in a new shopping center in Los Angeles. There are 14 movie screens tucked away on the eighth floor of the Beverly Center mall in West Hollywood, not by any means a world record. Cineplex, proprietor of the 14 theaters, holds the Guinness record for its 2l-screen complex in Toronto.

title: 'PINDOWN' TACTIC CALLED PERIL TO TIGHTLY PACKED MX MISSILE
description: If the United States bases its new MX missiles in a dense cluster, the Soviet Union might be able to keep them from being fired for the first few hours of a nuclear war, some weapons experts believe.

title: AIDE REFLECTS SHULTZ STYLE
description: After the tumultuous tenure of Alexander M. Haig Jr., the State Department has been placed in the hands of a group of men noted for their calm, conservative and self-assured authority. They are consummate old boys of the country's political/corporate network, who today are flying to northern California's exclusive Bohemian Grove to relax and confer on the future course of the State Department.

title: CORONA, ON STAND FOR FIRST TIME, DENIES KILLING 25 WORKERS IN '71
description: In an unexpected move, Juan V. Corona today took the stand in his own defense for the first time to deny he murdered 25 itinerant farm workers in 1971.

title: ROCKABILLY: STRAY CATS, AN L.I. TRIO
description: based rock-and-roll style that launched Elvis Presley and a host of other 50's pioneers, still exerts a more powerful attraction on contemporary musicians than any other roots style of rock. And its adaptability can be gauged by how differently it is used by younger groups.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ALTHOUGH about 6 to 8 percent of all births are premature, they are the cause of 85 percent of deaths of the newborn and the major cause of such nonfatal newborn complications as respiratory distress syndrome. Each year in this country, hundreds of thousands of babies born prematurely (after 20 weeks but before 37 weeks of pregnancy) encounter problems.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARAB AIDES OFFER NEW PLAN TO END WEST BEIRUT SIEGE
description: The Syrian and Saudi Arabian Foreign Ministers outlined a new plan to President Reagan today for breaking the Israeli siege of west Beirut, Administration officials said. Under the plan, the 6,000 Palestine Liberation Organization fighters there would be temporarily moved to northern Lebanon before being evacuated to several other Arab nations.

title: MEMORIES OF F.D.R.'s 'BLACK CABINET'
description: Alfred Edgar Smith's step is quick, his gray-blue eyes bright and his memory sharp as he reminisces in the study of his Northeast Washington home about the years when he was one of some 20 blacks in top executive positions and made up what was known as Franklin Delano Roosevelt's ''black Cabinet.''

title: Consultant to Head A Troubled Dreco
description: Jerry E. Goldress, a consultant to ailing companies, has been named president and chief executive officer of Dreco Energy Services Ltd., an oil-drilling and rig-building concern that is in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: 'MAN WHO STOLE THE SUN,' COMIC SCIENCE
description: ''THE MAN WHO STOLE THE SUN'' is the sad story of a science teacher who builds a homemade atomic bomb and uses it to demand a Rolling Stones concert in Tokyo, only to discover that he has contracted plutonium poisoning in the process. I'm not joking, and the movie isn't either. Well, maybe it's joking a little. But not enough.

title: Grey Expands In Australia
description: Grey Advertising in Sydney has moved from being the 21st largest to 14th largest in Australia by the simple expedient of buying Murray Evans Advertising, the 22d largest.

title: CONCERT: MOSTLY MOZART, CONDUCTED BY ZINMAN
description: AS befits a festival that bears his name, it was Mozart who benefited from the best performances at Monday evening's unusually rich, meaty Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: French Honor Nikolais

title: British Jobless at 13.4%
description: Unemployment, the most serious economic problem facing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government, worsened this month to a record 13.4 percent of the nation's work force, up from 12.8 percent in June.

title: RTC TRANSPORATION CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S the opening-night party for a new play, the play was a bomb and there you are standing next to one of the stars.
