Or a friend has just written a book and after reading it, you wonder why. But the person involved naturally expects some comment. What to do, what to do? Is honesty always the best policy, even when it may mean hurting or losing a friend?

title: PARADYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a pooling acquisition

title: From Computer to Car
description: Henry Burkhardt 3d, one of the three computer experts who helped found Data General, recently left the company's board to pursue other interests that include plans for a two-seat sports car.

title: THERE'S NO FREE MARKET IN SHIPPING
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomson Homer Wears Well
description: As soon as the rangy, silver-haired man in wire-rimmed glasses and a gray National League uniform had climbed the dugout steps at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, he was surrounded.

title: Kala Lobell Wins $723,250 Pace
description: Bill O'Donnell, who last year became the first driver in harness racing to win purses worth more than $4 million, moved closer to that plateau tonight as he scored with Chestnut Tree Stables' Kala Lobell in the $723,250 Sweetheart Pace at the Meadowlands.

title: Kaiser Prices Rise
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said that it was raising its prices for ingot and billet products sold overseas by 2.5 percent to 8 percent, effective immediately. The exact increases will depend on the product, alloy, form and geographic region, Kaiser said. ''Prices in many areas have become far too low, and we are not interested in participating in market areas where those low levels persist,'' Kaiser said.

title: A CALL FROM THE PLAINS: WHERE ARE WE GOING WITH THE MX MISSILE?
description: Dear Secretary Weinberger: Thank you, Mr. Secretary, for taking the time to visit with us here in Cheyenne, our ''Magic City of the Plains,'' before you make your next MX decision.

title: LUNDY ELECTRONICS & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $75,000...C-Including a $100,000 tax credit relatedto British tax legislation

title: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEATER: 'JAZZ SET,' TALE OF 6 MUSICIANS
description: RON MILNER'S ''Jazz Set'' looks like a play that has been rethought so many times that the author finally forgot what he was thinking about in the first place. It's full of half-baked ideas, blurry characters and fractured narrative lines that lead nowhere. At the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, it has been given a far better production than it merits by the director, Norman Riley, and a hard-working cast.

title: A GUATEMALAN GENERAL'S RISE TO POWER
description: Some politicians and diplomats here are offering a version of the events surrounding Gen. Efrain Rios Montt's rise to power that is at odds with the one given by the general and his backers.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 21, 1982
description: International A new plan for breaking the siege of west Beirut was outlined to President Reagan by the foreign ministers of Syria and Saudi Arabia at a 90-minute meeting at the White House, according to Administration officials. They said the proposal called for temporarily moving the 6,000 besieged Palestinian fighters to northern Lebanon before they are evacuated to other Arab countries. (Page A1, Column 6.) Soviet support for withdrawal of the Palestinians from west Beirut appeared likely. Leonid I. Brezhnev endorsed the use of a United Nations force to end the impasse as he restated opposition to any involvement by American forces. (A9:1-2.)

title: Sugar Import Fee Cut
description: Fees on imports of foreign sugar will be reduced by a cent a pound effective Wednesday because of higher domestic prices, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today. The fees were imposed in an effort to protect domestic producers from large amounts of cheaper foreign sugar entering the American market. When that failed to do the job, President Reagan imposed import quotas two months ago. Mr. Block said the new fees would be 2.4193 cents for raw sugar and 3.4193 cents for refined sugar.

title: 7 OFFICERS INDICTED FOR CORRUPTION
description: Seven police officers, including two sergeants, have been indicted on charges resulting from a two-year investigation into corruption in a Queens precinct.

title: GIANTS, ON 5-RUN 3d, TURN BACK PULEO
description: The performance of the Mets' pitching staff reached a new low tonight when Charlie Puleo, the most consistent starter in the last month, lasted just four innings in a 5-1 loss to the Giants.

title: GOODRICH, B F, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $4.4 million from the sale of a synthetic rubber plant and a gain of $5.2 million from a reduction in pension expense...C-After a loss of$8 million from devaluation of the Mexican peso

title: STEELWORKERS PROVIDE FOOD FUND FOR JOBLESS
description: Union workers still on the job at a Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation plant here have pledged $40,000 from their paychecks to help feed the families of steelworkers whose jobless benefits are running out.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. COMFIRMS A PLAN TO HALT TALKS ON A NUCLEAR TEST BAN
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the President had decided to set aside efforts to negotiate a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing until verification measures of existing testing treaties can be strengthened.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT'S an election summer in Gotham, a time for the city to take stock of itself, to monitor its condition and look to its future. What better time, then, for New York to undergo its annual checkup? Metropolitan Diary's attending physician, Dr. Joseph J. Neuschatz, was assigned to assess the health of our city, and here is his report:

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52

title: Careers; English Majors and Business
description: THE Association of Departments of English recently met for three days on an unlikely campus: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y. The group, consisting of 90 Ph.D's who are chairmen of English departments at colleges around the nation, hardly looked like a gathering of radicals, but there was a big difference between this meeting and earlier ones.

title: 10 Union Activists Are Freed in Turkey
description: A military judge today ordered the release of 10 leftist union activists who had been jailed since September 1980, when army officers overturned the elected Government.

title: GLEASON WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including a tax credit of $2.5 million

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Miriam Colon Edgar To Get Award Aug. 10

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect income deductions of $302,000 for the qr and $578,000 for the 6 mos from the adoption of LIFO accounting and new accounting rules for foreign currency translation

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Ascap Honors 17

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Kenny Rogers Signs Lucrative RCA Pact

title: TV: RERUN OF 'RAPE AND MARRIAGE'
description: do-well beautician in ''Diner,'' had the unenviable job of playing John Rideout in ''Rape and Marriage,'' a 1980 television movie being rerun tonight at 9 o'- clock on CBS-TV. Mr. Rideout, it will be recalled, was the Oregon husband whose wife, Greta, charged him with rape under a new law enabling her to do so. He wasn't entirely a heel, or at least Mrs.Rideout didn't fully think him one, because she briefly reconciled with him after the case was resolved. Their story is a little too complicated and sordid for the makers of this plain, well-meaning, none too imaginative television movie.

title: Wisconsin Worker Gets $196,500 in a Sex Suit
description: A Federal jury today awarded $196,500 to a state employee in a sexual harassment suit against his former supervisor.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: SOME rock musicians and songwriters are high-minded idealists who would like to change the world. And some are not. Queen, a British rock quartet that has recorded four gold and five platinum albums and will be at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday and Wednesday, belongs in the category of those would not - or at least Freddie Mercury, the band's lead vocalist, does.

title: NO MARINES TO BEIRUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Hazelwood
description: The Ford Motor Company has surveyed 960 auto workers laid off indefinitely from its Hazelwood, Mo., assembly plant and found an overwhelming number would return if a second shift were started, a spokesman said. The 1,200 first-shift workers have been working overtime since the beginning of March making the popular, large-size Mercury Marquis.

title: INCOME UP BY ONLY 0.3%
description: Personal income of Americans rose threetenths of 1 percent in June, about half as much as in the two previous months, the Government reported today. Consumer spending, though, fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest decline since last fall.

title: Fafnir Layoffs Set
description: Fafnir Bearing, which manufactures ball bearings, said it planned to lay off an undetermined number of employees at its New Britain and Newington branches and to furlough for one week about 275 workers later this month because of a ''continuing deterioration in Fafnir's incoming order rate.'' About 1,000 Fafnir workers have been laid off over the past 10 months.

title: RESEARCHERS RENEW WARNING ON EFFECTS OF GLOBAL WARMING
description: Plans for meeting future energy needs should consider the danger that use of fossil fuels may lead to higher temperatures and a worldwide climate change, the National Research Council said today.

title: GREATE BAY CASINO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
23.4 MILLION IN U.S. WERE OUT OF WORK SOMETIME LAST YEAR
description: Nearly 23.4 million Americans, or about one of five workers, were unemployed sometime in 1981, the Labor Department reported today.

title: WOMEN ARE MOVING UP IN CABLE TELEVISION
description: WHEN Kay Koplovitz called her parents in Milwaukee to tell them that she had just been named president and chief executive officer of the U.S.A. Cable Network, whose prime-time schedule consists mainly of live sports coverage, her mother wanted to know if the title meant she was the network's top sportscaster.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Diet Institute Inc., Marlboro, N.J., named Donald E. LeMoine vice president of franchise development.

title: REAGAN, IN FIRST POLICY STATEMENT, ASKS AN ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW
description: In his first general statement on environmental policy since taking office, President Reagan said today that a clean and healthy environment was ''fundamental to the promise of a better life.'' But he also said the nation must be more efficient in achieving that goal.

title: Market Place; Why Revlon Is Hurting
description: BIGGEST is often safest for investors during hard times. But Revlon, the nation's largest retailer of cosmetics with nearly a fifth of the market, may face more problems than its competitors.

title: ISRAELIS ARE AWAITING RESULTS OF U.S. TALKS WITH ARAB MINISTERS
description: Israel adopted a wait-and-see attitude today toward the United States-Arab talks in Washington aimed at solving the impasse over Palestinian guerrillas besieged in west Beirut.

title: ORANGE & ROCKLAND UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TV: 'JANE EYRE' STARTS 4-PART DRAMATIZATION
description: THE idle question comes to mind with the start tonight at 8 o'clock of a four-part dramatization of ''Jane Eyre'' on WNET-TV, and it asks whether anyone reads the Charlotte Bronte novel in its print original anymore.

title: FORD AND BIRDSONG IN REUNION
description: For Phil Ford, it was a reunion. When he entered a crowded restaurant today for his first news conference as a member of the New Jersey Nets, he was comforted by the sight of a few familiar faces.

title: LIMITS TO IRAN'S THREAT
description: Gulf Arabs are understandably concerned about Iran's advance into Iraq, but a careful assessment shows the threat to them is overstated; the current near-panic in the United States is dangerously excessive. Neither radical Islamic revolutions in the Persian Gulf area nor a widening of the Iran-Iraq war seems imminent.

title: Man Enters Guilty Plea In Theft of Rare Books
description: A St. Louis man pleaded guilty today in the theft of more than 500 rare books valued at $100,000 from libraries at several major universities.

title: Briefs on the Arts Elizabeth Ashley Buys Broadcast Rights to 'Cat'
description: Elizabeth Ashley has bought the world broadcast rights to ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' from Tennessee Williams. According to the actress, the negotiations took one and a half years.

title: PIES AND POLITICS MAKE A FULL LIFE
description: WASHINGTON WHEN Joan Specter walked into the capital's Palm Restaurant recently, she discovered that her name brought instant recognition. Not because she was the wife of a Senator, but because of her pies. The maitre d'hotel greeted her effusively; waiters stopped by her table.

title: BATUS EXPECTED TO SHIFT TOP EXECUTIVES AT FIELD
description: Only four months after acquiring the Chicago-based Marshall Field & Company, Batus Inc. has begun to dismantle the retailer's management, industry sources said yesterday. The move is aimed at improving links between the various Field divisions and Batus headquarters in New York, the sources said.

title: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $20,158,000 for the latest qr from the exchange of stock for debt and $4,526,000 for the yr-ago qr from a state tax settlemen

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MILITARY SPENDING DEBATED IN HOUSE
description: The House began voting today on amendments to a bill authorizing more than $177 billion for weapons, research and military operations and maintenance, turning back a proposal to cut such spending by more than $50 billion.

title: CONTROL DATA OFF 21%
description: Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that its net income rose 19.9 percent, primarily because of special gains related to the sale of part of its stake in its French affiliate, CII-Honeywell Bull.

title: Striking at Mrs. Thatcher
description: The male Argentine junta underestimated the political grit of Margaret Thatcher. Ditto Britain's railway men, who have now abandoned an impulsive strike after she warned they would be fired. Now comes the Irish Republican Army, which callously claims responsibility for the bloody bomb attacks in London yesterday. To defeat this gang would assure the Prime Minister a worthy place in history. Can she pull it off?

title: AWARDS FOR WINE LISTS
description: Twelve restaurants have been chosen by The Wine Spectator, the trade newspaper of the wine industry, as winners of 1982 ''grand awards'' for the quality of their wine lists. The awards will be announced in the publication next week and will be presented at the California Wine Experience, a convention to be held Oct. 9 to 11 at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco.

title: PHIBRO-SALMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE LIGHTER ICE CREAMS: NOW LESS IS MORE
description: MUCH of the news from the ice cream front is distinctly lighter. Lighter? With platoons of shiny new Frusen Gladje and Alpen Zauber carts plying the streets and dishing up 16 percent butterfat servings for a quick 275 calories? Nevertheless, the answer is yes, for if the wagons themselves are making their debut this season, the brands of dense, premium ice cream that they dispense have been around for a while.

title: Weaver Suspended for Striking Umpire
description: Earl Weaver, manager of the Baltimore Orioles, was suspended for one week and fined $2,000 by the American League president, Lee MacPhail, today for striking Terry Cooney, an umpire, during an argument.

title: PFIZER JUMPS
description: Philip Morris Inc. reported yesterday that strong domestic cigarette sales caused net income in the second quarter to increase 22.8 percent, while revenues advanced 6.2 percent.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rewards of Running Come Early in the Day

title: End to Steel Curb Asked
description: The European Economic Community formally asked the Reagan Administration today to suspend special United States duties on European steel products while new attempts are made to reach a compromise agreement on the level of European steel sales in the United States.

title: Zapata Wins Title
description: Hilario Zapata of Panama regained the World Boxing Council junior flyweight title today with a split decision over Tadashi Tomori of Japan. Zapata, a 23-year-old lefthander, took back the title he lost to Amada Urusua of Mexico in Panama City last February in a second-round knockout. Zapata first won the title from Shigeo Nakajima of Japan in 1980.

title: WHEELABRATOR-FRYE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,400,000 for the qr and $7,800,000 for the 6 mos

title: A PREMEDITATED WAR THAT GOT OUT OF HAND
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Envoy Arrives in Angola
description: Vernon Walters, a special United States envoy, arrived in Luanda, the Angolan capital, today for a new round of talks with Angolan leaders on the future of South-West Africa, the Portuguese radio reported. Mr. Walters said on arrival that he hoped his talks would lead to peace in southern Africa.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: There are certain cynics who insist that many New Yorkers think about only three things: finding the right apartment, the right job, and romance. This is not true. There are many New Yorkers who think about crime almost constantly.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $5.4 million for the qr and $9.7 million for the 6 mos

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,700,000 for the qr and $7,400,000 for the 6 mo

title: CHRYSLER PRESSED OVER CONCESSIONS
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union and the Chrysler Corporation began talks today on a new contract in which production workers expect to regain some of the concessions they made in the company's brush with bankruptcy in 1979 and 1980.

title: The U.N. Today; July 21, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission Working Group on New International Economic Order - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS REAGAN ON CITIES
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan was critical today of what he called a reversal by the Reagan Administration of the urban policy he helped to establish 14 years ago.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a pretax charge of $19.3 million for the closing of a facility and a tax credit of $71.7 million...C-After a pretax charge of $19.3 million for the closing of a facility, a pretax gain of $32 million on the sale of coal properties and a gain of $4,632,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change...D-Net income

title: 'Rogues to Riches,' Musical, Due on L.I.
description: ''Rogues to Riches,'' a musical by Robert Sevra, based on the 1957 comedy ''The Beaux' Stratagem'' by George Farquhar, will open Friday at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater, 158 Main Street, East Hampton, L.I.

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARMS OUTLAY RISE IN SOVIET IS SEEN
description: The Defense Intelligence Agency has estimated that the Soviet Union is spending more of its national wealth for military power than previously reported.

title: U.S. Advances In Federation Cup
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova swept singles matches today against Indonesia in the first round of the 20th annual Federation Cup tennis tournament.

title: YANKS FALL IN 9th; RIGHETTI FAILS
description: As if the Yankees' season has not been confusing enough, something more perplexing was added last night. Dave Righetti, whose three-week visit to Columbus had been pronounced a success, was knocked out in the third inning, and Doyle Alexander, whose poor performance in Oakland 12 days earlier prompted a blistering attack from club officials, pitched brilliantly in relief.

title: Von Bulow Puts Up $1 Million Bail Certificate
description: Claus von Bulow today put up a bank certificate for $1 million that will allow him to remain free while he appeals convictions of trying to murder his wife.

title: Mobil Withdraws Libyan 'Notice'
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn its notice of plans to relinquish its oil exploration and producing interests in Libya.

title: Spain Holds Drug Smugglers
description: The police said today that they were holding five Latin Americans who had tried to smuggle 10 pounds of cocaine into Spain. They said the smugglers, four Colombians and a Chilean, had the drug hidden in their clothes when they arrived at Madrid's Barajas Airport Monday on a flight from Bogota, Colombia.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago figures have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52

title: Organizing Recipes
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I greatly enjoyed Patrick Flanagan's article (''Organizing Those Stray Recipes for Easy Reference,'' July 7) - he's even more organized than I am.

title: Republic Steel Loss
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest steelmaker, announced yesterday a second-quarter loss of $85.2 million.

title: Telefunken Gets Pledge from Banks
description: AEG-Telefunken said today that its main creditor banks, which own roughly 50 percent of its equity, had agreed in principle to provide short-term bridging finance for the company.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bostwick Ketchum, Scientist Long an Aide at Woods Hole
description: Bostwick H. Ketchum, a microbiologist who was associated with the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution Woods Hole, Mass., for more than 40 years, died Thursday at his home in Tunbridge, Vt., after a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

title: DON'T LET ARMS RACE MUSHROOM
description: Horrified by a world in which two nations are unable to halt a lethal arms race? Imagine trying to work out arms control among half a dozen or more third world countries convinced that it is in their national security interests to build up nuclear arsenals.

title: More Mesquite
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Courtenay Beinhorn's story (''Mesquite: Bad Press but Great Flavor,'' June 23) inspired me and I came up with a source that doesn't require the purchase of a 10-year supply.

title: SHULTZ'S FIRST DECISION
description: George Shultz has wasted no time in changing the top command at the Department of State, and it is clear that he will have more freedom to do so than his predecessor, Alexander Haig.

title: PANEL HEARS TESTIMONY ON PLANS TO REGULATE THE FUNERAL INDUSTRY
description: Sidney A. Miller had ordered a plain pine coffin costing $95 for his uncle, but the funeral director later talked Mr. Miller's mother, Elizabeth, into buying a $1,350 package that included a $470 ''deluxe'' wooden casket. ''He told me the $95 coffin had holes in it,'' Mrs. Miller said.

title: MOSCOW FOR U.N. FORCE TO END BEIRUT IMPASSE
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev today endorsed the use of a United Nations force to end the impasse over the Palestinians trapped in west Beirut and restated Soviet opposition to any involvement of American troops.

title: HUTTON, E F, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE GRAVESEND HORROR WAS NO LYNCHING
description: To the Editor:

title: LANECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BLOW TO CRUCIAL HOUSING DEVELOPMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Collaborative Research Names a New President
description: Modesto A. Maidique, 42, has been named president and chief executive officer of Collaborative Research Inc., a leading biotechnology company based in Lexington, Mass.

title: HERONS ENJOY AN URBAN ROOKERY
description: Shooters Island is a mass of Mesozoic rock in Newark Bay in the polluted waters off northern Staten Island. For years, the island was regarded as a navigational nuisance at worst, as an eyesore at best.

title: A TWO-TIER STEAMER
description: ONE of the oldest surviving American Indian feasts from coastal New England tribes is the clambake. The traditional clambake is a labor-intensive but rewarding ritual that I usually perform once a year on the beach. It involves digging a pit and filling it with rocks, seaweed and dry wood, and then placing on top alternating layers of clams, lobsters, corn, sausages, potatoes and chicken. Everything cooks slowly under a durable cover, such as canvas, and the savory result is well worth the hours of toil.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The heavyweight champion, Larry Holmes, in town yesterday to pick up a permanent World Boxing Council title belt, said he would next fight in the fall against an opponent to be named. ... Vladimir Smirnov, the fencing champion from the Soviet Union, remained in a coma in a Rome hospital. Smirnov, the gold medalist in foils, at the 1980 Olympics has been in the coma since Monday when an opponent's weapon pierced his mask and entered his brain. ... Four harness racing trainers were suspended indefinitely by the State Racing and Wagering Board because the drug Clenbuterol was found in tests of their horses within 48 hours of the separate races in which their horses competed in June at Yonkers Raceway.

title: TAMASABURO STARS IN JAPAN'S 'DEMON POND'
description: THE remarkable Kabuki star Tamasaburo Bando is only one of many reasons to see ''Demon Pond,'' a most unusual Japanese film opening today at the Embassy 72d Street. ''Demon Pond'' is a fable, told in a colorful, whimsical, theatrical style. It concerns a shy, humble woman from a village beside the enchanted pond of the title, and a beautiful princess who lives in the pond among its mud creatures. Both women are played by the lithe, graceful Mr. Bando, who is not in any way recognizable here as a man.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AT a recent dinner a neighbor expressed a keen liking for fricassee of veal and asked if the dish could fit into a less-than-an-hour format. I explained to her that fricassees of meat had come about because they were an elegant way of preparing stew meat, such as the breast, that requires long, slow cooking. You cut the breast into cubes, soak it in cold water, cook it in chicken broth and seasonings for almost an hour, add vegetables and cook for another hour, at the end adding the thickening of egg yolks and cream.

title: News Analysis
description: With their state candidates having been selected at tidy, leaderdominated state committee meetings, the three minor parties in New York are now confronted with election campaigns that are especially critical to their futures.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Those responsible for these inhuman crimes do irreparable damage to the good name of Ireland and the cause of Irish unity.'' - Prime Minister Charles Haughey of the Republic of Ireland, after fatal bombings in London. (A11:3.)

title: SCHICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including investment gains $404,000 for the qr and after investment losses of$88,000 for the 6 mos...C-After investment losses of $1,543,000 and losses froma discontinued entertainment unit of $18,854,000 for the qr and including investment gains of $2,896,000 and after a loss of $11,309,000 from discontinued operations of an entertainment unit for 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Water Marathon
description: Those two hardy souls who swam around Manhattan Monday did it for more than the challenge. As it turned out, Drury Gallagher, who had never swum that far before, broke the around-the-island record by half an hour, doing the 27-mile route in 7 hours 14 minutes 42 seconds. But the main reason he and Tom Hetzel made the swim was to kick off the Manhattan Island Swimming Association, a group that hopes to make marathon swimming as popular in New York as marathon running.

title: SUSPECT IN SPY CASE
description: On the surface, Geoffrey Arthur Prime, the 44-year-old Briton charged with espionage, is a stark contrast to the other spies in this country since World War II.

title: BLACKS RATE CAPITAL: AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY CITY?
description: One of this city's more coveted invitations is to a gathering that takes place each Thursday in a back room of the Independence Federal Savings and Loan Association, the capital's first minority-owned savings and loan. For the past seven years its president, William Fitzgerald, has invited diplomats, politicians, socialites and business people to join him in an informal exchange of ideas over Bloody Marys and luncheon.

title: Musica Camerit Names Sanders Music Director
description: The pianist Samuel Sanders has been named music director of Musica Camerit, a new chamber ensemble at the Hebrew Arts School of the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On the Go at Age 96

title: POLICE BELIEVE PIANIST KNEW MURDERER
description: Detectives investigating the slaying of a 34-year-old concert pianist, Raymond Shigeoka, said yesterday that the murder may have been committed by someone Mr. Shigeoka knew or admitted to his midtown apartment.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
On Manning the Phone
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Enid Nemy's article of June 23 (''Does She Phone the Man in '82?'') really hit the spot. I have felt somewhat frustrated for a good time now over whether, when I am interested in dating a man, I should make the first move (assuming he does not), or just let slide by what could have been a worthwhile relationship.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1,277,000 on the sale of interest in Japanese affiliate

title: Gulf-Cities Service
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had extended until July 30, from today, the deadline for its offer to purchase Cities Service Company stock.

title: Czechs Bar a Polish Bishop After Visit to West Germany
description: A Polish bishop traveling home from West Germany was refused entry into Czechoslovakia by border guards today, the border police said.

title: I.R.A. BOMB ATTACKS IN LONDON KILL 8
description: Eight British soldiers were killed and 51 people were wounded today when two bombs planted by the Irish Republican Army exploded in two London parks.

title: BRITISH DISPLEASED AT U.S. TEST-BAN DECISION
description: The British Government said today that it was not pleased by President Reagan's reported decision to discontinue negotiations on a comprehensive nuclear test ban. At the same time, the Government said it was ''not surprised.''

title: ECUADOR'S ECONOMY: CLOUD FOR A LATIN DEMOCRACY
description: This is a city where past, present and future happen simultaneously. The colonial churches and immaculate plazas transport an observer back to the conquistadors of the 15th century. Indians, in bowler hats and ponchos, roasting guinea pigs in the crowded early-morning market, bespeak cultures far, far older.

title: Shades of Red
description: The New Jersey Devils are having, pardon the expression, a devil of a time getting their uniforms made. The new hockey team has chosen colors of white, red and dark green, but they are very particular about getting exactly the right shade of red, and that's the problem.

title: Stocks Climb; Dow Up 7.33
description: Responding favorably to falling interest rates and rising corporate earnings, stock prices forged ahead yesterday. Volume expanded to 61.1 million shares from Monday's 53 million.

title: WINE TALK
description: YOUNTVILLE,Calif. IF any doubt exists about wine's being a fashionable business these days, it should be dispelled by the influx of Hollywood celebrities and entertainers to the vineyards of northern California.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bomb Blast in Central Paris Wounds 10 on a Cafe Terrace
description: At least 10 people were wounded, one of them seriously, when a bomb exploded near Notre Dame Cathedral in central Paris tonight, the police said.

title: STATE STUDIES ALCOHOLICS' CHILDREN
description: A new report said yesterday that 500,000 children in New York State lived in families where there was an alcoholic and that these children were four times more likely than other children to become alcoholics themselves.

title: WEDNESDAY, JULY 21, 1982; Companies
description: Chase Manhattan reported a loss of $16.1 million in the second quarter as a result of dealings with Drysdale Government Securities and the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma, and top management was reshuffled. The quarterly loss, though the first in memory for one of the nation's 10 largest banks, was less than had been expected, analysts said. (Page A1.)

title: HYDRO OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After charges of approximately $165,000 for start-up costs for a new contract...C-Net income including a tax credit of $8,000; yr-ago shr earnings figure is fully diluted

title: WIRTH BILL ON PHONES IS DROPPED
description: The chairman of the House telecommunications subcommittee today abandoned his efforts to pass a bill that would toughen the terms of the antitrust settlement that the Justice Department reached with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company last January.

title: Advertising; TV Ad Prices Are Raised
description: DEPRESSED economy and declining audiences notwithstanding, the TV networks are asking from 15 percent to 20 percent more from advertisers making ''up-front'' buys of 52 weeks for the new season starting in the fall.

title: LAURENCE H. ELDREDGE
description: Laurence H. Eldredge, a lawyer in Philadelphia for many years and a former professor at the University of Pennsylvania's law and medical schools, died Saturday at his home in San Francisco. He was 80 years old.

title: Weaver Sued by King
description: Don King has filed a $20 million damage suit charging that Mike Weaver reneged on a contract to defend his World Boxing Association heavyweight title against Michael Dokes. Don King Productions Inc. filed the suit late Monday in United States District Court.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly identified the Seattle Mariner player tagging Butch Hobson of the Yankees. He was Todd Cruz.

title: A SINGLE AGENCY ON RATE SETTING URGED BY GOLDIN
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that the city's procedures for setting rates for taxis, cable television, vehicle towing, buses and a wide range of other services constitute a ''largely ineffective hit-and-miss process.''

title: Soccer Tour Cut
description: A sanction-breaking soccer tour by a team of international players, hit by a boycott by black teams and the withdrawal of three South American stars, will be cut in half. George Thabe, president of the Football Council of South Africa, said that the six-match tour would end after Wednesday night's match, the third in a tour that has drawn disappointingly small crowds in the wake of opposition by anti-apartheid groups.

title: ROTELCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Required Reading; Arizona's Condition
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, during Senate debate on a Federal reclamations bill, July 16, 1982:

title: Olympia Reports On Pabst Tenders
description: The Olympia Brewing Company said that 6.3 million Pabst Brewing Company common shares, or 76.8 percent of Pabst's 8.2 million outstanding shares, had been tendered to an Olympia subsidiary, OBC Acquisition Inc., as of July 19.

title: AIDED SCIENCE AND ARTS
description: Ella Dunlevy Milbank Foshay, a member of a New York family of philanthropists and a benefactor in the fields of zoology, health care and the arts, died Monday at Palm Beach-Martin County Medical Center in Hobe Sound, Fla., after a long illness. She was 71 years old, and had lived in Hobe Sound since moving from New York City several years ago.

title: THE SUPERFLUOUS MAN
description: A ll right, no more Mr. Nice Guy. Until now, nothing has been said in this space about the New York Knickerbockers professional basketball team because I was waiting for a telephone call. I have been waiting since the N.B.A. draft. Red Auerbach of the Celtics - surely Isaiah Berlin had Auerbach in mind, instead of Tolstoy, when he talked about the hedgehog and the fox - got all the credit in the N.B.A. draft for picking Landon Turner on the 10th round. Nobody seemed to notice that on that same 10th round, the Knicks picked me.

title: Documentary Televised Despite Mitterrand Plea
description: France's main television channel showed a program on the life of President Francois Mitterrand tonight despite his request that it be canceled.

title: Investors Reaping Profits on Yearlings; Emphasis Is On Breeding
description: More than half of the 2,000 people who crammed into the Keeneland Sales pavilion Monday night are more likely to buy $10,000 trucks than $2 million thoroughbred yearlings. They are local residents who come to the sales, pressing up against the glass rear wall of the pavilion three and four deep, to catch a glimpse of the regally bred horses, but mostly to shake thir heads in disbelief at the prices they bring.

title: Brown, 17, Upsets Teltscher, 6-4, 6-2
description: Jimmy Brown, 17 years old, upset thirdseeded Eliot Teltscher today, 6-4, 6-2, in the first round of the $240,000 D.C. National Bank tennis tournament.

title: Abortions New and Old
description: ''He dedicated himself to poor immigrant women,'' Kate Simons writes of a Dr. James in ''Bronx Primitive,'' her autobiography, ''for whom there was no sex information, no birth-control clinics, nothing but knitting needles, hot pins, lengths of wire, the drinking of noxious mixtures while they sat in scalding baths to prevent the birth of yet another child. At times one woman would inflict these well-meant injuries on a sister, a neighbor; sometimes they were solitary acts of desperation.''

title: NEW STATE LAW TIGHTENS PERSONAL-BANKRUPTCY ACT
description: Governor Carey signed a measure today tightening the state's personal bankruptcy law. The measure, supported strongly by business and banking groups but opposed by some consumer groups, is designed to replace a more lenient bankruptcy system enacted by Congress four years ago.

title: Thais Say Vietnamese Pulled Back in Cambodia
description: Vietnamese forces in Cambodia abandoned their forward positions near the Thai border early this month, Thai military sources said today.

title: American Home Gains
description: The American Home Products Corporation, maker of various consumer items, reported yesterday that both earnings and sales were up 13.5 percent in the second quarter. Net income rose to $126 million, or 81 cents a share, from $111 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales were $1.09 billion, against $954.97 million.

title: It's the P.L.O. That Has to Move
description: There are serious people who say the P.L.O. deserves in defeat what it failed to get in two decades of political and terrorist activity: American ''recognition'' and a guarantee of its own independent state. These people include humanitarians who are eager to avoid more loss of life in Beirut; Americans eager to punish Israel for its free use of American arms; and Arabs embarrassed at their own inability to help the P.L.O. For whatever motive, they all would reward the biggest hijacking in history - half of Beirut is the hostage - in a coin they do not possess, the Israeli-held West Bank. Negligent though he has been in Middle East diplomacy, President Reagan is wisely having none of this.

title: 68-Year-Old Woman Is Seized In Fatal Beating of Husband
description: A 68-year-old woman was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of her husband, who was found beaten to death in the bathtub of the couple's apartment in the West Farms section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Hard to Quit
description: ''Knowing when to leave the party is something all of us find hard to do.'' -Vito Antuofermo, announcing his retirement from boxing, Dec. 7, 1981.

title: MGM/UA TRIMMING ITS SAILS
description: Its recent past littered with richly mounted box-office failures, the MGM/UA Entertainment Company is now going to try to attract moviegoers with more tightly budgeted films.

title: Academy Chairman Named
description: Neil D. Chrisman has been elected chairman of the board of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Mr. Chrisman is a senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and has been on the academy's board for four years and chairman of the development committee for three years.

title: REAGAN REASSERTS STAND ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan has threatened to veto any ''budget buster'' appropriations bills that reach his desk. The President, in an interview to be broadcast by public television, said he expected Congress to adhere to the spending ceiling of $769.8 billion set forth in the compromise budget resolution for the fiscal year 1983. which was adopted last month by Congress.

title: SAN DIEGO GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain of 16 cents a shr from the sale of land

title: Credit Curb Bill Advances
description: A House subcommittee today approved legislation that would give the President authority to restrict the use of credit in efforts to combat inflation, recession or unemployment. The Reagan Administration opposes the bill.

title: U.S. INDICTS MITSUI UNIT FOR FRAUD
description: In a major crackdown on Japanese steel imports, a Federal grand jury today indicted a subsidiary of one of Japan's largest companies and three of its employees on charges of fraud and making false statements in a conspiracy to sell steel below market prices.

title: Chinese Composers To Offer Premieres
description: Music by contemporary Chinese composers, including two American premieres, will be played by the Brooklyn Philharmonic on Sunday at 2 P.M. at a free concert at Summerfare '82 at the Center for the Arts of the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: Suspended Archbishop Hopes to See Pope
description: A Roman Catholic Archbishop who was suspended from all priestly functions in 1976 by Pope Paul VI for his opposition to changes in the church will step down as head of his traditionalist movement in September, the Swiss news agency ATS said today.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Hot Off the Grill

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains of $897,000 for the qr and $2,551,000 for the 9 mos from spunoff operations...C-Including a gain of $444,000 for the qr and after a loss of $2,427,000 for the 9 mos from spunoff operations

title: BRIGHT-TASTING SORBETS FROM FRESH FRUIT PUREES
description: AFRUIT ice - sorbet - is the simplest and most refreshing frozen confection to make at home. For most flavors, a fresh fruit puree, a little lemon juice and judicious sweetening are all it takes to produce a bright-tasting sorbet, ready to freeze and scoop.

title: JAMES R. BROWN Jr.
description: James R. Brown Jr., president and chief operating officer of Dresser Industries Inc. of Dallas, died of a heart attack Monday at Medical City Hospital in Dallas.

title: Taking 'Yeomen' to Britain
description: I n the face of all coals-to-Newcastle precepts, 50 singers and backstage people from the Village Light Opera Group will be off to England Saturday, to sing Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Yeomen of the Guard'' almost in sight of the Tower itself.

title: U.S. ENVOY IN MANAGUA IRKED
description: Ambassador Anthony C.E. Quainton said today that he walked out on a Sandinist celebration Monday to protest ''strong and unjust'' criticism of American policies by Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the junta leader.

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Economic Scene; Controlling Money Supply
description: IN a more ideal world, better short-term monetary marksmanship is not especially important for its own sake. Few would argue that brief, and perhaps even sizable, deviations of money from a desired longer-term path have significant repercussions either for total spending and inflation or for expectations about their future movements as long as market participants recognize that the deviations will be corrected.

title: THE JUKEBOX, IT SEEMS, IS A HIT OF THE PAST
description: It was found almost anyplace people gathered to eat or drink - in soda shops and pizza parlors, diners and truck stops. For a nickel, then a dime and now a quarter, people could play if they were willing to pay.

title: DAVID GREENBAUM
description: David Greenbaum, a lawyer in Manhattan for more than half a century and a leader in Jewish civic and charitable affairs, died yesterday at his home in Rego Park, Queens.

title: 1 of 6 in College Said To Drink Excessively
description: One of six college students drinks excessively and more than one of 50 must leave school ultimately because of drinking problems, according to a survey of college deans.

title: E.F. Hutton's Profit Off
description: E.F. Hutton & Company, one of the nation's largest investment and brokerage houses, yesterday reported a 67 percent decline in secondquarter earnings. Phibro-Salomon Inc., a major investment house and commodities trader, said its earnings for the quarter dropped 10 percent from the same period last year, while Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said its net income for the quarter rose 33 percent.

title: CITICORP UP 40% ON GAIN IN INTEREST
description: Citicorp, the nation's second-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its net operating income in the second quarter increased by 40 percent, to $148 million, or $1.15 a share, from $106 million, or 84 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: FRY, FRY AGAIN
description: The present heat wave reminds me of my Uncle Henry who once fried chicken on the sidewalk. It was Uncle Henry's way of showing his contempt for newspapers.

title: HAWAIIANS QUESTION NEED TO SELL AN ARMY BEACH
description: Hawaiian officials, as they dig in to try to stop the Federal Government from selling one of the last bits of open space on Waikiki Beach, say they suspect that Hawaii's interests are being sacrificed for those of other states.

title: WHAT IS JUSTLY DUE NEW YORK'S UNIFORMED WORKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Roger Fransecky has joined Time Inc.'s Home Box Office in the newly created position of vice president, corporate affairs.

title: ARMS CONTROL TALKS PENDING
description: There are several arms control negotiations pending. Following is a list of those talks. Strategic Arms Talks - The United States and the Soviet Union are discussing limitation of long-range nuclear delivery systems.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY HOUSING PROGRAMS TIED TO ARSON IN REPORT
description: Buildings in New York City that benefit from two subsidy and taxincentive programs are more likely to be the targets of arson than buildings that do not receive those benefits, according to a city study released yesterday.

ISSUES ON SMITH'S FINANCES DISMISSED BY JUSTICE DEPT.
description: The Justice Department, in separate reports, today set aside accusations that Attorney General William French Smith acted improperly in accepting a $50,000 severance payment from a California steel company and investing in two tax shelters.

Valero Credit Line
description: The Valero Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed on a construction credit line totaling $115 million.

E.F. Hutton Chairman Adds Two Presidential Titles
description: Robert Fomon, chairman and chief executive officer of E.F. Hutton & Company, the brokerage house, and its parent, the E.F. Hutton Group, yesterday was also named president of both companies.

FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rookie of Year Wants Pay Parity
description: After hearing about the Nets' recent offer sheet to the free-agent center Dave Corzine - $3.2 million over five years - Buck Williams, the Nets' power forward, says he thinks he deserves a raise.

CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Nonperforming loans reduced net income by $9.8 million, or 51 cents per share, in the latest quarter compared with $5.4 million in earlier period; In the latest 6 months nonperforming loans reduced net income by $18.2 million, or 96 cents per share, compared with $9.2 million in earlier period

title: Debt Talks Set By Ambrosiano
description: The Government-appointed commissioners running Banco Ambrosiano since Roberto Calvi, its chairman, was found hanged in London, have invited creditors to a meeting in London on July 29, a bank spokesman said today.

title: INFORMATICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOW WE LOOK

title: COOLING BUSES IS AN UPHILL FIGHT
description: Air-conditioning units on New York City buses, both old and new, require such a high degree of maintenance that transit officials say they are fighting a losing battle to keep buses cool this summer.

title: Foe of Chad's Leader Killed in an Accident
description: Former Foreign Minister Ahmat Acyl, a leader of one of the political factions opposed to the new Chadian leader, Hissen Habre, was killed Monday in the southwestern city of Lai when he was struck by an airplane propeller, his followers announced today. They said the incident was an accident.

title: ANDREA RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. TELLS GLEN COVE TO LIFT BANS ON RUSSIANS
description: The State Department has ordered the Mayor of Glen Cove to stop meddling in foreign affairs and let local Soviet diplomats use the city's golf courses, beaches and tennis courts.

title: WNYC REBUFFED ON REQUEST TO INCREASE BROADCAST POWER
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in a case that has been pending since 1942, tentatively decided today to deny an application by WNYC-AM to move its transmitter to Staten Island and increase its broadcasting power to 50,000 watts.

title: OFFICIALS SAY STRINGENT RULES MAKE CRANE ACCIDENTS RARE
description: City and Federal safety officials say the giant cranes and derricks that dot the New York skyline are marvels of engineering that meet the strictest of design and operating standards.

PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Searle Venture
description: G.D. Searle & Company said that its joint venture with the French pharmaceutical concern Synthelabo had formally begun operations here.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Operating earnings; C-Net income

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. This one-night stop by the Rangers makes up for the snowed-out Stadium opener last April 6. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8 P.M.) White Sox vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Chicago. This is the only other game scheduled in the major leagues. (Television - USA Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Howard Davis Jr. vs. Anthony Collins, 10 rounds, welterweights. Jerry Cheatham vs. Robert Sawyer, 12 rounds, welterweights, at Sands Hotel, Atlantic City. Davis (17-1, 6 knockouts), from Dix Hills, L.I., and the only American gold-medal winner from the 1976 Montreal Olympics who has not won a world pro title, continues his quest against Collins (13-4, 11 knockouts), from Miami Beach. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Blizzard, at Toronto. The Cosmos have won three straight and will attempt to win their first game in Canada this year. They have not lost at home this year, but four of their six losses have been in Canada. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M.) Other Events Basketball: New York Pro Summer League at Nat Holman Gym, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, Manhattan, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. Gus Williams of the Seattle SuperSonics, the league's leading scorer (33 points a game), will be in the lineup for the New York Gems in the second game. The league's No. 2 scorer, Ron Davis of the Washington Bullets (30.9), will play for Budweiser in the game.

title: ROY ROGERS OPPOSES EFFORT IN CALIFORNIA TO REGULATE PISTOLS
description: The actor Roy Rogers has been recruited by the National Rifle Association to fight a voterinitiated referendum to restrict pistols in California.

title: MILTON G. HENDLICH
description: Milton G. Hendlich, for 29 years a senior staff psychiatrist at Chestnut Lodge, a private institution in Rockville, Md., died Tuesday of heart failure at Shady Grove Hospital, where he had been admitted Friday. He was 73 years old.

title: KOCH WANTS S.R.O. HOTELS BARRED FROM J-51 PROGRAM
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would support efforts to make single-room-occupancy hotels ineligible for the benefits of a taxincentive program for real-estate developers.

title: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results reflect a change in the method of accounting for foreign currency translation

title: TIMES CHANGING FOR WATCHMAKERS
description: Time is passing for Israel Snapper. Each day he takes up the tools of his trade, the eyeglass, the tiny screwdriver, the tweezers, and bends to his workbench, purchased 30 years ago - used even then, the bench of some watchmaker who had gone before.

title: B.P. KOIRALA, FORMER PRIME MINISTER OF NEPAL
description: Bisheswar Prasad Koirala, who served as Prime Minister during a brief period of Western-style parliamentary government, died at his home today. He was 67 years old.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WORTH HIS WEIGHT IN VICTORIES
description: F rank O'Mara is to harness drivers what Dick Butkus would be to jockeys - larger than usual. O'Mara, who, at 5 feet 11 inches, weighs 215 pounds and has been perched in his sulky weighing as much as 235 pounds, is 60 to 75 pounds heavier than the average harness-racing driver.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN DISTRICT TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest second quarter include the favorable impact of a New York City property tax settlement, largely offset by unfavorable foreign exchange conversions

title: Padres Rookie Arrested
description: Two officers arrested Alan Wiggins, the Padres' rookie outfielder, early yesterday ''for investigation of possession of cocaine,'' the police in San Diego said. Wiggins was released on $2,000 bail three hours after his arrest and entered a detoxification center.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
RIGHTS AIDE MAKES SECRET LATIN TRIP
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, had just concluded a secret fact-finding visit to El Salvador.

title: Posin Dance Debut Aug. 1
description: A dance by Kathryn Posin, as yet untitled, will have its premiere Aug. 1 at 6:30 P.M. at Creative Time's Art on the Beach at the Battery Park City Landfill, Gate No. 19 at Chambers and West Streets.

title: G.M. to Lay Off 4,325 Upstate
description: The General Motors Corporation said that 4,325 workers will be laid off Monday, most of them for one to two weeks, at its Harrison Radiator plants in Lockport and Buffalo while the plants are converted for production of 1983 model cars and trucks.

title: ECONOMY EXPANDS AT 1.7% RATE
description: The nation's gross national product rose in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.7 percent after adjustment for inflation, the Commerce Department reported today, the first upturn in this key indicator since last summer.

title: Driver Milestone
description: Carmine Abbatiello became only the second harness driver to achieve 5,000 victories when he won with First Born in tonight's first race at Yonkers Raceway. Abbatiello, 45 years old, trails only Herve Filion, who has more than 8,000 winners.

title: AUTHOR SUES PUBLISHER ON DISAVOWAL
description: The author of a biography of Katharine Graham, chairman of The Washington Post Company, filed a $6 million lawsuit yesterday against Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, accusing the publisher of breach of contract for disavowing the book shortly after it was published in November 1979.

title: Alydar Finally Tops Affirmed
description: Affirmed and Alydar, Alydar and Affirmed. It was probably the longest and closest rivalry in the history of thoroughbred racing, stretching over two years and a Triple Crown season. They met 10 times and Affirmed finished first in eight of them, but it was always close: Affirmed by a length and a half in the 1978 Kentucky Derby, by a neck in the Preakness, by a head in the Belmont.

title: RAPE LEGISLATION AND BURDEN OF PROOF
description: AN elderly woman was raped on an elevator in her Bronx apartment building last year by a young man with a gun. The assailant was later arrested, but was never prosecuted for rape because the woman could not prove that she had tried to resist her attacker.

title: RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Florida Bank Deal
description: The First Bankers Corporation of Florida said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the National Trust Bank of Florida, based in St. Petersburg, for about $14 million. Arthur E. Kavanagh, vice president and treasurer of First Bankers, which is based in Pompano Beach, said National Trust's shareholders would receive $13.3 million plus a proportionate share of National Trust's earnings from April 1 through the end of the month prior to the consummation of the agreement. First Bankers has 28 branches and $665 million in assets.

title: FALCONE IS WINNER ON STRONG 5 INNINGS
description: Pete Falcone pitched five strong innings today and the Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 6-2, making Manager George Bamberger's season-long search for a reliable starting rotation just slightly less maddening.

title: A General in Bolivia Is Sworn In as President
description: Gen. Guido Vildoso Calderon was sworn in as President today in a ceremony delayed by nine hours.

title: Technology; Cooling Air Efficiently
description: WITH the hot, humid days of midsummer upon us, and with offices and households using huge amounts of electricity to run their airconditioners, it may be wise to review the lessons learned during the energy crisis of 1974 and the conservation efforts that followed.

title: Mary Gordon's Novel Wins 2d Kafka Prize
description: For the second time, Mary Gordon has been named winner of the annual Janet Heidinger Kafka Prize for her 1981 novel, ''The Company of Women.''

title: Labor Board Modifies Union Neutrality Policy
description: The National Labor Relations Board today erased a 37-year-old policy that required employers to maintain strict neutrality toward competing unions seeking to represent their workers.

title: SPECTRADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Inland Loses $23.2 Million
description: The Inland Steel Company reported today that it lost $23.2 million in the second quarter of 1982, in contrast to a $29.5 million profit in 1981's second quarter. Sales fell 29 percent, to $743.6 million.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations $3.8 million

title: U.S. ASSAILED ON PLAN TO SELL 7 PROJECTS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development was sharply criticized today by the department's Inspector General for proposing to sell seven housing projects in the New York area without adequately determining the financial gains to be made by the purchaser.

title: Californian Climber Killed in Himalayas
description: A United States-British expedition has given up its attempt to climb Gasher Brum 2, in the western Himalayas, after one of its members was killed in an avalanche, the team leader, Michael Clarke, said today.

title: MYSTERY ENGULFS AN ANTI-ISRAELI AD
description: Although mystery surrounds many details regarding publication of an anti-Israeli advertisement July 11, it appears to be part of the Arab-Israeli battle to sway public opinion in the United States over the current war in Lebanon.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ahnert Enterprises, Bushkill, Pa., named Charles E. Shanahan executive vice president of corporate finance.

description: * ACF Industries' $30 million of 10-year, 14 7/8 percent equipment trust certificates were priced at 99.87 to yield 14.90 percent by Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc.

title: Computer Scores
description: The Boston Athletic Association is mailing out its official ''racer's recordbook'' this week to the 5,939 runners who started in the Boston Marathon last April. Here's a sampling of some of the statistics compiled by the computer that scored and timed the race:

SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW ISSUE IN TOWN: 1776 PENNSYLVANIA AVE.
description: Charles B. Benenson is a New York real estate man with a wary sense of how complicated a simple-looking lease negotiation can become with his properties in Washington, the capital of fine print. He acted quickly, then, in retaining not one, but five of the city's more powerful lobbying and law firms last spring when the lease-renewal negotiations on his building at 1776 Pennsylvania Avenue took an unexpected turn with the Federal Government.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FALLS are a frequent cause of injury in the home, and many are from ladders. In most cases the injuries could have been avoided if common-sense safety rules had been followed.

title: Virginia Uranium Find
description: The Marline Uranium Corporation today annnounced the discovery of a significant uranium deposit in Pittsylvania County that the company said was among the richest finds in the United States. About 30 million pounds of uranium lie beneath a 100-acre site the company has leased six miles northeast of Chatham.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lawyer Picked For S.E.C. Post
description: James C. Treadway Jr., a 38-year-old Washington lawyer, was nominated yesterday by President Reagan to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $929,000, or 9 cents a share, from a non-monetary exchange of property; year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Tiger Paw Ads Evoke The 60's
description: THE hot action in the passenger-car tire business these days is the ''all-season tire,'' the one that need not be changed come winter. Uniroyal has a major new entry in this category that Robert W. Horning, vice president-marketing, says will become ''the heart of our line,'' and the company has chosen to use all television advertising that neither uses the word tire nor shows a tire. An interesting way to go.

Bridge: New York District's Talent May Outshine All the Rest
description: A philosopher may be confident that the part cannot be greater than the whole, but a bridge player may have doubts, especially in the context of the Grand National Team Championship. The quality of the players in the New York playoffs is often greater than that of the later national playoffs.

description: Results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid May 1982

PUNISHING THE SOVIETS
description: At a meeting of the Pugwash Conference where scientists gather to discuss the great danger of nuclear war, the Soviet Ambassador to Canada, Alexander Yakovlev, voiced alarm at the idea of ''punishment'' in East-West relations.

title: CRANE VICTIM'S DEATH A SHOCK TO COLLEAGUES
description: Warren Frederick Levenberg, who died yesterday in the crane accident at 520 Madison Avenue, was the controller for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. He was struck in the head by a piece of falling granite.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CALENDAR: SOME ADVICE ON VEGETABLE GARDENS
description: First Aid for Your Vegetable Garden, New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bronx, 212-220-8747.

title: COLGATE IS FLAT
description: The Dow Chemical Company yesterday reported a 4.2 percent rise in second-quarter net income, but said sales dropped 11.1 percent. The earnings rise was attributed to a gain from the dissolution of a partnership with the Asahi Chemical Company of Japan.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IRAN BOMBS BAGHDAD FOR FIRST TIME IN OVER A YEAR
description: Iranian aircraft attacked the capital of Iraq today, while Iraqi jets bombed key cities in Iran's main oil-producing province.

title: News Analysis
description: Several months ago Yasir Arafat remarked that if the Palestine Liberation Organization could hold out against an Israeli invasion for 10 days it would win the political victory that all wars are ultimately fought for.

title: LIN BROADCASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTINENTAL POSTS $60.95 MILLION LOSS
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest banking organization, announced yesterday that it lost almost $61 million in the second quarter. Bankers said it was the biggest quarterly loss by a major banking company in recent history.

title: BEGIN SEEKS TALKS WITH KING HUSSEIN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that he intended to invite King Hussein of Jordan for peace talks, ''and the turn of Syria will also come.''

title: LOWER EAST SIDERS ASSAIL PROPOSAL TO DESTROY DRUG TRADE BUILDINGS
description: About 100 residents, legislators and representatives of 18 organizations and local churches assembled at City Hall yesterday to protest the possible demolition of abandoned buildings on the Lower East Side.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $17.2 million for the quarter and 6 monthson the retirement of debentures; C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $3.8 million for the quarter and $8.4 million for the 6 months

title: TAKING OUT THE MAN IN THE MIDDLE
description: B aseball is not particularly a contact sport, but don't try to tell that to the middle man on a double play. He is the marked man, the target for the runner barreling into second. Wipe out the middle man, and you avoid the double play.

title: BRIEFING
description: Spokesman's Retort

title: JOSLYN MANUFACTURING & SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income of $1,025,000 from discontinued operations

title: Retail Post at Batus For Saks Chairman
description: Arnold H. Aronson, chairman of Saks Fifth Avenue, has been named president of the Batus retail division of Batus Inc. Mr. Aronson, 47 years old, assumes the duties formerly held by Robert J. Suslow, who was recently appointed the division's chairman and chief executive officer.

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $3,990,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: 3 MEET FOR FIRST DEBATE IN G.O.P. SENATE RACE
description: In their first debate of the primary campaign, the three Republican contenders for the United States Senate from New York yesterday criticized each other and the Democratic incumbent, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER NEWSPAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOVIET HUNGER STRIKER STICKS TO A PERILOUS COURSE
description: To those who knew him as a strong-limbed man only a short while ago, Sergei Petrov is a pitiful sight. After 49 days on a diet of water, he has lost nearly 52 pounds, nearly 30 percent of his normal weight. He complains of dizzy spells, he can barely walk unaided and he tires quickly during his almost daily sessions with reporters.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: IF you yearn for the days of party lines and crank telephones, you can have that look with contemporary technology. The telephone company has introduced an authentic-looking line of phones of oak, with a nickel finish on the metal parts and braided fabric cord.

title: TOPAZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A POLITICAL PHENOM
description: In a country historically sensitive to joblessness, unemployment is the worst ever recorded. The Prime Minister, under attack for her economic policy, says she will not be moved an inch. The result must be political disaster for her -right? Wrong.

title: Doctor Convicted in Rape Surrenders in New York
description: A fugitive doctor convicted of participating in the rape of a nurse surrendered last night at Kennedy International Airport, two weeks after he was to begin serving a six-month prison sentence.

title: SOVIET ASSAILS U.S. ON A-TESTS
description: The Soviet Union accused President Reagan today of trying to sabotage talks on limiting nuclear tests. The charge came in a commentary by Tass, the official press agency, on Mr. Reagan's decision to seek amendments to two existing test treaties, introducing stricter means of verifying compliance.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WATT ANNOUNCES FINAL APPROVAL OF BIG OFFSHORE OIL-LEASING PLAN
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt today announced final approval of the most extensive offshore oil and gas leasing program in the nation's history, and said it would be conducted under ''stringent environmental safeguards.''

title: McEnroe a Hero
description: John McEnroe suffers from a spoiled-brat image, but to some children who suffer from cystic fibrosis and some adults who work with them, he's a hero.

title: Austerity in Belgium Dampens Big Parade
description: The Belgian Air Force took no part in a military parade here today to mark the nation's national holiday because the fuel needed to fly the planes was judged to be too expensive.

title: VERSATILE BOOKSHELVES CAN CONCEAL AND REVEAL
description: BOOKSHELVES have always been a necessity for storing ever-growing collections. But recently for some designers and architects, those ranks of shelving have proved a creative way to manipulate interior spaces: to create new rooms, accent existing architecture or conceal structural flaws.

title: CROWDED TERRACES CAN HELP TO SOFTEN CITY'S HARD EDGES
description: IT isn't so easy to walk quickly through Bob Davidson's mid-Manhattan terrace. In fact, navigating through the numerous tubs of flowers, vegetables, trees, shrubs and vines is nearly impossible, which may be just as well since it is pleasant to stand in one place and enjoy the greenery that obliterates the city.

title: U.S. REPORTEDLY REJECTED HINCKLEY PLEA BARGAINING
description: The Justice Department turned down a pleabargaining offer last November that would have sent John W. Hinckley Jr. to a Federal prison for at least 10 or 15 years, department sources said today.

title: ONE-ROOM SCHOOLS WANING IN VERMONT
description: Like the covered bridge, the oneroom schoolhouse has long been a charming ingredient in Vermont's landscape. But economic pressures are forcing some compromises with tradition.

title: BANCOHIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTH KOREA AND THE U.S. IN PERSPECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: DELAYS POPE'S VISIT
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, announced today that more than 1,200 people detained under martial law were being released, and that martial law itself could be suspended by the end of the year if tensions subsided.

title: PIONEER STANDARD ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Quito yesterday about Ecuador's economy was accom- panied by an incorrect photograph. It actually showed Bogota, Colombia.

title: AEG-Telefunken Loan
description: The bank consortium that has come to the rescue of AEG-Telefunken A.G. three times is showing increasing signs of strain over current negotiations for urgent financial aid, banking sources said today. The 24 banks in the consortium, which holds half of AEG's shares, saw a few banks decline to participate in further credits.

title: Indiana Editor Sues Greeley For Libel in Dispute on Files
description: A journalist today filed a $3 million libel suit against Andrew Greeley, an author and Roman Catholic priest who had accused the journalist of snooping in his private files.

title: MARKET IS MIXED AFTER SELL-OFF
description: A spate of selling in the final hour left stock prices mixed yesterday. At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 1.24 points, to 832.19, after ranging between 840.37 and 832 during the session.

title: HOUSE APPROVES 2 MILITARY PLANS REAGAN SOUGHT
description: The House of Representatives today narrowly defeated a measure that would have stopped spending for production of the MX missile. Hours later, the House also decided a heavily lobbied contest between the Boeing and Lockheed companies by upholding a Pentagon request to purchase 50 Lockheed C-5 cargo planes for military airlift.

title: LEGAL HISTORY BACKS BRITISH ON TRESPASS
description: The idea that a man who trespassed in Buckingham Palace and woke the Queen in her bed did not commit a criminal offense has left many people puzzled or skeptical. But British legal scholars say there is a clear basis in history and in the modern statutes for the decision against prosecuting Michael Fagan.

title: A SEA CAPTAIN'S PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.O.P. WINS KEY VOTES IN SENATE ON TAX BILL
description: The Republican majority in the Senate defeated several attempts by Democrats today to change the tax increases and spending cuts brought to the floor by the Finance Committee.

title: JOSEPH A. MCNAMARA
description: Joseph A. McNamara, an elections commissioner for Westchester County and secretary of the county Democratic organization, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 63 years old and lived in North Salem, N.Y.

title: DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bush Announces Grant For Morehouse School
description: Vice President Bush today announced a $2.6 million Federal grant to the Morehouse School of Medicine, the first predominantly black medical school to be created in this century.

title: GAINES BEATEN IN SWIM TRIALS
description: Tiffany Cohen captured the women's 400-meter freestyle tonight to qualify for her second world championship event during the United States swinnimg trials. But the men's world record-holder in the 100 freestyle, Rowdy Gaines, was defeated

title: RED LIGHT FOR GUNS
description: Recently in New York City two men were shot dead during a robbery in a bathroom of a Wall Street area skyscraper; a biker was gunned to death riding through Central Park on the way to work, and a young girl was shot and killed in a West Side boutique after telling a customer the store did not carry men's clothing. In 1980, the F.B.I. reported 23,044 murders in the United States, approximately 62 percent of them with guns. In less than 20 years the number of gun murders has tripled.

title: Taking the Plunge at 11
description: Jason Pipoly, an 11-year-old from Denver who hopes to become the youngest person to swim the English Channel, has arrived in Dover.

title: N.F.L. Agenda in Dispute
description: Negotiations will resume in Washington today to replace the contract that expired last Thursday between the National Football League's 28 clubs and their players. But there is disagreement even over the agenda.

title: TRANS WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GIFFORD-HILL & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: The head of Rhone-Poulenc, the big French chemical group that was nationalized earlier this year, has resigned in protest against the Socialist Government's policies.

description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt UN-AMERICAN ACTIVITIES. By Richard Kluger. 689 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.

description: The Diamond International Corporation announced a definitive agreement to sell the assets of four Diamond units to the Jefferson Smurfit Group of Dublin, Ireland, for $80 million and the assumption of certain undisclosed liabilities.
