description: B-After a loss of $188,000 from discontinued operations; C-Including income of 1,233,000 from discontinued operations

title: SHULTZ SEES CAMP DAVID AS BEST PATH TO PEACE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has declared that he favors no approach to Middle East negotiations other than those called for in the 1978 Camp David accords for granting self-rule to the Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: REAGAN STRATEGY SEEMS TO AVOID ECONOMIC POLICY
description: With a quick trip to St. Louis Thursday, President Reagan continues a busy week of work that seems designed to divert attention from the afflictions of his economic program.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Metals Service Co., a Miami concern, said it had closed its Connecticut warehouse and transferred its customer service and inventories to its Ohio warehouse.

title: More Bidding For Fidelity
description: A second round of bidding for control of Fidelity Savings of San Francisco will begin Thursday at the Washington office of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. But Citicorp's earlier bid seems unlikely to be topped, according to people in the California thrift industry.

title: Job Opportunities - for Children
description: At least the people who put out the child labor news in Washington seemed to recognize it as an embarrassment. They published it on a steamy Friday afternoon in July, when it was likely to receive minimum attention. The news is nonetheless politically baffling. It leaves the Reagan Administration looking callous, relentless and eager to give itself a first-class hotfoot.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BORN-AGAIN CARDBOARD FURNITURE
description: IF you think that you have seen the furniture before, you may be right. Ten years ago, Frank O. Gehry, a Venice, Calif.-based architect, designed a number of pieces made from corrugated cardboard.

title: U.S. Aides Say Arabs Got Cluster Munitions
description: Pentagon officials said today that the United States had sold cluster bombs to Arab countries as well as to Israel, but had attached conditions on their use only in the case of the Israelis.

title: Carter Policies Blamed For Afghanistan Crisis
description: Vice President Bush said tonight that indecisive policies by President Carter encouraged the Soviet Union to intervene militarily in Afghanistan in 1979.

title: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MITSUI'S AMERICAN SUBSIDIARY PLEADS GUILTY TO STEEL FRAUD
description: The American subsidiary of one of Japan's huge trading companies pleaded guilty today to charges of fraud and making false statements in a conspiracy to sell imported steel below allowable prices.

description: The Ashland Oil Company has agreed to take over a pilot synthetic fuels plant in Catlettsburg, Ky., from the Federal Government, the Energy Department said.

description: Two men suspected of having links to the Irish Republican Army were arrested in New York City yesterday while trying to buy 20 M-16 automatic rifles from undercover agents, the Federal Bureau of Investigaton said.

description: Year-ago results have been restated for the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: A major casualty of the scaled-down homes and public buildings we inhabit today is the grand stairway, that majestic, sweeping arrangement of steps and balusters once considered indispensable to any interior with serious architectural ambitions.

title: Dale Morsch, Manager For U.P.I. in West Asia
description: Dale D. Morsch, United Press International's manager for West Asia, died at his home here Monday. He was 50 years old.

title: No Headline
Whether to Make Perfect Humans
description: The rapid advance of genetic engineering raises a question fundamental to the nature of man: Should inheritable alterations to the human gene set be permitted? Unfortunately, genetic engineers, resentful of recent public debate over the health hazards of gene splicing, seem more interested in quietly perfecting their craft than in collaborating in a new inquiry into its consequences.

title: JUDGE REJECTS CUT IN BAIL FOR WILSON
description: A Federal District judge today rejected Government and defense motions to revise the $20 million bail set for Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent charged with illegally aiding Libyan terrorists.

title: VAN DUSEN AIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MURRAY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Q&A
description: Q. We are building a wood deck of spruce boards along the back of our house. In summer the deck will be exposed to rain and sun and in winter it will be buried in deep snow much of the time. I hate to paint every year, and semisolid stains have not stood up very well on our neighbors' decks. So what do you suggest as a finish? -M.H., Ashland, Me.

title: FOCUS OF CITY'S ECONOMY IS CHANGING
description: New York City has passed ''a historic milestone,'' with jobs in manufacturing finally exceeded this year by jobs in the finance, insurance and real-estate fields, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

title: WHY THE JAPANESE ARE OBSESSED WITH TV
description: TOKYO JAPAN'S Kabuki Theater is touring the United States and winning great applause. But here, where not one adult in 10 has seen Utaemon or Tamasaburo in the flesh or paid a single visit to the kabuki, modern entertainment -namely, television - is the rage. The Japanese lead the world in the number of hours spent daily in front of the set.

title: Futures in Singapore

The study will focus on financial futures contracts. Beverly Splane, an executive vice president of the Chicago exchange, will direct the study, which is expected to take four months.

Coleman, a retired acting justice in State Supreme Court and the assistant United States attorney who directed the Government's unsuccessful effort to ban James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' from the United States, died Monday in Basel, Switzerland, apparently of a heart attack. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CARIBBEAN BID PUSHED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan, saying nations in the Caribbean face ''grave economic problems and political instability,'' told a group of diplomats and American businessmen tonight that in the next few weeks he would ''personally'' seek to win Congressional approval of his Caribbean trade and aid plan.

title: Man at U.S. Embassy Shot
description: Antiterrorist police shot and wounded a man today who was carrying a grenade at the gates of the American Embassy after he threatened to toss it inside unless he got a visa to the United States. When the police shot the assailant, who was not identified, he threw the grenade at a group of onlookers, but it did not go off.

description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that its financing subsidiary had agreed to sell $500 million in automobile installment loans to a group of 39 banks. It was the first such sale since Chrysler's brush with bankruptcy in 1979 and 1980.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 22, 1982
description: International The freeing of two-thirds of the Poles interned under martial law was announced by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader. Addressing Parliament, he said martial law might be suspended by the end of the year if tension subsided. (Page A1, Col. 1.) Washington reacted cautiously to Warsaw's announcement that 1,227 Poles were being freed. The Reagan Administration reserved public judgment, but several officials said privately that Poland's initiatives appeared to fall far short of what is needed for the West to lift the sanctions it set when martial law was imposed last December. (A13:1-3.)

title: REDS DROP MCNAMARA, NAME NIXON

title: MAN KILLED, 16 HURT IN CRANE ACCIDENT
description: The 11-ton boom of a construction crane collapsed on the roof of a new Manhattan skyscraper yesterday and knocked loose chunks of granite that hurtled 44 stories onto Madison Avenue and 53d Street. One pedestrian was killed and at least 16 were injured.

title: SOME ESTHETIC PROBLEMS IN REVIVING OLD DANCES
description: IS it possible to revive old dances with fidelity? Ought they to be what they once were? Is there any sense in reviving dances if their original look and spirit cannot be recaptured in a different age? The questions are prompted by the revivals that start this week at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass., in celebration of the summer festival's 50th anniversary.

title: Annulment for Golfer
description: Jan Stephenson, the Australian golfer who won the Ladies' Professional Golf Association championship last month, had her short marriage to Larry Kolb declared void by Judge Joe Eidson in Fort Worth yesterday. In her petition for annulment, Miss Stephenson said she did not realize that she was already legally married, under Texas statutes pertaining to common-law marriages, to a Fort Worth oilman, Ernie Vossler.

An Impasse in Hockey
description: The National Hockey League owners and the Players Association will probably operate without a collective bargaining agreement or, at best, with an interim agreement in the coming season, Alan Eagleson, executive director of the players group, said. Eagleson said the players and owners were far apart in bargaining on the issue of freeagent compensation but that the possibility of a strike was slim. Eagleson said that if the owners and players could not reach an interim compromise, he doubted whether many players would report to training camps Sept. 12, which is three days before the expiration of the current contract.

title: Southern Pacific
description: The Southern Pacific Company said that it would lay off 1,200 railroad employees in the next month because of a decline in its railroad operations. It said that railroad loadings for the most recent four weeks were down 17.6 percent from a year ago, and that it expected business to continue at a low level for the rest of the year because of the recession. The layoffs will be spread across its 14-state territory, Southern Pacific said.

description: The Bristol-Myers Company said that net income in the second quarter increased 14.2 percent, to $81.3 million, or $1.21 a share, from $71.2 million, or $1.07 a share. Sales rose to $880.1 million from $851.9 million.

title: U.S. WITHHOLDS JUDGEMENT ON WARSAW ACTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration withheld judgment today on the actions easing martial law announced by Poland's leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. Privately, several officials said the moves seemed to fall short of what was needed for the United States and other Western nations to end the sanctions imposed when martial law was ordered last December.

title: Oglivie's Slam Leads Brewers
description: Brewers 10 Twins 4

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SMITH BARNEY OFFICER QUITS
description: A vice chairman of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company who had been its principal representative in negotiations to sell 25 percent of its stock to Middle Eastern investors has resigned, effective Aug. 1, the investment banking concern said yesterday.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $117,000 for the quarter and $240,000 for the 6 months; year-ago sales figures do not include sales from discontinued operations

title: COMPTROLLER'S INQUIRY BID
description: The Comptroller of the Currency, C.T. Conover, said today that he had asked the Inspector General of the Treasury Department to investigate the Comptroller office's handling of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which collapsed two weeks ago.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shares outstanding and share earnings amounts reflect a 10 percent stock dividend effective March 1, 1982

title: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERS
description: IN Brooklyn, a woman named Shirley Santos has been accused of beating her 4-year-old daughter, and her lawyer, Stephanie Benson, has chosen to use premenstrual syndrome or PMS as a defense. In Manhattan, the National Center for Premenstrual Syndrome and Menstrual Distress has just opened, advertising itself with slick blue leaflets that look like travel brochures with their romantic pictures of women photographed against a seascape.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
APSLEY HOUSE REOPENS AFTER RESTORATION
description: LONDON AFTER six years of renovation and refurbishing, Apsley House, the museum devoted to the life and military career of Arthur, First Duke of Wellington, reopened its doors this week to reveal itself in its early 19th-century splendor as one of the city's few remaining small palaces.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split paid in February 1982

title: STERLING BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST HOST OF 'TODAY' ON NBC-TV
description: Dave Garroway, the amiable, low-key television personality who served as the first host of ''Today'' on NBC-TV, was found dead of a gunshot wound yesterday at his home in the Philadelphia suburb of Swarthmore. He was 69 years old.

title: DOCUTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago revenue figures have been restated

title: WARP, PITCH & LINGERIE; Beat the Clock
description: Does Government really want to promote more mind-numbing television commercials for suds and cereals? That's the impression the Justice Department left when it insisted that the National Association of Broadcasters abandon any limit on commercial minutes per hour. In fact, Justice had in mind something quite different and useful.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary tax charge of $7,000 for the qr and a tax credit of $63,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,068,000 for the qr and $1,939,000 for the 9 mos

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPOOL BEDSTEADS: TIPS ON REFINISHING THEM
description: One of the tricky parts of staining furniture is working with end grain. If you think of the long surfaces of a piece of prepared timber as straight grain - graining following along the general direction of its length - then the surface exposed when the timber is cut across is end (or edge) grain.

title: AVX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $45,000 from discontinued operations; C-Including income of $602,000 from discontinued operations; D-Net loss including income of $154,000 from discontinued operations

title: ST. LOUIS IS SINGING A HAPPIER SONG
description: Nelson and Mary Laffey regard this city in much the same way they do the 80-year-old house they are restoring here. They think that the underlying positive aspects outweigh the apparent faults.

title: Market Place; New Wrinkle In Municipals
description: IN the bond market, hardship has become the mother of innovation. Municipals have been as hard hit as the rest of the bond market by violent fluctuations in interest rates, and long-term tax-exempts have been designed to reduce the uncertainties.

title: Profit Doubled At First Boston
description: First Boston Inc., parent of the First Boston Corporation, an investment banking firm, yesterday reported profits of $12.7 million, or $2.22 a share, for the second quarter, more than double last year's results. The gains reflected ''strong contributions by both securities trading and investment banking,'' said George L. Shinn, the company's chairman and chief executive.

title: Canada and Brazil Condemn Central America Interference
description: Brazil and Canada have called for an end to foreign interference in Central America, where they said the political climate would improve only when social and economic conditions did.

title: UNIMAX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,469,200 for the quarter and $7,191,200 for the 9 months resulting from the sales of Barry's Jewelers, and taxcredits of $89,500 for the quarter and $574,300 or the 9 months; C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $47,000 for the quarter and $542,900 for the 9 months and tax credits of $196,000 for the quarter and $575,000 for the 9 months

title: JEC LASERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SOUTHWEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Israelis Say 5 Soldiers Died in P.L.O. Attacks
description: Palestinian guerrillas operating behind Israeli lines in Lebanon have staged three attacks in the last 24 hours, killing five Israeli soldiers and wounding five others, a military spokesman said.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
ABC BACKS OFF CHARGE IT MADE AGAINST MOBIL
description: ABC News has told the Mobil Oil Corporation that it did not intend to include the company in its comments about consumer fraud that were broadcast June 20 in a documentary called ''The Oil Game.''

title: EVANS & SUTHERLAND COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $3,283,000 or 72 cents a shr

description: B-After a loss of $185,000 for the quarter and a gain of $137,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations; C-Including gains from discontinued operations$359,000 for the quarter and $782,000 for the 6 months

title: SEA GALLEY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DUN & BRANDSTREET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
50 IN CONGRESS PROTEST POLICY ON PROTRACTED A-WAR
description: Fifty members of Congress, most of them Democrats, have signed a letter to President Reagan protesting the Administration's policy on fighting a protracted nuclear war and urging him to reassess the policy.

title: COURT OVERTURNS VERDICT ON BLAZE
description: A Federal appellate court today overturned a verdict that had cleared aluminum wiring manufacturers of responsibility for a fire that killed 165 persons in 1977 at the Beverly Hills Supper Club in northern Kentucky.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods include a gain of $550,000 from a settlement of a dispute with the IRS

title: DEMOCRATS ATTACK ADMINISTRATION'S ROLE IN E.P.A.
description: Democrats in Congress and environmentalists joined today in a sharp attack on the Reagan Administration's management of the Environmental Protection Agency, asserting that the environmental laws were being undermined by executive action.

title: Bond Data Delayed
description: Statistics on new bond issues compiled by the First Boston Corporation were not available yesterday because of technical difficulties.

title: Hines H. Baker, Former Head Of Humble Oil Company, Dies
description: Hines H. Baker, former president of the Humble Oil & Refining Company, died Monday at the age of 88. Mr. Baker was a schoolteacher turned lawyer when he joined Humble in 1919.

title: The turnover in Turners.
description: THIS year may well go down in history as the year when more paintings by J.M.W. Turner - four, in fact - were offered at auction than in many decades. Relatively few Turners are in private hands, and therefore few come up at auction. The artist made a gift to the British Empire at his death in 1851 of 300 of his oils and more than 20,000 watercolors and drawings. Most of these are now in the Tate Gallery in London.

title: REAGANOMICS, R.I.P.
description: he first anniversary of Congressional passage of President Reagan's three-stage tax reduction bill is just a week away, so this seems a good time to pronounce it a solid, ringing failure.

title: ARVIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONTEFUSCO FINDS HIS PLACE IN THE SUN
description: It was a fitting sight. While most of his San Diego Padres teammates were preparing to face the Mets at Shea Stadium recently, John (The Count) Montefusco was sprawled on the floor, in his own world.

title: ERIKSON, MAY THAWART RANGERS
description: Two former New York center fielders made a brief visit to Yankee Stadium last night. One, Lee Mazzilli, the former Met, did not play against the Yankees and said he did not understand why. The other, Mickey Rivers, the former Yankee, played and the Yankees understood why.

title: City Agent Is Shot Issuing Summons
description: A Sanitation Department enforcement agent was shot on a Chinatown street yesterday while writing a $50 summons against a restaurant for a city code violation.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss after losses of $130,193 from discontinued operations and $45,000 from the sale of discontinued operations...C-After a loss of $205,984 from discontinued operations and including a gain of $3,100,000 from the sale of discontinued operations

title: JUILLIARD, 'OSSIE AND RUBY' AND POE
description: THERE'S no business like show business perhaps, but there's no show business like the music business, the business of serious music in which great art is faced with the problem of making a living. The process by which young people dedicated to serious music are educated in the challenges of making themselves heard in their field is tackled by ''Juilliard and Beyond: A Life in Music,'' a CBS News special with Charles Kuralt to be seen tomorrow at 10 P.M.

title: Conrail's Net Rises Sharply
description: Conrail reported yesterday that its net income rose sharply in the second quarter, to $56.2 million, or $2.21 a share, from $13.8 million, or 52 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. The gain came despite a 14.7 percent drop in freight traffic.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MCQUAY-PERFEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a net foreign currency translation loss of $20.8 million; yr-ago results have been restated for F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: 6 YANKS ARE DRILLED ON RECENT MISTAKES
description: Six Yankees who made mistakes in recent games showed up early at Yankee Stadium yesterday and took what Willie Randolph termed their ''punishment.''

title: DOUBLE PLAY EXECUTED WITH FLAIR
description: T he two men who created all the trouble for the Yankees in the 12th inning Wednesday night are Julio and Todd Cruz, the middle infielders for the Seattle Mariners. They aren't related and they have been playing together for only four months. But they share a talent that has made them the talk of the major leagues: the ability to turn the acrobatic double play.

title: IF USE OF SEAT BELTS WERE MADE A MUST
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Signs Order Blocking Railroad Walkout for 60 Days
description: President Reagan signed an executive order today blocking a strike threatened Friday against most of the nation's major freight railroads by the United Transportation Union.

title: AMERICA'S TOXIC-WASTE ALERT IS ON
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUNDERS LEASING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan 29, 1982

title: Advertising; Spoofing Network Television
description: IF it continues to spoof its clients' competitors so expertly, Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver might just get to be known as the Zap Agency, which, if nothing else, would be a great time saver for its switchboard operator.

title: Friday; ORANGE COUNTY FAIR
description: Through Aug. 1 the Orange County Agricultural Society is presenting its 142d county fair at the county fairgrounds, on the border of the city of Middletown, 60 miles from New York at the junction of Interstate 84 and Routes 17 and 6. Beef and dairy cattle, sheep, goats, arts, crafts, apples, pears, plums, grapes, pies, cakes, breads, needlework, flowers and plants by the thousands will all be competing for the traditional blue ribbons as well as $30,000 in prize money. Entertainment includes puppet shows, motorcycle stunt riding and music by Jimmy Sturr, the polka king. Tonight at 8, it's wrestling (admission, $4 and $6). General fairgrounds admission, $3; $2 for those younger than 12. Open noon to midnight. Information: (914) 343-4826. JAZZ ON GRAND STREET STAGE

title: Fire Captain Dies At Blaze in Bronx
description: A 46-year-old fire captain collapsed and died yesterday morning - apparently of a heart attack - after running up five flights of stairs in a Bronx apartment house, mistakenly believing that two children might be trapped in a burning dwelling.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATE VOTES A BILL TO WITHHOLD TAXES ON STOCK DIVIDENDS
description: In a victory for the Reagan Administration, the Senate tonight approved a proposal for a 10 percent withholding tax on stock dividends and interest received by millions of Americans.

title: MULTIMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Richard C. Bozzuto
description: Mr. Bozzuto gained prominence in state politics as the minority leader of the State Senate in 1979 and 1980. He was first elected to the Senate in 1972 and championed a position of fiscal conservatism in that office.

title: PUBLISHING: A PLAN TO BREAK THE GRIDLOCK IN BOOKS
description: ''ONE of the major signs of immaturity in book publishing is the failure of publishers to concern themselves with distribution, even though they're victimized by the present distribution method.''

title: AN UPSTATE FARM WHERE ARTISTS GROW
description: On an old dairy farm in upstate New York, the distinguished English sculptor Anthony Caro, noted for his work in welded steel, has begun to realize his dream of creating an international artistic community.

title: INDUSTRY GROUPS ASK U.S. TO END TEAMSTER STRIKE
description: Two major groups representing real-estate developers and builders, saying they have been severely hurt by a three-week-old truck drivers strike against the construction industry, have appealed to the National Labor Relations Board to move to halt the strike.

title: WOMAN'S WORK: RARELY BLUE-COLLAR
description: It rained the first day Antonia Hernandez went to work as an electrician's apprentice, digging holes and installing lampposts on the Long Island Expressway. And she slammed her hand with a hammer that day and received a stiff shock trying to turn off a generator with a metal crowbar.

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including nonrecurring gains totaling $20.3 million or 68 cents a shr

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ALISON MAZZOLA, a 1981 graduate of Smith College, recently got her f irst job, as associate beauty editor at Town and Country magazine. S o to celebrate, she threw a Midsummer Night's Eve party at Club A t he other night for 200 of her closest friends.

title: National Steel Loss
description: The National Steel Corporation, citing a severe drop in steel demand and prices, said yesterday that it lost $49.9 million in the second quarter, in contrast to earnings of $19 million, or $1.02 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. Revenues declined 27.5 percent, to $804.8 million, from $1.11 billion in the 1981 period. The company said steel shipments declined 29 percent from the 1981 quarter, to 1.3 million tons, and utilization fell to 45 percent of capacity.

title: IS LING-LING EXPECTING?
description: The reproductive saga of the pandas at the National Zoo has entered a period of intense scrutiny and waiting. Human volunteers began watching the female panda, Ling-Ling, on closed-circuit television 24 hours a day this month for signs that she might deliver a cub.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle yesterday on the White House bar- ber shop incorrectly stated the shop's cost arrangement. According to the White House Press Office, all users, including the President and the Vice President, pay $16 and up for haircuts.

title: A WORRY IN ISRAEL
description: As the siege of Beirut drags on, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon faces increasing criticism and ambivalence not only among liberals and leftist critics of the war but also among his staunchest supporters - members of Likud and Herut, on the political right.

title: FOES OF BALANCED BUDGET PROPOSAL SAY IT COULD BRING ON DEPRESSION
description: A bipartisan group of Senators asserted today that if the proposed Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget had been in effect, it would have pushed the current recession into a depression.

title: The U.N. Today; July 23, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade law commission working group on new international economic order - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FRANKENHEIMER'S 'CHALLENGE'
description: SCENERY and sadism are the main things on display in John Frankenheimer's ''The Challenge,'' a hard-boiled action film with great hopes of becoming something more. The setting is modern, urban Japan, presented with a fair amount of realism and detail. And the story, by Richard Maxwell and John Sayles, works hard to contrast East and West, old and new. There is much about ''The Challenge,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, to make the viewer sorry it isn't better.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The New York Jets released Tim Cotton, a wide receiver, yesterday after he failed his physical examination. The club then acquired Bob Grupp, a punter, from the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 23, 1982
description: International France defied Washington's order barring European companies operating under American license from producing equipment for a pipeline that will supply Western Europe with Soviet natural gas. The French order to proceed with the contracts applies mainly to a nationalized French company using American technology to make 40 turbine rotors for the 3,500-mile pipeline. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iran opened a new drive near the strategic Iraqi oil port of Basra, and Iraq said it had hurled back the two Iranian brigades that led the attack. Baghdad said several thousand Iranians had been killed. (A3:4-6.)

title: THE CITY IS NOW ROCKING TO MANY BEATS
description: rock at Maxwell's in Hoboken. Echo and the Bunnymen, who are probably the most popular band to have emerged from Liverpool since the Beatles, are at the Peppermint Lounge. George Benson, an exceptional jazz guitarist and a very successful pop vocalist, is at Radio City Music Hall. Angela Bofill is singing her personal urban pop at the Dr Pepper Festival on the Hudson. And there's more, lots more. It's a summer weekend in New York City, and it's alive with pop music of just about every stripe.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burlington Northern named Paul P. Senio vice president for taxes.

title: QUOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gretzky's Limitation
description: After a spring and summer filled with personal and television appearances all over the world, Wayne Gretzky has decided that after the 1982-83 National Hockey League season he will limit himself to appearing in a made-for-television movie. ''I'm very interested in acting, after I did the first 7-Up commercial,'' said the 21-year-old center with the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Hawiian Punch Drops Osmonds from Spots
description: And now for the bad news. After four years of good, faithful and smiling service, Donny and Marie Osmond have been dropped over the side by Hawaiian Punch in favor of commercials it hopes will present ''an upbeat, contemporary image.''

title: GRAND MET'S CHAIRMAN TO SHIFT TO QUIETER POST
description: Sir Maxwell Joseph plans to retire next March as group chairman of Grand Metropolitan, the British business empire that includes hotels and restaurants.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The feminization of poverty will become one of the major issues of the 1980's.

title: THE ULTIMATE WEAPON
description: From the Berlin Blockade to the Rebellion i n El Salvador, our responses to Soviet and Communist initiatives h ave been uniformly military. We have failed to use the one weapon t hat can give us the initiative - our economic clout. If we are to m eet the challenge of Soviet expansionism, we must look beyond p unitive economic policies to a constructive use of trade incentives a nd economic competition.

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HABIB EXPANDS ROLE IN SHAPING LEBANON POLICY
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, 6,000 miles from here, within earshot of the fighting in Beirut, surrounded by wanted and unwanted intermediaries, using the secure telephone almost daily to the State Department and the White House, has been a prime shaper of policy in the Lebanese crisis, according to Administration officials.

title: SENATE UNIT APPROVES BILL AIMED AT REDUCING ACID RAIN POLLUTION
description: The Senate Environment Committee, making a breakthrough on a highly divisive issue, drafted legislation today that would require industry to clean up pollution that is believed to cause acid rain.

title: COGGSHELLS DESCEND ON THEIR HOME STATE
description: As the steam rose from a clambake here the other evening, there stood a Coggeshall. And there a Coggeshall. And there. And there. And there.

title: Alcoa to Sell Units to Wesray
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, said it had signed an agreement in principle to sell two subsidiaries to affiliated companies of the Wesray Corporation, a New Jersey holding company headed by a former Secretary of the Treasury, William E. Simon. Terms of the agreement were not announced.

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A CHRISTIAN PRESIDENCY IS CRUCIAL TO RECOVER LEBANESE STABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP AIDES-AWAIT SHULTZ'S WORD ON THEIR FUTURES
description: George P. Shultz's first week as Secretary of State has ended in suspense for most of the top officials at the State Department. The officials are not only uncertain about many key policies, but, more to the point, they are also uncertain about their own futures.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the qr and $500,000 for the 6 mos

title: Bus-Truck Crash Kills Youth
description: An 18-wheel grocery truck struck a school bus broadside Wednesday, killing one teen-age passenger and injuring 19 people, including the driver. The youth killed, Thomas Vaughn, 15 years old, ''was thrown out of the bus and up under'' the truck, according to a sheriff's department spokesman. The bus was carrying home children from a summer program at Coahoma Junior College.

title: ENGINEERING GIANT GETS NEW PRESIDENT
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. yesterday named Charles E. Hugel president, succeeding Arthur J. Santry Jr., who will assume the chairman's title, which has been vacant. Mr. Santry, 63 years old, who has been president since 1963, remains chief executive officer of the Stamford, Conn., company, which had revenues of $3.8 billion last year. The changes are effective Sept. 1.

title: ROLL CALL OF NERVE GAS
description: Here is the roll-call of votes by representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on an amendment to remove from a military authorization bill $54 million for production of nerve gas weapons. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to remove the money.

title: MORRISON-KNUDSEN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RUSSIAN SEEKING EXIT TO U.S. ENDS 51-DAY HUNGER STRIKE
description: A 29-year-old Soviet freelance photographer today abandoned the 51-day-old hunger strike he had declared in support of his application to leave the country and join his American wife in the United States.

title: The Giants' Year of Promise
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. T he curse is gone. So are the negative vibes. The ''good luck, coach, you're gonna need it'' with a handshake has been replaced by a pat on the back and a ''We're gonna do it, coach, this is the year.''

title: CLUETT PEABODY & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $264,000 for the qr and $439,000for the 6 mos

title: E.P.A. CHIEF FORECASTS CUT IN AID TO THE STATES
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that she foresaw an eventual end to Federal assistance to the states for carrying out the nation's environmental laws.

title: Begin to Visit Zaire in August At the Invitation of Mobutu
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin will fly to Zaire early next month on a state visit, the Prime Minister's office in Jerusalem announced today. The exact date was not given.

title: EVELYN BYRNES RHODES
description: Evelyn Byrnes Rhodes, the founder and owner of a women's specialty shop in Manhattan, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Rhodes, who lived in Manhattan, was 75 years old.

title: REPUBLIC FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago figures have been restated for a foreign currency accounting change

title: IRAN-IRAQ WAR PRODUCES NO ALARM IN GULF STATES
description: Iran's invasion of Iraq has produced concern and caution among the oil-producing Persian Gulf states, but the seeming inconclusiveness of the fighting has limited destabilizing effects in the area.

title: JAPANESE-FORD STEEL PLANT DEAL
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to sell a controlling interest in its Rouge Steel Company subsidiary to a group of Japanese concerns led by Nippon Kokan, Japan's second-largest steelmaker.

title: CITY BANS DISMANTLING OF CRANES AFTER FATAL ACCIDENT
description: It was hardly the traditional kind of command center. But the roof of 520 Madison Avenue was turned into just that all day Wednesday and yesterday as crucial decisions were being made about a crane boom dangling 44 stories above 53d Street.

title: ISRAELI FORCES HIT SYRIANS AND P.L.O. ALONG TWO FRONTS
description: Israel, charging that the cease-fire had been violated by Syrians in eastern Lebanon and Palestinians in western Beirut, attacked on both fronts today with air and artillery strikes.

title: Ruppert Project Gains Approval
description: Plans for the final phase of the Ruppert Urban Renewal Project on the Upper East Side won unanimous approval from the Board of Estimate yesterday.

title: BANK'S COLLAPSE IS SAID TO IMPAIR THRIFT UNITS
description: One savings and loan association has been left insolvent, another is ''severely impaired'' and several others have been weakened as a result of uninsured losses they incurred in the recent collapse of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, according to the head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: FRANCE DEFIES BAN BY U.S. ON SUPPLIES FOR SOVIET PIPELINE
description: The French Government announced today that it was instructing French companies to fulfill their contracts to produce American-licensed components for a Soviet pipeline despite a ban by President Reagan.

title: AERO-FLOW DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LONDON CUTS CURBS AROUND FALKLANDS
description: Britain eased its 200-mile sea and air blockade around the Falkland Islands today, asking Argentina to keep its warships and military aircraft at least 150 miles away to reduce ''misunderstandings or inadvertent clashes.''

title: Motorola Net Off 11%
description: Motorola Inc., a leading manfacturer of electronic equipment and information systems, said today that its net earnings for the second quarter fell 11 percent, to $45.3 million, or $1.26 a share, from $50.5 million, or $1.41 a share, during the second quarter of 1981. Sales in the quarter rose 7 percent, to $965.1 million from $901.4 million. Robert W. Galvin, Motorola chairman and chief executive officer, said that the company would ''continue our efforts to improve productivity in all parts of our organization.''

title: Blue Cross Campaign Is Using Tommy John
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York has enlisted the Yankee pitcher Tommy John in a battle to keep medical costs, and therefore the tapping of its till, down in this area.

title: AIR FRANCE ACTS TO FILL A VACANCY AT THE TOP
description: Henri Sauvan, a longtime Air France executive, was named president of the airline yesterday, succeeding Gilbert Perol, who resigned after a dispute with the French Government over company policy. Mr. Perol is returning to the Foreign Ministry, where he worked early in his career.

title: ROMAN JACKSON, A SCHOLAR OF LINGUISTICS, IS DEAD
description: Roman Jakobson, the father of modern structural linguistics, elaborated sophisticated theories of language and communication that had profound effects on such disciplines as anthropology, art criticism and brain research.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NO MOVEMENT IN N.F.L. TALKS
description: Neither the players' union nor the National Football League owners made concessions on items such as individual player negotiations or drug testing today as talks continued over a new bargaining agreement.

title: Adhesive Hero
description: Bob Reese, the Jets' trainer, was surprised to find that his simple routine of taping knees and ankles fascinated officials from Soviet Bloc countries during a recent seminar on sports medicine in Austria.

title: JUDGE BLOCKS REAGAN PLAN TO EASE RULES ON WAGES AT BUILDING SITES
description: A Federal district judge today temporarily blocked a Labor Department plan to change the rules enforcing a law that established minimum wages for employees on hundreds of thousands of construction projects.

title: Economic Scene; Money Supply And Inflation
description: TODAY, few deny that controlling the money supply could end inflation. The proposed ''contemporaneous reserve'' requirements represent the latest in a series of steps that the Federal Reserve is taking to do so.

title: Hot Buses, Cold Facts
description: Want to know why a country that can keep TV cameras working while they circle the sun can't keep New York buses cool while they circle the city? The answer is part technical and part human. Neither part will be easy to change.

title: AMERICAN SEATING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June
GILMORE TRADED TO SPURS
description: The Chicago Bulls today traded Artis Gilmore, their veteran center, to the San Antonio Spurs for Dave Corzine, a center, and Mark Olberding, a forward.

title: Air Florida Jet With 12 Aboard Is Hijacked to Cuba by 2 Men
description: An Air Florida flight from Miami to Key West with 12 people aboard was hijacked to Cuba by two men tonight, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Pan Am, Braniff Discontinue Talks
description: Talks on joint operations between Pan American World Airways and grounded Braniff International are ''dead,'' according to Pan Am's chairman, C. Edward Acker, who spoke with security analysts in New York.

title: LLOYD WANER, BASEBALL STAR
description: Lloyd Waner, the younger part of a brother combination in baseball's Hall of Fame, died today at Presbyterian Hospital of complications related to emphysema. He was 76 years old.

title: ART: LITTLE-KNOWN CANADIAN MASTER
description: ALTHOUGH the cultural currents of Europe can flow in all directions, those of North America tend to move laterally. In New York City, for instance, the art public is much more likely to know what's new - and old - to the east and west of it than about developments in Canada or Latin America, a condition that the Center for Inter-American Relations strives to correct.

title: SECURITY FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: In January, a nationwide poll estimated that 68 percent of Americans under age 45 do not believe that Social Security will exist when they retire. In March, a follow-up poll confirmed those estimates. Throughout May and June, while preparing the 1983 Federal budget, Congress was paralyzed by the issue of Social Security benefits and financing. Social Security must survive. Thirty-six million Americans receive benefits; 40 percent of them rely on Social Security for three-fourths of their household income. But Social Security could do far more than merely survive. It could provide a capital fund for America's economic rebirth, without which there will be no security for the elderly, few jobs for our children and unquenchable Federal deficits for the indefinite future.

title: LOUGANIS CAPTURES 3-METER DIVING
description: Greg Louganis and Megan Neyer, national collegiate champions and members of the 1980 United States Olympic diving team, won the first gold medals of the National Sports Festival tonight, taking first place in the men's and women's 3-meter springboard finals.

title: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAPANESE FILMS WIN FANS IN THE CITY
description: This summer seems to be the season for Japanese films in Manhattan. Three Japanese retrospective series are under way, and two new films on Japanese themes, one made by an American, have just opened in commercial theaters. Whether your taste runs to samurai movies or to ''Godzilla'' or to dramas about the suffering of peasants under feudal lords, an Asian film is likely to be showing somewhere that will satisfy.

title: PRIME COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROGRESSIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
6 Children Are Killed By Grenade in Cairo
description: An unexploded grenade went off here on Wednesday, killing six children and wounding 13 other people, police sources said today.

title: CASE OF ALBANY LOBBYIST: CHECKS LOST AND FOUND
description: In the hectic closing days of the legislative session late in June, a lobbyist for the Long Island Lighting Company left behind a cardboard folder in a Senator's office containing checks made out to the campaign committees of five Legislature members.

description: The Seemala Corporation, a subsidiary of the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission it had acquired 1,038,500 shares, or 10 percent, of the common stock of Giddings and Lewis Inc. in connection with risk arbitrage and other activities.

title: Draft Resister Is Indicted For Refusing to Register
description: A former Yale University philosophy student who refused to register for the draft was indicted today by a Federal grand jury, becoming the third man to face criminal charges in a recent crackdown on resisters.

ALLEN TO HEAD JET PROPLUSION LAB
description: Dr. Lew Allen Jr., who retired last month as Chief of Staff of the Air Force, was named yesterday to head the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, the nation's principal center for the exploration of deep space.

title: UAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dailey Denies Payment Reports
description: Quintin Dailey has denied through his agent that he received $5,000 from a team booster while playing basketball at the University of San Francisco.

title: HABIB BEING SENT TO ARAB CAPITALS
description: Philip C. Habib, the special Middle East envoy, is being sent by President Reagan to Syria, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and possibly other Arab countries to try to persuade them to accept the Palestine Liberation Organization forces in west Beirut as part of a solution to the Lebanon crisis.

title: E.E.C. OFFER TO CURB STEEL SALES REJECTED BY U.S.
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige today rejected a proposal, made just hours earlier, from four members of the European Economic Community to cut their steel exports to the United States in an effort to settle a growing trade dispute.

title: BART STUYF IS DANCING WITH MIRRORS
description: Figures in white appear to be swimming through the air or stalking one another, stepping from invisible perch to perch. They run races, feet bearing down on nothing but light, and they curl protectively around one another's bodies while floating through space.

title: JERSEY'S NEW CLUB: GENERALS
description: The new football club to play in the Meadowlands Sports Complex, the sixth professional sports team to call it home, will be named the New Jersey Generals. The metropolitan area franchise in the recently organized United States Football League also announced today that its emblem would have a patriotic five-star motif of red, white and blue.

title: Rail Merger Hearing Held
description: The proposed merger of the Union Pacific, Missiouri Pacific and Western Pacific railroads was sharply criticized today by competing roads in an all-day hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $1,400,000 or 24 cents, and a gain from discontinued operations of $29,400 or 1 cent

WASHINGTON POST CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains of $244,000 or 2 cents for the qr and $291,000 or 2 cents , the 6 mos resulting from the restatement of yr-ago figures to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52...C-Includes a gain of $1,100,000 or 8 cents, on the sale ofthe company's minority interests in a photo composition company

title: Radio War With Cuba
description: One can imagine how indignant Ronald Reagan would be if a Democratic Administration spent money it didn't have to create a superfluous propaganda station, all to placate an ideological claque. That pretty well describes his Administration's determination to establish Radio Marti, to broadcast to Cuba.

title: AUDUBON FAIR: 684 ACRES OF BIRDS, SLUGS AND BUGS
description: City dwellers will get a chance to look for salamanders, make charcoal, observe such ''creepy crawlers'' as millipedes, spiders and slugs, taste wild plants, go on bird walks, learn how to make baskets and take short courses about wolves, snakes and whales this weekend at the annual Audubon Festival in Sharon, Conn.

title: F.B.I. ACCUSED OF BEING 'GIDDY' IN ABSCAM BRIBES
description: Senator Alan K. Simpson today accused officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of having grown ''so giddy'' with the success of the Abscam investigation that they failed to be discriminating in deciding who should be offered bribes.

title: THE PROPER CONTEXT FOR U.S. ENERGY POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: HABIB TRYING AGAIN TO GET SYRIA TO ACCEPT TRANSFER OF P.L.O.
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, arrived here tonight for what appeared to be a new effort to persuade Syria to reconsider its refusal to accept Palestine Liberation Organization fighters besieged in west Beirut by Israeli forces.

title: Bridge: Play in Summer Nationals Beginning in Albuquerque
description: For thousands of players gathering here today, this is a beginning: the start of the Summer National Championships, which will continue for 10 days.

title: NATIONAL CAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures for the latest periods are fully diluted; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: Market Place; How to Protect Social Security
description: SOCIAL SECURITY has all its eggs in one basket - a basket filled with United States Treasury bonds. Perhaps other baskets, containing common stocks and corporate bonds, would improve the performance of the Social Security Trust Fund and save it from the threat of insolvency.

title: MRS. GANDHI, ON EVE OF U.S. TRIP, DENIES INDIA IS IN SOVIET CAMP
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who will visit the United States next week, today disputed the idea that India belonged to the Soviet camp.

title: HEUBLEIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: DYCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Construction Worker Killed in 12-Story Fall
description: A construction worker fell 12 stories to his death in midtown Manhattan yesterday morning, the police said. The worker, identified as Henry Romero of Brooklyn, 31 years old, was working on the 12th floor of a building under construction at 900 Third Avenue, at 54th Street, when he fell into an open elevator shaft at about 10 A.M., according to Sgt. Edward Leshak, a police spokesman.

title: Blaze in Pinelands Engulfs 300 Acres
description: Firefighters evacuated a Burlington County mobile-home park as a quickly spreading blaze engulfed more than 300 acres of forest in the Pinelands this afternoon, officials said.

title: FORMER STABLES NOW CO-OP IN BROOKLYN'S PARK SLOPE
description: In its ambiance as a neighborhood, in its stock of stately Victorian brownstones, and in its prices, both for the brownstones and for apartments, Brooklyn's Park Slope has few peers in New York City.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago figures have been restated for a 10 percent stock divd paid Feb 19, 1982

title: Free 'Porgy' in Concert In Brooklyn Sunday
description: A free concert performance of George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess,'' with full orchestra, gospel choir and soloists, will be given Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Prospect Park Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. David Amram will conduct the group, which includes the soprano Theresa Merritt and the bass-baritone Edward Pierson.

title: Video Game Client To Benton & Bowles
description: Benton & Bowles has reported that it is now in the booming video games business, thanks to Games by Apollo Inc. of Dallas, itself new to the scene.

title: INTER-REGIONAL FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the merger with Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc on Dec 31, 1981; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 20 percent stock divd paid Apr 30, 1982

title: ROBIN WILLIAMS STARS IN 'GARP' ADAPTION
description: JOHN IRVING'S ''The World According to Garp'' wasn't a book that cried out to become a movie. But it has become one, and the movie is a very fair rendering of Mr. Irving's novel, with similar strengths and weaknesses. If the novel was picaresque and precious, so is the film - although the absence of the book's self-congratulatory streak helps the movie achieve a much lighter, more easy-going style. If the novel was haltingly plotted and full of foreshadowing, the film has similar trouble. And if it was finally the book's whimsical side that endeared it to so many readers, the movie is missing none of that charm. If anything, it's got a little more.

title: Antique Boats to Parade Down Mystic River
description: More than 40 sail and power boats up to 80 feet long and at least 42 years old will take part tomorrow at 3 P.M. in the Mystic Seaport Museum's seventh annual antique-boat parade down the Mystic River in Mystic, Conn.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Solidarity Backers Held At a Protest in Warsaw
description: The police arrested several supporters of the independent Solidarity trade union today at a counterdemonstration of song and prayer by more than 300 people just a few yards from official ceremonies marking Poland's National Day.

title: AETNA SETS TIE TO BANK IN BRITAIN
description: In an unusual international alliance of financial institutions, Aetna Life and Casualty Company said yesterday that it is going into partnership with the Midland Bank of Britain in ownership of the Samuel Montagu & Company group, a leading British investment bank and bullion house. Aetna is the largest publicly owned insurance company in the Unites States and Midland is Britain's third-largest clearing bank.

description: The three candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor appeared together at Town Hall in Thompson, Conn., a few days ago.

IRAN LAUNCHES THREE-PRONGED DRIVE NEAR IRAQI PORT
description: Iran launched a new drive Wednesday night near this strategic Iraqi oil port, and Iraq said today that it had repulsed the two brigades that led the attack.

3M Fell 7.9% and Textron 43.1% in Period
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that a combination of the recession and foreign-exchange fluctuations caused its earnings in the second quarter to drop 7.9 percent, while sales rose about 1.4 percent.

title: HOOVER UNIVERSAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEAM CALLED BLITZ
description: George Allen, coach and part-owner of Chicago's United State Football League entry, christened the team the Blitz today. Team officials said the name was chosen from 3,351 suggestions by more than 20,000 fans.

title: STAGE: PHILIP BARRY COMEDY AT BERKSHIRE FESTIVAL
description: If you're going to revive a Philip Barry comedy these days, you can't do much better than to cast John Shea, Sigourney Weaver and Anne Twomey in the leads. These three actors have just what Barry required of his upper-crust heros and heroines: breeding, youth, wit and an ineffable ability to look smashing in town and country evening clothes. It doesn't hurt, either, that these three stars, like the Katharine Hepburns, Joseph Cottens and Cary Grants of Barry's day, are on the tall side. Maybe the rich aren't really all that much different from you and me, but it's still romantic to believe that they are taller.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a nonrecurring casualty gain of $403,000

title: DAVIS STOPS COLLINS AFTER THREE ROUNDS
description: Howard Davis, tuning up for what he hopes will be a shot later this year at Ray Mancini's World Boxing Association lightweight title, gained an easy victory at the Sands Hotel tonight.

title: DECISION IS SURPRISE
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, is resigning to return to academic life. The announcment was made tonight in St. Louis, where President Reagan is making an overnight trip.

title: Part of the Hudson Is Safe for Bathing
description: Rockland County's Health Commissioner announced today that ''for the first time in years,'' the Hudson River north of the Tappan Zee Bridge is safe for swimming.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Family Affair

title: Bears Lose a Suit By Former Player
description: An Illinois Industrial Commission arbitrator has ruled against the Chicago Bears in a suit involving a former player.

title: SANGSTER'S BOAST RUFFLES BLUEGRASS
description: Robert Sangster, the British soccer-pool operator who bought a Nijinsky II colt for a record $4.25 million at the Keeneland Select Yearling Sales in Lexington, Ky., earlier this week, broke his usual silence the day after the sales and held a brief news conference to discuss his purchases. The audience, mostly Kentuckians, wished he had remained silent.

title: No Headline
description: The Energy Department was ordered today to respond to charges that it concealed information on the possibility of a core explosion or meltdown at its proposed Clinch River breeder reactor project in Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: BUCKLE OF ONYX
description: Lynn Tuttle is a sculptor who says she was working on a 500-pound chunk of onyx one day when a piece chipped off. ''I looked at it,'' she said, ''and saw a belt buckle.

Lloyd Waner Dies
description: Lloyd (Little Poison) Waner, a star outfielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1927 to 1941, has died at the age of 76. An obituary appears on page B6.

title: REAGAN URGES PRIVATE EFFORT TO AID NEEDY
description: President Reagan, speaking at a Boys Club supported by corporate contributions, described his private initiative program today as an antidote for the ''rocky misconception'' that the Government is solely responsible for helping the needy.

description: The General Electric Company filed suit yesterday against the Sony Corporation, contending that a plastic used for the housing of Sony consumer electronics products, including its video cassette recorder, infringed upon G.E.'s patent.

Rapist Doctor Hospitalized
description: Dr. Eugene Sherry, an anesthesiologist convicted in the rape of a Boston nurse, was hospitalized late tonight after he complained of chest pains hours before he was to appear in court on fugitive from justice charges. Dr. Sherry, 29 years old, returned to the United States from London Wednesday night. An arrest warrant was issued two weeks ago after he told the authorities he could not begin a six-month prison term because he was ill.

description: Karlfried Nordmann, former president of Mercedes-Benz of North America, died Wednesday at his Greenwich home. He was 66 years old.

title: Money Fund Assets Jump
description: Assets of the nation's money funds jumped $4.13 billion, to a record $208.87 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the third consecutive increase in assets.

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Back to Brooklyn, Where a Career Began

title: COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nuclear Sand in the Eye
description: The Reagan team's ''decision'' not to consider a comprehensive nuclear test-ban until two older treaties are perfected is so much sand in the eyes. The Administration has avoided test-ban negotiations for 18 months; it clearly has no interest in the total treaty. That is too bad for Soviet-American relations and for the cause of non-proliferation. Without great military risk to either power, a total ban would do much to help discourage other nations from pursuing nuclear weapons.

title: OFFSHORE OIL STEP RAISES FUROR
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to open one billion offshore acres to oil and gas leasing provoked an uproar today, with California preparing a court challenge and Interior Secretary James G. Watt accusing critics of ''political posturing.''

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that inventory liquidations added about $3 million to the net income in the latest second qr

title: MUSEUM SALUTES ROLE OF L.I. IN EARLY AVIATION
description: Before jumbo jets and space shuttles, before first-class accommodations and suburban sprawl, the skies over Long Island were crowded with self-taught pilots who were obsessed with breaking records and making aviation history. The most famous of these was Charles A. Lindbergh, who guided a small single-engine plane down a Long Island air strip called Roosevelt Field and off toward Paris 55 years ago.

title: EISENHOWER COLLEGE IS CLOSED BY LOSS OF AID AND STUDENTS
description: Eisenhower College, plagued by financial problems during much of its 16 years, has closed permanently, its administrators announced today.

title: Security for Browns
description: John T. Chappelle, a longtime member of the New York City Police Department, was hired yesterday by the Cleveland Browns as director of security. Art Modell, the Browns' owner, said, ''He will be active in keeping undesirable people from having any easy access to members of our organization, and he will coordinate his work with the league office and N.F.L. security.''

title: Reynolds Metals
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would temporarily suspend two aluminum potlines at its Troutdale, Ore., plant.

title: All-Too-Familiar Ground
description: W hen he pulled out of the Governor's race a few months ago, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan cited the disadvantage he thought he would have against Mayor Koch in scaring up money from big-time contributors. So there was mild irony in the location chosen for a fundraising event last night in behalf of the Comptroller's re-election campaign. It was the new restaurant opened in midtown by Mr. Koch's old finance committee chairman, Peter Aschkenasy. Clyde Haberman Laurie Johnston

title: West Side duck, swinging brasserie.
description: APPARENTLY not afraid of spreading their managerial and culinary talents too thin, the owners of the Peking Duck House in Chinatown and the Beijing Duckhouse on East 52d Street have opened a third outpost near Lincoln Center, on Amsterdam Avenue and 69th Street. Put up outside their month-old Peking Duck West are the reviews from the New York Times awarding two stars to both of the older restaurants. But based on four meals, that level has not yet been reached on the West Side.

title: THE GUEST BATONS OF SUMMER
description: SUMMER is the time when baseball managers find themselves looking to their bullpens for relief, while the fans debate whether their team has the kind of pitching to carry it into the playoffs. Much the same thing happens in the world of music.

title: I.B.M. Offers New Term Lease
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was offering a new term lease that would provide additional flexibility in the leasing of selected products and increase the lease and rental prices on most of the processors eligible for it by 8 percent.

description: A three-judge Federal court struck down part of Georgia's Congressional reapportionment plan today on the ground that district boundaries in the Atlanta area discriminated against blacks.

title: UAL DOWN 36.2%

title: CONVENTIONEERS LOOK TO THE FUTURE
description: To convene in midsummer in Washington in the hope of exchanging original ideas is risky, for visitors to this city's convention treadmill are talking and listening on the very Olympic grounds of soporific rhetoric. But Chuck Adam found a good way to warm up for his convention, the World Future Society's general assembly, even before he descended here from the Skyline Drive of the Blue Ridge Mountains.

title: DONNELLEY, R R, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: TOKYO AND GUESTS
description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival's formula of two guest soloists per concert led to a surplus of riches Tuesday night, when Emanuel Ax and Yo-Yo Ma joined the Tokyo String Quartet for a chamber program in Avery Fisher Hall. The problem, if it could be called that, was that Mr. Ma was present more as a name than a soloist, his talents being nearly wasted on one of the cello parts in Boccherini's Quintet in E.
