description: The controversy over Israeli use of American-supplied cluster weapons and reports that Israel has made such weapons have focused attention on the high level of arms shipments to the Middle East by the Soviet Union, France, West Germany, Britain, Italy, the United States and a number of smaller arms producers.

title: AMERICAN CAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ANGOLANS BARTER AS ECONOMY TOTTERS
description: At the Hotel Panorama, Luanda's best, an employee recently gave a foreign visitor some money and asked him to buy him a few packs of cigarettes at the hotel shop -an egalitarian reversal in this Marxist nation of the traditional relationship between guest and bellhop.

title: GIDDINGS & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROTOR PRODUCER IN FRANCE READY
description: Alsthom-Atlantique, a diversified French heavy engineering company, is Europe's largest manufacturer of turbines. The company - formed in 1976 by the merger of Alsthom, a producer of turbines and electric power generating equipment, with Chantiers de l'Atlantique, a big French shipbuilder - is considered to be the only company in Europe with the necessary licenses, expertise and industrial capacity to build turbines of the kind to be used in compressor stations along the new Soviet gas pipeline.

title: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POTENTIAL TROUBLE SPOTS FOR WEEKEND TRAFFIC
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street becuase of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation. B. Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive: Two lanes will be closed in either direction from the Brooklyn Bridge to the Battery. Also, the southbound ramp at Robert F. Wagner Sr. Place will be closed.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE bassist Arvel Shaw was one of those seemingly lucky people who achieve their ambition early in life and can settle down to long careers of doing exactly what they want to do. When he was growing up in St. Louis, he wanted to play bass with Louis Armstrong.

title: ABC's Profit Grows 6.7%
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday that a strong performance in television operations in the second quarter helped lift net income 6.7 percent, to $59.3 million, or $2.06 a share, from $55.6 million, or $1.96 a share, a year earlier.

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAZZ: JOHNNY HARTMAN SINGS
description: JOHNNY HARTMAN'S rich baritone voice and the emphasis he has put on the romantic aspects of his songs have made him somewhat of an anomaly in the jazz world. Even his most notable collaboration with a jazz instrumentalist, ''Lush Life'' with John Coltrane's quartet, is a straightforward interpretation that aims at color and mood rather than jazz phrasing.

title: FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $428,000 for the qr and $630,000 or the 6mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $3.3 million for the qr and $12.6 million for the 6 mos and an extraordinary credit of $292,000 for the qr and 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted to include operations of Memodyne Corp and Stevens-Arnold Inc on a pooling of interests basis

title: People
description: * Philip Cohen promoted to senior vice president at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: U.S. Seeks 9 Hitachi Employees; Warrants May Aid Extradition
description: Bench warrants were issued today by a Federal magistrate for the arrest of nine employees of Hitachi Ltd. who failed to appear today for arraignment on charges that they conspired to send stolen computer secrets to Japan.

title: 2 PAYROLL GUARDS KILLED IN A BROOKLYN ROBBERY
description: Two guards delivering a payroll were shot and killed in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon on a private Bay Ridge industrial street by gunmen who escaped with $40,000.

title: CONSUMER GROUP SEEKS BAN ON ARTHRITIC DRUG
description: A consumer group asked the Government today to ban benoxaprofen, a popular new painkiller for arthritis. It was the group's second such petition. A month ago the Health Research Group said that British doctors had associated the drug's use with 12 deaths. Today, the group revised its figures, stating that 45 deaths in Britain over the last 20 months and a recent fatality in the United States had been associated with the drug's use.

title: Marjorie Parsons, T.B. Siebens Wed
description: Marjorie Minturn Parsons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harris B. Parsons of Barrington, R.I., and Fishers Island, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Balfour Siebens, son of Mrs. Allen C. Siebens of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Siebens. The Rev. Peter Sturtevant performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island.

title: CITY'S BUCOLIC HAVENS WELCOME WEDDINGS
description: That Sunday afternoon, thunder rumbled ominously over Brooklyn, and Lillian Sullivan Hazaz brought the tables and chairs in and out of doors three times before deciding that the evening would not be wet after all. There were no showers, except for the rice that was rained on Sara Scheffer and Cornelius Hodges by their guests just after the couple exchanged marriage vows in the flower-covered gazebo of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Rose Garden. Mrs. Hazaz, special events coordinator, smiled happily.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $46 million or 74 cents a shr from the sale of oil and gas interests

title: ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net income; results for the latest 6 mos include net gain of $653,000 or 6 cents a shr, from settlements negotiated with certain defendants in an antitrust action against a number of corrugated container manufacturers

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHERE TO BUY OLD MASTER FOR $15 A PRINT
description: ONE of the more reliable elements of a New York summer is the annual old-master print exhibition at the A.A.A. Galleries, 663 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street. Quite apart from its other merits, which are many, this is one of the few places in this or any other city where you can buy a perfectly decent, well-attested and gently resonant work of older art for as little as $15.

title: RAYMOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ENSERCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bronco Decides to Play
description: Claudie Minor, an offensive lineman with the Denver Broncos who said earlier this week that he would retire, said yesterday that he plans to report to the Bronco training camp.

title: Pawnee Oil Acquisition
description: The Pawnee Oil Corporation said today that it planned to purchase Petrofrar Resources Inc., a closely held Nevada concern with oil and gas holdings in Utah and Oklahoma, for common and preferred stock valued at $3.25 million.

title: REAGAN ORDERS STUDY OF LEGAL ASPECTS OF THE U.S. PIPELINE BAN
description: President Reagan said today that he had asked the Commerce Department to study the legal obligations of Western European countries holding American licenses for the manufacture of gas-pipeline equipment sought by the Soviet Union.

title: Watchful Eyes On Earl Weaver
description: Earl Weaver's flamboyant techniques of umpire-baiting and umpiredebating have him in trouble again, but not enough trouble to suit Richie Phillips.

title: EARNINGS FALL 51.5% AT EXXON
description: The Exxon Corporation, citing sharp losses in its European markets, reduced worldwide demand for petroleum products and a continuing oversupply of oil, said yesterday that its net income in the second quarter fell 51.5 percent from a year earlier.

title: TAKE-OFF DECISIONS BELONG IN THE COCKPIT
description: To the Editor:

title: SONG: GERALDINE TURNER AT SWEETWATER'S
description: haired singer from Australia with a big voice and an interesting repertory, is making her American debut at Sweetwater's, 170 Amsterdam Avenue, where she will be appearing through July 31.

title: A Refreshing Visit To a Special Beach
description: The air smelled sweet and the Atlantic Ocean was assuringly warm yesterday at Breezy Point in Queens. Anticipation was in the wind as 11 teen-agers got down from the back of the aging school bus and headed for the beach.

title: Alfa Romeo Account Awarded to Marsteller
description: As frequently happens, Thursday brought with it - in addition to the prospect of Friday - a sudden spurt of account moves. The beneficiaries included Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, which was selected to be agency for Alfa Romeo Inc., the marketing company for the Italian car.

title: HOUSE DENIES FUNDS FOR NERVE GAS IN SETBACK TO REAGAN MILITARY BILL
description: The House of Representatives voted by a substantial margin today to halt the Reagan Administration's plan to start making a new form of chemical weapon.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD DELAYS SALE OF APARTMENTS AT $250
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday postponed approval of a proposal to sell apartments to tenants in some city-owned builidings in Manhattan for $250 each. Instead, it voted to approve the sales in principle only and not set a price until this fall.

title: TRICK USING BOGUS GUARD BILKS BANK PATRONS
description: A new kind of larceny, in which a bogus bank guard operates openly at some of the city's major banks, has cost more than two dozen New Yorkers thousands of dollars.

title: Hein I. Koolsbergen, 59, Dies;
description: U. S. Ethanol Corp. Chairman

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income of $2,153,000 for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Book and lyrics of new musical by Toni Morrison.
description: WITH Broadway musicals costing so much these days - $3 million and up - the workshop route is becoming the popular way to go. That is how ''Dreamgirls'' and ''Nine,'' the two musical hits of last season, began. The latest hopeful is ''New Orleans,'' which will have a book and lyrics by Toni Morrison, author of the best-selling novel ''Tar Baby.'' ''New Orleans'' has just begun a six-week workshop in New York, a no-frills test run before going into rehearsal for an opening in the fall.

title: COSMOS WIN ON WEGERLE GOAL, 1-0
description: Steve Wegerle put an end to an uninspired soccer game tonight, scoring his third goal of the season with four minutes left to give the Cosmos a 1-0 victory over the Toronto Blizzard before 10,856 fans at Exhibition Stadium.

title: CANADA SETS TALKS FOR JOINING AIRBUS CONSORTIUM
description: Formal negotiations are scheduled to begin here Friday between Canadian officials and a Western European aircraftmaking consortium, Airbus Industrie, on Canada's desire to join the group. For Canada, the partnership would be a major attempt to lessen the predominance of the United Sates in the country's commercial relations.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MERRIMACK BUYS WORKS FROM ARNO INVENTORY
description: Most of the inventory of scholarly and historical works published by Arno Press, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company, has been acquired by the Merrimack Book Service of Salem, N.H.

title: Jingle writer makes good.
description: in six years, he won 21 Clios, which are the Oscars of the ad industry - is trying to move from mass appeal to class appeal. He has formed a British production company called Chancery Lane Films, and shooting starts in England next week on ''Invitation to the Wedding.'' Mr. Brooks will direct. He has also written the score to be performed by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, and the St. Paul's Cathedral Boy's Choir. Sir John Gielgud and Sir Ralph Richardson will star. So will Susan Paul, who is Mrs. Brooks.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Baby Sitter Is Charged In Two of Five Deaths
description: A 19-year-old baby sitter was arrested on a murder warrant today and charged with strangling or suffocating two of the five children who died in her care over the last two and a half years.

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Official Cites Harvester Co.
description: A Federal administrative law judge has found the International Harvester Company guilty of deceptive and unfair practices because it did not tell owners of its gasolinepowered tractors of a fire hazard, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS A SAVINGS PACKAGE
description: The Senate Budget Committee today approved a package of legislative changes designed to result in savings of $12.2 billion through the fiscal year 1985.

title: TEXACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Suspicion
description: T his is a wary city, where people somehow know when someone is up to no good, even if the evidence is flimsy.

title: CAMERA SHOWS DAMAGE IN REACTOR CORE
description: A camera lowered into the reactor of the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear power station showed that the center of the reactor core was shattered, with the top of it lying in a ''bed of rubble.''

title: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 23
PITTSBURGH-DES MOINES STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCHWAB SAFE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Some Haitian Refugees Could Be Freed Friday
description: The release of more than 1,800 Haitian refugees held across the country could begin Friday, attorneys for the Government and the refugees said tonight.

description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $14,850,000 from an accounting change...D-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $57 million from an adjustment of receivable from the U.S. Government

title: Timely Writer Ready
description: Timely Writer, who was a favorite to win this year's Kentucky Derby before he was sidelined by an intestinal blockage, is scheduled to return to racing Aug. 14 in the $75,000-added Yankee Handicap at Suffolk Downs.

title: Where Eagles Go
description: If you're tired of cycling around the block, through Central Park or on some country road and want the ultimate summer challenge, there is still time to file an entry for the 18th Bob Cook Memorial Mount Evans Hill Climb in Colorado on Aug. 14.

title: BEMIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $960,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of Brown Printin

title: TEXAS ENERGIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
O'NEIL FORD, TEXAS ARCHITECT EMPHASIZED A REGIONAL STYLE
description: O'Neil Ford, a Texas-based architect known for his attempt to merge modernism with the architectural idioms of the pioneer Southwest, died Tuesday at Community Hospital in San Antonio. He was 76 years old.

title: AMERICAN BROADCASTING COS INC (ABC) reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
State Helps Defray Cost of Pipe Break
description: Governor Kean said today that he would approve payment of $200,000 to Jersey City to help defray the cost of repairing a water-main break that cut off water to residents of the city and three nearby towns for several days.

title: Rumor Sends Rates Down; Kaufman Said To Shift View
description: Interest rates declined yesterday amid talk in the credit markets that Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, revised his interest rate forecast and now expects a decline in rates instead of an increase.

title: SCHMIDT EXPECTS OTHERS TO FOLLOW FRENCH LEAD
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said today that other Western European countries would join France in defying President Reagan's sanctions against aiding the construction of the Soviet natural gas pipeline,

title: Jersey Court Bars State Rules Veto
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today ruled unconstitutional a law giving the State Legislature veto power over rules promulgated by state agencies.

title: LLOYD'S BROKERS FACE CURB ON UNDERWRITING
description: As a result of a bill approved by Parliament, Lloyd's of London will be forced to accept a separation between brokers and underwriters.

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $4,300,000 or 13 cents a shr from the sale of a Taiwan investment and the exchange of a Mallinkrodt investment; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in method of computing and accounting for unrealized foreign currency adjustments

title: SPERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest period include a gain on the sale of Sperry Gyroscope operations in the United Kingdom equal to 25 cents a shr; yr-ago figures have beenrestated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. No 52

title: Washington Post Gains
description: The Washington Post Company yesterday reported a 25.8 percent increase in net income and a 6.6 percent gain in sales for the second quarter of 1982. The company said that gains in advertising and circulation, as well as the sale of Inside Sports and The Trenton Times in late 1981, helped push net income to $16.6 million, or $1.17 a share, from $13.2 million, or 94 cents a share, for the similar period a year earlier. Sales rose to $207.2 million from $194.3 million in the corresponding quarter of 1981.

title: AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUELLER, PAUL, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DURABLES ORDERS OFF 1.6% IN JUNE
description: The Commerce Department reported today that orders for machinery, furniture and other durable goods fell 1.6 percent in June.

title: The Imperfect Politics of Less
description: The New York State and City legislatures, with some help from the courts and Justice Department, have adjusted electoral districts to a painful decline in population. Although critics have been loudly finding fault with the new maps, the reapportionment worked as intended - by imperfect compromise of conflicting objectives.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PLATINUM AND SILVER REGISTER SIZABLE GAIN
description: Precious metals futures advanced yesterday, with platinum and silver contracts posting larger gains than gold. Although the three metals all responded to the easing of interest rates, traders favored platinum and silver over gold, brokers said, because those two metals have declined in price far more than gold in recent months.

title: CROSS, A T, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock divd distributedin June 3, 1982

title: RSC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: B-Including gains of $240,000 or 8 cents for the latest qr and 6 mos and $144,000 or 6 cents for the yr-ago 6 mos on the sale of property; figures for the latest periods include the results of Valpey-Fisher Corp from the date of acquisition on Jan 1

title: Antitrust Move On Pabst Set
description: The Justice Department said today that it was prepared to file a court challenge to the proposed takeover of the Pabst Brewing Company of Milwaukee by a Minneapolis businessman, Irwin L. Jacobs.

title: DRAVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Somali Insurgents Say They Moved on 4 Towns
description: Somali rebels said today that their forces had advanced on the settlements of Belet Huen, Galcaio, Durukhsi and Dusa Mareb along a 500-mile front of the Somali-Ethiopian border and that they were consolidating the positions they won in three weeks of fighting.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
P.L.O.'S CASUALITIES IN RAIDS PUT AT 62
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization press agency Wafa said today that 62 people were killed or wounded in a 90-minute Israeli air strike against Palestinian positions in west Beirut.

title: PENN SQUARE: THE RESIDUE
description: James P. Hudson's job involves sitting at another man's desk, being surrounded by the other man's choices in western art (all tagged for identification) and even being waited on by the other man's personal staff. There is an inevitable sense of displacement, reflecting the temporary nature of his task.

title: MARK PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $22 million from the sale of tax credits

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Roz T. Collins Seeks Trot First
description: Mystic Park and Incredible Nevele are expected to overpower the 19-horse field in the $415,160 Yonkers Trot Saturday night, but George Forshey is gambling $25,000 of someone else's money that his colt, Roz T. Collins, can beat both of them.

title: Briefs on the Arts Florida Philharmonic Dissolved in Labor Dispute
description: The 18-year-old Florida Philarmonic, based in Miami, will disband because of a musicians' strike that has lasted for four months. The orchestra's board voted to dissolve the orchestra after 17 months of negotiations.

title: Iraqi Helicopters Attack Iranian Positions
description: Iraqi helicopter gunships scored direct hits today on Iranian positions east of the southern city of Basra, the official Iraqi press agency said.

title: DAY CAMPS TAP RESOURCES OF CITY TO LIVEN SUMMER
description: Wearing shorts and T-shirts and carrying small knapsacks and towels, ''the Fives'' were on their way to a swimming lesson in the basement of 5 West 93d Street. They were holding hands in pairs and giggling a lot, oblivious to the men in gray suits with briefcases who hurried past them on the sidewalk.

title: American Asks Moscow To Release Her Husband
description: The American wife of a Soviet hunger striker appealed to the Communist Party and the Soviet Parliament today to allow her husband to leave the country.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Christo Wins Approval For Biscayne Bay Project

title: STYLE LIKENED TO CHARLIE PARKER'S
description: Sonny Stitt, the alto saxophonist who was regarded by Charlie Parker as the inheritor of Mr. Parker's style and stature in jazz, died of cancer Thursday night at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 58 years old.

title: SALVADOR LAND AGENCY'S PRESIDENT ASSERTS IT IS MARRED BY CORRUPTION
description: The newly appointed president of the country's principal land redistribution agency has charged that the agency has been marred by corruption and mismanagement.

title: YELLOWSTONE OFFICIALS WORRY ABOUT OIL LEASES
description: Officials at Yellowstone Park are apprehensive about recent leases for oil and gas exploration that cover 25,000 acres at the doorstep of the park's western boundary. They fear damage to Yellowstone's wilderness, particularly its grizzly bears.

title: BANKERS ASSAIL 10% WITHHOLDING TAX ON INTEREST
description: Representatives of the banking and thrift industries, which will have to do the paperwork, reacted adversely to the Senate's passage yesterday of a tax bill that includes a provision for a 10 percent tax withholding on dividends and interest.

title: Sports People; Not Fading Away
description: John McNamara, who was dismissed as manager by the Cincinnati Reds earlier in the week, said yesterday he had no intention of forgetting baseball.

title: Players; PETTY STILL REIGNING AS KING OF THE ROAD
description: I n his time, the great racing driver has cut hairpin turns, crashed into pileups and walls and been carted off on a parade of stretchers. No problem. But now?

title: LEBANESE VALLEY QUIET AFTER A DAY OF FIGHTING
description: Quiet returned today to the Bekaa Valley of Lebanon after a day of fighting Thursday that broke the cease-fire that had held since June 25.

title: COPTER FALLS, KILLING ACTOR AND 2 CHILDREN ON SET
description: Vic Morrow and two Vietnamese children the actor was holding in his arms were killed early today when a helicopter crashed while they were making a movie northwest of Los Angeles.

title: Field Seeks Buyer For 5 TV Stations
description: The Field Communications Corporation, a subsidiary of the privately held Field Enterprises of Chicago, said that its five independent television stations are for sale, and that negotiations with ''interested parties'' have begun.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times Sly, Feisty Oriole By JOSEPH DURSO IT'S WHAT YOU LEARN AFTER YOU KNOW IT ALL THAT COUNTS. By Earl Weaver, with Berry Stainback. 300 pages. Doubleday. $14.95.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $100 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply declined by $100 million in the latest reporting week - a smaller-than-expected drop that disappointed many traders but was not alarming to economists. Interest rates rose slightly after the late-afternoon announcement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For those who believed that recent price performance indicated that inflation was down for the count, June's figures are particularly disappointing.'' - Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner, Bureau of Labor Statistics. (37:5.)

title: Lions Kill Swede
description: A man identified only as a 42-year-old Stockholm resident wandered outside his car in a wild animal preserve today and was killed by three lions, the police said.

title: A Suspect Is Arrested In Times Sq. Hit-Run
description: A 21-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with driving a stolen car that hit and seriously injured four persons in Times Square Wednesday, the police said.

title: Japan Plans to Increase Its Purchases of Arms
description: The Japanese Cabinet announced today a new fiveyear plan for arms purchases in the next five years that is higher than current spending but appears unlikely to satisfy the United States.

title: Hussein and Pym Hold Talks
description: King Hussein of Jordan held talks with the British Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, today during a private visit to London. A Foreign Office spokesman said they discussed the conflict in Lebanon and the war between Iran and Iraq but provided no details of the meeting.

title: WEICKER AND BUSH BATTLING TO WIRE
description: The intense fight for the United States Senate between Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Prescott Bush Jr., which has strained Republican loyalties and drawn $1 million in contributions to each candidate, neared a showdown tonight as delegates gathered at the Hartford Civic Center to open the party's state convention.

title: Auxiliary Policeman Is Held in Slaying of 2
description: An auxiliary policeman shot and killed a friend and her daughter yesterday during an argument in the victims' apartment in Queens, the police reported.

title: MODERNIZING OF 4 HOSPITALS IN CITY IS DELAYED BY A STATE COST SQUEEZE
description: Four of New York City's largest and most prestigious private nonprofit hospitals are asking the state this year to approve renovation costs of more than $1.5 billion for buildings they say are obsolete after decades of neglect.

title: Guilford Buy-Out Contested in Suit
description: Guilford Mills Inc., a fabric company based in Greensboro, N.C., said that a shareholder, Harry Lewis, had filed suit to enjoin the proposed sale of the company's assets to some members of its management for $23 a share.

title: Ziff Sale Accord
description: The Ziff Corporation, a diversified media corporation based in New York, said that it had reached preliminary agreement to sell four of its six television stations for about $60 million to a partnership that includes I. Martin Pompadur, the company's president. The four stations are in Augusta, Ga.; Saginaw, Mich.; Rochester, and in Steubenville, Ohio. Ziff, which is privately held, said that it had decided last year to sell its television stations and expand its magazine operations, which are its main business.

title: PANEL DEBATES TAMPON LABELS
description: A Federal Food and Drug Administration decision giving tampon manufacturers six months to comply with mandatory labeling requirements was a major concern at a recent Congressional hearing.

title: SPOILING SUCCESS
description: It's time that someone in the know blew the whistle on what's going on in America's international information programs - and time for responsible and sophisticated members of Congress to exert their good judgment.

title: News Analysis
description: The climate of public amiability that prevailed between Washington and Paris for most of the last year seemed to collapse spectacularly Thursday with France's decision to defy the United States ban on sales of gas pipeline equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: STRICT NEW RULES ON JUVENILE CRIME ADOPTED IN NEW JERSEY
description: A package of bills designed to deal more strictly with violent juvenile offenders and allow the monitoring of their home life was signed into law today by Governor Kean.

title: BRIEFING
description: Friendship Wins Out

title: French Spending Plan
description: The Industry Ministry has announced the way in which the 9.91 billion francs earmarked for French nationalized industries this year will be allocated. It said 2.4 billion francs would go to the steel sector, another 2.4 billion to Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann S.A., 1.26 billion to Rhone-Poulenc S.A., 400 million to Cie Saint-Gobain S.A., 850 million to Cie Generale d'Electricite S.A., 600 million to Thomson-Brandt S.A., 850 million to CII-Honeywell Bull S.A., 600 million to CDF-Chimie S.A. and 200 million to Enterprise Miniere et Chimique S.A. The French franc is worth slightly less than 15 cents in United States money.

title: Europeans Angered On Steel
description: The European Economic Community reacted angrily today to the Reagan Administration's rejection of a proposal to resolve a dispute over price levels of European steel exports to the United States.

title: UNDERFOOT, NEW YORK BEATS PARIS
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTERN AIR HAS PROFIT
description: Western Airlines Inc., which said last December that it would become profitable by this year's third quarter, today reported second-quarter net earnings of $3.1 million, or 18 cents a share, for the period ending June 30. The earnings, on revenues of $257.6 million, contrasted with a net loss of $8.4 million on revenues of $270 million in the second quarter of 1981.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Drums Along the Potomac

title:
Patents;
Circuit Coatings
description: A method of replenishing gold and coatings for such purposes as microelectronic circuitry has been devised for Bell Laboratories.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JULY 24, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose 1 percent in June, keeping the annual inflation rate at a double-digit level for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported. As in May, the increase in the Consumer Price Index resulted from a sharp rise in gasoline prices combined with higher food costs and a baffling rise in housing prices. Medical costs were also higher. Despite the two-month surge, however, the inflation rate is down from the levels of 1979 and 1980: In the past 12 months, the index has risen just 7.1 percent. Most economists predict it will be about 6 percent for the year. (Page 1.) Prices in the New York area rose 1.7 percent. (37.)

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Agronomics Corp. of Tampa, Fla., said it had agreed to sell its Precision Plastics Corp. subsidiary to American Hospital Supply Corp. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: TORRENTIAL RAINS KILL 63 IN JAPAN
description: At least 63 people were killed Friday in floods and landslides caused by torrential rains in southern Nagasaki, the police said.

title: POLICE SAY THEY KNOW 3 IN PAYROLL GUARDS' MURDER
description: The police said yesterday that they knew the identities of three men suspected of killing two guards during a $40,000 payroll robbery Thursday in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Canada Protests to Israel
description: Canada has protested formally to Israel over treatment of the Canadian Ambassador in Beirut. External Affairs Minister Mark MacGuigan said that the official Canadian residence had been hit twice by Israeli shells and that Ambassador Theodore Arcand's car was searched repeatedly this week by Israelis when he crossed from east to west Beirut.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: 3-D Films on TV Bring Run on Stock of Glasses

title: Forest Fires Burning In Three Western States
description: By United Press International Vast fires, sparked by lightning and human carelessness, ranged over 30,000 acres of timber and brush yesterday in California, Nevada and Utah.

title: DANCE: D.J. McDONALD PRESENTS HIS GROUP
description: D.J. McDonald has the look of a performer with minimal or late formal dance training, and his dances, presented Thursday by D.J. McDonald and Dancers at the White Dog Studio, suffer from a corresponding lack of intimacy with movement.

title: FAIR AND VITAL PROTECTION FOR AIRLINE LABOR
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE IN GRAND MARAIS: TO BE WILED BY THE CALL OF THE WILD
description: The other day, a large cow moose ambled out to the side of the Gunflint Trail, which runs north out of this Lake Superior community, and began to munch on the tender green leaves of young birch trees.

title: No Headline
description: A caption in a photo layout in yesterday's Metropolitan Report incorrectly stated Mikhail Baryshnikov's affiliation with the School of American Ballet. He occasionally studies with a teacher at the school.

title: DRUG STOCKS FALL
description: Drug stocks took a drubbing yesterday after the Senate passed a tax bill that included an amendment that would reduce the large tax advantages for pharmaceutical companies operating in Puerto Rico. Over all, the market closed slightly down in fairly light trading.

title: A WASTE OF COLLEGE
description: It has been said that test scores indicate that the intellectual level of our students has fallen in recent years. Having taught introductory chemistry for 13 years I can testify that this is not so. Young people today are fully as smart, as able to comprehend the wealth of human experience and understanding that we at the university have to teach them, as we were in our time. What I do perceive is an excessive professionalism directed toward entry into the traditional professions of medicine and the other health sciences and the law and toward the newer profession, engineering. I and my colleagues see this early professional tendency among our best and brightest students.

title: OF FISH AND MEN AND THE FATE OF THE WESTWAY PROJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. AIDE KILLED IN PARIS BOMBING
description: A Palestinian guerrilla leader was killed here today when three men tossed a bomb into his car as he was leaving for work.

title: CONSUMERS' PRICES UP BY 1% IN JUNE FOR SECOND MONTH
description: Consumer prices surged by 1 percent in June, the Labor Department reported today, keeping the annual inflation rate at double-digit levels for the second consecutive month.

title: A TAX INCREASE OF $99 BILLION VOTED IN SENATE
description: At the end of an all-night session that frayed tempers, the Senate early today passed the largest revenueraising bill ever approved by either house of Congress.

title: PROVISIONS OF THE SENATE'S TAX BILL
description: Following are the major provisions of the tax increases contained in the bill passed early this morning by the Senate:

title: TIMBER CONCERN'S NET SLIDES
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the world's largest timber products concern, said yesterday that the housing slump caused net income in the second quarter to plunge 65.2 percent, while sales fell 7.6 percent.

title: ELDERLY ATTACK PROPOSED RULES ON HEALTH CARE
description: The Government's proposals to eliminate some inspection rules for nursing homes drew sharp criticism yesterday from a group of nursinghome residents and health-care professionals.

title: WESTWAY MASTER GETS JUDGE'S ORDERS
description: A Federal judge yesterday appointed a New York lawyer, Lewis A. Kaplan, as a special master to monitor compliance with the judge's orders requiring new environmental reports for the Westway project.

title: POLITICAL SHIFT ILLUSTRATED BY MODERATES' DEPARTURE
description: In recent weeks, the three officials generally regarded as the most moderate voices in the National Security Council have left Government, each a man with impressive military credentials.

title: CITY CRITICIZED ON ENFORCING SOME AIR POLLUTION CONTROLS
description: The progress that New York City has made in curbing air pollution is being jeopardized by its failure to enforce pollution controls over thousands of oil burners, incinerators and factories, according to a General Accounting Office report.

title: Santa Fe Purchase
description: The Santa Fe International Corporation, a division of the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, said that it had signed an agreement to acquire the Andover Oil Company of Tulsa, Okla. for $150 million in cash. Andover is a closely held oil and gas exploration company with annual revenues of $78 million. Completion of the merger is subject to approval by Andover shareholders and regulatory authorities, Santa Fe said.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Coffee, Coast Style

title: Bridge: New York Team Defeated In Grand National Teams
description: Hopes of victory in the Grand National Team Championship ended here last night for a strong New York team. The team - Al Roth, Neil Silverman, Joel Friedberg, Brian Glubok and Ethan Stein - lost by 31 international match points to a Michigan quintet.

title: Martinique Frees American
description: A Virginia businessman convicted in 1980 of trying to smuggle cocaine through Martinique has been released after almost three years in prison there. William S. Smith Jr., 36 years old, was released June 29 and expelled from the French island the next day, the State Department said today.

title: Many Poles Defected On Trip to World Cup
description: About half the 819 Poles who went to Spain for the World Cup soccer championship stayed abroad, and some even fled en route, the weekly Communist Party newspaper Polityka said today.

title: About New York; FOND MEMORIES OF LIFE BEFORE THE AIR-CONDITIONER
description: Once upon a time, there was an enormous city that had a baseball team called the Dodgers, a Mayor named La Guardia and almost no airconditioning. People accepted the fact that there was a force larger than they, whether divine or meteorologic, that decreed that summer should be warm and that certain parts of July should be unbearable. It was a hot time in the old town, but that was the way it was.

title: Scouting; 100-Ring Circus
description: As Ray (Boom-Boom) Mancini went through the final preparations yesterday for his World Boxing Association lightweight title defense against Ernesto Espana today, there was one rather important element missing: a boxing ring.

title: WATT WARNS ISRAELI JEWS' ENERGY STANCE COULD ALTER SUPPORT
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt warned the Israeli Ambassador to the United States last month that American support for Israel could be undermined if ''liberals of the Jewish commmunity join with the other liberals of this nation'' in an effort to block the Reagan's Administration's effort to speed the development of energy resources.

title: WORKERS TO TRY CUTTING BOOM INTO PIECES TODAY
description: Experts finally decided yesterday to remove the tip of a construction boom that is lashed to the side of a new Manhattan skyscraper by cutting it into pieces and hauling them in through the windows, the Department of Buildings said. Work will begin at 7 A.M. today.

title: Why Push Plutonium?
description: The magic promise of breeder reactors has evaporated. People once expected that they would make plutonium out of inert uranium and that by the year 2000 such fuel would be needed for a thousand power reactors. But in the 40 months since the Three Mile Island accident, not a single new nuclear power reactor has been ordered in the United States. Work on 38 others has been abandoned. Uranium is in surplus, at a reasonable price.

title: McLouth Receives Offer for Assets
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation, reorganizing under Federal bankruptcy laws, said without elaboration that it had received a conditional proposal from Tang Industries for the acquisition of most of its assets.

title: A Public Bath in the Powder Basin
description: Interior Secretary Watt is in a great hurry to develop mineral resources. This week he announced a final plan to lease a billion acres of offshore lands -almost the entire coastline - to drillers for oil and gas. But this pace of development won't bring the public the best price, not if Mr. Watt's last marathon sale is a guide. Last April he hailed as ''resoundingly successful by any measure'' the sale of leases to Federal coal in the Powder River Basin of Montana and Wyoming. But a House hearing last week shows that where he claimed much credit, the public took a bath.

title: New York Day by Day
description: History Makes Itself Seen

title: RESTAURANTEURS CRITICIZE CUT IN MEAL DEDUCTIONS
description: Restaurateurs, hotel executives and credit-card sponsors were sharply critical yesterday of the Senate's approval of a tax provision that would halve deductions on business meals and entertainment.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bedlwether issues

title: MOBIL'S CONTRIBUTION TO THE 'CLEAN TEAM'
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC NEWS DEFENDS 'OIL GAME' DOCUMENTARY
description: George Watson, an ABC News vice president, has defended the accuracy and fairness of the network's documentary ''The Oil Game,'' broadcast June 20. The Mobil Oil Corporation had objected to what it called ''prejudicial inaccuracies'' on the program.

title: JOANNE CARNER IN LEAD
description: JoAnne Carner retained her putting touch and her lead today in the 37th United States Women's Open golf championship. Helped by two long par-saving putts and six birdie putts, she shot a two-under-par 70. Her 36-hole total of 139 was five shots under par and three ahead of Beth Daniel, who shot her second 71.

title: U.S. AGENCY ADMITS MEETING ON A LAND DEAL IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: The head of the General Services Administration disclosed today that he had met with a lawyer for the Marriott hotel chain, which is a big Republican campaign contributor, before ordering the speedy sale of Federal land to the city of San Francisco for use by Marriott.

title: LANDMARK HARDSHIP PLEA BACKED
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission has ruled that a recent decision making the former Mount Neboh Synagogue a landmark is preventing the present owners from receiving a reasonable return on their investment.

title: Index; International
description: Salvadoran land agency is as- sailed by its president 2 Poland frees more prisoners and reopens foreign phone lines 3 Spain decides to buy 84 F-18A fighter-bombers from U.S. 3 Bekaa Valley residents undis- turbed by Israelis 4 Bombing in Paris kills P.L.O. aide 4 Around the World 5 Government/Politics U.S. agency chief admits meet- ing on Coast land agreement 7 U.S. lists 45 more hazardous waste sites for cleanup action 8 Weicker and Bush battle to wire in Connecticut G.O.P. contest 25 A special master will monitor compliance in Westway case 27 State G.O.P. chief endorses Lehr- man for Governor 27 Washington Talk Briefing 7 Leslie H. Gelb on Haig, Inman and Jones departures 7 General Around the Nation 6 In Houston, a woman turns broken dream into a fortune 6 Drilling leases worry Yellow- stone Park officials 13 Corona denies exonerating his half brother 24 Day camps in the city are numer- ous and diverse 25 Rally held against U.S. proposals on nursing home inspections 26 Removal of the dangling crane on Madison Avenue begins today 27 Police say the identities of killers in Brooklyn robbery are known 27 Landmark ruling on former syna- gogue is eased 27 Los Angeles sues street gangs in bid to revove graffiti 28 Arts/Entertainment Theodore White finds book promotion demeaning 9 Frankie Armstsrong sings folk program 9 D.J. McDonald presents his dance group 10 ''Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' on screen 11 Memoir by Earl Weaver, man- ager of the Orioles, reviewed 13 ABC News defends ''Oil Game'' documentary 45 Style Consumer Saturday: Finding creme fraiche 46 Panel debates tampon labels 46 De Gustibus: Dining dollars and cents 46 Dior men's wear, set to music 46 Obituaries Sonny Stitt, saxophonist likened to Charlie Parker 28 Vic Morrow, TV actor 29 Sports Pages Mumphrey and Winfield lead Yanks past Angels, 6-3 31 Kotar of Giants ready to an- nounce retirement 31 JoAnne Carner has 139 for 3-stroke lead in U.S. Women's Open 31 Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini brings title defense home to Ohio 31 Mets lose to Padres, 11-4 32 Scouting: a pitcher's road back from tragedy 32 Players: Richard Petty still king of the road 32 Gerald Eskenazi on Richard Todd of the Jets 33 N.F.L. players union threatens job action 33 Features/Notes Issue and Debate: Has El Salva- dor made progress on rights 2 Going Out Guide 11 Saturday News Quiz 12 New York Day by Day 26 About New York 27 Sports People 33 News Analysis Hedrick Smith on pipeline dis- pute with the allies 5 Richard Eder on U.S.-European tensions 5 Michael deCourcy Hinds on U.S. regulations 8 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Gertrude R.B. Williams, 81; A Brooklyn Poet and Author
description: Gertrude Ryder Bennett Williams, a poet and author who published poetry for many years under the name Gertrude Ryder Bennett, died July 14 at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Inspector Had Suggested 'Risk' Warning on Dam
description: A state inspector said nearly two years ago that Lawn Lake Dam should be reclassified as a ''high risk,'' but his recommendation still had not been acted upon when the dam burst last week, killing four people, officials said Thursday.

title: THE BOTTOM DOLLAR
description: Washington types are always talking about the recession bottoming out. The Secretary of the Treasury, Donald Regan, told an interviewer a couple of months ago that he looked for the recession to bottom out in the very near future.

title: Your Money; Bond Portfolio Insurance
description: THE renewed interest in municipal bonds is evident in many areas of this market, including unit trusts and mutual funds, which have great appeal to the small investor, whose tax burden may not be so small.

title: Sports People; Disputed Call
description: A letter sent to umpires early this month by President Charles Feeney of the National League asking them to improve their work during the season's second half has led to criticism from a variety of sources. Feeney said in the letter that he had received more complaints from club officials this year than at any other time since he became league president in 1970.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in some copies of the New York Day by Day column yesterday about lighting at the Citicorp Center, and a related picture caption on page A1, gave the building's address incor- rectly. It is 153 East 53d Street.

title: ISRAELIS STRIKE WEST BEIRUT AGAIN FOLLOWING P.L.O. RAIDS IN SOUTH
description: Israeli planes and artillery attached Palestinian neighborhoods in west Beirut today for the second straight day after Palestinian guerrilla raids behind Israeli lines in southern Lebanon.

title: JUDGE IN LOS ANGELES ORDERS STREET GANGS TO ERASE GRAFFITI
description: A Superior Court judge, in a novel use of California's nuisance abatement law, issued a temporary restraining order today forcing about 80 members of three street gangs to remove graffiti from walls and store fronts.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES FALL 20.8%
description: New car sales by the Big Three auto makers in the mid-July selling period tumbled 20.8 percent from a year earlier, to an average selling rate of 15,971 cars per day. Of the five domestic auto makers, only Chrysler reported a sales increase.

title: CONSERVATIVES ADDED TO ROSTER OF FEDERAL CHARITIES
description: The advisory panel of the $87 million Federal employees' charity fund voted today to include such conservative groups as the Right to Life and Right to Work movements as recipients and sought to exclude the Planned Parenthood movement. The action immediately aroused an intense political controversy.

title:
Patents;
Noncompressible Fluid Pumps Electric Motor
description: A New York inventor who has worked for years toward deriving power from passing traffic was granted his third American patent on the subject this week.

title: BEHIND DEPARTURE OF WEIDENBAUM
description: One day after the surprise disclosure of his resignation as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum sounded a somewhat discordant note about Reagan Administration economic policy.

title: Scouting; A Job Well Done
description: The United States national soccer team didn't make it to the World Cup finals in Spain, but an American-born referee did, and he made quite a distinguished debut. David Socha of Ludlow, Mass., served as referee for the Scotland-New Zealand game in the first round, becoming only the second American referee to work a World Cup game.

title: AFGHAN TALKS HELD BY U.S. AND SOVIET
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have just concluded an unpublicized round of talks in Moscow on the possibility of a political solution in Afghanistan, Administration officials said today.

title: PIONEER IN NEW YORK SCHOOL
description: Betty Parsons, the adventurous New York art dealer whose midtown gallery played a major role in the development of the New York School of painting in the late 40's and early 50's, died of a stroke yesterday in her studio in Southold, L.I. She was 82 years old.

title: MORTON'S TAKEOVER STRATEGY
description: ''When it rains it pours.'' With that slogan, Morton-Norwich worked its way into the American consciousness. But the company, now a pint-sized conglomerate in the process of acquiring the Thiokol Corporation, has found in recent months that the maxim applies to more than its popular table salt.

title: HOUSTON SINGS PRAISES OF RESTAURATEUR WHO COOKS WITH LOVE
description: ''We always said we were cooking with love,'' said Ninfa Laurenzo, taking a sip of an icy, pale green margarita - or ''Ninfarita,'' as it is known at her restaurants. ''It was so beautiful, and we always said that. But we weren't really; we were cooking to survive and the main thing was to stay alive, and we were staying alive, so I'd say to the kids, 'Cook with love!' and that is the way we did it, to survive.''

title: SYRIAN CALLS ON U.S. TO END ISRAELI PRESENCE IN LEBANON
description: President Hafez al-Assad called on the United States today to resolve the ''major problem'' in Lebanon, how to end Israeli occupation, rather than concentrate on the evacuation of the Palestinians from West Beirut.

title: Nicaraguan Troops Said to Kill 96 Rebels
description: Nicaraguan troops killed 96 right-wing guerrillas in two weeks of fighting in the northeastern part of the country, the deputy army commander, Ramon Macis, said today.

title: Sports People; Colts Drop Landry
description: Greg Landry, a 14-year National Football League veteran who has been Baltimore's backup quarterback for the last two seasons, was released yesterday. The Colts gave no reason for dropping Landry, who threw almost 2,300 passes during his pro career, but only 76 in his last two years with Baltimore. ... Ray (Sugar Bear) Hamilton, the nose tackle of the New England Patriots for the past nine years, is retiring to go into his own printing business.

title: 2-Day Wait Expected On Polish Phone Calls
description: People in the United States wishing to call friends or relatives in Poland could anticipate, as of Friday night, a wait of two days to get through.

title: Saturday Sports
description: Baseball Baseball: Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 161st Street and River Avenue, Bronx. (Television - Channel 11, Radio, WABC, 770 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres at San Diego. (Television - Channel 9, 10 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570 10 P.M. Cardinals vs. Astros at St. Louis. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Boxing Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, champion, vs. Ernesto Espana for the World Boxing Association lightweight title, 15 rounds, Warren, Ohio. This is Mancini's first defense since taking the title from Art Frias. Mancini is 23-1 with 18 knockouts; Espana is 36-4. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Kid Gloves Tournament, third week of competition sponsored by Madison Square Garden for youngsters aged 10-15, at Brighton Beach Baths, 3205 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, 1 P.M. Admission is free.

title: Giants' Kotar Expected to Retire Today
description: Minutes after the Giants opened training camp today, Doug Kotar, their starting halfback for most of his seven-year pro football career, in effect retired. He will probably make it official Saturday.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Ups and Downs on Lex

title: Sports People; Impasse on Hipple
description: Russ Thomas, the general manager of the Detroit Lions, said that negotiations concerning a contract extension and bonus for Eric Hipple, the team's quarterback, have collapsed. As a result, Hipple, who advanced from third string to starter last year, is only in line for a 1982 salary of $60,000 in keeping with the three-year contract he signed as a rookie.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Mrs. Conlin, the Democratic nominee for Governor of Iowa, had campaigned against tax shelters. She came under heavy criticism after disclosing that she and her husband were millionaires who paid no state income tax for 1981, in part because they took advantage of such shelters.

title:
Patents;
Voice-Operated Heating
description: A Japanese electric company received four United States patents this week on voice-operated heating apparatus. Shigaki Ueda and several associates are the inventors named in patents 4,340,797 through 4,340,800, assigned to the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Cross-Cultural Baseball

title: Berkshire to Raise Cliffs Iron Stake
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., a diversified company with interests in insurance and textile manufacturing, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it may increase its stake in the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company, a mining concern, to 30 percent from 9.7 percent over the next 15 years.

title: Houston Area Reports 7.1% Unemployment
description: Buffeted by a downturn in the petroleum industry and the effects of the national recession, the once radiant economy of the six-county Houston area today reported its highest unemployment level since the present statistical base was adopted in 1974. The Texas Employment Commission said the jobless rate for June was 7.1 percent.

title: T.V.A. Directors Urged To Scrap Four Reactors
description: Officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority urged the utility's directors today to scrap four unfinished reactors that have already cost $1.85 billion.

title: Armco Payout Cut
description: Armco Inc., the nation's sixth-largest steelmaker, said that it had cut its quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share from 45 cents, payable Sept. 7 to holders of record Aug. 6. Armco, which earlier this week announced a loss of $57.4 million for the second quarter, said it had cut the dividend to conserve cash. The company said it was beginning a cost-reduction program.

title: 3 Rightists Joining Begin's Bloc
description: Techiya, the extreme right-wing party in Parliament, signed an agreement in Jerusalem today to join Prime Minister Menachem Begin's governing coalition.

title: PRINCETON SOPHOMORE WAS 19
description: Scott Meese, the 19-year-old son of Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, was killed shortly before midnight Thursday when his car swerved off a highway and struck a tree, the Park Police said today.

title: NEW YORK PRICES UP FOR 2D STRAIGHT MONTH
description: Consumer prices increased 1.7 percent in New York and northeastern New Jersey in June, rising even more steeply than in May and underscoring an end to a seven-month period of negligible inflation for the area, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: HOW THEODORE WHITE MAKES A BEST-SELLER
description: ''What you're trying to do is the hootchy-kootchy to get them into the tent,'' said Theodore H. White, describing the circuslike act that some authors go through during a radio-television tour to promote their books. ''It's demeaning and degrading. You have to strip yourself threadbare like a piece of fabric. But it's necessary because we are living through a period of cultural discontinuity in the United States - look at the arcades with Atari guns and the 'E.T.' mores.''

title: Du Pont Delaying Salary Increases
description: The E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it would delay salary increases another three months, beginning in August, for management and professional employees.

title: Dome Salary Cuts
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said that it would reduce the salaries of 4,200 employees by 10 percent on Sept. 1.

title: LEHRMAN WINS BACKING OF G.O.P.'S STATE LEADER
description: The New York State Republican chairman abandoned his neutrality yesterday and endorsed Lewis E. Lehrman for the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: CONNECTICUT G.O.P. DELEGATES CONVENE
description: Connecticut Republicans began their convention here tonight to pick nominees for Governor and United States Senator, amid bunting, balloons and bitter words.

title: Zimbabwe Extends Its Emergency Powers
description: Zimbabwe formally extended its state of emergency by six months today and introduced new laws shielding Government leaders, security forces and civil servants from criminal or civil prosecutions.

title: Hitachi Spurning U.S. Warrants
description: Hitachi Ltd., the Japanese electronics company, said that nine of its employees, charged with trying to steal industrial secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation, would not appear in court despite arrest warrants issued by a judge in California.

title: MANCINI GOES HOME TO FIGHT
description: Ray Mancini, the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, was more than a half-hour late for the ''Rally 'Round Boom Boom'' in his honor. But the crowd waited cheerfully at Mollenkopf Field, the 14,000-seat football stadium behind Warren G. Harding High School (''Panthers: State Champions 1971 and 1974'').

title: Stop the Flight From Social Security
description: While politicians struggle to keep Social Security afloat, a good many passengers are trying to abandon ship. Since Alaska took its employees out of the system two years ago, more than a thousand nonprofit employers have filed the required two-year notice of withdrawal.

title: YANKEES FINALLY OVERCOME ZAHN
description: The 50,314 fans at Yankee Stadium last night got what they came for: a home run by the Angels' Reggie Jackson and a 6-3 victory by the Yankees that moved them into fourth place in the American League's Eastern Division.

title: OF FISH AND MEN AND THE FATE OF THE WESTWAY PROJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Saturday; FINDING CREME FRAICHE
description: NEW York cooks in search of creme fraiche that tastes like the cremef raiche they had in France will have to settle for a reasonable f acsimile, but they now have many options from which to choose. Two i mports and one American-made version are now available, and several s hops are making their own and offering it for as little as $3.89 anda s much as $12 for 16 ounces.

title: Even London Has No Better Cabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: DETROIT (AL) - Placed Milt Wil- cox, pitcher, on 21-day disabled list; called up Dave Gumpert, relief pitcher, from Evansville of the American Association. TORONTO (AL) - Called up Dave Gei- sel, pitcher, from Syracuse of the Interna- tional League; sent Mark Bomback, pitch- er, to Syracuse.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of Canada Ltd. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an issue of $100 million of notes, due in 1992, to be offered through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: CORONA DENIES EXONERATING HIS HALF BROTHER
description: Juan V. Corona told the jury at his retrial for murder today that he could not recall telling a reporter that his half brother, Natividad, could not have murdered the 25 farm workers that Juan Corona is accused of killing in 1971.

title: Valtec Sued By Corning
description: The Corning Glass Works filed suit yesterday against the Valtec Corporation charging infringement of four Corning patents related to fiber-optic waveguide products and manufacturing processes.

title:
Patents;
Building A Station In Space
description: WASHINGTON THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration is ready to build a permanent space station when one is authorized. Key elements for its construction were patented this week for the agency.

title: BEIRUT'S SMELL OF DEATH
description: Armenian scholars no longer search for God in the Near East School of Theology in west Beirut. The cool archives room in the cellar is now a blood bank, and the conference hall where ecclesiastical nuances were once the topic of discussion now contains two operating tables for assembly-line amputations and a bin for severed limbs.

title: POLES FREE MORE DETAINEES AND OPEN TELEPHONE LINKS
description: The Polish authorities freed more political prisoners today and reopened international telephone lines to the public in a further relaxation of martial law.

title: AMERICAN OFFICIALS SEE POSSIBILITY OF U.S.-P.L.O. CONTACTS IN BEIRUT
description: Administration officials said today that they would probably authorize American officials to have direct contacts with the P.L.O. in the event that American peacekeeping forces were sent to Beirut and an emergency arose affecting the troops' security.

title: De Gustibus; DINING DOLLARS AND CENTS
description: As prices in restaurants climb ever higher, it might be reasonable to assume that customers will be served more and better food, but the very opposite might often be the case. Food is one of the few flexible cost factors that can be lowered to help owners offset skyrocketing fixed expenses, such as rent, utilities, equipment, wages and maintenance.

title: GET THE NET OUT OF THE CLOSET
description: President Reagan is still spreading his gospel of ''voluntarism'' around the country. And it's a laudable philosophy - the idea that the Federal Government will go broke if it alone has to take care of the needy and that private groups must therefore assume more responsibility.

title: China's Centenarians Get Some Recognition
description: There are at least nine people over 100 living in Peking, seven of them women, but the exact number must await the results of China's current census, the New China News Agency said today.

title: METS MAKE 4 ERRORS, LOSE TO PADRES, 11-4
description: The Mets fell apart tonight in as many phases as there are in a baseball game. Four pitchers, starting with the rookie Brent Gaff, allowed 15 hits in an 11-4 loss to the San Diego Padres, a team that had lost six of its last seven games. Four fielders committed errors to help account for the second-highest total of runs the Mets have given up in a game this year.

title: Job-Action Threat By the N.F.L. Union
description: The National Football League Players Association threatened today to take a job action, possibly a strike, during training season to prove that it is unified in its quest for a new contract.

title: 45 TOXIC WASTE SITES LISTED AS HEALTH RISKS
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced today that 45 more abandoned hazardous waste sites had been listed for cleanup action.

title: FOLK: FRANKIE ARMSTRONG
description: Frankie Armstrong is an English folk singer who is as much at home in traditional ballads as she is in knockabout music-hall songs and contemporary social statements. On Thursday evening at Folk City, 130 West Third Street, she sang unaccompanied, as she always does, and through the force of her warm, communicative personality, and the strong colors of her voice provided all the background and setting that her singing needed.

title: News Analysis
description: As part of his regulatory relief program for businesses last year, President Reagan directed Government agencies to regulate only when the resulting benefits would outweigh the costs. Politics and mathematics are sometimes hard to separate, however, especially when it comes to costly measures to protect consumers.

title: Free Music in Queens and L.I. Parks
description: Free music in the parks continues this weekend with a presentation of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' at Newbridge Road Park in Bellmore, L.I., and a Seuffert Band mixture of classical, pop and show music at Crocheron Park in Bayside, Queens.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Price of Convenience Goes Up a Dime

title: Second Marijuana Ship Seized Off New England
description: The second ship with a cargo of marijuana captured within a week off New England was escorted into Boston Harbor today by the Coast Guard, which said that the ship's crew had dumped its cargo.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan has been willing to risk a serious clash with Western Europe over its natural gas pipeline deal with the Soviet Union because he feels he must show Moscow he will carry out his warnings to broaden American economic sanctions if martial law in Poland is not lifted.

title: COMMISSION VOTES TO BAN HUNTING OF WHALES
description: The International Whaling Commission voted today to ban all commercial whaling, starting in 1986. The 25-to-7 vote, taken at the commission's session in Brighton, England, does not necessarily mean an end to the killing of whales. Participants at the commission's meeting said some of the nations that opposed the ban, including Japan and Norway, had threatened to file exceptions to the decision and continue to hunt whales.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 45. 1. Roxanne Conlin, pictured above, has led a tax-sheltered existence. Why is that newsworthy? 2. Although Michael Fagan was arrested after breaking into Buckingham Palace, he will not be prosecuted for trespassing. Why not? 3. A high-wire act was an act of heroism in mid-Manhattan. What happened? 4. The Disneys, the Smothers Brothers and other Hollywood celebrities are cultivating new images in similar fields. Explain. 5. One person in (5/7/9) in the United States is officially classified as having an income below the poverty threshold, according to a Census Bureau report.

title: THRIFTS MUST NOT BECOME COMMERCIAL BANKS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BANS ALL MEXICAN CITRUS
description: Federal agriculture officials stopped all shipments of Mexican citrus fruits into the United States today to prevent the spread of a crop-destroying disease to orchards in the United States.

title: GORDON P. STREET
description: Gordon P. Street, chairman of the board of North American Royalties Inc. and a civic leader in Chattanooga, Tenn., died at the Erlanger Hospital there on Wednesday after a short illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Dr. Harry I. Weinstock, A Mt. Sinai Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Harry I. Weinstock, a former director of the Department of Psychiatry at the Mount Sinai Hospital Services Division at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, Queens, died July 8 at Nyack Hospital in Rockland County. Dr. Weinstock, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 81 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JUST FOLKS

title: Speeding Car Kills Man, 100
description: A 100-year-old Bronx man was struck and killed last night by a speeding car three blocks from his home, the police said. The man, Tom Dushi, of 685 East 183d Street, was at 183d Street and Southern Boulevard at 6:08 P.M. when he was hit by a blue 1975 Pontiac. The driver left the scene, the police said.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: $250,000 Stradivarius Stolen From Player

title: Japanese Shipyard Plan
description: Major Japanese shipyards are seeking to resume pricing export contracts in dollars instead of yen as a result of the yen's depreciation, industry sources said today. Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Nippon Kokan said they were negotiating contracts in dollars with Chilean and Norwegian member lines of European South American Lines for one container ship each, both with a capacity of 1,900 containers.

title: DIOR MEN'S WEAR, SET TO MUSIC
description: In a bid to capture a greater share of the American market, Christian Dior Monsieur, as the men's division of Dior is called, presented its 1983 spring/summer collection Wednesday evening to the American fashion press and buyers, in a show filled with lighting effects, two short films, choreography, wildly mugging models and loud music. Presumably, the point was to prove that Dior's men's clothes can be just as spirited, young and exciting as those of American designers and the less-established Europeans.

title: Wingy Manone, 82, Trumpeter and Singer
description: Wingy Mannone, a New Orleans-born jazz trumpeter and singer whose swinging version of the ballad ''The Isle of Capri'' was one of the most popular recordings of the 30's, died July 9 in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 82 years old.

title: Scouting; Driving for Birdie
description: Carolyn Hill scored the only birdie of her opening round in the 37th annual United States Women's Open by sinking a 4-foot putt with her driver instead of her putter. The birdie came on No. 9 at the Del Paso Country Club in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Sister of Castro Is Punished For Prescription Drug Sales
description: Juanita Castro, the sister and bitter ideological opponent of President Fidel Castro of Cuba, was ordered into a pretrial counseling program Wednesday by a Miami judge.

title: IS EL SALVADOR MAKING PROGRESS ON HUMAN RIGHTS?
description: Sometime next week, President Reagan is expected to certify to Congress that El Salvador's Government has made progress in human rights and economic and political improvements.

title: Scouting; Pitcher's Return From a Tragedy
description: Three days before he was supposed to report to the Florida Instructional League with the Mets' other promising minor league prospects, a teen-aged pitcher named Jody Johnston accidently shot himself in the head. The Mets thought he would never pitch again, but Johnston wouldn't give up on his dream of reaching the major leagues, and now he is rated as one of the Mets' most promising young pitchers. Johnston, a 6-foot-1-inch, 175-pound right-hander, is 8-1 with a 2.29 earned run average for the Mets' Lynchburg, Va., farm team in the Class A Carolina League. And he's only 19 years old.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 24, 1982
description: International Israeli planes attacked Palestinian neighborhoods in west Beirut for the second straight day after Palestinian guerrilla raids behind Israeli lines in southern Lebanon. The P.L.O. press agency, Wafa, said 56 people were killed or wounded in the Israeli attacks. The attacks appear to reflect a mounting Israeli frustration with the failure of American mediation efforts to obtain a peaceful withdrawal of the 6,000 P.L.O. fighters trapped in west Beirut by Israeli forces. (Page 1, Columns 3-4.) Syria's President called on the U.S. to resolve the ''major problem'' in Lebanon, which is how to end the Israeli occupation, rather than concentrate on the evacuation of the Palestinians from west Beirut. This was the main point of four hours of talks in Damascus between President Hafez al-Assad and Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy to the Middle East. President Assad restated his Government's rejection of the American plant to transfer the besieged Palestinian fighters to the Syria, official sources said. (4:1-2.)

title: SAFETY BOARD ASKS ALL STATES TO FIX 21 AS DRINKING AGE
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, convinced that there is an ''irrefutable'' link between drinking and highway deaths among youths, said today that it would call on the governors and legislatures to raise the drinking age to 21, in line with a trend among some states.

title: Sports People; A Big $15
description: Sam Torrance, the Scotish Ryder Cup golfer, has edged out Severiano Ballesteros of Spain for a spot in next month's World Series of Golf by only a $15 margin.

title: Prince Philip to Visit U.S.
description: Prince Philip of Britain will visit the United States in September and November on behalf of the World Wildlife Fund, the organization's United States chapter said today. The trip, it said, will include stops in Los Angeles, Houston and Chicago.

title:
Patents;
Decoy Ballistic Missile
description: A decoy missile that can imitate an intercontinental ballistic missile re-entering the atmosphere from space has been patented for the Air Force.

title: 'WHOREHOUSE IN TEXAS,' REYNOLDS-PARTON VERSION
description: The Hollywood musical, in this era of ''Annie'' and ''Grease II'' and ''Can't Stop the Music,'' is not exactly enjoying a golden age. Even so, ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' is an outstandingly feeble addition to the roster. With its book rewritten from the stage version so as to remove most of the jokes, and with its musical numbers leadenly staged, this film lacks even the inadvertently buoyant awfulness that makes some bad movies fun. It's just plain dull.

title: SPAIN TO BUY FIGHTER JETS FROM U.S.
description: The Spanish Government said today that it had decided to buy 84 F-18A fighter-bombers from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for $3 billion.

title: THIOKOL CHEMICALS ATTRACTED MORTON
description: Few companies have been more deeply involved in the Government-financed space program than the Thiokol Corporation, a manufacturer of propulsion systems for rockets and missiles that last year derived well over half its $720 million in revenues from Government contracts.

title: HAITIANS LEAVING DETENTION IN MIAMI
description: With songs and chants from supporters, the first of 1,807 Haitian refugees ordered freed by a Federal judge were released today from a Federal detention camp near the Everglades.

title: Nalco Patent Suit
description: The Nalco Chemical Company said yesterday that it sued Britain's Allied Colloids and Allied's American subsidiary on July 9 for patent infringement. The dispute is over two Nalco patents dealing with methods for rapidly producing solutions containing certain polymers. Nalco said that the technology covered by the patents is widely used in mining, paper processing and refining.

title: Rules Panel Backs Measure To Allow Televising of Senate
description: The Senate Rules Committee voted Wednesday, 7 to 5, to approve procedures and regulations that would permit closed-circuit television coverage of the Senate's proceedings.

title: Sports of the Times; COLOR HIM HUMAN
description: R ichard Todd has a job that pays more than the minimum wage and is one of the prestige positions in sports - quarterback, New York Jets. But for better or worse, he retains the sensitive qualities, along with the Gulf Coast drawl and the shyness, that he displayed that summer day six years ago when he came in off the University of Alabama campus as Joe Namath's heir apparent.

title: Jacobs Ends Offer For Pabst Shares
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis businessman and dissident shareholder of the Pabst Brewing Company of Milwaukee, yesterday ended his tender offer for the company.

title: Marlene Kruger Married
description: Marlene Kruger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kruger of Los Angeles, was married in Beverly Hills, Calif., yesterday to Elliot Fields, who with his brother, the late Edward Fields, founded Edward Fields Carpetmakers.

title:
GARDENING;
LINDENS CONTRIBUTE A FRAGRANT BEAUTY
description: WHILE parking the car on a recent morning, I was fortunate to pick a place alongside a linden tree in full bloom. Its delightfully sweet fragrance, as delicate as any perfume, brought forth memories of the taste of clear, sweet honey on toast or rolls. Indeed, linden blossoms are the source of nectar for a very mild, sweet honey that is highly prized in Europe, if not as well known in this country.

title: Justice Dept. Aide Is Named
description: Attorney General William French Smith has named Walter Burkhart as acting director of the National Institute of Justice, a research arm of the Justice Department. The department said Wednesday that Mr. Burkhart, who joined the institute in 1970 as a social scientist, would assume his duties immediately.

title: KNIGHTS, COLONIAL TROOPS AND PILOTS
description: Vermont Sets A Repeat Of 1777 Battle

title: If You're Thinking of Living in ...; COLD SPRING HARBOR
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, a natural inlet on Long Island Sound fed by u nderground springs from the surrounding hills, has been serving as as afe harbor for new residents since the 17th century.

title: Kotar Makes It Official
description: Doug Kotar made it official today. After six and a half seasons as the Giants' primary running back and a season and a half on the injured-reserve list, he retired.

title: Maria Heibron, C.F. Richter Wed
description: Maria del Carmen Heibron, an associate in the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, was married in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations yesterday to Charles Franklin Richter, who is a partner in Quasha, Richter & Simon, New York lawyers. The ceremony was performed by Msgr.

title: Boxer Hurt At Festival
description: Tyrone Biggs, the reigning world amateur heavyweight boxing champion, suffered a broken right hand today for the second straight year in a semifinal victory in the National Sports Festival.

title: Season's Big Hits
description: GEORGE LEWIS is the president of Rolls-Royce here in the colonies, and he was smiling one day last week, busy with delight at this year's black ink.

title: Crowder Hurts Ankle
description: Randy Crowder, a defensive tackle for Tampa Bay who has missed most of the last two N.F.L. seasons with a knee injury, tore an Achilles tendon during the Buccaneers' first summer workout and underwent surgery. He will be sidelined for an undetermined period.

title: VIDEO GAMES GO MARCHING OFF TO WAR
description: The Army awarded last week a $29 million contract that defines the state of the art in war simulation. It calls for a ''nap-of-theearth'' level of realism in which pilots training for the new AH-64 Apache attack helicopter will control simulations of three-dimensional combat as they man realistic cockpit controls and dip away from flack bursts down to the treetops. Through the noise and vibration of combat, they will pass or hover, precisely as they choose, over villages, rivers, enemy guns, billowing foliage and even a nervous bird or two should the Army be willing to pay for that sort of computer detail.

title: Martha Wilhelm - To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R.
