Wilhelm of - Athens, Ohio, formerly of Westport, - Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Marsh - Wilhelm, to Lawrence Robert Kessler, son of Melvin Kessler and Mrs. Lillian Anthony Kessler, both of New York. The wedding is planned for next - spring.; Miss Wilhelm is a reporter on Congress for the Bureau of National Affairs, a publishing concern in Washington. She attended Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, and was

title: FRENCH HUNT 4 IN P.L.O. CASE
description: The French police today issued the descriptions of four men they believe killed a Palestinian official here on Friday.

title: Biting the Tax Bullet
description: The Republicans deserve credit for pushing a big election-year tax increase through the Senate. Although not every provision in the bill is sound, the revenues are badly needed to reduce the large deficits forecast for the 1984 and 1985 budgets.

title: Alice Nicholas Married to Robert Rose
description: Alice Regina Nicholas, a trader on the equity-options trading desk of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York, was married yesterday to Robert M. LeStrange Rose, a joint manager of institutional finanical futures at Thomson McKinnon Securities in New York. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: ENTICING PROGRAMS, MANY WITH NO FEE
description: SUMMERTIME living may be easy, as the Gershwins so eloquently proclaimed, but it can also be expensive, with the kids home and lots of leisure hours to be filled. Riding to the financial rescue, however, is our own County Parks Department, which is providing free family entertainment three times a week through mid-August.

title: U.S. Defeats Czechoslovakia in Singles
description: Martina Navratilova, responding to the roars of a pro-American crowd, came back from an 0-6 second set today to lead the United States into the Federation Cup final with a 6-4, 0-6, 6-1 triumph over Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia.

title: A 'MAGNET SCHOOL' FOR NEW ROCHELLE
description: WHEN the New Rochelle Board of Education adopted a reorganization plan closing four of its 10 elementary schools in the spring last year, the Daniel E. Webster School remained as the lone elementary school in the center of the city.

title: Mailbox; Drug Tests: Tool, Not a Weapon
description: To the Sports Editor: Unless there is a compelling reason, no person should be subject to a urinalysis test in order to detect substance abuse. When an individual voluntarily places himself or herself in treatment or is referred by a supervising agency, then urinalysis may have meaning as part of an overall treatment plan.

title: NEW HIGH IN SELLING
description: What's the point of a for-sale sign that can be seen only by birds, pilots and executives flying between Danbury and Hartford? Well, Alex and Shirley Vogel have been trying to sell their llacre estate in Newtown, Conn., for two years.

title: A NEW SERIES MINES THE POP PAST
description: Partly because recording sessions cost money and the music business has been struggling of late, we have been swamped with record reissues recently of every conceivable sort. Some of these are cynical recyclings. But the new Atlantic Deluxe series, the first four releases of which (11 disks in all) have just been released, is another matter: three of the four are of incontestable worth, real masterpieces of American vernacular music, and the fourth, while flawed, is at least invigorating.

title: LEBANESE TELL OF ANGUISH OF LIVING UNDER THE P.L.O.
description: For about six years, until Israel invaded southern Lebanon on June 6, the Palestinians had something closely approaching an independent state.

title: Clean-Air Devices
description: To the Business Editor: If the developers of pollution control equipment of the early 1970's operate at the gut level of the environmental industry, thanks for the early delivery of a grave marker, in ''Pollution Control Industry in Peril,'' (July 4). But you may not be too premature at that.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
DOVER STRIDING TO A REVIVAL
description: DOVER, once one of Morris County's declining communities, is on its w ay up again with a redevelopment plan that is recycling old b uildings in the heart of town.

title: THE VENICE BIENNALE-A FALL FROM CHAMPION TO INVALID; VENICE
description: For quite some time now the Venice Biennale has been the sick man of the international exhibition circuit. Its illness dates primarily from the tumultuous summer of 1968, when the pan-European student unrest almost forced the Biennale to shut down. A failure of nerve led to a failure of coherent intention, and although the Biennale did not in fact die it now leads the life of a distinguished invalid.

title: Randy Jeffrey Schafer To Marry Robin Flitt
description: Mr. and Mrs. David J. Flitt of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Flitt, to Randy Jeffrey Schafer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Schafer, also of Teaneck.

title:
THE WORLD IN SUMMARY;
ANd Now There Is One
description: On the 51st day of his hunger strike, Sergei Petrov decided that the Kremlin's stubbornness wasn't worth dying for. So, saying he wanted to spare his family any more pain, he called off his fast last week without winning a visa to join his American wife in the United States.

title: JAPAN REAPS BENEFITS OF EARLY SMART SHOPPING
description: With the indictment last week of four more Japanese businessmen accused of paying hundreds of thousands of dollars for computer secrets stolen from International Business Machines - the total number of indictments in the case is now 20 - the reputation of Japan as a technological parasite seems complete.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: THE AMBASSADOR'S THEORIES
description: DICTATORSHIPS AND DOUBLE STANDARDS Rationalism and Reason in Politics. By Jeane J. Kirkpatrick. 270 pp. New York: American Enterprise Institute/Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: WOODY ALLEN: SHUNNING MASTERY?
description: Woodyologists, as they may someday be known, will surely wonder why the dean of 1970's American screen humor made a film like ''A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy'' in 1982. To be sure, this is a pretty, amiable movie, and an entertaining one. But it's also unexpectedly slight, and it marks quite a departure from its director's usual methods. This is, among other things, a smoothly pastoral turn-ofthe-century tale in which love blooms, optimism is rampant, and the six central characters come to believe in fairies. However charming it may be, it certainly isn't what audiences have come to expect from Woody Allen.

title: AT PRISON, POLES AWAIT RELEASE OF KIN
description: A small knot of people sat on a bench by the guardhouse outside Bialoleka prison today, waiting to see whether their husbands and sons would be released.

title: A Change to Rental
description: Question:In 1977, I purchased a legal three-family dwelling constructed in 1940-41, consisting of a basement apartment and one each on the first and second floors. Since 1978, we have been using the entire building. However, a changing family situation will leave the second floor available for rent this fall. Does the apartment fall under rent control or rent stabilization? If so, what guidelines do I use in determining rent for the apartment? ... C.G., Brooklyn Answer:Your building will not be covered by rent control because apartment buildings are not placed under that system unless they have been expelled from the rent stabilization system. It will also not be covered by rent stabilization because that law applies only to buildings with six or more apartments. Thus, unless you are receiving a J-51 tax abatement from the city, you can charge whatever rent you wish, set the length of the lease and whatever increase in rent you want at its termination.

title: IRISH WAYS
description: PASSING THE TIME IN BALLYMENONE Culture and History of an Ulster Community. By Henry Glassie. Illustrated. 852 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. $29.95 IRISH FOLK HISTORY Texts From the North. By Henry Glassie. Illustrated. 161 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. Cloth, $13.50. Paper, $5.95.

title: Sarah E. Phillips Plans Wedding
description: Mrs. Stuart R. Shamberg of Chappaqua, N.Y., and William E. Phillips of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Emily Phillips, to Warren Beatty Kanders, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Kanders of Convent Station, N.J.

title: DAYLILLY HYBRIDS CAN BE HOMEMADE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Patricia Hubbell is a writer who specializes in growing wild flowers. BY PATRICIA HUBBELL

title: Miss White And Lawyer Are Married
description: Cassandra Bradley White, daughter of Mrs. Charles Bradley White of Watch Hill, R.I., and the late Mr. White, was married in the Watch Hill Chapel yesterday to Thomas J. Sweeney 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sweeney Jr. of Ridgefield Park, N.J. The Rev. Seymour St. John, an Episcopal priest and former headmaster of the Choate School, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
A Family-Run Shop Discounts Wallpaper
description: Ultima Designs in Hartsdale always discounts designer wallpaper and textured string and grasscloth wallpapers up to 50 percent, sells designer window fashions, including verticals and Levelors - at 25 to 40 percent off on verticals - and, during August, will have Bali blinds at 40 percent off. Prices drop further during periodic specials spring and winter sales. During July, for example, the bath shop offers an extra 10 percent reduction on already discounted prices.

title: Ex-Ranger Dead
description: Larry Mickey, a former National Hockey League right wing from 1964 to 1975, was found dead Friday in a parked car in his garage in Amherst, N.Y. The local police said that Mickey, 38, had died of carbon-monoxide poisoning, and that his death was apparently a suicide. Mickey, who had two separate stints for the New York Rangers in the 1960's, retired in 1975 after his contract with the Buffalo Sabres expired. He then coached hockey for several years in the minor leagues.

title: Rebellions and Relief; Insurgent Glen Cove
description: If the town fathers of Glen Cove on Long Island are going to play at foreign affairs, they ought to do it right. Barring Soviet diplomats from their golf course, tennis courts and beaches is the easy part.

title: SHARPENING SKILLS FOR ADVANCEMENT
description: THE sun streamed through the third-floor classroom as Denise Ganatt wrote an equation in her neat blue notebook with her sharpened pencil. ''Simultaneous equations,'' she said and shook her head. ''I haven't been exposed to math since high school.''

title: David Chandler Marries Elizabeth Ann Cosgrove
description: Elizabeth Ann Cosgrove, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Cosgrove of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to David George Chandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Chandler, also of Darien.

title: A MAN AND HIS AIRLINE
description: THE CHOSEN INSTRUMENT Pan Am. Juan Trippe. The Rise and Fall of an American Entrepreneur. By Marylin Bender and Selig Altschul. Illustrated. 605 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A MINOR VICTORY OF SORTS CAN HAVE A MAJOR IMPACT
description: IT WAS at a luncheon in Morristown last month that the reporter next to me noticed the Secretary of State leave the head table. ''Quick,'' she said, ''let's follow her. She's probably going to the john.'' Before I could answer, my colleague was off, hot on the trail of Jane Burgio, New Jersey's new Secretary of State. For a split second, I considered the indelicacy of the suggestion and the impropriety of trapping someone in the lavatory. But when, I wondered, would I ever have the opportunity to follow a State Cabinet member into the Ladies Room again? Maybe never.

title: UNLIKELY 'FINLANDIZATION' OF AFGHANISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Subsidy Curb Is Approved by Reagan
description: President Reagan has signed legislation curtailing tax subsidies for tobacco marketing. The measure will require some holders of tobacco allotments who do not in fact grow the crop to give up their tobacco ''base'' rather than, as has been the custom, allowing them to lease the valuable production allotment to others.

title: DANCE: RUSH TROUPE IN PREMIERE
description: If only the Rush Dance Company had lived up to the promises of its program Wednesday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. Patrice Regnier, the company's director and choreographer, creates tasteful arrangements of production elements - a pretty arrangement of limbs, a carefully decorative backdrop or set of costumes, a neat little musical smorgasbord. The program offered all, but, alas, no such signs of life as ''spontaneous combustion'' or ''intuition,'' as the titles of two dances suggested, and not even a wholehearted rush across the stage.

title: AMERICAN AUTO MAKERS USING MORE MEXICO ASSEMBLY LINES
description: Detroit's automobile companies, like other American manufacturers, are setting up an increasing number of plants in border towns like this one where American-made materials are assembled into finished products by inexpensive Mexican labor.

title: HAMPTON JITNEY LEAVES ITS POTATO-BARN PHASE FAR BEHIND
description: WHILE a few big Hamptons estates have their own heliports, and a sizable flock of private planes makes the East Hampton Airport a weekend roost, most ordinary New Yorkers bent on reaching eastern Long Island, as well as those going in the other direction, have three transportation options to choose from. Those with cars can drive the Long Island Expressway (or assiduously avoid it); those without can ride the Long Island Rail Road, or they can book themselves on the Hampton Jitney, a relatively recent choice.

title: Lisa Anne Camalier, Law Student, To Be Bride of E. Michael Diefenbach
description: Lisa Anne Camalier, who has completed her first year at the University of Virginia Law School, and E. Michael Diefenbach, a 1982 graduate of Virginia's Colgate Darden Graduate School of Business Administration, plan to be married Sept. 18.

title: Clerc Overcomes Fritz, Advances to Semifinals
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina had a close call today, turning back an unheralded Frenchman, Bernard Fritz, by 2-6, 7-6, 6-1 in the quarterfinals of the $240,000 D.C. National Bank clay-court tennis tournament.

title: Huntington's 400 For Historic Listing
description: I would like to add the following information to supplement your very fine story about historic preservation on Long Island (''Historic Sites Await Tax Break'').

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE SOUL OF A NEW MACHINE. By Tracy Kidder. (Avon, $3.95.) How a group of 30 whiz-kid engineers, working from mid-1978 to early 1980 in a dingy basement in Westborough, Mass. developed ''Eagle,'' a super-minicomputer, for Data General Corporation. ''Tracy Kidder has endowed the tale with such pace, texture and poetic implication,'' our reviewer Samuel C. Forman wrote, ''that he has elevated it to a high level of narrative art.'' A best seller in hard-cover, the book won a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award.

title: Kate Foley Is Married To John Halden Muller
description: Mary Catherine Foley, a sales representative with Calvin Klein Menswear in New York, was married yesterday to John Halden Muller, a vice president of marketing for the Cacharel Division of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation in New York. Msgr. Edward L. O'Malley performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Albany.

title: Yarborough Captures Pole
description: Cale Yarborough averaged 150.764 miles an hour today round the two-and-a-half-mile, three-turn track at Pocono International Speedway and led the qualifiers for Sunday's Mountain Dew 500.

title: TROUBLE INSIDE THE BIG VAULTS
description: THE American banking industry has been badly shaken. Two of the nation's largest, most profitable and best-respected banks - Chase Manhattan and Continental Illinois - have done what no money markets banks in recent history have done. They have lost money, plain and simple.

title: POP-JAZZ: BENSON SHOW AT MUSIC HALL
description: George Benson's two shows at the Radio City Music Hall on Friday found the eminent pop-jazz singer-guitarist backed by a 25-piece string section in addition to a lively eight-piece pop-funk ensemble. With such luxuriant support, it was inevitable that the pop, rather than the jazz, side of Mr. Benson should have been spotlighted.

title: LEGISLATORS REACT TO REVISED LINES
description: WHITE PLAINS ASSEMBLYMAN Peter M. Sullivan will not have to sell his condominium in White Plains and move to northern Westchester. Nicholas Spano, the Republican Assemblyman from Yonkers, will not be out of a job. And Assemblyman John M. Perone, Republican of Mamaroneck, whose district includes a portion of New Rochelle, will keep his piece of that city.

title: Around the Nation; Film Set Crash May Spur Inquiry Into Child Labor
description: A state official said today that criminal charges might be filed in the deaths of two child actors, working illegally late at night, who were killed in a helicopter accident with Vic Morrow, the actor.

title: AN ACTRESS'S PRESENCE IS STILL FELT
description: A plume of yellowish dust rises from a distant field, signaling a plow at work, as Butts Canyon Road snakes through the farmland of northern California en route to a patch of vineyard and an old house that once was the country home of Lillie Langtry, star of the British and American stage, who summered here before the turn of the century.

title: SCOTTISH SUMMERS
description: A MODEST HARMONY Seven Summers in a Scottish Glen. By Sheila Gordon. 277 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $13.95. By RONALD BLYTHE

title: IN SUMMER, HOME IS NOT ENOUGH
description: SUMMER in the suburbs is for kids. Everybody knows that. Where else is there such proverbial fresh air and lush grass? A basketball backboard in every driveway and a mountain of sports equipment in every garage?

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IF Dorothy could put together the heels of her magic ruby slippers today, leaving the Wizard's Emerald City behind, would she return to Kansas or choose a vacation in Connecticut instead? Debate on that question has officials in both states in a bit of a snit.

title: NEW YORK'S SIDEWALK CLOCKS DOWN TO 8
description: There was a time, before highway billboards and Madison Avenue, that an enterprising shopkeeper could, for about $600, install a permanent advertisement that was guaranteed to be seen by thousands of passers-by every day.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: EIGHT teen-agers from New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Florida are attempting to do what no one has ever done before: Make a trip around the entire perimeter of New Jersey all under their own power.

title: 200 GIVEN SUMMER JOBS AND CHANCE AT COLLEGE
description: About 200 high school juniors are participating in a new program that provides inner-city students with paid summer jobs and a chance to go to college.

title: Some Help For Whales
description: The International Whaling Commission's decision last week to ban commercial whaling, though a major achievement for conservationists, may be less of a victory for the whales.

title: VICTORIA
description: MOIRA FARROW is a reporter for The Vancouver Sun. By MOIRA FARROW

title: KYLIAN OFFERS SOME SURPRISES IN HIS RECENT CHOREOGRAPHY
description: The Netherlands Dance Theater's season, just ended at the Metropolitan Opera House, was somewhat different this year from its previous engagements. The schedule included two American premieres - William Forsythe's ''Say Bye Bye'' and Mats Ek's ''House of Bernarda Alba'' - by choreographers other than Jiri Kylian, the company's artistic director since 1978. Ostensibly such programming was meant to defuse charges - artistically irrelevant but voiced in Holland - that the state-supported company was dominated by Mr. Kylian and was seen abroad as a vehicle for himself.

title: OUR ARCHANGEL OF ALIENATION
description: LES FLEURS DU MAL By Charles Baudelaire. Translated by Richard Howard. Illustrated by Michael Mazur. 365 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $22.50.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
For Manhattan Development, It's Westward Ho!
description: With the East Side nearly bursting with high rise apartments and offices, Manhattan has been feeling a gentle but steady push westward. Last week, the push became a shove.

title: WHEN ARCO LEFT TOWN
description: RESIDENTS here remember Sept. 29, 1980, as the most bitter of all days. At 9 A.M., the Atlantic Richfield Company held simultaneous meetings in Los Angeles, Washington and Helena, the state capital of Montana, to announce the permanent closing of the 75-year-old Anaconda copper smelter. The smelter's 1,000 employees, who were at home awaiting the end of a nationwide copper strike, heard the news over the radio.

title: WESTERN BEIRUT BOMBARDED BY ISRAELIS FOR THE THIRD DAY
description: Israeli warplanes, artillery and gunboats attacked Palestinian-controlled neighborhoods in west Beirut for the third straight day today.

title: RELICS OF THE CHINA TRADE
description: FOX BUTTERFIELD is chief of the Boston bureau of The Times. BY FOX BUTTERFIELD

title: AT THE HEART OF THE ABSCAM DEBATE
description: Abdul Enterprises Ltd. may have looked like a gold mine to members of Congress who accepted money from associates of Arab sheiks. But when the Congressmen realized that they had stepped onto a land mine instead - that the sheiks were part of a sophisticated undercover operation -they raised a cry that is still echoing in Washington more than two years later.

title: SAN FRANCISCO BRIDGE SQUAD FAVORED IN GRAND NATIONALS
description: An experienced squad from San Francisco was slightly favored to win the final of the Grand National Team Championship here today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, but it had to face a Michigan quintet that has played impressively.

title: Business Conditions; OVERSEAS INVESTMENTS
description: A recent Commerce Department report shows the amount spent by foreigners to acquire or start businesses in the United States last year rose 57 percent from 1980, to $19.2 billion.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A NEW DAY DAWNS
description: Few days have been more meaningful in the annals of American numismatics than July 1, 1982. The first day of this month was also, in a sense, the first day of a new era for United States commemorative coinage.

title: Doctor to Marry Juannie G. Eng
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jim Eng of Sea Cliff, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Juannie Grace Eng, to Dr. Ira David Glick, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Glick of Passaic, N.J.

title: Hard Bargaining Over Welcome Mats for P.L.O.
description: Arab League emissaries last week proposed an itinerary out of west Beirut for Yasir Arafat and his 6,000 beleaguered guerrillas. But the price and conditions attached to the package ticket seemed exorbitant. Israel, signaling its impatience, launched repeated air attacks on Palestine Liberation Organization redoubts in west Beirut and on Palestinians and Syrians in the Bekaa valley. Syria, using Soviet SAM-8 missiles for the first time, downed an Israeli Phantom and captured two pilots.

title: SALVADOR SITUATION 'BAD' BUT IMPROVING
description: President Reagan is expected to certify to Congress this week that El Salvador is reducing human rights violations and making advances in land reforms, a Congressional requirement for continued United States aid. Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, who visited El Salvador last week, discussed his findings with Bernard Weinraub of The New York Times Washington Bureau. Excerpts from their conversation at the State Department follow.

title: JERSEY CITY CRISIS MAY STIR ACTION ON WATER BONDS
description: JERSEY CITY AFEW minutes after he announced last Wednesday that this city's five-day water emergency had ended, Mayor Gerald McCann admitted that the same thing - a breakdown of the supply system - could happen again.

title: VIEWS OF LIFE IN THE HAMPTONS
description: LOOKING woman who lives in a Manhattan high-rise is excitedly telling her husband about a summer rental she has just discovered in a newspaper's classified advertisements. The house, she says, has a hot tub, Jacuzzi, sauna, home computer, video games, Betamax, Robot Coupe, pasta machine and electric wok.

title: LUGAR ASSAILS LEGISLATION TO CURB ACID RAIN
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, campaigning for re-election in Southern Indiana coal country, today denounced legislation proposed to curb acid rain as ''potentially ominous'' for his state.

title: Jenine Dawson to Be Wed
description: Col. Wallace H. Dawson 3d, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Dawson of Manhattan Beach, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jenine Louise Dawson, to Richard Morris Flexner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Flexner of Livingston, N.J. The wedding is planned for Sept. 5.

title: P. Phillip Huffard 3d, Deborah Battin to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Spragg Battin of Sharon, Conn., and Walden, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Wick Battin, to P. Phillip Huffard 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Huffard Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Vieques, P.R.

title: A TALL STORY
description: When the modest apartment house at 813 Park Avenue was just five stories tall and 25 feet wide, it was not all that noticeable. Flanked by taller and more elegant neighbors at the 74th and 75th Street corners, it seemed to recede into its midblock site.

title: Susan Kanter Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kanter of Lake Success, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Toby Kanter, to Scott Greenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Greenbaum of Brooklyn.

title: A CROWN OF JEWELS IN RIO
description: WARREN HOGE is chief of The Times bureau in Rio de Janeiro. BY WARREN HOGE

title: Mary Ellen Burns Wed To Richard J. Zavoluk
description: Mary Ellen Burns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Burns of Marysville, Mich., was married yesterday to Richard J. Zavoluk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael O. Zavoluk of Queens Village, Queens. The Rev. Joseph T. Holcomb performed the ceremony in St. Catherine of Sienna Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: Dr. Carla Ginsburg Is Married to William D. Evans
description: Dr. Carla Helene Ginsburg, an attending staff physician in gastroenterology at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday to William David Evans, president and chief operating officer of the XTRA Corporation, a transportation equipment leasing company in Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Robert Miller performed the ceremony at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Boston.

title: ELIZABETH MOORE ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Moore of Stonington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth J. Moore, to James M. Roux, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Roux of Lewiston, Me. Miss Moore and her fiance, graduates of Bowdoin College, plan to be married next Octo-ber. Mr. Roux is attending the Univer-sity of Maine Law School.

title: TEAMS PREPARE FOR RAFT RACE
description: AMERICA'S CUP competition it is not, but the eighth annual Connecticut River Raft Race, scheduled for this Saturday, contains many of the elements of the famed sailing event, such as the almost manic enthusiasm among participants and the secrecy maintained in the preparation of their craft.

title: ELIZABETH WHITMAN TO BE OCTOBER BRIDE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Allen E. Whitman 3d of Devon, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sloan whitman, to John Studebaker Winder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dodd Winder of New Haven and Peru, Vt.

title: 1981 PLOT IN BAHRAIN LINKED TO IRANIANS
description: It was a small plot by world standards, the Information Minister says. But, with hindsight, it was an unusually significant one: An Islamic radical group, operating with apparent backing from Iran, conspired to take over this moderate Arab state on the Persian Gulf.

title: JUDICIAL AND COMFORTABLE
description: ONE thing that judges must do is a great deal of sitting, and the members of the Atomic Safety and Licensing Board hearing the testimony in the Shoreham case were not happy with any of the chairs that Suffolk County had to offer them. The solution was to bring their own up to the Island from Nuclear Regulatory Commission headquarters in Washington.

title: RECRUITING BAN MAY COST 6 COLLEGES DEFENSE PACTS
description: Universities whose law schools refuse to permit Army recruiting because the service will not accept homosexuals have been threatened with loss of all their defense contracts and Reserve training units.

title: AH, SWEET MYSTERY OF LIFE
description: BEFORE Charles Darwin died 100 years ago, he had bestowed on mankind a view of our place in life that overturned received ideas as radically as had Galileo's on the solar system and Newton's on gravitation.

title: Letters; Surpassing Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: LUCY A. ANDREWS TO WED ASSESSOR
description: Mrs. W. Austin Wadsworth of Geneseo, N.Y., and Avery Delanb Andrews 2d of Washington, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Avery Andrews, to Knox McIlwain Cummin of Huntington, Vt., son of Mrs. Graham French Cummin of Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Cummin.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JULY 25, 1982
description: International The Israelis bombed Syrian missiles in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon and lost a plane to Syrian fire, a military spokesman in Jerusalem announced. The spokesman said the missiles had been brought in from Syria during the night. They were said to be Soviet-made SAM-8 surface-to-air missiles, a more advanced type than previous Soviet missiles used by Syria. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Palestinian presence in Lebanon was similar to an independent state until Israel's invasion on June 6. Under the umbrella of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Palestinians maintained an army, a police force, a crude judicial system, an educational and welfare organization, a civil service and a foreign policy. The major tool of persuasion for those who might have resisted Palestinian rule was the gun, according to those who lived under it and are describing what it was like. (1:4 -5.)

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: TIME nearly ran out last week on U.S. Blues, a popular restaurantclub in downtown Roslyn. A statutory stay on an injunction to close the club, upheld in January by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, was due to expire at midnight Monday. But Supreme Court Justice Alexander Vitale, who had ordered the injunction, signed an extension of the stay allowing the club to remain open pending a hearing before the Supreme Court in Mineola tomorrow.

title: A CHANGE IN CHARACTER
description: When an actor takes a new role, he takes the name and face of the character he is playing, and many New York buildings do the same. Thus, the Printing Crafts Building at Eighth Avenue and 34th Street is being renamed 5 Penn Plaza and having its facade restored to reflect its new role as an office center.

title: Week in Business; CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ROSE 1% IN JUNE
description: Consumer prices rose 1 percent in June, the Labor Department said, with most of the increase coming from higher gasoline prices. The rise matched May's jump and was sharply higher than the two-tenths of 1 percent rise in April, but economists still expected an annual inflation rate below 8 percent.

title: HEAD OF GIRL SCOUTS REFLECTS ON CAREER
description: VOLUNTEERING has been part of the life of Jane C. Freeman, the national president of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., for almost as long as she can remember. The Ardsley-on-Hudson resident recalled volunteering even as a child in school. ''It probably started because both sides of my family were deeply involved in church as ministers and missionaries, and there's very much a sense of volunteerism in that,'' Mrs. Freeman said during a recent interview at the new Edith Macy Girl Scout Conference Center in Briarcliff Manor.

title: HEIDI ENGLER TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Edwin Engler of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Engler, to Walter G. Fritz, son of Mrs. Walter J. Fritz of Colonie, N.Y., and the late Mr. Fritz. A September wedding is planned. The future bridegroiom is production-music director of radio station WGY in Schenectady, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: VALHALLA'S Mental Retardation Institute will receive about 70 percent of the Federal grant it had been promised, but its director, Helen A. Murtha, said her reaction to the news was ''enthusiastic.''

title: WHAT'S NEW: 186 MORE ITEMS ON THE SHELF, BUT NO SOUP
description: If the confidence of companies issuing new products is any measure of economic health, the recession could be declared over. Businesses last month introduced 152 new products, a record number, says Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the advertising agency that has been keeping tabs since 1964. And that doesn't include a new, separate list of 34 new gourmet and health food products.

title: POP: GARY U.S. BONDS SINGS
description: Gary U.S. Bonds, the early 60's rock singer famous for such jubilant raveups as ''Quarter to Three,'' is one of the luckiest men in pop. Rescued from obscurity by Bruce Springsteen last year, Mr. Bonds has released two albums that Mr. Springsteen helped produce.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CENTER HELPS TEEN-AGERS HALT DRUG USE WITH AID OF PARENTS
description: MANHASSET BY the time the three teen-agers received their diplomas, there was hardly a dry eye in the house. For the 200 parents and grandparents who turned out to share in the joyful ceremony, there was a sense of pride and a sigh of relief. Finally, their children were considered drug-free.

title: Stephanie Lambert, David Simon Newton to Wed
description: The engagement of Stephanie Lambert to David Simon Newton has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lambert of New York, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Newton of London and North Aston, England.

title: Jewish Travelers
description: To the Editor: In the Q and A column (Travel, May 23) a reply was printed to a couple who desired information on travel destinations for Jewish travelers.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bogota $85,000 35 Walnut Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*chestnut trim, finished basement; taxes $1,575. Cliffside Park $102,000 300 Winston Drive *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old high-rise condominium; *2*parquet floors, river view; taxes $1,249. Cresskill $143,000 65 Engle Street *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old colonial Cape Cod; *2*in-ground pool, paneled basement; taxes $2,601. Edison $96,000 7 Cypress Court *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 4-year-old split-level; *2*fireplace, patio; taxes $2,082. Montvale $92,000 21 Waverly Place *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old ranch; *2*deck off kitchen, finished basement; taxes $1,683. Norwood $185,000 70 Pierson Avenue *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $3,208. OTHER SALES Larchmont, N.Y. $152,000 10 Rockwood Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old brick/ frame colonial; *2*new kitchen, playroom, 75-by-100-foot lot; taxes $3,301. Danbury, Conn. $72,500 91 North Ridge *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, town house condominium; last year's *2*electric heat $900; monthly charges $55; taxes $900. Lynbrook, L.I. $74,000 76 Rolling Street *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bathroom colonial; formal dining room, *2*finished basement, patio, two-car garage; taxes $2,380.

title: COMING OF AGE IN THE THIRTIES
description: UN-AMERICAN ACTIVITIES By Richard Kluger. 689 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $19.95. FLANAGAN'S RUN By Tom McNab. 443 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $14.50.

title: LETTER TO ISRAEL DEFENDED BY WATT
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said today that he was ''proud'' of a letter he sent in which he warned that opposition by Jewish liberals to Mr. Watt's energy program would weaken this nation's ''ability to be a good friend to Israel.''

title: THE MAN FROM NAUTILUS
description: SPREADING the gospel is not easy, according to Arthur Jones, i nventor of Nautilus exercise equipment and self-described genius. A fter a dozen years on the hustings, speaking to devotees and criticsa like about his theories on exercise, he sometimes feels like a p rophet without honor in his own land.

title: MUSIC: MOZART FESTIVAL PRESENTS TWO SOLOISTS
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival continued Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall with music by Beethoven, Haydn and, of course, Mozart. David Zinman conducted the Festival's orchestra in two symphonies - Mozart's early No. 13 in F (K.112) and the C minor, No. 95, from Haydn's later years. Alexis Weissenberg was soloist in the Beethoven C minor Piano Concerto and Elly Ameling, the soprano, sang three Mozart arias, ''Chio mi scordi di te,'' ''Vado, ma dove?'' and ''Voi avete un cor fidele.''

title: ENTEN ELLER'S CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Walkout Appears Unavoidable At Westinghouse, Unions Say
description: A union spokesman says a strike by about 30,000 workers at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation appears unavoidable unless the company agrees to resume contract talks.

title:
GARDENING;
LINDENS CONTRIBUTE A FRAGRANT BEAUTY
description: WHILE parking the car on a recent morning, I was fortunate to pick a place alongside a linden tree in full bloom. Its delightfully sweet fragrance, as delicate as any perfume, brought forth memories of the taste of clear, sweet honey on toast or rolls. Indeed, linden blossoms are the source of nectar for a very mild, sweet honey that is highly prized in Europe, if not as well known in this country.

title: HOW TO GET RESTORER'S TAX CREDIT
description: TO anyone with the slightest interest in investment real estate - f rom the major developer to the fix-up artist who would like to buy ad ilapidated old house and rent it - the new 25 percent tax credit forr ehabilitating historic buildings is an exceptionally attractive p roposition.

title:
ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
RESTORING NEUTRA TO HIS PLACE IN HISTORY
description: Richard Neutra's career is something of a paradox. He designed one of the truly great modern houses of the 20th century, the Lovell house in Los Angeles; several others that can surely be called distinguished, and quite a few buildings that are altogether mediocre. From the late 1920's through the 40's he was undoubtedly this country's greatest designer of houses in the sleek, austere mode of the International Style, but by the postwar years his work had become not so very different from the run-of-the-mill ''modern architecture'' that was dotting the suburban landscape everywhere. And at the time of his death in 1970, at the age of 78, he was widely viewed as a master in decline.

title: The Aerobic Push
description: Nobody can argue that running, swimming or cycling are not excellent aerobic activities (Letters, June 6, in response to the Health and Beauty Section, May 9). Any activity that increases the pulse rate is an aerobic activity.

title: IONA SUMMER THEATER
description: For the next two weeks, the sixth annual Iona College Summer Theater Festival will present five plays in repertory in its airconditioned Doorley Hall Auditorium. The non-Equity company is made up of students, members of the community and professionals from New York City.

title: LONG SHOTS WIN IN SPLIT SHEEPSHEAD ON BELMONT TURF
description: A pair of long shots scored surprising victories yesterday over some of the better female turf horses in the East in both divisions of the Sheepshead Bay Handicap on the grass at Belmont Park.

title: Napalm Used on Forest Fire
description: The United States Forest Service dropped napalm by helicopter today to help control a fire that jumped its lines and spread into wilderness so rugged that bulldozers could not be used.The napalm sarted a backfire designed to consume the main fire's fuel supply. In Colorado, Utah and Nevada,forest fires were reported under control after rain came to the aid of firefighters.had been contained or

title: CONCERTS IN GROTON
description: The William Billings Institute of American Music Inc., created last year and named for an American composer who wrote ''Chester,'' reputedly the marching song of New England soldiers in the Revolutionary War, has scheduled a series of concerts at the Avery Point Branch of UConn in Groton. Billings is also believed to have been the first American composer to have his works published.

title: Consumer Groups Sue to Bar Change in Rules on Hot Dogs
description: Four consumer groups have sued the Department of Agriculture, seeking to block a change in Federal regulations that would allow hot dogs, bologna and similar meats to contain finely ground bits of bone that would not be listed on the label.

title: Elizabeth Lynch To Be Fall Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Whalen Jr. of Menands, N.Y., of the engagement of Mrs. Whalen's daughter, Elizabeth M. Lynch, to Philip Andrew Haluska, son of Veronica Haluska of Cleveland and the late Andrew P. Haluska.

title: NEW ELEGANCE IN PUTTING A BEST ANKLE FORWARD
description: Nostalgia has been a chief source of inspiration for men's-wear designers this fall, with many striving to capture an old-world elegance in their clothes. And while men may well begin putting on the past as a way of putting off the present, this mining of other fashion periods has forged new interest in a category long ignored: hosiery.

title: POPULISM, A PRODUCER'S ZEAL AND WAGNER'S 'RING' IN SEATTLE
description: ''I call all of them celebrants, communicants, pilgrims - all of them - and they come year after year.'' Glynn Ross, the general director of the Seattle Opera Association is speaking of operagoers, a breed known for their loyalty and passion. But even among such ardent devotees, the ones he is speaking about are a very special sort. They have come to Seattle from 25 different countries and from every state in the Union for a presentation of the complete Wagner ''Ring'' cycle in six days.

title: Millicent Fenwick's Candidacy
description: I have been writing to Representative Fenwick for the past few years on serious issues, and I have appreciated her answers and help.

title: July 25, 1982
description: NONFICTION THE CHOSEN INSTRUMENT: The Rise and Fall of an American Entrepreneur. By Marylin Bender and Selig Altschul. 1 DICTATORSHIPS AND DOUBLE STANDARDS: Rationalism and Reason in Politics.

title: Opening Shots Over Wilson
description: Concluding that the word of a man who had to be tricked into handcuffs is not worth much, a Federal judge last week refused to reduce the extraordinarily high bail - $20 million - set for Edwin P. Wilson.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART It's not every gallery that gives care and thought to an invitational exhibition in the last weeks of July. But one of the exceptions is the Rosa Esman Gallery at 29 West 57th Street. Through July 30 it has a show of three younger artists - Otis Jones, Ursula Schneider and David James - that is well worth a visit.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: FILM For those who missed the recent appearance of the Grand Kabuki at the Met, or for those who were entranced, ''Demon Pond'' at the Embassy 72d Street Theater features the celebrated Kabuki star Tamasaburo Bando, a lithe young man with an extraordinary facility for portraying women. He has two roles in Masahiro Shinoda's film fable, playing both a sheltered wife from a small village and a princess who rules an underwater kingdom.

title: LOW-COST SPEAKERS OVERCOME THEIR DRAWBACKS
description: If trade statistics are to be trusted, a growing proportion of listeners choose loudspeakers in the price bracket below $150. This may be interpreted as a sign of hard times or - to take a more cheerful view of things - it may reflect the fact that musically rewarding speakers are now available near the bottom of a price range extending from $75 to the four-figure stratosphere.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: 1954, edited by Elliott Mossman. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Letters exchanged between the Russian poet and his cousin. THE DIARY OF VIRGINIA WOOLF.

title: AFGHANS IN PAKISTAN ARE NOW ESTIMATED AT OVER TWO MILLION
description: There are now more than two million Afghan refugees in Pakistan, and it is costing refugee organizations and the Pakistani Government several hundred million dollars a year to support them, according to refugee agency officials.

title: Design/Food By Marilyn Bethany; A PERFECT HOME FOR A COTTAGE CONGLOMERATE
description: When a representative of the Internal Revenue Service recently called on Martha and Andrew Stewart at home, one of the first questions he asked was, ''Occupation?'' Mr. Stewart, who, in fact, is a founder and president of Stewart, Tabori & Chang, Publishers, spread his arms to indicate all that lay about him. ''Our life is a business,'' he said.

title: AUDACIOUS GAMBLES WITH HIGH COMEDY
description: George C. Scott and Richard Foreman may both be creatures of the stage, but their artistic credos have about as much in common as, say, the political ideologies of General Patton and Che Guevara. Mr. Scott is a grand old veteran of the theatrical establishment; Mr. Foreman, an avant-gardist, likes to toss Ontological-Hysteric hand grenades. Yet they do share one trait not unknown among theater people - pure, unbridled egomania. And this summer they've each flexed their egos in the same way - by superimposing their own personalities over every pore of the vintage high comedies they've chosen to revive.

title: Tribute to Aaron
description: A statue of Henry Aaron will be dedicated at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium on Aug. 21, ending months of fund raising and a measure of controversy.

title: IMPORTANCE OF HAVING A SINGLE BUS SITE FOR ALL LINES
description: THE opening of the new three-block-long bus facility in Yonkers, to be operated by Liberty Lines for the county, represents a major step forward in providing vastly improved support services to back up the operation of the 250 buses serving Westchester's 28 million yearly riders. For the first time, all line buses operated by all 13 companies in the county will be providing a full range of services - from refueling to major overhaul -under a single roof.

title: Another Piece Of Romantic History
description: Gary Kriss missed the fun of the most romantic George Washington/ Mary Philipse myth of all (''Washington and Mary Philipse: The Romantic Legend Persists,'' July 4). It surfaced in Philadelphia, early in the 19th century:

title: COOPER RESTORATION ADVANCES
description: BURLINGTON RESTORATION of the dwelling where James Fenimore Cooper was born in 1789 should be completed in time for a public reopening in late summer.

title: Milan Museum
description: To the Editor: William Weaver, in his account of art museums in Milan -''In Milan, La Scala Is Just an Overture'' (Travel, June 27) - should have added the Ambrosian Picture Gallery (Pinacoteca Ambrosiana).

title: Lloyd's Next Big Goal Is a Job
description: Two years ago, when Dan Lloyd of the Giants was approaching the peak of his skills as a starting inside linebacker, he learned he was suffering from lymphocytic lymphoma, cancer of the lymph nodes.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN THERE'S a new baby in the house. She weighs 600 pounds and has a whole mouthful of teeth. Eighty-eight! She is adopted, not our own, technically, and because of the circumstances of the adoption, we have already named her - ''Mother.'' If this baby could talk rather than rattle the windows when she sounds off, she might express objections to the dateline on this column. Her family name is Steinway.

title: BED AND BREAKFAST, THE AMERICAN WAY
description: GLORIA LEVITAS is an anthropologist and writer who lives in New York. BY GLORIA LEVITAS

title: A MASTER AT DEFENSE
description: A little over half a century ago, when contract bridge was in its infancy, somebody at a college in Brooklyn showed the game to a teenage student with mathematical inclinations. His name was Alfred Sheinwold, and it quickly became clear to him that he had found his life's passion. After playing the game and reading the limited literature available, he found that he knew as much as the experts and sometimes more. By the time he left college he was writing about the game with zest and authority and soon became the youngest of an elite group: the ''ghosts'' of Ely Culbertson. The others were Albert Morehead, Alexander Sobel and Alphonse Moyse Jr., which resulted in a curious situation - whenever Culbertson shouted ''Al!'', all four came running. It was great experience for a young bridge writer, although Culbertson was sometimes too busy making millions to pay his ghosts an appropriate pittance.

title: Personal Finance; DIVIDING FUTURE BENEFITS IN DIVORCE
description: WHEN couples begin to wrangle over the specific details of a divorces ettlement, the first things they tend to think about are who gets t he house, furniture, car, stock and children. But equally important m atters, such as whether the wife will be covered under her husband'sg roup health insurance plan or have a claim against his pension, tendt o get overlooked.

title: Mailbox; Is Devils' Plan On Tickets Fair?
description: To the Sports Editor: John J. McMullen, the owner of the New Jersey Devils, has announced the ticket policy and plans for the sale of season tickets for team's games. Plan A provides for a limited number of prime location seats to be available to those willing and able to pay an initial fee of $2,000 a seat, plus the price of the ticket (currently $17.00) in exchange for the right to renew the purchase of the same seat(s) on an annual basis. Plan B provides for all other seats to be available for the price of the tickets only (currently $10.00, $12.00, $15.00 or $17.00), but without the right to automatically renew the purchase of the same seat(s). Apparently, no tickets will be available on a daily basis should the demand for season tickets exceed the supply.

title: Reopen Hamlet Murder Case
description: It was murder ''most foul, strange and unnatural,'' as the ghost of Hamlet's father put it, but Shakespeare may have gotten the idea from 17th century medical journals when he killed off Denmark's king with a dose of poison in the ear. At least, that's what Dr. Avrim R. Eden, an associate professor of otolaryngology at Mt.

title: THE RISKS OF ISOLATION
description: Reflecting on the sudden new outbreak of friction between Europe and the U.S., Andre Fontaine, the French commentator, recently spoke of ''California Gaullism.'' It wasn't meant as a compliment, even from that longstanding admirer of Charles de Gaulle.

title: FLUFF CLOUDING CABLE'S FUTURE
description: The cable picture is still fuzzy as far as the future is concerned. As all those extra channels come on the line, visions of programming wonders dance in the heads of expectant viewers. No more will they be limited to the juvenalia of the commercial networks. No more will they have to sit through movies that are edited and then interrupted incessantly for advertising pitches. No more will they be tied to rigid schedules since cable is awash with ''repeat performances'' at all hours of the day and night. All of this is true - but to a very limited extent. There are already disturbing signs that the highly touted promise of plenty may fall considerably short of reasonable expectations. The key questions are: Plenty of what? And at what cost?

title: WALTRIP CHAMPIONS RACING'S NEW LOOK
description: ''Probably one of the big reasons some of the folks out there don't cotton up to me so much is because I win a whole bunch of the time,'' Darrell Waltrip said as he doodled in wet circles with the bottom of a now-dead Perrier and lime on the rocks.

title: TO THE GREAT BARRIER REEF AND BEYOND
description: James P. Sterba reports on science for The New York Times. Herman Gross plunged over the stern into the Coral Sea on a sunny Sunday afternoon last November. Within seconds, the 16 pounds of lead strapped to his waist, and cameras in each hand, were tugging him down a foot per second through chilly, gin-clear water toward what, as he sank closer, looked less and less like a discarded length of rope and more and more like a very large snake.

title: Agony of Inventor
description: From lessons learned in a high school science class, Vincent D. De-Toia got an idea for a solution to a problem that worries many people today: what to do with hazardous nuclear waste. Mr. DeToia, a Bronx real-estate manager, proposed to convert the waste to electricity.

title: Henry Lenoir Is Dead at 69; A Retired Official of Y.M.C.A.
description: Henry Lenoir, retired director of urban affairs of the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York and former executive director of the Harlem Y.M.C.A., died Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HELEN MEDGYESY BECOMES BRIDE OF J.B. WALKER
description: Helen Susan Medgyesy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Peter Medgyesy of Attleboro and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to Joseph Baldwin Walker, son of Mrs. Kempton Churchill of Cohasset, Mass., and the late George Baldwin Walker, also of Cohasset. The Rev. John A. Greeley performed the ceremony at St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Half Time On the Potomac
description: Looking back over the first half of his Administration and planning for the last half, it must have occurred to President Reagan occasionally that even many of his own supporters, who like him personally and long for his success, have serious doubts about his leadership.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: DANCE Now is the time to take to the beaches -if you are a fan of experimental dance. Indoor performances make for slim pickings this time of year, but the number of outdoor performances increases.

title: WEST BEIRUT'S FUTURE COULD SETTLE THE FATE OF ALL LEBANON
description: week-old Israeli invasion of Lebanon hinges on the fate of the western half of this divided Arab capital. Will a peaceful formula be devised for evacuating 6,000 Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas, or will the Israeli army storm in and take them out? At stake is not only the future of the P.L.O., and to a certain extent, Israel, but also the future of Lebanon.

title: Making Room For a Whale
description: The Cold Spring Harbor Whaling Museum is planning to add the full skeleton of a pygmy sperm whale to its collection this year. To house the expanding collection, the museum is to be enlarged to include an adjacent house that was built in 1894.

title: THE HYPHEN MEANS MUSICAL MISCHIEF
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: VOLUNTEERS: THE BACKBONE OF FIRE SERVICE IN THE COUNTY
description: THEY thrive on danger and devotion, never knowing when the clang of a bell or the clarion of a horn may send them to a scene of tragedy amid flashing lights and screaming sirens. They are often the sons and grandsons of the men who served before them, continuing a proud tradition that in many cases constitutes a part of the basic fabric of every community.

title: Correction
description: The photograph accompanying the article ''Estelle Parsons: Alaska Diary''(Travel, July 4) showed the actress at Ninilchik on the Kenai Peninsula and not in Denali National Park, near Mount McKinley, as stated in the caption.

title: USUAL FEDERAL TINKERING WON'T HELP FARMERS NOW
description: Conventional wisdom has it that America's farm land cannot produce significant amounts of fuel for gasohol without painful sacrifices in food production and prices and greater erosion. But a recent study by Barry Commoner's Center for the Biology of Natural Systems concludes that the country could have its cake and its cars too.

title: Nancy E. Giles, Physician to Wed
description: Mary Magurn Giles of Troy, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Giles, to Dr. Carlos Encarnacion of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlos Encarnacion of Guaynobo, P.R.

title: A TASK FOR ARABS
description: The 21 countries of the Arab League possess territories 600 times and population 40 times the size of Israel's. All these Arab or Moslem countries have possessed national sovereignty with control of their own armies, economies and societies for longer than Israel, which did not gain sovereignty until 1948. What have they done with their nationhood except to mutually quarrel and fight, build skyscraper cities in the desert and ludicrously enrich their sheiks? As regards peace or settlement in their region, their only policy has been refusal, beginning with refusal of the partition determined by the United Nations in 1947 after repeated international commissions of inquiry. With the striking exception of Egypt, they have advanced no responsible policy and taken no responsible steps.

title: Susan Mara And Broker Are Married
description: In St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday, Susan Ann Mara, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington T. Mara of Rye, N.Y., was married to John Robert McDonnell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McDonnell of Allenhurst, N.J. The Rev. Kenneth Moore performed the ceremony.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: On Language By Ronald R. Butters How to Order Eggs
description: Ronald R. Butters, associate professor of English at Duke University, is editor of the journal American Speech. William Safire is on vacation.

title: REBELLIONS AND RELIEF; Sauce for the Gander
description: A Wisconsin government employee named David Huebschen claimed he'd been demoted because he'd rejected his female supervisor's sexual advances. Last week a Federal jury agreed and said she'd have to hand over $114,600 in damages. The jury also faulted a male supervisor for his ''callous indifference'' to Mr. Huebschen's complaint and tagged him for $81,900. Which should lead thinking people to answer a simple question: can there be more convincing proof that feminism is as good for the gander as for the goose than $196,500?

title: Millicent Fenwick's Candidacy
description: When I was growing up, and watched John Kennedy seek the Democratic nomination for the Presidency, he had to do battle with Lyndon Johnson. In support of his quest for the nomination, Lyndon Johnson extolled his great abilities and experience as majority leader of the Senate.

title: No Headline
description: An article on the Style page last Sunday incorrectly described the relationship of Scott Brown, a fashion model, to the late Arthur Prentice Rugg, Chief Justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Court. They were distantly related.

title: THE RIGORS AND REWARDS OF MARRIAGE TO A STAR
description: THIS was to be the first time I would see my husband start an opener in a uniform other than that of the Cincinnati Reds. I must admit I had butterflies, but I felt proud and enthusiastic about our decision. In theatrical terms, we wanted to play Broadway.

title: SLUMBER IN THE SAND
description: AN early morning walk along the Fire Island beach is not always a solitary experience, says Jesse Morris of Cherry Grove, one of a dozen or so communities that dot the 32 miles of barrier beach.

title: Prospects
description: An Unhappy Anniversary

title: REAGAN LEADS NEWS INDEX
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was slain last year, assassination attempts were made against President Reagan and Pope John Paul II, and the hostage crisis in Iran was resolved. But the most frequent entry in The New York Times 1981 Index, published today, is ''Reaganomics,'' a complex of articles about economic conditions, including finances, budgets and taxation.

title: ARE CHILDREN NO LONGER IN THE PROGRAMMING PICTURE?
description: WASHINGTON Sometime late in September or early October Bob Keeshan, whose longevity as Captain Kangaroo makes him the Johnny Carson of children's television, will end his daily appearances after 27 years. He and his show will take over hour-long slots on Saturday and Sunday mornings. As a result, for the first time in nearly three decades there will be no regularly scheduled weekday program for children on commercial network television.

title: ''BARBAROSA,'' AUSTRALIAN-DIRECTED WESTERN
description: The best western in a long while is ''Barbarosa,'' a film that uses one American legend, Willie Nelson, to create another. ''Barbarosa'' is the work of the Australian director Fred Schepisi (''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith''), whose foreignness in this instance works to his great advantage. Mr. Schepisi has turned Texas, where ''Barbarosa'' was filmed, into an exotic wilderness, and used it to give the film's outlaw story its strangeness and beauty. The film also has its share of bleak levity, as befits a tale set in a landscape so forbidding that the best things to eat are frequently armadillos.

title: TISSUE IS INSERTED INTO HUMAN BRAIN
description: In what is believed the first transplantation of new cells into a human brain, tissue from the adrenal gland of a Parkinson's disease patient in Sweden has been inserted into the core of his brain in an effort to reduce his symptoms.

title: Maria S. du Pont Will Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis Irenee du Pont of Wilmington, Del., and Chadds Ford, Pa., of the engagement of Mr. du Pont's daughter, Maria Sloan du Pont, to Thomas Peyton Wootton, son of Mrs. Frederick Howard Mason of Wilkes Barre, Pa., and the late Theodore Whitson Wootton of Watertown, N.Y.

title: Lincoln Kirstein And the Dance
description: Lincoln Kirstein's achievements in the American dance world are impressive (''Lincoln Kirstein: A Life in Art,'' by John Russell, June 20). Forming a ballet company and affiliate school of high caliber are admirable accomplishments.

title:
GARDENING;
LINDENS CONTRIBUTE A FRAGRANT BEAUTY
description: WHILE parking the car on a recent morning, I was fortunate to pick a place alongside a linden tree in full bloom. Its delightfully sweet fragrance, as delicate as any perfume, brought forth memories of the taste of clear, sweet honey on toast or rolls. Indeed, linden blossoms are the source of nectar for a very mild, sweet honey that is highly prized in Europe, if not as well known in this country.

title: Q and A
description: Question:Are any of the airlines currently offering a round-the-world fare that allows unlimited stopovers? What is the cost and what are the terms, and where can I find out about this? - K.J.C., New York, N.Y. Answer:Trans World Airlines offers a round-the-world fare that costs $1,999 in tourist class and $3,499 in first class; the first leg of the trip must be reserved and the entire fare paid 21 days in advance of departure. The ticket is good for six calendar months from the date of departure and, once the initial segment is completed, can be booked as you go along. Travel must be continuous in one direction with one exception; you can double back between Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: ''It's amazing how good one's memory is, even of events from way back,'' said Leon Edel from his home in Honolulu during a recent telephone conversation. ''If you sit long enough and think hard enough, you can even dredge up old smells and feelings. After all these years I can still put myself back on the prairie in Yorktown,'' the mining city in Saskatchewan where he lived until he departed for Montreal and McGill University at 16.

title: Investing in Minds
description: There in The Wall Street Journal last June 1, amid the stock and bond ads, was an invitation to ''invest in students - not institutions.'' The ad promised a ''limited opportunity to become a trustee of a major private university'' to anyone ''willing to invest $1,000,000 cash (minimum) for financial assistance to students.''

title: TIMOTHY STOLLER PLANS TO WED JILL SCHOSERG
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Schosberg of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill E. Schosberg and Timothy J. Stoller, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Stoller of Red Hook, N.Y.

title: CONCERT: VIVALDI PIECES
description: If the asterisks in the program are to be believed, all seven pieces on Thursday's Vivaldi program at Avery Fisher Hall were new to the Mostly Mozart Festival. Vivaldi left lots of concertos, to be sure. But all this novelty still seems odd, considering how congenial his music is to the cheerfully 1950's esthetic and performance style that governs this festival, with its penchant for bright, cheerful music brightly and cheerfully performed.

title: WATSON CARVING A PLACE AMONG GOLF'S GREATEST
description: TOM WATSON is a golfer of history now. His career is measured by trophies, not money. The reigning champion of both the United States Open and the British Open has won seven major tournaments, as many as Sam Snead and Gene Sarazen and Harry Vardon, only one fewer than Arnold Palmer and two fewer than Ben Hogan and Gary Player.

title: WHY THEY DON'T LIKE TO DRIVE
description: IN a recent ''About Long Island'' column, Richard F. Shepard wrote an article both amusing and sad on the quaint and graceless ways of suburban women drivers

title:
DINING OUT;
HUNANESE COOKING IN YONKERS
description: WHEN it opened in 1979, Peng's Yonkers branch made a welcome addition to the restaurants lining lower Central Avenue, Peng's offered at that time the increasingly popular Hunanese-style cooking, one that borrows freely from its neighbors - amalgamating heat from Sichuan and richness from Shanghai. Peng's menu was a cut above that of most Chinese restaurants in the county; the short menu offered relatively few dishes, hinting that they would be choice, and quite a few of them were. The kitchen still provides some fine dishes; however recent visits indicate that it is difficult to be assured of a satisfactory meal here. The kitchen has become careless; preparations lack consistency.

title: END 'CRISIS' IN HOUSING, STATE URGED
description: A13-year-old tenants' organization whose past efforts have helped to make New Jersey's rental laws some of the strictest in the country has submitted to the new head of the state's Department of Community Affairs a program proposing a variety of actions for Trenton and local officials to undertake.

title: Business Conditions; PRICES PAID FOR HORSES STILL RISING
description: Overseas buyers have helped America's horse breeders continue to flourish despite recession and a strong dollar, factors that have seriously eroded the value of most speculative investments.

title: HOW TO BE SURE-FOOTED WHEN WORKING ON A SLOPING ROOF
description: EVERY do-it-yourself homeowner will occasionally be faced with the job of doing a repair or improvement job that involves climbing up on the sloping roof of the house and then perhaps working in one spot for some time while trying to stay in place on the slanting surface. This may come about when there is a need to patch or replace damaged roof shingles or flashing material, to make repairs on the side of a dormer or to patch brickwork near the top of the chimney.

title:
CAMERA;
THE URBAN LANDSCAPE
Braves Beat Pirates on 4 in 7th
description: Chris Chambliss drove in two runs with a single to spark a four-run seventh inning that gave the Atlanta Braves a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: PENSION ISSUE STIRS COAST SENATE RACE
description: Mayor Pete Wilson of San Diego appears to have learned something this week that his fellow Republican, Barry Goldwater, learned in 1964, and President Reagan learned in 1981: It is politically risky to suggest tampering with the Social Security system.

title: Gail Solomon Becomes Bride of Steven Weinberg
description: Gail Robin Solomon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot M. Solomon of Pawtucket, R.I., was married yesterday to Steven Weinberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Weinberg of Huntington, L.I. Rabbi Leslie Y. Guttterman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Providence, R.I.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The Librarians' Lot

title: DORIS LESSING ON FEMINISM, COMMUNISM AND 'SPACE FICTION'
description: Lesley Hazleton is a British writer now living in New York.

title: FARE OF THE COUNTRY
description: HENRY KAMM, who was based in Bangkok for several years, is chief of the Rome bureau of The Times. By HENRY KAMM

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: FEDERAL and state environmental officials are fearful that persistent climatic and man-made conditions in the Atlantic Ocean may produce a major algal bloom and fish kill similar to those in 1976.

title: THE BURDENS OF STARDOM
description: People are always asking why I refuse to become a star. One reason is: I don't want to have my wattles surgically removed. It's not that I love my wattles, but that I fear surgery, particularly under the chin. I never let barbers shave me with a straight razor; I certainly don't want surgeons poking around in my wattles with a scalpel.

title: A MOVE TO RAISE SPIRITS AND FINANCES OF ALASKANS
description: Although the companies they run are among the largest in the United States, the heads of some of the Alaska Native Corporations face management questions that might be more easily settled around the campfire.

title: Lake Erie Swim Ended
description: John Muenzer, attempting to swim a 53.8-mile course across Lake Erie from Rondo Beach, Ohio, to Erieau, Ontario, covered approximately 35 miles in 27 hours before he left the water for medical reasons Friday evening. Muenzer, 20, a former swimming star at Toledo University, was asleep on a stretcher and wrapped tightly in a blanket when he was brought to Cleveland for rest. Dr. John Lombardo of the Cleveland Clinic, who had been accompanying the swimmer on a boat, said Muenzer's temperature had dropped as low as 95 degrees during the swim.

title: Heather Douglas Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bowman Douglas 2d of Saddle River, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Heather Leigh Douglas, to Jan Carlee, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Carlee of Montclair, N.J. A Sept. 25 wedding is planned. Miss Douglas is a freelance artist. Her fiance is a computer animator with Mathematical Applications Group Inc. in Elmsford, N.Y.

title: FREEING DETAINEES DOESN'T RELEIVE POLISH PRESSURE
description: During the night after Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski spoke to Parliament last week, police came to Victory Square and once again swept away the giant cross of flowers that has become the premier symbol of passive defiance in the Polish capital.

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Exiled From Caesars World
description: In Las Vegas, Caesars may own the World and occupy the Palace, but if the multi-million dollar gaming corporation wants to stick around Atlantic City, it must sever ties with the two men who created it.

title: LESS IS MORE, BUT IN DIFFERENT PLACES
description: I HAVE news for you. The weight of the shopping cart increases in inverse ratio to the loss of weight (Reitman's Law). Once upon a time, in painful remembrance, when I was a chubby half size encased in a five-foot envelope of fat, I carried my week's shopping in a paper bag easily liftable in one arm. This may seem strange. But consider:

title: Rail Engineers Lose Their Strike
description: Britain's striking railroad engineers might have guessed that a Prime Minister who would go to war over tiny islands thousands of miles away wouldn't hesitate to spank a defiant union at home. But they didn't, and last week Margaret Thatcher did.

title: POWERBOAT SPLIT CREATES 2 TITLE RACES
description: The Off Shore Commission of the American Power Boat Association has split from the Union Internationale Motornautique, which sanctions international powerboat racing, because of a disagreement involving who should run the world championships for the open class this year. As a result, there will be two world championship races, one in England and the other in Florida.

title: BUSH PLANS PRIMARY
description: A sharply divided Republican State Convention today endorsed Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. for a third term, and Lewis B. Rome for Governor, but gave their challengers more than enough votes to force statewide primary races Sept. 7

title: SCARLET AND GOLD ON PARADE
description: JOHN de ST. JORRE is the author of ''The Guards'' (Ridge Press/Crown Publishers). By JOHN de ST.JORRE

title:
ANTIQUES;
TREASURES OF WESTERN NEW JERSEY
description: BRIDGEVILLE FOR the uninitiated, it takes some hunting up and down country roads, but western New Jersey can be a never-ending source of American country antiques.

title: GRANDMOTHER PLANS TO BUILD A MEMORY FOR GRANDDAUGHTERS
description: SO the lines are long, so the water fountains are broken, so the $28 a day campground is built on landfill that reportedly oozes methane and spawns rats, I'm taking my granddaughters to the Knoxville Fair anyway; because my grandmother took me to the Century of Progress World's Fair in Chicago in 1933, and it is a dear, exciting memory of the kind that only grannies can effect.

title: A MIGHTY ASSEMBLY OF TOY SOLDIERS
description: Toy soldiers have probably been around as long as the world has had armies. And they have been collected passionately for centuries. Only over the last decade, however, has an assemblage of toy soldiers become important enough to fill a museum and become subject matter for a book.

title: Death by Explosion
description: Horses and humans screamed, falling to the ground in mangled heaps. Terrorist bombs, exploding in two London parks one midday last week, served as the grimmest reminder in nearly three years that if Britain does not consider itself at war, the Irish Republican Army does.

title: Carey Upholds Listing Of Legislators' Homes
description: Governor Carey has vetoed a bill that would have required the State Board of Elections to give out only lawmakers' business addresses.

title: Filly Seeks 5th Straight In Quarter-Horse Event
description: Shaken Not Stirred will be after her fifth consecutive victory and a first-place prize of $253,079 in Sunday's second leg of quarter horse racing's triple crown, the Rainbow Futurity.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S RULING TRIBE NO LONGER MONOLITHIC
description: Fissures have deepened recently in what was once a nearly monolithic defense of apartheid put up by South Africa's dominant white tribe, the Afrikaners. Prime Minister P.W. Botha has called a federal congress Friday of his National Party to ask endorsement of constitutional proposals that would bend the political color bar. The Government proposes a limited and symbolic role in central government for the smallest nonwhite communities - mixed-race people known as coloreds and Asians of Indian descent. When Mr. Botha spoke of ''healthy power-sharing'' (using a term that had been anathema to Afrikaner nationalists), extreme right-wingers headed by Dr. Andries P. Treurnicht, a former Botha Cabinet member, broke away and started the Conservative Party. Some Afrikaner students and intellectuals, meanwhile, have been defecting to the relatively liberal official opposition, the Progressive Federal Party.

title: IT WILL COME BACK TO HAUNT US
description: Should Congress Put a 'Made in U.S.A.' Stamp on Imported Cars? Malcolm Baldrige and Douglas A. Fraser have often locked horns over issues of trade and industry. Again, the Commerce Secretary and president of the United Auto Workers union are at odds, this time over proposed legislation that would, in effect, require major foreign-car companies such as Toyota, Nissan and Volkswagen, to make most of the vehicles for the American market in this country.

title: THE WORLD IN SUMMARY
description: By Carlyle C. Douglas, Katherine J. Roberts, and Milt Freudenheim NO Philby, but Grave Enough

title: U.S. PLANS OPTIONS FOR BEIRUT FORCE
description: If President Reagan sends American troops into Lebanon to help evacuate forces of the Palestine Liberation Organization, they would probably be paratroopers from the United States rather than Marines based in the Mediterranean, according to Defense Department officials.

title: PITFALLS ON THE TRAIL OF A CO-OP: A PERSONAL ACCOUNT
description: THEY speak English in Manhattan, and they take American money - lotso f it, in fact - but that is the end of the similarity between the r eal estate market here and in the rest of the country.

title: 1910 Mail Delay
description: The mail - some 500 pieces of it in two sacks - should have been delivered in 1910, but nobody noticed it until last month.

title: Cosmos Give Gee His Shot
description: The example of Darryl Gee of the Cosmos has reinforced the belief of those who say that Americans can perform proficiently in the North American Soccer League once they are given the chance to play.

title: Watt Unleashes Oil Explorers, To Some Dismay
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt last week cleared the deck for a tidal wave of oil and gas leases and denunciations from environmentalists when he announced final approval of plans to develop almost the entire outer continental shelf on both coasts. Nearly a billion acres - 20 times the total area offered to industry since offshore leasing began in 1954 - will be offered in 41 sales during the next five years. ''It is much easier to explain to the American people why we have oil rigs off our coast than it would be to explain to the mothers and fathers of this land why their sons are fighting on the sands of the Middle East as might be required if the policies of our critics were to be pursued,'' Mr. Watt wrote in a letter to 28 Congressmen who protested.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC David Johansen's recent live album, ''Live It Up'' (Blue Sky), is winning him new fans all over the country. But to countless New York fans, Mr. Johansen is first and foremost this city's rock standardbearer.

title: FOR WOMEN, A.D. 1405
description: THE BOOK OF THE CITY OF LADIES By Christine de Pizan. Translated by Earl Jeffrey Richards. Foreword by Marina Warner. Illustrated. 281 pp. New York: Persea Books. $16.95.

title: FRESH AIR CAMPERS SAVOR VISIT TO 'FRIENDLY TOWN'
description: It was a picnic worthy of Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer. Boys and girls ran barefoot along the river bank. Some plunged into the river to float with the current, giggling, and others launched canoes for expeditions upstream.

title: ABORTION CAMPAIGN TO BECOME ISSUE IN I.R.S. TRIAL
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a trial can be held on a lawsuit challenging the tax-exempt status of the Roman Catholic Church on the ground that it participates in political campaigns against abortion.

title: MARY DECKER TABB'S ENDLESS SUMMER
