description: meter race in Switzerland the day before, she happened to see a notice in the local newspaper for an all-comers track meet.

title: Mystic Park Captures Yonkers Trot by 4
description: Mystic Park won the Yonkers Trot tonight and established himself as an overwhelming favorite to capture the remaining two legs in trotting's triple crown series.

title: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO SELL SOME LAND
description: THOMPSON ON a sun-filled day here, where sparkling blue light shimmers off the waters of West Thompson Lake, it seems implausible that anyone in this idyllic setting could be concerned about something as remote and intractable as the national debt.

title:
CHESS;
POTENT COMBINATION
description: Putting a weapon like the Pillsbury attack into the hands of Mikhail Tal is like playing Russian roulette with all chambers loaded. This formation, which the brilliant American strategist Harry Nelson Pillsbury developed shortly before his debut victory in the famous Hastings 1895 International Tournament, has never been shorn of its potency despite the rise in defensive technique in recent decades. And Tal, now 45 years old, still executes a mating attack with the same virtuosity as when he won the world championship in 1960.

title: Taking Aim at Insanity Defense
description: When a jury last month found John W. Hinckley Jr. not guilty of shooting the President by reason of insanity, Mr. Reagan suggested publicly, but obliquely, that the insanity plea should go. Last week, Attorney General William French Smith made it official. The Administration, he told the Senate Judiciary Committee, wants to ''abolish the insanity defense (in Federal courts) to the maximum extent'' possible.

title: Sculpture Moves Outdoors
description: STANDING in a courtyard of the Louvre in Paris is an equestrian statue of the Marquis de Lafayette by an American artist, Paul Wayland Bartlett, the sculptural designer for the State Capitol in Hartford. The Daughters of the American Revolution commissioned the piece as a reciprocal gift for the Statue of Liberty in 1907. A reproduction was made in 1932 and installed on the grounds of the State Capitol at the head of Washington Street, where it still stands.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a captioning error by Paramount Pictures, a photograph on page 13 of the Arts and Leisure section today is incorrectly described. The man at the right is Douglas Day Stew- art, writer of ''An Officer and a Gen- tleman.''

title: U.N. SEEKS STAFF INTERESTED IN NAMIBIAN DUTY
description: The Secretariat has issued a call for staff members interested in working with the United Nations Transition Assistance Group in Namibia.

title: LINES DRAWN AT SHOREHAM HEARINGS
description: RIVERHEAD AN uninformed outsider walking into the county legislative meeting room on days when the Legislature is not using it would probably find, for much of this summer, a collection of conservatively dressed people - almost all men - sitting somberly at tables in front of a panel of equally serious men sitting in high-backed chairs. At first glance, the proceedings might resemble a trial, and in a sense they are - a very special one, in which phrases such as ''fault trees'' and ''event trees'' replace the usual talk about contracts or criminal activity.

title: Greenburgh Was Aid To Community Video
description: I was delighted to see the article on Greenburgh's pioneering efforts for public-access programming on cable (July 11), but I feel the article gives the impression that Greenburgh Community Video grew despite Town Board efforts, not because of them.

title: LEWIS'S 28-9 JUMP IS SECOND LONGEST
description: Carl Lewis, the 21-year-old sprinter and long-jumping star, continued his quest tonight for what once appeared to be the only record that was not made to be broken - Bob Beamon's long-jump mark of 29 feet 2 1/2 inches.

title: THEFTS BY P.L.O. ARE DESCRIBED
description: In the picturesque Maronite Christian village of Lebaa, east of Sidon, for example, an opportunistic cousin of the Raad family arranged for Palestinians to rent a country house belonging to the father of Dolly Raad, a 26-year-old executive of Middle East Airlines. Miss Raad said it was a deal made both in acquiescence to the occupiers and to the prospect of money, for the P.L.O. leaders had, by all accounts, a lot of money.

title: Barbara Jo Leer Wed To Dale Flick in Jersey
description: Barbara Jo Leer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Leer Jr. of Vero Beach, Fla., formerly of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Dale H. Flick, son of Dorothy H. Flick of Lebanon, N.J., and the late Harold W. Flick. The Rev. Dr. J. Calvin K. Jackson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: LANDSCAPER DIGS INTO HISTORY
description: AS a boy growing up in Mystic, Rudy Favretti developed an interest in the past and the ways in which it is preserved by observing and working with his father, a skilled cabinetmaker from Italy who frequently worked on restoring old houses. Although his father's work was done on the inside of buildings, it was the outdoors and ''growing things'' that attracted the son.

title: POSING A CHALLENGE TO THE L.I.R.R.
description: In the summer of 1974, when the Hampton Jitney first started its local run, the Long Island Rail Road was apparently untroubled by the fledgling bus service and did not officially oppose it.

title: Business Conditions; JOBLESS CLAIMS DROP
description: In a recession replete with mysteries, one of the most puzzling is why so few of America's 9.5 million idle workers are collecting unemployment benefits.

title: VASSAR FIELD HOUSE ABLE TO SEAT 4,000, NEARING COMPLETION
description: A new $4.9 million field house and auditorium at Vassar College, under construction since April 1981, is expected to be completed by Sept. 1, when fall semester classes begin, college authorities said.

title: Dave Garroway Family Plans A Jazz Concert as Memorial
description: The family of Dave Garroway, the original host of the ''Today'' television show, plans to stage a jazz concert as a memorial, his son, Michael, said today.

title: Audrey Maynard Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Sheridan Lord of Sagaponack, L.I., and Walter Maynard Jr. of New York and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Audrey Maynard, to Kaighn Smith Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Smith of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: MORE THAN ENDRIN DETECTED IN FOWL
description: A search for waterfowl contaminated by endrin, a highly toxic pesticide, has turned up significant levels of chemical and as many as 18 other toxic pesticides.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Reliving an Era

title: Forest Hills Paean
description: To the Editor:

title: REVISED MENU, INTIMATE SETTING
description: century yellow and brown clapboard house in Roslyn, recently changed hands. A transition period that lasted for several months has been completed, and a revised menu is now in place.

title: Hearns Fights Today
description: Thomas Hearns, the former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, faces unbeaten Jeff McCracken in a middleweight bout at Joe Louis Arena here Sunday. Hearns, whose only loss in 35 fights came last September against Sugar Ray Leonard, has abandoned the welterweight ranks. McCracken, a Californian with 19 victories, was Hearns's sparring partner for the Leonard fight.

title: A RADICAL BEYOND YASIR ARAFAT
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE FINISH LINE, A MEDAL FOR DIGNITY, TOO
description: THIS is my 11th year of jogging, but my second year of racing. Before last year, I didn't know that road races were run on weekends; even if I had known, I wouldn't have run anyway.

title: Exiled Iranian President Says War Benefits U.S. and Israel
description: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the former Iranian President, today condemned Iran's offensive in the war with Iraq and said the conflict could benefit only Israel and the United States.

title: No Headline
description: The Television Week column on page 3 of The Guide today misidentifies the cellist who will perform on ''Evening at Pops'' Saturday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13. He is Nathaniel Rosen.

title: Sex Education and Mrs. Schlafly
description: Last month, a study based on two Federally funded surveys of teenagers and published by the Alan Guttmacher Institute indicated that sex education in the public schools may discourage teen-age pregnancy. Contrary to rumor, young people who take such courses are no more likely to be sexually active than those who don't.

title: METS RALLY TO TOP PADRES, 4-3
description: Craig Swan gave the Mets his most encouraging performance in more than two years tonight, and although he did not gain a victory, the Mets did.

title: Penthouse Will Appeal Award Won by Lawyer
description: Attorneys for Penthouse magazine say they will appeal $567,500 in damages awarded by a Federal jury to a lawyer who said he was defamed in an article.

title: ISRAEL UNIVERSITIES ARE LOSING STUDENTS AND AID TO FIGHTING
description: The Israeli invasion of Lebanon has led to sharp reductions in the number of male students at Israeli universities and to cutbacks in government aid that threaten to end some academic programs, according to one leading educator.

title: Anthony Francis Cottone Weds Anne Louise Carlson
description: Anne Louise Carlson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Carlson of Groton, Conn., was married yesterday in New London, Conn., to Anthony Francis Cottone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Cottone of Devon, Pa.

title: BAND: GRAINGER AND BENNETT
description: Between pieces at the Guggenheim Band concert Wednesday night in Damrosch Park, Ainslee Cox, the music director, reminded the audience that the composer-pianist whose centenary is being honored this week used to walk down from his home in White Plains for solo appearances with the band in Manhattan. That man was, of course, Percy Grainger (1882-1961), a gifted eccentric who is best known for ''Country Gardens,'' ''Shepherds Hey'' and other such folk-inspired works that have given musical pleasure to untold millions for the better part of this century.

title: A STUDENT'S ROLE IN MAKING OF 'GARP'
description: LAST summer, Danny Goldman of New Rochelle ran with one of America's best-known writers, John Irving, and wrestled with one of the country's best-known comedians, Robin Williams. Soon the public will be see the results of his labor: a wrestling scene with Williams in the Warner Brothers movie ''The World According to Garp,'' which opened Friday at selected theaters.

title: FOR RUSSIAN IMMIGRANT, THE SKY'S STILL THE LIMIT
description: FORT LEE WHEN Mikhail Shabetayev survived a 10,000-foot fall after his parachute failed to open, military doctors in the Soviet Union told him that he would never walk again, let alone fly. Even so, in less than a year, he was a pilot again.

title: TEST BAN AND EPITAPHS
description: Ronald Reagan last week, in a move speaking volumes about his sincerity in the current strategic arms reduction talks, threw out 19 years of bipartisan American support for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. The military arguments he accepted have heretofore been consistently rejected.

title: BASEL
description: To the Editor: As Paul Hofmann notes in "What's Doing in Basel" Travel, July 4), Basel is no temple of gastronomy, and the bestknown hotels are slustered about the central railroad station, a pretty dreary area.

title: Kibbutzim
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW DISPUTE ARISES IN SEWER TAX ISSUE
description: PITTING residents against government for nearly 15 years, the Stony Brook-Port Jefferson sewer debate recently came a step closer to being resolved when Suffolk County closed public comment on how to upgrade the area's sewage plants to meet Federal and state laws.

title: THE LEGACIES OF 3 ARTISTS ON THE RIVIERA
description: ERICA BROWN, a writer based in London, is the author of ''Interior Views'' (Viking Press). By ERICA BROWN

title: DEADLINE ON LOFT APPEALS NEARS
description: OWNERS of loft buildings and their tenants are being urged by the C ity Planning Department to file no later than Saturday their a pplications for ''grandfather'' exemptions from new zoning r egulations on loft use. Those who fail to meet the July 31 deadline m ay lose their right to continue to operate or live in nonconforming l ofts.

title: REBELLIONS AND RELIEF; Country Houses
description: If Governor Carey signs a housing bill that reached his desk after easy passage in the Legislature, New York can spur construction of a thousand badly needed low-rent rural homes. Better yet, it will be able to build them with $5 in Federal funding for every $1 the state would have to put up.

title: Fighting Male Infertility
description: Katherine Bouton's assessment of male infertility seems to downplay the causal relationship between a man's infertility and his emotional, marital and sexual reaction to it.

title: PRUDENTIAL BETS ON GEORGE BALL TO MAKE BACHE A WINNER
description: THERE is a fresh scar across George L. Ball's left cheek - a battle scar not from Wall Street, b ut from a squash racket that slammed into his face during a recent g ame. He took up squash only a few months ago, vowing to three s quash-playing friends that he would soon beat them at their own g ame. He has already beaten two of the three, and still plans to b etter the third as well -this despite the fact that last week he b egan to put in 16-hour days as the new chief executive at Bache G roup Inc.

title: CHOOSING YOUR MANAGING AGENT
description: SINCE 1947, the tenants at 47 East 87th Street had relied on one c ompany to manage their 60-unit cooperative building. Then, in 1976, t he co-op's treasurer, Danelle Knapp began wondering why the company w as paying a bill for 3,000 pairs of white gloves a year.

title: FUND DRIVE TO AID WOMEN ALCOHOLICS
description: raising drive to continue operations, despite the difficult economic period.

title: THE S.R.O.'S ARE DOWN BUT STILL HOLDING ON
description: Two years ago, when the city's Human Resources Administration predicted that single-room-occupancy hotels would be extinct by 1984, few housing experts had reason to doubt it. The spiraling value of property in Manhattan, where most of the hotels were located, and the antipathy of many middle-class residents to the S.R.O.'s -and their poor tenants - had helped reduce the number of hotels from 298 to 189, and the number of rooms from 50,454 to 28,332, in just four years.

title: 'MEET YOUR NEW NEIGHBORS' IN BRENTWOOD
description: ON the evening of June 18, I went to the local 7-11 store for a pack of cigarettes and saw a stack of fliers on the counter. I thought it was the usual announcement of a garage sale or the usual protest against the L.I.R.R. or Lilco.

title:
GARDENING;
LINDENS CONTRIBUTE A FRAGRANT BEAUTY
description: WHILE parking the car on a recent morning, I was fortunate to pick a place alongside a linden tree in full bloom. Its delightfully sweet fragrance, as delicate as any perfume, brought forth memories of the taste of clear, sweet honey on toast or rolls. Indeed, linden blossoms are the source of nectar for a very mild, sweet honey that is highly prized in Europe, if not as well known in this country.

title: Lincoln Kirstein And the Dance
description: I found Lincoln Kirstein's tribute to his father in John Russell's article particularly appropriate for June 20 - Father's Day.

title: Around the World; Jury in London Declares Italian Banker a Suicide
description: A jury ruled Friday night that Roberto Calvi, president of Italy's largest private bank, killed himself in London last month.

title: LImiting War?
description: Recent talk by Reagan strategists of ''controlled nuclear counterattacks'' and ''protracted conflict periods'' appalled some members of Congress. So, last week, 50 legislators, mostly Democrats, wrote to President Reagan urging cuts in his five-year plan for military growth and abandoning any buildup aimed at fighting a protracted nuclear war.

title: Index; International
description: Foiled plot linked to Iranian in- terest in Bahrain 3 Outside Polish prison, people await kin's release 3 Quebec debates dividing schools by language 4 Around the World 5 U.N. issues a call for staff inter- ested in a Namibia tour 7 U.S. and Marshall Islands split over plebiscite 8 Floods and mudslides kill at least 135 in Japan 9 Afghan refugees in Pakistan said to exceed two million 9 Iran agrees to medition by Alge- ria under certain conditions 10 Lebanese Christians widen hold under Israelis 14 Defense Department has new plans for evacuation of Beirut 14 Syria seeks U.S. commitment on overall Mideast solution 14 Israeli universities losing stu- dents and aid to fighting 14 Government/Politics Senator Baker's daughter battles for a Congressional seat 19 Wilson's comment on Social Se- curity enlivens Coast race 20 Infighting seen as endangering election of blacks in Brooklyn 24 Antinuclear march June 12 cost city $1.8 million in overtime 30 Trial allowed against I.R.S. on tax-exemption challenge 31 General Around the Nation 16 Florida deer hunt tied to long- term water problems 17 In North Carolina camp, mi- grants wait for sun and work 23 Education/Welfare The Whitney Foundation has cut back severely and may close 25 Health/Science Swedish researchers transplant cells into human brain 15 Senator Lugar assails legislation on acid rain 21 Arts/Entertainment San Francisco team favored in bridge tournament final 28 Vivaldi program offered at Mo- zart Festival 42 ''Reaganomics'' leads entries in '81 Times Index 42 Style A block of new shops on Colum- bus 43

title: A DANGLING BOOM AND LETHAL CRASH
description: New York City's skyline, for all its beauty, was for many a source of terror last week. On the roof of an office tower under construction on Madison Avenue, a huge crane collapsed, raining down chunks of granite and shards of glass. On the sidewalk, 44 stories below, one pedestrian was killed and 16 were injured.

title: DROPOUT PURSUING A DOCTORATE
description: THERE was a time - perhaps even as recently as six years ago - when no one might have cast a vote for Charles E. McCabe of Huntington as most likely to succeed.

title: LOBBYISTS PROLIFERATE- SO DO THE HEADACHES
description: Last Tuesday, many members of Congress would rather ruefully admit, was a typical day on Capitol Hill. In one meeting room, the chairman of the House telecommunications subcommittee was claiming that a $2 million lobbying effort mounted by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had made it impossible for him to proceed with legislation that would stiffen the terms of the antitrust settlement the Justice Department struck with the communications giant.

title: FUGITIVE SPY OFFERED TO AID U.S., SEEKING A DEAL, DOCUMENTS SHOW
description: When he was apprehended last month, Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent charged with illegally aiding Libyan terrorists, was setting out on his own to establish an elaborate, covert intelligence organization in Central America, according to documents outlining the plans.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
EGLEVSKY ON TOUR
description: The Eglevsky Ballet is turning the map into a summer dance festival, performing all over. Ending its eight-concert series, the company will dance four times this week: today at the Chapin Lakeside Theater in Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, accompanied by the Long Island Pops Orchestra; Thursday at Bethpage High School on Stewart Avenue, Friday at Heckscher Park on Prime Avenue in Huntington and Saturday at the C.W. Post Center's Concert Theater in Brookville.

title: CHALLENGE TO AMERICA'S CHEESEMAKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating in Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: Nader on Dingell
description: To the Business Editor: In your (July 11) article on his career, Congressman John D. Dingell is quoted as saying: ''I've had some debates with Mr. Nader where I caught him telling untruths - I made no bones about it - I said, Ralph, you're not telling the truth, and he doesn't like that.'' Calls by my associate to his office requesting substantiation of this charge brought forth nothing.

title: by Mel Watkins
description: THE COLOR PURPLE By Alice Walker. 245 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovannovich. $11.95.

title: Rail Tickets
description: To the Editor:

title:
Investing;
PAC MAN THRILLS IN TREASURY BILL FUTURES
description: IN much the same way that video games have bewitched teen-agers, a n ew game of trading financial futures is mesmerizing some s peculative-minded adults. The game isn't Pac Man or Missile Command;i t's the Intermarket Spread.

title: Brewers Win By 7-4 As Cooper Bats in 3
description: Cecil Cooper drove in three runs with a home run and a single to lead the Milwaukee Brewers to a 7-4 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

title: Tracy Caulkins; Gets Third Victory
description: Tracy Caulkins of Nashville won her third race, and Mary T. Meagher and Steve Lundquist joined the list of double winners at the United States world championship swimming trials tonight.

title: Keeping Informed About the East End
description: Once again, the Long Island Weekly has taken the problems of the East End to its heart.

title: SUMMERTIME TIME FOR BROILING THOSE BIG FISH
description: In summer, big fish are especialy good eaten as steaks or kebabs and broiled outdoors over coals. The big three we see most often in the market are swordfish, tunafish and tilefish. To a lesser extent, there is mako shark. Their steaks, like those of the other three, can be marinated in olive oil herbs, grilled and served with lemon juice. Mako shark is sometimes sold as swordfish, but its flesh is darker and not as delicate. Whole swordfish steaks can be distinguished from mako shark steaks by their dark fatty spots and a firmer textured flesh.

title: Scrubbed Clean
description: In political attacks on tax inequities it's best for one without shelter to cast the first aspersion. Roxanne Conlin, a Democrat who was thought likely to become Iowa's first female governor, handily won a June primary in which she denounced tax shelters and low taxes for the rich. Then she disclosed that she and her husband were worth $2.2 million but, aided by real estate write-offs, paid no state income taxes last year and only $3,000 in Federal income taxes. Last week she huddled with her staff to assess the damage: Campaign funds had dried up and her 10-point lead in the polls was thought to have vanished.

title: CHEESE OUTPUT RISES IN NEW YORK AND NATION
description: Cheese production in New York and the United States rose to record levels in 1981, according to figures just released by the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

title: NOW, FOR A TOUR OF AMERICA
description: SAM JORDAN got his first glimpse of the Tour de France yesterday, from right in the middle of it. When it was over, the special events representative for the District of Columbia had a new gray hair or two and a rather succinct reaction to France's most popular sporting event: ''These people don't fool around.''

title: ECONOMIC FUTURE OF SOCCER: THE ESSENTIAL INGREDIENTS
description: WHEN I took over as president of the North American Soccer League one month ago today, I told everyone involved that I didn't have all the answers. Not by a long shot.

title: MANCINI KNOCKS OUT ESPANA
description: As rockets were fired into the air and a cheerful gathering of more than 15,000 spectators chanted ''Boom Boom Boom,'' Ray Mancini battered Ernesto Espana today as if he were a despised party crasher.

title: GONE BUT NOT QUITE FORGOTTEN
description: I HAVE been living for the past year or so in the company of some strange women whose obscure lives haunt me, depress me and, occasionally, unexpectedly cheer me. They are writers whose minor works and lives I've been reading for the revision of ''The Oxford Companion to English Literature,'' on which I'm now engaged. I am not, let me say, in the process of producing a feminist version of this volume, as a Swedish publisher suggested I should. There will be a certain amount of discreet new-Roget-style rephrasing, but I hope no extravagant claims. It is the very obscurity of some of these women that so interests me; they have no Virago reprint value.The obscure men are interesting too, but not, to me, in quite the same way. John Cunningham (1729-73), author of one successful farce, became an actor, and not a good actor, died in Newcastle, aged 43, and his pages in the British Library were uncut. That is sad, but it is a different style of sadness, and it touches me in a different way from the fates of those women who stretch behind us, some of them wringing their hands, pale, forgotten. ... Well, it is obvious why they concern me. I ask myself if there is anything representative, necessary, in their odd destinies, any linking thread, or are they merely casualties, each perishing alone?

title: 16 EX-U.S. OFFICIALS JOIN GROUP TO STUDY CIVIL RIGHTS RECORDS
description: Sixteen former Government officials are joining to monitor the civil rights records of Congress and the Administration.

title: THE SLOW, STEADY PROGRESS OF STRAVINSKY'S 'RAKE'
description: With an air of dignified leisure that the composer himself might have admired, Igor Stravinsky's opera, ''The Rake's Progress'' continues its slow march into music history. En route over the 31 years of its life, the ''Rake'' has encountered enthusiastic admiration from connoisseurs, mild distaste and reluctant praise from many music critics, but rarely ever the extremes of violent hatred or passionate fondness which a Wagner or a younger Stravinsky might have provoked with ''Tristan and Isolde'' or ''Le Sacre du Printemps.''

title: SUMMERTIME TIME FOR BROILING THOSE BIG FISH
description: IN the summer, big fish are especially good eaten as steaks or kebabs and broiled outdoors over coals. The big three we see most often in the market are swordfish, tunafish and tilefish. To a lesser extent, there is mako shark. Their steaks, like those of the other three, can be marinated in olive oil and herbs, grilled and served with lemon juice. Mako shark is sometimes sold as swordfish, but its flesh is darker and not as delicate. Whole swordfish steaks can be distinguished from mako shark steaks by their dark fatty spots and a firmer textured flesh.

title: JAPAN DEATH TOLL IN FLOODS HITS 140
description: Japan's worst floods in 25 years killed at least 140 people and nearly 200 others were reported missing, the police said today.

title: Miss Murdock To Be the Bride Of Kenneth Kirk
description: Mr. and Mrs. Brian S. Murdock of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gabrielle Alice Murdock, to Kenneth Patrick Kirk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rufus P. Kirk of New Orleans.

title: 500 PLASTIC PINK FLAMINGOS OFFER A FLIGHT OF FANCY
description: After disappearing mysteriously into the night earlier this summer, pink plastic flamingos are returning in force to this sleepy Mississippi river port.

title: THE WORLD IN REVIEW
description: By Carlyle C. Douglas, Katherine J. Roberts, and Milt Freudenheim REagan Leaves Test-Ban Talks In the Lurch

title: Article 039403 -- No Title
description: The annual five days of thoroughbred yearling sales that concluded last week in Lexington, Ky., are a kind of unofficial stockholders' meeting for the industry. Virtually every prominent owner, trainer and breeder is there, and between inspecting and bidding on yearlings there is plenty of time for gossip and argument.

title: 2 CAMPS, 1 FREEZE
description: It has been popular for some time to say that there is no longer a consensus on broad issues of national policy. The notion that consensus is both unachievable and inappropriate may have become so widely accepted that America's political cognoscenti have lost the nose for it. They can no longer smell the opportunity for consensus and instead even prefer the sweatier aura of politics by combat and caricature. The current debate over a nuclear-weapons freeze is a case in point.

title: THE RED BARON TAXIS TO CENTER STAGE
description: One musical number takes place during a mustard gas attack, set to dignified waltz-time. Others occur in slimy, rat-infested trenches during aerial bombardments. Several happen in mid-air; one jaunty tune is sung with aplomb by an Englishman plummeting from 7,000 feet in a free-fall. ''Quite the view from here, what scenery,'' he muses before crashing headfirst into a bomb crater.

title: Michigan Beaches
description: To the Editor: The article ''On the Beach: A Roundup'' (Travel, June 27) listed some favorites of my family.

title: HAMDEN RESISTS PROPOSED EXPANSION OF DUMP SITE
description: HAMDEN WHEN John L. Carusone, chairman of Media Services for the Hamden public schools, bought a hilltop house in a residential neighborhood of this New Haven suburb 18 years ago, one of the main attractions, he recalled, was its panoramic view of the Quinnipiac River.

title: GOOD VIBES BY HAMPTON
description: Lionel Hampton, a giant of jazz for 50 years, will be the star under the stars in a free concert in New Brunswick Thursday. The concert, which starts at 8 P.M. in Buccleuch Park, is sponsored by New Brunswick Tomorrow as part of its Music in the Parks summer festival. Guests are urged to bring blankets or lawn chairs, and may also bring picnic baskets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can confirm that the United States is airlifting military equipment to Somalia. This is in connection with the recent incursion by Ethiopians and Ethiopian-supported forces.'' -Rush Taylor, a State Department spokesman. (6:2.)

title:
THE REGION IN SUMMARY;
Working While Embers Smolder
description: In investigating fires, as in extinguishing them, the sooner the work begins, the better. For more than a year, 50 highly-mobile and highly-visible Fire Department marshals have been catching up with arsonists in neighborhoods in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

title: FICTION
description: 1 2 8 THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists marry one another. 2 1 19 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 3 13 4 CINNAMON SKIN, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) In his 20th adventure, Travis McGee investigates a tragic yet suspicious accident that befalls a friend's family at sea. 4 3 11 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 5 4 7 EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political upheaval on a Caribbean island. 6 5 13 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 7 6 25 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.)

title: WHALE WATCHING OFF CAPE COD
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a professor of the humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology. By ROBERT PACKARD

title: Correction
description: In last week's issue a typographical error in the Reading and Writing column, by Charles Simmons, obscured the fact that Donald Hall bought the farm on which he had spent his childhood summers.

title: MARIA B. MABEE WILL BE A BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Williams Mabee of Edgartown, Mass., and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and formerly of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Brattle Mabee, to Jeffrey Allen Mason, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Allen Mason of Cambridge, Mass.

title: PARTIES SET LINEUPS IN HOUSE RACES
description: HARTFORD ANY doubts that the Sixth Congressional District would not upstage the other five elections for the United States House of Representatives in Connecticut this year were quickly erased last week.

title: THE ASPIRATIONS OF PALESTINIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: ROOT OF THE EVIL ENTERS SENATE RACE
description: TRENTON LIKE many other New Jerseyans these days, Frank R. Lautenberg and Millicent Fenwick are arguing about money. Mr. Lautenberg, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, appears determined to spend as many of his millions of dollars as necessary to get his message across to the voters. Mrs. Fenwick, the Republican candidate, maintains that the electorate will be ''appalled by the lavish spending'' forecast for the fall campaign.

title: QUEBEC PLAN STIRS DEBATE OVER SCHOOLS
description: In the 18th and 19th centuries, a Canadian Protestant was presumed to speak English and a Roman Catholic French. From such tradition a religiously divided public school system arose in Quebec that the province is just now getting around to modifying.

title: FOR THE HAITIANS, SYMBOL OF HOPE
description: NEWARK BECAUSE he is trying to lead his people out of a kind of bondage and into the culture known as America, he is called ''Black Moses.'' His name is Jerome Audige, and in the three years since an article on these pages first told of his singular crusade to help fellow immigrants become contributing members of society, this oncerenowned Haitian lawyer has emerged as a symbol of persistence - and hope.

title: CRAFTS
description: TENAFLY TRADITIONAL approaches to crafts take many twists in the hands of contemporary artists. For example, sculptural baskets by Sheila Benedis and raku vessels by David Norton clearly manifest their indebtedness to the history of their respective fields.

title: Mary Schade Is Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Rolland Schade of Freeport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Alexis Schade, to Robert Justin McCormack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Michael McCormack of Short Hills, N.J.

title: IMAGINARY BASEBALL
description: SHOELESS JOE By W.P. Kinsella. 265 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $11.95. THE SEVENTH GAME By Roger Kahn. 321 pp. New York: New American Library. $13.95.

title: SundaySports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. The Yankees are hoping to surpass this season's American League series attendance mark, 139,897, which they helped set when they were swept by the Angels in Anaheim two weeks ago. (Television - Channel 11, Radio - WABC, 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Padres at San Diego. After this game, the Mets go to St. Louis for two games, then come home Thursday to face Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, Radio - WMCA, 570, 4 P.M. Boxing Thomas Hearns vs. Jeff McCracken, 10 rounds, middleweights, at Joe Louis Arena, Detroit. This is the third fight for Hearns (34-1) at the 160-pound limit since he lost the welterweight title fight (147 pounds) to Sugar Ray Leonard. McCracken's record is 15-0-1. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. San Diego Sockers at Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J. Both teams have won four straight games. Volkmar Gross of the Sockers is only the second goalkeeper in the North American Soccer League (after Jim Brown of Washington in 1980), to score a goal. He did it last week on a penalty kick. (Radio - WVNJ, 620, 7:30 P.M.) Other Events Auto Racing: Mountain Dew 500 at Pocono Raceway, Long Pond, Pa., 1 P.M. This is the second year that the Nascar circuit has stopped at the raceway, on Route 115, three miles south of Exit 43 on Interstate 80. Cale Yarborough and Richard Petty are in the field.

title: HOW WHITE PLAINS BEAUTIFIED ITSELF
description: year-old insurance man, decided in 1951 to do what George III did in 1760: line the streets of White Plains with trees. This summer, 31 years after that decision, tall shade trees shelter Mamaroneck Avenue for two-and-a-half miles and line shorter stretches along the Post Road, Main Street and Hamilton Avenue. The White Plains Beautification Foundation, founded by Mr. Wallach, has provided the city with 23 small parks, two large fountains and wall murals. This spring, 10,000 daffodils, hundreds of azaleas, and 300 cherry trees planted by the group were in bloom.

title: U.S. FLYING ARMS TO SOMALIA AFTER ETHIOPIAN RAIDS
description: The State Department announced today that the United States had begun flying weapons and military equipment into Somalia to help that nation repel Ethiopian attacks across the border.

title: MINORITY DIVISIVENESS SEEN IN BROOKLYN RACES
description: Competition among minority-group candidates could jeopardize the election of blacks in two Brooklyn Congressional districts that were redrawn to help their candidacies, according to some politicians.

title: Stoudt Reconsiders
description: Cliff Stoudt, the reserve quarterback of the Pittsburgh Steelers who picked up two Super Bowl championship rings before he ever appeared in a National Football League game, has retired as player representative for the Steelers. He said yesterday that he had submitted his resignation three weeks ago, after telling the N.F.L. Players Association that the Steelers were the only team that opposed a strike against the league.

title: SUMMERTIME TIME FOR BROILING THOSE BIG FISH
description: IN the summer, big fish are especially good eaten as steaks or kebabs and broiled outdoors over coals. The big three we see most often in the market are swordfish, tunafish and tilefish. To a lesser extent, there is mako shark. Their steaks, like those of the other three, can be marinated in olive oil and herbs, grilled and served with lemon juice. Mako shark is sometimes sold as swordfish, but its flesh is darker and not as delicate. Whole swordfish steaks can be distinguished from mako shark steaks by their dark fatty spots and a firmer textured flesh.

title: PLAYING SAFE WITH INSURANCE
description: S everal important innovations have recently been added to comprehensive insurance for travelers - the policies that are usually sold through travel agencies - but before you rush to sign up, it is important to understand that they all are limited in scope and have many exclusions. Unless you thoroughly understand the various offerings and their options, it is easy to buy too much or too little or to think you are covered for what you are not.

title: AS THE AUTHOR GROWS UP
description: Much has been written about the trials and tribulations of the young author, and it is frequently assumed that once a writer has made a name for himself, his worst problems are over. Indeed, we like to think of the archetypal literary career as forming a pleasing curve: Earnest apprenticeship gives way to the rich productions of middle age, which in turn nurture the achievements of the mature artist. Yet if this description fits those careers which have not ended in self-destruction (our other favorite model), it also needs some further elaboration. Talking with established writers, one realizes that the difficulties they face, though perhaps less poignant than those of obscurity, can be every bit as daunting.

title: Millicent Fenwick's Candidacy
description: William Geist's incisive and inspiring article, ''Millicent Fenwick: Marching to Her Own Drum''(June 27), does justice to a remarkable woman and restores a fragment of my faith in my Government.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: KEY POLITICAL RACES ARE SHAPING UP AFTER DISTRICT SHIFTS
description: FINALLY approved by the Justice Department, the courts and the State Legislature, the reapportionment of Congressional and legislative districts on Long Island has set the stage for a halfdozen significant elections in the two counties.

title: Alice O'Donnell, Michael Gee Wed
description: The marriage of Alice Irene O'Donnell, an associate producer of ''Evening Magazine'' at WBZ-TV in Boston, to John Michael Gee, sports editor of The Boston Phoenix, a weekly newspaper, took place yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Neilson, assisted by the Rev. John Haynes.

title: Versailles
description: To the Editor: I am afraid I must disagree most emphatically with Leonard Silk, the author of ''Versailles Journal: La Gloire'' (Travel, June 27). Versailles is definitely not a city to live in.

title: BETH DANIEL LEADS OPEN BY 1
description: Beth Daniel took the lead by one shot over JoAnne Carner today after the third round of the 37th annual United States Women's Open.

title: CAR-INSPECTION LINES ARE LONG AGAIN
description: LONG lines have become the rule again at the state's 55 motorvehicle inspection stations because of a decision to close the stations on Saturdays.

title: FLORIDA WILDLIFE HURT BY PROGRESS
description: In 1906 Gov. Napoleon Broward sent a giant dredger into the Everglades to gouge canals into the state's great swamp, beginning one of history's major land reclamation attempts. Today the Everglades is criss-crossed by an awesome network of dikes, canals, pumps, spillways and levees designed to provide drinking water for coastal cities in times of drought and to store flood waters in times of abundant rainfall.

title: NUCLEAR WASTE ISSUE SPLITS STATE AND U.S. OFFICIALS
description: Seven miles east of the confluence of the Colorado and Green Rivers in ruggedly handsome southeastern Utah, early inhabitants found the dryness of the red earth ideal for long-term storage of wheat and other valuables. Because the land is so dry, a new generation may use it for storage, not for valuables but for things no one wants.

title: More Advice Available On Divorce Mediation
description: Thank you for a most interesting and provocative piece on divorce mediation (''Mediation, a New Way to Divorce,'' June 27). I would like to offer a few additional points which may further clarify the emergence of mediation in the Greater New York area.

title: ALLIES ASK, IF CARTER WAS BAD, IS REAGAN WORSE?
description: After their testy relations with President Carter, European leaders who thought President Reagan would lead the alliance to a smoother course have been startled into anger and distress. Tensions have been growing since Mr. Reagan's European trip last month, all the more harshly because both sides thought they had achieved understandings. In irritation, they began to accuse each other of not wanting to understand for selfish national reasons.

title: TENNIS STARS TO VIE IN ESSEX
description: SOUTH ORANGE ''IT'S a kind of different tournament; it's got variety.'' So said a veteran member of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club last week as he bought tickets for the $125,000 Mutual Life Open, a professional tournament that has been contested in New Jersey for the last 12 years.

title: AMON G. CARTER JR., 62, PUBLISHER OF FORT WORTH NEWSPAPER, IS DEAD
description: Amon Giles Carter Jr., publisher of The Fort Worth Star-Telegram and a prominent business and civic leader in Fort Worth, died yesterday in Dallas of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title:
ART;
BARBIZON IN OLD LYME
description: OLD LYME AT the Lyme Historical Society until Aug. 29 is a substantial and interesting exhibition entitled ''Old Lyme, The American Barbizon.'' Some of the 60 works of art in the show are very beautiful, while others are the faintly comic artifacts of the taste of another era. But taken together in this exhibition they record a significant episode in the history of American art.

title: Amy Bonnett Shatz Wed To Dr. Lewis R. Sudarsky
description: Amy Bonnett Shatz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burton Shatz of St. Louis, was married July 17 in Brookline, Mass., to Dr. Lewis Richard Sudarsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Sudarsky of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Frank M. Waldorf performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

title: EARNING SERGEANT'S STRIPES FOR A MOVIE ROLE
description: There is a new D.I., or drill instructor, on the movie scene. He is as mean and tough as Jack Webb was in the 1957 film ''The D.I.'' He is foulmouthed, abusive, insulting, and calls his young recruits ''queers'' and ''eggheads'' and ''dummies.'' He even carries a swagger stick, on which he has carved a notch for each naval aviation officer candidate who has D.O.R.'d (dropped out on request) from the 13 weeks of intensive training that he administers in Port Rainier, Wash. Yet underneath the fastidious Marine Corps exterior of drill instructor Sergeant Foley, as played by Louis Gossett Jr. in the new film, ''An Officer and a Gentleman,'' opening Wednesday at the Astor Plaza, there beats a paternal, caring heart. By the end of the training, Sergeant Foley has become a father figure to the young officer candidates who have survived the grueling 13 weeks.

title: RX FOR AN AILING STATE UTILITY
description: WHAT do you do with a major utility company that provides electricity to 715,000 New Jersey customers and cannot pay its own bills?

title: EIGHT-YEAR 'LITANY OF MISMANGAGEMENT'
description: IAM a Republican. But more than that, much more, I am a Connecticut c itizen and taxpayer. I am a political leader. But more than that, m uch more, I am a breadwinner who, like you, pays the freight to run s tate government.

title: Forrest D. Voss Weds Christine Pate Burins
description: Christine Pate Burins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent W. Burins of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Forrest Denney Voss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest W. Voss of Houston. The Rev. John M. Taylor performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal church.

title: IT WILL HELP SAVE OUR AUTO INDUSTRY
description: Should Congress Put a 'Made in U.S.A.' Stamp on Imported Cars? Malcolm Baldrige and Douglas A. Fraser have often locked horns over issues of trade and industry. Again, the Commerce Secretary and president of the United Auto Workers union are at odds, this time over proposed legislation that would, in effect, require major foreign-car companies such as Toyota, Nissan and Volkswagen, to make most of the vehicles for the American market in this country.

title: 'MOLLY' DOESN'T MEASURE UP
description: NEW HAVEN ''BUTLEY'' and ''Otherwise Engaged'' by the English playwright, Simon Gray, have found favor over here, but no one has quite known what to make of ''Molly.'' Mr. Gray wrote it as a BBC Television play early in his career, and then revised it for the London stage.

title: Cab Driver Slain by Passenger In Upper Manhattan Dispute
description: A gypsy-cab driver was fatally shot yesterday afternoon in a dispute with a passenger near High Bridge Park in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: Old Wounds Still Bleeding
description: Forget? Fat chance. After asserting deadpan that they bore no grudges against the Federal Bureau of Investigation, members of a special Senate committee last week proceeded repeatedly to portray the agency's Abscam political corruption inquiry as uncontrolled persecution.

title: 'GREASE' LIGHTENING DOESN'T STRIKE TWICE
description: WANTAGH WHENEVER Sandy Dumbrowski or Betty Rizzo or Roger and Jan just stand there and sing, microphones in hand, the Jones Beach Theater production of ''Grease'' is on safe terrain.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHIC VIEW;
VIEWS OF THE MAYAN WORLD
description: The main feature of the Brooklyn Museum's exhibition ''Discovering the Maya'' is a group of photographs taken in the 1880's mostly by a well-to-do English archeologist named A.P. Maudslay. But the exhibition also includes two wash drawings done in 1843 by Frederick Catherwood, a painter who accompanied John Lloyd Stephens in the early 1840's on his pioneering expeditions to Central America and the Yucatan to study the ancient ruins of the Maya Indians. And one of Catherwood's drawings is of precisely the same subject as a photograph taken for Maudslay by a photographer named H.N. Sweet.

title: Foundation Is Formed For Assassin Victims
description: President Reagan has announced the formation of a foundation named for James S. Brady, the wounded White House press secretary, and dedicated to helping other unintended victims of assassination attempts.

title: COLLEGE RISES
description: The College of Insurance, which now has its classrooms scattered about the city in rented offices and borrowed rooms, is building a home of its own in Lower Manhattan, just north of the World Trade Center.

title: WORKERS REMOVE THE TIP OF CRANE BOOM
description: The tip of a construction crane boom that had been lashed to the side of a mid-Manhattan skyscraper since Thursday was removed yesterday.

title: OLYMPIA: SACRED WOOD OF THE GAMES
description: PETER LEVI is a poet and classical scholar at Oxford and the author of ''The Hill of Kronos,'' among other works. By PETER LEVI

title: Around the World; Japan Objects to Ban On Commercial Whaling
description: Japanese officials today protested the decision by the International Whaling Commission to end all commercial whaling in three years.

title: Of Nerve Gas, MX and Three Martini Lunches
description: Some of his colleagues ''may feel something has gone haywire,'' Representative Samuel S. Stratton, the strongly pro-Pentagon New York Democrat, conceded last week. But no ''damage'' to ''major programs,'' Mr. Stratton went on to insist, would be done by cutting the Armed Services Committee's recommendation for 1983 military spending by $3.2 billion, thus hitting the $177.1 billion target set by Congress's first budget resolution for 1983. And so voted the House. An air of unreality hung in the Senate chamber as well. There, almost to the day from approval of the Reagan Administration's three-year $435 billion tax cut - benefiting mostly business and the well-to-do -the Senators debated and then passed a three-year $99 billion tax increase - to be paid, mostly, by business and the wellto-do. It too was mandated by that budget resolution that was designed to hold the deficit somewhere near $100 billion.

title: Lincoln Kirstein And the Dance
description: I found it disconcerting to learn that one of our most valuable living Americans, who believes in a fundamental tenet, ''We teach the kids good manners,'' can nonetheless, just a few paragraphs later, desert a lunch table shared with one of his oldest friends, and offer only as an explanation: ''Because you bore me.''

title: Around the Nation; Colorado Prison Secured After 2 Days of Rioting
description: About three dozen convicts were transferred to more secure facilities today and more than 400 others were locked in their dormitories after two days of rioting at the Federal Correctional Institution south of Denver.

title: PORTIONS ARE SMALL, BUT TASTY
description: NORWALK IN an era of excessive hype, it is refreshing to come upon a restaurant that bills itself as A Little Something. Such modesty is apparent in the interior decor as well: a small room seating a mere 36, with the small kitchen open to view. There are white walls and a high ceiling with exposed wood beams on which two stuffed owls are perched. Legacies of a previous owner, the waitress explains.

title: IS RECOVERY AROUND THE NEXT CORNER?
description: A few days before he resigned as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum discussed the Reagan Administration's midyear economic review - twice postponed and now due out this week - with a reporter. Even in advance, it was known that the White House would offer an optimistic economic forecast, as it has invariably done under other Presidents. Would he, Mr. Weidenbaum was asked, make an equally optimistic forecast if the client were someone other than the President? No, he said, he would not - and he added with emphasis, he had taken pains to make sure that Mr. Reagan knew as much.

title: Without Solidarity, East or West
description: There's predictable news from Poland: General Jaruzelski is not about to let Solidarity come back to life. He is consolidating his martial-law regime, easing up slightly in ways that only prove his control, keeping Lech Walesa and the most troublesome rebels under arrest and releasing only those whom he expects to stay docile. The Pope has been disinvited and told to apply again next year, by which time martial law might reign under a different name. The general blames Ronald Reagan for the slow pace of the normalization; hostility and sanctions only prolong the rule of the gun.

title: NOTEBOOK: A DAY AT A CONVENTION
description: HARTFORD ELEVEN candidates wanted to be Secretary of the State, and with a nominating speech and two seconding speeches for each, it was a long ordeal for the 1,300 delegates at the Democratic State Convention at the Bushnell Memorial Auditorium last Saturday.

title: GLASS WORKS: 'NEW' MEDIUM GAINS
description: KATONAH AS a medium for artifacts, glass is at least as old as ancient Egypt and, in its natural form, obsidian, as old as man himself. Pre-Columbian cultures made small sculptures out of obsidian as well as knives and mirrors but art made of synthetic glass is a relatively new development and one made possible by the proliferation of glassblowing programs in university art departments.

title: AMERICAN TOWNS
description: SPECIAL PLACES In Search of Small Town America. By Berton Roueche. Introduction by William Shawn. 219 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $12.95.

title: ISRAELIS SAY JETS AGAIN DESTROYED SYRIANS' MISSILES
description: Israeli jets destroyed Syrian surface-to-air missiles in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon today and lost one Phantom to Syrian fire, an Israeli military spokesman announced.

title: Tonopah
description: To the Editor: I was glad to read ''Tonopah - Survivor of Mining Days'' (Travel, June 20) some 40 years after my first sight of it while serving on the air base just over the pass where B-24 bomber crews were trained.

title: Philip Shorin, 85, a Founder Of Topps Gum Concern, Dies
description: Philip Shorin, who with his three brothers founded Topps Chewing Gum Inc. of Brooklyn, died yesterday at Bal Harbour, Fla., where he had a retirement home. He was 85 years old.

title: Fighting Male Infertility
description: I enjoyed reading Katherine Bouton's overview of male infertility (''Fighting Male Infertility,'' June 13). As she points out, the whole issue of how often varicocele causes infertility is still being debated.

title: Smith Just Fine After Inspection
description: Attorney General William French Smith was certified as 99 percent clean last week. Solicitor General Rex E. Lee, announcing the results of a two-part inquiry, said there was no need to ask for an independent special prosecutor to look into a $50,000 severance payment Mr. Smith received from a California steel firm two weeks before joining the Reagan Cabinet.

title: SENATOR HATCH TO THE AID OF 'STUPID' MAJORITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Burns Married To Richard J. Zavoluk
description: Mary Ellen Burns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Burns of Marysville, Mich., was married yesterday to Richard J. Zavoluk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael O. Zavoluk of Queens Village, Queens. The Rev. Joseph T. Holcomb performed the ceremony in St. Catherine of Sienna Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: ROCK: CHRIS D'S FLESH EATERS
description: Chris D, whose band, the Flesh Eaters, made its New York debut Thursday at the Peppermint Lounge, was an early writer for Slash, the Los Angeles punk-rock fan magazine. The Flesh Eaters were originally a part-time project; Chris D would put together bands drawn from the Los Angeles punk community to perform his original songs on records and in occasional club appearances.

title: U.S. AND MARSHALL ISLANDS SPLIT ON A PLEBISCITE
description: Negotiations with the Marshall Islands over their political status have collapsed in a dispute over the terms for a plebiscite, according to Anton A. de Brum, the Secretary for Foreign Affairs of the island government.

title: REAGAN PHONE CALLS SPURNED
description: A 76-year-old man whom President Reagan was trying to call hung up more than six times on him Friday, convinced that the caller was a crank.

title: FREEWHEELING LIBERTARIANS BID FOR POWER IN ALASKA
description: Here on the northwest corner of North America, the Libertarian party has mounted a credible effort to secure a foothold in the nation's political process.

title: FOOD AND DRUG AGENCY SAYS SOME RISK MUST BE ACCEPTED
description: In an Administration committed to deregulation, a regulatory agency charged with protecting people's health will almost certainly anger some of the people most of the time. That agency is the Food and Drug Administration. Earlier this month, it prohibited the sale of starch blockers saying these purported diet aids are new drugs requiring Federal approval. Now the agency is defending itself in court against 19 manufacturers who claim the products are foods made from beans, not drugs. Last month, the agency began working on labels for aspirin, which has been linked to Reye's syndrome, a children's disease that sometimes follows influenza or chicken pox treated with aspirin. Consumer advocates, however, say agency action is too slow in coming. They said that again last week as they asked the F.D.A. to ban benoxaprofen, a new arthritis treatment, because the drug has been associated with deaths in Britain and the United States. Guiding the agency through this minefield is its commissioner, Dr. Arthur Hull Hayes Jr., who discussed F.D.A. regulatory activities with Michael deCourcy Hinds, a reporter in The New York Times's Washington bureau. Excerpts follow.

title:
ART;
DIVERTING PRINTS, JUNGLE VIGNETTES
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON THE last couple of years have seen the opening of several East End branches of New York galleries - a hopeful sign that the market for contemporary art does not take a universal holiday when its supporters leave Manhattan. One of the most upbeat showcases, established here last year, is the Sara Y. Rentschler Gallery, now in larger quarters - the former home of the ARF Thrift Shop - just off Main Street.

title: 'AIN'T MISBBEHAVIN'' A PROPER SUCCESS
description: ELMSFORD JUST a few months after ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' closed on Broadway, a reproduction of the Fats Waller minimusical with the original company was shown on television, and the show seems to be popping up on summer stages everywhere.

title: A BLOCK OF NEW SHOPS ON COLUMBUS
description: The latest West Side story is a shopping story, and the setting is one block on Columbus Avenue from 81st to 82d Street. In the background is the Endicott, a former single-room-occupancy hotel that was transformed into a cooperative apartment building. On its streetlevel is a row of shops with a unified architectural theme, and across the street new boutiques are opening.

title: ARE WE READY FOR COMPUTER OPERAS?
description: I hope I am not being disloyal to my own culture when I confess that I do not understand the appeal of electronic games. I remain unmoved by the sight of one Pac person consuming another. The notion of tiny planets bustling about pretending to destroy other tiny planets fails to stir my competitive juices. And playing hockey or soccer on a small screen strikes me as something less than an athlete's feat. To put it plainly: computerized games strike me as the modern young wastrel's equivalent to hanging around the corner pool room or pitching pennies until all hours under the street lights.

title: WHEN DEVELOPMENT AND LANDMARKING CONFLICT
description: ON the waterfront of the Whitestone section of Queens, in the very s hadow of the Throgs Neck Bridge, sits a handsome Tudor house behind a large parking lot. It is occupied by a catering establishment c alled Ripples.

title: O.A.U. CONFERENCE FACES MAJOR SPLIT
description: The Organization of African Unity begins preparations for its annual summit meeting next week, contemplating a past year of division and ineffectiveness that threaten its survival as the spokesman for a continent.

title:
ANTIQUES;
OLD SILVER KEEPS ITS LUSTER
description: HADDAM ''THE antiques silver market today is just where it should be - and where, as a matter of fact, it always has been, really, for true collectors,'' Malcolm Stearns Jr., the country's leading dealer in Georgian silver, said last week.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
A PLAY THAT SPOOFS THE ART WORLD
description: SOUTHAMPTON WITH a Ph.D. in cybernetics and another advanced degree from the London School of Economics, Robert Bell does not seem a likely candidate to write a comedy about the art world. But he is and he has: ''Let's Be Famous,'' which is in its world premiere run at Southampton College as part of a new East End Playwrights Series, which is devoted to uncovering and producing works by local playwrights.

title: EXODUS OF THE SUPPLY SIDERS
description: WASHINGTON THE newsletter sent out this month by the Council for a Competitive Economy, a libertarian business organization in Washington, was unequivocal. ''It is saddening and bodes ill that the cream of Mr. Reagan's Administration is leaving or has already left,'' the publication mourned. The roll call of Presidential advisers who have left, the editor hinted, is a clue that the Administration ''is simply another disappointing detour on our road to serfdom.''

title: UNDER ISRAELIS, LEBANESE CHRISTIANS WIDEN HOLD
description: The Armenian Hospital in the village of Azzuniye looms over the forward Israeli positions south of the Beirut-Damascus highway.

title: BAKER'S DAUGHTER RUNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Cynthia Baker, the 26-year-old daughter of the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., had just joined a small crowd of friendly Republicans gathered under the picnic shelter at the Stinking Creek Heritage Field in this tiny, isolated mountain community in northeastern Tennessee.

title: Inheriting Alcoholism
description: Children of alcoholics are particularly prone to be problem drinkers. The risk for them, researchers say, is four times higher than for the rest of the population and family agencies believe that between 40 and 90 percent of their caseload involves these children.

title: SUMMERTIME TIME FOR BROILING THOSE BIG FISH
description: IN the summer, big fish are especially good eaten as steaks or kebabs and broiled outdoors over coals. The big three we see most often in the market are swordfish, tunafish and tilefish. To a lesser extent, there is mako shark. Their steaks, like those of the other three, can be marinated in olive oil and herbs, grilled and served with lemon juice. Mako shark is sometimes sold as swordfish, but its flesh is darker and not as delicate. Whole swordfish steaks can be distinguished from mako shark steaks by their dark fatty spots and a firmer textured flesh.

title: CITY STUDIES HOME RELIEF RECIPIENTS
description: About half of New York City's Home Relief recipients have had some work experience, a new study shows. Of those people, 34 percent were employable and available for work, but had been out of work for about four and a half years.

title: Delos
description: To the Editor: The rundown on the Cyclades, ''Islands in a Wine-Dark Sea'' (Travel, June 20), brought back pleasant memories of a night spent on Delos, the uninhabited island near Mykonos that is said to be the birthplace of Apollo. v. ith a friend from Dublin, we set out from Mykonos on one of the small craft that one can hire complete with crew.

title: CHINA STEWART WED TO JAMES M. MEIER
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday China Eliane Stewart, daughter of Mrs. William H. Osborn Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., and James Stewart of New York, was married to James Michael Meier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Meier of La Habra, Calif. The Rev. Robert G. Brandt performed the ceremony.

title: FREEZE ISSUE REVIVES TACTICS OF THE 50'S
description: BRACE yourself. We seem to be in for another barrage of what used to be called McCarthyism, back in the frightened 50's. This time it is aimed at the paramount issue of our lives -the worldwide movement for nuclear disarmament.

title: IS THE VIRTUOSO A VANISHING SPECIES?
description: Our age distrusts flamboyant virtuosity or highly emotive self-expression of any kind. Yet no artist can have too much technique, and that goes for writers, painters and mathematicians as well as musicians. Moritz Rosenthal was once asked if he was not ashamed of showing off his technique. ''Is Rockefeller ashamed of his millions?'' he answered.

title:
STAMPS;
MANY NEW ISSUES HERALD WORLD CUP SOCCER
description: There was plenty of soccer action in the World Cup competition, which was recently won by Italy, but there was easily as much action on stamps as nation after nation marked the occasion with commemoratives.

title: YANKS WIN ON MUMPHREY HOMER
description: Joe Pepitone, the Yankees' hitting coach, says Jerry Mumphrey is capable of hitting 20 home runs a season. Last night the switchhitter took a small step in that direction when his ninth-inning shot to the right-field upper deck lifted the Yankees to a 6-5 victory over the Angels.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: In regard to the letter from Josephine Thomas (Travel, June 13) concerning the Palace Hotel in San Francisco, the original hotel did not survive the 1906 earthquake and subsequent fire. Badly damaged, the old Palace (designed by William Ralston in 1873) was razed after the fire and the present hotel erected on its site.

title: CANDIDATES WEIGH REMOVAL OF PRISON
description: WEST BRENTWOOD THE conversion of three unused buildings at the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center into Long Island's first state prison has become one of the few issues in this year's gubernatorial campaign on which the four major party candidates agree.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Around the World
description: Guerrilla followers of Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, kidnapped two Americans, two Britons and two Australians on a country road Friday night and reportedly threatened to kill them unless two jailed comrades were freed.

title: SYRIA PRESSES U.S. ON WIDE MIDEAST ISSUE
description: Syria is waiting for a firm commitment from the United States that it is ready to seek a comprehensive solution to the Middle East problem, Syrian sources said today.

title: Teaching and Treating Autistic Children
description: The many recent letters to the editor responding to a teacher's expression of futility in educating autistic pupils indicates how painful this disturbance is to all affected by it. But, though offering sharply divided opinions, all correspondents confuse education with treatment.

title: Ouster of Kenyan Protested
description: The Kenya Union of Journalists today protested the dismissal of George Githii, editor in chief of the Standard, and said the move was aimed at safeguarding local commercial interests of Lonrho, a London-based group that publishes the newspaper. Mr. Githii was dismissed Wednesday after he had written an editorial criticizing detention without trial in Kenya.

title: WHERE PLAYS ARE BORN AND TRIED IN TRANQUILITY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Don Shewey writes frequently about the theater. By DON SHEWEY

title:
DINING OUT;
A BIG TURNABOUT IN MORRIS COUNTY
description: IT IS always good news when a restaurant improves to the point of deserving a higher rating. In the case of Silver Spring Farm in Flanders, it is doubly good because the restaurant is moving from a Fair rating in 1978 up to two stars.

title: Susan Lewis To Be Bride
description: Susan Denise Lewis, an associate with the New York law firm of Brown, Wood, Ivey, Mitchell & Petty, plans to be married Sept. 6 to Dr. Scott Evan Brodie, a resident in ophthalmology at New York Hospital.

title: FOR ISRAELIS, THE TASTE OF VICTORY STARTS TO TURN SOUR
description: JERUSALEM

title: IN CAMP, MIGRANTS WAIT FOR THE SUN AND WORK
description: The migrant workers at Billy Tim's camp had little to do after rain muddied the dusty front yard and rotted peppers in the field. They just waited for work, something state labor officials say has been unusually scarce this year.

title: ALASKA
description: To the Editor: Estelle Parson's "Alaska Diary" (Travel, July 4) recalled to us our visit to Alaska three years ago. We, too, chose stops at Camp Denali in Denali National Park and at Katchemak Bay Wilderness Lodge, near Homer.

title: 'PIRATES' AHOY FOR ALL-OUT FUN
description: MIDDLE ISLAND IN contrast to a feeble but nominally professional production of ''Grease,'' reviewed in this issue, the Island Squire Dinner Theater's staging of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' is unassuming, allout fun on a local community theater level.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
WHITE PLAINS
description: IT first appears to be an ordinary swimming class. Two instructors in sleek tank suits are putting their students through the paces, showing them the proper way to crook an arm, the efficient means of treading water. There are exclamations of sudden understanding, a few frustrated laughs when a point is not well taken.

title: Paul Gustave Chace 3d Marries Sharon Brady
description: Sharon Joy Brady and Paul Gustave Chace 3d were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Watertown, Conn. The Rev. Peter R. Holroyd, chaplain of the Taft School, performed the ceremony

title: Barbara Ruth Boynton Becomes Bride
description: At the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday Barbara Ruth Boynton, daughter of Mrs. William F. Koegel of Scarsdale and the late Rodney Boynton, was married to William Harold Hinman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hinman of Liverpool, N.Y. The Rev. J. Scottie Griffin performed the ceremony.

title: Around the Nation; Suspect in Jordan Case Asks Transfer to Indiana
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, who is to be tried here next month in the 1980 shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader, has asked to be transferred from a Chicago jail to the county jail in South Bend because of threats to his life.

title:
Economic Affairs;
WHERE DEREGULATION MAKES NO SENSE
description: THE Reagan Administration's persistent attempts to realign the r elationship of the Federal Government with the nursing home industrye xemplify many of the themes the President has put forward as d esirable for this country. These include deregulation of industry, r eduction of government expenditures, shifting Federal functions to t he states and a reliance on private initiative.

title: ANTINUCLEAR PROTEST COST THE CITY $1.8 MILLION
description: The march and rally against nuclear arms in Manhattan on June 12 and an incident of civil disobedience two days later cost New York City more than $1.8 million in overtime pay for its workers, according to budget officials.

title: City's Ward Has No Voters
description: About 500 people live in a newly created voting ward of Adams County, but no one votes.

title: THE LEVYS AND THE MACBETHS
description: Jean Zorn is a freelance critic who both teaches and practices law. RIVINGTON STREET By Meredith Tax. 431 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.50. KING HEREAFTER By Dorothy Dunnett. 72l pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. By JEAN ZORN

title: Service Set for Meese's Son
description: A memorial service will be held at 3 P.M. Monday at the Emmanuel Lutheran Church in Vienna, Va., for Scott R. Meese, the 19-year-old son of Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan. The youth was killed Thursday night when his car swerved off the road and struck a tree.

title: FUND HONORS 12 FOR BRAVERY
description: The Carnegie Hero Fund Commission on has honored 11 Americans and one Canadian, including three posthumously, for risking their lives to save others.

title: Death in Taipei
description: A man was dead in Taiwan, and the official explanations appeared doubtful. Wen-chen Chen, a 31-year-old assistant professor of statistics at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, was in Taipei with his wife and year-old son to visit relatives when security officers picked him up on July 2, 1981, to question him about charges of anti-Government activity.

title: Around the World; Thousands Aiding Police In London Bomb Cases
description: Police officials investigating Tuesday's bombings here, believed to be the work of Irish nationalists, reported today they had received 2,500 offers of assistance in response to appeals for help.

title: WHITNEY FOUNDATION, SCALING BACK, MAY BE SHUT
description: The 36-year-old John Hay Whitney Foundation has radically scaled back its philanthropy since its founder's death in February, and its officials say they may eventually decide to close down.

title: HYPNOTISTS SAY MORE MINDS ACCEPT THE MATTER
description: While the sleepy business of a summer Sunday went by outside on Madison Avenue yesterday, members of the World Congress of Professional Hypnotists meeting at the Roosevelt Hotel talked quietly of regression, color energy, liability insurance and other topics peculiar to their craft.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Next Stop, 273 Bleecker S eventy-six trombones would have been a cinch, even on a 92-degree day, compared with the 150 guitars, banjos and mandolins that Matt Umanov and his friends carried across Bleecker Street yesterday.

title: Ogilvy Is Expanding Public Relations Unit
description: Showing its seriousness about becoming a factor in the public relations field, Ogilvy & Mather has opened offices for its O.& M. Public Relations in Chicago, where Roy Wiley will be head man, and in San Francisco, where it will be Michael Dunstan's show.

title: Actor Denies Taking Drugs With Belushi
description: The actor Robin Williams says John Belushi took no drugs while he was with him the night before Mr. Belushi died of a drug overdose, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: PADRES EDGE METS, 3-2, IN 10TH
description: For all the reasons that George Bamberger had not to smile, he had to. After all his monologues on the deficiencies of his pitching staff, Bamberger had just seen two of the best pitched games the Mets have produced this year.

title: KUSH WITH THE COLTS: CONTROVERSIAL ARCHITECT OF CHANGE
description: on collisions had made a favorable impression on those in attendance. Weekend bleacherites elbowed one another knowingly and remarked about how good it was to see the Colts being aggressive for a change.

title: HEARNS WINNER IN 8TH
description: Thomas Hearns, the former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, stopped unranked but previously unbeaten Jeff McCracken in the eighth round today to continue his drive toward a middleweight title fight.

title: Susan Duffy Is Married
description: Susan Elizabeth Duffy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Duffy of Vieques, P.R., and New York, was married yesterday to Peter Michael Lariviere, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Emile Lariviere of South Hadley Falls, Mass. The Rev. Orland Brugnola performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: PAPERS REVEAL SAKHAROV'S WIDE INSIGHT ON SCIENCE
description: Although in the public mind Andrei D. Sakharov is chiefly associated with his fight for human rights in the Soviet Union and his exile to the town of Gorky, his scientific writings have now been assembled to demonstrate the extraordinary degree to which his work has anticipated recent developments in physics.

title: GANNETT COLLECTS STAFF FOR NEWSPAPER
description: For the last several months the Gannett Company has been assembling staff members and equipment for a nationally distributed newspaper, USA Today, that it plans to start publishing Sept. 15 in Washington.

title: Glenn's Devotion
description: Mike Glenn hasn't forgotten where he came from. The 6-foot-3-inch guard of the Atlanta Hawks grew up in Rome, Ga., where his father was a mathematics teacher and the basketball coach at the Georgia School for the Deaf. Glenn played with his father's team in practices and easily picked up sign language.

title: REVISION OF AVIATION PACT DUE FOR SENATE DEBATE
description: The Senate is expected to take a brief recess from its budget and tax activities soon to consider an international aviation pact that could have a far-reaching effect on lawsuits prompted by airline crashes.

title: STONES JUST MISSES A NEW JUMP MARK
description: Dwight Stones, the 28-year-old once - and always - flashy high-jumper, and 29-year-old Francie Larrieu Smith gave the 13,238 fans who attended the conclusion of the track and field events a glance at the past in the National Sports Festival today.

title: CITY CARRIAGE HORSES THAT NEED NOT HAVE DIED
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Arrested In Payroll Deaths
description: Brooklyn detectives yesterday arrested one of the men suspected in the killing of two guards during a $40,000 payroll robbery on Thursday in the Bay Ridge section of the borough, the police said.

title: 5 Hijackers Thwarted On a Chinese Airliner
description: Five hijackers were overpowered today when they tried to force the crew of a Chinese airliner to fly from China to Taiwan.

title: News Analysis
description: The continuing case of John W. Hinckley Jr. is approaching his Aug. 9 release hearing in what one Government lawyer called ''a very strange posture,'' awash with ironies in a sea of legal uncertainty.

title: Commodities; Distortions Attract the Arbitrager
description: ARBITRAGE, one of the oldest methods of trading in commodities, is the most important of the random factors that influence prices in all futures markets. It helps keep markets liquid during dull periods and smoothes out the price peaks and valleys when they are volatile.

title: RICHARD NEUTRA'S ARCHITECTURAL MISSION LIVES ON
description: When they became engaged, Richard Neutra gave his fiancee, Dione Niedermann, a typewriter. When they married, she learned to use it. ''I typed from Los Angeles to Buenos Aires,'' Mrs. Neutra said, reminiscing about her 48-year marriage to the restless architect. Her specialty was letters typed frantically in taxis speeding to catch ships and planes.

title: Francis W. McGinley, Regent And Lawyer in Glens Falls, 76
description: Francis W. McGinley, former New York State Regent and a lawyer and civic leader in Glens Falls, N.Y., died Friday in Glens Falls Hospital after a short illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Driving Costs in 1981 Average 34.5 a Mile
description: American motorists spent an average of $2,790 to own and operate their automobiles last year, 6 percent more than in 1980, but the smallest increase since the Arab oil embargo of 1973, according to a study released today.

title: CHAIRMAN APPOINTED AT COMMUTER AIRCRAFT
description: David Tod, 56, a former partner at the Prescott, Ball & Turben brokerage firm, has been named chairman of the Commuter Aircraft Corporation, a company in Youngstown, Ohio, that plans to manufacture the CAC-100, a 50-seat, four-engine airliner for commuter airlines. He was already a director and an investor in the company.

title: PHONE FEE RISE CALLED ATTEMPT TO AID A.T.&T.
description: Officials of New York City and State said yesterday that $200 million of a $878 million rate increase sought by the New York Telephone Company would go for projects the utility might never use because an antitrust settlement could turn them over to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Washington Watch; Trying to Trim The F.C.C.
