description: WASHINGTON IF the Senate Commerce Committee gets its way, the Federal Communications Commission will be trimmed from seven members to five. The bill has passed the committee and is heading for the Senate floor.

title: NEW YORK TRYING TO ADD SHELTERS FOR ITS HOMELESS
description: New York City is asking private, nonprofit organizations to supplement the city's shelter system for the homeless, and has offered for the first time to pay such groups for some expenses.

title: FILLING THE VACUUM
description: Margaret Thatcher's dominance of the British political scene these days is due in part to the absence of a convincing alternative. The Labor Party is gripped by a passion for selfdestruction. If there is to be a real challenge to the Conservatives at an election in the next year or so, it will have to come from the Alliance of the Liberals and the new Social Democratic Party.

title: SOUTHAMPTON SUMMER NIGHT
description: There are a lot of things that can be and are said about the peripatetic group of affluent people who winter in New York, summer in the Hamptons and drop in on Palm Beach, Saratoga, Newport and Washington parties as casually as most people visit a supermarket.

title: CITY CARRIAGE HORSES THAT NEED NOT HAVE DIED
description: To the Editor It was with a sense of horror and outrage that I read about three carriage horses dying of the heat. To my mind, there are few New York City sights more depressing than those sad, old, sick horses lined up along Central Park South in freezing rain or blazing heat.

title: News Analysis
description: The New Jersey Legislature has officially disbanded for its summer break, three weeks late and $185 million short of passing all the programs both parties wanted. And already a host of unresolved problems are threatening to upset vacation plans.

title: The Juke Family
description: It's not entirely clear to us how a machine that played records if you fed it change got to be called a jukebox -juke being a West African word for wicked. There was nothing wicked about what we listened to.

title: PROBLEMS FOR MITSUI, JAPAN'S TRADE GIANT
description: For Mitsui & Company, the trading giant that traces its history back more than 300 years, these are not happy times. In recent years, it has been scarred by heavy exposure in Iran. Last Wednesday, it pleaded guilty and agreed to pay $11 million in penalties for selling steel at below allowable prices in the United States. It still faces challenges to its basic operating structure, which was set up after World War II.

title: John's Gold Wins Jamaica
description: The Jamaica Handicap at Belmont Park lost much of its appeal yesterday when Star Gallant, the 2-1 morning-line favorite, came down with a high temperature in the morning and was scratched. As a result, John's Gold, the only other early speed specialist in the field of five, was bet down to 4-5 and galloped to a 9 3/4-length victory.

title: Net Up 3.1% At McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported over the weekend that its net income increased 3.1 percent, to $49.8 million, or $1.27 a share, in the second quarter, from $48.3 million, or $1.21, a year earlier.

title: WRONG ROAD IN ULSTER
description: ''I long for the time when I can go to the United States and say: 'Look at what we have accomplished. We've got political stability and put some money in.' '' This is what James Prior, Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, told a London newspaper in February. Mr. Prior has now carried this message to the United States. But is political stability any closer in Northern Ireland? Mr. Prior inherited a tense security problem arising from the Irish Republican Army hunger strike, but he ended it successfully. There followed in November 1981 the assassination of the Rev. Robert Bradford, an Ulster Protestant member of the British Parliament, by the outlawed Provisional I.R.A. In retaliation the Rev. Ian Paisley formed a ''Third Force,'' an unofficial militia of hard-line Protestants. Once again civil war became a real possibility in Ulster. But Mr. Prior proved unflappable and decisive in defusing a dangerous situation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Right now, it is just pot luck.'' -Denise Figueroa on bus service for the handicapped. (B1:5.)

title: U.S. WOMEN TAKE 7TH FEDERATION CUP
description: Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd continued the United States' dominance of the Federation Cup today when they swept singles matches against West Germany to give the United States its seventh straight triumph.

title: Fund Prepares Salute To Vietnam Veterans
description: Vietnam veterans from around the nation are being urged to come to Washington in November for the welcomehome they never got.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE CROCODILE MAN. A Case of Brain Chemistry and Violence. By Andre Mayer and Michael Wheeler. 204 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $12.95.

title: Cockfield Brown Buys McConnell Advertising
description: North of the border last week, the big advertising news was acquisition news as Cockfield Brown, part of the Canadian agency scene since 1928, acquired - for cash - the more venerable McConnell Advertising, 79 years old.

title: EARNINGS PATTERN IS MIXED
description: Corporate profit reports for this year's second quarter indicate that the recession is still choking many of America's key industries, although the figures do show some pockets of strength in the United States economy.

title: ANGELS BEAT YANKEES, 6-4
description: Graig Nettles cost his team two runs in the field yesterday and failed to produce in a bases-loaded situation in the eighth inning as the Yankees lost, 6-4, to the California Angels.

title: 2 Mild Quakes Felt in Japan As Series of Tremors Goes On
description: Two earthquakes, the latest of more than a dozen mild tremors over the last three days, were felt in eastern Japan today, the Central Meteorological Agency reported. Initial reports did not indicate damage or injuries.

title: Arnoux Takes French Prix
description: Rene Arnoux of France, disobeying orders to let his teammate, Alain Prost, take the lead, won the French Grand Prix auto race today.

title: Cuba Issue and Namibia Separate, Angola Says
description: The Angolan authorities have again rejected Western proposals to link the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers to a pullout of South African forces from neighboring South-West Africa, the Angolan press agency reported today.

title: EMPLOYMENT AGENCIES SUFFER AS JOBS THEY CAN OFFER DROP
description: Benson Employment Inc., a small New York agency, is having no problem attracting job seekers, unemployment being what it is. Its problem, with fewer jobs than ever to offer its applicants, is that its commissions are tumbling, its profits are sliding and, in January, it had to let go one of its counselors - one-quarter of its entire staff.

title: LUCILLE PARKER MARKEY, 85, CALUMET FARM OWNER, DIES
description: Lucille Parker Markey, an owner of Calumet Farm who had long been synonymous with excellence in thoroughbred racing, died early yesterday morning of bronchial pneumonia in Miami. She was 85 years old and had been in poor health since suffering a stroke in 1977.

title: COSMOS WIN, 2-1, IN OVERTIME
description: The Cosmos had another close encounter tonight but emerged winners again after a goal by Steve Hunt in sudden-death overtime.

title: OILFIELD SLEUTH'S JOB: NOVEL, AT TIMES
description: Detectives, at least those depicted by various two-fisted prose stylists, have always regarded brevity as the soul of wit. And so, when David Ward pulled his black Audi 5000 off the highway between Childress and Quanah near the base of the Texas Panhandle not long ago, he succinctly described the oilfield chicanery of a suspected thief he was investigating.

title: Auditors Say Engineers Fail To Seek Lowest Rental Prices
description: The Army Corps of Engineers is failing to seek the lowest prices on the 13.5 million square feet of space it rents each year for Defense Department agencies, Congressional auditors say.

title: Masonite Plans Partial Sell-Off
description: The Masonite Corporation, the nation's largest producer of hardboard, announced yesterday that its board had approved a plan of partial liquidation of the company subject to certain conditions and approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Miss McElligott Bride of Lawyer
description: Christine Regina McElligott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McElligott of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Howard Kaufman, son of Mrs. Oscar Kaufman of East Rockaway, L.I., and the late Mr. Kaufman. The ceremony was performed in the Church Center for the United Nations by the Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest and professor of English at Bernard M. Baruch College, and by Rabbi Charles Lippman of New York.

title: Invasion a Surprise, Mrs. Thatcher Asserts
description: The invasion of the Falkland Islands by Argentina came from ''out of the blue'' and utterly amazed both British leaders and President Reagan, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said in an interview published today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In the Spirit of Friendship L ocal entrepreneurs have come up with some offbeat news about spirits, the bottled variety. The first report was from the New York company that represents Mount Gay Rum.

title: MUSIC: PARK SONDHEIM
description: ''I'M JUST A BROADWAY BABY'' from Steven Sondheim's ''Follies'' is a song that seems a belted-out recollection of all those older songs about making it on the Great White Way. On Saturday night, a block west of Broadway in Damrosch Park, that and other Sondheim originals were presented by the National Chorale directed by Martin Josman as part of a series of performances from the American musical theater in parks around the city.

title: 74 Are Saved as a Ship Burns Near Manila Bay
description: A tourist ship on a test run without any paying passengers aboard caught fire when an engine exploded Sunday night, a spokesman for the vessel's owner said.

title: POLLUTION FORCES RYE BEACHES TO CLOSE
description: The beaches here were closed today and thousands of bathers were turned away after foaming patches of pollution washed ashore from Long Island Sound Saturday afternoon.

title: Streets Again Shut At Site of Accident
description: Streets below and adjoining the site of the construction crane accident last week were closed to vehicle and pedestrian traffic again yesterday afternoon as a safety measure, the Police Department reported.

title: BUCKET BRIGADE JOINS THE BATTLE OVER ACID RAIN
description: The latest weapon in the Northeast's halting war on acid rain sits on a wooden stake here in Charles Gibson's backyard overlooking Lake Champlain. It is an empty quart-size plastic refrigerator container, the kind used to store leftover pea soup or half a pickle.

title: Briefs on the Arts National Symphony, Musicians Freeze Wages
description: On the heels of the demise of two symphony orchestras this month in Miami and Kansas City, Mo., the National Symphony's musicians have agreed to a one-year moratorium on wage increases. The orchestra, based in Washington, has Mstislav Rostropovich as its music director and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts as its home.

title: AMERICANS AT THE BRINK OF STREET PROTESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 300 NORDIC PROTESTERS MARCH IN SOVIET
description: A group of 300 antinuclear demonstrators from four Nordic countries left Moscow today for rallies in Smolensk and Minsk, some convinced that their tightly organized meetings amd marches had advanced their cause and others exasperated with what they regarded as manipulation by their Soviet hosts.

title: THE P.L.O. AND ISRAEL: A POLICY FOR U.S.
description: It should be the goal of American policy to provide the means for a gradual reconciliation of Israel to the fact of Palestinian nationalism under conditions that will no longer threaten Israel.

title: WALWORTH BARBOUR, DIPLOMAT WHO SERVED 12 YEARS IN ISRAEL
description: Walworth Barbour, who capped a lifetime Foreign Service career with nearly 12 years as the United States Ambassador to Israel from 1961 to 1973, died Wednesday at a hospital near his retirement home in Gloucester, Mass. He was 74 years old.

title: Art of Alexander Era to Be Exhibited
description: A pebble mosaic floor from Pella, the capital of the Macedonian kings in ancient Greece, an enormous bronze volute krater - a vessel for mixing wine and water - and a gold wreath with acorns and oak leaves will be among 180 works of Greek art to be exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum beginning Oct. 27.

title: DISPOSAL COMPANIES IN ACCORD
description: Chem-Nuclear Systems Inc. has agreed to be acquired by Waste Management Inc., the companies announced yesterday. Chem-Nuclear had gone to court to oppose the takeover bid, which was made June 29.

title: U.S. CLOSES UNIT THAT CITED HEALTH EFFECT OF LEAD IN GAS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has dismantled its Division of Environmental Hazards Research, whose director has performed key research on the effects of lead in gasoline on children's health.

title: Padre Disabled
description: Alan Wiggins, an outfielder for the San Diego Padres who was arrested for possession of cocaine last week, was placed on the 21-day disabled list by the team today. He has been in a detoxification center since his arrest last Wednesday.

title: CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: PEOPLE OF LEBANESE VALLEY FEAR RENEWED FIGHTING
description: Although life in the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon appears normal on the surface, there is a growing fear among the population that as soon as the battle for Beirut is settled, fighting will return to the valley.

title: A Shallow Diagnosis of Science Fraud
description: A surprising number of cases of scientific fraud have come to light recently, many at leading medical schools. Perturbed, the Association of American Medical Colleges has issued a report advising medical schools what to do when a faculty researcher is accused of inventing data.

title: NAVY FREES PETTY OFFICER
description: Petty Officer 2d Class Darryl I. Summons was released from custody Saturday after serving eight days of a three-month sentence for maltreating a sailor who died aboard the aircraft carrier Ranger. Rear Adm. Paul T. Gillcrist ordered the release after receiving a clemency request from Mr. Summons, said Comdr. Tom Turman

title: IF THREE CON ED PLANTS BURN COAL INSTEAD OF OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: One More Time
description: The World Cup soccer tournament is played only once every four years, so many passionate fans feel a sense of frustration when the quadrennial competition comes to an end. But the Spanish International Network, which televised all 52 of the games in this year's tournament in Spain, has a bonus in store for its viewers.

title: EXPERTS SPLIT ON FLAWS IN PACTS LIMITING NUCLEAR TESTS
description: Arms control experts agree that the two treaties limiting underground nuclear testing pose verification problems for the United States, but they disagree on whether the risks of Soviet violations are serious enough to require renegotiating sections of the accords.

title: CARDS' UTILITY MAN HERO IN 4-3 VICTORY
description: Mike Ramsey has never been a regular starter in his three years with the St. Louis Cardinals. The 28-year-old utility man, though, has been a valuable substitute at second, shortstop and third when injuries to others have pressed him into service.

title: HINAULT CLOSES FAST IN CAPTURING TOUR
description: Bernard Hinault easily won the Tour de France bicycle race today for the fourth time in five years. The 27-year-old Frenchman answered complaints that he had been riding colorlessly in the world's most prominent bike race by capturing the final leg in a sprinting finish.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the text of a letter by Interior Sec- retary James G. Watt to the Israeli Ambassador to the United States yes- terday two words were omitted. The last sentence of Mr. Watt's letter reads, ''I look forward to opportuni- ties to speak to groups of your support- ers in this nation so that I might share with them the truth of what this Ad- ministration is trying to do for Amer- ica and the free world.''

title: JUNE ORDERS FOR TOOLS ROSE 21% FROM MAY
description: Orders for machine tools rose 21 percent in June from May, but the industry was still severly depressed, with orders running 59.7 percent below the rate in June 1981.

title: STOCKMAN, ON STUMP, HAILS REAGANOMICS
description: When David A. Stockman arrived in Fresno, Calif. the other day to campaign for a Republican Congressman, he was greeted by 100 demonstrators and a 12-foot-high model horse.

title: Royals Set Back Brewers, 6-4
description: On Friday, after losing eight of 10 games on the road, the Kansas City Royals were happy to be returning to Royals Stadium. Yesterday, after they lost two of three games to the Royals, the Milwaukee Brewers were just as happy to be getting out of town.

title: Rossi Accepts Invitation to Play
description: The Italian World Cup star, Paolo Rossi, and two teammates, Dino Zoff and Marco Tardelli, have accepted the invitation to play in the World All-Star Game Aug. 7 at Giants Stadium, the United States Soccer Federation announced yesterday.

title: WHEN LIFE WAS HOT
description: The heat was another presence in those summers. It was like a taciturn relative we accommodated. We moved over a bit and down one at the table, and that was pretty much that. The Royal Theatre was the only air-conditioned building we had ever seen, so we associated it solely with theaters.

title: Patricia Wilde Named By Pittsburgh Ballet
description: Patricia Wilde, director of the American Ballet Theater School in New York, has been appointed artistic director of the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, effective Sept. 1.

title: LOUGANIS EXCELS IN DIVING
description: Greg Louganis took his second victory of the National Sports Festival when he captured the 10-meter platform diving competition today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Austin Co., Cleveland, appointed Andrew E. Carlson group vice president for United States district operations.

title: PRESIDENT OF ZIFF TO LEAVE COMPANY
description: I. Martin Pompadur, 47 years old, will step down as president of the Ziff Corporation on July 31, Ziff has announced. Mr. Pompadur has made a preliminary deal for the purchase of four of Ziff's six television stations.

title: ISRAEL TELLS SYRIA NOT TO INTRODUCE NEW ARMS IN FIGHT
description: Israel warned Syria today against introducing new weapons into the fighting in Lebanon. The Cabinet Secretary, Dan Meridor, said after the weekly meeting of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his ministers that he hoped menacing words published Saturday by Sana, the official Syrian news agency, were ''nothing more than words.'' The report had threatened Israel with weapons not yet used in the war.

title: CONGRESSIONAL PAGES: A PROPHECY
description: The year was 1966. The subject was the lack of supervision of Congressional pages. William L. Springer, at the time a Republican Congressman from Illinois, voiced his concern over the page system in a chapter of a book compiled by a House Republican Task Force. What he wrote proved more prophetic than he might ever have dreamed, given the recent allegations of possible misconduct involving members of Congress and largely unsupervised pages.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Not Sold on a Saltcellar I t would have been one giant saltshaker: a 54-foot-high dome at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens in which the Sanitation Department intended to store salt for snow removal. ''Who wants 54 feet of salt in your park - unless you're making bagels?'' asked Jesse Masyr, Deputy Borough President of Manhattan.

title: TOUGH CAMP AWAITS THE JETS
description: Walt Michaels will sound the warning tonight - perhaps even tell his favorite parable about the sea captain - when the first wave of New York Jets reports to training camp.

title: U.S. Court Denies Bid For Agent Orange Data
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the Government's refusal to release deleted portions of its official history on the use of Agent Orange and other herbicides in the Vietnam War.

title: Telefunken Aid Cleared
description: The way has been cleared for granting AEG-Telefunken, the electrical goods maker, the export guarantees that it needs to solve a cash crisis, the West German Economics Ministry said. In a statement Friday, the ministry said that all remaining questions had been settled with consortium banks for guarantees of up to $248 million, giving the company time to carry out its longer-term recovery plans.

title: A Sun Day in Baseball With Jackson
description: WHEN he stepped into the batting cage with his big black bat, Reggie Jackson was wearing his dark blue Angels' warmup shirt with a small white ''44'' high on the left sleeve. But he doesn't need a big number on his back to be identified, the swagger of his stride is always enough. Especially at Yankee Stadium, where the early arrivals for yesterday's game serenaded him with cheers. Moments later, he responded by smashing a ball that soared up, up and eventually landed among the last rows of blue benches in the right-center bleachers below the scoreboard. His idolators cheered.

title: DIGGING UP GREENWICH VILLAGE
description: Centuries before it became an idea, Greenwich Village was an Indian settlement. Later it became farmland, then a country resort and, eventually, a town.

title: Advertising; Agencies Find Rents A Problem
description: BECAUSE ad agencies are very much an image business, you can find their offices - usually terribly chichi - in only the finest business neighborhoods, usually terribly expensive ones.

title: JERSEY BUS WORKERS SET TO STRIKE
description: About 120 bus drivers, mechanics and cleaners of the De Camp Bus Company were prepared to walk off the job early Monday after efforts to resolve a contract dispute fell through.

title: Hoffa's Son to Ask Court To Declare Father Dead
description: James R. Hoffa vanished seven years ago next Friday, and his son has said that he would file the papers needed to declare the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters legally dead.

title: PEKING AGAIN URGES TAIWAN TO OPEN UNIFICATION TALKS
description: In a fresh peace overture, a prominent Chinese official has written Taiwan's President, Chiang Ching-kuo, offering to visit the island and to discuss in person Peking's proposals for reunification of Taiwan and the Chinese mainland.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Gregory Jackson to Be Host Of ABC-TV News Program

title: AS THE SUN BELT'S SUBURBS BLOOM
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN AIDES DISAGREE OVER MEDICAID PROPOSAL
description: President Reagan's proposal to have the Federal Government assume Medicaid costs now paid by the states has started an intense debate inside the Administration, with some officials warning that his ''new federalism'' plan could be a ''fiscal time bomb'' for the Government.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx. The Tigers become the first Eastern Division team to close out their season schedule in New York.

title: HILLENKOETTER'S LAWFUL RESORT TO COVERT ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Vic Morrow Is Eulogized
description: Vic Morrow, the actor, killed with two children Friday while filming a mock Vietnam battle scene, was eulogized today as having given the finest performance of his career in the movie, ''The Twilight Zone.''

title: Y.& R. Anniversary
description: Young & Rubicam, in a move that tugs at the heart strings, announced that it would celebrate its 60th anniversary much as it celebrated its 50th, with good works. Throughout the world, where the largest American agency has its 126 hard-working bastions, the Y.& R. folks will give that extra little bit of effort to create an additional public-service campaign to benefit the local community.

title: Two-Shot Victory for Peete
description: Cal Peete, showing high accuracy, shot a closing two-under-par 69 today and won the storm-shortened Anheuser-Busch golf tournament by two strokes.

title: DELAY AND EXEMPTION DON'T CLEAN AND THE WATER
description: The Reagan Administration has drawn a definite yet disguised blueprint for reversing a decade of progress under the Federal Clean Water Act. Labeling her recent proposals minor adjustments to a sound statute, Anne M. Gorsuch, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, hopes to abandon successful national policies and revert to old approaches that failed so miserably in the 1960's that Congress largely discarded them 10 year ago. Under the banner of ''administrative flexibility,'' the E.P.A. seeks a sweeping grant of authority to chart its own course without Congressional direction. Congress should tell Mrs. Gorsuch, ''No thank you.''

title: LOS ANGELES THEATERS TURN TO FILMS IN SPANISH
description: HOLLYWOOD METROPOLITAN Theaters was founded in 1923, the year Cecil B. De Mille's ''The 10 Commandments'' and Buster Keaton's ''Balloonatic'' played first run in downtown Los Angeles; and downtown Los Angeles was the center of moviegoing in southern California.

title: Khomeini Warns Region Not to Help the Iraqis
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini repeated warnings to Persian Gulf nations today against helping Iraq in its war with Iran.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JULY 26, 1982
description: International Israel warned Syria not to introduce new weapons into the fighting in Lebanon. The Israeli Cabinet Secretary, Dan Meridor, said that he hoped that a threat published by Sana, the official Syrian news agency, to use weapons against Israel not yet used in Lebanon was ''nothing more than words.'' He said that if Syria carried out its threat it would suffer ''very grievous consequences.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Yasir Arafat signed a document accepting United Nations resolutions that include Israel's right to exist, an American Congressman said after a meeting with the Palestinian leader in west Beirut. But Mr. Arafat corrected Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., saying what the P.L.O. had accepted was all United Nations resolutions ''concerning the Palestinian question.'' (A1:5-6.)

title: IRATE FARMERS SEEN AS FORCE IN NOVEMBER
description: Burnie Burkman watched a drought shrivel his corn crop last year. This year a hailstorm shredded a field of corn and soybeans. But Mr. Burkman feels that his natural misfortunes have been small in comparison with the damage he says has been inflicted by his Government.

title: Bridge: San Francisco Wins Title; 2 Familiar Faces at the Top
description: One major title went to San Francisco at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Saturday night, while two players were adding to a remarkable record in another event.

title: Strike at Westinghouse Is Averted at Last Hour
description: Bargainers for Westinghouse Electric Corporation and unions representing 30,000 blue-collar workers reached a settlement late tonight to avert a nationwide strike. The company and representatives for three unions announced the settlement at 11:30 P.M. Eastern daylight time, a half-hour before the threatened walkout was to take place, after more than 13 hours of talks.

title: UNIDENTIFIED RAIDERS ATTACK PRINCIPAL ZIMBABWE AIR BASE
description: Raiders attacked Zimbabwe's main air base early today and were said to have destroyed a large part of the country's air force.

title: MRS. ALEX WINS OPEN
description: Janet Anderson Alex, a 26-year-old Pennsylvanian who had never won on the women's professional tour in five years and 116 tournaments, rallied in the final round today to capture the 37th United States Women's Open championship by six strokes.

title: THE PATZES: WHEN FICTION IMITATES LIFE
description: Three years after the disappearance of Etan Patz, the child who vanished from his SoHo neighborhood on his way to school, the case remains a mystery. But the making of a movie based on ''Still Missing,'' a novel about an abducted 6-year-old, has revived once again the debate over the effects of fictional portrayals on the lives of real people and has raised anew the issue of the public commercialization of private tragedy.

title: JONATHAN L. QUITT WEDS CYNTHIA S. WEINSTEIN AT EMANU-EL
description: Cynthia S. Weinstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey E. Weinstein of Freehold, N.J., was married yesterday in the Beth-El Chapel of Temple Emanu-El to Jonathan L. Quitt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Quitt of New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: ALLISON CAPTURES POCONO AUTO RACE
description: Bobby Allison, conserving fuel while drafting behind the leaders, burst into the lead with three laps remaining and won the Mountain Dew 500 stock car race by 17.47 seconds today at Pocono International Raceway.

title: P.L.O. REPORTS AN AMBUSH
description: Israeli fighter-bombers attacked Palestinian neighborhoods in west Beirut again today, and the Palestine Liberation Organization mounted another ambush behind Israeli lines.

title: U.S. URGES 'EXTREME CAUTION' IN WEIGHING REPORT ON ARAFAT
description: The White House and the State Department urged ''extreme caution'' today in weighing a statement by a California Congressman saying that Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, had recognized United Nations resolutions on the Middle East and accepted Israel's right to exist.

title: HUGHES A STRONG FORCE FOR GIANTS
description: Ray Perkins, the soft-spoken coach of the Giants, had just finished saying that he thought Ernie Hughes was probably the strongest offensive center in pro football when someone in back of the room suggested that Hughes was ''so strong he can lift refrigerators.''

title: People
description: * Francis X. Dealy Jr., former vice president-general manager of Book Digest, named publisher of Tennis Magazine.

title: BECHTEL ASIA UNIT IS HABIB EMPLOYER
description: President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib, is also serving as a private consultant on Asia to the Bechtel Group Inc., company officials said today.

title: MRS. GANDHI IN U.S. TOMORROW TO SEEK BETTER TIES
description: India, an advancing industrial power in thirdworld garb, appears to have taken a new turn on the long, frustrating road toward what its leaders hope will be lasting economic health.

title: One Person in Seven
description: After the 1980 election, shocked liberals asked themselves, ''What should be our new agenda?'' Some answered with a guess: the old one. Once Ronald Reagan had been President for a while, they feared, traditional issues of rich and poor would again head the national agenda. That guess seems now to be confirmed, marked by two growing blocs of Americans, the poor and the new poor.

title: MOYNIHAN CITED NEW LOSS OF U.S. FUNDS
description: New York State's historically low share of Federal spending will be reduced further in the next five years by the Reagan Administration's policy of increases in defense spending and reductions in social programs, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today.

title: TATYANA GROSMAN, PRINT PUBLISHER, 78
description: Tatyana Grosman, who set standards of perfection in printmaking and print publishing through Universal Limited Art Editions, a company she founded in 1957, died in Mount Sinai Hospital on Saturday. She was 78 years old.

title: MORE CORPORATIONS PLANNING NEW ISSUES
description: As Treasury financings begin to loom larger, more corporations have decided to sell new debt issues and take advantage of the recent decline in interest rates. On Wednesday, the Treasury is expected to announce plans to sell up to $10 billion of new issues in the first week of August, as well as tentative plans to raise an estimated $45 billion of new cash this quarter.

title: Governor Brown Says Watt Should Quit Post
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has told Interior Secretary James G. Watt in a telegram that he should be ashamed about a letter he wrote to the Israeli ambassador to the United States.

title: The Friendly Skies
description: A little more than a week ago, thanks to speedy horses and astute traveling arrangements, Angel Cordero was able to win four rich thoroughbred stakes races that netted him almost $40,000 within 48 hours.

title: IF THREE CON ED PLANTS BURN COAL INSTEAD OF OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Hershey Profit Rises
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation has announced that its net income in the second quarter advanced 11.1 percent, to $16 million, or $1.03 a share, from $14.4 million, or $1.02, in the 1981 period.

title: OUTDOORS: LURING ATLANTIC SALMON
description: DAWSONVILLE, New Brunswick ONCE entranced by Atlantic salmon angling, one rarely escapes the hunger to do it again. It may be that an element in the sport's fascination is the infrequency with which most anglers, particularly nonresidents, can pursue it. In Canada, salmon rivers fall under two general categories, public and private.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Cleaner Coney Island C oney Island trumpeted its fourth million-plus crowd of the month yesterday, and some of those visiting the beaches thought that the year had brought improvement to the sand and the water.

title: CONCERT: STRAVINSKY, HAYDN AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Stravinsky and Haydn shared not only a program at Tanglewood's Berkshire Festival this afternoon. They also offered a common outlook on music in general.

title: Democrats to Cut Staff
description: The Democratic National Committee, perennially pressed for cash, says it is laying off some workers to cut expenses in order to have more money for the fall campaigns for governor.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Exhibition Stresses Edward Hopper Boyhood

title: BOYER THINKS OF BREAKING AWAY FROM TOUR
description: PARIS RIDING 22 days on the hard, narrow seat of a racing bicycle is enough to drive a man crazy - unless you figure that anyone who rides the Tour de France has a few bent spokes to begin with.

title: Topics; Top of the Charts; Genteel Graffiti
description: Video games like Space Invaders, Asteroids and Donkey Kong seem to get kids off the streets and into the arcades. They may also help get graffiti off the walls and onto game screens, by providing a new way to win recognition.

title: REAGAN MAY BACK SENATE TAX ACTION ON BUSINESS MEALS
description: The Administration might support legislation that would restrict tax deductions for business meals, Donald T. Regan, the Secretary of the Treasury, said today. He said this could be the Administration position if the House of Representatives did not require more complete reporting of tips by restaurant workers,

title: INFERTILITY: COUPLES' REACTIONS
description: THE realization that they will never bear children may plunge even t he happiest of couples into difficulty. They inevitably endure s hock, rage, sadness, self-doubt, guilt, blame and a sense of i solation. Eventually infertility becomes a pervasive obsession, and a s Ann Macdonald, a psychiatric social worker at St. Luke's-RooseveltH ospital Center, said, ''Couples wonder what they ever talked about b efore.''

title: 2 Seers Are Pointing To Increased Optimism
description: And now for the good news. Some light was discovered at the end of the tunnel not only by Ogilvy & Mather, but also by Craig Standen, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

title: MONDAY, JULY 26, 1982; The Economy
description: The Administration may support a restriction on tax deductions for business meals, passed by the Senate on Friday, unless the House agrees to require more complete reporting of restaurant workers' tips, according to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. (Page A1.)

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: City Opera Gets $100,000

title: LANCE PARRISH A BUDDING STAR
description: DETROIT BEFORE the recent All-Star Game, Lance Parrish, the catcher for the Detroit Tigers, was recognized - if he was known at all outside Detroit -as a big, square-jawed Californian with a Hollywood-sounding name.

title: UNEASE INVADES FALKLANDS IN WAR AFTERMATH
description: One month after the end of hostilities here, Falkland Islanders seem convinced that they will never again experience the way of life that Britain fought to maintain.

title: BROKERS BACK CAPITAL GAINS MEASURES
description: Despite the prospect of a 10 percent withholding tax on dividend and interest payments, Wall Street brokers are smiling broadly. The reason is that a companion proposal in the tax bill passed by the Senate last week would halve the holding period for long-term capital gains to six months.

title: RATE DROPS SAID TO OFFER LITTLE HELP FOR ECONOMY
description: Interest rates have declined, it is true, but many economists doubt that the drop in rates will be so great and long-lasting that it will lend vigor to what is expected to be an anemic economic recovery at best.

title: NUPTIALS FOR PHILIP LEAHEY AND CAROLE ALDERMAN
description: Carole Francis Alderman and Philip Michael Leahey, who are with Avon Products Inc. in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Marvin M. Alderman of Syracuse. Town Court Justice Jack Schultz of Dewitt, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: BUS WHEELCHAIR LIFTS SAID TO FAIL OFTEN
description: New York City buses equipped with wheelchair lifts failed to pick up more than half the disabled passengers who tried to board in a city survey of 14 of the buses' 33 routes.

title: A CABLE BILL ALARMS MUNICIPALITIES
description: Lobbyists in Washington for municipal governments have set off alarm bells in city halls around the country and vowed to fight a cable-television-regulation bill that was passed handily last week by the Senate Commerce Committee, but which faces an uncertain fate on the Senate floor and in the House. There is no similar measure in the House.

title: LAWYER SEEKING TO BLOCK MOVES TO DEPORT MOON
description: A lawyer for the Rev. Sun Myung Moon is preparing to file court papers in Manhattan seeking to block any move to deport the Unification Church leader because of his recent tax-case conviction.

title: City Housing Sets Incincerator Ban
description: The New York City Housing Authority has agreed under a state airpollution enforcement order to phase out all its refuse incinerators by the end of 1987 and replace them with compactors.

title: EMPLOYEE SHOT DEAD IN AN AMTRAK FACILITY CLOSE TO PENN STATION
description: An Amtrak employee who worked the midnight-to-8 A.M. shift in the railroad's nearly deserted electrical substation near Pennsylvania Station was found shot dead early yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; July 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: More Heavy Rains Imperil Japan's South
description: Further heavy rains threatened southern Japan tonight as the death toll in floods in an area centered on Nagasaki reached 196, with more than 185 people missing and feared dead.

title: RECESSION SAPS BANK PROFITS
description: Extraordinary losses reported by the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Continental Illinois Corporation have overshadowed the second quarter earnings results of the nation's largest banking concerns. But even without these two especially bad reports, the overall performance of the 15 largest bank holding companies in the United States was relatively poor.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A baseball player bats out of turn at the start of an inning and strikes out. The official scorer notices this and adds an out, making it two out. The same player goes to bat, in his proper turn, and strikes out again, making all three outs in the inning. Was the scorer's ruling correct?

title: Lloyd Injured
description: Dan Lloyd, the inside linebacker attempting a comeback after recovering from lymphatic cancer, was injured in his right knee yesterday during the afternoon workout. He will undergo arthroscopic surgery today for suspected torn cartilage.

title: Market Place; Insurers' Effect On Municipals
description: EXEMPT bonds offer such good yields today that high-bracket taxpayers can earn a raw 12 1/2 percent - as much as 25 percent in after-tax equivalents. But how does one invest with safety?

title: PENNSYLVANIA RACE A TEST OF REPUBLICAN MONEY
description: With Vice President Bush as the star attraction, about 1,200 Republicans gathered recently in Butler, Pa., at the 300-acre horse farm of Frank Rath, one of Pittsburgh's wealthiest industrialists, for a Congressional campaign fund-raiser.

title: U.S. Chief Justice Visits Pope
description: Pope John Paul II received Chief Justice Warren E. Burger of the United States in a private audience today, the Vatican radio reported.

title: 5-Year-Old Wyoming Girl Gets A Donor's Liver in Transplant
description: A 5-year-old Wyoming girl, who had been given only months to live unless a liver donor could be found, underwent a liver transplant operation in Pittsburgh and was reported in critical condition today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECALL

title: Haitian Relatives Sought For Refugees' Release
description: Resettlement workers searched this weekend for relatives who might sponsor the release of 390 Haitian refugees held at a former missile base bordering the Everglades.

title: Europeans to Continue Steel Talks With U.S.
description: Trade tensions between the United States and Europe over steel imports to this country have been eased, for the moment, at least, by the European Economic Community's decision over the weekend to undertake negotiations with Washington.

title: SMALL L.I. CHURCH STRUGGLES ON IN 250TH YEAR
description: Among the farmers of the North Fork, care for their church comes as naturally as care for their crops. ''Our people are close to nature,'' said John Wickham, a descendant of the founders of the Presbyterian Church of Cutchogue and an elder of the congregation. ''We know the soil, the water. We are aware of the grace of God in our lives.''

title: DEEP EDUCATION CUTS?
description: To the Editor:

title: ARAFAT SAYS U.N. DOCUMENTS HAVE P.L.O.'S ENDORSEMENT
description: An American Congressman said today after meeting with Yasir Arafat that the Palestine Liberation Organization leader had signed a document accepting United Nations resolutions that include Israel's right to exist. But Mr. Arafat corrected him, saying that what the P.L.O. had accepted was all United Nations resolutions ''concerning the Palestinian question.''

title: BABY SITTER ARREST CAME AFTER 5 DEATHS IN 2 YEARS
description: Five times since 1980, babies or small children have died while Christine Falling was baby-sitting them. Five times, the deaths were carefully investigated. Five times, the investigations led to uncertain conclusions and guesswork.

title: BRIEFING
description: $25,000 to Hear Haig?

title: DIGEST'S DISAPPOINTING SOURCE
description: When the Reader's Digest plunged into electronic publishing by acquiring the Source Telecomputing Corporation in 1980, it inherited a company with a history of management turmoil and financial losses. Graeme G. Keeping, the Digest executive sent to head Source Telecomputing, vowed to transform it into a successful business.

title: Toro Returns To Bates Unit
description: Campbell-Mithun, the large, autonomous subsidiary of Ted Bates & Company, a year ago lost its piece of the Toro Company business to Ogilvy & Mather, Chicago, when the client made one of those consolidation moves.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: St. Bart's Update W hat's happening, since nothing seems to be happening? That's the gist of the talk about St. Bartholomew's Church and the proposed 59-story office tower to be built over its community house on Park Avenue at 50th Street.

title: ROBERTSON, H H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HABIB'S INTEGRITY HAILED BY U.S. AND ISRAEL LOBBY
description: The White House, the State Department, several members of Congress and a spokesman for the Israeli lobby voiced confidence today in President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib.

title: RUNNER-UP WON A BIGGER TEST
description: Greg Louganis, the national diving champion, struck a familiar pose as he stood on the winner's stand Sunday afternoon to accept his gold medal in the 10-meter platform diving event at the National Sports Festival. He smiled, waved to the standing-room crowd, and turned to congratulate the third-place finisher, Mike Wantuck, standing below him on his left.

title: BORG-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a securities loss of $1.3 million, income of $33,000 from the sale of real estate, and a loss of $1.3 million from the sale of the American Title Company...C-After a securities loss of $487,000 and income from of $2.5 million from the sale of real estate...D-Includes a securities loss of $953,000 income of $403,000 from sale of real estate, and a loss of $1.3 million from the sale of the American Title Company...E-After income of $2.9 million from sale of real estateand a securities gain of $860,000

title: MERCHANT MARINE'S 'IMPOSSIBLE SITUATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Receives Chief Justice
description: Pope John Paul II today received Chief Justice Warren Burger of the United States. The Chief Justice, who arrived on Friday, was invited to Rome to address the Italian Constitutional Court. He met with President Sandro Pertini of Italy on Saturday.

title: CAN IRAN TOPPLE IRAQI?
description: Iranians have made it clear that the primary aim of their offensive against Iraq is the overthrow of President Saddam Hussein. But, as the present standoff indicates, the Iranians may find it more difficult than they think to achieve their goal. They are evidently counting heavily on an eventual uprising in the predominantly Shiite areas of southern Iraq and sheer disaffection in the institutions of state to bring down Iraq's Baathist Government. Their assumptions are chancy.

title: Porsche Raises Prices
description: Dr. Ing. H.C.F. Porsche A.G. today announced an average 2 percent increase in prices for its high-performance automobiles. Porsche cited rising costs and standard equipment changes for some of its models. The family-held company said the new listings will take effect Aug.1.

title: Short-Term M.A.C. Paper
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York announced yesterday that it had sold tax-exempt commercial paper for the first time.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT MANHATTAN LIFE
description: Franklin Maisano has resigned as president of the Manhattan Life Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the Manhattan Life Insurance Company. He cited differences of view and a personality clash with Donald M. Fordyce, the chairman and chief executive officer.

title: ENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company was formerly known as the Alaska Interstate Co

title: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brown & Sharpe Loss
description: The Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company, citing the effects of the recession and a 40-week strike, said today that it posted a second-quarter loss of $3 million and cut its quarterly dividend and the salaries of management personnel.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3-YEAR NBC AD DEAL FOR $250 MILLION IS SET
description: The American Home Products Corporation, the maker of Anacin and several other well-known consumer products, has agreed to purchase $250 million worth of advertising air time from NBC-TV over the next three years, the companies announced yesterday.

title: LOGISTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TIMKEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Making a Big Hit
description: A star athelete gets privileges and perquisites that even money can't buy, as Dave Winfield discovered during his drive to Yankee Stadium Sunday. The Yankee left fielder, in a sleek chocolate-brown sedan, swung off Route 87 in the Bronx onto the ramp that empties near the ball park and found it backed up half a mile, even though it was not yet noon.

title: AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $3 million

title: MEDIQ INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $47,000...C-After gains of $197,000 for the qr and $1,303,000 for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...D-After income of $802,000 from discontinued operations; the shr earnings in 1981 reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 21, 1982

title: Brewers Hire Garland
description: The Milwaukee Brewers have hired a former 20-game winner, Wayne Garland, as a pitching instructor with their Pikesville, Ky., team of the Class A Appalachian League. Garland, who was 20-6 with the Baltimore Orioles in 1976, signed a 10-year free-agent contract worth $2.3 million with the Cleveland Indians before the 1977 season. Garland, who was injured in 1978, pitched ineffectively until Cleveland released him after the 1981 season.

title: 5 ARE DEAD IN A CANADIAN JAIL AS ESCAPE ATTEMPT IS FOILED
description: Two prisoners committed suicide after killing three guards in a foiled escape attempt that turned into a riot at a prison north of Montreal, the police said today. Seven other guards were wounded.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bridge:; Hamman and Wolff Seek Another Title at Nationals
description: One of the world's great partnerships was in quest of yet another title at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here tonight. Going into the semifinal session of the life master pair championship, Bo Hamman and Bob Wolff of Dallas were in seventh position.

title: QADDAFI URGES EUROPEANS TO TRY TO SHUT U.S. BASES
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, has offered to help groups allied with the European antinuclear movement to try to close United States military bases in Europe and has urged that as part of the attempt, they cut off water and supplies at the installations, according to a left-wing West Berlin newspaper.

title: Rev. Daniel J. Sexton Is Dead Retired Priest in Manhattan
description: The Rev. Daniel J. Sexton, who had last been attached to the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior at 59 Park Avenue, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: WACKENHUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Empty Sailboat in Atlantic
description: The Soviet ship Vasily Struve has found an empty sailboat in the mid-Atlantic, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. Aboard the boat, Penetration, was the passport of John Thomas, 32 years old, of California.

title: Zimbabweans Hopeful On Hunt for Hostages
description: Security forces searching for six foreign tourists, including two Americans, taken hostage by Zimbabwean gunmen believe they are closing in on the gang, sources close to the search said today.

title: ADVERTISING
description: BBDO International, which is usually a good performer among publicly held agencies, announced second-quarter results yesterday. Revenues were up 19 percent, to $53.1 million, from $44.5 million in the same period last year, while net income rose 12 percent, to $3.7 million, or 85 cents a share, from $3.3 million, or 80 cents.

title: SAVE-WAY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fast-Growing Mountains
description: The most dramatic relief found on any of the continents, a difference of 22,740 feet between the Indus River in Pakistan and the summit of Nanga Parbat just 14 miles away, evolved through very rapid uplift, relatively speaking, of the mountains in that region, according to studies of tracks left in the rocks by particles ejected from atoms subjected to radioactive decay. The mountains appear to have risen an average of almost a half inch a year over the past million years, though erosion has prevented a corresponding growth in their total height.

title: A GRAND LADY OF THE ROAD TURNS 75
description: The five-tier cake was decorated with marzipan roses and a hood ornament, and the high point of the afternoon came when 350 people sang ''Happy Birthday'' to a car.

title: GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AROUND THE NATION
description: Union leaders predicted today that members would overwhelming approve today a nationwide contract agreed to just in time to avert a strike by 34,400 workers at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: Penn Square Asset Sale Due
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation hopes to begin soliciting bids for the purchase of $69.4 million in Penn Square Bank installment and real estate loans in 10 days to two weeks, an F.D.I.C. spokesman, Alan Whitney, said today.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Chase Aids T.D.F.

title: RANGERS TOPPLE BREWERS BY 3-1
description: Charlie Hough baffled hot-hitting Milwaukee on four hits as the Texas Rangers beat the Brewers, 3-1, tonight. The loss, coupled with Boston's victory, knocked the Brewers out of the American League East lead.

title: 19 TRUCKS TRANSPORT NUCLEAR FUEL SUPPLY TO SHOREHAM PLANT
description: Nuclear fuel was delivered to the Long Island Lighting Company's Shoreham nuclear power station over the weekend, for the first time, and Lilco officials said yesterday that the shipment marked a major step toward opening of the long-delayed $2.63 billion plant.

title: Cuban Visits Greece; Aim Is Closer Ties
description: Isidoro Malmierca, the Cuban Foreign Minister, arrived here today for a three-day official visit to Greece.

title: E.E.C. Talks With U.S.
description: Sir Roy Denkins, the European Economic Community's senior trade negotiator, and Lionel Olmer, United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, will open talks on steel here Wednesday, diplomatic sources said today.

title: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After extraordinary losses of $890,000 for the latest qr and $2,380,000 for the yr-ago qr from certain abandonment and the permanent shutdown of a facility

title: READYING THE PARK FOR PHILHARMONIC
description: Like Bedouins crossing and recrossing the burning summer sands of New York's five boroughs, the New York Philharmonic's caravan of trucks is moving through its peripatetic outdoor season. Tonight at 8 o'clock the orchestra alights on Central Park's Great Lawn for a mammoth free confluence of music, fireworks, picnics and sociability on the grandest of scales.

title: MIDLAND SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BAKER WANTS VOTE SOON ON BALANCED-BUDGET ISSUE
description: A major battle shaped up on Capitol Hill today as Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, vowed to seek a final vote this week on a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget.

title: SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $101,000 in the qr and $180,000 for the 6 mo

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
NETWORKS ON GOLF: VARIED APPROACHES
description: G olf tournaments are not alike, even if softening television ratings suggest that only hard-core golfers bother to watch anything other than the major championships these days.

title: BORG-WARNER ADVANCES 11.2%
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said yesterday that the profit on the sale of about 700,000 shares of Gould Inc. common stock, helped push net income up in the second quarter by 11.2 percent, to $46.7 million, or $1.10 a share, from $42 million, or 97 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1981. Sales advanced 5.3 percent, to $844.2 million, from $801.9 million.

title: A DENTIST'S PLEA OF GUILT VOIDED IN SEXUAL ABUSE
description: A New York State appellate court yesterday voided the guilty plea of a Brooklyn dentist who admitted to sexually abusing an investigator posing as a patient.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Living Costs Soar in Poland
description: Living costs surged by more than 104 percent and real wages plummeted as Poland's debt-ridden economy continued to decline during the first six months of this year, the Government announced today.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

A NOTE OF FANTASY SOUNDS AS PARIS COUTURE OPENS
description: The showings of couture fashions for next fall and winter may not be relevant but they certainly are extravagant. The clothes are escapist, like Hollywood movies of the 1930's, which they frequently resemble. In this fantasy world, there are oases of practicality, such as the suits at Christian Dior with their tailored jackets and calf-length skirts that fit smoothly over the hips and flare below. But romance and fantasy are rampant.

Kennett W. Hinks, 85, Is Dead; J. Walter Thompson Executive
description: Kennett Webb Hinks, a retired advertising agency executive and a psychological warfare and intelligence official for the Government during World War II, died of a heart ailment Thursday at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore. He was 85 years old and lived in Cockeysville, Md.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Two 21-year-old free agents, Grant Ledyard and Steve Hakala, have signed with the Rangers. Ledyard was voted most valuable player last season with the Fort Garry Blues of the Manitoba Junior Hockey League while Hakala was scoring 50 points for Merrimack College in North Andover, Mass. ... The Los Angeles Rams announced yesterday that Doug France, an eight-year veteran offensive tackle, is retiring because of a series of injuries.

title: Soccer All-Stars
description: The captain of the French national team, a Polish soccer star and a player from the World Cup champion Italian team have agreed to play in the World All-Star Game at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands on Aug. 7. Michel Platini of France, who played an outstanding game against West Germany on July 8, Zbigniew Boniek of Poland, the thirdleading scorer in the final phase of the World Cup with four goals, and Gioancarlo Antonogni of Italy were added to the exhibition sponsored by the Federation Internationale de Football Association.

title: MOST CITY POOR SAID TO DEPEND ON PAY PHONES

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. On the Mets' last visit to St. Louis, they won three of four games, beat Bruce Sutter, the star reliever, twice, and came home with a record of 34-30, in third place and three games out of first. The Mets will return home Thursday to face Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; 8:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Padres vs. Braves, at Atlanta. A twilight-night doubleheader. The Padres, in second place, are trying to gain ground on the Braves, who lead the Western Division. (Television - WTBS 6 P.M.) Basketball New York Pro Summer League, at Nat Holman gymnasium, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. This is the final week of action before the playoffs.

title: Dow Off 5.13 in Light Trading
description: Lower quarterly profits and rising yields in the fixed-income sector combined to send the stock market into retreat yesterday. Trading was the lightest in nearly four months.

The deal is subject to approvals by the boards of both companies and the Bankruptcy Court. Chukerman distributes industrial papers and products and was profitable in 1980, Saxon said.

description: Prime Minister Maurice Bishop of Grenada arrived here today for talks. The Soviet Union has taken an interest in the Caribbean island since Mr. Bishop came to power in a leftist coup three years ago.

description: IN another era, when society was firm in its view that automobile mechanics and plumbing were jobs for men and cosmetology and secretarial work were jobs for women, the public schools set up systems of vocational education reflecting these divisions.

title: WATT HAS REAGAN CONFIDENCE DESPITE FUROR, AIDE REPORTS
description: President Reagan retains his confidence in Interior Secretary James G. Watt despite the furor over the official's' comment that United States support for Israel could weaken if American Jews did not back Administration energy policies, Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said today.

description: Interest rates rose yesterday as prices of Treasury note and bond issues were depressed by selling and by an unwillingness of dealers to increase their inventories in advance of upcoming Treasury offerings.

title: Morton-Norwich
description: Morton-Norwich Products Inc. said it had started an offer to buy up to two million of its own shares, or about 18 percent of those outstanding, at $35 each. The company said the offer is part of its plan to merge with Thiokol to form Morton Thiokol Inc.

title: G.M. and Ford To Cut Output
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company have reduced their American production schedules for the rest of the year by a total of nearly 200,000 cars, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: BRIEFS

title: Briefs on the Arts Mehta to Lead Orchestra In Tribute to Mrs. Gandhi
description: Zubin Mehta will lead the New York Philharmonic Thursday evening at the White House, when President and Mrs. Reagan honor Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India on the occasion of her visit to the United States. The concert will mark the first appearance of the full orchestra at the White House.

title: IS BANDING OF BIRDS FOR RESEARCH OFTEN UNNECESSARILY CRUEL?
description: Evans as the group moved single file along a narrow path in the woods behind the Manomet Bird Observatory here. Strung vertically along the side of the path was a shoulder-high black nylon net and trapped in its fine, almost invisible webbing were six robins struggling vainly to free themselves.

description: On the afternoon of June 17, a five-inch-long pipe bomb exploded in Seth Low Park in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. The park's play area was crowded with pupils from the Magen David Yeshiva, who regularly use the park during recess.

description: President Reagan is expected to authorize a one-year renewal of the grain trade accord with Moscow later this week, Administration officials said. They said Mr. Reagan would continue Moscow's obligation to buy a fixed amount of grain for the year starting Oct. 1 but is undecided as to whether to increase that amount. (Page A1.)

description: In the wake of the New York City Opera's sudden decision to consolidate its fall and winter seasons and to eliminate its customary spring season, a rush is on to find a tenant to rent the State Theater at Lincoln Center next March and April, when it will be vacant.

description: The Democratic chairman and the senior Republican member of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa urged Secretary of State George P. Shultz today to adopt a comprehensive policy for the Horn of Africa to end the conflict between Somalia and Ethiopia.

title: POVERTY, BY CHOICE
description: The poverty rate is increasing and more so for blacks, says a new census report. Recession and unemployment are the main causes but there's a story hidden in the figures: an increasing number of unmarried black teen-agers are choosing poverty by choosing to become mothers.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JULY 27, 1982
description: International The U.S.-Soviet grain accord would be renewed for one year under an authorization that Administration aides expect President Reagan to announce this week. Under the expected announcement, Moscow would continue to be obligated to buy a fixed amount of American grain for the year beginning Oct. 1. (Page A1, Column 6.) The first domestic hijacking in China was officially acknowledged by the Peking authorities. The Chinese passengers and crew members fought a desperate midair battle with the five hijackers, who reportedly blew a hole in the side of the plunging airliner before being subdued. (A1:2-3.)

title: AS PHYSICAN SUPPLY SWELLS, HEALTH CARE IN RURAL U.S. SHOW SHARP GAINS
description: educated city boy from White Plains, Joel Silverstein, M.D., might seem slightly out of place in this village of 2,076 people. But here he is, a 37-year-old specialist in internal medicine, building his practice among the farmers and townsfolk of this northern Vermont area, hauling and splitting wood and raising a family and golden retrievers on a 100-acre farm just outside of town. He says he loves it, even if his wife, Vicki, complains about the dearth of Chinese restaurants.

description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community rose to 9.1 percent in June from 8.9 percent in May, with the Netherlands showing the sharpest increase, the community's statistical agency said today. Excluding Greece, which has a markedly different labor market structure and registration system, the number of people out of work in the Common Market rose 35 percent in the year ended June 1981 and an additional 22 percent in the year ended June 1982, the statistical agency said.

description: Even the attempt on President Reagan's life did not alter his opposition to gun control. In fact, he viewed John Hinckley's heinous deed as proof that gun controls don't work. CERTIFYING EL SALVADOR
description: In 1981, Congress signaled its anger over the course of the Reagan policy toward El Salvador by inserting into the Foreign Assistance Act a twice-yearly certification requirement. Accordingly, all military aid will stop this month unless President Reagan warrants that the Salvadoran Government is making a concerted and significant effort to achieve progress on human rights, land redistribution, a political solution to the guerrilla conflict and free elections. As all evidence we have runs directly counter to these propositions, any document providing a rationale for Presidential certification will necessarily be long on unsubstantiated assertion and short on demonstrable fact. In spite of this, the President is expected to sign the certification provided him by a bureaucracy more comfortable with barren continuity than creative change.

title: Women's Tennis Faces Demotion
