title: IMPERIAL OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a special gain of $18 million for the qr and 6 mos

title: Takeover of Steel Plant May Work, Study Says
description: Workers at the Weirton Steel plant here could succeed with plans to buy their mill if they are willing to forfeit one-third of their wages and benefits and dismiss 1,400 colleagues, according to a consultant's report released today.

title: A Whale-Size Loophole
description: A blizzard of postcards and determined diplomacy achieved a splendid victory last week when the International Whaling Commission voted to end the commercial slaughter of whales by 1985. With luck, the ban will come in time to save already imperiled cetaceans, and enable declining herds to rebuild themselves.

title: Humphrey Browning's New Job Title
description: If nothing else, Scott Miller as he returns to Humphrey Browning MacDougall will be pioneering a job title: senior vice chairman.

title: BECHTEL'S GOOD DEED
description: To the Editor:

title: A SWITCH IN PRO SOCCER
description: The San Diego Sockers joined the Major Indoor Soccer League yesterday - without quitting the North American Soccer League. At the M.I.S.L. annual meetings in Baltimore, the Sockers' principal owner, Robert W. Bell, announced that his team would play the full outdoor schedule of the N.A.S.L., but during the winter the team would join the M.I.S.L., whose teams played a 44-game schedule each last season.

title: TONKA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HUGHES TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. OCEAN SHIPPING LAW NEEDS TO BE OVERHAULED
description: T o the Editor: The thrust of your July 14 editorial ominously titled ''Beware the Cargo Ship Cartel'' is to attack our bills to improve the regulation of ocean liner shipping.

title: DR PEPPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Financial Futures Slide After Gaining for Month
description: Prices of Treasury bill and bond futures fell sharply yesterday in reaction to both the small decline in the money supply reported Friday and the lack of any fresh market stimulus. Brokers also noted that the decline was not surprising, given the strong advance in financial futures prices since the beginning of the month.

title: TRANSCON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $1,196,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net incom

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JETS' LONG IS TRADED TO BEARS
description: The New York Jets, confident that they can find a durable, full-time fullback, traded their longtime ''situation'' fullback, Kevin Long, to the Chicago Bears today for a sixth-round draft choice in 1983.

title: FORMER C.I.A. AGENT LINKED TO ASSASSIN'S WEAPON
description: The Justice Department asserted today that Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent accused of illegally aiding Libyan terrorists, played a key role in supplying the weapon that was used to assassinate a Libyan dissident in West Germany in 1980.

title: DOUBTS ON DENSE PACK
description: The House has approved $1.4 billion for production of the first nine MX missiles, but so narrowly that the real Congressional message to President Reagan is more nearly ''stop'' than ''go.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani THE THEATER WE WORKED FOR. The Letters of Eugene O'Neill to Kenneth Macgowan. Edited by Jackson R. Bryer, with the assistance of Ruth M. Alvarez. With introductory essays by Travis Bogard. 274 pages. Yale Univer- sity Press. $25.

title: A Homey Touch
description: ''P lanted Lot - Smell flowers, not Trash'' says a sign on a chain-link fence on 11th Avenue at 52d Street. A half-block deep, with perhaps 20 feet of frontage, the plot is filled with maple trees, their trunks pristinely white-washed; a birdhouse with enough perches to accommodate a crowd; rosebushes, day lilies, begonias, salvia, iris, impatiens, tomato plants, a brick barbecue oven and, two feet from the sidewalk, a picnic table with eight chairs.

title: Califano Agrees to Conduct Inquiry on Charges by Pages
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has accepted an appointment as special counsel for the House Ethics Committee investigation of charges of sexual misconduct and drug use involving members of the House and Capitol pages.

title: LOCKING THE BARN DOOR
description: In a city like this one, dense with people, buildings and rapidpaced activity, freak accidents are inevitable as potholes. A helicopter wheel-strut collapses with metal fatigue, the whirling rotor blade hits the rooftop landing pad, spins off wildly and people are dead. A loose chunk of stone molding suddenly falls off an old building in the Columbia University area and a student is killed. Subways and ferries and bridge cables wear out or go awry, and the accidents again make headlines, briefly.

title: Striking Gold
description: Bruce Furniss used to have two Olympic gold medals. Then he had none. Now he has one and is trying for two.

title: NICARAGUA-HONDURAS CLASHES SAID TO INCREASE ALONG BORDER
description: Border skirmishing between Nicaraguan and Honduran forces has increased recently, causing renewed fears of wider conflict in Central America, according to United States military analysts.

title: WITCO CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BELO, A H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK TIMES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that the final installment gain, $4.2 million on the April 1981 sale of its Australian magazine operations, was recorded in the 1982 second qrand the latest 6 mos results include installment gains of $8.4 million; the 1981 qr and 6 mos results included the initial installment gain of $2 million

title: Heileman Net Up 13%
description: Second-quarter earnings for the G. Heileman Brewing Company were up 13 percent and sales increased 6.4 percent, R.G. Cleary, Heileman president, said today. Earnings were $14.8 million, or $1.12 a share, up from $13.1 million, or $1 a share, in the same period in 1981. Sales increased to $283.8 million in the second quarter in 1982, up from $266.6 million in 1981.

title: MYERS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a $16 million gain on sale of investment

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: TELEVISION has conquered America, but last month it suffered two stinging defeats in higher education. The University of Mid-America, a Middle Western consortium of universities that attempts to improve opportunities for off-campus adult education, announced it has had to abandon extensive plans for a nationwide American Open University and that it would end its own operation by Sept. 30.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRITAIN HONORS THE FALLEN IN FALKLANDS
description: The nation paused today to celebrate the end of the Falkland war and to commemorate those who died there, Argentine as well as British, in a heavily attended and well-guarded service at St. Paul's Cathedral.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm going to send the bill to the Mayor's office. I don't know where else to send it.''

title: HUGHES TOOL
description: The Hughes Tool Company reported that net income in the second quarter dropped 27.8 percent, to $45.4 million, or 81 cents a share, from $62.9 million, or $1.13 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. Sales slipped 2.6 percent, to $426.6 million, from $438.2 million.

title: SEXISM CITED IN KENTUCKY PRISONS
description: A Federal District Court judge in Louisville ruled yesterday that the Kentucky state prison system was guilty of sex discrimination in its treatment of inmates, and he ordered that sweeping changes be made within 90 days.

title: BRIEFING
description: Only 180 Ongoing Strikes

title: Bringing Back the Trough
description: I t's just over a week since three carriage horses died of the heat. It's just over four years since a horse-watering trough for Central Park South was proposed to the Parks Department by Community Board 5, which had even found a trough that would be donated by the A.S.P.C.A.

title: MESA PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest qr earnings were increased by an after-tax gain on the sale of marketable securities of $24.9 million and were also reduced by foreign exchange adjustments of $9.4 million after-tax due to fluctuation in the Canadian-U.S. dollarexchange rate

title: BOTH LANDLORDS AND TENANTS CRITICIZE CITY HOUSING COURT
description: A decade after the Housing Court was established in New York City, the landlords and tenants who use it, as well as the legislators who created it, criticize it as chaotic and ineffective.

title: Nabisco to Sell Unit In $155 Million Deal
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell Julius Wile Sons & Company, its wine and spirits operation, to Whitbread & Company P.L.C., a London-based alcoholic beverage concern, for about $155 million.

title: SWIM MARK FOR GIRL, 13
description: Michele Richardson, at age 13 the youngest swimmer at the National Sports Festival, set a meet record of 8 minutes 40.24 seconds in winning the women's 800-meter freestyle tonight.

title: SPS TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50 - 16.00** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bedlwether issues

title: Dr Pepper Net Up in Quarter
description: The Dr Pepper Company said today that its second-quarter profit rose 17 percent from a year earlier but that its six-month earnings edged lower.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JANET ALEX GIVES CREDIT TO HER PRO
description: Janet Alex stood in the middle of her hotel room Saturday night with a golf club in her hand. She was practicing her stance while trying to cradle a phone between her left shoulder and ear so she could hear her husband's instructions on how to correct a minor fault in her swing.

title: The Old Neighborhood
description: J erry Friedland gave Tom Quinn and Bob Monahan the once-over. ''Hey, these guys don't look so tough anymore,'' he announced.

title: Mets' Allen Frustrated
description: Neil Allen is going through a frustrating period. After rejoining the Mets late in June upon recovering from a colon infection, he has allowed 22 hits, 11 earned runs, and has walked 10 batters, two intentionally, in 13 l/3 innings.

title: STEWART INFORMATION SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POSTAL FUNDS IN LIMBO
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD RISES 2.6%
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's seventh-largest oil concern, said yesterday that net income for the second quarter rose 2.5 percent from a year earlier, to $409.8 million, or $1.62 a share, from $399.6 million, or $1.60 a share. Sales declined 2.8 percent, to $6.8 billion, from $7 billion in the comparable 1981 period.

title: MUSIC: RAMPAL AS SOLOIST AND CONDUCTOR
description: Jean-Pierre Rampal has performed with the Mostly Mozart Festival since the concerts first began as a risky entrepreneurial foray into summer programming 16 years ago. Since then, of course, the festival has prospered and grown conservative and James Galway has become a rival for Mr. Rampal's position as reigning flutist. But Mr. Rampal still has his own style and his own following. And to expand his musical realm in recent years, he has taken up the baton.

title: MEAL TAX BILL FOUGHT BY UNION
description: A labor union that represents some 450,000 restaurant employees turned to the House of Representatives today in an effort to block tax legislation adopted by the Senate that the union contends would destroy jobs.

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PITTSTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EASTOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $321,000 for the qr and $566,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $300,000 for the qr and $763,000 for the 6 mos

title: Business and the Law; Class Actions: A New Phase
description: THE practice of law has its fashions. And since 1966, when new Federal rules of civil procedure were adopted, class action suits have been the rage. But fashions change, and if three recent cases are any indication, many judges are now reluctant to widen the scope of class actions any further.

title: Airline Heads Open Talks
description: Top executives from 60 airlines opened emergency talks here today to consider ways of fighting growing losses, high interest rates and reduced-price ticket sales.

title: ONLY FEELINGS ARE HURT
description: Mayor Koch's limousine, rushing through midtown traffic with a police escort so the Mayor could get to an appearance on time, sideswiped another car near Herald Square yesterday morning. No one was hurt - but oh, the commotion.

title: WANG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OIL SHALE CONSORTIUM SUGGESTED
description: The Mobil Corporation, anticipating continued national reliance on foreign oil, is seeking to form an industrywide consortium to exploit the virtually untapped domestic reserves of oil shale.

title: FIRST CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
African Ministers Conferring On Issue of Western Sahara
description: African foreign ministers met here privately today to resolve a dispute over the Polisario guerrilla group, which is seeking independence for Moroccan-controlled Western Sahara.

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CAUTIOUS SEASON FOR RETAILERS
description: Many of the nation's retailers, having come out of a difficult spring into a static summer, are buying sparingly for the fall season, reshuffling their list of suppliers and asking some to delay shipments until close to the time of need.

title: BALTIMORE'S WORLD THEATER FESTIVAL BLOOMS ANEW IN DENVER
description: Until this summer, the most ambitious international theater festival in the United States resided in Baltimore, where for three weeks national companies from Britain, Israel and a halfdozen other countries were imported to stage nightly performances in downtown theaters, school auditoriums and churches.

title: COME SUMMER, PEOPLE AND LITTER HIT THE STREETS
description: A four-wheeled yellow container stood the other day in front of the sparkling new International Paper Company building at 77 West 45th Street, right next to the unfinished International Paper Plaza.

title: Snipes Bout on TV
description: TV said yesterday that it had acquired television rights to a heavyweight fight betwen Trevor Berbick and Renaldo Snipes on Aug. 14 at a site to be announced. At the same time, the network said the Aug. 15 bout between Bobby Czyz, the undefeated New Jersey middleweight, and Chong-pal Park would have to be postponed. Park, ranked sixth by the World Boxing Association, had an appendectomy and will have to be replaced.

title: Cutbacks in Zimbabwe
description: The state-controlled Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company may have to close, and Zimbabwe Alloys, a ferrochrome producer, will reduce its operations, corporate officials said today. The recession has depressed demand for Zimbabwe's metals.

title: RYAN'S FAMILY STEAK HOUSES INC reports earnings for QTr to June 30
Bridgestone Tire
description: The Bridgestone Tire Company said it would soon ask the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry to pay $12.8 million in overseas investment insurance for a tire venture in Iran. The amount accounts for Bridgestone's 45 percent interest in the venture, which was nationalized by the Government of Iran in 1980.

title: OLYMPIA BREWING ENDS ITS OFFER FOR 49% OF PABST
description: With its merger into Pabst Brewing Company assured, the Olympia Brewing Company announced yesterday that it was terminating its offer to buy 4 million shares, or 49 percent of Pabst, under a plan announced by the two brewers earlier this month.

title: EXPLORATION SURVEYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNITED ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEPOSITORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on May 19

title: Dolphin Becomes Less Rare
description: Beached remains of a species of dolphin previously known only in seas of the Eastern Hemisphere, and thought to be rare even there, have been found in the Marquesas Keys of southern Florida. Last January, a shell collector there turned several peculiar dolphin skulls over to Dr. Daniel Odell, a marine mammalogist at the University of Miami.

title: Swig Buys Rest Of Fairmont Hotel
description: The Swig Investment Company said it had purchased all the outstanding stock of the Fairmont Hotel Company, a luxury hotel group, that it did not already own.

title: Peru Reported to Seek 26 F-16 Jets From U.S.
description: Peru has told the United States that it is interested in buying American F-16 jet fighters, Reagan Administration sources said today.

title: UJDUR, PARRISH THWART YANKS
description: The ''d'' in Jerry Ujdur's last name is silent, and so basically were the Yankee hitters when they faced the 25-year-old Detroit pitcher last night.

title: CHUBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: U.S. ASTRONOMERS PLAN VAST ARRAY OF ANTENNAS
description: A NETWORK of 10 radio antennas from Virginia to Hawaii and from Alaska to Texas has been proposed as a top-priority project for American astronomy. The network's ability to map distant objects in fine detail would be comparable to a dish-shaped antenna as large as the United States.

title: CHINA'S FIRST REPORTED HIJACKING: MIDAIR MELEE ON A DIVING AIRLINER
description: As a tourist group from New Jersey looked on aghast, Chinese passengers and crewmen fought a desperate battle in midair Sunday with five hijackers in China's first acknowledged seizure of a domestic airliner.

title: Dear Secretary Watt
description: It must be a singular privilege for the ambassador of a small nation like Israel to be singled out for your personal importunings on the politics of energy in America. Perhaps the encounter that inspired your letter to him revealed a fellow conservative under the skin who has done his share of battle against liberals back in his own country. Most of them are in fact Jews.

title: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: Qtr is after $60,000 loss on disposal of assets and a $140,000 gain in the 9 mos on disposal of assets

title: Second Haitian Group Freed From Detention
description: A second group of Haitians was released today from a detention center west of Miami. The Haitians clapped hands and sang in the church bus that drove them to freedom.

title: Article 043316 -- No Title
description: The General Motors Corporation today reported a net income of $560 million, or $1.82 a share, in the second quarter, exceeding most expectations within the industry and the financial community.

title: PENTHOUSE TO APPEAL LIBEL RULING
description: Norman Roy Grutman, a lawyer for Penthouse magazine, said today that Penthouse would appeal a court decision made Friday that cleared the way for a second trial in the legal battle between the magazine and two cofounders of the resort Rancho LaCosta.

title: Boy Born in Houston To Astronaut Couple
description: A 7-pound, 2-ounce boy was born today to the astronauts Margaret Rhea Seddon and Robert L. Gibson at a hospital near here.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELI PLANES HIT HIDDEN DUMP IN RAID ON BEIRUT
description: Israeli warplanes attacked Palestiniancontrolled neighborhoods in west Beirut today for the fifth consecutive day, knocking out what appeared to be a major guerrilla underground ammunition dump.

title: FLORIDA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUS LINE STRIKE IN JERSEY SLOWS DAILY COMMUTE
description: Drivers and mechanics of the DeCamp Bus Company went on strike early this morning, forcing approximately 8,300 daily riders to scramble for other means of getting to and from their jobs.

title: SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $200,000 loss from discontinued operations...C-After loss of $17.8 million from discontinued operations and a $18.9 million gain from bond repurchases

title: SALVADOR RIGHTS DEBATE CENTERS ON DATA'S VALIDITY
description: As the deadline approaches for President Reagan to issue a Congressionally mandated report on progress on human rights in El Salvador and on the country's effort to redistribute the land, the focus is on numbers. The civilian death toll has dropped considerably, while the number of land titles issued is rising.

title: EVANS-ARISTOCRAT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TWO MAJOR BANKS CUT PRIME TO 15 1/2%
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Chemical Bank dropped their prime lending rates yesterday by one-half point, to 15 1/2 percent, the lowest level for the closely watched interest rate in 20 months. Both big banks cautioned, however, that their actions should not be read as the start of a downward trend.

title: WILKISON IS UPSET IN JERSEY BY 6-1, 7-5
description: Sixth-seeded Tim Wilkison was upset by Erick Iskersky, 6-1, 7-5, today as play began in the $150.000 Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament.

title: BROWN & SHARPE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MERRILL LYNCH PROFIT OFF 46.7% IN QUARTER
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the holding company for the country's largest brokerage firm, said yesterday that it earned $36.1 million, or 90 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 25, down sharply from $67.7 million, or $1.72 a share, in the second quarter of 1981, which was the company's best quarter ever.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH THE REDS
description: N ot that long ago, the Cincinnati Reds were known as the Big Red Machine, but now they're just a little red wagon. While retaining much of the nucleus from the 1976 and 1975 World Series champions, the Reds had baseball's best overall record, 66-42, during last year's strike-interrupted season, but they finished second in each half, thereby failing to qualify for the playoffs. Then the front office chose to trade George Foster, Ken Griffey and Ray Knight, while allowing Dave Collins to test the free-agent market.

title: Sale to United Technologies
description: The United Technologies Corporation said that it had completed the acquisition of several telecommunications divisions of the General Dynamics Corporation for almost $100 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avantek Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., named E. Oran Brigham president, chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Harvester to Shut Plant in England
description: The International Harvester Company said it would close its agricultural parts plant in Bradford, England, and transfer the operations to two plants in Doncaster, England.

title: GIANTS 6, DODGERS 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)-Bill Laskey pitched a three-hitter, and Tom O'Malley highlighted a five-run double for San Francisco. Laskey (8-8), a rookie right hander, struck out six in his fifth complete game of the season and lowered his earned run average to 2.69

title: CONE MILLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOUISVILLE CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Crash Burn Victim Is 'Alert'
description: Rachel Schultz, 7 years old, who was severely burned when a Pan American jetliner crashed into her suburban New Orleans neighborhood on July 9, is ''conscious and alert'' but still in critical condition, a spokesman for the Shriners Burn Institute said today. The child, burned over 80 percent of her body, is undergoing a series of operations to remove damaged skin.

title: Conagra Agrees To Joint Venture
description: Conagra Inc. said it had agreed with Imperial Foods Ltd. of London to form a poultry processing company from two companies owned by the food giants.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some copies of Metropolitan Re- port Thursday an article about single- room-occupancy hotels incorrectly at- tributed a statement to City Council- man Edward C. Wallace of Manhat- tan. It was Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, Democrat of Manhattan, who said that a bill calling for stiffer penalties for illegal eviction originally covered only S.R.O. hotels because the Koch administration had consis- tently opposed an anti-eviction bill proposed in Albany by state legisla- tors from Manhattan.

title: HAZELTINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. SAYS AGAIN THE P.L.O. MUST ACCEPT ISRAEL'S RIGHTS
description: The White House said today that the United States would neither recognize nor negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization until it recognized Israel ''in a clear and unequivocal way.''

title: Reagan Urges Congress To Reject Arms Freeze
description: President Reagan urged Congress today to kill a draft resolution calling for a freeze of Soviet and United States nuclear arms at current levels and approval of the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated

title: POLICE USE TEAR GAS TO ROUT MEAT PLANT MARCHERS
description: It was economic war and Leon Anderson was among the walking wounded. But it was also a war that has sometimes become violent, and there was violence again this afternoon, when state police twice used tear gas to disperse marchers outside the strikebound Iowa Beef Processors Inc. plant here, where Mr. Anderson and 2,400 other members of Local 222 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union worked until seven weeks ago.

title: Learning How to Live With the New Masonite
description: The Masonite Corporation, the nation's largest producer of hardboard, committed itself over the weekend to liquidating a ''substantial'' chunk of its assets - namely, 361,000 acres of timberland in four states. The executive who will preside over the sale, Robert N. Rasmus, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago-based company, admits to a personal affection for the verdant acreage.

title: BONANNO CASE JURY IS TOLD IT WILL HEAR OF PLOT FOR KILLINGS
description: A prosecutor told a jury yesterday that it would hear testimony by an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation about a plot to murder three rival gangsters in ''the Bonanno family of La Cosa Nostra.''

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MISTLER REPORTS EARLY, BUT SADLY
description: John Mistler, last year's highly successful rookie wide receiver, reported to the Giants' training camp today, four days early.

title: RIGGS SEES DOUBLE
description: No knight errant, Bobby Riggs, at age 64, still seems the enfant terrible. The conqueror of Margaret Court and the victim of Billie Jean King - in the two mixed-sexes matches of nearly a decade ago that gave him, as he says, ''instant celebrity'' - Riggs remains on the prowl for a new hustle. And he has one. He calls it a ''godfather deal,'' so compelling it can't be refused.

title: EVENTFUL SUMMER HAS BRITISH ASKING, WHAT NEXT?
description: Dazed, stunned, jittery - such are the words Britons are using to describe the welter of conflicting emotions that have been aroused by a recent succession of inauspicious events.

title: A CABLE DEAL WITH PUBLIC TV
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications is joining forces with a group of public television stations to produce and distribute programs for public television, cable and home video. At the outset the operation will be limited to four adult educational series, but its scope might be expanded.

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $947,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of capital assets

title: U.S. Wife of Russian Leaves Without Him
description: A nurse from Baltimore left Moscow without her Soviet husband today. Clutching their 2-year-old daughter, Elena Kusmenko Balovlenkov, 29, boarded a flight for West Germany, where she planned to spend the night before flying to Baltimore Tuesday, according to a United States diplomat who accompanied her to the terminal.

title: Ruling Backs Home Knitter
description: A Federal district judge today upheld a Labor Department decision to allow commercial knitting of sweaters, scarves and other items at home.

title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
description: Dali Made a Marques

title: REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COLLEGE: NEW WAY TO PAY
description: The dramatic increase in college tuition poses an urgent dilemma for millions of young Americans and their families. No public or private entity can afford to subsidize the difference between the full cost of educating an undergraduate student and what all but the most affluent can pay. I believe we must create an alternative source of student financial assistance by developing capital markets for investment in higher education. In designing these markets, we will be forced to think about higher education in a new way.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (MIAMI, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to June
DIRECTING THE ELECTRONIC TRAFFIC
description: THE world of personal computers is probably second only to the Government as a user of acronyms and abbreviations. From BASIC (Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code) to CP/M (Control Program for Microcomputers), the uninitiated are constantly confronted by alphabet soup. About all they can do is wade in, ask questions and work their way deeper into the swamp. There is solid ground beyond it all.

title: PRENTICE-HALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHILIPS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Johnson & Johnson Loses Court Case
description: A Federal jury in San Francisco has awarded Handgards Inc. a $3.6 antitrust damage verdict in its 20-year-old claim against Ethicon Inc., a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson. Under the Sherman Act, the award can be tripled.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net income for the latest 6 mos reflects nonrecurring net costs of $6.5 millionassociated with the phase-out of carpet plants at Beech Creek and Marietta, Pa

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM MEXICO

U.S. AIDE ENDS SALVADOR VISIT TIED TO CERTIFICATION
description: The Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Thomas O. Enders, ended a two-day visit to El Salvador today.

title: Canada Signs Airbus Pact
description: Canada has joined the European aircraftbuilding consortium, Airbus Industrie, for development and production of a short- and intermediate-range airplane, Airbus said today.

title: NOMINEE TO SEA PARLEY WITHDRAWN BY REAGAN
description: The White House has notified the Senate that President Reagan has decided to withdraw the nomination of James L. Malone as Ambassador-at-Large for the sea-law talks in the face of conflict-of-interest allegations and Senate opposition, Congressional and Administration officials said today.

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition on the pooling of interests method

title: Newsprint Output Down
description: Canadian newsprint production declined sharply in June as the operating rate of mills fell to 79 percent of capacity from 88 percent the month before and from 96 percent in June 1981, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association reported today.

title: ROLLINS BURDICK HUNTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Cutback at Manville
description: The Manville Corporation, hurt by the housing industry slump, said yesterday that it expected to eliminate about 1,500 salaried positions by Sept. 1 instead of the 1,000 it had estimated in May. About $50 million will be saved by the measure, Manville added, with half the positions being cut through layoffs and half through early retirements. The Denver-based building products concern also said that, by the end of its second quarter, it had reduced its shortterm borrowings to $90 million.

title: IN WAKE OF MOUSE MIX-UUP, STUDIES ARE LEFT IN RUIN
description: WASHINGTON AT the University of Wisconsin, a cancer researcher reports that nine months of painstaking work were ''shot'' because the laboratory mice she was using were not the genetically pure strain she had ordered. At the National Institutes of Health in suburban Washington, a virologist says he had to repeat four months of work for the same reason. And at a major cancer center, a young investigator complains that his grant was not renewed and he will have to seek a new job because mislabeled mice caused his experiments to fail, leaving him with no valid findings to publish.

title: Crane Inquiry Results Due by Summer's End
description: The board of inquiry investigating last Wednesday's crane accident at 520 Madison Avenue that killed one person and injured 16 others is to complete its work by Sept. 1, a spokesman for the city's Buildings Department said yesterday.

title: Harold R. Foster Is Dead; Created Prince Valiant
description: Harold R. Foster, creator of the Prince Valiant comic strip, died Sunday at a retirement home in Spring Hill, Fla., near Tampa, where he had lived in recent years after moving from Redding, Conn. He was 89 years old.

Liverpool Neighborhood Erupts in Racial Brawls
description: Roving gangs of youths attacked policemen and firemen with bricks today in a new outbreak of the racial strife that engulfed the Toxteth district of Liverpool last summer.

title: Pennsylvanians Name Ballet Head
description: Robert Weiss has been named artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet. Mr. Weiss, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, will leave the City Ballet to take over his new post Sept. 1.

title: TO GIVE A KNIFE AN EDGE
description: ONE of the most frequent questions I'm asked while giving cooking demonstrations around the country involves the proper method of putting a sharp edge on a knife with a chef's steel. It is a critical issue for a cook because the difference between a well-honed knife and a dull one is the difference between easy, accurate food preparation and tedium.

title: Rizzuto Staying at Mike
description: Phil Rizzuto, who has been a Yankee broadcaster for 26 years, will continue in that role and not retire. There had been reports that the former Yankee shortstop was going to step down, but last night at Yankee Stadium Rizzuto, whose contract has options for the next two seasons, said ''I will honor my contract absolutely.''

title: Anaconda Move
description: Anaconda Industries said it had purchased Exxon Enterprises' silicon carbide venture in Greer, S.C., which produces fiber-reinforced aluminum products. Terms were not disclosed. Anaconda is a subsidiary of Atlantic Richfield and Exxon Enterprises is a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation.

title: Bill on Reactor Cleanup Cost Cleared for Full Senate Action
description: The Senate Environment Committee voted today, 10 to 6, to clear for action by the full Senate a bill that would require the customers of utilities using nuclear power throughout the country to pay part of the cost of cleaning up the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

title: IN PARIS, ANOTHER UNGARO TRIUMPH
description: The first cheers of the current showing season echoed at the Jacquemart-Andre museum this morning when Emanuel Ungaro introduced his fall and winter fashion collection and seemingly could do no wrong. The enthusiastic audience included such people as Marie-Helene de Rothschild and the Americans Lynn Wyatt and Mildred Hilson, who have watched the designer's star rise in the last few years. The rounds of applause began with his first styles, suits with a mannish but soft look in different shades of gray. Black and white knitted tunics over short skirts and knee-baring dresses in the same graphic patterns brought another burst of applause; so did the short bubble skirts for evening in black velvet with lacy camisole tops.

description: W. Earl McCormick, a former senior vice president and director of the Allied Stores Corporation, died Saturday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Bronxville.

description: The Warner-Lambert Company reported today that its second-quarter net income rose 24 percent, to $49.4 million, or 62 cents a share, from $39.7 million, or 50 cents a share in the same quarter last year. The health-care products concern reported that sales rose 2 percent, to $847 million, during the second quarter from $826.7 million during the comparable three months last year. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange rate changes, the company said, sales were up 12 percent.

Real Estate; Reacting To Office Rent Rises
description: LAWYERS and accountants may complain a lot about soaring office rents. Judging from a recent survey, however, the present office market is not creating serious problems for them. The study indicates that many firms simply raise their fees to compensate for large rent increases, and they give little consideration to cost-cutting possibilities, such as moving the firm (or part of it) into cheaper space, sharing offices, using smaller offices, sharing libraries with other firms or increasing the use of electronic storage of information.

title: Apple Charges Counterfeiting
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it was taking legal action against companies in Hong Kong, New Zealand and Taiwan to stop the manufacture and export of imitation Apple II personal computers.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE greatest wines made from the pinot noir grape, as every oenophile soon learns, are the Burgundies of France. Nowhere but in Burgundy are red wines of such majesty and finesse produced, wines of balance and complexity that are sought by collectors and stored away in cellars for consumption on special occasions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This was done in protest against our government's permitting the Soviets to occupy a residence in Glen Cove, tax free, and turning it against our national interests.'' - Mayor Alan M. Parente of Glen Cove, L.I., on the city's banning Soviet diplomats from its recreation sites. (A1:4.)

title: YANKEES ARE FINED OVER WINFIELD PACT

Blueberries
description: The best commercially available blueberries come from Massachusetts, but their season is short, the supply limited and their price, consequently, high. They are available for about a month. You should be able to find them at Balducci's in Greenwich Village, Fairway Fruit and Vegetable on the Upper West Side and Empire Fruit on the Upper East Side starting in about 10 days. Harold Seybert at Fairway estimates that the price for a pint will be at least $1 more than for New Jersey or Michigan blueberries, which are in the market now. Some of the New Jersey and Michigan berries are sweet, others bland.

title: A GIANTS CANDIDATE HAS POLITICAL PLANS
description: Robert Hubble became interested in politics when he was 4 years old. ''My father was a county commissioner in Texas,'' Hubble said today. ''He was in charge of road maintenance. He went to court almost every day, and I went with him. I was always asking, 'Daddy, why are they doing that?' And he would get tired of my questions and tell me to wait in the truck.''

title: CHILDREN'S OWN FAULT
description: Under our "no fault" juvenile justice system, children can get away with most crimes, even fairly serious ones such as burglary and mugging, because they are not considered to be responsible for their actions. But at some arbitrary age - it varies from state to state - youngsters are suddenly transformed into adults. The law judges them responsible for their crimes and they can be punished.

Rangers Dismissing Zimmer
description: Don Zimmer, the manager of the Texas Rangers, has been notified of his dismissal by the owner Eddie Chiles, with the formal announcement to be made shortly, club sources said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Much Waiting, Not Much Working

title: ATTEMPT TO ROB IRANIAN PRINCESS RELATED AT TRIAL
description: A Federal witness testified yesterday that he conspired two years ago with three organized crime figures to rob the Manhattan home of Princess Ashraf Pahlevi, a sister of the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran.

KAHANE HELD FOR HECKLING MARCH
description: Two hundred people marched through the center of West Jerusalem today, waving banners and chanting slogans against Israel's invasion of Lebanon.

title: FIRST LINCOLN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPERRY PLANS SALE OF ITS VICKERS UNIT
description: The Sperry Corporation plans to sell its Sperry Vickers unit to an investment group led by the unit's management and expects an agreement to be completed soon, the company said at its annual meeting in New York yesterday.

title: Cuba and Greece To Exchange Envoys
description: Greece and Cuba agreed today to exchange ambassadors, upgrading their diplomatic relations, after Foreign Minister Isidoro Malmierca had talks with Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: Careers; Training The Future Managers
description: AT a time of relatively high unemployment for middle managers, there is a shortage of teachers in business schools to train future managers. The shortage of holders of Ph.D's in business school subjects has grown so severe in recent years that a panel was set up in 1980 by the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business to study the problem.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEACHES OPEN FOR SWIMMING IN WESTCHESTER
description: Several beaches that have been closed to swimmers since Saturday after patches of foul-smelling pollutants washed ashore from Long Island Sound will be opened Wednesday, Westchester County health officials announced today.

title: ALBANY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: AIRLINES TO SEEK 5% FARE RISES

title: STEPHAN CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: DEFIANT GLEN COVE KEEPS CURBS ON RUSSIANS
description: Despite a request from the State Department that it not meddle in foreign affairs, the City Council of Glen Cove voted 6 to 1 late this afternoon to continue to bar Soviet diplomats from using the city's golf courses, tennis courts and beaches.

title: Group Lifts Stake In Chock Full
description: Jerry Finkelstein said that he and an investment group he leads had increased its stake in the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation to 674,100 shares, or 13.9 percent, from the previous 10.4 percent. Three new members to the group accounted for most of the increase. Mr. Finkelstein is chairman of the Struthers Wells Corporation and, with his son James, publishes the National Law Journal.

title: FILMTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALEXANDER J. SINGLETON
description: Alexander J. Singleton, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Caltex Petroleum Corporation, died Monday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: VENICE RESTORATION REVIVING HOPE AS WELL AS ART
description: Ever since the collapse of the Venetian Republic in 1797, people have been saying that the city of Venice is doomed to sink into that same sea that was once the source of its prosperity, and that it is in every way falling apart - physically, economically and morally. Many is the tract, many the novel and many the movie that has driven the point home.

title: AFRICA PARLEY DELAYED IN DISPUTE
description: The opening of a foreign ministers' meeting of the Organization of African Unity was delayed today by an impasse over the Polisario guerrillas.

title: SALEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss in the qr includes a $419,000 loss from discontinued operations and net loss for the 6 mos includes a loss of $808,000 from discontinued operations

title: CONDUCT TO BE MONITORED IN CITY'S POLITICAL RACES
description: Thirty New Yorkers yesterday announced the formation of a new organization to monitor this year's political campaigns in the city. The group seeks ''to discourage political campaigning that appeals to prejudice based on race, ethnicity, religious identity, national origin, gender or sexual orientation.''

title: ASARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
American Can, Transport Merger
description: The American Can Company said that its directors and those of the Transport Life Insurance Company had approved a definitive $152 million merger agreement under which holders of Transport Life's stock would receive $26.50 cash a share.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Con Ed Chief Executive Adds Title of Chairman
description: Arthur Hauspurg, who took over from Charles F. Luce as chief executive officer of the Consolidated Edison Company a year ago, was elected yesterday to succeed Mr. Luce as chairman as well, effective Sept. 1.

title: JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Decision Awaited
description: Hu Na, the 19-year-old Chinese tennis player who has requested political asylum in the United States, may have to wait several weeks for a decision, according to an official of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. David Ilchert, a district director of the agency, said he could not act until he received an advisory opinion from the State Department in Washington.

title: EL PASO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERSTATE MOTOR FREIGHT SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PICKING THE BEST FROM THE SEASON'S FRUIT CROP
description: GOLDEN peaches, nectarines with a blush of red on their cheeks and mahogany red cherries are beckoning from the fruit stands, just as they do every summer. The buyer, recalling taste sensations from summers past, tries a bite, then another, then a third - and is disappointed. The fruit looks good, but those looks have been deceiving. One bite into a perfectly ripened, deep purple Laroda plum, however, or an intensely colored West Side cantaloupe from California, both of which are in the stores now, have provided ample compensation for those other disappointments.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for QTr to May 31
description: B-Including gains from discontinued operations of $220,000 for the qr and $292,000 for the yr

title: A Turning Point For Coach's Son
description: Stan Williams is pitching for the Yankees - not the New York Yankees, but the Fort Lauderdale Yankees. And not the 45-year-old Stan Williams, but his son.

title: OCEAN DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RELIABILITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE LOCAL ALTERNATIVES TO TASTELESS TOMATOES
description: Several years ago the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association made an effort to convince American shoppers that the tomatoes they purchase in the supermarket are better than they think they are. The association said it is ''a common consumer misconception that tomatoes are thick-skinned.''

title: Guatemala Says Rebels Closed a Key Highway
description: Leftist rebels killed 22 peasants today and dynamited two key bridges, closing the Pan American Highway, the Defense Ministry said.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $1.6 million

title: XEROX PROFIT DECLINED 10.2% IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that net income in its second quarter declined 10.2 percent from a year earlier. And were it not for special gains, the company said, net income for the period would have fallen by about 36 percent.

title: INQUIRY PUZZLES CHIP MAKERS
description: Executives of Japanese and American semiconductor makers expressed puzzlement yesterday about a Justice Department disclosure that it was investigating six Japanese companies for possible price-fixing on shipments of computer chips to the United States.

title: Nucorp Energy Files A Chapter 11 Petition
description: The Nucorp Energy Corporation, an ambitious oilfield services company that flourished on sales to Southwestern drillers, said late this afternoon that it had filed for protection from creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In Central Park, Trees Offstage and On

title: LIEBERT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STUDY ON HOMELESS SEES SOME GAINS ON SHELTERS
description: A new report on New York City's public shelters for the homeless says that, while the public shelter system ''has been expanded considerably'' since last year, ''distressing deficiencies remain.''

title: Dr. Walter Mersheimer, A Medical Educator, 71
description: Dr. Walter L. Mersheimer, a former professor and chairman of the department of surgery at the New York Medical College, died of a heart attack Monday at the Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital.

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WEDNESDAY, JULY 28, 1982; The Economy
description: The Congressional Budget Office issued a new economic forecast that is more pessimistic than the Reagan Administration's. It said annual budget deficits would range from $140 billion to $160 billion over the next three fiscal years. (Page D1.)

title: J.A.L. to Buy 10 Jets
description: Yasumoto Takagi, president of Japan Air Lines, said today that J.A.L. planned to buy about 10 medium-range jetliners in 1986 to replace DC-8 jets. He told a news conference that J.A.L. had many models to choose from, including Boeing B-767's and Airbus Industrie's A-310's. J.A.L. now operates 41 B-747's, 17 DC-10's, 22 DC-8's and two B-727's. Mr. Takagi said he wants a final decision on the model toward the end of the year but J.A.L. would have to study fuel efficiency, noise and prices before deciding.

title: PLACEMENT OF ANTI-ISRAELI MESSAGE VIOLATED POLICY, AD AGENCY SAYS
description: The head of a New York-based advertising agency said yesterday that a political advertisement it placed in five newspapers, which appeared to attribute anti-Israel sentiments to six relief organizations, had been handled in violation of company policy.

title: Knoxville Police Find Explosives at Y.M.C.A.
description: The police found more explosive chemicals and a guide for making bombs today when they returned to a Y.M.C.A. with a former convict who officers say had hidden weapons, dynamite and stolen computer equipment in his rooms.

title: Huge Obstacles for Jet Tryouts
description: Someone pinch-hit for Babe Ruth, and Joe Namath eventually lost his job to a younger quarterback. So with the start of the New York Jets' training camp only a day away, is it surprising that some virtually unknown players are trying to land jobs as defensive ends on a team anchored by a pair of all-stars?

title: BUDGET-BALANCING FORCES WIN NARROW SENATE VOTE
description: Opponents of a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget took heart today after they made a strong showing in an early test vote on the Senate floor.

title: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Doctor Convicted of Rape Begins Prison Term
description: A doctor who left the country while awaiting sentencing on a rape conviction today was ordered to begin serving a six-month prison term.

title: UNCHANGED ARAFAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Con Ed Profit Climbs 8.8%
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday that it earned $87.7 million in the second quarter, up 8.8 percent from $80.6 million in the corresponding quarter of 1981.

title: SUMMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. AND INDONESIA, LONG CLOSE, DRIFT APART ON SEVERAL ISSUES
description: A modest protest recently at the United States Embassy in Jakarta by a group of Moslem youths protesting American support for Israel was just one example of the tensions between Indonesia and the United States.

title: More Integration Asked In Nashville Schools
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered more integration of schools in Nashville, saying that a plan approved by a Federal district judge did not place enough blacks in predominantly white schools.

title: ASMUSSEN MENDS IN FRANCE
description: sur-SEINE, France The surgeon tugged firmly on the drainage tubes in Cash Asmussen's left foot until the tubes broke free of the dried blood and swollen flesh.

Short-Term Interest Rates Up
description: Short-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday while note and bond yields declined slightly. Trading volume was light as market participants waited for today's announcement of Treasury borrowing plans.

description: B-Including a gain of $228,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of assets andnonrecurring income of $6,969,000 for the qr and 6 mos from license of uranium recovery technology...C-Includ ing a gain of $714,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of assets and a nonrecurring charges of $38,000 for the qr and $3,362,000 for the 6 mos from reorganization expenses

title: Economic Scene; The New Pragmatism
description: BACK from vacation, one finds many changes to sort out. Nothing to do but roll up the sleeves and plunge in: What is happening to United States foreign economic policy? Versailles was supposed to have straightened out our strained relations with our European allies and Japan. A deal on East-West trade was supposed to have been set, with the allies accepting limits on government-to-government credits to the Soviet Union in exchange for American acceptance of the principle of ''let the market function'' on private deals, presumably including the deals over the Soviet gas pipeline to Western Europe and the Sakhalin project for Japan.

title: ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $364,000 for the qr and 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: The Safe but Crowded Skies
description: It's been a year since President Reagan gambled that he could keep America flying without the striking air controllers. By all the obvious tests, he has won the showdown. Fewer controllers now police the skies, but safety remains impressive. Travelers are routinely inconvenienced by peak-hour delays at major airports, but all manage to get where they are going.

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOREIGN TRIPS, AT TIMES, BRING DOMESTIC TROUBLE
description: Was Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. misled by Yasir Arafat or did he misunderstand what the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization had to say about Israel's right to exist?

title: Sherrill Defends Pact
description: Jackie Sherrill, whose earnings as the new coach of the Texas A&M football team are expected to reach $225,000 a year with fringe benefits, says the sharp criticism of his contract has come from some academicians ''who live in glass houses.''

title: A LANDMARK 'VILLAGE' GAS STATION
description: It is a sorry shell of a building - a peeling, rusted, partly boarded-up shop in Greenwich Village with cracked windows, a spotty, red-shingled roof that is more roof than shingle and, inside, a yellowed calendar turned to the month of December, the year obscured by a rag.

title: Revenue Bill Is Stalled in the House
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, split along party lines, failed to reach agreement tonight on how to go about shaping a revenue-raising bill.

title: INDIANS EAGER TO GREET MRS. GANDHI
description: Hetal Gandhi takes ballet and tap lessons, knows all the words to such popular songs as ''The Eye of the Tiger'' and ''Valley Girls'' and wears the kind of casual summer clothes displayed in store windows in every suburban shopping mall in America.

title: THE 'CATASTROPHE' WATT IS INVITING
description: To the Editor:

title: PEERLESS CHAIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reagan Praises A Cut in Prime
description: President Reagan began applying personal pressure from the White House today to get big city bankers aboard his campaign against high interest rates.

title: Randolph Consultants Is to Be Reactivated
description: Charles C. Randolph Jr. has decided to reactivate Randolph Consultants, which had once worked for both Dow Jones and Hachette, the French publisher.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN MAY IGNORE CEILING ON MILITARY FUNDS
description: President Reagan does not feel bound by the ceilings on military spending for 1984 and beyond that were set by Congress last month with the White House's blessing, Administration officials said today.

title: E.E.C. Inflation Figures
description: The consumer price index for the 10-member European Economic Community rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent from May to June, the community's statistics agency reported today. Greece had the biggest jump in inflation during the month - 2.6 percent -followed by Luxembourg with 1.1 percent, and West Germany and Italy, each with 1 percent.

title: Kean is Suing to Block Offshore-Leasing Plan
description: Governor Kean has filed suit in Federal Court here to block the leasing by the Department of the Interior of 23 offshore tracts for oil and gas drilling.

title: Maine College Divestiture
description: Trustees of the University of Maine voted to divest the school of about $3 million in investments in corporations that do business with South Africa because of that country's racial policies, it was announced today.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE wlonk wlite of New York is sometimes awesome, as well as the things about our town that wlate. No comprende? Well, Donald E. Westlake does. Mr. Westlake, the author of such thrillers as ''The Hot Rock'' and ''Cops and Robbers,'' has been spending the summer dipping into the Oxford English Dictionary - the O.E.D. - and he has made a discovery.

title: CITY AGREES TO BROOKLYN HOME LOANS
description: The Koch administration has agreed to lend $10 million to a coalition of 36 Brooklyn churches that plans to build 5,000 singlefamily town houses in blighted sections of Brooklyn.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some recipes call for soaking potatoes, and I wonder why. How long should the soaking last? Is overnight too long?

description: B-After loss of $240,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net income is after $555,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: DRUG PATENT EXTENSION DRAWS HEAVY LOBBYING
description: Amid heavy lobbying, the House Judiciary Committee is considering legislation that would extend the life of patents to compensate drug and chemical companies for delays caused by compliance with Federal health and safety regulations.

description: B-Includes a gain of $4.5 million on the sale of fluid paper operations

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A VERY CHEESY WAR
description: So it has come to warfare with the Europeans, and once again America is caught with a shortage of songs to lift our morale as we face the dark days ahead.

title: Required Reading Waiting for Block
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, commenting on failure of Agriculture Secretary John R. Block to respond to a June 22 letter criticizing officials of the Food and Nutrition Service for refusing to provide information on food stamps, July 16, 1982:

title: Clinging to Caps
description: Our nation's capital may not have enough pro hockey fans, but those it has are diehards. In an effort to keep the Washington Capitals alive, they are putting in long hours scouring the area for potential ticket purchasers and helping to answer phones at the team's ticket office from 9 A.M. until 10 P.M. every day.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BLUE BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARGIOTTA'S EXTORTION CONVICTION UPHELD
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican Party chairman of Nassau County, lost an appeal yesterday to overturn his conviction for fraud and extortion involving insurance kickbacks for political associates.

title: Canada-Airbus Accord
description: The memorandum of understanding Canada signed with the European aircraft builder Airbus Industrie to develop a new commercial airliner is only an agreement to begin talks, a spokesman for de Havilland Aircraft of Canada Ltd. said yesterday. Canada's industry ministry said the agreement made formal an ''intention to begin formal negotiations to see if there is a basis for partnership by the Canadian aerospace manufacturing sector in the Airbus Industrie A-320 aircraft program.''

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $68,000 for the qr and $176,000 for the 6 mos...C-After foreign currency translation losses of $7,000 for the qrand $30,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: WARSAW ANNOUNCES COMPLETION OF THE PARTIAL RELEASE OF INTERNEES
description: The Polish authorities said today that they had completed the partial release of martial law internees announced last week.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Larry Demic, a forward for the Knicks for the last three seasons who rarely started, has decided to play his professional basketball in Europe next season. Demic signed a one-year contract to play for Benetton, of Treviso, Italy, according to his agent, Larry Fleisher. ... Don King, the promoter, announced that the Aug. 14 heavyweight fight between Trevor Berbick and Renaldo Snipes would be held in Cleveland and carried on ABC-TV . ... The latest players to confirm that they will come to Giants Stadium for the World All-Stars Game Aug. 7 are three men from the West German National Team that lost to Italy in the World Cup final - the goalkeeper Toni Schumacher, Karl-Heinz Foerster, a defender, and Pierre Littbarski, a forward.

title: Parks Better Pruned Than Pure
description: New York's Central Park is beloved by many for its canny imitation of nature. But it is admired by others because its natural materials are alive, sometimes rebelling against the most loving plans. The interventionists are led by the authorities charged with maintaining the park as an enchanted, varied garden. The aroused lobby opposing them is led by the city's Audubon Society, which prefers nature pure rather than pruned because it fears losing visits from migratory birds.

title: 'OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN,' NAVY LOVE STORY
description: THE hero of ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' is neither of those things when the movie begins, but he is both by the time it is over. In this resolutely old-fashioned Navy tale, a selfish, hard-hearted loner becomes a much, much better man, thanks to the rigors of basic training and the love of a good woman. Undeniably, there's an element of corniness to this. But that doesn't keep ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' from being a first-rate movie - a beautifully acted, thoroughly involving romance. If this summer hasn't previously had a wonderful Hollywood love story to call its own, it has one now.

description: B-After a $871,000 charge...C-After a gain of $133,000

title: Hunger by Any Other Name
description: ''Under-adjustment'' is a favorite Congressional word in a year of brutal budget cuts. It's a euphemism for letting programs erode, by not adjusting fully for cost-of-living increases.

title: CITY DISPLAYS ITS ROTTING STRUCTURES
description: ''From up here, it doesn't look so bad,'' George Zaimes said as a bus load of Federal, state and city officials rumbled over a bumpy Henry Hudson Parkway yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN NEW SET OF TV ADS
description: The Democratic National Committee announced plans today for a $1.5 million to $2 million television advertising campaign this fall and said half the money had already been raised with union help.

title: TRUMAN ON CUBA
description: To the Editor:

PETROLEUM ACREAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Reagan's News Session To Be on TV at 8 P.M.
description: President Reagan's news conference will be covered live tonight at 8 P.M., Eastern daylight time, on ABC, CBS, NBC, Cable News Network and Satellite News Channel.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Restaurants in Bavaria
description: TO THE THE LIVING SECTION: Having just read Marian Burros's ''Munich: A City of Contrasts'' (July 7), I recalled my own culinary experiences in Munich and other parts of Bavaria and the Black Forest last summer.

title: Help for Ex-Quarterback
description: The publicity given to a former Denver Broncos quarterback's troubles with alcoholism has prompted offers of help from several Broncos players, a Congressional candidate and numerous others.

title: COINCIDING INTERESTS FOR INDIA AND U.S.
description: India's Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi, will be President Reagan's guest tomorrow. We can hope that better mutual understanding and improved working relations between the largest and the most powerful of the world's democracies will result.

title: The U.N. Today; July 28, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission 15th Ses- sion - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Hanna Sees New Cash as Growth Aid
description: It was a long and frequently acrimonious takeover battle, and the target company was saved only by an 11th-hour Federal court decision. Norcen Energy Resources Ltd., a Toronto-based company controlled by Conrad Black, attempted to gain control of the Hanna Mining Company, a Cleveland company with heavy ties to the ailing steel industry. Resolution finally came a few weeks ago with an agreement between the warring companies that allowed Norcen to raise its stake in Hanna to 20 percent from 8.8 percent by buying newly issued shares. For its part, Hanna got paid $90 million in cash.

title: WELLS FARGO MORTGAGE & EQUITY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nebraska Guardsmen Arrive at Strike Site
description: National Guardsmen began taking up positions today at the gates of a beef processing plant and slaughterhouse where state troopers have repeatedly clashed with stone-throwing strikers over the past week.

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a tax credit of $3,488,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-After a tax charge of $450,000 from the reversal of a tax credit which was offset by a tax credit of $450,000; the company is listed on the Philadelphia and Boston stock exchanges

title: Phillips Bradley, 88, A Specialist on Labor
description: Phillips Bradley, a professor of political science who specialized in labor and industrial problems, died July 13 at a retirement home in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 88 years old.

title: UNITED STATES STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Second qr of 1982 includes results of the Marathon Oil Company acquired earlierthis yr

title: BEGIN AND HABIB MEET BUT GIVE NO PROGRESS REPORT
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin met for two hours and 20 minutes this evening with Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's mediator in the search for a settlement of the conflict in Lebanon. They emerged from the meeting separately, tired and taciturn, giving no indication of progress.

title: EASTERN, NORTHWEST POST LOSSES
description: Two of the nation's biggest airlines, Eastern and Northwest, said yesterday that they posted losses in the second quarter because air traffic declined and discount fares cut into revenue.

title: Colts' Carr Suspended
description: The growing bitterness between Roger Carr, wide receiver for the Colts, and the Baltimore management has passed the arguing stage.

title: '81 Winner Repeats At Festival
description: Jesse Benavides became the only repeat winner in boxing at the National Sports Festival tonight, and Floyd Favors, the world amateur champion, scored a controversial 3-2 decision over Herb Bivalacqua in the 125-pound division final.

title: Maglie in Hospital
description: Sal Maglie, a pitching mainstay of the Giants when they played at the Polo Grounds in the 1940's, is in critical condition in an upstate hospital after undergoing surgery for a brain hemorrhage. Maglie, who is 65 years old, was admitted to the Niagara Falls Memorial Medical Center on July 21 and was operated on three days later ''to drain a hemorrhage of the brain,'' according to Dr. David Cooper, a neurosurgeon.

title: BICYCLE RACER MAKING SPRINT TO THE TOP
description: An infuriated driver in midtown Manhattan once challenged Nelson Vails as the young cyclist leaned on the man's car for support at a red light. Vails, who was working for a bicycle delivery service, described himself as ''one of the very best'' in the business. And he said he did not get that way by backing down from a challenge.

title: TRICO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RECAST TIES TO ISRAEL
description: Both Yasir Arafat's deliberately ambiguous statement regarding United Nations Palestinian resolutions and Israel's scornful rejection were predictable. No one should expect the Palestine Liberation Organization to give up its commitment to Israel's destruction, which is its sole bargaining counter, without some assurance of a national home and ultimate self-determination. Prime Minister Menachem Begin, on the other hand, will do everything possible to avoid negotiations on that basis. That was his Government's main objective in invading Lebanon. It wished to destroy the P.L.O.'s top leadership and thus silence the only legitimate and recognized Palestinian opposition so Israel could impose Mr. Begin's own version of West Bank autonomy - a concept, as he has redefined it, that remarkably resembles apartheid.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AMONG foods believed to possess powers that exceed their caloric punch, oysters have long been prized as boosters of sexual potency. Though not quite the aphrodisiacs of myth, oysters, it turns out, are richly endowed with an essential nutrient crucial to sexual maturity and fertility.

title: FABERGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $97,985 for the qr and $168,034 for the 6 mos

title: Dow Declines 2.67, to 822.77; Weakness In Utilities
description: Stock prices gave ground yesterday as additional companies reported lower profits for the June quarter. Xerox and Avon Products, former glamour stocks, each sold at their lowest prices in many years after announcing a decline in earnings.

title: CASTRO TELLS CUBA OF HARD TIMES AHEAD
description: President Fidel Castro, blaming a ''capitalist crisis,'' warned Cubans Monday night that some of them might have to endure shorter workweeks and lower salaries because of the worldwide economic recession.

title: JACK HIGGINS'S ODYSSEY: POTBOILER TO BEST SELLER
description: ''TOUCH THE DEVIL,'' the new novel by the best-selling British author Jack Higgins, has a scene in which a terrorist penetrates 10 Downing Street and confronts Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in her study. Security is much tighter around British officials since those words were written, as a result of the recent discovery of an intruder in the Queen's bedroom and other security problems, but Mr. Higgins thinks it could still use improvement.

title: BRIEFING
description: Talk of Air Force One

title: NEWELL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Sweet Victories For Agency Incumbents
description: There must be something in the stars that is helpful to agency incumbents. Suddenly they are winning competitions. Usually they go down the drain.

title: GATEWAY TO THE FALKLANDS: AN ATLANTIC ROCK HUMS WITH SOUTHBOUND TRAFFIC
description: Each day from this volcanic island halfway between Britain and the Falkland Islands two Hercules C-130 transport planes head south toward Stanley, the Falkland capital.

title: Zimbabwe Intensifies Search For 6 Kidnapped Foreigners
description: The Zimbabwe Government has broadened a curfew to 20 hours a day and poured more soldiers into the search for two Americans and four other foreigners held under threat of death by kidnappers, an army colonel said today.

title: ABSCAM 'BOUNTIES' DEBATED IN SENATE
description: The question whether the Federal Bureau of Investigation paid a ''bounty'' to those who placed public officials in position to be bribed touched off debate today at Senate hearings on undercover activities.

Brazil Orange Output Grows
description: Brazil has edged ahead of the United States in orange production, helped along by Brazilian Government subsidies and tree-damaging freezes in Florida, according to Florida agricultural officials.

title: PITNEY-BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. AGENCY FINDS INDIAN POACHERS PERIL SALMON
description: The Federal and state authorities, fearful that declines in some salmon runs on the Columbia River may lead to extinction of the fish, have begun a determined fight to halt salmon poaching by Indians.

title: GF BUSINESS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Johns-Manville
description: Johns-Manville Canada Inc. said it had applied for a $35 million grant from the Canadian Government to resume expansion work at its asbestos mine in Quebec. The company, a subsidiary of the Denverbased Johns-Manville Corporation, suspended expansion work in two sections of its open-pit mine in February, laying off 150 workers.

title: 120 REPORTED DEAD AS ISRAELIS BOMB WEST BEIRUT AREA
description: In Jerusalem, where Palestinians and Israeli shoppers mingle, Palestinians of west Beirut are an abstraction for many Israelis. Page A16.

title: TAFT BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PREVENTING REACTIONS TO STINGS
description: Some 1.5 million Americans allergic to the stings of bees, wasps and other insects of summer should carry a fountain pen device full of adrenalin that can prevent possible death, a member of the board of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America said this week.

STANDARD-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MUSIC: PARKS SERIES OPENS WITH BANG
description: CLASSICAL music may be a highbrow art form, but it would have been difficult to believe that last night, at the beginning of the New York Philharmonic's 18th season of free summer parks concerts on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

title: Savings-Loan Bid Criticized
description: An official of Citicorp said today that the Federal Government had abandoned established rules in permitting a second round of bidding for Fidelity Savings of San Francisco.

title: ERA ENDS AS LAND LEAVES POLAROID
description: Edwin H. Land, the brilliant scientist who founded and built the Polaroid Corporation by inventing and constantly refining the instant camera, stepped down yesterday as chairman and a director, and said he would sever all ties with the company by the end of the year.

CHINA ASSAILS JAPAN'S BOOKS ON 30'S INVASION
description: China has mounted angry objections to what it says are distortions in new Japanese textbooks about Japan's invasion of the Chinese mainland before World War II.

title: 1. Borrowing From Men
description: Girls will be boys this year, borrowing blazers, dinner jackets and dress shirts from their men's wardrobes. To complete this black-tie look, there is enough haberdashery in women's departments to make them resemble the main floor at Brooks Brothers. The SoHo boutique called Diddington's has a good collection of these bits and pieces: bow ties made of leather printed in plaids or geometrics ($12.50), leather cummerbunds in red, charcoal gray, white or black ($32.50) or in printed satin or solid colored moire ($16), patterned suspenders ($6.50). For day wear, there are checked newsboy's caps ($16). Diddington's is at 143 Prince Street.

title: NOTED FOR TENDER MODERNISM
description: Kenzo Okada, a Japanese-American modernist painter whose delicate, highly praised abstractions have been exhibited around the world, died of a heart ailment Sunday in Tokyo, where a major retrospective exhibition of his work was recently on display at the Seibu Museum of Art. He was 79 years old and lived in Tokyo and Manhattan.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Qtr preferred divid requirements exceeded net income

title: A Dissident Voice
description: Another voice has been raised in opposition to a possible players' strike against the National Football League. Dan Fouts, quarterback for the San Diego Chargers, thinks that the demands of the N.F.L. Players Association are ''ridiculous'' and says that he will not strike if the union ''continues its current posture.''

title: MOBIL NET DOWN 55.7% IN QUARTER
description: Continuing a string of earnings declines in the oil industry, the Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, said yesterday that its second-quarter net income fell 55.7 percent, to $310 million. The company cited a continuing worldwide oversupply of oil that had held down the selling price of its crude in the face of higher costs of production.

title: PINKERTON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: WIDENING OF DEFICITS IS FORECAST
description: The Congressional Budget Office, in a new forecast more pessimistic than the Administration's, said today that annual Federal budget deficits would range from $140 billion to $160 billion over the next three fiscal years.

title: LAG IN DRAFT REGISTRATION RAISES DOUBT THAT LAW CAN BE ENFORCED
description: Almost 150,000 young men have failed to register for the draft since March, bringing the total to at least 675,000 since 1980, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: PARLEY ASSERTS U.S. UNDERCUTS FAMILY
description: The theorists, economists, politicians and evangelical ministers of the ''new right'' asserted today that the Goverment had systematically undercut the strength of the family in the name of aiding it and that the family itself was drowning in the tides of sexual revolution.
