Convicted Guerrilla Slain in Italian Prison
description: A convicted Red Brigades guerrilla was stabbed and strangled to death today by unknown assailants in the top security section of the prison in this Adriatic town, the police said.

title: NBC-TV Finds a Spot For 'Taxi' on Thursday
description: ''Taxi,'' the award-winnning comedy series dropped by ABC-TV last spring, has found a spot on NBC-TV's schedule, on Thursdays at 9:30 P.M., starting Sept. 30.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE-PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
N.R.C. LIMITS INVESTIGATION INTO SAFETY AT INDIAN POINT
description: A divided Nuclear Regulatory Commission today ordered that hearings on the safety of the Indian Point nuclear reactors be narrowed in scope.

CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Bid for Scherer
description: The R.P. Scherer Corporation said its board had unanimously decided that the FMC Corporation's $90.2 million tender offer for it was inadequate and not in the company's best interest. It urged shareholders to reject it.

title: REAGAN CERTIFIES SALVADOR FOR AID
description: President Reagan, seeking continued aid to El Salvador, certified to Congress today that that nation was making progress on human rights and on changes in the economic and political systems even though ''serious problems'' remained.

title: SHERRITT GORDON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Company is listed on the Toronto stock exchange

title: POSSIBILITY OF VETO IS RAISED
description: The House Appropriations Committee today agreed to a supplemental money bill of about $14 billion that would provide more than $6 billion for Federal pay increases. The measure would also place a ceiling on the outside earnings of members of the Senate.

title: Kurtz & Tarlow Wins Formica Account
description: Kurtz & Tarlow, a division of Geers, Gross Advertising, has become agency for Formica, a subsidiary of American Cyanamid.

title: XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
An Almost Fun Weekend
description: Over the weekend at the Stadium, the Yankees played baseball instead of crybaby, and it was almost fun again to watch them win two out of three.

title: Switch Is Possible
description: The politics of international soccer can be delicate, so nobody would dare suggest it outright. But it looks like Jupp Derwall, coach of the West German national team that lost to Italy in the World Cup final, may step down as coach of the European team for the World All-Stars Game that will be played Aug. 7 at Giants Stadium.

title: Accounts
description: * Alan Flusser Inc., a new men's wear designer, to Herman & Rosner Enterprises.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARGENTINA RELIEVES DEFEATED OFFICERS OF POSTS
description: The repercussions of Argentina's defeat on the Falkland Islands continued here as the army relieved the senior commanders directly involved in the campaign of their posts today.

title: VALERO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK CITY'S SOUND, BALANCED BUDGET FOR '83
description: To the Editor:

title: End to Tax Aid Urged
description: The United States Trade Office said today that the deferral of certain taxes on domestic income of corporations engaged in exporting should end. The practice has been criticized as a subsidy violating international trade rules by the European Economic Community in a complaint to the council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva.

title: FORD'S 2d-QUARTER PROFIT CLIMBS TO $205 MILLION
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it earned $205 million, or $1.70 a share, in the second quarter, its first quarterly profit since the second period of 1981, when it earned $60.2 million, or 50 cents a share.

title: 2 ARRESTED IN SILICON VALLEY THEFT CASE
description: In the latest of several arrests aimed at curbing the theft of sophisticated technology from companies in California's Silicon Valley, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it had arrested two men on charges of attempting to sell stolen electronics hardware to an agent posing as a representative of the Chinese Government.

title: SHELLER-GLOBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. STEEL EARNINGS FALL 97.4%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, citing the ''severe impact'' of the recession on its steel operations, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter plummeted 97.4 percent, to $4.3 million.

title: DICOMED CORP reports earnings for QTr to June 30
NEW COOKBOOKS SUITED FOR ENTERTAINING
description: THERE are several new cookbooks that dispute Harry Truman's aphorism - they may inspire you to get into the kitchen no matter how hot it is. These are attractive volumes, each filled with interesting recipes, menus and food ideas, simple and complex, mostly suited to entertaining. You won't just want to light the stove, you are likely to plan dinner parties.

title: Louis Dean, Advertising Man And Early Radio Announcer
description: Louis E. Dean, one of the first radio announcers and a former advertising executive, died Sunday at Tampa (Fla.) General Hospital.

title: RCA GAMBLING ON KENNY ROGERS
description: THE announcement last week that Kenny Rogers, the country-pop superstar, had signed a long-term worldwide recording contract with RCA Records has the record industry clucking. At a time when the industry is in a serious recession, the deal was reportedly the largest ever offered to a single act, which make it in excess of $20 million; RCA has refused to be specific about the terms.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JULY 28, 1982
description: International The siege of Beirut worsened. For the first time since Israel's invasion of Lebanon, Israeli jets bombed a heavily populated residential area near the heart of west Beirut, damaging more than a dozen apartment buildings. Police sources said 120 people had been killed and 232 wounded, most of them civilians. (Page A1, Column 6.) An Israeli-American meeting headed by Prime Minister Menachem Begin and the special mediator, Philip C. Habib, lasted two hours and 20 minutes. The two emerged from the conference in Jerusalem separately, weary and indicating that no progress had been made in the effort to ease the Lebanon crisis. (A16:1-3.)

title: GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DRAMATISTS GUILD SUED OVER ROYALTY PAYMENTS
description: A longtime dispute over royalties paid to writers in the Broadway theater ended up in court yesterday as a member of the League of New York Theaters and Producers filed an antitrust suit against the Dramatists Guild.

title: HERS
description: THE woman was standing on the overpass, hair matted and grizzled, gray skirts flowing around her despite the sweltering heat. Her shopping cart, crammed with her worldly possessions was drawn up beside her. She was leaning against the gray concrete balustrade and she occasionally raised her head as if to survey the view, the sea of cars moving around her. As we drew closer, I saw the notebook and the pencil. The woman was writing.

title: Coast Utility To Cut 16,000
description: The Pacific Telephone Company, California's largest private employer, plans to reduce through attrition its nonmanagement payroll by 16,000 workers over the next 18 months, a company spokesman said.

title: SCHOOLS ON LIST OF THOSE LOSING LOAN ELIGIBILITY
description: The Education Department named 528 schools today as ineligible for new National Direct Student Loan funds in the coming school year, on the ground their default rates were 25 percent or more as of June 30, 1981. Later, however, an aide to Education Secretary T.H. Bell said that 92 of those schools had successfully appealed to retain their eligibility.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Healthdyne Inc. said it would file with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of about one million shares, to be made in late August.

title: Kraft Off; General Foods Rises
description: Three leading makers of food and other consumer products reported substantially improved earnings in their food divisions for their most recent quarters, largely because the recession has not dampened consumer demand for the basic food items the companies sell.

title: WAR SPARED FALKLAND WILDLIFE, BUT WILL THE PEACE
description: The penguins, seals and other wildlife of the Falkland Islands were spared serious damage in the fighting here ''through a bit of good luck,'' said Ian J. Strange, the islands' conservationist.

title: WESTCOAST TRANSMISSION CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A ROOKIE AGAIN
description: Around this time each year since 1969, home for Joe Greene has always been room 138 in Bonaventure Hall, looking out over the little cemetery at St. Vincent's College in Latrobe, Pa., where the Pittsburgh Steelers perspire in training camp with the hope of freezing in the Super Bowl playoffs. But this year Joe Greene is carrying a briefcase in training camp, instead of a helmet.

title: DAN SEYMOUR, EX-ANNOUNCER AND ADVERTISING LEADER, DIES
description: Dan Seymour, who served as president and later chairman of the board of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency in the 1960's and early 70's, died Tuesday night of a heart attack in his apartment in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: Bats for Racquets
description: This time of year, the Volvo Grand Prix tennis tour stops at North Conway, N.H., and tonight is the night for the big North Conway showdown, the event that causes the most excitement among players and the town's tennis fans each year. And it is not a tennis match.

title: IMPORTS FROM ASIA CUT CARLISLE'S SALES OF BICYCLE TIRES
description: Twenty years ago, virtually every major rubber company in the United States manufactured bicycle tires and tubes. Today, the field has been reduced to one, the Carlisle Tire and Rubber Company, and it is struggling.

title: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains of $1.2 million for the qr and $2 million for the 6 mos on the sale of property and equipment

title: Profit for VW in U.S.
description: Volkswagen of America turned a marginal profit in the first six months of the year, according to James. W. McLernon, president. Mr. McLernon's statement Tuesday followed a 45 percent drop in sales this year compared with last year's sales of United States-built Rabbit subcompacts.

title: MGM UA AND WARNER ENDS TALKS
description: Warner Communications said today that it had terminated discussions aimed at acquiring the United Artists music company and Warner Bros. pre-1950 film library from MGM/UA, an unexpected decision that casts a long shadow over MGM/UA's efforts to resolve its financial problems.

title: DI GIORGIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
METS' PITCHERS FAIL AFTER STERN LECTURE
description: Manager George Bamberger warned the Mets tonight that they had two months to prove they were not losers or ''I'll do everything in my power to get rid of them.''

title: YOUTH WORK PROPOSALS ARE ASSAILED AT HEARING
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed changes in child labor regulations were described today as an effort to ''create a kiddy work force'' and an act of ''insensitivity and stupidity.''

title: DETROIT: THE SLUMP PERSISTS
description: With second-quarter earnings out, the nation's major car makers appear somewhat healthier. General Motors and Chrysler earned more than had been expected, and Ford had its first profit in a year.

title: Technology; Preserving Memories
description: IMAGINE how much less useful tape recorders would be if the tape were automatically erased every time the recorder was turned off. This has been the case with computer memory chips: Most computer memory chips lose their memory when the computer is turned off or when there is a sudden loss of power. There are chips that are like record albums and can store information permanently, but, like records, that information cannot be changed.

title: INTERNATIONAL SHIPHOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $595,000 for the qr and $1.2 million for the 6 mos...C-Net income

title: SAFEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sims Seeks Extension
description: The Detroit Lions' veterans are scheduled to report to training camp today, but Billy Sims, their star running back, may not be among them. Jerry Argovitz, Sims's agent, has told the Detroit management that his client will not report to camp unless the Lions agree to a contract extension.

title: 2 Top South African Officials In South-West Africa for Talks
description: West Africa, July 28 (Reuters) - Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha arrived here today for talks with the South-West African political parties on new developments that, he said, may have a negative effect on independence negotiations.

title: RAINSTORMS DISRUPT TRANSIT IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Periods of heavy rain and lightning swept the New York metropolitan area and other parts of the Eastern Seaboard yesterday. The storms caused power blackouts in parts of New Jersey, flooding in some areas and disrupted air travel at the metropolitan airports.

title: NEW HEAD IS NAMED AT THE ZIFF CORPORATION
description: Philip B. Korsant was named president of the Ziff Corporation yesterday, succeeding I. Martin Pompadur, who announced last week that he was stepping down to purchase four of Ziff's television stations.

title: HOUSE TIES TAX STAND TO SENATE BILL
description: The House of Representatives, in a break with custom, voted tonight to go to conference with the Senate on the Senate's three-year, $99 billion revenue-raising bill without first passing its own separate tax measure.

title: GUARANTEE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Operating loss; results for the yr-ago qr and 6 mos includes a gain of $563,000 from a lease cancellation

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Duran to Fight in Fall
description: Roberto Duran of Panama, the former lightweight and welterweight champion, will meet undefeated Tony Ayala of San Antonio in a junior middleweight bout Nov. 19, the promoter Don King announced.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JULY 29, 1982
description: International Guarded hope for peace in Lebanon was expressed by President Reagan. At his 12th Presidential news conference, Mr. Reagan carefully avoided placing blame for the conflict on Israel and said that in some instances the Palestine Liberation Organization had been ''the first to break the cease-fire.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) A Palestinian promise is sought in the negotiations on Lebanon. Prime Minister Menachem Begin said the American mediator, Philip C. Habib, promised him Tuesday to try to obtain ''an unequivocal commitment'' from the Palestine Liberation Organization to accept the principle of leaving Beirut. The Israeli leader said Mr. Habib, who returned to Beirut yesterday, believed that such a commitment was necessary for progress in the peace negotiations. (A1:5.)

title: Military Analysis
description: The belief that Israel, disregarding criticism at home and abroad, will tire of diplomatic negotiation and move on the Palestine Liberation Organization positions in west Beirut is growing among military experts in Washington and NATO capitals.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Veteran Struggles With Job as Impresario

title: Barnes Is Arrested
description: Marvin Barnes, the former Providence College and pro basketball star, has been released on a $1,000 personal recognizance bond after his arrest Tuesday on charges of buying marijuana on a street in Providence.

title: SEARS UP 22% IN QUARTER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 22 percent, to $163.7 million, from $134.5 million in the 1981 period.

title: A KITCHEN EXPANSION CHANGES APARTMENT'S TRAFFIC PATTERN
description: ''MOST old, elegant apartments were designed with servants' quarters in mind,'' says Philip Monteleoni, an architect. ''They were spaces that were isolated from the rest of the dwelling. But these days families inhabit every inch of space in their apartments, including the kitchens, full time. It is a challenge to bring these spaces back into the family nucleus.''

title: Washington Post Suit Goes to Federal Jury
description: A jury deliberated for six and a half hours today without reaching a verdict in a $50 million libel suit brought against The Washington Post by the president of the Mobil Oil Corporation and his son.

title: Italy's Influence
description: Until this week, ticket sales for the Federation Internationale de Football Association's World All-Stars Game on Aug. 7 had been selling at a good, but not spectacular, pace. Then they suddenly shot upward; by yesterday afternoon, sales had passed 45,000.

title: Petrofina Sells Unit
description: Petrofina S.A. said today it had raised 8.8 billion Belgian francs from the sale of 29 percent of Petrofina Canada. It said the rise of the dollar since the deal was transacted had provided extra benefit.

title: GULF DEAL WITH CITIES HITS A SNAG
description: The Federal Trade Commission voted unanimously today to seek an injunction that would block the acquisition of the Cities Service Company by the Gulf Oil Corporation. The F.T.C. said the huge merger could jeopardize competition in the sale of petroleum products, especially in the South and East.

title: JUNE'S TRADE DEFICIT GREW TO $3.44 BILLION
description: The nation's foreign trade deficit, pushed upward by a moderate increase in oil imports, widened to a seasonally adjusted $3.44 billion in June from $3.29 billion in May, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the largest monthly deficit since January.

title: CONCERT: CHINA IN INTERNATIONAL STYLE
description: born composer and conductor, has performed a valuable service with the Brooklyn Philharmonic's community concerts, which she co-founded and directs. In these concerts, Miss Leon has presented a cross-section of music by composers outside the mainstreams. Last night she did it again, with a concert of music for Western instrumental forces by various kinds of Chinese composers at the American Museum of Natural History.

PRESIDENT AND REPORTER SPAR OVER STUDY OF STATUS OF WOMEN
description: President Reagan, who is known as one of the nation's great communicators, engaged in a news conference colloquy tonight with Sarah McClendon, who is known as one of the most colorful communicators in the press corps. The result was something of a draw.

GUARDS AMONG 10 INDICTED FOR OSSINING PRISON BRIBERY
description: Ten men, including five state prison guards, a former guard and a New York City employee, have been indicted on bribery and narcotics charges in an inquiry into corruption at the Ossining Correctional Facility.

title: U.S. TO CHECK INCOMES FOR SCHOOL FOOD PLAN
description: The Agriculture Department said today that it would begin checking the Social Security numbers of parents seeking free or reduced-price meals for their children.

title: Some Cambridge Diet Drinks Recalled Because of Bacteria
description: Bacteria that can cause food poisoning has been found in some Cambridge Plan chocolate and vanilla diet drinks, and the manufacturer said it had already recalled the contaminated products.

title: HOUSE MEASURE LINKS SPENDING TO ARMS TREATY
description: The House voted today to bar funds for the development, testing, procurement or operation of any nuclear weapon that would undercut the first or second strategic arms limitation agreements with the Soviet Union.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM THE NORTH

title: Transcript of news session, page A18.
description: President Reagan, saying that he yearned to see ''the bloodshed and the shelling'' end in Lebanon, voiced guarded optimism tonight that a peaceful resolution could be found to the crisis there.

title: HOW TO CUT THE COST OF AIR-CONDITIONING
description: TEMPERATURE and humidity levels are up for the summer, and so are electric rates. But for people with home air-conditioners, staying cool and saving on electric bills need not be mutually exclusive propositions.

title: LAWSON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nursery Rhyme, Day Care Reason
description: Bye, baby bunting, Daddy's gone a-hunting, Gone to get a rabbit-skin To wrap the baby bunting in. It's an old nursery rhyme - based on an ancient concept of family life: Daddy, the hunter, out foraging; mother and child nesting by the hearth. It tells as much about the modern American family as ''Three Blind Mice'' tells about modern American agriculture.

title: JETS' CRABLE WEARS LOOK OF A STARTER
description: He put on a clean, green-and-white uniform for the first time today, but Bob Crable already has usurped a linebacker job on the Jets.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT MOVES TO LIFT GLEN COVE CURBS ON RUSSIANS
description: The State Department in Washington asked the Justice Department today to review possible legal action against the City of Glen Cove. The Government wants to force the city to lift a ban that prohibits Soviet diplomats from using the city's tennis courts and other recreational facilities.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax credits of $363,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $4,444,000 or 43 cents a shr for the 6 mos...C-After tax credits of $809,000 or 8 cents a shr for the qr and $1.012,000 or 10 cents a shr for the 6 mos; the 1981 results were restated for F.A.S.B. No 52

title: Chock Full o'Nuts
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said yesterday that it had received a copy of the 13-D statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Jerry Finkelstein, a shareholder, and an investment group he leads, and that it disagreed with Mr. Finkelstein's interpretation of a July 19 meeting held between members of his investment group and representatives of Chock Full. ''No specific agenda was agreed upon before the meeting, and the purpose was not to discuss the sale of William and Page Black's stock,'' said Dr. Leon Pordy, Chock Full's president. William M. Black, the company's founder and chairman, together with his wife, Page, owns 16.7 percent of the company's stock.

title: Bethlehem Steel Reports a Deficit
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, suffering from the lowest level of steel orders in 20 years, said yesterday that it lost $47.1 million in the second quarter of 1982. In the same period last year, Bethlehem earned $77.6 million, or $1.78 a share.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
4 ESTABLISH VENTURE FOR PAGING SERVICE
description: Four companies with broad experience in communications announced today that they had formed a joint venture to establish a national telephone paging and electronic message service.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
PAUL ELDRIDGE
description: Paul Eldridge, novelist, poet and writer of short stories, died Monday at a nursing home in Manhattan.

title: GRANDEUR IN PARIS: SAINT LAURENT, GIVENCHY
description: The fall and winter showings peaked today. Yves Saint Laurent occupied close to two hours this morning with the presentation of his sleek, sophisticated collection, leaving fashion followers a relatively brief time for lunch before going on to Hubert de Givenchy's opening at 3 P.M. Both are highly professional designers in complete control of their craft.

title: A WITNESS TELLS OF CRIME 'CREW' AND ITS ACTIVITY
description: A witness testified yesterday that he had realized a missing gangster was dead when someone took away the homing pigeons that the missing man had kept on the roof of a Brooklyn building as a hobby.

title: 75 House Members Seek Ban On Military Aid to El Salvador
description: Seventy-five House members co-sponsored a resolution today to suspend military aid to El Salvador and declare President Reagan's report of progress on human rights and land redistribution ''null and void.''

title: MISLED ON FALKLANDS, BRITISH PRESS SAYS
description: British reporters who covered the Falkland war told a parliamentary inquiry today that official briefings had ranged from erratic to purposely misleading. In one case, an admiral was said to have sought to have reporters file false information to confuse the enemy.

title: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gulf Credit Card
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said that it would levy a 3 percent processing fee on all credit card transactions nationwide, effective Sept. 1, in an effort to recoup some of the $75 million it spends annually on its credit card operations. Jobbers, dealers and companyoperated service stations will pay the fee, not consumers.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $850,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of certain assets of the company's PVO subsidiary

title: HOME BEAT
description: THEY happened to live there, so that was why Bebe Pritam Johnson and her husband, Warren Eames Johnson, opened Pritam & Eames, a gallery in East Hampton that specializes in one-of-a kind handcrafted wood furniture pieces. ''We spent a year visiting studios and selecting the works,'' said Mrs. Johnson, seated at left on one of Wendy Maruyama's ''Primary Chairs.''

title: WEYENBERG SHOE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Probation Violation Filed Against Reese

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFING
description: Paper as Troops' Backup

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Saharan Rebels to Skip O.A.U. Talks, Libya Says
description: Libya announced tonight that the Polisario Front guerrillas had agreed not to attend next week's Organization of African Unity meeting, apparently removing the major obstacle to the talks.

title: MAPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUBSTITUE FOR BLOOD REPORTED TO HELP THE SEVERELY ANEMIC
description: A blood substitute developed in Japan has significantly helped a small number of anemic patients in Los Angeles to survive surgery without the blood transfusions that they refused, according to a new study on the substance, called Fluosol-DA.

title: Bankruptcy Field Loses Judge but Gains Lawyer
description: For 18 years he has spent his career listening to companies and people going into bankruptcy. He oversaw the case of United Merchants and Manufacturers and its familiar Robert Hall Clothes subsidiary. He heard Weiss Securities, the big brokerage house. He recently took on National Shoes.

title: Former Helms Aide Gets State Dept. Post
description: President Reagan today announced the appointment of Richard McCormack as Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs.

title: GATX Spinoff Set
description: The GATX Corporation, the nation's leading owner of railroad tank cars, said that it would spin off a subsidiary, the Marine Transport Lines group, and distribute the unit's shares among GATX stockholders. Marine Transport, which charters and operates oceangoing ships, had profits of $2.2 million last year - accounting for 3.2 percent of GATX's consolidated net income. The spinoff will not have a material effect on GATX, the company said.

title: THURSDAY, JULY 29, 1982; Companies
description: The F.T.C. said it would try to block Gulf Oil's acquisition of Cities Service pending further study. It said the huge merger could jeopardize competition in the sale of petroleum products, especially in the South and East. Officials said the agency will ask a Federal court today for a preliminary injunction suspending the $5.13 billion deal until it can be examined more closely. (Page D1.)

title: SAN FRANCISCO GETS 15 PISTOLS AS BAN TAKES EFFECT
description: Police officials reported that only 15 pistols were turned in to them today when a law banning most residents of this city from owning the weapons went into effect.

title: Tentative Pact Reached With Western Union
description: Western Union and the United Telegraph Workers reached a tentative contract agreement late Tuesday night after a 90-minute walkout, negotiators said.

title: Standards for Cribs
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: We appreciate your effort to inform your readers about the Consumer Product Safety Commission's safety standards for baby cribs (''Where to Shop for Nursery Furniture,'' June 24). However, we would like to correct one possible misconception.

title: Jordache Seeking Fashion Show Record
description: Jordache, the jolly jean maker, places a great premium on being first, like being the first of its class to use the television advertising medium. That's exciting.

title: U.S. TO SUPPORT STATES IN REGULATING ABORTIONS
description: The Justice Department plans to file a brief in the Supreme Court Thursday supporting the power of state and local governments to regulate abortions to some extent without prohibiting them.

title: CITIBANK'S PRIME RATE CUT TO 15 1 2%
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest bank, lowered its prime rate yesterday to 15 1/2 percent from 16 percent, reflecting the generally lower cost of funds in the money markets.

title: Continental Off C.D. List
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has asked temporary removal from a list of banks whose certificates of deposit are used for settling futures contracts traded on the International Monetary Market.

title: No Headline
description: TOP IRANIAN AIDE ADAMANT ON WAR

title: STILL AN OLYMPIC HERO
description: It is still easy to picture the scene: It was 1980 in Lake Placid, N.Y., and the United States Olympic hockey team had just won the gold medal.

title: CAIRO REPORTED TO SHIFT ON P.L.O.
description: President Hosni Mubarak appeared today to have altered Egypt's policy of categorical refusal to give haven to any of the Palestinian fighters now trapped in west Beirut by the Israeli Army.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains of 8 cents a shr for the qr and 21 cents a shr for the 6 mos on the sale of a 50 percent interest in the company's Long Beach, Calif, cable system

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HCI HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for QTr to June 30
EVE QUELER HAS PLANS FOR MORE OPERATIC ESOTERICA
description: EVE QUELER'S Opera Orchestra of New York will continue its delvings into operatic esoterica next season with three unusual new presentations - Donizetti's ''Il Duca d'Alba,'' Berlioz's ''Benvenuto Cellini,'' and Richard Strauss's ''Guntram.'' The three works are almost unknown to the New York stage; and according to the Opera Orchestra the Strauss opera will be enjoying its American premiere.

title: SOCAL, SUN, CITIES SERVICE FALL
description: The Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday that its second-quarter profits had plummeted 57.3 percent from a year earlier, the steepest decline reported by an American partner in the Arabian American Oil Company.

title: Mexicans Pursue Case Of Slain U.S. Professor
description: A criminal court judge in San Ignacio, a town not far from here, has begun reviewing evidence against a deputy police chief and six officers charged with murdering a University of Colorado professor named Nicholas W. Schrock. The professor's body has not been found.

title: Construction Contracts Up
description: Led by a surge in major office projects, the value of new construction contracts rose sharply in June, the second consecutive monthly gain, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Astronauts' Baby Treated
description: Paul Seddon Gibson, the first child born to an American astronaut, was reported doing very well today in Hermann Hospital, where he was being treated for minor breathing difficulties. The baby, born Monday to Margaret Rhea Seddon, was expected to leave the hospital in about a week and a half, a spokesman at the Johnson Space Center said. The father, Robert Gibson, is also an astronaut.

title: BIG WHITE VOTE AIDED VICTOR OF CAROLINA PRIMARY
description: A relatively large turnout of white voters, especially in rural counties, pushed I.T. Valentine Jr. to a come-from-behind victory for the Democratic nomination for the House seat from the Second Congressional District.

title: TEXAS GAS TRANSMISSION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for oil andgas exploration activities

title: COSMOS WIN BY 2-1, CLINCH PLAYOFF SPOT
description: Giorgio Chinaglia scored with seven minutes remaining to give the Cosmos a 2-1 victory over the San Jose Earthquakes in a rain-delayed game tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: 'DIRTY TRICKS' IN THE BRINK'S ROBBERY CASE
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumanian Debt Plan
description: Western countries have formally agreed to reschedule $480 million of Rumanian debt due by the end of the year, diplomatic sources said today. They said the agreement was signed at a one-day meeting of the Paris Club, an informal grouping of 15 Western creditor countries.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $82,000 for the qr and $191,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago figures have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 43 regarding compensated absences

title: Savings Units to Merge
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles, the nation's largest federally charted mutual savings and loan, said yesterday that it planned to merge with the Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association of Ocala, Fla. The move, which would combine Fidelity Federal's assets of $118 million with California Federal's assets of $9 billion, has been approved by the directors of both and is subject to regulatory approval. It would be the second interstate merger for California Federal.

title: POE & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods reflect late 1981 acquisitions of Pan American Insurance Management and Matterhorn Bank Programs as well as the early 1982 purchase of Stetzel Thomson & Co Ltd

title: OUTDOORS
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. A puff of wind catches the small sail and, like a kite starting its flight, the sailboard begins to glide across Manhasset Bay. ''You've got it, but you forgot something!'' Neil McConnell, the instructor, yells from the beach. ''You have to smile. If you are too serious, you have to fall in and start all over.''

title: FRANCHISING OF HOME REPAIRS
description: With both franchising and home improvement booming despite the recession, Art Bartlett has made the logical connection: He is promoting franchised remodeling contractors.

title: Smokers Said to Risk Cancers Beyond Lungs
description: Minute radioactive particles in cigarette smoke may be the source of malignant tumors throughout the bodies of heavy smokers, a researcher has said.

description: Trade Law Commission 15th Ses- sion - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Phillies 4, Pirates 3
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Manny Trillo, second baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, set a major league single-season record by playing his 87th consecutive game without an error. Trillo handled five chances in the Phillies' 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. DEFENSE ABROAD: SEA POWER IS NOT ENOUGH
description: T o the Editor: An Institute of Foreign Policy Analysis study which recommends withdrawing most United States ground forces from Europe and South Korea and relying more upon sea power to defend U.S. interests abroad (news story July 11) resurrects dangerously flawed ideas that were incorrect 60 years ago.

title: BEGIN SAYS HABIB SEEKS P.L.O. PLEDGE ON PULLOUT
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he had an American promise to seek ''an unequivocal commitment'' from the Palestine Liberation Organization on the principle of leaving Beirut.

title: Pessimism Over Rates Erodes Futures Prices
description: Commodity futures prices crumbled in almost every market yesterday as the belief grew that the recent easing of interest rates would be short-lived. The selling became pronounced at midday, after falling prices touched off chart- and trader-initiated stop-loss orders.

title: Colombia and Venezuela Scuffle Along Border
description: Friction between Colombia and Venezuela over rights to an offshore area with oil potential has led to two border shooting incidents, according to a report today from Bogota.

title: Ukrainian, 14, Fears Return to Soviet Union
description: Walter Polovchak, a 14-year-old Ukrainian whose bid for political asylum has resulted in a court battle over parental rights, said today that he feared spending the rest of his life in prison if he was forced to return to the Soviet Union.

title: CUOMO-KOCH DEBATE BRISTLES WITH CHARGES
description: Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo repeatedly questioned each other's motivation, character, ability and tactics as they debated yesterday for nearly two hours.

title: WHAT TO DO IN AUGUST
description: Fall Flowering Bulbs Tulip and daffodil orders for October planting should now be completed to insure a colorful spring. It is time now too to order autumn-flowering bulbs, which are planted this month. Autumnflowering crocuses bloom in white, yellow and shades of purple: the meadow saffron (Colchicum) has taller blooms in a range of light blue and violets. Fall-flowering bulbs may be found at larger garden shops and mail-order suppliers such as John Scheepers (212-422-1177). Plant them with a bit of bone meal, in well-drained soil in window boxes and terrace tubs as well as yards, at a depth approximately twice their diameter. For a free booklet on bulb culture entitled ''From Holland With Love,'' send a self-addressed, stamped, legal-size envelope to Bulbs, P.O. Box 5283, F.D.R. Station, New York, N.Y. 10150.

title: 'Raiders' Wins 7 Awards From Fantasy Academy
description: ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' won seven honors, including best fantasy film and best actor, actress and director Tuesday night in the ninth annual Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror Films awards show.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DEBATE BY DEMOCRATIC ASPIRANTS FOR GOVERNOR
description: These are excerpts from a debate yesterday at The New York Times between Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Koch, Democratic candidates for Governor of New York. Strengths, Weaknesses

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID WEST BEIRUT FOR A SEVENTH STRAIGHT DAY
description: For the seventh straight day, Israeli planes, artillery and gunboats hit Palestinian bunkers and residential areas in west Beirut today.

AN AMERICAN PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: General in My Lai Case Loses Court Bid to Clear His Name
description: An Army commander who was censured and eventually demoted for not promptly investigating the 1968 My Lai massacre in Vietnam lost a court attempt today to clear his name.

title: PRESIDENT WARNS ECONOMIC REVIVAL WILL COME SLOWLY
description: President Reagan cautioned tonight that recovery from the recession ''is going to be slow,'' and he charged that Congressional inaction on his budget cuts had ''held back the psychology'' that is needed for the economy to grow.

title: Burroughs Suit
description: The Burroughs Corporation, a major producer of data processing and business equipment based in Detroit, has filed a suit in United States District Court against Ibis Systems Inc. seeking more than $20 million in damages for reported theft of trade secrets. The suit charges that Ibis, which is based in Duarte, Calif., used Burroughs's data-recording technology to manufacture magnetic computer disks. Ibis denied the charges.

title: STANDARD OIL CO OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $699,000 for the qr and a loss from discontinued operations of $6,372,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operationsr-ago results reflect a change in accounting

title: VOLCKER ASKS MORE DEFICIT CUTS
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that, if Congress approved additional tax increases and spending cuts next year, the Fed could be more flexible in its short-term money supply growth - a move that could lower interest rates.

title: OREGON PORTLAND CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BENJAMIN MARGOLIN
description: Benjamin Margolin, a certified public accountant and partner in the New York accounting concern of Margolin & Sedler, died Monday at his home in Manhattan.

title: GOLDWATER SAYS U.S. HAS OFFERED NOT TO UPGRADE ARMS FOR TAIWAN
description: Senator Barry Goldwater said today that the United States had offered Peking a new assurance to settle the dispute over arms sales to Taiwan. Under the plan, Taiwan in the future would not receive any more or better arms, of any type, than it gets now.

title: Bridge: Sanders Wins Second Title In the Summer Nationals
description: Winning two consecutive national titles is a very rare event, but it was achieved here Tuesday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Tom Sanders of Nashville, who had shared top honors in the master mixed teams three days earlier, captured the life master pair title with Ron Andersen of New York.

title: Motorola Pagers
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it was considering filing suit against Matsushita of Japanese, which Motorola accuses of dumping low-priced mobile pagers in the United States. Motorola said that Matsushita had been selling its pagers in this country at a lower price than Motorola's pagers.

title: No Headline
description: KIDNAPPERS IN ZIMBABWE APPEAR PART OF GROUP THAT HAS KILLED 30

title: Comings and Goings
description: The United States Soccer Federation announced that six more worldclass players had accepted an invitation to play in the World All-Stars Game Aug. 7 at Giants Stadium: They are: Daniel Passarella (Argentina), Roberto Falcao (Brazil), Alain Giresse (France), Bruno Pezzey (Austria) and Jose Camacho (Spain), have accepted invitations. Julio Cesar Arzu, the goalkeeper from Honduras, also accepted. ... Ernie Banks, a member of baseball's Hall of Fame, will become the first member of the Chicago Cubs to have his uniform number retired. Banks's No. 14 will be retired during ceremonies Aug. 22.

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a $1,350,000,000 one-time after-tax gain from the sale of the company's oil field services subsidiary

title: TRANSTECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest period include a pro-rata shr for 12.35 percent of Breeze Corps Inc earnings

title: CUBA ISSUE BLINDS U.S. IN NAMIBIA
description: President Fidel Castro's recent statement that Cuban troops will be withdrawn from Angola only after South African troops depart from Namibia clashes directly with the Reagan Administration's endorsement of South Africa's demand that independence for Namibia be linked to a prior or at least simultaneous Cuban withdrawal. Although the United States has forsworn explicit linkage in favor of ''parallel movement,'' the Reagan Administration risks allowing South Africa to once again slip off the hook of commitment to an agreement on Namibia, now the territory of South-West Africa.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE HAIR TRIGGER IN NUCLEAR STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: Leonard's Broad Hint
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, recuperating from eye surgery, says his love for boxing has ''died out'' and that he is leaning toward retiring from the ring.

title: Anheuser-Busch Gains 24.3%; NL Slips Slightly
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies, the nation's largest brewer, reported yesterday that record volume and an enthusiastic reception for the company's latest light beer helped earnings in the second quarter rise 24.3 percent, while sales grew 17.5 percent.

title: Treasury Sets $11 Billion Sale; Prices Show Little Change
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to sell $11 billion of notes next week, an amount that exceeded some dealers' forecasts, but not others. The Treasury's announcement caused little change in prices of outstanding issues, which had declined slightly earlier in the day with yields rising.

title: CITY OPERA PROPOSES YEAR'S WAGE FREEZE
description: The New York City Opera, facing the expiration of its major union contracts at the end of next month and a potential disruption of its fall season, has proposed an across-the-board one-year wage freeze to its unions.

description: B-After gain of $1,007,000 or 8 cents a shr from sale of capital assets; the yr-ago shr earnings and shrs outstdng for both periods are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock divd distributed in Dec 1981

HELPFUL HARDWARE;
MAKING LAWN CARE EASIER
description: DURING the hot months of July and August, extra attention to your lawn will keep it looking healthy. Several products are available to make care easier.

title: IOWA ELECTRIC LIGHT & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pursue Drunk Drivers of Any Age
description: It is dawning on everyone that young drivers have a scandalously poor safety record and that a major reason is alcohol. One-third of the 25,000 Americans who died last year in highway accidents attributable to drinking were under the age of 25 -although only 21 percent of the nation's drivers are in that age group.

title: Silverman Mower Gets Agway Assignment
description: Agway Inc., has delivered another chunk to Silverman Mower of Syracuse, helping it maintain its reputation as the largest ad agency with headquarters in upstate New York.

title: MANY SCHOOLS FACING U.S. CUTOFF OF FUNDS FOR STUDENTS' LOANS
description: The Department of Education moved today to halt further loan funds to 528 colleges and other educational institutions where defaults in repaying National Direct Student Loans total 25 percent or more.

title: Koch Campaign Pays Service Costs of Police
description: Mayor Koch's gubernatorial campaign began reimbursing the Police Department yesterday for the use of police officers, helicopters, police cars and other police services used on campaign swings.

title: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: Yr-ago results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: ROYALTIES SUIT SURPRISES PLAYWRIGHTS
description: Sorrow and surprise more than anger or angst marked the reaction yesterday by playwrights and producers to the antitrust action filed Tuesday by Richard Barr, president of the League of New York Theaters and Producers, against the Dramatists Guild.

title: Dial Merger Approved
description: Northwest Bancorporation of Minneapolis said yesterday it had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board for its purchase of the Dial Corporation. The two companies will formally merge on Aug. 31 through the cash purchase of approximately 4.5 million shares of Dial stock for approximately $252 million, Northwest Bancorporation said.

title: GIVE ME LIFE
description: Wit, fool, philosopher, gull, celebrant, criminal, hypocrite, exposer of hypocrisy: Falstaff is all those things. No character in Shakespeare is more expressive of humanity in its contradictions, its dark and light. ''Banish plump Jack,'' he says, ''and banish all the world.''

title: Mission Group Plane Falls in Texas; 11 Die
description: A twin-engine plane crashed and burned shortly after taking off from a private airfield tonight, killing all 11 people aboard, including seven children, the authorities said.

title: SYBRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including net gains of $1,450,000 or 13 cents a shr for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of real estate owned by a Sybron dental laboratory

title: MISS HOLTZMAN, JUDGE CLASH
description: A State Supreme Court justice and the Brooklyn District Attorney clashed sharply yesterday over the case of a woman who pleaded guilty to manslaughter for intentionally starving her baby to death.

title: EL SALVADOR: ARE WE ASKING THE RIGHT QUESTIONS?
description: Today Congress will begin hearings on the President's ''certification'' of ''progress'' in economic reforms and human rights in El Salvador. In the background, Central America is engulfed in conflict.

title: THE THEMES PLAYING ON CAPITAL HILL
description: Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican leader in the House, summoned up his righteous anger today and told his colleagues, ''Election year politics has governed the conduct of this House for months.''

description: B-Net loss...C-Including a gain of $328,000 from the exchange of long-term debt

description: In still another case of sweets to the sweet, Della Femina, Travisano & Partners and its subsidiary Sherwood & Schneider have become agencies for Sunshine Biscuits with its myriad cookies and crackers.

title: MURCER'S HOMER DEFEATS TIGERS
description: The Detroit relief pitchers do not have names like Fingers and Sutter and Quisenberry. Nor do they have arms like Fingers and Sutter and Quisenberry. They are Dave Gumpert and Dave Rucker and Bob James, and they are the names and arms that Sparky Anderson threw at the Yankees in the seventh inning last night.

title: EGYPT AND FRANCE PRESS MIDEAST PLAN
description: Egypt and France plan to start a major effort Thursday to win United States approval of the right of Palestinian Arabs to determine their own political future.

title: GANZABAL UPSET, 6-3, 6-2
description: A torrential rainstorm late this afternoon halted the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament, but not before the second of its eight seeded players had been eliminated.

title: FEDERAL TRADE PANEL VOTES RULES FOR FUNERAL INDUSTRY
description: Over the Reagan Administration's objection, the Federal Trade Commission voted today, 3 to 1, to issue a regulation requiring funeral directors to disclose and itemize prices and services.

description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it is offering to pay $22 a share for 4 million of its common shares. If more than 4 million shares are tendered, Tesoro, at its option, may purchase up to an additional million shares, it added.

description: Former Gov. William T. Cahill has been admitted to Our Lady of Lourdes Medical Center here with an unspecified ailment, according to the hospital.

description: 20th Century-Fox and the independent producer Daniel Melnick are parting company, halfway through Mr. Melnick's five-year contract to produce films exclusively for the studio, it was announced last night.

title: CONCERT: PAUL DUNKEL AT WASHINGTON SQUARE
description: ACCORDING to Paul Dunkel, who conducted the Festival Orchestra in the Washington Square Music Festival in Washington Square Park Tuesday night, Frank Wigglesworth was thinking of his summers living in Greenwich Village when he wrote ''Summer Scenes.''

description: Samuel Schulman, president of Alixandre Furs Inc. of Manhattan and of Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST people are so used to having electrical outlets handy inside the house that they miss them on the outside, especially when they want to use radios, stereo sets, electric rotisseries, lights or power tools such as hedge trimmers, lawn edgers, drills and power saws.

title: MRS. GANDHI VISITS BONWIT'S AND U.N.  York
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India made a variegated beginning to her American tour yesterday, ranging from a ceremonial meeting with the Secretary General of the United Nations to a shopping trip for cosmetics at Bonwit Teller.

description: Even for a professional restorer, hand-stripping furniture finish is a messy job; for the do-it-yourselfer, it can be overwhelming. A thorough job takes chemical solvents, brushes, steel wool, wiping cloth, a well-ventilated work space and much time.

American Leisure is planning to start construction on the Camelot Hotel in Atlantic City.

title: METAL IS TESTED
description: New York City's inquiry into the July 21 crane accident that killed one person and injured 16 others got under way yesterday. As the three-member board met in a closed session, investigators sent a portion of a rotating and lifting mechanism involved in the accident to Pennsylvania for testing.

description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed rules easing requirements that new chemicals be screened for potential dangers to health and the environment before they are manufactured.

She was struck on the head by what appeared to be a piece of a cornice that plunged from the 14th floor of a building at 66 Court Street, at the corner of Livingston Street.

description: Those folks up at Gillette certainly are sharp, who else would have thought of offering baseball fan-consumers a product-refund check signed by a baseball hero. If you cash the check not only are you disloyal, but you also lose the autograph.

title: The Passenger From India
description: Try, try and try again ought to be the hallmark of American diplomacy toward India and its sometimes prickly Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi, who visits the White House today. India and the United States have every reason to be partners - belief in secular democracy, a flourishing trade and the logic of geopolitics. What most divides them is petty chaff.

title: A PROTEGE OF ASHE FULFILLING PROMISE
description: Yannick Noah wasn't aware of the rustling in the bushes and the low murmur of voices. Deep in concentration, sticky with sweat in the hot sun, Noah heard only the resounding thwack of his returns to the young practice player on the other side of the net, and the polite applause of the row of spectators on folding chairs at the crest of the incline above him.

title: BAR EXAM A TRIAL FOR 4,500
description: No giant ocean cruisers have docked at Pier 88 on the West Side of Manhattan during the past two days. But the 1,620 law graduates who completed the grueling New York State Bar examination there yesterday held the fervent hope that their ship had finally come in.

title: Ambrosiano Shake-Up
description: Roberto Rosone, managing director of the Banco Ambrosiano, a Milan bank at the heart of an Italian financial scandal involving the Vatican, said today that he had received notice of dismissal from the three state-appointed commissioners running the bank, but that he intended to stay at his post. He was commenting on a report in a weekly magazine that said both he and the joint general manager, Filippo Leoni, had received dismissal letters and that Mr. Leoni had agreed to leave. Mr. Rosone said, ''My contract gives me the right to 12 months' notice.''

title: OPENING STATEMENT
description: Ladies and gentlemen I have a brief statement here. Nine days ago, on the steps of the Capitol, I delivered a message to the Congress from millions of Americans. Back-to-back decades of red-ink spending had brought our economy to its knees. Long years of runaway inflation, interest rates and high taxes had robbed people of their earnings, and weakened every family's ability to pay its bills and save for the future.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 7:30 P.M. The Mets are home for the first time since the All-Star Game. Omar Moreno of the Pirates is seeking his third National League stolen base title. (Television - SportsChannel, and WHT 7:30 P.M. Radio -WMCA, 570 and WGBB, 1240; 7:30 P.M.) Expos vs. St. Louis Cardinals at Montreal and A's vs. Twins at Oakland. This is the Thursday night doubleheader of the USA Cable network. (Television - USA, 7:30 P.M.) Braves vs. San Diego Padres at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Roger Mayweather vs. Carlton (Two Gun) Sparrow, junior lightweights, 10 rounds, at Showboat Hotel, Las Vegas, Nev. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Harness Racing Meadowlands Race Track, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M. Three Diamonds, last year's 2-year-old champion, is the favorite in the $427,500 Mistletoe Shalee Pace final featuring 12 of the top 3-yearold fillies. Her main competition should come from Adore and Bio Prelude. (Television - Cablevision and MSG Cable, midnight, tape.)

title: 2 KITCHEN RENOVATION STRATEGIES SPARK NEW LIFE IN OLD SPACES
description: ''I live in the kitchen, entertain there and make most of my business calls there,'' said Harley Baldwin, who is developing a Manhattan restaurant and market complex. So when Mr. Baldwin decided to renovate his old-fashioned galley-style kitchen in a penthouse of the Dakota last year, he enlisted the aid of both an architect and a kitchen designer.

title: ARCHITECTS ARE INTERESTED IN CLASSICISM ONCE MORE
description: THERE are not a lot of people who remember what A.G.B.A.N.Y. stands for, but 20 years ago next week these initials were on the front page of The New York Times. They signified the Action Group for Better Architecture in New York, and the reason they made page 1 is that on Aug. 2, 1962, such members of A.G.B.A.N.Y. as Philip Johnson, Aline Saarinen, Ulrich Franzen and Peter Samton put aside the dignity that architects normally affect, picked up picket signs and marched back and forth in front of the old Pennsylvania Station on Seventh Avenue to protest its demolition.

title: QUILT SALE TO BE QUITE A SALE
description: ART auctions in recent seasons have taken place on mountaintops, on trans-Atlantic flights, in department stores and in football-size arenas with dirt floors. Now auction buffs will have a chance to bid on period American quilts while cruising around Manhattan on a Circle Line ship. On Aug. 10 at 6:30 P.M., Guernsey Country Auctions will hold what it describes as the first all-quilt auction in New York City -and it will take place aboard ship, which bidders will board at the Circle Line's Pier 83, 12th Avenue and 43d Street. There will be a half-hour presale exhibition of the 125 quilts, during which refreshments will be served. The auction is expected to take about two hours of the 3 1/2-hour trip.

description: Will Soviet tennis players return to the United States Open next month? After two Soviet players, 17-year-old Julia Salnikova and Ludmila Makarova, 23, reached the semifinals of a $10,000 United States Tennis Association/Nike women's event yesterday in Fayetteville, N.C., their coach, Olga Morozova, said she would push to persuade Soviet authorities to let the players return for the Open.

description: Civil rights advocates agreed at a five-day conference here this week to pursue new strategies aimed at shifting the focus of the movement from political to economic advancement for minority groups.

title: K Mart Shuts 305 Units
description: The K Mart Corporation closed 305 of its more than 1,700 automobile service centers because they were not profitable enough, the company chairman, Bernard M. Fauber, said today. The closings took effect Wednesday, he said in a statement. Some 900 employees are affected by the closings, a company spokesman, Bob Stevenson, said.

title: HIGHWAY EMERGENCY PHONES FAIL TEST MADE BY AUTO CLUB
description: More than half the emergency telephones tested on New York City's major expressways and parkways were broken or missing, according to a recent survey by the Automobile Club of New York, and calls from some of the phones went unanswered by police precincts.

title: Federal Rules Revised For Teaching Disabled
description: The Reagan Administration next week will propose a major revision of the rules that govern school services for the nation's 4 million disabled children. One change would make it easier to remove from the classroom handicapped children who are considered disruptive.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK NO. 2 STATE POST TO EXPAND ROLE
description: ''Oh, I realize it's a weak job,'' Alfred B. DelBello said the other day. ''But it has a potential.'' And H. Carl McCall said: ''It's what you make of it. It has flexibility.''

title: Arabs' Fast Continues
description: Twenty Arab women, some the wives of diplomats, continued their fast in Lafayette Park across from the White House today, vowing to stay and not eat until Israel allows food and water into west Beirut. Except for flooding from the park's sprinkler system at 5 A.M., the first night of the fast was uneventful, said Hala Maksoud, the wife of Dr. Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League's observer at the United Nations.

title: TOP STATE COURT IS CALLED UNABLE TO PERFORM ROLE
description: A study of appellate justice in New York has found that the state's highest court is too busy hearing relatively unimportant cases to perform its principal task of defining and clarifying the law.

10th Nuclear Test of Year
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., July 29 (UPI) The 10th underground nuclear test of 1982 was detonated today at the Nevada Test Site, Department of Energy officials said. The test had an explosive force of less than the equivalent of 20,000 tons of TNT.

title: GLENN CLOSE AND THE LONG ROAD TO 'GARP'; Getting to be Garp's mother.
description: WHETHER or not they like the movie version of John Irving's best seller ''The World According to Garp,'' most critics have agreed to admire Glenn Close, who plays Garp's mother, Jenny Fields. It wasn't an easy job she had, either. Miss Close was asked to age 30 years in two hours on screen, and movie acting was brand new to her.

title: STATE ACTS AFTER MASONRY DEATH
description: The State Attorney General's office yesterday ordered further sales of cooperative apartments halted at a Brooklyn building where a 28-year-old woman was fatally injured Wednesday morning by falling masonry.

title: HARVESTER TO AMEND FISCAL PLAN
description: Predicting another year and a half of soft markets and huge financial losses, the International Harvester Company said today that it would ask its private lenders to suspend interest payments on debts of $1.6 billion until December 1983.

title: Koch Sideswiping Brings a $702 Bill
description: Ruth M. Kessler, whose station wagon was sideswiped by Mayor Koch's limousine as he hurried to an appearance in Manhattan on Monday, asked the city yesterday for $702.52 for repairs.

title: 3 Killed and 7 Injured In Border Car Accident
description: A hit-and-run suspect who tried to elude the police and cross the Mexican border drove onto a sidewalk and plowed into a crowd of Japanese exchange students today, killing three persons and injuring seven others.

title: The U.N. Today; July 30, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, 15th Ses- sion - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Potential Trouble Spots For Weekend Traffic
description: A. Henry Hudson Parkway: Both northbound and southbound traffic may experience delays from 125th Street to 144th Street because of road work. Also, the southbound exit ramp at 125th Street will be closed for rehabilitation.

title: CUTOFF OF STUDENT FUNDS SEEN AS MINOR
description: A cutoff of new funds from the National Direct Student Loan Program to colleges in the New York metropolitan area is generally expected to have slight impact, spokesmen for the colleges said yesterday.

title: Scherer Sues FMC
description: The R.P. Scherer Corporation, which makes gelatin capsules containing liquid drugs, said today that it had filed a suit in the United States District Court in Delaware asking that the FMC Corporation's tender offer for its shares be halted. It said the suit charges that FMC's tender offer materials are false and misleading. FMC manufactures agricultural and other chemicals.

title: PARIS FINALE: TRADITION AND INNOVATION
description: Alix Gres closed the current couture season this afternoon in the traditional way in her salon on the Rue de la Paix, without music, with the models carrying cards identifying their style numbers and the audience chatting among themselves about the clothes they liked and where they were traveling for the rest of the summer.

title: ZONDERVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bob Hope in Westbury
description: Bob Hope and the actress Lynda Carter will appear this weekend for four shows at the Westbury Music Fair on Long Island.

title: ADAGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
BROOKLYN CHURCHES GAIN CITY HELP FOR NEW HOMES
description: When an ecumenical coalition of 36 churches asked the city last month to help it build 5,000 single-family town houses in the Ocean Hill, Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn, the Koch administration was respectfully - but deeply - skeptical.

title: STELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal Stock Exchanges

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AT THE FRONT, P.L.O. DIGS IN FOR BIG BATTLE
description: Yasir Arafat was out touring the Palestine Liberation Organization's front-line bunker recently when one of the fighters leaning behind a red dirt barricade asked him whether it was true that the P.L.O. was withdrawing from Beirut.

title: Harrah's Lament
description: Despite a .326 batting average and 19 home runs, Toby Harrah is an angry member of the Cleveland Indians. The third baseman, who is playing his fourth season in Cleveland, accused the front office of being more concerned with finances than with winning a pennant.

title: SENATE REJECTS CHANGES IN BUDGET-BALANCING PLAN
description: Senate supporters of a proposed constitutional amendment mandating a balanced Federal budget continued today to turn back all attempts to alter the proposal.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company News report in Business Day yesterday gave an incorrect starting date for Pan American World Airways' mileage bonus program. It began yesterday.

title: Antiques in Whippany
description: Antiques dealers from around the United States and from Canada will gather this weekend at the 50th Meadowbrook Antiques Show and Sale at the Birchwood Manor, 111 North Jefferson Road, Whippany, N.J. Included will be fine arts and graphics dating from the 17th to the 20th century.

title: No Headline
description: TEXT OF ARABS' STATEMENT

title: SLUMS OF LIVERPOOL SWEPT BY MORE VIOLENCE
description: Rioting youths firebombed a betting parlor, set fire to two derelict houses and stoned a bus today in a third outbreak of violence in four nights in Toxteth, Liverpool's predominantly black district.

title: Jones, Cowboys Reach Agreement
description: Ed (Too Tall) Jones, the free agent defensive end, agreed tonight to a three-year contract with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Economic Scene; On Balancing Budget by Law
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN declared Wednesday night that a constitutional amendment for a balanced budget ''could have a very profound effect'' in speeding the painfully slow process of economic recovery.

title: Nordic Protesters End Soviet Rallies
description: Declaring ''together we shall overcome,'' 300 protesters from Nordic countries today completed the first officially sanctioned antinuclear march by Westerners in the Soviet Union.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Trial for Payne
description: Tom Payne, a former center at the University of Kentucky and with the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association, has been granted a new trial on one of three charges for which he was convicted and sentenced in Louisville, Ky., in 1977. That new trial could lead to a re-evaluation of his case.

title: CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RATIONING MEDICINE
description: The Supreme Court recently handed down what will probably become a landmark decision when it denied deaf 11-year-old Amy Rowley a full-time sign-language interpreter to help her at school. What it did, in effect, was to lay down a principle for rationing scarce social services for those who need but cannot afford them. The principle and its corollaries are likely to be influential far beyond the world of the handicapped.

title: SIERRACIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Talks Are Set In Bus Walkout
description: A spokesman for striking drivers and mechanics of the DeCamp Bus Lines said today that no talks had been scheduled in the four-day-old strike that has curtailed service to about 8,300 Essex County riders.

title: U.S. DROPPING RECALL EFFORT IN RETURN FOR A G.M. PLEDGE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it was excusing the General Motors Corporation from recalling nearly 700,000 automobiles that failed to meet emissions standards set by the Clean Air Act.

title: CASTLE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE WORLDS OF REDD FOXX WHEN HE'S NOT PLAYING SANFORD
description: He shuffles onstage with a cigarette clamped between his teeth and a sly grin on his face. A plate-size Mercedes-Benz emblem is embroidered in heavy gold braid on the leg of his blue jeans; a huge diamond ring glitters, big as a walnut, on one finger. A cluster of gold artifacts hangs from a chain around his neck.

title: ARMS FUND IS CUT $2 BILLION IN HOUSE AS BILL IS ADOPTED
description: The House tonight approved a $13.8 billion supplemental spending bill that probably set the stage for another Presidential veto.

title: CHARTER CO. PRESIDENT, 4 OTHERS DIE IN CRASH
description: The president and three senior executives of the Charter Company, the insurance, oil and communications conglomerate based in Jacksonville, Fla., were killed yesterday along with their pilot when their helicopter crashed in Ireland.

F.C.C. Changes Policy On Satellite Channels
description: In a change of policy, the Federal Communications Commission authorized the domestic satellite industry today to sell satellite channels as well as lease them.

description: B-Including a gain of $177,288 on the disposal of fixed assets and a tax creditof $503,000...C-Net loss including a gain of $95,727 on the disposal of fixed assets

title: CONTROL IS KEY TO PEETE'S SWEET SWING
description: Calvin Peete fell out of a tree in 1955 when he was 12 years old and broke his left elbow in three places. He did not worry about how this typical boyhood accident would affect his golf swing because he had no golf swing. Peete did not play a game of golf until the summer of 1966, when he was 23.

title: OUTSIDE CHILD CARE RISING WITH INCREASE IN WORKING MOTHERS
description: More than half the married women with children have joined the labor force, causing a remarkable increase in services for child care outside the home, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: KUHN TO FACE OPPOSITION
description: In less than three weeks, the major league club owners will determine Bowie Kuhn's future as baseball commissioner. There have been indications that Kuhn could have trouble gaining re-election for a third term.

title: ANDY KAUFMAN IN NEW FRAY WITH WRESTLER ON TV SHOW
description: Andy Kaufman, the zany comedian whose shifting moods and unpredictable confrontations keep his audience off-guard, got into an altercation on national television Wednesday night.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JULY 30, 1982
description: International Some progress in talks on Lebanon is being made by the special American mediator, Philip C. Habib, but major hurdles remain in working out an agreement for the departure of Palestinian guerrilla forces from west Beirut, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said that Egypt, Syria and Jordan had agreed to accept the Palestinians, but that details of a withdrawal had not been resolved. (Page A1, Column 6.) Guerrillas vow to fight on in interviews at a Palestinian bunker at west Beirut. Yasir Arafat has the problem of trying to negotiate an honorable withdrawal for the Palestine Liberation Organization from Lebanon that can be sold to his fighters as a victory. The P.L.O. is not expected to withdraw from west Beirut unless it gains political concessions that advance the Palestinian cause. (A1:5.)

title: CANADIAN CORPORATE MANAGEMENT CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $311,000 for the qr and $524,000 for the 6mos

title: Bridge:; Sanders and Lazard Lose In the Spingold Knockout
description: The Spingold knockout team championship continued here today at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals with many famous names already on the sidelines.

title: U.S. WEIGHS PASSING ITS INTERESTS IN URANIUM-ENRICHING TO INDUSTRY
description: The Reagan Administration is considering turning over the Government-owned uranium-enrichment business to private industry, according to a White House document.

title: Wisconsin Given N.C.A.A. Censure
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Assocition has reprimanded and censured the University of Wisconsin for two violations stemming from the recruitment of a basketball player last winter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bus Stop A nybody know what a Guide-a-Ride is? It's the four-sided plastic sign at a bus stop that's supposed to show the route map, the schedule and instructions on how to use them. The city has put up 6,000 since 1980.

title: C.I.A. CHIEF TELLS OF ATTEMPT TO AID SALVADOR VOTE
description: The Central Intelligence Agency tried to support the election process in El Salvador earlier this year by supplying invisible ink used to stamp the wrists of voters to prevent them from voting more than once, William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today.

title: FELMONT OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $1,974,000 from the sale of securities

title: Hitachi Plea Of Not Guilty
description: Hitachi Ltd. pleaded not guilty today to charges that it conspired to send stolen technology to Japan and that it attacked the undercover investigation that led to its indictment.

description: B-Including a pretax gain of $211,000 on the sale of marketable securities...C-Including net gains of $6.8 million for the latest yr and $3.4 million for the previous yr on the sale of marketable securities

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: WHAT do you do on a beautiful summer night when you're celebrating t he same birthday as the Radio City Music Hall, the Empire State B uilding and the George Washington Bridge? If you're Hugh Hardy, you g et some 300 of your best pals together for a dinner cruise aboard a C ircle Line boat, and with more than a dash of chutzpah you ask t hose best pals to bring the dinner, allocating a specific course of e thnic food to each guest.

title: Chasing Facts in Atlantic City
description: New Jersey officials think they've seen the first signs that organized crime is using unions to muscle in on gambling in Atlantic City. But they are having a terrible time proving it, and proving the efficacy of their touted ''controls'' against the mob.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Analysis
description: The fuzziness of the lines of responsibility in forestalling bogus advertising has been underscored by a misleading advertisement that was published July 11 in several major newspapers.

title: Midway Air Chief Quits
description: Gordon Linkon, 52, has resigned as president and chief executive officer of Midway Airlines, effective Aug. 9, the company's acting chairman, David R. Hinson, disclosed in a telephone interview yesterday.

title: Interpublic Net Income Rises 39.7% in Quarter
description: The second-quarter reports of the publicly held ad agencies, even though there have been only two so far, have had a certain rosy glow in the gloomy surroundings of other businesses. BBDO International, out on Monday, showed a 12 percent gain in earnings. Yesterday, the Interpublic Group of Companies showed its hand yesterday with a 39.7 percent increase in net income.
