FRIDAY, JULY 30, 1982; The Economy
description: The Administration, in its midyear economic review, predicts a recovery this year and next that would be more extensive than many current projections. The report, which has been rejected by some of the President's top advisers, forecasts a budget deficit of $115 billion for fiscal year 1983. (Page A1.)

title: CROWN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPLIT BY A PIPELINE
description: It was bound to happen. No honeymoon can last forever, especially when the two partners -France and the United States - have so little in common and so many reasons to disagree.

title: Topics; Pay Dirt; The Sum of the Parts
description: Instructive economics and not just malicious mischief appear to explain the stripping of abandoned cars along New York's streets. The parts have grown in value for the simple reason that the cost of car repairs has risen dramatically.

title: DEL LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ST PAUL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Glen Cove Gets State Dept. Protest
description: The State Department officially advised the City of Glen Cove today to ''immediately restore'' recreational privileges to local Soviet diplomats.

title: Cerone Feels Good About Trying Third
description: Rick Cerone does not envision himself as the Yankees' third baseman of the future, or as any more than an occasional player at the position. Yet he has tackled the experimental assignment with enthusiasm and an eye toward his enduring career.

title: Fujitsu Develops New 64K Chip
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said it had developed the world's smallest and fastest 64K dynamic random access memory chip, with deliveries starting next month. The new chip, 15 percent smaller than the present smallest chip, has a data output speed of 100 nanosecond (a nanosecond is one-billionth of second), a 20 percent improvement.

title: Free Nature Workshops And Walks Are Listed
description: Those in search of butterflies, rocks and picturesque walking trails will find activities to please this weekend in Central Park and along the Hudson River in the Bronx, and they are all free.

title: A CHAMPIONSHIP ENSMEBLE
description: The coach led his basketball players onto the creaky wooden floor of a gym that Hollywood could neither build nor buy if it tried. The players, dressed in conservative summer suits and sport coats, stood and gaped at the familiar but now aged surroundings. In the center of the court, a large silver trophy sat on a small table, with four neatly folded green-and-gold jerseys, a bottle of champagne on ice and five glasses.

title: RULING CLEARING ABC OF LIBEL REVERSED AND TRIAL IS ORDERED
description: A Federal appeals court today reversed a ruling that cleared ABC of libel in a lawsuit brought by a housewife who contended that she had been depicted as a prostitute in a documentary news broadcast.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MAX MORATH IN RAG AND 'UNRAGTIME'
description: MANHATTANITES haven't seen much of Max Morath since his one-man show, ''Max Morath at the Turn of the Century,'' at the Jan Hus House 13 years ago. He did an hour of his ragtime songs and piano playing at Town Hall in 1974 and 1975 as part of the late afternoon ''Interludes'' series there, and a year and a half ago he came as close as the Brooklyn Academy of Music with ''Living the Ragtime Life,'' the program with which he has been touring since 1978.

title: CRAIN, R L, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEAT GENERATRION ELDERS MEET TO PRAISE KEROUAC
description: Nearly 13 years after his death and 25 years after ''On the Road'' became his testament for the Beat Generation, young admirers and old comrades of Jack Kerouac gathered here this week to celebrate his life and his legacy.

title: Advertising; Maxell: A Times Sq.  Addition
description: THE latest Japanese manufacturer to add some color to the Great White Way is the Maxell Corporation of American, maker of audiotapes and videotapes for the consumer market. Artkraft Strauss workmen, who have put most of the signs in Times Square, are halfway through painting the 227-foot sign that wraps around the top of the building on the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street.

title: 2 Banks Seek Michigan Unit
description: A New York savings bank and a Michigan bank holding company today confirmed that they are bidding for Michigan's fourth-largest savings and loan association.

title: Standard-Coosa
description: The Standard-Coosa-Thatcher Company, a Chattanooga, Tenn., textile maker, said that its holders had approved a plan under which the company will be acquired by Wolsey & Company, a New York invectment banking firm, in conjunction with a group of Standard-Coosa executives, for $28 million, or $53 a share.

title: Johnson Gains 9% in Quarter
description: Johnson & Johnson reported today that earnings increased 11 percent in the second quarter of 1982 compared with the same period last year.

title: BANKS TOLD ITALY IS NOT LIABLE
description: International banks owed money by a Luxembourg subsidiary of Italy's troubled Banco Ambrosiano were offered no encouragement today by Italian authorities that their loans would be repaid. The subsidiary defaulted this month on $400 million in foreign loans.

title: GIANTS' 3 PASSERS EXCEL
description: Mark Reed completed eight of 15 passes for 102 yards, Phil Simms four of six for 51 and Scott Brunner three of four for 24. The three quarterbacks, none of them a rookie, were the stars of the Giants' annual rookie scrimmage today at nearby Briarcliff High School.

title: Guards' President Gets Prison Term
description: The head of two unions representing security guards who was convicted of racketeering and other charges was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison and fined $80,000.

title: AIDES PLEASED BY NEWS CONFERENCE LOW ON NEWS
description: Assessing President Reagan's performance at his news conference last night, several White House officials today rated it high on substance but low on news, a mix that obviously pleased them.

title: Ex-Student Convicted In Book-Stealing Case
description: A former Columbia University graduate student was convicted yesterday of fraud and selling stolen property in connection with the theft of more than 100 rare books from university libraries here and abroad.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Homeless, Revisited
description: New York City and State officials are finally doing a good job of housing the homeless. The Community Service Society's recent report on the problem doesn't give them enough credit. But it is right to point out how much more needs to be done.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States is making the same mistake with the P.L.O. that it did with the North Vietnamese.

title: ROBBERS ABDUCT 5 IN THEIR VAN AT THE STADIUM
description: A Connecticut couple, their two children and another child were robbed and abducted by two men as they left Yankee Stadium during Wednesday night's baseball game. They were threatened with a knife and driven around for 15 minutes in their own van before being released unharmed in upper Manhattan.

title: GUERRILLAS SEIZE U.N. SUPPLIES
description: Five armed members of the Palestine Liberation Organization have sealed off a United Nations warehouse in west Beirut, blocking relief supplies for 30,000 Palestinian refugees, the United Nations disclosed Wednesday.

title: Labor Charges Seen In Fatal Film Crash
description: California labor officials will bring charges against at least one entertainment company in the deaths of Vic Morrow, the actor, and two children killed when a helicopter crashed at a late-night movie set last week, a source close to the investigation said today.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS BACK AID FOR SALVADOR
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials, asserting that United States support was necessary to help El Salvador resist ''Marxist guerrillas,'' said today that that country had made what one called ''marred, but real'' progress in human rights.

People
description: * Nicholas Cannistraro Jr. has been named to the new position of director of marketing for The Washington Post.

title: HOWELL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Double Trouble
description: If you and your friend became the first teammates to both bowl 300 games in the same tournament, and your scores weren't certified, would you sue for your place spot in history? James Mack of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and Paul Petescola of Oradell, N.J., are in the midst of a lawsuit to get their 300 games, bowled in a sanctioned tournament in 1980, certified by the American Bowling Congress. The A.B.C. maintains that the lanes did not meet its specifications.

title: From Injury to Insult
description: Just an hour before the Court of Appeals upheld the extortion conviction of Nassau's Republican leader Monday, the county announced the results of the first competitive bidding for the insurance fees he used to tap to run his political machine. The ''strictly coincidental'' disclosure was that a Massachusetts firm would provide expanded coverage at less than 40 percent the previous cost, an annual saving of more than $275,000.

title: MAN, 32, KILLED AS CAR CRASHES INTO PLAYGROUND
description: A cabdriver who had stopped to have lunch with his family in the outdoor playground of a Queens restaurant was killed yesterday when a car veered out of control, plunged through a wrought-iron fence and struck him.

title: MUSICAL: MCANUFF'S 'RICHTHOFEN' ARRIVES AT PUBLIC
description: DES MCANUFF is a 30-year-old director, playwright and composerlyricist who has more talents than he knows what to do with - and he certainly hasn't figured out what to do with them in his new show at the Public's Newman Theater, ''The Death of von Richthofen as Witnessed From Earth.'' Mr. McAnuff seems to have poured every idea he has into this extravagant musical - ideas about stage esthetics, history, music and sex - but he hasn't found the one governing master stroke that might shape ''von Richthofen'' into a vibrant, not to mention coherent, piece of theater. The evening is at once overstuffed and undernourished: even as you admire its creator's fanciful riffs, you find yourself sinking rapidly into tedium.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cowles Communications Inc. said it had received approval from the Federal Communications Commission on July 26 to liquidate. The company said that the approval would become final on Sept.7, unless further proceedings are initiated, and that it had received a favorable tax ruling.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT AN INFILTRATION
description: Israel said tonight that a group of ''terrorists'' infiltrated Israeli lines near the village of Aamiq in eastern Lebanon this afternoon.

title: Manhattan Priest Is Cleared Of an Arms Charge in Dublin
description: Arms possession charges against an Irish-American Melkite priest who runs a home for troubled youths on Manhattan's Lower East Side were unexpectedly dropped today in Dublin's Special Criminal Court.

title: 2d Suspect Seized In Payroll Slayings
description: A 25-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged as one of the men who killed two guards during a $40,000 payroll robbery on July 22 in the Bay Ridge section of the borough, the police said.

title: Koch to Halt Use Of Police Copters
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would stop using a police helicopter to fly to campaign appearances.

title: Money Fund Assets Up $3.62 Billion in Week
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $3.62 billion, to $212.59 billion, a record, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: SAN FRANCISCO DROPS ITS BASKETBALL PROGRAM
description: The University of San Francisco, which won the national collegiate championship twice, announced yesterday that it has dropped varsity basketball indefinitely in order to preserve the school's ''integrity and its reputation.''

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
President Elected, By Phelps Dodge
description: Richard T. Moolick, 61 years old, a vice chairman of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, was elected president of the big copper concern, replacing George B. Munroe, 61, who continues as chairman and chief executive.

title: HACKENSACK WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.& W. SELLS UNITS FOR $350 MILLION
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell two of its subsidiaries for an estimated $350 million in cash, securities and property to a newly formed firm headed by a Gulf and Western executive.

title: DATA I-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
South Africa Sentences Mercenary to 10 Years
description: A South African Supreme Court judge sentenced Col. Mike Hoare, the leader of white mercenary operations in Africa for two decades, to 10 years in prison today for hijacking a jetliner to escape after a bungled coup in the Seychelles.

title: Operating Chief Leaving At Glenmore Distilleries
description: Paul Casi, president and chief operating officer of the Glenmore Distilleries Company, announced that he would resign in order to fulfill a long-standing desire to start his own company.

title: Uniworld Starts Unit To Create Hispanic Ads
description: The Uniworld Group, specialists in communicating with the black consumer, is one of the country's most successful black-owned ad agencies. It is now adding to its capability to create advertising as well for the fast-growing Hispanic community.

title: HOUSE UNIT PASSES SLURRY BILL AND PIPELINE EMINENT DOMAIN
description: The House Public Works Committee, overriding vigorous opposition from the railroad industry, has passed legislation that would give developers of coal slurry pipelines the power to order the sale of property sought for rights-of-way. A similar measure is pending in the Senate Energy Committee.

title: SUPERIOR OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ASSOCIATED BANC-CORP (WIS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SENATORS CHASTISE LABOR OFFICER ON JOBLESS AID
description: Labor Department officials encountered ridicule and scorn from senators of both parties today when they emphatically restated the Reagan Administration's opposition to an emergency program of unemployment insurance.

title: 'NIGHT SHIFT' VICE RING HUMOR AT MORGUE
description: THE makers of ''Night Shift'' must have been in a mighty odd mood when they came up with the idea for a comedy about a prostitution ring that operates out of a morgue.

title: DMI FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MICHIGAN SUGAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PUBLISHING: A DIP INTO THE WORLD CUP
description: MARIO VARGAS LLOSA played soccer in his youth, and he began writing regularly for newspapers soon after graduation from college, so he felt right at home covering the recent World Cup in Spain for several European dailies. Playing down any suggestion that he is an authority on the subject, however, the Peruvian-born author noted during a recent visit to New York, ''I covered it from the perspective of a novelist who loves the game.''

title: Determined Giant
description: A year ago, Kevin Kurdyla was a 21-year-old rookie free agent, an offensive tackle from Rutgers trying to make the Giants. Instead, he got hurt and spent the season on injured reserve.

description: Learning to Pass, Through the Gates

title: Big Band on L.I.
description: A free concert will be given tonight at 8 by the Bill Meyers Kingsmen, a big band, at Rath Park, 849 Fenworth Boulevard in Franklin Square, L.I. The concert, which will be open to dancing, is one of eight sponsored by the Hempstead Department of Parks and Recreation. It is suggested that audience members bring chairs. Information: (516) 488-1843.

title: 'DENSE PACK' IS WRONG FOR MX MISSILES
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 051142 -- No Title
description: A bill quietly enacted by the House of Representatives 10 days ago has begun to open the way for large commercial sales of American arms to foreign nations, including $1 billion worth of arms to India.

title: PETROLEUM ACREAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Owens-Corning Starts $7 Million Campaign
description: Taking the Pink Panther by the tail, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, the insulation specialists, is preparing to start a $7 million advertising and promotion campaign that is 20 percent up from last year. It is being built around the company's first sweepstakes, which will have a first prize of $50,000, and has been constructed to build consumer traffic at the retailers who are the company's customers.

title: 3 RESTAURANTS WITH A RIVER VIEW
description: AS though it were not enough to feast the eyes on the spectacular view of the Lower Manhattan skyline and the massive, sculptural sweep of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Fulton Ferry Landing offers more solid sustenance by way of food in three attractive restaurants.

description: The 1981 results have been restated for the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: UNR INDUSTRIES FILES FOR CHAPTER 11
description: UNR Industries of Chicago announced yesterday that it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code.

title: Ex-Congressman Quits Maryland G.O.P. Race
description: Former Representative Robert E. Bauman, defeated in 1980 after acknowledging that he was an alcoholic with homosexual tendencies, today dropped out of the race to win back his House seat, saying he had been viciously attacked by an opponent and was tired of the demands of a political campaign.

title: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place; Printers Of Checks Still Thrive
description: FOR years, portfolio managers have shunned the check printers as buggy whip companies. And why not? The era of electronic fund transfers has been heralded since 1960. But the eclipse has not happened and there is no sign that the blizzard of checks that courses through the system will do anything but grow larger for years to come.

title: ATICO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN AND MRS. GANDHI RESOLVE DISPUTE ON NUCLEAR FUEL FOR INDIA
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and President Reagan agreed today to increase scientific, cultural and economic cooperation between the nations and resolve a longstanding dispute over India's nuclear program.

title: DOW UP 0.38 TO END 6-SESSION DECLINE
description: Stock market prices, which had declined for six consecutive sessions, managed to close slightly higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Country Music Upstate
description: Two Sunday concerts by the singer Charlie Pride will cap the fifth annual Country Music Festival at Hunter Mountain on Route 23A in Hunter, N.Y. The weekendlong festival features music from 10 A.M. to midnight today through Sunday, with appearances by Mr. Pride at 3 and 8 P.M. Also appearing will be Bill Anderson, Bobby Bare, Dave Rowland, Charly McClain and others.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,276,000 for the qr and $6,798,000 for the 6 mos

title: TENOR SAXES ARE OUT IN FORCE AT THE CLUBS
description: SONNY STITT'S death last week left several rips in the fabric of jazz, for Mr. Stitt did several things surpassingly well. To many jazz fans, he was first and foremost the alto saxophonist who spoke Charlie Parker's language with incomparable fluency. But others valued his swaggering, gruff-toned tenor saxophone playing more. For every album of Parker-style alto improvisations he recorded, he must have made at least half a dozen on tenor, often in the bluesy, backto-basics tenor-and-organ-combo mold that was so popular with black jazz fans through the 1950's and 60's.

title: AMERICAN NATURAL RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss of $1.6 million for the qr and income of $16.5 million for the 6mos from Michigan Consolidated Gas, which has since been spun off, and a gain of $4.8 million for the 6 mos from a change in accounting for depletion

title: ART: DRAWINGS, RETICENT AND BOLD, AT THE MODERN
description: ONCE upon a time there were drawing exhibitions that did everything but hide under the table, so discreet were they. The drawings themselves hardly peeped out from beneath the thick mats. The frames were of thin plain wood. The lights were low. Every curtain in sight was drawn. You could hear yourself breathe, quite distinctly. From time to time an unmistakable savant would come out and look you over, just to make sure that you were not planning to do the drawings an injury.

title: A PREMIERE SCHEDULED ON THE APPALACHIAN TRAIL
description: A celebration tomorrow and Sunday, including a five-mile hike, a concert, a fair and a roast beef dinner will mark the opening of part of a new section of the Appalachian Trail along the New York-Connecticut border. The segment will be closed after the weekend, pending the completion of a bridge and acquisition of more land, and hikers will revert to the old trail.

title: MUSICAL 'BABY' IS ON THE WAY, STORY OF 3 1/2 COUPLES
description: WITH the baby boom so prominent in the news these days, it was inevitable: There is a Broadway musical in the works called ''Baby.'' It has a book by Sybille Pearson, whose ''Sally and Marsha'' was staged last season at the Manhattan Theater Club; music by David Shire, who won an Academy Award for his theme song for the film ''Norma Rae,'' and lyrics by Richard Maltby Jr., who will also be the director. Mr. Maltby won the Tony Award as best director for ''Ain't Misbehavin.' '' The plan is to give ''Baby'' a workshop production in November and to open on Broadway in the spring. The producer is James B. Freydberg, a co-producer of ''Master Harold ... and the Boys.''

title: BETZ LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'SWAMP THING' FUN AND FRIGHT
description: WHEN you have a horror film in which the ''creature'' looks like John Foster Dulles permanently stuck inside a scuba diver's cast-off wet suit, a rubbery, greenish thing fitted with its own varicosities, you can be fairly sure the movie is meant to be funny.

title: A YALE MAN GRABS JETS' NOTICE
description: John Rogan used to show up in short pants on the first day of football practice at Yale. But that is hardly the only difference in being an Ivy League quarterback and attempting to make the Jets, he conceded.

title: Who Will Fight Duran?
description: Roberto Duran, the former lightweight and welterweight champion, has a fight scheduled for Nov. 19, but the question is who will be his opponent: Tony Ayala or Davey Moore? The promoter Don King said Wednesday that Duran would fight Ayala in a 12-round match to be telecast by NBC. Yesterday, the promoter Bob Arum announced that Duran would challenge Moore for the World Boxing Association's junior middleweight title on NBC. Tom Merritt, a spokesman for NBC, said, ''We're looking for a Duran fight in prime time on Nov. 19.'' The opponent? Merritt said he didn't know.

title: EMERY AIR FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Village steakhouse; and Spanish touch.
description: SOON after it opened last year, K.O.'s, the atttractive, dramatically lighted modern steakhouse at Bank and Greenwich Streets, rated one star, and two seemed not far behind. That early promise has now been fulfilled because the kitchen staff has developed a more authoritative hand with seasonings and corrected some earlier flaws. The characteristic steakhouse sizzle may still be lacking as meats come from kitchen to table, but that shortcoming is compensated for by the superb quality of the carefully broiled meats and fish, and the diverting side dishes and appetizers that are more stylish than those in the standard steakhouse format.

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: B-Including a gain of $39,641 from the sale of equipment...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $207,498 for the qr and $232,841 for the 6mos, gains on the disposition of equipment of $196,259 for the qr and $478,638 for the 6 mos and a charge of $465,806 for the 6 mos from an accounting change

title: PRAYER AMENDMENT SPLITS FAITHS
description: Religious leaders disagreed vigorously today over whether the Senate should approve President Reagan's proposed constitutional amendment to permit officially sanctioned prayer in the public schools.

title: CHAMPION SPARK PLUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: THURSDAY NIGHT FEVER
description: ''Sometimes you look out the window at dusk,'' said a local resident, ''and you don't see any, and you think maybe they won't come, maybe finally they are gone.'' But as surely as bugs to porch lights, they return on summer nights to this small village - at first just a few, then later in swarms, covering sidewalks, driving patrons away from businesses, causing some property damage and keeping people awake until all hours of the night.

title: TEX OF SPEECHES BY REAGAN AND MRS. GANDHI
description: Following are the texts of speeches delivered today by President Reagan and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India during welcoming ceremonies for Mrs. Gandhi at the White House: President Reagan

title: 'N.I.M.H.,' SHADES OF DISNEY'S GOLDEN ERA
description: ''THE SECRET OF N.I.M.H.'' is a resourceful and valiant though unsuccessful attempt to revive the kind of animated feature identified with the Golden Age of Walt Disney, the era of ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' ''Pinocchio,'' ''Dumbo'' and ''Bambi,'' among others.

title: A Jet Fights For Fair Play
description: Fights in football training camps happen from time to time - a quick explosion of bodies, tempers flare, then a handshake and it's over. But Ben Rudolph of the Jets fought with a teammate yesterday for the second straight day, and he vowed to continue battling unless teammates playing across the line from him stop holding him.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New York 6, L.A. 113

title: ARAB NATIONS ENDORSE A P.L.O. PULLOUT
description: The Arab League announced a plan today calling for the Palestine Liberation Organization to leave west Beirut after it receives guarantees for its safe passage out of Lebanon and for the future security of Palestinian refugees remaining in Lebanon.

title: POPS, SPOOFS AND A SCIENCE MUSEUM
description: AMONG the many teams that take to the playing fields of television during the summer, one of the most steadfast is the Boston Pops Orchestra, now in its 13th season of public television's ''Evening at Pops,'' which appears with the cellist Nathaniel Rosen as guest star tomorrow night at 9 on WNET, Channel 13.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Agent Pleads Not Guilty in Arms Case
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, pleaded not guilty today to four charges of conspiring to smuggle 40,000 pounds of military-controlled plastic explosives to Libya five years ago.

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
YOUNG VIOLINIST IN OLD TRADITION, WITH VARIATIONS
description: Shlomo Mintz, the 24-year-old violinist appearing at the Mostly Mozart Festival tonight and tomorrow night, is both a typical and an atypical young virtuoso.

title: GULF'S DEAL WITH CITIES IS DELAYED
description: A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order today that bars the Gulf Oil Corporation for at least 10 days from proceeding with its plan to acquire the Cities Service Company.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE LAST ALGONQUIN. By Theodore L. Kazimiroff. 197 pages. Illustrated with maps. Walker. $12.95.

title: Latecomer's 67 Ties For Canadian Lead
description: Brad Bryant, who did not find out that he had been admitted to the Canadian Open golf tournament until midnight Wednesday, shot a four-under-par 67 today to share the lead with Bruce Douglass and Greg Norman.

title: SEALED AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Waiting to Get Through To Poland by Phone

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNION ELECTRIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Humphrey Retiring
description: Claude Humphrey a defensive end for the Philadelphia Eagles who won all-pro honors six times since he joined the National Football League in 1968, announced his retirement yesterday because of a knee injury that he suffered last season against the New York Giants.

title: COOPERS IN TIE
description: Coopers & Lybrand, the large international accounting and consulting firm, said that it had reached a merger agreement with Shaye, Lutz, Schwartz & King, one of Albany's oldest accounting firms, for an undisclosed sum. The merger, which will take effect in October, will allow Coopers & Lybrand to expand its practice in the Albany area, especially in state government-related business, according to Robert Hilliard, spokesman for the company.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THEATER: IONESCO MYSTERY
description: EUGENE IONESCO deals with the art of the impossible; events are taken past the point of their natural order. What is created, in his word, is ''irrationalist'' theater. Despite the seriousness of his purpose, he remains cheerful. Even as he flirts with death and destruction, he is a clown, and his plays are, first of all, comedies. Unfortunately, the revival of ''Victims of Duty,'' which opened last night under the auspices of the Theater for Actors and Playwrights at the Colonnades Theater Lab, is almost stupefyingly humorless.

title: AETNA, UP 3.7%, HAS PLAN TO BUY FIRM
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company reported yesterday that gains by its noncasualty and property insurance operations helped lift operating income in the second quarter of this year by 6.5 percent, while net income advanced 3.7 percent.

title: Sampson: No Regrets
description: Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot 4-inch center from the University of Virginia, said yesterday that he had withstood heavy pressures from three National Basketball Association teams - Detroit, Boston and Dallas - to turn pro.

title: Friday; MUSICAL FIREWORKS
description: The New York Philharmonic orchestra brings music - and fireworks - to two parks this weekend in two free concerts. John Nelson, music director of the Indianapolis Symphony, will conduct the orchestra in ''Scheherazade,'' by Rimsky-Korsakov with violin solos by Charles Rex; ''Francesca da Rimini'' and the ''1812'' Overture by Tchaikovsky. The fireworks accompany the ''1812.'' Tonight's venue is Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx at Broadway and West 242d Street. Tomorrow night, it will be Cunningham Park, at Union Turnpike and Frances Lewis Boulevard in Queens. Performances start at 8 P.M. Information, 877-2011. FREE DANCE IN BROOKLYN

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE APPROVES $175.3 BILLION MILITARY MEASURE
description: The House tonight approved a $175.3 billion military authorization bill for the 1983 fiscal year after voting an across-the-board reduction of 1 percent.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker; A GUIDE TO BROOKLYN'S REVITALIZED FULTON FERRY
description: IT is not Brooklyn Heights, it is not Cobble Hill, and it is not the area around the old Navy Yard. Until recently it was not even thought of as a neighborhood at all, but now it is spoken of as the Fulton Ferry area, recalling the days when it was the Brooklyn terminus of ferry service across the East River, from Brooklyn's Fulton Street to Manhattan's.

title: A Certificate Is Not a Policy
description: This much is palpable in the ''certification'' debate over El Salvador: Progress is in the eyes of the beholder.

title: BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for 9 mos sales
WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including securities gains of $1,858,000 for the qr and $5,500,000 for the 6 mos

title: SUBURBAN PROPANE GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTRODUCING NORTHROP'S F-5G
description: Two years ago, Thomas V. Jones, chairman and chief executive officer of the Northrop Corporation, set out on his own to develop a new plane without Government help.

title: GEORGE KLEINSINGER, COMPOSER, 68
description: George Kleinsinger, a composer whose works ranged from the children's favorite ''Tubby the Tuba'' to scores for the opera ''Archy and Mehitabel'' and its sequel, the musical ''Shinbone Alley,'' died Wednesday in New York at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SPACE MUSEUM HAS JUST THE THING FOR VISITORS
description: There are critics who say this era may never again see the likes of the master show this summer at the National Gallery of Art: 60 paintings by El Greco of Toledo, a show that stuns crowds of tired, dusty tourists each day. But these enthusiasts haven't seen the work yet of Kyle Murphy and his sidekick, Tim Johnson, two aerial artists in the National Air and Space Museum's latest entry in the tourist supershow competition.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BONDS UP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Prices of fixed-income securities moved up in active trading yesterday, with a concomitant decline in yields. Government securities dealers said the market found the Government's August debt refunding plan, which the Treasury announced Wednesday afternoon, to be favorable on balance.

title: W.R. SINGLETON, CORN GENETICIST
description: W. Ralph Singleton, a leading expert on corn genetics, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 82 years old.

title: NEEDLESS AND HURTFUL PROPOSAL ON OIL TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIME RATE CUT SPREADS
description: A half-point cut in the prime lending rate, to 15 1/2 percent, became widespread yesterday. The rate is down one percentage point from the 16 1/2 percent level that prevailed from mid-June to July 19.

title: OUT OF MIAMI DETENTION, HAITIAN TESTS FREEDOM
description: Shortly before Joseph Denis was released from the Krome Avenue detention center here, a Federal immigration official gave him a slip of paper. On it were Mr. Denis's name, his country of birth, Haiti, and the date on which his temporary release could be extended or revoked, Nov. 23, 1982.

title: 'Ruddigore' on 74th St.
description: Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Ruddigore'' will be presented by the Light Opera of Manhattan through Aug. 8 at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street.

title: Court Voids U.S. Contract
description: A Federal court in Alexandria, Va., ruled yesterday that a $65 million contract awarded by the Defense Department to the Federal Data Systems Corporation last March was void.

title: N.B.A. in Charge Against Union
description: Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said yesterday that the league had filed a charge of unfair labor practice against the National Basketball Players Association.

title: BRIEFING
description: Front-Runners Report

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings figures for the yr-ago 9 mos includes a 6 cent gain on real estatetransactions

title: McDonnell Order
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has been awarded a $421.4 million contract to start production of the first 12 AV-8B short-takeoff attack planes, the Navy announced. The Marine Corps plans to buy 340 of the planes.

title: FOR CANADIANS, ANNUAL MIGRATION TO 'THE COTTAGE'
description: The weather reports give detailed temperatures in the city and in ''Cottage Country.'' The afternoon traffic news, full of static from some hovering helicopter, talk about jams on the roads to ''Cottage Country.'' Over weekday lunches businessmen, teachers, mechanics, most everyone it seems, talks about the past weekend or the coming one in ''Cottage Country.'' Yet this favored land appears on no road maps.

title: 'MAYBE I WASN'T LADY-FIED'
description: The unwritten rule among her colleagues in journalism is that only fools patronize Sarah McClendon and her hardedged airily drawled questions.

title: I.B.M. Unit Drops British Lawsuit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation pulled out of a lawsuit in the middle of a High Court hearing, dropping its claim that an English public utility had awarded a major contract to an I.B.M. rival because the utility thought the United States had not given Britain sufficient support in the Falkland Islands conflict with Argentina.

title: U.N. CALLS ON ISRAEL TO LET FOOD INTO WEST BEIRUT
description: The Security Council voted tonight to demand that Israel immediately lift its blockade of west Beirut to permit food and other supplies to reach the besieged area of the Lebanese capital.

title: Required Reading; 'A Tobacco User'
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, in Senate debate over continuation of the tobacco price support program, July 14, 1982:

title: FORECAST QUESTIONED
description: The Reagan Administration, in a controversial midyear economic review that has been rejected by some of the President's top economist aides, predicts a recovery this year and next that is more optimistic than other forecasts.

title: RIGHTS: BULWARK OF PEACE
description: Many citizens active in efforts to promote peace are deeply suspicious of efforts to link discussions with the Soviet Union about disarmament with complaints about Soviet abuses of human rights. When President Reagan did this recently in his speech at the United Nations, the reaction of many peace activists was that the human rights issue was raised insincerely as a way of forestalling serious negotiations. Perhaps this view is correct; perhaps not. Yet doubts about the President's sincerity should not obscure the degree to which human rights and peace are organically intertwined.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUPREME COURT RECEIVES REAGAN PLEA ON ABORTION
description: The Reagan Administration formally urged the Supreme Court today to ''give heavy deference'' to state and local laws restricting abortion rights and strongly implied that the Court's 1973 decision legalizing abortion was wrong.

title: Saints Ordered To Drug Seminar
description: The New Orleans Saints will end training camp with a mandatory, three-day drug seminar before the players get their first paychecks, officials said today.

title: Darwin on Human Life
description: To the Editor:

title: ATHLONE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lesotho Guerrillas Raid Leader's House
description: Anti-Government guerrillas attacked the country home of Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan with mortars and other weapons Wednesday night, the Lesotho radio reported today.

title: 'Penzance' at Lyndhurst
description: A production of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' with the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players, will set sail for one performance tomorrow night at 8:30 at Lyndhurst, the National Trust for Historic Preservation property in Tarrytown, N.Y. Albert Bergeret, artistic director of the ensemble, will direct the outdoor production. The Sweet Adelines, an a cappella group, will give a preshow concert at 7 P.M. Tickets are $5 ($2 for those 12 and younger). Information: (914) 631-7766.

title: BISHOP GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $30,000 for the qr and $63,000 for the 6 mos...C-After a loss of $109,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $181,000 on the disposal of assets

title: R.J. REYNOLDS WINS HEUBLEIN
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's largest cigarette producer, and Heublein Inc., owner of Kentucky Fried Chicken and the nation's top producer of vodka and mixed cocktails, have agreed to a merger valued at $1.3 billion in which Reynolds will acquire Heublein for cash and securities.

title: Bell Turned Down On Data Link Rate
description: The Federal Communications Commission refused to approve rates for a data transmission service by an unregulated subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: THE BIGGEST HOAX
description: David Brinkley recently posed this question to his television audience: Has there ever been a bigger hoax in Washington than the so-called ''balanced budget amendment'' supported by the Reagan Administration?

title: AZTEC DISCOVERIES SHOWN AT MUSEUM
description: ''AZTEC MEXICO: Discovery of Templo Mayor,'' at the American Museum of Natural History, is an exhibition of sculptures, artifacts and jewelry from the extraordinary Indian civilization that had by the time of the Spanish conquest dominated central Mexico for 200 years. Of the 114 objects on view, the largest and most spectacular is a cast of a circular carved stone. It is also the most important piece in the show, for had the Coyolxauhqui Stone not been accidentally discovered by workmen in Mexico City four years ago the remaining Aztec treasures would not be on view.

title: No Headline
description: IRAN REPORTS SEIZING 60 SQUARE MILES OF IRAQI LAND

title: METS DROP FOURTH IN ROW, 4-1, TO PIRATES
description: Dick Davis, playing in right field last night in place of the injured Dave Parker, singled and hit a home run to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-1 victory over the struggling Mets at Shea Stadium.

title: CONQUEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-There are no yr-ago shr earnings because the company only went public in Jan

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAMUEL MORSE PAINTING SOLD FOR $3.25 MILLION
description: President Reagan's Ambassador at Large for Cultural Affairs has paid $3.25 million for an 1832 painting by Samuel F.B. Morse, who was a celebrated artist before he invented the telegraph and the Morse code.

title: 'Chemical Dependence'
description: Charles White, the Cleveland Browns' running back and the Heisman Trophy winner at Southern California in 1980, said yesterday that a ''chemical dependence'' could have ruined his family life and his football career if he had not sought professional help.

title: BROTHERHOOD GROUP'S NEW HEAD
description: An energetic and innovative leader in higher education was elected president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews yesterday. The new president, Jacqueline Grennan Wexler, who was president of Hunter College in New York from 1970 to 1979, succeeds Dr. David Hyatt, who will retire in October after 28 years with the human relations organization.

title: Norwegian Journalist Killed in Afghanistan
description: A Norwegian journalist traveling with guerrilla forces inside Afghanistan has been killed during fighting, the Norwegian Foreign Office said today.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: ROBERT MORRIS'S sculpture proposal for a new Veterans Administration hospital at Bay Pines, Fla., was greeted by agency officials with consternation. After seeing the proposal, which called for the installation of shells of the types that encased the nuclear bombs dropped on Japan, the administration immediately canceled the commission. Now Mr. Morris is suing the agency for payment.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS CITE PROBLEMS IN TALKS ON P.L.O. PULLOUT
description: Administration officials said today that, while Philip C. Habib was making some progress, major hurdles remained in working out an agreement for the evacuation of Palestinian guerrilla forces from west Beirut.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After pretax foreign currency translation losses of $254,000 for the qr and $641,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including pretax foreign currency translation gains of$921,000 for the qr and $1,410,000 for the 6 mos

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ART-ROCK: QUEEN PLAYS THE GARDEN
description: QUEEN, the English rock quartet that appeared at Madison Square Garden Tuesday and Wednesday, is renowned for its formidable technical skills. The group is as adept at operatically flowery artrock as it is at slamming heavy metal.

title: INDONESIA SEEKS TO KEEP PACE IN ARMS
description: A series of meetings in Washington this week between Indonesia's Defense Minister and the Reagan Administration are aimed at maintaining Jakarta's military equipment and retraining its personnel, the chief of internal security, Admiral Sudumo, said today.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens, 8 P.M. The Pirates have two players among the top 10 batters in the National League, Tony Pena and Johnny Ray.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1981 and restated for acquisitions on a pooling of interests basis

title: THE ATLANTIC ALLIANCE WON'T DIE OF ITS FUED
description: To the Editor:

title: NOAH BREEZES TO QUARTERFINALS
description: Yannick Noah, France's premier player, made his belated debut in the $125,000 Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament today, and was impressive in two victories as he reached the quarterfinals.

title: Jack T. Donnell
description: Jack T. Donnell, 53 years old, was president and chief operating officer of the Charter Company, a petroleum, insurance and publishing conglomerate with headquarters in Jacksonville, Fla., that has rapidly risen to 75 on the Fortune 500 listing of major businesses in the United States.

title: Fuji Cars in Portugal
description: Fuji Heavy Industries said today that it planned to start production of minicars in Portugal. The main parts would be supplied from Japan.

title: D.F.I. Holdings To Buy Dellwood
description: Dellwood Foods Inc., a major distributor of milk in the New York metropolitan area, announced that it had agreed to be acquired by D.F.I. Holdings Inc., a holding company owned by William R. Berkley, for $26.50 a share, or $12.3 million.

title: CMT INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARD TIMES DON'T GET PAST DISNEY WORLD DOOR
description: In this, the summer of America's hardest times in four decades, the press of humanity within the gates of the Magic Kingdom is nearly crushing enough to bring on fermentation. Lines, lines, lines, packed, long and pokey, are all over Disney World. The Sistine Chapel is more easily attained this July than the Country Bear Jamboree.

title: NEW YORK AIR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST-EVER PRIMARY FIGHT DEVELOPS FOR CONNECTICUT SECRETARY OF STATE
description: Setting up a statewide Democratic primary contest on Sept. 7, Patricia T. Hendel announced today that she would challenge Julia H. Tashjian for the party's nomination for secretary of the state.

title: Going Out Guide
description: ALIENATION

title: DU PONT POSTS SMALL DROP IN QUARTER
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter fell slightly, to $247 million, or $1.03 a share, and that without the inclusion of the results of the recently acquired Conoco Inc., the decline would have been much larger.

title: PR Newswire Sold
description: The Western Union Corporation said yesterday that it was selling PR Newswire Association Inc., a subsidiary, to United Newspapers P.L.C., a London-based organization, for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition of PR Newswire, a high-speed, automated communications network that reaches 400 media organizations, will take effect in August and will mark the entry of United Newspapers into telecommunications and its first major investment in the United States, the company said. United Newspapers publishes more than 60 newspapers and magazines in Britain, including The Yorkshire Post and Punch.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX FLAT IN JUNE
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, intended to forecast economic trends, was unchanged in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Yefet Tsedaka, Leader Of Samaritans in Israel
description: Yefet Tsedaka, leader of the Samaritan community in Israel for half a century, died today in his home in Holon. He was 87 years old.

title: FIRST CITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MONUMENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHAMPION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Around the World; Transit Workers Begin Strike in Montreal
description: Bus and subway operators began a strike today, leaving 600,000 commuters without public transportation.

title: SECOND U.S. TAX REBATE HAS LITTLE IMPACT ON PAYCHECKS
description: The extra take-home pay from the second stage of President Reagan's three-year tax cut, American wage earners say, is being spent the same way it has been received since July 1: little by little.

title: The London Symphony Wins Daytona Beach
description: The London Symphony Orchestra has raised the honky-tonk reputation of this town a note or two by renewing a musical romance that ended 13 years ago.

title: Sports of the Times; DEVILS MOVE IN AT MEADOWLANDS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. M ax McNab flings open a door and there, in the basement of Byrne Meadowlands Arena, piled like the rubble of a dead civilization, are the last remnants of the Colorado Rockies.

title: Sales of New Houses Dropped 14% in June
description: Sales of new single-family houses fell 14 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 343,000 units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: REAGAN POLLSTER FINDS PUBLIC PATIENCE WITH ECONOMIC POLICY
description: President Reagan was told by his pollster today that there was still a surprisingly large ''pool of patience'' with his economic program among the nation's voters.

title: Drop the Trains
description: Long distance train travel is a civilized pleasure, a welcome alternative to the rush of jets or the tedium of the interstates. But as a new report by Congress's Budget Office makes clear, passenger trains are also a heavily subsidized luxury that America can ill afford. This new assessment of Amtrak is a persuasive argument for limiting passenger rail to a few high-density intercity corridors, where fares might come close to covering costs.

title: No Headline
description: Briefs on the Arts Performing Arts Festival At Lincoln Center

title: PLANS FOR EAST RIVER HOUSING LOSES KEY FINANCIAL BACKER
description: The major financial backer withdrew yesterday from a planned housing and commercial development project along a stretch of the East River in Manhattan from 16th to 24th Street.

title: Sports People; Advice for the N.B.A.
description: Maurice Lucas, who was acquired last month by the Phoenix Suns from the New York Knicks, said yesterday that he hopes National Basketball Association teams will develop a better system of informing players of trades. Lucas learned of his trade from a fellow airline passenger while on the way to an N.B.A. goodwill tour in China.

title: BRIEFS
description: * B.O.C. International P.L.C.'s Airco Inc. subsidiary said it would build a $4 million carbon dioxide production facility in Franklin, N.Y., beginning this summer.

title: U.S. Holds Up Contract Rules
description: The Labor Department acknowledged today that it had halted proposals to ease antidiscrimination guidelines for Federal contractors and would rewrite the standards, apparently under White House pressure.

title: PUPETS ENCOURAGE NONVERBAL CHILDREN
description: A New York psychotherapist was granted a patent this week for a device to encourage dialogue with nonverbal or resistant children. Laura B. Solomon, a creative arts therapist on the staff of Rockaway Mental Health Services in Far Rockaway, Queens, got patent 4,341,521.

title: VOLCANO FELLS PALMS AND PLANES, BUT INDONESIAN VILLAGERS HANG ON
description: Gray dust from the nearby Galunggung volcano lies inches thick on the terraced rice paddies around this village of 8 houses and 60 people. The weight of dust has broken the coconut fronds. It has killed the fish, turned the air into a choking, gritty fog and caused the 6,504-foot volcano, little more than a mile and a half away, to disappear from view.

title: Dow Declines 3.61; 2-Year Nasdaq Low
description: Weakness in energy-related issues helped send the stock market moderately lower yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average registered its seventh decline in eight trading sessions.

title: DAILY NEWS WARNS UNIONS OF CUTS
description: The Daily News said yesterday that it would begin cost-cutting measures if its pressmen, paperhandlers, mailers and drivers did not agree to contract concessions by next Friday.

title: S.E.C. Sets Rules on Corporate News Releases
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today set new guidelines for the information that publicly held companies must disclose in news releases and public statements that deal with financial results.

title: No Headline
description: Carlton Wins 14th, Completes 11th Game

title: Canada Says It Backs Right Of Palestinians to Homeland
description: Canada is willing to participate in a peacekeeping force in Lebanon and believes the Palestinians deserve a homeland, the Government said today.

title: NO TO GUILT FOR ISRAEL
description: There is a specter haunting Israel and its American Jewish supporters. It is called guilt. Guilt over the ''repression of Palestinian human rights.'' Guilt over the refusal to remove ''the main obstacle to peace in the Middle East,'' the ''occupation of the Arab lands seized in 1967.'' Guilt over the unwillingness to give the ''Palestinians'' their own state in the ''occupied lands.'' And now, guilt over the killing of ''Palestinians'' and ''innocent civilians in Lebanon.''

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
News Summary; SATURDAY, JULY 31, 1982
description: International A plan for the P.L.O.'s withdrawal of 6,000 fighters from west Beirut was sent by Lebanon's Prime Minister to Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy. Palestinian officials said the P.L.O.'s plan called for the guerrillas to leave Lebanon by land over a one-month period and to be ''redeployed'' in Syria, Jordan, and Egypt, which they said had agreed conditionally to take in some of the fighters. (Page 1, Column 6.) A new cease-fire in Beirut arranged by Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, appeared to be holding. It began at 9 P.M. Lebanon time (3 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time), and followed the bombardment by Israeli forces of Palestinian neighborhoods in west Beirut from the land, sea and air. The attacks began only hours after the Palestine Liberation Organization presented the Lebanese Prime Minister with a detailed plan for the withdrawal of the besieged P.L.O. guerrillas from west Beirut. (1:5.)

title: Ford Planning A New Engine
description: The Ford Motor Company announced that its Lima, Ohio, engine plant will produce a new six-cylinder engine beginning in 1985 following worker ratification of a contract changing some work rules at the factory.

title: THE COSTLY CREWS OF U.S.-FLAG SHIPS
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMO ASSERTS BIAS IN LAW CONTINUES
description: An internal Reagan Administration memorandum says that ''substantive sections'' of Federal law make differentiations on the basis of sex despite the effort to remove such language.

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Briefing
description: Prophetic Criticism

title: TEXACO CANADA LTD reports earnings for QTr to June 30
BIRD & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lapka, Hubble in Giants' Cuts
description: The Giants made their first roster cuts of training camp today by dropping 12 players. They included Myron Lapka, the defensive lineman who was their third choice in the 1980 draft, and Robert Hubble, the 6-foot-7 3/4-inch tight end they selected in the eighth round last April.

title: Sports People; Change Considered
description: The Chicago White Sox lost for the 12th in their last 15 games Thursday night and the co-owners of the team conceded yesterday that they are considering the possibility of dismissing Tony LaRussa, the manager. Eddie Einhorn, one of the owners, said that a logical successor might be Bobby Winkles, the director of player development, who for a time in the 1970's was manager of the California Angels and the Oakland A's.

title: CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Around the World; South African Outlines Racial Rights Plan

title: Around the World; 40 Killed and Scores Hurt In French Road Collision
description: A multiple-vehicle collision early today involving two buses and six cars killed about 40 people and injured scores, with many of the victims children en route to August vacations, the police reported.

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Earnings for the first 6 mos of 1982 were somewhat affected by a strike which began June 14, 1982 by union hourly workers at the Versailles, Ky., distribution transformer plant

title: HEALTH PROBLEMS ARE CITED
description: President Aristides Royo of Panama resigned today, two years before his term was to end, a Government statement said. Vice President Ricardo de la Espriella was sworn in as the new chief executive hours later.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Is This Trip Necessary?'

title: INGLIS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Players Rebuffed On Pay Proposal
description: Federal Judge Robert L. Carter rejected yesterday a National Basketball Players Association's request that the N.B.A. be enjoined from proposing or negotiating a plan to moderate player salaries.

title: Rule Change In Accounting
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board said in a statement released yesterday that it would require companies to classify debt as a current liability rather than a long-term liability whenever they violate a loan agreement and are unable to get a waiver from the lender.

title: STEEL UNION VETOES INDUSTRY PROPOSAL ON REPLACING PACT
description: Leaders of the United Steelworkers of America, in a surprise action, today rejected an industry proposal to replace the present contract with a new one.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-After a loss of $5,702,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,392,000...C-Net loss after a loss of $30,405,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $51,000

description: B-After pretax losses of $146,000 for the qr and $600,000 for the 6 mos on the sale of securities...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $79,000 for the qr and $528,000 for the 6 mos, pretax losses on the sale of securities of $16,000 for the qr and $56,000 for the 6 mos and income of $196,000 for the qrand $85,000 for the 6 mos from equity in the earnings of an affiliate...D-Net loss

title: MISGUIDED CONCERN FOR P.L.O. SURVIVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota Production
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its vehicle production in 1982 would likely fall short of the 3,380,000 target because of a drop in export sales.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO ADOPT A TAIWAN ARMS COMPROMISE
description: President Reagan met today with pro-Taiwan Senators and Congressmen to spell out an American compromise on arms for the Nationalist Government that includes a new arms deal for Taiwan and a pledge to Peking that future American arms deliveries to Taiwan will not exceed current levels, members of Congress disclosed.

title: Letter: On Nursing Homes What Relaxed U.S. Rules Would Do
description: To the Editor: I support your editorial ''Nursing Homes Need Watching'' (July 15). On July 16, I was co-chairman of a House Aging Committee hearing in New Jersey to review Reagan Administration proposals to relax minimum inspection rules for nursing homes.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
Scouting; A New Nemesis
description: Greg Foster, the world's top-ranked hurdler, lost to Willie Gault last weekend in the 110-meter event at the National Sports Festival. What made the loss particularly crushing for Foster was that he has finally been rid of his nemesis, Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah, who left the track circuit to play wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers.

title: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a special gain of $12.3 million; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: HAROLD T. SAKATA
description: Harold T. Sakata, an actor best known for his sinister characterization of the killer bodyguard Oddjob in the James Bond movie ''Goldfinger,'' died Thursday. He was 62 years old.

title: STAKES HIGH IN ELECTION FOR MUSTO'S CITY OFFICE
description: The job of city commissioner here pays only $7,500 a year, but for the two candidates vying for a vacancy on the five-member commission, victory in next Wednesday's election carries implications that go beyond power or salary.

title: OREGON ENDING COHO SALMON SEASON
description: The Oregon Fish and Wildlife Commission yielded yesterday to Federal insistence that it stop sports fishing for Coho salmon in state waters off the coast.

title: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a nonrecurring charge of $17 million made in first qr due to shutdown of part of the Trona chemical plant in Searles Valley, Calif; the shr earningsand shrs outstndg results for 1981 were adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock spliton Oct 21, 1981

title: LEHERMAN TRYING TO WIN AN INDEPENDENT
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, a candidate for the Republican nomination for governor and assured of the Conservative Party nomination, is seeking to form a new party so that he can appear on a third line on the November ballot.

title: Lietzke, Sutton Share Lead at 136
description: Bruce Lietzke and Hal Sutton each shot a three-under-par 68 to tie for the lead today after the second round of the $425,000 Canadian Open golf tournament.

title: TRI-SOUTH INVESTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains from tax credits of $353,138 for the qr and $732,649 for the 6 mos...C-Including gains from tax credits of $950,350 for the qr and $1,697,121for the 6 mos

title: Pacific Telephone
description: The Pacific Telephone Company said its earlier statement that it planned to cut 16,000 nonmanagement jobs over the next 17 months was in error, and that no cuts are planned. The company, California's largest private employer with about 112,400 workers, said earlier tis week that the cuts would come through attrition. Pacific Telephone officials now say the statement resulted from internal confusion over a projection of the company's future employment needs, not current positions.

title: Miner Killed in South Africa
description: An explosion in a South African gold mine killed one miner and injured two others today. A spokesman for the West Driefontein Mine said six other black workers were missing and search teams had been sent out to find them.

title: SUIT CHARGES FRAUD AT CONTINENTAL
description: A Federal class action suit filed here on behalf of a group of Continental Illinois Corporation shareholders charges the huge bank holding company and its senior executives with ''fraudulently inducing'' the public to buy its stock by systematically masking the company's true financial condition.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a capital gain of $417,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of an investment

title: New York; RUSSIANS IN THE HAMPTONS
description: The civil rights division of the Justice Department is looking into deprivations being inflicted on Russians living in Glen Cove, Long Island. They have been denied beach, tennis and golf privileges, and the Reagan Administration is investigating to see if the loss of these inalienable rights constitutes a violation of Federal law.

title: KINARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. MAY NARROW FOCUS OF SANCTIONS
description: An Administration official told a Senate committee today that the sanctions against companies to prevent them from supplying equipment for the Siberian natural gas pipeline were being reconsidered. The point of the review, he added, was to relieve the impact on companies that sell equipment to customers not involved in the pipeline.

title: Frederic Worthen, Executive And Outward Bound Trustee
description: Frederic P. Worthen, chairman and chief executive officer of Worthen Industries, manufacturer of industrial adhesives, died of cancer Wednesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 62 years old and lived in North Andover, Mass.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Net income...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $80,000

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Are Steady
description: The prices that farmers get for raw products held steady in July after dropping in June, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Libya and Malta Seek Ruling
description: A longstanding dispute between Libya and Malta over oil-drilling rights in the Mediterranean is headed for a peaceful resolution, United Nations officials said today.

title: Summer and Smoke
description: T heatergoers at the Roundabout on West 23d Street had to contend yesterday with the unmistakable smell of smoke, remnant of a backstage fire of undetermined cause that broke out after Thursday night's performance of an adaptation of D.H. Lawrence's ''The Fox.''

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including gains from discontinued operations of $4,085,000 for the qr and $3,876,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $32,748,000 for the qr and $36,880,000 for the 6 mos

title: Bank Mergers Announced
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the McAllen State Bank of McAllen, Tex., for 2 million common shares. The current value of the shares is $35.4 million.

title: KANEB SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After income of $1,006,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $2,394,000 or 10 cents a shr for the 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,562,000 for the qr and $1,712,000 for the 6 mos; the yr-ago second qr had a gain of about $3.5 million from the sale of a drillship

title: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $193,000 and including a tax credit of $91,000...C-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $15,662,000

title: Around the Nation; Mayville, N.Y., Woman Not Guilty of Kidnapping
description: A Mayville, N.Y., woman was acquitted today of Federal kidnapping charges stemming from the 1980 abduction of a young Cleveland girl who was separated from her parents for more than a year.

title: LATIN AMERICAN THEATER TO BE STAR OF A FESTIVAL
description: The Third Latin American Popular Theater Festival will open in New York at the Public Theater tomorrow. Fifteen troupes from Latin America and the United States will participate in the two-week festival, which will run through Aug. 15.

title: OHIO-FERRO-ALLOYS CORP reports earnings for QTr to June 30
ISRAELIS AGAIN HIT PALESTINIAN AREAS
description: Israeli forces attacked Palestinian neighborhoods and artillery positions in west Beirut from the land, sea and air today.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOR SAN FRANCISCO, A PAINFUL NECESSITY
description: It was several days ago when the Rev. Charles Dullea, S.J., the chancellor and former president of the University of San Francisco, learned that the university might stop chasing another national basketball championship.

title: House Unit Passes Bill To Cut Farm Spending
description: The House Agriculture Committee has formally approved a package of commodity and food stamp proposals intended to cut billions of dollars from the Agriculture Department budget over the next three years.

title: Dr. G.C. Carlon Weds Carolyn M. McGinnis
description: Carolyn Marie McGinnis, administrator of the office of industrial affairs for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, was married in Allenhurst, N.J., yesterday to Dr. Graziano Carlo Carlon, chief of the department of critical care at Memorial Hospital and associate professor of anesthesiology at the Cornell University Medical College. Mayor James O'Malley of Allenhurst performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. McGinnis.

title: RECORD SOVIET PURCHASE SEEN IN GRAIN ACCORD
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block forecast today record Soviet purchases of American grain now that President Reagan has officially decided to seek renewal of the Soviet-American grain supply agreement for another year.

title: NEWSPAPER OFFICIALS ASSAIL RECENT TREND TO LARGE LIBEL JUDGEMENTS
description: Newspaper officials and lawyers who have specialized in defending newspapers said today that the $2.05 million libel verdict yesterday against The Washington Post Company could inhibit vigorous reporting. But the lawyers for plaintiffs in two well-publicized cases disputed that suggestion and said the verdicts would simply encourage more accurate reporting.

title: Sports People; Hornung Files Suit
description: A damage suit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association has been filed in Louisville, Ky., by Paul Hornung, the former college and professional football star, who is charging that the N.C.A.A. is depriving him of his right to make a living as a sports announcer. The N.C.A.A. has refused to hire the former Notre Dame and Green Bay Packer back as an announcer for 19 college games to be broadcast this season by station WTBS of Atlanta.

title: QUEENS FIGHTING DUMPING IN ITS PARKS
description: For years, a woody, swampy, section of Kissena Park in Queens has been used as the area's unofficial dump. This is all coming to an end.

title: Meanwhile, on the Bowery
description: W hile the city opened a spanking new shelter for homeless men this week on Wards Island, little changed on the Bowery. In front of a small liquor store, three men lay insensate beside their bottles.

title: Shift for British Oil
description: The state-owned British National Oil Corporation will transfer its oil-producing business on Sunday to a newly formed company, Britoil, Energy Secretary Nigel Lawson told the House of Commons today in a written parliamentary reply. Britoil has been set up to take over British National's oil exploration and production activities. The Government intends to sell up to 51 percent of Britoil's shares to the public in the autumn.

title: PEOPLES RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
BELL CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $8.7 million

title: DUET: ZUCKERMAN AND NEIKRUG
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival continued at Avery Fisher Hall Thursday evening with a recital by Pinchas Zukerman and Marc Neikrug. Mr. Zukerman played the violin in music by Mozart, Dvorak and Brahms and the viola in Schubert's ''Arpeggione'' Sonata. Mr. Neikrug was the pianist in all four pieces.

title: POLICEMEN IN MEXICO FACING TRIAL IN CASE OF MISSING AMERICAN
description: A judge in Sinaloa state has ruled that seven policemen must be brought to trial immediately in connection with the disappearance of a University of Colorado professor, Nicholas W. Schrock.

title: TV Notebook; SUMMER DOLDRUMS AFFLICT THE HITS
description: A newcomer to television glancing at the prime-time ratings this summer would have no idea that ''Dallas'' and ''Falcon Crest'' on CBS-TV and ''Dynasty'' on ABC-TV are three of the most popular network shows.

title: Observer; PLAYING THE GAME
description: President Reagan didn't seem very generous on television the other night. He blamed the last five American Presidents for not balancing the budget and said they were responsible for the economic mess he has on his hands.

title: OTHER SCHOOLS CITE COURAGE OF ACTION
description: Prominent coaches and administrators of intercollegiate athletics surveyed yesterday said that they viewed the University of San Francisco's decision to drop varsity basketball as a bold and courageous move.

title: HOFFA'S SON WANTS FATHER, MISSING 7 YEARS, DECLARED LEGALLY DEAD
description: On a warm afternoon seven years ago today, James R. Hoffa, wearing a blue sports shirt and dark trousers, left his home in a suburb of Detroit for a meeting from which he never returned. Today, according to state law, he can be presumed dead.

title: JURY GETS ANTITRUST CASE AGAINST 2 HAWAII DAILIES
description: After three weeks of often conflicting testimony, the antitrust suit against Hawaii's two major daily newspapers went to the jury today in Federal District Court.

title: Players; ANDERSON HELPS IVIE FEEL AT HOME
description: I t was late April when Sparky Anderson, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, received a phone call from Mike Ivie, asking for a job. Managers often get calls like this from players trying to hang on, but this one was different. Anderson said yes, he'd like to take a look at him in the batting cage. Ivie, in Houston, asked when Anderson would like to see him in Detroit.

title:
PATENTS;
WEIGHT AND PRICE AND PARCELS
description: WASHINGTON APROLIFIC inventor has found a method to weigh articles automatically and mark them directly with postage or other cost data, without need of labels. Jerome H. Lemelson, president of the Licensing Management Corporation of New York, was granted patent 4,342,038 this week for the scale and other equipment.

title: ARMY CHAPLAINS STRUGGLE IN SERVICE OF TWO MASTERS
description: The reading from the pulpit on this particular morning was drawn from the 18th chapter of the First Book of Kings. The man who delivered it was a chaplain in the United States Army, and he read these words:

title: Food for Frogs
description: Food for frogs is described in patent 4,341,800, awarded this week to Dozier Lester of Duson, La.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including a gain of $650,000 from the sale of land; yr-ago results have been restated for the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 regarding foreign currencytranslations

title: DEFENDANT CALLED A LIAR WINS APPEAL
description: A state appeals court has overturned a 1979 burglary conviction on the ground that the prosecutor went ''beyond the bounds of fair play'' by characterizing one of the defendants as a liar during closing arguments to a jury.

title: A Complete Explanation
description: B unny Louise Torres was born at Beth Israel Medical Center the other day while her deaf mother, Jackie, conveyed her own reactions with finger-spelling, and Mindy Burstein, using sign language, relayed the obstetrician's instructions every step of the way. It was not an unusual assignment for Miss Burstein, who is believed to be the only full-time sign-language interpreter on the staff of a hospital in the city.

title: JOY OF A SWIMMIN' HOLE
description: In a meadow less than a mile from the stores and houses that mark ''downtown Arlington'' is the Lions Club pool, a swimming pool with lifeguards, a cinder-block building for changing, a first-aid kit, even a pay phone. It's free to anyone and open from 1 P.M. to sundown. At other times the road to the pool is barred with a chain.

Tribune-Gannett Deal
description: The Tribune Company said today that it had agreed to print the Chicago-area edition of USA Today for Gannett Newspapers. The national newspaper will begin regular publication Sept. 15 in five states around Washington and Baltimore. The Chicagoarea edition is expected to start in the first quarter of 1983, the announcement said.

title: Around the Nation; Warner Bros. Charged In Deaths of 2 Children
description: Civil charges of exposing children to a hazardous situation and violating child labor laws were filed today against Warner Brothers and three individuals for a movie helicopter crash that killed the actor Vic Morrow and two children.

title: Scouting; Chandler in Plea For Black Stars
description: A petition with 742 signatures has been sent to the directors of baseball's Hall of Fame, asking that they ease regulations on the admission of ''old-timers'' so that more men who starred in the Negro Leagues can be admitted to the Hall of Fame.

title: METS LOSE THEIR FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: Johnny Ray, a candidate for rookie of the year, and Bill Madlock, who has won three National League batting titles, fattened their averages at the expense of the beleaguered Met pitching staff in the Pittsburgh Pirates' 5-1 victory last night at Shea Stadium.

title: GUIDRY, MAY HURL SHUTOUT
description: The Yankees beat Texas, 4-0, tonight for their first shutout in 56 games and spoiled Darrell Johnson's first evening as the Rangers' interim manager.

title: Two Soviet Astronauts Float Outside Salyut Space Station
description: Two astronauts went outside the Salyut 7 space station for 153 minutes today, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Diamond Merger Talks
description: The Diamond International Corporation said yesterday that merger talks with a company affiliated with Sir James Goldsmith, the financier, were nearing completion.

title: MCCORMICK OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The question that's most often asked is, 'Why has she come.' Well, my main reason was that I was very kindly invited by the President and I thought it would have been extremely discourteous not to accept.'' - Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, after meeting with President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (3:2.)
