title: GIRL HURT AT SHEA SEEKS $2.7 MILLION AND FUN SAFETY
description: To most of the 6,611 baseball fans at Shea Stadium on the night of May 25, 1979, the game between the Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates was memorable chiefly because it was called on account of fog.

title: JERSEY URGED TO DELAY SEWERS PENDING STUDY OF CORRUPTION
description: The New Jersey Commission of Investigation urged the Legislature today to delay passage of bills appropriating more than $100 million for local sewer projects. The commission said the funds should be withheld until legislation could be enacted to insure that the money ''won't be squandered or stolen.''

title: Clevepak to Shut Paperboard Mill
description: The Clevepak Corporation, a maker of specialty packaging and industrial products based in White Plains, said that it would shut down its recycled paperboard mill in Piermont, N.Y., as a result of dramatic increases in energy costs and a declining market for paperboard.

title: SaturdaySports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Arlington, Tex. If the Yankees win twice in Texas, they would become the first team in the American League to have 7,000 victories. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing, Queens. John Milner, a former Met, returns with the Pirates as a replacement for the injured Dave Parker. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570, and WGBB, 1240, 7:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Atlanta. (Television - Channel 4 and Manhattan Cable, 2 P.M.) White Sox vs. Boston Red Sox, at Chicago. (Television - Manhattan Cable, 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Alexis Arguello vs. Kevin Rooney, 10 rounds, junior welterweights at Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel, Atlantic City. Arguello, 75-4 with 60 knockouts, is the World Boxing Council lightweight champion. He makes his debut today as a junior welterweight against Rooney (19-1), a Staten Island native trained by Cus D'Amato. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Kid Gloves. Madison Square Garden outdoor tournament, Broadway and Getty Square, Yonkers. 1 P.M. Thoroughbred Racing Monmouth Park, Oceanport, N.J., 1:30 P.M. The $200,000-added Haskell Invitational handicap is to be a rematch between the Preakness winner, Aloma's Ruler, and Linkage, who finished second. Angel Cordero is riding Aloma's Ruler, and Bill Shoemaker is on Linkage. (Television - Channel 9, 6:30 P.M.) Belmont Park, Elmont, L.I., 1 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 6 P.M., tape, and Sports@Channel, 7 P.M., tape).

title: Mobil Wins Round In Coastal Fight
description: In the latest ruling affecting a six-year-old battle between the Mobil Corporation and the Coastal Petroleum Company over mineral mining rights, a Florida court ruled that Coastal did not have the rights to phosphate that was mined by Mobil under its own leases from 14,755 acres that also fall under Coastal's 1941 minerals lease with the state.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Dave Revering was cut yesterday by the Toronto Blue Jays and assigned to Syracuse in the International League yesterday.

title: Dailey's 'New Beginning'
description: Quintin Dailey, whose acceptance of payments prohibited under N.C.A.A. rules played a role in the University of San Francisco's decision to drop its basketball program, refused today to comment in detail on the matter. But Dailey said his involvement ''could have happened to anyone.''

title: Auto Makers List Layoffs
description: The five major domestic auto makers reported that fewer United States auto workers are on indefinite layoff this week than last, but 34,300 more are on temporary layoff than a week ago because of model change-overs.

title: Around the World; State of Emergency Imposed in Sri Lanka
description: The Government imposed a state of emergency throughout Sri Lanka today, the third since 1977, in an effort to curb the spread of violence between Sinhalese and minority Moslems.

title: Briefs on the Arts

description: What kind of arms control strategies should the United States pursue, and what can they reasonably be expected to accomplish?

title: Diplomacy Against Drugs
description: Since large supplies of heroin reappeared in major cities four years ago, the Federal Government has done little to choke the traffic at the source. The Carter Administration slashed funds for anti-drug efforts abroad and the Reagan Administration reduced them even more. The State Department's budget in this area is down to a modest $36 million.

Harvester Asks More Loan Aid
description: Top officers of the International Harvester Company asked its lenders today for more concessions in paying off its $4.2 billion debt to help keeping the giant farm implement concern going.

title: A DISAVOWED OFFICIAL FORECAST
description: Every summer, the White House must present for Congress, and everyone else who cares, its vision of the economy for the year to come.

title: U.S. AND EGYPT CALL ARAB PLAN FOR BEIRUT 'POSITIVE'
description: President Reagan and Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali of Egypt met today and agreed that an Arab League plan calling for the withdrawal of Palestinian forces from west Beirut was a ''positive step'' toward resolving the crisis in Lebanon, according to a senior Administration official.

title: Your Money; Converting Insurance
description: PEOPLE changing jobs or retiring often neglect to make a decision about converting their group life insurance policies. In the excitement of leaving, it is easy to forget that there are important savings to be gained from converting the company's group coverage into an individual life policy.

title: Reflections
description: N ear the McGuinness Boulevard exit in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, westbound traffic on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway sputtered yesterday, just as traffic planners had expected. They had closed off a large section of the right lane for one of the many jobs in this city that tend to be short on glamour but could be long on consequence.

title:
PATENTS;
Bilge Water Alert
description: A means of detecting excess leakage of water into the bilge of a ship has been invented by Douglas R. Price, president of the Atlantic Development Company in Baltimore, who received patent 4,341,178 this week. The device monitors operation of the bilge pump to compare it with normal operation and sounds an alarm if the rate of pumping is excessive. It will alert the vessel operator or dockmaster. Mr. Price says his company also has an accessory that enables the device to alert subscribers at home.

title: NEW YORK TOPS 6 OF 7 OTHER CITIES USING SAME SCHOOL READING TESTS
description: Comparative figures gathered for the first time by the Board of Education show that reading scores are higher in the New York City Public Schools than in all but one of seven other big cities known to use the same standarized test.

title: THEATER: 'THE MUSIC KEEPER,' ON WAGNER
description: Winifred Wagner, who died in 1980 at the age of 82, was the daughter-in-law of Richard Wagner, and she staged the annual Bayreuth Festival until the defeat of Germany in World War II, when she was convicted as a Nazi collaborator. It is her life that is under study in ''The Music Keeper,'' an absorbing footnote to history now being presented at the South Street Theater on West 42d Street.

title: Around the Nation; Reporter's Conviction Of Contempt Is Upheld

title: PERLMAN QUITS CAESERS PALACE UNDER PRESSURE
description: Caesars Palace, the Las Vegas, Nev., casino, announced last night that Clifford S. Perlman had resigned as chairman of the board. The move comes at a time of increasing pressure from New Jersey, which had asked the resort's parent company, Caesars World, to sever all ties with Mr. Perlman or sell its casino in Atlantic City.

description: Major oil companies have started to lower wholesale gasoline prices, halting a three-month surge in retail prices. The cuts followed an 11-cent-a-gallon rise in prices since April and reflected what analysts said was renewed competition for business because demand has been lower than expected during the peak summer driving season.

title: Bridge:; Top-Ranked Squads Win In Spingold Knockout Play
description: After a peaceful day in which all the top-ranked teams survived, 16 teams continued play here this afternoon in the Spingold knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: De Gustibus; WHAT'S A COOKBOOK WITHOUT THE FOOD?
description: If a book titled ''Cooking Without Food'' arrived in the mail next week, it would not come as much of a surprise. As we learn more about food and its effect upon the body, we are also learning that a lot of delicious things are bad for us and so must be cut out. If this trend continues, the entire gourmet movement may have to be adjusted and manmade nutritives will have to be worked into recipes that approximate familiar and much loved dishes.

title: A HOLE IN U.S. MONEY SUPPLY REPORTS

title: SATURDAY, JULY 31, 1982; Markets
description: The Federal Reserve Board approved a reduction to 11 percent from 11 1/2 percent in its discount rate, adding impetus to recent interesd rate declines and leading analysts to predict lower rates in coming weeks. The Mellon Bank lowered its prime rate a half point, to 15 percent, the first major bank to do so. Meanwhile, nation's money supply fell $800 million in the week ended July 21. (Page 1.)

He was 66 years old.

title: PROTECTION FOR BOYCOTTS
description: The boycott of commercial goods is firmly ingrained in American history as an effective form of political protest. Long before the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. made the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott the spearhead of the desegregation movement, colonial boycotts had forced repeal of the Stamp Act, antebellum abolitionists had refused to buy slave-made wares, and early 20th century Progressives organized boycotts of sweatshop industries.

title: BRITON HAD KEY ROLE AT NORMANDY
description: Gen. Sir Richard N. Gale, a British Army officer who parachuted into France to pave the way for the first assault in the D-Day landings in Normandy, died on Thursday at his home near here at Kingston-on-Thames, his family said. He was 86 years old. ---- Served as Aide to Queen By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

title: U.S. AGENCY SUED OVER LEAD IN AIR

title: OAKITE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUMMERTIME, AND THE PRICES GET LOWER
description: July ends today, half the traditional vacation season is over and the time has come for the perennial sales of midsummer. Thumb through any publication, tune in to any television channel, listen to any radio station and the sales pop out at you: lawn mowers, hoses, awnings, air-conditioners, lightweight clothing, backyard furniture, swimsuits, all at bargain prices.
